column2: Junior speed flyers of the United States and territories will compete for $3,600 in cash prizes at a three-day power model airplane contest at New York International Airport, Queens, International Air Exposition officials announced yesterday.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., May 2 (AP) -- Although he failed in his effort to win his fourth successive national all-around gymnastic championship, 35-year-old Frank Cumiskey of Union City, N.J., probably will be considered the top man of the United States Olympic gym team.

The Cunard White Star liner Britannic recently converted for peacetime service after five years' duty as a transport, will leave Liverpool May 22 for Cobh and New York on her first post-war commercial voyage.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Charter of the Organization of American States adopted at Bogota, Colombia, and made public by the State Department:

MISAWA, Japan, May 2 -- United States Army engineers are now approaching the completion of their largest construction project in Japan. This is the $13,000,000 Misawa Air Base in Aomori Prefecture near the northeast tip of Honshu Island.
CLEVELAND, May 2 -- The chief factors in the primary election in Ohio on Tuesday follow:

Mayor O'Dwyer took two steps yesterday to reduce the demand for beds in the city's twenty-four hospitals when he arranged for a widening of the Health Department's diagnostic services and for a new division of home care in the Hospitals Department.

LONDON, May 2 -- Another spate of May Day speeches and meetings showed today that the British Labor party was closing its ranks. It looks now as if the twenty-one "rebels" who sent a telegram wishing success in the Italian elections to the Left-Wing Socialist leader Pietro Nenni will comply with the ultimatum to toe the party line.

The Jewish Theatrical Guild last night honored an Episcopalian, Walter N. Vincent, president of the Actors Fund of America, who is 79 years old. Nearly 1,000 were present at the testimonial dinner in the Hotel Astor. Among them were representatives of the Catholic, Episcopal and Negro Actors Guilds.

All forty-five New York State members of the House of Representatives will be asked to appear before the House Rules Committee this week to oppose the Mundt Subversive Activities Control Bill, which requires registration with the Attorney General of all Communist and Communist-front groups, O. John Rogge, chairman of the New York State Wallace for President Committee, announced yesterday.
Five new films, including importations from England and Canada, are slated to open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

BERGEN, Norway, May 2 -- The seven vessels of the United States naval task force headed by the carrier Valley Forge now visiting Bergen are on a mission to prevent war, said United States Ambassador Charles U. Bay at a dinner given by him to the Norwegian authorities here. He said they were "peace ships."

A "godless, pagan atmosphere" prevails in American schools and places of recreation for young people, Msgr. John S. Middleton, secretary of education for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, charged yesterday.

Peanuts go to the ball park, they show up at the circus, they are invited to cocktail parties and, in the guise of peanut butter, they make a favorite sandwich for lollipop set. They fit into that group of popular, typically American foods that include watermelon, corn on the cob and turkey.

PARIS, May 2 -- The present basis for France's foreign policy, which is attempting to tone down Western power decisions that could be regarded by Moscow as a provocation, is founded on a fear that there is perhaps a greater danger of war this year than appears to be the considered opinion in Washington or London.

In a statement summarizing the results of the "Thanksgiving in Spring" campaign, sponsored by the New York State Food Merchants Association, in which 15,000 independent grocers featured special prices on various foods during April, A.F. Guckenberger, executive secretary of the Association, announced over the week-end that the organization will begin immediately a weekly advertising service which can be used in local newspapers by independent grocers to feature "thrifty food buys."
CLEVELAND, May 2 (AP) -- Freddie Hutchinson's three-hit pitching and an eight-hit attack on Bob Lemon today gave the Tigers their second straight victory over the Indians, 4 -- 2.

The United States Section of the International Society for Contemporary Music gave its third concert of the season at Hunter College Playhouse last night. Dedicated to the memory of Lillian Morgan Saminsky and devoted to piano music, the performances featured the first concert hearings of Claus Adam's Sonata and Robert Kurka's Sonatina, Op. 6.

While the task of social workers continues to be the alleviation of public dependency, greater efforts should be made to prevent that condition, Raymond M. Hilliard, recently appointed Welfare Commissioner, said yesterday morning.

Activity in wholesale markets last week was good, particularly where special prices were available, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Mother's Day sales, it was indicated, were expected to establish new records, partly because of concentrated retail promotion and greater quantities of available merchandise.
TOKYO, May 2 (AP) -- General MacArthur today warned the Japanese to guard their constitutional freedom against despotic forces that he said were on the march throughout the world.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- Threat of a rail strike resulted in tightening up the May deliveries of grain on the Board of Trade last week, the difference compared with July widening due to short covering and also switching of hedges to the deferred months.

NANKING, May 2 -- The modified Communist policy toward labor and industry in the Communist areas of China is explained in a long article, the text of which has been received here in a broadcast by the Communist North Shensi radio station.

Howard R. Hughes and Floyd B. Odlum have reached a tentative agreement for the purchase of the Atlas Corporation's holdings of Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation stock, it was announced here early today.
Important primary elections in the race for Presidential nominations will be held tomorrow in Ohio, Florida and Alabama.

NEWARK, N.J., May 2 (AP) -- Bob Porterfield, sensational rookie right hander, turned in his second successive shutout today When he blanked Buffalo, 4 -- 0, with three singles to give Newark. an even break in the Ruppert Stadium twin bill. The Bisons captured the opener, 9 -- 7.
CLEVELAND, May 2 -- Senator Robert A. Taft ended his primary campaign in the industrial north of Ohio today with an appeal to the Negro voters of southeast Cleveland.

The Northeastern Lumber Manufacturers Association will seek legislation providing for standing timber severance taxation in the six New England states, New York and Pennsylvania, R. E. Broderick, executive secretary, disclosed last week.

DALLAS, May 2 (AP) -- The American Cotton Shippers Association said yesterday that a world cotton production increase is "already in the offing." But, the association said, world supply will be tight for another year and some qualities will be "quite scarce" for eighteen months.

Fifteen thousand members of the Bronx Holy Name Societies marched north along the Grand Concourse yesterday afternoon from 168th Street and then east to a field altar before Keating Hall on the Fordham Campus. There they were reviewed by Bishop Thomas J. McDonald, national director of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith.
BERLIN, May 2 (AP) -- Official United States sources denied emphatically tonight that a missing Soviet officer had been sent to Washington or otherwise was under United States control.

DAMASCUS, Syria, May 2 (AP) -- If the Jewish villages of Dan and Dafne were attacked Saturday by the Syrian Army, they showed no battle scars today. Arab neighbors a mile from Dan and Dafne said they had heard no sounds of war.

A few days ago the Citizens Union, after having "studied carefully" the various plans before the city for modernizing its waterfront, chose the Port Authority plan. Now the Citizens Budget Commission, invited by Mayor O'Dwyer to make an analysis, has brought in a report also favorable to Port Authority operation.

ST. LOUIS, May 2 (AP) -- Chicago batters amassed nineteen hits against five Cardinal pitchers to swamp the St. Louis club, 13 to 4, today. Eight extra-base blows by the Cubs included a home run by Bill Nicholson.

The nations due to receive aid under the Marshall Plan have been told informally how the Administration expects the shipping section of the aid law to be carried out, according to marine sources here.

LONDON, May 2 -- A miniature gas turbine engine designed for use in road vehicles and believed to be the first in the world will be shown tomorrow at the opening of the British Industries Fair in Birmingham.

PITTSBURGH, May 2 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner found the home-run range at Forbes Field today to pace his first-place Pirate teammates to a 6-to-4 victory over the Cincinnati Reds in the rain-soaked opener of a scheduled double-header.
Three thousand persons attended the twenty-first annual service for the Knights Templar of the metropolitan area, held yesterday afternoon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- An examiner of the National Labor Relations Board has ruled that a union in Kansas City violated the Taft-Hartley Act by picketing a prefabricated housing development, it was announced today.
CASABLANCA, French Morocco, May 2 -- Arabs carrying traditional offerings of friendship to Jews after the Passover holidays were attacked by nationalist groups in two Moroccan cities last night.

The annual report on operations of the city's school cafeterias, made public yesterday, shows that while business increased considerably, increased costs put the operating revenues below those of the preceding year.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 2 (AP) -- Jack Kraus, veteran left hander, beat Montreal in the second game of a double-header here today, 3 -- 0, to snap a three-game Jersey City losing streak and give the Little Giants an even break in the twin bill after Montreal had captured the opener, 4 -- 3, before a crowd of 9,299.

NEWARK, N.J., May 2 -- Liberty Belle, Nat Krupnick's chestnut mare, made a shambles of the jumping events in the final night of the Newark Horse Show tonight to climax a brilliant evening performance by capturing the Col. John A. Barry Memorial Trophy.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- It was apparent today that the legislative mill of Congress must start to grind faster if its important business is to be completed in time for an adjournament before the Republican National Convention.

" THE British system will not die for lack of dollars, though it may suffer acute embarrassment. It will only die if it loses the energy and will to live." Paul McGuire's "Experiment in World Order"* is an examination of what he calls the British system, meaning the British Commonwealth and Empire, and a suggestion as to the best methods for employing British energies.

Three railroad brotherhoods with a combined membership of 150,000 announced their intention last week to resort to a nation-wide strike in order to exact wage dement; nevertheless it will come as found by the publicly constituted agencies charged with mediating railway labor disputes to be unjustified.

The fifty-ninth annual memorial service of Squadron A was held yesterday afternoon at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest. Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street. The service was preceded by a parade of active members of the unit, now called the 101st Mechanized Reconnaissance Squadron, New York National Guard, and of ex-members of Squadron A.
ZURICH, May 2 -- Erratic movements prices paid for gold coins on the "parallel" market in Paris last week were closely watched among countries not yet bound by the Bretton Woods convention.

Another American Soccer League club, the Brooklyn Hispanos, was eliminated from the annual cup competition of the United States Football Association by the Elizabeth (N.J.) Soccer Club yesterday in the third round at Sterling Oval in the Bronx before 2,500 fans.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 2 -- The convening of a proposed emergency session of the United Nations Security Council tomorrow or Tuesday to devise steps for stemming reported Arab invasions of Palestine was still undecided tonight despite Jewish Agency appeals for urgent action.

SEOUL, Korea, May 2 -- A small-scale war is reported to be raging on the Island of Cheju, sixty-five miles off the southern Korea coast. Korean police, supported by Korean constabulary, are battling swift-moving bands of Communists who are terrorizing the island's 276,000 inhabitants.

In view of increased expenditures for foreign aid and the need for strengthening the military establishment, the National Association of Manufacturers announced over the week-end that it has revised its previous recommendation that the fiscal 1949 Federal budget should not exceed thirty-one billion dollars. The NAM increased its recommended budget estimate by five billion dollars.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 2 -- National recognition of Otilio Ulate as the rightful President of Costa Rica was declared as complete political agreement regarding the country's future direction appeared to have been reached when the conference ended at 4 o'clock thus morning between Jose Figueres, military leader, and Senor Ulate, political leader.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 2 -- David O. Selznick has acquired an option to purchase the screen rights to "The Long Walk," a newly published novel by Betsey Barton, daughter of Bruce Barton, dealing with the problems and adjustments of the men in a paraplegic ward in a veterans' hospital.

Putting on one of those inimitable offensive splurges which take on an added glitter when their pitching assumes major league proportions, the Giants brought their first home stand of the season at the Polo Grounds to a triumphant close yesterday by polishing off Billy Southworth's ambitious Braves, 5 to 1.

A canvass of 3,000 radio homes in the New York metropolitan area by The Pulse, Inc., indicates that 5.6 per cent, or 168, are now equipped with frequency-modulation receivers, it was announced yesterday. The study was made from April 1 to 8.

Multiple sclerosis is a name unfamiliar to the general public. Tens of thousands of Americans, however, know it as a mysterious disease, the cause of which is unknown, which has left them permanently crippled with disabilities of all types. Long believed to be a rare disease, multiple sclerosis is now known to be relatively common and increasing in incidence.
Representatives of the diplomatic corps and United Nations members paid tribute yesterday to President Manuel A. Roxas of the Philippines, who died April 15.
PITTSBURGH, May 2 -- The Executive Council of the AFL Pennsylvania Federation of Labor voted today to endorse President Truman in the 1948 Presidential campaign.

The advertising firm of LaRoche Ellis, Inc., has changed its name to C.J. LaRoche Co., Inc., it was announced over the week-end by C.J. LaRoche. In announcing the reorganization of the agency and shifts in key personnel, Mr. LaRoche said that "it has been our conviction that the many drastic changes in the American economic structure have made new methods, new approaches, new techniques and new thinking essential."

WARSAW, May 2 -- The process known in Poland as "democratization" now has been completed in the Army Officers Corps. It is a process that is gradually being extended through every phase of Polish public life, and means simply political purification.
A caravan of fifteen horse-drawn, gaily decorated wagons carried 250 City College men and women yesterday on a hayride through the Bronx.

The business outlook has "not been significantly altered" by the break in commodity prices earlier this year and production is expected to continue "at or near an all-time peak" through the first half of this year, according to the latest survey of business prospects by the National Industrial Conference Board, released over the week-end.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 (AP) -- Citation's sashay in the Kentucky Derby yesterday left the Preakness people in Maryland begging today for a field to go against the Calumet king on May 15.

Three officials of the Economic Cooperation Administration left La Guardia Field by plane yesterday afternoon for Paris to begin the reorganization of the relationship of the ECA and the Organization for European Economic Cooperation. They will seek to further the flow of information about the progress of the European Recovery Program.
PARIS, May 2 -- Premier Schuman in a speech today at Metz declared the present Government would keep on with its work as long as it retained the confidence of Parliament.

TRENTON, N.J., May 2 -- The white standard poodle, Champion Blakeen Osprey, belonging to the Blakeen Kennels of Stamford, Conn., and handled as always by Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt, added another best in show to his record today in the nineteenth all-breed event of the Trenton Kennel Club.

PARIS, May 2 -- Spanish Leftist newspapers and organizations in France have suddenly started fulminating against the Soviet Government for the alleged interment of several score Spanish anti-Franco partisans in Karaganda concentration camps.
Veterans received 233,684 counseling interviews in 1947, the New York City Veterans Service Centers reported yesterday.

For over a year Congress had the opportunity to deal with the Displaced Persons problem on a bold and humanitarian basis. It had before it the Stratton bill to admit 400,000 of these "stateless" men, women and children from the DP camps over a four-year period, as a way of inducing all immigrant-receiving nations to open their doors and solve this human problem.

Under the watchful eye of a United Nations commission, a general election in the American zone of Korea will be held on May 10. It may decide the future of Korea and whether that unhappy nation is to be free and united or divided and enslaved. By every means in her power, short of open warfare, Russia is seeking to enslave it.
AMSTERDAM, May 2 -- Developments noticeable in Netherlands banking indicate that banks are taking a greater direct interest in the financing of industry.

BRUSSELS, May 2 -- The rift between the Catholic church and the state has endangered the coalition Government of Premier Paul-Henri Spaak, who, angered by the rapid development of the dispute, has threatened to resign.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Under-Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett met Department officials in a Sunday conference this morning.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 2 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Roswell K. Doughty of Mamaroneck today was elected president of the New York Department, Reserve Officers Association, succeeding Lieut. Col. Robert Parks of Binghamton.

AMES, Iowa, May 2 (AP) -- Art Griffith of Oklahoma A. and M. today was named coach of the sixteen-member United States Olympic wrestling team. Cliff Keen, University of Michigan, was named team manager.

To every parent comes a time when his boy child is seized suddenly with the Spirit of '76 and resolutely refuses to wear a hat chosen for him by his elders. He insists, instead, on wearing a hat of his own selection or, which is worse, of his own design.

ATHENS, May 2 -- Reports from areas north of Athens said today that the rebel radio station had declared that the murder of Minister of Justice Christos Ladas was "an achievement of democratic forces." The rebel broadcasts are not usually heard by Athens listeners because of Government jamming.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 2 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Roswell K. Doughty of Mamaroneck today was elected president of the New York Department, Reserve Officers Association, succeeding Lieut. Col. Robert Parks of Binghamton.

AMES, Iowa, May 2 (AP) -- Art Griffith of Oklahoma A. and M. today was named coach of the sixteen-member United States Olympic wrestling team. Cliff Keen, University of Michigan, was named team manager.

To every parent comes a time when his boy child is seized suddenly with the Spirit of '76 and resolutely refuses to wear a hat chosen for him by his elders. He insists, instead, on wearing a hat of his own selection or, which is worse, of his own design.

ATHENS, May 2 -- Reports from areas north of Athens said today that the rebel radio station had declared that the murder of Minister of Justice Christos Ladas was "an achievement of democratic forces." The rebel broadcasts are not usually heard by Athens listeners because of Government jamming.

The former Grace Protestant Episcopal Chapel at 414 East Fourteenth Street was dedicated yesterday as the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church by Auxiliary Bishop Stephen J. Donahue. At an outdoor ceremony preceding the 11 A.M. mass the Bishop laid a new cornerstone.

Either Paul S. Ames and his wife, Harriett, are shrewd investors or just lucky individuals. In the newly arrived hit, "Inside U.S.A.," their investment adds up to $56,250 -- Mrs. Ames, $50,000; Mr. Ames, $6,250. And that's not all by a long shot.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Stewart (Skip) Alexander of Mid-Pines, N.C., shot a four-under-part 68 this dark rainy afternoon to pull past Bobby Locke of South Africa and win the national capital open golf tournament with 271 strokes.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $52,508,979,205. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
I have read most of the comments on the housing shortage that have appeared in the newspapers. I am surprised that none of them touches the sore spot.

MOSCOW, May 2 -- The Literary Gazette today printed an open letter bearing the names of thirty-two United States writers, painters and composers, who, the magazine stated, were squarely on the side of the Soviet Union in opposition to current United States leadership and policies.

ROME, May 2 -- Attacks against Army ammunition dumps occurred with some frequency just before last month's election and have continued since then. Shots were fired last night from a speeding motor car at sentries guarding an ammunition dump at Novate Milanese, near Milan.

Warmed by the occasional appearances of the spring sun, New York's famous playground, Coney Island, is stirring out of its winter lethargy and within a few weeks will be "open for business" to the millions who annually seek its seaside pleasures. Already week-end crowds are finding many of the concessions in full Saturday and Sunday operation, as if to get a foretaste of the feast that is to come.

CAMP KILMER, N.J., May 2 -- The three-day paper war of the Seventy-seventh Division was brought to a close here today with a critique by Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, division commander, and members of his staff.

PITTSBURGH, May 2 -- Last week the rate of steel ingot production recovered 7 1/2 points to 86.5 per cent of rated capacity. Further gains are expected to be made this week. Some of the optimism over the quick come-back was dampened late last week, however, as steel leaders saw a possibility of new trouble when the present contract with the coal-mining unions ends in June.

Prices of cotton in the domestic futures market moved irregularly last week, closing the period at lower levels. Active futures showed net declines of 39 to 73 points on the New York Cotton Exchange, compared with an advance of 44 points to a decline of 40 points at the end of the previous week.

The foreign exchange market was jarred midafternoon of last Thursday by a recurrence of that "old bogy" -- currency devaluation -- with the result that substantial declines were recorded in the pound sterling, spot and "forwards," and the free currencies of Canada and Switzerland. Less severe cuts were found in other exchanges.

TEL AVIV, Palestine, May 2 -- The Haganah, Zionist militia that has a ring around the Arabs' principal seaport of Jaffa, has no intention of capturing it, according to informed sources here. It merely wants to immobilize Jaffa militarily so that Tel Aviv and sursounding settlements will be free from attack, the sources said.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (UP) -- A small business spokesman today voiced hope that a recent Supreme Court ruling will "disrupt monopolistic concentrations" in basic industries such as steel.

The annual report of Paramount Pictures, Inc., issued for publication today by Barney Balaban, president, showed a consolidated net income of $31,668,709 for the fiscal year of fifty-two weeks ended on last Jan. 3, after taxes and all deductions.

The May Day demonstrations, which had caused a good deal of anxiety in many parts of the world, have fortunately passed without any of the anticipated violence. But they have not been without significance. And their chief significance would seem to lie in two developments revealed more clearly this year than ever before.

PARIS, May 2 -- The annual Paris fair, in which virtually everything imaginable is exhibited, has opened. Exhibits show what is for sale on the French market and what will be for sale just as soon as materials are available and Government permission for manufacture has been received.

General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower took his farewell salute from the Army yesterday at Fort Myer, Va. A few hours later, at 4:35 P. M., he stepped from his car here to enter his new residence, President's House of Columbia University, 60 Morningside Drive. He was in uniform, with the SHAEF patch on his left shoulder, but he was taking the first step into civilian life.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 2 -- The real threat to America and freedom here is home-grown fascism, Henry A. Wallace said tonight in an address before a meeting sponsored by the Progressive party here.

Improvement in traffic conditions in the garment sector since the plan of extended hours of pickups and deliveries started on March 1, was reported yesterday by George Conboy, a member of the Joint Traffic Committee of the Garment Industry.

Plans of the International Chess Federation in connection with the 1949 world championship are taking shape. Two lists of leading international masters for the semifinals, to be held at Stockholm during next July, have been issued by the governing body, according to a report received yesterday from The Hague.

UTICA, N.Y., May 2 -- Mothers who have to work during the day are entitled to an opportunity to be with their children in nurseries or nursery schools at least one half day a week, in the opinion of James Marshall, member of the Board of Education of New York.

The facts about construction costs cited by Chairman Farrell of the New York City Housing Authority in opening the seventeenth annual meeting of the National Public Housing Conference make amply clear why it is that the housing problem cannot be solved without government intervention, and that on a substantial scale.

CLEVELAND, May 3 -- Harold E. Stassen predicted here today that three hundred and forty votes would be cast for him on the first ballot at the Republican National Convention in Philadelphia next month. This would make him the leading active contender in delegate strength.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 3 -- Thomas E. Dewey declared tonight that the United States would lose a major battle in the war of nerves and ideas with Russia if it tried to stamp out communism by outlawing it.

Without feeling for England, and the grand tradition of her deathless literature and language, handed down to us by the mother country, no proper respect or understanding of our own magnificent Government, and the workings thereof, together with the whole glorious institution of democracy, can be properly appreciated on this side of the broad Atlantic.

Mlle. Suzanne Melk, French glider champion and the first woman to be commissioned in the Free French Air Force as a military pilot, will give daily demonstrations at the international Air Exposition from July 31 to Aug. 8 at the New York international Airport.

More than a million workers are involved in wage disputes in key industries threatening to come to a head in the near future. The most ominous of these at the moment is the railroad wage controversy, in which three brotherhoods have rejected the findings of a Presidentially appointed emergency board and announced their intention to strike on May 11 unless granted a larger share of their original demands.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The clearest insight which the Chief Justice of the United States has publicly given of his legal equipment and his political philosophy is to be found in two opinions he wrote for a unanimous Supreme Court today. They concern the widespread effort of householders to bar, on racial or similar grounds, specified groups of citizens from acquiring homes in reserved neighborhoods.

The National Association of Manufacturers replied yesterday to the Congress of Industrial Organizations' presentation of its case for a third round of wage increases. The NAM charged the CIO's department of education and research with misrepresentation of statistics on profits, wages, cost of living and other economic factors.

Deflationary and inflationary forces appear temporarily to be "in fair balance," but for the future "visibility is low," the National City Bank of New York says in its Monthly Bank Letter, to be issued today.

A program of rapid mass education through better use of radio, films and phonograph records was advocated yesterday by the Rev. S. Franklin Mack, chairman of the World Radio Committee of the Foreign Missions Conference.

Bright Sword carried the colors of C.V. Whitney home first in the Oceanside Handicap, the Class C race that served as the main attraction at the Jamaica track yesterday. Second choice at 2 to 1 in a field of seven, which included the favored entry of Mahmoudess and Basileus II, Bright Sword ran evenly to score by a length over Mrs. H. Gordon's outsider, Laboulaye.

I fear that the correspondents whose letters appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES -- William H. Wranek (April 2) and J.M. O'Neill (April 5) -- have stretched Jefferson's statements regarding the teaching of religion in public-owned institutions out of all proportion to their expressed and intended meaning, as well as making Jefferson himself wholly unrecognizable.

MIAMI, Fla., May 3 -- The South is reaching new production records each month in its development of a new and vast regional industrial empire, according to reports made today at the seventh annual convention of the Southern Association of Science and Industry.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 3 (AP) -- Little Harp, flying the Shamrock Stable's green and white silks, dashed to a four-length victory in the $7,500 Baltimore Spring Handicap as Pimlico's twelve-day meeting got off to a chilly, wet start here today before 12,320.

On April 16 the United Nations General Assembly met in special session, on the initiative of the United States, to consider a plan for a "temporary trusteeship" of Palestine which our Government had announced that it would propose as a substitute for the partition plan, which it had previously favored.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor today called America's reciprocal-trade program a failure. The American Tariff League also asked that Congress let the program die.

DETROIT, May 3 -- The United Automobile Workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations demanded from the Ford Motor Company today a flat wage increase of 30 cents an hour and a number of fringe concessions which would bring the total increase to about $4 a day for 107,000 employes.
TRENTON, N.J., May 3 -- New Jersey's new cigarette tax law was approved today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll as part of his program to increase educational aid and reduce municipal taxes.

Hope that the masterpieces from Berlin's Kaiser Friedrich Museum be shown throughout the United States before their return to Germany has become a reality. All except the fifty-two most fragile of these 202 old masters, which have been in Washington for safekeeping since Allied troops rescued them from wartime hiding in a German salt mine, will go on exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum from May 17 to June 12.

The regular broadcast of one of the June programs of "We, the People" has been definitely committed for simultaneous presentation on television. June 1 is tentatively set for the twin appearance. Joining the CBS audio hook-up at the 11-year-old show's customary Tuesday night time at 9 will be WCBS-TV, the chain's video outlet here.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 (AP) -The third U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals today upheld the plan submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission by the American Gas and Power Company for disposal of six of its seven subsidiaries and simplication of its capital structure.
NANKING, May 3 (AP) -- President Chiang Kai-shek sought to stem outspoken unrest in his governing party today with an emotional pledge to destroy the Chinese Communists even if it cost his own life.

Stock prices displayed a stronger tone yesterday after a week of consolidating the gains registered during the April advance. Under the leadership of rails and selected industrial shares, values improved in slow trading. The turnover of 1,150,000 shares compared with 1,440,000 shares last Friday.

"The Brothers," a British film, with Patricia Roo and Will Fyffe, will have its local premiere this morning at the Sutton Theatre. The drama, produced by Sydney Box and directed by David MacDonald, is a J. Arthur Rank presentation being released here by Universal-International.

Robert Whitehead's trip to London to scout the possibility of a West End presentation of Robinson Jeffers' "Medea" has proved productive. Yesterday announcement was made that arrangements were concluded over the week-end to put on the play in the British capital late this summer.
BERLIN, May 3 -- Charges of the arbitrary requisitioning of homes in southwestern Bavaria were denied today by the Military Government.

ST. LOUIS, May 3 -- Pee Wee Reese may be back at shortstop and Bruce Edwards behind the plate when the Dodgers tangle with the Cardinals under the lights tomorrow night out here "where the test begins" -- or where it used to begin for them, at least.

Larceny on the part of some of the harbor's towboat crews has progressed in recent years to a point where it is now considered routine procedure, according to a survey by the Security Bureau, Inc., of 80 Broad Street, a maritime industry organization which is combating pilferage losses in the Port of New York.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., May 3 -- A resolution urging the Senate to preserve the right of taxpayers to be represented before the Tax Court of the United States by certified public accountants and other qualified non-lawyers was passed here today by more than 100 members of the council of the American Institute of Accountants, meeting in the Grove Park Inn.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The bill of Representative Walter G. Andrews, Republican, of New York, for a peace-time draft of men 19 through 25 years of age for two years of active service was approved by a 28-5 vote of the House Armed Services Committee today. It was scheduled for floor debate and action next week.

The Veterans Administration has begun to tighten the Government's purse strings against schools in this state that operate for profit and offer veterans instruction of "questionable value," David P. Page, deputy administrator for New York State and Puerto Rico, announced yesterday.

A varied exhibit of decorative fabrics, drawings and accessories opens tomorrow at the Cooper Union Museum for young designers to study and the public to admire. New additions to the museum, they range from a few ancient weaves by Egyptians to samples of luxurious fabrics by Dorothy Liebes.
LONDON, May 3 -- The appointment of Chakravarthi Rajagopalachari to be the first Indian Governor General of the Dominion of India was announced tonight.

Textile machine and equipment manufacturers have made considerable progress in clearing up backlogs of orders and are now in a position to give quicker delivery, according to manufacturers exhibiting at the Textile Machinery Exposition in the 71st Regiment Armory.

SENDAI, Japan, May 3 -- High ranking officials of the United States Army are becoming convinced that there is a constantly increasing undercover resistance to the occupation of Japan by "subversive elements directed from the outside."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 3 -- Vice Premier Edvard Kardelj said today at the second postwar congress of the Liberation Front at Ljubljana that the Yugoslav Government was strengthening the nation's armed forces "to the utmost possible under present conditions."

LONDON, May 3 -- A chorus of British spokesmen emphasized today that the dispatch of Army and Navy reinforcements to Palestine was purely a military measure to safeguard and facilitate the withdrawal of British units there and was not intended by any means to prolong the British occupation.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 3 -- The twenty-sixth Eastern States Antiques Fair opened this afternoon at the Westchester County Center with the auditorium and stage crowded to capacity with 100 dealers' booths. It will be open daily from 1 to 11 P.M. except for the last day, Friday, when the fair will close at 6 P.M.
In twenty cities throughout the country, 1,000 alumni of Bowdoin College, Brunswick, Me., began last night their part in the college's sesquicentennial campaign fund drive for $6,250,000.

The money market was fairly tight yesterday and Federal funds were quoted at 3/8 to 1/2 of 1 per cent. The Federal Reserve member banks here, which had reported excess reserves of $170,000,000 on Wednesday, suffered a drain which dropped the total to $130,000,000 on Thursday, and to a deficiency of $25,000,000 by Friday night.

Joseph D. Fackenthal, vice president of the Board of Education, whose seven-year term as a member from Brooklyn expires today, indicated yesterday that he would retire immediately, even though under the law he remains a board member until his successor is chosen.

Dynamic action by all governmental and private groups is required so that the American people may be housed decently in both urban and rural areas, 200 persons attending the National Public Housing Conference at the New Yorker Hotel were told yesterday.

ROME, May 3 -- The possibility of a split in the World Federation of Trade Unions, whose executive bureau is meeting in Rome, seemed to have decreased this evening, though its pro-Communist and anti-Communist factions continued to maintain an intransigent attitude. Giuseppe di Vittorio, Communist Secretary General of the Italian General Confederation of Labor, said after today's session that full agreement had been reached on all political questions, which, in substance, means the Marshall Plan.

Belgium will benefit both directly and indirectly from the European Recovery Program and may be expected gradually to ease its import licensing requirements, Charles H. Ducote, commercial attache at Brussels, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- President Truman asserted today that this year might "well determine the world's future, and whether liberty loving people everywhere are to remain secure in the freedoms they have gained through the centuries."

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 3 (UP) -- Jaroslav Drobny, Czechoslovak tennis champion, was reported en route to his homeland today to lead the Czecn Davis Cup team against Brazil in the second round of the European zone playoffs.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) Sports writers and broadcasters supporting Attorney General Tom Clark's efforts to whip juvenile delinquency today were incorporated under the title of Sports America.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 3 -- New York's proposed temporary closing of aqueducts in Westchester County for inspection and repair may cause difficulties for some communities, the Westchester Water Works Conference said today in a report filed with municipal officials throughout the county's 448 square miles.

Benjamin Fielding, License Commissioner, began a more intensive investigation yesterday into the sale of circus tickets at Madison Square Garden. Previously he had made brokers turn back thousands of tickets to the box office because of the shortage of medium and low-price tickets at the regular prices.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 3 -- Human poliomyelitis virus has been highly concentrated for the first time in history in a laboratory at the University of Minnesota.

The Yankees, scheduled to play fourteen games in the next thirteen days, will launch their first long home stand of the season at the Stadium today. Zach Taylor's Browns, who have been surprising most of the experts since the campaign got under way, will be the first of the Western clubs to be engaged.

The Government will become industry's largest storekeeper for metals, probably as an alternative to strict allocation plans displeasing to metal producers, industrial materials' experts revealed here yesterday. Furthermore, if the Russell bill, now pending in the House, providing subsidy payments to marginal mine producers, eventually becomes law, production of metals for defense are expected to be stimulated.
JERUSALEM, May 3 (AP) -- Civil war in the Holy Land, as in all wars of history, has created its displaced persons problem.
As long as man has lived upon this earth he has been scourged by a malignant affliction, the nature of which he never understood and the burden of which he could never lift.

Bernard P. Day, president of Joseph P. Day, Inc., said yesterday that a well-known restaurant chain was negotiating for the purchase of a good-sized part of 260 acres of vacant residential and business and on the Albany Post Road adjacent to the Roosevelt Homestead and Memorial Library at Hyde Park.

Stockholders of United Piece Dye Works, Lodi, N.J., will vote on a recapitalization plan at a special meeting to be held June 16, Under the plan, each share of 6 1/2 per cent preferred stock outstanding would be exchanged for one share of new $4.25 preferred, plus nine shares of new common stock, in lieu of all rights to accrued dividends.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- A countrywide railroad strike by 125,000 engineers, firemen and switchmen on Tuesday, May 11, appeared almost inevitable today as Federal mediators admitted there was little hope of settling the wage and rule dispute that provoked the walkout notice.

PITTSBURGH, May 3 -- Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America as well as the parent Congress of Industrial Organizations, said here tonight that the steel industry declined to negotiate the wage issue recently "in good faith."
Sketches of the winners of the Pulitzer awards follow:
MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 3 (AP) -- Southern Democrats focused their attention on Alabama tonight as the first testing ground for a battle against President Truman and his civil-rights program.

GENEVA, May 3 -- The Ministers of Finance of five Western European countries meeting in Brussels last week agreed to recommend to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation and the United States a new system for improving multilateral trade in Europe, it was learned here today.

MANILA, May 3 -- A United States Government delegation seeking increased trade for Japan conferred with Philippine Government officials for an hour today. They hoped to lay the groundwork for an increased acceptance of Japanese-made goods in the Philippines that would eventually raise the two-way trade of the countries to somewhere near the pre-war levels.

With industry's efforts to obtain new capital for expansion and plant improvement programs curtailed as a result of an apathetic investment demand for new stock issues, the question has been raised whether the sale of such equity securities might not be facilitated if they were sold on a partial payment basis.

GENEVA, May 3 -- A rectification of remarks, which came very close to an apology, by a Russian delegate saved the Economic Commission for Europe today from a split that Western delegations felt might have been fatal.

Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, who presided at the recent Geneva Conference of the United Nations on Freedom of Information and of the Press, declared here yesterday that the meeting had been a "pioneer achievement of major importance."

Liquidation of near-month contracts carried cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday to levels unchanged to 81 points net lower, with the weakness most pronounced in the near deliveries.
"Tree-up" ceremonies for a white cottage that is being built at Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street to raise funds for the New York Heart Association were held yesterday afternoon.

Despite thirteen bases on balls issued by four Violet pitchers, New York University beat Brooklyn College, 9 -- 8, yesterday at Ohio Field for its eighth Metropolitan Collegiate Conference triumph without a defeat.
LONDON, May 3 -- The suspension of the removal of Communist civil servants from work vital to the security of state was disclosed today by Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer.

Warren R. Austin, head of the United States delegation to the United Nations, and Aake Ording, director of the United Nations Appeal for Children, attended a concert and pageant last night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of needy children throughout the world.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 3 (AP) -- J.U. Gratton's Jupiter Light registered a surprise victory in the Pennsgrove, feature event today at Garden State Park.

Fish sold in the United States include approximately 160 varieties, and yet only about seven of these are known to consumers from coast to coast. This ignorance of a plentiful food may be one reason why the United States Department of the Interior has prepared a become-acquainted cook booklet, "Basic Fish Cookery."

MEANWHILE around the Cabinet table we were witnessing the swift and almost mechanical destruction of a weaker State according to Hitler's method and long design. Poland was open to German invasion on three sides. In all fifty-six divisions, including all his nine armoured divisions, composed the invading armies.

The Health Department intends to have the first of its proposed new diagnostic clinics ready by July 1 and will become thereby the first public health department to offer that service, Commissioner Harry S. Mustard declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- The United States Supreme Court today ruled that the Interstate Commerce Commission should have settled finally the claims of six dissenting stockholders when the ICC approved a merger of the Pere Marquette Company with the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company.

Eight parking lot operators, who had received summonses during the week-end drive of the Department of Licenses, were fined a total of $1,300 on their guilty pleas yesterday before Magistrate Samuel Orr in Municipal Term Court.

MUNICH, May 3 -- Fourteen thousand workers of the M.A.N. plant in Augsburg, manufacturing farm implements, staged a walkout at noon today in protest against the bad food situation. They indicated that all would appear tomorrow for work as usual but declared they would not take up their tools again unless the fat ration for the first ten days of May was met.

BOSTON, May 3 -- United States Civil Service Commissioner Arthur S. Flemming tonight assailed "lukewarm" churchgoers who were "sinfully" derelict in assuming their responsibilities as Christians. Dr. Flemming is president of the Federation of Churches of Washington and treasurer of the Committee on Religious Life in the capital.
ALBANY, May 3 (AP) -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein said today that former members of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps were entitled to a share in New York's $400,000,000 bonus.

New York's excursion boat season will get under way this month with at least seven steamboat companies offering trips around Manhattan Island, up the Hudson River and Long Island Sound and down New York Bay to Rockaway and points along the New Jersey shore.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 3 -- Pakistan is ready to leave the British Commonwealth the moment she feels that the usefulness of continued association with it from the point of view of world relations has vanished, Prime Minister Liaqat Ali Khan declared tonight.

CINCINNATI, May 3 -- Dave Koslo, the one-time parachute trooper, got the Giants off to an impressive start on their first swing around the National League's Western front tonight as he hurled the Polo Grounders to a 5-to-0 triumph over Johnny Neun's Reds to the dismay of 28,424 onlookers.

The 1948 Pulitzer Prize for the best original American play was awarded yesterday to "A Streetcar Named Desire," by Tennessee Williams. The award for the most distinguished fiction in book form went to "Tales of the South Pacific," by James A. Michener.

Albert F. Tegen, president of the General Public Utilities Corporation, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday that the electric and gas utilities have a great competitive advantage over the coal and oil industries, because of the high prices and restricted supplies of the latter fuels.

An analysis of our colonial civilization, entitled "Seeds of Liberty: The Genesis of the American Mind," by Max Savelle, Professor of History at the University of Washington, has been scheduled for May 24 publication by Knopf. It is a study in religion, science, economic and social thought, politics, philosophy, literature, music and art based on the writings of our forefathers.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 8 per per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended Saturday was 10 per cent.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 3 -- The present level of costs for production supplies and services and for equipment needed to complete a post-war expansion program is a source of great concern to the United States Steel Corporation, stockholders were told at the annual meeting here today.
VANCOUVER, May 3 (Canadian Press) -- The Pacific Coast Hockey League today became the fourth professional ice loop on the continent.

Negro and Jewish organizations and church and labor groups hailed last night the ruling of the Supreme Court forbidding use of the courts to enforce racially restrictive real estate covenants. It was said that more than 75 per cent of the new housing developments on Long Island and in Westchester had such agreements.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 3 -- The Taft-Stassen contest for Ohio Presidential delegates ended tonight with speeches by the candidates and the usual claims of victory from both camps.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of an issue of $5,500,000 of first mortgage bonds, 3 per cent, due 1978, of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, on a bid of 100 3/4, to yield 2.96 per cent.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 3 -Walter Wanger has purchased "The World and Little Willie." a photoplay by Stanley Roberts based on a screen story by Val Burton and Sheridan Gibney, and will produce it for release by Eagle-Lion with June Lockhart, who is under contract to E-L, in the leading role, the studio announced today.

Mayor O'Dwyer urged all city employes' yesterday to contribute to the Greater New York Fund, making his plea at a meeting of commissioners and bureau heads in City Hall. Declaring that the fund was "a must," he directed all department heads to set up solicitation committees in their departments, appointing Markets Commissioner Eugene G. Schultz to take charge of the campaign among city workers.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 -- An estimated 5,000 members of the industry, including many from foreign lands, attended today's opening of the fifty-second annual congress and show of the American Foundrymen's Association in Convention Hall.

SEOUL, Korea, May 3 -- Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, United States commander in Korea, today issued a statement to Koreans describing the recent Soviet-sponsored North and South Korean joint political conference held in Pyongyang, capital of the Soviet zone, as a trick, a smoke screen, and "more appropriately an all-Korean Communist conference."

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 3 (UP) -- Police Commissioner Eugene (Bull) Connor denied today that a sailor was beaten by police here Saturday when arrested in company with Senator Taylor. Mr. Taylor told the Senate today that the seaman was "unmercifully beaten."

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The State Department sought to curb speculation today that the appointment of John H. Hilldring as special assistant to Secretary Marshall on Palestine Affairs presaged another change in policy on the Holy Land.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 3 -- The Providence Teachers Alliance, AFL, which comprises more than half of this city's 1,204 public school teachers, voted tonight by a ratio of 4 to 1 to stop work and to picket the schools tomorrow morning as a means of backing up their demand for a single salary schedule.

Frederick Lasch, who pleaded guilty to taking part in the creation of an allegedly fraudulent will to obtain the $280,000 estate of Miss Mathilde Molsberger, testified yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Bernardino Mastromonaco that the latter had advised him the scheme had a "good chance" of being successful.

Navy, Harvard and Pennsylvania meet on the Schuylkill at the Henley distance of a mile and five-sixteenths for the Adams Cup in the feature of five college rowing regattas Saturday, and the consensus is that anything can happen.
Baseball attendance is taking out after last year's record total with 1,709,487 paid for the first two weeks of the new season, according to an Associated Press compilation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 3 -- Following are excerpts from the statement on the Palestine situation made here today by Arthur Creech Jones, British Colonial Secretary, before the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee:

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Howard Bruce of Maryland was nominated by President Truman today to be Deputy Administrator for Economic Cooperation and second in command to Paul G. Hoffman in the management of the European Recovery Program.

FUERSTENFELDBRUCK AIR FORCE BASE, Germany, May 3 -- A B-29 with twelve men aboard -- one of the 352d Very Heavy Bomber Squadron that took off from this base for Port Said, Egypt -- crashed two miles from here at midnight tonight.

It is a wrench for any soldier, especially a great commander, to leave the army he led to victory. Such a separation almost broke General Washington's heart. Something of the same emotion must have risen in the breast of General Eisenhower at Fort Myer as he bade a last farewell to the troops of the famous Third Infantry, authorized by the first Continental Congress. But it was conveyed only in a rigid, brave salute.
CHICAGO, May 3 -- The seven-week-old strike of the United Packinghouse Workers, CIO, against the "big four" meat packers and major independents moved into new tests today.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 8 per cent in April, compared with the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The largest increase of any of the twelve reporting stores was 19.3 per cent.
ST. LOUIS, May 3 (AP) -- The Cardinals climbed into third place over the idle Dodgers by downing the Cubs, 3 -- 1, today behind the effective pitching of Jim Hearn. The game drew 3,735.

Traffic on Madison Avenue between Fifty-seventh and Sixty-first Streets in the area where a 48-inch low-pressure gravity water feed main broke Sunday night, will be barred for at least fifteen days while repairs are being made, Borough President Hugo E. Rogers said yesterday.

Admiral Corporation introduced two new radio-phonograph console combinations, either of which may be used as the radio-phonograph unit in its "optional" television plan, at a New York area dealer meeting yesterday in the Essex House. The first combination will list for $130 less than the original radio-phonograph unit available when the "optional" arrangement was first announced in January.

UP until six months ago few Americans had ever heard of the Indian province of Garhwal. Not many have heard of it yet. But those who read Philip Woodruff's distinguished novel, "The Wild Sweet Witch," will not soon forget that picturesque region on the border of Tibet where the peasant hillmen cultivate their terraced gardens on the slopes of the Himalayas and where man-eating leopards break down barricaded doors to get at their prey.

Although the Norwegians, like other Scandinavians, have been designing fine modern furniture for some time, the first samples to be imported here on a commercial basis were presented to the trade yesterday by the Vaco Company in showrooms at the New Yorker Hotel.

ROME, May 3 -- Pope Plus XII will hold a Consistory at the end of this month or in the first few days of the next, it was announced in the Vatican today. Officials close to the Pontiff termed it "very probable" that some new Cardinals and perhaps even one more United States Cardinal would be created on that occasion.

The New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, in its 1947 annual report, issued yesterday, said that the organization had incurred a deficit of $84,827, the largest in its history. Its headquarters are at 1880 Broadway.

For 13,000 underprivileged children, yesterday morning will be one to remember for a long time. They packed Madison Square Garden to the rafters for the annual and unabridged performance of the circus.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (UP) -- Associate Justice David A. Pine of the District Court of the United States for the District of Columbia ruled today that a House un-American activities subcommittee had the right to ask a witness if he ever belonged to the Communist party.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 3 -- A younger brother of former United States Open Champion Billy Burke, who is generally known as Pete, now assistant pro at Glen Oaks played the best golf in the one-day pro-amateur tourney of the Long Island P.G.A. today and was chiefly responsible for his team's best-ball winning score of 66.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 3 -- The proposal of Arthur Creech Jones, British Colonial Secretary, for a provisional Palestine regime under the United Nations was greeted with interest by delegates of the Arab League states here today.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (UP) -- The Communications Workers of America (Ind.) announced tonight they would extend their contracts with the telephone industry for "short periods of time" to forestall a nation-wide telephone strike.
A letter from Soterios Nicholson concerning the threatened children of Greece prompts me to draw attention to the whole question of the admission of children to the United States.
Youngstown, Ohio, sold $2,700,000 of school district building bonds yesterday to the Northern Trust Company and associates at 100.688 for 2 1/4s, an interest cost of 2.1859.

Representative Angier L. Good-win and members of industry and labor groups joined yesterday in an appeal to Congress for clarification of the Fair Labor Standards Act to eliminate payment of "overtime on overtime."
BUFFALO, N.Y. May 3 (AP) -- Five new directors of the Western New York Water Company were elected today after a proxy battle for control of the parent company.

"Mr." Dwight D. Eisenhower, president-designate of Columbia University, said yesterday he was not coming to Columbia as a new broom to sweep clean, but was coming to the university to learn. He repeated emphatically that he was not a candidate for the Presidential nomination and added: "I have tried to make myself clear.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Supreme Court today ordered the lower courts to reopen questions of monopoly and conspiracy involved in motion picture theatre ownership and contract licensing as alleged to be practiced by larger producing companies.

ATHENS, May 3 (AP) -- The Minister of Public Order, Constantine Rentis, said today that Guerrilla Gen. Markos Vafiades would be tried in absentia as the "moral author" of the assassination Saturday of Justice Minister Christos Ladas.
DETROIT, May 3 (AP) -- Ned Day, the Milwaukee-Chicago specialist, fired a 1,979 total tonight to take the lead in the all-events division of the American Bowling Congress.

An attempt by the Federal Trade Commission to introduce new evidence in its three-year-old action against the National Retail Furniture Association, the American Retail Federation and 300 other individuals and trade organizations for an alleged conspiracy to suppress competition and restrain trade in furniture failed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Republican rebels challenged the party's top command in the Senate today in a move to force a big reduction in a pending rivers and harbors bill or to take the "ultimate responsibility" before the country.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- Grain prices averaged lower on the Board of Trade today, but May wheat rallied quickly, going to wider premiums over the July, reflecting uneasiness over a rail strike threatened for May 11. Closing trades on wheat were 1/2 cent a bushel higher to 1/2 cent lower than Saturday's final levels.

The United States must give free peoples everywhere "unmistakable evidence of our intention to support them in their struggle, so that the unsteady truce of today may become the stable peace of tomorrow." Secretary of the Navy John L. Sullivan said last night.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 3 -- Roger Conover, Army's ace right-hander, weaved a brilliant four-hit shut-out today, setting down Cornell, 12 to 0, at Doubleday Field for the Cadets' third Eastern League victory in four starts.

Both salt and fresh water fishing improved considerably in New Jersey over the week-end, with the trout showing more interest in flies and the first big catch of mackerel being brought in by the Paramount of the Brielle fleet.

The wage-fare tangle on the city's private bus and trolley car lines grew more complex yesterday with a surprise announcement by the Fifth Avenue Coach Company that it would ask an increase of "at least 2 cents" in its present ten-cent fare.

The Andrew Jergens Company will get its largest campaign for a face powder under way in June with a special drive on its new Woodbury products, it was announced yesterday. A feature of the campaign will be continuing 1,000-line ads in an expanding list of newspapers, scheduled to reach a total of sixty-two in forty cities as distribution progresses.

Mikhail Botvinnik, Soviet grandmaster who is leading in the tournament for the chess championship of the world, and Samuel Reshevsky, United States champion, met yesterday when play was resumed in the nineteenth round at Moscow and played to an adjournment, according to a report received from the Soviet capital.

The Coca-Cola Company and its consolidated subsidiaries, in the first quarter of this year, earned $5,718,233 after taxes and all charges, equal to $1.39 a share on the common stock, it was reported yesterday. The net profit for the corresponding three months of last year was $3,449,534, or 84 cents a common share.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Quickest possible action on the Taft-Ellender-Wagner bill for the construction of 15,000,000 homes in ten years was promised today by Representative Jesse P. Wolcott, Republican, of Michigan, chairman of the House Banking Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Congress approved and sent to President Truman today a bill permitting Senate members of the Joint Atomic Energy Committee to order Federal investigations of the "character, associations and loyalty" of Presidential appointees to the Atomic Energy Commission.

Ralph Sheldon, Minneapolis pianist, whose debut here took place in December, 1946, made his second New York appearance last night at Town Hall. Mozart's F major Sonata (K. 332) and Beethoven's "Waldstein" Sonata were his major selections, with Chopin, Prokofieff and Liszt represented by shorter works.
McKINNEY, Tex., May 3 -- A tornado blasted a twelve-mile path of destruction across north Texas today, centering its force on this prosperous cotton mill city. At least three persons were killed.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 3 -- Under the impact of news from Palestine that a truce in Jerusalem under International Red Cross auspices appeared possible, the Trusteeship Council swept aside the United States trusteeship proposals for the city.

A three-day meeting, called to expand and improve plant-level and community phases of the advertising industry's campaign for greater public understanding of the American economic system, opened yesterday in a studio of the National Broadcasting Company with about sixty representatives of leading companies present.
LONDON, May 3 -- Quiet ruled in the stock market here today.
ATHENS, May 3 -- Under the martial-law terms applied after the assassination of Justice Minister Ladas, restrictions upon the local press in reporting troop movements were indicated today.
The Thor Corporation, producer of home appliances, last year had the largest sales and earnings in its forty-one years, Raymond S. Hurley, board chairman, said in the annual report yesterday.

Louis (Satchmo) Armstrong, recently returned from an appearance at Nice in the International Jazz Festival, where he received the Sevres Vase from Vincent Auriol, President of France, gave the Carnegie Pop Concert last night.

Mayor O'Dwyer, praising the contributions of the Jewish people over the centuries to the physical and spiritual well-being of humanity, declared yesterday that "we owe to that race our full and whole-hearted support in their just ambitions."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 3 -- Declaring that it would be impossible to reach a decision by May 15, when the British Mandate over Palestine is to be terminated, Arthur Creech Jones, British Colonial Secretary, proposed here today that the United Nations General Assembly drop the United States plan for a temporary trusteeship.

I am an ex GI. I am not a Communist. I am an American citizen who has a point of view to express and believe it to be a representative attitude of many who fall into the same category. For a critical political situation exists in the American Congress, where the fate of many like myself as well as the entire world is being determine.
JERUSALEM, May 3 -- Palestine had its quietest day in the months today and tonight not a single casualty had been reported from any part of the country.

The Pulitzer awards in journalism this year emphasize once more the wide field of opportunity that beckons to a newspaper that seeks to serve its public well. They also show that our newspapers were alert to those opportunities in 1947.

Evidence introduced yesterday at a hearing in Mid-Manhattan Magistrates Court sought to link Benjamin H. Freedman, founder and secretary of the League for Peace with Justice in Palestine, with the Grand Mufti of Jerusalem and with the establishment of a sub-machine gun factory in Pakistan.
LONDON, May 3 -- War Secretary Emanuel Shinwell, who cast aspersions on nationalization yesterday when he said that it had been poorly prepared by the Socialists, swung to the other extreme today.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Covenants to bar Negroes or other racial groups from owning real estate were held legally unenforceable by a 6 to 0 ruling in the Supreme Court today.
Two hundred displays setting forth the beauties of various vacation spots went on view yesterday . afternoon in Grand Central Palace, 480 Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- The shutdown of Michigan manufacturing plants which receive natural gas from Consumers Power Company, would force the layoff of about 175,000 employes, the Power Commission was told today.

The United States Lines has added another member to the 670-man crew of the flagship America. He is Justus Damianis, Triestebonr linguist, who speaks seven languages fluently and is familiar with a dozen others.

Earl Sande, at one time the ranking jockey in American racing and now a trainer, was arraigned late yesterday before United States Commissioner Edward E. Fay in Federal Court, Brooklyn, on the charge of possession of narcotics. He waived examination and was released on his own recognizance for action of the Federal grand jury.

LONDON, May 3 -- Britain's mammoth industrial fair, so-called "shop window" through which the nation hopes to attract orders from all over the world, opened today. The British Industries Fair, held in three sections, will continue through May 14.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- A Navy Munitions Board official said today that the stockpiling of critical and strategic materials may have to be given priority over industrial requirements.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Senator Glen Taylor of Idaho told the Senate today he doubted that he would be alive if he had let himself be provoked into "talking back" to police after his arrest in Birmingham, Ala.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 3 (AP) -- Dinghy sailors from the Brown University Yacht Club retained the George Owen Trophy yesterday by defeating nine other college clubs in the annual intercollegiate regatta.
Nelson Bond, director of advertising of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, has been elected a vice president, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- A group of delegates to the National Health Assembly, representing fifteen national organizations with an overall membership of more than 15,000,000, a cross section of the AFL, CIO, the National Farmers Union, cooperatives, social agencies, and physicians' and veterans' groups, today submitted to the steering committee of the assembly a statement of immediate goals for national health security.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -California Electric Power Company today notified the Securities and Exchange Commission it proposes to sell publicly $2,500,000 of first-mortgage bonds due in 1978.

ROME, May 3 -- Pope Pius XII, in an encyclical letter addressed to the Catholic episcopacy, has expressed the wish that this year's prayers during the month of May should have the "particular purpose" of imploring the Blessed Virgin that "conditions of Palestine may at last be settled according to equity and that there also concord and peace may happily triumph."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 3 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was re-elected today to head the seven-nation drafting committee of the United Nations Human Rights Commission, which is tackling the 2-year-old job of drafting an international declaration and a covenant that aim to lay down and guarantee the human rights of all peoples of the world.
LONDON, May 3 -- Death, which has been stalking Capt. Roy Alexander Farran since 1940, entered his quiet home in an English village today and, by mistake, struck down his brother.

The Board of Higher Education announced yesterday that Dr. Paul Klapper, who resigned last month as president of Queens College, had been appointed temporary dean of teacher education of the four municipal colleges. He will begin work immediately to coordinate the expanding teacher-training programs of City, Hunter, Queens and Brooklyn Colleges.

The Southwestern Bell Telephone Company borrowed $100,000,000 on thirty-five-year debentures yesterday at an interest cost of about 3.03 per cent to maturity. A syndicate of sixty-three investment banking houses headed by Morgan Stanley Co. bought the obligations at competitive sale on a bid of 102.06999 for coupon interest of 3 1/8 per cent.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 4 -- Governor Earl Warren reiterated today that he was not interested in the Republican nomination for Vice President.

Prices continued to improve yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, but the rise was labored and developed several weak spots. Leading the list on the upgrade were railroad, steel and building shares, while motion-picture stocks, in belated response to the Supreme Court ruling against eight distributors, made the poorest showing. Volume was 1,460,000 shares, compared with 1,150,000 on Monday.

ANDRE SIEGFRIED, the distinguished French geographer, economist, diplomat and writer, is best known in this country for a book that was published here twenty-one years ago, "America's Coming of Age." Frenchmen are popularly thought to be so content with their native land that they are indifferent to travel.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 (AP) -- Eddie Joost's fourth home run of the season, delivered in the tenth inning with two out and Pete Suder on base, carried the Athletics to an 8-6 victory over the league-leading Indians today.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Harrisburg (Pa.) Gas Company received permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission today to issue and sell an additional 13,811 shares of no par value common stock at $90 a share. The company would use the proceeds for construction.

Joseph Sager and others have sold the twelve-story forty-nine-family apartment house at 50 Plaza Street, Brooklyn, to the 50 Plaza Corporation, represented by Samuel Edelstein, attorney. The property, on a plot 103 by 100 feet, is assessed at $470,000. Samuel Kutay was the broker.
The New York Curb Exchange announced yesterday the suspension for three months of Jack J. Dreyfus Jr., a regular curb member and partner in the firm of Dreyfus Co.

DETROIT, May 4 -- Despite objections by the United Auto Workers, CIO, the State Labor Mediation Board went ahead today with plans for a strike vote among Chrysler Corporation workers in Michigan. The union has called a strike for May 12 and contends that a Mediation Board strike poll is not necessary because Chrysler has plants in several states.
Earl Sande, owner-trainer, yesterday drew a sixty-day suspension following a meeting of the stewards of the Jockey Club.
A demand that Mayor O'Dwyer conduct an investigation into "progressive" education in the New York public school system was made yesterday by the board of directors of the Bronx Chamber of Commerce.

Fordham held third place in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference by turning back Manhattan, 11 to 8, in a free-hitting contest on wind-swept Fordham Field yesterday. It was the fifth triumph in eight starts for the Rams in Subway Circuit competition.

Tested according to American standards of individual initiative and of equality of opportunity, the provisions of the Taft-Ellender-Wagner bill offer this country a bargain in housing, Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican, of Vermont, declared last night.

ST. LOUIS, May 4 (UP) -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder said today he "wouldn't be at all surprised to see some tax increases next year if the nation is to avoid deficit financing." He spoke to the Missouri Bankers Association in convention here.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association opened its season yesterday with the playing of interclub team matches, better known as Cup Series. More than 500 women gathered in the three districts of Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey and some hard-fought matches ensued.

CINCINNATI, May 4 -- Still pluming themselves because of two successive complete games by their lightly regarded pitching staff, the second of them last night when Dave Koslo blanked the Reds, 5 to 0, the Giants were resting mighty comfortably today as they awaited the second and concluding encounter of this brief series with the Cincinnatians tomorrow afternoon.

The property at 240 Battle Avenue, White Plains, N.Y., consisting of a grocery store, a liquor store, a confection store and a dwelling, has been sold by Celeste Furlanich to Mr. and Mrs. George T. Durney. It had been held at $35,000.

PARIS, May 4 -- The Soviet Union obtained last year a complete economic stranglehold on Hungary by virtue of three secret protocols. They were signed in Moscow on Dec. 9 although not approved by the Hungarian Cabinet.

BERLIN, May 4 (AP) -- The United States Military Government said today that border violations have been committed by Russian and Czech soldiers along United States occupation zone frontiers in Germany.

With June the wind-up month of most of broadcasting's regulars, the hot-weather reserves are being mustered for early draft into the summer program schedules. Accordingly, Carmen Cavallaro and his orchestra have been named to relieve the NBC comedy sketch, "A Date With Judy," in the Tuesday night half-hour at 8:30 on June 29.

A basic minimum list of twenty-five grocery store merchandise classifications to be reported in the monthly grocery inventory of the Bureau of Advertising, ANPA, has been adopted by sponsoring newspapers, the bureau announced yesterday.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,222, compared with 1,210 last week and 849 in the corresponding week of last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 441 arrivals yesterday against 515 last Tuesday.
DETROIT, May 4 (AP) -- A nine-man "good-will" delegation from Stockholm provided the forty-fifth annual American Bowling Congress today with one of its most unusual aspects.

Capturing three firsts and scoring in eight of the ten open events, Boys High School won the tenth annual track and field meet sponsored by the Brooklyn High School of Automotive Trades at McCarren Park yesterday. The Red and Black scored 30 1/2 points for its second successive outdoor triumph in less than a week.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, reminded countries in the Marshall Plan today that he is not interested in recovery projects needing four or five years to show results because "European recovery can't wait that long."

Jean Ravaud, president of the French Chamber of Commerce of the United States and general manger of Carillon Importers, Ltd., yesterday received the Legion of Honor, degree of Chevalier, from the French Government in ceremonies held at a luncheon at the Hotel Plaza.

Canned peas, which are available in record quantities this spring, now are being featured at attractively low prices. In A. P. stores three twenty-ounce tins of Iona standard grade peas are 29 cents. The same tariff is being charged in Safeway stores for products of similar quality.

A newly published report from the United Smoke Council in Pittsburgh tells with some pride of the progress made there in smoke abatement and raises anew the question when New York City will tackle this problem on a scale equal to its importance as a civic nuisance.

CORVALLIS, Ore., May 4 -- The tempo of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's campaign in the Oregon Republican Presidential primary stepped up today as the New Yorker swung south through the state along the route taken by Harold. E. Stassen in mid-February.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 4 (AP) -- Senator Glen Taylor of Idaho was convicted of disorderly conduct tonight, but the case abruptly mushroomed into a question of civil rights violations. Police Court Judge Oliver Hall gave the Senator a tongue-lashing for introducing the racial issue into the case, and then fined him $50 and costs and sentenced him to 180 days in the city jail.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Foreign Affairs Committee of the House opened hearings today on demands for fundamental revision of the United Nations or, if the Russians rejected this, a gathering for mutual defense of all the democratic world.

PARIS, May 4 -- Jacques Griffe is one of the younger couturiers about whom Paris is talking. True to his training with Vionnet, he cuts fabric on the bias with telling simplicity and fine workmanship.
