Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong again yesterday and closed 38 to 55 points net higher.

With reduced unit turnover at retail unable to support the annual production rate of about 500,000,000 pairs of shoes noted in the first quarter of this year, output now is tending to fall rather sharply, trade reports indicated yesterday here.

Violations of the Motion Picture Association of America's Advertising Code may now cost member companies as much as $25,000 in penalties, according to a new clause in the code as reported by the MPAA. Previously the maximum penalty for an infraction of the code was $5,000.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, AFL, today asserted the union's right to seek jurisdiction over evolutionary or substitute printing processes without recourse to the National Labor Relations Board.

A plot containing 60,000 square feet on Queens Boulevard between Thirty-second and Thirty-third Streets in Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by Radelle, Inc., for improvement with a two-story building which will be used for the manufacture of lingerie.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Definite help toward bolstering American family life, regarded as weakened by war and post-war impacts, was promised at a press conference held today by three spokesmen for this week's National Conference on Family Life.
The American Export Lines passenger ship Marine Carp sailed for the Mediterranean yesterday with 265 passengers, among them a group of Palestinians returning to their native land.

Three hundred and seventy-five pounds of nickels, dimes and quarters, to a value of $4,000, were carted away either late Monday night or early yesterday morning by burglars who ripped open a safe in the offices of Spacarb, Inc., distributor of soda vending machines in 317 East Twenty-third Street.
LONDON, May 4 -- Newspaper reviews were generally enthusiastic bout Sir Laurence Olivier's British motion picture of "Hamlet," which was shown here privately yesterday.

The Commerce and Industry Association questioned yesterday the necessity of an appeal by Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the city's Golden Anniversary Committee, for $500,000 in contributions from business executives to help defray the costs of the celebration.

MUNICH, May 4, 1948 -- An army of workmen whacked, sawed and pasted to completion today scores of exhibits in time for the opening tomorrow of the International Press Exposition on the Munich Fair Grounds. The exposition expects to be host to hundreds of thousands of visitors before it closes on June 15.

Andrew Gainey, young American baritone, who made his Town Hall debut last night, has the intelligence and imagination to do what could be done with his vocal equipment. He sings music that is a far cry from the old-hat combinations that are standard fare at recital debuts, and he projects his personality in a way that makes you think he enjoys singing and hopes you will enjoy listening to him.

SENDAI, Japan, May 4 -- Attempts by the occupation authorities to introduce local autonomy in Japan as a step in the nation's democratization have met a few snags, according to indications prevalent today in the rural sections of Japan.
Today is the tenth day of The Greater New York Fund's eleventh annual campaign in behalf of 423 local hospitals, health and welfare agencies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 4 -- Paramount and Irving Berlin are negotiating a deal for production of a film to be called "White Christmas," in which Bing Crosby will be starred, it was learned today. The pattern of the contemplated deal will follow that established by "Blue Skies," made by Paramount two years ago, and by "Easter Parade," recently completed by M-G-M, both pictures being Berlin musicals produced in the lavish manner.

A real estate operator and three persons associated in rental agencies were arraigned yesterday in Special Sessions on charges of extorting $19,200 as gratuities for obtaining apartments for clients. According to the District Attorney's office, a New York grand jury voted five informations containing twenty-seven counts alleging charges of excessive rentals.

Prof. Dora S. Lewis, chairman of the Home Economics Department of Hunter College, has been invited to work in Japan this summer and advise Gen. Douglas MacArthur on the possible introduction of American family patterns into Japanese life in an effort to release the Japanese from militaristic tensions, she announced yesterday.

LONDON, May 4 -- The firm announcement that Britain would not compromise with the Soviet Union and would stay in Berlin featured a long review of foreign affairs by Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin in opening a two-day debate in the House of Commons today.

To his credit, Senator Taft said in his recent Denver address that the Air Force and the Navy "clearly contemplate duplicate development, duplicate roles and duplicate missions * * *" and that he favored "the Air Force concept of offensive action by land-based planes over the Navy concept of carrier-based planes."

Restraint and quiet taste were emphasized in the custom originals designed and made for Sada Sacks, Inc., of 671 Madison Avenue, and shown yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. Employing an essentially wearable silhouette, a gently indented waist and softly flaring skirt, the fashions were notable for their interesting combinations of fabric and detail of embroidery and applique rather than for any extremity of line.

Vincent R. Impellitteri, president of the City Council, was toastmaster last evening at a reception and dinner to commemorate the fiftieth wedding anniversary of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Culkin. Mr. Culkin, who was elected Alderman the year he was married, was active in city politics over a long span of years.

Parents are largely responsible for racial and religious prejudices in children and need to be educated if a solution is to be found for this problem. That was the general conclusion reached by eight New York public school pupils yesterday in a panel discussion sponsored by the Board of Education's bureau of visual instruction at the American Museum of Natural History.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- The back-to-work movement by employes of the Chicago plants of swift Wilson meat packing companies, struck since March 16 by the United Packinghouse Workers of America, CIO, increased today as pickets turned out in far less numbers than yesterday, according to plant officials.
"The Turning Stream," by Duncan Aikman, an analysis of the technological, economic and social can Aikman, an analysis of the United States, will be published by Doubleday on May 20.
Many dinner parties were given last night at the formal reopening of the St. Regis Roof for the twenty-first season, one of the largest being that of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Astor.

ROME, May 4 -- Considerable progress toward avoiding a split in the World Federation of Trade Unions was made today when the six-man committee appointed to conciliate the contrasting viewpoints of the pro-communist and anti-communist affiliates accepted the minimum demands submitted by James B. Carey of the CIO.

Any move to increase the price of copper, now 21 1/2 cents a pound, will be opposed by the Kennecott Copper Corporation, E.T. Stannard, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting held here yesterday. He said he was in accord with the steel industry and others in their recent attempts to combat inflation by halting price-wage increases.

Temporarily, at least, Bucky Harris stopped viewing with alarm the inconsistency of his mound staff. For yesterday at the Stadium, the Yankees started a pitcher other than Allie Reynolds and the starter was the finisher as the champions defeated the Browns, 6 -- 1.

Executors of the estate of Mrs. Adabelle R. Terry sold Willowstone, the Italian style villa at Belle Haven, Greenwich, Conn., according to Previews, Inc. The property, which was reported held at $120,000, was acquired by a client of James Meighan, New York broker, and Edson Edson, Inc., brokers of Greenwich.

The American and Dutch letter writing campaign prior to the Italian elections played an important part in defeating the Communists, according to passengers who arrived here yesterday on the Gdynia America liner Sobieski, the first passenger ship to arrive since the April 18 election.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Members of Congress, news reporters or anyone else divulging confidential information given to Congressional committees would be subject to jail sentences under a bill approved today by the House Rules Committee.

GENEVA, May 4 -- A tendency to overproduction is visible in parts of Europe because of the hamstringing effects of the bilateral-payments agreements in intra-European trade, a Benelux countries' representative told the Economic Commission for Europe today.

Fifty years ago the New York School of Social Work, Columbia University, opened its doors to the first social work students to meet in this country. Since then the history of the school has been one of growth and pioneering. Forerunner of forty-nine similar graduate institutions now established in the United States, the New York school was among the first to demonstrate that social work as a profession requires the skills of scientific method.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The National Health Assembly, called by Federal Security Administrator Oscar R. Ewing, at the request of President Truman, to map "areas of agreement" between the various medical and lay groups on a feasiable ten-year health program for the nation was concluded here today after four days of intensive exploration.
TRENTON, N.J., May 4 -- Platforms of the New Jersey Republican and Democratic organizations were adopted today without change and with little comment.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Wednesday, May 5 -- Following is the text of the report to the United Nations General Assembly adopted today by the Trusteeship Council:

David Sarnoff, chairman and president of the $216,000,000 Radio Corporation of America, drew applause from the 500 stockholders at the twenty-ninth annual meeting yesterday when he scored an irate stockholder for his demands on management for increased dividends.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 4 (UP) -- Showers fell over most of Indiana today as a small number of voters went to the polls for the Congressional primaries.
Miss Lyda Mae Vosburgh completed yesterday her fiftieth year of service in one office -- the Erie Railway Express Terminal in Jersey City.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Government issued today a new regulation designed to make it more difficult for traders to use commodity futures markets for the purpose of avoiding income taxes.

Modoc, one of the veteran members of the elephant herd of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, strolled seventeer blocks down Eighth Avenue yesterday to lend her prestige to the Greater New York Fund's 1948 drive for $8,000,000.
LONDON, May 4 (AP) -- France's tennis team completed a surprising comeback today to reach the second round in the European Zone Davis Cup eliminations with a 3-2 triumph over Rumania at Bucharest.

Red Shoes, a 5-2 shot, showed her heels to the rest of the field in the Incetatus Purse, yesterday's feature race at Jamaica. Accepting the challenge of four others, including Mrs. Nicholas M. Schenck's favored Dangerous Age, the 5-year-old daughter of Easton had to withstand a late challenge in the mile-and-a-sixteenth test for 4-year-olds and upward.

MIAMI, Fla., May 4 -- The Southern Association of Science and Industry ended its annual convention here today with the admonition that in the development of research laboratories lay the only answer to mankind's struggle to provide sufficient food for the world's growing population.

Prof. William Bradley Otis, for forty-four years a member of City College's English Department, announced yesterday that he would retire "with the greatest reluctance" at the conclusion of the current semester. Dr. Otis reached the compulsory retirement age of 70 in March.

"There is no danger of a business recession in any form during the coming twelve months," Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance, New York University, told members of the American Spice Trade Association at a luncheon in the Astor Hotel yesterday.

Backed by the personal pledge of former General Dwight D. Eisenhower, incoming president of Columbia University, to help the educational world to improve and perpetuate the American economic system, Dean Philip Young of Columbia University's School of Business, yesterday outlined plans for an expanded graduate school of business in 1949.

LONDON, May 4 -- Britain is through as a first-class power unless she can produce and export at a higher rate than ever before, Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, warned at the annual conference of the Confederation of Engineering and Shipbuilding Unions at Weston-Super-Mere today.

YONKERS, May 4 -- Proposals for the unification of this municipality's 81.4 miles of bus and trolley lines under one company were filed this afternoon with the Yonkers Common Council by the Mayor's Transit Committee.

New York's great forest preserve in the Adirondack region is again threatened with inroads based upon private interest. Last year a plan was afoot to build a dam on the Moose River at Higley Mountain. This would have submerged thousands of acres of forest land and inundated one of the great deer refuges.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 4 -- The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly decided today to establish a subcommittee to bring in a proposal "for a provisional regime for Palestine."

Commercial bankers here, cautiously anticipating an advance in the rate on the Government's short-term obligations, are now shortening terms on new commercial loans and renewals, it was learned yesterday. According to loan officers in several large banks, the current policy of most individual lenders is "wait and see," since the prevailing view is that the Government's rate will be increased soon.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The National Grange expressed opposition today to extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act unless Congress were empowered to nullify any future pacts.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Whether top generals and admirals should have three free military assistants after retirement became an issue today between the White House and the House Armed Services Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Truman today conferred for more than an hour on the future of the social security program with Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, and some leading Democrats of the House and Senate.

LONDON, May 4 -- The leaders of Britain's three principal political parties jointly conceded today that they had failed to work out an agreement for a comprehensive revision of the powers of the House of Lords, which remains as a vestige of Britain's feudal past.
HANOVER, May 4 (AP) -- Strikes in protest against food shortages spread today in the British and United States occupation zones of Germany, and 81,000 workers may be idle tomorrow.

Responsibility for self-education in business lies with the employe rather than the employer, Ben Duffy, president of the Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn advertising agency, told more than 125 advertising unit trainees of the City College Midtown Center last night at graduation ceremonies in the Beekman Tower Hotel.

Plans for construction of a five-story school building at 151-53 East Sixty-sixth Street for the Literary Society of St. Vincent Ferrer of 689 Lexington Avenue were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings by Eliott L. Chisling-Ferrenz Taylor, associated architects, of 420 Madison Avenue.

Mayor O'Dwyer accepted yesterday on behalf of Sydenham Hospital a check for $1,000 from the Police and Fire Departments as their joint membership fee in a Save Our Sydenham Society. In a ceremony at City Hall, the Mayor praised the departments for donating the money, which was raised by means of a basketball game.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 4 -- Anti-Truman convention delegates and electors took the lead in first returns from the Democratic primary tonight, but strong "loyalty" candidates were cutting down their margin.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 4 (AP) -- Floridians by the hundreds of thousands voted quietly today in one of the state's biggest elections.

Sol Strauss, acting head of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, yesterday declared he had been informed that it would be illegal for him to enter into negotiations with the New York Boxing Managers Guild pertaining to bouts because the body does not hold a license as a manager.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- With railroad, coal and other strikes threatening, Congressional hearings aimed at tightening the Taft-Hartley act were set today for May 24.

PARIS, May 4 -- United States representatives, for the first time, today took part officially in the work of the European Economic Cooperation organization, assisting European experts with aid-programming for the third quarter of this year.

GENEVA, May 4 -- William Hallam Tuck of the United States, executive secretary of the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization today bluntly accused the governments that undertook to solve the problem of the displaced persons after World War II with hypocrisy and lack of charity.

Firm prices now are being quoted on about 50 per cent of items purchased by larger industrial procurement departments, it was disclosed here yesterday. The remainder of the items are bought either on an emergency negotiated basis, or at prices subject to escalator clauses, according to spokesmen for purchases amounting to more than $50,000,000 annually.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman urged today, after a talk with President Truman, a trusteeship for Jerusalem and its environs, ultimate partition of Palestine, a truce of three or four months and an international force that could keep the peace there.

Needless blasts of automobile horns were designated yesterday by Martin Klein, director of safety, Automobile Club of New York, as "one of the city's most nerve-racking sounds." He urged that motorists restrict the use of their loud signals to a minimum as a contribution to the city's Noise Abatement Week.

With shipments of automobiles in the first quarter of this year 60 per cent larger than in the corresponding three months of 1947, the Packard Motor Car Company reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $1,304,727 in contrast to the net loss of $1,148,173 sustained in the March quarter a year ago.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 4 -- Careful supervision of children's reading was advocated here today at a forum before the Mount Vernon Council of Home and School Associations in the auditorium of Nichols Junior High School. Most comic books were denounced as harmful to morals and intellect.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 4 -- Dartmouth came from behind to score five runs in the eighth on four walks and two errors to defeat Harvard, 9 to 6, today.

Pinball machine operators agreed yesterday on a code of regulations to be submitted to the City Council that would bar play by children under 18 years, ban the machine from the vicinity of schools and churches, provide tax revenue for the city and require licensing of all operators, it was announced by the Associated Amusement Machine Operators.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Wednesday, May 5 -- After nine days of work and a ten-hour session lasting until after 1 A.M. today, the United Nations Trusteeship Council ended its efforts to find a formula for peace in Jerusalem. It reported that only one measure had gained support of both the Jews and the Arabs.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 4 -- Samuel Goldwyn, independent producer and long-time advocate of trust-busting in the film business, today described the Supreme Court decision remanding the Government anti-trust action to the Statute Courts, as "a distinct victory toward restoring free enterprise in the motion-picture industry."

CLEVELAND, Wednesday, May 5 -- Senator Robert A. Taft was leading Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, in fourteen of the twenty-three contests for Ohio delegates to the Republican National Convention in returns early today from yesterday's primary.

Play in the twentieth round of the tournament at Moscow for the chess championship of the world resulted in no decision yesterday, but Mikhail Botvinnik, Soviet grand-master, came still closer to the coveted goal, according to a report received from Russia.
JERUSALEM, May 4 -- The International Red Cross offered today to raise its flag over the whole of Jerusalem, making it a "neutral security zone," if invited to do so by both Jews and Arabs.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- Grain markets closed strong on the Board of Trade today, final sales being about the top, with the May deliveries showing independent strength. Wheat futures rose 1 3/4 to 3 1/4 cents a bushel, corn 5/8 cent to 2 1/2 cents and oats 5/8 cent to 2 5/8 cents.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- An incentive bonus plan, designed to spur the voluntary enlistment of a needed 700,000 men into the armed forces, was entered into competition with the proposed stop-gap draft in the House today.

The Transport Workers Union, CIO, last night set 4 A.M. Friday as the deadline for a strike that would cut off bus and trolley car service in all of Manhattan, the Bronx and lower Westchester and parts of Queens. The tie-up would affect six private transit companies serving 3,500,000 riders a day.
CLEVELAND, May 4 -- Harold Stassen and Senator Taft are not precisely the most frivolous men in politics, but their campaign for Ohio's Republican delegates did produce a few laughs.

An issue of $20,000,000 of convertible preferred stock to increase the working capital and the resources of the Sunray Oil Corporation for exploration and expansion will be placed on the market today by a syndicate of investment-banking houses headed by Eastman, Dillon Co.

With the May 11 deadline for a strike of 150,000 members of the railroad operating unions less than a week away, Government officials yesterday appeared to be shifting their sights more and more from the problem of how to keep these workers on the job to the problem of how to keep the nation's trains running if the threatened walkout materializes.

MOSCOW, May 4 (UP) -- Reports from two big Russian cities today appeared to support predictions that the third "voluntary"* $4,000,000,000 reconstruction loan would be oversubscribed within a day or two.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The building of private homes accounted for almost 40 per cent of all new construction work in April, the Commerce Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- A compact to permit Southern states to operate regional universities won House approval today.

BOSTON, May 4 -- Responsibility for averting war with Russia was placed squarely on the shoulders of America's churches tonight by John Foster Dulles, Republican foreign policy spokesman and a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations.

MANHASSET, L.I., May 4 -- Two veterans preparing to install an aerial on the roof of a South Strathmore house for a radio television set were killed instantly today when the aluminum ladder they were using struck a high-tension line of the Long Island Lighting Company. Both men were electrocuted.

Even in this motorized age there are many horses working in the streets of New York, pulling heavy loads around the docks, drawing peddler's carts and delivery wagons. It is no easy time they have in the city traffic, but they can endure it if they have plenty of water to drink.

A master trainer of thirty-seven elephants for the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus was instructed yesterday by Magistrate William E. Ringel in Mid-Manhattan Court "to be more gentle in the future with animals."

Indian war dances, so authentic they sent a very young spectator fleeing from the room in terror, were performed yesterday by the Red Shield Boys Club of Baltimore before several hundred delegates to the forty-second annual convention of the Boys Clubs of America at the Commodore Hotel.

The Bodies of 4,183 American war dead including 690 from the metropolitan New York and the New England areas -- the largest single shipment of World War II victims from the European battle-fields -- will arrive here Friday aboard the Army transport Lawrence Victory.

LONDON, May 4 -- Charges of lack of "objectivity" in rejecting Yugoslav territorial demands on Austria were leveled by Soviet Deputy Nikolai Koktomov at delegates of the United States, Britain and France during the meeting of the four-power committee on Austria today.
CHICAGO, May 4 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

EVANSVILLE, Ind., May 4 (UP) -- The Bucyrus-Erie Steel Company told the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, CIO, today that it refused to "do business with a Communist-dominated union."
NANKING, May 4 (UP) -- Chen Li-fu, leader of the extreme Rightist "C-C Clique," resigned today as Kuomintang (Government party) Minister of Organization.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- Responsibility for averting a threatened nation-wide strike next Tuesday of 125,000 members of three railroad operating brotherhoods rested with President Truman tonight as a result of the collapse of Government mediation efforts in Chicago today.

The Curtis Cup women's golf team was entertained by the United States Golf Association at a luncheon yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria. The group will leave today on the Mauretania for England to play in the first international matches since 1938.
The Spence-Chapin Adoption Service has sold the four-story dwelling at 232 East Sixty-second Street, which it has owned and occupied as offices since 1919, to a client of Wm. B. May Co., broker.
New exhibitions by a septuagenarian and an octogenarian lend interest to the art scene this week.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Truman proclaimed today that the general trade agreement with China would go into effect on May 22.

Last night's program by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House was officially "American Choreographers' and Composers' Night," but it might also have been called "John Kriza Night," for Mr. Kriza had a leading role in each of the four works which constituted the extremely long bill.

JERUSALEM, May 4 -- Camouflaged regulars of the Lebanese Army, equipped with light artillery, entered Palestine near Udeisa, a village on the northeastern frontier, early this morning, according to a Haganah broadcast. They were believed to be heading for Ramat Naftali and other Jewish settlements in the Huleh Valley.

LIKE Unus, the circus performer who balances himself on one finger, the St. Louis Browns have been precariously balancing themselves in the first division since the start of the season. If they begin to lose their equilibrium in the near future, no blame should be cast in the direction of James Wren (Zack) Taylor. The amiable Zack is a manager who had most of his ball players sold out from under him between seasons.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- With his eighty-first birthday two weeks off, Dr. Harcourt A. Morgan went to the White House today to retire as vice chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority. President Truman then nominated Dr. Harry Alfred Curtis, Dean of the College of Engineering in the University of Missouri, to succeed him as a director of the TVA.

For the first time since March 29, the visitors' gallery of the New York Stock Exchange is once more open to the public. Yesterday 777 persons visited it. School groups in particular have become more "Exchange conscious" since the strike, and appointments for them are exceeding those of last year. In 1947 an average day in the gallery brought about 500 persons.

NANKING, Wednesday, May 5 (AP) -- Premier Chang Chun announced today that he and the Chinese Cabinet would resign collectively prior to the May 8 inauguration of Chiang Kai-shek as China's first constitutional President.

A banking group headed by the Chase National Bank won yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,000,000 of road bonds of the State of West Virginia at competitive sale. Its bid was 100 for interest of 4 per cent on $200,000 bonds and interest of 1 1/2 per cent on $800,000 bonds, an interest cost of 1.60 per cent.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 4 -- Following is the text of the reso lution adopted today by the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee:

ATHENS, May 4 -- Twenty-four Leftists accused of murders during the occupation and in the subsequent attempted overthrow of the Greek Government in December, 1944, were shot by a firing squad today outside Athens.

BALTIMORE, May 4 (AP) -- Bomar Stable's Piet, winner of five races last year including Laurel's Spalding Lowe Jenkins, made his 1948 debut successful today when he scored a two-length victory in the $7,500 added Ral Parr Stakes at Pimlico.

At the same time that inflated costs of living are preventing persons from buying all the insurance that they need, the Government's policy of keeping interest rates at an "extremely low level" has caused the net cost of insurance to rise, the Committee of Public Debt Policy asserted in its sixth study of the national debt problem, made public yesterday.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 4 (UP) -- Colombia broke diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union not only because of "the great geographical distance but also the fundamental differences as to their concept of the state itself," the Foreign Ministry announced today.

BUENOS AIRES, May 4 -- Argentina expects to receive more than $1,000,000,000 for exports, largely through the Marshall Plan, within the next twelve months, Miguel Miranda, head of the National Economic Council, told the American Legion here last night.
Helen Marie Bennett and H. Stanley Ford Jr., have joined the flat goods division of the Burlington Mills Corporation. They both will do sales promotion work, the former with retail stores.

More than 3,000,000 tons of steel products and cast iron, chiefly line pipe, will be needed by domestic gas utility companies in the next eighteen months if they are to meet the gas demands of present customers and new housing extensions, committees of the American Gas Association and the American Petroleum Institute have determined from surveys just completed.

BERLIN, May 4 -- Approximately 375,000 denazification cases were disposed of in the United States zone in April, and only 28,065 remain to stand trial, the Military Government announced today. It is hoped to dispose of these "hard core" cases before July 1.

The results of tests of a new building material designed to reduce costs and cut construction time were announced yesterday by John D. Dale, president of Durisol, Inc. Known as durisol, it is a light-weight, multi-purpose material made from chemically treated and impregnated wood fibers mixed with cement in a special patented process and precoated with waterproof cement plaster at the factory.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., yesterday received authorization of the Public Service Commission to take two major financing steps. The first was the approval by Chairman Milo R. Maltbie of the company's request to seek bids for the underwriting of $57,382,600 of fifteen-year 3 per cent convertible debentures.

Americans who talk about "inevitable war" are echoing Soviet propaganda in Europe. Next to the campaign against the European Recovery Program, which pictures the United States as the devouring enemy of the political and economic independence of the nations involved, the Communists put all their emphasis on the charge that America is leading its followers straight toward war, of which the battlefield will be the European continent.
ST. LOUIS, May 4 -- After blowing a 2-0 lead by ragged defensive play in the fifth inning the Dodgers staged a ninth-inning rally tonight that had a crowd of 27,768 fans on the edge of their seats.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 4 -- The Soviet Union tried again today to write into the proposed international declaration on human rights a statement that a basic aim of the United Nations was to eradicate "the remnants of nazism and fascism."

Mary A. Walsh has sold the blockfront vacant plot of land at the northwest corner of Westchester Avenue and Unionport Road, in the Parkchester section of the Bronx, to Land Properties, Inc., of which Leo Silver is president.

Groupings for the seventh Goodall match-play round-robin benefit golf tournament which is to start tomorrow at the Wykagyl Country Club in New Rochelle were announced yesterday by Tournament Supervisor Harold McSpaden.

Excellent pitching by Sam Piacentino brought a sudden end to New York University's string of eight consecutive Metropolitan Collegiate Conference victories as the City College nine handed the Violets their initial circuit setback, 7 -- 4, yesterday at Ohio Field.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Truman may summon the parties in the railway wage dis pute to the White House within forty-eight hours preliminary to Government seizure of the railroads if further efforts for a truce prove abortive.

Henry Witte, vice president of Macy's, New York, yesterday called on carpet mills and distributors supply increasing quantities of twelve and fifteen foot carpeting in wanted weaves, styles and colors. He intimated that if manufacturers revamp production schedules to accomplish this, retailers will not object to higher prices.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 4 (AP) -- A split over Government subsidies for Catholic schools threatenedd the Belgium Cabinet of Premier Paul-Henri Spaak today.

Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Set up subcommittee to report on proposal for provisional regime in Palestine, taking into account work of Security and Trusteeship Councils and suggestions made in course of committee's debate.

Chamber Music Associates, a group of enterprising and skillful young instrumentalists, which gave its debut program a month ago, presented its second New York concert last night at Times Hall. The illness of two of its performers necessitated a few changes, but it was still a refreshing and exhilarating event.

Further competition in South America for Pan American Airways and Pan American-Grace was seen here yesterday in Monday's decision of the Civil Aeronautics Board refusing to suspend or alter Braniff Airways certificate for service from the Middle West and Southwest, initially to Peru and subsequently across the Andes to Rio de Janeiro and Buenos Aires.

IN every war in which the Royal Navy has claimed the command of the seas, it has had to pay the price of exposing immense targets to the enemy. The privateer, the raiding cruiser, and above all the U-boat, have in all the varying forms of war exacted a heavy toll upon the life-lines of our commerce and food-supply. A prime function of defence has therefore always been imposed upon us.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., May 4 -- Jerry Desio, Green Valley pro, found himself in a two-way tie with partners Charles Wood of Tamarack and Charlie Delucca of Dunwoodie at a one-day pro-amateur golf tournament of the Westchester P.G.A. at Leewood Golf Club today.

In your issue of April 21 you report Paul Hoffman, the Economic Cooperation Administrator, as telling the House Appropriations Committee that his great fear "is that even with the most careful planning and the most rigorous supervision of expenditures, this amount ($5,300,000,000) may prove insufficient to accomplish the degree of recovery we seek."

"Hold It!", entirely financed by Anthony B. Farrell, 48-year-old president of the Ramsey Chain Company of Albany, will begin its career at 8:15 tonight at the National. Already costing him more than $200,000, the musical comedy represents his first Broadway investment.

PROVIDENCE, May 4 -- More than half of this city's 1,200 teachers went out on strike today for increased pay and other concessions, closing sixty of the sixty-seven public elementary and high schools. Only 1,100 of the 28,000 children had classes.
Discussed Palestine situation with former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman.

Benjamin H. Freedman, who says he has spent more than $100,000 of his own money fighting Zionism, charged yesterday that outstanding Americans of the Jewish faith were the "dictators" of our policy on Palestine.

A group of University of California psychologists are making what a Johannesburg dispatch to this newspaper describes as "a scientific study of racial prejudice in South Africa." They plan to distribute questionnaires to six major racial or religious groups -- Europeans, Boers or Afrikanders, Jews, Indians, part-colored and those of pure native stock.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Senators and the White Sox battled to a 3-3 tie tonight in a game called at the end of five innings because of rain.

Protestant churches and social organizations were urged yesterday to raise funds for the Katy Ferguson House at 162 West 130th Street, the main private center in this city for care of unmarried young Negro mothers and their children.

Hope that the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations could purge their ranks of Communist influence and reunite was expressed yesterday in a letter sent by Matthew Woll, chairman of the international relations committee of the AFL, to Philip Murray, president of the CIO.

In the first change of ownership since 1866, six old holdings in the Twenty-third Street district at the Avenue of the Americas have been purchased by the Treber Realty Company from Henry G. Darling to round out a plot of nearly 22,000 square feet.
ATHENS, May 4 (AP) -- The Government announced the executions today throughout Greece of 152 persons convicted of murder -- most of them in connection with the 1944 leftist revolt.

BOSTON, May 4 (AP) -- Boston's Red Sox today made it three victories in a row for the first time this season by defeating the Tigers, 6 -- 3, before 17,316 paid fans and 1,479 Ladies' Day guests at Fenway Park.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- Justices Hugo L. Black and Robert H. Jackson expressed opposing views on the Supreme Court bench today while hearing a plea that a former Nazi be saved from deportation.

Padraic Colum's quibble on "misuse" of the term "Ulster" by Herbert L. Matthews, in a recent TIMES dispatch, as an excuse for discourse on ancient Irish history to justify abolition of partition, appears flimsy. While he stated that partition is relatively a minor problem, he added that, nevertheless, "correct information about it should be in order."

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Senate became engaged today in a decisive aspect of the Congressional struggle over repeal of the Federal tax on oleomargarine, but put off until tomorrow an all-important test vote on the question of what committee should shape the fate of the repealer.

The need for establishing a definite cultural program to aid American Indians and to guide them toward economic efficiency was emphasized yesterday by educational and cultural leaders at a luncheon sponsored by the American Indian Fund of the Association on American Indian Affairs, Inc.

Retail failures in the apparel lines showed a marked increase in the first quarter of 1948, in contrast with failures among wholesalers of apparel and dry goods in the same period, according to a compilation by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Russia got $35,013,000 worth of metal-working machine tools and machinery from the United States in 1947. This was 11.8 per cent of all American exports of such tools and machinery. This was reported today by the Department of Commerce.
Random notes:

The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday that net income for the first quarter of 1948 was off $1,945,944 from the comparable 1947 period to $8,659,014. Operating revenue rose $9,708,511 to $97,159,047 and operating expenses were up $11,255,344 to $72,498,509.
The year 1947 was the year that saw the turning point in the war on cancer. In 1947 the American people poured more money than ever before into the battle against our enemy.

The Last Chore The last chore in spring cleaning is the hardest; it consists of wrestling two bundles of magazines, an Army cot, a superannuated electric heater and two cartons of miscellaneous equipment up to the attic.

If the business of the American Chain and Cable Company continues to run ahead of last year, Wilmot F. Wheeler, president, yesterday told stockholders at the annual meeting, he would recommend to the board raising the dividend rate of 35 cents a share on the common stock.

Fall lines of lingerie and blouses will feature imported silk fabrics and cotton laces which have been purchased recently by American manufacturers, according to Herbert Miskend, president of Yolande, Inc. Landed prices on these materials, he said, now make it possible to utilize them to a larger extent than any time since the end of the war.

Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, United States Army, retired, declared yesterday that Gen Douglas MacArthur must be the next President of the United States. He spoke of his long friendship with General MacArthur and described his "greatest and strongest qualifications" as not only military but as statesmanship.

Members of The New York Herald Tribune unit of the Newspaper Guild of New York, CIO, voted last night to authorize acceptance of an agreement obtained as a result of contract negotiations between the newspaper and the union. The decision was taken at three sessions held at the Guild Clubhouse, 133 West Forty-fourth Street.

The Rev. William Jones Gordon Jr., son of the late priest-in-charge of St. Luke's Protestant Episcopal Church, Spray, N.C., will be consecrated as the youngest Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church at 10:30 A.M., May 18, at Good Shepherd Church, Raleigh, N.C., by Presiding Bishop Henry Knox Sherrill, it was announced here yesterday.

A potpourri of new designs in decorative furnishings was presented to the press in a special Showing yesterday at the house of Dan Cooper, 21 East Seventieth Street. Although Mr. Cooper's specialty is hand-printed fabrics of his own design, he likes to feel that a decorator can assemble a whole scheme in his showroom and pick up a few pieces of furniture and accessories besides.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 4 -- The existence during the war of a Japanese-built opium extraction plant in Mukden, Manchuria with a production capacity of fifty tons of heroin a year -- at least fifty times the legitimate world requirements -- was disclosed here today by Harry J. Anslinger, Commissioner of the United States Bureau of Narcotics and delegate to the United Nations Commission on Narcotic Drugs.

Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett yesterday urged New Yorkers to take part in the Red Cross blood donor service at a ceremony marking the opening of the Manhattan blood donor center at 4 East Thirty-seventh Street.
LONDON, May 4 -- Firmness again marked a generally quiet stock market here today.

TEL AVIV, Palestine, May 4 -- Irgun Zvai Leumi, Jewish underground force, was reported to have captured today the large and important Arab village of Yehudia north of Lydda airport along the Lydda-Tel Aviv road. [Yehudia barred the main highway approach to Lydda airport, The Associated Press said.

Poland will spend $65,800,000 on a shipbuilding and buying program, an improved fishing industry and rehabilitation and expansion of port facilities, it was reported here yesterday by Capt. Jerzy Panski, marine consul of the Polish Consulate.

Randy Brown, 163, Mount Vernon, N.Y., and Jimmy Mangia, 164, East Side, fought an eight-round draw in the main event at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. A crowd of 3,500 watched the show, the final one of the season.

LONDON, May 4 -- A decision on the question of how many passengers a cargo vessel may carry and still retain its freighter classification is expected to be decided tomorrow by the general problems committee of the International Conference on Safety of Life at Sea.
Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, hero of Bataan, and Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, received last night Masonic Medals for humanitarian achievement.

PARIS, May 4 -- Bulgarian Peasant Leader Nikola Petkov, who was executed by the Communist-led Sofia Government last Sept. 22, refused a last-minute offer of mercy, according to a Bulgarian emigre newspaper published here.
Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, hero of Bataan, and Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, received last night Masonic Medals for humanitarian achievement.

PARIS, May 4 -- Bulgarian Peasant Leader Nikola Petkov, who was executed by the Communist-led Sofia Government last Sept. 22, refused a last-minute offer of mercy, according to a Bulgarian emigre newspaper published here.
Improved operating results for the first quarter of this year were reported yesterday by the Douglas Aircraft Company and North American Aviation, Inc.

A leaking gas pipe, broken by movers as they were bringing in a piano, led to an explosion that demolished the four-family house at 75-10 and 75-12 197th Street, Cunningham Crest, Queens, at 9:50 A.M. yesterday. One of the moving men was killed and six other persons were injured, two critically, by the blast.

Affording golf enthusiasts an opportunity of seeing some of the top-flight professionals in action, the Goodall round-robbin charity tourney will get under way today at the Wykagyl Country Club, New Rochelle, N.Y. A selected field of sixteen will take part.
NEW DELHI, India, May 5 -- The rulers of eight Sikh Princely States in East Punjab signed a covenant with the Indian States Ministry today forming the Phulkian Union.

Successful in winning both of his adjourned games from the nineteenth and twentieth rounds in the tournament for the chess championship of the world at Moscow yesterday, Mikhail Botvinnik, Soviet grand-master, extended his lead to 3 1/2 points, according to a report from Russia.

Increases in the cost of equipment, maintenance and wages will require higher passenger fares on Eastern railroads to avoid further losses this year, according to testimony presented yesterday by railroad officials at a hearing called by the Interstate Commerce Commission in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Munitions Board disclosed today that it had blocked the sale of 100 Government-owned war plants during the past four weeks to permit their possible inclusion in an "industrial reserve" for use in an emergency.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Walter Masterson stopped the White Sox on four hits tonight as Washington snapped a five-game losing streak, 6 -- 0.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 5 -- Bipartite authorities were completely out of sympathy with German officials who appealed to them today for help as nearly 100,000 workers in the bizonal area went out on strike.

Quite a lot of young people are working quite hard to conceal a case of arrested musical comedy development at the National. The case is labeled "Hold It!," which was put on at high speed last evening and ought to be removed without any appreciable slackening of pace.

Shimshon Oxman, while purporting to correct a few historical remarks made by Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick, himself makes inaccurate statements, which, I hope, are unintentional and based on unauthentic information, since they constitute an insult to nearly half-a-billion followers of Islam all over the world.

THE list of novels, books of travel, comment, plays and poetry by Cecil Roberts runs up, by now, to around thirty volumes. He writes easily, conventionally and, it must be said, somewhat superficially about the more pleasant aspects of English life and English places and the points on the Continent and in America to which Englishmen go.

Prices of soaps and other household cleaners will be reduced today about 6 per cent in most stores. This passes along to consumers the wholesale price reductions announced yesterday by major soap-makers.

An exchange of style and production ideas by American and European manufacturers of women's ready-to-wear was proposed yesterday by Albert Lempereur, president of the Federation Francaise des Industries du Vetement Feminin.

Except for Government procurement of certain bulk food products and a small volume of relief supplies such as drugs, American exporters will continue to do business in private trade channels under the European Recovery Program as they have in the past, Joseph A. Mack, acting regional director of the New York office of the Department of Commerce, made clear here yesterday.

Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Subcommittee met at 4 East Seventy-ninth Street and discussed five-point outline submitted by France as working basis for its study of provisional regime for Palestine.
Although new sales peaks were reported yesterday by two large department store chains, their earnings for the fiscal year ended with January showed declines from the previous year.

MUNICH, Germany, May 5 -- In a country so starved for newsprint that the dominantly popular illustrated periodical Heute can allow only 200 copies for distribution in an area with 4,000,000 population, this Bavarian capital today became the focal point for European and United States journalists.

Dr. Haven Emerson, retiring president of the Association on Indian Affairs, Inc., said yesterday that the American Indian peoples could be aided best if the Federal Government would take as much interest in its Indian wards on reservations as local communities took in their citizens under normal conditions.
LEXINGTON, Ky., May 5 (AP) -- As a result of his own generosity, Eddie Arcaro's victorious ride on Citation in the Kentucky Derby will gross him only $2,085.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 5 (UP) -- A majority of Alabama national convention delegates chosen in yesterday's Democratic primary will walk out at Philadelphia if President Truman's civil rights program is adopted, mounting returns showed today.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Even after more than thirty years, echoes of the great Black Tom and Kingsland explosions in New Jersey during World War I sounded at the Treasury today. That department announced another distribution of payments to persons receiving awards from the old Mixed Claims Commission between this country and Germany.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- The Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation, San Diego, Calif., today registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission 1,159,849 shares of common stock which will be offered to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Administration told Congress in the gravest words today that any insistent effort now fundamentally to alter the United Nations might destroy it and drive dangerous wedges across the world.

First new orders for defense production have been received by some leading New York manufacturers, spokesmen for metalworking industries revealed here yesterday. An official of the Pressed Metal Institute, among others, declared that some of their members had received contracts for new production for national defense purposes.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 5 -- The first United Nations reports on world-wide efforts to suppress traffic in women, children and obscene publications were issued here today.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The result of the Republican preference primary in Ohio has started an argument that no preceding test of the party's sentiment toward its 1948 nomination has evoked. The argument, which clearly will not be settled until the test comes at the Philadelphia convention, turns on these points:

BALTIMORE, May 5 (AP) -- A scratch-riddled field of three competed in the $7,500 added Carroll Handicap for fillies and mares at Pimlico today and the tenth running of the sprint was no contest. S.H. Rogers' Ginargie was so much the best that she was blocked, pulled up and still won by three lengths.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- The text of the statement by Secretary of State Marshall before the House Foreign Affairs Committee today follows:

VIENNA, May 5 -- Soviet occupation authorities in Vienna have become certain that Karl Marx was right when he predicted the capitalistic system must inevitably lead to a depression. They have proved it to their own dissatisfaction in the Austrian industries they confiscated as German property, which they have been administering since on a strict profit basis.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Great Britain informed the Economic Cooperation Administration today of its intention to comply with the Foreign Assistance Act and received a grant of $33,500,000 for the purchase of wheat, flour and bacon from Canada. This was the largest single allotment to date.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 5 -- Argosy Productions, the John Ford-Merian Cooper Producing Company, today announced the purchase of screen rights to "Mission Without Orders," a 1947 Saturday Evening Post short story by James Warner Bellah, as a prospective vehicle for John Wayne and John Agar.
The Ohio Oil Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended with March a net profit of $12,447,155 after all charges including $4,403,949 provision for taxes.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 5 (AP) -- Reid Robinson, organizer for the Congress of Industrial Organizations, who denies a charge by the Canadian Government that he is a Communist, was released here today by a Canadian immigration official.
Making one of his few speeches in recent weeks, Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday that he had not lost faith in the United Nations despite "recent events."
PARIS, May 5 -- Premier Schuman's Government will ask the National Assembly to fix the term of compulsory military service provisionally at fifteen months, it was announced today.

LOS ANGELES, May 5 -- Howard Greet, who discontinued his custom salon in Beverly Hills, has taken new quarters in Los Angeles, where he is creating store collections exclusively. Guided by the side-saddle habits of the elegant days of Edward VII, Greer has developed a new side-back attraction that is interesting and wearable.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The 51-day meat strike resisted Federal mediation efforts and conferences virtually collapsed today.

A house dress market week has been arranged for Jan. 9-12, in the Hotel Astor, it was announced yesterday by the House Dress Institute. The showing will be held in connection with the annual convention of the association. A whole floor has been reserved for sample room showing, with participation limited to institute members only, according to M. J. Lovell, director-counsel.

Fifteen annual awards in the fields of art, music and literature were announced jointly yesterday by the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters. Van Wyck Brooks is chairman of the grants committee.

NANKING, May 5 -- Gen. Ho Ying-chin, China's representative on the United Nations Military Staff Committee, was busy here today exchanging views with top Government officers and college professors in preparation for the formation of a new Cabinet.

PARIS, May 5 -- Winston Churchill, in an article published today in the Paris weekly Carrefour, as a preview of the meeting on European federation Friday at The Hague, declared that the choice for Europe was union or catastrophe.

NO frontier has ever received the same strategic attention and experiment as that which stretches through the Low Countries between France and Germany. Every aspect of the ground, its heights and its waterways, has been studied for centuries in the light of the latest campaign by all the generals and military colleges in Western Europe.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 5 (AP) -- Irisen, flying the red and white silks of O.L. Nyberg, splashed her way over a rain-swept course today to win the six-furlong Haddon Heights purse at Garden State.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., May 5 -- An invitation subscription dance will be given in the Tuxedo Club on the night of May 29 as a benefit jointly for the Tuxedo Memorial Hospital and the Orange County branch of the New York State Division of the American Cancer Society.

A Pennsylvania industrialist and a New York patent attorney were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on four counts charging that they engaged in an ingenious conspiracy to conceal the German ownership of a $3,000,000 patent holding company and to falsify its tax liability.

BOSTON, May 5 (AP) -- Junior Stephens' eleventh-inning homer carried the Boston Red Sox to a 4-3 victory over the Tigers today after Ted Williams had saved the game in the tenth with a magnificent double-play throw to the plate to retire the side with the bases loaded.
The value of company-sponsored medical care for employes was emphasized yesterday as Columbia University conducted a day-long conference on administrative problems in industrial medicine.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 5 -- The United Nations General Assembly will meet at Flushing Meadow, Queens, at 11 A. M. tomorrow to act on the Trusteeship Council's plan for a special municipal commissioner to administer Jerusalem after the end of the British mandate on May 15.
Eddie Arcaro, a $100,000-a-year man who seems headed for record earnings this season, again was the key figure in the main act of the rain-drenched racing show at Jamaica yesterday.

Now that the average taxpayer has had an opportunity to digest the new tax law, it would appear that Congress, in its effort to treat married couples in all states alike under the community tax provision, has placed an unfair portion of the tax burden on single people.

BOSTON, May 5 -- A four-year program of world-wide evangelism, including a campaign against communism, was adopted unanimously here today by the quadrennial general conference of the Methodist Church. The program, which is expected to get under way within the next few months, will be carried out in addition to the regular activities of the denomination.

CLEVELAND, May 5 -- Senator Robert A. Taft and Harold E. Stassen claimed victories today in yesterday's Ohio primary election, but the general impression here was that one more "victory" like this one would be the undoing of both candidates.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The White House officially announced today the itinerary of an extensive pro-convention speaking tour that left no doubt that Mr. Truman meant to make an all-out campaign to succeed himself as President.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday a revision in the requirements for the listing of corporate securities. The revision pertains to stocks issued in connection with mergers, reorganizations and similar transactions, also stocks issued to officers and directors under options or as special remuneration.
Fine chocolates literally melt in the mouth, having what the trade calls a "low melting point." They're rich and smooth in texture, with a flavor delicately balanced between sweet and bitter.
First-nighters will have a conflict of openings this evening when "Sally" comes to life again at the Martin Beck and "The Alchemist" is done at the City Center, the civic operated house.

"Literature of the Graveyard," by Roger Garaudy, former teacher of philosophy and now Member of the French National Assembly, will be brought out by International Publishers later this month. The book will contain four essays dealing with the writings of Jean-Paul Sartre, Arthur Koestler, Andre Malraux and Francois Mauriac.

Expenditures for national advertising in newspapers during March were 8 per cent higher than for the like period of last year, and 6 per cent lower than in February this year, according to an announcement yesterday by Printer's Ink. The dollar outlay for national advertising in all media for March was reported up 6 per cent, but was 3 per cent less than in the previous month.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- John L. Lewis today asked a Federal Court to toss out a plea by soft coal operators for an order blocking pension payments to retired miners.
Quadruplet tiger cubs were born to Dacca and Rajpur Tuesday in the Bronx Zoo.

American Export Lines had a net operating profit last year of $4,550,430, after all charges and provision for Federal income taxes, according to the company's annual report, made public yesterday. The 1947 net income was $129,508 higher than that of the previous year.

Reports from the Catskills late yesterday indicated that the recent rain, while it raised the level of some of the streams, did not result in more than a slight discoloration but did lower the water temperatures.

LONDON, May 5 -- A vigorous impromptu speech against Communist infiltration in the British Labor party brought Prime Minister Attlee an ovation today at a private meeting of the Parliamentary Labor party called to discuss the executive committee's disciplinary action against suspected fellow-travelers.
Alrick H. Man Jr., captain of the Davis Cup team last year, has been renamed to lead the American forces that will defend the trophy in the challenge round Sept. 4, 5 and 6.

The larger cities have immensely complicated traffic problems, but to date they have not been seriously concerned with bicycles. This is, however, a growing problem in suburbs and towns. It is estimated there are approximately twelve million bicycles in use in the United States, contrasted with nine million in 1940.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The deportation proceedings against Gerhard Eisler and four other men accused of communistic activities were delayed today by Associate Justice T. Alan Goldsborough of the Federal District Court.

Representative Clare E. Hoffman's bill to force disclosure of confidential information gathered by Executive Departments to Congressional committees and then to protect such information from unauthorized publication has dangerous implications for our democratic liberties.

Thirty-five musicians of the Old Folks Club of Union Settlement, 237 East 104th Street, ranging in age from 65 to 95, had the thrill of their musical lives yesterday afternoon when two noted concert performers joined their 2-year-old band for an hour's recital.

NEWARK, N. J., May 5 -- Federal District Court Judge William F. Smith, on application of the Government, said today that he would issue an order directing the forfeiture and partial sale of seventy-seven cases of explosives and machinery consigned to Palestine that had been seized for improper licensing by the Government Jan. 3 at Pier F, Jersey City.

A democratic vote by the membership set last Saturday as the day on which to repair the tennis court. Due to the storms of winter, plus other things under remote control, a good many of the posts needed replacement, as well as all the wire.

Controversy over "progressive" education in the New York public schools flared yesterday among leading educators as the result of a demand by the Bronx Chamber of Commerce that Mayor O'Dwyer conduct an investigation into the city's school system.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- High Administration officials told Congress today that the European Recovery Program would be endangered by failure to extend the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act for three years without weakening amendments.
WARSAW, May 5 -- The Polish Government today gave the United States State Department the choice of curtailing most of its propaganda efforts in Poland or exposing Poles to arrest and imprisonment.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The behavior and morals of the 200,000 American personnel stationed in Germany compare favorably with those of a similar number living in the United States, according to a special survey made by the Army and released today.

Amid a downpour and high winds, which may be encountered while they are abroad, the United States women's Curtis Cup golf team sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Mauretania for England to take part in the first international matches in ten years.

LOS ANGELES, May 5 -- "A terrible mistake "will be made" if we approach the problem of anti-semitism specifically in our role as Jews," the national commission of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith was told tonight.

Large furniture retailers are about to end extremely cautious ordering policies followed since the end of the year, department and furniture store spokesmen disclosed yesterday. Most stores will place substantial orders for medium priced quality case goods in the next sixty days, they reported.

LONDON, May 5 -- A notable weakening of the medical profession's opposition to the British Government's universal health service plan led the council of the British Medical Association to recommend today that the doctors support the new service that is scheduled to begin functioning in two months.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- This country must be made to see the immediacy of the crisis confronting American family life, Eric Johnston told the opening session tonight of the National Conference on Family Life, of which he is chairman.

LONDON, May 5 (UP) -- Pravda, official organ of the Communist party, celebrated Soviet Press Day today with an editorial urging Russian newspapers to show more spirit in attacking the "survivals of capitalism."

The Army of Tomorrow, now under consideration by Congress, may comprise twelve regular divisions and ancillary troops, perhaps 837,000 strong, backed up by thirty-four National Guard divisions or their equivalent and twenty-five reserve divisions -- the whole to cost more than $8,200,000,000 annually by the fiscal year 1952.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Efforts to bring Senate and House Reublican policy into accord on the whole defense program will be made before conflicting selective draft bills are taken to the floors for debate and action, it was disclosed today.

The International Committee of Bankers on Mexico announced yesterday its intention to distribute $4,702,028 to holders of bonds of the Mexican Government and of the National Railways of Mexico deposited under an agreement made in 1922 and amended in 1925.

Formation of a new central body to coordinate and direct continuing development of the advertising industry's program for greater understanding of the American economic system will be the next step in the campaign, it was announced yesterday.

EUGENE, Ore., May 5 -- Every major advance of communism in the last few years has been "made possible by the mistakes of our own Government," Gov. Thomas E. Dewey declared tonight as he advanced his own eight-point program for winning the peace.
Thirteen thousand veterans from all over the state have received assistance at the Masonic Veteran Headquarters at 71 West Twenty-third Street, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, May 5 -- Stimulated by a batch of good dividend announcements, industrial shares were best in an otherwise quiet stock market here today.

The threatening labor picture exercised considerable restraint on the stock market yesterday and induced selling in the rails which then spread to some of the pivotal industrials. The session marked a return to the conventional type of trading in evidence last week and losses were around a point.

ROME, May 5 -- The Executive Committee of the World Federation of Trade Unions today unanimously approved a seven-point motion aimed at curbing the powers of the Federation's Secretary General and other officials and so preventing them from assuming political attitudes in contrast with the opinion of affiliates.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- While President Truman hoped that some way would be found to avert a railroad strike threatened for Tuesday, the first of a series of embargoes on perishable goods was ordered today by the Louisville Nashville Railroad, effective on Friday.

Integration of the Burlington Mills Corporation will be confined to weaving and finishing of textiles and will not encroach upon rayon yarn producers or garment manufacturers, J. Spencer Love, chairman, declared yesterday.

Two new issues of securities of Western public utility companies -- $15,000,000 of first mortgage bonds of Southern California Gas Company and 150,000 shares of common stock of Idaho Power Company -- will be placed on the market today by investment banking syndicates.
You printed on May 1 a letter from John M. Swomley Jr., who identifies himself as the director, National Council Against Conscription.
W. Averell Harriman, Ambassador at Large to Western Europe, declared yesterday that no arms would be sent to countries receiving aid under the Economic Cooperation Administration.

Production of crude oil in the United States declined 1,950 barrels to 5,413,450 barrels last week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. For the week ended May 3, 1947, crude oil production totaled 4,950,700.

DETROIT, May 5 -- Two Cleveland lawyers refused tonight as counsel to answer certain questions asked by the Securities and Exchange Commission with respect to the agency's investigation of the recent $10,000,000 common stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Advocates of repeal of Federal taxes on oleomargarine presented a striking show of force in the Senate today by scoring a 47 to 30 victory in a preliminary test to determine what committee should handle the repeal legislation.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 5 -- Maintenance of a stabilized market during the present inflationary period and the anticipated return to normal, along with sounder public relations, are major problems facing the nation's brewing industry.

The way that the $100,000,000 Southwestern Bell Telephone bond issue caught the financial district napping is still the subject of lively conjecture in bond houses. Until the eve of bidding, the consensus of market analysts seemed to favor a 3.05 per cent as the "going" yield basis for the issue.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended April 28:

PARIS, May 5 -- Foreign Minister Bidault warmly defended today the French course in the London negotiations looking toward agreements among France, the United States and Britain on western Germany. He said such agreements would be the sole hope for the future of Europe.

A grandiose scheme in which ninety-seven persons contributed $35,000 in advance rents for apartments in a non-existent building resulted yesterday in the arraignment of a 53-year-old real estate promoter in Special Sessions. He was charged with gouging $5,800 from at least eight of the prospective tenants as bonuses for leases in a proposed twelve-story building in East Seventy-eighth Street.

An enlarged board of directors, broadened to include many new members, was elected yesterday at the thirty-sixth annual luncheon meeting of the Children's Welfare Federation at the Henry Hudson Hotel. Newbold Morris was reelected president of the group.

BALTIMORE, May 5 (AP) -- Vice President Robert W. Purcell of the Alleghany Corporation explained to stockholders today that the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company needs a close tie with the New York Central Railroad so it will have facilities for handling coal from new fields which it is tapping.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- Edwin R. Embree, president of the Julius Rosenwald Fund, which will close its thirty-one-year career on June 30, today announced the award of $100,000 to forty-seven Fund Fellows for 1948. This concludes the fund's program in which $2,000,000 has been expended on fellowships for promising Negroes and white Southerners.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated over a wide range yesterday and closed unchanged to 55 points lower, with old-crop months showing the most weakness.

SARONA, Palestine, May 5 (AP) -- The new Hebrew state -- with its army of more than 50,000 men but still lacking a flag or a name -- will proclaim its independence eleven days hence in this suburb of Tel Aviv.

WASHINGTON, May 5 - The Senate approved by a voice vote today a temporary sixty-day extension of the special Federal program of insurance of home and rental housing mortgages embodied in title six of the National Housing Act.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., May 51 -- Miss Harriette Aull, executive director of the Girls Clubs of America, asked 150 delegates to the third annual conference today to revaluate their local programs to determine whether they met "present-day needs."

"Evangeline," an opera in three acts and eight scenes after Longfellow's poem, the text and music by Otto Luening, was given its first public performance last night by the Columbia Theatre Associates in cooperation with the Columbia University Department of Music and with the aid of a grant from the Alice M. Ditson Fund of the university in Brander Matthews Hall on West Seventeenth Street.
DETROIT, May 5 (AP) -- The automobile industry's truck market is beginning to feel the effects of sustained high level output.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 5 -- Premier Paul-Henri Spaak presented his Cabinet's resignation this afternoon in a dramatic move that cut short the bitter Parliamentary debate on the old question of state subsidies for Roman Catholic schools.

Business men were assured yesterday by John M. Hancock, partner in Lehman Brothers and former United States delegate to the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, that the Soviet Union is about twenty years away from completing an atomic bomb.

ATHENS, May 5 (AP) -- The Greek Parliament tonight was suspended for one month as the result of a Government crisis. The Liberal Premier, Themistocles Sophoulis, announced the suspension after an hour-long conference with Dwight P. Griswold, administrator for the United States aid program, and Karl Rankin, United States charge d'affaires.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 5 -- The two-day strike of Providence public school teachers ended tonight with their acceptance of an interim single-salary schedule offered by the school committee.

A warning to landlords to "desist from interfering with the lawful rights of tenants during the housing shortage" was handed down from the bench yesterday by County Judge Samuel J. Joseph. His warning came in the form of a four-month jail sentence imposed in Bronx County Court on John J. Meehan, 49 years old, who pleaded guilty to the third degree assault of his wife's tenant.

The strike threat against the Third Avenue Transit Corporation was lifted last night after the company had agreed to make a 24-cent hourly wage increase effective as of May 1 and to negotiate further on retroactive pay from Oct. 1 when its old contract with the Transport Workers Union, CIO, expired.

William Cooper, 37-year-old ex-convict, was arrested by Treasury Departments agents yesterday and charged with defrauding the Government of taxes amounting to $692,269 due in connection with an electrical and hardware supply business he formerly conducted at 50 East Forty-second Street.
PITTSBURGH, May 5 (AP) -- Scoring two runs with two out in the ninth, the first-place Pirates beat the Braves, 3 -- 2, today for their sixth straight triumph.

CINCINNATI, May 5 -- Johnny McCarthy, by way of establishing himself as a full-fledged modern Giant in his role as first-base understudy to Johnny Mize, hit a gaudy home run at Crosley Field today. So did Bobby Thomson.

There is a "wide and disheartening gap" between knowledge of the processes of learning and teaching practices in American colleges and universities, Dr. Paul Klapper, former president of Queens College, and newly appointed dean of teacher education for the four municipal colleges, declared last night.
The elections of J.L. Van Volkenburg and J. Kelly Smith as vice presidents of the Columbia Broadcasting System were announced yesterday by Frank Stanton, president.

TEL AVIV, Palestine, May 5 -Seven British soldiers, including a major, were shot to death this afternoon by machinegun fire from an armored car that blocked their path in the Nathanya area between Tel Aviv and Haifa.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Senator Robert A. Taft expressed pleasure today over the results of the Ohio Republican primary and in a statement said:

GENEVA, May 5 -- Led by the Soviet Union, Eastern European nations told Western European countries today that the European Recovery Program would fail and leave the Continent fatally weakened. At the same time Eastern spokesmen in United Nations Economic Commission for Europe held out a promise for the potential development of East-West trade as a practical alternative to the acceptance of United States aid.

CHICAGO, May 5 (AP) -- Prices of hogs dropped today to their lowest average since the end of price controls in October, 1946, as the market declined generally 50 to 75 cents. An estimated 5,000 remained unsold.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The first proposed change in the Taft-Hartley law with a chance of adoption appeared today in a bill introduced by Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican, of New York.

Capt. Harry Grattidge of Stafford, England, who has been in Cunard White Star service since 1914, was in command of the liner Mauretania when she arrived here from Europe Monday, and yesterday on her return crossing.

JERUSALEM, May 5 -- Members of the United Nations Security Council's Truce Commission reported they were "very optimistic about the prospects for a truce in Jerusalem" after they had conferred today with two representatives of the Arab League at Jericho.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 5 (AP) -- Guy W. Vaughan, president of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, testified today that the leader of a common stockholders' committee tried to break up the company's annual meeting here on April 21.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill to establish a national science foundation of twenty-four members eminent in the sciences, engineering, education or public affairs.

Art critics were on the receiving end last night as spokesmen for thirty-six artists who had called a forum meeting in the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, turned critics themselves. Several hundred persons, many of them prominent in art circles, attended.
Drawing on his war experience, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower stressed yesterday the far-reaching consequences of mental and emotional instability in our armed forces.

Ten galleries of the Metropolitan Museum's North Wing will display 150 world famous paintings from Berlin museums for four weeks beginning May 17, the Metropolitan announced yesterday. The masterpieces are due to arrive at the museum on the preceding Friday in trucks escorted by an Army convoy.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- May deliveries of grain closed higher on the Board of Trade today, while the distant months, after showing strength early, broke sharply late in the session and finished heavy. Wheat was 3/4 cent a bushel higher to 1 cent lower than yesterday; corn, 1 1/4 cents higher to 1 cent lower, and oats, 1 1/4 cents higher to 1 3/8 cents lower.

A banking syndicate headed by Bankers Trust Company submitted the highest bid yesterday for issues of slum clearance, rehousing and other bonds of the city of Chicago totaling $66,500,000 and maturing from 1949 to 1968. The Bankers Trust group's offer represented a net interest cost of 2.215 per cent.

Several strategic steps have been taken by the Brazilian Congress and the leading political parties there to solve that country's financial and economic problems. One of the major moves was the recent pact among the political groups to set aside partisanship for a united consideration of measures to cope with the problems.
