Spontaneous adoption of a resolution commending American Legion leaders for bringing about that organization's endorsement of the Taft-Ellender-Wagner housing bill marked yesterday the closing of the National Public Housing Conference's three-day meeting in the New Yorker Hotel.

Housewives who are putting down small scatter rugs on bare floors for the summer can make the rugs skid-proof with inexpensive new preparations now in New York stores. The products, liquids or powders, are designed to eliminate the falls and trips caused by loose small rugs, which recently were found to be the most widespread cause of accidents in New York metropolitan homes.
Expressed hope rail strike would be averted, as Presidential Assistant Steelman met with mediation board.

Joe Walcott, who will meet Joe Louis for the heavyweight championship in June, announced from his training quarters at Grenloch, N.J., yesterday that he would begin boxing regularly in a new outdoor ring on May 15. Bleacher seats holding 2,000 will be ready by that date.

BERMUDA, May 5 -- Claims for salvage brought by the Royal Navy, the Canadian Navy and an American merchant ship against the Swedish vessel Lena Brodin were heard by the Supreme Court, which today ordered that the ship and cargo be advertised for sale in New York with a reserve price of 5,000.
BALTIMORE, May 5 (AP) -- The Navy's 1948 football schedule was squared away finally today with announcement by city officials of agreement to keep the Notre Dame game in the Municipal Stadium.
BALTIMORE, May 5 (AP) -- The old and new look in race horses, Stymie and Citation, arrived today at Pimlico in quest of more glory and greenbacks.

The Maritime Commission, through its Atlantic Coast District headquarters, 45 Broadway, announced yesterday the modification of the present operating agreement with four steamship companies serving Alaska. The alterations of the agreement go into effect immediately and continue until the expiration on June 30 of the special Federal legislation covering the Alaskan service.

If all the persons in the United States between the ages of 31 and 65 could be induced to go to movies once a week annual boxoffice receipts would be increased by nearly $800,000,000, even after taxes, according to the most recent survey made by Audience Research, Inc.

From the gray and green cottons in which two tiny models, Joan and Bob, opened the show to the navy blue net embroidered in a diagonal brilliant spray with which the model in the role of matron closed it, the Arnold Constable fashion performance in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday noon consistently held the interest of the audience.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 5 -- Navy blanked Princeton, 2 -- 0, today under shivery conditions and leaden skies. Lee Rensberger, big middie right-hander handcuffed the Tigers with five hits and never appeared to be in serious trouble.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture expects to continue buying wheat and flour for export, even though it already has bought virtually all it needs to fill quotas for the crop year ending June 30.

Relief payments by voucher should be adopted by welfare departments all over the state to prevent the possibility of abuses by persons who receive cash payments, Paxton Blair, member of the State Board of Social Welfare, declared here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Dalton Trumbo, a film writer, was convicted today of contempt of Congress by a jury of seven men and five women in Federal District Court.

The United Nations Freedom of Information Conference in Geneva was described yesterday by members of the United States delegation as a solid achievement if only because it forced a clarification of opposing views on what is meant by the "fundamental right of the peoples of the world to know what is going on."

Thirty of Ohio's fifty-three delegates to the Republican convention, all pledged to Senator Taft, were unopposed in Tuesday's primary election. Mr. Taft and Mr. Stassen fought it out for the remaining twenty-three. Of these Mr. Taft has won fourteen and Mr. Stassen nine. Several conclusions seem warranted.

John Ringling North's reported statement against permitting a complete performance of the circus he heads to be televised after this year was described yesterday by Henry North, his brother and a vice president of the show, as a "reasonable thing to say."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 5 -- This city's tax rate for 1948, announced today by the Hudson County Board of Tax Commissioners, is $68.99 on every $1,000 of assessed real estate valuation, a reduction of $8.28 on every $1,000 below last year's record high of $77.27.
LONDON, May 5 -- Britain plans to administer the sterling area in the future as she has in the past, Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today at a press conference.
Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, AFL, came to this city yesterday with Elmer Brown, vice president of the union.

Rain washed out yesterday's game between the Yankees and the Browns at the Yankee Stadium. No new date was set for the contest, which will be played during one of the future visits of the St. Louis club to New York. The finale of the current series will be played today at 2:30 P. M.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 5 -- The bare framework of a United Nations provisional regime for Palestine began to take tentative shape today.

In your editorial "Military Aid to the West" you criticize sharply the concurrent resolution introduced by bipartisan groups in the Senate and House for "a revision of the United Nations with or without Russia."

ST. LOUIS, May 5 -- A brisk rain, which started shortly after 2 o'clock today and later became a persistent light drizzle, prevented the Dodgers' second game here with the Cardinals and gave the latter the series, one game to none.

LONDON, May 5 (UP) -- Sir John Boyd Orr, director general of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, said today that full stomachs were the answer to communism, "but the United States won't or can't understand this."

BERLIN, May 5 -- Reports from London that a majority of the Jewish displaced persons in Germany now did not want to go to Palestine were denied here and in Frankfort on the Main today. [A London dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES Tuesday quoted unimpeachable sources as having said that 80 per cent of the Jewish refugees now desired to go to the United States instead of Palestine.]

City departments and agencies were urged yesterday to convert from fuel oil to coal wherever possible. The recommendation came in a report by Mayor O'Dwyer's Emergency Fuel Oil Committee, which foresaw a fuel oil shortage next winter.
TOKYO, May 5 -- Japanese parents today are spending millions of yen to keep the traditions of Japanese feudal glories and Japan's legendary heroes alive in the minds of their sons.
CHICAGO, May 5 (AP) -- The Phillies launched their Western invasion with a 13-9 victory over the Cubs today, but that was small solace for the loss of Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe.

"East Side Scrolls of Honor" were presented last night to former residents of Manhattan's lower East Side at the Madison House Golden Jubilee Dinner, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, attended by 250 persons.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 5 - Universal military training is favored by 81 per cent of the male student body of Fairleigh Dickinson College here, and 56 per cent are for the draft, according to a survey just completed by the market research class at the college.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 5 (AP) -- Mr. Stassen termed his showing in Ohio "one of the most significant developments of the entire national campaign." In a statement, issued today from his headquarters here, the candidate said:

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 5 (AP) -- Twenty-seven foreign players, including the defending champion, Willie Turnesa of White Plains, N.Y., and seven other Americans, will compete in the British amateur golf championship, May 24-29, at Sandwich.

LONDON, May 5 -- A Western European union backed by the United States was held up in the House of Commons today by all parties except the Communist as the best hope for preventing war. The second and last day of the big debate on foreign affairs was dominated by what Anthony Eden called the "fantastically horrible" possibility of another war.

SEOUL, Korea, May 5. -- The two non-Communist South Korean political leaders who attended the Soviet-sponsored North and South Korea joint political conference because they opposed the United Nations-sponsored elections in Korea, crossed the border into South Korea near Kaesong this afternoon.

VIENNA, May 6 -- Today's interruption of the London negotiations on an Austrian treaty was an unpleasant surprise to the Austrian Government but the consensus here was it would prove only temporary. It is believed that the Soviet Union is making a final gesture of support for the Yugoslav claim but that Moscow's desire for the conclusion of a treaty will prove ultimately the determining factor.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- President Truman refused today to disturb the secrecy surrounding administration plans for giving military aid to countries taking part in the European Recovery Program. He refused either to confirm or deny suggestions that legislative authority would be sought for such a plan.

EDDYSTONE, Pa., May 6 (AP) -- The General Steel Castings Corporation said today it has made changes in its board of directors to conform with a request of the Department of Justice for elimination of interlocking directorates between the corporation and two of its large common stockholders.

Officials of the New York Central Railroad declared yesterday that declining passenger traffic in the face of rising service expenses necessitates the increases in passenger fares currently being sought by sixty Eastern railroads.
Settlement of the bus strike scheduled for 4 o'clock this morning was reached at City Hall at 12:20 A.M. today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 6 -- Delegates of the Netherlands and the Indonesian Republic on the United Nations Good Offices Committee in Batavia have joined in protest against statements made here last week by Indonesian representatives charging the Dutch authorities with violating the Renville truce agreement, it was announced here today.

The third annual Collier's Congressional awards for distinguished service to the nation will be presented today at a White House ceremony to Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky and Representative Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 6 (AP) -- Jaroslav Drobny, Czechoslovakia's No. 1 tennis star, returned to Prague late today to join the Czech team in its first Davis Cup test with Brazil, May 14-16.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Early Wynn dealt the White Sox a second successive shut-out tonight, pitching Washington to a 5-0 victory. Wynn allowed only three hits -- none in the last six innings -- for his second decision of the season.

JERUSALEM, May 6 -- Negotiations for a truce in Jerusalem centered today on the question of whether the road from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, over which the Jewish quarter receives most of its supplies, should be opened or remain closed.

BOSTON, May 6 -- Frederic C. Dumaine, 82-year-old financier of Groton, Mass., said today that he and his associates had gained a majority of the available preferred stock of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad. This brought into the open a struggle for control of the reorganized road that has been under way for several months.

ROME, May 6 -- The President of the Italian Republic, Enrico de Nicola, let it be known definitely today that he was not a candidate for re-election. He said the precarious state of his health made it impossible for him to face a seven-year term of office.

TRIESTE, May 5 (Delayed) -- The Communist party of Venezia Giulia is willing to collaborate in the reconstruction of Trieste under any plan, including the European Recovery Program, that may improve the workers' conditions, Vittorio Vidali, Moscow-trained Communist leader of the Free Territory, said today.
The Columbia University Committee of the New York Young Republican Club has urged support of selective service and both economic and military aid to China, it was made known yesterday.

A comparatively optimistic picture of the future of the city's hospitals was drawn yesterday by Commissioner of Hospitals Edward M. Bernecker at ceremonies starting a celebration of the seventy-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Bellevue Schools of Nursing.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A House Armed Services subcommittee warned today that a "grave" insufficiency of petroleum endangered the national defense. It recommended compulsory steel allocation and rationing of oil and petroleum products if conservation and production stimulants proved inadequate.

Two Bronx boys were drowned yesterday while taking advantage of spring-like weather on a parochial school holiday to enjoy an impromptu outing in an abandoned rowboat off Orchard Beach in the Bronx. Two other boys who were in the boat with them were rescued by five teen-age lads who were on the beach.

DETROIT, May 6 -- The Kaiser-Frazer corporation's effort to stabilize the market in connection with its recent $10,000,000 common stock offering, and the price of the new stock, were common knowledge in Detroit brokerage houses before the new issue was offered publicly, it was disclosed today.

John Foster Dulles, Republican foreign policy expert, called last night for the creation of a Federal organization with cabinet status that would lead a strong counter-attack on international and domestic Communist "subversive warfare."

In a recent issue of THE TIMES David P. Page, Deputy Veterans Administrator for New York and Puerto Rico, gives rather belated advice to GI's who are seeking training, or have already spent two years of valuable time (not to mention huge sums of taxpayers' money) in pursuing training that will fit them to take a job in civilian life.

Wagner College defeated St. Peter's College of Jersey City, 1 -- 0, in a 12-inning baseball contest at Clove Lake Park, Staten Island, yesterday behind the two-hit hurling of Ed Mensing, a right hander. Mensing had a no-hitter until the eleventh when he was reached for two infield singles.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 6 -- Among all products advertised in newspapers, beer stands second highest in reader interest, Alfred B. Stanford of New York, director of bureau of advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, declared today.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Moderate decreases in prices of most farm products and foods, together with sharp decreases for cattle feed and oils and fats, were mainly responsible for a decrease of 0.6 per cent in primary market prices for the week ended May 1, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

John Jay Stone, proud of his record as the dining car steward with the longest service on the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, retired yesterday after celebrating his seventy-fifth birthday with his passengers and staff on the New York-Springfield, Mass., run.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 6 -- Economic experts forecast today that Yugoslavia would gather this year the biggest wheat harvest since the end of the war. If climatic conditions remain good the government expects to have on hand an exportable wheat surplus of at least 300,000 metric tons.

A four-hour tumultuous annual meeting of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company stockholders ended yesterday as a victory for management, but by a very close margin. More than 300 stockholders debated at length two proposals that, if accepted, would have resulted in a "detailed audit" of the company's books and 50 per cent reduction in officers' salaries until there was a return to a dividend-paying basis.

Youth United opened yesterday a preventive drive against juvenile delinquency in Brooklyn with the start of a house-to-house canvass of 20,000 families, aimed at bringing teen-agers into the programs of eight borough settlement houses.

NEWARK, N.J., May 6 -- Holding a six-inch section of a chair rung in the pocket of his trench coat to simulate a pistol, 24-year-old Simon Liford of Twenty-third Street, Coney Island, was arrested here today for investigation on charges of robbery and assault.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- President Truman today informally proclaimed "children and dogs as necessary to the welfare of this country as Wall Street and the railroads" and asked for speedy House action on the housing bill.

Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, national chairman of Veterans for MacArthur for President, sent a cablegram yesterday to Gen. Douglas MacArthur urging him to return soon to the United States to "inspire renewed hope and unity to our people."

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president-designate of Columbia University, was elected to the board of trustees of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace at a meeting of the board yesterday. Harvey Bundy, Boston attorney and president of the World Peace Foundation, also was made a trustee.

Rising costs and continuing shortages of materials combined to hold down net profit of the Chrysler Corporation in the first quarter of 1948 to $14,921,644, equal to $1.71 a common share, compared with $21,502,407, or $2.47 a share, in the first three months of last year, K.T. Keller, president, reported in the financial statement sent to stockholders yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The conflict over alleged racial discrimination between the American Association of University Women and its Washington branch reached a stalemate today, pending court action.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Strand, the attraction is "The Woman in White," Warner Brothers' adaptation of the Wilkie Collins novel with Alexis Smith, Sydney Greenstreet, Eleanor Parker and Gig Young heading the cast.

Tomorrow night marks the final performance at the Music Box of Elisabeth Bergner's starring vehicle, "The Cup of Trembling." Adapted by Louis Paul from his own novel, "Breakdown," the play will have been performed twenty-three times under the joint auspices of Paul Czinner (Miss Bergner's husband, who also directed) and C.P. Jaeger.

A defense motion to discharge the case of the State Attorney General against A. Terry Fahye, charged with flouting a Supreme Court injunction barring him from engaging in stock transactions here, was upheld yesterday by a 2-to-1 decision of the Court of Special Sessions.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 -- The Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific Coast estimated today that the shipping industry on this coast would have to pay longshoremen an extra $20,000,000 if overtime-on-overtime suits were upheld by the courts.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Charles W. Sawyer, who today became Secretary of Commerce, announced that the steel industry has agreed tentatively to guarantee supplies for atomic energy projects and the housing program.

A price increase in cement amounting to 6 cents a barrel went into effect here yesterday, making delivered prices in Manhattan in bags in carload lots $3.10 per barrel. (There are four bags to the barrel.) A sharp increase in new orders was reported by cement companies, not only because of the price increases, but also as part of an effort by customers to obtain larger New York inventories because of the rail strike threat.
The text of the address by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower before the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York yesterday follows:

BUFFALO, May 6 -- Growth of television in the next five years into a $1,000,000,000 industry and a possible new record volume of business in home appliances were forecast here today by an executive of the AVCO Manufacturing Corporation.
Although the situation with respect to men's fall clothing orders has several confusing aspects, trade authorities here yesterday cited these as the major trends:

The Rev. F. Slade Danzoll. assistant to the Rev. Thomas McCandless, rector of St. Michael's Protestant Episcopal Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-ninth Street has been elected president of the New York Churchman's Clericus, it was announced yesterday.

BALTIMORE, May 6 (AP) -- Mrs. Esther duPont Weir's Darjeeling, a winner on the flat and at hunt meetings, took the $5,000 added Spring Maiden Steeplechase at Pimlico today. The 5-year-old coasted into the finish line six lengths ahead of Frank Adams' Premise, with Herbert A. Dunn's Leche Hombre third.

Today, May 7, is the twelfth day of The Greater New York Fund's eleventh annual campaign in behalf of 423 local hospitals, health and welfare agencies. In 1929, the first Sunday in May was devoted to the beginning of National Music Week.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 6 -- The United States, Canada, Argentina and Australia account for 97 per cent of current wheat exports in the world, excluding Russia, according to the latest issue of the United Nations Monthly Statistical Bulletin, released today.

The Sculptors Guild, whose activities were interrupted for six years by the war and other events, has resumed its series of annual outdoor shows. Their new exhibition opens to the public today at 16 Washington Square North, just west of Fifth Avenue.
Three hardy Swedish sailors ended a 10,000-mile voyage Monday when they tied up their twenty-three-foot sailboat at the Seventy-ninth Street yacht basin.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 6 -- A bill will be presented to Congress this week dealing with the principles and setting forth the conditions for removing civil Government employes who upon investigation should be found connected in any manner with communism.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- National defense and the urban and rural economic existence of this country are threatened through failure to provide adequate roads, delegates were told today at the opening of the second Highway Transportation Congress, sponsored by the National Highway Users Confererence here.
FORT BRAGG, N.C., May 6 -- Thirty thousand troops from every army area in the country were making final preparations tonight for the largest maneuver to be held in the United States since the war.

For its annual spring concert, last night at Town Hall, the Branscombe Choral, under Gena Branscombe, had prepared an all-American program, with Floyd Worthington, baritone, as soloist. The chorus, composed of women's voices, was assisted by an instrumental ensemble which included Jeanne Mitchell, violinist; Esther Gruhn, 'cellist; Nina Dunkel, harpist; Ruth Freeman, flutist; Phillis Gugino, clarinetist, and James A. Hager, tympanist.

Five city firemen announced yesterday they had settled for $150,000 their claims for injuries incurred while fighting a fire in a garage two years ago. The men, one of whom will receive $90,000, had brought suit Tuesday in Bronx Supreme Court for a total of $750,000.
The largest gift to date, $140,000, has been contributed to the Greater New York Fund's 1948 campaign by the Chase National Bank, it was announced yesterday by Henry C. Alexander, campaign chairman.

The efforts of the White House to avert a nation-wide railroad strike injected new life into the stock market yesterday. The course of the share list was abruptly reversed after early selling caused further losses in the carriers and, as demand gained momentum, major sections turned upward Early losses of fractions to a point were converted into gains of the same dimensions by the close.

To all appearances the Wall Street strike is definitely ended. The four brokerage firms that had been picketed since March 29 are no longer bothered by striking United Financial Employes. Letters were sent to the firms, Shields Co., A.M. Kidder, Bache Co. and E.F. Hutton Co., advising them that the pickets were being withdrawn.

LONDON, May 6 -- Col. J.D. Tassoev, Soviet Army officer reported by the Russians to have been kidnapped by United States agents in Bremen last week, has arrived in Great Britain at his own request and will be allowed to remain here as a political refugee, the Foreign Office said today.
Two municipal college presidents charged yesterday that Students for Wallace organizations in the city's higher education institutions were infiltrated with Communists.

The United States must not "quail" from making provision for the military security of Western Europe, General of the Amy Dwight D. Eisenhower said here yesterday. He argued that their military security and economic recovery must go forward hand in hand.
BOSTON, May 6 -- A step toward breaking down racial barriers within the Methodist Church was taken here today by action of the quadrennial General Conference.

John R. Steelman will confer at the White House this morning with leaders of the three railroad brotherhoods who have threatened to take 150,000 key operating employes off their jobs in a nation-wide strike next Tuesday. Mr. Truman's top negotiator is expected to hold similar talks later with representatives of railroad management.

PARIS, May 6 -- The forms of the economic questionnaires that will be sent to the sixteen powers and the zones of Germany were approved today at the meeting of the Executive Committee of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 6 -- The United Nations Economic and Employment Commission completed its third session here today by providing specific advice for countries embarked on economic recovery or suffering from inflation or from lack of development.

WASHINGTON, Nay 6 (AP) -- The Equitable Gas Company of Pittsburgh today registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed public offering of $14,000,000 of first mortgage bonds. The offering will be made at competitive bidding, which will determine the price, interest rate and underwriting terms.

Negotiators representing the International Typographical Union, AFL, and the Publishers Association of New York City will meet at 2:30 P.M. today in the association's offices, 1475 Broadway, to resume efforts to achieve agreement on a contract covering composing-room workers in the plants of thirteen major daily newspapers in this city.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 6 -- The Truce Commission of the United Nations Security Council has found no evidence to confirm charges made by the Jewish Agency for Palestine, last Saturday that Lebanese, Syrian and Egyptian troops have invaded the Holy Land, it was announced today.

" THE NAKED AND THE DEAD,"* by Norman Mailer, is in many ways the most impressive novel about the second World War that I have ever read. It has faults and serious ones; but its total effect is overwhelming. Here as rarely before in print is the terrible urgency of battle, the chilling excitement, the stupefying exhaustion, the tension, fear and despair.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's extemporaneous speech today to the National Conference on Family Life:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 6 -- "Serenade," a James A. King story which Frances Marion has adapted to the screen, will be Michael Curtiz's next production at Warner Brothers, Curtiz disclosed today. The story, bought by Warners in 1945, has been on and off Curtiz's program for more than a year, but it is now scheduled for the cameras late in June, with James Mitchell in the leading role and Curtiz directing.
LONDON, May 6 (AP) -- Headed by the royal family, an audience of the elect tonight welcomed Sir Laurence Olivier's screen play of "Hamlet."

GENEVA, May 6 -- The Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization, in a resolution adopted today, requested the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations to sponsor an international convention on the procedure for legally establishing death.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Congressional forces demanding a basic revision of the United Nations shook off today the Administration's heavy and formidable disapproval and returned strongly to the attack.

In the absence of Mikhail Botvinnik, leading with the score of 12 -- 4, interest in the world chess championship tournament at the Hall of Columns, yesterday centered upon the fifth and last encounter between Samuel Reshevsky, the United States champion, and Vassily Smyslov, Soviet expert, in the twenty-first round, according to a report received from Moscow.

Coordinated table settings, in which dinnerware, glasses, tablecloths and napkins are related in color and design to form a pleasant background for dining, can now be had at budget prices. Designer Russel Wright, known for his simple modern dinnerware, has created tablecloths and napkins as well as tumblers to go with his American Modern sets.

This is about the time of year when the gardener looks up from his spring planting program to discover that his grass is growing. No matter how small his lawn may be -- and in these days of economy-sized building lots lawns may be very small indeed -- the unmistakable evidence that the grass has shaken off its winter sleep and is reaching for the sun is greeted with mixed sentiments.

A major depression here in ten or more years would be a greater danger to the nation than an early economic breakdown, Leon H. Keyserling, vice chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, declared last night.

This is in response to your news item, "Care Urged on GIs in Picking Schools," of April 12, which refers to difficulties in obtaining jobs by veterans through the technical schools they attend. Of course, the reasons graduates of schools have difficulty in obtaining jobs are multiple.

LOS ANGELES, May 6 -- Transformation of the campaign for civil rights from a transitory effort to a continuing national endeavor by the establishment of regular Federal agencies in the field was recommended today at the annual national conference of B'nai B'rith Anti-Defamation League.
GENEVA, May 6 -- France led the West today in defending the European Recovery Program before the Economic Commission for Europe.

PITTSBURGH, May 6 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week showed further pronounced gains, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh. Despite a moderate decline in trade the bureau's adjusted index of business advanced from 182.8 per cent of the 1935-39 average in the week ended April 24 to 197.1 last week, a gain of more than 14 points.
Net income of $1,377,254 on sales of $14,374,928 in the first quarter of 1948 was reported yesterday by the Republic Aviation Corporation of Farmingdale, L.I.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- The House Interstate Commerce Committee, ending hearings on proposals to set up a national heart institute, today heard Dr. Howard A. Rusk urge that a Federally backed program of research and prevention be authorized.

ATHENS, May 6 -- Nineteen persons were executed by a firing squad on the island of Aegina, off Piraeus, this morning, for murders committed during the German occupation and the insurrection of December, 1944.

BOSTON, May 6 (AP) -- In a lengthy contest marked by a brief fight between Detroit first sacker George Vico and Boston catcher Birdie Tebbetts, the Tigers today defeated the Red Sox, 8 -- 3. The triumph, credited to Hal White, who relieved Hal Newhouser in the first inning, was fashioned on fifteen hits and snaped a four-game Boston winning streak.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 1, 1948, totaled 891,638 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 39,329 cars, or 4.6 per cent more than in the preceding week, 9,064 cars or 1 per cent more than in the corresponding week of last year, and 220,327 cars, or 32.8 per cent more than during the corresponding week of 1946.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- What the Democratic voters of Alabama decided at their primary yesterday was sensational by every political test. They nominated eleven candidates who are sure to become electors in November and are pledged to cast the state's vote against President Truman if he is the Democratic nominee.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The House Rules Committee paved the way today for action by the chamber late next week on a bill to curb the activities of the American Communist party and require the registration of party members.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 6 -- Hofstra won both ends of a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference double-header from its Nassau County rival, Kings Point, today. The Flying Dutchmen won the opener, 7 to 3, behind the three-hit hurling of Jack Demarest, and pushed over a single counter in the eighth inning of the second game to annex a 9-to-8 contest for Elmer Demarest.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- President Truman said today the United States was continuing every possible effort through the United Nations to prevent bloodshed in Palestine.

LONDON, May 6 -- As a result of last Saturday's unruly Fascist demonstration here, all public processions of a political character have been banned in Greater London for three months starting at midnight tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- George C. Marshall, Secretary of State, called on Congress today for a three-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act as essential to maintenance of this country's economic leadership of the non-Communist world.

TOKYO, May 6 -- On the Japan front the United States is losing to Russia the battle of radio propaganda. The Russians are still jamming Voice of America broadcasts but are getting a steadily growing audience for their Japanese programs from Siberia.

Counsel for the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League offered evidence yesterday that Benjamin Freedman, anti-Zionist founder of the League for Peace With Justice in Palestine, cooperated with an Arab publicist in preparing a memorandum for presentation to the State Department in behalf of the Arab cause.
OSLO, Norway, May 6 -- Norway's chances of obtaining the alliance she desires with Sweden are regarded as extremely slim in leading political circles here.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- During the week ended May 5, member bank reserve balances decreased $10,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
PITTSBURGH, May 6 -- The high flying Pirates laid their six-game winning streak on the line today and lived to regret the move almost immediately after making it.

A whole range of sun-tanned tones, shading from pale cream to a deep-bronzed brown, provided the color theme in the summer fashions presented yesterday at the Plaza Hotel by Rosette Pennington of 10 East Fifty-sixth Street. Interspersed among the ready-to-wear models were a few custom-made designs by this shop.

Celebrating its 101st birthday anniversary, City College rose to third place in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference by turning back Brooklyn College, 8 to 7, yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium. A charter day gathering of 700 students and alumni saw City stage two-out rallies which erased a three run deficit in the sixth inning and sent the winning tally across the plate in the eighth.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday and closing prices were 7 to 39 points net higher, with the strength most pronounced in the near months.

Thirty-seven youngsters -- survivors of concentration and displaced persons' camps and who have known little happiness in childhood -- saw the Big Show, Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, yesterday for the first time.

BOSTON, May 6 (AP) -- The Massachusetts Boxing Commission today launched an investigation of reports that middleweight Johnnie Walker of Everett was stimulated by lighted matches against his back during a professional boxing bout in Salem Tuesday night.

HAVANA, May 6 -- The Government today confiscated the Communist party radio station Mil Diez. The station, which operates on both long and short wave, will be operated by the Ministry of Communications, according to a Presidential decree.

The escapades blueprinted for Ezra Stone and those who abet him in "The Aldrich Family" will go off the air for the summer after the broadcast of June 24. It is now known that the sponsor, General Foods, will restore the program to NBC's hook-up Thursday nights at 8 on Sept. 30.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 6 -- A record-breaking 66 over the Wykagyl Country Club course by Lloyd Mangrum of Niles, Ill., sent the former U.S. Open champion to the top of the list in the opening round of the Goodall round-robin charity golf tournament today.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Railroad union leaders today were summoned to a White House conference tomorrow morning in an effort to avert a country-wide railroad strike on Tuesday.

LONDON, May 6 -- The drain on Great Britain's gold and dollar reserves has been slashed at a rate of $20,000,000 a week, compared with twice that sum weekly in March and $51,000,000 a week in January, it was learned authoritatively today.
Fred H. Buck, formerly president of Seaboard Distributors, Inc., has been named industrial sales manager for Ultra Chemical Works, Inc., Paterson, N.J.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, discussed musical harmony in the White House today, and President Truman accepted his invitation to a free concert sponsored by the federation.
ROME, May 6 -- Night attacks against ammunition dumps and other military installations have become almost nightly events since last month's general election.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 6 -- While bipartite authorities presented an optimistic forecast on the opening of the Hanover Export Fair May 22 and a 25 per cent increase in steel production since December was announced, strikes and shortages in the steel industry itself cast gloom over the economic picture in Germany.

Recommendations for possible savings of $30,500,000 in the city's proposed budget of $1,160,538,857 were renewed yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission in an hour-long hearing before the City Council's finance committee.

Willie Howard is willing, but the show is weak. The show is "Sally," with a score by Jerome Kern and a book by Guy Bolton. In 1920 Marilyn Miller of the golden personality made it shine under Ziegfeld's pleasure dome, and Leon Errol of the collapsible legs made it look funny.
SEOUL, Korea, May 6 -- Dr. Kimm Kiu Sic, moderate south Korea political leader, who returned last night from the Soviet-sponsored north and south Korean political conference, said today: ...

CHICAGO, May 6 -- Grains closed firm on the Board of Trade today after an easy opening. Wheat closed unchanged on May and 1 1/2 to 2 cents higher on the deferred months. Corn was 3/4 to 2 cents higher, December leading. Oats were 1/3 to 1 1/8 cents higher, and soy beans 7 cents lower.

Recent forecasts concerning the future of television by some "experts" are strong on fancy, but neglect more practical concentration on current facts about the growing entertainment and advertising medium, Hugh M. Beville, director of research for the National Broadcasting Company, asserted yesterday.

MANILA, May 6 -- The Philippine House of Representatives today unanimously adopted a resolution calling upon the two principal American-owned light, power and telephone utilities to show cause why their franchises should not be revoked for alleged failure to furnish adequate service.

ATHENS, May 6 (AP) -- the Populist (Royalist) and Liberal parties agreed tonight to reshuffle the Greek Cabinet, Parliament has been suspended for at least a month, guaranteeing the existence until June of the Government headed by Premier Sophoulis, Liberal, and Vice Premier Constantin Tsaldaris, the Populist leader.

Introduction of employe-suggestion systems in the last two to five years has saved forty business organizations throughout the country from $1,100 to $1,100,000 each, Charles H. Hall, secretary, American Surety Company, disclosed yesterday.

The Great Neck Manor, Inc., of which Norman W. Zaubler, builder, is president, has obtained mortgage loans totaling 1,621,000 at 4 1/2 per cent for twenty years from the Dime Savings Bank on 119 private homes to be erected on a thirty-five-acre tract on Baker Hill Road, between Middle Neck Road and Station Road, Great Neck, L.I.

" A Sunday by the sea" gave the tempo to the Mabs of Hollywood swim-suit showing, staged yesterday by Franklin Simon in its sports department. Against a background of bathhouses with swinging doors the suits for which that designer is now famous were exhibited.

SOUTHPORT, England, May 6 (UP) -- The field for the final 36 holes of the Dunlop professional golfers' tournament was trimmed to thirty-five today as four stars tied for first place at the halfway mark with 36-hole scores of 147.

PILSEN, Czechoslovakia, May 6 -- This industrial city broke out American flags today in a spontaneous, unofficial celebration of the anniversary of its liberation by the United States Third Army of Gen. George S. Patton Jr.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 6 -- Max W. Ball, director of the Oil and Gas Division, Department of the Interior, predicted today that barring a "shooting war," the American public in the years ahead would receive a more abundant supply of better petroleum products at lower relative costs than it ever has known.

An agreement between representatives of the Fur and Leather Workers Union, CIO, and the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers to end a strike of seven weeks involving 15,000 employes and 750 manufacturers, was reached early yesterday. P. George Greenberg, executive manager of the association, said the agreement is subject to ratification by the union and association members.

Eddie Eagan, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, held an informal conference with representatives of the Boxing Managers Guild and Mike Jacobs and Sol Strauss of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club yesterday, in an attempt to seek a solution to the television controversy that has been muffling boxing in this area.

Several steps have been taken to effectuate the new plan for Motty Eitingon, Inc., which was confirmed by order of Referee Irwin Kurtz on Tuesday, it was learned here yesterday. It is not expected there will be any appeal of the order of confirmation.

Business and professional women from theatre, radio, fashion and other fields joined last night in support of the United Jewish Appeal at an annual dinner-meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Held under the auspices of the appeal's women's division the dinner was the climax of a series of events in which $2,000,000 has been donated.

Five teen-agers outlined their ideas of appearance, behavior, ideals and ambitions for themselves and the world in general at the Fashion Group luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore. All high school students, they were introduced by Mrs. Alice Thompson, managing editor of Seventeen.

All major railroad lines in the nation announced yesterday that they would not attempt to operate in the event of a strike on Tuesday threatened by national unions of engineers, firemen and switchmen. Wholesale lay-offs of other employes were implied in some of the announcements and in at least two cases railroads said they would shut down all departments.

New wage demands expected in the next few months from a number of paper and pulp industry unions, plus those granted to some mill-worker groups last month, make price increases on many paper products more than likely, an official of a large company said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The National Labor Relations Board decided today that an election to unseat an incumbent union was not necessary after that union has renounced its own claim to be bargaining representative of the employes involved.

Relief parcels containing food, clothing, books, sporting goods and other articles will leave for the Netherlands tonight aboard the Holland-America Line passenger vessel Veendam, it was announced yesterday by United Service to Holland.
As a result of the keen observation of a young ex-veteran who is now on the police force, a murder case suspect was seized in a northbound IRT subway train yesterday, ending a hunt since April 27.
LONDON, May 6 (AP) -- A teenaged Danish tennis team defeated Egypt today at Copenhagen and belatedly joined fifteen other survivors in the European Zone Davis Cup tournament.

Fleet Admiral William F. Halsey declared yesterday that the American merchant marine was suffering from two defects -- a shortage of troop carriers and tankers -- which would seriously hamper the efforts of the nation in the event of another war.

The warning recently given to veterans by David P. Page, deputy Veterans Administrator for New York and Puerto Rico, to check schools carefully before enrolling under the GI Bill of Rights is a sound one and should be thoroughly studied by each former service man or woman who plans to take advantage of his government-sponsored privilege of continuing his education.
Big league scouts flocked to Ohio Field yesterday to see Al McEvoy pitch for Holy Cross.

LONDON, May 6 -- Four-power talks here on an Austrian peace treaty were adjourned indefinitely today as the United States, Britain and France split with the Soviet Union over Yugoslavia's claims on Austria.

WESTFIELD, N.J., May 6 -- The Women's New Jersey Golf Association opened its season under a brilliant sun that lured over seventy players to try their luck over the fairways at Echo Lake Country Club today:

DETROIT, May 6 -- The United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, broke off negotiations today with the Chrysler Corporation only six days before the sched uled start of a country-wide strike.
Established last year through New York City Cancer Committee grants to fifteen hospitals and clinics, Cancer Prevention and Detection Centers served thousands of persons.

Courtlandt D. Barnes Jr. has been elected secretary and a director of A.S. Barnes Co., it was announced yesterday. Horace J. Gardner, sales manager, was elected vice president, Miss Josephine Lees, assistant secretary, also was elected to the board.
The clippings from your paper just received indicate that a brief statement on the ill-fated Amne Machin Expedition is needed to clarify some facts.

Dictograph Products, Inc., maker of Acousticon hearing aids, which recently ran a local newspaper test on its new "Hearette" pocket aid, will introduce a new low-price conventional aid later this year, it was learned yesterday. The pocket aid test, which is reported to have produced a high response, will be followed up with additional advertising here and in other markets, according to Mae Wagner, advertising manager.
Dallas County, Texas, announced yesterday that it will receive bids Saturday for $1,000,000 of juvenile building bonds dated June 10, 1948, and due April 10 from 1949 to 1978.

Spring blossoms formed an appropriate floral decor for a May Ball given last night in the main ballroom of the plaza to mark the fifty-third anniversary of the opening to the public of the New York Botanical Garden. Proceeds from the supper dance will advance the garden's exploration and scientific research projects.

NORWICH, Conn., May 6 (AP) -- A count of proxies, completed early today, showed that a group of independent stockholders of the United States Finishing Company will be able to outvote a management group by more than 2 to 1 at the annual meeting May 26, it was announced.

The destruction of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory in the Bar Harbor forest fire of last October was a major scientific calamity. Spontaneous expressions of dismay and sympathy poured in on the staff from cancer specialists and experimental biologists all over the world.

BERLIN, May 6 -- Bipartite coal control officials are seeking a further and extensive revision of the reparations program. They say the dismantling of German companies producing mining equipment seriously threatens the output of Ruhr coal.

PARIS, May 6 -- Gen. Maxime Weygand, commander of the French armies in the final phase of France's 1940 military debacle, was exonerated today by the Investigating Committee of the High Court of Justice of all charges of having collaborated with the enemy.

The American Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that it has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission an issue of 500,000 shares of common stock intended to be marketed publicly by a banking syndicate to be headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc.

Earnings of the General Motors Corporation in the first quarter of 1948 were at a new peace-time high mark, with sales the second largest for a quarterly period, according to the report of Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman, and C.E. Wilson, president, mailed yesterday to more than 435,000 stockholders.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Senate, by a runaway vote of 74 to 2, followed the House today in demanding that the Air Force be built up, starting now, to a military sky power of seventy latest-model combat groups.

Charles Platt, New York architect advocated yesterday a plan to combat the slum problem by bringing under neighborhood control a nine-block area where the people themselves, with appropriate Government measures, could undertake their own salvation by a program of self-aid.
The Travelers Aid Society of New York during the past year gave assistance to 127,050 persons at the city's rail, air and sea depots.
That od line, "Always play the outsider in a three-horse race," paid off in the Class B Blackstock Handicap at Jamaica yesterday.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 6 -- The Union of Turkish Tobacco Traders and Planters, at a meeting here, has accused Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor of Germany, of having "obstructed" the sale of Turkish tobacco to Germany.

Registering an increase for the first time since April 14, commercial, industrial, and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System, gained $17,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday.

Nora Kaye last night gave her second performance of Agnes de Mille's new ballet, "Fall River Legend", in the Ballet Theatre season at the Metropolitan Opera House, and a stupendous performance it proved to be.

The Anglo-American textile conference held in Great Britain last month has set the pattern for a joint program in maintaining active export markets for American and British cotton goods, it was pointed out yesterday by Claudius Murchison, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute.

Amid hysterical protests by Zach Taylor and all his Brownies, Bobby Brown circled the basepaths at the Stadium yesterday, crossing the plate behind Ed Stewart with the 2-run eighth-inning homer that gave the Yankees a 6-5 victory over the St. Louis aggregation.

ABOARD S.S. BRAZIL, at Sea, May 6 -- The 20,000-gross-ton liner Brazil, completely rebuilt and refurnished for the luxury New York-South American trade, put to sea early yesterday for her first commercial voyage in more than six years.
LONDON, May 6 -- In a generally quiet stock market here today British Government bonds made gains of as much as a quarter on small but steady investment buying.

Since the City Center's theatre company seems to have appointed itself the patron of Ben Jonson this season, it has followed last winter's revival of "Volpone" with his "The Alchemist" as the lead-off play of its spring series. Under the direction of Morton Da Costa the Elizabethan comedy is being given the broad playing its author obviously intended with a cast that plunges into it with zest and goodwill.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- United States exports rose $54,700,000 in March to break a four-month down-trend, the Census Bureau reported today. Export values totaled $1,141,000,000.

QUONSET POINT, R.I., May 6 -- Comdr. Ralph A. Fuoss, USN, one of the Navy's leading jet fighter pilots, met a tragic death here today as he led his pioneer jet fighter squadron, known as "Seventeen Able" to a landing on the broad runways of the Quonset Point Naval Air Station.
LONDON, May 6 -- A lesson in Communist journalism was given to the Royal Commission on the Press Feb. 18, according to the minutes of evidence published today.

Since March 19 the Senate Public Lands Committee has had before it a report of its Subcommittee on Territories urging that Hawaii be granted statehood. On April 15 the subcommittee held hearings at which no witnesses in opposition appeared. Yet the bill is still in committee.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Union workers in the building trades received hourly wages 11 per cent higher than a year ago, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

BAR HARBOR, Me., May 6 -- Reconstruction of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory, which was partly destroyed by the fire which swept Maine last fall, began here this afternoon with simple ground-breaking ceremonies.

Some of the ideas on dispensation of public welfare money that have been advanced by Paxton Blair, member of the State Board of Social Welfare, will be considered hopelessly old-fashioned, we suppose. Speaking before the Kiwanis Club, Mr. Blair, who is a lawyer, deplored the "curious doctrine of making relief respectable."

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP) -- The Athletics went to the top of the American League the hard way today, batting Bullet Bob Feller for eight runs in three and one-third innings to defeat the Indians, 8 to 5. With two hits, two walks and a pair of costly errors by Manager Lou Boudreau, Philadelphia scored four runs in the first inning.

As one of the thirty-two men and women who signed the letter to the Russian writers, I should like to comment on your news story regarding it. I agreed to the use of my name as a gesture of friendship from writers and artists of this country to those of Russia.

Though asparagus, a favorite spring-season vegetable, rose 6 cents this week to a city-wide average of 25 cents a pound, other items in the fresh produce markets of New York remained steady. Some even went down a bit in cost, according to the City Department of Markets. The rain that caused all of us annoyance was the reason for the rise in asparagus, which favors sunny weather.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 6 -- Three thousand striking workers have tied up an oil pipeline from Iraq to the Mediterranean Sea, and the belief that Communists are behind the strike is causing serious concern here. With mediation efforts rebuffed, the Iraqi Government is believed to be planning strong measures to break the strike.

Speaker Martin is to be congratulated in forcing consideration of the bill which would put the United States in the World Health Organization. For weeks a handful of men in the House Rules Committee has blocked this move, though the Senate and the House Foreign Affairs Committee recommended passage.

HAWLEY, Pa., May 6 -- The rain descended in this area yesterday in a manner which the local citizens described as "torrents," but apparently the trees soaked it up, for the Shohola and Blooming Grove were almost normal in flow and as clear as any one could wish.

Direct from Ford plants in Da-I genham, England, the Amglia and Z Prefect automobiles and Thames !vans were introduced yesterday by J. R. Davis, vice president and director of sales and advertising of The Ford Motor Company.
In its first concrete action to meet the immediate crisis in Palestine, the United Nations General Assembly asked Britain yesterday to appoint a special Municipal Commissioner for Jerusalem.

Despite the bright sunlight out-of-doors yesterday life seemed a dismal gray to Miss Corena Synhorst, 22 years old, of 25 East Seventy-sixth Street, when she appeared in Downtown Traffic Court in custody of a warrant officer.

Gang violence is likely to flare up in the city unless Mayor O'Dwyer's bill banning pinball and bagatelle machines is adopted, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander told the general welfare committee of the City Council yesterday at City Hall.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 6 (AP) -- The Court of Chancery today barred a common stockholders' committee of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation from entering about 40,000 proxies as evidence in a proceeding to determine the legality of the company's recent annual meeting.

The ultimate conquest of sickness lies in the development of robust health through proper nutrition rather than in an increase in the number of doctors and medical facilities, a symposium sponsored by the Medical Society of the County of New York agreed last night.

Universal military training is the primary requirement for a sound national security program, Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, said last night in an address at the annual convention dinner of the Boys Clubs of America in the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The State Department announced today that the office of the United States Information Service in Warsaw would continue to make available to Polish citizens who desired it "information concerning the United States and views expressed in speeches and editorials in this country."
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 6 (AP) -- Delegates of twenty-two European countries gathered tonight to make plans for organizing a United States of Europe.

A change in "the philosophy of the American people" to provide a broader program of rehabilitation for handicapped persons in all sections of the population was advocated yesterday by leaders in this field of medicine and social welfare at the meeting of the National Council on Rehabilitation in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

COOS BAY, Ore., May 6 -- The Ohio primary results of the contest between Senator Robert A. Taft and Harold E. Stassen imparted an obvious lift today to Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's campaign for Oregon's delegation of twelve to the Republican National Convention.

Goldye A. Wind has purchased the thirty-family apartment house at 1706 Nelson Avenue, the Bronx, from the Danlow Realty Corporation. The property, assessed at $70,000, was sold subject to a first mortgage of $43,775. Abraham Nitzberg was the broker and the attorneys were Lester A. Kent for the buyer and Jacob Manicoff for the seller.

Today's events: Dino Ancona, piano, Town Hall, 3 P.M.; Pop Concert, Chopin-Schubert night, Walter Hendl, conductor, Ellen Faull, soprano; Ralph Herbert, baritone; Leo Nadelmann, piano; Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Fraternal Mandolin Society, Thomas Sokoloff, conductor; Adeline Trentadue, soprano, Town Hall, 8;
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- A $2,000,000 appropriation to finance new equipment for Federal barge lines was recommended today by the House Appropriations Committee.
NEW LONDON, Conn., May 7 -- The Dogfish started out as an ordinary, conventional, fleet-type submarine.
Modern examples of stained glass and abstractions by three young painters are on view this week in local galleries.

ATHENS, May 7 -- After several days of discussion between Premier Themistocles Sophoulis as head of the Liberal party and Deputy Premier Constantin Tsaldaris, chief of the majority Royalist-Populists, changes agreed upon in the coalition Government were announced tonight. Also, King Paul signed a decree postponing the reopening of Parliament until June 10.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., May 7 -- Residents of New Bedford, terminal for the steamboat passenger line to the summer resorts of Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket, endorsed yesterday a proposal for state operation of the service.

DUMONT, N. J., MAY 7 -- A stranded woman and her four small daughters, to whom Dumont had opened its heart in various ways, were put on a train for their home in Vergennes, Vt., last night. With the aid of Mayor William H. Losee, the police took up a collection for the woman and when she left she had enough for a railroad ticket, a sum for food and incidentals and other gifts.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Advocates of revision of the United Nations urged Congress today to declare itself for such an action even if it were wholly apparent that the Administration would do nothing now to try actually to bring about a change.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 7 -- A rainstorm forced postponement of this afternoon's third round of the Goodall round-robin tourney at the Wykagyl Country Club today, but the standings underwent quite a shift during the second round this morning.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Two "exploratory" conferences with union leaders at the White House today failed to make definite progress toward averting a countrywide strike of 125,000 firemen, engineers and switchmen, set for 6 A.M. next Tuesday.
CHICAGO, May 7 -- Broadening of the meat strike threatened to day as additional union packing-house workers here and in eight other cities voted to walk out next week.

Permit me to comment on three aspects of the Palestine situation which are frequently overlooked in the discussions in the United Nations as well as in the press, but which seem to be of cardinal importance.

It was thirty years ago today that President Woodrow Wilson left his desk long enough to witness the departure of the first airmail flight from Washington, D.C. The country was at war, but the President sensed the significance of the occasion. A "Flying Jenny" war plane carried the mail to New York on that first aerial journey.

ALBANY, May 7 -- The State Board of Law Examiners reported today that 423 of the 922 applicants for admission to the bar had passed the examination held March 3 and 4. Three hundred fifty-three of the successful applicants live in the First and Second Departments.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, 20 West Fortieth Street, yesterday asked James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, not to stage the federation's second annual free music appreciation program in Constitution Hall because of the past policies of the Daughters of the Daughters of the American Revolution, owner of the hall, in barring its use by Negro artists.

MUNICH, Germany. May 7 -Lobster and champagne, truffles and baba au rhum as well as roast beef, rare, medium and well done, were on the menu tonight in Munich as a gala international reception marked the reopening of the Vier Jahreszeiten [Four Seasons] Hotel in Bavaria's capital.
CHICAGO, May 7 (AP) -- Things are getting a little formal with the Chicago Cardinals since Owner Charley Bidwill died and the club won its first National Football League championship since 1925.

BOSTON, May 7 -- The quadrennial general conference of the Methodist Church, by almost unanimous vote, today denounced the "sinfulness" of war and appealed to the United States to take the lead in seeking the universal abolition of peacetime military conscription.

After the receipt yesterday of applications by six private transit companies to take their higher-fare applications to the Public Service Commission, Mayor O'Dwyer called a special meeting of the Board of Estimate for 4 o'clock Monday afternoon at City Hall to pass upon the applications.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -Bob Lemon's four-hit pitching moved Cleveland into second place in the American League as the Indians defeated Washington, 8 -- 0, tonight to snap a four-game losing streak. Allie Clark and Joe Gordon slammed fifth-inning home runs off Mickey Haefner.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 7 -- The United States was appointed today to serve on the five-nation commission to supervise a United Nations plebiscite to determine the future of Kashmir.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., May 7 -Floyd Odlum, board chairman of the Consolidated-Vultee Aircraft Corporation, announced today that LaMotte Cohu probably would become president of the concern.

Supreme Court Justices Ernest E. L. Hammer, Lloyd Church and Morris Eder, sitting in Special Term, reversed yesterday a ruling by Municipal Court Justice John M. Lewis, which dismissed eviction proceedings brought against Gregori Nicolaeff, operator of a private school to educate children of Soviet officials, at 6 East Eightyseventh Street.
NEWARK, N.J., May 7 -- Gen. Jonas Cernius, former Prime Minister of Lithuania and chief of staff of his country's army, was discovered today working as a $30a-week machinist in a factory here.

Miss Lelah McRobert of the Ohrbach A. A., defeated Missh)0*0*0*iLorna Richman of the Women's Swimming Association in the fifty-yard free-style junior metropolitan championship race that was a feature of the carnival last night at the London Terrace Pool. The victor's time was 0:32.3.
NANKING, May 7 -- China's first constitutional Parliament is scheduled to convene here tomorrow with less than one-third of its full membership in attendance.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Senate Republican Policy Committee decided, in the course of a 2 1/2-hour closed session today, to make a determined effort to close the Eightieth Congress down, for keeps, on June 19.
Eleven police lieutenants will be promoted to captain and 333 probationary patrolmen will be graduated from the Police Academy at a ceremony at noon today at Washington Irving High School.

Hume Wrong, Canadian Ambassador to the United States, criticized last night the "over-dramatic" presentation of news from the Arctic. He declared that emphasis on military activity in the Arctic had been frequently "misplaced" and that while defense had been an element of Arctic activity other investigations, some of them dealing with routine meteorological and equipment surveys, had been the prime interest of the Canadian Government.
Following is the text of the address by Winston Churchill yesterday at the opening of the Congress of Europe in The Hague, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 7 -- One of the chief reasons that the world is nearer to war now than seemed possible at the end of World War II is that members of the United Nations are not conducting their international affairs according to the terms of the Charter, Walter H. C. Laves, acting director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and, Cultural Organization, said here today.

SOUTHPORT, England, May 7 (UP) -- Fred Daly, British Open champion, and his Irish assistant, Ted McNeill, finished in a tie for the 2,000 ($8,000) Dunlop professional golf championship today. They will meet in a 36-hole playoff for the title tomorrow.

Negotiations are well advanced for the sale of the twenty-threestory Farmers Loan Trust Company Building at 475 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Forty-first Street, it was learned yesterday. The tall office structure with banking quarters occupied by the Farmers Loan Trust Company is being sold by the 475 Fifth Avenue Company, of which Alfred Rheinstein, head of the construction firm bearing his name, is the president.

Palestine's national theatre, Habimah, puts on its second bill this evening at the Broadway Theatre under the combined auspices of Theatre Incorporated and the American Fund for Palestinian Institutions. It is "David's Crown," a tragedy in three acts by Calderon de la Barca, dealing with the bloody effects that result from the disputes among King David's sons for his throne.

Contract negotiations between thirteen major newspapers in this city and the International Typographical Union, AFL, became clouded yesterday when Woodruff Randolph, president of the union, proposed that further negotiations be conducted by himself and Elmer Brown, second vice president.

The recent charge by the Automobile Club of New York that certain garage operators were rent-gouging was made without basis and only to promote its own membership, it was asserted yesterday at a meeting of 600 membersh)0*0*0*iof the Metropolitan Garage Board of Trade at the Yorkville Casino, 210 East Eighty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Industrial plants which cost the United States Government more than $7,000,000,000 to build, and which are capable of producing war material for ten or twenty more years, have been preserved as an emergency potential, the Munitions Board announced today.

CHICAGO, May 7 (AP) -- The Interstate Oil Compact Commission estimated today that domestic demand for petroleum products would increase 7.4 per cent and the export demand decrease 7.1 per cent the year ending next March 31.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 7 -- Following is the text of the general conclusions and recommendations in the report presented to the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission here today by France, the United Kingdom and the United States:
ST. PAUL, May 7 (UP)--The State Supreme Court today prohibited women from tending bar in Minnesota.

The increasing complexity of modern industry demands that scientists occupy many administrative positions in business and this requires that they enlarge their views to include the everchanging aspects of human behavior, Dr. Charles Allen Thomas told the twenty-fifth anniversary meeting of the American Institute of Chemists last night.
Fur workers and manufacturers ratified yesterday a settlement reached Wednesday by their negotiating committees ending a six week-old work stoppage involving 15,000 employes of 750 plants.

PEIPING, China, May 7 -- Funds derived from the rationed sale of American relief supplies will be used here during the next two months to supplement the meager diets of 42,000 college and high school students, it was announced today.

ALBANY, May 7 -- The State Banking Department announced today that it had approved certificate of change of name of the Bank of New York, 48 Wall Street, New York, to the Bank of New York and Fifth Avenue Bank. Approval also was given to a certificate of increase of capital stock from $6,000,000, consisting of 60,000 shares at $100 par value to $8,000,000, consisting of 80,000 shares at $100 par value.

ST. LOUIS, May 7 (AP) -- The Cardinals offset shaky fielding with long-range hitting attack to subdue the Phillies tonight, 7 to 4. It was Howie Pollet's first victory in three starts. A three-run homer by Nippy Jones and a tworun single by Del Rice were the big blows in the ten-hit St. Louis attack on three pitchers.

WASHINGTON, May 7-- The Boeing Aircraft Company gave notice today that it would not enter collective bargaining conferences with the International Association of Machinists, but Cyrus S. Ching, Federal Conciliation Director, told the company it was its duty under the law to attend any meetings set up by the service and then discuss limitations on its appearance.

LONDON May 7 -- Britain in the coming year will become a major importer of cotton as well as woolen and worsted piece goods if the government program now being started proves successful. The nation is endeavoring to purchase finished cloth from "soft" currency countries for use in domestic markets and thus free a greater percentage of British textile output for export to dollar areas.

Tenants of seven Bronx buildings faced yesterday the outcome of a group of court cases testing the rights of landlords to collect rent increases granted by the Housing Expediter. Because the amount involved in the test case has reached $42,000, it was indicated that efforts would be made to make the case conclusive.

Serge Koussevitzky, retiring conductor of the Boston Symphony, spoke a word for Government subsidy of musicians last night. The occasion was the National Music League's tenth anniversary dinner at the Town Hall Club, where he was named the "conductor who has done most for young American musicians."

New York State's ninety-seven delegates to the Republican National Convention, solidly for the nomination of Governor Dewey for President, will hold a luncheon meeting Monday at the Ten Eyck Hotel in Albany to select a convention floor leader and plan strategy for Governor Dewey's campaign.

A 17-year-old student who combines scholarship at City College with piano studies at the Manhattan School of Music was announced yesterday the winner of a $2,000 scholarship that will finance a year of study beginning in September at the University of Zurich, in Switzerland.

The senior class of Hunter College, led by Barbara Duke, won for the second year running the thirtysecond Annual Sing, an inter-class competition for which afternoon lectures were suspended yesterday. The event was held in the college assembly hall and witnessed by 2,000 persons.

IN the first days of November I paid a visit to France for a conference on our joint operations with the French naval authorities. Admiral Pound and I drove out about forty miles from Paris to the French Marine Headquarters, which were established in the park around the ancient chateau of the Duc de Noailles. Before we went into the conference Admiral Darlan explained to me how Admiralty matters were managed in France.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 7 -- A party of 180 Congerssional secretaries and two Congressmen on a visit to United Nations headquarters were told today by Warren R. Austin, permanent United States delegate, that any attempt to take away the veto would kill the international peace organization.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 7 -- Twice as many diesel engines will be put in operation on this nation's railroads during the next five years as were in use on Jan. 1, last, the general marketing division of the American Petroleum Institute was told today.

The driving rain and the chilly winds didn't stop Walter E. Dunn from coming to work as usual yesterday. It was his eightieth birthday and the day marked his sixtieth year of continuous service with Ames Rollinson, engrossers, of 50 Church Street, who turn out diplomas and certificates.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., May 7 -Mrs. J. Herbert Johnson of Worcester, Mass., today was re-elected president of the Girls Clubs of America. It is her fourth term. The organization ended its third annual conference with a luncheon.

PARIS, May 7 -- The Russian Orthodox Church, which is under complete control of the Soviet administration, is quietly seeking to assume control of the Orthodox communities in Poland, Hungary and Finland and to "reunite" the religious community of emigre Russians in France with the mother church in the Soviet Union.

Directors of the Walt Disney Productions intend to pay the remaining arrears on the $25 par, 6 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock, Roy O. Disney, president, said yesterday in announcing two regular quarterly dividends of 37 1/2 cents a share each on the preferred, payable on July 1 and Oct. 1, 1948.

Preparations were made in the city yesterday both for starting the second nationwide railroad strike since 1946 and for ameliorating, to whatever extent possible, its expected paralyzing effects. Apparently determined to carry through their strike threat, associate leaders of the engineers, firemen and switchmen unions made ready to begin executive sessions here to plan overall strike strategy.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Techniques for holding union-shop elections in the construction industry will get a "test run" on Monday in thirty-three western Pennnsylvania counties.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 7 (AP) -- A common stockholders' committee of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation was prohibited by court order today from reconvening "any purported recessed meeting" of the $135,000,000 concern's 1948 annual session.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The logistics of President Truman's transcontinental speaking tour next month were worked out in the White House this afternoon while Democratic party affairs continued to develop frictions elsewhere.

CINCINNATI, May 7 (AP) -- Elwell Blackwell, star Cincinnati pitcher, failed to finish for the fourth consecutive time this season and went down to defeat before the Braves today, 4 to 3. Home runs by Bob Elliott, most valuable player in the National League last year, and Jeff Heath, along with six walks and three other safeties in 5 2/3 innings, were enough for Blackie.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- Although still opposed to universal military training, the overwhelming majority of American educators will support the re-enactment of the Selective Service Law if it is needed for national defense, Dr. George F. Zook, president of the American Council on Education, declared today.

Mother's Day will be observed in the churches of all faiths tomorrow and in the synagogues today in the New York area and the nation. As the week-end will mark the close of "Family Week," pastors and rabbis will combine their sermons on "Mother" with pleas for more religious training in the home.

BERLIN, May 7 -- The first notice given by the Russians to the United States Military Government that Col. J. D. Tassoev was missing in Bremen was in the form of a written charge that he had been deliberately kidnapped, publication of an exchange of communications today revealed.
Far west on Fourteenth Street is a district given to commerce in meat. Beef comes there in carload lots from Chicago, and chickens by trailer truck from Maryland and its Dixie suburbs.

The Joint Committee of the American Merchant Marine, representing governmental, industrial and labor agencies concerned with the country's maritime future, will intensify its promotional and educational campaign throughout the country in the next few weeks, members of the committee reported yesterday.

Maurice Braunstein, 24 years old, a taxicab driver, of 2137 Seventyfourth Street, Brooklyn, was booked last night at the Fort Hamilton station, Brooklyn, on a charge of homicide in connection with the death early yesterday of Young Hong Keng, 38, a mess boy employed by the United States Lines, 1 Broadway.

MUNICH, Germany, May 7 -Another "captive" Czech plane landed in Germany three days ago, American authorities at Erding Field, near Munich, revealed today. Five non-Communist passengers forced the pilot at gunpoint to bring them into Germany, according to the authorities.

Rained out of their scheduled clash with the Tigers yesterday, the Yankees will engage the Bengals in the season's first local doubleheader today at the Stadium. The curtain-raiser will start at 1:30, with Bucky Harris nominating Ed Lopat and Vic Raschi and Steve O'Neill countering with Freddie Hutchinson and Hal Newhouser for hurling duties.

Coming Offerings The financial district is preparing for the marketing of two substantial blocks of equity securities next week. A syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation and Harris, Hall Co., will offer on Wednesday or Thursday 800,000 shares of new convertible preferred stock of the Southern California Edison Company.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- A new electrical method for determining the subterranean extension of geologic bodies, oil or mineral; a navigational instrument which may be used to solve mechanically the astronomical triangle; and an improved projectile-exploding device for fighter aircraft requiring no adjustment prior to firing, were among the 453 inventions patented this week by the United States Patent Office.

The stock market followed closely yesterday the changing tenor of the day's developments in the threatened nation-wide railroad strike. Through the greater part of the session, and while the conference was underway at the White House on the situation, the list tended to a higher plane, but, when no progress was indicated, prices turned reactionary and surrendered some of the early gains.

DETROIT, May 7 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission asked the Federal District Court here today to order two Cleveland lawyers to answer certain questions asked of them by the agency in its investigation of the recent $10,000,000 common-stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.

New York manufacturers are organizing traffic methods to keep their factories running in the event of a rail strike by increasing truck shipments of incoming supplies. Wholesalers, too, are planning to obtain enough shipments to maintain operations, Frank Schumaker, purchasing agent, Patterson Brothers, hardware merchants, 15 Park Row, said yesterday.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 7 -The Costa Rican "Second Republic" will be formally inaugurated at noon tomorrow when the revolutionary junta takes over the country at a Foreign Office ceremony to be attended by the diplomatic corps.
