CHICAGO, May 7 -- Prospects that the threatened rail strike might be averted started scattered selling of grain futures on the Board of Trade today and disclosed a weakened technical position. Wheat fell around 3 cents a bushel, and corn nearly that much at one time.

High lights of the rain-soaked proceedings at Jamaica yesterday were victories by Ted Atkinson in the first three races and an on-the-wire triumph by Argentine-bred Vertigo II in the four-horse main event.

NEWARK, N.J., May 7 -- The Board of Public Utilities Commissioners of New Jersey approved today the long pending joint application of the Public Service Coordinated Transport and the Interstate Transportation Company, subsidiaries of the Public Service Corporation, for a basic increase in bus and trolley fares from 5 to 7 cents, effective July 4.

WARSAW, May 7 -- The Polish Government today told foreign correspondents to "wait and see" what would happen if the United States Information Service in Warsaw continues to issue news bulletins not confined to American domestic affairs.

A 27-year-old mother smothered her two infants to death early yesterday morning "because they wouldn't stop crying." and then tried to take her own life by slashing her throat and arm, the police reported.

BUFFALO, May 7 -- The National Electrical Wholesalers Association announced here today completion of a comprehensive report to assist electrical distributors to solve problems of television receiver installation and servicing. The report, entitled "Television Service and Installation -- A Manual of Experience," will be copyrighted by the group for distribution to its members.
Continued discussion of Palestine question; appointed UnitedStates to serve on five-nationcommission to mediate Kashmirdispute and heard summarystatements by India and Pakistan.

A banking syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., submitted yesterday $10,800,000 for the highest of four bids of new school bonds of Houston, Tex., Independent School District, due Jan. 10, 1955 to 1978.

At the White House yesterday President Truman discussed with his Cabinet the nation-wide strike threatened for Tuesday by three railroad brotherhoods. Meanwhile leaders of the three unions were meeting in another wing of the building with John R. Steelman, Presidential Assistant, to discuss with him proposals designed to forestall the walkout.
Settlement of the seven weeks' labor dispute in the fur industry will result in a rapid revival of production and make for increased activity in the raw fur market, reports here yesterday indicated.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The dispute threatening a strike at 6 A.M. on Tuesday, involves three railroad unions and all the Class I railroads.
PITTSBURGH, May 7 -- As the Giants sat idle watching a soft patter of rain wash out their scheduled night game with the Pirates, Manager Mel Ott was confronted today with fresh woe.

Newark's new television station, WATV, operating on Channel 13, announces that it expects to begin commercial operation on Saturday, May 15. For the first two weeks it plans to offer various types of films, being on the air from 4 to 9 P. M. every day except Monday and Tuesday.
READING, Pa., May 7 (AP) -- The annual national convention of the Socialist party began today on the familiar note of "draft Thomas."

HAVANA, May 7 -- Communist influence must be destroyed throughout America if World War III is to be avoided, Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, Presidential candidate of the Cuban Revolutionary party, said today.

Prospects for the resumption of negotiations between the stockholders of the 277 Park Avenue Corporation and the New York Central Railroad on the lease of the apartment building at that address appeared more hopeful yesterday, according to reports made to a special meeting of the stockholders in the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- State aid required by New York and other cities to help solve their spiraling traffic problems and for building arterial routes is about twenty-five per cent of the motor taxation paid by motorist residents into the state treasury.

There has been an unfortunate tendency lately to label an act of protest against unfair governmental edicts as Communist agitation. This gives the Communists far too much credit for always being alert to injustice and robs those of us who are strongly anti-Communist of the honor of participating in the battle against social and political injustice.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 7 -- The United Nations' two years of negotiations for world control of atomic energy were called off today by the Western powers.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -Robert N. Denham, chief counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, told Congress today that the NLRB had jurisdiction over the labor relations of virtually every business in the United States.

The United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, charged with the preparation of an international control system that would lift from mankind the nightmare of future atomic warfare, has received a recommendation to suspend further work on that project until an improved international situation provides a better basis for agreement.

With a contract between the Long Lines division of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the American Union of Telephone Workers, CIO, expiring at midnight tonight. Cyrus H. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, appealed yesterday to both sides to continue negotiations.

The American Cancer Society is telling millions of people the facts of cancer through dis tribution of literature, talks to groups, film showings, public exhibits, radio presentations, forums, school programs, organizations, libraries, and personal contacts -every medium that reaches the eyes and ears of the public.

ROME, May 7 -- When the British mandate over Palestine ceases there will almost certainly be a considerable exodus of Jews from Italy to the Holy Land. About 25,000 Jews have been waiting in Italy throughout the post-war period for a chance to emigrate to Palestine openly or clandestinely.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -President Truman will be 64 years old tomorrow. He plans to work as usual, or perhaps harder than usual, because of the threatened rail strike.

BERLIN, May 7 (UP) -- The four-power deputy commanders of Berlin held a fruitless twelve-hour meeting today at which they could not even agree on what happened at the last meeting or when the next one would be held.

Tarbooshes and takems are standard items of wardrobe for dining-room stewards of the Egyptian liner Mohamed Ali El Kebir, which left here yesterday on the eastbound leg of her maiden voyage between the United States and Mediterranean ports.

Faced with a 49 per cent rise in caseloads since V-J Day, the Welfare Department must remove from its rolls the "minority which is making a racket of public assistance," Raymond M. Hilliard, Welfare Commissioner, said last night.
LONDON, May 7 -- Virtual idleness prevailed today in the stock markets here and price changes generally were unimportant.

Forced transfers of real estate in Manhattan last month showed substantial increases in number and dollar volume over the previous month and over April, 1947, the monthly foreclosure analysis of the Real Estate Board of New York disclosed yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 7 -Alarmed over possible large losses in event of a railroad strike, California's fruit and vegetable growers appealed today to President Truman to do everything possible to prevent the threatened walkout.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture in a revised report today estimated the 1947 cotton crop at 11,851,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight each. This was an increase of 157,000 bales over the last previous estimate, made in December.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Civilian employment rose 1,000,000 between March and April, the Bureau of the Census reported today. The total was 58,330,000 during the week of April 4 to 10. That was 1,630,000 more than a year ago.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 7 -- Unmindful of rain which fell during the entire seven-hour session, many of the nation's leading gunners gathered at Travers Island today and started competition in the three-day amateur trapshooting championships of America.

Timed opportunely for the season when weddings and picnics are in order are two newly arrived sliced meats. They are a Westphalian-style ham from Holland and turkey prepared by a method different from the customary stuffing and roasting.

LONDON, May 7 -- Practically all operations in Palestine have been suspended by the Iraq Petroleum Company, the British, French, American and Dutch combine that is the biggest private enterprise in the Holy Land, and oil men here said today that it was "anybody's guess" when work would be resumed.

CAMP CAMPBELL, Ky., May 7 -- More than 260 planes of the Ninth Air Force were poised tonight at half a dozen fields in the Carolinas, Tennessee and Kentucky, ready for the start tomorrow of the largest air-ground maneuver held in this country since the war.

Lack of academic freedom and definite pressure on teachers from the administration at Columbia's Teachers College was charged yesterday by Dr. Clyde R. Miller, Associate Professor of Education at the college, when it became known that his college appointment would be terminated June 30.

HAWLEY, Pa., May 7 -- With assurance of good dry fly fishing this morning "provided no rain falls during the night," the prospects were excellent until about 8 A.M., when a driving rain began that continued most of the day.

ALPINE, N. J., May 7 -- Three boys who left their homes in Queens yesterday, turned up here today and were reclaimed unharmed by their parents. They were among five who had planned a two-day hike. The two others returned without help from the police.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- Sixteen physicians completed today at the University of Chicago's Institute of Radiobiology and Biophysics the first extensive medical course in history designed to teach them how to understand, prevent and treat radiation injury, serious hazard of atomic warfare.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The House Appropriations Committee, reviving the long-fought issue of private versus public power, moved today to block plans of the Tennessee Valley Authority for construction of an $84,000,000 steam generator.

Problems of the American Composer" received the attention of the New York Federation of Music Clubs' day-long forum at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday. Among the speakers were Willard Rhodes of Columbia University, Fred Erdman of ASCAP, John Tasker Howard and Lamar Stringfield, composers; Gustave Reese, musicologist, Sigmund Spaeth, the Federation's motion picture chairman, and John Schulman, copyright lawyer.

Great shortages of materials, skilled labor and decreases in productivity per man hour in countries of western Europe have increased construction costs abroad above levels for similar work here, John W. Harris, president of John W. Harris Associates, New York builders, declared here yesterday.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 7 -- German trade union and Government officials threatened today a general strike in Lower Saxony that might spread throughout the bizonal area unless the bread and meat rations were increased.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- William Benton, head of the American delegation to the Geneva conference on freedom of Information and the press, asserted today that the recent meeting was a turning point in giving the world a clearer understanding of the American concept of the press, liberty and freedom of speech in contrast to that of Russia.
BALTIMORE, May 7 (AP) -- Those terrific twins from Calumet Farm, Citation and Coaltown, are going to renew their racing duel in the Preakness Stakes after all.

THE novels of Storm Jameson have had a steady, well-deserved popularity in this country. Although probably none of them has made the best-seller list, they have almost without exception been interesting, thoughtful and extremely well written. Indeed, there may be better women novelists now writing in Miss Jameson's native England, but at the moment, and having just read her newest book, "The Black Laurel,"* I do not think of any.
SEOUL, Korea, May 7 -- The Soviet-controlled radio in north Korea announced last night that the supplying of electric power to south Korea would be suspended.

Brig. Gen. William F. Heavey, former port engineer in New York for the Army Engineers and now consulting engineer of the city's Department of Marine and Aviation, will leave New York this summer to become Port Director of Houston, Tex., it was announced yesterday.

GENEVA, May 7 -- Working parties of the Economic Commission for Europe struggled in closed meetings today to reconcile Eastern and Western views on future commission work in the field of intraEuropean trade.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 7 -The New York Department of Catholic War Veterans in annual convention here late today voted unanimously for a resolution in favor of universal military training.

The Gulf States Utilities Company reported yesterday, in its statement covering the twelve months ended with March 31, 1948, net income of $4,133,128, equal to $1.62 a share on the 2,182,820 shares of common stock outstanding.
If the threatened rail strike starts on Tuesday and lasts a day or two, this city will begin to experience a major food crisis, trade leaders reported yesterday.

BRYAN, Ohio,May 7 (AP)--A 14-year-old junior high school pupil admitted last night that he shot and killed a 57-year-old couple because he wanted their automobile for a dance, Sheriff Norman A.Barnes reported.

The overwhelming majority (74 to 2) by which the Senate adopted the seventygroup, modern-plane Air Force bill leaves no doubt that Congress is going to override the recommendations of the Defense Establishment as to air needs and give the Air Force what it alone has asked for.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Economic Cooperation Administrationh)0*0*0*itoday authorized shipments worth more than $4,000,000 to Austria, Denmark, Greece and the Netherlands. At the same time, two other countries qualified for aid under the European Recovery Program.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- One of the first bank advertising campaigns based on research conducted by the Association of National Advertisers and the American Association of Advertising Agencies on free enterprise and betterment of the understanding of American business will be started next week by the First National Bank of Chicago.
ATHENS, May 7 (AP) -- The British Embassy said today it had asked the Greek Government for "details and an explanation" of the execution of more than 200 Leftist prisoners this week.

The extension of the Social Security program to provide relief for disabled persons and assure their rehabilitation was advocated yesterday by Government officials at the closing session of the National Council on Rehabilitation in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- First efforts to bring Senate and House Republicans to policy agreement on the entire defense program appeared tonight to have failed. Whether further attempts would be made before each branch had its own voting showdown remained to be seen.
MEDFORD, Ore., May 7 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York applauded the Republican Congress tonight for voting the seventy-group Air Force.
CHICAGO, May 7 -- Jolly Cholly Grimm probably was counting Dodgers walking to first base when he went to bed tonight, but that isn't the cure for insomnia that sheep-counting is alleged to be.
SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, May 8 -- The Soviet troops in the northern part of this country were reported poised today for immediate withdrawal from Korea.
WICHITA, Kan., May 7 (AP) -Three thousand workmen today were busy modernizing and remodeling heavy bombers in a recently reactivated plant of the Boeing Airplane Company.

W. H. Auden, winner of the Pulitzer Prize in poetry, has edited for Viking a "Portable Greek Reader," covering Greek culture from Aesop to Galen, to be published in September. He also will do a four-volume set of "Portables" covering the poets of the English language from Geoffrey Chaucer to Thomas Hardy.

Gen. Douglas MacArthur is doing "a tremendous work in spreading the roots of democracy in Japan," Dr. Iwao Frederic Ayusawa, the first Japanese official to leave that country since the war, declared here yesterday.
James Munro has purchased from the estate of Charles Larsen the two-family house at 34-04 Thirty-eighth Street. Long Island City, Queens. William A. Krahe Son were the brokers.

Shortages of steel and insufficient shipyard labor continue to plague European shipbuilding, with the result that the delivery of new merchant vessels is considerably behind schedule, as much as twelve months in some cases, Maersk McKinney Moller, chairman of the board of the Moller Steamship Company, Inc., said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Demands for the right to court appeal of tariff cuts effected in trade pacts were heard by a House Ways and Means subcommittee today as hearings on extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act neared completion.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 7 -- Winston Churchill set before the first Congress of Europe here today the immediate task of constituting a European assembly to make the "voice of Europe" continuously heard in all free countries.

Large families for educated couples, women's colleges rather than co-educational institutions and early discipline for children were advocated yesterday by Mrs. Helen Gartside Hines, the "American Mother of 1948," who was honored at a reception in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

Pointing out that the United States has no need of importing to the extent necessary for full repayment of foreign loans, Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, predicted yesterday that the loans will not be repaid.

Five diamond dealers arrested by Secret Service agents were arraigned before United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter yesterday on charges of violating the Gold Reserve Act of 1934 by conspiring to acquire and possess gold illegally. Four were released in bail and the fifth on his own recognizance to await grand jury action.

The New York City Federation of Women's Clubs went on record yesterday in favor of a measure, now pending in the City Council, to establish a two-year continuous residence requirement for 11 persons seeking home relief, veterans' assistance and old-age funds.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- Threats of a country-wide railroad strike next Tuesday caused uneasiness among housewives in the Central West and in Chicago's commodity markets today. The family marketers feared a possible food shortage, while traders speculated on the possibility of interruption in deliveries.
" Whispering City," a melodramaproduced in Canada and featuringPaul Lukas, Mary Anderson andHelmut Dantine, will open thismorning at the Gotham.
The second round of play in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's inter-club series was conducted yesterday in a down-pour of rain and biting winds.
JERUSALEM, May 7 -- The Arabs agreed today to a cease-fire in all Jerusalem beginning at noon tomorrow, and the Jews said they would comply if the Arabs actually halted their firing.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 7 Warning that there was only a week left to find an emergency solution for the Palestine crisis, Britain placed before a General Assembly subcommittee today a proposal to set up a "very humble" United Nations agency in the Holy Land.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 7 -Maintenance of high employee morale with greater personal interest in workers is essential to the efficiency of any business organization, Dwight Thomas, executive vice president of the Gulf Brewing Company, Houston, Tex., said today.
JERUSALEM, May 7 (UP) -Akram Hamari, a member of the Syrian Parliament. was quoted today as having said:

LOS ANGELES, May 7 -- If establishment of an independent Jewish state in Palestine fails because of covert opposition "then the United Nations might as well fold up," Justice Meier Steinbrink of the Supreme Court in New York, told the B'nai B'rith Anti-Defamation League tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 7 -- The British Government, which was requested by the General Assembly yesterday to appoint a special Commissioner for Jerusalem to carry on the municipal government, threw the question back in the lap of the United Nations today.

OBERLIN, Ohio, May 7 -- "God must have been a Democrat," read a rain-smeared sign on what was left of one of the floats which participated in the parade which ushered in the twenty-second Republican mock convention at Oberlin College today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 7 -Arrangements for Z. Wayne Griffin and John Beck to produce "Family Honeymoon" at Universal-International on an independent-profit-sharing basis, have been concluded and contracts will be signed Monday, it was learned today from the studio.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The "happily ever after" concept of family life must go back to the never-never land from which it came, Dr. Eduard C. Lindeman of the New York School of Social Work, told the National Conference on Family Life tonight.

The annular eclipse of the sun that will begin today in Burma and end, five hours later, in the Aleutian Islands, is of particular interest now because of the possible development of long-range military devices.

Taking the stand in his own defense, Bernardino Mastromoco 36-year-old Bronx attorney, testified in General Sessions yesterday that he did not see the allegedly fraudulent will for the $280,000 estate of Miss Mathilde Molsberger until the day after a prosecution witness had asserted it was prepared.
More than 800 persons bared their heads yesterday on a rain swept pier at the Brooklyn Army base in solemn tribute to 4,183 American war dead who arrived on the Army transport Lawrence Victory.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were somewhat irregular yesterday and closed 13 points lower to 23 points net higher.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 7 -- A special three-member subcommittee of the House Education and Labor Committee took testimony here today into the circumstances surrounding a move to substitute an honor guard of marines for professional pallbearers at a reburial service for a marine killed on Iwo Jima.

Benjamin Freedman, anti-Zionist founder of the League for Peace With Justice in Palestine, testified yesterday in Mid-Manhattan Magistrates' Court that last winter he discussed partition at a dinner of fifty-two members of Congress and that he gave to each Representative literature and advertisements opposing partition and political Zionism.

Frederick Lundy, owner of Lundy's Restaurant on Emmons Avenue at Sheepshead Bay, has added to his holdings in that area of Brooklyn through the purchase of the land and building of the old Villepigue's Inn at 3078 Ocean Avenue, now known as Sanford's.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -The Civil Aeronautics Board ruled today that the crash of the American Airlines plane "Alpha" in Bowery Bay of Long Island last Aug. 8 probably was due to an attempt to land without sufficient speed.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Thirty-six House Republicans asked President Truman today to lift the embargo against arms shipments to the Jewish forces in Palestine.

At The Hague yesterday Winston Churchill made the keynote speech for an unusual convention. The First Congress of Europe in modern times brought together 800 delegates, some of whom are members or former members of governments. But not one represents a government.

LONDON, May 7 (AP) -- Some thirty Americans will meet the King and Queen at a court party in Buckingham Palace next Thursday, but there will be no formal presentation line and no inflexible code of bowing, curtseying and obligatory wearing of fanciest dress.
Navy and Harvard, the top two crews of 1947 and among the leading contenders for the Olympic assignment, will match sweeps today in the most interesting of five regattas listed for the afternoon.

The farm market should be carefully studied for evidences of collapse and general economic trends, speakers told the farm marketing group, American Marketing Association, New York chapter, yesterday, at the Sheraton Hotel. George Kreiger, manager of rural marketing, Ethyl Corporation, said that $1.50 of every $100 worth of advertising now was going into farm media, but he warned that any drop in this prosperous market would have a serious effect on the whole economy.

Retail trade here this week made a small increase despite unseasonably cold weather and an unusual amount of rain. Department store sales were estimated as showing a gain of about 5 per cent. Last week's increase was 8 per cent.

Net earnings of the MidContinent Petroleum Corporation and its subsidiaries rose to $7,007,163 or $3.77 a share in the first quarter of this year from $3,869,129 or $2.08 a share earned in the 1947 quarter-year.

The American Hospital Association has started to organize into a national congress 300,000 women volunteers serving as auxiliaries in hospitals all over the country, it was announced yesterday at a conference in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Wolff Chamber Players gave their third and last concert of the season last night at Times Hall. Units of the organization participating at this event includedh)0*0*0*ia trio composed of Henry Siegl, violinist; Shepard Coleman, 'cellist, and Joseph Wolman, pianist, and a woodwind ensemble including Charles Ehrenberg, flutist; John Mack, oboist; Bernard Garfield, bassoonist; Wallace Shapiro, clarinetist; Ray Alonje, hornist, and Lilian Kallir, pianist.

LINCOLN, Neb., May 7 (AP) -Students, campus police, city police, deans and the Governor became embroiled today in a University of Nebraska parking problem. It caused a demonstration during which police tossed a tear gas bomb in an effort to disperse some 2,000 students.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- A new method of producing gray iron of greatly improved physical properties, which was hailed by metallurgists as an outstanding contribution to the industry, was revealed today at the fifty-second annual congress and show of the American Foundryrmen's Association in Convention Hall here.

Donald T. Withers, 24 years old, a New York University student, of 3130 Kingsbridge Avenue, the Bronx, went out last evening to find out at first hand how long it takes the police to go to work on criminal cases. He got the answer with lightning swiftness after he allegedly held up a liquor store manager who happened to be a retired police sergeant.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 8 (AP) -- Meet records were broken today as Yale's well-balanced and favored track and field forces defeated Harvard, 83 1/2 to 56 1/2, at the Stadium in their fifty-second such meeting.

An intensive program aimed at recruiting teachers is under way in many New York and New Jersey high schools associated with the Metropolitan School Study Council, a research affiliate of Teachers College, Columbia University.

With imports now rising to record peaks, foreign traders here will give strong support to the Celler and Buck bills amending the Foreign Trade Zones Act to permit exhibition and manufacturing in these zones, it was reported here last week.

German industry and German aircraft production facilities -- contrary to official and popular impression -- were not by any means fully mobilized for war when Hitler invaded Poland in 1939, according to a comprehensive official study and report prepared for the Secretary of the Army.

Detailed procedures whereby private enterprise may be protected in its participation in the European Recovery Program, under the terms of the Economic Cooperation Act, are under intensive study, although not yet fully formulated by the official agencies concerned, it was learned yesterday. Of special interest to the financial community, of course,

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The first concrete unification yet effected by the Armed Services will go into effect on June 1, it was announced today by Secretary of Defense James Forrestal, when the Military Air Transport Service begins operation of a worldwide network of air transportation routes.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- Sixty-four red roses and a big birthday cake decorated President Truman's desk today -- it was his sixty-fourth birthday anniversary.

RAY DOOLEY, who has been playing a housewife exclusively for the last thirteen years under the sponsorship of Eddie Dowling, will interrupt the long run in Bayside on Tuesday. Broadway, whose musical stage she adorned for a couple of decades, will reclaim her that evening, still under the Dowling auspices.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 8 (AP) -- The "Command Volunteers, Southern Front Palestine" issued a communique today saying that Egyptian volunteer forces has penetrated about thirty miles into the Holy Land.

WASHINGTON -- An international effort to develop a "little Marshall Plan," which would encompass the profilation of tourist travel into a potent force for European economic recovery, was reported here last week by Dr. Herbert A. Wilkinson, special trade policy adviser of the Commerce Department's Office of International Trade.

The teaching future of Gen. Jonas Cernius, former Prime Minister of Lithuania, who was found Friday working as a $30-a-week machinist in a factory in Newark, N.J., appeared confused last night. Midwestern College in Hillman, Minn., with a representative of which General Cernius has been negotiating, is not yet regularly established, it developed.

INYOKERN, Calif., May 8 -- Expressing the belief that the public had gotten away from the "pushbutton war" delusion, John Nicholas Brown, Under-Secretary of the Navy for Air, warned today against comparable error in underestimating the importance of scentific research.

THE one hundred news, sports and feature pictures selected from 1,000 entered in the Fifth Annual News Pictures of the Year Competition and Exhibition, are reproduced in "The Great Pictures - 1948" (Garden City: Garden City Publishing Company, $3), just published.

ROME, May 8 (AP) -- A member of the Executive of the World Federation of Trade Unions predicted tonight agreement within twenty-four hours to permit the French "Workers Force" to enter the federation.

PARIS, May 8 -- Premier Robert Schuman, addressing his Popular Republican party congress in Toulouse today, proclaimed his intention of going forward with the Government recovery program undeterred by the pressure from Gen. Charles de Gaulle or by Communist attacks.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- Jewish community center activities in 1947 gave "a picture of vigor and promise," Frank L. Weil of New York, president of the National Jewish Welfare Board, told the opening session of the national convention here tonight.

THE interrogation of Norms Drooschen by Lieutenant Decker is something quite out of the ordinary. That is why it has been permitted to take up the greater part of this story. There are occasional flashbacks indicating bits of what really happened, which is not what Norma is telling Decker.

" I'M so sick of satiric novels about the rich," someone called Steve Eckenthal says about three-quarters of the way through this book. "Juicy exposes of their rotten way of life * * * end of an erotic era, war hysteria, rich men's sons flaking off and molding like Roquefort cheese."

EVERY generation wants to translate again the foreign classics it has new reasons to admire. But Dante, in our own time, has been an exception. For three decades a fresh interest in his work has been growing in England and here.

IF the art of satire at Miss Powell's hand is less baleful, knife-edged and glittering than when Mr. Evelyn Waugh puts his hand to it, it is equally relevant, and more humane. In "The Locusts Have No King," Miss Powell pins down her locust -- some New York barflies, bigwigs and gadabouts -- with drastic precision, but never without pity.

Journeys I WAS especially fascinated by the notion of hurried journeys. In the great romances of literature they provide some of the chief dramatic moments, and since the theme is common to Homer and the penny reciter it must appeal to a very ancient instinct in human nature.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Candidate Harry S. Truman's bad luck has begun to level off and he is on the comeback trail toward at least a partial restoration of his popularity both with the voters and the managers of the Democratic party.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 -- There are growing signs that the West Coast, the part of the country that would be most affected, is swinging around to the view that Japanese and other Orientals now excluded should be admitted to the United States under the quota system and made eligible for citizenship.

" ASYLUM FOR THE QUEEN" is kingly fare for the romantic reader. The story, built around the attempts of a group of fanatical aristocrats to rescue the royal family during the French Revolution, gives Miss Jordan full opportunity to display her fine narrative gift in its gaudiest expression to date. Her book is resplendent with period glitter.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- Daniel Harrington, retiring safety chief of the Bureau of Mines, has recommended that the Federal safety code for coal mines be abolished. You could not shove safety down people's throats, he said.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 8 -- Wisconsin won the varsity race, Columbia the Freshman and Syracuse the junior varsity in a new quadrangular rowing regatta that was a lot less than it was intended to be on part of Onondaga Lake today.

THE Stratford Memorial Theatre is in the news again. Well, it always is in the news about this time of year because a large number of diplomats and even more journalists go down there to celebrate Shakespeare's birthday and all that.

In "We Need a Program For as Well as Against," Chester Bowles has shown conclusively that we are not forced to choose among evils, outworn laissez-faire at home, militant imperialism abroad, or the Wallace program of fuzzy idealism and futile appeasement.

IT is a bromide, of course, to observe that this is a big country, but workers in music need to be reminded that New York, despite the vast activity centered here and the wide influence swung by its musicians, press and managements, tells only part of the story.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 8 -- Drafting of the United Nations plan for an emergency regime in Palestine began today.

THE story of Elizabeth Ann Seton, better known as Mother Seton, contains so much material of historical, ecclesiastical, and personal interest, that it should cause no surprise that it has been told once again. The present book is written in novel form by Evelyn Eaton (best known for "Quietly My Captain Waits") and Monsignor Edward Roberts Moore.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 8 -- Miss Elaine Moore of White Plains, astride Hugh Grant Straus' 9-year-old bay gelding, Catnip, held the edge over Albertus A. Moore's gelding, Hydro Fashion, for the working hunter championship of the two-day Secor Farms Riding Club horse show at the conclusion of sessions this morning, afternoon and evening in the indoor arena at Hillair Circle.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Dr. Edward U. Condon, Director of the Bureau of Standards, has appealed to President Truman to make public a report by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on the atomic scientist's loyalty.

HANOVER, N.H., May 8 -- After spreading seven hits over as many innings and allowing only one run, Princeton's ace hurler Bob Walcott fell apart in the seven-run eighth and Dartmouth defeated the Tigers, 8 -- 3, for the Indians' sixth Eastern League triumph against no defeats.

SEOUL, Korea, May 8 -- Further details of the Soviet notice to the North Korean authorities that the Soviet Union was ready to withdraw its troops from Korea reached here today. It was indicated that the Soviet Union intended to force a showdown with the United States on the continued occupation of this country.

Mayor O'Dwyer told graduating probationary policemen yesterday to pay careful attention to regulations on the use of force in their performance of duty. He advised them not to use force unless necessary and then no more than was needed.

A delegation of twenty farmers from Long Island, Staten Island and New Jersey protested yesterday at a meeting of the Northeastern Vegetable and Potato Council in the New Yorker Hotel against the projected closing of the Gansevoort Market, at which they sell vegetables to retailers in lower Manhattan.

TIRE manufacturers are now hard at work solving problems of cold-weather motoring that were revealed by the severe winter. Data gathered by the Society of Automotive Engineers indicate that tires suffered from cold weather as never before and that something must be done about them before another winter.

The police put fifty men around a Fifth Avenue apartment building early yesterday morning in a fruitless effort to apprehend a young burglar who leisurely had ransacked a penthouse apartment there and had disappeared after binding his victims with neckties.

With the deadline for what would be the nation's seventh general railroad strike only hours away, Eastern carriers yesterday promulgated tentative schedules canceling long-distance trains due to leave terminal points tomorrow afternoon and evening, and combined or shortened the run of others.

THE publication of an increasing number of collections of American folklore would seem to be a logical result of our national growth. Having come so far in so short a time, we are bound to search insistently into the sources of our strength, our ideals and our peculiarities.

TRANSPORTATION and communications are themes in an airmail series which Hungary is issuing, and the designs include portraits of men who were pioneers in those fields. Advance illustrations reached J. H. Stolow last week. Two of the men honored were Americans.

CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- The rail embargo fixed a slowly strangling grip on the California - Florida fruit and vegetable industries today. It was the first big pinch of the threatened rail strike paralysis.

THERE has been, lately, a certain improvement in standards of reproduction in American art publishing. This is evidenced by the three portfolios at hand. The color reproductions in "Modern Italian Painters" would do credit to a Viennese or Zurich publisher, and it is a pity that hardly more than three or four of the artists included seem to deserve the lavish technique and care spent on their plates.

Ben F. Whitaker's clean-up in Jamaica's stakes races continued yesterday when his 4-year-old filly Carolyn A., fifth choice in a field of half a dozen fillies and mares, cut loose in the stretch and won the $25,000-added Firenze Handicap by close to three lengths.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- The packing strike of almost eight weeks reached an impasse today with settlement efforts at a standstill despite efforts of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service to continue meetings with the packers and the United Packinghouse Workers of America, CIO.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- Radar, the eye that sees through the dark, is going to work to help river shipping.
With ten runs in the first inning, Columbia's baseball team registered its fifth straight victory by beating Brown, 19 -- 0, before an Alumni Day gathering of 1,000 at Baker Field yesterday.

Religious services will be held by Roman Catholics, Protestants and Jews this morning at Bellevue Hospital commemorating the seventy-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Bellevue School of Nursing. All will join in a reception and coffee hour in Chapel Hall at 9:30 A.M.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Because of increased pressure on communication facilities in Palestine and plans of the British Cable and Wireless to close down when the British leave the country, the State Department today requested the Navy to set up communication facilities in Jerusalem.

ROME, May 8 -- The thirty-first Italian Legislature -- the first since the end of the war -- was inaugurated this morning when the Senate and the Chamber resulting from the Christian Democratic victory at the polls last month met separately to elect their respective presidents.

HERE are two new examples of the suspense novel, one American, the other English. Both are skillful, well-written stories, suspenseful enough to hold your interest until the last chapter; and yet neither of them is completely successful and for the same reason, that their endings lack punch.

JOHN STEINBECK, author of "The Grapes of Wrath," "The Red Pony," "Of Mice and Men," and a number of other stories and novels which have become American classics, met the famous photographer, Robert Capa, in a bar one day.

CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- The 10-year-old National Basketball League today appeared in danger of collapse. This followed disclosure that three key members would jump to the rival Basketball Association of America and that Commissioner Ward (Piggy) Lambert would quit his $15,000-a-year job.

MUNICH, Germany, May 8 -- As the wave of strikes against the cut in fat and meat rations expanded in Bavaria employes of the Munich street railway system walked away from their street cars this morning, leaving many stranded on the streets.

PROCEEDINGS of the National Health Assembly in Washington last week put a lot of stress on "positive health." Dr. Leona Baumgartner, chairman of the Assembly's Maternal and Child Health Section talked about this in an interview the other day.

TWO thousand three hundred years ago painters were attacking critics -- about 400 B.C. the Greek "magic realist" Zeuxis complained that "criticism comes easier than craftsmanship." Ever since critics have faced an open season.

The genius of Winston Churchill shines through the magnificent and fascinating panorama he is painting of the events that led to the most devastating war in history. No one of our sorely tried generation can read these pages without reliving the stirring events they portray.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Sunday, May 9 -- An outline of the organization for the united Europe advocated by Winston Churchill began to emerge overnight after hours of debate, often amid great confusion, as the unofficial Congress of Europe plowed through its first real day of business.

Federal controls over scarce materials now appear inevitable because a nation-wide contest in metals procurement has already started, leading manufacturers disclosed here yesterday. Demand is so far ahead of supply, partially because of rearmament and foreign

SEVERAL weeks ago this department made some mention of a book by Max Picard, a Swiss physician, which has been much discussed in Europe. Its thesis is the lack of continuity and cohesion in the life of modern man. Published here under the title, "Hitler in Our Selves," Picard's book finds in Nazism the ultimate expression of this disintegrating tendency.

Public school education came to a virtual standstill in Providence last week as the teachers in the second largest city in New England went out on strike. After two busy days of picketing and negotiations, the teachers returned to their classrooms.

ANOTHER opportunity to gauge the abiding vitality and alluring traditional stability of the French in their drawings is available this week in two exhibitions of graphics at the Delius and Dinet Galleries. The Delius show harks back as far as the formal elegance of Fontainbleau and stops with a recent page from Picasso's exploration of pre-Christian myth, a study for "Le Berger."
TEL AVIV, Palestine, May 8 -- With one week to go under the British mandate, this Jewish city appeared today to be at peace with the world and satisfied with itself.

RECENT political disturbances in Central and South America have had little effect upon tourist interest in Latin-American travel. Shipping and airline offices report no change in the strong demand for transportation to southern points.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y. May 8 -- The collapse of United Nations atomic control planning is expected to lead to a formal move to abandon all disarmament talks within the world organization, it was learned here today.
The Big Show takes the road tonight, winding up a thirty-two and one-half day run at Madison Square Garden. The first stop is in Boston Garden on Tuesday night. Thereafter, it will be under canvas.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A White House conference between representatives of the railroads and three major operating unions today failed to remove the threat of a country-wide strike scheduled for 6 A.M. Tuesday.
PANAMA, May 8 -- Panamanians will vote for President, two Vice Presidents and forty-two members and forty-two substitutes for the National Assembly tomorrow.

AFTER twenty years of planning, testing materials and models, erecting suitable buildings, inventing automatic machinery of unprecedented smoothness of operation for its size, grinding and shaping a twenty-ton disk of glass and coating it in a vacuum with a film of aluminum two-millionths of an inch thick, and solving a thousand difficult mechanical and electrical problems, the 200-inch astronomical reflecting telescope of Palomar Mountain in California is about ready to scan the heavens.
TOKYO, May 8 -- The Japanese Government today made public a detailed draft of the long-delayed budget for 1948, the largest in the country's history.

What follows is a compilation of items from recent Russian newspapers and periodicals. The material was selected and the article written by Harry Schwartz, Assistant Professor of Economics at Syracuse University and an authority on Russian affairs.

EQUIPPED by years of background travel, residence and broad understanding of the people, Carleton Beals writes again of Latin America with assurance and with zest. Whittling down some of his glittering generalities and superlatives would make for a more accurate, albeit a more modest presentation of the subject expressed in the volume's subtitle "The Awakening From Rio Grande to Cape Horn."

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Members of the National Board of the American Association of University Women from all over the country joined today in a statement defending the board's action against the stand of the Washington, D.C., branch on the racial issue.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Although Soviet authorities have made an all-out effort to increase the production of coal, "the bread of industry," it appeared today that the output for the first three months of 1948 was still insufficient to provide for the desired development of Russian industry.

New York University's Westchester Center, organized in 1946 for high school graduates who had been denied a college education because of overcrowding in most of the nation's higher education institutions, will be disbanded at the end of the current academic year, it was announced yesterday.

IN one of television's more ambitious and lavish ventures to date, Gertrude Lawrence came before the video cameras last Sunday in George Bernard Shaw's item of trivia known as "Great Catherine." While the production was hardly an epic in polished stagecraft, it afforded Miss Lawrence an opportunity for sixty minutes of frolic and nonsense which consistently was diverting if not always acting.

THE paradox has been pointed out a sufficient number of times in the case of Stravinsky. It lies in the contrast between his gospel of neo-classicism conveyed in terms of purely objective music for the concert-room, and the fact that every one of his historical and indisputable successes as a composer have been the works composed for the stage, and choreography.

OLDER boys will welcome the news that Mr. Riesenberg has come up once more with a villain-laden yarn involving modern piracy on the high seas. Our friend Bob Nelson is the hero, of course -- with hard-bitten Captain Hull and a young cadet named Larry Bruce completing a formidable trio of stalwarts who are intent upon seeing justice triumph.

JOSIAH E. GREENE has a talent for putting a community under a microscope and significantly revealing what he finds there. He did it in his hard-hitting novel, "Not in Our Stars," and he has done it again in his latest book, "A Bridge at Branfield."

BOSTON, May 8 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns, consigned by nearly everyone but themselves to the American League cellar, up and socked Boston's highly regarded Red Sox, 9 -- 4, before 11,662 windswept customers today.

DAYTIME radio writers cannot be classified as simply writers, because the book review section never compares one of them with Ernest Hemingway or Gypsy Rose Lee. It is even, strictly speaking, difficult to class them as daytime radio writers, because so many of them have less in common with each other than the Capulets with the Montagues. Still, there is the case of David Driscoll.

IN working over complex material, Professor Whitaker, of the University of Pennsylvania History Department, lecturer in South American universities, author of "The United States and the Independence of Latin America" and other books, avoids two traps for experts, especially in Latin American studies: that of not seeing the dissonant parts of a subject and that of not seeing the whole.

NANKING, May 8 -- The Government managed to convoke the new Legislative Yuan on schedule today. But the opening of China's first constitutional Parliament was marred by the absence of about 400 representatives and a political boycott by two small parties in the coalition Government.

THE week's most interesting novelty, "Ballet Ballads." opens a series of six performances at Maxine Elliott's Theatre tonight, produced by the Experimental Theatre and presented under the auspices of the American National Theatre and Academy.

In "V of V" formation thirty-seven fighter aircraft piloted by members of the Naval Air Reserve and Marine Air Reserve flew over New York and other cities yesterday afternoon to observe the thirty-seventh anniversary of naval aviation.

Magistrate Francis X. Giaccone in Felony Court yesterday told a 24-year-old man accused of beating his 6-year-old stepdaughter that he was "a mean little monster" and set bail at $10,000 for a hearing May 13 on a charge of felonious assault.

The article, "Wanted: Experts to Run ERP," by Donald H. McLean Jr., in which he proposed an Overseas Administration Corps for the administration of foreign relief and economic programs leaves one with a feeling of astonishment, anxiety and resentment.

GENEVA, May 8 -- Ending a tense critical two-week session, the Economic Commission for Europe took the first step today on a new path that it hoped would lead to improved economic relations between Eastern and Western Europe.

Prof. George I. Wallace and Miss Ione Rhymer of the University of Illinois bacteriology department have found that bacteria apparently killed by streptomycin can be restored after three days to normal activity by the addition of a mysterious "inhibiting factor."

CHICAGO, May 8 -- America's international program of information and education will help develop a greater sense of world citizenship in this country, George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, declared here today.

THE other day Dutton threw a party for George Herman (Babe) Ruth, the occasion being the publication of "The Babe Ruth Story" (as told to Bob Considine), and this department's representative was, naturally, the man who regularly suffers the highest grandparental mortality during the midsummer season.

Prices fluctuated irregularly in yesterday's brief session on the Stock Exchange and closed mixed, with oil and textile shares exhibiting the best performances. Petroleum and rail issues were the feature of an irregularly higher market during the week.

AFTER six years' absence from the exhibition field the Sculptors Guild resumes its activities with its current outdoor show in a vacant lot on the north side of Washington Square, just west of Fifth Avenue. More than a hundred pieces have been assembled, ranging from sheer naturalism to sheer abstraction.

READING, Pa., May 8 -- With reluctance Norman Thomas, veteran New York Socialist leader, announced late today that he has agreed to accept the party's Presidential nomination for a sixth time if it is offered to him. Mr. Thomas' decision virtually assured his nomination at tomorrow's session of the twenty-sixth annual national convention of the party.

An annular eclipse of the sun occurs today (May 8 or May 9, depending on the international dateline) over a 5,320-mile path which starts in the Indian Ocean, follows the west coast of the Pacific Ocean and extends as far as the Aleutian Islands. The moon will not completely cover the sun.

TRIESTE, May 6 (Delayed) -- United States Brig. Gen. Ridgely Gaither, head of the Allied Military Government, today expressed confidence that the Communist workers would support a "good economic program" such as the one now being studied by Allied economic experts to integrate Trieste's industrial economic potential with that of the Western European nations.
THREE years ago this month the San Francisco Conference on International Organization was in the early stages of its work.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- Plans for establishing Randolph Field in Texas as a United States Air Academy comparable to West Point and Annapolis have been approved by Secretary of the Air Force W. Stuwart Symington, Representative Paul J. Kilday, Democrat, of Texas announced today.

A year ago this summer Dr. Charles L. Camp, Professor of Paleontology at the University of California, organized a scientific expedition to study on the spot the fossil remains of man-apes found in 1936 at Sterkfontein, near Johannesburg, South Africa, by Dr. Robert Broom.

Dino Ancona, Italian pianist, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The most extensive of the offerings he presented were Beethoven's "Moonlight" Sonata and Chopin's Scherzo in B flat minor, "Berceuse" and Polanaise in A flat major.

RE-EDUCATING the populace to the glories of the living theatre is turning into one of those grand crusades which may yet erase the sneering critics. One more piece of testimony came through the other day with the disclosure that Margaret Webster's plans for her Shakespeare company were nearing completion and "Hamlet" and "Macbeth" will be giving 128 performances in colleges, schools and universities throughout the land.

The recommendation of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission that, inasmuch as it had reached an impasse, there was no use of continuing its work, is a matter that cannot pass without serious notice. It represents Russia's refusal to agree to the inspection idea and joint cooperation as proposed by the United States two years ago. The Moscow delegates have stuck to their unwillingness to accept what they call an infringement of national sovereignty.

THE sixty-four-dollar issue in the Government's ten-year-old monopoly suit against the motion-picture industry -- whether the five major producer-distributor companies should be divested of their theatre holdings -- was left unsettled by the Supreme Court's ruling last Monday.

THE doorman of the little Hotel Bellevue was only following instructions when he prepared for a visiting Duke by unrolling a red carpet. He had no notion of disrupting the town, tying up traffic, hurdling street vendors or running all the way out into the country.

ST. LOUIS, May 8 (AP) -- Harry (The Cat) Brecheen stopped the Philadelphia Phillies with one scratch hit tonight and the St. Louis Cardinals swept their two-game series with the Phils, 5 to 0. Nippy Jones batted in four Card runs with a single and a home run.

THIS is the story of a couple of young and amiable runaways from the radio business. Chuck Bartlet and Joe Dobbs decide to live peacefully in the country with their families. They would probably have done so, except the wives put together a radio show of their own ("Airing Cur Children") that starts coming out of Joe's own living room every morning.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The House-approved measure to admit Hawaii into the Union as the forty-ninth state was shunted aside today by the Senate Committee on Public Lands by a vote of 7 to 5.

WITH the multiplicity of outdoor jobs now demanding the gardener's attention, it is easy to forget about house plants. Fascinating kinds, in varieties often difficult to obtain from the florist, can readily be grown from seed.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 -- Leading the reduced field for the final two miles, Identiroon, 6-year- old black gelding belonging to Samuel R. Fry of Wyomissing and with J.C. Arthur riding, captured the rigorous four-mile steeplechase over timber for the Radnor Hunt Cup today.

GENEVA, May 8 -- Brazil has agreed to accept an unlimited number of refugees in family groups with the usefulness of the immigrants as manpower only of secondary consideration, Helio Lobo, Brazilian delegate and vice chairman of the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization, said at a commission meeting today.

At the northeastern edge of Tel Aviv, the all-Jewish city on the eastern shore of the Mediterranean, lies the tree-shaded suburb of Sarona. Its name is derived from Sharon (Heb.: plain), the fertile coastal section of Palestine. The suburb was used by the Mandate Government as a key police post until the British withdrew from the Tel Aviv area three months ago.
WHAT this country needs perhaps most of all -- aside from a sense of humor and an inspired diplomacy to cope with the tangled foreign situation -- is a good $5,000 house.

Winthrop Rockefeller, who saw battle action with the infantry on Guam, Leyte and the Kerama Retto Islands, made a plea last night for world peace and told veterans of the 305th Infantry of the Seventy-seventh Division that he hoped they would not have to put on their uniforms again.

ANYONE who thinks the human race -- particularly the feminine division -- was created to make hay in psychiatric sunshine will find plenty of supporting evidence in James Maresca's account of his tribulations as a New York cab driver.

NEXT Tuesday the song writer who composed the overture to the Jazz Age, who turned out a ballad that almost rivals "The Star-Spangled Banner" as the national anthem, who lightened the horrors of two wars with his melodies and whose tunes at present are causing throbs in the hearts as well as the feet of the nation, will be 60 years old.

THE reading of the picture as it has been read by countless generations has become one of the lost arts of antiquity. No longer is it considered cricket to admire or comprehend the thought behind pure combinations of form and color.

MAY is the month for sowing seed and setting out tiny plants of annuals, so necessary to insure color in the flower border this coming summer. One of the big advantages of planting annuals is that the experimental gardener has a chance to try new combinations, thus keeping the garden and gardening from becoming monotonous.

Led by its top-flight sprinters, Boys High kept its undefeated string intact yesterday at Triborough Stadium by capturing the open team championship in its own tenth track and field games. Registering five first places in the fifteen events contested, the Brooklyn school scored 41 points to runner-up New Utrecht's 25.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 8 -- In promotion of the residential and business attributes of this municipality, civic and commercial organizations will join in presenting a White Plains Parade of Progress for ten days beginning Saturday.

The simple love of a mother for her children should serve as an inspiration to the military, political and economic leaders of the world in formulating a program for world security and peace, Rabbi Samuel M. Segal said in a pre-Mother's Day sermon in Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street, yesterday.

MADRID, May 8 -- An agreement through which Spain undertakes to expropriate German property here valued at approximately 600,000,000 pesetas (about $80,000,000) for Allied reparations and liquidation of Spanish claims on Germany was announced today.

Summer travel will soon be in full swing. It's an art to look and feel cool and at the same time smart when holiday bent. Today the task is made easy by the number and variety of fabrics which are not only suitable, but many of which provide crash-resistance. In them designers offer attractive and at the same time casual styles.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 8 (AP) -- The national commander of the Catholic War Veterans called tonight for a fight against "practica communism" with the "unbeatable weapon of practical Christianity."

BOSTON, May 8 (AP) -- The American Society of Newspaper Editors moved today to safeguard newsmen from a pending Congressional bill which would penalize disclosure of confidential information by legislative committeemen.

JUST fifteen years ago this week in this Review: Norman Douglas took over Page 1 by "rifling" his past in the form of an autobiography entitled "Looking Back" In the "formlessness of this book of recollections," Mr. Douglas "chooses to remember higgledy-piggledy" and to "skip about maliciously." . . .

Questions affecting the nation's security as important as any that ever have been posed in peacetime will be before Congress for decision during the next few days. Both the Senate and the House already have voted by overwhelming margins to begin immediate construction of a modern, seventy-group Air Force.

LONDON, May 8 -- The possibility that Britain will enter the second half of this year without a concrete 'blueprint" of her economic program loomed here today. Lacking rulings on numerous features of the European Recovery Program, the Labor Government has not been able to outline definitely the dollar expenditure and import programs that are so vital to her rehabilitation planning, officials said.

CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- Wheat and corn suffered losses extending to several cents a bushel on the Board of Trade today. The selling came mainly from traders unwilling to carry grain over the weekend in view of a possibility that the railroad strike would be avoided.

With Secretary of Defense James Forrestal scheduled to speak Wednesday night, the seventeenth annual conference of the Chaplains Association of the Army and the Navy of the United States will be held tomorrow through Thursday in the New Yorker Hotel, it was announced yesterday.

BEAR MOUNTAIN -- The outdoor recreational facilities of this 44,000-acre playland were officially opened yesterday for the summer season. It was the earliest opening date in the park's thirty-seven-year history and it brought predictions of a record season from park officials.

The wage increases being sought by two maritime labor unions in negotiations for a new contract with Atlantic and Gulf, Coast steamship companies were described yesterday by Frank J. Taylor, chairman of the owners' negotiating committee, as "unwarranted and apt to bring about chaos" in the American Merchant Marine.
WASHINGTON. IT isn't only the weather that people are always talking about, but seldom do anything about. For a close second to the weather, there is the administration of the American Government.

THE off-and-on deal for Howard Hughes to buy the controlling interest in RKO-Radio from Floyd Odlum's Atlas Corporation emerged from the rumor stage last week with a cryptic announcement by the two principals that Hughes and Odlum had reached a "tentative" agreement for the transfer of the Atlas holdings, which reportedly amount to 929,000 shares.

" 26-in-1" is the challenging slogan of the American Overseas Aid-United Nations Appeal For Children, 50 Broadway, New York, behind which twenty-six welfare agencies, including the U.N.'s International Children's Emergency Fund, have thrown their support as one, to save as many as possible of the two hundred and thirty million sick and starving children in the world.

The latest issue of Branch Library Book News, available now for the asking in the central building, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, and the branches, is a timely one for June brides and grooms. Books are listed that tell how to plan a wedding, how to decorate a home, how to fry an egg; that advise on remodeling a house, repairing plaster and planning a budget for two.

With the aid of a new emulsion the Eastman Kodak laboratories have for the first time successfully recorded tracks of electrons directly on a photographic plate. Electron tracks in emulsions were reported from the University of Montreal in 1946, but the new Eastman tracks, first obtained in the company's laboratory at Harrow, England, and later in Rochester, N.Y., are long enough to remove all doubt as to their identity.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 8 -- The Redmen of St. John's kept alive their hopes for a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference championship today with a 13-inning, 8 to 7 victory over Hofstra.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- More than a million Federal employes are due for another rise -- they think. The House and Senate have voted for it, but the trouble is they have not voted for the same bill.

A Pan American Airways Constellation made a skid landing early today while coming into LaGuardia Field with a small fire in its cockpit and slipped into shallow water in Bowery Bay, slightly injuring two of four crew members who had been making a routine night training flight without passengers.

Your two-page feature, "What Is Liberalism?," is most heartening as evidence that the political climate in the United States isn't as bad as painted, or rather, smeared. Of the six Presidential aspirants, including the present White House incumbent, who contributed their answers to your timely query, only one is on the other side of the fence.

E.N. DILWORTH has felt proud to point out [last Sunday] the inadequacy of your critic's judgment of O'Neill. Because Mr. Atkinson declares that O'Neill's chief virtue lies in his ability to convey vitality and not in specific ideas or stylist prose, Mr. Dilworth boldly sets out to crush your critic and through him O'Neill by introducing cockroaches and children and football players with vitality.

The investigation of professionalism among players in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference yesterday revealed that City College, "acting on information supplied by another member of the Conference," had dropped two men from its varsity roster.
PARIS, May 8 -- There is scant possibility that the five-power military alliance of Brussels will be expanded to include Italy for many months to come.
ATHENS, May 8 (AP) -- Constantine Rentis, Minister of Public Order, said today that halting the executions of prisoners by the Greek Government would be an admission that "terrorism" paid.

THE theme of this study is that it is possible to have a planned, managed economy, founded on free enterprise and democratically controlled. This would require periodic surveys of our needs, on the one hand, and our resources and productive facilities on the other.

Predictions that the end of the war would see the disappearance of business in this country in "melee" or small diamonds under one-fifth of a carat have proved baseless, Joseph Baumgold, secretary of Baumgold Brothers, Inc., largest diamond cutters in the world, said at the week's end.
Retail activity was high last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Coat, lingerie and accessory departments were particularly active.
IN Hollywood there are two classes, men with dreams and men with money. Mutually exclusive as the classes may be miscegenation is necessary to produce a motion picture.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 8 -- The Yale nine fought an uphill battle today to defeat the University of Pennsylvania, 5 -- 2, before a chilled crowd of 1,200 at Yale Field.

CAMBRIDGE, May 8 -- In a race rowed completely in the dark, Yale's eight defeated the Massachusetts Institute of Technology crew by four lengths on the Charles River tonight. Yale's junior varsity and freshmen defeated their M.I.T. opposite numbers to make it a clean sweep for the Elis.

THE last words you hear in the recording of Brooklyn Baseball Cantata (Victor, two ten-inch disks) are, "Any similarity to characters living or dead is purely coincidental." Now, who would take offense at the words and music of this cantata?

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 8 -- Army cleaned up in three major sports events today to dispel the general gloom occasioned by chilly, sullen weather which held to a skimpy, shivering handful the usual gay throng of Saturday visitors to the Military Academy.

The only solution for the impending rail strike is not to postpone it but to prevent it. The crisis is near. The Government must meet it firmly. The three unions which threaten to tie this nation into an industrial knot must be made to yield to the voice of reason, as all the other unions working for our railroads have done.

Dwight David Eisenhower moved into a new headquarters last week -- a four-story twenty-two-room house at 60 Morningside Drive, New York City, home of the president of Columbia University. (On June 7 he will take up his duties as president.)

Robert Worker's "Mapmakers' Nightmare" tells of the difficulties which result when one government does not accept the maps of another. The example given is Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, whose incorporation into the U.S.S.R. the United States does not now recognize.

FOR this exciting tale of pre-history Mrs. Rienow has chosen that point in time when the Cro-Magnon man was in the ascendancy, when Neanderthal man was making his last stand in a world which had outgrown him.

NEAR the close of the week it was granted, of course, that a railroad shutdown would paralyze business. The weight of opinion, therefore was on the side that no such thing would happen. And developments have justified this idea.

Analysis of bids received by the New York Quartermaster Purchasing Office in the last thirty days indicates a clear-cut willingness by the great majority of suppliers to take Army business. Total bids received exceed the directive quantity listed in the QM's invitations by 100 to 1700 per cent on items such as foods, cotton textiles, jackets, trousers, shoes, underwear, socks, buckles and ornaments, it was pointed out last week.
MILWAUKEE, May 8 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, said tonight he doubts that it would be wise to ban the Communist party.

THIS novel is the life story of Wally Howard, a weakling in body and spirit He has four brothers, all older than he and all taller, stronger and handsomer. They take delight in ridiculing Wally for his timidity and innocence. The worst of the four is Henry, who is nearest to Wally in age.

MADISON, Wis. -- The tourist, whose spending makes tourism the third largest industry in Wisconsin, will be especially welcome -- and entertained -- this spring and fall, for this is the state's centennial year. Wisconsin's 3,500 resorts and fishing camps are busy sprucing up and adding historical exhibits to their normal attractions -- scenery, beautified lakes and big wall-eyed pike.

BALTIMORE, May 8 -- Over the same track and under similar conditions that brought him victory in the Pimlico Special last fall, the Calumet Farm's Fervent galloped home first in the Dixie Handicap today.

Although labor has again become the major national problem, particularly in the railroad field, it was of minor importance as a stock market influence last week. While strikes and potential strikes continue to becloud the near-term outlook, financial markets, following
Cotton features on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated over a moderate range yesterday and closed 10 to 28 points net higher.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 8 -- Princeton University's varsity track team turned the tables on Cornell for the first time since 1942 in Palmer Stadium today. The Tigers won, 76 -- 64, despite Paul Robeson Jr.'s record-breaking performance in the high jump for the Big Red.

If an apple blossom is like a wild rose in miniature, it is no accident, but rather a kinship of the kind which links many strange cousins. The rose, the apple, the pear, the chokecherry, even the shadbush, all belong to the same botanical family. And if one wishes for more thorny kin, add the hawthorns in all their variations.

THE National Road (once called the Cumberland Road and usually referred to now as U.S. 40) is one of probably the most famous American highways. Begun about 1807 from a starting point at Cumberland, Md., it slowly extended its sinuous and rough surface through a corner of Pennsylvania and across what is now the West Virginia corridor to Wheeling.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics pulled the first triple play of the 1948 major league baseball season today and retained their slim first-place lead by walloping the Chicago White Sox, 16 -- 1.

Holders of substantial amounts of preferred and common stocks of the Commonwealth Southern Corporation yesterday submitted a compromise list of amendments to the plan filed by the corporation with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 8 -- Herman J. Abs and Otto Schniewind, former leading banking officials during the Nazi regime, have been ruled out as nominees to the presidency and chairman of the board, respectively, of the trizonal bank.
LONDON, May 8 -- Britain's prospective Olympic rowing crew split today over differences in rowing style.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 8 -- John Moran, an electrical engineer from Indianapolis who has been shooting at clay disks since 1940 but who has hunted with bird dogs for over thirty years, captured the 200-target singles crown today as the second day of competition in the thirty-ninth annual amateur trapshooting championships of America was held at Travers Island.

MOMO'S red-gold Lhasa terrier came to her by a miracle, an answer to persistent prayer. Only a miracle could give the high-bred Pempa, prince of dogs, to the daughter of a humble Tibetan mail-carrier. When a thieving trader stole Pempa and carried him off to India, Momo supplemented her faith by works and confidently started off to recover him.

Gen. Douglas MacArthur believes that the increasing interest of women in politics is one of the most encouraging features of contemporary American life, he declared in a message received yesterday by Mrs. Louis J. Ehret of 1155 Park Avenue, chairman of the Women's Committee of Independent Citizens for MacArthur.

FOR THIS WEEK: Now that apple trees have reached the flowering stage, it is safe to sow all kinds of flower seed outdoors. . . . Tent caterpillar webs are the size of a folded handkerchief. To get rid of them, spray with DDT. . . . Thin out seedlings so that they have room to develop. Reduce them to a thin line first, then space between the individual ones.
Modern air transport planes were placed on exhibit yesterday at La Guardia Field for inspection by the public and members of the New York section of the Institute of Aeronautical Sciences.

BOSTON, May 8 -- The flurry over Lieut. Gov. Arthur W. Coolidge's complaint that the South was trying to "kidnap" New England's woolen industry has died down, but the problem remains one of considerable importance to this area.

LONDON, May 8 -- The problems confronting the representatives of Great Britain, France, the United States, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, now meeting in London to consider the future of Germany, are both economic and political.

In his article, "The Civil Rights as Seen in the South," Hodding Carter expresses the opinion that my speaking in Atlanta "of Churchill and England in the same breath with Hitler and Mussolini * * * may be mildly described as meaningful, especially since there was no accompanying denunciation of Stalin."

For the past twelve months the American economy has been running generally smoothly and at high speed. Nearly 60,000,000 people, more than ever before in peacetime, have jobs. Industry is producing at the record rate of $240 billion a year. There has been relatively little open strife between labor and management -- except in the coal industry.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 8 -- Setting the pace in both the third and fourth rounds today, Herman Barron of Fenway moved out ahead of the field going into the final stage of the Goodall round-robin with a substantial margin of seventeen points.

THERE are probably more ways of defining that one little pesky word, art, than there are recipes for combining sugar, ice, bourbon and mint. And it plainly is just as dangerous to be dogmatic about what it means as it is to tell any South'n gentleman how a proper mint julep should be made.

Dean Dixon, 33-year-old Negro conductor has been selected by Columbia University as the recipient of its 1948 Alice M. Ditson $1,000 award for American conductor who has rendered distinguished services to American music.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 8 -- Harold E. Stassen declared here tonight that the United States should move with confidence and determination "into the offensive in the economic and ideological clash with materialistis communism."

Msgr. John L. Belford, for the past forty-three years pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity, Classon Avenue and Madison Street, Brooklyn, will celebrate the sixtieth anniversary of his ordination as a priest this month.

Just as in Elizabethan days hopeful young men would "come up" to London with a play or a sheaf of madrigals concealed about their persons, so for decades have aspiring youths of this country flocked to New York with their embryonic literary wares, their aspirations and their hopes.
The United States Navy is tracking hurricanes in the Caribbean Sea with seismographs. This procedure is an outgrowth of our needs in wartime when it was difficult to obtain adequate weather data.

PARIS, May 8 -- Experts of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation completed today their first technical job and announced the dispatch of questionnaires on which the member Governments will return their estimates of needs and resources for the third quarter of 1948 by May 22.

BOPPET was a puppy who wanted a child -- for he was so full of play that he tired out all the other animals in the pet-shop. When a lonesome old lady took him home to her quiet old house he tired her out, too, and her old cat, the old mouse, even the old goldfish.

MUSIC under the stars is an American summer institution. This year the Essex County Symphony Society's stadium concerts in Newark are being discontinued, but most of the other series throughout the country will soon be going strong.
SEOUL, Sunday, May 9 (AP) -- Communist terrorism, arson and murder, stepped up in preparation for tomorrow's election, hit South Korea this week-end, as expected.

A BANNER season is forecast for boating enthusiasts this summer in and around New York, whether their preference is sail, motor or manpowered craft. Rentals and general operating expenses will be comparatively modest.
