HERE is Dad's and Mom's answer to a prayer: a book on good manners for the teen-age boy who is in high school or about to enter college. It is sensible and witty and highly entertaining; furthermore, it's as up-to-the-minute as the latest Louis Prima live disk.
WHENEVER a sensational flower is discovered, we feel we must share it with other gardeners. Such a discovery is a new bright red tulip, Marie Nicholson.

SEVERAL months ago in these pages while commemorating the twenty-fifth anniversary of Marcel Proust's death. I passed in review the voluminous literature devoted to his work in French and English and attempted to evaluate his present position.

ONE of the chief hindrances to decent education in America today is the overloading of our schools by placing on their shoulders responsibilities which in other times and other countries have as a matter of course been assumed by the home.

BOSTON, May 8 -- Diversion of tax funds to the support of private and "sectarian" schools was "unalterably" opposed here today by the Methodist Church at the closing session of its quadrennial general conference. Such a "scattering progress," the conference declared, "would in a short time destroy the American public school system and weaken the foundations of national unity."

THE Detroit Tigers were in town briefly last week and the most articulate of all the Bengals is Billy Evans, the reformed umpire who now serves as Tiger general manager. Somehow or other Billy got to talking about baseball jockeys with H.G. Salsinger, the gracious gentleman who must be the original inhabitant of the Detroit press box, and this shameless eavesdropper has no compunctions about reporting on their conversation.

THE New Dance Group, which has given several highly stimulating festivals of modern dance in the past, will give another one May 23-27 at the Mansfield Theatre, opening with a matinee on Sunday the 23d. Soloists and groups who will appear are the Jane Dudley-Sophie Maslow-William Bales Trio, Jean Erdman and her company, Pearl Primus and her company, Hadassah, Eve Gentry, Mary Anthony and Joseph Gifford, and the New Dance Group.

MR. MILLIGAN, who as United States District Attorney for the Western District of Missouri sent Tom Pendergast and some of his henchmen to jail, has written an earnest, impassioned and factual account of the rise, fall and revival of the most notorious political machine in our recent history.

ATHENS, May 8 (Reuters) -- Eighteen thousand Greek Communists and Communist sympathizers are in prison or in exile, according to official figures issued here by the Ministry of Justice and the ministry of public order. The figures are in a statement prepared by the late Justice Minister Ladas for the foreign press.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Ominous signs of a possible strike wave appeared on the labor front horizon this week. Despite their gravity they did not seem to indicate a repetition of the record-breaking walkouts of the post-war period.

The International Game Fish Association, an organization with headquarters at the American Museum of Natural History, which records the authentic sports fishing records from all parts of the world, has just issued its latest record sheet and at the same time produced evidence that light tackle fishing definitely is on the upswing.

THE city garden, where annuals compete with long shadows cast by tall buildings, is quite different from a garden in the country where the air is fresh and the sunshine unobstructed. Yet by trial and error the urban gardener discovers which plants will survive in town under trying conditions.

An exhibition designed to show how the writings of the great men of ancient Greece have been handed down through the centuries to our own time opens tomorrow in the Pierpont Morgan Library, 33 East Thirty-sixth Street.

With a little more than one month to go before the Republican convention, the nomination race seems pretty much a wide open affair. The Big Three contenders -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York, Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio -- are still much in the race.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, May 8 (UP) -- The University of Puerto Rico was closed today for the remainder of the current term after a week of demonstrations by striking Nationalist students. Thirty-five students have been arrested.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 8 -- Ron Burton pitched three-hit ball today as Navy defeated Cornell, 12 -- 2, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game. Burton worked easily despite freezing weather and set Cornell down in order the last seven innings after yielding all three hits and two runs in the second frame.
The Fordham baseball team won its fourth victory in a row yesterday by defeating Villanova, 8 -- 3, at Fordham Field.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- Lady Luck finally turned her smiles on Johnny Schmitz after frowning on the ace southpaw all spring and he turned in a brilliant whitewashing job as the Cubs beat the Dodgers, 6 -- 0, today to even the curtailed series at one victory each.

CAMP CAMPBELL, Ky., May 8 -- The "Army of Tomorrow" - an army of the skies -- soared 500 miles above the wooded crags of the Great Smokies today to seize and hold an air-strip on the Kentucky-Tennessee border.
BERLIN, May 8 (Reuters) -- Soviet authorities sought today a three-day postponement of the next meeting of the Allied Kommandatura, four-power governing body of Berlin, due for next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- Senator Albert W. Barkley, Democrat, of Kentucky, and Representative Christian Herter, Republican, of Massachusetts, received today the Colliers Congressional awards for distinguished service to the country.

THE English amateur photographer still queues up when he wants to purchase film, can buy only second-hand cameras and is "gasping for color," according to Percy W. Harris, new president of the Royal Photographic Society of Great Britain, on his arrival here last week.

The library of Thomas Bird Mosher, the famous Portland (Me.) publisher of fine books who died in 1923, will be auctioned tomorrow and Tuesday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.
PHILADELPHIA, May 8 -- Pennsylvania defeated the Columbia track and field team on Franklin Field today, 81 2/5 to 57 3/5, despite the valiant efforts of Bill Vessie and Bill Berger, Lion stars.
FRENCH lilacs make the old-fashioned kind, lovely as it is, seem drab by comparison. No matter how small the garden, there should be room for one of these exceptionally beautiful plants.

BEND, Ore., May 8 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey today virtually accused Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota, his opponent in Oregon's Republican Presidential primary, of "inventing" a challenge to debate in order to get back into the state for a third time ahead of schedule.

Jess, the backwoods Sherlock, brings two of his dogs with him, thinking that they may prove useful, which they do.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 -- Navy's Poughkeepsie champion eight, one of the prime favorites in the Olympic sweepstakes, met defeat for the first time of the rowing season today, leaving Cornell as the only unbeaten varsity crew in the east.

An otherwise quiescent segment of the nation's private utility industry, the gas and electric companies in this state, is becoming disturbed over the effect that delayed hearings by the Public Service Commission are having on their financing programs.

MICHAEL SHAYNE'S is fussy about cognac. It has to be the real stuff and properly aged or he can't enjoy drinking it. In the second story in this volume, "A Taste for Cognac," he makes the amazing discovery that a certain saloon is serving rare old French cognac out of bottles bearing California labels.

IT is significant that the best first book of poems to appear since Elizabeth Bishop's "North and South" a year ago should be published by a new publisher. The fact is that the big houses, with few exceptions, no longer publish new poetry.

With steel production and shipments this year running at a record pace and steel requirements for two important programs due to be slashed appreciably, the domestic steel industry is now convinced -- and many Government officials are said to be ready to agree -- that a system of Government controls over distribution of the material will not be necessary.
THE City Gardens Club will hold the second part of its annual tour of Manhattan gardens this Wednesday. Two penthouses and four backyards will be open.

Henry A. Wallace proposed yesterday the adoption of a Constitutional Amendment to end discrimination against women and establishment of a Women's Fair Employment Practices Commission to give women equal working rights with men.

" That fellow makes pitching look easy, doesn't he?" Bucky Harris was talking between games in his clubhouse office at the Stadium yesterday. The graying skipper of the Yankees was grimly paying a compliment to Freddie Hutchinson, who had pitched the Detroit Tigers to victory, 3 to 2, shading Ed Lopat in a pitchers' duel that was enjoyed by 25,246 thoroughly chilled fans.

The American Women's Voluntary Services will be the beneficiary of a buffet dinner and bridge tournament to be held on Thursday night in the Baroque Suite of the Plaza. Proceeds will further the organization's national program of veterans' assistance and community services.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The dispute threatening a strike at 6 A.M. on Tuesday involves three railroad unions and all the Class I railroads.

Columbia's varsity lightweight crew had little trouble with Iona College's 150-pounders yesterday on the Harlem River, winning by three and a half lengths. The Lions' time for the Henley distance of a mile and five-sixteenths was 6:31.1 to Iona's 6:45.

Business and professional women conducting a "help-a-heart campaign raised $14,348 to aid the fight against heart disease, Dr. Charles A.R. Connor, medical director of the American Heart Association, announced yesterday. Thirty-five affiliated clubs of the Business and Professional Women's Clubs of New York State Inc., participated under the chairmanship of Mrs. Vera Watson Schmidt of Tarrytown.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The House Armed Services Committee, maintained today that a bolstering of the nation's military strength through a peace-time draft had been made imperative by the "new and ominous" possibility that "the Soviet Union may now be willing to risk a showdown" with the United States.

ONE of the prime enigmas of the movie "whodunit" is whodunit first. You can find out from any of the standard histories of motion pictures when the first Western or the first spectacle or the first musical was produced.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Eric Johnston, chairman of the National Council on Family Life, today asked delegates from 125 local organizations to pool their efforts, on their return home, through community councils on family life.
Robert Wronker's article on the troubles encountered by mapmakers nowadays recalled similar difficulties while prospering in Colorado many years ago.

LONDON, May 8 -- In the course of a two-day debate on foreign affairs in the House of Commons this week Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin made a striking statement that was all the more striking for being true.

As means of combating juvenile delinquency, participation in sports and the elimination of prejudices that prevent widespread enjoyment of community activities were suggested by junior high school pupils who took part yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.

PERHAPS Mr. Mailer should not be damned for attempting to reduce by frontal assault what better writers have failed to win by infiltration. "The Naked and the Dead" -- the story of an imaginary battle in the Pacific -- trumpets his dusty answer to the brutality of modern war.

Retailers maintained their sales volume last week by offering promotions of "special value" seasonal merchandise, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. It was generally expected, the report continued, that fall and winter business will be good if special value promotions continue to draw, consumer response.

LAS VEGAS, Nev. -- The pseudo-Old Western atmosphere of Las Vegas, with its gambling and bars and the night clubs, headline entertainers and big-name bands has been publicized to the point that many vacationists are unaware this is the ideal headquarters for the outdoorsman and the sightseer on a holiday.

The United States Maccabi's annual Jewish festival, "Sports on Parade" took place last night at the St. Nicholas Arena with 2,000 on hand. A brief memorial service for the late Benny Leonard was held in the same ring where the unbeaten lightweight boxing champion died a little more than a year ago while refereeing a bout.
JERUSALEM, May 8 -- Peace of a kind returned to Jerusalem at noon today, when the cease-fire agreed to by the Jews and Arabs went into effect.

JOHN L. SULLIVAN, Secretary of the Navy, testified before the Deficiency Subcommittee of the Senate Appropriations Committee a few days ago that "Naval aviation is the spearhead around which today's Navy is built."

Patrolman Bernard Jennings, a police hero who had been attached to the West Twentieth Street police station, was found dead at 1:30 A.M. yesterday in the IRT subway station at Seventh Avenue and Fourteenth Street.

Lyle F. Watts, chief of the United States Forest Service, said in his 1947 report to the Secretary of Agriculture that a reappraisal of the forest situation in this country showed that saw timber was being taken from our forests one and a half times as fast as it was being replaced by growth.

The passage of the Revenue Act of 1948, over the President's veto was a great victory for the cause of uniformity of the taxation of income throughout the United States. Those who devoted themselves to the task of unifying the effect of income tax law in its application to family incomes deserve recognition.

IF asked to guess the oldest program on the air, many listeners no doubt would think of Amos 'n' Andy or the Cities Service Hour. Actually, the honor falls to a strictly religious program -- the National Radio Pulpit, which today starts its twenty-sixth year on NBC.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 8 (AP) -- Mrs. E.K. Haggerty's Rampart turned back William G. Helis' highly regarded Rippey by a half-length margin in today's $15,000 added Valley Forge Handicap at Garden State Park. Another half-length back Allan T. Hurff's Senoril was third in the field of ten.

PEACH trees are displaying their deep pink flowers now. In home gardens memorable spring pictures are made by the graceful, color-laden branches in combination with plantings of narcissus and early tulips.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- In a new challenge to Senator Robert A. Taft, Harold E. Stassen announced his determination today to win the support of a majority of the South's delegates to the Republican National Convention.

" THE Princess and the Vagabond," being produced this week by the Hartt Opera Guild in Hartford, is my second opera. Having wearied from looking for a performance for my first opera, "Homo Sum," the story of why I wrote the second may prove of interest to music lovers because it points the road, albeit a thorny one, that American opera may travel.

LEXINGTON, Ky. -- Kentucky is getting mountain-laurel conscious for the first time since 1941, and the early blossoming of the laurel is only partly responsible. The main reason is the revival of the annual Kentucky mountain laurel festival which the war interrupted.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Republicans of the Senate, the critical arena, were unable this week, as they had been last week, to advance their first choice in the so- called civil rights program, the anti-lynching bill.

In its now historic report, "To Secure These Rights," the President's Committee on Civil Rights made fifty-four recommendations for action by Government and private groups. The overwhelming majority of these recommendations called for Federal legislative or executive action.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- Larry Doby, Cleveland's Negro outfielder, smashed a 450-foot homer today in the eighth inning to help the Indians score a 6-1 victory over Washington.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- In the month since Congress voted $5,300,000,000 for starting the European Recovery Program and turned it over to Paul G. Hoffman, the Economic Cooperation Administration has spent $110,000,000 for food, fuel and fertilizer for delivery to participating nations.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 9 (AP) -- Erwin (Bob) Porterfield, Newark's sensational rookie righthander, racked up his third consecutiveh)0*0*0*ishutout victory today when he stopped the Rochester Red Wings on three hits, 6 -- 0. The Wings came back to win the abbreviated nightcap, 8 -- 3.

In Birmingham Senator Taylor was scheduled to speak to a youth assembly in a Negro church. Some white youths were present. The police insisted that the church put up signs at two doors, such as the law demands shall be put up in public places.

Trade association supporters of the O'Hara bill, which would compel the Federal Trade Commission to try its cases in the courts, declared over the week-end that their efforts can be classed as a "firstround" victory.

Although he held A 1-1 tie in their return match with Brookhattan at Sterling Oval, the Kearny Americans finished first in the Lewis Cup competition, sponsored by the American Soccer League, yesterday.
AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, May 9 (Reuter) -- Excerpts from Winston Churchill's speech today follow:

Among this week's art events is the long-awaited Pierre Bonnard retrospective exhibition which comes to the Museum of Modern Art on Wednesday from Cleveland, where the first American showing in tribute to the modern French master was held.

Wholesale markets here were quiet last week while most apparel manufacturers prepared their fall lines for openings which are scheduled to take place shortly, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

SILVER CITY, Calif., May 9 -Irene, the fashion designer, puts emphasis on back-dip skirts for fall. Tailored suits retain the slim, slashed, even line but dresses for day and evening almost all have a downward curve to the back.

Palestine is a little country with less than one-tenth of 1 per cent of the world's population. Its inhabitants, Jews, Arabs and Christians, are not more than one-third the number of those of Jewish faith alone who were butchered by Hitler. If we measured events solely by the masses of men and women directly affected China would be two hundred and fifty times as important as Palestine, India two hundred times as important.

ABOARD U.S.S. SAIPAN, off Block Island, May 6 (Delayed for Navy release) -- In a rough open sea naval aviation today answered affirmatively most of the questions that have been raised as to the operability of jet aircraft from carriers.

Winners 0f the four. teen Ingersollart prizes in the nation-widecontest sponsored by ScholasticMagazines were announced yesterday.More than 125,000 junior andsenior high school students participatedin the competition.

While the attention of the country is naturally turned to the question whetherh)0*0*0*iCongress will appropriate funds necessary for national security through air power, the civil airlines continue to make important strides in service and in safety. Pan American-Grace Airways has just inaugurated its express flight "El Inter Americano," which links Miami and Buenos Aires in the space of a single day and night.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Under a dripping sky the Giants' triumphant sweep through the West skidded sharply off course today as two unfortunate circumstances combined to give Cholly Grimm's Cubs the opener of a three-game series, 2 to 0.
PITTSBURGH, May 9 -- Today's double-header, witnessed by 40,797 fans, many of them on the playing field at Forbes Field, was a sorry affair, so far as pitching went.

Another effort is about to be made to purge the securities laws of certain unworkable requirements which have operated to frustrate the dissemination of information among investors and to stultify the orderly consummation of transactions in securities.
PITTSBURGH, May 9 -- The steel ingot rate last week advanced again as steel companies tried to regain production levels in effect before the coal strike in March.

ALTHOUGH it was the U-boat menace from which we suffered most and ran the greatest risks, the attack on our ocean commerce by surface raiders, would have been even more formidable could it have been sustained. The three German pocket battleships permitted by the Treaty of Versailles had been designed with profound thought as commercedestroyers.

A gallant adventure and in the sum of it a noble accomplishment was the performance yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, by Serge Koussevitzky and the chorus and orchestra of the Juilliard School.

The tumultuous meeting of the first Italian Parliament since Mussolini consolidated his seizure of the Government proved a strange contrast to the calm which prevails in the rest of the nation. At the same time it was a demonstration that the Communists, overwhelmed by huge opposition majorities in both houses, have lost their power to do more than make loud and disagreeable noises.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 9 -- Concentrating at the local level, the nation's prohibitionists have established more dry territory inh)0*0*0*ithis country than before prohibition, Ralph P. Kettering of Chicago, director of the anti-dry campaign of the National Beer Wholesalers Association of America, reported tonight.
ATHENS, May 9 (AP) -- Greek Army troops engaged the Communist-led guerrillas today in heavy fighting in western Mecedonia, a General Staff communique said.
h)0*0*0*iOPRAGUE, May 9 -- Parliament adopted today a new Constitution, which Communist speakers said would pattern Czechoslovakia after Russia.

Applicants for enrollment in the New York University College of Dentistry now are required to submit to a series of psychology and aptitude tests to determine whether they are physically and mentally equipped to become practicing dentists, it was announced yesterday.

Green-uniformed Girl Scouts and trim little Brownies, members of troops that meet in Protestant Episcopal Churches in New York and Westchester, took part yesterday in a special Girl Scouts' service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Charges that cartels bring high prices to consumers and foster inefficiency by protecting high-cost producers are among those contained in a forthcoming report by the Twentieth Century Fund, advance portions of which were made public over the week-end by Evans Clark, executive director.

Recent scattered instances where manufacturers have begun packaging such articles as bedding, clothing, toys and hardware have ceased to indicate merely a trend, and are spurring other companies to meet the competition this "added attraction" has for retailer and consumer dollars.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that the most complete atomic energy exhibit ever assembled would play a dominant role in the city's Golden Anniversary Exposition to be held in Grand Central Palace between Aug. 23 and Sept. 19.

Rutgers Presbyterian Church, Seventy-third Street and Broadway, opened a week-long celebration of its sequicentennial yesterday at its morning service. Dr. Wilbur LaRoe Jr., Washington lawyer and moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, delivered the morning sermon.

Mikhail Botvinnik, pride of Soviet chess devotees, fulfilled their expectations yesterday by gaining the championship of the world as a result of play in the twenty-second round of the title tournament at the Hall of Columns in Moscow, according to a report from the Russian capital.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 9 -Howard Hughes will take over the block of RKO stock (estimated at 929,000 shares) owned by Floyd Odlum's Atlas Corporation unless Odlum has obtained a better offer than Hughes reported $9,000,000 bid by tomorrow, it was learned today from a source close to Hughes.

Three days of intensive White House effort at mediation by John R. Steelman, the President's personal representative,h)0*0*0*ihas failed to break the deadlock in the wage dispute between the railroad unions and management. In the absence of some last-minute development today which might alter the course of events, the 150,000 union members affected will go on strike at 6 o'clock tomorrow morning.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 9 -- The British Government has informed the United Nations Palestine Commission that it wants assurances regarding the protection of British economic interests in Palestine, including the oil pipeline from Iraq to Haifa, after the termination of the British mandate next Saturday.

PEIPING, May 9 -- Eighteen different grades of flour and more than three million experts are making life complicated for the rationing boards that are distributing supplies here under the interim $45,000,000 American relief program.
Your editorial of May 2, "South Pacific Commission," could be considered rather less than fair to Prof. Felix M. Keesing, recently appointed to represent the United States in the commission.
MOLINE, Ill., May 9 (AP) -- Murray Wier, Iowa's All-America basketball player, today signed a oneyear contract to play with the Tri-City Black Hawks of Moline, Bryan Grafton, club president, said.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 9 -- One Jew has died here of injuries received when three were beaten by a mob on Thursday as a result of bad feeling aroused by the Palestine situation. Authorities denied the victim had died but said that his condition was critical.

The Young People's Concerts Committee of the PhilharmonicSymphony Society of New York announced yesterday that its third annual auditions had been won by Elizabeth Rich, 16-year-old New York pianist, and Diana Regina Steiner, 15, Philadelphia violinist.

OBERLIN, Ohio, May 9 (AP) -Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan for President and Senator Raymond E. Baldwin of Connecticut for Vice President were the choices today of the twentysecond Oberlin College mock Republican convention.

LONDON, May 9--The SundayDispatch, which has a circulationof more than 2,000,000, got hotunder the collar today about theAmericans Who are bringing "stuntmidget car" racing to the Britishwhile "Britain's own genuinesports such as speedway racingand greyhound racing are all stillsavagely shacklec~ by the government's mid-week ban on sports."

The Zionist Organization of America opened yesterday its "Liberation Week" throughout the country with emphasis on the enrollment of greater numbers of American Jews in the organization in support of the Jewish state in Palestine.

Twenty thousand girls of the Archdiocesan Union of Sodalities of the Immaculate Conception of the Blessed Virgin Mary from the ten counties of the New York Roman Catholic Archdiocese participated yesterday in the first combined observance of World Sodality Sunday.

The Experimental Theatre showed that its heart was in the right place by giving the dance a share in its final production of the season, "Ballet Ballads," which opened at Maxine Elliott's Theatre last night. It was a gesture perhaps more kindly than wise, forh) 0*0*0*ithere proved to be very little the dance could do under the circumstances.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced last night it had notified Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, that it was opposed to shifting to Washington at this time negotiations with the American Union of Telephone Workers, CIO, whose contract with the company expired Saturday.

LONDON, May 9 -- The sixpower conference on Western Germany enters its last week of negotiations tomorrow. France and the United States have reached a virtual deadlock over many details of the solutions being sought for a German federal government and for control of the Ruhr economy.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 9 -- Former Postmaster General James A. Farley paid a Mother's Day tribute here today at the annual communion breakfast of the Holy Name Society in the auditorium of the parochial school of the Church of the Blessed Sacrament.

The National Marine Exposition returns, to New York City on May 17 for a six-day showing at Grand Central Palace, closing on Maritime Day. The show will include a hundred exhibits from virtually every phase of the nation's maritime industry.

A cab driver, tentatively identified as William Willis, 50 years old, of 326 East 155th Street, the Bronx, was found dead behind the wheel of his cab early yesterday morning with a bullet hole in his right cheek. The cab was in front of 3 West 129th Street when the murder was discovered by another cab driver at 6:40 A.M.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Prices of corn averaged higher last week on the Board of Trade, with May leading, but the aggregate trade was relatively light and the market easily influenced by professional operations. Country offerings of cash corn remain comparatively light, but apparently are ample for the demand, as cash corn premiums eased somewhat compared with May late last week, number 2 yellow being quoted around 9 cents a bushel over the future.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The Senators put three hits together in the first inning today for as many runs and defeated the Browns, 3 -- 1.

Although New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, will be opened in eighty days, the Van Wyck Expressway, main traffic link between mid-Manhattan and the field, will not be completed for at least eighteen months, it was reported yesterday.

LONDON, May 9 -- The Clarence Derwent actors award, made by the president of American Equity for the best supporting performance of the year, went today to Jessica Spencer for her performance in the play, "Royal Circle," and to Colin Gordon for his part in "The Happiest Days of Our Lives."

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 9 -- Having weathered pelting rainh)0*0*0*iduring the first session and high winds in the second, the field in the three-day amateur trapshooting championships of America finally was rewarded with a sunny day as the thirty-ninth annual competition came to a close at Travers Island today.

Your editorial "South Pacific Commission," which appeared in THE TIMES on May 2, is a remarkable example of restraint in commenting on an odorous example of "palace politics" in the matter of appointments.

SIAN, China, May 9 -- The Communists have accompanied theirh)0*0*0*irecent offensive into west central Shensi with radio propaganda from their north Shensi station. They are emphasizing a policy of moderation in dealing with the peoples of newly conquered areas.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Enrollment increases in elementary schools and colleges, and attempts to improve the economic status of teachers were among the outstanding developments in education in the United States last year, according to the Encyclopedia Britannica's Book of the Year.

" The Rape of Poland: Pattern of Soviet Conquest," an autobiography by Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, has been scheduled for October publication by Whittlesey House. Mr. Mikolajczyk, formerly Prime Minister of the Polish Governmentin-Exile, Deputy Prime Minister of the Provisional Polish Government in Warsaw and Chairman of the Polish Peasant Party, also tells of Poland's struggles from 1939 to 1947.

A "battle of the beverages" will enliven the revival of competitive advertising this summer, key marketing and advertising observers predicted last week. Increased consumption of colas and other soft drinks has aroused tea, coffee and beer makers to prepare an offensive with bigger ad plans, it was stated.

The college in Hillman, Minn., for which Gen. Jonas Cernius, former Premier of Lithuania, has been engaged to teach, appeared last night still to be pretty much on paper. The general was found on Friday working as a $30-a-week machinist in Newark, N.J.
Three new films, including an importation from France, are slated to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:
The Yankees matched their season's high in home-run production at the Stadium yesterday before 33,059 fans while Frank Shea whitewashed the White Sox, 8 -- 0.

I would like to talk to you about several hundred young friends of mine. Some of them may be known to you, too, for they come from hundreds of neighborhoods throughout our great city, including, perhaps, the one in which you live.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 9 -- A message of hope was addressed today by Winston Churchill to the "broad proletarian masses" when he repeated his call for a united Europe.

Contrasting the strict regulation of customs brokers with the freedom enjoyed by forwarders of foreign freight, some of whom "engage in questionable practices," Martin A. Kerner, president of the Customs Brokers and Forwarders Association of America, Inc., yesterday urged the policing of the forwarding industry as a means of elevating its professional level.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 (AP) -The amazing Athletics pounded out a pair of victories over the Tigers today, 10 -- 5 and 5 -- 3, to run their consecutive victory streak to eight, longest for the Mackmen. since their last pennant-winning year of 1931.

Roulette wheels and all kinds of lotteries will be completely eliminated, as "money-raisers" by churches and organizations of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York if the Bronx Convocation has its ay at the 165th convention of the diocese tomorrow at thc Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
MOSCOW, May 9 (AP) -- The Soviet Supreme Court has ruled that Russian wives can sue their husbands for alimony and division of property without suing for divorce.

Beginning today sales headquarters for the War Assets Administration will be at its new customer service center in the Bronx, Eastchester Road at Haswell Street, it was announced over the week-end by John R. Campbell, regional director. Thirteen new sales programs covering $8,217,000 worth of goods are scheduled within the next six weeks in addition to those previously listed, he said.

The divorce problem has become so great in this country that it is unsettling the basic foundation of American life, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, said in his sermon yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 -The possibility of affiliation of the independent Marine Firemen, Oilers, Watertenders and Wipers with the American Federation of Labor or the Congress of Industrial Organizations before the end of this year was forseen today by Vincent J. Malone, president of the union.

SHAWNEE ON DELAWARE, Pa., May 9 -- With an assurance by Dean Richard S. Cox of the Philadelphia Textile Institute that motor transportation home would be made available to all in the event of a railroad strike, speakers and members attending the Third National Textile Seminar to be held May 10 to 14th inclusive, began arriving here today.
LONDON, May 9 -- Great Britain's steel industry broke its own production record for the fourth month in succession, it was announced today by the British Iron and Steel Federation.

IT had seemed for the longest while that the statistical part of football was quite elemental, such as eleven men on a side and a series of four downs to gain ten yards. But that was before Hugh (Shorty) Ray went to work on the subject. He's the Technical Adviser to the National Football League and is the darndest figure filbert you ever did see, a real nut on the topic.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 9 -- Miss Jean Cochrane's bay gelding My Chance, with a splendidh)0*0*0*ishowing all through the second day's program, annexed the working hunter championship at the annual spring horse show staged by the Secor Farms Riding Club this evening.

WASHINGTON, Monday, May 10 -- It became evident early this morning that efforts to avert the nationwide railroad strike were still unavailing. The walkout is scheduled for tomorrow at 6 A.M., standard time.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 9 -- Plans for establishment of a $1,000,000 union health center in Manhattan were announced here today by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO, and the New York Clothing Manufacturers Exchange. The announcement was made on the eve of the opening tomorrow of the union's sixteenth biennial convention.

PARIS, May 9 -- Representatives of Paul G. Hoffman in this city, according to authoritative circles, have been informed of the monetary plans formed in Brussels by the Finance Ministers of France, Great Britain, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg and their experts.

JERUSALEM, May 9 -- Commandos and sappers of the Palmach, striking force of the Haganah, went into action early today to clear the 200-yard-long, threefoot-high Arab road block at Bab el Wad that has obstructed the road from Tel Aviv to Jewish Jerusalem for nineteen days.
READING, Pa., May 9 -- Nominated without opposition, Norman Thomas, veteran political campaigner, today became the Socialist party's Presidential candidate for a sixth consecutive time.

Legislation authorizing the Bureau of the Census to combine its scheduled 1948 canvass of manufacturing with one on business and distribution is in danger of being so long bottled up in Congress that the much-needed data will not be available until 1950.

Our scout, who had not Toward been able to get much beyond the Battery when he made his last report, has been exploring the perimeter of our city, and he is impressed by the fact that it is, indeed, a greater city -and convinced that Little Old New York, which was contained by Manhattan Island, is a very small part of it.

BERLIN, May 9 (AP) -- The Russians today dismantled an automobile aid station surrendered by the British on the motor highway linking Berlin with western Germany. A similar station abandoned by the Americans, at Russian request, also is expected to be wrecked.
BEND, Ore., May 9 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York set forth today a ten-point program for the conservation and development of the natural resources of the West.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UP) -- A special committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce urged today that the United States withhold its approval of the Havana Charter for an International Trade Organization and seek its renegotiation.
PARIS, May 9 -- Reports are current in diplomatic circles here that Moscow is contemplating incorporating Rumania into the Soviet Union as an independent Soviet republic.

BOSTON, May 9 (AP) -- Cleveland's Indians took over the American League lead today by twice defeating the Red Sox, 4 -- 1, in ten innings and 9 -- 5, before 34,298 fans. Ken Keltner clouted three home runs for the winners, two in the opener, the second starting off the visitors' tenth inning three-run victory rally.

VLADIMIR ULIANOV was born in Simbiosk on the Volga in 1870. He was the son of a mathematics teacher and school inspector, one of six children. His childhood was unusually happy. He was a good student, with an "exemplary" record in the eyes of his teachers. But in 1887, when young Vladimir was only 16, his elder brother, Alexander, whom he adored, was hanged for his part in a conspiracy to assassinate the Czar.

W. Averell Harriman, ambassador-at-large and special representative of the Economic Cooperation Administration, expressed confidence in the European Recovery Program yesterday afternoon at La Guardia Field as he boarded a Pan American World Airways Constellation.

TOKYO, May 9 -- The annular eclipse of the sun was successfully observed today in northern Japan. Clear weather with only light scattered clouds enabled American and Japanese scientists to make observations as well as detailed photographich)0*0*0*iand motion picture records at both the Tokyo Astronomical Observatory and on the little island of Rebun off the coast of Hokkaido.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- A major attack on the school-health problem is strongly advocated in a report just prepared for publication by the maternal and childhealth section of the recent National Health Assembly.
Mother's Day was observed yesterday at simple home gatherings and large public celebrations.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Lard futures averaged slightly higher on the Board of Trade last week. Part of the strength came from sympathy with cottonseed oil, which at one time was quoted at a premium of about 18 cents a pound over loose lard, an almost unheard-of difference.

Cotton prices in the domestic market continued to move irregularly last week. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 33 to up 84 points from the closing level of the previous week.

Since "David's Crown" is less spectacular than "The Dybbuk," it is likely to seem less remarkable to New Yorkers, many of whom, it is said, do not understand Hebrew. It is a dramatization of Old Testament history, written by the seventeenth-century poet, Pedro Calderon de la Barca, translated into Hebrew by I. Lamdau and recently introduced into the Habimah repertory.

BERLIN, May 9 -- The Russians today told the Germans that the United States not only was a great world enemy of peace, freedom and democracy but also that it had entered World War II for the specific purpose of breaking the hold of Germany and Japan on the principal world markets grabbing those markets for itself.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during May 1 to 7 are given in the appended tabulation:

The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday an embargo on livestock, poultry and perishable freight to go into effect at one minute before midnight tonight, standard time. It was forced to this action, the company said, "to prevent the needless waste of food which would not reach its destination" if the scheduled nationwide strike is carried through.

JACKSON, Miss., May 9 -- In an action believed to be unprecedented in Southern history, Governor Fielding L. Wright "advised" the Negroes of this state today that if they contemplated eventual social equality and the sharing of school, hotel and restaurant facilities with white persons to "make your home in some state other than Mississippi."

Anne Katz, New York contralto, who formerly sang regularly with the Workmen's Circle Chorus, gave her first local recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. It was an unexcpected pleasure to find so fine a singer this late in the season, for generally at this time the quality drops.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The United States does not have enough physicians to meet all demands likely to be made under a Federal program of compulsory health insurance, a study made by the Brookings Institution said today.

As part of its security loan campaign, the Treasury Department has prepared pamphlets to encourage women to participate either in the payroll savings plan or the bond-a-month program for buying United States Savings Bonds.

It is not by chance that the debate at the Congress at the Hague reaches a level of eloquence unequaled at any recent international conference. It is because the men gathered there are fired by an idea which is more vital, more rooted in real emotion, than anything that has been put forward since the war.

Your May 5 editorial on smoke in New York City is timely and constructive. I would suggest one correction. You say that 50 per cent or more of the coal consumption in 1947 was bituminous coal. You may be right about that; I do not know.
Truck transport from near-by farms will meet most of the fresh fruit and vegetable requirements of the metropolitan area in the event of a railroad strike, trade spokesmen said yesterday.

A protest against proposed changes in the personnel of the New York City Rent Advisory Board that would add three tenant representatives and drop a landlord representative was made yesterday by William E. Russell, general chairman of the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee, who said the switch would "prejudice" the realty owners' request for a general increase in rents.

PARIS, May 9 -- Foreign Minister Bidault told cheering delegates to the Popular Republican party congress in Toulouse today that France would hot abandon her essential claims for security from Germany and said there still were hopes that the Western Allies would reach an accord.

Henry C. Alexander, campaign chairman, announced yesterday a gift of $175,000 by the Consolidated Edison System to the Greater New York Fund's 1948 campaign, the largest single gift ever made to the fund since its inception.

A Navy reserve pilot was lost and another flew home safely with a crumpled wing on his plane after a collision yesterday on a training flight, sixty miles east of their base at Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn.

R. R. Compton, formerly central regional manager of Nash Motors division of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation, Detroit, has been appointed sales promotion manager of Nash Motors for the United States and Canada.

Abraham Straus, Inc., Brooklyn store unit of the Federated Department Stores, Inc., transacted a high record volume of sales in the fifty-two weeks ended on Jan. 31, last, Walter Rothschild, president, reported in the annual statement mailed to stockholders over the week-end.

ROTORUA; New Zealand, May 9 (UP) -- New Zealand's two largest volcanos are on the rampage again and geologists are awaiting with interest the effects of magnetic and radio disturbances on seething mountains.

VIENNA, May 9 - The men whom Washington made responsible for United States economic policy here and responsible Austrians have reported to the State Department that the European Recovery Plan proposals are dangerously underestimating the economic menace to Austria.

The regular broadcast Wednesday morning at 9 of WJZ-ABC's The Breakfast Club" win be televised .~rnultaneously over an Eastern network, of which the DuMont station, WABD, will be the local' outlet. The sixty-minute program, now broadcast from NewYork, will switch for .the occasion to the Academy of MUsic in Philadelphia.

h)0*0*0*iOThe proposed mental hygiene clinic for the region of Madison House, 226 Madison Street, can become a muchneeded reality only if the settlement house's current campaign for funds achieves its goal. The plan for handling specialized mental cases in the Madison House district, inhabited principally by a heterogeneous low-income population, may well be jeopardized unless the public responds generously to the urgent appeal of this valuable organization.

PARIS, May 9 -- The flags and bunting left out after yesterday's celebration of V-E Day added color today to the innumerable church services, parades and wreath-laying ceremonies throughout France that marked St. Joan of Arc Day.

The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company reported yesterday for the first three months of this year, a net income of $1,349,226, equal to 54 cents a common share. This is an increase of $341,841 or 34 per cent over the same period in 1947, excluding income received then while the company had the war emergency pipelines under lease.

LONDON, May 9 (UP) -- Czechoslovakia last night accused the British Government of violating the Anglo-Czechoslovak cultural pact, the only cultural accord that Britain has concluded with an eastern European state since the war.
CAMP CAMPBELL, Ky., May 9 -- The sound and fury of battle have been brought to the Army's peacetime war games with the aidh)0*0*0*iof wire recorders and sound trucks.
ROME, May 9 -- The mysterious attacks against military installations continued last night when soldiers guarding an ammunition dump at Beano, near Udine, were under fire for about half an hour.

For the first time in their 4,000-year history, the great majority of the Korean people will have an opportunity today to vote in a free general election as the first step toward the restoration of their independence and the creation of their first free and democratic government.

Determined to do everything in her power to give "Sleepy Hollow" the sheen of a hit musical, Lorraine Lester has called in Marc Connelly to lend a helping hand. Now in Philadelphia, where the show began a fortnight's run last Tuesday night, Mr. Connelly is revising the book and re-staging the offering.

ATHENS, May 9 -- Taking up his appointment as successor of the assassinated Christos Ladas, Minister of Justice George Melas said today that there "would not and could not" be any interference in the matter of the 2,961 persons, mostly Leftist fighters, condemned to death on charges of murder committed during the Nazi occupation and the December, 1944, insurrection.

Describing traffic congestion as the city's most pressing problem, Edward C. Maguire, Commerce Commissioner, recommended to Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday that the city enlist its business leaders in a new Traffic Commission specifically charged with solving the problem.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- William Benton and the delegates associated with him at the United Nations Conference on Freedom of Information in Geneva, March 23April 21, declared tonight in a unanimous report to Secretary of State Marshall that "in the face of difficulties" the conference had a "remarkable" record of "constructive achievement."
SEOUL. Korea, Monday, May 10 -- More than 6,000,000 voters are expected to go to the polls today in the first general election in the 4,000-year history of Korea.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 9 -- United Nations delegates worked intensely at eleventh-hour meetings this week-end to set up emergency "caretaker governments" for Palestine and Jerusalem in time to meet the critical May 15 deadline.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (UP) -The National Geographic Society reported today that bad weather conditions seriously hampered most of the expeditions it sent out to observe an eclipse of the sum

TEL AVIV, Palestine, May 9 - David Ben-Gurion, head of the Jewish provisional government, announced tonight that the Jewish state would be proclaimed May 16, the day after the British mandateh)0*0*0*iends. At the same time the provisional government will begin formal operation and its national army will come into existence.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (UP) -The National Geographic Society reported today that bad weather conditions seriously hampered most of the expeditions it sent out to observe an eclipse of the sum

TEL AVIV, Palestine, May 9 - David Ben-Gurion, head of the Jewish provisional government, announced tonight that the Jewish state would be proclaimed May 16, the day after the British mandateh)0*0*0*iends. At the same time the provisional government will begin formal operation and its national army will come into existence.

ST. LOUIS, May 9 (AP) -- The Cardinals knocked in six runs in the sixth and seventh innings to drive Warren Spahn from the mound and defeat the Braves, 6 to 4, today. Jeff Heath and Jim Russell led the Boston attack with a home run apiece.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 9 Profiting by the margin he had established in yesterday's two rounds, Herman Barron of Fenway captured the Goodall round-robin golf tournament over the Wykagyl Country Club today by a margin of six points, with a final total of plus 38.

Mother's Day is a rebuke to "modern pagans who would destroy the home by insidious propaganda for divorce and birth prevention," the Rev. William T. Greene declared yesterday in a sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

New Rochelle Police Headquarters had its patrol wagon back yesterday morning but late into the day the faces of the bluecoats were still red. Someone stole the wagon from right in front of headquarters at 23 Lawton Street at 1 A.M.

The Arnold Bernstein Line's passenger vessel Continental is scheduled to leave Genoa for New York today with 350 passengers, and will start regular service between New York, Plymouth, England, and Antwerp, soon after her arrival, officials of the company announced yesterday.

LONDON, May 9 -- The weight of money again is telling on the stock markets here and lifting them out of the rut into which they fell and in which they seemed likely to remain, failing some outstanding event of stimulating importance.

The cook who all winter bakes thick apple pies, steams spicy puddings and fills the kitchen with the fragrance of mincemeat turnovers has a change of heart with the change of season. No longer does she regard such substantial desserts as interesting to make or to eat.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, May 9 -The absence of United States and British exhibitors from the current International Trade Fair in this city has caused keen disappointment among Yugoslav officials whose job it is to bring heavy machinery into this country to assure the program of industrial expansion under the Five-Year Plan.

WESTFIELD, N.J., May 9 -The Baker House, at 725 East Broad Street, one of Westfield's historic homesteads, has been sold by the estate of the late Frederick C. Leary to Ralph J. Van-Derwerker, superintendentengineer of the Union County Mosquito Commission, through Edwin O. Edwards.

PARIS, May 9 -- A guarded but conciliatory attitude toward both left and right was taken today by the congress of the Popular Republican, party in final resolutions that asked that work for recovery should have priority over all else.

Imports of gloves from Europe in the fall will be of pre-war quality and workmanship, Arthur Stanton, president of Aris Gloves, Inc., 511 Fifth Avenue, declared over the week-end in a report on his recent visit to the glove manufacturing centers of Europe.
BALTIMORE, May 9 (AP) -- Senator Millard E. Tydings, Democrat?? of Maryland today quoted President Truman as having categorically denied rumors that Premier Stalin had made peace talk overtures.
Cities throughout the nation were preparing yesterday to cope with the threatened railroad strike.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- America does not need today the largest Army in the world, but it must continue to have the best one, Secretary Kenneth C. Royall told the convention today of the National Jewish Welfare Board.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 9 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan. Toledo (Ohio) amateur, won the Delaware open golf championship tournament today with a thirty-six-hole score of 138.

CINCINNATI, May 9 (AP) -- The Phillies rolled over the hapless Reds in both games of a twin bill today, 14 -- 2 and 8 -- 0, before a crowd of 20,831, thousands of whom left the park midway in the second game. Lefty Ken Heintzelman twirled a four-hitter for the nightcap victory after the Phillies' prize rookie, Curt Simmons, had won the opener for his first victory, as against two defeats.

ZURICH, Switzerland, May 9 -Feeling is running high in Switzerland at the arbitrary action of the Argentine Government in suddenly suspending all exports to the Swiss Confederation. No official reason has been given, but the obvious aim is to exert pressure to compel Switzerland to provide dollars which Argentina needs urgently to carry her five-year industrialization plan to completion.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- A measure to prohibit the exportation of seamless and welded steel pipe and certain types of carbon steel sheets, designed primarily to halt steel shipments to Saudi Arabia, has been drafted by Senator Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska, it was learned today.

WILLIMANTIC, Conn., May 9 -In the best show ever held by the Windham County Kennel Club, the chief award today went to Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt's white standard poodle, Ch. Blakeen Osprey, handled by the owner. The final was judged by Miss Anna Katherine Nicholas.

Wages, hours and working conditions in the plumbing industry in New York City have been frozen in a stabilization agreement between contractors and journeymen plumbers that will hold for two years and is expected to increase production and employment, and cut the costs of building.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- The threatened railway strike resulted in considerable irregularity in the grain markets on the Board of Trade last week, and short covering tightened up the May deliveries as compared with July. Prices went to a new recovery high, but failed to hold that level because of scattered liquidation.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 9 -- Alcoholism is not a moral problem but a health problem, speakers emphasized here today at a meeting in the County Center sponsored by eighteen groups of Alcoholics Anonymous. They said that recovery was assured in 70 per cent of the cases that followed the program of the organization.

A 95-year-old mother, the oldest member of the congregation, was singled out by the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, for tribute on Mother's Day at services yesterday morning.

BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP) -- Bovard, Mount Marcy and Vulcan's Forge stretched their legs in good style in today's Survivor Stakes. They finished in that order to increase their chances of going after the $100,000 Preakness pot.

IQUITOS, Peru, May 10 (UP) -- Cooperation to harness the riches of the Amazon basin was pledged today by representatives of ten nations as they signed two agreements creating the International Institute of the Amazon Forests.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands May 10--The Congress of Europe, dedicated to the creation of supranational organization to bring lasting peace to the Continent, completed the first phase of its task here today after four days of intensive debate.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Note 1. If the railroads had not encouraged Congress to exclude their employes from the scope of the Taft-Hartley Act, the Government could by injunctive process now gain another period of eighty days before a railroad strike could take effect.

Joseph Dwyer has been re-elected president of Theatrical Protective Union No. 1, the stagehands' organization. The annual election was held on Sunday at the union's headquarters, 254 West Fifty-fourth Street. A total of 1,108 votes were cast.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 10 (AP) -- Midshipman George J. Eliopolus, 23, died today, twenty minutes after a javelin flung by a fellow-athlete pierced his neck, Navy officials reported.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Congressional leaders have now finished their private talks on what political and military action they think should be taken to improve the security of Western Europe.
Random notes.

Store Sales Up 2% Here Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 2 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 7 per cent.

Flashing a wealth of speed in the stretch, the Lester Manor Stable's Compliance stepped home first in the Maud Muller Purse at Jamaica yesterday. Ridden by Conn McCreary, the 3-year-old daughter of Requested pulled away from seven others in the drive to the wire to score a convincing triumph at 5 -- 1.

THE most important problem which confronts the human race is not the newest, the control of atomic energy, or the most publicized, the conflict between opposing philosophies of individual freedom and state despotism, but the oldest of all, man's persistence in destroying the means of his own existence. This is the thesis of Fairfield Osborn's carefully documented, soberly written little book of solemn warning, "Our Plundered Planet."*

OTTAWA, Ont., May 10 -- Gen. A.G.L. McNaughton, Canadian delegate on the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, commented publicly on its work tonight. He told an audience that the circumstance that the Soviet Union did not yet agree on the course to be taken should not be regarded too seriously at this stage.

PANAMA, May 10 -- Although no official returns from yesterday's Presidential elections have yet been reported, the three leading candidates are claiming victory on the basis of unofficial information.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 10 -- An advertisement showing a Royal Canadian Mounted Police constable drinking beer while on duty drew criticism in the House of Commons today from Conservative member B.L. Smith.

A national mental hygiene program, in which 70,000 members of the National Council of Jewish Women in 300 senior and junior sections all over the country may serve as volunteer aides, was announced yesterday by Mrs. Joseph M. Welt of Detroit, national president, in a statement released at council headquarters, 1819 Broadway.

GASTONIA, N.C., May 10 -Full-scale three-shift operations have started at the newly built plant of Associated Spinners, Inc., here, and use of a revolutionary spinning process is expected to produce fine worsted yarn at prices 5 to 20 per cent less than yarn made on conventional machinery.
AMSTERDAM, May 10 -- All efforts are now being concentrated on intensification of United States-Netherlands economic relations and early resumption of American industrial investments here.
GENEVA, May 10 -- Guatemala proposed to the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization today a project for colonizing her undeveloped area by 50,000 displaced persons.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Washington Senators pounced on Sam Zoldak for four runs in the sixth inning tonight to defeat the St. Louis Browns, 6 -- 2. Early Wynn limited the Browns to five hits to win his third victory of the season.

A personal training program "entirely new to the field of merchandising" is to be put into operation immediately in all stores of Gimbel Bros., Inc., John J. McCarthy, director of central training and personnel for Gimbel Bros, and Saks Co., disclosed yesterday.

MUNICH, May 10 -- Despite assertions by labor union officials that they had had definite assurance that at least 90 per cent of the employes of the Munich street railways would vote no on a proposal to extend the walkout of Saturday to a genuine strike, approximately 90 per cent voted yes when the question came before the Workers Council this morning.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's Executive Order for seizure of the railroads follows:

TRENTON, N.J., May 10 (AP) -- The state's share from the first twenty-one days of horse racing in 1948 is more than double last year's receipts in the same period, Racing Commission figures showed today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 10 -- Despite continued efforts by the United States to persuade it not to do so, the Jewish Agency for Palestine intends to proclaim a Jewish state in Palestine as soon as the British mandate is terminated, an Agency spokesman reiterated here today.

Earle C. King, chief accountant of the Securities and Exchange Commission, declared last night that the accountancy profession had a public duty to resolve differences of opinion on principles governing the preparation of corporate income statements so that they required no "explanation or clarification beyond that contained in the statements themselves."

BORDEAUX, France, May 10 -- The formal beginning of United States help under the European Relief Program for France was celebrated here today, a few days less than eleven months after Secretary of State Marshall had stated his principles of cooperative aid in an address at Harvard University.

ST. LOUIS, May 10 (AP) -- Johnny Sain, strong-armed right hander of the Braves, snapped the five-game winning streak of the Cardinals tonight, 6 to 0. Although giving up ten hits, nine of them singles, Sain was strong in the pinches and the Birds were never in the game after the Braves took an early lead.

An eleven-point shipbuilding aid program introduced in the House yesterday by Representative Alvin F. Weichel embodies nine features previously suggested to Congress by the National Federation of American Shipping, the organization announced in Washington.

PARIS, May 10 -- Myron C. Taylor, personal representative of President Truman to the Vatican, is returning to Rome tomorrow after a tour of Western Europe in the interests of Christian unity upon the question of war and peace.

JACKSON, Miss., May 10--The States Rights Democrats, a group stemming largely from Southern disapproval of proposals to eliminate racial discrimination, unanimously voted today to hold their own convention on July 17 if the national convention nominated President Truman or failed to repudiate his civil rights program.

NYACK, N.Y., May 10 -- President Truman was asked to order Federal operation of Rockland County buses, in a telegram sent today by Assemblyman Robert Walmsley. Bus drivers for Rockland Coaches, Inc., and four affiliated companies that handle 40,000 customers daily here and in Bergen County, N.J., have been on strike since April 4.

Crosley Distributing Corporation has dropped between 5 and 6 per cent of its refrigerator, television and radio dealers for cutting list prices, Bert Cole, vice president and general manager, revealed yesterday. The organization is the local factory branch of the Crosley division, Avco Manufacturing Corporation.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The text of President Truman's statement on the seizure of the railroads follows:

Cohama Fabrics' fall advertising and merchandising campaign will feature a strong appeal to the consumer's sense of touch, it was announced yesterday. Its theme will be "the Feel of Fashion Is Crisp." Initial ads will be double-page, four-color spreads scheduled to appear in nine fashion magazines and trade publications during August and September.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 10 (AP) -- The Elmendorf Farm's Shoe Buckle registered a length victory over the Winlochan Stable's Wishmeluck in the feature race at Garden State Park today.

Opposition to Communist influences and aims within maritime labor will be a primary subject at the biennial convention of the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, in Detroit this week, union leaders said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- President Truman and Congress were reminded today by Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, that this country's foreign policy commitments and continued shortages of strategic materials required extension of export priorities, allocation and other powers beyond the May 31 expiration date.

Although Mayor O'Dwyer did not make fully explicit his reservations about the plan for a new Traffic Commission proposed by his Commerce Commissioner, he has apparently had some second thoughts about it, and feels it needs further analysis and study.

A program designed to more than double funds for promotion of coffee in the United States was approved as the chief item of business at the opening here yesterday of an extraordinary session of the Pan-American Coffee Conference.

NANKING, May 10 -- Two outspoken Kwangsi generals, Vice President Li Tsung-jen and Minister of Defense Pai Chung-si, were reliably reported today to be lining up behind a military reform program that would expand the civil war base and loosen Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's hitherto undisputed intervention in the tactical field of operations.

Giving expression to a dream of centuries, the unofficial Congress of Europe, consisting of 600 delegates from twenty-eight nations, has unanimously adopted resolutions in favor of a European federation at the price of surrender of some of their sovereign rights.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Maj. Gen. Edmond H. Leavey, who was ordered to run the railroads during the emergency, won the greatest among many distinctions in the last war while doing a job for the Navy.

I am certain that many readers of Churchill's "War Memoirs" are grateful to Topics of The Times for explaining the reference to Defoe's "Memoirs of a Cavalier." But there is still the question why Churchill singled out this obscure English novel as his literary model.

It is a little early to predict who the next President of the United States will be, but among those who will not become President will be Norman Thomas, who has just been nominated for the sixth time as the candidate of the Socialist party. Mr. Thomas reached his peak with 900,000 votes in 1932.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The old Belasco Theatre, now used as a storehouse for Treasury Department records, will be restored and will become the first legitimate theatre in the nation's capital which will not discriminate against Negroes, it was learned tonight.

LOS ANGELES, May 8 -- In the showing of eight women designers known as Affiliated Fashionists Marjorie Montgomery advocates jumpers, and favors a fine rayon gabardine in solid colors with contrasting sleeves. Dresses are flared moderately or are straight cut with semi-dolman or dropped shoulder sleeves in three-quarter push-up style.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall told the opening session of the fourth international congress on tropical medicine and malaria today that the tropical regions held the key to a world of plenty, and tropical medicine held the key to the tropical regions.

TORONTO, May 10 (AP) -- The Toronto Daily Star announced today that its publisher had willed it to a charitable foundation. The publisher and owner, Joseph E. Atkinson, died Saturday of heart disease at the age of 82.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 10 -- Egypt charged in the United Nations Commission on Narcotic Drugs today that Palestinian terrorists had been trading narcotics for arms in Egypt. She also called on Turkey and Greece to tighten their controls on drug traffic.

FROM the beginning of the war Commodore Harwood's special care and duty had been to cover British shipping off the River Plate and Rio de Janeiro. He was convinced that sooner or later the Graf Spee would come toward the Plate, where the richest prizes were offered to her. He had carefully thought out the tactics which he would adopt in an encounter.

BALDWIN, L.I., May 10 -- Mal Galletta, North Hills, and Freddie Catropa of Peninsula, combined for a card of 32, 34 -- 66 in winning the second weekly one-day amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island P.G.A. at the Willow Brook Club today.

Buying was normal yesterday in the city's retail food shops as housewives seemed confident that local storage holdings, with replenishments by truck transport, would outlast a railroad strike. Most prices were unchanged from last week's.

Customers of various utility companies have received notices of increased gas and electric rates recently because of higher operating costs, but several thousand consumers in up-state New York are in line for a $1,000,000 annual reduction in their utility bills.

A recommendation by the international law committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York that the Draft Declaration on Human Rights, prepared by the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, be abandoned will be voted on tonight at the association's annual meeting, it was announced yesterday.

DETROIT, May 10 -- A nationwide walkout of workers in Chrysler Corporation plants seemed certain late today after a meeting between management officials and negotiators for the United Automobile Workers, CIO, had failed to break the deadlock which has existed since Feb. 27.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- American cities must look to their fire defenses as national security preparedness and completely revamp civilian defense thinking in the light of atomic warfare, state fire marshals and other fire technicians were told here today.

The Korean people have made an auspicious start on the road toward liberty and independence by turning out to vote in record numbers, in defiance of a Russian-dictated Communist wave of terror openly designed to "smash" a free election. Some 85 per cent of all eligible voters in the election zone lined up before the polling booths to cast their ballots, the total passing 90 per cent in the capital of Seoul.

The Patchogue Electric Light Company would be authorized to issue $350,000 of first mortgage bonds under a financing plan which has been announced by the Public Service Commission of New York. The company had asked for authority to issue $550,000 of bonds and approval of a plan for reclassification of its capital stock.

Bootlegging is depriving the Government of an estimated $1,000,000 a day, now that sugar and copper are again available, R. E. Joyce, president of the Distilled Spirits Institute, declared yesterday. He told more than eighty members of the National Conference of State Liquor Administrators during their annual meeting at the Roosevelt Hotel.

A bit of detective-story sleuthing by a public school principal resulted yesterday in the arrest of two 12-year-old pupils who had caused nearly $1,000 damage when they broke into Public School 179, at 155 West 102d Street. Sunday afternoon.
The first summer fashion luncheon in the pink aura of the St. Regis Hotel's roof restaurant--the showing of mint-cool tints by Russeks--and a balmy day made a happy combination yesterday.

Tremendous increases in births in this city may force the Board of Education for the first time in its history to look to the state for financial aid in new school construction, it became known yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 10 -- Preston Sturges has signed a contract with Twentieth Century-Fox to write, direct and produce another picture in addition to the recently completed "Unfaithfully Yours." His next film will be "The Beautiful Blonde From Bashful Bend," a photoplay which he previously had shelved in favor of "Unfaithfully Yours."

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 10 -- Crapo C. Smith, bachelor grandson of a former Governor of Michigan, who had spent the last of his seventy-nine years living in a room off the campus of Michigan University, has left more than $1,000,000 to the college. This became known today from the terms of Mr. Smith's will.

Democrats of the State of New York, of both high and low degree, contributed time and money to their party's cause last night, but were markedly sparing in enthusiasm, at the annual fund-raising dinner of the Democratic State Committee held at the Commodore Hotel.

After what can only be described as an extraordinary demonstration of patience and determination in its efforts to avert a threatened railroad strike, the Administration yesterday took the only logical course left to it if country-wide economic paralysis was to be averted.

RYE, N.Y., May 10 -- A record season-opening field of 106 members turned out for the one-day curtain-raiser of the women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association, beginning its twenty-fifth season, held today over the south course at the Westchester Country Club.

Robert P. Boylan was re-elected yesterday as chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Boylan, an independent floor broker with offices in E.F. Hutton Co., who served as vice chairman from 1940 to 1941, has been a member of the Exchange since 1936.

As the result of a steady and increasing demand for cargo space and passenger accommodations from the Gulf ports to the Caribbean, the Alcoa Steamship Company announced yesterday that the Alcoa Cavalier would operate from New Orleans instead of New York beginning in June.

DAYTON, Ohio, May 10 -- The new science of television will become one of the most important aids to the Armed Forces and may well be a decisive factor in future warfare, David A. Sarnoff, president and board chairman of the Radio Corporation of America, said here tonight.

"Freedom and Order," by Anthony Eden, has been scheduled for July 27 publication by Houghton Mifflin. It is the former British Foreign Minister's defense of government by consent of the governed and his analysis of the price of internationalism.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong yesterday and closed virtually at the best levels of the day, 39 to 59 points higher than Saturday's final levels.

The medical profession must increasingly organize itself to participate in community efforts in the development of sound health and medical services, Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of Columbia University's Faculty of Medicine, declared yesterday. His statement was made in his annual report to Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of Columbia.

An eventful year was reviewed at the annual meeting of the corporate members of the American National Theatre and Academy yesterday afternoon at Maxine Elliott's Theatre. After the meeting it was disclosed by Vinton Freedley, president, that the non-profit organization, chartered by Congress in 1935, had a balance of $33,000 at the close of the fiscal year May 1.

The announcement that the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and the New York Clothing Manufacturers' Exchange will jointly establish a million-dollar medical center carries forward a trend that became manifest in the garment trades as early as 1910, when the cloak and suit makers of the city struck partly because of the unsanitary conditions under which they then had to work.
TRENTON, N.J., May 10 -- New Jersey Legislative leaders agreed tonight that they had set themselves too big a program in January to complete before a spring recess next Friday.

WARSAW, May 10 -- The Polish Government raised a new issue today in the Polish-American propaganda and information dispute, with a strongly worded complaint about American failure to grant visas to Polish newspaper men.

CAMP CAMPBELL, Ky., May 10 -- A revolution in military communications which ultimately will eliminate the use of the Morse Code is forecast by developments exhibited here in "Exercise Assembly" -- the Army's largest post-war maneuvers.

WASHINGTON, May 10--President Truman today prepared a special message to Congress on support for farm prices and soil conservation. At the same time he formally accepted the resignation of Clinton P. Anderson as Secretary of Agriculture.

There are certain pitchers, it appears, who by merely warming up can wrap up the enemy. Hal Schumacher, to mention one, used to affect the Reds that way. And Red Embree, whom the Yankees acquired from the Indians, apparently holds a similar grip on the White Sox.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The nation-wide railroad strike, set for tomorrow at 6 A.M., Eastern standard time, was canceled tonight after Justice T. Alan Goldsborough had signed a temporary restraining order.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- Though the Giants, because of the weather, were deprived today of atoning for the humiliating three-hit shut-out Russ Meyer of the Cubs slapped on them yesterday, an aura of contentment enveloped the Polo Grounders.

The stock market did little more yesterday than mark time, pending developments in the railroad situation, although evidence late in the session that a strike would be averted permitted some semblance of recovery. The carrier stocks led the way to an irregularly higher close while scattered units in the oil division made new gains.
The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday a deficit of $163,268 for the first quarter of 1948, in contrast to a net income of $1,236,342 in the comparable 1947 period.
CHICAGO, May 10 -- Uncertainty as to what turn the rail situation might take, regardless of Government seizure, resulted in short covering in-the grain markets on the Board of Trade today.

SHAWNEE ON DELAWARE, Pa., May 10 -- With defense programs likely to cost up to $30,000,000,000 annually, a civilian commission should be established to scrutinize and discuss general matters of policy and efficiency with which it is carried out, Beardsley Ruml, author of the pay-as-you-go tax plan, declared here tonight.

The 9,100-ton motorship Golden Gate has left Sweden on her maiden voyage to Pacific Coast ports of the United States and Canada, it was announced here yesterday. She is the second of five fast new vessels being built in Sweden for the Johnson Line. Her sister ship, the Seattle, entered service last December.
