After six weeks of bickering over division of television receipts, during which the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, which promotes boxing at Madison Square Garden and the St. Nicholas Arena, was unable to present a program, a settlement was made yesterday between Sol Strauss, the club's acting promoter and the Boxing Managers' Guild of New York.

LONDON, May 10--United States post-war shipments of food and relief supplies by the Government and individuals to distressed countries were praised here today by Sir John Boyd Orr, former director general of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, as an act of generosity "unparalleled in history."

ALBANY, May 10 -- Expressing confidence that the Republican National Convention would nominate Gov. Thomas E. Dewey for President, the New York State delegates to that convention today adopted a resolution pledging the ninety-seven votes of the state to the Governor's candidacy.

A luxurious kitchen to inspire Brooklyn housewives to better their their own work centers is the feature attraction of Namm's week-long spring housewares carnival, which opened yesterday. The Westinghouse Garden-View Kitchen, designed by the staff of House and Garden magazine, has a friendly warm appearance due to a combination of pink-toned wood walls and an attractive garden arrangement over the sink area.

A hold-over April grand jury, which has been examining evidence of alleged gouging on residential and business rental agreements, yesterday filed a twelve-count misdemeanor information against a former $45-a-week housing investigator for Stuyvesant Town, a Metropolitan Life Insurance Company housing development.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 10 -- An invitation match for the benefit of the North County Community Hospital of this locality brought out an impressive gathering of top-flight professional golfers who teamed with women and men amateurs in an eighteen-hole contest over the Piping Rock course today.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- The national council of the National Jewish Welfare Board, at the final session of its three-day annual meeting today, adopted a statement of principles setting forth the functions, aims and role in the community of the Jewish community center.

MUNICH, May 10 -- Leonard Bernstein, former conductor of the New York City Center Symphony, received a tremendous ovation last night when he directed the Bavarian State Opera Orchestra before a German and American audience in the Prinzregent Theatre.

Miss Mary Ellen Manley, director of the division of nursing of the Department of Hospitals, declared last night that the city's municipal hospitals and medical centers needed at least 3,000 more trained nurses. She spoke in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel before 1,000 nurses, physicians and civic officials at the seventy-fifth anniversary dinner of the Alumnae Association of the Bellevue Schools of Nursing.

On the heels of President Truman's seizure order, railroads here and generally throughout the country were quick yesterday to rescind earlier decisions not to attempt operation after today's strike deadline of 6 A.M., standard time.

LONDON, May 10 -- Concern that United States economic aid and closer British cooperation with European countries may adversely affect trade with the British dominions has led the Australian and New Zealand High Commissioners in London to undertake consultations with officials of the United Kingdom Government.

One of the mightiest members of this nation's wartime fleet was exhibited yesterday as she will look in moth balls. The Navy permitted reporters and photographers to view the process by which the battleship New Jersey is being inactivated at the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn.

DETROIT, May 10--A manufacturer's agent, who sells parts to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, told a Securities and Exchange Commission board of inquiry today that he sold 1,000 shares of Kaiser-Frazer common stock at the time of the recent stock offering and was "sorry because I didn't sell all my holdings."
CHICAGO., May 10 (AP) -- Four key clubs today quit the National Basketball League and simultaneously were accepted as new members by the rival Basketball Association of America.

Applications by six private bus and trolley companies to increase their fares must take the regular course prescribed by the City Charter and will not be expedited or by-passed to the Public Service Commission, it developed yesterday at an unusual meeting of the Board of Estimate.

Wandering a few evenings ago in a section of our metropolis to which he is greatly addicted -- Gastronomia -- a New Yorker dubbed by himself a gourmet and by unperceptive friends a gourmand, opened the door of a small midtown restaurant and suddenly found himself in pre-war Austria.

BEND, Ore., May 10 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York accepted an invitation tonight to debate on the same platform with Harold E. Stassen, his opponent in the Oregon Republican Presidential primary.

The railway strike crisis again has brought forcibly to the attention of the American people the serious menace which a tie-up in a public utility may bring to a community or to the nation. Until after the passage of the Wagner Act, in 1935, there were few, if any, unions which included nearly all of the workers in a particular field.

ATHENS, May 10 -- The large rebel force that attacked the town of Grevena in Western Macedonia over Saturday night, considerably harassed the Government forces in the area for a while, according to reports reaching Athens today.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., May 10 (AP) -- Deliberate and expert tampering with the rails was responsible for the train wreck here that killed two crew members last night, officials of the Reading Company said today. A Reading spokesman said that the manner in which the mischief was done showed clearly it was the work of a track expert.

The NBC ban against allowing mystery shows on its facilities before 9:30 P. M. will be reflected in rearrangements for the summer in the network's Tuesday night schedule. Specifically affected will be the warm-weather replacements for "Amos 'n' Andy" and Eddie Cantor, respectively, sponsored by Lever Brothers and Pabst beer.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 10 -- Search for a neutral "mayor" to run the city of Jerusalem, but not police it, continued today, both here and in the Holy City, after the leading candidate, a British banker, declined the job.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 10 -- A working paper containing the framework for provisional Palestinian government after May 15 was placed before a subcommittee of the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee here today.

A joint program to get employable persons now on home relief in New York State back to self-supporting work was announced yesterday by the State Labor and Social Welfare departments in cooperation with the welfare departments of this city and Utica.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 10 -- The Representative Town Meeting appropriated $103,000 tonight on the recommendation of the Board of Estimate and Taxation for a 10 per cent cost of living bonus to 650 town employes.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- A Senate-House conference committee agreed promptly late today to a placing of orders now, months ahead of budgetary timetable, for planes that would build up the Air Force to a fighting establishment of seventy combat groups of the latest possible design.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 11 -- The Soviet Union has accepted a United States proposal that the two countries should open discussions on the differences between them, the Moscow radio disclosed early today.

Standard Oil Company (Ohio), in its report for the first quarter of 1948, issued for publication today, showed a net income of $6,052,604 after all charges. This equals $1.66 a common share and compares with $2,443,783 or 81 cents a share earned in the first three months of last year.

Negotiations between the publishers of thirteen major daily newspapers here and the International Typographical Union in an effort to end a wage dispute affecting 2,500 composing room workers stalled yesterday afternoon after Woodruff Randolph, president of the union, announced that he would not participate in the proceedings.

MUNICH, Germany, May 10 -- Up to late tonight the combined efforts of American and German criminal investigators had not produced any trace of a 17-year-old German boy who vanished after apparently murdering an American Criminal Investigation Division agent and a German policeman.

Harvard and Navy, the two standout crews of 1947, have been seeded as the two top varsities in the third annual championship regatta of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges, to be held over the Olympic distance course of 2,000 meters on the Charles River, Cambridge, on Saturday.

Racking up two runs in the top half of the sixteenth, Fordham's baseball team beat St. John's University, 4 -- 2, in a marathon Metropolitan Collegiate Conference tussle at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 10 -- A blunt warning to Communist elements in the Congress of Industrial Organizations that there was no room in the organization for groups that opposed the European Recovery Program was voiced here today by Philip Murray, national president of the CIO.
LONDON, May 10 (AP) -- Military censorship in some areas is hampering news coverage of the Arab-Jewish war for Palestine.

ROME, Tuesday, May 11 -- After leading all other candidates last evening in the balloting for the Presidency of the Italian Republic, Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza announced early this morning that he had withdrawn from the race.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- Private United States loan capital, as distinguished from equity capital, mainly direct investment, "evidenced no particular desire during 1947 to share substantially in the dollar financing required for world reconstruction," according to the Encyclopedia Britannica's Book of the Year, to be issued shortly.

Excitement attending the impressive victory of Mikhail Botvinnik in the tournament for the chess championship of the world had receded somewhat by the time play was scheduled to be resumed yesterday in the game between Paul Keres of Estonia and Vassily Smyslov of Russia, adjourned from the twenty-second round at the Hall of Columns in Moscow, according to a report received from the Russian capital.

A stockholder of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation filed suit in Federal Court yesterday to compel Henry J. Kaiser, Joseph W. Frazer and eight other company officers to purchase from the company 186,200 shares of common stock it bought last Feb. 3 in order to support the market for a proposed new stock offering.
LONDON, May 10 -- The stock market here today opened the week quietly and prices moved narrowly.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- President Truman was urged today to recognize a Jewish State in Palestine when the British mandate ends on May 15, in an open letter sent to the White House by the Nation Associates.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, disclosed today that Dr. Edward U. Condon, director of the Bureau of Standards, had agreed to forego restricted information on atomic energy pending a review of his qualifications by a reviewing board under Owen J. Roberts, former justice of the United States Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, May 11 -- The Moscow broadcast of the United States note and of the Russian reply early today took Administration officials by surprise. After midnight, in response to many queries, Lincoln White, State Department press officer, released the text of Ambassador Smith's note.

Dallas County, Tex., sold an issue of $1,000,000 of juvenile building bonds, due from 1949 to 1978, to a banking syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. at a bid of 100.03 for 2 1/2s. The bonds were re-offered at prices to yield 1 to 2.55 per cent. Participating in the offering are Detmer Co., the Commerce Union Bank, Thomas Co. and Campbell, Phelps Co.

The Rev. Robert J. White, dean of the Catholic University Law School and president of the Chaplains Association of the Army and Navy of the United States, declared yesterday that it was not the association's function to take an official stand on the methods to be used in the prospective enlargement of the military services.

Mayor O'Dwyer emphasized the immediate medical needs of Palestine yesterday by calling on the citizens of New York to donate blood for Jewish men and women, fighting to defend "the soil which the United Nations in its ruling of Nov. 29 said should be theirs as a Jewish state."

Net sales of Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., for the fifty-two weeks ended with last January reached a new high of $65,556,789, increasing 15.9 per cent from the previous year's volume of $56,562,447, according to the report signed jointly by J. Edward Davidson, chairman, and James S. Schoff, president, issued for publication today.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 10 -- A triple with the bases loaded by Norm Robinson, right-fielder, in the seventh inning, gave Army a 12-9 victory over an erratic City College nine on Doubleday Field today. Outhit by the Beavers, the Cadets took advantage of nine errors and thirteen bases on balls to gain their fourteenth victory of the season.

Stockholders of the Humble Oil and Refining Company at the annual meeting held yesterday in Houston, Tex., authorized an amendment of the charter so that the value of the capital stock may be stated at $475,000,000 to correspond more nearly with the present net investment in fixed assets of $481,690,000. Capitalization of the company had been $300,000,000.

LONDON, May 10 (Reuters) -- Surrey fared badly against the Australian cricket tourists on the second day of the match at the Oval today and at the close of play was 466 runs behind. The scores were Australians, first innings, 632; Surrey, first innings, 141, and second innings, 25 for 2.

Many an old playgoer will suffer a nostalgic wrench from the quiet disappearance of Viola Allen into the wings from which she had so often emerged triumphantly. Well-trained, technically gifted, and with considerable emotional range, she was for many lovers of plays the ideal heroine of a romantic age.

BERLIN, May 10 -- Signs multiply that the Soviet Union has launched a campaign to destroy the Berlin Kommandatura and thus eliminate the last vestiges of quadripartite government in Germany. If the Russians are able to do this -- and they can if they wish -- they will be able to say that there is no longer any logical reason for the Western Allies to remain in Berlin.

Besides extending its teaching and research activities in 1947, the New York Hospital increased its medical and surgical services so that 76,340 patients were cared for, the institution announced yesterday in its report for its 177th year.
LONDON, May 10 (AP) -- Odds on the favored My Babu to win the English Derby June 5 eased off to 9 to 4 tonight in a callover at the Victoria Club, bookmakers' headquarters.

LONDON, May 10 -- The British Labor Government will continue to oppose the convening of a European Assembly as voted by the unofficial Congress of Europe in The Hague today. This was confirmed by a Foreign Office spokesman.

A controversy over the roof rights of tenants, specifically in connection with television aerials, got under way yesterday in Flat-bush Magistrate's Court only to end in the lap of the Court of Special Sessions.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- An official report indicated today the nation will produce its third largest wheat crop in history.

Sales of leading mail-order and chain-store companies increased 11.8 per cent in April, compared with the corresponding month in 1947, according to compilations covering thirty-nine companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. An increase of 21.9 per cent was shown for the first four months of the year.

LONDON, May 10 -- With the termination of British civil authority in Palestine next Saturday, the gates of the detention camps in Cyprus will in effect be opened and 28,000 Jewish immigrants there will be free to leave for the Jewish State in Palestine.

SIAN, China, May 10 -- A smashing Government defeat of raiding Communist columns along the Shensi-Kansu border during the last week has terminated the immediate Communist threat to strategic Government areas in Northwest China, Gen. Hu Tsung-nan declared in an interview today.

LONDON, May 10 -- With the termination of British civil authority in Palestine next Saturday, the gates of the detention camps in Cyprus will in effect be opened and 28,000 Jewish immigrants there will be free to leave for the Jewish State in Palestine.
Urging business men to aid the city in relieving traffic and transit pressure, Mayor O'Dwyer called yesterday for a stagger system that would spread the hours of travel and business.

PITTSBURGH, May 10 -- Backed by the timely hitting of Ralph Kiner, who drove in three runs with a homer and a double, Elmer Riddle's five-hit pitching turned the Dodgers back tonight, 4 -- 2, and gave the Pirates the series, two games to one.

CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- Deaths from coronary thrombosis, one of the most common and fatal forms of heart disease, can be cut from one-third to one-half with new blood-controlling drugs, a countrywide study showed today.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- John L. Lewis notified hard coal operators today that the United Mine Workers of America intended to end its contract in sixty days and wanted a new one by July 10.

SEOUL, Korea, May 10 -- Ignoring Communist threats of violence and reprisal, more than 85 per cent of South Korea's 8,000,000 eligible voters went to the polls today, it was estimated, to cast their ballots in the United Nations-sponsored election.

BOSTON, May 10 (AP) -- With Manager Lou Boudreau starting a triple-play and Larry Doby and Joe Gordon crashing homers, the Indians made a clean sweep of a three-game series with the Red Sox today with a 12-7 triumph.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (U.P.) -- Three B-29 superfortresses left Merced, Calif., today on a round-the-world flight.

Senator Gurney announced yesterday general acceptance by the Senate Armed Services Committee of most of the provisions of a bill to combine revival of Selective Service with a plan for Selective Military Training. Under this measure enough young men in the 19 through 25 age group would be called into two-year Selective Service to round out the present quotas of the Army, Navy and Air Force.

BOSTON, May 10 -- The two-year contract that prevents the CIO United Steelworkers from striking for a wage increase was signed as an anti-inflation gesture, officers of the union explained today in a report implying that the steel industry had failed to keep its bargain on prices.

Add to the list of films opening this week, "The Fuller Brush Man," the Columbia comedy starring Red Skelton, which will arrive at Loew's State on Friday. Janet Blair is co-starred in the Edward Small production, which was produced and directed by S. Sylvan Simon.

LONDON, May 10 -- Ladislas Fodor's play. "The Vigil," opened in the West End tonight at the Prince of Wales Theatre. It was virtually unchanged from the production staged in February at the suburban Embassy Theatre and drew favorable reviews.

As a result of the Government's actions in the face of the railroad strike threat, a number of lines throughout the country announced yesterday the lifting of embargoes imposed in anticipation of a strike. Some roads also canceled furlough notices to their employes.
BIRMINGHAM, May 10 (AP) -- A new athletic conference -- strictly amateur -- was formed here today by nine Southern colleges.

The proved receptivity of the capital market to new offerings of equities was pointed up yesterday by reports in underwriting circles that the postponed offering of 120,000 shares of convertible preferred stock of Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., is now likely to reach the market late this month.

JERUSALEM, May 10 -- The Haganah smashed through Bab el Wad gorge today after thirty-six hours of fighting and reopened the Tel Aviv-Jerusalem highway, which had been closed for twenty days. A westbound passenger convoy and an eastbound truck convoy moved through the narrow gorge fifteen miles west of Jerusalem at 6 o'clock this evening.

TOKYO, May 10 -- Gen. Douglass MacArthur's headquarters reported today that it had refused to let the United Nations Korean Commission establish a headquarters in Tokyo. The members may come as individuals, however.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Department of the Army, under the personal direction of Secretary Kenneth S. Royall, tonight laid plans to operate the rail network of the United States.

Grigori G. Dolbin, charge d'affaires of the Soviet Embassy in Washington, sent a sharp note of protest to the United Nations Club in Washington in a vain attempt to stop a White Russian Relief party in the clubhouse last Saturday evening, it was learned here yesterday.

Jack Kramer and Bobby Riggs, who come into Madison Square Garden tomorrow night for their return match, there, have been making a big killing on their tennis tour across the country. Promoter Jack Harris revealed the figures yesterday at a luncheon given at Toots Shor's restaurant.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Congressional demands for new legislative weapons against national railway strikes arose today, but found no immediate encouragement among the Republican leaders.

"Hope's the Thing," the collective title for three Richard Harrity comedies, will be offered this evening at 8:15 at the Playhouse under the joint auspices of Eddie Dowling and the American National Theatre and Academy. The one-act plays include "Gone Tomorrow," "Home Life of a Buffalo'' and "Hope Is the Thing With Feathers."

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- As a sequel to its ruling a week ago, that courts could not enforce restrictive covenants on real estate, the Supreme Court today upset an Ohio court decision confining the use of church property to white persons.

Tonight's events: Pop concert, American Relief for Italy, Inc., benefit, Emanuel Balaban, conductor, Giuseppe De Luca, baritone, Giovanni Martinelli, tenor, Jean Carlton, soprano, Eddy Michaels, baritone, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P.M.; Music of the Faiths, Harry R. Wilson, Robley Lawson, Ernest E. Harris, conductors, Richard A. Carpenter, piano, Weldon Wilber, French horn, Town Hall, 8:30; Theodore Charles Stone, baritone, Times Hall, 8:30.

Far from the beaten track of art lovers, in the heart of a neighborhood that was notorious for decades for its gang wars and other kinds of violence, an art gallery opened yesterday, the first in the district once known as Hell's Kitchen.

The "Corbett Project" for a $25,000,000 health and recreation center as a Manhattan war memorial, has been rejected as too big and too expensive by the executive committee of the New York War and Peace Memorial Committee, it was announced yesterday by Maurice P. Davidson, chairman.

Jack Kramer and Bobby Riggs, who come into Madison Square Garden tomorrow night for their return match, there, have been making a big killing on their tennis tour across the country. Promoter Jack Harris revealed the figures yesterday at a luncheon given at Toots Shor's restaurant.

The "Corbett Project" for a $25,000,000 health and recreation center as a Manhattan war memorial, has been rejected as too big and too expensive by the executive committee of the New York War and Peace Memorial Committee, it was announced yesterday by Maurice P. Davidson, chairman.

CLEVELAND, May 10 (AP) -- The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, one of the three unions involved in the nation-wide rail strike crisis, had on its hands today a strike at the brotherhood-owned Park Lane Villa Hotel here.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Congress responded today with some restrained hope, a great deal of skepticism and very much silent reserve to the Soviet Union's expression of willingness to discuss its differences with the United States.
GENEVA, May 11 -- The United States faced European criticism today on two big economic issues.

KEARNY, N.J., May 11 -- Occupation forces in Japan under Gen. Douglas MacArthur have demilitarized that country and paved the way for a democratic form of government, but the economic condition of the Japanese is so critical that it is costing the United States $1,000,000 a day to keep them from starvation.
CAIRO, May 11 -- King Farouk I, 28-year-old Egyptian monarch, declared today that he "cannot and will not tolerate a Zionist state in the Middle East, close to Egypt's borders."

The Museum of Modern Art opens to the public today a retrospective exhibition of paintings and graphic work by Pierre Bonnard. More than eighty oils, a group of water-colors, a score of drawings, another score of lithographs and illustrations for books have been assembled to attest the fruitfulness of the career of this great French colorist, who died last year just before reaching 80.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York, at its annual meeting last night, declined to approve a report of its committee on international law calling for abandonment of the Draft Declaration on Human Rights, prepared by the United Nations Commission on Human Rights.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (UP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's statement today on Russia:

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 -- With all trains of the carrier running on schedule, Martin W. Clement, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, predicted this afternoon that the railroad strike issue will be settled before the expiration of the nineday court injunction period.

MILWAUKEE, May 11 -- Joseph D. Keenan, secretary of the Chicago Federation of Labor, was named director of Labor's League for Political Education, the American Federation of Labor's political action organization, at a meeting of the league today.

Voters in eleven New Jersey municipalities held their quadrennialh)0*0*0*ielections for commissioners yesterday. These municipalities, which operate under the commission form of government, are scattered through seven counties of the state.

LIMA, Peru, May 11 (AP) -- Sharp earthquakes rocked southern Peru and northern Chile early today, killing at least one person and injuring an undetermined number. Heavy damage to homes and buildings was reported.
Southern and West Coast lumber mills have raised prices $2 to $5 a thousand board feet in the last few days, local distributors and yard representatives reported yesterday.

There is at least one item which should be added to the brief article on the Junior Year Abroad, that appeared in Section 4 of THE NEW YORK TIMES on Sunday, April 25. There should be mention of the University of Delaware's part in this movement.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., May 1 -Delays in turning vessels around at New Zealand ports -- particularly the chief shipping centers of Auckland and Wellington -- because of lack of facilities and because of labor troubles has "reduced to the vanishing point the prospects of chartering vessels bringing much-needed supplies to the Dominion."

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., May 11 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen announced he would leave here by airplane tonight for Portland. Ore., for his radio debate with Governor Dewey. The former Minnesota Governor said he had not been advised as to the date of the debate.
Action likely to produce a ban on general public sale of fire extinguishers containing methyl bromide was considered yesterday by the city Department of Health at an initial hearing on the question.

JERUSALEM, April 26 (Delayed) -- The Senate of the Hebrew University has published a resolution declaring that all statements of a political nature bearing the name of Dr. Judah L. Magnes, president of the university, expressed only his personal views and not the views of the university or its academic staff.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -The State Department today released this text of Ambassador Walter Bedell Smith's additional comments on Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov's reply to a United States note of May 9:
John Kramer, world amateur tennis champion in 1947, and Bobby Riggs, national professional titleholder, will come back into Madison Square Garden this evening for a return match.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- While the vast railroad network was operating today under the technical supervision of the Army, the unions that had threatened a strike at 6 a.m. were told by Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, that he had no authority to settle the dispute.
LAKE SUCCESS. N.Y., May 11 -- Backed by France, the United States revived today its plan for a temporary United Nations trusteeship in Jerusalem.

Thirty-two sketches of George Bernard Shaw by Feliks Topolski will be brought out on July 26 by Oxford University under the title "Portrait of G. B. S." The sketches are said to "catch Shaw in every mood and at almost every angle."

The exchange of notes between the United States and Soviet Russia, suggesting the possibility of new discussions for a settlement of their differences, has stirred the imagination of people everywhere and at the same time unleashed world-wide speculation as to just what this exchange means.

The leader of one of the three brotherhoods whose members threatened to walk off their jobs this week, leaving the nation without railroad transportation, was discussing the other day the legal position of the unions in their dispute with management. "You know," said he, "there is nothing in the Railway Labor Act which says we have to accept the conclusions of the President's fact-finding board."

The City Council passed yesterday a proposed local law which, if approved by the Board of Estimate and Mayor O'Dwyer, will grant to policemen their maximum basic pay of $3,400 after three years of service instead of five, as at present.

BOSTON, May 11 -- Philip Murray, president of the United Steel-workers, CIO, implied today he was not ready to sign a non-Communist affidavit and said that in any event the union should spend its money to challenge that and other provisions of the Taft-Hartley Law in the courts.

Volumes have been written about dogs, cats, rabbits and other sizable quadrupeds adopted by children as pets, but entirely too little attention has been given to the smaller forms of animal and vegetable life which play their roles as pets and as scientific projects in many households where the strange curiosities of the young are tolerated, or even encouraged.

There's one department of cookery in which American housewives cannot be beaten. No one else can turn out angel food so light and fluffy, or devil's food so meltingly rich. Perhaps because cake is such a favorite with families here, it is a dessert that every young bride wants to learn about.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -Cecil B. deMille, motion picture producer-director, said today that twelve labor leaders could bring this nation to a standstill "in just half an hour." He urged laws guaranteeing "the right to work."

DETROIT, May 11 -- A strike against the Chrysler Corporation at 10 A.M. tomorrow became a certainty late tonight when the national council of the Chrysler Department of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, voted unanimously to support the stand of its negotiating committee.

LONDON, May 11 (AP) -- Pairings for the British women's amateur golf championship beginning May 31 were drawn today and the first name out of the hat was that of Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare of Merion, Pa.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities presented today what it called documentary proof that the Communist party of the United States and its leaders advocated the Government's overthrow by force and violence.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 11 (AP) -William G. Helis Salmagundi defeated Mrs. M. Jolley's Picnic Lunch by two lengths in the featured six-furlong dash at Garden State today.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 11 -- A floating managerie, the American President Lines' freighter President Grant, tied up here today with a $35,000 cargo of elephants, bears, monkeys, birds and reptiles originating in the jungles of Siam.

ATLANTA, May 11 (AP) -- R. B. Ellison, named as one of the ringleaders in the recent "black raider" floggings, today pleaded guilty to participating in two terrorist whippings and received a sentence of three years.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell declared a mistrial yesterday in a $2,100,000 anti-trust suit against a group of motion-picture distributors after a defense attorney reported to him that two jurors, one of them a fashionably dressed blonde model, had been seen talking to a prospective witness for the plaintiffs at luncheon in a restaurant near the Federal Building.

It will become almost mandatory for Japan to be allowed to manufacture goods for export on a broad scale, including both specialty and mass market merchandise, to enable the country to strike a trade balance, K. Russell Knoblauch, vice president of the Brown Instrument Company, subsidiary of the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company, said here yesterday.

The loss of well trained psychiatric clinic personnel to private practice has "taken on serious proportions," according to the 1947 report of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, Inc., issued yesterday at headquarters, 1790 Broadway.

Reports giving the impression that the United States will be called upon for large quantities of hides, skins and leather financed by the Economic Cooperation Administration are "wholly unjustified by the tentative estimates of the State Department," the Tanners Council of America declared in a statement issued yesterday.

The first of the American Export Lines new "Four Aces" will be ready for service between New York and Mediterranean ports in mid-September, marking the company's post-war resumption of passenger ship service, John E. Slater, executive vice president of the steamship company, announced yesterday.

The state administration must help solve the problem of financing this city's schools, Andrew G. Clauson Jr., president of the Board of Education, declared yesterday after being re-elected unanimously by his fellow members to a third one-year term as board head.
CAMP CAMPBELL, Ky., May 11 -- Some of the world's largest, smallest and strangest aircraft were on display here today as the Army and the Air Force gave a preview of the shape of things to come.

SEOUL, Korea, May 11 -- Reports slowly trickling in from South Korea's nine provinces today indicated that it would be several days before the results of yesterday's general election, held under United Nations observation, would be evaluated.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- By a vote of 192 to 152, the House rejected today the Tennessee Valley Authority's plans for raising yearround production to meet all prospective demands for power in the seven-state area which it serves.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 11 -Floyd Odlum, chairman of the board of RKO-Radio Pictures, today announced the consummation of a deal for the transfer of the Atlas Corporation's controlling bloc of RKO stock to Howard Hughes after five months of negotiations.

Rare laces and pure-silk fabrics lavishly used characterized the custom - made trousseau fashions presented yesterday at the RitzCarlton Hotel by Emma Maloof of 444 Madison Avenue. Picturesque tea and hostess gowns of flowing chiffon and satin, elaborated with lace and applique detail, made up half of the show.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration granted $36,000,000 to China today for food, cotton, petroleum and fertilizer in the first allocation of funds to that country under the Foreign Assistance Act. An additional $500,000 was set aside for administrative expenses and engineering surveys of reconstruction projects in China.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 11 -- It developed tonight, after another unprofitable afternoon of debate, that there was virtually no possibility that the United Nations General Assembly could approve a provisional regime in Palestine before the termination of the British mandate this week.

PARIS, May 11 -- While expressing openly a feeling of relief at the prospect of peace talks between Washington and Moscow, French official and political circles nevertheless today displayed much reserve regarding the manner and outcome of any such negotiations.

BUENOS AIRES, May 11 -- A new antibiotic of the same group of organisms that produce streptomycin has been discovered here by an agronimist at the laboratories of the central experimental station of the Ministry of Agriculture.

Increased promotion of coffee in the United States will result in a rise of $300,000,000 in the coffee business, it was declared last night by George V. Robbins, president of the National Coffee Association. He spoke at a banquet for the delegates to the extraordinary Pan-American coffee conference, in the Plaza Hotel, where he emphasized that such an increase is necessary to support Western Hemisphere trade.

OBERURSEL, Germany, May -- About 1,000 refugee Czechs have received direct aid from the United States Army in a special Camp here since the Communist Group. Among them are Josef Cerny, former Minister of the Interior, and Dr. Ferdinand Veverke, former Ambassador to the United States.

MOSCOW, May 11 (AP) -- The Soviet press and radio gave wide publicity today to Russian acceptance of what they said was a United States 'proposal to confer on a settlement of their mutual differences.

Bedridden with paralysis as late as January, 1947, Miss Jamie Coffman, 25 years old, of Whiteville, Tenn., walked with the aid of crutches yesterday into the Biltmore Hotel, where she was honored at a luncheon as the Sweetheart of the Lions Club.

While communism forms the world menace to democracy, it is the "pro-Fascists" in this country who form a "native American fifth column," who must be exposed if traditional American liberties are to be retained, speakers at the twelfth annual dinner-meeting of the Friends of Democracy, Inc., declared last night.

With summer barely on the threshold, milliners are advancing their fall styles. Always the forerunners of new fashions, they showed new trends yesterday afternoon, in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre Hotel. These advanced spirits were the eight members of the Millinery Creators Guild: G. Howard Hodge, Vogue Hats (Garfunkel makers), Bernice Charles (Dave Herstein Co.), Germaine Montabert, Jeanne Tete, Milgrim Hats, Harryson Hats and Edgar J. Lorie.

Based on current production rates, carpet output this year will be 85,000,000 yards -- an all-time record, W. C. Hammel, vice president and general sales manager, Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company, estimated last night. He addressed a merchandising clinic and style show sponsored by the Carpet Institute, the Floor Coverings Distributors Council and the Metropolitan Carpet Club in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

PARIS, May 11 -- If the United States and the Soviet Union reached a comprehensive understanding, it would mean a revision of the entire European Recovery Program and the voting of new credits or a new distribution to include the countries of Eastern Europe, W. Averell Harriman declared today.
Among the by-products of the last war was the rediscovery of something partly spiritual. Army doctors, when they grasped its value and elusiveness, dubbed it TLC.

LONDON, May 11 -- Only 26 per cent of those engaged in coal mining in Britain are in the category of "productive" workers, whereas in the United States the bituminous mines average is 72 per cent, according to a report released here today by the National Coal Board.

Connecticut's use of radar in traffic supervision work is not a means to trap speeders, but is another weapon in the state's widening campaign to reduce highway accidents, Commissioner Edward J. Hickey of the Connecticut State Police has explained in an article in Public Safety magazine.

Mayor O'Dwyer made clear in his talk to the city's business men that construction of a Second Avenue Subway is still one of his foremost aims. Without it he sees no way to reduce substantially the frightening load on other rapid transit in Manhattan. He asks the support of business leaders in the steps necessary to finance this $500,000,000 project.

On the eve of his eighty-second birthday, the Right Rev. William T. Manning, retired bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, declared yesterday he was in favor of universal military training, and condemned what he called "sentimental pacifism" as inviting rather than preventing war.

CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) -- The National Basketball League today threatened court action in its fight with the rival Basketball Association of America over four, bolting clubs. At the same time, the N.B.L. announced it had issued a franchise to a Detroit syndicate associated with "Forum, Inc."
Stated that May 4 message to Moscow did not change American policy with regard to Russia.

Allie Reynolds, a more effective pitcher against the Indians than he ever was for them, strongarmed his former team-mates into submission yesterday as the Yankees snapped Cleveland's fivegame winning streak, 4 -- 1, before 29,723 spectators at the Stadium.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 11 (AP) -The Egyptian Senate approved tonight a proposal that the Egyptian Army "shall with other Arab armies enter Palestine at a suitable time to restore stability and prevent massacres in Palestine."

Richard S. Childs, in his recent letter commenting on the Italian elections, should have mentioned that the Christian Democrats won 53 per cent of the seats with slightly more than 48 per cent of the votes. Their majority, then, was won in spite of PR, not because of it.

Domestic production of steel fell off its record pace during April to a total of 6,229,762 net tons of ingots and steel for castings as the coal strike caused sharply curtailed operations, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. Production in the preceding month as 7,608,135 tons and in April, 1947, it was 7,042,697 tons.

General AssemblyCommittee I (Political and Security)--Adopted United Statesproposal calling for new Subcommittee 10 to examine further measures for protection ofJerusalem and to make recommendations to committee. Subcommittee 9 discussed basicpoints of working paper on provisional regime for Palestine.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- The population of the United States increased at an estimated rate of 2 per cent, the highest rate in the last two decades, in the 1947 fiscal year. Leon E. Truesdell, chief of the population division of the Bureau of the Census, reported today The Federal fiscal year of 1947 began July 1, 1940.
Al Shean of Gallagher Shean fame, will celebrate his eightieth birthday today, but -- "absolutely, Mr. Gallagher" -- he does not consider it a noteworthy event.

ONTARIO, Ore., May 11 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey declared today that the Soviet radio report that the Russians were prepared to sit down with representatives of this country to work out a peaceful solution of actual problems was "the best news since V-J Day if they mean it."

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Chloromycetin, the latest germ-killer isolated recently from a soil organism, has been found in the first human tests by the United States Army in Malaya to be "highly efficacious in the treatment of patients with scrub typhus."

The industrial building containing 7,500 square feet at 19 Hudson Street, New Rochelle, N.Y., has been sold by Philip Hacker to Isaac Aronoff through Harry D. Cole, broker. During the war Mr. Aronoff was a large producer of model airplanes used for target practice by Army and Navy airmen.
Random notes.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 11 -Princeton's baseball team suffered its sixth straight setback today, bowing to Rutgers, 5 -- 3, on University Field. Norm Morton went the route for the Scarlet, giving up only six hits and two walks, while his team-mates capitalized on the wildness of four Tiger hurlers to score their eleventh victory in twelve starts.

MAURICE WALSH, who says that his father knew all about horses and whisky, knows plenty about the same subjects; as why shouldn't he, being an Irishman, a sportsman and a writer? Mr. Walsh has been producing a novel every two years since 1922, a grand parade of good adventure stories and engaging romances which have never found the public they deserve on this side of the Atlantic Ocean.
ST. LOUIS, May 11 -- Rained out of a game for the second successive afternoon in Chicago today, the Giants hustled here by rail tonight to run into more bad news.

ROME, May 11 -- Senator Luigi Einaudi, First Vice Premier and Minister of the Budget in the present Government, was elected President of the Italian Republic by the combined Senate and Chamber of Deputies on the fourth ballot this evening.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 11 -Despite tremendous expenditures under the European Recovery Program, the nation's exports will be "considerably less" this year than last year's volume of $19,600,000,000 Raymond Rodgers, Professor of Banking at the New York University School of Commerce, predicted here today at the New Haven Lawn Club.

NEW DELHI, May 11 -- Earl Mountbatten, the Governor General of India, has invited the Nizam of Hyderabad -- reputedly the richest man in the world and currently one of the world's most uncertain royal rulers -- to visit him in New Delhi.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 12 -Most London critics agreed today their New York colleagues had been justified in giving "All My Sons," by Arthur Miller, their highest award last year. The play, which opened last night at the Lyric, in Hammersmith, a suburb, was greeted by W. A. Darlington of The Daily Telegraph as "the best serious play that America has sent us for some time."

LONDON, May 11 -- A parcel post bomb was delivered today to the home of Lieut. Gen. Sir Evelyn Barker, former British military commander in Palestine, who is on the Stern Group's death list. The bomb did not explode.

The United States Associates of the International Chamber of Commerce, headed by C. R. Smith, chairman of the board of American Airlines and president of American Overseas Airlines, yesterday made a report of a study of international air commerce.

THE thousand-mile-long peninsula stretching from the mouth of the Baltic to the Arctic Circle had an immense strategic significance. The Norwegian mountains run into the ocean in a continuous fringe of islands. Between these islands and the mainland there was a corridor in territorial waters through which Germany could communicate with the outer seas to the grievous injury of our Blockade.

Your editorial on April 25 on "The Central Issue," pointing out that the weakness of democracy rather than the inherent strength of dictatorships is what has given power to the enemies of democracy, whether they were Nazi Fascist or Communist, was a masterpiece as far as it went.

New York University's baseball team was unable to cope with the combination of Bob Allard's excellent pitching and Lafayette's timely hitting lost its fifth game of the season yesterday, 13 -- 4, at Ohio Field. The triumph was the victor's seventh against six defeats.

The Yeshivah Rambam-B'nai Israel has purchased the onestory temple building at the northwest corner of East Thirtysecond Street and Kings Highway, Brooklyn, from the Kingsway Jewish Community Center of Flatbush.

There were no standout events listed at the Jamaica race track yesterday, but the lackluster card did not deter 25,648 fans from turning out anyway. The race that attracted greatest attention was the six-furlong Devon for a purse of $4,000.
PARIS, May 11 (UP) -- The first comment from behind the Iron Curtain on the notes was that the exchange was a victory for Russian policy. In Prague, the newspaper Pravo Ladu said:

A group of city officials and their guests made a two-and-ahalf hour run in the East and North Rivers yesterday aboard the recently reconditioned Municipal ferryboat President Roosevelt, which re-enters service between South Ferry and St. George, S.I., today after an absence of two years.

PARIS, May 11 -- Gold prices on the French Stock Exchange and the black market rate for the dollar declined sharply today following the news that the Russians were prepared to discuss a settlement of disagreements with the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The stop-gap draft and selective training of 18-year-old youths as military reserves were approved by the Senate Armed Services Committee today, but under circumstances involving the issue of racial segregation in the armed forces that indicated trouble ahead for both proposals.

SHAWNEE - ON - DELAWARE, May 11 -- Secrecy surrounding the many projects in atomic energy has seriously hampered developments for defense and for peacetime commercial and social application, Dr. C. Rogers McCullough of Monsanto Chemical Company and consultant to the Power Pile Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, asserted here today.

The fifteen-story apartment house with fifty suites at 166-74 West Eighty-sixth Street has been sold by Leo and Bertha Tower, after an ownership of three years, to the North Nineteenth Street Corporation for cash above a mortgage of $388,000, held by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

THE Cleveland Indians straggled into their dressing room at the Yankee Stadium yesterday by twos and threes. But there was a buoyant lift in each step as if every little Indian was highly elated by the fast start the Tribe has made this season. There hasn't been such optimism since those sad days of long ago when Cleveland annually was picked to win the pennant and invariably wound up in third place.

ATHENS, May 11 -- A rebel force numbering 1,500 has been surrounded on the densely wooded slopes of Mount Hassia in Thessaly, according to press messages reaching here from Trikkala. These messages suggest that the rebels had taken the offensive and find themselves in their present predicament as the result of a quick counter move by the National Army.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- Leston B. Nay, president of the First Securities Company of Chicago, told a Securities and Exchange Commission Board of Inquiry today that the recent common stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation was such a "mess" that his company adopted a three-point program to safeguard the interests of its clients.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 11 -- Mayor O'Dwyer of New York plainly indicated here today that he had abandoned any hope or interest in President Truman's re-election.
BALTIMORE, May 11 (AP) -Lazy F. Ranch's Nathaniel found the dry-cushioned strip to his liking at Pimlico today and he won the Jennings Handicap by a neck.

After hearing that the Governmentcontrolled board of directors of the American Bemberg Corporation was considering the desirability of merging the company with the North American Rayon Corporation, a companion organization, minority stockholders of the former company pressed yesterday vigorous attacks against the Office of Alien Property, the majority stockholder, for its stand on a large number of corporate matters.

Normal was the word to describe travel conditions in the nation yesterday. The Army, by direction of the President, was operating the railroads, but so far as the ordinary traveler was concerned, the threatened railroad strike, the seizure of the roads by the Government, the operation under Army control, all were events to read about in the newspapers.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -Some Congressmen holding union cards found their $12,500 annual salaries momentarily jeopardized today by the House Appropriations Committee.

LONDON, May 11 -- The principal reaction to the Soviet's acceptance of the proposal of the United States to talk over "differences" was an advance in prices of European bonds in the stock market here today. Austrian, German, Greek and Hungarian issues gained as much as 1 1/4 points.

Henry A. Wallace made public last night "an open letter to Premier Stalin," in which the third-party Presidential nominee veered slightly more toward "center" in his political thinking than he had previously.

The annual report of the United States Lines Company, mailed to stockholders yesterday, showed for 1947 a net profit of $10,145,572 transferred to earned surplus, compared with the 1946 adjusted profit of $7,630,044. The 1947 net included an operating profit of $8,491,159 and a profit of $1,654,413 from nonrecurring transactions.

PARIS, May 11 -- The present and probably temporary relaxation in Soviet-American relationships results from a well-timed "smoking out" operation by Washington. What will come of it is impossible to predict.

The 165th annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York refused to act yesterday on a resolution condemning the use of lotteries and gambling wheels as money-raising devices for church projects. The convention met in the Snyod House of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street.

Seattle, Wash., announced yesterday that it would receive bids June 1 on $7,500,000 of lighting and parks bonds dated July 1, 1948 due in two to twenty years and callable either on July 1, 1953, or July 1, 1958.

The traffic commission proposed by the city's Department of Commerce "looks like another attempt to solve New York City's traffic ills by setting up a debating club to be known as the Division of Planning and Performance in a traffic commission operated by the Police Department under its usual power," C. McKim Norton, executive vice president of the Regional Plan Association, Inc., declared yesterday.

Declaring that the crisis in Palestine had put the Jewish scene "out of focus," Dr. Israel Mattuck of London, leader of the Liberal Jewish Synagogue, declared last night that creation of a Jewish state would affect adversely the position of Jews throughout the world.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Officials here today canvassed all possible reasons why the Kremlin breached diplomatic custom and the confidence of the Government of the United States by making public unilaterally the American note of May 4. It is the first time the Soviet authorities have committed such a violation of the amenities.
BATON ROUGE, La., May 11 (AP) -- Earl Kemp Long became Governor of Louisiana today with a slogan and a program made famous by his late brother, Senator Huey P. Long.

Philip Silverstein, operator of Utopia Service Stations, Inc., has purchased the plot about 71 by 60 feet at the northwest corner of 192d Street and Station Road in Auburndale, Queens, from Clinton T. Roe and plans to improve it with a service station.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., May 11 -Culminating fifty-one years of a useful existence that served boys from practically every state, the National Farm School and Junior College became today a senior four-year college, authorized by the Pennsylvania State Council of Education to grant the Bachelor of Science Degree.

With efforts to import oil being steadily increased, a significant development was yesterday's announcement by the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., that it had just received its 1,000,000th barrel of crude oil from the Persian Gulf. That milestone was reached yesterday with the delivery at the company's refinery at Paulsboro, N.J., of a cargo of 110,000 barrels after a thirty-day trip from the Middle East.

System companies of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation spent $93,901,748 last year for additional property and plant improvement, Justin R. Whiting, president, revealed in the annual report to stockholders, being distributed today.

Net earnings of M. Lowenstein Sons for the first three months of this year were $4,620,562, equal to $4.52 a share of common stock, it was reported yesterday by the cotton textile manufacturing concern. For the initial quarter of 1947, net earnings were $2,280,000 or $2.28 a share.

The role of Hollywood screen stars who adopted children was reversed yesterday when five youngsters representing the American Overseas Aid-United Nations Appeal for Children "adopted" Miss Madeleine Carroll in a ceremony at the Astor Hotel. The!youngsters wore costumes of various countries aided through thecurrent appeal for $6,600,000, whileMiss Carroll wore a Navy bluespring suit.
Jack D. Mendelson has been appointed field sales director for Air King Products Company, Inc., Brooklyn, manufacturers of radios, combinations, wire recorders and television receivers.
Its battle with the Boxing Managers Guild settled amicably, the Twentieth Century Sporting Club yesterday announced three tenround bouts would head the card at Madison Square Garden Friday night.
LONDON, May 11 (AP) -- King George and Queen Elizabeth will hold two court presentations at Buckingham Palace tomorrow and Thursday for the first time since 1939.

OSLO, Norway, May 11 -- A conquering hero's welcome greeted Winston Churchill on his arrival here by air today from The Hague. One more European capital added its tribute in flowers, flags, cheers and tears to the man hailed here as the "Liberator of Europe."

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Companion bills introduced today in the House and Senate, with the backing of the Joint Air Policy Board, would authorize development and construction, under Federal auspices, of transport airplanes adapted to both military and civilian operation.

The battle to retain possession of The Second Presbyterian Church, 6 West Ninety-sixth Street, waged by numerous Scottish organizations, appeared to have been won yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein accepted a bid of $850,000 from the Rev. L. Humphrey Walz, the church's minister, in the County Court House, and reserved decision in the foreclosure sale.
Several long-term benefits have begun to be realized as a result of the formation of the State Food Commission last fall, Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Commissioner of Health, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- Corn developed independent strength on the Board of Trade today and closed at the top with gains of 1 7/8 to 4 1/2 cents a bushel, May leading, the latter going into new ground since April 21. Oats also were strong and up 1 1/8 to 2 1/8 cents with July leading.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -Dr. I. I. Gardescu, geologist for the Trans-Continental Gas Pipeline Company, Inc., testified today that the company had more than adequate reserves to meet requirements for twenty years. The company proposes to build a 26-inch, 1,400-mile pipeline from Texas to the Eastern Seaboard at an estimated cost of about $180,000,000.

Columbia University was named principal legatee in the will of Mrs. Kate La Montagne Butler, widow of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president emeritus of the university, offered for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Mrs. Butler, who was 83 years old, died May 4, leaving an estate formally valued at "more than $20,000."

The Manhattan Realty Company has purchased the one-story taxpayer building at 802-806 South Orange Avenue, corner of Vermont Avenue, Newark, N.J., from Morris Lennett and Associates. The Asset Realization Company, broker in this transaction, also reports the sale of the property at 1280 North Broad Street, Hillside, for the Carlton Holding Company to the Jay Realty Company, which will alter it for use as a restaurant.

JERUSALEM, May 11 -- Jerusalem's cease-fire fell to pieces tonight while Fawzi el-Kawukji, field commander of the Arab Liberation Army, personally led a desperate attempt to regain control of the Jerusalem-Tel Aviv highway.

John Foster Dulles, Republican foreign policy expert, cautioned Americans yesterday to shun the appeal of violence by which, he said, Soviet communism had fired the imagination of youth, the underprivileged and the hopeless. He emphasized, rather, the need for a revival of dynamic, contagious faith in American institutions to meet the "serious" Russian challenge.

Martin's of Brooklyn met summer yesterday with clothes for a boardwalk stroll, for a summer club dance and for grandchild and grandmother in a display at the St. George Hotel to aid the charities to be helped by the Brooklyn Week for the Blind.

BOSTON, May 11 (AP) -- Aided by two home runs by Vern Stephens and one by Bobby Doerr, the Red Sox today blanked the White Sox, 8 -- 0, behind the six-single pitching of handsome Jack Kramer, against whom only one enemy base runner advanced so far as second base.

The Empire Liquor Corporation plans to move from 239 West Sixtysixth Street to the Bronx, where it has purchased the one-story building at 816-26 East 140th Street from Fred Kalmbach in a cash transaction. The Bronx building, 150 by 100 feet, will be used by the distillery concern for its main office and warehouse.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -The House passed today the Bulwinkle bill permitting railroads and other carriers to make agreements on rates, with immunity under the anti-trust laws if such agreements are approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon called upon his Republican colleagues today to uphold the party's stand on civil rights and send back to committee a House-approved bill endorsing a compact to establish regional universities for Negroes in the South.
Following is the text of Henry A. Wallace's "open letter to Premier Stalin," as distributed last night at the Wallace rally at Madison Square Garden:

The American Bible Society distributed 829,737 complete Bibles in 1947, more than in any previous year, according to a report to be given at the 132d annual meeting at 3 P.M. tomorrow at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftyfirst Street.

MONTREAL, May 11 -- Buddy O'Connor, lightweight play-making center of the New York Rangers, set hockey history today by winning both the Hart and Lady Byng trophies in the same National Hockey League season.

The trial of Bernardino Mastromonaco, who had been indicted for alleged complicity in a will fraud plot to obtain the $280,000 estate of an elderly spinster, ended yesterday afternoon in a disagreement when a General Sessions jury reported it was "hopelessly dead locked" and could not reach a verdict.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday and final prices were to 12 points net lower.

LONDON, May 11 -- The British Government put forward today constitutional proposals for Cyprus that plainly indicated Britain's intention to hold on to the island colony, which was acquired 70 years ago, as a strategic outpost in the eastern Mediterranean.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 11 (AP) -- Stockholders of Panhandle Producing and Refining Company, New York and Wichita Falls, Tex., voted today to eliminate preemptive rights to stockholders with respect to all issues of common or securities convertible into common when issued for cash.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 11 -- Diplomats from East and West agreed today that understanding between the Soviet Union and the United States would make the United Nations an overnight success, but the curve of hopefulness dipped steadily throughout the day.

LONDON, May 11 -- The most embarrassed man in Great Britain today was United States Ambassador Lewis W. Douglas. He knew nothing whatever about the suggested Soviet-United States negotiations and hence could tell Foreign Secretary Bevin nothing about them when the latter asked him this morning.
Citadel Realty was co-broker in the recent sale of the taxpayer at the northeast corner of 215th Street and Horace Harding Boulevard, Bayside, Queens, by George Brezel to Morris Teitelbaum.

The Medal of Honor of the National Sculpture Society was presented last night to Adolph A. Weinman, honorary president of the society, at a dinner in the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street. Since the society was founded in 1893, the award, recognizing outstanding contribution to the fine arts, has been granted to only eight.

Rich-looking carpeting with a scroll pattern worked in two heights of thick pile is outstanding not only for its lustrous all-over design but because it is the first all-nylon carpeting to be ready for consumers. Introduced yesterday after eight years of research by the Nye-Wait Company, it is available through Sloane's.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,121, against 1,222 last week and 1,294 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 537 arrivals yesterday, compared with 441 last Tuesday.

Renewed fighting last night impaired, at least temporarily, the hope that either today or tomorrow Jerusalem will be declared an open city by common consent of both Jews and Arabs. For this hope the International Red Cross, operating through its chief representative in Palestine, Jacques de Reynier, has been given high credit.

Deliveries of cheese, butter, eggs and cream to independent grocers, dairies and delicatessens in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx will be sharply curtailed if 500 members of Local 202, International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs, AFL, go through with plans for a strike Monday.
Offerings of public utility and industrial securities having a total market value of more than $48,000,000 will be made by underwriting managers here today as follows:

William White, president of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, disclosed yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders here that the company owns 46,700 shares, or 13.8 per cent of the common stock of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad, and said that the Lackawanna management hopes eventually to merge the two roads.

Play in the twenty-third round of the tournament for the chess championship of the world, which already has been annexed by Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia, failed to disturb the relative standing of the five competitors at the Hall of Colums in Moscow yesterday, according to a report from the Soviet capital.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Unnecessary obstructions to the flow and function of risk capital in the form of double taxation of dividends, treatment of capital gains and discriminatory margin requirements must be removed to avoid governmental interference in business, Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, declared here tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey today registered 1,265,255 shares of capital stock with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The shares are to be offered in exchange for outstanding common stock of the International Petroleum Company, Ltd., which operates in Peru and Venezuela and has a subsidiary operating in Colombia.

Wholesale prices of some fresh vegetables and fruits were lowered yesterday as continued plenty was assured by the seasonal increase in production and the end of the railroads' embargo against perishable freight. A spokesman for the Department of Agriculture said meat prices might decline at retail next week.

One can start the morning coffee by pushing a button in the bedroom, turn off the living room radio while answering the telephone in the hall, or perform a dozen other remote control feats by means of a new wiring system announced yesterday by General Electric.

Theodore Charles Stone, Chicago baritone, who made a favorable impression at his debut here last year, gave his second New York recital last night at Times Hall. There was an advance in artistry, but he still has not fully developed as a mature singer.

BERLIN, May 11 -- The Soviet Union's sudden public acceptance of the "invitation" to bilateral talks with the United States was regarded in official quarters here as an indication of the Russians' eagerness to open discussions that might lead to an at least temporary settlement of differences.

NANKING, May 11 -- About 250,000 Communist troops were reported today to be massing for a new offensive in Manchuria after a ten-week fighting lull in that crucial civil war theatre. Most of the roads are now dry following the spring thaws, and Red Gen. Lin Piao is maneuvering his mobile assault forces in a preattack pattern reminiscent of his two-months "winter offensive" that ended late in February.

Nothing has happened to alter the original impression of Richard Harrity's "Hope Is the Thing With Feathers." It is an original and moving play with a compassionate point of view. Having been introduced by the Experimental Theatre a few weeks ago, it was acted again at The Playhouse last night with two other short plays by Mr. Harrity.

Luigi Einaudi was elected last night as the first President of the Italian Republic. Distinctly a dark horse, the way to the executive chair was opened for him by withdrawal of Count Carlo Sforza. The final vote stood at 518 for Einaudi and 320 for Orlando, aged elder statesman who was Premier in the First World War.

BERLIN, May 11 -- Weaknesses in the Soviet Union's economy and the necessity of consolidating newly won territory and integrating its industry in the Russian economic structure lie behind Soviet willingness, as expressed in Foreign Minister Molotov's note, to enter into discussions with the United States, a reliable source declared today.

The stock market yesterday broke into new high ground for the year as a result of domestic labor and international developments. Few of the heavy industrials gained 1 to 2 points, but the price index only added 0.34 point. The aircrafts was the only group to show major weakness.

The National Broadcasting Company has leased three RKO Pathe sound studios at 106th Street and Park Avenue for the expansion of its television facilities, it was announced yesterday. When the new studios are put into service, they will bring to five the number operated in this city by the network.

PARIS, May 11 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, United States Ambassador to Moscow, said today that he regarded as confidential his exchange of notes with Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov on SovietAmerican relations.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- President Truman denied today that there was any change in this country's policy toward the Soviet Union.

" The Iron Curtain," a Twentieth Century-Fox topical drama about Russian espionage in Canada, starring Dana Andrews and Gene Tierney, will have its premiere this morning at the Roxy. The picture, based on the personal story of Igor Gouzenko, former code clerk in the U.S.S.R. Embassy in Ottawa, was directed by William A. Wellman and produced by Sol C. Siegel.

Celanese Corporation of America will issue in its June promotion kits what it believed to be the first television commercial produced by a manufacturer for use by retailers, it was announced yesterday at a preview held at the CBS television studios, 15 Vanderbilt Avenue.
Local 50 of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union, AFL, will serve notice today on any or all of the "Big Eight" baking companies in New York of intention to strike sometime Friday.
Several upsets marked the third round of the interclub cup series matches of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday.
Fordham pulled a second straight extra-inning Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game out of the fire yesterday when it beat Brooklyn College, 14 -- 8, on the loser's diamond.

I-Iaving earned the approval ofeight of the nine critics for "ThePlay's the Thing," Michael Ellis!and James Russo, co-sponsors withGilbert lViiller of the Molnar rexval, are pondering the potentialities of two scripts. One is tentatively called "Hardwood," an Irishcomedy by Leslie MacLeod.

It is obvious that in such a monumental work as Winston Churchill's Memoirs slips may occur. May I therefore ask your kind permission to comment on a statement made by Britain's greatest national figure which appeared in his memoirs in your issue of April 30?

Vrhimsical designs In sombertones have been applied to decorative tiles by Warner Prins, whopresented his latest pieces yesterday at his showroom in 10 Rockefeller Plaza. The dark colors andfree-flowing abstract motifs makethe tiles usable as inserts in coffeetables, book ends, pictures, ashtrays or other accessories.

NUREMBERG, Germany, May 12 -- The unexpectedly sudden conclusion yesterday of testimony in the trial of I.G. Farben officials -twenty-four hours ahead of schedule -- brought estimates at the Palace of Justice here today that judgment might be expected sometime in July.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -Frazer A. Bailey, president of the National Federation of American Shipping, today urged broadened Federal shipbuilding subsidies to strengthen the merchant fleet for national defense.

The number of Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference players barred from further college competition because of participation with professional clubs reached nine yesterday. Tom Cusmano, Fordham captain, and Sam Piacentino, City College's star right-hand pitcher, were declared ineligible.

Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, yesterday described the facilities at New York International Airport at Idlewild as far surpassing in convenience and roominess those available at La Guardia for the foreign flag airlines that will move to the new field on July 1.
CAMP CAMPBELL, Ky., May 12 -- The nation's largest post-war maneuver, which ended its major phase here today, has revealed numerous training weaknesses, official observers agree.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 -- Dr. Robert E. Wilson, chairman of the board of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana and a recognized authority in the petroleum and chemical industries, predicted tonight that there will be a 5 per cent increase in petroleum supplies for domestic consumption this year.

New developments and methods for improving sales effectiveness of store and window advertising displays were presented yesterday in a symposium and exhibit held by the Point of Purchase Advertising Institute at the Biltmore Hotel.

A Broadway showcase has been found for the Arthur Goodman play, "Seeds in the Wind." Yesterday Eunice Healey, Harald Bromley and Herbert Freezer, producers of the incoming attraction, concluded booking arrangements with Lester Meyer for the use of the Empire Theatre.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -Following is the text of Secretary of State Marshall's news conference statement today on the exchange of notes between the United States and the Soviet Union:

Chinese hooked rug importers yesterday tabled plans for action to bring about a 50 per cent tariff reduction for these products. The Oriental Rug Importers Association already had begun preliminary action in the matter when it was learned that the Government cannot put the cut into effect until India and Pakistan sign the Geneva Trade Agreements.

Frank Edwinn, bass, disclosed uncommon interpretive skill at his first New York recital last night at Town Hall. With remarkable positiveness and insight for an artist in his mid-twenties, he knew how to make his offering communicative and fraught with mood and meaning.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Robert W. Janshoff, a trader in the local office of Otis Co., Cleveud investment banking concern, denied today that he had told representatives of any brokerage companies here on Feb. 3 that the common stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation would be made the next day at $13 a share, or 50 cents less than the market price on Feb. 3.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Corn futures continued their sensational advance on the Board of Trade today, closing at the top with gains of 3 to 6 1/2 cents a bushel, May leading and being up 13 3/8 cents from the low on Monday and the highest since April 16 as the result of heavy short-covering, which found offerings light.

Applications for charge accounts in retail stores since May 1 in the Metropolitan area are up approximately 11 per cent over the corresponding period last year, a survey of credit officials showed yesterday. The increase was traced in part to a gradual disappearance of depression fear on the part of the consumer.

America still presents the greatest field of opportunity and adventure -- "as great as ever existed before," Bernard M. Baruch, 77year-old financier, philanthropist and adviser to Presidents, declared testerday after receiving one of six Horatio Alger Awards from the American Schools and Colleges Association.

With both Senate and House now scheduled to take up next week their differing Selective Service measures, the danger persists that in the bitter fights forecast over the question of Universal Military Training and racial segregation Selective Service itself will be so crippled or delayed that the manpower crisis in the armed services will be continued and even deepened.

A squad of sixteen players representing the famous Liverpool Football Club of England and including three English, three Scotch and two Welsh internationals, arrived here yesterday afternoon aboard the Queen Elizabeth of the Cunard White Star Line.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Several hundred delegates of fortytwo nations attending the joint international congresses on tropical medicine and malaria witnessed a dramatic aerial demonstration today at the agricultural research center of the United States Department of Agriculture, Beltsville, Md., of all the latest weapons in man's age old warfare against insects.
TEL AVIV, Palestine, May 12--The Haganah, Zionist Militia, will take over the military occupation of Arab Jaffa tomorrow, just one day before the new Jewish state is proclaimed.

Because of its traditional policy of tolerance and brotherhood, the Boy Scout movement in Russian satellite nations has been stamped out, Lord Rowallan, chief Scout of the British Commonwealth and Empire, declared on his arrival here yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth.

In recognition of his services to the city's voluntary hospitals, Roy E. Larsen, president of the United Hospital Fund, received last night a scroll at the annual dinner of the Greater New York Hospital Association. The dinner, which took place at the Commodore Hotel, was the climax of many celebrations by the city's hospitals of National Hospital Day.

THE end of the year 1939 left the war still in its sinister trance. An occasional cannonshot or reconnoitering patrol alone broke the silence of the Western Front. The Armies gaped at each other from behind their rising fortifications across an undisputed "NoMan's-Land."

Declaring that the international situation is moving rapidly toward a major climax, Adolf A. Berle Jr., State Chairman of the Liberal party and former Assistant Secretary of State, said last night that he did not believe there would be any war with Russia.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 12 -- Lord Pakenham British Minister for Austria and Germany, said today the Western Allies were prepared to give a West German government a military guarantee against possible reprisals.

NANKING, May 12 -- The Government's application of imaginative political techniques is proving successful in the Peiping-PaotingTientsin triangle of Hopeh Province. Gen. Wang Feng-kang is credited with having driven Communist guerrillas from this small but important section of the North China countryside by reducing land rents, unifying tax collection and establishing a loyal peasant militia.

If one may judge by current crop reports, domestic and foreign, nature would seem to have entered, to some extent at least, into the spirit of the European Recovery Plan. Although this country will not equal last year's record wheat production, it is now clear that we came through the serious crop threat of last winter with a minimum of damage and that we are going to have another bumper output.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The drastic House appropriations cut on social security administration, from $1,686,579 to $221,000, was protested before the Senate Appropriations Committee today by labor and child-welfare representatives.
Apropos Noise Abatement Week and the earnest appeal to motorists to observe it by the director of safety, Automobile Club of New York. Will they do it?
