WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -Senator William F. Knowland, Republican, of California, denounced Senator Taylor, a candidate for the vice presidency on the third party ticket of Henry Wallace, in the Senate today after Senator Taylor had criticized President Truman and called the Secretary of Defense James Forrestal, "a potential Hitler."

OSLO, Norway, May 12 -- Before a gathering of 1,000 Norwegians, including King Haakon and political, military and academic leaders, Winston Churchill received the honorary degree of doctor of Philosophy from the Oslo University today.

The opening of "Clandestine," the French feature film drama about the resistance, slated for the Stanley on Saturday, has been changed to Saturday, May 22, it was announced yesterday by the management. "Triumph of Youth," a Russian - made feature - length documentary in color dealing with the 1947 all-Soviet youth festival in Moscow, will be the associate attraction on the program.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 12 -President Truman, Thomas E. Dewey and Henry A. Wallace were bracketed together tonight by Harold E. Stassen as he arrived after a transcontinental overnight air trip to begin a final week-long drive to win Oregon's twelve delegates to the Republican National convention.

" The Precipice," a new novel by Hugh MacLennan, has been scheduled for September publication by Duell, Sloan Pearce. It is a story of a Canadian girl who spends most of her life in the United States. Mr. MacLennan is the author of "Two Solitudes," which won the Canadian Governor General's Literary Award for fiction as the best novel of 1945.
Changes among the executives of Scripps-Howard enterprises were announced yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 12 -- The United States won the first round today of a United Nations struggle between the American trusteeship plan for Jerusalem and a new and vastly strengthened version of the British plan for a special municipal commissioner for the holy city.

SOME expert once figured out that there are 150 different ways in which a horse race can be lost. That sounds rather ominous for Citation, the top-heavy favorite to annex the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday. Or does it? The ordinary rules of the turf just don't seem to apply to this sensational colt who wears the devil red silks of Calumet.
BOSTON, May 12 -- The convention of the United Steelworkers, CIO, repudiated the third-party movement today amid repeated outbursts of anti-Communist feeling.

The confusion created by Soviet Russia's deliberate misrepresentation of the exchange of notes with the United States, which led both to false hopes and to false alarms, has now been clarified beyond the possibility of further misunderstanding by the statements of President Truman, Foreign Secretary Bevin, and especially Secretary Marshall, whose language is particularly to the point.

Dr. Harry J. Carman, dean of Columbia College, announced yesterday that Robert Silbert of Brooklyn and Bernard W. Wishy of Manhattan had been designated valedictorian and salutatorian of the class of '48. They will speak at Class Day exercises on May 31.

To meet the problems of an increasingly complex economy, Dr. G. Rowland Collins, dean of the Graduate School of Business Administration at New York University, yesterday urged insurance leaders to develop systematic employee education and training for all levels of employment.

Daniel G. Arnstein, who had to quit school when he was 13 years old to go to work at $2 a week but who now owns a fleet of taxicabs that gives employment toh)0*0*0*i1,800 persons, thinks it is a good idea to have a college education even though he never had that chance.

When meat is scarce, as it was during the war, or high-priced, as it is now, housewives are forced into buying less of it. To mak up for protein losses caused by its absence, menus must be mapped out knowingly. Especially is this true if there are youngsters in the household, for protein is a "must" for growth, which means it's specially requisite for children.

LONDON, Thursday, May 13 -Nearly half of the editorial page of The Times of London is devoted this morning to two commentaries on the fiftieth anniversary of a speech by Joseph Chamberlain, a senior British Cabinet Minister, in 1898.

More awareness of need for counseling and a shortage of specialists competent to give it add up to a real dilemma now faced by parents, according to the Child Study Association of America. To have a pediatrician say of a child's illness, "

An entirely new type of furniture construction which is hard to believe even when seen has been incorporated into the latest designs by Alvar Aalto, Finnish architect. It was exhibited to the press yesterday at the showroom of Finsven, Inc., 925 Madison Avenue.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 12 -- A team of specialists from the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund is on its way to Germany to report on the needs of children in connection with requests for aid received from the commanders of the United States and British zones of occupation, the fund announced here today.

LONDON, May 12 -- The first meeting of the Permanent Military Committee of the five Western Union nations was held here in secret May 5 and was devoted principally to devising security measures to safeguard confidential military information that will ultimately be pooled, it was learned today.

A collection of 150 manuscripts and printed books from the renowned library formed by Baron Horace de Landau at Florence, Italy, will be on sale July 12 and 13 at Sotheby Co. of London, it was announced yesterday. Fiftytwo of the most important items will be on exhibit here from June 7 to 19 at the Rosenbach Company, 322 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Tonight's events: Contemporary American Music Festival, St. Paul's Chapel, 8:30 o'clock; Carnegie Pop concert, Viennese program, Richard Karp, conductor, Elaine Malbin, soprano, John Hendrik, tenor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Lisa Gentry, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30; Sarah Lawrence College Chorus and Dance Group, Times Hall, 8:30; Doctors Orchestral Society, Hunter College Auditorium, 8:30; Leon Kushner, pianist, Manhattan School of Music, 328 East 105th Street, 8:15.
Dallas, Tex., will receive on June 1 bids on $3,580,000 of street, parks, storm sewer and airport bonds to mature within twenty years.

To help relieve the shortage of skilled Negro social workers, three fellowships valued at $600 each have been opened to college students in the metropolitan area who can meet the admission requirements of the New York School of Social Work, Columbia University, it was announced yesterday.
SEOUL, Korea, May 12 -- Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge has demanded an immediate conference with the Russians over the threats of North Koreans to cut off power to the American zone in the South.
TEL AVIV, May 12 (UP) United States Secretary of State Marshall has sent a personal message to David Ben-Gurion, the Premierdesignate of the Jewish state, reliable sources said today.

WARSAW, Poland, May 12 The Socialist newspaper Robothik reported today that a third Polish newspaper man had applied unsuccessfully so far, for a United States visa and in a bitter editorial entitled "Enough of This Two-Faced Game" asked for reciprocal treatment of correspondents from the United States.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 12 -- Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands told her people in a broadcast this afternoon that she would abdicate in favor of Princess Juliana next September after the celebration of her Golden Jubilee.

Recent rains followed by warm weather yesterday brought into full bloom 60,000 Dutch tulips that have been planted by the Department of Parks in the traffic islands along Park Avenue between Thirtyfourth and Thirty-ninth Streets and at the Central Park Plaza at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

Arrangements have been completed for the "Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air" to return to the WJZ-ABC network early in the fall. The Metropolitan Opera Association will continue to cooperate in the series, for which the Farnsworth Television and Radio Corporation will remain the sponsor.

PITTSBURGH, May 12 (AP) -Blix Donnelly, Philadelphia pitcher, today gave only three hits to beat Pittsburgh, 5 -- 0, in the Pirates' first National League shut-out defeat of the season. The little right hander was in control all the way while Pittsburgh used three pitchers, who permitted 13 hits.

PARIS, May 12 -- France's extensive road system, ravaged by the passage of heavy German and Allied military equipment during the war, is still far from its prewar condition, according to a report made today by the French Road Union, a group of automotive and road transport interests.

On May 28, when the Post Office Department opens the sale in Washington of the Four Chaplains Memorial stamp, the National Conference of Christians and Jews will sponsor a special cachet. It will show the four clergymen, as depicted in the stamp and in a painting, standing on deck with locked arms as their ship went down.

The founders, officers and board of directors of Thrift House, a rummage shop operated by volunteers at 39 West Fifty-seventh Street for the benefit of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, were honored yesterday by the Women's Division Board of the federation.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange became somewhat irregular yesterday and closed 43 points higher to 7 points lower. The old-crop months -- May and July -- showed the most strength.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 12 -New York University, taking advantage of the sparkling six-hit pitching of Tom Casey, provided some timely batting to defeat Army 2 to 1, in the rain at Doubleday Field today.

Baseball without hot dogs maybe the menu at New York ballparks next week if plans of Local 50, Bakery and Confectionery$Vorkers Union, AFL, to strikeagainst the Gottfried BakingCompany tomorrow materialize.

Guided by experts in their field, literary-minded patients at St. A1bans Naval Hospital occupy themselves by writing material for shows. A play written under the supervision of the Authors Workshop for Veterans, a non-profit organization is to be presented Thursday mght, May 27, at Lost Battalion Hall, 93-29 Queens Boulevard.

As the opening speaker before the convention of the Aviation Writers Association yesterday Howard Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, was able to report encouraging progress in providing for this region the airport facilities appropriate to its position as a crossroads of the air world.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- What may be the test case before the Supreme Court on a company's duty regarding social security programs was enunciated today by a trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board, J. J. Fitzpatrick.

PARIS, May 12 -- Slender sleeves on fur coats for next winter form only one of a wealth of ideas that greeted the press at Jacques Heim's important mid-season showing of charming clothes ranging from beach wear to an autumn prelude in furs.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., May 12 -The way to stop Russia is to unite the non-Communist world in the determination to establish a world community and then to make every effort to get Russia to see that it is in her interest to join that community, James P. Warburg said here tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- After Secretary Marshall had read formal statement at today's news conference, he threw himself open to questions. The ensuing exchange between Secretary Marshall and correspondents, as reported in the third person, follows:

Restoration of sterling convertibility by Britain may take from two to five years, Dr. C. T. Murchison, president of the Cotton Textile Institute, said yesterday. He told the luncheon meeting of the textile section of the New York Board of Trade at the Pennsylvania Hotel that this was the impression taken away by the United States cotton delegation following its conferences with representatives of the British cotton industry at Manchester.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 12 -- The Amalgamated Clothing Workers, a pillar of the antiCommunist forces in the Congress of Industrial Organizations, demanded today that United States immigration authorities lift their ban on the entry into this country of five Canadian delegates to the union's convention.

An alleged rent gouger, who in one instance is said to have obtained a $3,000 bonus from a dentist for arranging a professional apartment lease in Stuyvesant Town, was arraigned yesterday in Special Sessions and accused of extorting excessive rentals from three persons.

The first reports of city-wide solicitation for the annual Greater New York Fund for $8,000,000 to meet the maintenance requirements of 423 participating agencies of health and welfare services, showed yesterday that $3,006,355 has been collected in a little more than two weeks.
At opposite poles of the new art exhibitions opening this week are exhibitions by self-taught painters and by the president of the Royal Academy.
LONDON, May 12 -- British Government bonds were the feature of a generally quiet stock market today. Small but steady investment buying brought gains of as much as a quarter.

Mayor O'Dwyer, in a goodhumored interchange with the City Hall reporters yesterday, conceded that he would campaign for President Truman if the President is nominated by the Democratic National Convention.

PARIS, May 12 -- Reassured by a first-hand account from Lieut. Gen. W. Bedell Smith that no two-power negotiations had been intended in the Moscow exchange, the French Cabinet today officially reaffirmed the French demand to be a party in any dealings on European or world settlement.
PENDLETON, Ore., May 12 -Gov. Thomas E. Dewey declared tonight that the only realistic course open to the United States was to "use its food production in the battle against communism."

SOUTHAMPTON, England, May 12 (AP) -- United States women golfers, after a rough Atlantic crossing, arrived on the Mauretania today to play a British team in the Curtis Cup matches at Birkdale on May 21 and 22.
Large straw brims, laden with flowers and tied with veils, made up the showing titled "Belmont Brims," presented yesterday at the Plaza Hotel by several of New York's leading millinery designers.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -American sales to Russian-bloc nations may be boosted by a Department of Commerce "catalogue" listing things they may buy from the United States, and under what terms.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 12 -A request that no representatives of the World Federation of Trade Unions be permitted to enter the Western zones of Germany "for the purpose of putting pressure on democratic trade unionists to become part of a totalitarian machine" will be addressed by the American Federation of Labor to the United States Military Government in Germany, it is learned here.

JERUSALEM, May 12 -- The Palestine administration announced today that the Mandate would formally end at midnight Friday [6 P. M. Eastern Daylight Time] and that the High Commissioner Lieut. Gen. Sir Alan G. Cunningham, would leave Jerusalem for Haifa that day and embark aboard the cruiser Euryalus.

BALTIMORE, May 12 (AP) -- Setting a new track record, Bayard Sharp's Lieut. Well took the $10,000 added Jervis Spencer Steeplechase Handicap for the second straight year at Pimlico today. The 7-year-old opened a long lead, but was a tiring winner a length and a half in front of Mrs. Esther duPont Weir's Canford in the thirty-sixth running of the 15jump two-mile affair.

Riding with the Allen T. Simmons' entry in the $19,725 Remsen Handicap at Jamaica yesterday was $100,545 of the $201,726 win pool. It was a safe ride. The Okron radio executive's Eternal World won it with hardly any trouble and his Swords Town cut in for a sliver of the purse by finishing fourth.
A committee of nine residents of Greenwich Village helped Bishop William T. Manning celebrate his eighty-second birthday yesterday.

Although the last compilation of the Department of Commerce on foreign trade shows a rise in exports, shipping men in the port of New York believe a decline is threatened by the growing shortage of export cargo available at rail terminals for overseas shipment, it was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -House building picked up sharply in April. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today that builders started 90,000 permanent non-farm dwelling units last month. This was an increase of 29 per cent over March and 34 per cent above April, 1947.
The American Cable and Radio Corporation reported yesterday that operations in 1947 resulted in a consolidated net loss of $1,525,998, compared with a net loss of $624,798 in 1946.

Crude oil production in the United States last week declined 700 barrels to a total of 5,412,750 barrels, according to yesterday's report of the American Petroleum Institute. In the week ended on May 10, 1947, production of crude oil amounted to 5,004,600 barrels.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended May 5:

WASHINGTON, May 12 --Strong encouragement to the world's democratic nations to gather at once in mutual defense arrangements, under an unaltered United Nations Charter, was offered today in high official and unofficial Republican quarters.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 12 (UP) -- Midshipman George J. Eliopulos, of Rawlins, Wyo., who was killed Monday when struck in the neck by a javelin tossed by a classmate, was buried with full military honors today.
John Kramer came back into Madison Square Garden last night like the conqueror of his amateur days and made amends for his defeat there in December by Robert Riggs.
M. C. Berg, operator, was the seller of the property at 141 West Eighty-seventh Street to Henry J. Rorke and not the property at 141 West 183rd Street as was reported in these columns yesterday.

At a brief ceremony attended by leaders of the congregation of Temple Emanu-El, a memorial room containing the collection of ceremonial objects willed to the congregation by the late Judge Irving Lehman was dedicated yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- National concern as to safeguarding the Chief Executive, his family, his staff, and "irreplaceable Americana" from a White House fire is "absolutely justified," a National Fire Protection Association committee stated today at the conclusion of an inspection tour of the Executive Mansion.

BUENOS AIRES, may 12 -- The Government took another step toward making Argentina economically independent and protecting local interest when it issued yesterday a decree saying all goodsh)0*0*0*ileaving Argentine ports later than ninety days after May 4 must be insured by Argentine companies.

George G. Sommaripa has joined the American Standards Association as head of the national standardization work on consumer goods. During the last year of the war he was deputy assistant director for production for the textile, clothing and leather bureau of the War Production Board.

Hospitalized veterans of all faiths in the New York area, numbering 1,200, will be the guests of the Jewish War Veterans, Department of New York, at the third annual "All-Star Show" next Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden.

JERUSALEM, May 12 -- Tonight, as the High Commissioner, Lieut. Gen. Sir Alan G. Cunningham, issued proposed truce terms for Jerusalem, Arab regular and irregular forces launched the most violent attack yet made upon key Jewish positions west and south of Jerusalem.

LONDON, May 12 -- Britain, like the United States, believes there should be no negotiations with the Soviet Union in the present circumstances, Foreign Secretary Bevin said in the House of Commons today.

CINCINNATI, May 12 -- Humiliation as well as defeat was inflicted on the long-suffering Reds by the Dodgers under the Crosley field lights tonight as the losing streak of Johnny Neun's team was stretched to six games.
GENEVA, May 12 -- Britin leads the world in the number of displaced persons accepted for resettlement, the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization announced today.

A buying wave in the last hour bolstered a wavering stock market yesterday, permitted the recovery of earlier losses and sent the price index within striking distance of the 1947 high mark. Even the motors, depressed by the strike at Chrysler, shared in the late recovery and, while the average increase held at about 1/2 point, there were many key issues that gained more than a point.

Secretary of Defense James Forrestal asserted last night that professional military men viewed without pleasure the possiblity of war, but were resolved to maintain the nation's strength consistent with its responsibilities. Mr. Forrestal addressed 400 persons at the annual dinner of the Chaplains Association of the Army and Navy of the United States in the New Yorker Hotel.

What set out to be the initial arclight fiesta of the local baseball season developed into an utter fiasco last night when, after one delay of an hour and thirty-two minutes in the first inning, the contest between the Yankees and the Indians was finally called off because of rain after another wait of thirty minutes in the fourth ining.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -Communist efforts to gain control of the Near East without invasion have failed, a House committee reported today.

The twelve-story store and office building at 180 Broadway, between Maiden Lane and John Street, has been sold by Jack Resnick to a syndicate of investors headed by Nat P. Jacobs, Benjamin Kaufman and Seymour J. Goldman. The deal involved a resale of a contract bought about a month ago by Mr. Resnick from Famous Fashion Shops, Ltd., which has leased the store for a long term.
BOSTON, May 12 -- The American Academy of Arts and Sciences, at its 167th annual meeting, tonight re-elected as president Prof. Howard Mumford Jones of Harvard.

Hollywood fired its first Shot in the "cold war" against Russia yesterday, just when a faint hope was glimmering that maybe moderation in fact might be achieved. It came in the shape of "The Iron Curtain," which opened locally on the Roxy's screen and in some 400 other theatres throughout the United States.

LONDON, May 12 -- To prevent the demands of the European Recovery Program from encroaching unduly upon the needs of the British colonies for capital goods, British Government officials have been contemplating a system of priorities for allocating supplies between the United Kingdom and its dependencies.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 12 -- Two hundred and twenty-seven students at New York University's Westchester Center petitioned the White Plains Mayor, City Council and Board of Education today to permit continuance of the center in the senior high school building here.

DAMASCUS, May 12 (Reuters) -- Arab League sources said here today that the Arabs would reject the British-American proposal for a three-month Palestine truce.
The fortieth anniversary of the Navy Nurse Corps was marked yesterday
American aspects of the Russian "acceptance" of what the Soviet had termed a United States invitation to a conference to discuss differences have dominated "Voice of America" broadcasts.

An appeal to prospective passenger.s not to complicate sailing dayby appearing with refrigerators,radios and washing machines disguised as baggage, was issued bythe French Line last week. Passengers on all lines are permittedlimited free baggage, and cancarry as much extra baggage asthey wish at excess rates, but theexcess schedule does not coverhousehold goods, bath t~ubs andother similar equipment.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 12 -- Over the objections of Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union, the United Nations Security Council decided today to authorize its Truce Commission in Palestine to utilize the assistance of any facilities available there in carrying out any truce agreements that it might negotiate.

The field is now open for private capital to take over much of the task of world economic recovery and stem the advance of statism, Charles R. Eaton, Republican chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said last night.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Secretary of State, when asked today whether he thought the Soviet breach of diplomatic conduct in releasing the texts of the recent confidential exchange between Ambassador Smith and Mr. Molotov would be harmful to world peace, cheerfully replied that maybe it would be helpful.

BERLIN, May 12 -- Russia's apparent desire for "peace" talks is strongly motivated by the failure of her plans for her own rehabilitation through "reparations" from Eastern Germany, it was said today in circles close to the Soviet military administration.
PARIS, May 12 -- The United States Government has given reassurances to London and Paris regarding the exchange between Foreign Minister Molotov and Lieut. Gen. W. Bedell Smith, Ambassador to Moscow.

Spurred by fears of greater shortages of tin, industrial purchasing departments have started searches for substitute metals which could be used to replace tin bronzes if an emergency develops in the near future, spokesmen declared yesterday.

After receiving higher fare applications yesterday from six privately owned bus lines in Manhattan and five in Queens, the Board of Estimate decided in executive session to send them today to Controller Lazarus Joseph for investigation and report.

The doctrine that "the king cando no wrong" received a chillyreception when it was advanced inthe United States Circuit Court ofAppeals yesterday as justification/for an attempt by the FederalGovernment to evict the operatorof a gasoline service station infavor of a lessee willing to paymore rent.
The Long Island Golf Association's tourney in honor of the late William D. Richardson will be inaugurated today with a medal play round at the Seawane Harbor Club, Hewlett, L.I.

SHAWNEE ON DELEWARE, May 12 -- Assailing the principle of State Department control of tariff policy, speakers at the National Textile Seminar today called for drastic revision of the international trade organization charter and a return to Congress of authority to administer the trade agreements program.

An extra dividend of 50 cents and a regular of $1 on the common stock, both payable on June 11, was voted by Allied Mills, Inc. This brings the total for the fiscal year ending on June 30 to $2.50, which compares with $3 in the previous year.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A Government move to encourage resumption of direct negotiations to settle the railroad wage dispute is expected in a few days. Aside from steps taken by the Secretary of the Army, Kenneth C. Royall, to obtain consultant aid in operating the Government-seized roads, the entire dispute today was marked by a letdown.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 (AP) -The league-leading Athletics combined three hits with four walks in the second inning tonight to score six runs, defeat the Browns, 8 to 4, and extend their winning streak to ten games. Dick Fowler was credited with his second victory in two starts, though he needed help from Bob Savage and Lou Brissie.
ROME, May 12 -- The new President of the Italian Republic, Luigi Einaudi, was sworn in today in the presence of the assembled Senate and Chamber of Deputies.
In view of the differences of opinion between us, I much appreciated the generosity of your editorial "Norman Thomas Runs Again."
DETROIT, May 12 -- Production was halted at fifteen of the sixteen plants of the Chrysler Corporation by a strike today of the United Automobile Workers, CIO.

The market for capital lived up yesterday to the expectations of banking syndicates which opened subscription books on issues of common stock and convertible preferred stock having a market value of more than $40,000,000. While the digestion of this large and varied assortment of securities was not accomplished instantly, Wall Street was in general more than satisfied with the distributions.

Net profit of the International Paper Company and subsidiaries in the first quarter of 1948 was $13,313,408, or $3.68 a common share, compared with $11,660,540, or $3.21 a share in the first quarter of last year, R. J. Cullen, chairman, reported here yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders.

GENEVA, May 12 -- Fifteen European countries and the United States reached an agreement today on the continuation of a special coke allocation program that permits an increase of 1,500,000 tons yearly in the European steel output.

Backyard gardens and verdant penthouses lured nearly 600 persons yesterday to the second and final seasonal tour provided by the City Gardens Club to aid its gardening projects for underprivileged children. In contrast to last week's tour through wind and rain, the sun shone brightly on newly opened lilies of the valley and budding dogwood
America's wine industries have shaken off their 1947 slump and March shipments were 68 per cent above those of the 1947 month, Harry Baccigaluppi, president, the Wine Institute, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The issue of racial segregation in the armed forces was headed tonight toward voting showdowns in both houses of Congress when the awaiting selective draft bills reach their floors.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- The publishers of Chicago's five daily newspapers offered what they called a "final, complete contract proposal" today to their 1,500 printers, who have been on strike since Nov. 24. They raised their previous offer of a $6 weekly wage increase to $9.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 12 -Loretta Young is expected to sign with Universal-International for the leading role in "The Gay Goddess," a photoplay by Roy Huggins based on a story by Lewis Meltzer and Oscar Saul about a woman whose life is ruined by gambling, it was learned today.

Fifty state chairmen of the Golden Rule Foundation and state mothers chosen by the association along with other representatives of mothers' groups, parent-teacher organizations and social agencies, were present yesterday at the opening session of the American Home Institute at the WaldorfAstoria, Hotel.

A friend of this corner who is writing a book and shows it by his demeanor, which may be described in a nutshell as belligerency plus, breezed to our desk-side the other day, fixed us with a glittering eye, and remarked defiantly:

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -Detroit concentrated all its fourteen hits in three innings to defeat Washington. 14 -- 9, in a wild game tonight. The Tigers moved into fourth place as Dizzy Trout, third of four Detroit pitchers, notched his second victory.

ATLANTA, May 12 (AP) -- James Barfoot, the Wallace party's proposed gubernatorial candidate in Georgia, said today that he had been dismissed from his teaching post at the University of Georgia, effective June 1.

Mayor O'Dwyer appointed 2,000 school children as honorary members of the I Am An American Day committee yesterday at exercises in City Hall Park, which served as a prelude to the demonstration scheduled for Sunday afternoon on the Central Park Mall.
BANGKOK, Siam, May 12 -- A gang of twenty to thirty armed men hijacked a $2,000,000 international gold shipment today as it was being taken to a customs house.

TRENTON, N.J., May 12 -- The New Jersey Legislature rejected tonight a Democratic minority proposal for a public referendum on legalized Bingo, assured state employes of pay increases, advanced a program for sick benefits for workers in the state and set "fair trade" prices for cigarettes.

Rear Admiral Richard F. Whitehead, who as a lieutenant in 1931 became the first commanding officer of the naval air station at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn, returned to the field yesterday to conduct the station's annual military inspection. Admiral Whitehead is chief of Naval Air Reserve training.

BOSTON, May 12 (AP) -- Bobby Doerr's third home run of the season, driven high over the wall screen in left field with two mates aboard in the tenth inning, today lifted the Red Sox to a 6-5 triumph over the White Sox, who have lost eight games in succession.

LOS ANGELES, May 12 -- The merger of Abbott Kimball Company, Inc., of California with DunFenwick Co., Inc., was announced here today. The new organization will bear the name of the former, it was stated. An immediate result will be expansion of the Kimball Company's fashion division.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The 200-member policy committee of the United Mine Workers will meet here Monday, twenty-four hours in advance of the opening of joint parleys for a new contract covering about 350,000 bituminous mine workers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 12 -- A new United States interim plan for Palestine, calling for the appointment by the five great powers of a High Commissioner who would have no governmental powers but would attempt to keep essential public services going during the expected war between Jews and Arabs, was announced tonight by the United States delegation to the United Nations General Assembly.

One has only to think back to the exhausting 113-day strike of the automobile workers against General Motors in 1945 to realize how serious the present walk-out of Chrysler workers may become. That 1945 strike crippled the union, set the industry back and helped start a wage spiral which is still climbing.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Allen Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, told a Congressional committee today that the legislators might have to "reconsider" their attitudes on taxes, on allocations and other Federal authority over the economy.

Walker Cooper, Giants' catcher, yesterday entered Harkness Pavilion of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in preparation for an operation tomorrow morning for removal of bone chips from his right knee. Dr. Harrison McLaughlin will perform the operation, which is expected to keep the hard-hitting catcher out of action from four to eight weeks.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Secretary of State Marshall threw moreh)0*0*0*icold water today on the Soviet proposal for a United States-Russian "peace" conference.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 12 -- Abdel Moneim al-Tanamly, representative of the Arab League, told the United Nations Ad Hoc Committee on the proposed Economic Commission for the Middle East here today that all foreign influence should be excluded from such a commission.

BOSTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Christian Science board of directors today announced election of Miss L. Ivimy Gwalter of New York as director of the Mother Church, the First Church of Christ, Scientist, in Boston.

American Airlines, Inc., reported yesterday in its statement of operations covering the quarter ended with last March a net loss of $5,168,394 after all deductions, against a loss of $5,008,569 before tax credits for the first three months of last year.
DETROIT, May 12 (AP) -- Immediately after the start of the Chrysler strike Gov. Kim Sigler ordered a complaint against the strikers under Michigan's new Bonine-Tripp Law.

Although he had a majority in the second ballot and would probably have been elected, Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza eliminated himself from the race for the Presidency of Italy. The first President of the Republic will occupy a memorable place in a new chapter of Italian history.
More than 300,000 persons participated in the Metropolitan Miami Fishing Tournament during the past winter, competing for some $15,000 in prizes offered for the largest fish of thirty-one species.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A bill to admit 200,000 displaced persons over a two-year period with a minimum of administrative limitations was introduced in the Senate today by two Democratic legislators, J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island and Carl A. Hatch of New Mexico.

ICE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 12 -- An Australian attempt to introduce economic rights into the proposed international covenant on human rights was defeated here today in the United Nations committee drafting the covenant.

In sharp contrast to the lack of decorum that characterized annual meetings of stockholders of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation in recent years, holders of about 165 per cent of the line's securities met quietly yesterday for an hour and forty-five minutes.

Uniformed and mounted policemen and a large but undisclosed number of plainclothesmen patrolled inside and outside the Roxy Theatre last night to prevent the recurrence of the mass picketing that developed late Tuesday night over the showing of a new film entitled "The Iron Curtain."

ALTHOUGH, as we now know, May 10 [1940] was already chosen for the Invasion of France and the Low Countries, Hitler had not yet fixed the actual date of the prior Norway onslaught. Much was to precede it.

Guy W. Vaughan, president of the Curtiss - Wright Corporation, told the Aviation Writers Association at breakfast in the Commodore Hotel yesterday that, for the first time in the history of the aircraft industry, the five-year plan adopted by Congress enables it to achieve peacetime stability.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 13 -- The Soviet Union insisted today that it had the right as the one great neighbor state to participate in any United Nations economic development plans for the Middle East.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Wertheim Co. will place on the market today a new issue of $10,000,000 of 3 per cent twenty-year debentures of the Bristol-Myers Company, manufacturer of dentrifices, toilet articles and other products.

BALTIMORE, May 13 (AP) -- The State Racing Commission today authorized straight betting only for Saturday's Preakness Stakes, which shapes up as a four-horse race with Citation, the Kentucky Derby winner, an odds-on favorite. The commission, pointing out the state would have to split the loss of a minus pool, with the Pimlico track, said in a statement:

Commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System registered a second consecutive weekly advance last week gaining $38,000,000, the best since the week of Dec. 24, 1947.

The bargaining power inherent in "offshore" purchases in Latin America of $2,000,000,000 or more under the Economic Cooperation Administration should be used by foreign traders to seek removal of trade restrictions in Argentina and spur payment of overdue drafts by Brazil, Wilbert Ward, vice president of the National City Bank, suggested here yesterday.

The Army Quartermaster Corps' industrial mobilization goal is selfstarting industrial production so well organized in advance that a declaration of war or national emergency would automatically set it in motion. Major General W. H. Middleswart, deputy Quartermaster General, declared yesterday.

Railbirds are hopeful that by tomorrow the weather will be clear and the track fast enough for athletes of the Ivy League to demonstrate their true potentialities in the Heptagonal Games at West Point. There are at least half a dozen solid Olympic prospects in the sacrosanct group who would revel in an opportunity to cut loose under good conditions.

Madame Reine, who is a frequent commuter between New York and Paris, has a happy faculty of welding French chic with that restraint which American women court in their millinery. Yesterday afternoon, she presented her first fall collection in her showrooms at 2 East Fifty-seventh Street.

LONDON, May 13 (AP) -- Thirtytwo Americans attended the presentation party at Buckingham Palace today. Sponsored by Ambassador and Mrs. Lewis Douglas, they mingled with nearly 2,500 other guests representing many countries.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall in an informal address told a class of forty-eight who were commissioned in the foreign service today that they were entering upon their duties "at a very critical period" when the world was in "social revolution."

The Mayor's announcement of an annual pay rise of approximately $600 to the city transit workers, when viewed in the light of a meager $250 rise for the general city employes, will be a bitter pill to swallow for those of the latter group who have steadfastly placed their faith in a municipal pay policy based on merit rather than on threats, intimidation and slowdowns.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. told a local Republican meeting tonight that "the change in the trend of our Government is the biggest single accomplishment we have achieved so far."

The Starlight Roof of the WaldorfAstoria was opened for the late spring and summer seasons last night with a gala fete arranged to benefit the George Junior Republic in Freeville, N.Y., a pioneer organization in the field of self-government for youth.

BALTIMORE, May 13 -- A tenhour annual meeting of the Certainteed Products Company, Ardmore, Pa., roofing company, ended just after last midnight with something of a record for duration and after a hot proxy fight.

Radio programs to which parents and children listen together, with definite periods set aside for the purpose, ought to be part of life in every family inl the view of the radio committee of the United Parents Association, 289 Fourth Avenue. Values found in this sharing of entertainment were stressed yesterday by the committee's chairman, Mrs. Rose Kobert.

INTERSECTIONAL play involving the East and the West in both major leagues came to a temporary halt after yesterday's games. All of the American League contests floated gently out to sea on the spring floods. Rain may make the flowers beautiful but in baseball the only things it nourishes are summer doubleheaders, which are neither beautiful nor welcome.
Hartford County, Md., announced yesterday that it will receive bids June 2 on $4,000,000 of school bonds dated July 1, 1948 and due July 1 from 1952 to 1973.

Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler vice president and general manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, presented arguments yesterday on the question of outlawing the Communist party in the United States, though professing "mounting sympathy" with those who demand affirmative action against it.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- President Truman asserted today that it was contrary to American principles to outlaw a political party. He thus implied that he would veto the Mundt bill aimed at the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder took an unusual step today to quash widespread reports that an increase was imminent in the interest rate on one-year Government securities. The rate of 1 1/8 per cent that has prevailed since Jan. 1 will be maintained through June and July, he announced.
SOUTH ST. PAUL, Minn., May 13 (AP) -- Picket lines of the CIO packinghouse workers held firm here today against efforts of police and sheriff's officers to open them.

Before the debate begins next week in Congress on the Selective Service bills it might be well for members to look at the record of the other Great Powers, both as to present armed strength and as to methods of recruitment. SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 -George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State, defined America's aims here today in addressing the first plenary session of the Pacific Regional Conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- Grain prices were lower the greater part of the day on the Board of Trade, but a strong rally came shortly before the close, which carried prices up rapidly, only to weaken later, corn closing at the bottom with losses of 1 1/4 to 2 1/2 cents a bushel.

NEW HAVEN, May 13 (AP) -Four of Yale's eight varsity oarsmen were reported today to be recovering from grip as the Elis prepared to head for Cambridge, Mass., and the important Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges regatta.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The question in Washington now is no longer who was right and who wrong in the United States-Soviet "peace conference" incident, but where do we go from here?

ATHENS, May 13 -- Another report on the current executions of the death sentences imposed by civil courts for criminal acts during the German occupation and the subsequent Communist-inspired uprising of December, 1944, was filed today to the British Foreign Office by the British Embassy here.

It was clear from the first that Pancho would walk alone, if not, perhaps, through any fault of his. Formally purchased with a good share of life's savings, he arrived a puppy, with a pedigree paper extending into a far corner of the next county.

MEMPHIS, says Shields McIlwaine, who knows a deal about the cotton capital on the Chickasaw bluffs above the Mississippi, has always been Southern with a Western twist. It was founded by Indian traders and land speculators in the good old frontier tradition. It grew through a whole series of booms and disasters.

DETROIT, May 13 -- Probably 100,000 and as many as 150,000 workers in plants supplying the strike-bound Chrysler Corporation will be made idle by a prolonged walkout, it was estimated today by a spokesman for the Michigan Manufacturers Association.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 13 -- Convention delegates representing 375,000 members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO, voted unanimously here today to condemn the national Third party headed by Henry A. Wallace as "disastrous to the vital interests of organized labor and of the country as a whole."

A new oil paint that dries to a flat finish and also affords many of the conveniences of a water-mix paint was demonstrated yesterday at The Cottage in Hampshire House by the National Lead Company, makers of Dutch Boy paints. Various ways in which it might be used for interior decorating were illustrated by three room-settings designed by Mrs. Ethel Clarke of McMillen, Inc.

Senator Dennis Chavez of New Mexico denounced last night the State Department's approach to the Palestine problem, asserting that the Department should be "made acquainted with the facts of life; its approach to the problem is unrealistic, wrong and unAmerican."

The Rev. Dr. Hanns Lilje, Bishop of Hanover, Germany (Lutheran), emphasized yesterday the great need of more Bibles in Germany at the 132d annual meeting of the American Bible Society at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftyfirst Street.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Army newspapers and broadcasting stations must refrain from support or criticism of special political candidates or issues, the Department of the Army ordered today in a circular distributed to all commands.

TRENTON, N.J., May 13 -- The Court of Errors and Appeals set aside today a Chancery Court injunction obtained by former Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City in 1945 to restrain John Warren, Jersey City attorney, from proceeding with a $2,000,000 libel suit filed against the State Democratic leader in Monmouth County Common Pleas Court in 1942.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The House Republican Steering Committee approved today a one-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act with new restrictions on the President's authority to lower tariffs.

A Federal grand jury failed yesterday to indict Earl Sande on a charge of illegal possession of narcotics, but The Jockey Club announced its sixty-day suspension of the one-time famous rider would stick. The grand jury, after investigating the case, reported to Judge Leo Rayfiel without returning a true bill.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The "Program for peace" submitted to the White House recently by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ was assailed today by the American Council of Christian Churches, which also presented a peace program to president Truman.
LONDON, May 13 -- The arrival of two high-ranking Soviet Foreign Office officials en route to the United States aroused considerable speculation here today.

LONDON, May 13 -- A sudden spurt of progress has brought the six power conference on Western Germany within sight of important agreements, it was learned today. The conference will be adjourned until after the Whitsun Holidays and will be resumed Tuesday.

PITTSBURGH, May 13 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates snapped a fourgame winning streak of the Philadelphia Phillies tonight, defeating the Quakers, 5 -- 1, before a crowd of 29,789. Bob Chesnes, Pacific Coast rookie making his first start in the majors, received credit for the victory, although he had to be relieved in the seventh.

The current "incomprehensible" rise in raw fur prices was described yesterday as a "mad speculative scramble to make a quick dollar" by Sol Rosenberg, president of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc., 393 Seventh Avenue, which on June I will be known as the Associated Fur Manufacturers, Inc.

Still fretting over the bad-weather break that cost them a potential victory over the Indians the night before, the Yankees were dealt another blow yesterday, when rain prevented them from engaging the Indians in the series finale at the Stadium.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The United States will refuse economic aid to any European nation supplying war materials or equipment to Soviet Russia, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, told Congress today.

LAKE SUCESS, N.Y., May 13 -- Harold Evans, Philadelphia Quaker and practicing attorney, was designated here today as the Municipal Commissioner for Jerusalem after a special agreement on the selection was reached by the Arabs and Jews.
LONDON, May 13 (AP) -- Following is the text of statament by the Foreign Office and the Colonial Office on the termination of the British mandate in Palestine:

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 13 (AP) -J. L. McCaffrey, president of the International Harvester Company, said today that the company's production and sales had reached high records in the first half of the fiscal year but the trend of net income had not kept pace.
Details of the McDonnell Parasite jet fighter with no landing gear that will be based on a larger plane and take off and land while in mid-air were disclosed yesterday by the Air Force.

PARIS, May 13 -- The French Academy, the official body of scholars devoted to the improvement of French letters, today published the text of a letter it had received from Pope Pius XII praising it for its work in perfecting what the Pope called "one of the richest idioms God has given men to speak."

NEW DELHI, India, May 13 -The Madras Provincial Government, in an official statement this week, took note of the "wanton attacks" by large bands of armed "Communists" in villages in the Malabar district and warned that "any attempt by any party or section of people to take the law into their own hands or provoke disorders cannot be tolerated."

CHICAGO, May 13 -- There is no greater need today than the advancement of the cause of religious faith among the peoples of the world, no matter what that faith may be, it was asserted here tonight by Samuel Rothstein, president of the United Synagogue.

Long-cherished dreams of passing a few hours among the tokens of freedom and historical attractions of the nation's capital were shattered yesterday for fifty-one New York children by Negro segregation and discrimination rules as practiced in Washington.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Cyrus S. Eaton, largest stockholder in the investment banking firm of Otis Co. of Cleveland, was named today as a client of two Cleveland attorneys, one of whom was in Detroit on Feb. 9 on behalf of Mr. Eaton to ascertain if a lawsuit had been filed there against the KaiserFrazer Corporation.

Private social agencies can play a vital part in putting the city's Department of Welfare on a sounder footing, Raymond M. Hilliard, recently appointed commissioner of the much-criticized department, said yesterday.

Yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel a forward and feathered movement in hats was sponsored by members of the Millinery Designers League. This group, which includes most of the mass production artists, is responsible for 85 per cent of all the hats worn by women.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Mrs. Eugene Meyer, member of the President's Commission on Higher Education, today charged before the conference on human rights at Howard University that Speaker Joseph Martin was nullifying the will of the people by blocking House consideration of Federal aid to education.

Earl O. Shreve, vice president of the General Electric Company on the president's staff and president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, has retired from the company after forty-four years of service, it was announced yesterday by Charles E. Wilson, GE president.

BOSTON, May 13 -- The United Steelworkers' convention, with President Philip Murray firmly in control, overwhelmed today a small but stubborn "grass roots" demand that the CIO union's officers immediately sign non-Communist affidavits under the Taft-Hartley Law.

The National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots of America, AFL, will demand of other maritime unions that no attempt be made to draw shipmasters away from their vessels in the event of a strike, it was reported yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 13 -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine appealed to the United Nations Security Council tonight to take immediate action to prevent an attack on the Jewish area of Palestine by King Abdullah of TransJordan after the termination of the British mandate.

Boxing will return to Madison Square Garden tonight after six weeks given over to the circus. The program arranged by matchmaker Chickie Bogad will be made up of three ten-rounders, with the top spot assigned to lightweights Jesse Flores of Stockton, Calif., and Johnny Williams of Montgomery, Ala.

Young children have long been the classic, chronic sufferers from accidents. After a certain age one expects the patter of small feet to dissolve into stronger sounds of clatter and crash. But it is disheartening to learn from a recent study by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company that accidents now outrank every other cause of death for the pre-school-age group and have shown the least improvement over the years.

PITTSBURGH, May 13 (AP) -President Ben Moreell of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation today declared that two damage suits charging illegal offers to sell his company's steel were intended to "lead the attack on gray marketing."

A shutdown late this afternoon by the "Big Eight" baking companies, which supply 80 per cent of the white bread and cake for restaurants and grocery stores in the metropolitan area, appeared imminent last night.

Msgr. John L. Belford, pastor for forty-three years of the Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity, Classon Avenue and Madison Street, Brooklyn, was honored at a pontifical mass yesterday morning in celebration of the sixtieth anniversary of his ordination as a priest.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -The controversial Moore-Rizley bill to amend the Natural Gas Act and curb the Federal Power Commission's authority over the industry was pigeon-holed today by the Senate Commerce Committee.

The North American Company announced yesterday a proposal to transfer its holdings of all the outstanding common stock of West Kentucky Coal Company to Union Electric Company of Missouri, North American's major subsidiary.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Senate voted today, 38 to 37, to shelve a House-approved resolution giving Congressional sanction to a compact of fifteen Southern states to establish regional educational institutions.
