Charges that the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, is conducting an illegal secondary boycott against the recording and transcription industry by not permitting its members to make disks were filed yesterday with the National Labor Relations Board here.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- President Truman asked Congress today for $2,434,441,000 of additional money, plus $40,000,000 more contractual authority, for strengthening the American armed forces. This was on top of the $11,000,000,000 contained in the original 1949 military budget, and $725,000,000 which Mr. Truman requested on April 8 for procurement of aircraft for the Air Force and naval aviation.

PARIS, May 13 -- Paris has made its greatest social preparations since the liberation for a cordial and sumptuous reception for Princess Elizabeth and Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, who arrive tomorrow on a four-day official visit to the French capital.
Held news conference. Said his hopes for peace not increased by recent note exchange with Russia.

LONDON, May 13 -- There are at least 300 persons in London who are not thankful that American food is on its way to their dinner tables. These 300 sat as silent as stones tonight in Finsbury Town Hall, the center of a dingy working class district, when the United States was favorably mentioned.

Paul S. Kennedy, vice president of the finishes division of the Interchemical Corporation, Newark, was elected president of the New York Paint, Varnish Lacquer Association yesterday at a meeting in the Biltmore Hotel. Also elected were Frank P. Connolly of Valentine Co., vice president; Harold L. Davis of D.H. Litter Company, Inc., secretary; and Hendrick E. Hendrickson of S. Winterbourne Co., treasurer.

ST. LOUIS, May 13 (AP) -- Ten Professional Golfers Association champions, including defending titleholder Jim Ferrier of Australia, are in the field of 128 that will start qualifying rounds next Wednesday in the week-long national P.G.A. tourney at Norwood Hills.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Some members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee began considering today an effort to limit, but not to alter in substance, the Vandenberg plan to commit the United States to the principle of qualified military aid to western Europe.

Reports from reliable sources make it a practical certainty that millions of people in Europe today are on a slow starvation diet. As usual we have had some "official reports" which attempt to gloss over the matter, but the evidence is overwhelming, particularly for those who have been sending food parcels to Germany and receiving first-hand news from friends and relatives there.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 13 -Considerable military activity is evident as one travels through the Arab countries but military censorship prevents the publication of details or even the identification of troops by their nationality.
Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman advocated last night a national health crusade by public and private agencies to assure a nation of healthy and stable Americans.

Wholesale meat prices have been erratic this week, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Retail tariffs have wandered, too, but entirely in an upward direction. Though supplies of everything but lamb are supposedly adequate for demand, increases of 2 to 5 cents have been general on beef and veal.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, scouted today the danger of unleashed inflation or disastrous depression and anticipated an accelerated return to lower prices and a competitive era in the national economy.

DETROIT, May 13 -- With a special police squad of 100 officers on guard to prevent disorder, Henry A. Wallace appeared before thousands tonight to assail Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg in the latter's home state as the champion of Government "for the rich and the well-born."
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -President Truman has signed a bill providing for the licensing of radio telegraphers as ship officers.

BUFFALO, May 13 -- The Protestant Episcopal Church consecrated today a new Bishop of the Western New York Diocese, the Right Rev. Lauriston L. Scaife, formerly of Pittsburgh, in St. Paul's Cathedral. The Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill of New York, Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church headed the group of visiting dignitaries and presided at the ceremonies.

A captivating springtime exhibition opens today at the Metropolitan Museum, where a thirty-threefoot-long Chinese scroll is displayed along the entire east side of the balcony. This Ming copy of a Sung painting represents the Spring Festival on the Yellow River, dedicated to the honorably buried dead, which is celebrated with carnivallike gaiety.

" The Fuller Brush Man," a comedy starring Red Skelton, which arrives at Loew's State, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The Edward Small production, which is being presented by Columbia Pictures, was produced and directed by S. Sylvan Simon from a screen play by Frank Tashlin and Devery Freeman and a story by Roy Huggins.

Four Army cars, six motorcycle policemen and four Army trucks drew up to the Metropolitan Museum at 9:15 o'clock yesterday morning to deposit there the $80,000,000 worth of old masters from the Kaiser-Friedrich Museum in Berlin for the exhibition that will open next Monday.
LONDON, May 13 -- The United States is considering its policy toward the sterling area in the European Recovery Program, W. Averell Harriman, roving Ambassador, said here today at a press conference.

Max Band, who was born in Lithuania and lived in Paris until he immigrated to California in 1940, is showing ten years of his work at Wildenstein's. He is a painter who likes paint, and he has learned to bring out sensuous qualities in rich surfaces and to ring resonance from sea-deep blues, forest-and-emerald greens, and little touches of vermilion.

NANKING, May 13 -- Martial law has been declared in Chengteh, capitol of Jehol Province, after a series of Communist attacks launched against three key highway points northwest, north and east of the city, it was reported here tonight.

Eugene L. Hofmann, superintendent of the Long Island Rail Road, told Public Service Commissioner George A. Arkwright yesterday that the railroad carried 9,000 standing passengers daily, but it had a plan to cut down on the overcrowding in the near future.

The Army Engineers' 315-foot dredge New Orleans has entered the Hoboken yards of the Todd Shipyards Corporation for an extensive, four-month overhaul job, which will amount practically to rebuilding the thirty-seven-yearold ship, the repair company announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (UP) -John J. Moran, president of the CIO long distance telephone workers union, accused the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today of refusal to bargain on a new contract.
TEL AVIV, Palestine, May 13 (AP) -- All trained Jewish men and women of fighting age were called to arms today as a new Zionist state neared its zero hour.

LONDON, May 13 -- The belief that the United States has lost an opportunity in rejecting the Russian offer to negotiate was expressed today in some British quarters. Typical expression of this is contained in an editorial in this morning's Manchester Guardian.
LONDON, Friday, May 14 (UP) -Tass, the official Soviet news agency, charged today that the United States Department of State had issued a distorted version of Mr. Molotov's reply to Ambassador Smith.
The "new look" in policewomen's uniforms was approved yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander at a preview of the "more feminine" style at Police Headquarters.

ATHENS, May 13 (AP) -- Three thousand Communist-led guerrillas were reported retreating northward today from the Agrapha area in central Greece to their Grammos Mountain stronghold along the Albanian border.

In a cash deal reported yesterday the East River Savings Bank sold the seven-story store and apartment building at 16 to 24 East Ninety-sixth Street, southwest corner of Madison Avenue, to Irving Maidman, operator, who said a physicians' cooperative was being formed to acquire the structure and convert the upper floors into two doctors' offices.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, of the American Federation of Labor, today sharply criticized the ITU's New York local for the manner of its dealings with New York City newspaper publishers.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- Plans for an intensive unionization drive in the meat-packing industry have been discussed among the 800 delegates attending the general convention here of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen, AFL, it was learned today.

PARIS, Friday, May 14 -- French gendarmes said early today that Lady Kathleen Hartington had been killed in a plane crash near St. Bauzile in the Rhone River valley north of Marseille. She was the daughter of Joseph P. Kennedy, former United States Ambassador to Britain.

Dr. Benjamin Hyman Budoff has purchased the dwelling at 518 Front Street, Hempstead, L.I., from Anna Ingraham for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $14,000. The A. W. Brierly Agency was the broker in the sale of the property, which occupies a plot 100 by 150 feet.

The emotional tribulations of a young woman about to undergo an appendectomy were presented in musical form last night when "The Hospital," a suite by Dr. Herman M. Parris, Philadelphia physician and composer, received its orchestral premiere in Hunter College auditorium, Lexington Avenue and East Sixty-eighth Street.

Americans have a stake in the universities of China. If a "strong, united, democratic" China -- the stated object of United States policy -- is ever to appear, much of the leadership will have to come from the students and faculties of these universities, long the centers of liberal, democratic thought in that war-torn country.

Operations of Paramount Pictures, Inc., in the quarter ended with last April 3, it was disclosed yesterday, resulted in estimated earnings of $7,760,000 after all deductions, including provision for taxes.

Further price rises threaten to undermine the gains made in American living standards unless Congress authorizes stand-by price control and allocations, Dr. Mary Dublin Keyserling told fifty delegates from consumer groups in Eastern and Midwest cities last night at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange have been told to do a little home-work on the rules of the Exchange, and Rule 504 in particular, which requires diligence in the acceptance of orders from customers about whom essential financial and business facts are not fully known.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, May 13 (AP) -- Willie Turnesa arrived from the United States on the Queen Mary today, all set to defend his British amateur golf championship in the week-long tournament beginning May 24 at Kent.

A new plans committee of the Bureau of Advertising, ANPA, has been established with Don U. Bridge, advertising director of the Gannett Newspapers, as its chairman, it was announced yesterday. Lawrence T. Knott, assistant advertising director of the Chicago Sun-Times, will serve as vice chairman.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on last Saturday totaled 880,617 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 11,021 cars, or 1.2 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 3,625, or 0.4 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week of last year, and 195,675, or 28.6 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

On the London boards since May 30 of last year, "Edward, My Son," starring Robert Morley, is slated to come to the Martin Beck, probably in October, under the auspices of Gilbert Miller and Henry Sherek. Although contracts await the signatures of the persons involved, arrangements have been agreed upon.

Latin - American Communists have aligned themselves with the most extremely reactionary forces in many of the republics and the combination constitutes the gravest immediate threat to the democracy of the Americas, Victor Raul Haya de la Torte, founder and leader of the APRA party of Peru, said yesterday.

Erica Morini, violinist, will be the featured soloist at the first Lewisohn Stadium concert on Monday, June 14, it was announced yesterday. She will play the Tchaikovsky Concerto, and Fritz Reiner will conduct the PhilharmonicSymphony.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 13 -- The Soviet Union proposed here today that all Governments that sign the international covenant on human rights be required to furnish to their citizens premises and equipment for printing newspapers.

" The refugee problem is not being solved because we have too little of too many things -- too little time, too little money, too few ships and, most important of all, too little Christian charity among nations."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 13 -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine was described as a fanatical and terrorist organization, employing police state tactics, in a document prepared by the Arab Higher Committee and distributed today by the United Nations.

LONDON, May 13 (Reuters) -- Cambridge University appears certain to suffer the same fate as Worcestershire, Leicestershire, Yorkshire and Surrey when it continues the cricket match against the Australian tourists at Cambridge tomorrow.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 13 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, 39-year-old Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, who has been the Soviet Union's chief spokesman here for more than two years, will leave soon for Moscow and may not return to the United Nations, he revealed today.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- President Truman declared in his weekly news conference today that the recent exchange of views with Russia had not increased his hopes for peace because funda mental issues had not even been touched.

PARIS, May 13 -- Trimming of finest braiding and self cording in lace-like designs highlights Carven's summer frocks for teen-agers. It borders shepherdess necklines, garlands the shoulders of tight bodices, is massed in a wide band about the hips or about hemlines.

A report by consulting engineers confirming the physical and economic aspects of the Port of New York Authority's plan for the development of municipally owned waterfront facilities has been submitted to Mayor O'Dwyer by Howard S. Cullman, Port Authority chairman, it was announced last night.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., May 13 -- Although pouring billions of dollars into Europe to stop communism, our legislators fail to recognize that the best method of combating it here is to build a prosperous economy, Emil Rieve, president of the Textile Workers Union, declared here today.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- An increase of $9,000,000,000 in total deposits of all operating banks in the United States and its possessions was noted during the six months ended on Dec. 31, last, Marple T. Harl, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, stated today.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- In the face of renewed expressions of opposition by President Truman, the House passed today a bill designed to force executive departments and agencies to produce information demanded by Congress. The vote was 219 to 142.

New York public school authorities should be empowered by legislation to pass on plans for all large-scale housing and community home developments in order to protect the educational interests of children, it was recommended yesterday in a special report of the Board of Education.

Corporations and their employes must increase their support of charitable agencies and campaigns or the Government will have to step in to sustain their welfare programs, John D. Rockefeller 3d declared yesterday at the first report luncheon of the Brooklyn division of the Greater New York Fund in the St. George Hotel.

One of the largest automatic washer producers in the country shortly will announce termination of a number of dealer franchises for pricecutting and transshipping, it was learned yesterday. The action will be the first of its nature taken by a producer, although several radio and appliance distributors have done so recently.

HEWLETT, L.I., May 13 -Most of those who weathered the wind and rain over the Seawane Harbor Club course for the Long Island Golf Association's qualifying round in the William D. Richardson Memorial tournament today looked like sailors on a heavy sea before they had finished.

Fifty women between 18 and 55 years old, 60 per cent of them mothers, were participants in unusual graduation exercises yesterday when they received diplomas from the Baby Sitters Association of America, Inc., 44 West Fiftysixth Street, qualifying them as scientifically trained child attendants.

Maximilian Lom, the recently appointed second Czechoslovak commercial attache to the United States in this city, arrived here yesterday to prepare for the fiveyear import-export trade plan of his country that will start next year.

A national survey of state liquor control laws has now been approved, officials of the National Conference of State Liquor Administrators revealed here yesterday, following enactment of a resolution urging such a study. The resolution joined the NCSLA with five other national associations in sponsoring the proposed study.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Department store sales in the week ended May 8 were 6 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

WOODMERE, L.I., May 13 -Mrs. Anne G. Steinmann, Democratic County Committeewoman for the Ninety-sixth election district here, today refused to resign her post, asserting that she was a "loyal Democrat" despite her support of Henry A. Wallace.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A recommendation by a non-official conference of foreign affairs experts, political scientists and legislators for "prompt recognition of the Government of the existing Jewish State" in Palestine was made public today by the three Senatorial sponsors of the seminar.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 13 -- German legal experts representing various political parties and areas within the bizonal region met with Dr. Herman Puender, Chief Executive of the Bizonal Economic Administration, today to discuss the drafting of an occupation statute.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 13 -Harold E. Stassen declared today that if he was President now he would "use the Taft-Hartley Law" in dealing with the strike of meat workers.

Random notes. The prospects for a satisfactory nesting and rearing season for waterfowl on the great Canadian breeding grounds are excellent, according to a report from Ducks Unlimited. Bert W. Cartwright, chief naturalist of the organization, reports that some of the early season species already have arrived in fair numbers and that the early run-off of water would benefit this year's duck hatch.

PARIS, May 13 -- Robert Marjolin, secretary general of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, today defined the objectives of the organization as the reconstruction and modernization of the European economy for the development, along with the United States, of the world's resources.

The Amdro Construction Company has purchased the vacant land both sides of 213th Street between Union Turnpike and Richland Avenue and part of the block between Oceania Street and Peck Avenue, in the Surrey Estates section of Queens from Augusta L. Michaelson.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- A study of the new national security set-up, including the three military services, will be made by the commission on organization of the executive branch of the Government, headed by former President Hoover.

An appraisal of American mores and institutions by Harold Laski, representing the work of thirty years, will be published June 7 by Viking under the title "The American Democracy." Mr. Laski also offers several suggestions, among them a seven-year term for the Presidency, power for the President to prorogue the Senate in case of disagreement on foreign policy and a possible third party.

The Martian jitters has afflicted some Russian literary critics. But the foul fiends who have disturbed the equanimity of the critics are laughing over the incident and they are planning to publish its case history for the amusement of their less serious readers, it became known yesterday.

The importance of the planned $25,000,000 Madison Square Garden in terms of business to hotels, local industry and business men was stressed yesterday by Brig. Gen. John R. Kilpatrick, president of Madison Square Garden Corporation, at the monthly luncheon of the New York chapter, Hotel Sales Managers Association, at the Astor Hotel.

LONDON, May 13 -- British Government bonds continued to improve spurred by reinvestment demand in the stock market here today. Buying orders, although small, were steady and gains of as much as 5/16 point were made.

Frederick J. Woodbridge, partner in the firm of Evans, Moore Woodbridge, architects, was installed last night as incoming president of the Architectural League of New York, succeeding Wallace K. Harrison.
ST. LOUIS, May 13 -- Swinging into action after three days of idleness, the Giants today concluded the western portion of their season's first road tour on a high and exhilarating note.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 13 -- Against the combined opposition of the Russian bloc and the Arab countries, the United States succeeded today in getting its trusteeship plan for Jerusalem safely through a United Nations subcommittee and onto the agenda of the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 13 -- After some hesitancy two German bankers have accepted nominations to the presidency and chairmanship of the board, respectively, of the new Trizonal Bank of German States. It is expected that announcement of their confirmation will be made tomorrow by Gen. Lucius D. Clay and Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, United States and British Military Governors.

A concert of organ compositions by contemporeaneous Americans and the first performance of Roy Harris' Mass were the features of the concert given as one of the events of the fourth annual Festival of Contemporary Music, sponsored by the Alice M. Ditson Fund of Columbia University, last night in St. Paul's Chapel.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- During the week ended May 12, member bank reserve balances increased $54,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The victory of the advocates of a seventygroup air force, about to be enacted into law by Presidential signature, should not obscure, but rather should illuminate, a very useful comment that was made in the Senate about this program. Seldom has a legislator about to support a measure expounded it so objectively and with so plain and constructive an end in view.

CINCINNATI, May 13 -- With Preacher Roe spinning four and two-thirds innings of perfect pitching today, the Dodgers slapped the Reds down to their seventh straight defeat by a 9-3 score and grabbed a chartered Eastern Airliner for home.

The outdoor musical events which have become fixtures in its summer program schedule will be carried again by the Municipal Broadcasting System this coming season. The outlets will be WNYC and WNYC-FM.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 13 -Plans for screen production of two wartime Broadway plays, "Sunny River" and "Jacobowsky and the Colonel," were announced today. Jack Skirball and Bruce Manning, independent producers, disclosed that they had concluded a cooperative agreement with Sigmund Romberg and Oscar Hammerstein 2d for filming the 1941 musical comedy "Sunny River" in Technicolor late this year or early in 1949.

BERLIN, May 13 (UP) -- Soviet representatives walked out of a four-power Public Safety Committee meeting today after an argument with British delegates over a police official in the Soviet sector of Berlin.

BERLIN, May 13 -- Johnston Avery, well-known anti-trust attorney and close friend of Secretary of Army Kenneth Royall, has resigned from the United States Military Government as a direct result of the recent drastic change in decartelization policy.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange had narrow price fluctuations yesterday and closed 2 points higher to 15 points lower.

There could be few more convincing pledges of confidence in an industry's future than the opening of United Air Lines' huge new maintenance base at San Francisco. Everyone knows how to make money out of an airliner -- in the air. The industry's reports last year, showing a growing proportion of ground to flight costs, point plainly at the weak point in air commerce's economic structure -- on the ground.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -The first-graders of Colfax School, South Bend, Ind., have given their blessings to Paul G. Hoffman and the European Recovery Program.

The New York City-NewarkJersey City industrial area's leadership as the nation's greatest manufacturing center will be maintained, J. C. Capt, director of the Bureau of Census, predicted yesterday in a press conference at the Pennsylvania Hotel.
HOOD RIVER, Ore., May 13 -Governor Thomas E. Dewey brought to a close today the second stage of his campaign for Oregon's twelve votes in the Republican National Convention.

CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- Bill Voiselle, who appears to have regained his form after a winter operation for varicose veins, hurled his fourth straight victory for the Boston Braves here today when he blanked the Chicago Cubs with a four-hitter, 2 to 0.
TEL AVIV, Palestine, May 13 -the proclamation of the Jewish state of Palestine will be announced, as scheduled, before midnight tomorow.
TOKYO, May 13 -- Informal Cabinet decisions on prices and wages have underlined a definite improvement in real living standards over those of the past ten months.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 13 -Senator Robert A. Taft declared here tonight that the United States "whole foreign policy is conducted in a completely wavering and inept manner." In this connection he cited what he called the "fiasco" of the recent exchange of notes with Russia.

In contrast to the comparatively tame play in the last two rounds of the tournament for the chess championship of the world at Moscow, the tactics employed in the two games of the twentyfourth round yesterday were forceful and decisive, according to a report from Russia.

MADRID, May 13 -- Spain's exports to the United States in the first quarter of 1948 more than double those of any quarter in 1947. The total exports for this quarter were valued at more than $11,500,000, of which nearly $10,000,000 worth were in foodstuffs.

Mid - Manhattan Magistrate's Court, which is mostly accustomed to airing the minor troubles of citizens, yesterday found itself providing -- if somewhat reluctantly -- a guard of protection for a witness to and from his home.

The stock market took its cue yesterday from Washington developments and, in increased trading which passed the 2,000,000-share mark, edged closer to the high levels set last year. A long list of active stocks gained more than a point, with emphasis again placed on the rails and on low-price issues, while the combined averages rose 0.69 point.

Seventy-five employes of the Welfare Department, all members of the United Public Workers of America, CIO, demonstrated yesterday at the department offices during the luncheon period because of the alleged inadequacy of the clerical staff.
New York took its first step toward a general "face-lifting" since 1916 when the Board of Estimate voted $160,000 yesterday for a comprehensive survey of the zoning regulations.

The glint of metallic threads has proved so popular in decorative fabrics that Joseph Blumfield, California rug designer, has worked metallic yarn into new handloomed carpets. The first of his rug designs with gold, silver or copper colored accents to be introduced locally was shown yesterday at the showroom of Eward Fields, Inc., 509 Madison Avenue.

SEOUL, Korea, May 13 -- With only eight of South Korea's 200 voting districts unreported in Monday's national election, it was indicated that Dr. Syngman Rhee, aged independence and anti-Communist leader, was assured of the support of slightly more than half of the 192 Representatives in the National Assembly.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 13 -- The text of the plan for a truce in Palestine adopted here today by a United Nations subcommittee and referred to the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee follows:

LONDON, May 13 -- Chronicling one of the most abject failures in British Imperial history, an official obituary notice was issued today for the twenty-seven-year-old British administration in Palestine, which expires in futility and frustration tomorrow night.

First winning favorite at rainsoaked Jamaica yesterday was Cornish Knight, who during his three seasons of racing has scored nearly all of his eleven victories at the Metropolitan Jockey Club's course.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A decline of 0.4 per cent in primary market prices in the week ended on May 8, was the result of moderate decreases in prices for most farm products and foods, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

DETROIT, May 14 -- Phil Schmidt and Zigmund Starr of Detroit rolled into a tie for tenth place in the American Bowling Congress doubles competition today, breaking a twelve-day spell in which no changes had been recorded on the list of the ten leaders in each division.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 14 (AP) -Osborne (Ozzie) Cowles, 47-yearold basketball coach at Michigan, today was named head basketball coach at the University of Minnesota. The appointment was recommended by James L. Morrill, Minnesota president, and confirmed by the Board of Regents at its meeting today.

The North Shore Motor Sales Corporation has purchased the vacant plot 167 by 180 feet at the northwest corner of Thirty-ninth Avenue and Lawrence Street in Flushing, Queens, from Townsend Lawrence for cash above a mortgage of $17,500.
The United Nations General Assembly rejected yesterday the United States plan for a temporary trusteeship regime in Jerusalem.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee ended today its long hearings on proposed revisions of the United Nations in apparent determination to bring out, at minimum, a resolution sharply critical of the present functioning of the world organization.

ALBANY, May 14 -- The State Banking Department announced today that it had approved an application from the Food Dealers Industrial Bank, 1622 Pitkin Avenue, Brooklyn, for permission to change its branch office from 4612 Thirteenth Avenue to 156 Montague Street, Brooklyn.

As is true of so many other good things in the world, there probably never will be enough good nurses. In New York City the situation is critical. Miss Mary Ellen Manley, director of the division of nursing of the Department of Hospitals, reported at the seventy-fifth anniversary dinner of the Bellevue School of Nursing that there was now a shortage of 3,000 in the city hospitals alone.

The hectic days of the Nineteen Twenties were re-enacted yesterday on the floor of the New York Stockh)0*0*0*iExchange when the most turbulent session in recent years produced increases of 1 to 7 points in the share list. Accompanied by a burst of bullish enthusiasm not witnessed in almost a decade, the deluge of buying orders so taxed the facilities of the Exchange that the reporting ticker tape lagged behind floor transactions by five minutes.

Having spent over thirty years of my adult life trying to enlighten my fellow-citizens regarding the evils of racial and religious prejudices, permit me to compliment you upon the splendid and penetrating editorial, "Analyzing Prejudice," which appeared in the May 5 issue of your paper.

The Western European group of nations is short of military equipment and cannot produce the needed armaments except at the expense of the all-out program of reconstruction and economic rehabilitation, Gen. Sir William D. Morgan. British Army Chief of Staff in Washington, declared yesterday.

ST LOUIS, May 14 (UP) -- A tworun homer by Stan Musial and some fancy clutch pitching by Howie Pollet enabled the St. Louis Cardinals to down the Pittsburgh Pirates, 2 to 1, tonight and regain second place in the National League.
WESTPORT, Conn., May 14(AP) -- The Federal Government tied up part of Vivien Kellems' property today to collect a bill for withholding taxes which she had refused to pay.

WARSAW, May 14 -- The United States Embassy today issued a visa to a Polish newspaper man whose previous failure to get admission to the United States had been the subject of a Polish protest at the recent United Nations Conference on Freedom of Information at Geneva.

NUTLEY, N.J., May 14 -Mrs. Beatrice Perry, 57-year-old founder and director of the Reinheimer Boys Club, an organization for Negro youth, was selected today by a civic committee as the winner of this year's Lions Club award for outstanding citizenship.

LONDON, May 14 -- W. Averell Harriman, Roving Ambassador for the Economic Cooperation Administration, took a plane for Washington this afternoon, leaving a London perplexed and slightly anxious about the European Recovery Program.

Mrs. Arthur M. Reis, for the last twenty-five years chairman of the board of directors of the League of Composers, resigned that position at a meeting of the board, the auxiliary board and national composer-members yesterday afternoon at 820 Fifth Avenue.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 14 -Premier Paul-Henri Spaak, at the request of the Regent, Prince Charles, withdrew today the resignation of his Government that he tendered on May 5.

The Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions pressed an action yesterday to evict twenty-four families from 47 Claremont Avenue. It presented testimony before Charles O'Connor, hearing officer of the New York City Rent Commission at 500 Park Avenue.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 14 -The executive council of the American Federation of Labor today rejected a proposal by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, for joint participation with the CIO in certain phases of the European Recovery Plan.

The Columbia Gas System, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday that net income for the twelve months to March 31 amounted to $16,143,208, equal to $1.32 a share, compared with $16,151,695, or $1.32 a share in preceding twelve months.

Today's events: Children's Concert, Dean Dixon, conductor, withPaul Robeson, Robert Penn, PeteSeeger, Tony Sraber. Town Hall,2:30 P. M.; Bronx and 5{anhattanChorus, Jewish People's FraternalOrder, Maurice Rauch, conductor;Cantor saak Gladstone:

TEL AVIV, Palestine, May 14 (AP) -- The Haganah, Zionist Army, was locked in a bitter battle today with the major strength of the Arab volunteer army at the Bab el Wad gorge, ten miles west of Jerusalem. Control of the JerusalemTel Aviv Highway was at stake.

The Mutual Broadcasting System filed a general denial in Federal Court yesterday of charges made against it by Dan Golenpaul, owner of the radio show "Information Please," in a $500,000 damage suit alleging that the network was negligent in its handling of the program.
The current measles epidemic among New York children has been diminishing for about three weeks and probably has passed its peak, data obtained yesterday from the city Health Department indicated.

You printed on May 6 a letter from Herbert Bayard Swope claiming that I misrepresented the record in commenting on "Baruch's program of industrial mobilization with all that means in the way of regimentation of labor."

LONDON, May 14 (AP) -- Mel Patton, University of Southern California track star and chief American hope in the Olympic sprints this summer, was listed officially today as co-holder of the world 100-yard dash record.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, tonight called President Truman's recognition of the new Jewish state "a logical and proper step." Mr. Vandenberg, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, issued the following statement:
Dr. Chaim Weizmann, who is expected to be the first President of the State of Israel, appealed directly at noon yesterday to President Truman for recognition of the new Jewish nation.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, May 14 -- Russia can demonstrate her sincerity in preserving world peace by aiding the United States to finance rehabilitation of war torn countries, Herbert H. Schell, president of Sidney Blumenthal Co., declared here tonight.

HEWLETT, L. I., May 14 -- Stan Koslowski and Ernest Gerardi, visitors from Worcester, Mass., who led the qualifiers in the Long Island Golf Association's William D. Richardson Memorial golf tourney yesterday, captured both their matches over the Seawane Harbor Club course today.

Cardinal Spellman has appointed a special committee of the clergy for the resettlement of Catholic displaced persons from Europe, with the Rev. Cyril J. Potocek, a World War II chaplain, as archdiocesan director. The appointment was announced yesterday by the Right Rev. Msgr. Edward R. Gaffney, vicar general of the archdiocese.

The Women's Metropolitan interclub cup series got a jolt from the weather yesterday and only Long Island completed all its scheduled matches. The entire series in New Jersey was postponed, while the Cup 1 group in Westchester voted to put off its contests until Wednesday.

Lamb prices reached a record high in the history of the city yesterday, with loin chops quoted at $1.05 a pound. Beef rose to the point where it now costs more than it has at any time this year. Rib roast averages 73 cents a pound.

CANON CITY, Col., May 14 (AP) -- Warden Roy Best said today that a troubled conscience caused Charles McClelland, 19 years old, a convict, to confess the slaying of Robert L. May 2d and his wife, Betty, both 22. Mr. May was the son of a Virginia utilities operator.
CAIRO, Saturday, May 15 -Egyptian armed forces have been ordered to enter Palestine, the Egyptian Government announced in a communique issued last midnight.

The Hoboken Bank for Savings has sold the building at 901 Clinton Street, Hoboken, N.J., containing four stores and eighteen apartments, to Carolyn Lewis. J. I. Kislak Inc., broker in this transaction also reports the sale of the property at 154 Fifth Street, Hoboken, comprising four apartments and three stores, for the F. H. N. Realty Company to David Chinich.

The Board of Estimate's approval of a $165,000 expenditure for a one-year study of present and future land use in relation to the city's zoning regulations is a long overdue, if modest, beginning of some real planning for New York City. It would be raising false hopes to assume that this, in itself could mean that a master plan would spring into being, full-fledged, in a year or so.

Two-year-old Michael Colon's habit of hiding in the bedroom closet and locking the door proved fatal to him yesterday when fire swept his family's six-room apartment at 956 Stebbins Avenue, the Bronx.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 14 -- The bread nation in three German states was raised today, bringing them to near-parity with the rest of the bizonal area. Generals Lucius D. Clay and Sir Brian Robertson agreed to increase the bread ration in Lower Saxony, Bavaria and Schleswig-Holstein to 8,500 grams monthly, still 150 grams below that prevailing in other states.

By an unpredictable circumstance this writer arrived too late at the concert of chamber music given by the Juilliard String Quartet as part of the Columbia University Musical Festival last night in McMillin Theatre to hear the Quartet in G of Lukas Foss.

PARIS, May 14 -- Speaking in faultless French with just the touch of a British accent to delight French ears, Princess Elizabeth today asked France and Britain to make a common effort to lead Europe to moral and intellectual as well as economic reconstruction.

All segments of the furniture industry are preparing for an all-out fight against railroad proposals to cancel furniture freight rate exemptions, traffic executives of both furniture and department stores disclosed yesterday. They estimated that adoption of carrier recommendations will add $25,000,000 annually to current freight costs, with expenses on some items rising 225 per cent.

TRENTON, N.J., May 14 -- The New Jersey Legislature closed its spring session tonight with enactment of an employes' cash sickness benefit program. Disability grants will range from $9 to $22 a week for not more than twenty-six weeks.

LONDON, May 14 (AP) -- The odds against American-bred Senator II, from the English stables of New Yorker William Woodward, tumbled from 66 to 1 to 28 to 1 at a call-over tonight for the English Derby.

The track and field talent of the Ivy League, which includes such bright Olympic prospects as Bill Vessie, Sam Felton, Vic Frank, Jim Fuchs, Jack Hammack and Jeff Kirk, will be marshaled in review at West Point today in the fourteenth annual Heptagonal Games.
The cotton futures market was moderately active on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were unchanged to 18 points higher.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 14 -Princeton used seventeen players today on University Field, but the Tigers lost their Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game to Harvard, 5 -- 3. It was the sixth straight loss for Princeton and the first League victory for Harvard.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Leaders in the field of malaria from the United States and abroad reported today before the joint international congresses on tropical medicine and malaria that six new drugs, thoroughly tested on a large number of human victims of the disease, had been found to provide complete protection against the recurrent, as well as the frequently fatal non-recurrent, types of malaria.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth, which sailed for Cherbourg and Southampton yesterday, carried 2,231 passengers -eighty-three less than extreme capacity -- the highest eastbound total of either of the giant "Queens" since last fall.

New Yorkers, who planted 450,000 wartime Victory Gardens within the city limits, have started no more than 250,000 Freedom Gardens in response to the Government's current program, it was estimated yesterday. The goal set by the Department of Agriculture is 500,000 gardens in this city to help hold down food prices and to release food for shipment to hungry Europe.
Midnight struck for the Cinderella team of baseball yesterday when the Yankees, self-appointed enforcement agency of the law of averages, halted the ten-game winning streak of the amazing Athletics.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., May 14 -- In fall fashions by Marusia, fabulous fabrics from the finest looms of this country and Europe are so artfully handled they need no applied decoration and present excellent foils for jewels. Button for embroidery trims are used restrainedly on a few day dresses land formal gowns sometimes have quilted or self-appliqued design placed low on skirts.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -Publicly reported cash dividend payments in April totaled $456,000,000, an increase of 14 per cent ove. April, 1947, the Department of Commerce reported today. For the February-March-April period these amounted to $1,250,900,000, a 13 per cent rise over the same period of last year.

CAIRO, Saturday, May 15 (AP) -Syrian and Lebanese troops also are poised on the northern border of the Holy Land apparently awaiting an invasion zero hour expected shortly after midnight, a Damascus dispatch said. A late report said Dan was under attack.

The butcher, the baker, the candlestick maker -- even an Italian Olympics swimming star turned painter -- were among 200 artists participating yesterday in the opening of the thirty-third semi-annual Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit.
MOSCOW, May 14 (UP) -- Pravda, Communist party paper, said today that American leaders had been shown up as double dealers in their handling of the recent United States-Soviet diplomatic exchange.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- A proposed minority report from the old Senate War Investigating Committee, denouncing much of the committee's activity in the Howard Hughes inquiry, was prematurely published today and then "substantially revised" by its four ostensible Democratic signers.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Truman asserted tonight that there would be a Democrat in the White House during the next four years and that he would be the man. He made the statement to a cheering audience of 1,000 young Democrats at their meeting here.

The House Ways and Means Committee, on a strictly party division, voted 15 to 9 yesterday against extending for the customary three years the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act of 1934. The Committee's action was plainly taken at the party policy level, since it was patterned on a decision made twenty-four hours earlier by the Republican Steering Committee.

BALBOA, C.Z., May 14 -- Maj. Gen. Joseph C. Mehaffey sailed for New York aboard the Panama liner Ancon today after completing a four-year term as Governor of the Panama Canal Zone. His next assignment is to the Engineers Corps in the Ohio River Valley.

SHEFFIELD, England, May 14 -- Although eighty-two coal miners of the Waleswood Colliery near here came to the surface early today after a ten-day "stay-down" strike, a major stoppage of mines in the rich Yorkshire and East Midlands coal fields became a distinct possibility tonight.
AMES, Iowa, May 14 (AP) -- A $1,850,000 addition to the Ames Laboratory at Iowa State College was authorized today by the Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- A bill to support research in heart and circulatory diseases and to establish a national heart institute was approved unanimously today by the Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare.
TEL AVIV, Palestine, Saturday, May 15 -- Air raiders bombed this all-Jewish city at about dawn today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 -- Management and labor have been brought to book for disregarding the public interest in collective bargaining, Fred W. Climer, vice president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, said here today.

A special community vesper service tomorrow at 4 P.M. in the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie will honor Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands, who will abdicate next September after the celebration in her homeland of her half century on the throne.

Finals for high school instrumental groups competing in the thirteenth annual Catholic School Music Festival were held yesterday afternoon at Town Hall under the auspices of the Music Education League and the sponsorship of the superintendents of schools of the Archdiocese of New York and the Diocese of Brooklyn.

Isidore Ginsberg, Queens attorney who testified last January before the Senate Housing Committee investigating the "gray market" in building materials, and his 20-year-old son, Maurice, were indicted yesterday by the Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on charges of using the mails to defraud.

The difference within the International Typographical Union, AFL, over contract negotiations with thirteen major newspapers in this city will be submitted to the membership of New York Typographical Union No. 6 at a meeting tomorrow, it became known yesterday.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 14 -A prosperous future for the metalworking industries of New England was forecast here tonight by Ferederick S. Blackall Jr., president and treasurer of the TaftPierce Manufacturing Company of Woonsocket, in a talk before 275 members of the six New England chapters of the American Society for Metals.
CAIRO, Saturday, May 15 (UP) -Upwards of 30,000 trained Arab troops had massed on three frontiers of Palestine for an invasion, according to observers here.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 14 (AP) -- Between showers, Leigh Brite, M.I.T. alumnus, sailed to victory today in the third annual "afterguard" dinghy championships of the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association.

LONDON, May 14 -- One of the few features today in the stock market here which preceded the Whitsun holidays was the activity in Canadian Pacific on United States and Canadian buying based on expectations of possible oil developments on the company's lands in western Canada.

CHICAGO, May 14 -- A possibility that the United Packinghouse Workers of America, CIO, will admit defeat in its fiftynine-day-old strike against major meat packers was seen today in calls for two special meetings of top union chiefs in Chicago tomorrow and Sunday.
LONDON, May 14 -- The British Industries Fair, which ended its eleven-day run today, drew approximately 15,000 overseas buyers, officials said tonight.

Wages of American able seamen, the highest in the world, now are more than 300 per cent above prewar days, and 50 per cent over the war bonus inflated wage, according to statistics released here by the American Merchant Marine Institute.

The old battleship Mississippi, now an auxiliary gunboat, arrived in New York yesterday for weekend "liberty and recreation" and will leave again on Monday for ten days of operation in the Atlantic. The Navy announced that the ship, at Pier 60, North River, at West Twentieth Street, would be open for public inspection today and tomorrow from 1 to 5 P.M.

JERUSALEM, May 14 -- As Britain's last high commissioner in Palestine left Jerusalem today the Union Jack over Government House was hauled down and a Red Cross hoisted. A solitary bag-piper skirled the Highland lament as Sir Alan walked out of the official residence on Mount Zion for the last time.

CHICAGO, May 14 Corn and oats were strong and wheat was easy on the Board of Trade today. Corn closed 1 1/4 to 2 1/4 cents a bushel higher than yesterday and oats were up 1/8 to 1 cent. Neither grain held its full advance, however. Wheat lost 1/4 to 3/4 cent.

CLEVELAND, May 14 -- Robert J. Bulkley, former United States Senator from Ohio and attorney for Cyrus S. Eaton, largest stockholder of the investment banking firm of Otis Co., of this city, refused today to answer certain questions about the recent $1,000,000 common stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.

PRIVAS, France, May 14 (AP) -The body of Kathleen Lady Hartington, killed in a plane crash with a British lord and two fliers, was taken tonight to an improvised funeral parlor in the Privas Town Hall.

BALTIMORE, May 14 -- Calumet Farm's Citation, who left his stablemate Coaltown and four other mud-spattered 3-year-olds up the stretch behind him in the Kentucky Derby on May 1, will run against an even smaller group of hopefuls in the $100,000 added Preakness Stakes at Pimlico tomorrow.

AROUND 1794, in the wilds of Pennsylvania, a colony was established to receive refugees from the French Revolution. Sponsors of the venture, which was partly philanthropic, partly speculative, were the Americans Robert Morris and John Nicholson, and such French noblemen as Louis Marie, Viscount de Noailles, and Antoine Omer, Marquis de Talon.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 14 (AP) -- A United States B-29 Superfortress crashed in the Saudi Arabian desert and a rescue convoy that reached the wreckage found but one survivor of the fourteen crewmen and passengers, United States Air Force headquarters announced tonight.
Leaders and the rank and file of various Zionist groups hailed yesterday the proclamation of a new Jewish state in Palestine.

WASHINGTON. May 14 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today gave shipper groups the right to participate in cases before it in opposition to attempts of the Government to obtain an estimated $2,000,000,000 reparation from the country's railroads on wartime shipments.

Police of the Bomb Squad, aided by other detectives, an emergency squad and uniformedh)0*0*0*ipatrolmen, made an unsuccessful search of the five-story Iraq Consulate at 36 Riverside Drive late last night after an anonymous telephone caller had warned that the building would be "blown up in fifteen minutes."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 14 -Franchot Tone has been signed by RKO for a leading role in "Every Girl Should Be Married" with Gary Cooper and Betsy Drake, the studio announced today. The picture, a comedy about a photographer's model based on a story by Eleanor Harris, is scheduled for the cameras in two weeks with Don Hartman producing and directing.

PARIS, May 14 -- The Government of Premier Robert Schuman was checked in the National Assembly tonight when a Socialist amendment transferring twenty-six French primary schools from Catholic to national control was adopted by a narrow margin.
In these days of chaotic bewilderment, may I take up the cudgels on behalf of that great army of misunderstood souls, "the bald-headed men," the men who have lost all hope.

LONDON, May 14 -- With obvious relief, Britain turned her back on Palestine today. From now until the final withdrawal of troops on Aug. 1, A. V. Alexander, Minister of Defense, told the House of Commons, Britain's main consideration in Palestine will be the safe and speedy evacuation of her troops.

Getaway day at Jamaica today will be featured by the tenth running of the $75,000 added Gallant Fox Handicap, in which the outstanding handicap horses in training will race a mile and threesixteenths. With any break in the weather, upward of 50,000 persons may turn out for the thirty-ninth day of the meeting.

Of unusual significance because of the Olympic implications, the third annual championship regatta of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges will be held today on the Charles River Basin at Cambridge.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 14 -"The Princess and the Vagabond," a captivating new American opera by Isadore Freed, had its world premiere here last night. Presented before a full house by the Julius Hartt School of Music, in the school auditorium, the work and its production had ingenuity, musicality and finesse which would have done credit to Broadway.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- New and improved devices to provide facilities of increased usefulness for aviation, communications, transportation and for purposes of attack or defense, were among the 425 inventions patented this week by the United States Patent Office.

NEWARK, N.J., May 14 -- Vincent J. Cannera of 276 Ampere Parkway, Bloomfield, faces a possible maximum sentence of thirtyfive years in a Federal penitentiary and $70,000 fine as a result of a verdict of guilty returned against him this afternoon by a jury in Federal court before Judge Guy L. Fake.

THE DALLES, Ore., May 14 -Harold E. Stassen emerged eagerly from his campaign bus today to greet Thomas E. Dewey, his rival in the battle for Oregon's twelve-man delegation to the Republican National Convention.
BERLIN, May 14 (AP) -- Reports reached Western Allied officials here today that dozens of high officers were being sent back to the Soviet Union in a purge of the Soviet administration in Germany.

Anger, incredulity and shock, mixed finally with relief, made the General Assembly session at Flushing Meadow last night the most stirring United Nations meeting to date as a result of the United States recognition of the new state of Israel.

Retail trade here this week made a small increase despite several days of bad weather. Department store sales were estimated as about 5 per cent over the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were up 2 per cent.

" Accordingly we, the members of the National Council, representing the Jewish people in Palestine and the Zionist movement, met together in solemn assembly, by virtue of the natural and historic rights of the Jewish people and of the resolution of the General Assembly of the United Nations, hereby proclaim the establishment of the Jewish State in Palestine, to be called Israel."
Brooklyn College celebrated its eighteenth birthday yesterday with faculty members and students alike leaving their classes to attend the college's tenth annual "country fair."

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to permit Robert R. Young, chairman of the board, and Robert R. Bowman, president, of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, to sit also on the board of the New York Central, and to enjoy full voting rights of 400,000 shares of New York Central stock, which the C. O. now owns.

HAVANA, May 14 -- In case of a third world war, Cuba would furnish soldiers as part of her contribution to the defense of democracy, Dr. Ricardo Nunez Portuondo, Presidential candidate for the Liberal Democratic coalition in the June elections, said today.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -Gerhard Van Arkel, AFL International Typographical Union attorney, served notice today that he might boycott hearings on charges that the ITU violated the TaftHartley law in dealings with newspaper publishers.

Ending a two-day conference in the Pennsylvania Hotel, the National Association of Consumers adopted yesterday a comprehensive platform for the coming year. Planks ranged from support of general price control to advocacy of stronger anti-monopoly enforcement.

A drizzling rain that started in the first inning of last night's game between the Braves and Dodgers at Ebbets Field, finally resulted in a reluctant cancellation an hour and fifteen minutes after the first pitch.

LONDON, May 14 (AP) -- Jaroslav Drobny won his first Davis Cup test of the year for Czechoslovakia today, but his country's tennis team gained nothing more than an even split with Brazil as they opened their second-round series in the European Zone eliminations.
Denial of excessive speculation in raw furs at the present time was made yesterday by George Adelstein of Schild-Adelstein and president of the American Fur Merchants Association.
Cleveland, Ohio, announced yesterday that it would receive bids June 8 on $12,000,000 of water works revenue bonds dated July 1, 1948, and due Feb. 1 and April 1 from 1953 to 1972.

The executive board of Local 50, Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union, AFL, accepted unanimously last night a "package proposal" from the Big Eight baking companies, ending the threat of a strike and management work stoppage scheduled for tomorrow afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Joint Economic Committee, after almost a year of research and cross-country investigation in the high cost of living, reported to Congress today that cooperation by industry, labor and the public would be helpful and that the whole question required much more study.

BETWEEN 4:30 and 5 a.m. on April 8 [1940] four British destroyers laid our minefield off the entrance to West Fiord, the channel to the port of Narvik. At 5 a.m. the news was broadcast from London and at 5:30 a note from His Majesty's Government was handed to the Norwegian Foreign Minister. The morning in Oslo was spent in drafting protests to London.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The House completed preliminary debate today on a bill to expose and control communistic activities with sponsors claiming a 4-to-1 margin for passage, expected Tuesday.
Jesse Flores, a newcomer to the local fistic scene, gave a good account of himself against Johnny Williams of Montgomery, Ala., in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

CHICAGO, May 14 (UP) -- Andy Pafko hammered his third home run of the season deep into the left field bleachers to give Russ Meyer and the Chicago Cubs, a 1-0 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today before a ladies day crowd of 10,510.
Carroll L. Pfeifer, former director of sales fgr Sculpture House, has joined the creative staff of Visual Methods Company, Inc.

After hearing both the Soviet Union and the Arab delegates denounce the United States for its sudden recognition of the new Jewish state in Palestine, the United Nations General Assembly decided last night to send a Mediator to the Holy Land to do what he could to arrange a truce and carry on public services.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Truman announced early tonight recognition by the United States of the new Jewish State of Israel. The President acted instantly upon being informed that the new nation had been proclaimed.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 14 -- Jacob S. Potofsky, nominated by acclamation for his first full term as president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO, said here today that the unity demonstrated by the 1,250 delegates to the union's convention was the best answer to charges by Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, that there was a cleavage between the leaders and the rank-and-file of American labor.

Two new films will open locally today. "Big City," a romantic drama with music and a Manhattan locale, will be presented by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer at Loew's Criterion. Margaret O'Brien leads off a cast which includes Robert Preston, Danny Thomas, George Murphy, Karin Booth, Edward Arnold and Betty Garrett ...

Another phase of the bitter jurisdictional warfare between the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America and the United Automobile Workers, two of the largest CIO affiliates, came to light in Federal Court yesterday when Local 475 of the UE sued to prevent the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board from holding a collective bargaining election asked by the UAW.

Korina, the new wood veneer recently introduced by the United States Plywood Corporation, made its first appearance yesterday in ready-made furniture in a new line of sectional storage units by Advance Design, Inc.

TEL AVIV, Palestine, Saturday, May 15 -- The Jewish state, the world's newest sovereignty, to be known as the State of Israel, came into being in Palestine at midnight upon termination of the British mandate.
LONDON, May 14 (AP) -- Members of the United States Curtis Cup team played a series of practice matches "for fun" today at the Berkshire Golf Club, almost in the backyard of Windsor Castle.

A hearing of Sullivan Law charges against Joseph Untermeyer, 19-year-old adopted son of the poet, Louis Untermeyer, of 600 West End Avenue, and Isaiah Warshaw, 30, of 15 Mill Street, Brooklyn, was adjourned yesterday by Magistrate Abraham Bloch in Felony Court until May 28.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 14 (AP) -The president of the United States Chamber of Commerce described a Buffalo industrial exposition today as an example of prosperity and security which "the windy words of the political stump" cannot replace.

LEXINGTON, Va., May 14 -Lessing J. Rosenwald, president of the American Council for Judaism, said here tonight that behind the United Nations Assembly's vote recommending the partitioning of Palestine last November was "a sordid story of pressuring and high-handed methods of lining up votes."

One of the most constructive activities of the American Automobile Association will be dramatized today when more than 15,000 boys and girls of the school patrols from all parts of the country parade down Constitution Avenue in Washington. We are sorry that fifty-one young New Yorkers will not be there.

Delbert Clark's article on denazification trials in the American zone, in your issue of May 5, conveys very interesting information. The article may, however, mislead those of your readers who are not thoroughly familiar with the development of denazification in the American zone on two points.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 14 -- National Guard troops were ordered to South St. Paul and Newport, towns on opposite banks of the Mississippi River near here, by Governor Luther Youngdahl today following violent disorders at strike-bound packing plants in the area and the statement of the local sheriffs that their forces could not maintain law and order.
HICKSVILLE, L.I., May 14 -The 300th birthday celebration of this community will get under way tomorrow morning with exercises at the steps of the old courthouse and will continue for eight days.

GENEVA, Switzerland, May 14 -- Shifts in the allocations of European coal that will save an estimated $1,500,000 on coal imports from the United States during the third quarter of 1948 have been agreed to in the allocations subcommittee of the Coal Committee of the Economic Commission for Europe.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 14 -Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota agreed today to debate Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, his opponent in the Oregon Republican Presidential primary, under conditions imposed by the latter.

Spurred by problems of steel allocations, about fifty steel distributing companies throughout the country will re-activate tile Steel Products Warehouse Association as a national trade organization at a meeting to be held May 20 in the Statler Hotel, Cleveland.

CHICAGO, May 14 -- Establishment of a Jewish state in Palestine gave dramatic significance today to discussion of Jewish education at the biennial convention of the United Synagogue of America here.

The Chemical Bank and Trust Company has been appointed trustee, paying agent and registrar for $5,500,000 of New York State Electric and Gas Corporation first mortgage bonds, 3 per cent series, due in 1978.
Capturing three first places and a second in the eleven-event program, Jamaica High School won the annual city P.S.A.L. novice track and field championship at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium yesterday.

Housewares dollar volume has improved appreciably in the last few weeks and most large outlets are running from 15 to 45 per cent ahead of last year, buyers reported yesterday. They stated that the mild drop in late April has disappeared as May promotions continue to chalk up imposing gains.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Tentative allocations of loans and grants totaling $1,186,000,000 through June 30 were announced today by the Economic Cooperation Administration. The total included $908,000,000 of grants and $278,000,000 of repayable loans.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The government emphasized today the non-military character of railroad operations, despite Army control, in a minor question that arose in connection with the strike against the Chrysler Corporation.

The visiting Habimah, Palestine's national theatre, will set up its third production this evening at the Broadway Theatre. It is "The Golem," described as a poetic drama in three acts and a prologue by H. Levik. The work, which never has been offered here in the Hebrew version, deals with the creation of a giant out of clay for the purpose of protecting the Jewish people against their enemies.
Your editorial of recent date entitled "South Pacific Commission" and letters to the editor signed by Roy E. James and J. C. Furnas published on May 10 have come to my attention.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (AP) - Soggy fairways and 103 sand traps were no protection for par today as a quartet of golfers traveled the first round of the Philadelphia Inquirer $15,000 invitation tourney in 69 strokes, three below regulation figures.

An enemy will not attack the United States as soon as it has the atomic bomb if the United States has a strong air force capable of carrying our atom bombs to our enemies, W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force, said here last night.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Truman requested Congress today to provide lasting security for the American farmer by giving him a permanent, flexible system of parity price support, an expanded soil conservation program and other general and personal benefits.
TEL AVIV, Palestine, May 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Declaration of Independence of the Jewish state:

The eight-story store and loft building at 43 East Twentieth Street has been sold by the Visionette Optical Company to Joseph Levine, manufacturer of coat fronts, for investment. It was sold for cash over a mortgage of $32,500 through Williams Co., brokers.
BOSTON, May 14 -- The United Steelworkers, CIO, voted today to bar Communists from union office.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Navy expects to launch early next year the first of a class of new flying boats, equipped with four turbine propeller engines, that will set new records for this type of patrol plane, it was announced here today.

Ignoring racial differences, merry groups of School Safety Patrol contest winners joined yesterday in a program of entertainment given by the Automobile Club of New York after they had received awards for protective achievements in traffic.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 14 -- Assault charges filed against two Port Chester policemen by Abraham Seabrook of Port Chester, 26 years old, were dismissed here today by a Westchester County grand jury. The policemen, who waived immunity and testified, had been accused of breaking Mr. Seabrook's jaw.
DETROIT, May 14 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers came home from the East today to run smack back into the victory drought that has steadily postponed their first victory of the season at Briggs Stadium.

There has been held this week in New York City the seventeenth annual conference of the Chaplains Association of the Army and Navy of the United States. In their discussions these men gave a demonstration of religious unity that was heartening to observers.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Ways and Means Committee approved today a one-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act with restrictions which Democrats opposed as "crippling."

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 14 -Mrs. W. French Githens' black miniature poodle, Champion Ensarr Salute, from Bernardsville, N.J., who made his ring debut in the event a year ago, took bestin-show today in the fourteenth specialty of the Poodle Club of America on the grounds of the Garden City Hotel.
TEL AVIV, Palestine, May 14 (AP) -- A secret censorship was imposed for twenty-four hours, ending at noon today, on dispatches of foreign correspondents in Tel Aviv.

MANILA, May 14 -- The reported prospects of the imminent surrenderh)0*0*0*iof Luis Taruc, leader of the 3-year-old Hukbalahap rebellion, to President Elpidio Quirino caused widespread excitement among Filipinos today.

First orders of electrical equipment for installation of two-way radio-telephone on Pullman cars of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad are due to be delivered within three weeks, William Haines, vice president of Electric Specialty Company, Stamford, Conn., revealed here yesterday.

Television station WATV, Newark, fourth video station to be on the air in the New York-North New Jersey area, will begin operations on a regularly scheduled basis at 4 P.M. today with a telecast of horse races from Garden State Park, Camden.

New York University's nine will face the opportunity to move one step closer to the Metropolitan Collegiate Conference crown when it faces Manhattan College at Van Cortlandt Park in one of six local collegiate games scheduled today.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., May 14 (AP) -- New shot-put and 440-yard records were established today as favored Maryland and the defending champion, North Carolina, each won eleven qualifying places in the twenty-fourth Southern Conference track and field championships.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -Grenville Mellen, a member of the Maritime Commission, urged Congress today to get the commission out of the Alaskan transportation field "as soon as possible."

Doubt was expressed yesterday in underwriting circles as to whether or not the Consolidated Edison Company of New York will receive any bids on Tuesday for the management of its stand-by offering to stockholders of $57,382,000 of convertible debentures.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, May 15 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge accused the Russians today of cutting off electrical power from North Korea "as a political bludgeon" to force South Korea to surrender to the Communists.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Navy asked Congress today for authority to shift sharply its construction of fighting craft from battleship, cruiser and destroyer types to guided missile vessels, a 65,000-ton carrier able to base, far at sea, planes with an operating radius of 1,700 miles, better submarines and floating "enemy submarine killers."
CLEVELAND, May 14 (AP) -- The Alleghany Corporation reported today a consolidated net income of $1,502,587 for the first quarter of 1948, compared with $231,939 in the corresponding quarter of 1947.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Quick action by Congress on the international wheat agreement so that its provisions would cover the crop year starting on July 1 was urged today before a Senate foreign relations subcommittee by Norris E. Dodd, acting Secretary of Agriculture, and Willard L. Thorp, Assistant Secretary of State.

The Lotos Club's exhibition of American paintings since 1870 and three group shows in local galleries of work by younger artists this week provide instructive and pointed contrast between past and present-day directions in American painting.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 14 -Joseph M. Dodge of Detroit, president of the American Bankers Association, urged the nation's banks today to continue a policy of restraint on loans because there is still a potential threat of inflation in renewed Government spending for armament and European relief.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 14 -- A plea for broader educational programs in schools to provide for the emotional, mental and social growth of students, as well as for their intellectual development, was issued tonight by Dr. Willard E. Olson, president of the American Educational Research Association.

VIENNA, May 14 -- The Allied Council for Austria considered only two matters at its session today and agreed on both. This was a new recent record for the council as was the brevity of its three-quarter-hour meeting.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -North American Aviation, Inc., told the Securities and Exchange Commission today the General Motors Corporation would sell publicly its entire holdings of 1,000,061 shares of the aviation company's stock.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Senate Labor Committee approved today, by a vote of 7 to 4, a bill to establish in the Labor Department an extension service. Modeled on the type of education offered to farmers by the Agricultural Extension Service, it would provide some 40,000,000 industrial workers with "useful and practical" information about their work and industrial relations.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Large-scale tests with the anti-tuberculosis vaccine known as BCG, providing what was described "as one of the most impressive and conclusive proofs that the vaccine is highly effective in reducing the death rate from tuberculosis," were described here today before the Joint International Congress on Tropical Medicine and Malaria.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 15 -- An international armament race, which is made more threatening by the unconcealed determination of the Soviet Union to break the United States monopoly of the atomic bomb, is now threatened as a result of the failure of the United Nations to achieve either international atomic control or general disarmament.

CHICAGO, May 15 (AP) -- Grains started steady today on the Board of Trade but backed down before the close of the market. Losses were substituted for early fractional gains. The decline followed a let-up in short covering in May contracts. In part, the selling represented week-end profit-taking.
