LONDON, May 15 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia's tennis team, attempting to reach the interzone Davis Cup finals for the second straight year, moved to within one victory of the third round in the European zone eliminations today with a doubles triumph over Brazil.

CAIRO, May 15 (AP) -- The Under-Secretary of the Interior announced today that 400 "Communists and Zionists" were being rounded up in the Cairo, Alexandria and Port Said areas and were being placed in detention camps at Cairo and Alexandria.

ROME, May 15 -- Luigi Einaudi's election to the Presidency of the Italian Republic is expected by many people to herald easing of the tension between the Communists and anti-Communists both inside and outside Parliament.

Possessing more significance from the standpoint of international economic recovery and peace than at any time since its inception in 1935. World Trade Week begins today. Sponsored nationally by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, numerous events will be held here and in other cities during the week to focus attention on the vital role of "two-way trade."

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Truman vetoed today, as an "unwarranted encroachment" on his authority, a measure providing for investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of the loyalty and character of his nominations to the Atomic Energy Commission.

Fifty foot and mounted policemen, and sixty detectives were sent to Harlem late last night as a precautionary measure following a disorder in the afternoon in a food market at 101 West 116th Street, at Lenox Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -- Back from their highly exhilarating tour of the West, the Giants today invaded Shibe Park and to the consternation of 12,875 on-lookers, who doubtless were braced for something more vigorous from the maulers of New York, promptly fell asleep.
PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -- Penn's baseball team downed Harvard, 7 -- 6, at River Field today before a crowd of 1,204, mostly members of the Associated Harvard Club.

HAIFA, Palestine, May 15 (UP) -- Jews danced in Haifa last night while truckloads of their men rode off to war. Jewish communities took on a carnival air as soon as the solemn formalities of the Israel proclamation were completed. Beneath the gaiety, however, there was the earnestness of war.

Zionist leaders in this country continued yesterday to express joy over the creation of the new Jewish state in Palestine and to plead for the lifting of the embargo on arms shipments to the Holy Land.

SEOUL, Korea, May 15 -- The elections held May 10 in South Korea under the observation of the United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea resulted in an overwhelming victory for the anti-Communist political forces headed by Dr. Syngman Rhee, aged Nationalist and for many years Korea's unofficial Ambassador to Western capitals.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 15 -- Confronted with a message from the Egyptian Government announcing bluntly to the United Nations that Egyptian troops had invaded Palestine, the Security Council met today to decide what to do about this threat to peace.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- If the May 4 statement of American foreign policy which this Government instructed Ambassador W. Bedell Smith to read to V. M. Molotov effected a diplomatic administrative or political triumph for the United States vis-a-vis Soviet Russia, this certainly has not been established in revealed opinion anywhere since Mr. Molotov made known the contents of the statement and his reply.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, May 14 (Delayed) -- The Hungarian Government today denied a NEW YORK TIMES story of May 4 from Paris about a secret Russo-Hungarian financial agreement. The denial was as follows:...

HEWLETT. L. I., May 15 -- Stan Koslowski, Rhode Island amateur champion, and his partner. Ernest Gerardi, saved themselves from the age-old jinx usually associated with winning the medal by waging an uphill fight gain to the final round in the Long Island Golf Association's William D. Richardson Memorial tourney at the Seawane Harbor Club today.

Special ceremonies will be held at the New York University Heights Campus Thursday, at which a bronze bust of Dr. Walter Reed, conqueror of yellow fever, will be permanently installed in the Hall of Fame for Great Americans, James Rowland Angell, director of the shrine, announced yesterday.

President Truman received scattered applause mingled with quite a few boos while the Soviet Union and its retiring representative in the United Nations, Andrei Gromyko, were wildly applauded at a "Salute to the Jewish State" rally and pageant in the Polo Grounds last night.

A new drug developed in the laboratories of Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons and the Schering Corporation, Bloomfield, N. J., "is of definite value in treating cholera," Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of the college, announced yesterday.

Support of two bills now pending before Congress designed to permit manufacturing and exhibition of goods in United States Foreign Trade Zones, was expressed last week in a resolution adopted by the board of directors of the Customs Brokers and Forwarders Association of America, Inc., according to an announcement by Martin A. Kerner, president of the association.

Retail activity last week was slowed down by rainy weather, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Cotton dress, beachwear and lingerie departments reported good sales volume.

IN the early days of scientific medicine, physicians were men of considerable learning in wide fields of science and letters. Often they were philosophers and leading thinkers of their day. With the increasing complexity of medical science, however, the physician has necessarily been forced to restrict his interests to smaller and smaller spheres.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 15 -- Jim Fuchs and Vic Frank, a couple of brawny footballers, pulled favored Yale through to a hair-breath victory over Army in a tense duel for team honors in the fourteenth annual Heptagonal Games at the Military Academy today.

WHAT always strikes the reader of Storm Jameson's novels is their skillful blending of speculative thought and dramatic, often explosive, action. She is among the few present-day novelists who see conflict wholly in terms or moral consequeness and have the breadth of sympathy to sound a universal note.

As its major exhibition of the season the Museum of Modern Art has opened a retrospective show of the paintings and graphic work of the late Pierre Bonnard, whose eighty years spanned the period from battles over impressionism to the present, when the modern movement in all essentials has become established.
Today, May 16, is the twenty-first day of the Greater New York Fund's eleventh annual campaign in behalf of 423 local hospitals, health and welfare agencies.

SAN DIEGO, Calif. -- Although California is in the habit of touting most of its attractions as "biggest and best," there is a brand new item in this category awaiting 1948 tourists which no man can gainsay.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 15 -- A celebratory week marking the 100th anniversary of the first session of the German National Assembly in 1848 starts tomorrow. The streets of Frankfort are already bedecked with the red, black and gold flags of the revolutionists and the white and red banners of this medieval city where the Germans sought to establish a confederation.
JERICHO, Palestine, May 15 (AP) -- King Abdullah's Arab Legion from Trans-Jordan took military control of a large area of Palestine's Judean Hills today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 15 -- For nearly four months, the United Nations has had before it an appeal for "immediate and urgent" consideration of the case of the Jewish populations in Arab and Moslem countries stretching from Morocco to India.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 (AP) -- Johnny Palmer of Badin, N. C., carved out a wind-blown three-below par 69 today to take the lead by a single stroke at the halfway point in the Philadelphia Inquirer's $15,000 invitation golf tourney.

On each of twelve stamps in an Italian series received by New York Stamp Company is inscribed "Primo Centenario Risorgimento" (First Centenary of the Risorgimento), the 1848-49 uprisings which led eventually to unification of the Italian states.

SALT LAKE CITY -- A series of six-day "stagecoach" tours will this summer open up to tourists Utah's national-monuments and river-gorge regions usually glimpsed only by geologists and explorers. These rambling trips traverse 600 miles of dirt roads and an equal distance of paved highways in new, deluxe eight - passenger, air - conditioned limousine coaches.
GARRET MOUNTAIN, N. J. -- Plans for handling 25,000 visitors daily during the summer at the Garret Mountain Reservation, just west of Paterson, have been completed by the Passaic County Park System.

SOUTH AMERICA is so big and exciting that the choice of where to go and what to see and do can overwhelm even a veteran tourist. Our six-month combination business and pleasure trip through most of the South American countries was too long and too busy to be recommended for other pleasure travelers.

The Liverpool soccer team of England will open its eleven-game tour of the United States this afternoon against a strong metropolitan all-star eleven at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island. The local players have been selected from the New York Americans, Brookhattan, Wanderers and Brooklyn Hispano, all members of the American Soccer League.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Officials of the Democratic National Committee said tonight that President Truman's speech to the Young Democrats last night was not broadcast on the West Coast. They would like to know why.

As a traveling salesman for many years I was very much interested in the article by Robert R. Young on "Railroads of the Not Very Distant Future." But it is going to take more than that to make travelers like myself, judging from talks with other salesmen, use the trains.

TEL AVIV, Palestine, May 15 -- Irgun Zvai Leumi and the Stern Group announced tonight that they would fight to bring all Palestine under the flag of Israel and that they would cease their underground activities within the new state.

HOLLYWOOD. TWO of Southern California's major industries, the psychic business and the motion picture business, joined hands recently to create a quaint Hollywood event. On May 6 thirty psychic mediums gathered at the Falcon's Lair, home of the late Rudolph Valentino, to see if the shade of the matinee idol had any communications for the living on his fifty-third birthday.

THERE are 32,000,000 housewives in this country; they form the nation's largest occupational group. Right now their worries are many. Their dollars -- and they are our biggest spenders -- no longer buy what they did even a relatively short time ago.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 15 (AP) -- Cord Meyer Jr., national president of the United World Federalists, Inc., predicted tonight that some kind of world government will be created within the next few years.
LONDON, May 15 (AP) -- A Russian radio commentator said tonight that "the Soviet peoples would also like other governments to demonstrate their readiness for genuine cooperation" for world peace.

W. Averell Harriman, European Ambassador-at-large for the Economic Cooperation Administration, returning yesterday from Paris and London after an absence of six days, reported that he was pleased with the progress made by the sixteen-nation council working to implement the recovery program.

HICKSVILLE, L. I., May 15 -- Between 1,500 and 2,000 persons lined the streets of this village this morning as a town crier in old colonial dress on a brown horse and ringing a bell called 'Hear ye, hear ye" to the throng to announce the opening program of the 300th birthday anniversary of Hicksville.

SIR BERNARD PARES is of that small tribe of men like Wm. H. Donald of China and T. E. Lawrence whose understanding, sympathy and affection for a country other than their own passes beyond the temporal changes in their Governments.

NANKING, May 15 -- Although the $45,000,000 United States interim relief program has failed to check war-induced inflation, it has helped the Government to conserve foreign exchange, eased its food problem and brought effective aid to millions of Chinese.

The problem of German reparations in capital goods as presented in letters to the editor by such authorities as Julius C. C. Edelstein, Special Adviser to Secretary Marshall, and Albert C. Carr, Consultant to the Inter-Allied Reparation Agency, Brussels, overlook basic economic and technological facts.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 15 -- Judge N. Louis Paladeau Jr. of Jersey City was chosen today as president of the New Jersey State Bar Association at its fiftieth annual meeting here. He succeeds Joseph J. Summerill Jr. of Camden.

PERCY W. HARRIS, new president of the Royal Photographic Society of Great Britain, will be guest of honor at a reception tea by Volunteer Service Photographers, Inc., May 24, in the Music Room of the Biltmore Hotel.

Tomorrow (May 17) the first flexible-throat wind tunnel of the supersonic Wind Tunnels Laboratory at the Ballistic Research Laboratories, Aberdeen Proving Ground, Md., is to be dedicated. It is the first large wind tunnel that can be continuously operated at a speed four times that of sound.

R. C. SHERRIFF, motion-picture writer and author of the memorable war play "Journey's End," evinces unhappy signs of Hollywooditis in this latest novel. The first two-thirds of his unpretentious story, built around the experiences of an elderly English country parson in the slums of London, are appealing in their quiet charm and chuckly humor.

THE successful home gardener divides his vegetable crops into two classes. Those that may be safely seeded and planted as soon as the ground can be worked in the spring; and those that may not be safely planted until mid-May because of their tropical background.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- A National Maritime Union (CIO) strike today threatened to tie up a large portion of Great Lakes oil shipments, with an estimated fifteen to eighteen tankers either stopped or ready to tie up as soon as docked.

In your "Letters" column of May 2, Mr. Blaise Pelletier contrasts chowder disparagingly with that hodge-podge of fish known as bouillabaisse, apparently on the supposition that chowder is of American origin, and therefore bad, and bouillabaisse is French, and therefore good.

THIS year's tourist seems to know where he wants to go and is well informed about his destination, according to the men and women who staffed the display booths at the International Travel and Vacation Show held in Grand Central Palace.

DAYTON, Ohio, May 15 (UP) -- Bennett E. Meyers, former major general now serving a prison sentence for subornation of perjury, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today for income tax evasion. The chief procurement officer for the Army Air Forces during the war "willfully and knowingly attempted to defeat and evade a large part of the taxes due and owing by the Aviation Electric Corporation," the charge said.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The opening of World Trade Week tomorrow elicited statements today from the Secretaries of State and Labor re-emphasizing the Administration's belief in the necessity of continuing the reciprocal trade agreements program in the interests of peace and prosperity.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 15 -- United States Ambassador Nathaniel P. Davis has set at rest today local doubts regarding possible technical difficulties on United States recognition of the new Costa Rican Government in a letter to Foreign Minister Benjamin Odio.

Like all members of the all-powerful Russian Politburo. Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov has offices within the Kremlin compound. His is a large room in a yellow stone building that also houses the offices of Premier Joseph Stalin. It is there -- rather than in the Foreign Office Building outside the Kremlin walls -- that Mr. Molotov receives the Ambassadors of other powers.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (UP) -- School safety patrolmen from thirteen states marched in Constitution Avenue today, but a New York City delegation, including four Negroes, did not join the parade.

THE flavor of the classic yellow-backed French novel pervades this story of a grande passion in Vienna at the beginning of World War I. Its theme is l'amour for l'amour's sake. The style inclines to the romantically florid, but it is surprisingly smooth and idiomatic when one considers that the author with this book assumes her third language.

TEL AVIV, May 15 (UP) -- Troops of Syria and Lebanon were attacking Jewish settlements in northern Palestine. Trans-Jordan and Iraqi forces moved in from the east and the Egyptian army invaded from the south.

After four months of investigating charges that Communists and their sympathizers dominated the Welfare Department, John M. Murtagh, Investigation Commissioner, said yesterday that his inquiry would be finished soon with a report to Mayor O'Dwyer.

Royalty no longer rules the lands in which it still flourishes. It has become the servant of the people. So the present visit of Princess Elizabeth to Paris represents an official effort to bring France and Britain into closer leadership of a new Europe.

The Commission on Narcotic Drugs of the United Nations is making "every effort" to expedite action on a draft protocol that would regulate international movement and control world production of new synthetic analgesic drugs to prevent the diversion of such drugs to non-medical purposes, Commissioner H. J. Anslinger of the United States Bureau of Narcotics, said yesterday.

BUSINESS interests and other citizens last week were attempting to appraise the Soviet peace offer. They came up with about the same conclusion that was voiced by Secretary of State Marshall. This was phrased as. "Let's see some action and less double-talk."

ANY given note of a melody is in itself perfectly meaningless. A melody is an organism in time, and the whole, or at least a considerable proportion of the whole, must be heard, through an appropriate duration, before the nature of the tune can be discovered.

ELIZABETH, N. J., May 15 -- Preservation of the First Presbyterian Church here, founded in 1664, as one of the state's historic shrines is asked in a bill introduced in the Legislature by Assemblyman G. Clifford Thomas of Elizabeth at the suggestion of leaders of the church.

OBERLIN, Ohio. "VAN THE MAN" -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan -- will be the Republican candidate for President. His running mate will be Senator Raymond E. Baldwin of Connecticut. That's the choice and prediction of the Oberlin Mock Convention, which last week held its quadrennial meeting here.

National Maritime Day May 22 will draw public attention to the present-day American Merchant Marine as differentiated from the pre-war fleet, it was announced yesterday by the Maritime Commission and the American Merchant Marine Institute.
Final plan were completed yesterday for today's celebration of "l Am an American Day" in Central Park. The observance w/ll begin at 2:30 P,' M., with Mayor 0'Dwyer as chief speaker.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Government negotiations bogged down today and a union leader said a strike was virtually certain after June 7 at Oak Ridge, Tenn., atomic laboratories.

"CAMERA ART" is a versatile book by a versatile author. Hungarian-born Dr. Max Thorek is a Professor of Surgery, a Doctor of Laws and Science and a prizewinner in international salon shows. As he himself says, "This is mainly a book of personal experiences, of theories and methods.

CHICAGO, May 15 (AP) -- The Soviet Union spent more than $1,225,000,000 on atom bomb development and other military research in 1947, according to Brig. Gen. Edwin L. Sibert, assistant director of the Central Intelligence Group in Washington.

John AIarshall of Jersey City The broke a scoreless deadlock in the top of inning eyes yesterday to gain a 1-0victory over Saint John's University. The John Krysika scored from third basedon a pass ball by Cather Jack Gimmler.
The picture layout entitled "High Cost of Traffic Jams" is the most constructive set of photographs which I have as yet seen on the subject.

Dr. Karl F. Meyer, director of the Hooper Foundation of the University of Califorina, and Miss Ethel Meyer, a bacteriologist on his staff, visited Cleveland recently to study the purified tetanus and diphtheria toxins of Dr. Louis Pillemer, associate professor of immuno-chemistry in Western Reserve University, and to determine whether or not Pillemer's methods would lend themselves to the production of toxins against plague.
ITHACA, N. Y., May 15 -- Bob Swanson, Columbia pitcher, went into the last half of the ninth with a two-run lead today, but Cornell scored three runs and defeated the Lions, 7 -- 6.

The Steering Committee of the House has just flagged the powerful Rules Committee to use its power in a cause which can affect all humanity. It has approved -- as have the full Senate and the House Foreign Relations Committee -- the bill which would put the United States into the World Health Organization.
ATHENS, May 15 (AP) -- The General Staff announced that Greek guerrillas had fired twenty-five artillery shells into Konitsa near the Albanian border today.

The Hotel Association of New York City, Inc., representing the management of sixty-eight local hotels. will provide virtually complete free medical care for more than 30,000 employes, it was learned last week. The new services, including a $200,000 medical center at 226 West Forty-second Street, represents an expansion of the association's three-year-old employe group life, accident and sickness insurance program worked out on a collective-bargaining basis with the New York Hotel Trades Council AFL.

STRANGE incidents hamper Jane Phillips as she journeys from Los Angeles to New York to visit her Great-Aunt Susan. First, she almost misses her train through no fault of her own. Then she narrowly escapes being left behind at a station where the train stops for only a few minutes.

RADIO'S determination to give things away reached a new high in absurdity last Sunday on the "Stop the Music" program. A grandmother in Providence, R. I., received $18,500 in prizes for repeating the title of a "mystery" song which previously had been identified in newspapers from coast to coast.

Breaking out of the narrow trading range which it had occupied since September, 1946, the stock market last week was catapulted to new heights. Relieved of the anxiety of a national railroad tie-up, yet faced with a major strike in the automotive industry, sentiment veered suddenly from a low ebb to high optimism.

ON the calendar this week is the first New York appearance of the Ballet Espanol Ana Maria in the Carnegie "Pops" series on Thursday. Beginning next Sunday, which brings it just into the scope of this listing of events, the New Dance Group presents its modern dance festival of six performances at the Mansfield Theatre.

PROF. CRANE BRINTON, the Harvard historian to whom we owe a number of important books on the French Revolution and on nineteenth-century political ideas, has written a thoughtful and urbane little dissertation on one of the most disputed political problems of today, the question of world government and the prevention of war.

THIS second in the projected four-volume set of Ozark folksongs makes a delightful companion to the British Ballads and Songs published last year by the State Historical Society of Missouri. Authoritatively annotated, it is a rich source book of Americana that brings together both the familiar and lesser-known songs and ballads of the South and West popularized in the Ozark region.

The "breakdown of the race barrier in private homes" was cited as the primary achievement during 1947 of the Hamilton Grange Interracial Discussion Group, which announced yesterday the "successful completion" of its second year of existence.
In THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 11, Arnaldo Cortesi, in a dispatch dealing with the Italian Presidential election, says:

The first major tightening of credit terms in the sale of industrial machine tools and equipment is about to be imposed here by distributors because of increased delays in payments by industrial buyers. Where formerly more than 90 per cent of industrial customers paid their bills in full within thirty days after date of invoice, now only 75 per cent are paying in thirty days, industry spokesmen revealed.

THE best indication of how big this summer will be in amateur photography can be found in the laboratories of the nation's photo-finishers. Here new equipment is being installed and preparations are being made to process perhaps the largest volume of amateur films in the 109 years of photography.

HERE, in a carefully planned and conscientiously assembled book, are all the important public utterances of General Eisenhower from his V-E order of the day and broadcast on May 8, 1945, to his final report as Chief of Staff to the Secretary of the Army only three months ago.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 15 (AP) -- Delegates from Young Republican Clubs in fourteen Midwestern states were told at their annual convention here today that they were members of the age group forming the biggest potential political group in the country.

Establishment of the new Jewish state of Israel and the United States' prompt recognition of it were hailed by rabbis in sermons here yesterday. A majority of the rabbis expressed the hope that the United States would give material aid to the infant nation.

The financial-industrial scene last year was a baffling one with conflicting signs of boom and impending recession. Demand for goods and continued high purchasing power, however, were the mainstay for factories which achieved capacity operations during 1947. Industrial production surpassed all peacetime records, with American incomes and wages, costs and corporate earnings all reaching new high levels.
BOSTON, May 15 -- In face of moves to change its charter to some form providing for a City Manager, Boston is being readied for a fifth term under Mayor James M. Curley.

MOLLY and Stephen Travis, left alone in the world, go to spend a year with cousins in France. They are entranced by the life in the little French village and especially by the mysterious House of the Swan which Cousin Bella rents.

Some of the recommendations made by the Joint Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation to the Ways and Means Committee of the House Of Representative were discussed in this column a week ago. Further consideration by the Ways and Means Committee of the one purporting to grant relief from the capital gains tax in respect of gains from the sale of personal residences has been "pass over" or deferred.

PARIS, May 15 -- A small group of de Gaullist and Right Center Deputies that has in recent weeks moved into a position of holding the whip hand in the National Assembly started its congress here today as the Cabinet was nursing the wounds received in last night's debate when the Government was defeated on lay schools.

An analysis of business and price trends by leading industrialists, purchasing agents and economists will feature the thirty-third annual international convention and "Inform-a-Show" of the National Association of Purchasing Agents at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel May 31 through June 2, it was announced yesterday by George A. Renard, secretary-treasurer of the association.

THE second complete opera recorded at the Metropolitan Opera House, Puccini's La Boheme, is now available in a package of two albums (Columbia, thirteen twelve-inch disks) which sell for $19.95. You also get a serviceable, if not inspired, English version of the libretto for your money.

COMPLETE working equipment for developing transparencies and color prints in normal room lighting is offered in an automatic agitating color processing unit made by Technical Industries, Inc., Detroit. Now being marketed as the Agi-Matic, the unit was designed for amateur processing with ordinary home facilities such as the kitchen and bathroom.

Electrolux Corporation, one of the largest vacuum cleaner producers merchandising exclusively on a house-to-house canvassing basis, will add a new branch office every two weeks for the rest of the year, Walter Dietz, president, revealed last week.
WEST POINT, N. Y., May 15 -- The Army nine bunched four hits for six runs in the sixth inning to pave the way to an 8-2 triumph over Brown on Doubleday Field today.

JERUSALEM, May 15 -- The embattled new independent Jewish state is a parliamentary democracy, with a thirteen-man Cabinet, a Provisional Council or Parliament of thirty-seven. Its center of government is Tel Aviv and its spiritual and cultural capital is Jerusalem.

SHEFFIELD, England, May 15 -- Early and drastic reorganization of Britain's National Coal Board was forecast here today by those familiar with the coal industry. Included in the reorganization, it was said, will be the Yorkshire regional office of the board.

ITHACA, N. Y., May 15 -- Cornell University began today a two-year campaign for $15,500,000, of which $3,000,000 will be for faculty salaries, $10,000,000 for the endowed divisions at Ithaca and $2,500,000 for the medical college in New York.

PARIS, May 15 -- French multitudes warmed to Princess Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh today and claimed them for their own. Respectful homage paid with fitful cheers and scattering applause on the first reception day turned into frantic admiration.

DETROIT, May 15 (AP) -- Art Behrns, 24-year-old war veteran from North Tonawanda, N. Y., threw some excitement into an otherwise dull day at the American Bowling Congress tournament today by rolling the second highest single game of the 1948 tournament, a brilliant 298.

To the learning which enables Professor Nichols to produce a fresh study of the eve of the Civil War must be added luck and temerity. He is lucky in his timing. The "American Democracy" in his title is the name of the party, more often called the Democratic party, which usually held power in the United States from 1829 to 1861.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 15 -- The Big Five powers will meet Monday at 3 P. M. to begin the search for a United Nations mediator for Palestine, it was announced today by Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations.

ORIGINALLY prepared as a textbook for the middle grades of the elementary school, this book covers the wide range of Western civilization from prehistoric times to the discovery of America. The story of man's peaceful adventure in trying to build a better world constitutes its core.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 15 (AP) -- Penn State won its first Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association championship today by routing Yale, 9 -- 0, in the final round at the Atlantic City Country Club. Unbeaten in eight starts this season, the victors justified their role as favorites by making a runaway of four of the six final matches.

DETROIT, May 15 (UP) -- A Federal suit by two stockholders today charged officers of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation and others with conspiracy and misconduct and the loss of $23,000,000 in Kaiser-Frazer funds.

In "Wanted: Experts to Run ERP," Donald H. McLean Jr. writes that "promising sources of material include college and university students who have lived overseas, competent men now with Military Government," etc.
Mayor William O'Dwyer was reported yesterday to be inclined toward the nomination of Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente for Surrogate of New York County.

Recent evidence that some advertisers are returning to a misuse of marketing research techniques to bolster "scientific" claims for their products was condemned here last week by reputable marketing men.

HERE is a novel of substance, dramatizing one of the most tragic figures of our time, the displaced person. Though Mr. Mangione does not carry the emotional impact of a Valtin or a Remarque (he lacks their penetrating sense of terror and torment), he writes with an ethical militancy equal to their own and with a high degree of artistic skill.

The "battle of the third round" increased in intensity last week. The chief issues at stake are labor's demand for a third post-war increase in wages to offset the higher cost of living, and management's demand that wages be held down to forestall higher prices.

During the recent war Dr. J. Brooks, H. P. Hale and Dr. J. R. Hawthorne served as food tasters for Great Britain, this for the reason that the Government wanted to make sure that it was getting its money's worth when it bought food valued at hundreds of millions of pounds.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Truman was said at the White House today to have under consideration the lifting of the arms embargo by the United States against the entire Middle East. It has been officially in force since last December.

ROME, May 15 -- Pope Pius XII is following the fighting in Palestine between Jews and Arabs with very deep concern because of the possibility that the war may spread to other areas of the world, Vatican circles said today.

THE American Broadcasting Company's plans for a series of documentary programs on communism, scheduled to be put on the air this summer, has run into a snag. Robert Saudek, the network's director of public affairs, despite a diligent search has been unable to find a writer who would imbue the scripts with the proper note of impartiality.
BOSTON, May 15 (AP) -- Boston's Red Sox took over the American League's fourth place today on a classy three - hit 5-0 victory pitched by Right Hander Joe Dobson against the Washington Senators.

LONDON, May 15 -- For those immediately involved in the Palestine conflict, it is naturally a Jewish-Arab issue. Zionists want their national home and they are going to do their utmost to make it safe and flourishing. The Arabs, for obvious reasons, believe that a Zionist state in Palestine is a menace and they are going to try to eliminate it.

Apparently on its way to its sixth straight Metropolitan Collegiate Conference crown. New York University's nine turned in an impressive display of batting power yesterday as it downed Manhattan College, 12 -- 4, at Ohio Field. The triumph was the ninth in ten loop starts for the pacesetting Violets, who have only four more circuit tests and now lead by two full games.

I have read "The Stalinist Myth." by James T. Farrell, in a recent Sunday edition. My first impression of this letter is that it is based on much emotion and little factual proof. Naturally, any decent person, regardless of race, color or creed, would condemn any government which would perpetrate the outrages alleged by Mr. Farrell.

NOBODY likes changing settled habits in middle age, and nations dislike it as much as people. By any reckoning, the nations of Western Europe, all of them with a history of hundreds of years of independent nationhood, are advancing to ripe years. Yet here they are attempting to abandon separate statehood and form a new super national community.

HOBOKEN, N. J., May 15 -- The dedication of the new Baylis Building for student activities and the presentation of a $15,000 check, gift of the alumni association, highlighted the Alumni Day ceremonies at Stevens Institute of Technology, here today.

MUSIC in Italy this winter has been somewhat disappointing. However, considering the fact that the war ended but a few years ago and that there is a severe economic crisis here, great strides have been made.

HOWARD HUGHES last week concluded the largest cash deal in motion-picture history when he acquired control of RKO for a reported $8,825,500 after five months of dickering with Floyd Odlum, head of the Atlas Corporation, which had held the controlling RKO stock.

LOS ANGELES, May 15 -- Henry Wallace today proposed that the United States cut off all economic aid to Great Britain if the "British-sponsored" Arab Legion made a move against the new State of Israel.
The Medical Society of the State New York will begin its 142d annual meeting tomorrow at the Pennsylvania Hotel, it was announced here yesterday.

Adult education contributes to American citizenship, educators and civic leaders declared yesterday at an annual luncheon sponsored by the adult education section of the Board of Education in the Commodore Hotel.

OMAHA, May 15 -- Middle West business men and farm groups are showing a lively interest in the business available to them through the Marshall Plan and its offspring, the Economic Cooperative Administration. This has been particularly true since the most recent crop report of the Agriculture Department indicated that the nation might have another wheat crop in excess of one billion bushels.

WHEN the engineers first gave us the modern bathroom all we asked for were sanitary fixtures and plumbing that worked. After those things came to be taken for granted the decorators arrived and added washable wallpapers, gay shower curtains, matched towel sets and flower-painted accessories, all by way of making the room pleasant to look at.

WHEREVER Americans went or whatever they did, they made up songs. They made them up out of the real-life situations of the farms, mines, ranches, canals, plantations, sailing ships, factories and lumber camps. People who shared the same experiences also shared the musical expressions, modifying or expanding their heritage into a common store of musical tradition.

CHUNGKING, May 13 (Delayed) -- One of the most popular facilities in the offices of the United States Information Service here are the six old and battered war-surplus typewriters. Saved from post-war disposal as wartime Office of War Information machines of no further use, they have been put back into operation now to serve as equipment in the unique typewriter-practice room of the local Information Service establishment.

Suggestions from the Soviet government for workable international controls of atomic energy are inadequate, John M. Hancock, former American delegate to the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, warned last night in an address in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, at the forty-ninth anniversary dinner of the National Jewish Hospital at Denver.

Rear Admiral Richard F. Whitehead, USN, commanding naval air reserve training, told the Aviation Writers Association at Floyd Bennett Field yesterday that the comprehensive display of naval aircraft assembled at the field represented the weapons with which the Navy would fight any immediate war.

SIMULTANEOUS shows of paintings by Ben-Zion are being held at the Jewish Museum and Bertha Schaefer's gallery this week. This artist is one of a few moderns who seems able to venture onto the quicksands of religious emotion without going under in a bath of bromides and spurious extravaganzas of feeling.

NOT so many years ago there was one question no one connected with the destinies of a major symphony orchestra wanted to think about. What would we do if, because of war conditions, there were no more maestro-conductors from Europe?

TWO weeks before the opening of "Mister Roberts," one of the town's newest hits, a lady went to the box office of the Alvin Theatre. As he took her money for tickets to a performance several weeks ahead, the box-office treasurer smiled and said, "Thank you for your patronage."
CHICAGO, May 15 -- United States recognition of the new Jewish State of Israel was acclaimed here tonight by speakers at the biennial convention of the United Synagogue of America.

In the rambling red brick buildings overlooking the East River at the foot of Fifteenth Street is an unusual organization that is playing an increasing role in the health of this city. Few of the thousands who daily speed down the East Side Highway even notice Willard Parker Hospital; even fewer know of the Public Health Research Institute of the City of New York tucked away in the Department of Health Laboratories there.

Color comes in a rush, on the wing as well as on stem and bough. You look at an apple tree, all full of pink and white, and you see the sunny flash of a busy goldfinch. You turn to the lilacs, their big heads of sweet bloom just opening, and you catch the matchless orange of an oriole's breast.
BREMEN, Germany, May 15 (AP) -- The port of Bremen, knocked completely out by Allied war action, is again in business -- in fact, more business than ever.

Mount St. Michael retained the team title in the senior division of the thirty-second annual Athletic Association of Private Schools track meet at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium yesterday. The Mounties won three firsts and scored heavily in twelve of the sixteen events totally 59 1/6 points.

OXFORD, Ohio, May 15 -- Harrison Dillard, great Negro sprinter and hurdler for Baldwin-Wallace, ran his victory chain to 67 in a row today to set a world record for consecutive triumphs in collegiate competition.

THE Postoffice Department's announcement that five stamps have been added to the 1948 philatelic program brings to fifteen the number of "special" postal items to which the department is committed for this year.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 15 (UP) -- The Colt Manufacturing Company announced today that it was ending its contract with the union of its employes because Communist influences hampered production during World War II and it sought to prevent a recurrence during the new defense program.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- The sixty-one-day meat-packers' strike in Chicago appeared headed for a showdown. Ralph Helstein, international president of the United Packinghouse Workers of America, CIO, met today with the union's executive board and has a meeting scheduled tomorrow with the strike strategy board.

NO other artist has during his lifetime been so consistently subjected to the glare of publicity as Picasso (his newest show is on at Durand-Ruel Galleries here through May 29) and one instinctively feels uneasy at the thought of yet another memoir.
OTTAWA, May 15 -- On Tuesday Finance Minister Douglas C. Abbott will introduce the budget in Parliament and make his report on the financial position of the country.

Speedboat racing is growing into bigger sizes of folding money. This may be the millenuium in the sport of outboard competition. At any rate, the sixteenth running of the 130-mile Hudson River marathon from Albany to West 72d Street on Sunday morning, June 13, establishes a significant new record.
Written examinations for 18,000 men seeking positions as city firemen were held yesterday in nine schools in the five boroughs. Half of those taking the tests were veterans.

The future of the nations of Europe is closely related to that of the United States, both from the standpoint of their economy and on the basis of freedom, according to views expressed yesterday at the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.

THE annual meeting of the Aviation Writers Association, held last week, had an opportunity to look both backward and forward into aviation. For the nearly two hundred aviation specialists in newspaper, magazine and radio fields, the armed services and the industry showed about everything that the new rules for security permitted them to show.

ABOUT 300,000 people live in the ten counties that comprise the Delta of Mississippi -which is roughly the region between the Mississippi and the Yozoo River. Of these, fully two-thirds are Negroes. From Memphis, which stands on the northern border of this region, to Greenville in the center, and to Vicksburg on the south, the Negro is ubiquitous.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Congressional tempers have cooled off since the Government averted a country-wide railroad strike this week by obtaining a court order restraining the walkout.

Hundreds of persons along the East River shore watched anxiously yesterday as the crew of the fireboat Thomas Willett rescued three Brooklyn men trying to stay afloat in the choppy waters after their small sloop had capsized.

MAY a Southerner give utterance to his sentiments after attending "The Respectful Prostitute"? To my perhaps jaundiced eye, M. Sartre's play is compounded more of cheap sensationalism than of brilliant melodrama; but considering the question of its being true to life aside from that of its literary worth, it is a caricature as extravagant as it is savage.

THE increasing number of tulips year after year gives cause for appreciation and not a little wonder at Dutch horticultural craftsmanship. Literally dozens of new, improved varieties become available from Holland annually. Seen at the peak of their bloom now, this year's newcomers rate enthusiasm indeed.
DETROIT, May 15 (AP) -- Behind the strong right arm of Dizzy Trout, the Detroit Tigers beat the St. Louis Browns, 4 to 1, today for their first victory in seven games on their home lot this season.
CHICAGO, May 15 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

The comments on re-reading books in today's Topics was enjoyable, but as any habitual re-reader knows, it did not go far enough. To be thoroughly satisfactory, one must have a time and place for this delightful relaxation.

Activity in wholesale markets here last week centered on manufacturers' openings of fall apparel lines, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 15 -- The accusation that the United States Assistant Military Attache in Belgrade, Lieut. Col. Chester M. Stratton, had concealed a former Chetnik from Yugoslav authorities, although aware of his war record, was renewed yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 15 -- A ten-day Parade of Progress, with "White Plains has the best of everything" as its theme, was started here today by local merchants and industrial organizations under the joint sponsorship of the Civic and Business Federation, White Plains Chamber of Commerce and the Brand Names Foundation.
TOKYO, May 15 -- A tax law draft now under discussion would make changes designed to attract foreign capital into investment in Japan.

Walter C. Bryan, lawyer, of 45 East Fifty-fifth Street, will receive an LL. B. degree from Columbia's Law School this June which he earned, but could not receive, twenty-two years ago. The degree had been waiting for Mr. Bryan, a veteran of both World Wars, to complete his undergraduate work which he did last year at Columbia.

AN English actress whose stage name is Millicent French comes to New York to star in a revival of Dion Boucicault's play "The Octoroon." During the second night's performance an unidentified woman is murdered in the star's dressing room, but the play goes on.

A critical need exists for special programs to help and guide physically handicapped college students, according to Dr. Charles Roth, executive officer of the Health Guidance Board of the City College of New York.

"FUN WITH YOUR CAMI-- ERA" is a book slanted for the amateur, and describes the less complicated photographic techniques in a simple manner. The athor is a photography editor of THE NEW YOEK TIMES and has set about making the "shutterbug" and his camera better acquainted with' each other.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 15 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor of Germany, said today in an interview that he foresaw an "organized movement" of Jewish displaced persons from Germany. He promised that the Army would, as much as it could, help legal emigration and, as in the past, provide transportation to the German border.

WHATEVER else it may or may not have accomplished (and there is something to be said on both sides), the Ballet Society has more than justified its existence by commissioning and producing the Balanchine-Stravinsky-Noguchi "Orpheus."

Out of the welter of words about the acceptance by the Russians of an invitation to a conference with the United States which Washington says was not an invitation to a conference, there looms up one question of importance: Why did Foreign Minister Molotov show such alacrity in the matter? It is not that one expects to get an accurate answer by posing the question. Yet the question is interesting.

THIS is an indoor novel. In fact one of the people in it doesn't get out of the house for four years. It's an indoor novel because it's a housewifey novel: the look at life is from the kitchen and the parlor.
I find Raymond Daniell's statements in "Pattern for a Totalitarian State" in direct contrast with what Robert St. John writes in his book, "The Silent People Speak."

SAO PAULO -- The writing profession in Brazil is finally beginning to meet the much maligned though universal criterion of our times. It's paying off. Critics for the literary supplements of big Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo newspapers get twenty dollars or more for their articles.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 15 -After taking jeers and verbal abuse from a crowd of CIO packing-house strikers and sympathizers for three hours early today, Minnesota National Guardsmen swept the main streets of South St. Paul clear for a mile and a half where they parallel the town's big packing plants.

ELIZABETH, N. J. May 15 -- With a catalogue value of three to five cents as a collector's item, one-cent stamps of 1916 issue, in coils of 1,000, are being sold at the Elizabeth Postoffice. A nickel inserted in a recently installed stamp - vending machine will purchase five of the stamps.
NOTES on the Literary Life, as practiced in various places:

CORNWALL ON HUDSON, N. Y., May 15 -- Nat Krupnick's chestnut mare, Liberty Belle, from Preakness, N. J., ridden by Jimmy Darling, won the open jumping, class on the first day of the third annual New York Military Academy Horse Show today. The show will end tomorrow.

For the first time since the end of World War II, American teachers and students in substantial numbers are planning to spend part of their summer vacations in Europe. Although various reasons are offered, the tours in many instances will combine business and pleasure.

HANOVER, N. H., May 15 -- Frank Quinn was too much for the Dartmouth baseball team today as he pitched Yale to a 6-2 victory over the league-leading Indians. It was the Green's first loss in seven Eastern League games this season.

Byron Price, assistant secretary general of the United Nations and United States Director of Censorship during the war, paid tribute last night to the high ideals and sense of responsibility of America's free press. He spoke at the semi-annual dinner of the Society of the Silurians at the New York Athletic Club, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

OF the hundreds of amateur color transparencies sent to us daily for processing only about one-half are satisfactory. Some of these are just acceptable, while the number of better-than-average and really outstanding shots is small.

ST. LOUIS, May 15 (AP) -- Johnny Hopp broke up Harry (The Cat) Brecheen's scoreless inning string at 32 2-3 innings tonight but the Cardinals already had an eight run lead for an 8-3 victory over the Pirates. The Red Birds hold undisputed possession of the National League lead for the second time this week.

IN the tradition of a man biting a dog, a theatre operator paying his customers not to see his films makes news. Things such as that don't happen every day, of course, and the wonder is that such a development could come to pass even in a spot as urban as Cambridge, Mass., without attracting wide attention.

FOURTEEN-YEAR-OLD Cathy, serious and shy, faces the summer with problems. How can she change her noisy, carefree family into a more conventional group? How can she help her artist father sell his paintings? How can she earn money for riding lessons?

The Octogenerian Cornelius McGillicuddy's amazing Athletics yesterday threw an over-sized monkey wrench into Yankee plans into the West as for marching American league flag leaders, and under circumstances that were distressing, to say the least.

BUENOS AIRES, May 15 -- A group of businessmen from the United States, Canada and Cuba arrived today in a special plane to be guests of the Argentine Government. They will call on President Juan D. Peron Monday.

BOSTON, May 15 -- The convention of the United Steelworkers, CIO, ratified a dues increase today after Philip Murray, president, warned that labor, including the steel workers, was facing rigorous tests of strength and must be financially prepared to meet them.

Cotton futures opened 12 to 19 points higher yesterday and final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 29 to 37 points net higher, with the closing at or near the best levels of the day. The strength in stocks was a factor.

Although plainly disappointed by the Treasury's refusal last week to advance the basic interest-rate pattern, bankers here continued to hope that some adjustment would be provided at the next opportunity. Treasury Secretary John W. Snyder, in making the announcement, it was pointed out, explained that "at an appropriate time" the Treasury might make a change, and, according to the bankers, this seems to indicate that "the door is still open."

SALEM, Ore., May 15 -- Harold E. Stassen offered the voters of Oregon a single campaign package of three items today as he tore over the state on one of the longest and most exhausting one-day schedules ever undertaken by a Presidential candidate in American history.

THOSE aware of the history and achievements of the League of Composers through the first twenty-five years of its existence may logically feel concerned at the news of the resignation of Claire Reis from the chairmanship of its board of directors.

"ATLANTIC BETWEEN" is the highly personalized, diary-like account of the doings of Rhoda van Bibber Tanner Doubleday and all the van Bibber Tanner relatives, associates and acquaintances, beginning in Kentucky and Tennessee and extending to the casinos, clubs, and hotels of Europe, not forgetting shikari expeditions in India.

LONDON, May 15 -- The British Government has given no consideration to following the lead of the United States in granting de facto recognition to the Palestinian state of Israel, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.

Notice of the existence of a dispute between three CIO maritime unions and some forty Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators has been given to the United States Mediation and Conciliation Service, Frank J. Taylor, chairman of the shipowners' negotiating committee, announced yesterday.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 15 -- Princeton's varsity 150-pound crew, leading all the way, swept to an impressive victory over Pennsylvania. Harvard and Yale in the final of the 150-pound championship regatta of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges on Lake Carnegie today.

Faultless came back into his own at Jamaica yesterday, while Stymie was an also ran. Running as an entry with Fervent in the colors of the Calumet Farm, Faultless slipped past the finish line a nose in front of his stable-mate in the $75,000 added Gallant Fox Handicap and regained in some part the eminence he had enjoyed a year ago when he won the Preakness.

PARIS, May 15 -- The possible reaction of France's large North African Arab population must be studied carefully in connection with the possible French recognition of the new Palestinian state of Israel, it was indicated here today.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 15 -- In response to protests of the Frankfort Correspondents Association, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, ordered today a revision of circular No. 33, which gave members of his command to decide what were "matters of public interest."
LONDON, May 15 (Reuters) -- The Australian cricket tourists hit the phenomenal total of 721 all out in six hours by the close of play at Southend today on the first day of their match against Essex.

Ferdinand Jieinsky, manager of the Prague Credit Bank agency here since its establishment in 1939, has given up his position in the bank and is in exile again from Czechoslovakia -- his third enforced separation from home in thirty years.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 15 -- By a fraction over a second Harvard's varsity eight got home ahead of Yale to prevent an Eli sweep in the championship regatta of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges on the Charles River Basin today.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 15 -- A group of Southern Democrats openly hostile to President Truman and his civil-rights program took formal steps this week to threaten the national Administration with political reprisal.

ST. LOUIS, May 15 (AP) -- Australian-born Jim Ferrier, who will try to become the sixth title repeater in the thirty-year history of the National P.G.A. championship, is hoping such an accomplishment may be one of the surprises likely to strike next week's event at Norwood Hills Country Club.

BROADWAY is passing through the dreariest fiscal May since its pre-war years. This may seem incongruous when you consider that the thirty shows on display last week represented unusual activity for the end of a season that boasted only twenty-eight productions during a busy December week.
CHICAGO, May 15 (AP) -- The Reds walloped Dutch McCall and three successors for fourteen hits to defeat the Cubs by 5 to 2 today and snap their losing streak at eight straight.

HONOLULU, May 15 -- A model city, which designers and backers believe will set the highest living levels ever achieved in any large agricultural or plantation community, will be built on the Hawaiian Island of Maui during the next twenty-five years, is was announced today by Harland Bartholomew and his associates of the City Planning Organization.

The slaughter of spawning striped bass on the Virginia coast a few weeks ago may result in legislation which will increase the conservation not only of stripers, but of other coastal species threatened by wasteful commercial fishing practices.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 15 (AP) -- Rex Mays, who has entertained a lot of racing fans and burned up a lot of automobiles, today won the number one starting position for the thirty-second annual 500-mile race on Memorial Day.

JUST fifteen years ago this week in this Review: "The Industrial Discipline and the Governmental Arts," by Rexford O. Tugwell, took over Page 1, as reflecting "a new spirit in government." . . .Dorothy Brett's "Lawrence and Brett: A Friendship" caused the critic to tick off some of the books on Lawrence since his death, the authors of which were J. Middleton Murry, Catherine Carswell, Mabel Dodge Luhan.

DETROIT, May 15 -- The Ford Motor Company upset the third-round wage increase struggle of the automobile industry today by asking the CIO United Auto Workers Union to accept wage cuts to accomplish an objective of "public security."

New aircraft for airborne and air transportable operations, as shown or described last week at the Army-Air Force Camp Campbell (Ky.) maneuvers, indicate considerable but still limited, advances in the development of troop and cargo-carrying planes.

BALTIMORE, May 15 -- Citation did it again today. In command from the instant the doors of the starting gate popped open, the Calumet Farm's great 3-year-old colt won as he pleased -- or as Jockey Eddie Arcaro pleased -- in the seventy-second edition of the $134,870 Preakness Stakes at old Pimlico.

A new system of student counseling, which would promote a closer and more personal relationship as well as a better understanding of individual problems, will be inaugurated next September at Barnard College. Four counselors, each of whom will be assigned to a class for the four-year period, will replace the present freshman and sophomore advisers.

Korea is split in two. The northern and industrial half is occupied by Russia, the southern and agricultural half by the United States. The occupying powers were unable to reach agreement on a united administration for Korea. As a result there has been almost no traffic or commerce between the two zones.

BUFFALO, N. Y., May 15 (AP) -- Jersey City snapped a five-game losing streak today, defeating Buffalo, 4 -- 3. The game was marked by a bat-throwing incident which resulted in the banishment of the Jersey catcher. Sal Yvars, in the fourth inning.

A CONSIDERABLE portion of the passenger space available to sea travelers under the American flag represents tonnage normally considered by naval architects and marine engineers to be obsolescent. But the post-war reconversion orders, under which war-weary ships have been brought back to pleasure-travel standards, have been so thorough, and incidentally so costly, that in the majority of cases the customer would have a hard time telling the vessels from new ships.

THIS time Johnny Fletcher visits a poultry show and becomes interested in gamecocks and a couple of murders. Sam Cragg trails along, which is just as well, for Johnny frequently has need of a strong right arm to get him out of jams.
TEL AVIV, Palestine, May 15 --The army of Israel said that its new-born state was invaded today from the north and south, shelled from the east and bombed and machine-gunned from the air.

Lee E. Cooper's speculations on "The '$5,000 House' -- A Challenge" are absurd. In my area you can't even build a $15,000 house unless you want your "castle" to be one of a row of twenty, all alike. Mass production may be, as Mr. Cooper says, an economic answer to the housing problem, but the way it's carried on today it's a poor one esthetically.

THE Horticultural Society of New York will hold a tulip show in its club rooms, 598 Madison Avenue, on Wednesday. Displays varying from twelve to fifty square feet are scheduled, and also several classes for vases of cut blooms. A flower-arrangement section is included.

THE lobbyists in Washington are out in full force. The reason is self-evident. The Congressional calendar is jam-packed with controversial legislation which affects the pocketbooks and general welfare of millions of businesses, trade organizations, labor unions, professional societies and individual citizens.

LACK of uniform traffic regulations throughout the country and the wretched condition of rural roads have been classified as two major highway problems confronting the nation today. The first is held responsible for innumerable motor accidents while the second is found to be adding needlessly to the cost of foodstuffs.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- Eighty-seven thousand members of the International Typographical Union, AFL, will decide, next Wednesday, whether they will re-elect incumbent officials of the ITU, who will continue present strike policies for obtaining union demands on employers, or whether they will replace their chiefs with new officers who have promised to restore "peace, harmony and order" to the organization.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 15 -- The stake that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York and Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota have in the Oregon Republican primary next Friday is far greater than the twelve delegates to be chosen.

VIENNA, May 15 -- A great majority of the Austrians want the Western Allied occupation troops to remain because they fear a Communist seizure of power if forces are withdrawn. The Austrians overwhelmingly support the Marshall Plan and are convinced that its purpose is primarily to keep Europe from going communist.

Competitive selling has spurred adoption in the textile industry of technological improvements largely held in abeyance during the prolonged sellers' market. Spokesmen for all segments of the industry attending the third National Textile Seminar at Shawnee-on-Delaware. Pa., agreed that emphasis now is on lower mechanical operating costs.

THE $100 limit on goods American travelers may bring back home with them free of duty may be lifted to $400 in time to benefit summer tourists, as the result of unexpected and unusually swift action by the House and Senate last week.

Two hundred residents of the Bedford, Stuyvesant and Williamsburg areas of Brooklyn voted yesterday to ask Mayor O'Dwyer to appoint a Negro to the Board of Education to fill the vacancy caused by the retirement of Joseph D. Fackenthal. They met at the First African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, Tompkins Avenue and McDonough Street, Brooklyn, under the auspices of the Schools Council of the three districts.

MEDIA, Pa., May 15 -- Mechanize, owned by Jack Grabowsky of Ambler and ridden by P. Smithwick, won the Rose Tree Plate Steeplechase today at the eighty-ninth annual spring meeting of the Rose Tree Hunting Club.
CHUNGKING, China, May 15 -- Chungking's general citizenry and also local medical men are baffled by the case of a girl who seems to live without food.

MAN has a brief memory for the gadgets he contrives to give him comfort and convenience in the world. He easily forgets, too, the means by which he labors to loose his spirit from flesh, the techniques of meditation and self-examination which the mystics, inventors in the field of prayer, technicians in the search for God, devise, test, and offer to others.

THE reissue of Freda Utley's "Lost Illusion'' (Introduction by John P. Marquand. 288 pp. Philadelphia, Pa.: Fireside Press. $3.) calls attention to the existence of a distinct genre of writing in contemporary letters -- the literature of political disenchantment. Bertrand Russell in England, Andre Gide in France, Silone in Italy, Koestler in central Europe and Ciliga in the Balkans are some of the noteworthy figures who have contributed to it.

BALTIMORE, May 15 -- Citation did it again today. In command from the instant the doors of the starting gate popped open, the Calumet Farm's great 3-year-old colt won as he pleased -- or as Jockey Eddie Arcaro pleased -- in the seventy-second edition of the $134,870 Preakness Stakes at old Pimlico.

A new system of student counseling, which would promote a closer and more personal relationship as well as a better understanding of individual problems, will be inaugurated next September at Barnard College. Four counselors, each of whom will be assigned to a class for the four-year period, will replace the present freshman and sophomore advisers.

FINALLY the much-discussed paintings from the Kaiser Friedrich Museum in Berlin have arrived in New York (via the salt-mine in Merkers and the National Gallery in Washington). Beginning to morrow they will be exhibited at the Metropolitan Museum.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 15 -- This city of blast furnaces was the scene yesterday and today of the forty-first annual Bach Festival. Packer Memorial Chapel on the Lehigh University campus was filled to overflowing as Dr. Ifor Jones directed a choir of 246 voices and an orchestra of fifty pieces.

ENGLEWOOD, May 15 -- The sensational Boys High School track team came through with another impressive victory at Winton J. White Stadium today by capturing the second annual Englewood Memorial invitation meet crown in competition with forty-one New York and New Jersey high schools.

Henry G. Alexander, vice president of J. P. Morgan Co. and campaign chairman of the Greater New York Fund campaign, said yesterday that support of the fund was "the best way for a person to be a good citizen and a part of his community."

THE mistakes that many home movie makers made in the first days of 16mm movies, barely a quarter of a century ago, are still being made by movie-camera owners today. I know, because for the past few months it has been part of my job to review hundreds of amateur movies.

FEW periods in the history of the English-speaking world have been so thoroughly investigated and so voluminously reported on as that of the American Revolution. The magnificent literary outpouring of the generation that fought the war has been used by successive generations of historians.
SIAN, China, May 11 (Delayed) -- In Shensi Province death is the penalty for trafficking in opium and other narcotics.

The stock market was swamped again yesterday by an avalanche of buying orders reminiscent of public participation in the boiling sessions of 1929. The fresh increase in prices, which came on top of the rapid climb of Friday, proved more tempered, however, with gains limited to 1 to 2 points.

A BIG blond kid with a guitar under one arm and an enormous cast, slit to allow draining, supporting the other, asked me one day on the grounds of Halloran General Hospital, Staten Island, to take a picture of him and his pal.

IN February, 1942, the French underground secretly printed 350 copies of a novelette, "Le Silence de la Mer" (The Silence of the Sea), by an unknown who called himself Vercors. Passing from hand to hand, copies reached England and America as the symbol of intellectual resistance to Nazi occupation.

IT was perhaps T. S. Eliot more than any other man in our time -- though there were others who labored -- who directed our attention to Dryden and, through Dryden, to Pope. Now The Modern Library offers a substantial coda to these earlier labors by publishing "Alexander Pope, Selected Works" ($1.25), a compact volume, and complete as you could want it short of the collected works.

A record post-war toll of 17,000 deaths and 2,000,000 injuries as the result of industrial accidents in 1947 has proved so alarming that the United States Department of Labor, at the request of President Truman, is starting a nationwide "Operations Safety" program.

SHANGHAI, May 15 (UP) -- The Soviet Union relaxed the ban on transporting Americans behind the Far Eastern iron curtain today after the United States planned to send a merchant ship to Dairen, Manchuria, with replacements for stranded consular officials.

In 1944 New York University conducted tests with air-supported roofs for the United States War Production Board. As Herbert H. Stevens, a New York engineer, tells the story in Nature, flat circular membranes, fixed around the periphery, were stretched above the elastic limit by air pressure to form a shallow dome, then tested for load-bearing properties.

ON April 28th, the night of the second opening of "The Play's the Thing," twenty-two years after the original Broadway premiere -- like every author at every one of his revivals, I imagine -- I stood in the wings, my nerves on edge, filled with misgivings, pessimistic, completely at a loss, in fact, from 8:40 to 10:50.

BRIDGE hands published in books and newspapers seem, strangely enough, to appeal to many people who do not now play bridge, including quite a few who have never played the game. A famous songwriter, asked some years ago to make a fourth at bridge, sat down at the table very reluctantly and with the statement that he had never played.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 15 -- The following are the texts of a cablegram from Abmad Mohamed Khachaba, Egyptian Minister of Foreign Affairs, to Alexandre Parodi of France, this month's President of the Security Council, and of a statement before the Security Council by Dr. Mordecai Eliash of the Jewish Agency for Palestine:

FRESNO, Calif., May 15 -- Long-legged Mel Patton of the University of Southern California wrote a new page for foot-racing history today with a world record bettering time of 9.3 seconds in the 100-yard dash.

AS the theatrical sun sets over Broadway it rises over the Ginza -- the street of silver -where a new theatrical season is just getting under way. This year will see the first mass return of American works in almost a decade.

WHEN I go on another photography trip this summer, I shall carry over my shoulder a light leather case containing two twin-lens reflex cameras -- one for color, the other for black-and-white -an exposure meter, a light yellow filter with sunshade, and a dozen rolls of film.

SPORTS fans will storm the turnstiles today, eagerly fighting to get inside to see the big show. The famed Liverpool Football Club of England will play a soccer game against a picked American team at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island this afternoon, but that won't be where the storming will be done. The jamming will take place outside the Yankee Stadium, where the Bronx Bombers take a last shot at the Philadelphia Athletics.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 15 -- Mrs. Edward P. Alker's Champion Twin Ponds Belle, the Welsh terrier that set the rings afire at the beginning of the outdoor dog show season a year ago, got off on the right foot again today as the new metropolitan outdoor campaign began with the forty-second all-breed event of the Ladies Kennels Association.

THE native American historical novel, as Robert Wilder ably demonstrates in "Bright Feather," is now as indigenous and predictable as corn fritters. It has something for everyone -- provided in this case, of course, that everyone is casually athirst for a story of Florida in the Eighteen Thirties, when the betrayal-stained Seminole Wars took their turn at tormenting that hot and restless land.

At the request of prominent Long Island residents and club members, a fleet of nine buses will start operating as "week-end specials" to Montauk and the Hamptons on June 11, it was announced yesterday. Charles Tyte, president of Eastern Tours, announced at its headquarters, 165 West Forty-sixth Street, that air-conditioned buses would supply transportation for fourteen consecutive week-ends.

MANY a new home site holds the possibility of a charming woodland garden. Sometimes potential locations, however, are reduced to flat areas far beyond practical needs, and a clean sweep is made by the bulldozer of all but a tree or two.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 15 -- Mental hygiene for the vast numbers of persons who live on the "borderline of happiness" was urged today by Dr. Nicholas Hobbs, Assistant Professor of Psychology, Teachers College, Columbia University.

Paul Robeson, baritone; Dean Dixon leading the American Youth Orchestra, and Peter Seeger, folk singer, headed a concert at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, to which no adults were admitted "unless accompanied by children." The program was sponsored by the Jefferson School of Social Science, and the only empty seats were those temporarily vacated by those young listeners.

WITH that cogent novel, "If I Have Four Apples," Josephine Lawrence demonstrated that she understood the fallacies of white-collar arithmetic, and the emptiness of white-collar dreams, as well as most observers.
MONTPELIER, Vt., May 15 -- Vermont Republicans maintained tradition today at their quadrennial state convention by electing nine unpledged, uninstructed delegates to the party's national convention.

ASTORIA, Ore., May 15 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York swung through northwest Oregon today, lashing out harder than ever at Harold E. Stassen, his opponent in next Friday's Republican Presidential primary, for his proposal to outlaw the Communist party.

ONE of the attributes that make a plant valuable for landscape use is a so-called "four-season effect." While the April show of forsythia, for example, is charming, it is, in fact, a one-season plant. Royal azalea, however, qualifies as a four-season plant, and for this reason alone merits wider use.

When Aristide Briand returned from the Locarno Conference in the autumn of 1925 he told the people of France: "A Locarno nous averts parle europeen. C'est une league nouvelle qu'il faudra bien que l'on apprenne." At Locarno he had talked European with Stresemann, the German, and Austen Chamberlain, the Britisher.
In Tel Aviv, at 4:06 last Friday afternoon (Palestine time), in the Museum of Art on Rothschild Boulevard, the Jewish Provisional Government proclaimed the sovereign State of Israel.
TEL AVIV, Palestine, May 15 -Nearly 1,000 immigrants, carrying tFShe make-shift visa of the one-day-old State of Israel, arrived here today, and 700 landed in Haifa, Jewish-held northern port.

The Christian world has been pleased to learn that in 1947 the American Bible Society distributed 829,737 complete Bibles, more than in any previous year. It is gratifying to learn further that a heavy demand for the books has come from Germany, Japan and Russia.

SOME people believe that cartoonists are people who couldn't draw well enough to become artists. Others have the notion that cartoonists lie in bed every day until noon while the mailman shoves fat checks under their doors for drawings that any child could make in fifteen minutes.
SALT LAKE CITY, May 15 -- Residents of Salt Lake have received a pointed reminder that opportunities for rural youngsters in this land of equality may be more limited than city-folk suspect.

ATHENS, May 15 -- A Moscow radio broadcast yesterday, as heard here, asked that Greece be arraigned before the International Court of Justice at The Hague "to answer for the recent executions of Greek patriots." [The executions ten days ago were of Greek Leftists convicted of murder after the December, 1944, uprising.]

"INTEREST in radio producer John Guedel depends entirely on the individual point of view. If you, like many listeners, label audience participation shows which feature parlor games, stunts and extravagant prizes as horrendous entertainment, your desire will be to stick pins in a Guedel effigy, for back in 1938 he introduced such games on his first radio series, then on a Pacific Coast network.

Books, paintings and bronzes from the collections of the late Frank W. Crowninshield, works of art from the estate of the late Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt and five English paneled rooms to be offered in final liquidation of the stock of Edward I. Farmer, Inc., are among the notable items to be auctioned this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

A group of Argentine Army officers, headed by Maj. Gen. Jose Humberto Sosa Molina, Minister of War, arrived here yesterday for an official visit to the United States as the guests of Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall.

HAVING written two intervening chamber operas since "Peter Grimes," Benjamin Britten is at work on a second large-scale opera. He expects to have it ready by the beginning of 1950. The libretto is said to be based on an original story of seventeenth century England.

Not a Dodger reached third base yesterday at Ebbets Field as Warren Spahn pitched the Braves to a 1-0, 4-hit victory over the home club. So superb was the southpaw's mound work that none in the gathering of 14,569 could dispute his right to his second triumph of the campaign.
Although handicapped by highly variable weather conditions, retail trade here last week continued to show a gain over last year. Estimates put department store volume at about 5 per cent higher.

Paul Robeson, baritone; Dean Dixon leading the American Youth Orchestra, and Peter Seeger, folk singer, headed a concert at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, to which no adults were admitted "unless accompanied by children." The program was sponsored by the Jefferson School of Social Science, and the only empty seats were those temporarily vacated by those young listeners.

WITH that cogent novel, "If I Have Four Apples," Josephine Lawrence demonstrated that she understood the fallacies of white-collar arithmetic, and the emptiness of white-collar dreams, as well as most observers.
MONTPELIER, Vt., May 15 -- Vermont Republicans maintained tradition today at their quadrennial state convention by electing nine unpledged, uninstructed delegates to the party's national convention.

ASTORIA, Ore., May 15 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York swung through northwest Oregon today, lashing out harder than ever at Harold E. Stassen, his opponent in next Friday's Republican Presidential primary, for his proposal to outlaw the Communist party.

ONE of the attributes that make a plant valuable for landscape use is a so-called "four-season effect."
