While the April show of forsythia, for example, is charming, it is, in fact, a one-season plant. Royal azalea, however, qualifies as a four-season plant, and for this reason alone merits wider use.

ST. LOUIS, May 16 (AP) -- A high pop fly by Terry Moore dropped into left-center field for a hit and Ralph Lapointe scored from first base to break up a tenth-inning tie and give the Cardinals a 6-to-5 victory over the Pirates today.

" Exploring the UN," a television series during which each of the fiftyeight nations in the international body are to participate, will be introduced by WPIX some two weeks after its scheduled opening June 15 on Channel 11. The video outlet will be operated here by The Daily News.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The United States is expected to give strong support to the new State of Israel in Palestine and its right to defense against invasion. But whether this will be reflected in instructions to Warren R. Austin, representative with the United Nations, for announcement to the Security Council tomorrow afternoon at Lake Success was uncertain tonight.

LONDON, May 16 -- Since relations between the East and the West have deteriorated so alarmingly in the past year, there was a slight ripple of excitement in financial markets here last week on the Soviet Union's apparent move toward obtaining an improvement of relations with the United States.

The trend of prices in the domestic cotton market last week was toward higher levels, and practically all contracts were at new seasonal highs at the close, with net advances of 40 to 104 points on the New York Cotton Exchange.

New evidence that good mental health for the next generation depends more on prevention than on treatment of children's difficulties. and that help cannot be given too early or on too broad a base, comes from the first year's work of the Council Child Development Center, 227 East Fifty-ninth Street.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 16 -With more than half an eye cocked on California's fifty-three votes in the Republican national convention Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and Harold E. Stassen planned today to make a beeline there as soon as the Oregon Presidential primary is concluded.
" How would you feel if you had just lost about 200,000 admissions?"

Quiet prevailed in most sections of the foreign exchange marketlast week, but even on this subdued market interest there developeda number of significant price changes. These included a narrowingof the spread between spot and future contracts of pound sterling, andnew high levels for the free currencies of Canada and Switzerland.

Headed by officials of both the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, 2,000 trade unionists gathered yesterday afternoon at Manhattan Center to hail the establishment of the new Jewish State and call for the immediate lifting of the United States arms embargo.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 16 (AP) -Ralph Hepburn, 51, of Van Nuys, Calif., for thirty years one of America's top-ranking automobile and motor cycle racers, was crushed to death today in the Novi Special he had driven to all-time records over the Indianapolis motor speedway.

Counting twice in thc first half and adding three more goals in the second, the rugged and colorful Liverpool Football Club of England began its tour of this country and Canada yesterday by halting the American Soccer League Metropolitan All-Stars, 5 to 1, at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island.
CHICAGO, May 16 (AP) The Reds tallied twice in the tenth inning to nose out the Cubs, 13 to 11, in a free-scoring battle before 32,226 fans today.

DETROIT, May 16 -- Ford Local 600, United Automobile Workers, CIO, voted $125,000 today in aid of the Chrysler strikers. At the same time it rejected the Ford proposal yesterday of a wage reduction to bring Ford pay into line with the pay of General Motors and Chrysler.

Officials of the Columbia Broadcasting System said here yesterday that every effort would be made to uncover the facts of Mr. Polk's death. Davidson Taylor, vice president of the system, ordered Winston Burdett, CBS correspondent in Rome, to fly to Salonika and make an independent investigation.

Maj. Gen. Jose Humberto Sosa Molina, Minister of War of the Argentine, with a group of Argentine Army officers and members of their families, attended solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer delivered a sharp retort yesterday to the Catholic War Veterans, which had criticized his opposition to the Mundt Bill. He denounced the legislation as "a dangerous short-cut to thought control and police-state regulation."

Camp Syndicate, Inc., of New York, represented by Joseph G. Abramson, attorney, has purchased from Michael Knoville and Arthur Klein of Chicago the twostory building occupying a plot 100 by 100 feet and containing seven stores and ten apartments at 255-21 and 255-29 Northern Boulevard in Great Neck, L.I.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) C. W. Harder, president of the National Federation of Small Business, today urged President Truman to veto the Reed-Bulwinkle Bill exempting railroads from anti-trust laws.

SCARBOROUGH, England, May 16 -- By indirection, the British Labor party's leaders served notice tonight that they intended to proceed with the nationalization of the steel industry. The national executive committee, meeting on the eve of the Labor party's annual conference, voted to expel Alfred Edwards, Member of Parliamenth) 0*0*0*iand a steel company director, who has repeatedly declared that it would be "suicidal" and "treachery" to persist in the present nationalization plans.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 16 -- The World Jewish Congress called upon the United Nations today to take emergency steps to protect Jews living in Arab countries from pillaging attacks and "mass pogroms."

ATHENS, May 16 -- The United States Consulate General in Salonika reported today that the body of George Polk, 34-year-old chief Middle Eastern correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System, had been found by local police washed up on the shore of Salonika Bay early this morning.

BOSTON, May 16 (AP) -- Rain halted a double-header at intermission and dispersed a crowd of 33,042 today after the Red Sox came from behind for a 14-5 victory in the opener by battering three Washington pitchers for nineteen hits.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 16 -Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and Harold E. Stassen settled down today to the preparation of their debate on communism, which they expect millions of radio listeners throughthe country to hear tomorrow night.

Capt. Charles F. May of San Francisco, who was elected president of the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, on Saturday, will represent his union at the International Congress of the International Transport Federation, which will meeth)0*0*0*iin Oslo beginning June 19.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Many Americans -- the writers are among them -- have criticized the "iron curtain." Our criticism has been that the iron curtain sought to shut out the free discussion of the ideas that democracies believe in. Our criticism has been that behind the iron curtain the power of the state is used to suppress political parties that try to oppose the parties that control the Government.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 16 -Tragedy ended a race at 1 P.M. today between two sailing dinghies, manned by students of the Stevens Institute of Technology, Hoboken, when one of the boats capsized a half mile from the Jersey City shore of Newark Bay, and Richard Prosser, 21-year-old student, of 306h)0*0*0*iLydecker Street, Englewood, N.J., drowned.

ALBANY, May 16 (AP) -- Unfavorable weather cut over-all production of maple sugar and maple syrup in New York State to near record low levels this spring. The State Department of Agriculture reported today that producers made only 26,000 pounds of sugar this year.

In the largest single spot-bid sale of surplus property ever to be held in the New York-New Jersey region, more than 500 jobbers' lots of miscellaneous merchandise and equipment, totaling $15,000,000 in cost value will be offered at the War Assets Administration disposal center in Linden, N.J., to all types of buyers Thursday, it was announced over the week-end.

The mystery that surrounded the Japanese merchant marine before World War II blankets the operations of most of the Russian merchant fleet, the American Merchant Marine Institute reported yesterday on the basis of a survey of Soviet shipping.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Grain markets showed increased activity last week on the Board of Trade and prices averaged higher, due in part to buying induced by strength in securities and evening-up operations in the May deliveries. Trading in the latter will cease at the close of business on next Friday, and any contracts remaining open thereafter can be closed only by a tender of the actual grain.

Nell Boardman, chairman of the annual spring outdoor art exhibit in Washington Square, announced yesterday the winners in the various categories of original paintings shown at the exhibit that opened last week.

MILAN, Italy, May 16 -- As ocular demonstration of the gigantic effort being made by the people of Italy in seizing the opportunity for economic rehabilitation provided under the European Recovery Plan, the 26th Milan International Samples Fair which closed today was a complete success.

LOS ANGELES, May 16 -- Henry Wallace began a three-week campaign tour of the Far West tonight with a demand that the United States follow up its recognition of Israel with an "ultimatum" to Arab leaders to lay down their arms.

With the first and second places determined in favor of Mikhail Botvinnik, who succeeded the late Alexander Alekhine as titleholder last Monday, and Vassily Smyslov, the runner-up, four of the competitors in the tournament for the chess championship of the world met yesterday in the twenty-fifth and final round at the Hall of Columns in Moscow, according to a report from the Soviet capital.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 16 -- Full support for the third party candidacy of Henry A. Wallace was recommended here today by the International Executive Board of the International Fur and Leather Workers Union, CIO.

The state executive committee of the American Labor party issued yesterday a statement specifying the conditions under which it would endorse candidates of other parties for Representative in Congress, a point of special interest to Democratic incumbents in this city.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 16 -"Battleground," a photoplay about the Battle of the Bulge, will be made by RKO next fall with Robert Mitchum, Robert Ryan and Bill Williams in the leading roles, the roles, the studio has announced.

h)0*0*0*iOTO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As one of the thirty-two writers who signed the open letter to Russian writers, I should like, if I may, to challenge the concept that in doing so I took a Russian stand. I do not believe that being against war and fascism is an exclusive possession of the Rus sians.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 -- More than 1,500 members of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, voted overwhelmingly today to reject a six-cent hourly wage increase offer from the Budd Company, manufacturer of automobile bodies and railroad cars.

HEWLETT, L.I., May 16 -- In a final that went to the last hole for a decision, the Brooklyn team of Jim Oleska and Johnny Mikrut won the Long Island Golf Association's William D. Richardson Memorial tourney by 2 up at the Seawane Harbor Club today.

h)0*0*0*iWith 115 horses in the entries, fifteen in the $25,000 added Toboggan Handicap, Belmont Park's month-long spring meeting opens today. In addition to providing eight puzzles a day for the horse players, it will provide the best racing of the New York campaign.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 16 (UP) -The Southwest Conference yesterday put a brake on wholesale appearances of its members in New Year's Day football bowls and fell in line with the National Collegiate Athletic Association's "sanity code" on financial aid to athletes.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 16 (AP) -- President Charles Seymour of Yale said today that an indifference to moral values in America between the world wars "culminated in disaster," and even now "constitutes a serious menace."

Openings of fall apparel lines dominated activity in wholesale markets here last week, while mail consisted principally of reorders for low-end merchandise, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leadingh)0*0*0*iresident buying offices.

MOSCOW, May 16 (AP) -- Pravda qestioned today Henry A. Wallace's right to stand as a judge between the United States and Russia, but praised him as a realist whose suggestions to Premier Stalin had contributed to SovietAmerican relations.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 16 -- That small-town and downonthe-farm life celebrated in song and story still is not too attractive from the housing viewpoint for the average Southern family, according to a survey released today by the Southern Regional Council.

Oblivious of the heavy rain, a crowd estimated by Police Inspector Daniel O'Sullivan at 75,000 persons milled in the streets adjacent to Madison Square Garden early last evening awaiting admission to the "Salute to Israel" rally under the auspices of the American Zionist Emergency Council.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 16 -Craig Spangenberg, a partner in a Cleveland law firm, told a Securities and Exchange Commission board of inquiry yesterday that he never knew until last Thursday that two of his partners represented Cyrus S. Eaton, or that they were interested in a law suit filed against the Kaiser-Frazer corporation.

Many American homes are in a "dilapidated condition" because they have been "attacked by Satan and burglarized by sin," the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-Seventh Street, declared yesterday in his sermon.

Urging free exchange of students, professors and scientists between the United States and the American zone of occupied Germany, Dr. Robert Maynard Hutchins, chancellor of the University of Chicago, left La Guardia Field yesterday for Frankfort on the Main, where he is to deliver an address tomorrow on the 100th anniversary of the German National Assembly.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Achievement of a culture "in which men will conceive of themselves as servants of God rather than as competitors for domination over one another" has become indispensable for human survival itself, Dr. Louis Finkelstein, president of the Jewish Theological Seminary of New York, declared tonight.

A banking syndicate headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc., will place on the market today an issue of 500,000 shares of common stock of American Broadcasting Company, Inc., at $9 a share. The issue will increase the capitalization to 1,689,017 shares.

The Right Rev. John I. Blair Larned, Bishop in charge of the Convocation of the American Protestant Episcopal Churches in Europe, reporting yesterday on his church's progress toward reconstruction, told the morning congregation at Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, that humility was the decisive factor that could wreck or establish any present institutions for European government or peace.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 16 -- Lord Mayor Walter Kolb of Frankfort drew a strong parallel today between the democratic ideals of the first National Assembly of Germany 100h)0*0*0*iyears ago and those that inspired the United States.

The Children's Aid Society served 45,000 youngsters last year, the largest number in its ninety-fiveyear history, William Church Osborn, president of the society, reported yesterday at its headquarters at 105 East Twenty-second Street.

Dr. James E. West brought a boy's heart and a man's brain into lifelong harmony for the elevation of American youth. For more than thirty years his influence was felt in growing millions of American homes as he led the Boy Scout movement to its present full fruition.h)0*0*0*iO

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 16 -By getting a second place in one race, Bobby Mosbacher was declared winner today of the Sparkman Trophy in the series for International Class craft at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Ralph Vaughan Williams' new Symphony No. 6, which received its premiere last month in London's Royal Albert Hall, will be performed for the first time in this country during the Berkshire Festival, Serge Koussevitzky, conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, announced yesterday.

Employment opportunities for semi-skilled Negroes increased substantially last year despite intense competition and tightening of hiring specifications, the Urban League of Greater New York declared yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial "Some Thoughts on Welfare," on May 7, you discussed the speech of Paxton Blair, member of the State Board of Social Welfare, before the Kiwanis Club. We agree with your concluding sentence, in which you state: "We believe that Mr. Blair's several ideas on welfare deserve some thoughtful consideration."

The triennial debate over the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act is with us again. Since the London, Geneva and Havana tariff conferences have taken place, in that order, since this legislation was last extended for what has come to be regarded as the "standard" period of three years, the programh) 0*0*0*ihas become more firmly embedded in our economic structure even than it was before, and the argument for its continuance has been correspondingly broadened and strengthened.

As part of its $125,000,000 postwar expansion program to help relieve the national shortage of aluminum products, the Aluminum Company of America will start within a month to erect a large production plant at Point Comfort on Matagorda Bay between Houston and Corpus Christi, Texas, it was announced yesterday.

CLEVELAND, May 16 (AP) Home runs by Joe Gordon, Ken Keltner and Eddie Robinson sparked the Cleveland Indians to a 9-to-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox in the nightcap of a double-header today before 47,695 fans.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Committee on Economic Policy of the United States Chamber of Commerce today urged employers to provide more steady jobs for their workers, but remained skeptical of the guaranteed annual wage as a depression preventive.

Two young singers stepped before the golden curtain of the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday to realize a cherished ambition. As winners of the 1948 Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air, contracts with the world-renown opera company contracts were awarded to them.
Consolidated net sales of the Burlington Mills Corporation for the six months ended with last March 27, aggregated $134,700,206, according to the report released today.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 16 -- The invasion armies of five Arab nations hammered away with air and artillery attacks today at outlying Jewish settlements in Palestine, dispatches from Arab capitals said.

The aspirations of Henry Wallace to the Presidency are "a disservice to labor," Max Zaritsky, president of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union, AFL, declared yesterday. The third-party candidate, who, the union leader asserted, "talks labor and acts Communist," was urged to withdraw from the Presidential race.

The consumers' price index (formerly called "Cost of Living Index") for mid-March dipped 0.2 per cent below that for mid-February, according to figures released over the week-end by the National Industrial Conference Board.

While blaming Russia for the absence of peace, former Postmaster General James A. Farley said yesterday that war, in his opinion, was not imminent. The surest way to prevent war with Russia, he declared, was "to be ready at the shortest possible moment."

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The State Department announced tonight that a United States Army sergeant stationed at the Embassy in Moscow had gone "absent without leave," refused to return to this country and said he intended to remain in the Soviet Union.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 16 (AP) -- Jersey City split a twin bill with the Red Wings today, winning the seven-inning nightcap, 2 to 0, after dropping a free-scoring opener, 12 -- 10.

Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York and Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, will be contenders for the preference vote and twelve delegates to the Republican National Convention in the Oregon primary election on Friday, just one month before the convention opens in Philadelphia.

It has been proven notoriously difficult to modernize the official attitude in New York City toward the taxicab. The regulations seem to assume that the passenger in a cab is entitled to more physical protection, through cab construction, than the rider in an ordinary passenger car.
TEL AVIV, May 16 (Reuters)--Israel is applying to the fifty-

Despite forecasts of a general swing to competitive promotion advertising observers last week reported that "sell" ads soon will be closely crowded by a whole new crop of educational and public relations campaigns. Should even half the latter now in the works materialize in print, it was noted, the general public will be made more than aware of organized efforts to "inform" it on a variety of topics.
Small apartment buildings formed the bulk of properties passing to new control in Manhattan deals reported over the week-end.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -John L. Lewis has threatened to fight the seating of some soft coal industry negotiators when new contract talks begin here Tuesday, it was revealed today.
SOUTH ST. PAUL, Minn., May 16 -- Gov. Luther W. Youngdahl late today sent National Guardsmen to Albert Lea, Minn., to help maintain order at another strikebound Minnesota meat-packing plant.

Appointment of Lawrence A. Appley of Chicago as president of the American Management Association was announced over the week-end. John M. Hancock, chairman of the board of AMA and a partner in the New York banking firm of Lehman Brothers, said Mr. Appley would take over the post of president on July 1.

PITTSBURGH, May 16 -- Steel consumers last week found quite a variation in the prices of major steel items. But if they were substantial users they stood to save considerably if the cuts remained in force at least six months. The reason for the variation was the different reductions made by steel companies on the same products.

While the new Jewish State of Israel came into being Saturday night, its leading cultural emissaries, the Habimah, celebrated the birthday at the Broadway with another demonstration of theatre artistry come of age. Having displayed its affinity for a supernatural tale in "The Dybbuk" two weeks ago, the Hebrew speaking troupe from Palestine returned to the cabalistic mists to resurrect the story of "The Golem."

DETROIT, May 16 (AP) -- A single by Roy Partee in the ninth inning drove across Whitey Platt with the run that enabled the Browns to beat the Tigers today, 3 to 2, in the final game of the series. Platt, who opened the ninth with a triple, also hit a homer in the sixth.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Fifty thousand persons at the Chicago Stadium tonight cheered Senator C. Wayland Brooks, Republican, of Illinois, as he called for immediate lifting of the arms embargo as an aid to the new Jewish republic. Senator Brooks spoke at a rally sponsored by Americans for Haganah.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 16 -- As 500 delegates to the second biennial convention of the United Public Workers, CIO, began arriving here tonight, union leaders announced that they would move the entire assemblage to Washington if the Senate opened debate this week on a bill to bar from Federal employment workers belonging to organizations whose officers had refused to sign nonCommunist affidavits.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 16 (AP) -- Increased salaries and injury benefits and lifting of union restrictions were asked today by the New York State Federation of Post Office Clerks, AFL, at their biennial convention.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, May 16 -- Security censorship bars the disclosure in detail of the positions of Trans-Jordan forces; but in general, headquarters in this capital of Trans-Jordan said today, they are assuring the safety of the Arab area in central Palestine against Jewish attack while the Syrians and Iraqis are playing a role more on the offensive.

NANKING, May 16 -- The PeipingMukden Railway has been cut by the Communists on both sides of Shanhaikwan, the coastal pass at the eastern terminus of theh)0*0*0*iGreat Wall, it was reported here tonight.

SALONIKA, Greece, May 16 (AP) -- The coroner here estimated that Mr. Polk's body had been in the water about seven days. Robbery apparently was not the motive, since a wrist watch and a wallet containing about 300,000 drachme [about $30] were found on the body.

Norwegians all over the world for the past 134 years have celebrated May 17 as their greatest national festival. It was on this day, in 1814, that the Norwegian Parliament assembled at picturesque Eidsvold, forty miles north of Oslo, and declared Norway an independent kingdom.

More than 25 per cent of large industrial organizations have no planned program for development and training of key personnel, according to a nationwide survey conducted by the extension division of the College of the City of New York.

" The Permanent Goethe," edited, selected and with an introduction by Thomas Mann, will be issued on June 21 by the Dial Press in advance of the 200th anniversary next year of Goethe's birth. The volume will include 100 selections from Goethe's poems of love and youth, dramas, ballads, prose, short stories, essays, maxims and reflections.h)0*0*0*iO

AMSTERDAM, May 16 -- Considerable importance was attached last week to the announcement of the first capital issues from two Netherlands Indies enterprises -- Deli Maatschappy, with an issue of 12,800,000 guilders, and Tabak Maatschappy, with one of 1,600,000 guilders.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 16 -- The United Nations amateur radio station, first direct link between the international peace organization and the people of the world, will send out its K2UN signal from here tomorrow with an opening message from Secretary General Trygve Lie.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 16 -- For the second day in succession, Egyptian planes attacked Tel Aviv today. They bombed and strafed the port area in three separate attacks and then headed back toward Egypt minus two Spitfires.

VIENNA, May 16 -- Washington has made an important Austrian economic decision, according to reports here. It has thrown itself fully on the side of the Confederation of Labor and the Socialist party leadership and fined up against the banking, industrial and agrarian interests, which are being severely squeezed by a monetary deflation.

The request of the Mayor's Golden Anniversary Committee to use art treasures from the Governor's Room in City Hall to dress up the exhibit of the Mayor's office at the exposition to be held this fall in Grand Central Palace has been turned down regretfully as too risky, it was learned yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., May 16 (AP) -Pitching in a pouring rain Bob Porterfield, sensational rookie righthander, hurled his fifth straight triumph today but saw his scoreless skein snapped at 36 innings as he hurled the Newark Bears to a 10-3 triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs in the opener of ah)0*0*0*ischeduled double-header.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 (AP) -Johnny Palmer of Badin, N.C., sloshed through a driving rain in 34, 34 -- 68 today to skim four strokes off par and win the first prize of $2,500 in the Philadelphia Inquirer invitation golf tourney with a total of 281.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $52,516,660,205. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 -- The Giants and Phillies made a noble effort today to stage their doubleheader before a crowd of 28,750, but after two unsuccessful stabs had to bow to a persistent drizzle which drowned out the whole show after only two and one-third innings of the first game had been played.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -Speaker Martin said today that the House would pass anti-lynching legislation if the Senate did. He declared that the House would not be first with floor action.

Recently we called attention to the importance of the Surrogate's Court, with special reference to the vacancy which will arise by reason of the impending retirement of Surrogate Delehanty because of age. It is clearly the duty of the political leaders of both parties to offer to the electorate this fall candidates for Surrogate who combine in the highest degree character, knowledge of the law and experience in dealing with this specialized subject.

MONTREAL, May 16 -- A Canada stronger than ever before in all departments of air power was described here today by leaders in government and industry and demonstrated in new Canadian airplanes at Dorval airport.

The leading art event of the week in the waning season is the Metropolitan Museum's exhibition opening today of the collection of 150 old-master paintings from the Kaiser Friederich Museum which have been recently shown in Washington and are scheduled for a national tour after their local showing.

JERUSALEM, May 16 -- A battle in the area between St. George's Anglican Cathedral and the Damascus Gate, on the north of the Old Walled City, was in progress today for a third day, without either side gaining the mastery.

BOSTON, May 16 -- Although its own constitution now bars Communists from office, the United Steelworkers, CIO, will continue to refrain as a matter of principle from signing non-Communist affidavits under the TaftHartley Law.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Members of Congress hailed the new Jewish state of Israel tonight and urged lifting the embargo on arms to the Middle East. They recommended to the United Nations Security Council that any invasion of Israel be deemed a threat to world peace.

The Open Pier Every now and again various careworn agencies, including the Port of New York Authority, issue detailed plans for improving the waterfront. "Improving" is the word they use, and the drawings are handsome and well reproduced.

Four authorities on medical economics, members of the Committee for the Nation's Health, assailed yesterday the recent study of the Brookings Institution that said the United States did not have enough physicians to meet all demands likely to be made under a Federal program of compulsory health insurance.

The value of Christ's teaching lies not in "telling us how we ought to behave in all circumstances but in revealing His fundamental attitudes," the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken, pastor of Riverside Church, said yesterday in his sermon.

The chances of Soviet cooperation in joint efforts to revive world trade are almost zero, it is declared in a forthcoming Twentieth Century Fund report on the policy of the United States on international cartels, advance portions of which were released over the week end.

Samuel A. Telsey, president of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, announced yesterday that a committee from his organization would leave for Europe within a few weeks to expedite the passage of displaced persons to Israel.

CINCINNATI, May 16 (AP) -Ernie Crosbie, 38-year-old heeland-toe artist from Baltimore, Md., breezed to an easy victory today in the combined National A.A.U. 50,000-meter walking championpionship and final tryout for the American Olympic 50-kilometer walking team.
PARIS, May 16 -- Under the spell of a tiny Princess and her charming Duke a pre-war Longchamp thrilled Parisians today. Habitues could not believe their eyes.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Congress, just five weeks away from its proposed adjournment date of June 19, must do a terrific amounth)0*0*0*iof legislating or drop many controversial measures, observers suggested tonight.
PHILADELPHIA, May 16(AP) The Phillies were informed today that First Baseman Dick Sisler may be out of action for some time.

The Dodgers and Braves played one and a fraction innings yesterday at Ebbets Field before rain brought about a halt. After a thirty-seven minute wait the contest was called off, making it the second postponed game of the series.

PARIS, May 16 -- The question of nationalized industries has become acute once more in France. Official circles, including most of the Socialists and Popular Republicans have admitted publicly, though with differences of viewpoint, that management of theseh) 0*0*0*iindustries ought to be reorganized because of certain difficulties they are causing both for the budget and the Treasury.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 16 -- Dr. Chaim Weizmann, senior statesman of Israel, tonight was elected President of the Council of Government -- a post tantamount to Provisional President of the new state.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 16 -- A boxer previously unknown to fame, Mrs. George A. Wilford's Ch. Mazelaine Gallantry from Tamaqua, Pa., got best in show today under a rain-sodden tent in the forty-sixth all-breed event of the Long Island Kennel Club at the Meadow Brook Club.

LIKE Victor Kravchenko, Igor Gouzenko chose freedom. Both men fled from their posts in Russian embassies, Mr. Kravchenko from the Soviet Embassy in Washington, Mr. Gouzenko to the protection of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police in Ottawa. Both men have written books. Mr. Kravchenko's "I Chose Freedom" was a long, specific, powerful story of life under the Soviet terror, one of the most convincing and important documents of our time.

h)0*0*0*iOAbraham Mazer, New York paper manufacturer and communal leader, presented a gift of $250,000 to the United Jewish Appeal in celebration of the establishment of the Jewish state, Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman of the Appeal's drive for $250,000,000, announced yesterday.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 16 -Religious pageantry and an imposing program of vocal and instrumental music drew several thousand visitors to the Casino Auditorium at Georgian Court College here this afternoon. The event marked by the presence of the Most Rev. William A. Griffin, D.D., Bishop of Trenton, was the annual Georgian Court musicale, featuring Jessica Dragonette, well known alumna of the college.

The fourth annual Festival of Contemporary American Music, sponsored by the Alice M. Ditson Fund of Columbia University, closed with a concert given in collaboration with the Columbia Broadcasting System, yesterday afternoon in McMillin Academic Theatre.

R. A. Wenger has resigned as president and general manager of Scott-Burr Stores, Inc., a retail subsidiary of Butler Brothers, Chicago. B. R. Prall, executive assistant to the president, will direct operations of the stores until a successor is named.

Heavy rain curtailed yesterday's observance of "I am an American Day" on the Mall of Central Park. Despite the downpour a crowd estimated by the police at 15,000 remained throughout, about half of them without umbrellas.

EAST STROUDSBURG, Pa., May 16 (AP) -- The derailed engine and one of eight cars of a Lackawanna Railroad passenger train careened into the Delaware River today as the train started the winding run through Delaware Water Gap.

Sophia Vembo, Greek singer and entertainer, reconstructed her country's musical history since 1821 in folk and popular song and recitation yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. She had the assistance of Alice Vembo, her sister; Menios Manolitsakis, accordionist and whistler, and Leo Rapitis, pianist.

FOR many generations Norway, with its homely, rugged population engaged in trade, shipping, fishing and agriculture, had stood outside the turmoil of world politics. Far off were the days when the Vikings had sallied forth to conquer or ravage a large part of the then-known world. The Hundred Years' War, the Thirty Years' War, the wars of William III and Marlborough, the Napoleonic convulsion, and later conflicts, had left Norway unmoved and unscathed.
Eleven new films, including importations from England and France, are due to open in firstrun theatres this week. The programs follow:

h)0*0*0*iThe American Jewish Committee declared yesterday that the United States Government "and every other democratic nation" must prevail on the United Nations Security Council to bring "into action every power that it has under the Charter to suppress violence leading to a breach of the peace in Palestine."
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 16 -- The Provisional Government of the State of Israel applied today for membership to the United Nations.
PARIS, May 16 -- A stage of striped awning, a ramp raised above the lawn in his garden and a perfect May afternoon formed an appropriate setting for Jacques Fath's mid-summer showing.

CORNWALL ON HUDSON, N.Y., May 16 -- Sun Beau, a trim chestnut gelding from Sterling Smith Stables, Ravenna, Ohio, and ridden by George Braun, splashed his way over a rainswept obstacle course to nose out Peg's Pride, a grey gelding of Hutchinson Farms.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -The State Department, which opened its information office tonight to make the announcement about Sergeant McMillin, gave out this formal statement:

Gay playtogs, cool cottons for town and print frocks for dancing on summer nights make up the summer fashions to be presented today on Gimbel's third floor. Sunback dresses with little boleros that convert them into covered-up fashions for town are a popular favorite.

Now until November is the flush season for ducks. From Long Island, one of the largest duckproducing centers in the world, freshly killed birds arrive here daily. Ducks from this area also are shipped to all parts of the country, though usually in frozen form.

Appeals for the lifting of the arms embargo to Palestine were voiced last night by speaker after speaker at a "Salute to Israel" rally in Madison Square Garden. The meeting was held under the auspices of the American Zionist Emergency Council, parent organization of all Zionist groups in this country.

In a time as fluid as this, it is to be expected that the world stage should be full of figures coming and going. The remarkable thing is that there are few new figures. A survey of the governments that have emerged after a war that displaced institutions and regimes as well as millions of people discovers an extraordinary number of the same faces on the political scene.

ACTORS and other entertainers have an expression they use for an audience which is unresponsive, viz., namely and to wit: "They sat on their hands." No applause, no laughter, no display of emotion, no nuthin'. The folks who crowded Pimlico on Saturday for a gander at the latest wonder horse, Citation, actually sat on their hands.

BERLIN, May 16 -- Five thousand homeless Jews solemnly celebrated the birth of the new Stateh)0*0*0*iof Israel at the principal displaced persons camp here today. In brilliant sunlight that beat down on the dusty compound of Dueppel Center, they sang "Hatikvah," the national anthem, paraded with banners and heard patriotic speeches.

Whatever else may be said of the policy of Soviet Russia, it is consistent. Ever since the Red Army moved into Korea after the collapse and surrender of Japan in 1945, Soviet policy in that unhappy small country has been one of obstruction of all efforts at reunification on a peaceful basis.

We stumbled onto one of those deep theatrical secrets. Talking to Guthrie McClintic recently, he said a playwright was at work on a script for his wife, Katharine Cornell, in case Kate O'Brien's dramatization of her novel, "For One Sweet Grape," wasn't accepted.

Having failed to settle the problem of Palestine while it still had authority over the Holy Land as a mandated territory, the United Nations is now confronted with a new situation which begins to assume every aspect of internationalh)0*0*0*iwar. A new state, that of Israel, has proclaimed its independence and its provisional government has been recognized by the United States, and tacitly by others, as the de facto authority within its domain.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- May corn acted tight on the Board of Trade last week and increased its premium over July, but it failed to hold the full gain. There was some buying of corn against sales of wheat by spreaders based on a suggestion by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics of the Department of Agriculture that corn might sell above wheat when the peak of the movementh)0*0*0*iof the new wheat crop was underway.

Members of New York Typographical Union No. 6, at a meeting yesterday afternoon in Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street, endorsed the procedure taken by its officials in contract negotiations with the thirteen major newspapers here.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- The decline in business evident in some lines during the first quarter of this year appears to have been slowed down and possibly halted, according to a survey conducted among members of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago.

The New York Infirmary announced yesterday that it had changed its mind about moving from its present location on Fifteenth Street east of Stuyvesant Square to York Avenue and Sixtysecond Street. The change of plans, it was said, is due to a desire to cooperate with the Hospitalh)0*0*0*iCouncil of Greater New York in its effort to space hospitals where they are most needed throughout the city.

A few moments after he had telephoned a friend that he was taking seventeen sleeping tablets, Werner Clauss, 36 years old, operator of a trucking and stevedoring business, was found yesterday afternoon on a bed in his second floor apartment at 128 East Seventysecond Street.
Five teen-age youths at target practice on the roof of a Bronx apartment house were accused yesterday of wounding slightly two women and a boy walking along the Grand Concourse near 184th Street.

Belmont Park will be the rendezvous for members of society today for the opening of the spring racing season of the Westchester Racing Association, of which George D. Widener is president. The racing program will continue for four weeks.

W. A. Mather, president of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, has announced that the first of two passenger steamships under construction in Scotland for the company's British Columbia coast service will be launched this month.

The Rev. Dr. Erling Eidem, Archbishop of Upsala and Primate of the Lutheran Church of Sweden, will spend the next six weeks in this country as a participant in the nation-wide festivities marking the centennial of Swedish migration to the United States.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, May 16 -- The new trizonal Bank of the German States, which is expected to play a vital role in the impending currency reform, may have to start operations without a president.

An eleven-man board of trustees will direct the projected $15,575,000 New York University-Bellevue Hospital Medical Center, Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of the university, announced yesterday. The board will be headed by Richard W. Lawrence, president of the Bankers Commercial Corporation.

The stock market's balance was upset yesterday morning by profit taking, but the list resumed the advance in the later trading to leave prices slightly higher on the day. A few gains of a point or more were made by the oils, rails and meat packing shares, but only in fractions, with the combined averages up 0.05 point on the day.

" Ballet Ballads," which completed a successful run Saturday at Maxine Elliott's Theatre, where it was offered by the Experimental Theatre as the group's final production of the season, will move to Broadway this evening, opening at the Music Box.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 17 -- Following is the text of a statement on the Palestine question made today by Warren R. Austin, United States representative, before the United Nations Security Council:

Hallam M. Richardson, who is seeking a complaint charging criminal libel against the Rev. Henry A. Atkinson, chairman of the advisory committee of the Nonsectarian Anti-Nazi League, denied under cross-examination in lower Manhattan court yesterday that he had been counsel for Gerald L. K. Smith.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Representatives of about 75 stevedoring companies, operating in East Coast and Gulf ports came to' Washington today to work for legislation to relieve them from the threat of having lo pay retroactively what they termed "overtime -on-overtime' pay to longshoremen employed by them.

One of the most important and ambitious projects of the post-war world has ended in at least temporary failure as a result of the suspension by the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission of all further efforts to reach agreement on effective control of the atomic bomb.

Reports from various sources indicate that the wide cooperation needed to make a success of the city's Golden Anniversary celebration is developing and that New York and its visitors can expect to see a good show, learn something and benefit the city by their participation.

SCARBOROUGH, England, May 17 -- The extreme Left Wing members of the British Labor party who have called the European Recovery Plan an American "imperialist" plot and who advocate a close British alliance with the Soviet Union lost their belligerency in the face of obviously overwhelming opposition at the opening sessions of the party's fortyseventh annual conference today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 17 -- The United States presented a resolution to the United Nations Security Council today ordering Jews and Arabs to stop fighting in Palestine within thirty-six hours after adoption of the proposal.
NEW DELHI, India, May 17 -The Governor General, Earl Mountbatten, has apparently decided to take a hand in the quarrel between India and Hyderabad, the only Princely State remaining independent.

BUENOS AIRES, May 17 -- The Central Bank of Argentina has notified all other banks that they no longer have the right to remit dollars, Swiss francs and Swedish kroners for imports received here. In effect the ruling brings to a standstill Argentine trade with the United States, Switzerland, Sweden and other hard-currency areas.

PARIS, May 17 -- Princess Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh tonight closed the official program of their four-day visit of FrancoBritish friendship here in a blaze of social brilliance at a gala performance at the National Opera.

Proposed incorporation of the temporary $650 cost-of-living allowance into the permanent salaries of instructors at the four municipal college was recommended last night by the Board of Higher Education, meeting in Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Democratic organization of Alabama, supported by an overwhelming majority of the party voters in that state, are now perfecting plans by which to realize a rosy dream. If this dream comes a fact, they and the Democratic majorities in other Southern states -Mississippi, South Carolina, Arkansas and, less possibly, Virginia -- will have achieved the following political miracle:

Municipal Court Justice Christopher C. McGrath in the Bronx overruled yesterday the Office of the Housing Expediter, which had granted a landlord a rent increase because a baby had been born to a tenant. Following the precedent set in a Brooklyn court in a similar case last month, Justice McGrath said that "no agency of the Government should penalize parents for having children because that is the natural object of marriage."

LONDON, May 17 -- The Moscow radio tonight broadcast Premier Stalin's acceptance of the program outlined by Henry A. Wallace, third party Presidential candidate, as a "good and fruitful basis" for discussion and settlement of the differences between the United States and the Soviet Union.

Advance showings of women's coats and suits for fall got off to a good start in the garment market here yesterday. Held primarily for local stores, they will continue through the week and will help set the stage for a large influx of visiting buyers who are expected to attend the official openings beginning May 24.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The National Military Establishment issued today, effective next Wednesday, the first of a series of regulations on procurement designed to revamp military purchasing policy in line with the combining of the three military services.

SALONIKA, Greece. May 17 -Raleigh A. Gibson, United States Consul General, said today that he was satisfied that the Salonika police were making "every effort" to solve the murder mystery of the death of George Polk, Columbia Broadcasting System correspondent in Greece.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The White House announced today that three "improved" atomic weapons had been fired with complete success in recent experiments in Eniwetok atoll in the Pacific.

Should summer ever unfold, Saks-Thirty-fourth has a complete vacation wardrobe in its new Sun and Fun Shop. This shop believes in the barest of swim suits, usually two-piecers with shoestring tied halters, in calico, metallic-threaded rubber, a chintz print on sateen.
Cornell, California and Washington, the only college varsity crews of the country that remain unbeaten face the big show-down this week.

NEW DELHI, India, May 17 (UP) -- Moslem guerrillas from the State of Gilgit, bordering on the Soviet Union, have infiltrated into Kashmir State and are attacking Indian troops guarding Kashmir's northern approaches, the Government announced tonight.

The Presidential candidacy of Governor Dewey was hailed last night at a fund-raising dinner of the New York Republican County Committee, held at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. Twelve hundred guests, paying $50 each, netted the county committee close to $50,000 for campaign expenses.

STATE COLLEGE, Miss., May 17 -- The new responsibilities that world power imposes on the United States offer to every trained and prepared person of this generation wider opportunities than ever before existed, Turner Catledge, assistant managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said here this afternoon.

One of these days -- or nights -the Dodgers might beat the Braves, but they may be too old to enjoy the fruits of such a victory. For last night at Ebbets Field the Bostonians made it four in a row over the Brooks, this time by a 12-3 margin, and the fans are beginning to ask questions.

HATTERAS, N.C., May 17 -The dead calm, known locally as a "doldrum" ever since the day Raleigh placed the first white foot on these shores, was succeeded by a howling south wind shortly after we arrived at noon yesterday.
ALBANY, May 1 (AP) -- Tightened fishing regulations take effect July 1 in six New York Counties, the Conservation Department announced today.

The Mayor in his announcement of the incrased fares on transit lines berated home owners and others owning real estate because he thought real estate should be paying more of the cost of running the city. He compared the percentage of the city budget borne by real estate some years back with the present percentage.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 17 (AP) -- Federal Judge Louie W. Strum granted today the petition of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad and seven other roads the right to intervene "as interested parties" in the reorganization of the Florida East Coast Railway.

TOKYO, May 17 -- Twenty fullfledged conspiracies by Japanese Army and Navy leaders to conceal information about war crimes have been uncovered, Alva C. Carpenter, chief of the occupation forces' legal section, asserted today. He said his office also was working on six more such cases and was preparing dozens of perjury charges against the Japanese concerned.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 17 (AP) -Blue Helen, flashing the Blue and Gold silks of J. A. Kroeck, dashed to a length-and-a-half decision in the feature of today's card at Garden State Park.

PARIS, May 17 (AP) -- Hungary knocked France out of the running for the Davis Cup, emblematic of world tennis supremacy, today as the quarter-final bracket in European Zone competition was virtually completed.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- Commisioner D. D. Hammond of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service today opened hearings looking toward ending the strike of the National Maritime Union, CIO, .which since last week has tied up 'most of the oil tankers on the Great Lakes.

Your news story of May 7 from Manila entitled "U.S. Utilities Face Seizure in Manila," without the background of information, gives the impression that the Philippine Government is gong to confiscate private American property without legal sanction and without due compensation.

An encouraging bit of news to come from the annual convention of the American Spice Trade Association, meeting several days ago in this city, was that pepper supplies, notably short during 1947, are expected to increase in the coming months.

Work on a new shopping center in East Orange, N.J., has been started by the Tishman Construction Corporation, wholly-owned subsidiary of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, Norman Tishman, vice president, announced yesterday.

The turn toward optimism is being reflected in greater activity on completing advertising campaigns which recently were delayed by cautious planning and close consideration of dollar expenditures, it was reported yesterday. Careful handling of budgets still prevails, it was learned, but there is marked relaxation on the question of results.

The Third Avenue Transit Corporation, which has applied for an eight-cent fare and two-cent transfers, will argue before the Board of Estimate hearing on May 25 that with the city increasing its bus fare to 7 cents to cover operating costs, the company, as a private operator, will need an eightcent fare because it must cover not only operating costs but taxes and debt requirements as well.
LONDON, May 17 (Reuter) -Close of play scores in the eight County cricket matches today were:

LOS ANGELES, May 17 (AP) -Assistant Secretary of State George V. Allen said today that failure by Congress to renew the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act due to expire June 12 "would be disastrous for our cause."

The American Gas and Electric Company announced yesterday that it had contracted to buy for $1,500,000 all securities of the Citizens Heat, Light and Power Company of Indiana. The arrangement with the United Public Utilities Corporation is subject to approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission and other regulatory bodies.

The last technical objections to flying into New York International Airport are expected to be settled at a meeting scheduled here on Friday with the Civil Aeronautics Administration. The foreign-flag airlines, scheduled to start using the big new airport on Jamaica Bay on July 1, the airline pilots who have been testing the approaches, the domestic airlines and the Port of New York Authority all will be represented.

For the first time in the history of the Board of Education's summer school program, summer evening high schools will be open to adults who are not war veterans, Frederic Ernst, associate superintendent in charge of the academic high school division, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Because of the deep interest in psychiatry and the misconceptions about it which have arisen in the mind of the public, the psychiatric profession must make certain to give the public "material which is sound, truthful and progressive, not sensational or alarmist," Dr. Winfred Overholser, president of the American Psychiatric Association, declared today.

Policemen, firemen, engineers, a theatrical lighting expert, food dealers and a news magazine are among the volunteers who will make possible the staging of the Scout-O-Rama by 17,000 Boy Scouts in Madison Square Garden next Saturday afternoon and evening.

NANKING, May 17 -- Defeated eighteen days ago in a hotly contested race for the national Vice Presidency, Dr. Sun Fo was reelected President of the new Legislative Yuan today by a large majority.
PHILADELPHIA, May 17 -- The skies cleared for the Giants tonight but it still didn't seem to improve their vision to any appreciable extent.

With a sharp rise in the country's birthrate, the need for agencies such as the Children's Aid Society becomes increasingly more apparent. In its ninety-fifth annual report the Society points to the work it has done during the past year and outlines a constructive program for the future.

LONDON, May 17 -- The Soviet Union officially recognized the new State of Israel tonight in a note that is regarded by diplomatic observers here as going farther than the de facto recognition extended to Israel on Saturday by the United States.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 17 -Playing in an all-day Long Island P.G.A. pro-amateur best-ball tournament, forty-five teams encountered all varieties of weather over the Garden City Country Club course today.

The Houston Oil Company, Texas, voted a dividend of $1 on the common stock, for the six months ending on June 30, payable on June 30. The company made two disbursements last year, 50 cents each in June and December.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 17 (U.P.) -- Mr. Wallace said here tonight that Premier Stalin's response to his "open letter" was a real offer by Russia "to sit down and find a way to end the 'cold war.'"

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The United States Supreme Court returned to a lower court today the question of whether war contractors operating Government-owned plants on a cost-plus, fixed-fee basis should have paid overtime wages.

CHENGTU, Szechwan, China, May 17 -- A new move by President Chiang Kai-Shek to deal with the powerful economic and military positions of the old war lord groups in this Province is seen here in the recent appointment of Gen. Wang Ling-chi as Governor of Szechwan.

DETROIT, May 17 -- Violence in the Chrysler Motors strike and open indications that a walk-out against the General Motors Corporation may be started, by the end of the month, by 225,000 members of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, today intensified the critical labor-management relations in the automobile manufacturing industry.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 17 -- In a keynote address bristling with denunciation of President Truman and Congress, Abram Flaxer, president of the United Public Workers, CIO, called on the union's convention here today to serve notice that it would not tolerate any more "kicking around" in the form of legislation to bar Communists from civil service jobs.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 17 (AP) -The United States Embassy here said yesterday that the Egyptian Air Force had confiscated four C-47 transport planes that the Trans World Airline had agreed to sell to Saudi Arabia.

LOS ANGELES, May 17 -- After nearly two years of discussion, deliberation and much controversy, the nation's radio station operators moved today toward final adoption of a code of ethics for broadcasting.

KEARNY, N.J., Tuesday, May 18 -- Four tanks, two containing tar and two pitchblende, exploded at 11:25 o'clock last night at the plant of the Koppers Coke Company here. Tho blasts rocked houses in the Hackensack and Passaic River valleys.

" Another Part of the Forest," a Universal-International drama starring Fredric March, Dan Duryea, Edmond O'Brien and Ann Blyth, will have its premiere this morning at the Rivoli. The adaptation of the Lillian Hellman play was directed by Michael Gordon and produced by Jerry Bresler from a screen play by Vladimir Pozner.

Taking to heart a teacher's assignment to "get a new slant on spring," 17-year-old Elissa Isaacson, a student at the High School of Music and Art, wrote a twelveline lyric poem titled "The Child and the House." The verse, first she ever had submitted in a competition, won top honors yesterday in the twenty-sixth annual InterHigh School Poetry Contest.

THE window-breakers return to the Polo Grounds tonight. That's Eddie Brannick's pet name for his beloved Giants. Being a chap from the sidewalks of New York, the sartorially exquisite Mr. Brannick can remember when he was a kid, which is long-distance remembering with a vengeance. But in those ancient days the youngster who could hit the ball the farthest in stickball or other variety of street baseball used to break windows.

BERLIN. May 17 -- Communist political activity based on the theme of German unity has increased in the Western zones of occupation. According to reliable sources here, this is in anticipation of the announcement of agreements in London by the three Western powers and the Benelux countries [Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg].

GREENWICH, Conn., May 17 -Work by individual citizens toward world peace is a part of the price of world peace, speakers asserted tonight at "What's On Your Mind?", radio forum of THE NEW YORK TIMES, presented before 900 persons in the Greenwich High School auditorium.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 18 (AP) -- The Moscow radio said today that Sgt. James M. McMillin of the United States Army had told the Mayor of Moscow that he intended to stay in Russia "as a protest against the anti-Soviet policies of the capitalists who at present rule America.

David A. Schulte is reported to have signed a contract for the purchase of the Jenson Building at 665 Fifth Avenue southeast corner of Fifty-Third Street, from the City Investing Company, of which Robert W. Dowling is president. Details of the consideration are not available, but it is understood that the purchase price exceeds the $2,200,000 assessed valuation of the property.

I want to express what millions of my fellow-countrymen must be feeling when they read that President Truman has affixed his signature to the Aid bill bringing relief to Europe; and that is to say "Thank you."
Brazil is opposed to communism and will continue to stand against it with the United States, Dr. Mauricio Nabuco, new Brazilian Ambassador to this country, declared here yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 17 (AP) -- Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation today asked the Federal Court to stop a steel broker from representing himself as able to obtain part of the company's output at higher than list prices.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- A world reunion for conservative Judaism was called for today by Rabbi Israel Goldman, president of the Rabbinical Assembly of America, as that body opened its three-day annual convention here.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 17 -- Two former Army comrades who were confined in the same Japanese prison camp in 1944-45 are plaintiff and defendant here in a $5,100 Supreme Court suit scheduled for trial Thursday. Defense papers refer to alleged black market operations in merchandise owned by the Army and the American Red Cross.
VIENNA, May 17 -- Russian soldiers here are working under tightened nonfraternization-with-Americans regulations.

ALBANY, May 17 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals today granted permission to the American Jewish Congress and the American Civil Liberties Union to file briefs in a taxpayer's suit to nullify a state housing grant to Canisius College.

The largest number of golfers in the history of the event -- including Defending Champion Lew Worsham and nine past titleholders -- have fixed their sights on the national open championship at Los Angeles June 10-12, it was reported by The Associated Press.
WASHINGTON, May ,17 -- The National Labor Relations Board rejected today a formal challenge by the United Steelworkers, CIO, of the validity of the Taft-Hartley non-Communist affidavit requirement.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, May 17 -- Following an official order to confiscate all goods in Egyptian ports that are in transit to Palestine and useful to the Egyptian military effort, customs officials, seized today 3,200 tons of cargo from four ships here.

Aided by six Fordham errors, St. Peter's yesterday halted the Rams' 6-game winning streak with a 3 -- 2 victory. The contest, staged at Fordham Field, was called because of rain at the end of the seventh frame.

The largest entry in history has been received for the seventysecond annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. outdoor track and field championships. Asa Bushnell's final check yesterday revealed that forty-seven colleges had nominated 585 competitors for the varsity classic at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island May 28-29.

In an address at Los Angeles Henry A. Wallace has described as "a deliberate criminal lie" the comparison so frequently made between Soviet Russia and Nazi Germany. It is not difficult to understand Mr. Wallace's strong feeling on this point. He was a vigorous critic of Hitler's domestic policies (police state, concentration camps, etc.) and a vigorous advocate of measures of self-defense against Nazi aggression.

There is beauty in the dunes on a sun-blessed day when a ruffled blueblanketed ocean stretches to the horizon. The lace-caps of low waves catch the sun's rays and cream-white jewels gleam momentarily and disappear. A long plume of black smoke unwinds behind a distant steamer and forms a horizontal exclamation point where sky and water meet.

CLEVELAND, May 17 -- Inflationary pressure will be greatly intensified if increased military expenditures are piled on top of the normal Truman budget, Merryle Stanley Rukeyser of the International News Service declared today at the fifty-second annual convention of the National Association of Credit Men.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The earliest possible starting of construction of a super-aircraft carrier, almost one-half again the tonnage of the largest now on the seas, was promptly and unanimously approved by a House Armed Services subcommittee today.

WESTPORT, Conn., May 17 (AP) -- Miss Vivien Kellems, waging a one-woman battle against the withholding tax law, said today she had warned her bank that she would hold it accountable if it turned over any of her company's money to the Government.

Dr. Chaim Weizmann, whose lifelong efforts on behalf of a Jewish state in Palestine have been crowned by his selection as President of the Provisional Council of Government of the new State of Israel, accepted his election yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 17 -- Harry Tugend has completed the scenario of "Take Me Out to the Ball Game," a musical comedy which Arthur Freed will produce at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer starting next month. The screen story, from which Tugend worked, deals with baseball in 1908 and was written by Gene Kelly and Stanley Donen.

The first indoor playground will be built next year at Betsy Head in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday in officiating at dedication ceremonies for a new outdoor playground at Union Settlement, 237 East 104th Street.

In connection with National Airmail Week, a "talking mail box" was installed yesterday between 1440 and 1450 Broadway. Questions on mail service and delivery schedules were answered. From 9 A.M. to 7 P.M. the box chatted with patrons.

With the weather cool and overcast, the majority of the smartly dressed women attending the opening of the racing meet at Belmont Park yesterday were attired in softly tailored suits or fitted coats worn with furs and small decorative hats. Navy blue was the overwhelming color favorite, with pearl chokers and closed heel and toe pumps fashion notes in the accessory field.
LONDON, May 17 (AP) -- Willie Turnesa, who won the British amateur golf championship last year in an All-American final, open the defense of his title next week -- against another American.

Permission to build and operate a television station in Washington on channel 12 will be requested of the Federal Communications Commission by a new corporation to be formed by The Washington Post and the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Foreign buying of packaged steam generators has increased sharply during the last thirty days, G. E. DeSiena, vice president of Superior Combustion Industries, Inc., 1475 Broadway, revealed here yesterday, after completing a survey of equipment purchasing trends.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 17 -- This city underwent three air raids today, suffering a considerable number of casualties. Of three known dead in the third attack one was a patient in a northern Tel Aviv dispensary and another was a nurse who was attending him.
Excerpts from the speeches made by Governor Dewey and Harold E. Stassen in their debate in Portland, Ore., last night as transcribed by the Mutual Broadcasting System follow:

A consolidation of interests for the production of pictures in England only was announced yesterday by David O. Selznick and Sir Alexander Korda. The linking of these two top independent producers holds many potential economic and talent advantages for both.

A radar exhibit showing the aco tual movements of shipping entering and leaving ~he harbor drew the interest of a majority of the visitors yesterday at the third annual National Marine Exposition in Grand Central Palace.

Two incidents in early American history have each been made the subject of two novels. One was the establishment of the French colony of Asylum, in Pennsylvania, in the French Revolution. The books about it are "Asylum for the Queen," by Mildred Jordan, issued by Knopf, and "I Thee Wed," by Gilbert W. Gabriel, issued by Macmillan.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 17 (AP) -- Dr. John S. Badeau, president of the American University at Cairo, protested by cable to President Truman today the United States recognition of Israel. He also opposed the proposed repeal of the United States embargo on arms shipments to the Middle East.

A resolution to amend the constitution of the American Medical Association so as to prohibit the exclusion of Negro physicians from membership in component county societies was introduced yesterday at the annual meeting of the House of Delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York, at the Pennsylvania Hotel.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -The United States Treasury, several congressmen and union leaders today urged repeal of Federal taxes on oleomargarine.

Fog rolled in midway in the opening day proceedings at Belmont Park yesterday, and William Helis' Rippey rolled out of it to take the first stake of the Westchester Racing Association's month-long spring meeting.

IF the characters in "The Ship and the Flame,"* by Jerre Mangione, were more sympathetic human beings their plight as refugees from Hitler would seem far more moving than it does. That is one of the occupational hazards which lie in wait for novelists: the danger of missing the emotion and drama of a tragic situation through fear of sentimentality, through too much restraint.
Members of society from many parts of the East and South attended the opening-day program of the forty-second spring meeting of the Westchester Racing Association at Belmont Park yesterday.

TRONDHEIM, if it were within our strength, was of course the key to any considerable operations in Central Norway. To gain it meant a safe harbour with quays and docks upon which an army of 50,000 men or more could be built up and based. Nearby was an airfield from which several fighter squadrons could work.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 17 -Moshe Shertok, Foreign Secretary of Israel, stated today that the citizens of Israel would be known as Israelis, as residents of Iraq are called Iraqis.

NEW ORLEANS, May 17 -- Development of oil resources needed for national defense might, be deterred if title to the disputed tidelands should be vested in the Federal Government, H. C. Weiss, chairman of the board of the Humble Oil and Refining Company, said here today.
BOSTON, May 17(AP) -- Boxing is "monopolized by a small clique," a former Boston welterweight charged today.

A recent series of teen-age crimes spurred the women's division of Youth United to hold an "emergency" meeting yesterday. The group called upon Brooklyn housewives to support its program for prevention of juvenile crime.

A violent thunderstorm pelted sections of the metropolitan area with large hailstones yesterday afternoon and drenched the city and surrounding communities with three-tenths of an inch of rain at the start of the homebound rush period.

Consumers' merchandise returns, always a problem with the retailer, have been increasing steadily this year, according to department and specialty store executives, and at this time at least four major stores here are making a systematic study of the problem, it was learned yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 17 -- Senator Glen Taylor praised the International Fur and Leather Workers Union, CIO, today for the "militant and forthright manner in which the members of your union have stood up for the things you believe right."

The financial counselor of the French Embassy here will assist French owners of assets still blocked in this country in complying with the regulations of the United States Treasury and the Department of Justice affecting such owners, it was announced yesterday.

Buying at the opening of the second annual New York stationery show yesterday in the New Yorker Hotel was brisk, according to both exhibiting manufacturers and buyers. Approximately 545 department store stationery buyers and proprietors of small stationery and gift shops attended, compared with 700 on the opening day last year.

The newspapers recently carried and other story concerning the Francis Thompson case giving readers the impression that Mr. Thompson was dismissed from the City College staff "because he was a Communist." The American Civil Liberties Union has been approached since that story broke in regard to its position on dismissing people for belief in communism or membership in the Communist party.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 17 -- The brand names promotion campaign, which opened here Saturday with the curtain-raising fanfare of a parade and civic functions, moved today into the serious job of selling.

The nation's merchant fleet as of May 1 totaled 3,542 vessels of 1,000 gross tons or more, a decrease of thirty-five ships from the total made public a month earlier, according to thc research division of the National Federation of American Shipping.

SOUTH ST. PAUL, Minn., May 17 (AP) -- Production workers went into the Swift and Armour meat packing plants here today past the picket lines of striking CIO United Packing House Workers. National Guardsmen were on duty. There was some cat-calling by pickets but no incidents.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- An employer who advises his employes not to join a union is within his "free- speech rights" under the Taft-Hartley Law, according to a decision announced today by the National Labor Relations Board.

A rally against the Mundt bill, designed to control subversive activities, and the Franco regime in Spain was staged last night in Madison Square Garden by the Joint Anti-Fascist Committee. The rally was "in behalf of 180,000 Spanish Republicans in exile in France and Mexico."

NEWARK, N.J., May 17 -- Discharging 300 union carpenters, bricklayers and laborers, Arthur H. Padula, vice president of the Fairmount Construction Company, announced today that its $10,000,000 housing project on the old Ivy Hill City Farm would institute the open shop policy.
PARIS, May 17 -- When the Soviet armies thrust into non-Russian Europe in 1944 and 1945, the Kremlin for the first time was faced with train problems of propaganda and discipline.

Sales for New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 7 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday also was 7 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -American Power and Light Company was authorized today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to make a cash contribution of $9,237,520 to the capital of Texas Utilities Company.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York will build a twenty-two-story building for its new home office on the east side of Broadway between Fifty-fifth and Fifty-sixth Streets. Alexander E. Patterson, president, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The United States reminded Marshall Plan countries today that they would be required to fix more realistic rates of exchange "in the near future" and nominated the International Monetary Fund to police the job.

LONDON, May 17 (AP) -- Following is the text of a reply by Premier. Stalin of Russia to Henry A. Wallace's open letter, as broadcast in Russian by the Moscow radio and heard in London by the Soviet monitor:

Art assumed the status of war surplus property yesterday when the War Assets Administration announced a public sealed-bid sale of a State Department collection of modern American painting, ending June 19. The group will be exhibited at the Whitney Museum (open daily, except Mondays, from 1 to 5 P.M.) from Friday to June 18.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday were somewhat mixed. The July contract closed 16 points lower than Saturday's final levels, but other months were 24 points higher to 2 points lower.
NEWARK, N.J., May 17 -- The urgent need for planning to solve urban transportation problems was stressed here today as the threeday National Citizens Conference on Planning got under way.
Boston, Mass., announced yesterday that it will accept bids until May 26 on $5,800,000 of bonds dated June 1, 1948, and due on each June 1 from 1949 to 1963.

About 500 stockholders at the hour-and-a-half-long sixty-third annual meeting of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., yesterday, heard Ralph H. Tapscott, president, tell an inquiring stockholder that the management "is not worried" about the dissolution of Morgan Stanley Co. syndicate last Friday on an issue of $57,382,000 of convertible debentures on which bids were due today.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Senate-House Atomic Energy Committee approved today by 11 to 5 a bill to extend the terms of the present members of the Atomic Energy Commission for an additional twenty-three months. The terms would expire June 30, 1950, if the bill becomes law.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -Samuel Hamilton Kaufman was nominated today to be a district judge for the Southern District of New York. His name was sent to the Senate by President Truman to fill the vacancy left by the death of Judge John Bright.

From the beginning of this century Dr. Chaim Weizmann has devoted himself to the cause of Zion. His election as President of the Council of Government of the new State of Israel comes now as a natural reward for years of faithful and distinguished service to that cause.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 17 -- Victor E. Motto, a radio amateur of Villa Isotta, Fino Mornasco, Como, Italy, became the first person to make contact officially with the United Nation amateur radio station, K2UN, which made its debut on the air this evening.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 17 -- The United Nations Atomic Energy Commission voted at 1:06 P.M. today to suspend all work toward international control of atomic power.
Mayor O'Dwyer was introduced yesterday to a cheering union convention as a man who deserves a higher political office -- and he said that he "liked it."

CLEVELAND, May 17 -- Robert J. Bulkley, former United States Senator, refused today for the second time to answer certain questions asked by a board of inquiry of the Securities and Exchange Commission. The board is investigating the recent $10,000,000 common stock offering of the KaiserFrazer Corporation.

Net sales of the Lionel Corporation, largest manufacturer in the United States of model electric trains and accessories, reached a new high of $12,167,290 in the fiscal year ended with last February, according to the annual report of Lawrence Cowen, president, released for today.

World trade is a key to world peace, Mayor William O'Dwyer said yesterday in ceremonies held at City Hall to open World Trade Week and mark the golden anniversary of this city in international commerce.
