WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The statement of Premier Stalin tonight that Russia was ready to negotiate differences between the Soviet Union and the United States met a mixed reaction here, but one that was not wholly unfavorable.
ABERDEEN, Md., May 17 -The Army today unveiled a huge new firing chamber used to test aircraft guns and ammunition under stratospheric conditions.

The Parker Pen Company, in its fifty-ninth annual statement to stockholders, reported yesterday onsolidated net earnings of $3,637,683 after taxes and all charges, for the fiscal year ended on Feb. 29. This is equal to $9.77 a share on 372,400 shares and compares with $4,173,974 or $11.03 each on 378,400 capital shares, for the previous fiscal year.

ST. LOUIS, May 17 (AP) -- To the surprise of some competitors, the stymie has been added to the natural hazards of the Norwood Hills Country Club for the Professional Golfers Association's thirtieth annual championship starting on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Railroad contract discussions will be resumed here tomorrow in an effort to settle the dispute which led to Government seizure of the nation's carriers and a court injunction against a strike on May 11.

American women, whose cry formerly was "the sheerer the better," are now weighing extreme sheerness against potential longevity and, with an eye on their pocketbooks, demanding heavier and more serviceable hosiery.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 17 -Joseph W. Martin Jr., Speaker of the House, said today he was "not interested" in being Vice President. He continued, however, to leave the door open to a call for the Presidency.

VIENNA, May 17 -- The Russian guard at the Danube River bridge of Enns between the United States and Soviet zones of Austria this afternoon surrounded the car of Lieut. Col. Roderick Carmichael and removed Baroness Gertrude von Trotha, secretary to the deputy director of the United States Information Service branch here.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 17 --- In the first of its answers to $198,000,000 in damage suits filed against it as a result of the Texas City disaster of April 16-17, 1947 the Federal Government here today denied negligence in the disaster.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., May 19 -- The prospective development of television within the next five years may call for Hollywood to triple or quadruple its output of motion pictures.

Eleven persons, including a blind man and a 10-year-old boy, facing eviction because a rooming house operator had gone out of business, won the sympathy yesterday of the City Rent Commission. A commission spokesman said it was considering a Supreme Court suit to stay their eviction from a threestory rooming house at 57 West Ninetieth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- A White House announcement that arms shipment to the Middle East was under study prompted a series of Senate speeches today in which the preponderance of sentiment favored support for the Jewish state.

GREAT NECK, L. I., May 17 -St. John's University gained its sixth Metropolitan Collegiate Conference victory today, turning back the United States Merchant Marine Academy nine, 3 to 0, in a game called in the fifth inning because of a thunderstorm.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade today, breaking early only to have wheat and corn rally strongly in the late trading, wheat rising 1/4 cent to 1 1/2 cents a bushel and corn 3/4 cent to 1 1/8 cents. Oats were heavy the greater part of the day and finished 1/8 to 1 1/2 cents lower.

Presenting products so attractively that the consumer won't be able to resist them is an aim of the packaging industry. Appearance isn't all it considers, however. Its experts are trying to win the housewife's favor by providing containers that are easier to use and increase the keeping quality of what is inside.
MOSCOW, May 17 (AP) -- The Soviet Government, announcing tonight its recognition of the State of Israel, made public the text of Mr. Shertok's message, dated May 15, as follows:

PORTLAND, Ore., May 17 -Harold E. Stassen invited Gov. Thomas E. Dewey tonight to support the Mundt-Nixon Bill dealing with Communist activities and said such a pledge of "unequivocal support" would satisfy him that the two rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination were in agreement on outlawing the Communist party.

Under a smoky riverfront haze the Army secured a beachhead yesterday -- by prearrangement -- at Wall Street and the East River and quickly landed simulated invasion supplies. The operation was accomplished with an Army freight supply vessel, two amphibious ducks (officially spelled DUKW, the manufacturer's code letters), a boatload of "brass," and reporters and photographers, in full view of indolent tugboat and steamship crews.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 17 (AP) -- A spokesman for Lipsett, Inc., told The Jamestown Post Journal today that the company is about to start what he called the largest salvage job in history -- the clearing of war supplies from the Marianas.

The United States Treasury issued a further call in its War Loan Accounts with the Class B banks, yesterday, the second within the last few days. Under its terms, the banks will be required to provide 10 per cent of the balances as of the close of business on May 14, with half payable on May 21, and the remainder on May 24.
JERUSALEM, May 16 (Delayed) -- Arab artillery shells fell today in the heart of Jerusalem, now virtually entirely in the hands of the army of Israel after fifty-one hours of furious street fighting.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 17 -- The Palestine Commission, symbol of a futile United Nations effort to effect the peaceful partition of the Holy Land, passed into limbo today after four months' work during which it never left Lake Success.
JERUSALEI~, May 17--Arabs I ~trongly attacked the Jewish quarIter in the Old City today, and areI believed to have improved theirl position in the central parts of the city.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Four Democratic members of the old Senate War Investigating Committee issued today a revised and softened report omitting all direct criticism of Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine, its chairman, in the Howard Hughes investigation.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The International Wheat Agreement was opposed as economically unworkable and governmentally bureaucratic before a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee today by spokesmen for the grain trade, feed manufacturers and millers.

RAMALLAH, Palestine, May 17 -- Neve Yaakov was occupied at dawn today by the Arab "Liberation Army" after it had been evacuated by the Haganah. Ac cording to Arab leaders, this leaves completely open the road into the Arab section of Jerusalem except for the Sheikh Jarrah quarter, on the northern edge of the city, which is held by the Haganah and is a naturally strong position.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- A good American citizen must be deeply concerned with world affairs, speakers attending the third national conference on citizenship stressed here today.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- Swift Company representatives, meeting with Federal conciliators, offered three conditions today for settlement of the two-months-old strike of 100,000 members of the United Packinghouse Workers, CIO.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 17 (AP) -Arab dispatches said today that Arab armies had penetrated northeastern Palestine in an operation that could determine control of that fertile region. The area is claimed by Israel.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 18 -- With the United States and the Soviet Union both urging speed, the United Nations Security Council finally reached agreement tonight on questionnaires to be sent to Jews and Arabs regarding the fighting in Palestine.

NEW DELHI, India, May 18 (AP) -- India expects to have a 2,000,000-ton merchant fleet plying the oceans of the world by 1955. cutta operate between India and Ministry official, concedes that the goal is a big one. He says that India hopes to attain it by purchasing ships from foreign governments and by building some of her own.

Mrs. Emory J. Barnes was elected president of the Women's City Club of New York last night at its thirty-second annual meeting at the New Weston Hotel. She succeeds Miss Florence M. Kelley, an attorney, who has been president since 1946.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Proposals to modify or kill the Mundt-Nixon Communist-control bill were rejected by the House today in a noisy demonstration of its determination to pass the measure without any weakening amendments.

SCARBOROUGH, England, May 18 -- If British big business does not voluntarily curb its profits during the next year, Hugh Dalton, former Chancellor of the Exchequer, warned today, its enterprises may be listed for nationalization by the Labor Government.

President Truman was called upon by the City Council yesterday to lift the arms embargo on Palestine, to seek the immediate admission of the new State of Israel as a member of the United Nations and to do all in his power to bring an end to fighting in Palestine.

In an editorial recently, titled "Death by Violence," several quotations from the Travelers' traffic study were coupled with other comments in leading up to a final clause stating that defects "support strongly the current movement toward compulsory periodic inspection."
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Justice T. Alan Goldsborough of the Federal District Court tonight extended until May 29 the restraining order which headed off a scheduled railroad strike last week.
St. John's University gained a second-place tie with Fordham in the Metropolitan Baseball Conference by downing City College, 4 -- 0, yesterday at Dexter Park.

A catastrophe unit, to be administered by the New York Hospital, is being organized, Dr. Stanhope Bayne-Jones, president of the Joint Administrative Board of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, announecd yesterday afternoon at Charter Day exercises held by the Society of New York Hospital in the lounge of the Nurses' Residence, 1320 York Avenue.

A new easy chair designed to replace the "dreadnaught" overstuffed armchair was the principal exhibit of a new collection of furniture presented yesterday by Knoll Associates, 601 Madison Avenue. New designs together with other current items in the line were exhibited in freshly decorated backgrounds suggesting home interiors.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 18 (AP) -- Stockholders of American Airlines, Inc., were told today at their annual meeting here by C.R. Smith, chairman, that completion in early 1949 of deliveries on the line's order for seventy-five Convair Flagships "will give us a five-mile-a-minute passenger fleet."

ATHENS, May 18 -- Constantin Rentis, Minister of Public Order, announced tonight that eight of the nine persons suspected of taking part in the murder of Justice Minister Christos Ladas on May 1 had been arrested.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- A camera in which moving photographic film or paper is completely developed four seconds after exposure was demonstrated here yesterday by the Beck-Lee Corporation, makers of medical instruments.

PEIPING, May 18 -- Yenching University and the neighboring suburb of Haitien were placed under martial law tonight when Communists were reported to have attacked within three miles of Peiping's main airport. The university and the suburbs are east of the airfield but northwest of the Peiping City Wall.

Representatives of all phases of industry were among the 486 passengers aboard the excursion steamer Sandy Hook yesterday as the Port of New York Authority marked World Port Day with a complete tour of New York Harbor, from the lower industrial areas of the North and East Rivers to the Narrows and the Port of Newark.

The American Academy of Arts and Letters announces that museums in twenty states are this year's recipients of thirty-two oils, water-colors and drawings purchased under the terms of the late Childe Hassam's will. Beginning next Sunday and for a period of six weeks thereafter they will be on display in the galleries of the Academy, Broadway between 156th and 157th Streets.

One of the biggest bon voyage parties reported for the year crowded Pier 84 at West Forty-fourth Street yesterday, contributing to congestion that resulted in delaying the Italian-flag liner Vulcania for an hour.

A small, 3-year-old mongrel, with a great deal of Boston terrier in its makeup, more frightened than the passengers it terrified in two subway cars, caused an eight-car train on the IRT elevated line in Queens yesterday to be taken out of service.

Th executors of the estate of Harriet Hart White sold the plot 100 by 121 feet at the northeast corner of Montague Street and Pierrepont Place in Brooklyn, to Bayview Towers, Inc. The property is assessed at $116,000. Prudent Management, Inc., was the broker and the title was insured by the Lawyers Title Corporation.

Dwight P. Griswold, chief of the United States mission for aid to Greece, arrived at La Guardia field from Greece aboard the Trans World Airline Constellation "Star of Dublin," at 7:35 o'clock last evening.

LONDON, May 18 -- The Soviet news agency Tass stamped "made in Russia" tonight on three more inventions generally credited to the West. They were the steel girder, steel cylindrical arches in buildings and the metal towers that replaced masts on modern warships.
GENEVA, May 18 -- Politicians do not understand that the world is facing a great catastrophe unless the long-run food shortage is solved, Sir John Boyd Orr said here today.

NANKING, May 18 -- Driving down in force from southwestern Honan, Communist troops under Gen. Liu Po-cheng have captured Laohokow, major port on the Han River in Hupeh Province, the Defense Ministry announced tonight.

LONDON, May 18 -- Strength in Wall Street plus renewed talk that the pound sterling may be devalued, brought sharp upward adjustments in dollar stocks in the stock market here today. Gains ranged up to six points but jobbers said that British holders were not selling despite big premiums represented by present London prices.
Two Army chaplains assisted yesterday afternoon in rescuing from drowning a woman who either fell or jumped from a Staten Island ferryboat 200 feet off Castle William at Governors Island.
DETROIT, May 18 -- An overnight change in strategy by the United Automobile Workers, CIO, brought peace today to the picket lines here.

DETROIT, May 18 (AP) -- The Tigers exploded for ten runs in two big innings today and racked up a 10-to-7 victory over the Red Sox in the opener of a two-game series. It was only the second triumph for Detroit in nine starts at home.
HARTFORD, Conn., May 18 -- "Decentralization" of music and music criticism was advocated here today at a two-day symposium opened by New England music critics.

GENEVA, May 18 -- The absence of a regime in Palestine that has been generally recognized by the United Nations has forced the International Refugee Organization to suspend the sponsorship of refugee movements to that area, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Republican majority of the Joint Economic Committee indicted the Administration today for the "tremendous impact of Government spending" in nurturing inflation.

LONDON, May 18 (AP) -- Denmark's teen-age tennis team joined the squads of seven other nations today in the quarter-finals of the European Zone Davis Cup eliminations. The round of eight was completed when Denmark ousted Ireland, three matches to two, in the last second-round series at Dublin.

On April 29 the House of Representatives drastically slashed the appropriations request of the Social Security Administration for next year. In short, Commissioner Altmeyer's immediate staff is cut by two-thirds, his public information and research staffs by more than half, and the sum needed for grants to states for United States Employment Service and unemployment insurance are reduced by $22 million.

HATTERAS, N.C., May 18 -- If skates and rays were selling at a dollar each, Lee Wulff and the writer could have paid a large deposit on a wide stretch of Buxton shore property yesterday, but with the wind blowing as it was the property probably would have moved in the direction of Nags Head.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 18 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey declared today that big government was here to stay, but warned that the nation could no longer afford "to leave it in the hands of little men."

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The America Psychiatric Association was called on today by Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of The Journal of The American Medical Association, to take action to combat the large number of "psychiatric quacks" now "swindling" the people of the nation out of millions of dollars annually.

NEWARK, N. J., May 18 -- Paul Windels, president of the Regional Plan Association, in a series of sweeping proposals, called today on New York, New Jersey and Connecticut officials to develop a long range, coordinated plan to avert a continuing "disorganized sprawl" in the growth of the Metropolitan area.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 18 -- Connecticut Republicans resolved all party differences on the surface today by choosing nineteen nattional convention delegates who will back Senator Raymond E. Baldwin for President.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 18 -- The Right Rev. James P. De Wolfe, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, called on the church today to meet the challenge of communism. He addressed the annual diocesan convention here.
PHILADELPHIA, May 18 (AP) -- The Phillies handed Chicago three unearned runs today and the Cubs took the first game of the series, 3 -- 2, behind the six-hit hurling of Southpaw Johnny Schmitz.

Consolidated net income of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company and its subsidiaries amounted to $13,069,818 after all charges except depreciation for the three months ended on March 31, according to the report released today.

G.T. Baker, president of National Airlines, refused yesterday to re-employ pilots who went on strike on Feb. 3 except as vacancies occur. Mr. Baker and other company officials met yesterday morning in Miami with representatives of the striking pilots, who are members of the Airline Pilots Association, AFL, after President Truman had appointed an emergency hoard in the dispute.

International competition for the Prentice Cup between combined Oxford-Cambridge and Harvard-Yale teams will be renewed this year, marking the restoration of one more of the outstanding tennis fixtures interrupted by the war.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- A dramatic collapse of the joint bituminous coal wage conference a few hours after the opening session today was narrowly averted by a decision to recess until 10 A.M. tomorrow. The agreement expires on June 30.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The House Rules Committee, which has blocked the universal military training program from floor consideration for nearly ten months, was urged by the majority of the armed services committee today to permit a two-year revival of the draft to go to a voting showdown in its place.

Marketing groups have been called on to consider adoption of a "code of professional practices" together with a set of survey-reporting standards for research organizations, it was announced yesterday by Donald E. West, 1947 president of the American Marketing Association's New York chapter.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration will supply American know-how as well as financing and equipment in helping Western Europe modernize its industrial production methods, Administrator Paul G. Hoffman said today.

All good things have a habit of ending sometime, and the Theatre Guild's "Oklahoma!" is no exception. On May 29 Broadway's longest-run musical will give its 2,202d and final performance at the St. James, where it has been entertaining theatregoers -- young and old -- since March 31, 1943.

The Dodgers used only one of their seven remaining able-bodied pitchers at Ebbets Field yesterday, but they still couldn't win. The Cardinals beat 'em, 4 -- 3, with a terrific two-run homer by Country Slaughter.

MEDFORD, Ore., May 18 -- Harold E. Stassen charged tonight that rival candidates had united forces in a "tremendous" campaign to try to stop him in Oregon in his drive for the Republican Presidential nomination.

CHICAGO, May 18 (AP) -- Witnesses in a damage suit threw a brief glimmer of light today on the shadowy steel "gray market" and brought a Federal judge's plea to the steel industry to "clean its own houses."

Acceptance of a new code of standards by the membership of the National Association of Broadcasters, meeting in convention in Los Angeles, must be viewed with mixed emotions. As a gesture toward self-regulation and self-improvement, it can be welcomed as a step far preferable to further government regulation of radio programming.

A grateful reply by President-elect Lincoln, written in acknowledgment of aid proffered by Gen. John E. Wool two days after the first shots were fired in Charleston Harbor in a pre-civil war skirmish, was sold at auction yesterday for $1,450.

CLEVELAND, May 18 -- A group of Kaiser-Frazer automobile dealers from Northeast Ohio denied today that cars were "backing-up" in their showrooms. They told a Securities and Exchange Commission board of inquiry that the demand was so great they had a difficult time getting enough cars.

The brakes were applied quite forcefully yesterday to the two-month-old bull market in shares on the New York Stock Exchange. Theoretical considerations were outweighed by the practical urge to take profits, which produced a slump in prices comparable to that of April 26 and the widest since Feb. 11.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's inter-club matches were completed in the Long Island district yesterday with the Creek team of Mrs. J.B. Balding, Mrs. A.K. Atkinson Jr., Mrs. Caryl H. Sayre, Mrs. V.D. Crisp and Mrs. Longstreet Hinton winning top honors.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- Organized labor's fight against the non-Communist affidavit requirement of the Taft-Hartley law reached the Supreme Court today.

First details of shipments of steel mill equipment for Europe, now at an all-time high of more than $65,000,000 for five countries, were revealed here yesterday by Charles Muchnic, a director and consultant for United Engineering and Foundry Company, Pittsburgh.

An underwriting group headed by Morgan Stanley Co. and Dominick Dominick will offer to investors today a new issue of 50,000 shares of the Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company's 4.20 per cent, $100 par value, cumulative preferred stock at $102.50 a share.

A banking group headed by Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association won the award yesterday at competitive sale of a new issue of $9,000,000 of bonds of San Jose Unified School District, Santa Clara County, Calif., at an interest cost of 1.813 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- A board of inquiry reported to President Truman today, at the end of a sixty-day cooling off period, that a deadlock persisted in the labor dispute at the atomic-energy plant at Oak Ridge, Tenn.
The annual field day of Hunter College was celebrated yesterday on the Bronx campus of the institution with ball games, gymnastic drills and folk dancing.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) --The Supreme Court refused today by a vote of 4 to 4 to review the cases of seventy-four German war prisoners convicted by an international court at Dachau of complicity in the massacre of unarmed American prisoners during the Battle of the Bulge.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Republicans will have to curtail hearings on ideas for the 1948 platform or seek a resolutions committee chairman from outside the party's top Congressional leadership, it was indicated today.

The steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral looked like a terraced garden yesterday for the fifteenth annual flower mart of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association. Nearly 6,000 spring blooms donated by passers-by local florists attracted paassers-by by the hundreds, and fifty young women serving as volunteer venders were kept busy replenishing their baskets and carts with fresh supplies of roses, lilacs, tulips and other cut flowers.

Television is not yet ready to transform the motion picture industry but it will shortly affect film shorts and commercials, Richard de Rochemont, producer of "The March of Time," declared here yesterday. He spoke at the final season luncheon of the Advertising Women of New York, held at the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- President Truman invoked the emergency powers of the Taft-Hartley law today to head off a threatened nation-wide strike of long lines telephone workers. He declared that a strike or lockout would "imperil national health and safety."

The Board of Education was ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred V. Norton in Brooklyn to approve the nomination of Lucien Lamm, first assistant of the Department of Social Studies at the Bronx High School of Science, to the Board of Examiners of the Board of Education. The post pays $12,000 annually.

ST. LOUIS, May 18 -- Johnny Lindell had a miserable time of it in sun-flooded right field at Sportsman's Park today as Allie Reynolds and the Yankees went crashing to defeat before the Browns, 6 to 5.

SEOUL KOREA, Wednesday, May 19 -- The Soviet-controlled North Korea radio last night broadcast a statement by Kim Tchaik, vice chairman of the North Korea Peoples Committee, declaring that the power supply for South Korea from the Soviet zone would continue to be cut off "until the American authorities change their usual attitude."

Two men, one of whom served from 1942 to 1947 as an assistant to the local regional director of the Federal Housing Administration, were arraigned yesterday in Special Sessions and charged with extorting a $4,000 bonus for a professional apartment lease in Stuyvesant Town.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Senate Republicans pushing the so-called civil-rights program have abandoned all but the faintest hope that the anti-lynching bill in its present form can be passed at this session of Congress.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 18 -- Following are excerpts from a statement concerning the United States recognition of the State of Israel, presented to the United Nations Security Council by Warren R. Austin:

One robber was shot dead and another seriously wounded early yesterday morning by the police when, with four other men, the thugs tried to open a safe that contained only $5. Ordinarily, the safe held no money.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,751, compared with 1,121 last week and 1,624 in the similar week of 1947, according to listings appearings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,015 arrivals yesterday against 537 last Tuesday.

Stalin's reply to the open letter of Henry Wallace should remove the last doubt that we are in the climactic stage of a great political war. When the head of the Soviet Government goes on the air to back the Wallace "peace campaign" he demonstrates that the American election is a factor of major importance in Russian calculations.

KANSAS CITY, May 18 (AP) -- Don Faurot, University of Missouri athletic director and football coach, today revived the issue of football recruiting by accusing several schools from other states of going after Missouri high school athletes.

NEWARK, N.J., May 18 -- Construction work of the $10,000,000 veterans housing project at Ivy Hill was about 25 per cent of normal today, Arthur H. Padula, the builder, said after his announcement that the project would be completed under open shop conditions.
CHENGTU, China, May 17 (Delayed) -- A determined bid to get a share of American aid to China is being planned by the Szechwan provincial government.

Possible return to service of the Furness Bermuda Line's "Queen" late this year is expected to greatly stimulate the island's resort trade and produce increased advertising and promotion activities, it was learned yesterday. It was also reported that a new slant on some Bermuda advertising will suggest that vacation trips to the island offer attractions equal to more expensive trips to Europe.
Created board of inquiry to investigate the threatened strike of long-lines telephone workers.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 18 -- The Montclair Antiques Show opened this afternoon at the Montclair Athletic Club, 203 Valley Road. Called the largest spring exhibition in New Jersey, the show may be visited from 1 to 10:30 P.M. daily through Friday.
LONDON, May 18 -- The State Department's action was expected here. The presumption was that the British Foreign Office approved of the United States' stand, although no official comment was made.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 18 -- Egyptian planes, performing acrobatics before their dive attacks, today bombed and strafed a civilian bus station in this city.

Rearmament, the Economic Cooperation Administration's demands on domestic production and generally increased power loads may extend the utility industry's five-year $6,000,000,000 expansion program ten years beyond 1951, Philip Sporn, president of the American Gas and Electric Company, said yesterday.

The announcement that tests of three "improved" atomic weapons, not otherwise identified, were made at Eniwetok Atoll in the Pacific confirms the hints that have been dropped in hearings held by Congressional committees and in the cautiously worded addresses of public officials in high places.

HONOLULU, May 18 -- Recent atomic tests at Eniwetok involved a series of nuclear explosions carried out under conditions as close to laboratory control as possible. Their basic purpose was the scientific and engineering perfection of improved designs in atomic weapons.

Directors of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation yesterday authorized immediate filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission of a plan for consolidation of the Buffalo Niagara Electric Corporation, the Central New York Power Corporation and the New York Power and Light Corporation, in accordance with the terms and conditions specified by the Public Service Commission in its memorandum of May 5.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 18 -- The supply of new cars is dwindling so rapidly below the level of a year ago as to approach a famine, Verne L. Murray, president of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York, declared here today. He urged care of vehicles now in service regardless of age, with stress on safety.
CHICAGO, May 18 (AP) -- The Senators opened their first Western invasion with a 5-4 victory in twelve innings over the White Sox today. It ended a four-game Washington losing streak.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The United States rejected today as a basis of bilateral negotiation the points suggested by Prime Minister Stalin as a "good and fruitful basis" for discussion and settlement of the differences between this Government and the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Trans-continental Western Air, Inc., today asked the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a loan of $10,000,000. The line stated that it is unable to meet a payment of $1,100,000 due on $40,000,000 of primary indebtedness on May 28.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 18 -- A jury in Westchester County Court here filed a verdict this evening finding James A. Sullivan, political figure in Yonkers for twenty-four years, guilty of three felonies pertaining to forgery. The verdict could result in a maximum penalty of twenty-seven years' imprisonment.
Bobby Thomson, strictly a pull hitter, made a "wrong field" double last night that was as telling a blow as any he ever has struck for the Giants.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 -- More than two years will be required to fill the orders now on automobile dealers' books, it was declared here today by M. E. Coyle, executive vice president of the General Motors Corporation. He spoke at the fourth annual dinner of the Philadelphia Chapter of the American Marketing Association in the Warwick Hotel, where he received the 1948 Parlin Award.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 18 -- Henry A. Wallace, Presidential candidate of the Independent Progressive party, renewed a demand today for direct American negotiations with Russia.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 18 -- Amid tumultuous cheers from representatives of 86,000 unionized civil service workers, a ranking official of the Congress of Industrial Organizations challenged here today the charge of Philip Murray, national CIO president, that the national third party movement had been brought into being by the Communist party.

Hallan M. Richardson, attorney, who is seeking a complaint charging criminal libel against the Rev. Henry A. Atkinson, chairman of the advisory committee of the Nonsectarian Anti-Nazi League, conceded in court yesterday that he had written the foreword for a pamphlet by a man whom he described as "an anti-Semite, a Fascist, pro-Nazi and pro-Hitler."

JERUSALEM, May 17 (Delayed) -- Consular officials of nearly every Christian nation represented here strove desperately today to arrange a truce before the historic churches, mosques and synagogues within the ancient walls of the Holy City are destroyed.

The North American Company's plan to set up a new utility holding company system is being opposed by the trustees of the Central States Electric Corporation and by the latter's subsidiaries, the American Cities Power and Light Corporation and the Blue Ridge Corporation, it was disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Despite all that is being said and done against it, the United Nations is going to work for peace, President Truman asserted today.

Reiterating an earlier prediction that he will knock out the challenger in their scheduled fifteen-round title fight at Yankee Stadium June 23, heavyweight champion Joe Louis arrived yesterday morning from Bloomingdale, Mich., to open the final stage of training for his battle with Jersey Joe Walcott.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 18 (AP) -- Members of the International Typographical Union, AFL, will vote tomorrow on seventeen officers of the union.

CLEVELAND, May 18 -- Latin-American countries have exhausted credit worth $4,500,000,000 in American banks since the end of the war, it was revealed today at a meeting of the foreign trade panel of the National Association of Credit Men.

BERLIN, May 18 -- The United States' rearmament, and especially the recent atomic weapon tests at Eniwetok atoll, as well as certain infirmities in the Russian economy, have motivated the Soviet Union's temporary adoption of an apparently conciliatory attitude toward the settlement of problems besetting the two powers.

The House of Delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York adopted yesterday without a dissenting vote a resolution urging a change in the constitution of the American Medical Association designed to prohibit county medical societies throughout the country from excluding Negro physicians from membership.

CAIRO, May 18 (Reuters) -- Egyptian military forces in Palestine today carried out several reconnaissance patrols with "deep penetrations into areas held by the enemy," an Egyptian communique stated tonight.

Taking advantage of what is in effect an appeal by Henry A. Wallace for aid in an American Presidential campaign, Premier Stalin has now brought off a double-barreled propaganda maneuver of so many implications that it will require careful scrutiny to measure both the hope it may hold for peace and the danger it may pose for the democracies in general and the United States in particular.

BERLIN, May 18 -- Wilhelm Pieck, aging leader of German communism, today called on the German people to "fight for unity" and assailed the Frankfort celebration as a step toward the division of the country.

Committee leaders have completed arrangements for "Salute to Summer," a tea and cocktail party with music and other incidental divertissements, which will be presented on May 26 at the Savoy-Plaza to advance the expansion program of the Memorial Hospital Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases.

A bill now with the Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce of the House of Representatives proposes that the $10,000-a-year salaries of top administrators of the Securities and Exchange Commission be raised to $15,000 a year.

In the minds of the American people during this last half century the school has taken the place of the frontier and has come to be the great open road to opportunity, Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, declared last night.

Edward Otto, sports promoter of Newark, N. J., has awarded the general contract for his half-million dollar stadium on Route 17, opposite the Paramus Skating Rink, in Paramus, N. J., to Samuel Braen, Inc., of Wyckoff. The 10,000-seat arena is scheduled for completion late in June.

The right of the City Rent Commission to refuse to issue eviction certificates to landlords on the sole ground that they want the premises for their own occupancy has been upheld by the Appellate Division in three decisions overruling the Supreme Court in Brooklyn, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, May 18 -- Britain will not withdraw British officers, the monetary subsidy or the supply of arms to Trans-Jordan's Arab Legion unless the United Nations decides that the Arabs are acting illegally, a Foreign Office spokesman said tonight.

John J. Swan, who is retiring June 30 as Controller of Barnard College, was honored for his twenty years of service to the school in a special ceremony yesterday morning in Milbank Hall, 117th Street and Broadway.

ON April 20 [1940] I had procured agreement to the appointment of Lord Cork as sole commander of the Naval, Military, and Air Forces in the Narvik area thus bringing General Mackesy directly under his authority. There was never any doubt of Lord Cork's vigorously offensive spirit. He realised acutely the danger of delay; but the physical and administrative difficulties were far greater on the spot than we could measure at home.

The development of "a universal sports program" might lead to the solution of "the problem of war," Branch Rickey, president of the Brooklyn National League Baseball Club, declared yesterday in outlining proposals for curtailing juvenile delinquency.

A room for a 4-year-old daughter should be gay enough to match an elfin personality, but the basic furniture must have charm and grace to suit her as she reaches her teens. With this in mind, decorator Ormond Butler Riblet combined bright paint and wallpaper in his daughter's room with furniture that is similar in design to pieces in the master bedroom.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- In the fifteen years since Maxim Litvinov came to this country to negotiate the recognition of the Soviet Union, the United States and the U.S.S.R. have been parties to about twenty major agreements.

Making the second start of her career. Frank Frankel's Fond Embrace stamped herself as a bargain filly yesterday when she scampered home the winner in the fiftieth running of the $10,000 added Fashion Stakes at Belmont Park.
BOSTON, May 18 (AP) -- The Pirates tonight snapped right handed Bill Voiselle's string of pitching victories at four by beating the Braves, 4 -- 3, before 19,181 fans.

ST. LOUIS, May 18 -- With practice rounds completed, a field of 144 is ready to start tomorrow on the first lap of the thirty-six-hole qualifying test of the thirtieth annual Professional Golfers Association championship. The tournament will be held over the Norwood Hills Country Club's west course.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 18 -- Fighting in Jerusalem is increasing in intensity, according to two communications from the French consul there. The dispatches were read today to the Security Council by its president, Alexandre Parodi of France.

Anticipating that Congress would enact legislation admitting displaced persons from Europe soon, an official committee named by Governor Dewey began preparations yesterday to absorb "at least 10 per cent of the national quota" into New York State.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 18 (AP) --Hearth Mouse, racing for H. Hessey Miller, scored a surprise victory in the feature at Garden State Park today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 18 -- The United States Embassy requested the Yugoslav Foreign Ministry tonight to correct publicly repeated attempts by the press to link embassy officials with subversive elements and war criminals.

Considerable imagination was expressed in the Brigance sportswear collection, which was previewed by the press yesterday morning, on Lord Taylor's fifth floor. Brigance "does things" with fabrics. If he combines a bold plaid and a plain material he tucks the solid color to suggest the pattern of the lined one.

NEW ORLEANS, May 18 (AP) -- William T. Burton, oil man, and two others were convicted in the Federal Court he today on charges of conspiring to influence a Federal jury. Former Gov. James A. Noe was acquitted of the same charge.

Two new films will open in first- run theatres this morning. At the Paramount the attraction is "The Sainted Sisters," a romantic comedy produced by Paramount and starring Veronica Lake and Joan Caulfield in the title roles, with Barry Fitzgerald. William Demarest, George Reeves, Beulah Bondi and Chill Wills featured.
BERLIN, May 18 -- A poll of its readers' opinions on how long the Western Allies will remain in this city has proved a disappointment to the Soviet-licensed newspaper Nachtexpress.

Spyros P. Skouras, who was re-elected president of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation at yesterday's annual meeting, informed stockholders that second quarter earnings are expected to be better than those in the first quarter as a result of economies in producing pictures, estimating them at about $1.25 a common share.

The Health Insurance Plan of New York is now making payments to the medical community at the annual rate of $2,373,938, it was reported yesterday at the third annual meeting of the plan's board of directors and corporation members at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Under the influence of July liquidation the cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange broke yesterday to losses of 22 to 56 points.

EDDIE DYER stood on the dugout steps at Ebbets Field yesterday watching appreciatively as Stan Musial stepped into the batting practice cage and caromed one off the scoreboard. There was a dull thud as the ball collided with the fence and it seemed as though he'd touched off some hidden spring. Instantly the heavens opened and rain pattered down.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 18 -- The ritualistic exercises commemorating the 100th anniversary of the first German National Assembly were dramatized unexpectedly today.

The Most Rev. Theophilus, Archbishop of San Francisco and Metropolitan of the Russian Orthodox Greek Catholic Church of North America, was honored by religious and civic ceremonies last night on the completion of fifty years in the church since his ordination as a deacon.
A Board of Education proposal to establish uniform entrance requirements for New York's four municipal colleges will be presented this fall to the Board of Higher Education, it was learned yesterday.

A woman was made unconscious and a man cut by flying glass yesterday when a large stone was hurled through a window of a southbound New York Central Railroad commuter train, Harlem Division, at 168th Street and Park Avenue.

The Communist party's request yesterday for free radio time in which to reply to views brought up in the debate Monday night between Harold E. Stassen and Governor Dewey received a prompt consent from the Mutual Broadcasting System.

Mrs. Will Irwin has sold the house at 240 West Eleventh Street to Mrs. Jeanne A. Reynal for occupancy. The Irwins bought the home in 1921 and occupied it for about a quarter of a century. Frances Spencer, Inc., negotiated the sale.
TEL AVIV, May 18 (UP) -- The infant state of Israel won its first major victory over the Arabs today when ancient Acre on the north coast surrendered to the Haganah storm troops.

The Rev. Dr. Julius Mark, rabbi of Vine Street Temple, Nashville, Tenn., has been recommended for election as senior rabbi of Congregation Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, by unanimous vote of the board of trustees, it was announced yesterday.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, May 18 -- The Arab Legion of Trans-Jordan has occupied part of the Jewish Quarter of Jerusalem's Old City and moved artillery into position to shell other Jewish sections, it was announced officially tonight.

Mrs. Will Irwin has sold the house at 240 West Eleventh Street to Mrs. Jeanne A. Reynal for occupancy. The Irwins bought the home in 1921 and occupied it for about a quarter of a century. Frances Spencer, Inc., negotiated the sale.
TEL AVIV, May 18 (UP) -- The infant state of Israel won its first major victory over the Arabs today when ancient Acre on the north coast surrendered to the Haganah storm troops.

The Rev. Dr. Julius Mark, rabbi of Vine Street Temple, Nashville, Tenn., has been recommended for election as senior rabbi of Congregation Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, by unanimous vote of the board of trustees, it was announced yesterday.

Every trade unionist must "plunge wholeheartedly into the political fight this year" if the "most drastic wave of reaction against unionism ever experienced in this country" is to be counteracted, 200 delegates to the thirty-sixth annual convention of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers were told yesterday.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, May 18 -- The Arab Legion of Trans-Jordan has occupied part of the Jewish Quarter of Jerusalem's Old City and moved artillery into position to shell other Jewish sections, it was announced officially tonight.

Business executives who gave up leisure hours during the last year to act as volunteer advisers to high school juniors and seniors running model production companies to learn how capitalism works were honored last night at Achievement Day dinners in fifteen cities of the country.

GENEVA, May 18 -- Air transport of refugees from Germany to Canada will begin this month, reach a monthly rate of 1,400 persons by mid-July and a total of about 17,500 in the first year, the International Refugee Organization announced today.

Sales of homes and building sites in Plantation Estates, the former Count de Bary place near Sanford, Fla., are being made to many persons in the New York area, according to Frederick L. Spiro, president of Plantation Estates, Inc., with offices here.

OTTAWA, May 18 -- Following his declared policy of reducing the national debt, preparing for emergencies and checking inflationary tendencies, Douglas C. Abbott, Canadian Finance Minister, presented in Parliament this evening his 1948 budget which gives little or no taxation reduction but provides for an estimated surplus of $489,000,080.

Adolf A. Berle, chairman of the Liberal party, and Louis Waldman, general counsel of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union, AFL, supported yesterday the objectives of the Mundt bill, requiring the Communist party to register and make public its membership lists.

Vaudeville shows patterned after the bills that once enlivened New York's Palace Theatre will be recalled from the past in the "Texaco Star Theatre" on NBC's television network, beginning Tuesday, June 8, from 8 to 9 P.M. From seven to ten acts are to be presented during each of the weekly performances, which will be carried here by WNBT.

KEARNY, N.J., May 18 -- The police today listed ten men dead and two injured in a fire that struck the plant here of the tar products division of the Koppers Company at 11:27 o'clock last night. In an estimate given to the police, company officials set the damage to the plant and its contents at $150,000.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo told the National Press Club today that another world freedom of information conference might increase the flow of news from behind the Russian "iron curtain."

A series of "arrangements," involving two-party endorsements of candidates for several judicial posts, is being discussed by the principal leaders of the Democratic, Republican and American Labor parties in the areas involved, it was reported yesterday.

New York is a stage on which the scene-shifters are on the job -- and often in as plain view as the Chinese property man -- even while the play goes on and the stage is crowded with actors. But the actors are absorbed their own stage business.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 18 -- Jack W. Kenney, director of services of the National Retail Furniture Association, today urged furniture merchants to reposses merchandise promptly if credit purchasers fail to settle delinquent accounts after repeated notices.

This city dweller went out to Westchester yesterday to see how that county's largest department store, Howard Ware's, is supplying householders not only with frozen foods but with freezers in which to store them. She came back full of envy for Westchester housewives, who have available to them one of the biggest assortments of frozen products in the country.

Complacency by both manufacturer and retailer, plus the high Federal excise tax, were blamed yesterday for failure of the toiletries industry to increase sales volume under what were described as ideal conditions.

WITH THE ARAB LEGION, Attacking Jerusalem, May 19 (UP) -- The Arab Legion opened a two-pronged attack at 4 A.M. from the Mount of Olives on the eastern side of Jerusalem and above the Sheikh Jarrah section on the northern side.

THE many disappointments and disasters of the brief campaigns in Norway caused profound perturbation at home, and the currents of passion mounted even in the breasts of some of those who had been most slothful and purblind in the years before the war. The Opposition asked for a debate on the war situation, and this was arranged for May 7 [1940].

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 19 -- With Congress considering legislation to bar from Federal employment members of organizations whose officers refused to sign non-Communist affidavits, the United Public Workers, CIO, prepared tonight to cut down its roster of officers and thus ease the way for signing the oaths if such action becomes necessary to protect the union's membership.

A large parcel near the site of the proposed new Madison Square Garden changed hands for the first time in sixty years when Nathan Wilson bought five five-story store and apartment buildings on a plot 125 by 100 feet at 745 to 753 Ninth Avenue, between Fiftieth and Fifty-first Streets, from the estate of Andrew Ewald.

Reflecting a larger sales volume, the net profit of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and its subsidiaries increased to $10,415,705 in the March quarter this year from $7,929,845 earned in the corresponding three months of 1947, Robert C. Stanley, chairman and president, reported yesterday.

Your excellent reporting of the National Health Assembly just concluded in Washington hardly emphasized enough the fact that the high costs of sickness are now everybody's business -- laymen and physicians alike. At that meeting, over 600 representatives of the medical and allied professions, and of business, labor, farm, church, women's, veterans', cooperatives, and other groups framed a national health program.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The 1948 bituminous coal wage negotiations collapsed today within twenty-four hours after the opening session, catapulting into the hands of the Federal Government a test of the practical workings of the Taft-Hartley law.

Careful, scientific analysis could further reduce infant mortality here, a preliminary survey of the city's health needs set forth yesterday. Three hundred members of the Health Council of Greater New York received the report at an annual luncheon in the Roosevelt Hotel.
SCARBOROUGH, England, May 19 -- The question of extending British recognition to the state of Israel was sidestepped today by the annual conference of the Labor party, which rules this nation.

The American Zionist Emergency Council urged yesterday that the United States "deny to Britain the means to supply Arab aggressors." The statement attributed the fighting and loss of property and life in the newly formed state of Israel to the "British-financed, British-trained, British-supplied and British-officered Arab Legion."
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 8 points higher to 7 points lower.

GRAND ISLE, La., May 15 -- A man-made island in the blue-green waters of the Gulf of Mexico was the scene today of a demonstration of the way the United States oil industry is just beginning to develop new oil resources of incalculable potentialities.

The Market Research Council will meet Friday at the Yale Club to consider the code of professional practices and the set of survey-reporting standards presented to marketing groups by a committee of six research organization representatives, it was learned yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, May 19 -- A code of ethics for radio, in preparation nearly two years, was formally adopted today by the board of directors of the National Association of Broadcasters meeting in annual convention. A compromise among large and small radio stations of differing opinions and economic interest, the statement of "standards of practice" imposes no striking changes.

NANKING, China, May 19 -- Lieut. Gen. Teng Jen-yi, Nationalist military spokesman, said today that Government planes had raided a village near Fouping, northwest of Hopeh, on May 13 and scored direct hits on buildings where 200 top Communist leaders were reported to have been holding a meeting.

DETROIT, May 19 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser returned to form today with home-run backing at the plate and double-play support in the field as the Tigers took their second straight decision from the Red Sox, 4 to 1.

Coaltown, Calumet Farm 3-year-old commonly called the "world's fastest equine" for a mile or less, substantiated that description yesterday by winning the forty-seventh Swift Stakes at Belmont Park. With 27,359 fans looking on, the sparkling son of Bull Lea hardly worked up a sweat as he romped to a six-length triumph over Ben F. Whitaker's My Request in his first outing at a local track.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- A four-man committee of business experts who studied the recovery program planned for Japan and Korea in a visit there endorsed without qualification today the Army's proposal that $220,000,000 worth of raw materials be plowed into these recovery efforts in the next twelve months.

ASTORIA, Ore., May 19 -- "A quarter of a million dollars" is being spent by the "Eastern combination of Taft-Dewey forces" in the Oregon primary campaign "in a desperate effort" to stop him, Harold E. Stassen asserted today.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, May 19 -- With the fall of Sheikh Jarrah district of Jerusalem the road will be open for Arab forces into the western section of the city now held by the Haganah and the plight of the Jewish forces in Jerusalem was believed here to be desperate.

BOSTON, May 19 (AP) -- Vern Bickford, right-handed pitcher who became Boston instead of Pittsburgh property on the toss of a coin two seasons ago, tonight pitched the Braves to a 4-1 victory over the Pirates. It was the first loss of the season for Rip Sewell and the Braves' first victory of the year over Pittsburgh.
WATERLOO, Iowa, May 19 -- The Iowa National Guard was called out tonight to help Waterloo police quell a riot which broke out at the Rath Packing Company plant when a picket was shot dead.

TULSA, Okla., May 19 (AP) -- Venezuela, while respecting the integrity of oil concessions which it already has granted, does not propose to make any more, Dr. Jose Martorano Battisti, president of the country's petroleum bureau, said today.

At the annual meeting of the Sinclair Oil Corporation yesterday, Harry F. Sinclair, president, told stockholders that he would recommend to directors at their meeting next month that the dividend be placed on a 50-cent quarterly basis. This would increase the annual rate to $2 a year.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Thomas K. Finletter today was appointed by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, as chief of the agency's special mission to the United Kingdom. He was recently chairman of the President's Air Policy Commission and had been special assistant to the Secretary of State.

ST. LOUIS, May 19 -- At the end of the first eighteen-hole qualifying round of the Professional Golfers Association national championship over the Norwood Hills Country Club course outside of St. Louis, two former champions, Ben Hogan, a native Texan, and Bob Hamilton of Landover, Md., were co-leaders with 66, five under par.

BUENOS AIRES, May 19 -- Two of the knottiest problems facing United States businessmen here, getting remittances out and obtaining import licenses for getting goods in, may eventually be tied in a roundabout fashion to the Marshall Plan dollars to be spent here, according to informed opinion in this capital.

The Urban League of Greater New York opened a three-day conference yesterday in the offices of the Good Neighbor Federation, 115 East 106th Street, to improve social services for Negroes in this city. The conference, which will be directed by Dr. J. Raymond Walsh, will include discussions of problems of housing, education, employment and training.

Miss Florence P. Weiss, who will retire June 1 as the secretary of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street, after serving thirty-five years, was honored at farewell reception in the parish house parlors last night. The function was under the sponsorship of the Church Council.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 19 -- There was another series of air raids on Tel Aviv today but the attacks were on a small scale and the damage caused was negligible. Planes came in singly, bombed and flew off in the direction of Egypt.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 19 -- Al Beebe set the Penn nine down with five hits on University Field today to lead Princeton to a 4-1 triumph over the Quakers. The victory was Princeton's second in the Eastern Intercollegiate league against five losses.

LONDON, May 19 -- The State of Israel made a formal request today for recognition by Great Britain. The request will not be granted at this time, since it was stated at the Foreign Office that the British Government's attitude remained unchanged.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Following is the text of the State Department statement on the status of the issues that Prime Minister Stalin said might be discussed profitably by the United States and Russia:

NEW HAVEN, May 19 (AP) -- Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks today authorized the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad's reorganization committee to distribute $46,916,727 in common stock to satisfy the claims of security holders in the railroad's former capital structure and others whose claims already have been approved by the court.

The high cost of air shipment is strangling the growth of a business vital to the national security program, Maj. Gen. William H. Tunner, new deputy commander in the Military Air Transport Service, declared yesterday in discussing new possibilities of "Transportation by Air."

All true mugwumps are looking for a Presidential candidate this year, and the search is not so simple as it might seem. The party is small and its rules are severe. Unable to fill a regular convention hall, it may do what it has considered in the past, which is to ask the angels to move over slightly and share the head of that pin.

NEW DELHI, May 19 -- The Government of India announced today a new policy of restricting the large-scale movement of Moslems from Pakistan into this Dominion. These are the followers of Islam who went to Pakistan during the period of religious strife after the partition and who desire to return to the land of their birth now that peace has been restored.

Allaying the concern occasioned by his failure to last the distance in two successive starts on the road, Larry Jansen shut out Cincinnati with seven hits yesterday as the Giants subdued the Reds, 5 -- 0, before 10,120 paying spectators at the Polo Grounds.

THERE'S no telling what byway of history our novelists will lay hold on next. The United States is a young nation, but, thanks to the writers of fiction, every schoolboy, every holder of a library card, knows by now that even the minor chapters of our history are studded with sanguinary conflict, made glorious by the doughty deeds of countless brave men, the devotion of unnumbered fair women.

New silverware just received from Norway will enliven even formal table settings. Many of the hollowware pieces have bright enameled designs, while sterling silver pepper shakers and sugar bowls take the form of sprightly birds and roosters.

NEWARK, N.J., May 19 -- The American Federation of Labor began mass picketing this morning at the $10,000,000 housing project in Ivy Hill here in reply to the builder's announcement that he had found union labor too expensive and would complete the development under an open shop policy Police kept a close watch on the picket line.

BERLIN, May 19 -- After more than a year of disagreement, the Western Allies and a Soviet delegation reached an agreement today on a plan to reform this city's school system. The agreement was reached by the deputy commandants of the Kommandatura, four-power body that rules this city, after the Soviet representative had agreed to permit a small number of private schools to operate.

Arnold Webb led Brooklyn College to the team championship in the second City College invitational track and field meet yesterday at the Williamsbridge Oval, the Bronx. Webb tallied fifteen points as Brooklyn defeated C.C.N.Y., 66 points to 55, with six other squads far behind.

With its gardens in full springtime flowering. The Cloisters celebrated its tenth anniversary yesterday by opening an exhibition of newly purchased liturgical objects and furniture. These handsome acquisitions help to re-create the secular and religious life of the Middle Ages to which this branch museum of the Metropolitan in Fort Tryon Park is dedicated.

Europe has had its ups and downs, but probably never in such quick succession as in the past week. The news that the United States and Russia might talk things over came as an exhilarating surprise to the man on the street. Diplomatic niceties naturally mean little to him.

LOS ANGELES, May 19 (UP) -- The Rev. Stewart P. MacLennan will be tried under laws of the Presbyterian Church for marrying film actress Lana Turner and Henry (Bob) Topping, tinplate heir, the Los Angeles Presbytery has announced.

Chartered planes will fly mail one to three times a week at the sender's risk to "somewhere in Israel," replacing services abandoned three weeks ago by the United States Post Office, the Jewish Agency for Palestine announced here yesterday.

The Alabama Southern Railroad Company has declared dividends at $4 each on the ordinary and preferred stocks, both payable on June 26. Last year the company disbursed $3.50 on June 26, and $3 on Dec. 24. As of Dec. 31, 1946, the Southern Railway Company owned 34,500 shares of the preferred, or 51 per cent, and 92,111 shares of ordinary stock, or 58 8/10 per cent.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 19 -- Doormats in twelve consecutive league games, the United States Merchant Marine Academy nine of Kings Point practically eliminated Fordham from the Metropolitan Collegiate Conference race today, 3 to 2, for their first victory in loop competition.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 19 (AP) -- Mrs. E.L. Hopkins' Three Rings, beaten by a scant nose in his last outing, gave a front-running performance to win the feature race at Garden State Park today.

The stock market returned yesterday to a more normal trading range after a mid-morning advance failed to extend itself. As the force of the bullish enthusiasm generated last week weakened, prices ended mixed in the dullest session in a week.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 19 -- The United Nations was assured today of a home until July 1, 1951, regardless of what action Congress may take on the proposed construction of a permanent United Nations headquarters on the East River site in Manhattan.

Delegates to the sixth biennial convention of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union, AFL, voted yesterday to "do everything possible" to defeat Henry A. Wallace in his campaign for the Presidency.

Zionism as a world force in Jewish affairs faces ultimate extinction as the new state of Israel becomes secure and unmolested, Rabbi Joseph H. Lookstein, Professor of Sociology at Yeshiva University, declared last night. He spoke to 400 persons attending the evening session of the opening day at the twelfth annual convention of the Rabbinical Council of America in the Riverside Plaza Hotel.

If the Republican party does not wish to go into the national campaign correctly tagged with the same label of "economic isolationism" which has cost it heavily in the recent past, then it is time for Republican Presidential aspirants and others highly placed in the party's councils to take a hand in an important issue on which debate is about to begin in Congress.

Initial shipments to distributors of two new Westinghouse Electric Corporation upright vacuum cleaners have just been completed, R.E. Dobson, vacuum cleaner merchandise manager, disclosed yesterday. They will be available in retail stores next week, he said.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- The Rabbinical Assembly of America, in convention here, today unanimously approved a proposal that annual pilgrimages be undertaken by its members to Israel to strengthen the bonds between American and Palestinian Jewry.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- South Carolina added twenty national convention votes and eight Presidential elector nominees to Dixie's anti-Truman column today. But the President picked up twelve votes in Montana to run his total pledged and claimed delegates for the Democratic nomination to 469.
Nine bases on balls by Jack Toomey, Jasper pitcher, helped City College to score a 6-4 victory over Manhattan College in a Metropolitan Baseball Conference game yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.

A lifting of the embargo on arms for Palestine would be followed within a few weeks by an end of the fighting between the Jews and Arabs, Mrs. Golda Myerson, a member of the provisional council of the new State of Israel, predicted yesterday upon her arrival at La Guardia Field.

Miss Vivien Kellems, manufacturer of cable grips in Westport, Conn., announced yesterday at her town house at 59 East Sixty-fourth Street that her Westport bank had had to turn over to the Government $1,685 from her account to satisfy a tax lien.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The House passed the Mundt-Nixon Communist-Control Bill today, 319 to 58.

Union Township, N.J., School District awarded yesterday an issue of $1,545,000 of school bonds to B.J. VanIngen Co. and associates at a bid of 100,309 for 2.40s. The bonds, which will mature from June 1, 1950 to 1973, were reoffered at prices ranging from a price to yield from 1.10 per cent to a dollar price of 99.

TRENTON, N. J., May 19 -- An investigation of the Municipal Administration of Atlantic City was ordered today by Supreme Court Justice Howard Eastwood on petition of thirty-four taxpayers in the resort.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Attacking the "monopolistic powers" of labor unions and labor leaders, Donald R. Richberg, former head of the National Recovery Administration, called upon the Government to curb the "recklessness" of the unions by law.

Installation of two-way radio patrol cars in the Bronx last Thursday paid off early yesterday morning when two detectives, summoned by a message from one of the news cars, captured a youth reported to have attempted a holdup.

SCARBOROUGH, England, May 19 -- Delegates at the British Labor party's annual conference demanded today a declaration of British independence from both the United States and the Soviet Union and urged the creation of a "United Socialist States of Europe" -- but they did not mean exactly what they said.

The House of Delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York adopted a resolution at its 142d annual meeting yesterday at the Pennsylvania Hotel recommending that the society "advise" its more than 22,000 members "not to become participating physicians in any voluntary health insurance plan unless it has been approved by the Medical Society of the State of New York."

Directors of the Wheeling Lake Erie Railway Comuany have authorized its officers to negotiate terms for leasing their line to the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad Company. John W. Davin, president of Nickel Plate and chairman of the board of Wheeling Lake Erie, said no other action was taken on the proposal advanced by the Nickel Plate's board two weeks ago.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 19 -- The Arab Legion today continued to exert pressure on Jerusalem, shelled parts of the city and captured the Sheikh Jarrah quarter, a strategic district controlling the roads to Lydda and to the near-by Hebrew University. They also took a police training station in the vicinity.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 19 -- Twentieth Century-Fox announced today that Jeanne Crain will play Lady Windermere in "The Fan" instead of Gene Tierney, who has withdrawn from the cast because of approaching maternity. Dorothy Parker, Ross Evans and Walter Reisch have completed the scenario from Oscar Wilde's play "Lady Windermere's Fan," and filming is expected to start early next month.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- A final complete contract proposal made by the Chicago Newspaper Publishers Association to Chicago Typographical Union, Local 16, of the International Typographical Union, AFL, for settlement of the union's strike against five daily newspapers here has been turned down, John J. Pilch, president of the local, announced today.

In a quick turnover of a business property, the twelve-story loft building at 20 West Seventeenth Street, west of Fifth Avenue, was resold by Henry Goelet, the operator, to the Alvin Industrial Corporation in a transaction reported yesterday by Mills Co., the brokers.

An increase of nearly 50 per cent in the reliance of American business on professional industrial designers to give their products consumer appeal from an art, engineering and merchandising standpoint was indicated in a survey by the American Management Association in collaboration with the Society of Industrial Designers, released yesterday.

Building construction contracts awarded in the metropolitan New York and northern New Jersey area last month amounted to $96,966,000, an increase over the previous month and over April, 1947, that raised the cumulative gain for the first four months of this year to 12 per cent greater than the corresponding period of 1947.

Leaders in the American theatre joined well-wishers of the new state of Israel last night in honoring the Habimah, Israel's national theatre, with a dinner reception at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The thirty-member Jewish acting troupe is now appearing at the Broadway Theatre.

Service and know-how undoubtedly will be the big factors in deciding whether or not this port will continue its pre-eminence in the handling of general cargo, but costs cannot be ignored, Walter P. Hedden, director of port development of the Port of New York Authority, asserted last night.

A new kind of discrimination is evident in the market for tax-exempt municipal bonds following the gradual exhaustion of bullishness brought on by last week's news of a continuance of the Treasury's one-year 1 1/8 per cent borrowing rate. Yields designated for new first-grade utility revenue obligations, such as the Akron, Ohio, and Evanston, Ill., flotations, evidently were more attractive in the primary market to new offerings of straight prime credit.

Methods of the Consolidated Edison Company in estimating present costs in support of its application for higher rates for gas were questioned yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commission by John T. Ryan, special commission counsel.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused a Wall Street broker of fraud of the "crudest and most flagrant type" and took away his broker's registration.

PEIPING, China, May 19 -- This North China cultural center is not believed to be under any immediate threat of attack from the Communists in spite of fighting that occurred yesterday within earshot of its western suburbs. Military observers take the view that the main Communist objective is to disrupt land communications rather than attack the city or its airport.

The Rev. Dr. Erling Eidem, Archbishop of Upsala and Primate of the Lutheran Church of Sweden, arrived here yesterday from Goeteborg on the Swedish American liner Gripsholm. The ship, carrying 1,215 passengers, docked at Pier 97, North River, at 8:35 A.M.
Carroll L. Lowe of Norwalk, Conn., has been appointed manager of bank lock sales of the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company. He formerly was a hardware manufacturer's representative in New York State.

The alleged ringleader of a fake automobile mishap ring that is reported to have mulcted insurance companies of $750,000 in the last decade was held in $25,000 bail yesterday after a forty-one count indictment was filed against him in General Sessions.
LONDON, May 19 -- United States specifications for the fireproof construction of passenger vessels are winning considerable support at the International Conference on Safety of Life at Sea here.

The announcement by the Zionists of the establishment of their state, Israel, seems to have been accepted by the American press as if it were a solution to the problem of Palestine. The President's unprecedented haste to recognize this embryonic, unproved state has gone without criticism in spite of his autocratic omission from consultation of the Department of State or of the American delegation to the United Nations.
NEWARK, N. J., May 19 (AP) -- Newark registered its first double victory of the season tonight as Bob Keegan and Dick Starr hurled the Bears to 5-3 and 12-4 triumphs over Toronto.

LONDON, May 19 -- Unfavorable "surprise" has been aroused in "leading circles" of the Soviet Union by the United States State Department's reply to Prime Minister Stalin's message to Henry A. Wallace, it was announced tonight by Tass, the official Soviet news agency.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Interest in the affairs of Palestine is so great in this country, and events there exert so many different pressures on American life, that the meaning of our de facto recognition of the state of Israel and the historical background of that act call for some detailed explanation.

GASTONIA, N.C., May 19 (AP) -- Fred Erwin Beal, author and former Communist who fled to Russia to escape prison for the slaying of Police Chief O.F. Aderholt during a strike disturbance here in 1929, but later returned to the United States, regained his citizenship in Superior Court today.

Production of crude oil in the United States last week increased 9,850 barrels to 5,422,600 from 5,412,750 barrels the week before, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Crude oil production for the week ended May 17, 1947, was 5,008,050 barrels.

"Marvelous Journey: Four Centuries of Brazilian Literature," by Samuel Putnam, will be published by Knopf on June 14. It is a study of the course of Brazilian writing from 1500 to the present, giving its cultural and historical origins and an analysis of individual writers and their work.
The Federal Government moved yesterday into the dispute between Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators and three CIO maritime unions by assigning a conciliator.

The results of the fifth annual National Poll of Serious Music on the Air, conducted by the magazine Musical America, were announced yesterday. The 600 music editors and critics of this country and Canada who did the voting considered it significant that a contemporary opera, Benjamin Britten's "Peter Grimes," was the first choice among Metropolitan Opera broadcasts, since they believed it might reflect a growing taste for serious contemporary music in this country.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade today. Corn weakened after an early upturn had carried the May delivery to a new high since early last February, with the close 7/8 to 2 cents lower than yesterday.
If the Cardinals are the team to beat it must be recorded that the Dodgers, last year's National League champions, are doing less than nothing about it.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Secretary of State Marshall declared today that the test of Prime Minister Stalin's sincerity in proposing understanding between Russia and the United States would be the cooperation the Soviet Union showed in the future on outstanding world issues before the United Nations and other international agencies.

YORKTOWN, N.Y., May 19 -- In a running revolver fight on the Taconic State Parkway near here this afternoon, the state police captured two men suspected of a series of recent robberies and car thefts in New York. The jaw of one suspect was shattered by a bullet in the battle.
LONDON, May 19 -- The feature of the first day of the new account in the stock market here today was activity in gold mining shares.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 12, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 19 -- Britain led an attempt in the Security Council today to water down the United States proposals calling for forceful action in Palestine unless both sides agreed to stop fighting at once.

In today's issue THE NEW YORK TIMES completes the publication of installments from the first volume of the war memoirs of Winston Churchill. The narrative began with an appraisal of the "follies of the victors" after the First World War and has carried the story to the author's appointment as Prime Minister on the eve of catastrophe in the Second.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Andrews stop-gap selective draft bill, which the House Armed Services Committee approved May 3 by a vote of 28-5, faced new delays and perhaps serious trouble tonight. There was a possibility that the House Rules Committee would not release the measure for consideration in its present form.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 19 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey angrily denied tonight that he and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio had entered into a $250,000 deal to defeat Harold E. Stassen in the Oregon Republican Presidential primaries.

BERLIN, May 19 -- The United States Office of Military Government cut the flow of Communist propaganda into the United States zone today by banning temporarily the importation into that area of all Russian-authorized newspapers, books, magazines, posters and other publications and their sale, distribution and display.

THE Customers Always Write -- Larry Stevens of New York offers this postscript: "Anent the column on jockeys (baseball type), you mentioned as one of the top riders of our time a certain Waite Hoyt. And you were right. Here's one more example.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- A union won the first round today of a test case that may determine whether strikers must pay the wages lost by non-strikers who are forcibly prevented by pickets from working.

BOSTON, May 19 -- Discovery of thirty-four male hormones that may provide a clue to the cancer mystery was announced for the first time today by Dr. Cornelius P. Rhoads, director of Memorial Hospital and Sloan-Kettering Institute of New York.

PARIS, May 19 (AP) -- Miss Barbara Scofield of San Francisco and Miss Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, and Rollins College, had relatively easy times today in the first round of the French international tennis tournament.
