ATHENS, May 19 -- Greece's answer to last week's Russian note, in which the Soviet Government expressed concurrence "with the Soviet peoples' indignation over the mass executions of patriots," was made public today. It was handed to the Russian charge d'affaires, Nikolai Tchernychev, last night.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- All prospect vanished today for passage at this session of the anti-lynching bill in its present form.

New York City is trailing the rest of the country in post-war construction, Thomas S. Holden, president of the F.W. Dodge Corporation, told the members of the New York Building Congress at their twenty-seventh anniversary luncheon meeting yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

CINCINNATI, May 19 -- Harold J. Ruttenberg, vice president of the Portsmouth Steel Corporation, charged today that he had been "vilified" by "agents" of the Securities and Exchange Commission during their investigation of the recent $10,000,000 common stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.
Two new district champions were crowned yesterday as New Jersey and Westchester completed their schedule of interclub team matches in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association tournament.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Palestine fighting -- for a long time guerrilla in character -- has now developed into full-fledged war.

ROME, May 19 -- Minister of Defense Cipriano Facchinetti resigned today to facilitate Premier Alcide de Gasperi's task of reorganizing the Cabinet. All Ministers placed their portfolios at the Premier's disposal some weeks ago, but Signor Facchinetti today formally reiterated his resignation.

In its first change of ownership since 1904, the Irving Hotel, a nine-story building containing 140 rooms at 26 Gramercy Park South, running through to 133 East Nineteenth Street, has been sold by the R.J. Blake Realty Company to a syndicate of investors headed by Charles H. Kelman, attorney.

Naming "Communist nations" as likely aggressors against the United States, Gen. George C. Kenney, commanding general of the Strategic Air Command, declared last night that in spite of the existence of a threat of war, "we will still strive to settle matters at the international conference tables."

PARIS, May 19 -- The story in Jean Desses' thirty models for summer resort wear is in fabric. A sweeping dolman evening coat in lime faille appears over a full gown of white linen with black polka dots, a gown that has a bouffant back peplum in black with white dots.
GENEVA, Switzerland, May 19 -- The International Red Cross will make a new effort to establish a zone of security for Jerusalem, it was learned here today.

Young persons in Japan are meeting the challenge of communism by turning to religion, declared Soichi Saito, general secretary of the Y.M.C.A. of Japan, yesterday afternoon at the National Council of the Y.M.C.A., 347 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The texts of the letter sent to Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, by John C. Gall, counsel for the Southern Coal Producers Association, and of a statement by Thomas Kennedy, vice president of the United Mine Workers of America, in connection with the collapse here today of coal wage conferences, were as follows:

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 19 -- The 8,000 delegates to the ninety-first annual session of the Southern Baptist Convention overwhelmingly voted today against a motion to commend President Truman for officially recognizing the new Jewish state, Israel.

CHICAGO, May 19 (AP) -- Pitcher Early Wynn used his bat today in helping the Senators beat the White Sox, 4 -- 1, for a sweep of the two game series. Wynn's pinch single in the seventh inning scored Washington's first two runs off Joe Haynes to wipe out a 1-0 Chicago edge.
AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, May 19 (AP) -- Abdel Rahman Azzam Pasha, secretary general of the Arab League, said tonight that Arabs were ready to "accept peace at any time" for Jerusalem.

Declaring that South Africa stands on the threshold of a "vast industrial transformation," Harry T. Andrews, Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary of the Union of South Africa, yesterday called for better balanced trade between the United States and the Union and greater participation by American capital in its development.

A committee representing the Association of the Bar of the City of New York called yesterday on Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall to discuss possible candidates for Surrogate of New York County and to express opposition to the nomination of Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente. A majority of the Tammany executive committee is reported ready to put forward the Justice for the nomination.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 19 (UP) -- Dispatches from Damascus reported that Iraqi and Syrian artillery was shelling Israeli strong points at Safed and Beisan in northeastern Palestine.
LONDON, May 19 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Moscow broadcast in Russian, as recorded and translated by the Soviet Monitor:...

The Paramount Pictures Choral Society, directed by Edith Morgan Savage, gave its spring concert last night at Town Hall, assisted by the Glee Club of St. John's College, under the Rev. Robert J. Rivard. Henry L. Scott, pianist, was the guest artists.

Shachnow Brown, Inc., builders, sold to Raff Brothers the building containing sixty-three apartments and ten stores at the northwest corner of Reservoir Avenue and Kingsbridge Road the Bronx, through Max Weinstein, broker.

ALBANY, May 19 -- Arguments upholding the right of a taxpayer to challenge the constitutionality of public acts were presented to the Court of Appeals today in behalf of Henry Adsit Bull of Buffalo, a lawyer, who is seeking to nullify a state grant of $128,000 to Canisius College, a Catholic institution, on the ground that the allocation is contrary to both the state and Federal Constitutions.

With each season Hattie Carnegie Jeune Fille gets a bit more ambitious. This year the finale of the showing, which for several successive springs has opened the summer season of the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, struck a high note of glamour.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Secretary of State Marshall said today that the question of raising the embargo on shipments of arms to the Middle East was involved with measures the United Nations Security Council might take to stop the fighting in Palestine.

The Alumni Association of the Graduate School of Journalism of Columbia University held its annual dinner meeting last evening in the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street. Douglas M. Black, president of Doubleday Co., Inc., and alumni trustee of the university, and Nell MacNeil, assistant night managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, addressed the meeting, at which Dr. Carl W. Ackerman, dean of the school, presided.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Persons who "most definitely ought to have known better" were accused tonight by Sumner T. Pike of the Atomic Energy Commission of misleading the public by distorting information about atomic energy.

The evolution of the hospital nurse's uniform from the bustle and the Mother Hubbard cap to the trim outfit of today was depicted last night in a pageant presented by the School of Nursing of Bellevue Hospital.

Strong language was used by the authors of a resolution which was adopted without dissent by the House of Delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York and which would end the discrimination that has prevented qualified Negro physicians from joining county and state medical societies and hence the American Medical Association.
Edward C. Maguire, Commissioner of Commerce, proposed last night the establishment of a Foreign Trade Center to strengthen the present and future status of "the municipal port community."

A program to provide $2,000,000 annually for advertising and promotion of coffee in the United States was approved yesterday at the closing session of the extraordinary Pan-American Coffee Conference convened May 10 at 120 Wall Street.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 19 -- The International Fur and Leather Workers Union, CIO, reaffirmed today its stand to by-pass the Taft-Hartley Act, denounced the Marshall Plan as a "Wall-Street program," and gave all but final approval to Henry A. Wallace and the third party.

MADRID, May 19 -- A.W. Robertson, chairman of the board of Westinghouse Electric Corporation and a member of President Truman's Economic Advisory Committee, held extended interviews today with Generalissimo Franco, Foreign Minister Martin Artajo and Commerce and Industry Minister Juan Antonio Suances.

PARIS, May 19 -- Certain British officers are now admitting privately that Kenya would not be a practicable military base for protecting Britain's Mediterranean interests. Kenya could serve only as a fount for aerial and airborne striking power.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Foreign Relations Committee unanimously recommended to the Senate today a declaration which would commit the United States to the principle of military aid to international alliances drawn up among its friends.

Tonight 250 employes in the veteran's club of the Eagle Pencil Company will gather in the company dining room at its factory office, 710 East Fourteenth Street, to honor its "dean," Edward Dinkel, credit manager. For in two weeks he completes 70 years since he first joined the company as a $3-a-week office boy and now becomes holder of the Eagle service record.
BIRKDALE, England, May 19 (AP) -- The United States women's Curtis Cup golf team completed its fourth day of practice today and then expressed concern that rains might wash out all its gains.

CLEVELAND, May 19 (AP) -- Bob Feller lost a shutout in the ninth inning tonight but pitched a brilliant three-hitter as the Indians remained in first place by defeating the Athletics, 6 to 1, before 33,871 at Municipal Stadium.

HATTERAS, N.C., May 19 -- If all of the bonito, bluefish, amberjack and albacore that were hooked, played and lost between Hatteras Inlet and the Diamond Shoals Lightship yesterday were placed end to end they would reach from here to Swanquarter.

Blame for the recurrent food shortages in Germany rests with the peace policies of the Western powers as well as with those of Soviet Russia, a committee of Common Cause, Inc., charged yesterday. The committee put forth a specific food program designed to help Germany become a peaceful, democratic and self-supporting nation.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that the European Recovery Program, the Federal tax cut and prospects of greater military spending kept the business boom going at an all-time high during the first three months of this year.

LONDON, May 19 -- The program of Princess Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh in Paris last Sunday, which included race-going, dancing and visits to a theatre and a night club, brought two sharp protests from Scotland today.
The freighter Robin Kettering is scheduled to leave Pier 3, Erie Basin, Brooklyn, Saturday on her first voyage for the Robin Line to ports in South and East Africa.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Norway and Denmark have appealed to the United States for arms and ammunition to bolster their defenses, Government officials said today.

Public school facilities in the Morningside Heights area are inadequate, and so are the Board of Education's officially announced plans for supplementing them, according to a report made public yesterday by Morningside Heights, Inc., a newly formed non-profit organization headed by David Rockefeller.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 19 -- Playing well on all except one hole, Mrs. J.B. Balding of the Creek Club won low gross honors in the opening one-day tournament of the Long Island Women's Golf Association today over the Piping Rock course with a 39, 40 -- 79.

A charge of obscenity against the Creative Age Press, 11 East Forty-fourth Street, for publishing Charles G. Gorham's book, "The Gilded Hearse," a novel of the publishing business in the Nineteen Thirties, was dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Frederick L. Strong in Municipal Term Court.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 19 -- California's maritime training ship, Golden Bear, returned to her home port today from a four-month tour on which she delivered 1,000 tons of canned and powdered milk to children of France, Italy and Greece.

The first of this spring's maple syrup crop is arriving in stores here this week. It's coming, mainly from Vermont, in containers ranging from twelve ounces to one gallon. Most important, the shops are offering it at prices slightly below those of a year ago.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Shipments from this country rose by $10,500,000 during March to a total of $409,200,000, the Department of Commerce reported today.
The half-way mark in the 1948 campaign of the American Cancer Society to raise $16,042,000 for research and public education has been reached, Elmer H. Bobst announced yesterday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 19 -- A Yugoslav Government spokesman confirmed today the arrest of Petar Chulitch, Roman Catholic Bishop of Mostar, which had been rumored abroad.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 19 -- Only an "infinitesimal" share of music critics have genuine interest in contemporary music, according to William Schuman, composer and director of the Juilliard School of Music.

HAVANA, May 19 -- Cuban holders of debentures of the Havana Electric Railway Company, which is American-owned, plan to institute criminal proceedings against the directors of the company in an effort to halt foreclosure proceedings which have been instituted in the courts there by the Hanover Bank and Trust Company of New York, according to Ramon Fernandez Scott, president of Scott Co., stock brokers.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., May 19 (AP) -- The F.W. Woolworth Company plans to spend $24,000,000 this year for new buildings and to

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 19 -- For the second successive day Chancellor Robert M. Hutchins of the University of Chicago cited the United States educational system as a poor example for Germans to follow. This time he expanded on the observation that the United States was rich and powerful despite, rather than because of, her educational system.

ST. LOUIS, May 19 -- In the seventh inning at Sportsman's Park today, Yogi Berra blew a double with the bases loaded over the head of Pete Layden in distant center field that lifted the Yankees to an 8-4 decision over the Browns, snapped a three-game losing streak by the world champions and pulled left-handed Ed Lopat to his second victory in his first complete game this campaign.

CLEVELAND, May 19 -- Continued high business activity for the remainder of 1948 was forecast today by David C. Elliott, economist for the Cleveland Trust Company, before two meetings held in conjunction with the fifty-second annual congress of the National Association of Credit Men.

Three new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall, the attraction is "The Pirate," a Technicolor picturization of the S. N. Behrman play, starring Gene Kelly and Judy Garland. The musical with songs by Cole Porter was directed by Vincente Minnelli and produced by Arthur Freed.

Five persons were injured, four seriously about 5 P.M. yesterday when a ton and a half delivery truck crashed into a newsstand at River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx. Vehicular traffic was congested for some time after the accident at the intersection, at which the Yankee Stadium is situated.

While detectives of the Missing Persons Bureau continued yesterday their search for his missing mother, a 9-year-old Norwegian immigrant boy, who does not speak a word of English, was living at the Children's Shelter, Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, under the threat of deportation as a public charge.

In observance of the inauguration Sunday of a regular program service by WCAU-TV, the Philadelphia affiliate of CBS, the television network will carry a full-hour "Open House" from its New York studios, beginning at 9 P.M. Frank Stanton, CBS president, will discuss the relationship of the network to the television station in the course of the salute.

The average boat owner was described yesterday as more careless than the average motorist in meeting minimum requirements for safety. The Greater New York Safety Council, which made the characterization, offered a set of safety rules to mark the start of the boating season.
Commissioner of Hospitals Edward M. Bernecker saw yesterday at Bellevue Hospital how the "new look" in clothing had enhanced the morale of 300 child patients.

PARIS, May 19 -- A 20 per cent increase in wages and benefits and a lowering of prices through closer Government controls were asked for here today by the General Confederation of Labor during a meeting of its executive bureau.

Major improvements in promotional selling techniques by drug wholesalers will soon bring an increase in toiletry sales, C.T. Lipscomb Jr., vice president, McKesson Robbins, Inc., predicted yesterday at the second session of the Toilet Goods Association's annual convention in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Communist party declined yesterday to meet Norman Thomas, Socialist Presidential nominee, in a debate scheduled for last night by the Mutual Broadcasting System to permit the party to reply to views exchanged on the radio Monday night by Harold E. Stassen and Governor Dewey.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- Members of the United Packinghouse Workers of America, CIO, will vote in local meetings throughout the country tomorrow on whether they want to call off their strike against the major meat-packing companies, which began March 16.

The extensive tour of the New York harbor taken aboard the excursion steamer Sandy Hook by municipal officials of New York and New Jersey, along with several hundred business men of diverse interests, must have produced in many of these passengers a fresh sense of awe at the tremendous natural advantages we enjoy in this area.

Seventeen provisions for negotiated contracts including fixed price, cost type and a new class of "incentive type" contracts are included in the Armed Service Procurement regulations which became effective yesterday. These new rules, at this time embracing only three out of fourteen sections which eventually will be issued, apply to purchasing policies and practices by the Army, Navy and Air Force.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (AP) -- With four straight hits, a triple by Johnny Blatnik and singles by Del Ennis, Eddie Miller and Howie Schultz in the ninth inning, the Phillies scored two runs and a 2-1 victory over the Cubs tonight. The Phillies had been held to four hits by Cliff Chambers until their uprising.

William Soper Pettit of Woodmere, L.I., one of Long Island's leading civic, legal and realty authorities, was killed yesterday in an automobile accident at Billings, Dutchess County, N.Y., according to The Associated Press. He was 68 years old.

WITHIN THE OLD CITY OF JERUSALEM, May 19 (AP) -- Trans-Jordan troops slashed deep into modern Jerusalem today while in the Old City a small Israeli garrison was bombarded at intervals for fifteen hours.
TEL AVIV, May 19 (AP) -- Irgun Zvai Leumi fighters were trying to capture Ramleh and thus give the Israel control of a strategic position astride communications in that sector.
Mayor O'Dwyer received the first special flag made for the city's Golden Anniversary in a City Hall ceremony yesterday.
Warren R. Austin, American delegate to the United Nations, added his invitation last night to Soviet Russia to bring its "eagerness for a discussion looking toward settlements" to Lake Success.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., May 19 (AP) -- Two Oak Ridge scientists have been suspended from access to restricted atomic information pending clarification of their loyalty status.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 19 -- Our present "unstable" economy not only carries the threat of depression but has repercussions in our international relations, Prof. Mabel Newcomer of Vassar College, said at this morning's session of the fifty-fourth annual convention here of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs.
Warren R. Austin, American delegate to the United Nations, added his invitation last night to Soviet Russia to bring its "eagerness for a discussion looking toward settlements" to Lake Success.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., May 19 (AP) -- Two Oak Ridge scientists have been suspended from access to restricted atomic information pending clarification of their loyalty status.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 19 -- Our present "unstable" economy not only carries the threat of depression but has repercussions in our international relations, Prof. Mabel Newcomer of Vassar College, said at this morning's session of the fifty-fourth annual convention here of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs.

Seventy-nine families, including many well-known in society, politics and the business world, face loss of their apartments in River House, one of New York's most luxurious residential buildings, as the result of a sale and reconstruction plans announced last night for the property.

TOKYO, May 20 -- The reaction to the Johnston report on Japan's economic future has been surprisingly sober. Although delighted with the tone of the document, newspapers and business spokesmen emphasize the part Japan must play in recovery.

Meat continued its upward trend in price this week for the second week in succession, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday. But the cuts that show an increase today are fewer than on last Friday

The City of New York is undertaking a new survey of its waterfront facilities and will prepare another port rehabilitation program for study, along with other plans in hand, it was reported yesterday.
ALBANY, May 20 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission today authorized New York railroads to increase some minimum passenger fares on a graduated basis for short hauls.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 20 -Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York wound up three weeks of campaigning for the twelve Oregon delegates to the Republican National Convention with a statement tonight that "competence and faith in ourselves" would solve the country's problems.

LONDON, May 20 -- The Venerable J. H. L. Morell, Archdeacon of Lewes, Sussex, today publicly defended the way in which Princess Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh spent part of last Sunday in Paris. He said the complaints were "bosh and an example of the sort of muddle-headed thinking which is becoming so common among us."
CHICAGO, May 20 -- Short covering and liquidation by holders of May grain contracts unsettled the grain markets on the Board of Trade today and the close was irregular.

LONDON, May 20 -- The British Government grimly stood pat today on the Palestine issue in the face of a mounting wave of American criticism. This problem appears to be causing more Anglo-American ill will than any issue that has come up since the Labor Government took office nearly three years ago.

NANKING, May 20 -- Amid growing demands inside the Kuomintang [Nationalist party] and the army for fundamental policy chances, President Chiang Kai-shek presented himself today as the leading advocate of a revitalized program to streamline his administration, equalize land ownership and drive corrupt elements from the National Government.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -A sharp drop in financing for new plans and equipment was reported today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -Mexico has "blacklisted" Arkansas and Mississippi, refusing to let Mexicans go there as temporary farm workers because of what it termed racial discrimination practices.

VIENNA, May 20 -- The Austrian Government released for publication today the text of an angry note to the occupation authorities protesting against the decision to continue occupation' costs this year. The note said flatly that the Government and Austrian people saw no possible justification for continuing the occupation at all, let alone charging Austria for the occupation costs.

Mayor O'Dwyer signed without comment yesterday a local law increasing the city fee for keeping a pistol in the home or place of business from $1 a year to $10 a year. The new law also increases the fee for renewals from $1 to $5.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (UP) -Increased spending for defense, on top of a Government deficit and expanding bank lending, may force prices still higher, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

An absentee from winners' enclosures since May of 1946, when he took the same race, Fleettown captured the International Steeplechase Handicap, first over-thejumps stake of the New York campaign, at Belmont Park yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 20 --Vassily A. Tarasenko, Ukrainian representative, charged in the United Nations Security Council today that Trans-Jordan's Arab Legion was a part of the British armed forces and that Great Britain was "one of the belligerents" Jordan.

At a student class dinner marking the thirty-fifth anniversary of the Columbia University School of Journalism, Dean Carl W. Ackerman announced last night the winners of three Pulitzer traveling scholarships, valued at $1,500 each. Named also were the recipients of two $215 Sacket graduate fellowships.
GENEVA, May 20 -- A new approach to the problem of how to make Western Germany viable is being quietly explored by European economic technicians.
ALBANY, May 20 -- The constitutionality of the 1948 law validating the City of New York's rent laws was upheld unanimously by the Court of Appeals in two separate cases today.

The controversial collection of progressive American paintings which formerly belonged to the State Department will be on view from today until June 18 at the Whitney Museum, under the auspices of the War Assets Administration. Meanwhile the WAA, which is sponsoring the exhibition, will accept sealed bids for the paintings.

Two old salts, William I. Wheaton, 75 years old, and James M. Winter, 77, were the guests of honor yesterday at the Third National Marine Exposition in Grand Central Palace. The veteran seafarers, both of whom live at Sailors Snug Harbor, Staten Island, were guests of Lewis D. Parmelee, president of the Atlantic, Gulf West Indies Steamship Lines and national president of the Propeller Club of the United States.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 20 -- The United States zone border was closed today to Russian personnel seeking to travel directly between the Russian zone and the vari ous Soviet military missions in Frankfort.

ALBANY, May 20 -- The Court of Appeals uphold today the right of Teachers College to cease operation of the Horace Mann-Lincoln School and divert a $3,000,000 endowment fund to the Horace Mann Institute of School Experimentation.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Dwight P. Griswold, administrator of the American aid program for Greece, predicted today there would be "material improvement" in the Greek civil war situation before winter. But he deplored continued political wrangling in Athens which, he said, prevented national unity and retarded governmental efficiency.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 20 -- The convention of the United Public Workers, CIO, left the door open today for setting up a separate union of Federal employes if the organization fails in its efforts to block enforcement of the Keefe rider, now pending in Congress.

Fashion highlights of the Esther Dorothy Jeune Couture fur collection, seen yesterday at the Pierre Hotel, lay in the natural padless shoulders, the use of belts and buttons, the treatment of high, faceframing collars and the straight greatcoat silhouette.

A juvenile war between two teen-age gangs from the Ridgewood sections of Brooklyn and Queens wound up with the arraignment yesterday in Queens Felony Court, of seventeen toughs after an innocent boy had been beaten and stabbed.

Loomis J. Grossman, operator, has purchased the new two-story taxpayer building at the northwest corner of Eighty-ninth Avenue and 165th Street, Jamaica, Queens, from Dr. Ernest Hass. The property occupies a plot 90 by 86 feet and is directly opposite the new branch store of R. H. Macy Co.

Marking the first industry-wide effort of leading mills for a united drive to boost stainless steel sales, George S. Rose, secretary of the American Iron and Steel Institute, disclosed here yesterday that a permanent exhibit of thirty alloy steels will be opened to the public today in the Architects' Samples Building, 101 Park Avenue.

Continuation of the Committee for Economic Development as a permanent organization was unanimously voted yesterday by its board of trustees at their semiannual meeting at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. W. Walter Williams, banking and real estate executive of Seattle, Wash., was elected chairman, succeeding Paul G. Hoffman, Administrator for Economic Cooperation.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Sharp increases in prices of most farm products and foods were largely responsible for an increase of 1 per cent in primary market prices for the week ended on May 15, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The bureau's comprehensiveindex now stands at 163.5 per centof the 1926 average.

The United States should institute a moral offensive to champion the cause of justice, religion and freedom in the world and to arouse a revival of faith in the American system of freedom and opportunity at home, Elliott V. Bell, State Superintendent of Banks, declared last night.

The first application for city and state funds to fight juvenile delinquency was made yesterday in a letter to the New York City Youth Board, it was announced by Assemblyman Howard Henig, chairman of the survey committee of the Twenty-fourth Precinct Coordinating Council.

Two 17-year-old Portuguese stowaways, who told the police they had been kept virtual prisoners for a year and a half aboard the freighter Star of Alexandria, were turned over to immigration authorities yesterday and later returned to the ship, which was scheduled to sail today for Florida.

Discussing the settlement of the bus strike threat, you remark editorially concerning the Fifth Avenue Coach Company: "The differential of higher wages that they have been paying has a historic basis and had some justification, perhaps, when it was supported by rich earnings. That day is past,and there is no realistic basis now fora differential except that, perhaps, fordriving a double-deck bus."

NUTLEY, N.J., May 20 -- The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, dedicated here yesterday a tower for research into communications that is as futuristic aesthetically as it is scientifically. At a luncheon presided over by Sosthenes Behn, president and chairman of the company, E.M. Deloraine, technical director, predicted that the 300-foot shaft of aluminum would make worldwide television possible.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange developed some irregularity yesterday and closed 45 points higher on old July, while other months finished 9 higher to 6 points lower than on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Department store sales in the week ended May 15 were 7 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended May 15 totaled 847,403 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. The carloadings in detail were:

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 20 -Tommy Strafaci of the Plandome Club turned in a one under par 36, 35 -- 71 to take low gross honors among the scratch-to-nine handicap players in the one-day tournament of the Long Island Golf Association at the Cherry Valley Club today.

A three-day institute to try to put the building industry on the path toward producing again "decent, livable homes in the $7,000 to $10,000 class" and apartments to rent at $50 to $75 was announced yesterday by State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman.

ROME, May 20 -- George Beurling, 26 years old, leading Canadian ace in World War II, was killed this morning when an airplane he was testing crashed at the Rome civilian airport and burst into flames.

JERUSALEM, May 19 (Delayed) -- Palmach shock troops of the Haganah before dawn today burst into the sacred square mile of the walled Old City of Jerusalem through the Zion Gate to relieve the beleaguered Jewish quarter while heavy mortar fire pilloried the Arab positions.

Woodruff Randolph, seeking reelection as president of the International Typographical Union, affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, last night held a 3-2 lead over his opponent, John R. Evans, on the basis of incomplete, unofficial returns.

LONDON, May 20 (UP) -- A spokesman said that the Foreign Office was considering the status of Sir Hugh Dow as the United Kingdom representative in Palestine. It is expected that he will have the status of consul general.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Officials of the new munitions board said today that the board's activities were being keyed to the purpose of preventing another war. What is going on, they explained, is not industrial mobilization, but planning for industrial mobilization.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The House-approved Communist control bill was referred today to the Senate Judiciary Committee. A meeting was set for Monday to consider opening hearings.

Purchase by the Hoving Corporation of John David, Inc., was announced last night by Walter Hoving, president of the corporation. Operating six stores in this city, John David, Inc., is one of the largest retailers of men's clothing and furnishings in the United States.
Following is the text of President Truman's address to the students of Girard College, Philadelphia, broadcast yesterday, as recorded ang transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 20 --The only way to stop the bloodshed in Palestine would be to "bring strong pressure to bear on all the parties concerned," the United Nations Truce Commission reported to the Security Council today.

The organization of the Western World as a regional unit within the United Nations, for the purpose of economic cooperation and collective self-defense, has advanced another step through the action of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Acting unanimously, this Committee has adopted a resolution which undertakes to accomplish in the military field what the European Recovery Program is designed to accomplish on the economic plane.

ROME, May 20 -- Pope Pius XII today termed the rights of the individual, upheld by private law, one of the pillars of Western civilization and denounced systems that advocate the leveling of all classes and the abolition of private property.

Dr. Willard C. Rappleye declared yesterday that the action of the Medical Society of the State of New York in advising its members not to participate in the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York is "regrettable" and "against the public interest."

PORTLAND, Ore., May 20 -Oregon Republicans, with the greatest registration in the state's history, go to the polls tomorrow to choose between Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York and Harold E. Stassen after a bizarre Presidential primary campaign which was pressed by both candidates far into election eve.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., May 20-Retail profits are being threatened by rising promotion costs on top of other increased expenses, Howard P. Abrahams, manager, sales promotion division, National Retail Dry Goods Association, told members of the Fort Wayne Advertising Club tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Air Force has sent one of its new Consolidated B-36 bombers on a successful flight of about 8,000 miles with a simulated bomb load which was dropped half way through the flight, it was announced here today.

After two successive weekly increases, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve system declined $23,000,000 last week. According to the data on changes in the banks' assets and liabilities during the period ended on Wednesday, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, earning assets were up $272,000,000.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 20 -- Willie Goggin of Century, onetime Texan, set a scorching pace at the Elmwood Country Club today as the Westchester County Golf Association opened its season with a pro-amateur tournament. Shooting 32, 34 -- 66, four below par, on his ball for individual laurels, Goggin led his team into a tie for first place at 63 in the best-ball event.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -Gilbert W. Skinner, president of the Alaska Steamship Company, denied today that he dictated Alaskan freight rates.

Mayor O'Dwyer named four leaders of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, yesterday as principals in a Communist-directed scheme to strike the city's transit lines in preference to accepting pay increases offered by the city.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -President Truman declared today that the atomic age was the greatest in history and that this country was working to make it an age of world peace and welfare rather than of destruction.

Operating on a split-second schedule, 15,000 Cub Scouts, Boy Scouts, Senior Scouts -- augmented by 3,000 adult leaders -- will stage their Scout-O-Rama tomorrow afternoon and evening in Madison Square Garden.
SEOUL, Korea, Friday, May 21 -- Headquarters here of the United States Army's Twenty fourth Corps announced this morning that all Army dependents would be evacuated from Korea by July 31.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- This nation is "morally derelict" as well as "economically foolhardy" in not providing adequate hospital care for its mentally ill adolescents, it was charged today by Dr. Herbert A. Perry and Dr. Sol Levy of Eastern Slate Hospital, Medical Lake, Washington.

Miss Helen Roarity, a former teacher of drama and clubwoman who had lived in seclusion in a nine-room brownstone house at 206 Lexington Avenue, in the once-fashionable Bedford district of Brooklyn, was found dead late Wednesday night among the yellowed mementos of her earlier years.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Palestine issue not only is dividing Jews and Arabs, but also is dividing the United Nations and the United States and Britain.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The House Rules Committee today granted a rule for floor action on a new bill for United States membership in the World Health Organization. A House vote is expected next week. The measure has been approved by the Senate.

Until "we get the problem of caring for children licked we are not going to have a good welfare program in New York City," Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard declared yesterday at the Women's City Club of New York in the New Weston Hotel.

An account of America's westward expansion and its effect on the Indians of the Great Plains, entitled "Warpath and Council Fire," has been scheduled for publication by Random House for June 1. It is written by Stanley Vestal, a pseudonym for Walter Stanley Campbell, Professor of English at the University of Oklahoma, author of a number of books about the western frontier.
BERLIN, May 20 -- Soviet military authorities are pushing the integration of the economy of the Russian zone into the new economic empire of the Soviet Union and its satellite states.
MIAMI, Fla., May 20 -- Circuit Judge George E. Holt today ordered the release of $20,000, remaining assets of the estate of Max Kovensky, to the new State of Israel.

The House of Delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York has adopted a resolution recommending that the Society advise its more than 22,000 members "not to become participating physicians in any voluntary health insurance plan unless it has been approved" by the Society.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 20 -Harold E. Stassen concluded his quest for Oregon's twelve delegates to the Republican National Convention today. He made a fourcounty tour, three speeches and participated in a torchlight parade tonight in Multnomah County, in which are concentrated one-third of the state's votes.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 20 -Sidney D. Kline of Reading, Pa., told the Pennsylvania Bankers Association today that bankers must oppose "the creeping tendency to broaden the functions of Government and of taxing private business investments out of existence.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Chicago members of the United Packinghouse Workers of America, CIO, following instructions of their union leaders, voted tonight to end their nine-week-old strike against all of the "big four" meat-packing companies, except Wilson Co., on company terms, it was reported.
At two record-breaking dinners in behalf of the United Jewish Appeal drive for $259,000,000, the rayon and silk industry and the law divisions of the appeal raised $4,000,000 last night.

CLEVELAND, May 20 (AP) -- The Indians were aided by 15 bases on balls in defeating the Red Sox, 13 to 4, before 43,158 fans tonight. The passes obtained from lefthanders Mickey Harris and Maurice McDermott tied the American League record set by the Tigers on Nay 9, 1916, as Cleveland increased its league lead to a game and a half over the Athletics
The State of Montana will offer on June 22 an issue of $3,000,000 of state highway debentures dated July 15, 1948, due July 15, 1958, and callable in 1953.

Frank J. Sampson, leader of Tammany, has called a meeting of the men members of its executive committee for this afternoon, presumably to discuss designation of Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente for the Democratic nomination for Surrogate of New York County.

We are late in coming to grips with the most heartbreaking and the most manageable problem left by the war. For three years now the displaced persons in the camps of Western Europe have been waiting to be placed. They cannot help themsleves, and their fate does not have to be decided in agreement with Russia.

PEORIA, Ill., May 20 (AP) -- The CIO-United Automobile Workers tonight was voted bargaining agent for the Caterpillar Tractor Company's plant in a special run-off election. The CIO-UAW received 7,702 votes against 5,644 votes for the AFL United Automobile Workers.

The third contingent of outdoor exhibitors in Greenwich Village will open a fair of crafts tonight just off Village Square, at Avenue of the Americas and Eighth Street. Craftsmen's Equity, an organization of profesisonal craftsmen, is holding its second annual Spring Fair in a vacant lot bounded by Christopher Street and a diner, a florist and the New Jefferson Market, which lent the site, on the square.

The largest graduating class of nurses in the ninety-year history of St. Luke's Hospital, 101 members, received diplomas yesterday at special commencement exercises held in conjunction with the baccalaureate service in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
~k dividend of I2~ cents a common share, payable on June 21, hasbeen declared by the AdvanceAluminmn Castings Corporation.This is the first declaration sinceDecember, 1945.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Senate Republicans are preparing a surprise attack by which they intend to try to break in obliquely upon the entrenched Southerners and push through one of the socalled civil rights bills at this session.

Margaret M. Behrman sold to Benjamin Botwinick the dwelling on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 57 Trenor Drive, New Rochelle, in Westchester County, for cash over a mortgage of $25,000. Title to the property was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

HAIFA, Israel, May 20 --Lebanon has seized forty-one Americans, three Canadians and twenty-five other male passengers from the American steamship Marine Carp as "Zionists of military age," it was disclosed today. All sixty-nine were sent to a concentration camp.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- During the week ended May 19 member bank reserve balances decreased $581,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The 1948 campaign of the New York Heart Association raised $573,620, exceeding its $500,000 goal, between Jan. 1 and April 30, it was announced yesterday by Carl Whitmore, chairman of the drive.

I. Howard Lehman, active for many years in communal and philanthropic affairs, was elected president of the New York County Lawyers Association, at its fortieth anniversary meeting last night in the Law Building of the association, 14 Vesey Street.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican Presidential aspirant, asserted categorically today that none of his campaign committees or supporters "has spent one cent in Oregon, nor have we participated in any other way" in the brisk fight between Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota and Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York for that state's twelve delegates.

The Bronx County Democratic County Committee held its third $100-a-plate dinner last night in the Concourse Plaza Hotel, Grand Concourse and 161st Street, the Bronx, with 875 persons attending. Edward J. Flynn, county leader, announced that the organization would donate $1,000 each to the Protestant Welfare Foundation, the United Jewish Appeal and the Catholic Charities.

LONDON, May 20--The mere fact of past membership in the Communist party or in a Fascist organization will not alone be sufficient evidence to dismiss any civil servant from a state "security" post, but fairly recent membership will be taken into account, according to a Treasury announcement tonight of the procedure for purging the civil service.

The Hilton Hotels Corporation has formed a subsidiary company known as Hilton Hotels International, Conrad N. Hilton, president of the corporation, announced yesterday. The new company will develop and operate hotel properties outside continental United States, with particular attention to commercial and travel centers of the western hemisphere.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- Two Southerners, both of whom have steered cleared of the split in Democratic ranks, were selected unanimously today to fill key posts at the Democratic National Convention, convening here at 2 P. M., Monday, July 12.

Tonight's events: Salute to Fats Waller, benefit for the Metropolitan Music School, in which Abrasha Borodkin and Galvin Jackson will be conductors, and Maxine Sullivan, Bill Robinson, Bob Howard and deep River Boys will appear as soloists, and Ferrante and Teicher, piano duo, will also take part, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Cosmopolitan LittleSymphony, Everett Lee, conductor,Virginia MacWatters, soprano,Town Hall, 8:30; NancyTow, program of songs, TimesHall, 8:30.

The Housing Institute and cooperative approach to housing problems announced yesterday by the State Housing Commissioner are the culmination of months of study, conference and preparation. What they may mean in the reduction of construction costs can only be determined in the future. Butwe may be sure of one thing, and thatis that we shall know a great dealmore about the cost elements in theconstruction process when .this experiment is under way.

Anton Raadik, fast-punching Estonian middleweight, will oppose Smuggy Hursey of Washington, D.C., in the main bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The clash is listed for ten rounds and promises to provide more than a fair share of action, since each battler likes to move in punching at a brisk clip.

MATCH play will begin today in the thirtieth annual championship of the Professional Golfers Association, the classic PGA which ranks as one of America's top-drawer tournaments. In fact, it ranks just in back of the National Open because the National Amateur, like the old gray mare, ain't what she used to be. At least it hasn't seemed the same since Bobby Jones retired.

BOSTON, May 20 -- The typical moron is a semi-skilled laborer who gets to work on time and earns more money than the average male with a normal intelligence quotient, Dr. Ruby Jo Reeves Kennedy, said today. Dr. Kennedy, chairman of the department of sociology at Connecticut College, addressed the seventy-second annual meeting of the American Association on Mental Deficiency.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Administration's stop-gap selective draft program entered an uncertain race with Congressional adjournment tonight. It was still being predicted at high Capitol levels that there would be a drafting, for two years, of men 19 through 25 years of age.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Inspired by the greatest batting day Joe DiMaggio has enjoyed since pre-war times, the Yankees touched record heights in the vital statistics department at Comiskey Field today when they overwhelmed the hapless White Sox, 13 to 2.

ST. LOUIS, May 20 (AP) -- The Browns enjoyed a field day at the expense of six Washington pitchers tonight as they opened their night home season with a 17-to-7 victory. The victory enabled them to climb into fifth place ahead of the Senators and Red Sox, who also lost tonight.

For the past two years I have been mailing magazines and The Sunday TIMES -- with all its advertisements -to friends in Germany. I know from my last visit there how grateful the people are for newspapers and periodicals.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 20 -- For the first time Israeli Air Force planes went into action last night, attacking military objectives in northern Palestine, the Haganah reported tonight. They struck at a concentration of Iraqi and Arab Legion forces at the lower end of the Sea of Galilee, it was said.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 20 -Making an auspicious start in defense of the title he has won in each of the last two years, husky Jack Lyons of the home club annexed the medal in the thirty-eighth annual invitation golf tourney in memory of Walter J. Travis, over the Garden Cify Golf Club today.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, May 20--The entire Israeli colonies of Beit Haarava and Sdom, cut off in Arab territory, were evacuated last night. Before the colonists withdrew they set fire to the Palestine Potash Company's plant, owned by Jewish capital.
Seven hundred men and women who had given up to 10,000 hours of voluntary service in local hospitals were honored yesterday at a ceremony sponsored by the United Hospital Fund of New York.
New York International Airport at Idlewild has the first tenant for the first permanent building to be erected on the field.
PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP) -The Cubs rapped three pitchers for 14 hits today to score a 5 -- 3 victory over the Phillies and capture the series, two games to one.

ST. LOUIS, May 20 -- Playing in his first National P.G.A. championship, Stewart (Skip) Alexander of Lexington, N.C., equalled the all-time low qualifying score for the event when he came in with a 64 over the Norwood Hills Country Club course today for a 36-hole total of 134.

The correctional phase of the stock market gave way yesterday to a more definite trend as the list resumed the advance, spurred by demand for low and medium price issues. The oils and liquors set the pace on the Stock Exchange and showed increases exceeding 2 points although laggards in other divisions held the gain in the index to 0.11 point.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 20 (AP) The Egyptian Defense Ministry announced that Egyptian mobile forces occupied Beersheba, southernmost limit of the Holy Land in biblical times, and captured two strong Jewish positions on the Pal estine coast beyond Gaza.

Two new films will open in firstrun theatres this morning. At the Strand, the attraction is "Silver River," a Warner Brothers Western starring Errol Flynn and Ann Sheridan. Thomas Mitchell, Bruce Bennett, Tom D'Andrea and Barton MacLane are among the featured players.

The recent Report of the House Select Committee on Foreign Aid entitled "The Soviet Union in 1947" seems to be seriously in error on the important question of Soviet defense expenditures. According to the report, "the Soviet budget for 1948 involves the expenditure of 51 per cent more resources on national defense than in 1940."
The observance of National Maritime Day tomorrow was preceded last night by gatherings of representatives of the shipping, industry in Seattle and Jacksonville.

Howard Fox, a nineteen-game winner with Syracuse last year, but victory-starved since he became a big leaguer, pitched the Reds to a 3-1 triumph over the Giants yesterday at the Polo Grounds. The 6-foot-3-inch righthander, whose specialty is a sinker, failed to finish any of his previous four starts before the Giants made him look good.

BIRKDALE, England, May 20 (AP) -- A United States women's golf team begins the defense of the Curtis Cup tomorrow, heavily favored to retain the trophy against the challenge of Great Britain. Glum was the word for British golf experts tonight as they surveyed the line-ups of the teams that will tee off at 1:30 P.M. (9:30 A.M., New York time) in three foursome matches.

ROME, May 20 -- The Italian Government has asked the Ambassadors of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union in Rome to intervene in the boundary disputes between Italy and Yugoslavia and to assume the responsibility for delimiting the frontier between these two countries.

Mayor O'Dwyer asserted yesterday that New York's Police Department was the most efficient in the country. He pointed out that the city, since the end of the war, has had the lowest crime rate per 100,000 persons of any other city in the nation.

Members of the team of designers who won the $40,000 prize in the national competition for plans for the Jefferson National Expansion Memorial in St. Louis attended a dinner last night at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Bituminous coal operators representing most of the contry's coal production, including the Southern Coal Producers Association, asked John L. Lewis today to resume contract negotiations, which collapsed yesterday.

Boston, May 20 (AP) -- Falling on starter Red Barrett and both his successors for seven hits and two walks for eight runs in the fourth inning, the Pittsburgh Pirates today smothered the Boston Braves, 13 -- 0, before 3.089 fans.

DETROIT, May 20 -- Immediate reduction of the present requirement of a 75 per cent margin in the purchase of common stocks listed on national Stock Exchanges was urged today by Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 20 -- Maj. Aubrey S. Eban has been appointed by the Provisional Government of Israel to act as its representative at the United Nations, it was announced here today. Major Eban, 33 years old, is believed to be the youngest representative at the world organization's headquarters.

With purses for the lengthy season expected to surpass a million dollars, harness racing returns to the metropolitan area tonight. Headed by the $5,000 Westbury free-for-all trot, an eight-event program will be staged at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The party is getting rough -- the Republican party, that is. As its Oregon voters prepare to make between two Presidential aspirants a primary choice which has taken on undue importance through special circumstances, prevailing politeness has given way to harsh accusation and blunt retort.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 20--The Southern Baptist convention adopted unanimously today a "gag rule" amendment to its constitution that would require delegates to be from "regular" Baptist churches that were considered friendly, cooperative and sympathetic with the convention.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 20 -- Count Folke Bernadette, president of the Swedish Red Cross and nephew of King Gustaf v, was unanimously named by the Big Five powers today United Nations mediator for Palestine. As agent of the Security Council he will serve as a neutral figure to whom Arabs and Jews can turn when they are ready to arrange for peace.

BUXTON, N.C., May 20 -- The lot of the surfcaster is a hard one, whether he fishes at Martha's Vineyard, North Point off Barnegat or Buxton Hook, for he must be willing to put in a dozen dull days for every day of good fishing.

Stock replenishment of fastmoving apparel and accessory items is the main objective of resident and visiting buyers in New York garment markets, a survey indicated yesterday. Off-price inbetween season purchases, it was learned, have attracted many buyers to the market prior to formal openings on fall lines.

SCARBOROUGH, England, May 20 -- By a patient exposition of his peace policy, Foreign Secretary Bevin won a resounding vote of confidence today from his Labor party supporters, who at the same time rejected proposals for closer collaboration with the Soviet Union's eastern European bloc.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, recommended today that the Senate Armed Services Committee approve a less-ambitious retirement plan for National Guard and military reserve members than the $400,000,000-per-year bill approved by the House.

Characteristics of communism based on "experience of a third of a century" were described yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Dr. Henry Smith Leiper, associate general secretary of the World Council of Churches, at the annual luncheon of the Clergy Association of New York and Neighborhood at the Masonic Club, 71 West Twentythird Street.

WARSAW, May 20 -- The Polish Peasant party's re-entry into the Government will take place during the session of the Sejm opening tomorrow. The Parliament will approve the inclusion in the State Council of Joseph Niecko, who succeeded Stanislaw Mikolajezyk as Peasant party leader.

James E. Scott, a securities dealer of 70 Wall Street, whose registration was revoked on Wednesday by the Federal Securities and Exchange Commission on a charge of fraud, was enjoined permanently yesterday by the Supreme Court from dealing in securities in New York State.
LONDON, May 20 -- Most sections of the stock market here today lost much of the liveliness that had been induced by opening of the new account. But gold shares still drew a big speculative following.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The cost of living resumed its climb in the mid-March to mid-April period.

If the Dodgers ever again see the Cardinals, with emphasis on Stun Musial and Enos Slaughter, it will be too soon. In a manner that severely shook the faith of 11,953 Ebbets Field loyalists, Eddie Dyer's wrecking crew yesterday completed the deflation of Flatbush's erstwhile favorites.

RALEIGH, N.C., May 20 -- TheNorth Carolina Democratic StateConvention today elected an uninstructeddelegation which is expectedto cast the bulk of its thirty-twovotes for the nomination ofPresident Truman at the DemocraticNational Convention.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, speaking officially for the 8,000,000 members of his organization, assailed yesterday for the first time the British Labor Government for its policy on the new State of Israel.

COLUMBUS, Ohio. May 20 -Professional baseball players incapacitated by World War II service will receive lifetime passes to all the country's parks. major and minor. George M. Trautman, president of the minors' National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, announced the plan today.

Is the Bronx Chamber of Commerce so far uptown that it has lost its educational perspective? Has it lost sight of the United Nations going up in midtown Manhattan? Is it aware of man's desperate struggle against aggression, tyranny, the atom bomb and war? Our very survival depends upon a new approach to education.

ATLANTIC CITY MAY 20-- Members of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs were urged, in a discussion this afternoon on "The Citizen's Participation in Public Affairs," to become more "articulate" not only as an organization but as individuals.

Carpet manufacturers are increasing output of twelve and fifteen-foot widths in response to retail demand, mill spokesmen disclosed yesterday. Figures relating to current and future yardage and dollar increases were withheld on the ground that this information is competitive.

WASHINGTON, May 20--A measure calling for American participation in the problem of proriding for the displaced persons of Europe reached the floor of Congress today, after almost two years of futile legislative efforts and Presidential promptings.

PARIS, May 20 -- Foreign Minister Georges Bidault before the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Council of the Republic, France's upper house of Parliament, outlined today a foreign policy marked by exceptional caution on all current international issues.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- The projected seventy-group Air Force of the United States would have to be replaced at an annual rate of one-quarter of its 15,000 airplanes, according to Gen. Carl Spaatz, recently retired Chief of Staff.

A consolidated net income of $853,173 after taxes and all charges for the first quarter of 1948 was reported yesterday by the Greyhound Corporation. This is equal to 8 cents each on 9,330,090 common shares and compares with $1,198,152, or 12 cents a common share, for the corresponding three months of 1947.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UP) -Dr. E. U. Condon said tonight that there was "only one occasion" since he started doing secret atomic research that "a person tried to get from me information which he was not authorized to have.

MANILA, May 20 -- The third hundred-day session of the first Philippine Congress adjourned at dawn, having passed the late President Roxas' economic program almost in toto, including a heavy spate of nationalistic legislation designed to curb and control foreign trade and commerce in the Philippines.

A cable dispatch clarifying provisions of the Argentine law requiring cargo insurance in Argentine companies has been received by the Department of Commerce from the United States Embassy at Buenos Aires, it was announced here yesterday.

Rejecting a defense demurrer contending that Section 965 of the Penal Law, governing excessive rental charges was "vague and indefinite," three justices of the Court of Special Sessions convicted yesterday David Kaskel, 35-yearold real estate operator, of rent gouging.
R. W. Miller and I. R. Cunningham were elected directors of the Creole Petroleum Corporation at yesterday's annual meeting of stockholders. R. H. Sherman resigned as a board member.

Cottons, rayons, nylons and similar fabrics finished during the first quarter of 1948 totaled 2,375,000,000 yards, according to the Bureau of the Census yesterday. This was the highest quarterly production reported since the series was originated and 5 per cent more than the fourth quarter of 1947.

TEL AVIV, May 20 (UP) -- It was admitted here today that the Arabs now had the initiative in the Mount Scopus sector and that if they got the Hadassah Hospital on top of it they would dominate the Old City.

DETROIT, May 20 (AP) -- The faltering Athletics fell dangerously near third place in the American League today as the Tigers shellacked three Philadelphia pitchers for 15 blows, taking the opener of a three-game series, 4 to 2.

Thanks to the vigor and tang of the acting, Mr. O'Neill's sea saga, "S.S. Glencairn," is still fine theatre. These are the four brief plays about seamen that come out of Mr. O'Neill's earliest period. Under Jose Ferrer's pithy direction, they were put on at the City Center last evening for a fortnight of repertory.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 20 -"Shout Freedom," historical musical drama, written by Legette Blythe of The Charlotte Observer staff, depicting the story of the Mecklenburg Declaration of Independence, had its premiere here tonight before an audience of several thousand at the Southern States Fair Grounds.
INSIDE THE OLD CITY OF JERUSALEM, May 20 (AP) -- An Arab assault force captured the Tiferet Israel Synagogue, Jerusalem's tallest building, in an attack today in the Jewish quarter of the old city.

BERLIN, May 20 -- Copies of the Overseas Weekly of THE NEW Y0RK TIMES have been confiscated by the German police on the orders of the military administration in the Soviet zone of occupation and the weekly is now barred in that area, William Freese, European manager of the overseas edition, said tonight.

A manufacturer of women's lingerie, now serving a six-month sentence for the attempted bribery of an agent of the Internal Revenue Bureau, was named yesterday in a three-count indictment charging him with evading the payment of $177,690 in income taxes.

Neither formula nor pattern will be imposed on writers for the "Radio City Playhouse," the summer replacement for Kay Kyser on NBC beginning Saturday, July 3, at 10 P. M. According to Richard McDonagh, manager of NBC's script division, writers will be invited "to tell a story in their own fashion," expressly for broadcasting.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Senate refused today, by a vote of 51 to 20, to bring out of its committee pigeonhole a House-approved bill to make the Territory of Hawaii the forty-ninth state of the Union.

Indicative of the contribution which the nation's railroads are prepared to make toward the success of the European Recovery Program, William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, said yesterday that the railroads of America have invested $250,000,000 in piers, wharves, grain elevators, coal dumpers and other facilities for the expeditious handling of freight between shore and ship.

BERLIN, May 20 -- Copies of the Overseas Weekly of THE NEW Y0RK TIMES have been confiscated by the German police on the orders of the military administration in the Soviet zone of occupation and the weekly is now barred in that area, William Freese, European manager of the overseas edition, said tonight.

A manufacturer of women's lingerie, now serving a six-month sentence for the attempted bribery of an agent of the Internal Revenue Bureau, was named yesterday in a three-count indictment charging him with evading the payment of $177,690 in income taxes.

A bronze bust of the late Dr. Walter Reed, conqueror of yellow fever, was installed formally yesterday in the Hall of Fame for Great Americans. Sculptured by Cecil Howard, the bust was unveiled at the New York University Heights Campus by Maj. Gen. Walter L. Reed, USA, retired, son of the pioneer in tropical medicine.
Formation of the Mortgage Bankers Association of New York as a chapter of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America was announced here yesterday.

Many gardeners toil amid their ragged rows of beans or clumps of flowers without ever knowing that there are two patron saints of gardens with whom they might commune, if they feel so inclined, when mildew is on the march and aphids wax fat on carefully nurtured greenery.
CHICAGO, May 29 (AP) -- Ten national awards for distinguished service in American journalism in 1947 were announced today by Sigma Delta Chi, professional journalistic fraternity.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Prudence Island, ten miles north of Newport, R.I., in Narragansett Bay, is the probable location of the new $25,000,000 laboratory for foot and mouth disease research, the Agriculture Department said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 20 -Edward Small's production, "FBI Meets Scotland Yard," which went before the cameras Monday, is a melodramatic treatment of Communist spying in the United States, it was learned today. According to a spokesman, the picture presents no ideological arguments, but merely identifies antagonistic characters as Communists in search of American secret weapons.

Jacob A. Malik arrived here yesterday to become Russia's chief United Nations delegate and set a new pier record for the variety and number of the topics he refused to discuss -- everything from war and peace to his own age.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 20 (AP) -Minor league baseball is ready to fight against invasion of its territory by televised major games.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will give a dinner party before the benefit premiere of the film "The Time of Your Life" next Wednesday night ah the Mayfair Theatre.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 20 -- A feverish search is being made by 3,600 housewives of Westchester County and Fairfield County, Conn., for frigid havens for $500,000 worth of frozen foods stored in five plants of the American Frozen Food Lockers, Inc.

PARIS, May 20 -- Sharp differences have developed in the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, it was learned today, respecting the monetary solutions that had been suggested to the sixteen nations here as a result of the conference of five Ministers of Finance at Brussels.

I ~ new coloring material fori painting on glassware will enablehomemakers to decorate bottlesand jars for vases or transformglasses into smart~looklng accessories. Called Dek-All, the newmaterial, now at Gimbles in severalcolors, was shown yesterday in anexhibit arranged by the AmericanCrayon Company at 9 RockefellerPlaza.

Dropping of baseball players from Metropolitan Collegiate Conference squads continued yesterday with the announcement that five additional cases of participation in professional ball had been discovered. Shortstop Eill Wells of New York University, First Baseman Dom Montalbano and Pitcher Jack Toomey of Manhattan, Pitcher Don Wiederecht of Fordham and Centerfielder Bob Noble of St. John's were dropped for alleged professional play during the war.
John E. Currier has been appointed New York representative for its plastic molding equipment line by the F.J. Stokes Machine Company, Philadelphia.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 20 -- The German Writers Congress opened today and almost immediately East-West tensions arose. In the midst of a discussion of styles and techniques, the chairman, a "scientific Marxist," was asked where the German writers from the Soviet zone were.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Petitions were filed today with the Chicago regional director of the National Labor Relations Board seeking an injunction under the Taft-Hartley Act to end the strike of the National Maritime Union, CIO, against three Lake shipping companies.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 20-Samuel Booth, treasurer of the Bryant Electric Company, Bridgeport, Conn.,. declared today that industry is faced with a decline in business or a recession and that it may already have occurred in certain phases of the plastics industry.
PARIS, May 20 -- Gen. Nguyen Xuan was elected today President of the provisional Government of Indo-China at Saigon by the French-controlled, anti-Communist Viet Nam Congress.

The story of the Resurrection furnishes the underlying theme of Ladislas Fodor's new play, "The Vigil," which Alexander Markey and George Jessel are bringing to the Royale tonight. The curtain is advertised to rise at 8 o'clock.
The curry powder destined for the dinner table of the Bernard De Votos of Cambridge, Mass., may be in the toils of the nation's G-men, or maybe it just dropped into the limbo of the lost.

Hezekiah Cobb was in from the country the other day on one of his occasional visits to this metropolis. Foxhunting being out of season, he has been following the races since the Kentucky Derby, and especially since the Calumet colt, Citation, went on to win the Preakness as well, down at Pimlico, which is, so to speak, just outside Hezekiah's front gate.

SEATTLE, May 21 -- Ultimate overthrow of Chinese "feudalism," despite American support of "the tottering, corrupt dictatorship of Chiang Kai-shek," was predicted here tonight by Henry A. Wallace in an address at Memorial Stadium.

NEWARK, N.J., May 21 -- Police Capt. Thomas J. Rowe, 56-year-old commander of the First Precinct, was shot fatally with his own service revolver in his office at 4:25 A.M. today, ten minutes after he entered it with an attractive red-haired woman companion.

Frank J. Sampson, leader of Tammany, told the men members of its executive committee yesterday that he was not going to resign as leader. He made the statement at a hurriedly called meeting at the organization's headquarters, 331 Madison Avenue, at which most of the committee members had expected that designation of Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente would be discussed.

Dmitri Mitropoulos, having the time of his life, conducted remarkably fine orchestral performances, as usual without score, of Alban Berg's Chamber Concerto for piano, violin and thirteen wind instruments and Stravinsky's "L'Histoire du soldat" last night in the concert hall of the Juilliard School of Music on Claremont Avenue.
ST. LOUIS, May 21 -- Claude Harmon of Winged Foot eleminated the defending champion, Jim Ferrier, 1 up in the second round of the national P.G.A. championship at the Norwood Hills Country Club today.

In his reply to Henry Wallace, Premier Stalin was careful not to mention Austria among the issues which the United States and the Soviet Union might profitably discuss. Austria is too pat an example of the barren result of the most persistent attempt to reach agreement with the Russians by the conference method.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- After a White House conference lasting more than an hour, Senator Alben W. Barkley, minority leader, said today that President Truman would ask for widened social security benefits in a special message to be sent to Congress within a few days.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned slightly easier yesterday and closed 7 to 13 points net lower.

An unsuccessful attempt to match the year's high marks was made yesterday by the stock market, but moderate selling pressure in the late trading nipped the fresh advance. A good case again was made for the oils on the Stock Exchange, but the industrials suffered in the afternoon realizing so that extreme gains of approximately three points were reduced substaintially by the close, and the composite rate for fifty issues rose only 0.44 point.

Padraic Colum's attack on Northern Ireland in THE TIMES of April 26 and on the statutory settlement by which that area remains part of the United Kingdom is based on a series of inaccuracies which, in spite of repeated refutation, continue to be circulated by pro-Eire propagandists.

Employment of 64,000,000 workers by midsummer and 75,000,000 in 1949 was predicted yesterday by Jerome Barnum, technical training adviser, Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, Inc. He addressed more than 125 members of the Systems and Procedures Association of America at the first annual convention at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel.

A suit to bring about the merger of the Surface Transportation Corporation with its parent organization, the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, was brought before Justice Ferdinand Pecora in Supreme Court yesterday by Irving M. Ross, holder of more than $250,000 in 5 per cent adjustment mortgage income bonds, on the ground that the present organization is unfair to adjustment bondholders.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Whether it is legal to put Bibles in public schools remains an unanswered question.
ROME, May 21 -- Formation of Premier Alcide de Gasperi's sixth government, which was expected to be announced today, was delayed because of last-minute objections of the Liberal party.

Gen. Albert Orsborn, International Commander of the Salvation Army, and his wife, whose headquarters are in London, England, will arrive here Wednesday for six days of public appearances from the Middle West and Canada where they have been on a speaking mission.

WASHINGTON May 21 -- The headquarters of the Strategic Air Command will be moved during the summer from Andrews Field, Md., to Offutt Field, near Omaha, Neb., close to the geographic center of the United States, it was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The United States has protested against the removal of American citizens from the American steamship Marine Carp at Beirut and has demanded their release, the State Department announced today.

On the day he was promoted to the rank of Commander in the Haganah, Milton Geberer, 28-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Geberer of 792 East 175th Street, the Bronx, was killed in action in Jerusalem.

A group of approximately fifty individuals, representing publishing, motion picture, authors' and theatrical organizations, met informally yesterday afternoon in the Longacre Theatre, 220 West Forty-eighth Street, and decided to call a formal meeting to establish a national organization to fight censorship in the United States.

The first step toward a world peace, guaranteed by force, must be complete and wholehearted cooperation between the United States and Great Britain, Lawrence Hunt, New York lawyer and a leading proponent of closer Anglo- American relations said last night in an address before the British Schools and Universities Club of New York, at its annual Empire Day dinner in the Pierre Hotel.

Large retail operators have continued to delay commitments in boys' fall clothing, although smaller retailers in numerous instances have covered some 70 per cent of their requirements for the coming season, according to reports in the trade here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Government possession of the country's railroads for the indefinite future appeared likely today. Negotiations between the management group and the chiefs of three unions ended without result.
Events in the Eastern Mediterranean have caused serious confusion to American shipping companies serving the area, it was reported yesterday.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 21 -- The Southern Baptist Convention amended its constitution today to provide for a credentials committee that would "screen" all delegates on their qualifications to@ participate in @nual Convention sessions.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 2l -- The sale of home freezers for the care of meats and vegetables rose several hundred per cent today in parts of Westchester County and southern Connecticut as 3,600 housewives prepared to move frozen food from lockers of the American Frozen Food Lockers Corporation.
ALBANY, May 21 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals upheld today the right of cities to ban motion pictures even though the films have been licensed by the state.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., May 21 (AP) Harry Wood head resigned today as president of the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation and Floyd B. Odlum was named president for an interim period. La Motte Cohu is expected to become president after June 1 when his resignation as head of Transcontinental and Western Airlines becomes effective.

CAIRO, May 21 -- Egyptian light forces entered Hebron at noon today, according to tonight's Egyptian communique, and patrols were advancing toward Bethlehem. [The United Press said the Egyptians were at the edge of Bethlehem.]

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Industrial mobilization begins with the determination of military requirements in case of war. The foundation planning for this is now being done in the Munitions Board by a special division in cooperation with other national security agencies and private business and industry.

The Holiday Inn and Annex at 921-923 Oceanfront, Long Beach, L.I., which has been owned by the Holiday family for more than thirty years, has been purchased by Mary Pidgeon Shelton through Fred A. Moehlenbrock, broker. The new owner plans to renovate the hotel and convert the annex into a restaurant and bar.

One hundred and forty members of the crew of the Norwegian-America liner Stavangerfjord led by Capt. Thorbjorn Thorsen will leave New York by bus today for an indoctrination tour in American historical lore.

LONDON, May 21 -- Sobered by the responsibilities of nearly three years in office and looking toward the next national election, the British Labor Party concluded its forty-seventh annual conference today without having put forward a single new radical Socialist project for this country.

Cheering delegates to the sixth convention of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union, AFL, heard their president, Max Zaritsky, denounce British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin yesterday as a betrayer of his country.

CAIRO, May 21 (UP) -- Today's Egyptian communique followed closely upon one from Amman, Trans-Jordan, disclosing that the Arab Legion artillery, east and north of Jerusalem, had strafed the southern suburbs. Talpiyot and Mekor Haim were the chief targets.
