LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 21 -- In view of the "extreme gravity" of the situation in Palestine, the Truce Commission appealed to the Security Council today to send a large and powerful United Nations force to the Holy Land. At the same time Russia urged the Security Council to adopt the United States resolution holding the situation a threat to peace and ordering both sides to cease firing.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- John L. Lewis today rebuffed the attempt of bituminous coal operators to obtain a reply to their invitation to resume collective bargaining.

Lumber production for the week ended May 15 increased 1.9 per cent from the previous week but was 8.3 per cent below the same week a year ago. Shipments were up 15.5 per cent compared with a year ago and orders were up 21.9 per cent, according to reports received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Sale by auction of quantities of Nazi loot for the benefit of unrepatriable displaced persons will begin here next month, it was made known yesterday. Details of the manner in which the mate-...

Dr. George Zuckerman, assistant superintendent in charge of elementary and special schools in Manhattan, north of 125th Street, told the final session yesterday of the conference sponsored by the Urban League of Greater New York that schools in Harlem had improved in administration and programming.

CLEVELAND, May 21 (AP)--The long silent bats of the Red Sox boomed today in an 18-hit barrage that swamped the league-leading Indians, 11 to 5. Paced by Ted Williams' eighth home run, a tremendous clout into the upper deck in right field, Boston erased an early Cleveland lead and turned the game into a rout.

SEOUL, Korea, May 21 -- A Soviet Army Yak-19 fighter plane crash-landed Wednesday in a field north of Taejon, in south-central Korea, 115 miles south of the Thirty-eighth Parallel, said an announcement today by headquarters of the United States Army Forces in Korea.

May I point out to W.G. Manning, whose letter on tobacco allocation in ERP appeared in your columns on May 5, that there is considerable protest, in many parts of Great Britain, over the amount of tobacco they are being asked to take under ERP. The British Government has imposed a 250 per cent purchase tax on tobacco in order to cut down on consumption.

HATTERAS, N.C., May 21 -- For three long days we rejuvenated our back and arm muscles by repeated but unsuccessful casts along one stretch of beach, and on the fourth day we moved. Needless to mention, that was the day the channel bass appeared in to the surf we abandoned.

The United Public Workers of America, CIO, turned a deaf ear yesterday to pleas of the Welfare Department that it abandon demonstrations planned for today in Harlem and the Bedford-Stuyvesant area in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- An eight-member advisory committee on fiscal and monetary problems was appointed today by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator.

LONDON, May 21 -- Reports from Washington that President Truman plans to lift the arms embargo on Palestine aroused keen misgivings here today. British officials are already very much worried about the deterioration of Anglo-American relations over Palestine and they point to the fact that their supplies of arms to the Arab countries are being dried up just as the United States seems to be ready to send arms to Palestine.

PARIS, May 21 -- Persons connected with the Ministry of Finance have been informed by private banking interests and securities experts of nationalized banks that private capital to re-equip nationalized industries could probably be raised.

Dr. Abraham Lefkowitz, principal of Samuel J. Tilden High School, a founder of the American Federation of Teachers and the New York Teachers Guild, and for more than thirty years a teacher in the city's schools, was the recipient of a tribute last night from 1,000 representatives of education, labor and government at a dinner in the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Two of the Hollywood writers who defied the House Un-American Activities Committee in its inquiry into Communism received sentences of a year in jail and a $1,000 fine each today.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 21 (AP) -- Optimism for the immediate future of United States business was voiced today by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman, before the fortieth annual meeting of General Motors Corporation stockholders.

STOCKHOLM, May 21 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, chairman of the Swedish Red Cross, accepted today the invitation to become United Nations Mediator in Palestine and will leave for Palestine Thursday from Paris. With his personal staff he will fly to Paris Tuesday to join Ralph Bunche, chief representative of Secretary General Trygve Lie, in his mission to the Holy Land.

Since the recent ruling by the Supreme Court against the Morton Salt Company on the question of quantity discounts, there has been considerable speculation in business circles as to the general effect of the decision. The decision in brief forbids the granting of quantity discounts where savings in production through volume cannot be proven by the seller to the satisfaction of the Federal Trade Commission.

Paying traditional tribute to outstanding talent in literature and the arts, the American Academy and National Institute of Arts and Letters conferred fifteen $1,000 grants on artists, writers and composers at a joint ceremony yesterday before 500 in the academy auditorium, 632 West 156th Street.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 21 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet representative, again urged the United Nations Security Council today to accept a United States resolution terming the situation in Palestine a threat to the peace and ordering both sides to stop fighting in Palestine.

DES MOINES, May 21 (AP) -- The F.W. Fitch Company, manufacturer of shampoos and other items, announced today that the major portion of its future advertising will be in newspapers and general magazines instead of on radio networks.

The five-story apartment building also containing four stores at 320-322 Beekman Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Lenox Hill Hospital to the Frenmore Realty Corporation, represented by Schaeffer Sheldon, attorneys. The Oregon Realty Company was the broker and Amend Amend were attorneys for the seller.

The city Board of Health heard argument yesterday on whether cream from the Midwest should be allowed into New York for sale in view of an anticipated shortage this fall. About 150 representatives of various interests in the milk industry attended the public hearing in the Health Auditorium, Worth and Centre Streets.

The annual spring outdoor art exhibit in Washington Square, now in progress, brings up once more the agonizing problems of the young or relatively unknown artist who would like to get his work before the public but who cannot afford to rent a midtown gallery at prices that range upward of $250.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer today made public a letter to Representative Fred L. Crawford, Republican, of Michigan, in which the Cabinet officer contended that a public official is not disqualified when his daughter, against his will, works for Tass, the Soviet news agency

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Senate upheld today President Truman's veto of a bill which would have permitted a Senate committee to utilize the Federal Bureau of Investigation to investigate the President's nominations for the Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Political and economic unification of all western Germany in the near future under a provisional government was forecast today in testimony before the Senate Appropriations Committee by United States occupation officials.

"Oedipus Rex," the fourth and last play in Habimah's current American repertory, will open a week's engagement at 8:30 o'clock this evening at the Broadway. The Hebrew version of the Sophocles tragedy was staged for Israel's national theatre by Tyrone Guthrie of London's Old Vic Company.

BOSTON, May 21 -- Charging that the lack of adequate programs for the mentally deficient of the country was "appalling," Dr. Lloyd Yepsen, president of the American Association of Mental Deficiency, called tonight for the establishment of a special commission in every state to make a concerted attack on the long-neglected problem.

LONDON, May 21 -- Introduction of the United States plan for providing enough lifeboats on cargo vessels to accommodate twice the number of the ship's entire personnel is being pushed at the International Conference on Safety of Life at Sea here.

BOSTON, May 21 (AP) -- Warren Spahn's rainy-night southpaw slants checked the victory surge of the St. Louis Cardinals and Harry (The Cat) Brecheen tonight as the Braves, without an earned run, gained a 3-1 triumph over the National League leaders before a well-soaked crowd of 22,917. Stan Musial ruined Spahn's shut-out with an eighth-inning homer.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board moved today to relieve Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., of a financial predicament which threatened to leave the line insolvent on May 28.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The National Labor Relations Board decided today that it could not hold union-shop elections under the Taft-Hartley Law in states where union shops are banned by state law.

Stichting Hoenderloo, a boys' school in Apeldoorn, Holland, has been "adopted lock, stock and barrel" by one of the Y.M.C.A. schools of New York, it was reported yesterday. Students at the McBurney Preparatory School for Boys, an affiliate of the Y.M.C.A. schools, have set up a special committee to provide the Netherlands educational institution with equipment, clothing and funds.
For a change, it will be Eddie Arcaro vs. Calumet Farm in the $25,000 added Metropolitan Handicap at Belmont Park today.

GENEVA, May 21 -- A two-week conference of nearly 100 non-governmental organizations interested in the work of the United Nations ended today. It approved numerous resolutions calling the attention of the United Nations to means of improving relations with the organizations, suggesting changes in the proposed Declaration of Human Rights and recommending an extension of several activities of the United Nations Department of Public Information.

Holding more goods in inventory than at any previous time in the last year, rayon converters are poised to fill a large anticipated demand for piece goods soon after the fall dress openings, according to a survey of the trade yesterday.

Final figures submitted to the United Nations Commission by Korean election officials show that in Korea's first election in her four thousand years of written history 90.6 per cent -- or almost 7,000,000 -- of the 7,729,909 persons who had registered cast their ballots.

Charges that New York public School children cannot read as effectively as in previous years, because of the "activity" program now in force, are denied in a report by two experts of the Board of Education.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 21 -- Extra-hole matches, two of which went to the twenty-fourth and one ending on the twenty-second, featured the second round of the thirty-eighth Walter J. Travis Memorial tournament over the Garden City Golf Club course today.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- The sixty-seven-day nation-wide strike of the United Packinghouse Workers of America, CIO, which was marked by violence that resulted in the death of two union pickets and the use of the National Guard in Minnesota and Iowa, was called off today against all of the major packing companies except Wilson Co.
CHICAGO, May 21 -- Chicago's city fathers, burdened with tax, housing and other problems, took cognizance of another one today -- the White Sox.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 19 -- Senator Robert A. Taft carried his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination into New Jersey today. This morning he conferred with Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and met the state's thirty-five convention delegates at Trenton, then came on to Princeton for a buffet supper at Princeton Inn as the guest of Senator and Mrs. H. Alexander Smith, and an address tonight to faculty and students in Alexander Hall.

Ladislas Fodor has done one remarkable thing. He has made the story of the resurrection seem tedious and commonplace. In "The Vigil," which was solemnly acted at the Royale last evening, he has reduced the gospel to the level of a monotonous courtroom story.

LONDON, May 21 -- The best feature in an otherwise quiet stock market here today was speculative buying of Brazilian utilities as the Brazilian Government is expected to purchase the companies with funds out of sterling balances. However, Brazilian Government bonds lost ground on cessation of official support.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 21 -- The estate of Mrs. Florence Guggenheim of Sands Point was appraised at $7,216,386 gross and $6,965,450 net by the state for tax purposes in an appraisal filed in Surrogate's Court here today. State taxes amounted to $792,822.

PITTSBURGH, May 21 -- A new $3,500,000 laboratory and plant of the United States Bureau of Mines was dedicated today at Bruceton, thirteen miles south of Pittsburgh, by Secretary of Interior Julius A. Krug as a key in America's fuel production for both peace and war.

ALBANY, May 21 -- The State Banking Department has approved an application of the Empire Trust Company, New York, to change a branch office from 580 Fifth Avenue to 7 and 9 West Fifty-first Street, Manhattan.

WOODSTOCK, Ill., May 21 -Attacking "jingoism" in history text books, Prof. Charles W. Bishop of Carleton College, Ottawa, proposed today that an international commission be formed to prepare standardized history books which could be used by all nations.

VIENNA, May 21 -- The Austrian Socialist party's leadership charged today that Vice Chancellor Adolf Erwin Schaerf was trying to play in the Austrian Socialist party a role like that of the pro-Communist Zdenek Fierlinger in Czechoslovakia and of Arpad Szakasits in Hungary.

A new group of germ-killing drugs, which may be effective against infections that survive even such "wonder" compounds as streptomycin, seems to have been developed from a common soil bacteria known as polymyxa, experts agreed yesterday during a conference held by the New York Academy of Sciences.
PORTSMOUTH, N.H., May 21 -- The Navy's first postwar submarine U.S.S. Volador, especially designed for fast underwater operations, was launched today at the Portsmouth Naval Base amid overcast skies.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A committee of newspaper and radio representatives was appointed today from Overseas Writers, an organization of correspondents with foreign experience, to seek to "uncover the whole truth" concerning the death of George Polk, American representative in Greece of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- A three-way conference call across the North American continent officially opened the first public telephone exchange at historic Kodiak Island, Alaska, at 2:30 P.M. (E.D.S.T.) today when the call was made between Kodiak, Chicago and Washington, D.C. Residents of Kodiak, the oldest settlement in Alaska, are now for the first time in telephone communication with the United States and the rest of the world.

The Vocational Advisory Service will conduct its first fund-raising appeal this year, it was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the service in the Allerton House for Women, 132 East Fifty-seventh Street. After Mrs. James M. Pickett of the service board of advisors reported that a public appeal would be made for funds, Mrs. Beardsley Ruml, president of the service, said it was necessitated by the need to expand its activities.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 21 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York maintained a lead late tonight over Harold E. Stassen as statewide returns slowly filtered in from today's Presidential preferential primary in which they battled for Oregon's delegation of twelve members to the Republican national convention.

WASHINGTON, May 21--President Truman signed the $3,198,100,000 military aircraft procurement bill today. But he did it with notice that he would order cautious spending of the $822,000,000 which Congress demanded, above his recommendations, for starting now an Air Force of seventy modernized combat groups.

BERLIN, May 21--German communism is "losing one position after another" to "reactionaries," according to Wilhelm Pieck, elderly boss of German communism and first chairman of the Socialist Unity party, the Communists' "cover" party in the Soviet zone.

Operations of Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., mail-order and chain-store operators, for the quarter ended on April 30 resulted in a net profit of $14,307,818 after all charges including $10,025,000 provision for taxes, the report disclosed yesterday.

Many people have wondered about the rather childish ways in which our so-called statesmanship is using appeasement. A thing should be accepted or condemned because it is good or bad. The bill in Congress which has as its purpose the appeasement of a very aggressive group is designed to set aside our immigration laws.

The Walker Butter Egg Company, tenant for the last fifteen years in the four-story building at 20 Harrison Street, between Hudson and Greenwich Streets, has purchased the property in a cash deal from the estate of James Hopkins.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- S. Pinkney Tuck, a career diplomat of thirty-five years' experience, resigned today as Ambassador to Egypt for "compelling reasons of a personal nature." President Truman accepted the resignation, effective at the end of this month, "with deep regret."

MUNICH, Germany, May 21 -- Considerable agitation was evident in official circles here today following publication of accounts of extra food rations issued to Minister-President Dr. Hans Ehard, members of his Cabinet and other administrators.

CLEVELAND, May 21 -- Trappist Thomas Merton, 33-year-old monk at the Monastery of Our Lady of Gethsemani, Kentucky, received today the citation of the Literary Awards Committee of the Catholic Press Association of the United States for "the most distinguished volume of verse published in English by a Catholic poet in 1948."

BERLIN, May 21 -- United States Military Government officials have rejected a Soviet request for the initiation of talks on railway transportation problems, Maj. Gen. George P. Hays, Deputy Military Governor, disclosed today.

LONDON, May 21--Britain lost ground again last month in her battle to achieve a balance in her foreign trade. The value of goods imported during April, according to Board of Trade figures issued today, broke all previous records with a total of 186,200,000 (about $744,800,000).

LAKE SUCCESS, May 21 -- Confirming that Count Bernadotte would go to Paris next Tuesday to confer with Secretariat representatives, Secretary General Lie also disclosed that Harold Evans, the Philadelphia Quaker chosen as Special Municipal Commissioner for Jerusalem, would leave for Palestine via Cairo tomorrow afternoon.

LONDON, May 21 -- As a result of the Soviet refusal to end the deadlock that brought about the indefinite suspension of the four-power talks on the Austrian treaty, United States delegate Sam Reber has requested permission from the State Department to return to Washington, it became known here today.

Lexington, Mass., announced yesterday that it will receive bids Wednesday on sewer, water and school building bond issues totaling $1,110,000. The bonds will be dated June 1, 1948, and will mature from 1954 to 1968.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 21 -- D. Emmert Brumbaugh, Pennsylvania's secretary of banking, said today that "one of the greatest threats to the liberty and freedom of the American people is the gaunt specter of inflation which threatens our economic security."

INTERLOCHEN, Mich., May 21 -- The national music camp at Interlochen won its long-standing battle against James C. Petrillo today, when the Mutual Broadcasting Company agreed to put the teen-age symphony on a countrywide hook-up despite the camp's blacklist status with the musicians' union. The broadcasts will start Monday, July 5, from 9:30 to 10 P.M., Eastern standard time.

PARIS, May 21 (AP) -- Miss Doris Hart of Miami, Fla., and defending champion Mrs. Patricia Canning Todd of La Jolia, Calif., advanced to the third round in the French international tennis championships today with straight-set triumphs.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 21 (AP) -- International Typographical Union headquarters said late today that Woodruff Randolph had received in 271 of the 850 locals 25,173 votes for president and his Independent party opponent, John R. Evans, 16,634.

Fear of war is the first major handicap which must be overcome before world trade can be freed from government controls, Representative Christian A. Herter, Republican, Massachusetts, said yesterday. He also declared that proposals of the House Ways and Means Committee for legislative changes in the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act "will not undermine either the theory or practice of the act."

John Toomey and Dom Montalbano of Manhattan College were erroneously reported by the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference to have been dropped for participation in organized baseball. The two players were given a clean bill of health by Manhattan officials yesterday when investigation proved that mistaken identity was behind the announcement by the conference of their suspension.

Taking up where the Braves and the Cardinals left off, the Pirates sent the Dodgers down to their sixth straight defeat yesterday in a demonstration that again stressed to 8,803 fans at Ebbets Field the woeful qualitative and quantitative inadequacy of the Brooklyn pitching staff.

Replying yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer's denunciation of four leaders of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, as followers of the Communist party line, Austin Hogan, one of those named, said it was "unbecoming" of the Mayor to attack union leaders under the current circumstances.
CHICAGO, May 21 -- The adage is, "after the feast the famine" and it was never more painfully illustrated for the Yankees than today at Comiskey Park.

First public details of three five-year industrial preparedness plans in the aviation, machine tool and gauge fields were embraced in discussions here yesterday of industrial mobilization at the first postwar national gauge conference. It was held by the American Ordnance Association in cooperation with the New York University College of Engineering at University Heights.

Greatness will be achieved or enhanced before nightfall today by one of 2,664 dogs in one of the world's foremost bench shows, the eighteenth event of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club, in the splendid setting of the Dodge estate at Madison, N.J.

Associated Magazine Contributors, Inc., of 68 West Forty-fifth Street, publishers of the Magazine '48, filed a petiition in Federal court yesterday for permission to reorganize under Chapter 10 of the National Bankruptcy Act. The concern listed liabilities of $581,425 and assets of $172,080.
ST. LOUIS, May 21 (AP) -- A four-run third inning, capped by Jerry Priddy's two-run single, enabled the St. Louis Browns to defeat the Washington Senators tonight, 4 to 3.

The board of managers of the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday directed that margin rates on non-trade accounts be returned on Monday to the level existing prior to Dec. 1, 1947. This action will have the effect of maintaining present margin requirements on transactions up to 34 cents a pound while reducing margins on transactions over that price.

A tragic chain of circumstances, including the death of her only son in the war and an auto accident in which she was injured a year ago, culminated yesterday in the death of Mrs. Sarah Friedman, 61 years old, of 3400 Tryon Avenue, the Bronx, when she slipped on a wet floor and plunged from her bedroom window.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 21 -- Barbara Bel Geddes will play the leading feminine role in "Bed of Roses," the screen adaptation of Anne Parrish's 1928 novel, "All Kneeling," which RKO has owned since 1945, the studio announced today. Charles Schnee and Edith Sommer have completed the scenario, which departs from the novel in that the period is to be the present and the setting to be Los Angeles.
DETROIT, May 21 (AP) -- Getting all their runs in clusters of three, the Athletics cracked a three-game losing streak by licking the Tigers, 9 to 6, today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 21 -- The British-Brazilian trade treaty was signed this afternoon by Foreign Minister Raul Fernandes, Finance Minister Pedro Luis Correa de Castro, Sir Neville Butler, the British Ambassador, and Sir John Wise, head of the British Trade Mission.

A mortgage loan of $628,100 insured by the Federal Housing Administration was obtained by Richard Terrace, Inc., on the three-story garden apartment project for seventy-two families under construction at the northwest corner of Beach Twenty-second Street and Cornaga Avenue, Far Rockaway, Queens. J. Halperin Co., were the brokers.

Retail trade here this week continued upward as customers' purchases continued strong, showing increases over the heavy buying of last year. Department store sales were estimated as being up to 5 per cent over the corresponding week last year.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Here is the vote by which the Senate upheld today President Truman's veto of a bill which would have permitted Senators to call on the Federal Bureau of Investigation to investigate key atomic energy appointees (two-thirds majority necessary to override):

BIRKDALE, England, May 21 (AP) -- This country's biggest golfing throng since pre-war days saw half a dozen feminine links stars from the United States roll up a 2-1 lead over Great Britain today in defense of the gleaming silver Curtis Cup.

The need for a virile American merchant marine, not only for trade and travel, but also as a defense measure, was the principal topic at noontime exercises yesterday marking the fifteenth annual National Maritime Day.

An important factor in preventing stability in international relations has been "the absence of any positive program on the part of America" for solving world problems, the New York East Methodist Conference declared in its annual pronouncement yesterday morning at Hanson Place Central Methodist Church, at St. Felix Street, Brooklyn. The sessions started Wednesday and will end tomorrow.

SEATTLE, May 21 -- With the balloting in the Oregon Republican Presidential primary still in progress, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey flew into Washington State today in a bid to consolidate the delegate victory he scored in this state last Saturday.
Anton Raadik, transplanted Estonian now living in Chicago, received the decision over Smuggy Hursey in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A new and improved process for the manufacture from natural or synthetic rubber of seamless hollow articles such as pneumatic cushions, hot water bottles and toys, was one of the 393 inventions cited for patent awards this week by the United States patent office.

When children go to summer camps open to all faiths they should be encouraged in membership of their own religious groups, in the opinion of leading authorities of Protestant, Catholic and Jewish faiths.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 21 -- Mrs. Harry W. Moore of Flemington, international relations chairman for the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs, said today there has been too much "stalling" on important issue, owning to this being an election year.

"Clandestine," a French film about the Resistance army within France, will have its local premiere today at the Stanley. The cast features Suzy Carrier, Georges Rollin, Constant Remy and Samson Fainsilber.

The voters of New York County must elect this year a Surrogate to take the place of Surrogate Delehanty, who retires because of the age limit. This Court touches the lives and fortunes of more people from all stations of life than any other court in the city.

In a city of the magnitude of New York it is always more pleasant to dream of what might be in the distant future than to set a course limited to the possible within a fixed time. Mayor William O'Dwyer took office on Jan. 1, 1946. His term expires at the end of 1949.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The White House announced today that President Truman would on Tuesday discuss state problems with Dr. Chaim Weizman, President of the Council of Government of Israel.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- The Salvation Army has begun in Chicago a world-wide youth evangelism project. This was disclosed at a session of the first Western Hemisphere conference of the Salvationists, meeting under the leadership of Gen. Albert Orsborn, international head of the Army, and Mrs. Orsborn.

Nancy Tow attempted the difficult feat of singing a program of songs with the accompaniment of her own piano playing at Times Hall last night. This is a technique well developed by cafe and drawing-room entertainers but rarely tried by concert artists for reasons which became apparent in Miss Tow's recital.

The slumping Giants dropped another decision yesterday, this time finishing second to the Cubs, who, despite their lowly status, packed most of the power and triumphed with plenty to spare before 7,511 at the Polo Grounds. Sealing the verdict with a 6-run outburst in the fifth, the Chicagoans never trailed.

A definitive history of the Wells Fargo Company has been scheduled for fall publication by Random House, under the title "Wells Fargo." The author is Edward Hungerford, who has written a number of volumes on American railroads.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 21 -- Sidney Hanover, L. L. Herrin's 7-year-old bay that created a new world record for one mile and a sixteenth here last year, captured the $5,000 Westbury Free-for-All Trot by a length tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Former President Herbert C. Hoover chairman of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, announced today that Ferdinand Eberstadt, New York investment banker, would head a working committee to study the set-up, but not the military, policy of the Army, the Navy and the Air Force.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, Syracuse, N.Y., fried today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan providing for the consolidation of its three principal operating subsidiaries, the Buffalo Niagara Electric Corporation, the Central New York Power Corporation and the New York Power and Light Corporation.

Every year, on May 22, the nation observes Maritime Day, commemorating the voyage of the ship Savannah in 1819, using steam on part of her eastward voyage. The annual observance means more than a rereading of the first chapter in an uneven history. From that small and revolutionary beginning the country strode to eminence on the sea.

Cancer "tag day" was observed in all boroughs yesterday, with 1,500 women volunteers seeking to aid the New York Cancer Committee reach its $1,750,000 goal by next Saturday. With $500,000 still to go, "tag day" assumed special significance.

With Eugene Ormandy on the podium, the Hollywood Bowl Symphony Orchestra will begin an eight-week series of concerts over the Columbia Broadcasting System on Sunday, July 18. The concerts will be heard in the time usually reserved by the network for symphonic music: from 3 to 4:30 P.M.

St. John's University strengthened its hold on second place in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference by defeating Manhattan, 7 -- 4, yesterday at Dexter Park. The St. John's record is now 8 and 3.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The United States Government is paying $1.48 a barrel for the same grade of Arabian crude oil that the British Admiralty is buying for 20 cents a barrel, James A. Moffett, retired oil company executive and a former member of the Petroleum Advisory Committee of the National Recovery Administration, declared today.

The House of Delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York, representing more than 22,000 physicians in the state, has taken measures to set up a program of its own on blood donors and blood banks based on a policy diametrically opposed to the American Red Cross nation-wide blood donor program.

Five hundred fifty cadets of the Fordham University Reserve Officers Training Corps observed their annual Demonstration Day yesterday afternoon on the Fordham campus. The regiment was reviewed by the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, university president, and their commanding officer, Col. Norman E. Hartman, Professor of Military Science and Tactics.

PARIS, May 21 -- United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization headquarters here announced today plans for spreading the organization's activities to the United States, British and French zones of Germany.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph M. Houston will complete three conference years as the superintendent of the New York District of the New York Methodist Conference, which will hold its annual meeting Wednesday through May 30 in the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.
TEL AVIV, May 21 -- With five armies and an air force attacking them, Israel's Army and Air Force struck back today on all fronts.

Net income of the Erie Railroad for April amounted to $842,967, equal to 27 cents a common share before capital and sinking fund provisions, compared with $581,892 or 17 cents a common share for the corresponding month of last year, R.E. Woodruff, president, announced at the monthly board meeting held yesterday in Passaic, N.J.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 21 -- Dr. Jan Papanek, former Czechoslovak delegate to the United Nations, charged today that Prague's envoy to Washington had instructions to report daily to the Soviet Embassy.

The Civil Aeronautics Administration, despite protests from American flag carriers, stood fast yesterday on its contention that the proposed temporary operation of International Airport (Idlewild) satisfied all safety requirements on landings.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- President Truman requested Congress today to bring Alaska speedily into the Union of States and offered a detailed program for further settlement and economic development of the great territory.

UNION TOWNSHIP, N.J., May 21 -- Mrs. H.C. Ramsey of Baltusrol scored 45, 38 -- 83 today over the tricky Suburban links to win the second one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association. She finished three strokes ahead of Mrs. T.U. Lyman of Maplewood, who was out in 42 but returned in 44 for an 86.
OKLAHOMA CITY, May 21 (AP) -- Two boys who piloted a stolen airplane 120 miles on knowledge gleaned from comic books puzzled authorities tonight.

Customs authorities in New York are facing a costly and complicated task of refunding customs duties as a result of the new regulation extending duty-free import privileges for Americans to $400. The law, raising the $100 exemption that has been in force for fifty years, went into effect on Thursday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 21 -- The drafting of an international declaration and covenant on human rights moved into its semi-final stage today after two years of gradual progress on what may become a landmark in the growth of human freedom.

The Cosmopolitan Little Symphony, under Everett Lee, made a definitely favorable impression at its concert last night at Town Hall, with Virginia MacWatters, soprano, as soloist. This interracial instrumental ensemble, composed of thirty-eight professional musicians and including several women players, was formed by Mr. Lee last September, and had given a semi-public concert earlier in the season at City College. But it made its formal debut yesterday evening.
NANKING, May 21 -- Reluctant to continue as Premier, despite heavy pressure, Gen. Chang Chun resorted to the standard Chinese political stratagem today and abruptly left the capital to "take a rest."

An issue of industrial debentures -- $30,000,000 of twenty-five-year obligations of the National Dairy Products Company -- is to be the most substantial public offering of the market for new capital next week. The offering is expected to be made on Thursday by a syndicate headed by Goldman, Sachs Co. and Lehman Brothers.

Lord Inverchapel, for the last two years Britain's Ambassador to the United States, was prepared to sail early this morning for England aboard the Queen Mary, closing out forty-two years in Britain's diplomatic service. In a matter of days -- once the formalities of retirement are dispatched -- the 67-year-old senior Ambassador of Britain will devote himself to farming his 4,000-acre ancestral holdings in the West Highlands of Scotland.
CHICAGO, May 21 -- Action of the May deliveries of grain, trading in which ceased at the close of business, resulted today in unsettled markets on the Board of Trade.

Recently on a Sunday I was among the strollers who visited the Untermeyer estate, just above Yonkers. The trees, the pleasant lawns, the magnificent view across the Hudson, contrasted with the decay of the gray mansion.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee will not insist now on fundamental revision of the United Nations Charter, but intends to express some dissatisfaction with the present functioning of the world organization.

GENEVA, May 21 -- The International Committee of the Red Cross addressed a new appeal today to Arab Governments and the Government of Israel to respect security zones in Jerusalem. Motivated "solely by anxiety to protect the greatest possible number of human lives," the International Red Cross urged the combatants to "take all necessary measures so that at least security zones be respected."

SAPPORO, Japan, May 21 -- While Japan, with its population increasing at the rate of 1,000,000 yearly, has again begun to hint that Japanese emigration must be permitted if minimum living standards are to be maintained, this northern island of Hokkaido, second largest in the Japanese Archipelago, still remains one of the world's wide open spaces.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 21 (AP) -- Counter-attacks by Israeli forces were reported tonight in the Haganah Army communique which said there were "no changes in the battle for Jerusalem's old city."

New Jersey strawberries will reach their peak in point of supply the first week in June. As supplies of fruit from that state wane, New York will take over, with the peak scheduled for June 15. This is vital information to those who preserve and freeze the berries at home, because for such purposes locally grown fruit is superior to that shipped from a distance.
DETROIT, May 22 (AP) -- Carefully shrouded in canvas, new Ford passenger automobiles are daily being hauled from assembly plants across the country.

LOS ANGELES, May 22 (AP) -- Mel Patton again demonstrated that he is the No. 1 candidate of the United States for the Olympic Games sprint team, but the widely heralded "Race of the Century" last night turned out to be the blunder of the year.

MARSEILLES, the French port in which the principal action of this novel occurs, is also, for the author's purposes, the whole modern cosmos: what happens in its streets, cafes and houses during the telling of the story is also being enacted in the larger reaches of the world.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 22 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, victor in the Oregon Republican Presidential primary, flew 800 miles to keep a luncheon date today with Gov. Earl Warren of California, the one avowed White House aspirant who has eschewed the primary trail.

The Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., will be the beneficiary of two parties in the near future, the performance of "Inside U.S.A.," at the Century Theatre on Thursday night and a basket luncheon and bridge on June 2. The latter will take place at the Village and the luncheon will be served on the campus.

Establishment of the Jewish State in Palestine and the Italian elections were the outstanding news events from the international viewpoint cited by junior high school students taking part yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.
ST. LOUIS, May 22 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns defeated Washington, 4 -- 2, today for a clean sweep of their three-game series, with Gerry Priddy providing the winning punch before 2,993 fans.

TWO American ladies undertake a job of post-war espionage in Switzerland, where the Nazis are believed to be up to something in preparation for the next war. Miss Ann Thorne is about 50, was an ambulance driver in World War I and knows Europe like a book.

MAX SAVELLE, professor of history in the University of Washington, has written an ambitious, well-intentioned and conscientious book on the components of the "American Mind" in the generation preceding the American Revolution.

The strongest United States Navy conceivable would be crippled without the backing of an adequate merchant marine, and the American people should realize that our merchant fleet and our national existence are inseparable, Admiral Louis Denfeld, USN, Chief of Naval Operations, declared last night.

Two automobiles collided head-on on the east-bound service road of Union Turnpike, 500 feet east of Queens Boulevard, at 1:45 A.M. yesterday. Three persons were killed outright. Three others died later in Queens General Hospital and three others were injured critically.

A twenty-four-hour search by water and air for two high school boys who disappeared Friday night in a rowboat off Brighton Beach had failed to disclose any trace of them last night. The search is continuing.

New York University and Sarah Lawrence will jointly sponsor the Second Workshop in Contemporary Culture to be held at the latter's Bronxville campus from June 7 to July 2. The program will offer seminars, studio and laboratory work in the physical and social sciences, the arts, literature, psychology and philosophy.

THE opening of a regular program service last week by WATV, Newark, brought with it an unpleasant surprise to a number of owners of home television receivers. They discovered that they could not tune in the station's programs on channel 13.

The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation announced yesterday a grant of $225,000 to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for re-establishment of the Sloan-sponsored fellowship program to provide graduate training in business administration and economics to young business executives of outstanding promise.
WELLESLEY, Mass., May 22 -- President Mildred McAfee Horton of Wellesley College has announced the election of Mrs. Lee B. Morey of New York City as Alumnae Trustee.

BRYAN FOY, a producer who obviously doesn't let moss grow on topical themes, will tackle an atomic subject for his first picture as an independent producer at Eagle Lion. This is a yarn tentatively titled "These Are My Orders," based on an article by Norbert Gagen, who reportedly was a counter-intelligence agent during the war and had some melodramatic traffic with the atom bomb plant at Oak Ridge, Tenn.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (AP) -- The cellar-dwelling Cincinnati Reds went on a hitting spree today, banging out 15 base hits to score their first victory of the season over the Philadelphia Phillies by a 9-to-2 score.

THE radio program of the past week clearly was the debate between Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and Harold E. Stassen on the subject of controlling communism. The lively if indecisive pro and con between two of the Republican candidates for President was far and away the most arresting political broadcast in many a day, one which conceivably could be copied with profit for the voter during the formal campaign this summer.

PORT-OF-SPAIN -- Down at the end of the long arc of the West Indies, Trinidad is a transportation crossroads and the busiest port in the Antilles. It is getting busier now that the cruise ships are coming back.

THE last bit of paper work has been done on one of the trickiest subjects ever entertained by a British film company -- T.S. Eliot's "Murder in the Cathedral." The project, which is a straight commercial proposition and no monkey business, is the joint enterprise of the author and Austrian-born director George Hoellering, the man behind the Academy, London's best-known continental cinema.

Encouraged by the upward trend in retail trade here last week, retailers showed greater inclination to place fall orders, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

ON Sept. 20 of last year the world in general and New York City in particular suffered a peculiar loss. That was the day Fiorello La Guardia died. It has been rumored that during the last week of his hopeless illness the former Mayor of the City of New York felt bitter and deserted.

Commenting yesterday on Mayor O'Dwyer's declaration that four leaders of the Transport Workers Union followed the Communist party line, Bernard G. Brophy, president of Local 380, Municipal Transport Workers, AFL, expressed surprise that the Mayor's list had omitted the name of Councilman Michael J. Quill, international president of the TWU.

Lack of cotton textile contracts for delivery in the third and fourth quarters will force many mills to curtail their production beginning July 1, if not sooner, it was learned last week. Narrow sheeting mills, hit by dull business in the bag trade, have already begun to reduce extra-shift operations and they will be followed by producers of many other categories of goods.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 22 -- United States Consul General Thomas C. Wasson was seriously wounded by a sniper's bullet at noon today in the center of Jerusalem as he was returning from the French Consulate.

I rejoice to see a political figure like Winston Churchill speak out from the height of his international authority for the need for uniting the countries of Europe in a political federation, thus completing the economic unity envisaged by the Marshall Plan.

If the inexpensive radioisotopes now obtainable from Oak Ridge, Tenn., through the Atomic Energy Commission are to be utilized scientifically with the highest efficiency, research workers will have to learn more about them than they now know. Hence four-week training courses have been organized by the commission and the health physics section of the Oak Ridge National Laboratory.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) -- The National Coal Association demanded tonight that Congress put the United Mine Workers under the anti-trust laws and forbid collective bargaining on welfare and pension plans.
WICHITA, Kan., May 22 -- Kansas farmers are singing a sad, old song this pre-harvest season -- the weatherman has done them wrong again. There ham been entirely too little rain.

With Irving Mondschein accounting for nineteen points in five events, New York University outscored Manhattan College, 101 to 86, to take team honors for the seventh time in a row at the fifteenth annual metropolitan intercollegiate outdoor track and field championships yesterday.

TOKYO, May 16 (Delayed) -- This correspondent has just made a brief cruise aboard one of the vessels of the new Japanese Coast Guard. This is the "Maritime Safety Board," against which the Soviet delegate recently protested in the Allied Control Council as constituting a reconstructed Japanese Navy.

WITH Professor Peattie of Ohio State University, a "flatland furriner," as impartial chairman, a team of eight newspaper men have put their county's best foot forward. Some books are penned with an eye to Hollywood; this well-illustrated volume seems aimed at the throngs of paying guests who constitute Berkshire's second industry.

Two young would-be cowboys who vanished on May 9 from their homes on Washington Heights with $1,175 in bonds and $300 in rare coins were located yesterday in Tucson, Ariz., with complete Western outfits, down to hand-tooled knife scabbards, but only 85 cents in cash.

THE Sunday boatsman and the man who cranks an outboard motor only when on vacation will have their day on the Hudson River June 13 when the sixteenth annual Hudson River outboard motor boat marathon will be run from Albany to New York.

To the consternation of Jolly Cholly Grimm and his surprisingly cheerful Cubs, who doubtless had been lulled to expect something of a different order, the Giants snapped out of their doldrums at the Polo Grounds yesterday with such violence they all but tossed the startled Chicagoans clear into the adjoining waters of the rippling Harlem.

WASHINGTON. ONCE a month, sometimes oftener, a curious ceremony takes place on the second floor of the Department of Agriculture building in Washington. Officials under armed guard open the double locks on a strongbox, empty its contents, then file into a suite of offices.

READERS of "The Gift of the Golden Cup" will delight in this new book continuing the adventures of Atia and Gaius. Atia is a young Roman matron now, but marriage has not quenched her taste for excitement, and her brother Gaius preserves his knack for always being about when things are happening.

The New York Furniture Exchange yesterday said they had experienced what manufacturers' representatives termed "the first normal Friday in several months." Heavy retailer attendance in the morning tapered off later in the day but some substantial orders were placed by smaller stores before owners and buyers left the building.

Dominated by mixed labor developments, financial markets last week lost some of their buoyancy through profit-taking. After the long sharp rise, liquidation of stocks was not unexpected, but prices firmed up in the last Saturday session for four months.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 22 -- Frank Quinn, Yale's ace hurler, turned in a brilliant effort today at the blanked Army, 1--0. This was the Eli's eleventh consecutive baseball victory and its fourth triumph against one setback in defense of Eastern Intercollegiate League honors.
PARIS, May 22 (AP) -- Frank Parker of Los Angeles got an assist from darkness late today in his third-round struggle with France's Bernard Destremau in the French international tennis championships.

JUST such a book on Spenser for the educated reader, not the scholar, has been long overdue. That it should be written with easy assurance (Mr. Bradner knows the latest in Spenser scholarship and the whole of Spenser's works) and in a lively style is double cause for rejoicing.

Retail activity last week was excellent despite unfavorable weather, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Beachwear, cotton dress and accessory departments reported exceptionally good business.

Capt. Michael Angelo Musmanno, USNR, who presided over the United States military tribunal in Nuremberg that tried twenty-four members of the German Elite Guard, or SS, on charges of murdering 2,000,000 persons, returned yesterday to this country aboard an Army transport.

WITH Memorial Day falling on Sunday, Monday, May 31, will be generally observed as a holiday. Banks and schools will be closed, and most offices will not open, in order to allow their workers to take advantage of the long weekend.

THIS carefully compiled volume of 430 selections from many and varied authors is for modern readers interested in the meaning and goal of life and who are convinced "that there exists an ultimate Reality that is by nature both transcendent and immanent."

The most hotly contested election of officers of the Medical Society of the County of New York, largest county medical society in the country, will take place tomorrow night at the New York Academy of Medicine, when for the first time in many years New York doctors will have the opportunity to choose their officers for the next year from two slates of rival candidates.

For three hours and twenty minutes yesterday afternoon and again in the evening, New York City's Boy Scouts -- 15,000 in shiny khaki, blue and green uniforms, directed by 3,000 adult leaders -- demonstrated in colorful fashion at Madison Square Garden every phase of scouting activity.

VIENNA, May 22 -- Austria's money shortage, which will be intensified by Marshall Plan deliveries, led to a minor crisis in the State Treasury today when most extreme measures had to be taken to get together 200,000,000 Austrian schillings to pay for past gifts under Congressional relief deliveries.

ST. LOUIS, May 22 -- A comeback that Gene Sarazen essayed in the National P.G.A. championship at the Norwood Hills Country Club just twenty-six years after he won the title for the first time, failed today after a keen match that went to Ben Hogan of Hershey, Pa., by 1 up at the thirty-sixth hole.

THE spacious installation and clear lighting which the Metropolitan Museum has accorded its exhibition of masterpieces from the Berlin museums have resulted in a more impressive showing than the earlier rather crowded display at the National Gallery in Washington.

SEVERAL years ago Bill "Bojangles" Robinson, the untiring little man who had then been rated the greatest tap-dancer in the world for more than a quarter of a century, parried a question about his apparent agelessness by saying: "By the time I'm 70, I ought to be a pretty fair hoofer." Robinson will be 70 day after tomorrow.

American citizenship carries with it not only many rights and privileges but even greater duties and responsibilities. This was the theme stressed by 1,000 civic, professional, business and school leaders who attended the third National Conference on Citizenship this week in Washington.

MADISON, N.J., May 22 -- Champion Rock Ridge Night Rocket, the Bedlington terrier that is the greatest show dog in Continued in Page Column 2 America, won the world's biggest outdoor exhibition today when he was waved to the center of the ring in the eighteenth Morris and Essex Kennel Club event at Giralda Farms.

"NO curfew order has ever been more strictly enforced or more implicitly obeyed," says Author Jim Corbett, "than the curfew imposed by the Man-Eating Leopard of Rudraprayag." It was a curfew of terror.

AN increasing number of children between the ages of 1 and 4 are being killed by automobiles during the months of May and June, according to surveys conducted by the accident-prevention department of the Association of Casualty and Surety Companies.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 22 -- The United Nations Security Council paused in its debate on the Palestine crisis today to express deep sympathy for Thomas C. Wasson, United States Consul General in Jerusalem, who was wounded while carrying out his duties as American representative on the Council's Truce Commission.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 22 (AP) -- Harold Stassen said today in a statement that he had sent congratulations by telegraph to Governor Dewey on his victory in the Oregon primary.

IN the heated struggle of ideologies that dominates post-war Europe, a new concept of the most important post in a Government has emerged. In case after case -- in front of as well as behind the Iron Curtain -- that post has been shown to be the Ministry of the Interior. Technically a subordinate Cabinet member, the Interior Minister in many lands today is more powerful than his Prime Minister.

NAGS HEAD, N.C., May 22 -- This section is now attracting more anglers now than at any time in its history, for with comfortable modern hotels and excellent bay, surf, offshore and black bass fishing it insures some kind of angling in all weather.

THREE series honoring noted Russians are being issued by the U.S.S.R., according to word received from Moscow last week by J. H. Stolow. One group marks the fiftieth anniversary of the death of Ivan Ivanovich Shishkin (1831-1898), painter and engraver, whose likeness is on 30-kopecs and 1-ruble, with his painting "Rye" represented on 50k and his canvas "Bears in the Woods" on 60k.

ONE of the most important questions before the world today is: On what information do the Soviet leaders appraise Soviet-American relations? That question and its importance have been re-emphasized by the recent exchange between Russia and the United States over Soviet-American relations.

A CITY garden that does not look like every other city garden apparently can be made, after all. It began to look as if every urban planting, pleasant though it might be, had to have the same limited group of shrubs and flowers arranged in pots and tubs or in narrow borders around the inevitable grass plot.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., May 22 -- The bottom fishing boat, Squirt, a thirty-two footer, capsized about a mile off Manasquan Inlet early today. Of the thirty-four persons believed to have been aboard, one was drowned, another died on the way to a hospital, and thirty-two were fished out of the chilly waters by other fishing boats and a private cruiser.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 22 (AP) -- J.M. Roebling's consistent Blue Peter, paying $4.20, $3 and $2.40 for $2 across the board, sped to a three-quarter-length track record triumph today over Crispin Oglebay's surprising colt, Noble Impulse, in the feature at Garden State Park.

Dr. Harry S. Mustard, city Commissioner of Health, said yesterday he saw no reason why the stand of the Medical Society of the State of New York opposing in effect the American Red Cross nation-wide blood donor program should interfere with the plan in operation in this city.

Encouraging results in clinical studies of polymyxin, a new substance, for treatment of certain illnesses not curable by penicillin or streptomycin, were reported yesterday at the closing session of a two-day conference on antibiotics derived from bacillus polymyxin.

BRIDGETON, N.J., May 22 -- Seabrook Farms, a large processor of frozen foods, made an offer today to provide free facilities for saving any of the stores of frozen meats, vegetables and fruits that are not removed from the lockers of the American Frozen Food Lockers Corporation in New York and Connecticut when its five plants are closed next Saturday.

BETWEEN the publication of his first volume of "The Journals" last year and his second volume this year, Andre Gide was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature. Since this distinguished literary prize is given on the basis not of a single book but of a body of work there can be no quarrel with the award, except perhaps as it is belated.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 22 -- Harold Evans, the Philadelphia Quaker leader who was selected by the United Nations as Municipal Commissioner for Jerusalem, left today for the Holy Land to try to negotiate a Jerusalem truce between the Arabs and Jews.

HOW, I wonder, will it be if in our pursuit, of knowledge we stumble upon some awkward fact as disturbing for the human race as an inquiry into the state of his own finances may sometimes prove to the individual? The pursuit of knowledge can never be anything but a leap in the dark, and a leap in the dark is a very uncomfortable thing.

DWARF French marigolds are unsurpassed for continuous color near the edge of the border, and every year new and worth-while varieties of this most popular annual are available. This season, for example, brings Red Head, one of the best and most richly colored of the French marigolds, to the market.

CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) -- Ky. Colonel and Olympia, swift juvenile colts, raced a thrilling dead heat in the twenty-first running of the $10,000 added Joliet Stakes on the Lincoln Fields program at Washington Park today. Ol' Skipper was third before 22,806 fans, largest crowd of the Chicago season.

LONDON, May 22 -- Against a background of reports from the United States that Anglo-American relations were undergoing their severest strain since the end of the war, Foreign Secretary Bevin today invited United States Ambassador Lewis W. Douglas to discuss the divergencies between their policies on Palestine.

MR. PREBBLE is a young English journalist who fought in the Lowlands and Germany and served in the Occupation. "The Edge of the Night" is his second novel, his first to appear in this country. As a reflection -- manifestly a close one -- of his 1944 and 1945 experiences, it braves the difficulties of our period of shifting sentiment -- from emotional involvement to realistic detachment -- in three ways.

CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) -- Sewell Avery and his lieutenants in Montgomery Ward Co., appeared today to have settled their rumored differences of opinion. A change in the company's by-laws, filed with the Chicago Stock Exchange, defined the powers of Mr. Avery as chairman of the board, Wilbur Norton as president and of the several vice presidents of the big mail-order and retail chain store organization.
THE French are thrifty; they are good cooks. What's more, they can be both at the same time. That's something to remember now, when a dollar scarcely buys a pound of butter.

Despite reported indications that official Washington has become less concerned about the continuance of the inflationary trend, savings bankers still consider it the nation's No. 1 problem, it was learned yesterday.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 22 (UP) -- Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, widow of the President, hinted today that she might soon relinquish chairmanship of the United Nations Human Rights Commission.

Jacques Rachmilovich, Russian conductor who founded and directs the Santa Monica-Symphony Orchestra, made his New York debut yesterday when he conducted the NBC Symphony in one of the regular early Saturday night concerts of its summer series.

Favored by some superb twirling by Tom Casey, its sophomore star, New York University's nine assured itself of at least a tie for first place in the Metropolitan Collegiate Conference yesterday by defeating Fordham, 5 -- 2, at the Rams' field.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The preference primary in Oregon, last of the series in which Republican voters can indicate their Presidential choice for 1948, finally proved what the previous primaries strongly suggested. This is, that there are no wings on the seat of any of the three candidates who are actively running for the nomination.

AS a result of a favor to George, an uneasy ghost, Pete and Joe, two 13-year-olds, meet some of the most famous persons in the legends and folklore of the Hudson River Valley. With George's guidance the two boys are soon on speaking terms with their restless spirits.

Industrial management methods are being constantly drawn upon by the City of New York to reduce costs and improve municipal administrative efficiency, Abraham D. Beame, assistant director of the budget, revealed during the second day of the first annual convention of the Systems and Procedures Association at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel.

The School of Education at New York University in cooperation with the United Nations will conduct this summer a six-week workshop for teachers and "lay workers" on "The United Nations and International Understanding," Dean Ernest O. Melby announced yesterday.
All last week in many languages Russian radio transmitters beamed to the world statements like this:
CAIRO, May 22 (AP) -- Egyptian mobile forces have entered Beth lehem, five miles from Jerusalem, and El Majdal, an important military objective on the Mediterranean coast, it was announced tonight.

FOR THIS WEEK: Pinch the blossoms off strawberry plants set out this spring, so they can make better growth before bearing fruit. . . . Weeds grow faster than seedlings and most planted areas need to be gone over once a week at this time of year. Try a hoe, hook or hand weeder. . . . Train the new growth of wines to their supports.

THERE is no peace for the music critic. Just when he thinks he has his armory of similes neatly sorted out for easy reference, something comes along that makes him start all over. Take the problem of saying something odious about a singer; why, all you need to observe is that he or she has the voice of a frog, and that settles that.

CECIL ROBERTS has a competent style and a flair for the sort of landscapes which attract the literary tourist's eye; the lichen-grown English manors, the picture-postcard beauties of Italy, the perfectionist simplicity of Palm Beach, the lights and shadows of Riviera life.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 22 -- Interest in Georgia's Gubernatorial campaign mounted this week as rumors persisted that Herman Talmadge might step out of the race in favor of either his mother, widow of Eugene Talmadge, or Representative Eugene Pace.
GENEVA, May 22 -- Unless a quick solution is found to the problem of freeing the channels of intra-European trade, Western Europe's 1949 dollar deficit is likely to be greater than that for 1948.

Overriding attempts to postpone the question, delegates to the convention of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union, AFL, voted yesterday to bar Communist -- as well as "Fascists and members of other subversive groups" -- from local and international offices in their organization.
Double the guard around the Gowanus Canal, post additional sentries on the Brooklyn, Williamsburg and Manhattan bridges and alert all lifeguards at Coney Island. The Dodgers lost again.

NEW DELHI, India, May 22 -- A comprehensive program to raise India's production of food grains 10,000,000 tons a year, thus ending recurrent threats of famine, and raising the general subsistence level is outlined in the report of the Food Grains Policy Committee, was made public today.

RENO, May 22 (AP) -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey said here to night that the United States had "taken a propaganda licking from the Communists in Russia who have absolutely nothing to sell but slavery and souls."

Upon reading Mr. Taubman's detailed and colorful description of the Rachmaninoff contest (NEW YORK TIMES, April 30), a contestant's memory brings back another impressive gathering of musicians at the Rubinstein contest in Paris, in August, 1905, when forty-three men from various countries competed for the 10,000-franc awards.
BUENOS AIRES, May 22 -- The Central Bank, which recently took drastic steps to conserve the dwindling supply of dollars, announced yesterday another restriction on foreign exchange.

The French Chamber of Commerce of the United States announced yesterday that the newly formed Committee of French Exhibitions, in cooperation with the cultural section of the French Embassy, would organize a series of "French Weeks" in cities throughout the country, beginning next month.

BUENOS AIRES, May 22 (UP) -- George Lohman, prominent United States cattle breeder, is still under arrest at Asuncion, Paraguay, despite a Paraguayan denial in Washington, D.C., that he ever was arrested, reports from Formosa said today.

For the last eight months a steady stream of scientific and technologic propaganda has poured out of Moscow to convince the world that Russians were the first inventors of principles and machines maliciously credited to Americans, Englishmen and others who were unfortunate enough to have been born in Western democracies and to come under the malign capitalistic influence.
The annual report of the Holly Sugar Corporation showed yesterday a net profit of $2,165,911 after all charges, including $1,425,000 provision for taxes, for the fiscal year ended last March.

The existence of a concerted movement in government and maritime industry circles to have the effective date of the Weichel Bill moved up from July 1 to June 1, to give the country's merchant fleet an earlier start toward revitalization, was confirmed here yesterday by reliable shipping sources.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 22 -- All the elements of this wierd spring weather except more rain were present today to usher in the opening of the championship summer sailing season on Long Island Sound.

THE National Council of State Garden Clubs will hold its nineteenth convention and annual meeting at the Lafayette Hotel, Lexington, Ky., Monday through Thursday. With the slogan "Garden Clubs in a Changing World," the 400 delegates will plan activities for the coming year.

TWO debut recitals are to be found on the week's schedule. Tomorrow at the Cort Deborah Bertonoff will make her formal New York bow, and on Wednesday Judith Martin will appear at the Ethnologic Theatre.

Early results of the European Recovery Program upon France and other European countries were praised yesterday at La Guardia Field by Henri Bonnet, Frenca, Ambassador to this country. M. Bonnet boarded an Air France plane for Paris for consultations with his Government for the first time since September.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 22 -- A Yugoslav Government spokesman refused to comment tonight on reports circulated abroad of numerous arrests in Yugoslavia in a move to purge the Communist party and the Government of opposition elements.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 22 -- Coach Bob Giegengack's Yale track team rolled up 85 3/4 points in a triangular meet with Penn and Dartmouth at Dewitt Cuyler Field today to triumph easily and maintain its undefeated status in dual and triangular competition this year both indoors and out.

WASHINGTON -- An increase from $100 to $400 in the value of goods and gadgets that could be brought in duty-free by American travelers abroad was approved by President Truman last week, terminating a half-century-old limitation that had restrained tourists and world trade.

FIVE books on photographic lighting have been published recently to keep up with the growing interest in the subject among amateur photographers. Two of the books deal with the application of lighting principles to portraiture, the others with pictorial lighting, general illumination and flash work.

IF there was, in your youth, a teacher who seemed to make you feel you would one day be capable of doing something worth while, then you will especially appreciate and enjoy this portrait of a public school teacher.

THIS notable volume is the collaborative work of five American scholars. Kemp Malone writes of "The Old English Period (to 1100)"; Albert C. Baugh of "The Middle English Period (1100-1500)"; the late Tucker Brooke of "The Renaissance (1500-1600)"; George Sherburn of "The Restoration and Eighteenth Century (1660-1789)"; and Samuel C. Chew of "The Nineteenth Century and After (1789-1939)."

COOPERSTOWN -- After nearly eight decades of wandering, the Great Cardiff Giant, the "eighth wonder of the world," America's most famous hoax, has come back to up-state New York. Last week he was put on view once more, this time in the Farmers' Museum, operated by the New York State Historical Association in Cooperstown.

WOODSTOCK, Ill., May 22 -- Only through the creation of a sense of world citizenship can we prevent a third world war, Dr. Quincy Wright, Professor of International Law at the University of Chicago, warned today.

AN experiment in practical community service has proved so successful in the Washington Heights district that the Mayor's Committee on Unity has recommended a similar program for the East Bronx. Four years ago twenty street gangs roamed over Washington Heights, breeding juvenile delinquents who tangled constantly with the police and the courts.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 22 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York added Oregon's twelve delegates today to his prospective first ballot total at the Republican National Convention.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 22 -- The Philadelphia No. 1 squad stood out as the top team following its double triumph during the second day of the sixteenth annual National lacrosse tourney of the United States Women's Lacrosse Association at Adelphi College today.

Fall and winter buying by New York department and specialty stores will be guided mainly by consumer demands, according to leading retailers questioned here at the week's end. Executives in a number of stores stated that careful studies of consumer desires in quality, price and fashion have been made during the last few months and the results have shown clearly that the price structure of inventories must be corrected.
MAY ushers in a wealth of flowering material with which to beautify our homes. So many forms, colors and textures are available that an endless variety of arrangements can be made.

To preserve the benefits of Social Security for wholesale salesmen, an emergency conference of Senators and House Leaders with representatives of fifty-six organizations having an estimated membership of 35,000 salesmen will be held tonight in the Statler Hotel, Washington, D. C.

IF, after fifty pages, Irish Annie Jordan -- red-gold hair, level gaze, head held high, and all --doesn't forcibly remind you of Greer Garson, doesn't fairly leap off the page, twist your arm, and make you holler "Walter Pidgeon," just return the unread portion of the book and this reviewer will cheerfully refund double your $150,000.

To make a fluoroscopic examination, the physician places the patient between the X-ray tube and a fluorescent screen. He flicks a switch, whereupon X-rays pass through the patient's body, and the screen glows. What the physician sees is a shadow of the internal organs.
BIRKDALE, England, May 22 -- America's links queens retained the big silver Curtis Cup today by defeating the best women golfers that England, Scotland and Ireland could muster.

AT ZION GATE, in Jerusalem, May 22 (AP) -- Waves of Israeli soldiers charged Arab Legion positions in the Zion Gate early today but failed to reach their comrades, hemmed into a corner of Jerusalem's Old Walled City.

The recent monograph published by the Southern Association of Science and Industry may become a milestone in the comprehensive, long-term plan of Southern States to improve their industry and agriculture. This monograph is the first of twelve projected studies.
New York supporters of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey were greatly encouraged yesterday, as reports of Mr. Dewey's victory over Harold E. Stassen in the Oregon preferential primary on Friday were received.

THIS is the time to see tree peonies at the height of their handsome bloom. These shrubby counterparts of the familiar perennial are distinguished principally by their woody stems, but usually they are taller with bigger flowers, and they begin to blossom two or three weeks earlier than ordinary peonies.

CHUNGKING, May 16 (Delayed) -- The most extensive post-war construction program of any city in China has changed the appearance of Chungking. Americans who left here at the end of the war with Japan would have difficulty in finding their way about China's wartime capital.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- An inadvertent error by THE NEW YORK TIMES in reporting the Oregon debate on communism between former Gov. Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota and Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York has been continued into The Congressional Record.

MOST bridge players contend that it is hard to bid misfits, the hands where neither partner can support the other's suits. But it isn't hard to bid misfits, because you don't bid them, you pass them. The really hard hands to bid are the perfect fits, the dream hands in which every high card is valuable, every suit is worth its weight in tricks, and everything works.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 22 -- Turkish newspaper criticism of the United States' attitude toward Turkish economic interests has become more pronounced as signs of an economic crises grow. More than sixty businesses, three of them large, have gone bankrupt.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated within a narrow range during the short session yesterday and the volume of business was rather small. Final prices were 4 to 9 points lower.

CLEVELAND, May 22 (AP) -- Gene Bearden, 27-year-old Purple Heart war veteran, tossed a six-hit shut-out at the Boston Red Sox today as the league-leading Cleveland Indians recorded a 7-to-0 victory before a ladies' day crowd of 28,997.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 22 -- Herman T. Stichman, New York State Housing Commissioner, spoke this afternoon at ceremonies marking the commencement of demolition of seventy old buildings for construction of the Winbrook apartments, a $5,500,000 low-cost housing development here.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 22 -- The United Nations Security Council called on Arabs and Jews today to stop the fighting in Palestine within thirty-six hours from midnight tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The ominous announcement that three "improved" atomic bombs have been successfully fired at Eniwetok has spurred the activities of a little group of men in the Pentagon here. Headed by Russell J. Hopley, they are seeking to devise a country-wide plan for civil defense in the United States if it should ever be attacked.

A 21-year-old burglar suspect was shot fatally early yesterday when surprised by a war veteran in the basement of a brownstone private house in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, according to the police of the Ralph Avenue station.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 22 (AP) -- The Lebanese Government's reply to the United States' protest against the arrest and internment of forty American passengers from the United States ship Marine Carp was cabled today to Washington.

This has been a season of boy wonder accordionists. Earlier there were accordion recitals by Joseph Pizzi and Charles Amato, both 13, and yesterday afternoon there was a recital at Town Hall by an even younger boy, John Melani, aged 10.
LINCOLN, Neb., May 22 (AP) -- Madill (Bud) Gartiser and Richard Ault rewrote the Big Seven hurdles record sheet today, leading Missouri to a smashing triumph in the conference track and field meet.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 22 -- Following is the text of the statement made today before the United Nations Security Council by Warren R. Austin, permanent representative of the United States:
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 22 -- In its penultimate outing of the season, Army overwhelmed Rutgers, 122 to 18, in a one-sided track meet at North Athletic Field today.

A PIONEER Alaskan, Herbert Hilscher has done an excellent stint of explaining "Alaska Now." He has used a lifelong knowledge of his subject. He has made his result as lively, as authentic, as vivid as it is thorough. His is probably the most engaging of the several recent books about the past, the present and particularly the future of the territory which our post-war interest has called forth and caused to publish.

LONDON, May 22 -- The thorn of Palestine has been extracted from the British lion's paw, but after one week there is no relief from the pain. Being a stubborn animal he is not likely to perform tamely at the circus at Lake Success until he feels better.

WITH the international tug-of-war seeming to ease in the week, business attention turned more closely to domestic affairs. Strike news and politics was the chief fare. The packing-house strike was called off on the terms of the companies, with one exception, at about the average wage increase of the "third round."

Nine Bethlehem Steel Company Atlantic Coast shipyards, employing some 30,000 workers, were notified yesterday by the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, that its members want a "substantial wage increase."

SAN CARLOS DE BARILOCHE, Argentina -- Bariloche is one of those never-never places, a picturesque little town on the southern shore of Lake Nahuel Huapi, in the extreme western corner of the national territory of Rio Negro, near the Chilean border.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Welfare and Retirement Fund of the United Mine Workers, as now constituted, will finance the $100-a-month pension plan originally proposed by John L. Lewis. This is the opinion of Murray W. Latimer, industrial pensions expert employed by the union to examine the problem.

THE New Dance Group Festival, which gets under way at the Mansfield Theatre with two performances today, is the third major festival of this enterprising organization, and its first since 1945. The six performances will make for some pretty concentrated dance-going between now and Thursday night.
