With the date for adjournment for the political conventions less than a month away, Congress still has to decide some fundamental questions about the armed services of this country. The most important is whether to reenact Selective Service. That is the key to all the rest.

The beginning of a long-term expansion of capital goods buying by India, represented here by the recent $3,000,000 purchase of three model 749 Constellation aircraft, will be followed by purchases of industrial machinery and equipment, officials of Tata Industries revealed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) -- The Navy revealed tonight that it had developed a pilotless aircraft for "immediate usefulness in the event of war."

A placard of terrifying significance stares America in the face. In public buildings, schools, offices, in our bustling market places and overflowing stores, the picture of a mother and child looks out -- gaunt faces and weary eyes reflecting hunger, illness and desperation.

It is hard to understand why the Bikini test of atomic bombs in 1946 was heralded with a fanfare of publicity and the test at Eniwetok Atoll, announced last week in Washington, was carried on with the utmost secrecy. We were told only that three unidentified atomic "weapons" were tested at Eniwetok with brilliant results.

LAST week the departmental record keeper, pencil poised until the proper moment, marked down "Man and Superman" as the longest-run Shavian play in America. It was an occasion to be honored and everyone so intended.

Twelve "rallies" -- five in Harlem and seven in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn -- were held yesterday by the United Public Workers of America, CIO, against the advice and pleas of Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard.

HELSINKI, Finland, May 22 -- Yrjoe Leino, Communist Minister of the Interior, was dismissed from office today by President Juho K. Paasikivi. The Minister's departure signalized the start of a strike of dock workers in this port ordered by the Communist-dominated stevedores union as a protest against his ousting.

BOSTON, May 22 (AP) -- Ed Chapdelaine of Manchester, Conn., stroked the Boston University freshman crew to victory today and three hours later paced the varsity eight to triumph in the sixth annual Dad Vail regatta on the slightly choppy Charles River.

DETROIT, May 22 (AP) -- Exploding for three runs in the ninth inning before a man was retired, the Detroit Tigers wrung out a 6-to-5 decision over the Philadelphia Athletics today, dropping the A's a game and a half behind the league-leading Cleveland Indians.

LEO DUROCHER, a modest and self-effacing character who never leads with a light left if he can lead with his chin, has stuck out his jaw again in his usual inviting fashion. He has written a book, "The Dodgers and Me." Leo slipped up slightly in his choice of titles. It should have been, "Me and the Dodgers," that being the order of importance.

The election of new officers was announced yesterday by William G. Woolfolk, chairman of the American Light and Traction Company in compliance with an order of the Securities and Exchange Commission to separate the company from its parent, the United Light and Railways Company.

THIS critical study of Oscar Wilde as critic, poet, writer of fiction and fable, and playwright, is included in a series now being issued by New Directions under the general, and somewhat ambiguous, title of "Makers of Modern Literature."

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Mundt-Nixon bill "to protect the United States against un-American and subversive activities" swept through the House of Representatives this week by the resounding majority of 319 to 58. The event was accompanied by loud acclaim from the Right and by cries of anguish from the Left -- a din that will continue for some time.

PARIS, May 22 -- The first effect of Marshall Plan aid in France became apparent today when Premier Robert Schuman announced that, thanks to this aid, the French bread ration would be raised from 200 grams to 250 grams [roughly 8 ounces] a day June 1.

BERLIN, May 22 -- Aroused by the growing antagonism of the populace and the waning influence of the Soviet-sponsored Socialist Unity party, Soviet military authorities have launched a new campaign to strengthen the Communist hold on the people of the Soviet zone.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The State Department has assured the Senate that the United States will not finance arms for Western Europe or underwrite any European defense agreement without specific permission from Congress.
LONDON, May 22 (Reuters) -The Australians made a good start today in their sternest test of the tour so far, when they scored 407 for five wickets against the Marylebone Cricket Club at Lords.

An exhibition celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the International Society for Contemporary Music opens tomorrow in the Music Division of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The display in "One World in Music" will include autograph letters received by the society from famous composers and conductors and photographs of the composers whose works will be performed in Amsterdam, Holland, next month when the annual international festival will be held.
Denouncing British aid to Arabs, rabbis in sermons here yesterday urged prompt United Nations action on Palestine and the lifting of the arms embargo by the United States.

THERE have been many changes at the Paris Conservatory of Music since 1823, when 11-year-old Franz Liszt was turned away by dour Maria Luigi Cherubini, then director, because the child prodigy pianist was a foreigner.

AS I have been in the habit of standing to see the more popular shows on Broadway for the last four years, I have noticed a marked inconsistency in distribution of tickets for standees at various theatres. Two years ago I was forced to make five trips to "Annie Get Your Gun" before securing a standee's ticket.

Soviet industrial leaders have adopted a new approach to the expansion of the country's industrial economy, one by which they hope to make up for the lag behind the plans in 1947 and to achieve ambitious goals in 1948, information gathered from Russian sources disclosed yesterday.

NEWPORT, R. I. -- The second annual three-day pilgrimage to colonial Newport, May 29-31, will give this city another opportunity to relieve its pre-Revolutionary War days. Newport was founded in 1635, and the history of many of its famous structures goes back almost that far.

AS everyone who reads knows, Mr. Bromfield, the novelist, is engaged in a farming venture which his skill and energy have turned into something of importance to his country. Since "Pleasant Valley," his first report on his project, in 1945, Mr. Bromfield has bought one more farm and leased another.
SOME parents see their own children through mumps and measles, fist fights, growing pains and graduations; then they start all over with other people's children. Why do foster parents do it?

Recommendations made yesterday by the Manhattan Chapter of the Congress of American Women called on the Park Department of the city to increase the number of playgrounds in congested areas so as to assure greater safety for children during the summer months.

Former Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. said last night that as a result of the establishment of the new state of Israel large-scale assistance for the Jews in Palestine and Europe had become an immediate necessity.

LONDON, May 22 -- Unrepentant after his expulsion from the Labor party, Alfred Edwards, Member of Parliament for East Middlesbrough, sailed from Southampton on the Queen Elizabeth today for a business trip to the United States.

ARAB LEGION ADVANCE HEADQUARTERS, in Palestine, May 22 -- The Arab Legion made a new advance into Jerusalem today to consolidate its hold on the Nablus road outside the Old City and to increase its pressure on the Haganah garrison holding out within the Old City.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 (AP) -- Duke Nalon, a big man with a lot of racing experience, today tamed the 550 wild horses under the hood of a Novi Grooved Piston Special.

MR. BRYDON'S book assembles from original sources a wealth of historical material not accessible to the general reader who is curious about the significance of what went on in England's oldest colony on this continent.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 22 -- By the margin of one second, Cornell beat off the blistering closing challenge of Yale on the placid waters of Lake Cayuga this evening to remain the only undefeated varsity eight in the East.

THE themes which Waldo Frank has examined in his two most recent novels are of major importance. He did an impressive amount of research for "Island in the Atlantic" to analyze the fate of an individualist and idealist in conflict with late nineteenth-century materialism.
NEW ORLEANS, May 22 -- Earl K. Long has had smooth sailing in his first ten days as Governor of Louisiana, but there are signs of breakers ahead.
DETROIT, May 22 (AP) -- The two millionth motor vehicle to be built in the United States this year is scheduled to be assembled about the end of this month.

The article, "The U.S. as Seen by the U.N. Staff," by George Barrett, seems to give a fairly accurate account of the not-always-so-pleasant living conditions of the nonAmerican U.N. workers. It also tends to give the impression that the United States is responsible for their difficulties, and echoes surprisingly little appreciation for the many, many good points of the American way of life.

A PROGRAM of classes in amateur photography is announced by the Police Athletic League as part of the league's over-all program to provide recreation and guidance for the city's boys and girls. Instruction will be given by volunteer experienced amateurs, who will use simple equipment and materials donated by the photographic industry.
PARIS, May 22 -- United States diplomacy is traditional enough in method to be both irritated and confused by the oblique Soviet peace feelers extended during the past fortnight.
In labor-management relations last week the atmosphere was tense. The economic setting of the conflict is this:

OUT of close, affectionate observation of a growing kitten and experience with what young children like, Irma Simonton Black has written another domestic animal story. Taken early from his mother, a grocery store cat, to live in an apartment, Toby, learned through trial and error to drink from a saucer, to leap from chairs to shelves, to mistrust the chiming mantelpiece clock, to capture a rubber mouse.

IN writing last week about the thoughtful character of the asides in Aldous Huxley's early travel book, "Jesting Pilate," I made no mention of one which brought from me that warm response which we always feel for an idea which we ourselves have always harbored.

MR. ROBERTS has disregarded the current prejudice in favor of elaborate anthologies. His volume is agreeably small. Of James' numerous essays he has reprinted only eleven, most of them bearing directly on the author's prime interest, the fictional art.

HOLLYWOODS uneasy awareness of television and its potentialities for dislocating the film production system was sharply stimulated last week by W.W. Watts, vice president of the Radio Corporation of America, who told the Society of Motion Picture Engineers in convention here that, perhaps' within five years, the television industry will consume 1,800 two-hour feature films annually, or three to four times the current output of all picture producers.

THE trial of Alice Williston for murder is a vexatious one for Assistant District Attorney Esau Frost. He is reasonably sure that Alice killed Jimmy Madena, who was found dead in her apartment, but he is equally convinced that the verdict should not be murder in the first degree.

NEW DELHI, India, May 22 -- Working days lost in industrial disputes have been halved since the Indian Government and representatives of management and labor signed a three-year "industrial truce" last December. Of 596 labor disputes pending last year, 470 have been settled by arbitration.

Eight days have passed since the State of Israel was proclaimed as an "independent republic" -- a tiny country of 5,500 square miles (a little more than the area of Connecticut) in a hostile Arab world of 1,300,900 square miles. Eight days have passed since the nations of the Arab League sent their armies into Palestine to wage a "holy war" against Israel.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The activity of the Munitions Board in planning for industrial mobilization that has evoked greatest criticism is that of stockpiling of strategic and critical materials. Board officials concede that the stockpiling program is unbalanced and behind schedule, and must be accelerated.

JUST twenty-one years ago this week in this Review: "Twilight Sleep," a satirical novel of New York's fashionable world, by Edith Wharton, took the weekly spotlight, occasioned this bow: "[Mrs. Wharton] maintains herself at so consistently high a level that any occasional faltering of the imagination may be charitably set down as nothing more serious than a change of pace, any lapse in artistry as a mere peccadillo of the pen." . . . "

BOSTON, May 22 -- Unless attention is given to the world's mentally deficient a large number of the "minds of men will drift into those dilemmas out of which wars are created," Dr. George S. Stevenson, president-elect of the American Psychiatric Association said today.

For the second time in eight days, the seventy-five-foot oceanographic vessel Balanus, en route to Bermuda from Woods Hole, Mass., was in difficulties at sea last night, according to a wireless message received in New York at 5 P.M. from the James Jackson, which was standing by.
The sporting library of the late Harry Worcester Smith of Worcester, Mass., will be auctioned tomorrow at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

In a box which accompanied my article on the 200-inch telescope of Palomar Mountain, it was stated that at the re quest of the late Dr. George Ellery Hale, the International Education Board, a Rockefeller philanthropy, supplied the money.

The picture of Arab snipers on the cover of your May 9 Magazine prompts me to forward this letter, just received from a close friend in Palestine. The writer is Mrs. Hilde Schneer, who lives in the cooperative community of Kwuzath Srajim, near Affula.

In 1714, when New York was a city of only 8,000 persons, six members of the Common Council met to consider the establishment of a city institution. In the institution, which was not built until twenty years later, was an infirmary of six beds, the forerunner of Bellevue Hospital.
BERLIN, May 22 -- The battle for Germany has been stripped to its essentials in the last few weeks.

WITH some advance planning, potted plants win maintain a succession of bloom on the terrace for a fairly long season. The strongest colors will provide the best effects, although in hot, sultry weather the softer tints and even a quantity of green are more welcome.

THE selection of characteristic paintings, one each, by ten of Pierre Matisse's group of moderns at his gallery this week is a lively affair, more than a little instructive in recent directions of our more advanced and restless experimenters.

COLUMBIA, Mo. THE great Billy Sunday traveled up and down the land a few decades ago exorcising Satan and thundering mightily for the Lord. He brought fear and repentance to thousands of the wicked, drove the idlers from hundreds of saloons and pool rooms and turned them, for a spell at least, into the paths of righteousness.

EVERY operator of a straw hat theatre can tell you that when spring comes summer cannot be far behind. Highly mindful of this seasonal truism, the warm-weather impresarios for some weeks have been suffering the various tortures incident to planning their seasons of summer stock, which vary in duration from ten to sixteen weeks.

DESPITE its tragic and touching ending, there is a true feeling of the juvenile about this Civil War construction -- told once again from the Confederate angle. The history reads as if it were lifted clumsily and amateurishly off the pages of a high-school text.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 (AP) -- Progressive party candidates are maintaining their 3-to-2 majority for the re-election as officers of the International Typographical Union, headquarters here announced today.

An article published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 16 reported that about 300 American teachers and graduate students were to start this summer on a three months' tour of Europe. The project, called "Marshall Plan in Action," is designed to acquaint teachers and students with conditions abroad.

LONDON, May 22 -- The Moscow radio broadcast tonight a reply to the eleven-point State Department's statement Wednesday on Soviet-United States relations and on every point it charged that United States policy was to blame for the differences between the two countries.
MOSCOW, May 22 (AP) -- It is believed the Soviet Union may look with favor upon any application by the Finnish Government for a reduction in war reparations.

WITH the passing of Mme. Olga Samaroff the music world has lost a great and noble champion. We, her pupils, feel her loss profoundly. Mme. Samaroff achieved lasting renown in all fields of musical endeavor: as a concert pianist, teacher, author, critic and lecturer.

Bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development have come of age. Last week, after ten months of seasoning in the most uncertain and convulsive bond market in two decades, the bank's obligations could be said to have passed two major tests -- that of comparative market performance and that of acceptability for legal investment in the nation's major institutional investment centers.
LONDON (By Wireless). KING ABDULLAH IBN EL HUSSEIN of Trans-Jordan is a man with an obsession. For an Arab he is also a man of remarkable decisiveness and tenacity.

SANDWICH, England, May 22 -- Brazil's Mario Gonzalez, a skinny six-footer, established himself today as a top favorite to take away Willie Turnesa's British amateur golf crown in the week-long championship tournament which begins Monday.

The drug industry, through the American Foundation for Pharmaceutical Education has taken another major stride in preventing a future shortage of trained pharmacists, it was announced last week by Dr. E.L. Newcomb, foundation secretary.

CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) -- The CIO meat handlers strike was over at most plants throughout the country today. Industry sources said that meat supplies would probably start spurting next week as some livestock believed held back on farms was shipped to market and that lower retail prices might result.

BERLIN, May 22 -- The bizonal area of Germany will not meet its commitments under the European Recovery Program during the second and third quarters this year because of the poor production record of the coal mining industry, United States Military Government officials predicted today.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The National Education Association today made public a study, "The Voter and Non-Voter," which showed that the higher the educational and economic level of citizens the greater the proportional number going to the polls.

BOSTON, May 22 (AP) -- Although slammed for three home runs, Murry Dickson today pitched and helped bat the National League leading St. Louis Cardinals to a 6-4 victory over the Boston Braves before 11,443 fans.

THE awful, constricting grip of tyranny upon any country sends a few of its people spurting like seeds from an orange upward to unwonted heights of heroism, and squeezes others downward. What remains in the hand of the tyrant is the crushed and dripping pulp of a nation.

KINGSTON, Jamaica -- The Executive Council of Jamaica's Government is considering a comprehensive recovery plan by which it is expected the little British colony in the Caribbean will earn $5,000,000 a year providing accommodation for 1,000,000 American tourists.

SOME time having elapsed since we have had a standard Broadway revue, gilded over with professionalism, "Inside U.S.A." looks and sounds very satisfactory indeed inside New York City. This is the crisply styled carnival in which Beatrice Lillie and Jack Haley are beguiling the populace with modish merriment to the flaring tunes of Arthur Schwartz and the witty doggerel of Howard Dietz.

THE nation's summer music season, which began earlier this month with a rash of May festivals, gives every indication of being the largest in history. Traditionally, music in the summer is offered either in a concentrated dose called a festival or spread out thin under the stars.

MR. LEHR, in his letter last week, criticizes Jean-Paul Sartre's "The Respectful Prostitute" for its lack of a "true-to-life" portrayal of the South. In this respect, he is correct. The drama is not one which should merit success for its realistic qualities.

ATHENS, May 22 -- Reports from Yanina, Greek Army headquarters in Epirus, said today that communications had not yet been restored with the town of Paramythia, scene of a fourteen-hour battle between a rebel unit of about 200 men and a small garrison of National Guard and Gendarmerie.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 22 -- A speed-up of immigration to Israel is a primary aim of the new state. The problem of large immigration was a main point in the conflict between the British mandate administration and the Arabs on the one hand and the Jews on the other.

Hawaii's forty-five-year quest for statehood seems to have foundered again on the rock of Senate inertia. By a vote of 51 to 20, the Senate has refused to discharge its Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs from further consideration of the Hawaii Statehood bill.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 22 -- Fighting uphill all the way, Jack Lyons, 24-year-old home club star, won the Walter J. Travis Memorial Trophy for the third consecutive time as the thirty-eighth annual Garden City Golf Club invitation tournament was concluded here today.

More than $100,000,000 may be spent soon to build the East's first 350,000-ton steel mill in the Greater New York area. Savings of between $15 and $20 a ton which would be made possible by the new mill would assure its profitable operation, according to leading engineers.

WHEN Bryn Mawr College recently asked if it could name a chair of drama for me, I was naturally very flattered. I was also surprised, for I had erroneously assumed that chairs of this kind were always a posthumous honor.

CONNECTICUT may not be the most romantic of states, but it has admirers among those who write for a living. The Connecticut countryside probably supports more authors per acre than any like area on the globe. Since authors like to write about their home locales, it should come as no surprise that the Nutmeg State is currently being written about with a vengeance.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 22 -- With the adoption of a report containing important provisions for broadening and tightening international narcotics control, the United Nations Commission on Narcotic Drugs completed its third session today and adjourned until next May.
SPOKANE, Wash., May 22 (AP) -- Henry A. Wallace challenged tonight the top framers of the nation's bi-partisan foreign policy to a series of debates.
CHICAGO, May 22 -- The Yankees went in for extremes today at Cominskey Park as they bade adieu to the hapless White Sox before a gathering of 14,032.

The New York Newspaper Guild, CIO, announced yesterday that a complete slate of pro-administration, anti-left wing candidates had won all positions in the election of delegates and alternates to the convention of the American Newspaper Guild to be held in San Francisco starting June 28.

OUT of every 100 American voters, a recent poll notes with dismay, sixty-two could not remember the name of their own Congressman. In the face of such a situation, and this being an election year, it would seem as good a time as any for a Congressional stocktaking.

IN less than 200 pages Mr. Neider has succeeded not only in giving a profound analysis of one of the most fascinating and enigmatic modern writers but in attacking a large number of fellow-commentators. Mr. Neider expects a good deal from his readers, but he gives them an abundance in return.
CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Eightieth Congress is trying hard to be turned loose finally about June 18 for work at the Presidential conventions and at home. Its prospects are highly uncertain.

Roger Langley, president of the National Ski Association of America, last night disclosed that Mrs. Gretchen Kunigk Fraser of Vancouver, Wash., had been unanimously chosen as the winner of the American Ski Trophy for 1948.

THESE two volumes encompass a century of devotion to music. About half of these years are recorded in Mrs. Hughes' memoir, which is not so much a personal history as it is the story of music in Cleveland. In a time when Cleveland was as far from the center of the musical universe as Alaska is today, Mrs. Hughes brought there David Bispham, Mary Garden, and Schumann-Heink, in all their early glory.

The long-awaited revision of its export licensing policy was issued last week by the Office of International Trade and is credited with meeting substantially all of the changes urged during recent months by foreign traders. The revisions, contained in bulletin 457 alter the original provisions of bulletin 431 and become effective on June 1.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- It is distinctly unfashionable in Washington to say on optimistic word about relations with the Russians. It is also somewhat unprofitable, for the capital has been tuning in on catastrophe for so long that it has no wave-length for the faintest chirrup of hope.

The steadily mounting barrage of criticism in recent months against a revival of crass "huckstering" techniques in advertising was described by key agency officials last week as evidence that the industry's leaders are determined to fight any disinterment of practices that shattered public faith in advertising during the Thirties.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (U.P.) -- Dr. Albert P. Kreuger reported tonight that he had succeeded in making a virus reproduce in the absence of living cells. He is chairman of the Department of Bacteriology at the University of California and scientific director of the Office of Naval Research.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 22 -- Four Spitfires of the Egyptian Air Force were shot down by British fighter planes and a fifth was damaged by machine-gun fire from the ground yesterday in an Egyptian attack on the Ramat David airfield, five miles southwest of Nazareth, it was revealed here today.

ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, May 22 -- Declaring that the people are deeply concerned with the foreign policy of the United States without knowing what it is or whether it is leading to peace or war, Senator Robert A. Taft suggested tonight a four-point program which he said would preserve freedom in this country and peace in the world.

SCHROON LAKE, N.Y., May 22 -- The New York State Young Republicans, elated over the results of the Oregon primary, adopted unanimously today a platform urging the election of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and giving complete backing to his views on communism.

MURDER is done in Madison Square Garden just as the starting gun is fired for the 440-yard race. Everyone is so intent on the race that no one notices that the starter is dead until after the race is over. It is another job for Inspector Schmidt, who is among the spectators along with his friend and chronicler, George Bagby.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Secretaries of Defense and Commerce announced today a joint effort to develop a single countrywide navigation and traffic control system for the common use of civil and military aviation. It would include a radar network which could be used also in the detection of enemy planes, thus filling what is considered to be one of the most serious gaps in the country's defense system.

The season of important Presidential primaries last week came to an end. The season ended pretty much as it had begun. Each of the major Republican Presidential candidates could claim victories. Each had suffered defeats. Thus -- four weeks from the Republican National Convention which opens June 21 in Philadelphia -- the outlook is for a wide-open battle.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Efforts also are being made through diplomatic conversations here to bring an end to the misunderstanding between the United States and Britain over Palestine lest it widen into a serious breach.

THE contemplation of an ashtray, thinks Architect George Nelson, is as good a way as any of preparing yourself for a declaration of independence in decorating. In a recent lecture on "Contemporary Interiors," he allowed that "experts are fine people, but actually the only way to improve your houses is to do it yourselves."

THE Air Force has changed the designation of its fighter planes from the long-familiar "P" -- P-51, P-47, etc. -- which stood for "pursuit," to "F" -- F-84, F-86, and so forth. The change is more than routine. It marks emphatically the new age in the air.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- A Republican move in the House to bring out next week legislation to broaden Social Security coverage and increase certain benefits was made known today by a leading majority spokesman on the subject.

Recent shifts in the policy of the United States with respect to certain matters of popular interest have not unnaturally led to some criticism of the Department of State, and in some quarters I have heard wholesale denunciations of its current activities.

The New York University College of Dentistry has established a series of psychological and physical tests for prospective students, designed to reduce the number of students who do not have the mental or physical qualifications to be successful practitioners. Previously, it was found, many students who had been selected solely on an academic basis studied at the college for as long as a year before dropping out.

In winning the Oregon primary Governor Dewey had to come from behind to overtake the lead which Mr. Stassen had built up both through his early efforts on the spot and through the prestige of his victories in the Wisconsin and Nebraska primaries. This is a very considerable feat, and Mr. Dewey is entitled to take great satisfaction in the accomplishment of it.

FANS of Benny Greenspan, fictional prototype of the Hollywood agent, the malapropistic ten-percenter, the conniving flesh-peddler, might well prepare to see their hero in the Smithsonian Institution, under glass. For what Hollywood refers to blandly as "the revolution" is in full cry, and the talk in some authoritative quarters is that Benny may be one of its casualties.

Representative Vito Marcantonio kept several hundred of his supporters waiting for more than four hours yesterday afternoon and then sent word that he would be unable to appear at a meeting at Park Place, 5 West 110th Street, at which a campaign for his reelection was opened.
Back at the track where he had marked up his first victory in 1943, Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Stymie did it again in the $25,000 added Metropolitan Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

PARIS, May 22 -- A split developed in the French Cabinet today over the elections to be held this fall. To avoid a break-up of Premier Robert Schuman's Ministry, the members finally decided to pass the problem to the Assembly and to have the question not one of confidence in the Government.

When the Supreme Court last month outlawed the pricing system of the nation's cement companies, it also sealed the doom of the basing-point systems of the steel industry and other businesses which rely on similar methods for determining price.
Congratulations on Hannah Trimble's article, "Milk Can Be Homogenized But Not Children."

Closing in on pleasure boat owners from several points of the compass are some governmental as well as civilian agencies with a sane, commendable goal. They want to make 1948 the safest season in history for yachting and yachtsmen.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 22 -- Four Arab League states officially notified the United Nations Security Council today that they would not negotiate with Israel for an end of the Palestine war.

The wild columbine, known to botanists as Aquilegia canadensis, is playing host to bumblebees and other insects with equally long tongues. May is its particular month, and if you can find a stony hillside with one plant you probably will find a dozen or a hundred of them with their rich scarlet and gold blossoms swaying in the wind.

BEETS to eat next winter and spring, from seed sown this month, sound a bit farfetched. To add that each beet weighs from one-half to one and one-half pounds makes the statement even harder to believe. Yet this is exactly what any gardener may enjoy by planting seeds of the variety Winter Keeper.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Palestine became a battleground this week as the new State of Israel was attacked by the regular armies of five member states of the Arab League.
Miss Perera writes the scripts for the children's program "Story to Order."
BOSTON, May 22 (AP) -- G.R. Schneider's George Gains breezed to a front running, four-and-a-half length triumph today in the $10,000 added Plymouth Rock Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

THE highlight of the concert given recently by the Doctors Orchestral Society in the Hunter College Auditorium was not, it seems, the virtuoso performance by the soloist, Benno Rabinof, of the Wieniawski violin concerto, Op. 22.

OF run-of-the-mine newspaper columnists we perhaps have too many. Of good newspaper columnists -- men on whose daily pieces the shadow of genius sometimes falls -- we have too few. These latter bring to their task the leavening of humor, gentle irony, compassion, common sense and deep integrity. They are not hacks, they are creative artists.

The aircraft carrier Valley Forge arrived in New York Harbor yesterday and maintained her reputation for provoking as much speculation as fanfare. With her were two destroyers that had accompanied the 27,000-ton warship on a "good-will mission."

AS an average American parent I disagree vigorously with Bernard Iddings Bell's article ("The School Can't Take the Place of the Home") on the moral incompetence of modern parents. I side with Mrs. Alfred H. Everson, chairman of the Family Service Division of the Brooklyn Bureau of Social Service, who feels that a child is an asset anywhere, even in an apartment.

HANOVER, Germany, May 22 -- The Bizonal Export Fair opened here today. Compared with the Russian-sponsored Leipzig Fair, as many in Germany will compare it, this is a drab affair of few persons and little excitement. There are 2,100 scheduled exhibitors, but laborers still are working to complete the erection of a substantial part of the fair grounds.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- After almost two years of dilatoriness and political jockeying, there came up for Congressional consideration this week measures to provide a haven in the United States for a limited number of the uprooted and homeless people of Europe.

In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, H.E. Priester makes the sweeping charge that such authorities as Julius C.C. Edeistein, special adviser to Secretary of State Marshall, and Albert Z. Carr, consultant to the Inter-Allied Reparations Agency, have "overlooked basic economic and technological facts" in upholding the German reparations program.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 22 -- Princeton University's varsity baseball team staved off a ninth-inning uprising by Manhattan College to score its third consecutive victory, 4--3, today on University Field.

NINE out of ten theatre operators will tell you that what the movie business needs now more than anything else is a whole raft of good comedies. People, they say, want to laugh to forget taxes, rising prices and the ominous rumblings of war drums.

Thomas Campbell Wasson, named by President Truman in April as United States representa tive on the United Nations Truce Commission for Palestine, was at that time Consul General at Jerusalem, with a long and successful record as a foreign service officer of the State Department.

The long packing house strike, now ended, was a conspicuous example of economic waste. Some 80,000 men were out for 67 days. In that period their wages would have amounted to $40,000,000. The packers lost many millions more. Farmers, denied sales of their stock, also lost.

CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) -- Scattered selling sent wheat lower for most of the session on the Board of Trade today. Corn was mostly steady, while oats showed little change. Trading was slow at the start, but picked up later.

SEVENTY-NINE oils and thirty-eight water-colors which have been declared "surplus" by the State Department are currently exhibited at the Whitney Museum where they will be sold at sealed bid by the War Assets Administration.

TEL AVIV (By Wireless). WHEN, in 1924, Tel Aviv was 15 years old, just emerging into civic maturity, its elders and sages decided that it should have a fitting coat of arms. They chose the Shield of David as a base. Then they superimposed a gateway on the sea with a beacon light casting its beams for the guidance of all Zionists wherever they might be.

The mounting tempo of the European Recovery Program is having a telling effect on reducing the drain on foreign gold and dollar reserves. Aid extended before the program became operative and since its enactment by Congress has been credited for reducing the flow of gold here in the first quarter of the year and correspondingly improving the dollar balances of those European countries participating in the plan.

The Ukrainian National Chorus of New York, under George Kirichenko, gave its first concert last night at Town Hall. The ensemble, composed of singers of this city and Northern New Jersey, included some displaced persons, who formerly were members of choral groups in the Ukraine.

ON Jan. 25, 1942, shortly after he had been asked to assume responsibility for the American forces in the China-Burma-India theatre, Joseph W. Stilwell wrote from Washington to his wife: "It is stupid that I can't tell you everything, for I know you don't talk. I am going where I believe you would want me to go.
Two of the largest industrial purchasing departments in the country have held up orders for $20,000,000 to keep from "breaking the market" on several important products.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Secretary of State Marshall in a message to William Burdett of Macon, Ga., Vice Consul, who had immediately assumed charge of the Consulate General, commended Mr. Wasson and others attached to the Consulate General, several of whom have been wounded recently.

In an interview at the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and East Forty-fourth Street. Senator Robert A. Taft said yesterday that he would lead all other candidates for the Presidency on the first ballot at the Republican national convention in Philadelphia.

THIS is a history of magic in the Western world, written on a grand scale and pictorially crammed with woodcuts, diagrams, thaumaturgic spells, circles, seals and similar magical esoterica. Seligmann himself, a surrealist painter whose ethnic roots lie in Switzerland although he has lived in New York since 1939, has long felt the attraction of magical ways embedded in living European folklore and the contemporary relics of such practices in the East.

Prices of shares on the Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday, with small fractional changes prevailing. It was the final Saturday trading until October. A few selected issues showed gains up to a point, but the oil and rails groups made the best showing.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican, of Massachusetts, said today he had asked Secretary of State Marshall just what action the department was taking to investigate the death of George Polk, correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting Company in the Middle East, whose body was found, washed ashore at Salonika, Greece, a week ago.

ROME, May 23 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi announced this evening his sixth Cabinet based on a coalition of Christian Democrats, Right-Wing Socialists, Republicans and Liberals. Its distinguishing feature is that it includes two Ministers Without Portfolio, whose duties will be to watch over the application of the Marshall Plan.

The effects of the Palestine war on the United Nations and on relations between the United States and Britain throw light on another facet of the central problem of our time. All the strains and tensions of the post-war period stem from the struggle to establish a new world order, democratic or totalitarian, on the ruins of the old.

" Oedipus Rex" is not a practical drama for audiences that do not understand the language. In this case the language is the Hebrew of the late Dr. Saul Chernikhovsky, who translated the Sophocles tragedy for the Habimah Players. They acted it on Saturday evening at the Broadway Theatre as the fourth and last production in their current repertory.
Seven new films, including French and Italian importations, are due to open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Israeli Government issued a ceasefire order today in response to a plea from the United Nations Security Council, the State Department was informed through its diplomatic channels.

LONDON, May 23 -- The diplomatic exchanges between Moscow and Washington have demonstrated finally how slender are hopes of real improvement in relations between the East and the West at the present time, and this slight prop of the financial markets here consequently has given way.

CLEVELAND, May 23 -- Joe DiMaggio drove three successive home runs at Municipal Stadium today before a record gathering of 78,431 fans, to sweep the Yankees to victory over the Indians in the first game of a twin bill.
Taps sounded in several city parks yesterday as wreaths were laid in pre-Memorial Day services amid speeches and invocations stressing preservation of American freedom.
BOMBAY, India, May 23 -- India and the principality of Hyderabad stand tonight on the brink of open conflict.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, May 23 -- With the Jewish part of Jerusalem cut off from the world except for small hill tracks to the west, a truce was offered last night in the name of the Arab League that would allow the Jewish population to get food and water.

Prices on Class C sheetings have receded to a point of negligible return to mills and a further reduction of 1 cent per yard will result in some shutdowns, it was learned in Worth Street last week. Slow movement of all types of narrow sheetings and Osnaburgs, commission men said, is creating a dangerous inventory position for producers which will call for decisive action in the next thirty days.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 23 -- State Senator Kenneth C. Hand called upon Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today to get the maximum possible consideration for this area in the expansion program of the Port of New York Authority. Mr. Hand asserted that there was many opportunities for further waterfront development and its related industrial expansion in this city and near-by Linden.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Senate will be asked this week to talk less and vote more in a last-ditch drive to wind up Congress before the Republican nominating convention at Philadelphia four weeks hence. A similar speedup is planned in the House.

The program of research on national economic problems which the Committee for Economic Development will continue as a permanent organization was outlined over the week-end by W. Walter Williams, newly elected president of the CED. The decision to continue the program, started in 1942, was made by trustees of CED, who voted unanimosuly to extend the work of the committee's research and policy committee under the chairmanship of Raymond Rubicam of New York.

Members of the Second Presbyterian Church, 6 West Ninety-sixth Street, gathered at their regular morning service yesterday to give thanks for the friends who had helped to raise $850,000 for retention of the "apartment-house church."

The annual award of the Park Association of New York for notable service to the public through the park and recreational system has been voted to the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation for its gift to the public of the summer concerts given by the Goldman Band.

PARIS, May 23 -- The Soviet Union is having digestive troubles at the ends of its Eastern European satellite bloc, but it is dubious whether these political bellyaches will hamper the present consolation phase of Moscow's policy in the region east of the Stettin-Trieste line.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 23 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York slightly increased his numerical lead over Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, as the tabulation of the vote from Friday's primary neared an end tonight.

An American-Indian child aid project will be started with help to schools on the Navajo Reservation by the Save the Children Federation, Inc., 1 Madison Avenue, with the cooperation of the Bureau of Indian Affairs, it was announced yesterday.

The continued difficulty of obtaining bunker oils on world-wide markets has once more hit the Arnold Bernstein Line's plans for re-establishing a transatlantic service between New York and Antwerp, Belgium, John J. Dwyer, passenger traffic manager of the company, announced yesterday. He said the line's chartered vessel, the Continental, was now scheduled for an initial departure on June 7.

BRUSSELS, May 23 (AP) -- Cyrille Delannoit, unheralded Belgian boxer, dethroned Marcel Cerdan as European middleweight champion tonight by scoring an upset, fifteen-round decision over the Frenchman. Each weighed 160 pounds.
AMMAN, May 23 (AP) -- Azzam Pasha also said he saw no reason to exclude Arabs from the control of Jerusalem and to make it an international free city.

A total of $3,000,000 worth of consumer and industrial items in 377 lots will be offered by the War Assets Administration to all types of buyers in a three-day sale beginning June 9 in the Customer Service Center in the Bronx, Eastchester Road and Haswell Street, it was announced over the weekend.

BERLIN, May 23 -- The rivalry between the United States-controlled Bremen ports and the British-controlled port of Hamburg acquired a sharper edge recently when officials of both areas announced new post-war records in tonnages handled last month.

BRIDGETON, N.J., May 23 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey will be guest at the village of Greenwich near here on Tuesday when the 200th anniversary of Cumberland County courts will be observed.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, emphasized today that his predictions of huge Federal deficits in the next three years were conservative "and more likely to be exceeded than reduced."

ZURICH, May 23 -- Fitful fluctuations of the free dollar rate in Switzerland all last week marked the belated action of French nationals in applying for certification for non-enemy ownership accounts still blocked in the United States before the May 31 deadline.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 23 -- Racing practically nose and nose for ten-and-one-half miles on Long Island Sound, Corny Shields, with his International Class sloop Aileen, and Arthur Knapp, at the helm of the Bumble Bee, finished a split second apart. Aileen was victor.

Marking what it calls a return to "normal" sales methods and responsibilities, the Johns-Manville Corporation has just concluded a one-month intensive training course for seventy-seven salesmen-in-training at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, N.Y., to condition them to "match wits with competition" and "create business instead of having it handed to us on a platter."
CAIRO, Egypt, May 23 (UP) -- The Egyptian Government said tonight it was preparing an answer to the United Nations request for a cease-fire agreement in Palestine, but gave no details.

A hold-up suspect was shot yesterday afternoon in the Bathgate Avenue Police Station, the Bronx, as he attempted to escape while being booked on a charge of robbery. One of the policemen who had captured him and another man about an hour earlier fired two shots, one of which hit the fleeing man in the hip.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 23 --Throughout the Holy Land it appeared tonight that both sides were fighting desperately to hold or improve their positions before any cease-fire order became effective.

FOR many years that clarion call has been the rallying cry for all of the better pirates. But one Pirate who refuses to follow the Robert Louis Stevenson script is Billy Meyer, the new boss of the swashbuckling Buccaneers from Pittsburgh. Billy is much too smart a baseball man for that and too strict a disciplinarian to put up with any nonsense.

Losing only two of his eleven bouts in a keenly waged final round-robin, Dr. Daniel Bukantz captured the fourth Olympic foil tryout competition staged yesterday at the New York Athletic Club. The tryout attracted twenty contestants.

BOSTON, May 23 (UP) -- Dr. James Luther Adams of Chicago opened the 123d anniversary week of the American Unitarian Association tonight with an attack on what he termed "Roman Catholic bullying in the name of God."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 23 -- Harry Popkin, independent producer, has purchased two new stories for his program of ten pictures for United Artists, he disclosed this week end. The yarns, both written directly for the screen, are "Valley Seward," by Grover Lee Scrimpsher, which deals with a returning veteran, and "The Phoney," a comedy by Charles Martin.

PARIS, May 23 (AP) -- Frank Parker, top-ranking American ace, today defeated Bernard Destremau of France and Frantisek Vrba of Czechoslovakia to advance to the quarter-final round of the French international tennis championships.

LONDON, May 23 -- Discussion of devaluation of currency has been started on a fresh run here by a report from Washington last week that the United States may require the recipients of Marshall aid to devalue their currencies if the present rates of exchange are imposing an unjustifiable burden on their balance of payments.

The ability of exceptionally bright children constitutes one of this country's richest resources and much of it goes to waste, according to the latest symposium on the gifted child. The term "gifted," as used by the United States Office of Education, includes marked superiority in art, music, mechanics, social leadership or other specific direction, as well as in high "I.Q."
PORTLAND, Ore., May 23 -- Dorothy McCullough Lee, who won a clear majority in a field of seven candidates in Friday's election, will take office as the first woman mayor of Portland Jan. 1.

PARIS, May 23 -- On next Tuesday a meeting will be held of the committee on payments and intra-European exchanges of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation. Delegates of the five countries which signed the Brussels pact will submit to other nations benefiting from the Marshall Plan the proposals framed by the monetary conference held in Brussels.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The plant survey of American industry and the allocation of industrial capacity among the Army, Navy and Air Force now being made by the Munitions Board, are part of its long-range planning for industrial mobilization in case of war.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Evening-up operations in the May deliveries of grains, trading in which ceased at the close last Friday, resulted in considerable irregularity on the Board of Trade last week. Uncompleted contracts in May futures were largely eliminated in the final day of trading, and brokers say the markets now will reflect supply and demand developments more closely.

" THE MEMOIRS OF CORDELL HULL"* comprise a document of major historical importance. Scholars will be conducting excavating operations in their 1,804 pages for generations to come. They contain vast quantities of interesting information. But the labor involved in unearthing it should not be undertaken lightly.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Americans for Democratic Action today released a telegram sent to the Senate Judiciary Committee asking deferment of action on the Mundt Bill at this session of Congress.

SANDWICH, England, May 23 (AP) -- Dick Chapman of Pinehurst, N.C., who barely missed the British amateur championship last year in the tournament's first all-American final in history, spearheads a nine-man American bid tomorrow to keep Wee Willie Turnesa's crown in the United States.

Here and there along the coast silver-weathered, zig-zag rail fences wind down from sloping pastures and side-hill fields to below the line of high tide. Long years ago when pioneers chose home sites along the ocean they cleared land for crops and pasture. Since men ceased their nomadic wanderings and struck roots in the earth they have used materials at hand to enclose their land.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., May 23 -- The Virginia Music Festival successfully ended its second annual concert series this afternoon in the Scott Stadium, University of Virginia, with Tchaikovsky's familiar Fifth Symphony, played by the Detroit Symphony Orchestra. Karl Krueger conducted.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 23 -- Michael A. Stavitsky of Newark, was re-elected today to his second term as president of the American Association for Jewish Education at the closing session of the group's four-day annual meeting here.

Wars will cease only when all men realize that, as children of God the Father, they are "brothers in Christ," the Rev. Charles J. McManus of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral declared yesterday in a sermon at solemn mass there.
Israel can in no way represent those of Jewish faith who are citizens of other nations, the American Council for Judaism Inc., declared yesterday.

Motorcycle Patrolman Charles Meyer, 39 years old, was killed yesterday morning when his vehicle was in collision with an automobile at Horace Harding Boulevard and 102d Street, Corona Queens. The driver of the car, Demetrios Vrachopoulos, a 61-year-old sculptor of 102-14 Sixty-second Road, Corona, was placed under arrest on a charged of vehicular homicide.

A powerful youth who had fled from an East Harlem church with a collection box was captured yesterday by the police with the help of 300 neighborhood boys. Then the patrolmen had to fend off the angry youngsters to get their prisoner safely to the station house.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 23 -- The attention of the seven Southeastern states that are served by facilities of the Tennessee Valley Authority will be centered tomorrow on the national capital when their civic and political representatives close ranks and put aside partisanship to fight a battle for the TVA.
A new threat to telephone service arose last night when a national union of telephone-exchange mechanics announced that a strike of its 30,000 members was "imminent."

Three-fifths of the world's Christians will be represented at the assembly of the World Council of Churches this summer, the Rev. Dr. Henry Smith Leiper declared yesterday in a sermon at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The pulp and paper industry broke all previous production records -- except for newsprint -- in the first quarter of this year.
MILWAUKEE, May 23 -- Varied issues face the Northern Baptist Convention when it opens annual sessions here tomorrow.

DETROIT, May 23 -- Efforts of the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, to reach an agreement that would avert a threatened walk-out of more than 200,000 employes next Friday failed today. As an emergency negotiating meeting broke up, however, both parties announced that another session would be held tomorrow.

BERLIN, May 23 -- The Russian-inspired campaign of the Socialist Unity party to collect signatures to petitions demanding German unity began today with a blare of propaganda and a notable lack of enthusiasm.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz and Kings County District Attorney Miles McDonald spent five hours ending early yesterday in a tour of Brooklyn saloons and billiard rooms, but they differed sharply in what they observed.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 23 -- There is no possible excuse "for not making it clear to the entire world that we are at all times ready, either as an individual nation or as a member of the family of nations, to discuss any and all problems which are today causing misunderstanding and are likely to lead to war," Representative Christian A. Herter declared here today.

The ministry of Jesus Christ is on every level of man's life, social, economic and physical as well as spiritual, the Rev. Dr. Powel M. Dawley, professor of ecclesiastical history at the General Theological Seminary, declared yesterday at the holy communion service in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

DETROIT, May 23 (AP) -- Virgil (Fire) Trucks spoiled a brilliant pitching duel with Walt Masterson today by walking in the only run of the game after two were out in the ninth inning to give the Senators a 1-to-0 victory over the Tigers. Washington got only four hits off Trucks, while the Tigers had six off Masterson, the winner.

ST. LOUIS, May 23 -- One of the longest matches in the thirty-year history of the P.G.A. championship went to Claude Harmon of Winged Foot when he holed a twenty-foot putt for a birdie 3 to beat Sam Snead, the 1942 titleholder, 1 up, 42 holes, just before dusk tonight in the quarter-finals over the rolling Norwood Hills Country Club course.

While public housing has given the housewife of low income many advantages over her neighbor still living in the slums, it has in addition raised her sense of values and caused her to look ahead to further improvements in her living conditions.
Cotton prices in the domestic market moved irregularly last week but the general tendency was toward slightly lower levels.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell warned his congregation yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church to "be suspicious of any kind of goodness the pursuit of which does not result in genuine happiness.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Reciprocal Trade Extension remained a strictly party issue tonight as Republicans and Democrats of the House Ways and Means Committee made public opposing reports on a Republican bill to extend the present law, with amendments, for one year.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 23 -- Despite the fact that his successor, Jacob A. Malik, arrived last week, Andrei A. Gromyko is expected to continue representing the Soviet Union in the United Nations until the middle of July, usually well informed sources said today.

Speakers at the final meeting of the centennial session of the New York East Conference of the Methodist Church warned yesterday that civilization would die unless people changed their spiritual attitude toward their fellow men and attempted to solve world problems in a new spirit of brotherhood and justice.

Foreign exchanges had opened last week quietly and with the same degree of evenness apparent in the preceding fortnight when it was greeted in Tuesday's session with the report of the United States Advisory Council that modification of exchange values should be a requirement of ERP aid.

Lois Jordan, soprano from Elizabeth, N.J., who made her local debut two years ago, gave her third recital here last night at Town Hall. Having an unusually fine voice and being a sensitive and serious artist, she gave her listeners a good deal of pleasure.

With the Republican National Convention at Philadelphia only four weeks away, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey by his primary election victory over Harold E. Stassen in Oregon jumped back into the position of leading contender for the Republican nomination for President and seems likely to lead all other candidates on the first ballot.
PARIS, May 23 -- The Sultan of Morocco today issued a statement expressing solidarity with the Arab leaders in Palestine but pleading for a continuation of peace between Arabs and Jews in Morocco.
In an address on "The Rights of Man" from Radio Station WNBC, Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, yesterday defined his position on six issues of the national campaign.

" Roosevelt and Hopkins -- An Intimate History," an account of the part Harry Hopkins played as a confident of the late President, has been scheduled for publication in October by Harper. Robert E. Sherwood has based his book on Mr. Hopkins' notes and memoranda.
The United States Golf Association yesterday announced the allotment of places for the national open golf tournament's twenty-eight sectional qualifying rounds.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, May 23 -- The Trans-Jordanian Defense Ministry announced today the occupation by the Arab Legion of Ramat Rahel, two and one-half miles south of Jerusalem, on the Bethlehem road, which had been stormed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Exiled leaders from six of Europe's Communist-controlled nations will assemble for a four-day conference here tomorrow. Delegates intend to lay plans for the merging of all of Europe's exiled non-Communist political groups into an international democratic front.

Through the medium of an "authorized" statement representing the views of its "leading circles," the Russian Government has now replied at length to the indictment of its policies issued by the State Department, which placed responsibility for the present world tensions squarely on the Soviet Union.

Billy Meyer and his dauntless Pirates, who have been providing one of the milder sensations of the current baseball campaign, came to the Polo Grounds yesterday for a one-game series and forthwith let the Giants have their very best punch.

New York gallery patrons have a variety of art exhibitions to choose from this week. Today's openings include two shows at the galleries of the Associated American Artists -- recent paintings by Bruce Mitchell and a group review of the year, being new paintings by the organization's member artists.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Representatives of fifty-five wholesale salesmen's associations met tonight at the Statler Hotel and planned an all-out fight against the Gearhart bill, H.J. Res. 296, which it was said would jeopardize the rights of 1,500,000 wholesale salesmen to Social Security benefits.

The Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation reported yesterday in its statement for 1947 that it had a consolidated net profit of $5,085,847, including profit from the sale of capital assets. The profit is equal to $1.30 a share of common stock and compares with $12,187,805 or $3.17 a share earned in 1946.

Marine radio operators who quit one Congress of Industrial Organizations union this year and were rebuffed in an attempt to join another have formed their own organization, remaining within the CIO, it was learned last night.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $52,519,973,205. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

The Williamsburg Settlement and its sponsoring agency, the Brooklyn Philanthropic League of the United Order True Sisters, presented the fifth annual Williamsburg Settlement Gold Medal award to Harry Hershfield, humorist, last night at the settlement's silver anniversary dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- A "noticeable pick-up" in retail sales was reported by the Department of Commerce today. The department said that retail buying had snapped out of the lag of recent months -- a lag that had proved worrisome to some merchants during the pre-Easter period.

TOKYO, May 23 -- Japanese political analysts were attempting today to assess the meaning of Premier Hitoshi Ashida's recent statements that the Government was "carefully studying" the exclusion of Communists from public office. The majority regards the declaration as a trial balloon designed to test the reaction of Japanese, and particularly of United States opinion, rather than as a concrete plan.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 23 -- Irgun Zvai Leumi, erstwhile terrorist organization now militarily absorbed in the fighting forces of Israel, proclaimed its political independence tonight by suggesting to the Government that virtually all British newspaper correspondents be expelled from the country. Irgun charged that 99 per cent of them were serving British intelligence.

While apparel manufacturers continued preparations last week for openings of fall lines, many retailers sought low-end and popular priced merchandise for special sales in June and July, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The watchword of the Republican party is "mere political expediency," Senator J. Howard McGrath, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, declared today in a public statement.
Robert D. Blasier has been appointed assistant to the vice president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and placed in charge of the company's law department.

NEW DELHI, India, May 23 -- An aged Brahmin lawyer is planning the defense of Nathuram Vinayak Godse and the eight others charged in the assassination of Mohandas K. Gandhi. Their trial is expected to open Friday.

Action is now being taken by Westchester County to cope with one of the major hazards of our multi-lane highways. This is the practice of cutting from one traffic lane to another without any signal to guide following cars. It has resulted in many bad smash-ups, William J. Slater, Chief of the Westchester Parkway Police, reports that signs now being prepared for erection along the parkways will contain pertinent warning against such driving.

Dr. Simon Greenberg, provost of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, will serve as its acting president for the academic year 1948-49, Alan M. Stroock, chairman of the institution's board of directors, announced yesterday.

Repeal of the State Department of Education regulations covering released time for religious education of public school students was urged yesterday on Francis T. Spaulding, State Commissioner of Education, by the Public Education Association.

CARMEL, N.Y., May 23 -- An electrified kite wire, apparently abandoned by a boy after it had become entangled in a tree and near-by high-tension wires, caused the death this afternoon of Mrs. Estelle Trafton, 42 years old, and serious injuries to her husband, Alfred, 45.

A man in a rowboat was run over and fatally injured by a pilotless motor-boat in the Hudson River yesterday afternoon. The victim of this bizarre accident was William McDermott, 48 years old, of 549 Riverside Drive, who was busy preparing to cast off a rowboat at the Interstate Boat House pier, just south of Dyckman Street, when the motor-boat hit him.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, May 23 -- Utah Republicans assured Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York today that he would have the support of a near-majority of the state delegation of eleven on the first ballot at the national convention.

Net profits after tax reductions for 323 department and specialty stores with an aggregate sales volume of $3,673,358,000 for 1947 declined to 4.2 per cent of sales, a nation-wide survey by the controllers' congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association disclosed in figures released for publication today.
Five hundred community leaders representing American Jews pledged yesterday support of the migration of 120,000 refugees to Israel before the end of this year.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The little Arab state of Lebanon, just north of Palestine, rejected today the demand of the United States for the release of forty-one American citizens taken off the American ship Marine Carp at Beirut Thursday.

Development of hydroelectric resources on the St. Lawrence River by New York and Ontario would involve a greater financial outlay than if coupled with navigational aid, opponents of the plan said yesterday.

Early indications at Ebbets Field yesterday were that the famine had ended, for the Dodgers romped to a 5-0 lead over the Reds. Surely, it was logical to presume that Lefty Joe Hatten had a comfortable working margin and that victory, at long last, would belong to Brooklyn.

TRENTON, N.J., May 23 -- The command of the New Jersey National Guard will be subject to reorganization in the near future under legislation approved by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll. He announced today he had signed a legislative measure to create a new Department of Defense.

The Transport Workers Union, CIO, will meet with the Board of Transportation today to demand that the 24-cent hourly increase approved for city transit workers be extended to the board's own clerical employes. The white-collar group is scheduled to receive an increase of $250 a year, or less than half the amount to be paid operating employes.

NORTH PLAINFIELD, N.J. May 23 -- Sir Thomas of Rumak, an English springer spaniel belonging to Mrs. William McKelvy of Pittsburgh, took his first best-in-show and finished his championship simultaneously today in the Plainfield Kennel Club's sixth all-breed event.

A broad curving sweep of plate glass framed in bronze, extending to the top of the building, will be a striking feature of the main entrance to Macy's-White Plains store, according to detailed plans for the new structure outlined yesterday by Harold B. Wess, vice president in charge of New York projects for Macy's, and Noris Donlon, coordinator of branch stores.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 23 -- President Truman emphasized today that systematic saving by individuals diverts funds from the purchase of goods and services and reduces the pressure for higher prices.

LONDON, May 23 (AP) -- Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, Prime Minister of the Union of South Africa and veteran Empire statesman, today called for an association of the British Commonwealth and the United States to "give pause to any potential aggressor."
PARIS, May 23 -- Balmain returns to straight lines in a small but exquisite collection of summer and autumn models.
The 100th anniversary year of The Associated Press was observed yesterday with a special broadcast dramatizing the ten biggest news stories of the last century as selected by AP editors.

A "pilot project" for the intensive study of public and private recreational facilities for children and youths in the lower Bronx, and for prompt action to remedy major faults, will start this week under the sponsorship of the New York City Youth Board.

JERUSALEM, May 23 -- United States Consul General Wasson, 52, who died early today of the wounds he received yesterday from a sniper's bullet, will be buried tomorrow in this war-ravaged Holy City, which is still locked in a bloody stalemate after eleven days of battle.

Our man with the unlikely name of Balboa Prawn dropped by this department the other day, and putting down a small potted cactus about the size of a tennis ball with a beautiful pink flower growing straight up from the top of it (he just couldn't resist buying it, he said), he produced a cherry-wood pipe, the bowl of which was as big as his fist.

CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- Joe Dobson's wild pitch in the tenth inning sent Don Kolloway across the plate with the winning run of the curfew contest as the White Sox took two games from the Red Sox by identical scores of 4 -- 3 before 27,259 fans today.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period May 15 to 21 are given in the appended tabulation:

WARSAW, May 23 -- In a pastoral letter read in all Catholic churches today during the ceremony of the Holy Trinity, the Polish hierarchy asserted its "right and duty" to participate in education and condemned the "materialistic point of view."

Mayor O'Dwyer is scheduled to break ground for Public School 111 at Thirty-seventh Avenue and Thirteenth Street, Long Island City, Queens, tomorrow at 3 P.M., the Board of Education announced yesterday. The building is the first school to be started this year and the twentieth since the board resumed construction in September, 1946.
BOSTON, May 23 (AP) -- Boston's Braves moved into a tie with the Pirates for third place in the National League today by drubbing the Chicago Cubs 8 -- 5 and 12 -- 4, before 31,693 fans.

The municipal bond market will face this week a series of substantial sales of new issues of tax-exempt bonds. Minneapolis, Minn., will receive bids Thursday on $8,891,000 of bonds maturing from 1949 to 1978; Boston, Mass., will offer $5,800,000 of bonds on Wednesday.
CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- The day when housewives can serve themselves at the butcher's counter may not be far off.

Work is now 65 per cent complete on the mechanical changes necessary to rapid transit operation under the higher fare schedules that go into effect at midnight on June 30, the Board of Transportation said yesterday.

A conference that could be vital for the future of New York has been held at the Good Neighbor Federation, 115 East 106th Street. The conference was called by the Urban League of Greater New York to consider what can and should be done to improve the housing, education and training of our 700,000 Negroes and to break down the barriers of discrimination that still deny some of them equal opportunities for employment.

Any producer would give his right arm for the services of Margaret Sullavan. That's how much the stage and screen star means to the box-office. Despite the number of new scripts submitted to her since she last appeared here in "The Voice of the Turtle," Miss Sullavan has accepted Herman J. Mankiewicz's offer to act in "The Man With a Load of Mischief" next December on Broadway.

PITTSBURGH, May 23 -- There was anxiety in the steel industry last week over the possibility of another stoppage of coal mining in July. Such a strike again would pull the steel ingot rate down, but at a much faster pace than it did in the recent strike.

Because his playroom, the kitchen, had an unpleasant smell early yesterday morning, 15-month-old Leonard David Friedman transferred his toys to the bedroom where his parents were sleeping, and by this move saved all their lives.

NEWARK, N.J., May 23 (AP) -- Beto Avila's one-out double in the fourth inning stood between Dick Starr and a perfect seven-inning game today as the Newark Bears swept a twin bill from Baltimore, 7 -- 4 and 8 -- 0, before 6,505 fans. The sweep allowed Newark to run its winning streak to six in a row and move into second place in the International League.

I read with considerable interest your editorial, May 11, on the candidacy of Norman Thomas for the Presidency. Having had the honor of placing his name before the Socialist Convention, I should like to comment on your statement that his "campaign won't do us any harm at all."

After defeating the New York Cubans, 3 -- 2, in ten innings, the Baltimore Elite Giants went on to top their rivals, 9 -- 6, in the afterpiece in a Negro National League double-header before 5,000 at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 23 -- A nation-wide membership drive to raise funds to maintain the Touro Synagogue here as a National Shrine and to house historic objects tied to its history was started today at the inaugural meeting of the Friends of Touro Synagogue.

A strike of 20,000 carpet and rug workers in four large companies was threatened yesterday by the Textile Workers Union, CIO. Jack Rubenstein, director of the union's carpet and rug division, said a walkout would be ordered June 1 unless the companies met the union's wage demands before that time.

HAMBURG, Germany, May 23 (AP) -- In a listless ten-round fight studded with clinches, 39-year-old Walter Neusel today defeated Max Schmeling, 42-year-old former world heavyweight champion. Neusel weighed 209, Schmeling 191.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 23 -- The Southern Baptist Convention, representing 6,000,000 members in 26,764 churches, ended its annual meeting today with an evangelistic service attended by one of the largest gatherings in the convention's 103-year history.

LONDON, May 23 -- The Board of Deputies of British Jews, a representative organ of British Jewry, adopted a resolution at a meeting here today recording the "joy of Anglo-Jewry at the re-establishment in Palestine of the State of Israel after almost 2,000 years of wandering and homelessness."

VALHALLA, N.Y., May 23 -- Water in New York's Kensico Reservoir here was at a record height today as the New York Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity continued notifying communities that the Catskill Aqueduct, main feed line for the reservoir, would be closed at 12:01 A.M. Thursday for two or three days.
ZEILSHEIM, Germany, May 23 -- Seventeen Jews left a displaced persons camp here today, bound for a European port to embark for service with the Haganah in Palestine.

Helen Hayes will become this season's first straw-hat star when she appears Friday evening in J.M. Barrie's "Alice-Sit-By-the-Fire" at the Olney (Md.) Theatre. With her in the engagement, her only one for the summer, will be her daughter, Mary MacArthur, and John Williams and Elfrida Derwent.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 23 -- The announcement that Israel would abide by the Palestine truce request the United Nations Security Council issued last night was received here with a new feeling of hope. This first reaction, however, was mixed with strong doubts that the Arabs, for their part, would agree to lay down their arms.

The Rabbinical Council of America, composed of 375 orthodox religious leaders in the United States and Canada, views the creation of the new state of Israel as "an opportunity for the reestablishment in Palestine of religious authority for world Jewry," Dr. Israel Tabak, recently elected president of the organization, said last night.

Shot by a sniper's bullet while on a mission of peace, Thomas Wasson, our Consul General in Jerusalem, gave his life as devotedly as any soldier on the battle line. No man can give more to his country and the world.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 23 -- Foreign Minister Nedjmeddin Sadak set forth today conditions under which rapprochement between Turkey and the Soviet Union could be realized.

The New Dance Group, that unique and indomitable co-operative organization, opened its first "Festival Series" since 1945 with two performances yesterday at the Mansfield Theatre, and four more to follow nightly until Thursday. Six dancer-choreographers, appearing now as soloists, now in groups, with or without the assistance of the ensemble of the New Dance Group itself, offered some twenty dances on the two programs, half a dozen of them premieres.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- A final complete contract proposal made by the Chicago Newspaper Publishers Association for settlement of the six-month-old newspaper strike has been rejected by the negotiating committee of Chicago Typographical Union, Local 16, it was stated to members of the union today at their regular monthly meeting.

JERUSALEM, May 22 (Delayed) -- The willingness to turn Jerusalem into a "Stalingrad," declared by a Jewish Agency spokesman today, epitomizes on both sides the feelings in the battle for the city. For both, the city is the supreme symbol of the struggle for which they are prepared to sacrifice the stones and mortar of holy places as well as many lives.
