GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 23 -- The United States team defeated the United States Reserves, 7 -- 2, as the sixteenth annual national tournament of the United States Women's Lacrosse Association closed at Adelphi College today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals rained base hits all over Shibe Park today and drubbed the Philadelphia Phillies twice, 18 -- 3 and 4 -- 1. The rampaging Cardinals set a season scoring high in the opener, scoring in every inning but one and shelling four Phils' pitchers for 17 safeties.

On May 3 THE TIMES published a United Press dispatch which gave the totally false impression that the undersigned thirty-two writers and artists had taken sides against their own country in an open letter addressed to Soviet writers. Since the publication of this dispatch in newspapers throughout the country we have been attacked in editorials and by Congressman Rankin, and our loyalty has been called into question.

Mrs. Chaim Weizmann, making her first appearance as First Lady of the Republic of Israel, expressed yesterday "profound sorrow" at Great Britain's attitude in the Palestine crisis. She added, however, that she was "sure that the moment is not far off that Great Britain will join hands with the western civilization and will abandon the people who are fighting against us."

After a cold buffet, fruit fritters, served steaming hot, are an appetizing contrast for dessert. The crisply coated pieces of banana, apple, pear or almost any fruit, tinned or fresh, may be sprinkled with confectioner's sugar or topped with hot wine sauce.

The rowboat in which two high school boys disappeared Friday night while practicing landings off Brighton Beach was recovered Saturday night, it was announced yesterday after positive identification of the frail craft had been made.

The interest of the Davega Stores Corporation in WMCA, New York, has been purchased by Nathan Straus, majority stockholder, it was announced yesterday. Herman M. Stein, president of the selling interest and, for four years, treasurer of the station, explained that his radio responsibilities and the expansion of his company together "imposed too great a burden" on his "time and energy."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 23 -- A Yugoslav Government spokesman last night reiterated charges that Lieut. Col. Chester M. Stratton, the assistant United States military attache here, and other United States officials had hidden Ilija Mangovitch, a former Chetnik who was sentenced to death last Monday for participating in the slaughter of Partisans during the war.

The New York Employing Printers Association will make formal training programs for junior office executives and other skilled white collar employes a permanent activity, Don H. Taylor, executive vice president, disclosed in an interview last week.

ST. LOUIS, May 23 (AP) -- Philadelphia's surprising Athletics steamrolled the Browns twice today, 7 to 3 and 8 to 1. Ferris Fain, Sam Chapman and Buddy Rosar hit home runs in the two contests, Fain's coming in the seventh inning of the nightcap with two on base. Dick Fowler and Lou Brissie were the winning pitchers.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., May 23 -- The annual stockholders' meeting of the Glens Falls group of insurance companies was held here last week. The group consists of the Glens Falls Insurance Company, Glens Falls Indemnity Company, Commerce Insurance Company and Glens Falls Corporation.

Newspaper advertising in fifty-two cities totaled 197,221,289 lines during April, a gain of 17.1 per cent over the like period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed over the week-end. Gains were recorded in all categories, with retail up 20.9 per cent; classified, 15.8 per cent; financial, 14.3 per cent; automotive, 8.9 per cent, and general, 8.4 per cent. Total display was up 17.5 per cent.

VIENNA, May 23 -- The resignation of Dr. Arthur Marget, chief of the financial and economic division of the United States forces in Austria, to become financial adviser to W. Averell Harriman, is regretted by the Austrian Government.

The Communist party indicated yesterday that it would not nominate a Presidential candidate this fall, thus leaving its members free to support the Third party ticket headed by Henry A. Wallace. This would parallel the position taken by the Communists in 1944 when they failed to put a nominee in the Presidential race and gave their tacit backing to Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Bernard Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., heads a group of thirteen department store presidents making up a retailers' advisory committee for fashion presentations during the city's Golden Anniversary, Grover A. Whalen, anniversary chairman, announced yesterday.

Cessation of hostilities by Arab forces in Palestine is the only condition under which troops of the Provisional Government of Israel will lay down their arms, Maj. Aubrey S. Eban, newly appointed representative of Israel at the United Nations, asserted yesterday.

Challenging what he called a popular impression that modern psychology favored giving full rein "to our appetites and instincts so as to avoid unhealthy complexes," the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken said yesterday that there was no such sanction in psychology or in ethical religion.

I read with great interest the article of your chief South American correspondent, Milton Bracker, which appeared in your May 3 issue. Mr. Bracker generally states that the constitutions and laws of the Latin-American nations lack guarantees with regard to expropriations.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- A large short interest was shown in May corn in the final days of trading last week on the Board of Trade. But the effect of this was offset by the liquidation of a concentrated holding with the July taken in exchange.

A recent report by the Department of Agriculture is an arresting statement of the progress of machine food production. Publication 630, "Progress of Farm Mechanization." surveys the growth of machinery in agriculture and summarizes some of the results. Few urban dwellers realize that horses and mules, at their peak in the First World War, have since decreased by approximately two-thirds.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 23 (AP) -- Jersey City snapped its four game losing streak before a crowd of 4,079 here today by taking both ends of a doubleheader from Toronto, 6-5 and 10-8.

In devoting practically the whole of Page 4 of your issue of May 14 to the text of the official British statement on Britain's Palestine adventure you were, of course, following your admirable policy of placing before your readers all documents essential to an understanding of the great current problems.

Probably the person who knows most about what foods are consumed by Manhattan and Richmond families is Mrs. Louise H. Whitaker of East Orange. She said yesterday that she had just interviewed almost sixty housewives in the two boroughs in an effort to learn for the United States Department of Agriculture what is eaten in urban homes.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that the five Borough Presidents had agreed to cooperate with other city departments in consolidating street openings for repair work by city agencies and private utilities. The aim was to help the Police Department ease traffic congestion.

Norman Thomas, Socialist Presidential candidate for the sixth time, and John P. Freeman, director of the Citizens Committee for Universal Military Training, upheld opposite viewpoints last night at a debate on "Is Conscription Necessary for Our Security?" in Brooklyn College's Boylan Hall.

BUTTE, Mont., May 24 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York learned today as he invaded Montana on the last leg of a delegate hunt through the West that the state's eleven-man delegation to the Republican National Convention was "very favorably" inclined to him.

A performance of uncommon musicality was given to Joseph Haydn's rarely heard oratorio, "The Seasons," at Town Hall last night. The occasion was the commencement concert of the Music School of the Henry Street Settlement; the performance by the Mozart orchestra and chorus of the Music School, under the direction of Robert Scholz.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The House Rules Committee acted today to forbid any effort on the floor to change the Republican reciprocal tariff bill as it came from the Ways and Means Committee.

The drive by Raymond M. Hilliard, Welfare Commissioner, to remove from the relief rolls the "minority which is making a racket of public assistance" resulted yesterday in the arraignment of two women accused of having accepted support from the Welfare Department while they were employed.
Deborah Bertonoff, mime and "droll dancer" from Palestine, made her formal New York debut last night in a recital at the Cort Theatre, with Carl Mosbacher as the assisting pianist.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The proposed drafting of 18-year-old youths for one year of training as future reserves was abandoned formally by the Senate Armed Services Committee today.

For serving as human "guinea pigs" in the testing and development of devices to replace their lost limbs, five men who lost arms or legs by amputation were cited yesterday by the Army for outstanding patriotic civilian service to the nation. Four are veterans of World War II.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 24 -- Henry A. Wallace claimed tonight for the "new Progressive party" a share of the credit for "getting the civil rights message out of President Truman," and he looked to the party to help force out of the Administration and the Republicans "more than a message; more than their new, better-than-ever lip service."

LONDON, May 24 -- Lord Citrine, chairman of the British Electricity Authority, explained at a press conference today that yesterday's electricity failure over a wide area of southern and eastern England was not a result of nationalization of the electricity supply.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Exiled leaders of six Peasant and Agrarian parties, driven from their homelands by Soviet-supported Communist oppression, today elected Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, Poland's wartime Premier, as chairman of the International Peasant Union.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- In an effort to divert problems of nation-wide significance and import to the home front for solution, the National Council for Community Improvement today held its first session of a three-day conference here.
DETROIT, May 24 (AP) -- Pitching his way past a shaky start, Hal Newhouser settled down to shutout hurling through the last eight innings today as the Tigers whipped the Senators, 5 to 2.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 24 -- The Proprietary Association of America was urged today to further expand its research facilities as a contribution to the nation's health.

The Social Service Employes Union, Local 19, CIO, announced yesterday that it had made a conditional offer to let an arbitrator decide whether it still had a binding contract covering administrative employes of the national board of the Y.W.C.A.
ST. LOUIS, May 24 -- Mike Turnesa of the Knollwood Country Club today became the third member of his noted golfing family to gain the final round of a P.G.A. championship.

During a tense anti-Mundt bill rally last night in the DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx, speakers were booed and a group, including members of the Catholic War Veterans, walked out. A police detail guarded the meeting against disorder.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 24 -- Preparation for an animated version of the Hiawatha story has gotten under way at the Walt Disney Studio, the producer disclosed today, and Dick Kelsey, a Disney artist, is scheduled to leave next week for the Hiawatha country in Minnesota to prepare sketches and background material for the film.

A resolution to work for religious unity among Jews here and abroad was adopted yesterday at the final session of the fiftieth annual convention of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America in Yeshiva University, Amsterdam Avenue and 186th Street.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The seven Arab nations have been told officially that the United States is "gravely disturbed at the present course of events in Palestine" and have been called upon to respect the cease-fire resolution of the United Nations Security Council.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- A 34-year-old ship's captain told a House Labor subcommittee today that two seamen's unions had unjustly blacklisted him, making it impossible for him to get employment.
The last big college rowing race before Poughkeepsie sends Cornell's unbeaten varsity against Navy Saturday on the Severn at Annapolis.

Clarence E. Steinberg, attorney, and John Chingos have acquired from Gustave Kempler three acres of land on the north side of New Power House Road, east of Searingtown Road, Roslyn, L.I., for improvement with fifteen dwellings. Title to the property was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.

TOKYO, May 24 -- Joseph B. Keenan, American chief prosecutor at the Japanese war crimes trials, far outstripped the principal defendant, former Premier Hideki Tojo, as a best-selling author, according to figures made available today.
SANDWICH, England, May 24 (AP) -- Dick Chapman of Pinehurst, N.C., carried his challenge for the British amateur golf championship through the first round today with a squeaky 1-up victory.

PARIS, May 24 (AP) -- Frankie Parker and Budge Patty, already occupying quarter-final rungs in singles, attained the same round in men's doubles today in the French international tennis tournament. The Los Angeles tandem ousted Fernando Olozaga of Spain and Heraldo Weiss of Argentina, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 0, 8 -- 6.

However desirable it may be that a tenant receive notice when his landlord seeks a rent rise, such notice cannot be required by the courts in the absence of action by the legislature, Municipal Court Justice Martin M. Frank declared yesterday.

The American film industry plans to release fifty-two feature pictures in Germany during the coming year as compared to the thirty released last year, according to Marian F. Jordan, general manager for Germany for the industry's Motion Picture Export Association.

Thirty-four war refugees, some of whom feared that their exit visas might not be extended by the new Government in Czechoslovakia after they expired this month, arrived at La Guardia Field from Prague yesterday aboard a plane that had been chartered from Pan American World Airways by the Joint Distribution Committee.

TORONTO, May 24 (UP) -- Last Mark, a husky brown gelding, ran away from the field in the stretch at Woodbine Park today to set a new record in winning the eighty-ninth running of the historic King's Plate, the oldest continuously run horse race in North America.

Holders of 102,802 shares of $5 preferred stock of American Power and Light Company have formed protective committee in connection with the proceedings before the Securities and Exchange Commission for the recapitalization of the company under the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- As workers returned to their jobs today after ending their ten-week strike, Armour, Cudahy and Swift meat-packing companies promised that all of their plants would be in full operation in a week.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 24 -- The financing of new homes will total $12,000,000,000 in the United States this year, Curtis F. Scott of New Orleans, retiring president of the National Savings and Loan League, predicted today at the opening session of its fifth annual convention.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 24 (AP) -- Arab spokesmen indicated today that the Arab nations would agree to a truce only if the Israeli Army were disbanded and the Palestine partition plan shelved.
I refer to the letter of George Tichenor which appeared in THE TIMES of May 22, entitled "Decay of Untermyer Estate" at Yonkers.

Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., in its annual report for the fiscal year ended with last March issued yesterday by A. E. Lyon, president, disclosed a net profit of $6,035,278. This is equivalent to $2.60 a share of common stock and compares with $4,958,150, or $2.04 a common share earned in the previous fiscal year.

In his masterly review of Fairfield Osborn's book warning us of the imminent threat of world-wide starvation, your Orville Prescott suggests that we "take far more intelligent and forceful steps to preserve our own diminishing land and food resources."

Food and grocery manufacturers will average a profit of about three cents on every sales dollar received during 1948, as compared with three and a half cents earned last year, Paul E. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, predicted yesterday at the annual convention of the Flavoring Extract Manufacturers Association in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Young Rubicam, Inc., celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of its founding yesterday by presenting a $25 United States Savings Bond to each of its 1,000 employes in the agencies' nine offices here and abroad. "The bonds seemed a better idea than the usual big party," Sigurd S. Larmon, president, commented.
NEW ORLEANS, May 24 -- Drastic tax increases proposed by Louisiana's new Governor, Earl K. Long, are meeting widespread opposition from business and labor groups in Louisiana.

The money market continued tight yesterday, with Federal funds quoted at 1 3/16 per cent. Member banks here, which had reported a deficiency in reserves of $100,000,000 on Wednesday night, suffered a further drain through payments for a new issue of Treasury bills, and an outflow to other areas, and by Thursday the deficiency was increased to $200,000,000.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 24 -- The United States Naval Academy, long the cradle of Naval tradition, is approaching its June Week ceremonies -- traditional climax of each academic year -- once again the storm center of a local controversy that has wider implications.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Dwight P. Griswold, head of the United States Mission for Aid to Greece, will make a personal report to President Truman this week on the results of the first year's operation of the so-called Truman Doctrine.

Neither size nor complexity constitutes any basis for separation of essential management into opposed levels of exclusive authority, it was declared last night by William Whigham Jr., supervisor, wage and salary administration, Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation.
BERLIN, May 24 -- Anti-Communist elements of this city's trade unions expect to announce on Wednesday the establishment of a new leadership to represent the 700,000 union members in Berlin.
LONDON, May 24 -- The Palestine situation and the adverse April import figures had a depressing effect on the stock market here today.

The expansion program of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board will get under way today when 125 volunteers, comprising thirty-two teams, will call on property owners, real estate brokers, builders and others interested in real estate and invite them to become affiliated with the board.

PARIS, May 24 -- More than 200 town halls in small communities around the cities of Nantes and Niort in Western France were closed today in protest against the attitude of the Government toward various forms of public aid for Catholic schools.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 24 (AP) -- The Israeli Army said tonight it had driven Arab forces out of the entire Jordan Valley.

Surrogate William T. Collins will entertain a petition this morning fried by Public Administrator Francis T. Mulligan, as administrator of the estate of Willard Blossom Segur Jr., to intervene in the probate proceedings in the estate of Mrs. Mabel Seymour Greer, who died Aug. 10, 1946, leaving more than half of her $500,000 estate for charitable purposes.
The Eastern Steamship Line has filed suit against the United States Government in a shipping dispute involving the long-idle liner Acadia.

Fall buying of women's apparel began in earnest yesterday as coat, suit and dress manufacturers in the New York garment market displayed their lines to the first contingent of out-of-town buyers. There was a readiness to place orders immediately after fall lines were shown, it was learned, but buyers have adopted a careful attitude which, however, is not as stringent as it was last year.

With the powerful and contagious ideas of democracy and communism clashing in a world in much of which there are extremes of poverty and wealth, we must conceive and execute a "positive, aggressive political program designed to win the masses of people of the world to our banner," Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas asserted last night.

MADRID, May 24 -- Fines totaling 125,000 pesetas (about $11,000) have been imposed on five prominent Spanish monarchists as a result of an unauthorized meeting held here in mid-April, it became known today.

TOKYO, May 24 -- The possibility that Emperor Hirohito may abdicate within the next few months again is becoming a subject of general discussion among Japanese. Now, for the first time, it is being mentioned in the Tokyo press.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Maj. Gen. William J. Donovan, organizer and director of the war-time Office of Strategic Services, today accepted appointment as counsel to a committee appointed by Overseas Writers, an organization of correspondents, "to inquire into the murder of George Polk."

A fireman and a patrolman, first recipients of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York annual gold medal for valor, were honored yesterday at the monthly luncheon-meeting of the association's board of directors at the Yale Club, Forty-fourth Street and Vanderbilt Avenue.

LONDON, May 24 -- Great Britain's influence in the Middle East, which is still greater than that of any other power, notwithstanding the post-war decline in her prestige, was being strongly exerted today in an effort to persuade the Arab states to agree to a cease-fire in Palestine.

Belgian and British sources are offering large steel tonnages to foreign customers of American steel exporters in Latin America and are rapidly taking away foreign sales volume built up by this country in the competitive pre-war period, Meldon F. Smith, general manager, Charles Williams and Associates, Ltd., merchant exporters, 50 Church Street, declared in an interview yesterday.

CLEVELAND, May 24 -- The time has come when Americans must give thoughtful, humane, scientific and skillful attention to our most precious assets, our people, Leonard W. Mayo, vice president of Western Reserve University, told 2,000 delegates to the National Congress of Parents and Teachers convention tonight.

LONDON, May 24 (Reuters) -- The Australian cricket tourists today got the better of the Marylebone team, strongest they have met so far, dismissing the English batsmen on a rain-deadened pitch for 189 runs.

The week-end sweep of the honors in three of the four sections of the competition by upstate bowlers became permanent last night when the thirty-three-day New York State championships drew to a close.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Goldman, Sachs Co., Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, and Piper, Jaffray Hopwood will place on the market today a new issue of 120,000 shares of convertible preferred stock of Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., chain merchandiser of automobile accessories and other goods.

Patience, fortitude and a reasonably well-pitched game were all the Dodgers needed to regain their winning ways. After eight straight setbacks, which taxed every Wailing Wall in Flatbush, the Brooks had all three yesterday at Ebbets Field and the result was a 9-4 victory over the Reds.

A scale model of a house decorated and furnished by graduating students of the New York School of Interior Decoration is featured in an exhibit that opens today at the school design annex, 119 East Fifty-fourth Street. It will be open through Saturday and from June 1 to 4 between 10 and 5, as well as this Thursday evening between 7 and 9:30.

HELSINKI, Finland, May 24 -- Workers throughout Finland struck today to protest the Government dismissal of the Communist Interior Minister Yrjoe Leino. Cabinet members held emergency conferences to seek a solution of the unprecedented crisis.

The three members of the Board of Transportation yesterday heard an appeal from 2,500 nonoperating employes of the board for the same increase in salaries on July 1 as that granted to the operating employes. The proposed increase for nonoperating employes has been set at $250 annually with a $650 increase for the operating force.

Trading on the stock market became more leisurely yesterday and the pattern proved conventional. Prices fluctuated narrowly and the slight gains made by some sections in the morning generally were eliminated in the late dealings. A few issues managed advances in excess of a point but at the close the list leaned to the lower side with a loss of 0.29 point in the combined averages.

New York public school children do as well as or better than pupils the country over in the "three R's," Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, declared last night in a sweeping denial that "progressive" education in the city schools was the cause of poor scholarship or lack of discipline.

Madison Square Boys Club started its annual Boys Fair Week in highly successful fashion yesterday at the clubhouse, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street. As token closing of the club's "winter" season the fair will continue through Saturday with exhibits, contests, parties, dances and dramatic productions.

VIENNA, May 24 -- Russia's secret police, the MVD, and Ministries of the Interior in the satellite countries have cooperated to prepare "watch lists" of politically wanted or suspected persons. Several hundred persons already have been arrested by Soviet guard posts in Austria.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- President Truman's forthcoming Western speaking tour took on impressive proportions today as the White House issued an itinerary showing that he would make five major addresses and about a dozen "off-the-cuff" talks.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 24 -- In a move to "sell democracy" to women throughout the world, the General Federation of Women's Clubs has far more than doubled its membership since last October by bringing in 5,102,000 new foreign members, it was announced here today.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 24 -- The possibility that the Russians might call for a meeting of the Allied Control Council to take up the question of German unity was vouchsafed by Wilhelm Pieck, Communist leader of the Socialist Unity party in the Soviet Zone, today at a jammed press conference following the public rally in Roemerberg.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- President Truman recommended today a comprehensive expansion of the Social Security System. His program would add 20,000,000 workers not now covered, increase benefits for the aged and dependents and increase Federal aid to the needy.

IT is easy to see from reading "The Stilwell Papers" why their author was called "Vinegar Joe." Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, "a deck hand with a one-track mind," as he called himself, was a master of barrack abuse. When he was angry, which was much of the time, the fur flew and the sparks crackled. No American commander in the second World War tried to do more with less under more exasperating conditions than Stilwell.

City Councilman Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, is spearheading a new drive to have the national Congress of Industrial Organizations act against the left-wing leadership of the Greater New York CIO Council, it was learned last night.

The Coast Guard, in a move to improve its search and rescue organization, has distributed ten portable mechanical "iron lungs" to units in this country, Alaska and Hawaii. The new equipment is designed to shorten the time between the receipt of a distress call and the arrival of a fully equipped rescue team.

We have pointed out more than once recently why, in our opinion, it is a misjudgment of the first magnitude for the leaders of organized labor to press demands for a "third round" of wage increases at this time. These reasons add up to the fact that the conditions are already present or in the making for a renewal of the forward march of inflation.

GENEVA, May 24 -- At the halfway point in its work, the conference of the facilitation division of the International Civil Aviation Organization has considerably advanced the cause of simplifying the movements of goods, planes and supplies across frontiers but has produced little that is likely to help passengers directly.

The two-story loft building also containing a store at 122 Seventh Avenue has been sold by Guy Cary and Philip A. Carroll, as executors and trustees of the estate of Robert W. Goelet, to B. Tannenbaum, who has occupied the property for fifty years as Ben's Clothes Shop.

LONDON, May 24 -- There was a keen contest today between British and United States dealers at the auction of early Americana from the library of the late Sir Leicester Harmsworth. Much of the buying for United States collectors was done on behalf of Miss Emily Driscoll, New York dealer.

The Columbia Broadcasting System will add another program to the growing list of radio's audience and listener participation shows on Saturday when it offers the premiere of "Sing It Again," an hour's melange of music and money-laden questions, starting at 8 P.M.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Senate Republicans intend to try to rescue and pass the anti-lynching bill by throwing it, as a rider, into the oleomargarine tax repealer, a measure strongly supported by the Southerners.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The complicated case in which the Federal Government accuses the Aluminum Company of America of a monopoly of the ingot market was returned to the Second Circuit Court of Appeals in New York by unanimous decision of the Supreme Court today.
NANKING, May 24 -- Dr. Wong Wen-hao, noted geologist and chairman of the National Resources Commission, was named Premier of China today after the two leading candidates had rejected the job.

Prospects for business are good because, if the Republican party holds its present normal strength, it is sure to win the Presidency, it was declared last night by Raymond Moley, Professor of Public Law at Columbia University. He spoke at the annual meeting of the New York Employing Printers Association, Inc., in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

MILWAUKEE, May 24 -- Rigid conformity to ecclesiastical dogma coupled with a tendency to water down realities inherent in the teachings of Christ were singled out tonight by the Rev. Dr. G. Kearnie Keegan, first vice president of the American Baptist Home Society and pastor of the Temple Baptist Church, Los Angeles, as basic reasons for the failure of the church to proclaim its message on a world scale.
The Cunard White Star liner Britannic, which left Liverpool Saturday on her first commercial crossing of the Atlantic since the war, is scheduled to arrive here next Monday.

A record turnout was indicated early last night as members of the Medical Society of the County of New York went to the polls to choose officers for the coming year. For the first time in the history of the society there were two strongly-backed slates.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- President Truman today nominated Charles F. Brannan of Denver to be Secretary of Agriculture. The nominee has been Assistant Secretary since June, 1944. He would succeed Clinton P. Anderson, who resigned to run for the Senate in New Mexico.

LONDON, May 24 -- A handwriting error that gave rise to the impression that the battleships Warspite and Valiant had exhausted their supplies of anti-aircraft pom-pom ammunition led to the withdrawal on May 23, 1941, of British naval forces sent to prevent the German invasion of Crete.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Army and Navy Union today decorated Attorney General Clark for his activities against subversive elements.

BOSTON, May 24 -- The General Alliance of Unitarian and Other Liberal Christian Women turned down today a resolution condemning universal military training and censuring "the military" as leading the United States into war.
NEWARK, N. J., May 24 -- Federal Judge Guy L. Fake, senior Federal judge for New Jersey, issued the following statement today connected with the resignation of Edgar H. Rossbach:

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The two independent divisions of the National Labor Relations Board -- its five members and the general counsel -- urged Congress today to get rid of the union shop election procedure.

The Hotel Greeters of America opened yesterday their thirty-eighth annual convention with meetings at the New Yorker and the Pennsylvania Hotels. One thousand delegates attended the sessions, which will continue today and tomorrow. Paul W. Mangan is general chairman of the convention.

With less than four weeks remaining before the date set for the adjournment of Congress on the eve of the Republican convention, the most important measure in the whole field of national defense still marks time. This is the Andrews bill, providing for a two-year revival of Selective Service.

NEWARK, N.J., May 24 -- Arraigned on a charge of murdering Police Capt. Thomas J. Rowe in his precinct station office early Friday, Mrs. Ann S. Powers, 39- year-old waitress, collapsed in the First Precinct Court this morning when Police Judge P. James Pellechia ordered her held without bail for the grand jury.

A man in a blue uniform resembling that of a collector for the Brink's, Inc., armored car service, took $4,288 from the cashiers of two Horn Hardart automats yesterday afternoon and escaped despite a city-wide police alarm.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 24 -- The ten-day Parade of Progress celebration held in this city under auspices of the Civic and Business Federation, the White Plains Chamber of Commerce, and Brand Names Foundation, Inc., closed this evening with a dinner attended by 300 at the Contemporary Club here.
President Truman recognized the State of Israel immediately after it was proclaimed because it had a "legitimate claim to statehood," David A. Morse, Under-Secretary of Labor, said yesterday.
The weakfishing at Peconic Bay seems to be hitting a new high, with the fishing running much heavier than they usually do during the early run.

The only Broadway opening of the week, as well as the final play of the dwindling 1947-48 season, will be exhibited this evening at the Empire Theatre. It is Arthur Goodman's "Seeds in the Wind," which recently served as the initial bill in the Experimental Theatre's Invitational Series program.

PARIS, May 24 -- France made a triple move today to protect French property in Jerusalem and to insure the protection of sites in the Holy City that are important for historic, social or scientific value.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- An unusual poll of Republican and Democratic Congressmen on the qualifications of Republican Presidential possibilities resulted today in a narrow victory for Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, but simultaneously gave new impetus to a movement to nominate Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan if the front-runners are deadlocked.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 24 -- The United Nations special committee studying the creation of an economic commission for the Middle East rejected today by a vote of 10 to 1 the Soviet Union's claim to membership in such a commission, but approved membership for eleven other countries of the region.
Scheduled five major speeches for June cross-country tour.

WITH THE ARAB LEGION, in the Old City Jewish Quarter of Jerusalem, May 24 (AP) -- Arab Legionnaires hammered the Jewish Quarter of the Old City with artillery and machine-gun fire tonight while Arab dynamiters blew up a concrete pillbox.

LONDON, May 24 -- French insistence on stronger United States guarantees for Western Europe again brought the six-power conference on Western Germany into difficulties today. There has been a long series of ups and downs in this conference, and once more it looks as if the talks will drag on longer than expected -- at least until the end of this week.

The Board of Estimate will hold a hearing today on the petitions of more than a dozen privately operated bus lines for modification of franchise contracts to permit the charging of a higher fare. Nine of these lines do not specify the amount asked, suggesting merely a "higher rate of fare," to be later determined.
ALBANY, May 24 (AP) -- Political events at home and abroad almost force the Lutheran Church "into new relations with the state," the president of the Lutheran Synod of New York said tonight.

Prices of cotton futures turned easier on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closed to 63 points net lower, with the weakness most pronounced in old July delivery. Early in the session July was 101 points, or $5.05 a bale, below the previous close.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Resignation of Edgar H. Rossbach, Federal attorney for New Jersey, has been accepted, the Justice Department announced today. No reason was given for the resignation.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn sustained yesterday a lower court ruling upholding the judges of the Kings County Court in their controversy with District Attorney Miles F. McDonald over control of the court's calendar.
JERUSALEM, May 21 (Delayed) (UP) -- Water is almost as dear as life itself today in Jerusalem while brandy is selling for $2.64 a quart.

Representative Arthur G. Klein, Democrat, whose district covers the lower East Side, expressed the belief yesterday that President Truman would announce a lifting of the arms embargo to Palestine today. Mr. Klein made it clear that he was voicing only a personal opinion, but he was confident that the announcement would come after the visit of Dr. Chaim Weizmann, president of the Provisional Government of the State of Israel, to the President today.

Area and local officials of the American Red Cross challenged yesterday a statement in a report adopted last week by the house of delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York. The report said the Westchester County chapter of the Red Cross had agreed to cooperate with a local blood donor service program that made free blood available only to the indigent.

LOS ANGELES, May 24 -- Congress should exercise its Constitutional power over money to correct the policies of the Treasury Department which are increasing inflation, according to Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of New York.

The new state of Israel is entitled to the protection of the United Nations, and the United States Government should lift the embargo on arms immediately, speakers declared last night at the ninety-sixth annual convention dinner of B'nai B'rith, District Grand Lodge No. 1, in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ARAB LEGION HEADQUARTERS, Palestine, May 24 -- In bitter but inconclusive fighting the hospice of Notre Dame de France, near the western corner of the Old City in Jerusalem, changed hands twice today. It was captured by Trans-Jordan's Arab Legion but retaken by the Haganah, the Israeli Army.

Three American students who broke through State Department protocol have discovered cracks in the "iron curtain" large enough to permit students from Russian-dominated nations to visit here this summer for the first time since the war.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- President Truman's new call for broadening of the Social Security program was received with little enthusiasm on Capitol Hill tonight.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- More than 800 new super markets will spring up this year with an indicated $400,000,000 to be spent on expanding the industry, it was predicted today by Nathan W. Lurie, secretary-treasurer of Wrigley's Stores, Inc., Detroit.

Reggie Pearman, New York University's stretch-galloping middle distance ace, has his sights set on a double triumph in the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island Friday and Saturday.

Social scientists all over the world were urged yesterday by Dr. John R. Rees of London, president of the International Committee for Mental Hygiene, to gain greater competence in the solution of problems of human relations in order to aid their governments more effectively.

WARSAW, May 24 -- The Polish Government officially took no notice today of a Sunday Catholic Church pastoral letter that condemned materialism and reiterated the church's determination to remain a factor in educating the country's youth.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 24 -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder said here today that he feared the country would have to return to deficit financing by the end of the next fiscal year on June 30, 1949.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- The job of explaining itself to its employes and to the public is about as important a one as confronts management, it was held here today at a one-day conference of more than 200 business leaders from the Chicago area.

DETROIT, Tuesday, May 25 -- A settlement of differences between the United Automobile Workers, CIO, and the General Motors Corporation appeared near early this morning on the basis of reports from reliable sources.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 24 -- A sparkling triple play in the fifth inning featured Maryland's 10-to-7 victory over Army in a lengthy contest at Doubleday Field today.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- President Truman sent to the Senate today the appointment of Miss Frieda B. Hennock of New York as a member of the Federal Communications Commission.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 24 -- The United Nations Security Council agreed tonight, unanimously but with obvious foreboding, to extend the deadline for its appeal for a cease-fire in Palestine to 1 P. M., Wednesday, Eastern daylight time.

NEW DELHI, India, May 24 -- Prime Minister Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and V. P. Menon, Secretary of the Indian States Ministry, motored today to Mussooorie, a mountain resort 168 miles from New Delhi, to confer on the Hyderabad situation with Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, Vice Premier and States Minister.

The private, non-sectarian, "nonprofit" cemetery business is under investigation by the State Attorney General, it was learned yesterday, as a result of increasing complaints during the last two months of profits made from the sale and upkeep of graves.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The National Education Association said today that it had found surplus funds in the states to be "utterly inadequate" to meet the country's educational deficiencies.

Alfred Glasser has purchased the one-story taxpayer property at 111-54 Van Wyck Boulevard, Dunton, Queens, from Margaret Schooner. The building is on a plot 109 by 20 feet. Philip Golden was attorney for the buyer and Lester C. Rinse acted for the seller, Title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.

Two books about Germany have been scheduled for June publication by the Henry Regnery Company of Hinsdale, Ill. "Whither Germany?" by Hans Zbinden, Swiss writer and publisher, will be issued on June 15. Scheduled for June 22 is "The German Opposition to Hitlerism: An Appraisal," by Hans Rothfels, Professor of Modern History at the University of Chicago, formerly of the University of Konigsberg.

LAWRENCE, Kan., May 24 (AP) -- Heads of two Big Seven Conference schools spoke out strongly today against an interpretation of an athletic eligibility ruling that would affect a score or more players.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., May 24 -- Harold S. Adamson, a member of the Americanism Committee of the American Legion, was found dead today in his room at the Elkwood Hotel, Second Avenue and Broadway, this city. His skull had been fractured.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 24 (AP) -- Henry Bruere, president of the Bowery Savings Bank of New York, told the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks today that if it were necessary, bankers would sell their investments in Federal bonds to finance home building.

The most desperate human group in the world -- two hundred and thirty million hungry and sick and destitute children in Europe, the Middle and Far East -- have no ambassador to plead their cause. They must depend on the mercy of the adult world. Many individuals do understand and have responded.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., May 24 -- The first team off in the morning in a field of seventy-five teams, Irwin Jackson and Jack Mallon, Cold Spring Country Club, finished first with 32, 32 -- 64, in the first amateur-pro event of the season staged by the Metropolitan P.G.A. at the Wheatley Hills Club today.

ROME, May 24 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi's sixth Cabinet came officially into office this afternoon when Luigi Einaudi, President of the Republic, administered the oath of office in his official residence to the new Ministers.

LONDON, May 24 -- The indefinite suspension of four-power talks on the Austrian peace treaty was formally reported to the Council of Foreign Ministers here today by Samuel Reber, United States deputy in the negotiations and chairman of the next meeting, if any.

PARIS, May 24 -- That Anglo-American relations have suddenly dropped to a new and astonishing low level as a result of the Palestine war is an open secret throughout the capitals of Western Europe. This in itself is sufficient cause for alarm.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 24 -- Borba, the official Yugoslav Communist party organ, confirmed indirectly today the presistent rumors of a struggle in the upper ranks of the party over the tactics to be employed in socializing the country's agriculture.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture will offer price-supporting loans on early harvested wheat at rates averaging $1.96 a bushel, farm basis. The rates for last year's crop averaged $1.83.

MANILA, May 24 (AP) -- Luis Taruc, ailing commander of the Hukbalahaps, today defiantly offered the Philippine Government peace -- an armed peace -- with his bands of armed peasants on his own terms. He also declared that he long had been and still was a member of the Philippine Communist party.

The New York County grand jury voted superseding criminal informations yesterday against five persons accused of rent gouging. Among them was a woman charged with obtaining a $5,000 bonus for arranging a Park Avenue apartment lease.

The Empire City Racing Association, operator of the Empire City race track in Yonkers since it was built by James Butler, founder of the grocery chain, has completed arrangements to buy several tracts of land in the Bronx on which it proposes to build a new racing plant.

LONDON, May 24 (UP) -- Identity cards will serve as passports for the 5,000 athletes who will come here this summer for the Olympic games and they will not have to pay the customs duty, purchase tax and other levies usually imposed upon visitors.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (UP) -- A House Un-American Activities subcommittee has been holding secret hearings on the loyalty of Dr. E. U. Condon for more than a week, it was disclosed today.

LONDON, May 24 -- The veteran liner Aquitania will begin a new career tomorrow on the North Atlantic carrying emigrants from Britain to Canada. The 45,000-ton vessel will sail from Southampton for Halifax, Nova Scotia, with more than 1,400 settlers for Canada.

There are disturbing reports from Washington that measures embodying a comprehensive long-range housing program again may be lost in the shuffle of last-minute legislative deliberations. There is danger that all of the debates, hearings and studies which have been inspired by the so-called Taft-Ellender-Wagner bill may go for naught, and that the measure may not even be reported out of committee unless some Congressional leaders cease their filibustering and delaying tactics.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (UP) -- The Government today charged the Bobbin Manufacturers Association of Boston, its officers and eleven manufacturing companies with conspiring to fix prices in the sale of bobbins and other products used in making yarn and cloth.

With a Presidential board of inquiry scheduled to begin hearings this morning on a strike threat affecting long-distance telephone service throughout the nation, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that strikeless settlements had been reached between seven of its affiliated companies and thirteen unions representing 54,000 Bell System workers.

The perplexity of the man in the street about modern art and the answer to his dilemma are presented in a film to be released soon, it was announced yesterday. The motion-picture short, in color, was produced by Riethof Productions, Inc., of New York, in association with Spencer Samuels, head of the paintings department of French Co., 210 East Fifty-seventh Street.
BERLIN, May 24 (AP) -- The United States Military Government announced today it could not consent to the establishment by the World Federation of Trade Unions of a liaison bureau in Germany.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Associate Justice T. Alan Goldsborough directed John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers today to show cause on June 1 at 10 A. M. why they should not be temporarily enjoined from refusing to bargain collectively with the Southern Coal Producers Association.

Daylight saving has been in effect for about a month now, and it should be abandoned forthwith. Clearly it has failed. Instituted under the thesis of increased production and a happier and fuller life, it has succeeded only in making everyone more tired than he has a right to be at this time of year.

Ten-year-old Donald Lee Stover of Harrisburg, Pa., who had kept two jumps in front of the police since he arrived in this city Sunday, finally was found last night and taken to the Youth Center at 2 East 105th Street to await the arrival of his parents.

Eddie Arcaro dominated the proceedings at Belmont Park yesterday. The veteran rider thrilled a crowd of 27,054 fans by winning three races on a bang-up card that proved to be one of the most interesting weekday offerings of the season.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 9 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 6 per cent.

HELSINKI, May 24 (Reuters) -- Chairman Kusto Kulo of the People's Democratic party (the Com munist-Left Socialist coalition), which has threatened a general strike for tomorrow, announced formation of an "action committee."

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Senate sent to the White House today a bill to permit a Chinese medical couple to remain permanently in this country. They are Dr. Timothy C. H. Liang and his physician-wife. Esther Chang Liang. The bill gives their present residence as Newton Memorial Hospital, Cassadaga, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's message to Congress calling for a broader social security program follows:...

New York University gained its sixth consecutive Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference crown in a dramatic setting yesterday, as Tom Casey struck out Tommy Tolan to halt a three-run rally by St. John's in the ninth inning, giving N. Y. U. a 7-6 victory at Ohio Field.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (AP) -- Walt Dubiel retired the first eighteen men in order and then went on to hurl three-hit ball as the Philadelphia Phillies defeated the league leading St. Louis Cardinals 6 to 2 tonight. One of the Cards' hits was Stan Musial's homer following Red Schoendienst's single in the seventh.

Italy's new Cabinet, the sixth in less than two years and the first under the new Constitution, appears to be the strongest and best balanced that could have been assembled. A little left of center, elements of the extreme left and extreme right are both excluded. The discordant voice of Communism is silenced in affairs of state.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 24 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet representative on the United Nations Security Council, invoked the "double veto" today to block a hearing on charges that the Soviet Union used the threat of military force to help bring about the Communist coup in Czechoslovakia last February.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- Reports of good rains over parts of the West and Southwest and liberal receipts of cash corn led to general selling of grain on the Board of Trade early today, with prices declining around 2 cents a bushel from Saturday's finish.

LOS ANGELES, May 24 -- Fabrics, tailoring and detail denote continued interest here in the soft look. Prevalent are slim skirts with easy width below the knee introduced by gores, flounces and ingenious arrangements of pleats. Sleeves are focal interest in cuts and contrast fabrics.

John F. O'Connell, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, announced yesterday that the body would take "appropriate action" when it received from Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz specific data about the Brooklyn saloons he had called upon the Authority to close.

The report in your paper, according to which I offered a 50 per cent majority share in a large Ruhr concern to a French financial group, is untrue. I have not offered for sale a single share to French or any other foreign syndicates, let alone a large parcel of shares, neither have I entered into negotiations with German or foreign interests with any such object in view.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- When Harold E. Stassen decided to make an outright bid for delegates, and to contest territory where one or the other of his two active competitors was acknowledged to be strong, he faced the disadvantage of the Western nations in their struggle to restrain expanding Soviet spheres of influence.

HEWLETT, L. I., May 24 -- Miss Kathryn M. Guiterman, 33 years old, was found dead of a bullet wound in the right temple at 4:30 P. M. today in a bedroom of her parents' home on Everit Avenue, in the residential Hewlett Bay Park section here, according to the Nassau County police. Her body was taken to the Meadowbrook Hospital morgue pending an investigation.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The activities of the new Munitions Board have had a chief effect under unification of the armed services on military procurement practices. Some of these will take a long time to complete and others will require continuous study, but board officials say that uniform procedures already set up and being set up will soon assure a common approach to industry on all procurement matters.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 24 -- The Soviet Union accused the United States here today of delaying the arrival of two United Nations delegates from Byelorussia (White Russia) and the Ukraine, and of denying the delegates from the two Russian republics the diplomatic immunities promised to all foreign officials traveling to this place.
May I reply to the letter of Stephen B. L. Penrose Jr. in THE TIMES of May 20 criticizing our country's recognition of the State of Israel.

A blue-ribbon jury of twelve men and two male alternates was completed yesterday afternoon before General Sessions Judge James G. Wallace to try the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, 176 Broadway, and three of its officials on charges of conspiracy and issuing false information to other banking establishments.

Abraham L. Pomerantz, a New York attorney, told a Securities and Exchange Commission board of inquiry yesterday that he considered litigation recently instituted against the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation by James F. Masterson of Philadelphia, also an attorney, to be a "collusive suit."

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee today approved a bill to exempt securities issued by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development from the Securities Act and the National Bank Act.

Raymond M. Hilliard, Welfare Commissioner, said yesterday that a preliminary study submitted to him as chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Child Care indicated that a critical situation existed in the need and the facilities for foster care of children in the city. He added that this type of child was not getting the proper care in the city.

Senator Gurney and the Senate Armed Services Committee have bowed to political realities in deleting from the Senate Selective Service bill the compulsive training feature for a selected number of 18-year-olds. With Senator Taft against it and with little chance for passage in the House, the Senate Committee apparently decided that the risk of losing Selective Service by coupling it with Military Training was too great to take in present circumstances.

Causing a brief uproar that was heard all over Public School 64, 609 East Ninth Street, two overgrown youths and two seventh grade schoolboys attacked Morris Krapes of 131 Penn Street, Brooklyn, a teacher, before a class of forty pupils yesterday afternoon, in revenge for a severe reprimand Mr. Krapes had given the schoolboys for misbehavior at the morning session.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -Branch Rickey Suggested today that it might be a good idea to have a Secretary of Recreation in the Cabinet. The president of the Dodgers told the National Council on Community Improvement that an adequate program for this nation's youngsters was a difficult problem.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- World-wide use of river valley developments on the model of the Tennessee Valley Authority was foreseen today by Chester Bowles, former administrator of the Office of Price Administration, in an address on America's food in a hungry world.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 25 -Maj. Gen. Horace L. McBride, head of Turkish United States Army Group, told a press conference here today that by next December the fighting power of the Turkish armed forces would be "well above what it was before American aid."

Secretary of State George C. Marshall was the guest of honor at a special dinner given last night by the Economic Club of New York in the Astor Hotel. Two thousand persons, including leaders in the city's religious, civic, business and financial life, attended.

OMAHA, Neb., May 25 -- Confident that a majority of Southern and Western delegates will vote for him on the first ballot at Philadelphia, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey headed home tonight, still uncertain of his strategy between now and convention time.

Svend O. Sandgren of 41 Tier Street, City Island, the Bronx, custodian of Public School 107 in the same borough, was found guilty of second-degree manslaughter yesterday by an all-male jury in Bronx County Court. The jury recommended mercy.

Damages of $1,000, the maximum permitted under the State Civil Rights Law, were awarded yesterday to a 24-year-old Negro dancer by a jury that found he had twice been denied the use of ordinary passenger elevators at Tudor City.

The human relations commission of the Protestant Council of the City of New York made public yesterday a resolution asking defeat of the Mundt-Nixon bill, designed to outlaw subversive organizations. The resolution declared that while it was necessary to make provision for the identification of totalitarian movements, the Mundt-Nixon bill, now pending before the Senate, has "important defects and we are convinced it should be defeated."
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Poland has blocked the efforts of the United States to ascertain whether 20,000 persons there are United States citizens, the State Department announced today.
HAIFA, Israel, May 25 (AP) -British authorities closed the port of Haifa today to incoming passenger traffic.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Railroad labor leaders today urged Government ownership of the country's railroads.

Despite propaganda drives, special privileges and tax exemptions, the Soviet Government is making slow progress this spring in its campaign to collectivize farming in its annexed and recovered territories, according to information from Soviet sources that became available yesterday.

VIENNA, May 25 -- Recognition of the State of Israel promises to solve the Jewish displaced persons problem in Austria by the end of the present summer, greatly to the relief of the Austrian Government and the United States Army. There are still 20,000 Jews in camps in the American zone of Vienna and Austria, but they are leaving steadily.

In "Seeds in the Wind," acted at the Empire last evening, Arthur Goodman has seized a subject that cannot be pushed to one side. On a Carpathian mountain top he has assembled some Lidice orphans, bitter and disillusioned, who regard adults as their enemies.
Plans to broadcast by televisionthe "Command Performance" entertainment last night in MadisonSquare Garden were canceled atthe last minute by Station WCBSTV, which had scheduled theevent for 9 P.M.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 25 (AP) -- Shannon II, the Australian champion, was tried and found wanting again today as he ran fourth to Mafosta, Irish-bred speedster, in the $10,000 Angeleno Purse at Hollywood Park.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 25 (AP) -- Some of the mystery surrounding the victim in the Harold S. Adamson death was removed today with the reports of Dr. Julius Toren, assistant Monmouth County medical examiner, and the Police Department.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Planning by the Munitions Board for industrial mobilization in case of war calls for the imposition of wartime controls more promptly and more extensively than in World War II. The board's thinking runs parallel in many respects to that of Bernard M. Baruch, whose industrial mobilization plan prepared between World Wars I and II but never adopted, still furnishes much of the general foundation of current planning.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., May 25 (U.P.) -- Representative Karl Mundt, Republican co-author of the MundtNixon oil providing for stiff regulation of Communists, announced tonight that he would debate by radio Monday with William Z. Foster, national Communist party chairman.

Reflecting the coal walkout and its effect on other industries, which reduced traffic volume, the New York Central Railroad reported yesterday a net income of $16,659 for April. This contrasts with a net income of $1,039,213 for the similar month of a year ago.

The New York War and Peace Memorial Committee, in extending the competition for ideas for a living war memorial in Manhattan to Aug. 1, has decided to reject any plan costing more than $5,000,000, Maurice P. Davidson, chairman, announced last night.

LONDON, May 25 -- Under fire from some of its own supporters as well as from the Opposition benches, the British Government promised the House of Commons today that the present limited newsprint allocations for the nation's newspapers would not be reduced.

PRAGUE, May 25 -- The Catholic Church became today the only institution in Czechoslovakia to set an official limit upon its collaboration with the regime here. The Vatican disclosed that the Archbishop of Prague, Dr. Josef Beran, had forbidden priests to be candidates in the coming singlelist vote, which has replaced elections.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 25 --William L. Maude of Newark, who was elected president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks today, declared that for the first time since 1935, mortgage loans of the mutual savings banks of the nation have topped the $5,000,000,000 mark.

NEW DELHI, India, May 25 -Authoritative sources from Hyderabad have disclosed that the Government of the Princely State -- the only one remaining independent in India -- has offered a new and closer relationship to the Dominion Government on the condition that the State's ruler, the fabulously wealthy Nizam, receive a guarantee of continued internal sovereignty.

LONDON, May 25 -- The news of President Truman's projected loan to the State of Israel dropped like a bomb into Foreign Secretary Bevin's office today as he was talking with United States Ambassador Lewis W. Douglas.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The House Ways and Means Committee reached substantial agreement today on a largely uncontroversial bill to make eighty-one changes in present tax laws.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Former Governor Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota is still talking like a winner in the Republican Presidential race despite his reverse in Oregon at the hands of Governor Thomas E. Dewey of New York.

In their preoccupation with each other, New York University and Yale will be well-advised not to overlook Michigan State and Penn State in the tally of team points fat the seventy-second Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships at Randalls Island Friday and Saturday.

Heads of the Greek Orthodox Church and the Russian Orthodox Church in North America joined yesterday in a "great vesper" service that its sponsors considered a milestone in bringing the two Eastern churches together.

A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. submitted the highest bid for $3,586,000 of improvement bonds of the Park Cities Water Control and Improvement District No. 2, of Dallas County, Tex. The bid was 100.079 for 2 1/2s and 2 1/4s due from 1951 to 1977, an interest cost of 2.3048 per cent.
PARIS, May 25 (AP) -- Frank Parker and Budge Patty of Los Angeles brushed past two Italian Davis Cup players today to reach the semi-finals of the French international tennis championships.

Jacob S. Potofsky, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, and Charles H. Silver, general sales manager of the American Woolen Company, were honored last night by 900 members of the clothing and woolen industries and allied unions at a dinner sponsored by the United Jewish Appeal.

Settlement of a suit that charged Gordon B. Todd of 25 Broad Street and five others with being involved in a usurious "beat the margin" scheme, was announced yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Truman asked Democratic Congressional leaders today to press for a rise in the minimum wage and passage of Federal aid to education in the short time left of the present session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- There will be "really no difference" in the Air Force that is planned for the fiscal year 1949, to begin July 1, whether Congress appropriates funds for seventy groups or for sixty-six, according to Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Chief of Staff of the Air Force.
Asked Congress, through Democratic leaders, for Federal aid to education, and for increase in minimum wage.

The price of standard cane refiners' sugar may drop to somewhere between $6.60 and $7 per hundred pounds, possibly a little lower by the end of this year or shortly thereafter if history repeats itself in this post-war period, George L. Wright, vice president of Lamborn Co., Inc., told members of the Flavoring Extract Manufacturers Association at their convention in the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday.

General Electric Supply Corporation has written $90,000 worth of orders during the first two days of its open house for dealers which began on Monday and will end on Friday, James F. Galloway, traffic appliance manager, disclosed yesterday. He estimated that volume will reach $250,000 by Friday.

Residential hotels here are being caught in a squeeze between rising costs and slower room sales, Fred O. Cosgrove, president of the Hotel Association of New York City, Inc., declared yesterday. With costs of both labor and supplies steadily advancing, he added, the residential hotels rented 93.4 per cent of their rooms in the first quarter of this year compared with 96.3 per cent for the same period last year.

Nimble feet abetted by keen ears overcame lack of sight yesterday as nearly 200 blind women danced the tango, foxtrot and polka with a skill that eyes alone cannot provide. Quiet guide dogs sat proudly in the Lighthouse of the New York Association for the Blind at 111 East Fifty-ninth Street as their owners skipped out the steps of a square dance led and called by a blind woman.

May I take this opportunity of congratulating you on the consistent stand THE NEW YORK TIMES has taken in favor of the admission to the United Sates of its fair share of the displaced persons, first through your support of the dead-in-committee Straton bill, and now of the Fellows bill?
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The House Rules Committee today again deferred until tomorrow final vote on the Navy Public Works Bill with its $12,000,000 item for a Naval Academy airfield at Sandy Point, Md.

" Three Who Made a Revoluton," by Bertram Wolfe, biographical studies of Lenin, Trotsky and Stalin and a history of the Russian Revolution, will be issued by Dial Press on Sept. 23. It will cover the period from 1870 to the beginning of World War I.

ST. LOUIS, May 25 -- Little Ben Hogan of Hershey, Pa., gained the golfing heights again today when he captured the P.G.A. championship for the second time, turning back the challenger from Westchester, Mike Turnesa of the Knollwood Country Club, White Plains, N.Y., 7 and 6.

Delegates to the seventh annual meeting of the American Women's Voluntary Services were advised yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick of The New York Herald Tribune to tackle in their own communities the racial, educational and health problems for which foreign countries criticized the United States.

' Independents' Were Accused in Spirited Campaign of Being for 'Socialized Medicine' By a two-to-one margin, the largest turnout of doctors to vote in the history of the Medical Society of the County of New York upheld the candidates selected by their official nominating committee and rejected an independent slate backed by the Physicians Forum in their annual election, according to the results announced yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 25 -- The Israeli Army said tonight that Jerusalem underwent its first air bombing in history this afternoon.

Secretary of State George C. Marshall, who flew here from Washington, and Governor Dewey, homebound from Oregon, found themselves with at least one care in common yesterday. Both were bothered by the weather, as were a host of lesser citizens who sloshed through a day in which .62 inches of rain drenched the city.

A weakness in pleading with the peoples of Europe our case against Russia has been their Justified claim that our plans in their regard are subject to continual changes. In so far as these are due to our particular kind of democratic government, it is hard to effect amelioration.
May I say a few words about Thomas Wesson, Consul General of the United States, who fell at his work in Jerusalem.

Mayor O'Dwyer made fortythree awards to members of the New York Police Department at a special ceremony yesterday at City Hall. Six medals of honor were presented to the widows of New York Police Department members who gave their lives in the performance of duty in 1947.
Interim Committee (Little Assembly), Subcommittee 3 -- Discussed possibilities of modification of veto.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Although department store sales rose 6 per cent to a new peak last year, profits were reduced by a 2 per cent jump in the expense-sales ratio, with gross margins as well lowered by sharp mark-downs, Professor Malcolm P. McNair of the Harvard School of Business declared here today.

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- A needy band musician or debater may fare better than an impecunious football player from campus financial aid, if the National Collegiate Athletic Association strictly enforces its "Sanity Code."

MARGERY SHARP, who goes in for one of the most interesting hair-dos to be found in literary circles on either side of the Atlantic (see picture), has had her last three novels honored by the accolade of the Book-ofthe-Month Club. No other English writer, and no other American writer, has surpassed this record unless I am unusually forgetful.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A program for holding 254 war production plants in readiness for any emergency call is now cleared for floor action by the Senate and the House as soon as their crowded calendars will permit debate and voting.

The famous old steamer Meteor, which plied the Long Island Sound routes to Boston, Providence and many other New England points for more than a half century, and has been lying idle off Shooters Island, S. I. for the last year, will again be placed on the auction block, it became known yesterday.

Two thousand persons, one of the largest groups to attend a testimonial dinner in Brooklyn, gathered in the St. George Hotel last night to pay tribute to Msgr. John L. Belford. For forty-three years pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity, Classon Avenue and Madison Street, Brooklyn, Msgr. Belford is celebrating this month the sixtieth anniversary of his ordination.

DALLAS, Tex., May 25 (AP) -Texas Republicans named today a National Convention delegation composed of 30 supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft, two supporters of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey an one supporter of Harold E. Stassen. The action was at the state convention at Corpus Christi.

HELSINKI, Finland, May 25 -The Helsinki stevedore strike, ordered by the Finnish Communists as a protest against the dismissal from the Cabinet of Communist Minister of the Interior Yrjoe Leino, spread today to the port of Hangoe.

This nation will fail in statesmanship as well as in humanity if it permits a generation of hungry children to develop into a generation of embittered adults, Secretary of State George C. Marshall told an audience that packed Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A partisan fight over the reciprocal trade issue, with the high command of each party exerting its utmost influence, was projected for the House floor tomorrow at Republican and Democratic meetings today.

Terry Young, New York lightweight, has been matched with Jesse Flores of Stockton, Calif., for a feature bout carded for ten rounds at Madison Square Garden Friday night, June 4, it was announced yesterday by the Twentieth Century Sporting Club.

Latest Government action in a case concerning deceptive advertising was described yesterday by the National Better Business Bureau as a warning that Federal agencies intend to make vigorous use of the strong new weapon given them by the United States.

A merchant seaman arrested in front of the Roxy Theatre May 11 while taking part in a demonstration against the film, "The Iron Curtain," and charged with third degree assault was held for Special Sessions yesterday by Magistrate Raphael Murphy in Mid-Manhattan Court.

LAWRENCE, L. I., May 25 -Because two-thirds of movie boxoffice receipts are paid by persons under 30 years old, the industry should produce films beneficial to youth, speakers declared today at the 131st weekly forum of THE NEW YORK TIMES in the "What's On Your Mind'?" series.

Although operating results in the first quarter of 1948 were more favorable than in the similar period of last year, the net deficit of United Air Lines in the first three months of the current year amounted to $3,550,534, compared with $3,450,671 in the 1947 period, W. A. Patterson, president, reported yesterday.

The custom fur designs Ralph Marano presented yesterday at Russeks were marked by generous use of skins, such as silver bleu mink flowing hem-length in a sweeping mantle and natural wild mink falling in voluminous folds, and by the use of multiple shoulder capelets, bands of tiers and yoke treatments.
NEWARK, N.J., May 25 (AP) -The track operators said it never would work.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 25 -Lester Cutler, film producer, today announced the formation of a new independent company, National Pictures, Inc., with headquarters at the Motion Picture Center.

Mrs. Edith Douglass Roth, daughter of Dr. Mabel S. Douglass, founder and first dean of the New Jersey College for Women at New Brunswick, N.J., left one-third of her estate to the trustees of Rutgers University, providing they accept the legacy to furnish and equip an Alumnae Room on the campus of the women's college to be known as the "Mabel Smith Douglass Room."

LONDON, May 25 (Reuters) -The touring Australian cricket team today defeated Marylebone Cricket Club by an innings and 158 runs. Marylebone was dismissed in its second innings for 205 runs after they had followed on to a first innings total of 189 in reply to the Australian first innings of 552.

An analytical examination of communism in the United States will form the substance of the second documentary to be broadcast this year by the American Broadcasting Company, Robert Saudek, vice president in charge of public affairs, announced yesterday.

If the Republican leadership of the House of Representatives had stayed up nights for a month, trying to think up ways of giving the country a stunning exhibition of provincialism and partisanship at their unexampled worst, it could not possibly have hit upon a more successful means of doing so than in the position it has taken onh)0*0*0*irenewal of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act -- an issue due for a test vote today.

Although office revamping at the 100 Broadway headquarters of the First Boston Corporation has been going on one way or other since the merger with Mellon Securities Corporation, the sprawling and staid-looking layout holding over from pre-war days did not yield completely to the new look until this week.

ST. LOUIS, May 25 (AP) -- The fast-fading Boston Red Sox were the victims of a murderous seventeenhit assault by the Browns tonight and dropped their seventh game in eight starts on their Western trip, 9 to 4.

The election of a director of graduate studies as the first step in training candidates for the ministry for posts in the field of general education and for "technical specialization in the various social services" was urged yesterday.

The widest setback in a week was experienced yesterday by the stock market when a selling wave that developed late in the morning put an end to strength evidenced at the opening. Prices failed to recover despite an easing of pressure later and the combined averages lost 1/2 point on tho day, with wider declines in some issues.

The stole came into its own at the colorful fashion presentation made by Peck Peck yesterday noon at the Chatham Hotel. Thrown about the shoulders of girls wearing suntan frocks of colorful cottons it took the place of a bolero or little jacket making the dresses suitable for wear at country clubs during the luncheon hour.

Holland may buy American automotive parts via Canada, paying for them in American dollars under the European Recovery Program, according to reports yesterday in foreign trade circles here. The reports were said to have some significance as indicating a possible shift in buying, but, pending confirmation, were the subject of considerable speculation.

PARIS, May 25 -- The Communists today continued to absent themselves from the High Court of Justice, which was formed to try leaders in the Vichy administration on charges of collaborating with the enemy. Louis Nogueres, High Court President, continued the sessions without the Communists and lots were drawn to obtain Deputies to replace them.

Bernard F. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, and chairman of the Mayor's Fashion Coordination Committee for the city's Golden Jubilee celebration called yesterday the first meeting and luncheon of the committee at the Metropolitan Club.

Many luncheon parties were given yesterday at the formal opening for this season of the Outdoor Garden of the Ritz-Carlton. In the party of Mrs. Robert Morris Phillips were Mrs. Theodore Schumacher, Mrs. Lyttleton Fox, Mrs. Chester L. Dane, Mrs. Clark Williams and Mrs. Charles Harrison Goddard.

Damp and dripping weather forced the Giants to put off until tonight their arclight contest with the Cardinals at the Polo Grounds. The scheduled matinee between the Dodgers and the Cubs, who meet tonight at Ebbets Field, also was rained out.

The first of the series of free musical events to be presented in the metropolitan area by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians will be the appearance of a fifty-piece band in the Memorial Day parade of the Grand Army of the Republic.
