PORTLAND, Ore., May 25 -- A plea that American clubwomen dedicate "every waking moment" to the building of a world having "peace with justice and freedom for all" was voiced by Mrs. J. L. Blair Buck of Washington in her keynote address today to the convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 25 -- Robert H. Estill, American chairman of the United States-United Kingdom Control Group, agreed in response to a question today that the German mine management, like the Communist elements in the miners' ranks, was sabotaging production of Ruhr coal, on which so much of Europe's economy depends.

SYRACUSE, May 25 -- An increase in retail milk prices in the New York City milk marketing area, possibly in June, appeared inevitable when an advance of 44 cents per 100 pounds to milk producers in the metropolitan milk shed was announced here last night.

BERLIN, May 25 -- The production of textbooks for German schools in the United States zone continues to be one of the neglected projects of the Military Government, educational advisers declared today.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Truman attested his faith today in John C. Virden. Commerce Department official, who resigned under Congressional fire last week because his daughter worked for Tass, the Russian news agency.

SANDWICH, England, May 25 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, and Dick Chapman of Pinehurst, N.C., a pair of famous United States golfers, moved into the third round of the British amateur tourney today along with a pair of lesser-known countrymen.

Cyrus S. Eaton, largest stockholder in the Cleveland investment banking firm of Otis Co,, denied yesterday that he had tried to sell short 20,000 shares of the KaiserFraser Corporation's common stock on March 1.

A ceramic mural By WarnerPrins representing "The Mainspring of Democracy" was givenby the artist yesterday to the SaraDelano Roosevelt Memorial Housefor Hunter College at the annualmeeting of the Roosevelt HouseLeague.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -The Andresen Committee's report showed the largest group of resident alien traders was forty-five claiming Chinese citizenship. There were thirty-one from Poland, twentyeight from France, nineteen from England, nineteen from Germany and forty-four of unknown nationality.

Three leaders of an anti-Communist faction in the Bloomingdale department store union have been ordered expelled from the union and their store jobs by the local union's executive board, it was learned yesterday.
CLEVELAND, May 25 (AP) -- Bob Lemon shut out the Senators with four hits and struck out eleven tonight in hurling the Indians to a 4-to-0 victory.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 25 -- As Secretary of State Marshall met top United Nations officials in New York today there were strong signs that the Arabs would not agree to the unconditional cease-fire by tomorrow noon as demanded by the Security Council.

Advertising in New York metropolitan newspapers during the first four months totaled 48,131,1879 lines, an increase of 4.26 per cent over the comparable period of 1947, according to an analysis of Media Records figures. However, losses were registered for three of the five classifications as follows: Financial, 4.72 per cent; classified, 4.71 per cent and general, 0.18 per cent. Gains were recorded of 28.77 per cent for automotive, and of 7.32 per cent for retail.

GENEVA, May 25 -- The Soviet Union today advised the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe that the Russian zone of Germany would apply the international agreement for the exchange of railway cars, beginning on June 1.

Plans for resumption of rifle matches between a team of the 107th Infantry, New York National Guard (the old 7th Regiment) and a team of the crack British Regiment, the Queen's Westminsters, have been called off, it was learned yesterday.

Transcontinental and WesternAir~ Inc., which has pending beforethe Reconstruction Finance Corporation an appeal for financial aid,reported yesterday a net less of$3,914,235 in the first three monthsof 1948, compared with a deficit of$5,853,651 in the corresponding period of last year.

HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, N.J., May 25 -- Mayor John F. Knowlan announced tonight that this muinicipality and its two neighbors, Carlstadt and Wood-Ridge, would close their streets at 6 A.M. tomorrow to all through traffic that tries to detour around the fourmile closed section of State Highway 17.

The accidents of newspaper make-up resulted in an interesting confrontation in THE TIMES of May 17. On page 17 you announced the opening of the exhibition of the paintings removed from Germany to this country for safekeeping -- an exhibition for which your art and editorial columns have more than once expressed the hope in recent weeks.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Union shop polls were criticized by construction contractors as well as unions in testimony today before the Joint Congressional Committee on Labor-Management Relations.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,935, against 1,751 last week and 1,489 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 868 arrivals yesterday compared with 1,015 last Tuesday.

More than 15,000 tons of sheet steel will be saved as a result of an amendment to Conservation Order M-8, which now permits the use of tin in the manufacture of coffee cans of two pounds size or larger, W. F. Williamson, secretary-manager, National Coffee Association of the U.S.A., 120 Wall Street, declared in an interview yesterday.

The New Dance Group last night offered the fourth of those busy evenings of its "Festival Series" at the Mansfield Theatre, with three solo dancers and the New Dance Group ensemble dividing the program between them.
TEL AVIV, May 25 -- The text of the Israeli Government's protest to the Security Council today follows:

DETROIT, May 25 -- The General Motors Corporation reached a unique cost-of-living agreement today with the United Automobile Workers, CIO, to raise the wages of 225,000 employes. The contract is to run two years.

New York knows what to do for its underprivileged children, but for lack of "equipment, facilities and funds, is not permitted to put its knowledge to the best possible use," Raymond M. Hilliard, Commissioner of Welfare, declared yesterday. He was the principal speaker at the annual conference and luncheon of the Brooklyn Jewish Child Care Council at the Astor Hotel.
A national campaign to raise $100,000 in the food industry for the construction of the seventh unit of Boys Town in Italy was started at a luncheon yesterday in the Pennsylvania Hotel.
Leonard Lesley's play, "Days of Hate," has been selected as the winner of the second Olga Shapiro Memorial Award of $500, it was learned yesterday.
LONDON, May 25 -- Both interest and business were lacking in the stock market here today.

LONDON, May 25 -- Princess Elizabeth received the honorary degree of Doctor of Civil Law at Oxford University today amid scenes of enthusiasm and pageantry rarely equaled in the long history of the university.
The market started unchangedto 16 points higher.

FORT WORTH, Texas, May 25 (AP) -- With only six absentees -- including new PGA champion Benny Hogan, who is also defending champion here -- the selected thirtytwo-player field for the third $15,000 national invitation golf tournament was on hand for trial trips at the Colonia Club today.

PARIS, May 25 -- A new process for the photographing and the projection of color motion pictures was hailed by the French press here tonight as the most important advance in movie technique since the adoption of sound.

h)0*0*0*iOLast night the Museum of Natural History opened the Leonard C. Sanford Hall of Biology of Birds. The first major permanent exhibit to be opened at the Museum since 1942, the new hall has been named in honor of a Museum Trustee and Honorary Fellow and a patron of the institution for almost half a century.

Price increases for wool fabrics can be expected for next spring on the basis of raw material and labor costs, Frank L. Foreman, general sales manager of Botany Mills, Inc., asserted yesterday. Inventory holding of goods at the high prices is dangerous, he said, but the current situation does not hold any promise for lower costs.

MILWAUKEE, May 25 -- The churches of America were called upon today by the Rev. Dr. Edwin T. Dahlberg of Syracuse, N.Y., president of the Northern Baptist Convention, to join forces in a crusade for world peace "powerful" enough to permeate all fields of human endeavor, including government, labor, industry, education and the United Nations.
Customs agents here announced yesterday that they had seized six pounds of crude opium valued at about $30,000 and had arrested two seamen and were seeking a third for attempting to import the drug.

JERUSALEM, May 25 -- In a setting reminiscent of many World War II battle fields and beachheads, funeral services were held Monday for Thomas C. Wasson, United States Consul General in Jerusalem, and Chief Petty Officer Herbert Walker of the United States Navy communications team, who died Sunday after having been shot by snipers.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, May 25 -- A twenty-four-hour battle for the Latrun crossroads, controlling the vital Bab el Wad road into Jerusalem has ended in an Arab Legion victory with 600 Haganah dead, the Trans-Jordan Defense Ministry announced tonight.

Somewhere on the Hudson River between Harlem and Yonkers, Bill (Bojangles) Robinson took the wheel of an excursion ship yesterday and squinted through the pilot house at the rain. Then, turning on the dazzling grin as famous as his dancing feet, he shouted into the public address system:

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 (AP) -Six-hit pitching by Paul Erickson and Schoolboy Rowe and Del Ennis' fifth homer of the season with one man on base carried the Phillies to a 4-1 decision over the Pirates tonight.

The many and varied problems that confront the domestic steel industry will be discussed at the fifty-sixth general meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute today and tomorrow in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel here. A record attendance of more than 1,200 officials of the industry from all sections of the country has been assured.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Doubt that Henry A. Wallace would continue his third-party candidacy through to the November election was expressed here today by Arthur Krock, chief Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Despite rising prices and extended use of buildings, the New York public school system hasreduced its fuel bills by $2,628,676 in six years, it was disclosed yesterday in a report by Harold D. Hynds, superintendent in charge of the Bureau of Plant Operation and Maintenance.

S. Reed Anthony, formerly assistant sales manager of the rayon fiber division of the American Viscose Corporation, has been appointed a merchandise executive of Greenwood Mills, Inc.. effective June 1.

The Port of New York Authority made public last night the long-awaited scale of charges for airline users of New York International Airport at Idlewild with the assertion by Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Authority, that use of facilities at the new field would cost less than the charges now imposed at La Guardia Field.
Mr. and Mrs. Jules J. Vatable, who have been at the Weylin for several months, have gone to Lochgraeme, their summer home in Islip, L. I.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Department of Agriculture predicted in a food report today that there would be no sharp downward trend of food prices for the rest of 1948, due to a continuation of a high level of economic activity.

ALBANY, May 25 (AP) -- The Lutheran Synod of New York voted today to permit the withdrawal of its seventy-nine New Jersey congregations, which would units with other New Jersey churches to form a separate synod.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 26 -- The Moscow radio said today that the Soviet Union had agreed to exchange diplomatic missions with Israel. The broadcast said the decision was made by Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov "on the proposal of Moshe Shertok, Foreign Minister of the State of Israel."
CAIRO, Egypt, May 25 (AP) -Leaders of five Arab countries met at Amman, Trans-Jordan, today to decide whether to obey the extended United Nations demand that firing be stopped in Palestine.

Home accessories outstanding for their functional designs and graceful lines, whether they are humble cooking utensils or tall floor lamps, are now being made by Swedish craftsmen for American homes. They were shown yesterday at the opening of the importing showroom of Swedish Handicrafts, at 153 Lexington Avenue.

Yesterday's joint announcement byh)0*0*0*irepresentatives of the General Motors Corporation and its CIO United Auto Workers that a wage compromise had been reached came only seventy-two hours before the deadline set for a walkout of the company's 225,000 employes. The settlement, however, is likely to prove important, in the long run, not so much because of this dramatic circumstance as for its wider implications.

A complete course in birdlore,which might serve as an excellentrefresher for parents beset bychildren's questions about robinsand pigeons and Dodo birds, beganat the American Museum of NaturalHistory yesterday as theLeonard C. Sanford Hall of Biologyof Birds opened.

The European Recovery Program is the nucleus of a policy but it is by no means a whole policy. It is more a beginning than an end. It puts the United States into a new relationship with the nations of Western Europe, in many respects a more delicate and difficult because a more intimate relationship than before.

Small ways in which homemakers can turn kitchens into efficient work shops without any remodeling are suggested by the Kelvinator division of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation, makers of kitchen equipment. These things turn largely on the arrangement of little items.

Declaring that the Title Guarantee and Trust Company of 176 Broadway had a "reserve for contingencies" of $1,600,000 to cover any unexpected losses, Joseph V. McKee, counsel for the bank, said yesterday that it was improbable that the concern would enter into any criminal act for the sake of $4,000 to $15,000.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Trustees of the United Mine Workers Welfare and Retirement Fund met today but avoided discussion of the injunction suit brought by Ezra Van Horn, operators' trustee. The suit has prevented payment of pensions to the soft coal miners.

ATHENS, May 25 -- The Greek General Staff's communique today referred to "intensive offensive incursions into bandit lairs in the Peloponnesus." This was construed here as a laconic announcement of a large-scale Army drive to clear the Peloponnesus area.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Dr. Chaim Weizmann, first President of Israel, met President Truman today and came away with the belief that the embargo on arms for the Middle East would be lifted and that his country would get a loan for arms and reconstruction.

The interesting point about the Board of Estimate hearing yesterday on a higher fare for bus lines in New York City was the absence of the erstwhile champions of the five-cent fare among the witnesses. The hearing room was filled. There had been, at least in some quarters, an expectation that a display of political fireworks might develop.

Watermill ground a field of seven others into defeat in the eighteenth running of the Acorn Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. Second choice to the King Ranch's Scattered, Watermill scored a convincing victory in the $15,000 added feature for 3-yearold fillies, racing the mile in the fine time of 1:37 over a fast track.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Truman went out of his way today to welcome Dr. Chaim Weizmann, President of the Provisional Government of Israel and one of the stoutest fighters for the Zionist cause.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 25 -- Investigators attempting to solve the mystery of the death of Harold S. Adamson, 57-year-old anti-Communist crusader, whose battered body was found in his room at the Elkwood Hotel here yesterday, tried tonight to trace his actions on the week-end that ended in his death.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Senate approved today by a voice vote a $1,126,727,405 agricultural appropriation bill for the fiscal year beginning July 1.
SEOUL, Korea, May 25 -- The recently elected Korean National Representative Assembly will meet here next Monday to take the first steps in the formation of a national government.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Truman went out of his way today to welcome Dr. Chaim Weizmann, President of the Provisional Government of Israel and one of the stoutest fighters for the Zionist cause.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 25 -- Investigators attempting to solve the mystery of the death of Harold S. Adamson, 57-year-old anti-Communist crusader, whose battered body was found in his room at the Elkwood Hotel here yesterday, tried tonight to trace his actions on the week-end that ended in his death.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Senate approved today by a voice vote a $1,126,727,405 agricultural appropriation bill for the fiscal year beginning July 1.
SEOUL, Korea, May 25 -- The recently elected Korean National Representative Assembly will meet here next Monday to take the first steps in the formation of a national government.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 25 -- The achievements of the United Nations in the economic and social fields are being displaced in newspapers and radio by headline news of discord and conflict, Assistant Secretary General Benjamin A. Cohen reported today to a group of information experts.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 25 -- Boyden Roseberry, executive secretary of the Westchester County Medical Society, said here this afternoon that the society, the County Hospital Association and the county chapter of the American Red Cross were in "complete agreement" on the proposal to provide free blood bank service in the county only to the indigent.

The Security Council of the United Nations suffered another blow to its already shaky authority when it permitted Mr. Gromyko, the departing Russian representative, to cast a "double veto" against consideration of the charges that the Soviet Union engineered the Communist coup in Czechoslovakia.

PARIS, May 25 -- Experts of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation today began intensive work to prepare programs under the European Recovery Program and started to discuss the problem of intra-European payments.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres today. At the Mayfair Theatre the attraction is "The Time of Your Life," the adaptation of the William Saroyan prize play, featuring James Cagney, William Bendix, Jeanne Cagney and Wayne Morris.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Grain markets were easy at the opening on the Board of Trade today but rallied and closed unsettled with wheat 1/4 cent a bushel higher to 1/4 cent lower, and corn, unchanged to 1 1/4 cents up. Oats were 3/8 cent lower to 1/8 cent higher.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The first issue of foreign-currency securities was announced today by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. The entire issue of about $4,000,000 of 2 1/2 per cent Swiss franc serial bonds maturing in 1953 and 1954 was purchased by the Bank for International Settlements at Basle, Switzerland.

LONDON, May 25 -- Clothes rationing was eased by the Board of Trade today to give millions of Britons a chance to replenish threadbare wardrobes. A summer bonus of twelve coupons was granted, ties and gloves were removed from rationing and the coupon values of a number of essential items were reduced.

The Board of Estimate, at its hearing yesterday on the applications of fourteen private bus and trolley companies for higher fares, received caustically a proposal that the city buy all the private lines to achieve complete transit unification.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 25 -- A simple official announcement in today's newspapers provided the first concrete clues concerning the respective positions in the Communist party hierarchy held by those persons who, with Premier Tito, share the real power in Yugoslavia.
DETROIT, May 25 (AP) -- Following is a statement issued by the General Motors Corporation concerning the two-year agreement reached with the United Automobile Workers, CIO:

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A "get tough" policy toward Argentina in financing purchases there for the European Recovery Program was indicated today by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic CoSenate Appropriations committeemen threatened to wrtie legislative restriction on ECA dealings with the Peron Government.

CLEVELAND, May 25 -- The practical solution to this country's mounting traffic toll is to make driver education a separate course of study in the nation's 28,000 high schools, Mrs. L. K. Nicholson of Salt Lake City told delegates to the annual convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers today.
Random notes.
CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- Buddy Rosar's sixth-inning single scored Hank Majeski with the winning run as the Athletics defeated the White Sox, 4 -- 3, before 19,426 persons tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The United States has warned Egypt and Syria that it will not recognize their blockades of Palestine, the State Department announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -The oil and natural gas industries are not going to get all the steel they say they need, a House committee was told today.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 25 (AP) -Mrs. Andy Schuttinger's Justice, under the handling of Jimmy Stout, romped home three lengths in advance of his nearest rival to annex the feature at Garden State today.

DETROIT, May 25 -- It took the Yankees and Tigers a couple of innings to get going today at Briggs Stadium. For those two innings 18,864 onlookers thought they were watching a flock of fellows emulating Humpty Dumpty.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has authorized the acquisition of control of the Beech Creek Railroad Company by the New York Central, which is operating the property under a 999-year lease, entered into in 1890.

JERUSALEM. May 25 -- Arab preparation for a major effort to conquer Jerusalem before the deadline, tomorrow, set by the United Nations Security Council in its cease-fire appeal are "clearly indicated by all our sources of intelligence," a spokesman for the Jewish Agency for Palestine declared today.

In a surprise move, the longlines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and representatives of its 25,000 unionized employes decided yesterday to renew direct negotiations, instead of submitting their wage dispute to a Presidential fact-finding board.

The intention of "dark horse" candidates for the Republican presidential nomination to keep their candidacies alive up to and through the early balloting in Philadelphia in June was emphasized yesterday.

PRETORIA, South Africa, May 25 -- As voters prepare to go to the polls in the national elections tomorrow, it is clear that Prime Minister Jan Christiaan Smuts is facing the sternest electoral trial of his career. The loss of twelve seats would put him in the minority; the loss of seven would leave him without a working majority.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 25 -- Argentina will head a fight tomorrow to force an inquiry into the Communist coup in Czechoslovakia despite the Soviet Union's veto of a subcommittee to hear evidence on the change of government in Prague.

BERLIN, May 24 -- The United States formally charged the Soviet military administration today with kidnapping Germans and forcing them to labor in the uranium mines in the Soviet zone of occupation. The charge was made at meeting of the deputy commandants of the Berlin Kommandatura.

JERUSALEM. May 25 -- Arab preparation for a major effort to conquer Jerusalem before the deadline, tomorrow, set by the United Nations Security Council in its cease-fire appeal are "clearly indicated by all our sources of intelligence," a spokesman for the Jewish Agency for Palestine declared today.

In a surprise move, the longlines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and representatives of its 25,000 unionized employes decided yesterday to renew direct negotiations, instead of submitting their wage dispute to a Presidential fact-finding board.

The intention of "dark horse" candidates for the Republican presidential nomination to keep their candidacies alive up to and through the early balloting in Philadelphia in June was emphasized yesterday.

PRETORIA, South Africa, May 25 -- As voters prepare to go to the polls in the national elections tomorrow, it is clear that Prime Minister Jan Christiaan Smuts is facing the sternest electoral trial of his career. The loss of twelve seats would put him in the minority; the loss of seven would leave him without a working majority.

Two painters whose scaffold, slung five stories above the Avenue of the Americas at Forty-third Street, broke suddenly yesterday morning, escaped death by clinging to ropes until rescued by passers-by.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 26 -- Princeton's varsity baseball team scored two runs in the ninth inning and defeated Fordham, 5 -- 4, on University Field today. The victory extended Old Nassau's current winning streak to four games.

HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, N. J., May 26 -- An early end to the battle of road blocks between the State Highway Department and three communities affected by the closing of a two-mile section of Route 17 for widening operations seemed in prospect tonight.

KINGS POINT, N. Y., May 26 -- The American Merchant Marine can compete successfully with foreign shipping if given the opportunity, but first a better "householding job" on our vessels is required, Hans J. Isbrandtsen, president of the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., declared here tonight.

RANGOON, Burma, May 26 -- Thakin Nu, Premier of Burma, announced today that he would resign on July 20 and undertake to unite all Left parties in the country on basis of a Socialist program featuring, a rapproachement with the Soviet Union and other Communist countries.

The agreement for a $65,000,000 interest-free loan from the United States to the United Nations for the erection of a permanent home for that organization in this city was signed more than two months ago by Senator Austin and Trygve Lie. It still lacks Congressional approval. The matter must be brought to a prompt vote if it is to be disposed of at this session.

JERUSALEM, May 23 (Delayed) -- Arab shells crashed into the streets of Jewish Jerusalem sporadically -- now singly, now in salvos -- for the eighth day in succession today and the wind from the desert made it the hottest of the year.

LONDON, May 26 -- Great Britain's decision on the withdrawal of British officers from Trans-Jordan's Arab Legion still waited tonight upon the Arab states' ultimate response to the United Nations Security Council's call for a cease-fire in Palestine.

ALBANY, May 26 -- The New York Central Railroad expects net earnings this year to exceed those of 1947, despite a deficit in net income for the first four months of 1948, stockholders were told here today at their annual meeting. They re-elected the entire board of directors, thereby rejecting Robert R. Young and Robert J. Bowman, chairman and president, respectively, of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company, who were nominated from the floor.

Many of the dry-fly anglers who fish the Beaverkill, Willowemoc, Neversink and Esopus are beginning to wonder what has happened to the normal fly life on these streams, for reports indicate that the hatches on these streams have been few and scattered.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The House, disassociating itself from bipartisanship in a key aspect of the country's foreign policy, passed today the Republican - sponsored bill to extend the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act for one year in a restricted form. The vote was 234 to 149.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Sandy Point Airfield project is only one of several expansion and construction projects tentatively planned by the United States Naval Academy.

THE TIMES has directed its editorial influence toward improving traffic conditions in New York City in a series of excellent editorials. A recent one on the need for smaller taxicabs was particularly to the point.

Johnny Schmitz, the stylish southpaw of the Cubs, sent the Dodgers stumbling back into the distressingly familiar rut of defeat last night with a nifty six-hit performance that was good for a 4-1 triumph before 22,853 spectators, the smallest after-dark attendance in recent memory at Ebbets Field.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The United States relaxed controls today on exports of industrial equipment and materials to the first of a series of countries in the Russian sphere, approving export licenses for shipments to Finland of machine tools, steel, power generating machinery and other items worth $3,890,000.

Our friendly cop on the corner is such a commonplace that we are prone to take him for granted. Mayor O'Dwyer, in handing out awards at City Hall of seven departmental medals of honor -- six of them given posthumously -- and thirty-six other medals for police heroism in 1947, reminds us that our policemen live dangerously.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 26 -- James Hoge, Washington, D. C., general counsel of the Proprietary Association of America, condemned today present procedures of the Federal Trade Commission relative to advertising regulations covering the packaged medicine industry.

THIS is the Olympic year. Or have you forgotten? But you won't get much chance to overlook that fact any longer. With all the momentum of a snowball rolling down a mountainside, the preparations for the big international show at London will increase in size, speed and importance in the next six weeks. The snowball then will land kerplunk in Wembley Stadium and probably smother the athletes from the rest of the world.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 26 -- Andrei A. Gromyko made one of his most bitter attacks against the United States today, accusing it of leading a "veto hunt" in the United Nations Security Council and scouring the "dives" of Europe for "political prostitutes" to testify in the Czechoslovak case.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The State Department's "Voice of America" broadcasts were raked with salvos of criticism today by indignant Senators defending their states against what they deemed slights and distortions.

Samuel L. Sharp, Eastern European expert for the Foundation for Foreign Affairs, is working on a book, "The United States and Poland," for Harvard's American Foreign Policy Library series edited by Sumner Welles. He is now in Poland completing his research for the book.

Maj. Mary Metz, head of the Salvation Army's Missing Persons Bureau for the last four years, received an official farewell yesterday at the Army's headquarters, 120 West Fourteenth Street. She will retire this week after forty years of service.

CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -- The Athletics recorded their fourth straight triumph by toppling the White Sox, 7 -- 1, today. The victory, highlighted by Joe Coleman's five-hit pitching, was the Mackmen's fifth in nine games on their first Western swing.
LONDON, May 26 (AP) -- Owners of 36 of the original 386 entries for the English Derby paid the final 100 pounds ($400) today to keep them in the race at Epsom Downs on June 5.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Segregation in some instances of white and Negro soldiers at recreation clubs for troops in the European theatre, together with other instances of alleged discrimination, brought forth a protest today in a report prepared for Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army. by a group of Negro newspaper publishers who visited Europe at Secretary Royall's invitation.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 26 -- The National Association of Mutual Savings Banks ended its twenty-fourth annual conference, held in the Traymore Hotel here, by adopting today a series of resolutions designed to uphold the economic and financial condition of the nation.

OFF CALIFORNIA, May 25 -- With a prayer for the Navy's departed heroes and for the men who will follow in their tradition the First Task Force, 150 miles at sea, today sent an old warrior to a grave 1,800 fathoms beneath the Pacific.

Arthur M. Hill, chairman of the National Security Resources Board in Washington, said last night that the Administration had three basic answers to the "triple threat" of world communism against the United States.

ST. LOUIS, May 26 (AP) -- The Red Sox defeated the Browns, 5 -- 3, today, with Sam Mele scoring the deciding run in the tenth when Catcher Less Moss fumbled Dom DiMaggio's sacrifice and threw wild to first base for a double error.
BOSTON, May 26 (AP) -- Rallying behind Hank Sauer's tenth homer of the season, the Cincinnati Reds came from behind to defeat the Braves, 8 -- 5, tonight before at chill-braving crowd of 18,839.

TRENTON, N. J., May 26 -- Turning his attention from the West to the East in his quest for delegate support at the Republican national convention, Governor Dewey of New York was told today that he had the second-ballot support of a majority of New Jersey's thirty-five delegates.

MOSCOW, May 26 (AP) -- The Soviet Government published today documents purporting to show that the British Government, as late as August, 1939, had offered Hitler a free hand in Europe in exchange for a British-German alliance.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 26 -- The seven nations constituting the Arab League rejected tonight an appeal by the United Nations for a cease-fire order in Palestine, and gave the Council a time limit of forty-eight hours in which to submit to them a proposal on the entire problem of the Holy Land.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 26 -- Mrs. F. K. Thayer Jr. of Piping Rock won low gross honors in the second weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association over the Cherry Valley course today with a fine round of 39, 43 -- 82.

Clifford J. Hunt, radio and television sales manager, Stromberg-Carlson Company, called yesterday on television set producers to improve frequency modulation sound reception facilities in their products. Mr. Hunt said that few manufacturers now have audio systems capable of bringing out the full FM tonal range, particularly in music.

With an explosive outburst that tossed 44,128 onlookers into an incredible uproar, Mel Ott's mauling Giants rose en masse in the eighth inning at the Polo Grounds last night and sent eight runners whirling over the plate as if catapulted out of a gun.

The twelve-story and penthouse apartment building for forty-one families on a plot 75 by 100 feet at 949 West End Avenue has been sold by the Voredes Hotel Corporation to Seymour R. Candee, operator. It is assessed for $325,000 and was sold through Pearce Mayer, Eugene O'Hussey and Raymond O'Keefe, brokers.

Secretary of State George C. Marshall has declined the annual award of The Churchman, a Protestant Episcopal magazine, it became known yesterday. Dr. Guy Emery Shipler, editor of the magazine, disclosed that Mr. Marshall had refused to accept the award, which is given annually to the person chosen by a poll of the magazine's readers and others for service in the promotion of good-will and understanding among people.
Issues of debentures of industrial and public utility companies totaling $55,000,000 will be offered to investors today by underwriting syndicates, as follows:

JERUSALEM, May 26 -- The heaviest fighting in Palestine was today going on around Latrun, half-way point on the Tel Aviv-Jerusalem road. And there was no prospect of its being halted by the United Nations Security Council's call for a cease-fire.
New Yorkers, many of whom will join the pleasure-bent exodus from the city tomorrow, began yesterday observing the deeper significance of the Memorial Day holiday at rites honoring the war dead.
Wayne J. Holman Jr. has been named vice president and general manager of Chicopee Sales Corporation.

A group of safe-crackers, crude in vault-opening technique but with a faultless eye for value in collectors' postage stamps, has engineered the largest theft of philatelic treasures known to the field, it was learned yesterday.

BELLPORT, L. I., May 26 -- Several cans of shoe polish and plenty of elbow grease were converted today into $100 for the Camp Eddy building fund campaign by Frank Trotta, local merchant, who dug up his old bootblack chair and spent the entire day polishing shoes in front of the Trotta Brothers Supermarket on Main Street.
ROME, May 26 (AP) -- Pope Pius received today four children whose dreams came true.

DEVON, Pa., May 26 -- Sheer Genius, an 8-year-old chestnut mare, was ridden to victory by her owner, Jack B. Ward of New Rochelle, N. Y., in a $500 five-gaited stake for mares, the feature event tonight at the Devon Horse Show and Country Fair.

CLEVELAND, May 26 (AP) -- The Indians were handed their first shutout of the season tonight as Sid Hudson and Tom Ferrick combined to limit Cleveland to three hits as the Senators triumphed, 2-0, before 30,612.

BERLIN, May 26 -- The anti-Communist forces in this city's trade unions tonight issued to the Communist leadership an ultimatum that was interpreted as making final the first split in the post-war German trade union movement.

"IT was high time the people in all the swell houses around here began to know who he was," ruminated dull-witted Aaron Adams; "time they began to realize that he was somebody, too." So Aaron took time out from clipping Westchester hedges, that bright mid-September morning, to prove to Westchester and the world that he was somebody.

Glove production in France has recovered to 80 per cent of pre-war output and only the lack of quality skins holds up full recovery, according to Jean Buscarlet, vice president of the Federation of Glove Manufacturers of France.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The United States tonight returned to Societe Rhodiaceta of France patent rights on rayon yarn manufacture which this Government seized from the concern during the war.

The Oil Industry Information Committee will break a $750,000 campaign tomorrow, starting a series of full-page black-and-white ads on what the industry has done to increase production. Five general magazines and two Sunday newspaper supplements will use about once-monthly inserts until the end of the year.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved gradually upward yesterday and closed firm, 35 to 50 points net higher.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 26 -- Formation within the next two years of a National Council of the Churches of Christ in the United States of America was virtually assured today when the Northern Baptist Convention, with only a few dissenting votes, became the twelfth national church body to approve establishment of the overall Protestant agency.

Patsy Parr, a skillful and self-assured 10-year-old pianist from Toronto, made ter New York debut last night at the Pop Concert at Carnegie Hall. She played Mendelssohn's G minor concerto with the orchestra conducted by Abrasha Borodkin.

A three-year contract providing no immediate increase in the general level of wages was offered yesterday to the American Union of Telephone Workers, CIO, by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

The election of Theodore Rousseau Jr. to the post of curator of the Department of Paintings of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the retirement of Richard F. Bach, dean of Museum Extension and Education, were announced yesterday by the institution's board of trustees.
ALBANY, N. Y., May 26 (AP) -- The Lutheran Church is making plans for a five-year period of European relief, the executive secretary of the National Lutheran Council said today.

One doesn't have to look far for an answer to the problem of what to take a hostess this coming holiday week-end. Delicacy shops here are ready with suggestions rather less obvious than the perennial box of candy. Whatever her tastes, they have assembled such a variety of food gifts that it should be easy to find one that will please her.
DETROIT, May 26 -- The trouble with the Yankees today lay in their throwing. Their hitting was all that could be desired.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The United States has proposed to Great Britain, France and the Soviet Union a four-power meeting to start July 30 in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, to draft a convention for free navigation of the Danube, Secretary of State Marshall announced today.

The Journal of Commerce Corporation of 63 Park Row yesterday filed plans for the six-story printing plant and offices of The Journal of Commerce to be erected at 99-103 Worth Street at a cost of $650,000. William Ginsberg Associates are the engineers.

Crude oil production in the United States last week increased 16,600 barrels to a record high of 5,439,200 barrels daily, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Production of crude oil for the week ended May 24, 1947, was 5,024,850 barrels daily.
The instrument approach and approach lighting systems at New York International Airport at Idlewild were officially approved yesterday by the Civil Aeronautics Administration.

Opera for College, which has been taking its production of Mozart's "Cosi fan tutte" round the country in a station wagon, last night gave New Yorkers a chance to hear it at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A. It proved a credit to all concerned.

The Senate, rushing through last-minute legislation, must put the brakes on long enough to amend a bill which disgracefully ignores American tradition and pledges. This is the Wiley-Revercomb bill which limits the entry of DP's over the next two years to a maximum of 100,000, sets nationality and other restrictions, and aims at destroying those last family units in the DP camps which survived Hitler.

A good five-cent cigar is pleasant enough, to be sure, but what this country really needs is a dishwashing machine which will retail for one dollar. Any reasonable home will be willing to provide kitchen space and to supply all the water that is required.

William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation, advocated last night wide participation in health insurance plans as a way of lightening the load of taxpayers and city agencies in providing medical care for the indigent.

An application for a complaint charging criminal libel against the Rev. Dr. Henry A. Atkinson, chairman of the advisory board of the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League, was dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Hyman Bushel in Mid-Manhattan Court.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Administration program for drafting men 19 through 25 years of age for a stop-gap strengthening of the armed forces ran into new trouble today.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Secretary of State Marshall, it was learned today, has sent to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee a catalogue of cases in which the Soviet Union is charged with violating agreements with the United States.
LOS ANGELES, May 26 (AP) -- Enrique Bolanos wants a third shot at world lightweight champion Ike Williams and may ask the California Athletic Commission to help him get it.

GENEVA, May 26 -- A stiff test of the European countries' determination to hasten their independence of United States economic aid is being made in the series of all-European coal meetings now going on in Geneva.

Two new films will open in first-run theatres this morning At the Astor the attraction is "Melody Time," a Walt Disney live-action and cartoon feature-length musical filmed in Technicolor. The talents of Ethel Smith, Bobby Driscoll, Luana Patten, Buddy Clark, the Andrews Sisters, Roy Rogers and Trigger and Fred Waring and his Pennsylvanians are employed in the RKO release.

The oldest concern in the decorative fabrics trade has been converted to modern decor. J. H. Thorp Co., founded in 1819, held a formal opening yesterday of its second floor showrooms at 250 Park Avenue, remodeled in resplendent contemporary style by Lester Tichy, an architect.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Truman got into the fight today for the Tennessee Valley Authority's proposed new steam plant. He urged the Senate to restore the first construction item of $4,000,000 which has been killed by the House. the prompt installation of this new capacity, and of integrating the power available from this source into that provided by the hydroelectric system of the Tennessee Valley Authority."

Downtown at the Henry Street Playhouse this evening the Associated Playwrights, the group which introduced "Our Lan'" last spring, will put on its second and final offering of the season. It is a new play entitled "g-II," written by Edmund B. Hennefeld.

Electronic instruments for measuring the pattern of vibrations set up by odor-bearing and flavor-carrying agents and the subsequent use of these vibrations in the manufacture of synthetic flavorings and perfumes were named as a future possibility by Lynn A. Watt, director of the development department, organic chemicals division, Monsanto Chemical Company, yesterday.
PARIS, May 26 (AP) -- A 26-year-old ex-bomber pilot was a man without a country tonight, despite everything the United States Embassy could do to dissuade him from giving up his American citizenship.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- Grain markets developed strength on the Board of Trade today after a small decline early. Short covering started in corn and started the market up and other grains followed, corn closing at 2 to 3 1/4 cents higher, the distant months showing the most strength.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 26 -- Announcement that Secretary of State George C. Marshall will appear Friday before the General Federation of Women's Clubs, in convention here this week, was made today by Mrs. J. L. Blair Buck of Richmond, Va., Federation president.

The number of the European graduate students who will be invited to attend a three-month seminar at Massachusetts Institute of Technology this summer has now been fixed at seventy, it was announced yesterday by Earl W. Eames Jr., chairman of the M. I. T. student committee that is sponsoring the project.

WARSAW, May 26 -- The Polish Catholic Church came out today in support of this country's new western borders and of the decision to expel all Germans from lands taken over by Poland at the end of the war. The declaration of support was unofficial.

VIENNA, May 26 -- The last stronghold of Communist influence over the Austrian police was eliminated tonight by the reorganization of the economic police as an independent department under a new non-Communist chief:

Faint hopes for peace in Palestine, revived by the recent Arab request for more time to consider the cease-fire order issued by the Security Council of the United Nations, have again been dashed to the ground. The Arab states insist on attaching to their acceptance of such an order conditions which for practical purposes amount to a flat rejection of it.

LONDON, May 26 -- Dirty rainwater dripped from a stiff tarpaulin spread over scaffolding in Star Chamber Court at the Palace of Westminster at noon today. It left great splotches on the shoulder of Winston Churchill's outgrown Edwardian frock coat.
Pledges totaling $2,600,000 were received here last night at three separate dinners sponsored by the United Jewish Appeal in its campaign for $250,000,000.
Industry's stock of tools has been allowed to dwindle for the first time in American history, Fred G. Clark, general chairman, American Economic Foundation, New York, declared yesterday.

A suspended Bronx inspector of highways, who was described as a "leg man" in alleged rent gouging deals at Stuyvesant Town, pleaded guilty yesterday in Special Sessions to two criminal informations charging extortion of excessive rentals.

Men's neckwear continues a bright spot in the men's furnishings picture and will be further, aided by volume for Father's Day on June 20. However, Father's Day trade this year is expected to be substantially broader than in recent years, with a wide variety of sports wear also to the fore.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Government moved today to support sagging prices of raw sugar and wholesale prices of refined sugar. In effect, the Department of Agriculture acted to reduce future supplies. Officials said an increase in prices naturally could be expected.

Banks' Bad Debts The so-called reserve method of accounting for bad debts has been adopted by 275 banks in this state, according to a survey by the New York State Bankers Association. Of 492 member banks polled recently, 56 per cent reported that the method had been adopted and had been used by them in completing returns for the 1947 tax year.
WASHINGTON May 26 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee voted today to extend wartime use and export controls over scarce materials through June 30, 1949.
Although the price trend on many important raw furs continues upward, the manufacturing season for fall is getting off to a comparatively slow start, reports in the trade here yesterday indicated.

LONDON, May 26 -- Divisions among the Christian churches of Great Britain were stressed in the speech of the new Moderator of the Church of Scotland, the Right Rev. Alexander MacDonald, at the close of the annual general assembly in Edinburgh today.

COEUR D'ALENE, Idaho, May 26 (AP) -- Henry A. Wallace said today that he would remain in the 1948 presidential race until the last votes were counted in November. He replied to a Chicago address by Arthur Krock, chief Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who said he believed the former Vice President would abandon the race before November.

BOSTON, May 26 -- Harold E. Stassen added Massachusetts today to the list of "favorite son" states which he considers favorable to him as a second choice for the Republican Presidential nomination. Second and third choices he said, would "do the nominating" at Philadelphia.

Dr. Chaim Weizmann, president of the Provisional Government of Israel, and his wife departed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Mauretania for France. Mrs. Weizmann said that "to our great sorrow, the attitude of Great Britain has prevented us from going to London."

The debate betwen Representative Karl E. Mundt of South Dakota and William Z. Foster, national chairman of the Communist party, on the Communist control bill will be held over the WJZ-ABC network Monday from 10:30 to 11 P. M.
Business agents of the Dress Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, will distribute vacation checks today to 65,000 dressmakers in New York garment factories.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Senator Joseph H. Ball, of Minnesota, said today the National Labor Relations Board was a "bottleneck" in labor law cases and that the transfer of unfair practice charges to the Federal courts appeared to be a desirable solution.

Raymond M. Hilliard, Commissioner of Welfare, said yesterday afternoon that he conceived rehabilitation and preventive programs to be the highest duties of his department and the only way of avoiding eternally rising relief costs.

Lee Pressman, New York attorney and former general counsel for the Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared yesterday that he had "absolutely nothing to do with any law suit filed against the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 26 -- "Cry Danger," a screen melodrama by Jerry Cady about an ex-convict, has been purchased by Santana Productions, the Robert Lord-Humphrey Bogart film company, for production next year. Dick Powell has agreed to play the convict role, Santana announced today, and Bogart is not expected to appear in the picture.

The police in Queens were confronted yesterday by the murder of a man in his home, in which the only apparent clues were a stepladder beneath a living room window and a bicycle leaning against a near-by tree.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Truman expressed in a letter to Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. today "a hope" that the House would pass the Federal aid-to-education bill approved April 1 in the Senate to meet "a real crisis."

Declaring that the present age is one of unbounded opportunities, Charles F. Kettering, research consultant and a director of the General Motors Corporation, said yesterday that the steel industry has a public responsibility to continue heavy expenditures for research to aid human progress.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service completed arrangements today for simultaneous and joint conferences Tuesday on the East, West and Gulf Coasts with the principals affected by maritime disputes involving six unions.

SYRACUSE, May 26 -- With the importance of increasing women's political influence as the dominant theme, the annual convention of the Business and Professional Women's Clubs of New York State opened here this evening.

Directors of Calumet Hecla Consolidated Copper Company took no action yesterday on the dividend which normally would have been declared at this time. A general gas shortage in Detroit and a furnace breakdown at the smelter at Hubbell, Mich., reduced earnings in the first quarter, according to Endicott R. Lovell, president.
The New York City Housing Authority voted yesterday to exclude veterans and others earning more than $3,984 annually from housing it plans to build and rent for $16 a room a month.

To celebrate the third year of supervision by City College of recreation activities for neighborhood youngsters, its Department of Hygiene was host yesterday at Jasper Oval, 138th Street and Convent Avenue, to 300 children from the adjacent Hamilton Grange area for the annual "play day" program.

The stock market responded strongly yesterday to the prospect of two years of labor peace in the automobile industry. A last-hour rally, led by the motor issues, carried the list within a point of the high mark of May 15 and was the most substantial advance since May 1.

The end of a long-standing contest between private and public power proponents over the electrification of rural America was signaled yesterday with the announcement by Charles E. Oakes, president of the Edison Electric Institute, that virtually all of the rural homes and farms in the United States will be connected to power lines by the end of 1951. About 90 per cent of the 15,800,000 occupied rural dwellings are now connected.

TRENTON, N. J., May 26 -- The expected shake-up in the New Jersey military command began today with Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's appointment of Brig. Gen. Edward C. Rose of Princeton as Chief of Staff in the Department of Defense.

Last night's program by the New Dance Group in its Festival Series at the Mansfield Theatre was divided between Jean Erdman, with and without the assistance of a group, and Mary Anthony and Joseph Gifford, with Sophie Maslow's new ensemble piece, "Champion," to close the evening.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 26 -- The United Nations Security Council pondered the next steps in the Palestine crisis tonight as it faced the final breakdown of its efforts to preserve peace in the Holy Land.
One of the grand old men of intercollegiate sports, James Murray, was honored last night for fifty years of service as coach of the Columbia University fencing team.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended May 19:

PRAGUE, May 26 -- The Ministry of the Interior has directed that no foreign correspondents be permitted to visit polling places next Sunday during the voting on the Government's single list. The Information Ministry, announcing this today, promised to ask the Ministry of the Interior if the ruling could be changed.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- A small fleet of transport planes has been sent to the eastern Mediterranean to evacuate United States citizens from the Middle East if necessary, the State Department announced today. The planes are at the island of Cyprus, a British dependency.

S. A. Swensrud, executive vice president of the Gulf Oil Corporation since May, 1947, was elected president yesterday to succeed J. F. Drake, who becomes chairman of the board. W. L. Mellon, one of the founders of the corporation and for forty-five years its active head, retired as chairman of the board, but will continue to serve as a director.

SEATTLE, Wash., May 26 -- A preliminary draft of social pronouncements for 1948, which calls upon this country to try to "excel Russia in constructive statesmanship rather than in toughness, momentary cleverness, recrimination or inflammatory utterances," was in the hands today of commissioners to the 160th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

A special dispatch from Paris, published in THE TIMES of May 11, concerns the recent visit to World Council of Churches officials of Myron C. Taylor as "the President's intermediary with religious denominations of all types." Unfortunately, possibly because of its brevity, the dispatch creates very erroneous impressions. I would ask you to permit me through your columns to set the record straight.
PARIS, May 26 (AP) -- Three all-American teams reached the women's doubles semi-finals today in the French international tennis championships.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- The new trend in self-service merchandising of prepackaged meat came in for discussion today at the convention of the Super Market Institute here, with the prediction that the trend would continue to grow.

SANDWICH, England, May 26 (AP) -- The defending champion, Willie Turnesa, and three other crack United States amateurs advanced to the fourth round of the British amateur golf championship tournament today with twin conquests of strong opposition and English Channel squalls.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 26 -- Bizonal preparations for currency reform received a sharp setback today when the Socialists joined with the Communists in defeating a price increase measure in the Bizonal Economic Council.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Statue of Liberty is due for a $500,000 beauty treatment.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 26 -- Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, came out tonight for the nomination of President Truman in a speech at the annual dinner of the Nassau County Democratic organization in the Garden City Hotel.

The General Electric Company, the country's most outspoken exponent of the theory that a third-round wage increase would promote inflation, announced last night that it would voluntarily reopen the wage question at a meeting this morning with the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 26 -- Tallying three runs in the third inning and successfully defending the advantage from that point on, Holy Cross halted Yale's eleven-game winning streak, 4 -- 1, before a crowd of 2,000 at Yale Field today. The string was the Elis' longest in thirty-five years.

The Rev. Joseph P. Wiest, pastor of St. Ambrose Roman Catholic Church, Tompkins and DeKalb Avenues, Brooklyn, was honored last night at a testimonial dinner celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of his ordination.

HSIFENGCHEN, Kansu, China, May 25 (Delayed) -- Tough, handsome, 28-year-old Gen. Ma Chiyuan, son of Moslem Governor Ma Pu-fang of Chinghai Province, has become a popular hero here following his recent victory over some 30,000 attacking Communists in the Kansu-Shensi border region.

The Choristers of the Department of Welfare, under Florence Mardirosian, presented their third annual concert, last night at Town Hall, with Maurice Wilk, violinist, as soloist. The concert was given for the benefit of the Army, Navy and Marine hospitals in the New York area, which will receive the entire proceeds.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission, taking into account the long and favorable record of earnings and dividends of the Chesapeake and Ohio, approved today an issue of $4,450,000 of equipment trust certificates of 1948, bearing a dividend rate of 2 1/4 per cent.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 26 -- Yugoslavia appealed to the United Nations today to try to obtain an annulment of the judgment of the American Military Tribunal at Nuremberg on Field Marshal Wilhelm List. [The tribunal sentenced List to life imprisonment.]

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- If Congress merely recesses over the period of the two national conventions because of unfinished business, its forced return will lead to what one of its closest observers, Mr. C. P. Trussell, prospectively terms "wild chaos, widespread absenteeism and very sloppy legislating."

Two hundred and ninety-five members of the graduating class of the United States Military Academy will arrive here this afternoon for a tour of inspection tomorrow of the installations of the New York Port of Embarkation, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, May 26 -- Paced by British Government bonds, which opened three-eighths lower in the stock market here, today all sections were subdued with most changes being downward.
Urged House to pass Senate bill providing $300,000,000 in Federal aid for schools.

Winners of the annual $1,000 Anisfield-Wolf Awards were announced yesterday by The Saturday Review of Literature, sponsor of the literary awards. The winners were John Collier for "Indians of the Americas," and Worth Tuttle Hedden for "The Other Room," which were described as "the best books on race relations published during 1947."
Resuming consideration of India-Pakistan question, heard Warren R. Austin, United States representative, criticize both parties for failing to agree to Council orders on Kashmir.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- The Chicago Newspaper Publishers Association tonight notified Chicago Local 16 of the International Typographical Union that it had until June 7 to put to a vote of its membership a final contract proposal of the publishers made on May 12 for settling the union's six-month-old newspaper strike.

The Seamen's Church Institute of New York announces two competitions open to active merchant seamen: one in painting, the other in cartoons. The closing date for the painting contest, which includes oils and water-colors, is Oct. 1 and for cartoons Dec. 1.

Rising costs and increased services -- mostly to patients unable to pay -- left Roosevelt Hospital with an operating deficit of $296,000, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Gayer G. Dominick, president.

PARIS, May 26 -- Charles de Gaulle's chances for increasing his political influence were improved today when the Schuman Government decided to seek in October the election of one-third of the members of the General Councils of the Departments.

The office of Founder and President Emeritus of the Metropolitan Opera Guild was created for Mrs. August Belmont and a resolution was passed appointing her to fill this post for life at the annual meeting of the board of directors, held last week at the Hotel Pierre, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Democratic National Committee reorganized its executive division today as the aftermath of the resignation of Gael Sullivan, former executive director. William J. Primm Jr., of Washington and Montgomery, Ala., was named assistant to the national chairman.

A resolution opposing the Gearhart bill because "it would cripple the present reciprocal trade agreement program" was adopted unanimously yesterday at the annual convention of the League of Women Voters of the City of New York in the McAlpin Hotel.

Job opportunities for women college graduates are the best in three years, 5,000 Hunter College students were told yesterday afternoon. Desired positions are obtained without knowledge of shorthand and typing, once considered essential for admittance to most fields, it was declared.
The New York City Housing Authority sold yesterday $15,450,000 of temporary loan notes dated June 17 and due Dec. 17 at interest rates ranging from 0.90 per cent to 1.10 per cent.

Stopped by New Utrecht in the Brooklyn championships last week after triumphing in eleven straight meets this season, Boys High School's track team bounced right back to the victory trail yesterday by capturing the city Public School Athletic League title at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island.

BERLIN, May 26 -- Communists claim that more than 6,000,000 Germans have signed petitions for German unity since Sunday, but in the Soviet sector of Berlin today this claim, and indeed the whole apparatus of petitioning, was greeted with bitter cynicism.

The report of Federated Department Stores. Inc., for the three months ended on May 1 issued yesterday by Fred Lazarus Jr., president, showed a net profit of $3,223,824 after all charges, including $2,131,891 provision for taxes.

CLEVELAND, May 26 -- The Mundt Anti-Communist Bill is "dangerous and un - American," Raymond Walsh, Professor of Economics at Columbia University, told the National Congress of Parents and Teachers today.

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation reported yesterday that consolidated net income for the twelve months to April 30 amounted to $29,325,474, a drop of $2,703,779 from the earnings reported for the preceding twelve months.

HELSINKI, Finland, May 26 -- Finland's Cabinet crisis ended surprisingly today when President Juho K. Paasikivi and his Cabinet, yielding to Communist pressure all along the line, gave the important Ministry of the Interior to Eino Kilpi.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- John C. Virden, the Department of Commerce official who resigned last week because his 22-year-old daughter, Euphemia, is a teletype operator for Tass, the Soviet news agency has decided to remain at his post, Secretary Charles A. Sawyer announced today.

The M and M Wood Working Company, manufacturer of plywood, doors and other wood products, reported yesterday an increase of 45 per cent in sales and one of 74 per cent in earnings for the nine months ended with April over the corresponding period of the preceding year.

LONDON, May 27 -- Prime Minister Attlee and United States Ambassador Lewis W. Douglas joined tonight in affirming that their countries entertained no aggressive intentions toward any other nation but would not be deterred from their chosen paths.
Corpus Christi, Tex., announced yesterday that it will receive bids June 11 on $5,450,000 of bonds. Of the total $2,200,000 will be water revenue bonds, and $3,250,000 will be general obligations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 27 -Filming of Lester Cowan's comedy, "Hearts and Diamonds," previously titled "Diamonds in the Sidewalk," starring the Marx Brothers, will start on June 21 at the General Service Studio, with David Miller directing, Cowan announced today.

With Sir Oliver Franks, newly appointed British Ambassador to the United States, among her 2,112 passengers, the Cunard-White Star liner Queen Elizabeth docked at Pier 90, North River, at 9:50 o'clock last night after being delayed for more than twelve hours by fog.

An unemployed hospital orderly and his wife, formerly a rooming house operator, were arraigned yesterday in General Sessions on a forty-three count indictment charging them with victimizing prospective tenants of $70,423 in three ill-fated apartment house ventures on Manhattan's East Side.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 27 -- Following are the texts, of a statement made today before the United Nations Security Council by Sir Alexander Cadogan, British representative, together with the first draft of a British resolution:

With all prospects pointing to a tense, exciting battle for team honors between New York University and Yale, blazing individual competition and top-notch performances, star athletes from forty-seven colleges assembled last night for New York's biggest track and field show of the Olympic year -- the seventy-fifth annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. championships.

Mrs. Golda Myerson, Israel's administrator for Jerusalem, meeting at a closed session yesterday with the executive committee of the United Palestine Appeal, asserted that at least $75,000,000 is needed before Aug. 1 for Israel's top priority tasks of immigration and defense.

NEWARK, N.J., May 27 -- At his home in East Orange tonight Mr. Rossbach said he had no comment to make on reports that he had been asked to resign by Attorney General Tom Clark. He indicated that he might make a statement in the "near future" explaining his resignation.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The United States has rejected protests by the Soviet Union against low-flying military and naval aircraft in the western Pacific, the State Department announced today. A formal note to that effect was delivered in Moscow by Ambassador Walter Bedell Smith on Tuesday.

Custom calls for a picnic over the Memorial Day week-end, and the shopper doing her marketing today will notice a strong incentive for such an outing. At the meat counter prices are at the same high levels they've been for some time.

If the United States does not continue to demonstrate good faith in easing tariff barriers, she will have undermined her position as leader of the democratic world, Paul P. Rao, assistant United States attorney general, declared yesterday.

FINDLAY, Ohio, May 27 (AP) -O. D. Donnell announced today his retirement as president and manager of the Ohio Oil Company. His son, J. C. Donnell 2d, was elected to succeed him at the annual stockholders' meeting of the company here.

Egyptian authorities have notified the United States that its examination of ship manifests to uncover cargo destined for Palestine had been extended to the ports of Suez and Port Said, according to information received by local shipping companies yesterday.

City dwellers who suffer from the heat but cannot afford complete air conditioning systems for their rooms may find comfort in new, powerful fans designed to blow hot air out of a room. Recentlydeveloped techniques for obtaining the best cooling results with home-size electrical fans -without sitting directly in their path -- were explained by Westinghouse engineers in connection with the introduction yesterday of their new Mobilaire fan.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee today "requested" Gen. Douglas MacArthur to return from Japan Tuesday or Wednesday to advise it on Far Eastern appropriations.

First details of a new principle of equipment by using "magnetic suspension" which eliminates the need for mechanical bearings were revealed in a press conference on a new single-phase watthour meter demonstrated yesterday by General Electric Company at its executive offices here.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Broadcasts by the National Broadcasting Company, beamed in Spanish to Latin America in behalf of the State Department's "Voice of America" program, were taken under investigation by President Truman and Congress today.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -The nation's lending and spending can be controlled by requiring banks to carry more reserves, a Government expert said today. Since reserves are bank assets that cannot be lent, they limit the ability of a bank to lend money, Woodlief Thomas told a joint HouseSenate committee on the economic report.

The announced intention of Senator Langer of North Dakota -- an avowed opponent of the draft -- to fight the battle of civil rights in the Senate over the body of the Selective Service Bill is an improper use of parliamentary procedure to cloud the issue on a vital question of national security.

LONDON, May 27 -- Responsible sources reported today that Lieut. Col. J. D. Tassojev, highranking Soviet official, has been returned to the Russians since his arrival here earlier this month with a request for political refuge.

SEATTLE, May 27 -- The Rev.h)0*0*0*iDr. Jesse H. Baird, president of the San Francisco Theological Seminary, was elected Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America on the fifth ballot this evening.

LONDON, May 27 -- Dr. Cyril F. Garbett, the Archbishop of York, warning that the Church of England should not take part in a "holy war" or religious crusade against communism, said today that such action would meet with the disapproval of millions of Christians in Communist countries.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 27 -- The Soviet Union today pressed for the inclusion of articles banning discrimination because of race, sex, religion or nationality in the future declaration of human liberties.

FORT WORTH, Tex., May 27 (AP) -- Clayton Heafner, the big pro from Charlotte, N.C., had his putter working like a four-alarm fire today to card a three-under-par 67 and take the first-round lead in the $15,000 Colonial National invitation golf tournament.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 27 -Three out of fifty-two competing teams in this afternoon's Westchester County Golf Association pro-amateur tournament at the Dunwoodie Club tied for best-ball honors at 63, but the various bits of team-work became secondary to the job turned in by the association's amateur champion, Doug Ford of Bonnie Briar.
DEVON, Pa., May 27 -- Three challenge trophies were retired in the feature classes of this afternoon's and evening's events at the fifty-second Devon Horse Show and Country Fair.

Plans for five low-rental housing projects to cost $58,765,000 and provide 3,970 apartment units were approved yesterday by theh)0*0*0*iBoard of Estimate. The projects are included in the city's $200,000,000 housing program announced by Mayor O'Dwyer in March and designed to provide living quarters for more than 17,000 families.

ALBANY, May 27 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey returned to Albany today from his 10,000-mile campaign tour confident that his travels of the last twenty-seven days had bolstered his chances for the Republican Presidential nomination.

SANDWICH, England, May 27 (AP) -- Defending Champion Willie Turnesa of White Plains, N.Y., and Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, carried the United States challenge into the quarter-finals of the British amateur golf tournament today.

VIENNA, May 27 -- The Joint Export-Import Agency in bi-zonal Germany has rejected a proposal by Austrian book publishers to export books and magazines in exchange for German publications and non-essential raw materials. In contrast, the Soviet zone of Germany has approved in principle a similar arrangement, on condition, however, that the Austrian books exported be acceptable to Russia.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 27 (AP) -Government lending and Government guarantees of credit are a one-way road to a completely socialized state, Evans Woollen Jr., vice president of the American Bankers Association, said today.

LONDON, May 27 -- Britain's decision to withdraw seconded officers from service with the TransJordan Arab Legion and reconsider her commitments of aid to other Arab armies was the outcome of a long Cabinet meeting today. During the session the Ministers received evidence of mounting disapproval of their Palestine policy.

Minneapolis, Minn., sold bond issues totaling $8,891,548 yesterday to banking groups headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. and the Northern Trust Company, bidding jointly. An issue of $1,700,000 of refunding bonds due July 1, 1949 to 1958, was taken by the two banking groups with a bid of 100.258 for 1.60s.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- Representatives of the United Mine Workers and of the anthracite operators today elected a joint negotiating committee to work out a new wage agreement for about 80,000 hard-coal miners in eight eastern Pennsylvania counties.
Today, lay 28, is the thirty- ]third day of the Greater NewIYork Fund's eleventh

Two pictures will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Golden Theatre the newcomer is "Fric-Frac," a French comedy drama starring Fernandel, Arletty and Michel Simon. Maurice Lehmann produced and directed the importation from the play by Edouard Bourdet.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., May 27 (AP) -- The State Hospital Association was told today that a student nurse recruiting program was going reasonably well but that auxiliary personnel still was needed to help graduate nurses in many hospitals.

PURCHASE, N. Y., May 27 -- An option to purchase 220 acres of the 545-acre estate of the late Whitelaw Reid, known as Ophir Farm, has been acquired by a group of Boston investors in a plan to build a shopping center costing between $6,000,000 and $7,000,000, it was learned today.

On the first page of the current issue of The Harvard Alumni Bulletin the editors announce that, to celebrate the first half century of The Bulletin's existence, they have attempted to recreate, at least in part, the Harvard of fifty years ago in which their periodical was born.

Greece is a "free country" and a "real democracy" where the majority decided on a king because a king represented to them the furthest point from communism, Miss Helen G. Vlechos, associate editor and daughter of the publisher of the Greek newspaper Katherimini, declared last night at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- New York and New Jersey shipper interests today told the Interstate Commerce Commission to stand by a recent decision that has been protested by motor carriers operating in the area of New York City.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 - George Killion, president of the American President Lines, announced the retirement today of T. J. Cokely, vice president in charge of operations, and the reassignment of three top officials.

" A ship is not just a steel hull," Lieut. Comdr. Prescott Wintersteen, chaplain of the submarine tender Nereus, told the members of the Navy task force that was preparing to sink the condemned former heavy cruiser Salt Lake City off the California coast.

JERUSALEM, May 27 -- While the fighting in Jerusalem itself ebbs and flows, the Arabs and the forces of Israel are disputing the fate of this city fifteen to twenty miles away on the road and in the plains at Latrun below Bab el Wad.
TOKYO, May 27 -- The Japanese Government at an extraordinary Cabinet session this afteroon, adopted the third and, it is hoped, final draft of the long-delayed national budget for 1948.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Once more Senator Vandenberg has leaped into wild water to rescue a sound principle in bipartisan foreign policy and at the same time to prevent his party from submerging itself with its intended victim. Despite the overwhelming Republican vote in the House yesterday to emasculate the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, Mr. Vandenberg today reasserted his belief that it should not be devitalized.

LONDON, May 27 -- The sixpower conference on Western Germany was struggling today with what is hoped will be its last snag -- how to elect members of the proposed German constituent assembly and when to hold the first session of that body.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- Grain markets developed a heavy undertone on the Board of Trade in the late trading today and closing sales were about the bottom. Wheat lost 1/4 to 3/4 cent a bushel and corn was down 7/8 to 1 5/8 cents. Oats were off 7/8 to 1 1/2 cents.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, May 27 -- The political aspect of the war in Palestine is holding more attention than the military at this moment among outside observers. The Arabs hold certain definite military positions and feel confident that they can keep them as matters now stand.

A study in contrasts between well-dressed American and ill-clad foreign youngsters was staged yesterday at the Tavern-on-the-Green by American Overseas Aid-United Nations Appeal for Children to spur its current $6,600,000 drive.
