Titled "Sackcloth and Satins," the show comprised junior beach and party wear from Arnold Constable, eighteen youngsters from many of the twenty-six participating agencies in the appeal and children wearing clothing improvised from gunnysacks.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -The Federal Trade Commission today accused ten candy and confectionery companies, including the makers of Wrigley's gum, Luden's cough drops and Oh Henry and Clark candy bars, of violating the Robinson-Patman anti-monopoly law.
CHICAGO, May 27 -- The cost of living will go up 2 to 3 per cent by the end of the year, Leon Henderson, former Administrator of the Office of Price Administration, said here today.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Strong hints that an official request had been made for the recent resignation of Edgar H. Rossbach as United Statess Attorney for New Jersey were given today. Moreover, there were suggestions that an investigation would be undertaken, or perhaps had begun, into certain angles of Mr. Rossbach's conduct of his office.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The descriptions of six states broadcast by the Voice of America to Latin America follow in abstract. These abstracts were made by Senator Homer E. Capehart for presentation to the Senate, with the exception of the abstract on Wyoming, which was taken from the original script released today by the State Department.

BAR HARBOR, Me., May 27 -- Dr. Clarence C. Little, chairman of the board of trustees of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory and director of laboratory operations, announced today the receipt of $662,729 toward the $1,500,000 emergency fund being raised for reconstruction, enlargement and maintenance.

Earning assets of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System dropped $179,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, it was reported yesterday. According to the weekly statistics issued by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, loans alone, however, were $265,000,000 higher.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 20 to 39 points net lower, influenced by continued liquidation by houses with southern connections.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 27 -T. Howard Duckett, Hyattsville, president of the Maryland Bankers Association, said today that prices would seek a fair level, and that unless machinery was taken out of production there would continue to be a high level of living, reasonably full employment at fair wages, and increasingly better conditions for some years to come.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended May 22 totaled 879,158 cars, the Association of Americanh) 0*0*0*iRailroads announced today. This was 31,755 cars, or 3.7 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 11,447 cars, or 1.3 per cent, below that for the corresponding week last year, and 307,685 cars, or 53.8 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The consolidation of two historic organizations -- the New York Bible Society and the Brooklyn Bible Society -- took pIace yesterday with the signing of legal merger papers at the headquarters of the former, 5 East Forty-eighth Street.

MILWAUKEE, May 27 -- Merger of the Northern Baptist and the Disciples of Christ denominations came a step closer to realization today when a "report of progress" presented by the Northern Baptist convention's Commission on Conference With the Disciples of Christ in America was received by 4,000 vigorously applauding delegatesh)0*0*0*iattending the annual meeting here of the Baptist body.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Senate hearings on the Mundt-Nixon Communist control bill opened in bitterness today amid charges from Congressional and other proponents that the Communists were pressing a campaign to misrepresent the measure.

PARIS, May 27 -- Three hundred experts of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation today encountered new difficulties, this time arising from the excessive demand for key products, in the estimates submitted for the third-quarter programs of imports.

Under revision of assignments in the dress departments of Kirby, Block Co., announced yesterday, Josephine Schey will buy all misses' dresses, $19.75 and up, women's $23.75 and up, and formal and evening, $29.75 and up. Tobey Saunders will buy all better casuals, $13.75 and up, and all misses' dresses from $10.75 to $19.75.

MILWAUKEE, May 27 -- Carrying a cargo of gift packages, manufactured products and the good wishes of the citizens of Wisconsin, the 2,600-ton freighter S.S. Ornefjell left Milwaukee Harbor this evening for Norway.

PHILADELPHIA. May 27 (AP) -Curt Simmons, the Phillies' $60,000 bonus southpaw, pitched a threehit 2-1 victory in a duel with Kirby Higbe of the Pirates tonight. Ralph Caballero scored the deciding run from second in the fifth inning when a pitch to Del Ennis eluded Catcher Clyde Kluttz for a passed ball.
PHILADELPHIA, May 27 (AP) -The Pennsylvania Railroad reported today a deficit of $5,551,465 in net income for April and a deficit of $10,172,529 for the first four months of 1948.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Friday, May 28 -- Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, elder statesman of the world, has lost his seat in the South African Parliament. He was beaten in the national elections by 224 votes in the Transvaal constituency of Standerton, which he had represented since 1924.

The National Wallace for President Committee issued yesterday a formal call for the "National Founding Convention of the New Political Party" to be held in the Convention Hall at Philadelphia on July 23, 24 and 25.

ATHENS, May 27 -- Greek security authorities reported today that, as a result of the investigation of the assassination May 1 of Justice Minister Christos Ladas, 160 persons have been arrested during the last few days in Athens and seventy more near the city.

BERLIN, May 27 -- The Soviet Military Administration in Germany is exerting steady pressure on German politicians of all parties with the object of creating a national demand for the withdrawal of all occupation armies, including the Soviet Army, it was learned reliably today.
IN THE OLD CITY OF JERUSALEM, May 27 (AP) -- King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan paid a surprise visit to his troops in the old walled city today and was hailed as "King of Jerusalem" by 25,000 Arabs.

JERUSALEM, May 27 -- Jerusalem's residents are not collapsing in the streets because of hunger after six weeks under siege but it is difficult to get a square meal, even at stylish hotels like the Eden, where ration cards are not required.

Meyer Davis, orchestra leader, whose 26-year-old son, Garry, renounced his United States citizenship in Paris on Wednesday, appealed to Secretary of State Marshall yesterday to postpone Government action on his son's move.

The scientific foundation known as the Pacific War Memorial announced yesterday that it had acquired a former Japanese research center in the Palau Islands and that two areas on Saipan had been set aside for its use.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -The Athletics moved into first place in the American League tonight in the midst of the most explosiveh)0*0*0*ioutburst by Washington fans in recent years. Accompanying the 7-3 Philadelphia victory over the Senators was a 15-minute barrage of bottles, beer cans and other debris thrown at Plate Umpire Red Jones.

Proposed changes to tighten the city's control over 300 commercially operated clinical laboratories were debated yesterday by spokesmen for organized physicians, laboratory owners, druggists and other interested groups at a hearing in the Health Auditorium, Worth and Centre Streets.

0*0*0*iOWASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -Marriner S. Eccles today asked President Truman to quit thinking of designating him vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board in view of the President's failure to do so earlier.
Sultana Hosiery Company, with stores throughout the Metropolitan area, to Lew Kashuk Son Advertising Company, for its first advertising in nearly twenty-five years. Newspapers and magazines.

The Mutual Broadcasting System has canceled the series of concerts it had agreed to carry this summer from the national music camp at Interlochen, Mich., it became known yesterday. The broadcasts were to have started July 5.

ROME, May 27 -- The first victim among Communist leaders of the defeat suffered by the extreme Left-Wing parties in last month's general election is Giancarlo Pajetta, who has been removed by the Communist party directorate from the post of Communist federal secretary for Lombardy.

Study of a group of public soda fountains indicates that use of paper cups costs no more than for glasses, and effects savings in some instances, the Paper Cup and Container Institute reported yesterday. The survey was made during 1947 by the Business Research Corporation of Chicago.

Seldom has an Ambassador of a foreign nation been so well equipped to deal with the most important, specific business at hand as is Sir Oliver Franks, who arrived on the Queen Elizabeth last night. As a leading figure in the Sixteen-Nation Conference at Paris he came to know, as possibly no other man in Europe, the aims, the possibilities, and the attendant national responsibilities of the Marshall European Recovery Program.

THE finest historical novel about the Middle Ages that has come my way since I read Charles Reade's "The Cloister and the Hearth" as a school boy is "The World Is Not Enough,"* by Zoe Oldenbourg. This long, massive and violent book is an amazingly successful recreation of the dark and brutal world of the twelfth century, an exciting and dramatic narrative and an unusually good example of the difficult art of characterization.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 27 -- Veteran demands for G.I. home loans have declined sharply since last fall, Thomas Sweeney, assistant director of the loan guaranty service of the Veterans Administration, revealed today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 27 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie sent a special emissary to London last week to tell Foreign Secretary Bevin that Britain might destroy the United Nations by her policy toward Palestine, it was disclosed here today.iO

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Average primary market prices were unchanged during the week ended May 22, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The bureau's comprehensive index remained at 163.5 per cent of the 1926 average. It was only 0.2 per cent below the level recorded for the week prior to the market break in February, 1948, and 1.2 per cent below the high point reached in mid-January.
Random notes.

Permanent Government ownership and operation of the nation's railroads for reasons of efficiency and labor peace was strongly advocated yesterday by A. F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen.

DETROIT, May 27 -- As the General Motors Corporation and the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, reached a wage agreement today, negotiatorsh)0*0*0*ifor the Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, were reported to be divided by only one cent.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 27 -- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub team cup series was concluded over the Knollwood Country Club course today with the crowning of many new champions.
Said lifting of Near-East arms embargo still under consideration.

Laurence H. Victory, president of the New York local of the International Typographical Union, AFL, announced last night that the local had revised its newspaper contract proposal to conform to "minor changes" proposed by the parent union and was awaiting approval of the revised draft before resuming negotiations with the Publishers Association of New York City.

At the annual meeting of the Municipal Art Society yesterday Francis Keally was elected president, succeeding Charles C. Platt, who held the office for three years. The meeting was held at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.

John Gunther's best-seller "Inside U.S.A." and WPA state guide books were the source for many of the quotations in the Voice of America broadcasts denounced on the Senate floor as "drivel, nonsense and downright falsehoods," it was learned here yesterday.

Plans for the study of ultra-high frequencies to determine whether they can accommodate the expansion of television broadcasting were announced yesterday by Dr. C. B. Jolliffe, executive vice president in charge of RCA Laboratories. At the same time the Radio Corporation of America applied to the Federal Communications Commission for a license to install an experimental station in Washington over which to conduct the tests, expected to start about Sept. 1.

The American market currently reveals a much greater demand for goods from Great Britain than British exporters have been supplying, and even greater potentials may be realized if sales, advertising and promotion methods are improved.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Injection of the segregation issue into the Congressional fight over the stop-gap selective draft has not caused any change in President Truman's instructions to the Secretaryh)0*0*0*iof Defense to eliminate racial discrimination within the armed forces, the Chief Executive told a news conference today.

SUMMIT, N.J., May 27 -- Defending champions Bud Geoghegan and Mike Cestone of Crestmont, won the qualifying medal today in the New Jersey State pro-amateur match play golf tournament, with a five-under-par 68 at the Canoe Brook Country Club.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- During the week ended May 26, member bank reserve balances increased $395,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

A freakish fog tied up the two largest liners in the United States and British merchant marines off Ambrose Light for four to twelve hours yesterday and disrupted air transport activity at La Guardia Field for a half day, yet left virtually unaffected the ferryboat service and other shipping in the inner harbor.
After such a deafening barrage of approval of President Truman's recognition of Israel, it is refreshing to find one brave American voice come out boldly condemning such hasty action.

Slightly more than 50 per cent of the Greater New York Fund's 1948 campaign goal -- $4,013,109 of the $8,000,000 it is trying to raise -- has been collected in the first four weeks of the drive, it was announced yesterday by Henry C. Alexander, campaign chairman and vice president of J. P. Morgan Co.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A movement which may become bipartisan shaped up in the Senate today to modify the House-approved restrictions on the Administration's authority to make reciprocal trade agreements with other countries.

ATLANTA, May 27 -- Dr. John R. Cunningham, president of Davidson College, told Southern Presbyterians tonight that unless the nations agreed on some form of world government there would be war and the end of civilized humanity.

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to complete the demolition of the old Aquarium in Battery Park. It had taken similar action at least five times previously in the six-year controversy over the structure, but this time it appeared that the decision would be final.
LONDON, May 27 (AP) -- Secretary General Lie is "under heavyh)0*0*0*ipressure from various quarters over Palestine," he told Secretary Bevin, a Foreign Office spokesman said tonight.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 -Gov. Earl Warren of California, candidate for the Republican nomination for President, called upon his party tonight "to rise to the heights of a new order of politics."

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., made a new high sales record of $301,246,089 in the fiscal year ended last Jan. 31, Bernard F. Gimbel, president, reported in the annual statement to stockholders, which will be released today.

Weather forecasts that at best could be summed up as "maybe good, maybe not," appeared last night to be no check on the plans of thousands of New Yorkers to hie themselves out of town on the warm season's first three-day week-end.

The All-Veterans Orchestra, under Sascha London, gave a program of Norwegian music last night in the Hunter College Auditorium. Presented under the patronage of Wilhelm Morgenstierne, Norwegian Ambassador to this country, and Erling S. Bent, Norwegian Consul General in New York, the concert, with Granth)0*0*0*iJohannesen, pianist, as soloist, featured works by living composers.

Profit-taking developed late yesterday in the stock market, but only after prices had made a new approach to the year's high. Most selective gains evaporated and theh)0*0*0*icombined averages fell 0.11 point on the day. Business on the Stock Exchange held the pace set in recent sessions, with transfers of 1,830,000 shares, compared with 1,840,000 on Wednesday.

PARIS, May 27 -- The National Assembly approved without opposition today a commercial accord recently negotiated with Poland. This was the first such accord with an Eastern European country to be ratified by the Assembly.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -Great Britain is using an export tax on Malayan tin ore to "hamstring" operation of the Texas City, Texas, tin smelter, John Croston of the National Securities Resources Board said today.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- By a vote of 40 to 33 the Senate approved today a modification of its pending bill to raise to 200,000 the number of displaced persons to be admitted into the United States in the next two years.

LONDON, May 27 -- Princess Elizabeth's action in going to races and to a night club on Sunday during her visit to Paris was defended today in the Lower House of the Convocation of Canterbury. Both the Upper and Lower Houses of the Convocation are meeting in London to discuss revisions of canon law.

" Woman With A Sword," by Hollister Noble, a biographical novel of Anne Carroll of Carrollton, Md., an unofficial member of President Lincoln's cabinet, will be published July 22 by Doubleday.h)0*0*0*iMiss Carroll is credited with giving Lincoln the Union Army's "grand strategy that won the Civil War."

The sound judgment and fine disregard of small political considerations which the American people have come to expect of Arthur H. Vandenberg are evident in the comment of the Michigan Senator on the Reciprocal Trade Agreements issue.

Full details regarding the Bankers School of Public Relations -the first such project of its kind to be established in this country -have been issued by the New York State Bankers Association. The school, sponsored by the association in cooperation with Syracuse University, will hold its first session, July 26 to 31, in Syracuse, N.Y.

Senior week activities at Barnard College will begin at 7 P.M. today with the traditional step singing and ivy-planting ceremonies. Other special events have been planned for the next four days, climaxing on Tuesday, when 300 Barnard seniors will receive Bachelor of Arts degrees at the Columbia University commencement exercises.

TRENTON, N.J., May 27 (AP) -New Jersey's Court of Errors and Appeals -- the world's largest appellate tribunal -- folded its law books and called it quits today, 104 years after it began dispensing "Jersey justice."

Darrell Clingman, ex-flat race rider and ex-Coast Guardsman from Wickenburg, Ariz., made at least two contributions to the winning of the Charles L. Appleton Steeplechase at Belmont Park yesterday astride Mrs. Corliss Sullivan's The Heir.

Signs of revolt have developed in the ranks of the New Stages acting company. Dissatisfied actors gave vent to their feelings at a meeting held yesterday afternoon at the group's headquarters, 159 Bleecker Street. They are demanding two more directors be added to the board of five, which consists of David Heilweil, Norman Rose, Robert Gundlach, Alexander Scourby and Betty Winkler.

SEOUL, Korea, May 27 -- North Korean armed forces ambushed a party of American civilians yesterday near the border between the United States and Soviet zones on the Ongjin Peninsula, wounding one with light machinegun fire.
The Bareco Oil Company declared a quarterly dividend of 15 cents, payable on Aug. 2. The company previously paid 10 cents in each quarter.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 27 --- Infuriated by Britain s suggestion for a world-wide arms embargo, a spokesman for the Israeli Government made it plain today that the Jews would reject a Security Council cease-fire appeal based on the British draft resolution.

An increase in the number of available hospital beds, a decrease in the cost of hospital care and an improved sense of well-being for victims of illness or accident can all be achieved when a hospital extends its service to include home care, Dr. Martin Cherkasky said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, today wrote Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican, of New Jersey, the following letter regarding "Voice of America" broadcasts:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 27 -Delegates attending the annual convention of the Business and Professional Women's Clubs of New York State were urged today to foster "aggressive democracy." Mrs. Rhea M. Eckel, executive secretary of the New York State Citizens Council, defined this as active practice of the precepts embodied in America's historic political documents.

Mayor O'Dwyer swore in Magistrate James J. Lanzetta yesterday as a Justice of the Domestic Relations Court for a full ten-year term. Justice Lanzetta, who succeeds Justice W. Bruce Cobb, retired,h)0*0*0*iwill receive a salary of $14,000 annually.

The Playboy Motor Car Corporation, an enterprise organized in November, 1946, to produce fourcylinder, three-passenger automobiles to sell for about $1,000, is offering to the public as a speculation an issue of 20,000,000 shares of common stock.

Friends of the late Dr. Emily Lewi presented a check for $14,000 yesterday to the trustees of the New York Infirmary to start an endowment fund in her memory. Income will be used for the care of ailing women physicians connected with the infirmary and their children.

Sumner Welles, former Under Secretary of State, said last night that in no instance had United States disregard for United Nations interests been more evident than in its policy toward Palestine. He addressed more than 400 representatives of national organizations at a meeting in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel called by the American Association for the United Nations, of which he is honorary president.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 27 -- For the third successive week since the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association opened its season of one-day tournaments, Mrs. Edwin Longcope of Siwanoy was the winner. She toured the women's par-73 course at Wykagyl in 42, 41 -- 83 for a four-stroke victory today.

Saul Mills, secretary of the leftwing Greater New York Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, has been dropped as a member of the executive committee of the Health Insurance Plan, it was learned last night.

JERUSALEM, May 27 (AP) -Twelve foreign newsmen, including seven Americans, protested today to Israeli's Premier, David Ben-Gurion, against the refusal of the Israeli authorities to arrange their transfer out of Jerusalem.

The New York Conference of the Methodist Church, meeting in 149th annual session yesterday afternoon at the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, Eighty-sixth Street and West End Avenue, changed the name of its Social Service Commission to "Commission on Social Education and Action" and adopted a report of a speclal committee defining its functions.

ALBANY, May 27 (AP) -- The generalh)0*0*0*imanager of the Home Gas Company, which supplies gas to concerns in some New York State areas, said today his company would not accept new customers this year.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 27 -Prompt enactment by Congress of a temporary and limited selective service program was urged today by the General Federation of Women's clubs in its fifty-seventh annual convention.

Closing of the 150 camps and installations for Jewish displaced persons in Europe could be accomplished within a year if the United States provided the necessary funds, Harold Glasser, director of the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds' Institute on Overseas Studies, asserted yesterday.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 27 -- With a strike of 600,000 steelworkers threatening in the Ruhr, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, said today that such a walkout would come "close" to being a strike against the occupation authorities and indicated special measures might be taken.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 27 -- The very presence of United States troops in Europe constitutes a sufficient guarantee against aggression, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, said today.

JERUSALEM, May 27 -- Arab Legion and Egyptian forces have been shifted from the north and south, respectively, of this city to the Bab el Wad area, where they are digging in astride the Jerusalem lifeline to Tel Aviv, an Israeli spokesman said today.

Harvard College receives property valued at $238,553 from the estate of Mrs. Nina L. Warburg, widow of Paul M. Warburg, banker and philanthropist. She died Jan. 21, 1946, leaving a gross estate of $4,975,494 and a net of $3,825,624, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Senate Finance Committee unanimously approved today the repeal of Federal taxes on oleomargarine on the condition that public eating places be required to identify the colored product to distinguish it from butter.

DETROIT, May 27 (AP) -- A Detroit doubles team of Joseph Walker, auto plant inspector, and Joe Patti, 30-year-old truck driver, smashed unheralded into seventh place in the two-man event of the forty-fifth American Bowling Congress tournament today with a 1,302 count.

The net income of the Todd Shipyards Corporation for the year ended March 31 was announced yesterday as $3,954,333, after deduction of Federal income taxes. The corporation's net earnings for the previous year were reported as $944,740.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The lifting of the embargo against arms shipments to the Near East is under consideration by the United Nations, President Truman said at his news conference today. He added that the United States had imposed its embargo last autumn at the request of the United Nations, which extended it to all member states.

After two acts of dramatic vertigo at the Henry Street Playhouse last evening, your correspondent withdrew, leaving a number of hardier people still jousting with the play. It was a portentous piece of symbolism entitled "g-II," by Edmund B. Hennefeld, a man of law, who last year wrote an intelligible play entitled "The Deputy of Paris."

INSIDE THE OLD CITY, in Jerusalem, May 27 (AP) -- Riflemen of Trans-Jordan's Arab Legion clambered across blood-stained rubble in Jerusalem's Old City tonight in an attempt to dig out the last of the Israeli defenders besieged in three ancient stone houses.

Five hundred lawyers, meeting last night under the auspices of the New York City Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild, adopted a resolution expressing opposition to passage of the Mundt bill, now pending in the Senate. Speakers at the Bar Association Auditorium, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, attackedh)0*0*0*ithe measure as a threat to the Bill of Rights and to the liberties of the American people.

A disagreement between passengers and the captain of the fishing craft Squirt, which capsized offh) 0*0*0*iManasquan Inlet last Saturday with the loss of two lives, developed yesterday at an official hearing on the accident. The hearing was held at the Coast Guard offices, 42 Broadway, before a special board.

Two police detectives were guarding the home of Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle at 93 Joralemon Street in Brooklyn Heights, but when he found out about their assignment he had them withdrawn immediately, it was learned last night.

Constantine Stronghilos, pianist, gave a recital in a well-filled Times Hall last night. In the portion of his program heard by this reviewer he demonstrated fingers of notable dexterity, a strong sense of musical form and meaningfulness, and a control of dynamics and color contrasts which added up to some very rewarding listening indeed.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -Attorney General Tom Clark said today a Federal Grand Jury called for next Tuesday will look into lobbying activities connected with the grain speculation investigation of early this year.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Foreign Relations Committee called on the Senate today to make it plain now beyond any misunderstanding that this country would instantly and powerfully resist any attack "affecting" its national security.

The summer Saturday shutdowns in the major security and commodity exchanges throughout the United States will begin tomorrow, and the week-end holiday will be extended by the observance of Memorial Day on Monday.The Chicago Board of Trade and other grain markets will operate as usual on Saturdays but will close on next Monday.
A waterfall nearly thirty feet high will begin cascading in Times Square as soon as test operations -- the latest of which will be held tomorrow at 1 A.M. -- are completed.

NEW DELHI, India, May 27 -The trial of Nathuram Vinayak Godse, accused of the assassination of Mohandas K. Gandhi on Jan. 30,h)0*0*0*iand of eight others allegedly implicated in the plot opened in New Delhi this morning.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 27 -The two runs that Columbia tallied in a rained-out Eastern intercollegiate league contest with Yale here on May 12 proved the victory margin when the game was resumed at Yale field today. The final score was 2 -- 0.

INSIDE THE OLD CITY, in Jerusalem, May 27 (AP) -- Riflemen of Trans-Jordan's Arab Legion clambered across blood-stained rubble in Jerusalem's Old City tonight in an attempt to dig out the last of the Israeli defenders besieged in three ancient stone houses.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 27 -- Sir Alexander Cadogan, British representative on the United Nations Security Council, today introduced another resolution requesting Israeli and Arab forces to agree to a cease-fire order in Palestine.

NEW DELHI, India, May 27 -The trial of Nathuram Vinayak Godse, accused of the assassination of Mohandas K. Gandhi on Jan. 30,h)0*0*0*iand of eight others allegedly implicated in the plot opened in New Delhi this morning.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 27 -The two runs that Columbia tallied in a rained-out Eastern intercollegiate league contest with Yale here on May 12 proved the victory margin when the game was resumed at Yale field today. The final score was 2 -- 0.

The feature ten-rounder at Madison Square Garden tonight will be a welterweight struggle between Jerry (Kid) Gavilan, Cuban boxer, and Rocco Rossano, hard-hitting Brooklyn battler. Backing up the top attraction will be another tenrounder in which Rocky Castellani, Luzerne (Pa.) middleweight, will trade punches with Harold (Red) Green of Williamsburg.

New York was described as a city of "the quick or the dead" by Donald McCullough of London yesterday, when giving his impressions of traffic conditions here. The inhabitants were termed "nimble folk who owe their existence to agility."

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., May 27 -- A program under which qualified students from any university in the country may complete their work for a Doctor of Philosophy degree through employment on research problems in atomic energy at Oak Ridge was announced today by the Oak Ridge Institute of Nuclear Studies.
ALBANY, May 27 (AP) -- The Lutheran Synod of New York urged today that more young men enter the ministry.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 27h)0*0*0*i-- By a unanimous vote, the Standing Committee of the United Nations Correspondents called on Secretary General Trygve Lie today to bring the killing of George Polk, Columbia Broadcasting System correspondent slain in Greece, to the attention of the Human Rights Commission of the United Nations.

NANKING, May 27 -- Two Government armies defending isolated Changchun, former capital of Manchukuo, lost their air supply contact with China proper today. Gen. Lin Piao's Communist forces captured one airfield south of the city and stepped up attacks against another field to the north.

The Negro population of New York City has increased steadily since the Harlem community first became the center of a marked migration from the South and the West Indies, and research reports have indicated lately that far more than 500,000 Negroes -some estimates have gone as high as 700,000 -- now reside in the five boroughs.

Harold E. Stassen, candidate for the Republican nomination for President, and the Columbia Broadcasting System collaborated last night in what almost certainly will become a new method of political campaigning -- by television.
PRAGUE, May 27 -- Czechoslovakia's regime is doing its best to placate the Catholic Church before Sunday's elections. The Corpus Christi holiday was observed today with processions and ceremonies.

A 30-year-old unemployed veteran of World War II attempted unsuccessfully last night to rob a liquor store because he was afraid to tell his wife that he had lost his job two weeks ago. He was captured after a chase in the financial district at rush-hour time.

BOSTON, May 27 -- Maintaining that for modern men esthetic enjoyment is almost inseparable from knowledge and that feeling needs the support of understanding, Walter Lippmann said here today that art museums must become libraries and laboratories of research and education as well as repositories of unique original works.

A national drive in the fur industry to seek removal of the present 20 per cent Federal excise tax is getting under way. With both raw fur and finished garments at high levels, industry leaders feel removal of the tax is vital to check growing consumer resistance.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday the resignation of License Commissioner Benjamin Fielding, effective at the close of business on June 30. Mr. Fielding will be associated with Loew's, Inc., the theatre chain, in an executive capacity beginning July 1.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Federal Government has full power to fire employes with Communist affiliations, Attorney General Tom C. Clark today notified Seth W. Richardson, chairman of the Loyalty Review Board.

Withdrawal of the representatives of the State of Israel from participation in the presentation of a special citation by The Churchman, independent Protestant Episcopal magazine, to the new state was announced yesterday by Aubrey S. Eban.

Two group shows this week by painters, young and old, who are having their first exhibition opportunity, merit attention. At the Weyhe Gallery nine painters are being shown in the annual end-ofseason show of new talent that has in recent years become a regular gallery feature.

The continued efforts of the Congress to find a solution for acquiring the necessary manpower for our country is irreconcilable with the dissipation of vast accumulations of war materials, plants and property which has continued under Congressional authority.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 27 (AP) -Arab political sources in Cairo indicated today that the Egyptian Army was taking up the main operations against Jerusalem itself. They said the Egyptian Army aided by Arab legionnaires and irregulars, attacked the city from the south this morning.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Department store sales in the week ended May 22 were 7 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of Columbia University, announced yesterday that the university's full-time associate professors would benefit by July 1 from the new salary scale, put into effect for parts of the faculty last year.

Having no liking for the dank National League cellar, the Dodgers climbed out of it again yesterday by beating Jolly Cholly Grimm's Cubs, 4 -- 2, behind the six-hit pitching of big Ralph Branca, who turned in his second complete game and the seventhh) 0*0*0*ifor Leo Durocher's staff.

Congress was called upon yesterday by speakers at the concluding session of the American Iron and Steel Institute's annual meeting here in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to intercede for the steel industry in preventing Government interference with the distribution of its products.
Drew Pearson, radio commentator and columnist, received yesterday from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president-elect of Columbia University, a silver medal as "Father of the Year."

It seems hardly credible that some officials within the city administration could still be giving serious thought to any plan for city financing of our waterfront rehabilitation, in view of other staggering and urgent demands on the capital budget. Yet the Department of Marine and Aviation is said to be undertaking a new survey of the piers, and preparing a revised and enlarged program to compete with the World Trade Corporation and Port Authority proposals.
LONDON, May 27 -- The British Government has awarded 100,000 [about $400,000] free of tax to Air Commodore Frank Whittle for his work in the development of jet propulsion, it was announced tonight.
LONDON, May 27 -- The Palestine situation had an adverse influence on business in the stock market here today, causing it to come almost to a standstill.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 28 -- The Presidential yacht, the Williamsburg, will drop anchor in the Severn tomorrow morning and the nation's Chief Executive will forget the cares of state in a day's enjoyment of a big program of athletics at the Naval Academy.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 28 -- The International Court of Justice, handing down its first decision, ruled in effect today that the Soviet Union's string of vetoes against five states applying for United Nations members was illegal.
CHICAGO, May 28 (AP) -- The White Sox loaded the bases three times but failed to score and the Indians defeated Chicago, 2 to 0, tonight before 18,082 persons.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The United States will send Iran $60,000,000 worth of "nonaggressive weapons," including tanks, guns and fighter planes, under a military aid program outlined by State Department spokesmen today before the Senate Appropriations Committee.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Anyone who would destroy or urge the destruction of America's heritage of wealth, education and steady progress toward individual freedom and opportunity is "either a fool or a traitor, perhaps both," Edwin R. Embree, president of the Julius Rosenwald Fund, said tonight at a dinner which marked the closing of the 31-year-old fund.

VALHALLA, N.Y., May 28 -Edward J. Clark, chief engineer of the New York Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, said this afternoon that the Catskill Aqueduct between Kensico Lake here and the Ashokan Reservoir eighty miles northwest is in "very good condition."

MINEOLA, L.I., May 28 -- Justice Francis Hooley took the mechanical greyhounds out of the legal doghouse in a decision in Supreme Court here today. Justice Hooley ruled that the amusement was not a game of chance but a game of skill.

LONDON, May 28 -- Following Prime Minister Jan Smuts' unexpected defeat yesterday in the South African elections, gold shares slumped in the stock market here today. As soon as the market opened, jobbers, as a protection against selling, marked prices down and made their buying and selling margins wider.

Continued opposition "to any legislation that would permit the use of public funds for any school owned by religious groups or under the domination of such groups" was registered yesterday in the annual report of the Social Service Commission of the New York Conference of the Methodist Church.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 28 -- A national conference of Maritime unions to formulate joint strategy in the event of a strike on June 15 was called today by Harry Bridges, president of the CIO International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.

Dr. George B. Pegram, dean of Columbia University's Graduate Faculties and wartime head of the university's Committee on War Research, will be the guest of honor Tuesday at a luncheon given by Columbia alumni representing fifty classes.

SEATTLE, May 28 -- A vote on a plan of healing an eighty-seven-year split between Northern and Southern Presbyterianism to produce a united denomination of 3,000,000 members was delayed today for at least a year by the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The heroic deaths of four chaplains, depicted on a postage stamp as a symbol of interdenominational fraternity, was characterized by President Truman today as "the greatest sermon that ever was preached."

PANAMA, May 28 -- Preliminary reports by the provincial elections juries on the votes east in the Presidential elections May 9 give former President Dr. Arnulfo Arias a slight lead over Domingo Diaz Arosemena in the contest for the Presidency.

ALBANY, May 28 -- Further arguments in an effort to invalidate two Civil Service lists for the position of veterans counselor in the State Division of Veterans Affairs were presented in the Supreme Court here today. Justice Roscoe V. Ellsworth reserved decision and allowed two weeks for the presentation of supplementary briefs.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Grain prices were on the upgrade today on the Board of Trade, with the finish at or slightly under the best level of the day. Corn led the advance and gained 1 7/8 to 2 7/8 cents a bushel. Wheat rose 1 1/4 to 2 cents and oats were up 1 1/8 to 1 3/4 cents.

New orders for furniture in April declined 17 per cent compared with the like month last year and were down 16 per cent from March, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, accountants for many leading furniture factories.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark announced today that thirty-six Governors and 300 Mayors had agreed to cooperate in local juvenile delinquency conferences next September, which would be named National Youth Month.

LONDON, May 28 -- Re-establishment of the 1938 standard of living is the most Europe can look forward to by 1952, Foreign Secretary Bevin said today. Mr. Bevin was addressing the eighteenth annual conference of representatives of the unions of women workers.

Mortgage financing of $1,336,000 insured under Section 608 of the Federal Housing Administration was arranged for Cropsey Avenue Realties through J. Halperin Co., brokers, with the Bowery Savings Bank for the permanent loan and the County Trust Company for the building loan on the garden apartment project for 192 families on the block bounded by Shore Road, Cropsey Avenue, and Bay Sixteenth and Seventeenth Streets, Brooklyn.

Gerry (Kid) Gavilan, welterweight contender from Camaguey, Cuba, almost set a house record when he knocked out Rocco Rossano of Red Hook in the main bout at Madison Square Garden last night before a crowd of 8,294.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The House passed today a bill for United States membership in the World Health Organization, but with restrictions opposed by some supporters of the organization.

CINCINNATI, May 28 (AP) -- Cincinnati scored eight runs on homers tonight but they were not enough as the Cubs staged five and four run innings and went on to win, 10 -- 8, before a crowd of 18,972. Hank Sauer, Reds' left-fielder, clouted his eleventh and twelfth round-trippers to drive in four runs. Grady Hatton and Johnny Wyrostek also homered for the losers.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers Journal tonight described the General Motors wage settlement as "a definite backward move."

Lumber production for the week ended May 22 was 7.7 per cent above the preceding week but was 8.5 per cent below the like week last year. Shipments were 8.5 per cent above last year and orders up 20.3 per cent, according to reports received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CAIRO, May 28 (UP) -- The Arabs have reportedly added psychological warfare to the tanks, mortars, cannons and men dedicated to the Latrun fight, dropping trilingual leaflets urging Israeli men to join the battle against partition.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommended today that the Pennsylvania and Atlantic Railroad be permitted to abandon and eighteen-mile branch between Toms River and Bay Head, N.J. The railroad said in its petition that passenger and freight business has been diverted to highways.
SEOUL, Korea, May 28 -- The newly elected national Korean Assembly met yesterday in an unscheduled secret session in Seoul and elected Dr. Syngman Rhee temporary chairman.

SANDWICH, England, May 28 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan, golfing Adonis from Toledo, stroked his way brilliantly today into the final of the British amateur championship, but Willie Turnesa of White Plains, N.Y., the defending title-holder, couldn't make it.

LONDON, May 28 -- This was a day of gathering gloom at the Foreign Office. Early hopes that the United States would back Britain's truce plan for Palestine were dashed. The belief that British-United States tension on this problem would be eased has been succeeded by grimness.

An outcropping of demand in the aircraft section enabled the stock market to remain yesterday on the higher side. The session rounded out the third consecutive month with prices higher, but trading dwindled in view of the lengthened week-end holiday.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- White House conferences today seeking settlement of the wage dispute between the railroad engineers, firemen and switchmen, were resumed today upon the direction of Dr. John R. Steelman, assistant to the President, but the situation remained deadlocked this evening. A recess was taken until Tuesday.

Your editorial comment of May 26 on the GM wage formula, in which you say "It would be a good deal less than accurate to say that, from the standpoint of national economic well-being, the General Motors settlement has produced the perfect formula," is well taken.

LONDON, May 28 -- The British Commonwealth is the only agency with sufficient political experience and ability to lead the world to peace and prosperity, Sir John Boyd Orr, retiring Director General of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, said today.

Some retailers will offer cotton rugs at reduced prices in the next two weeks, buyers reported yesterday, in a move to clear inventories as quickly as possible. A few of the larger outlets said they do not intend to follow any price-cutting policy.

Because of dividend restrictions in a bank loan, the Autocar Company's directors took no action yesterday on a common dividend due at this time. The company said that bank loans obtained for the settlement of tax liabilities recently agreed upon with the Federal Government restrict the paying of the dividend.
PEORIA, Ill., May 28 -- Former Gov. Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota picked himself "a tough nut to crack" today in seeking "second choice" votes among the fifty-six Republican delegates from Illinois.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 -- Still trying to catch up with the astounding Athletics, the Yankees tonight were disposed to ascribe the league-leading position of Connie Mack's crew to something more than an early-season flash.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- There are indications in Washington that Secretary of State Marshall may, after all, follow up the let's-talk-it-over exchange between Ambassador W. Bedell Smith and Foreign Minister Molotov With a few discreet approaches to the Soviet Union.
Andre Simon, father of the Wine and Food Society in England and America, is here from London for three weeks to inspect the state of our gastronomic arts.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 28 -- The Official Gazette published today details of the establishment of state companies called Petrol Export that have an export monopoly on oil and its derivatives and an import monopoly on the materials and chemicals for all industries.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 28 -- Four students of the Mesifta Torah Vodaath Rabbinical School, Brooklyn, who celebrated the Jewish holiday of Lag B'Omer -- equivalent to the American Fourth of July -- yesterday afternoon by peppering tin cans in the Elizabeth meadows with weapons they hoped to send to the Haganah, today drew suspended fines of $25 each from Acting Police Court Judge John T. Glennon.

A pressman's revealing description, a detective's hunch and intensive police leg work combined yesterday to bring to book a husky, dull youth on a charge of slaying a man in his home in Jamaica, Queens, on Wednesday morning.
LONDON, May 28 -- Deputies of the Council of Foreign Ministers met today to continue their discussions on Italian colonies but they still found themselves bogged down on procedure.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today his agency does not maintain files on prominent citizens or members of Congress "as such."

Calumet Farm, which has been exceedingly kind to the opposition at Belmont Park, having started only three horses at the meeting, shoots for its third victory and second stake of the session today. Warren Wright's remarkable racing establishment shoots with Coaltown, alias Speed Inc., and it's 1 to 10 or less, pricemakers say, that he'll whack the bullseye.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The State Department learned today from Beirut that the forty-one United States citizens who had been removed by Lebanese authorities from the S.S. Marine Carp en route to Palestine were now willing to return directly to the United States.

Gertrude and Gerson Lerner have purchased the four-story apartment house with stores at the northeast corner of Alabama and Livonia Avenues in Brooklyn from Simon Flesher. The property, on a plot 50 by 100 feet, was acquired for cash above a mortgage of $17,000.

The General Motors wage plan, which provides for (1) a flat annual increase of 3 cents in the base hourly wage of its workers and (2) an increase of 8 cents an hour to restore the purchasing power of the workers' dollar to that prevailing in 1940 (which may subsequently be raised or lowered) has evoked widespread interest and comment.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 28 (UP) -- The cause of Christ faces "the scourge of atheistic communism abroad" and "secularism and indifferentism" at home, William E. Burke of Utica, state deputy of the Knights of Columbus, said today in his annual report at the fifty-third annual convention of the New York State Council, K. of C.

All the particulars having been agreed to, Nanette Fabray is now set for the leading feminine role in the new Cheryl Crawford musical, "Love-Life," heretofore labeled "A Dish for the Gods." The contracts were drawn up yesterday and are expected to be signed over the week-end.
Sales of town houses in scattered sections of Manhattan featured realty deals reported yesterday.

Memorial Day will be observed in the churches of all faiths in the city tomorrow with sermons paying tribute to the dead of this country in all wars. In addition patriotic and military organizations will attend special memorial services. Everywhere prayers will be offered for an early peace in the Holy Land.

BALTIMORE, May 28 (AP) -- Capt. William Odom, 'round-the-world speed flier who has always been lucky at beating fog, piloted a big flying boat to an emergency landing at the head of Chesapeake Bay today.

PARIS, May 28 -- The Soviet "peace offensive" crystallized today when the Democratie Nouvelle, the most important Communist publication on this side of the Trieste-Stettin line, published a special edition designed to prove that only the United States and reactionaries everywhere were seeking war.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- Senator Kenneth S. Wherry, Republican, of Nebraska, predicted today that Congress will renew compulsory controls over scarce materials unless industry cooperates more fully with the voluntary allocation program.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Government today lifted a seven-year-old freeze against withdrawal of about $60,000,000 in Spanish-owned assets in this country.

Introductory advertising for the Renault (French) Motor Car Company's export model, a rear-engined 1,200-pound four-door sedan, will be started in metropolitan newspapers within the next few weeks, it was learned yesterday. The ads for this latest addition to the foreign-car market will feature what is probably the highest mileage claim -- fifty-five miles per gallon -- yet made for any motor vehicle other than a motorcycle.

The Association of American soap and Glycerine Producers, Inc., through its directors this week decided to give all members equal voting strength. Previously had used a "bicameral" system of voting, in which either one group of large contributors to expenses, or another group of small contributors, could prevent positive action on any program.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 28 -- Twenty-three cruising yachts got under way off Larchmont breakwater tonight on the Storm Trysail Club's 193-mile race around Block Island.

American engineering and management "know-how" is now employed in completing the first large chemical plant in India, at a cost estimated in excess of $30,000,000. It promises to provide cheap ammonium sulphate for agriculture at a rate of more than 350,000 tons annually.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The brewing industry today won a second postponement, to June 30, of the effective date of its voluntary grain-saving agreement under the anti-inflation act.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Bert M. Jewell, former president of the Railway Department of the American Federation of Labor, will represent the American Federation of Labor as its adviser to Paul Hoffman, Administrator of the Economic Cooperation Administration, it was reported today.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., May 28 -- The eighty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Army Signal Corps was observed here today with a parade and ceremony in which eighty chief executives of the nation's leading communications industries participated.

The business affairs of the Council on African Affairs, Inc., became more tangled than ever yesterday when Dr. Max Yergan, executive director of the council for ten years, sought to dislodge members of the left-wing faction led by Paul Robeson and Dr. Doxie Wilkerson from possession of the office.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Beneficial effects of the European Recovery Program are already to be noted in western Europe, Sir Oliver Franks, the new British Ambassador, said on his arrival today. He was accompanied by Lady Franks and their two daughters.

PARIS, May 28 -- Premier Robert Schuman today staked his Cabinet on a vote to be taken Tuesday on the Government's "guillotine" measure for the reduction of the civil service by 150,000 state employes. Behind this internal issue lies a growing resistance against French foreign policy in recent London talks.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Senate Republican policy leadership set out today to exert "every human effort" toward a final adjournment of the Eightieth Congress on June 19. But it gave no guarantees.

Every possible effort must be made to clear up the murder in Greece of George Polk, Columbia Broadcasting Company correspondent, as soon as possible. Every competent agency of the United States and Greek Governments and of the United Nations should exert its best efforts to that end.

WARSAW, May 28 -- Strict security precautions were taken by the Polish Government today for the arrival of the Bulgarian deputation headed by Premier Georgi Dimitrov, which will discuss a treaty of mutual assistance with Polish leaders for three days.

IN their volume, "Gettysburg,"* Earl S. Miers and Richard A. Brown have given us the story of one of the world's great battles in the words of the men and women who experienced it. In these excerpts from the diaries, recollections, memoirs and histories written by the civilians, soldiers, officers and others who lived through the grim, bloody three-day conflict in July, 1863, something of what Gettysburg was really like can be understood.
City College faculty members and alumni paid tribute last night to Dr. William Bradley Otis, who will retire in September as Professor of English after forty-four years at the college.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would extend to San Francisco and Los Angeles its investigation of the recent $10,000,000 common stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.

Since Soviet Russia began to couple its "cold war" against the West with a spring "peace offensive" to undermine Western solidarity and influence the American Presidential election, Moscow has torpedoed two conferences where peace had been discussed for many months and where Russia's real intentions had been put to the test.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Thirty-two additional organizations were branded by Attorney General Tom C. Clark today as "subversive," thus greatly increasing the list of about ninety groups put in the same category last November.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals unanimously reversed yesterday the convictions of former Navy Comdr. John D. Corrigan, his business associate, Robert H. Wells, and their industrial engineering corporation on charges of conspiring to deprive the Government of Corrigan's honest services while he was a Navy inspector of wartime manufacturing plants.

New York University's athletes, rising to the occasion with a series of inspired performances in the qualifying tests yesterday, moved a long step toward a successful defense of the team title in the finals of the seventy-second annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships at Randalls Island today.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur declined today to return voluntarily to the United States before the Republican National Convention on the ground that it would be condemned by many as politically inspired.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 28 -- Indictments charging Warden Joseph W. Buckley of the Hudson County Penitentiary in Secaucus and an assistant with misconduct in office and other indictments charging six keepers with atrocious assault and battery for beatings administered prisoners, were handed up by a holdover grand jury to Judge John Drewen in Quarter Sessions Court here today.

A group of members of Local 4, Consolidated Edison Employes, Utility Workers of America, CIO, protested to the city's Labor Relations Division yesterday against a ruling that requires them to work on street openings on weekends. Borough President Hugo E. Rogers had previously ruled that street-opening work be concentrated on week-ends so that weekday traffic would be expedited.

Illuminated three-dimensional advertising displays will be installed between the express tracks at six stations of the city subway system next fall, William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation, announced yesterday. A three-year contract for the installation and maintenance of 480 of these "spectaculars" has been awarded to the McArthur Advertising Corporation.

August F. Matthes, a former city fireman, whose escape from Pilgrim State Hospital had resulted in a police guard at the home of Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle, was caught yesterday by Detective Walter Laurie a few blocks from Mr. Quayle's home.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- President Truman's Memorial Day Proclamation, issued today, was entitled "Prayer for Peace: Memorial Day, 1948," and he appealed for "a universal prayer in the evening of that day."

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Retailers today are depending far too much on decisions made by "rule of thumb" and on guidance by experience or "feel" instead of studied facts, John J. Kavanagh, general manager of the Controllers' Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, warned today at the closing session of the congress' convention here.

LAKE SUCCESS. N.Y., May 28 -- The Government of Chile accused the Soviet Union today of violating "fundamental human rights" by refusing to allow Russian wives of foreign citizens to leave the country with their husbands and asked that the case be put on the agenda of the next General Assembly session.

Now that another spring is with us and the voice of the baseball fan is heard again from coast to coast, it is interesting to realize that one of the least changed features of the constantly changing American scene is baseball.

Tenants in River House, luxurious twenty-six-story apartment building facing the East River at Fifty-second Street, plan to invoke Federal and municipal rent-control laws in an effort to keep their living quarters, it became known yesterday.

By a vote of 40 to 33, the Senate has approved an amendment to the absurd Wiley-Revercomb bill, raising its proposed admission of 100,000 Displaced Persons to the United States to 200,000 over the next two years. This is the first official Congressional recognition -- by actual test vote on the floor -- of the crucial need for America to show world leadership in the matter of DP resettlement.

ALBANY, May 28 -- Release of public school pupils for religious education during school hours was described today as a violation of the American principle of the separation of church and state. During court arguments on a petition to terminate the released-time program in New York State, this claim was advanced by Arthur Garfield Hays, counsel for Joseph Lewis, president of the Freethinkers of America.

The Fabian Theatres Corporation has been granted a license by the Department of Licenses to operate a $350,000 "drive-in" open-air motion picture theatre on the east side of Richmond Avenue, Green Ridge, S.I., it was learned yesterday. The theatre will be opened tonight.
Cotton futures were rather quiet yesterday before the three-day holiday, and closing prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 5 to 19 points higher.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 28 -- The "new look" achieved by American women required "nearly 4,000,000 yards of cloth at a time when most of the world's women have barely enough clothing to cover their bodies," the Rev. Dr. Harold C. Case, minister of First Methodist Church, Pasadena, Calif., told nearly 2,000 club women at today's session of the General Federation of Women's Clubs' fifty-seventh annual convention.
PARIS, May 28 (UP) -- Mrs. Patricia Canning Todd of La Jolla, Calif., lost her French international women's singles championship today.

Hoping to preserve the old Long Island Sound steamer Meteor for continued use as a passenger carrier, representatives of A.H. Krause, the present owner, have turned down a number of bids for the ship from scrapping concerns, they reported yesterday.
Los Angeles will receive bids on June 29 on bonds amounting to $18,200,000. Of the total, $16,600,000 is to mature over forty years and the rest, over twenty years.

The taxpayer building containing five stores at 115-07 to 115-15 Merrick Road, Jamaica, Queens, has been purchased by the Elri Realty Corporation, represented by Milton F. Deutsch, attorney, from the 115-07 Merrick Road Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- A spokesman for the National Broadcasting Company accepted today the onus for the "regrettable" broadcasts in Spanish for the State Department's "Voice of America" which were branded as odious and slanderous by angry members of Congress.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., May 28 (AP) -- Hospitals, like hotels, "make or break their reputations" on good food service, the director of the Buffalo General Hospital said today.

MADISON, Wis., May 28 (AP) -- Charley Fonville, shot-put star from Michigan, and Fortune Gordien, Minnesota discus thrower, smashed records as expected and favored Ohio State set a fast qualifying pace in the Big Nine outdoor track and field meet today.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Early Wynn's pinch single scored Carden Gillenwater from second base with two out in the seventh inning tonight to lift Washington to a 2-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox. The defeat dropped Boston into seventh place as the Senators moved into sixth.

PRETORIA, South Africa, May 28 -- Prime Minister Jan Christiaan Smuts handed the resignation of his Cabinet to Governor General Brand von Zyl this morning. Then, escorted by a single secret service man, the defeated Prime Minister passed through the pillared corridors of the Union Buildings to return to his farm at Irene, away from the stress of politics.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Jean Chappelear, 14-year-old daughter of the town barber of Black Horse, Ohio, today was crowned spelling champion of America's grammar school pupils.

Five teen-age hoodlums from the Fort Hamilton section of Brooklyn were found guilty of juvenile delinquency yesterday in the shooting up of a Brooklyn school teacher's home last month, and were sentenced to varying terms by Justice James V. Mulholland in Brooklyn Children's Court.

It may be of interest to those who read THE TIMES editorial relating to the salary adjustment plan of General Motors that the plan of adjusting pay of employes in accordance with the consumer's price index computed by the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics has been in operation in about eighteen public jurisdictions -- mostly cities in the western part of the country.

The conference in London which has been wrestling for three months with the problem of what to do with Western Germany is about to wind up with a compromise which does not satisfy the British and Americans or remove all the objections of the French. Meetings of representatives of these three Powers began in February and were enlarged five weeks ago to take in Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 28 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Star said today in a copyright article that finished pig iron has been produced for the first time in history from the rock called taconite.

James Hilton, author of "Lost Horizon" and "Good-bye, Mr. Chips," has been signed to act as narrator for a new dramatic series which will have its premiere on CBS on Thursday, June 10, from 10 to 10:30 P.M. The new program will be called "Hallmark Playhouse" and will replace "Radio Edition -- Reader's Digest" for the same sponsor, Hall Brothers, Inc.

" The First Opera Film Festival," a feature-length picture composed of excerpts from four operas, will open an engagement today at the Little Carnegie. The film offers abridgments of Rossini's "William Tell," Mozart's "Marriage of Figaro," Donizetti's "Don Pasquale" and Bizet's "Carmen," sung by Cloe Elmo and Tito Gobbi.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz demanded yesterday in a letter to the State Liquor Authority that someone "assume responsibility" for the situation in Brooklyn that enabled minors to buy liquor.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 28 -- The Old Walled City of Jerusalem fell into Arab hands today, ending a siege that had lasted five months. The besieged Jews, on the verge of starvation and without ammunition to defend themselves, surrendered unconditionally.

Unless a change in policy develops, there will be few, if any, iron and steel scrap shipments approved by the United States Army in Germany from the estimated 10,000,000 tons reported available there.

In your editorial of May 26 on the GM-UAW-CIO settlement, which we are recommending be accepted by the General Motors locals of our union, you devote principal attention to the so-called cost-of-living adjustment.

LONDON. May 28 -- Jan AIasaryk, Czechoslovak Foreign Minister, was found dead on the day on which he had planned to escape from Czechoslovakia, Blazej Vilim, former Secretary General of the Czech Social Democratic party, told a Czech "shadow government" today.
DETROIT, May 28 (AP) -- Motor vehicle output in the United States and Canada this week will total 92,105 units, Ward's Automotive Reports estimated today.

DEVON, Pa., May 28 -- Sergeant Murphy, entry of Harry S. Nichols of Indianapolis, Ind., and Robin Hill's Mam'selle, owned by the Robin Hill Stables of Westwood, N.J., won legs on challenge trophies at the Devon Horse Show and Country Fair tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 28 -- Shattering the placid debate of the Security Council on the war in Palestine today came word of a new and imminent threat to the Holy Sepulchre and other holy places in Jerusalem.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Following is the text of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's message to chairman Bridges of the Senate Appropriations Committee:

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Appointment of Dr. A. Remington Kellogg as director of the United States National Museum was announced today by Dr. Alexander Wetmore, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, which administers the museum. Dr. Kellogg, the institution's curator of mammals for seven years, is recognized as a leading authority in mammalogy.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Registration statements covering more than $150,000,000 of new financing were filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by three companies.

ST. LOUIS, May 28 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns moved into a virtual tie with the Detroit Tigers for fourth place tonight when they downed the Bengals, 5 to 4. Bob Dillinger's third hit, a sacrifice, and Gerry Priddy's single produced the winning run in the seventh inning.

I read your editorial entitled "The GM Wage Formula," and was surprised that you did not note that, as a practical matter, it is extremely unlikely that there will be any decrease in wage rates pursuant to this formula.

BOSTON, May 28 -- Victory for the Dodgers over the Braves was a long time coming, and tonight's successful operation required nearly three hours, but the Durocher crew finally achieved it by a 7-5 score. They had dropped eight straight to Boston, four of them in 1947.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Farm prices went down slightly between mid-April and mid-May, the Department of Agriculture reported today. Prices paid by farmers for commodities used in living and in crop production, on the other hand, increased a little.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 28 -- Following is the text of a speech by Secretary of State George C. Marshall before the General Federation of Women's Clubs here tonight:

JERUSALEM, May 28 -- The Israeli garrison of the Old City of Jerusalem surrendered to Trans-Jordan Arab Legion troops at 2:30 P.M. today after an eleven-day battle. More than 2,500 men, women and children, still sheltered in the ruins of the Jewish quarter, were included in the surrender.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- American Communists would not support the United States in any conceivable war with the Soviet Union nor would they under any circumstances obey pending legislation restricting communism, their leader swore today.

Textiles and apparel valued at $39,018,873 constituted the principal commodities furnished for the Federal Government by New York manufacturers and dealers during April under the Walsh-Healey Public Contracts Act, it was announced yesterday.

Two newly opened group shows this week, at the Kraushaar and Associated American Artists' Galleries, are notable additions to the waning art season. Both feature old work and new by regular gallery members and come as end-of-season reviews.

MUNICH, Germany, May 28 -- Murray D. Van Wagoner, United States Military Governor of Bavaria urged the electorate tonight to review the records of individual candidates in the state elections Sunday, instead of voting for them as party representatives.

The Rev. Garland Gladstone Lacey began his duties this week as the pastor of the Mount Washington Presbyterian Church, 84 Vermilyea Avenue, near Broadway and 204th Street, succeeding the Rev. John U. Stephens, who resigned because of his health.

A colorful "master swindler," charged with frauds totaling more than $100,000, was arrested yesterday in Newark, N.J., after evading efforts of the New York authorities for more than a year to bring him to justice here.

PRAGUE, May 28 -- Communist Premier Klement Gottwald and the chiefs of the Communist-dominated General Confederation of Labor insisted in their final appeals today that Sunday's single-list vote for Parliament was the freest of all elections.

HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, N.J., May 28 -- The four-mile section of Route 17 that was closed to traffic Tuesday morning to permit start of construction of a fourth lane may be opened for the three-day holiday week-end, State Highway Commissioner Spencer Miller Jr., informed the Mayors of Hasbrouck Heights, Carlstadt and Wood-Ridge today.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, declared today that the Taft-Hartley Law threatened the union's existence. Senator Joseph M. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, told him that he was seeking privileges he would not accord to employer associations.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 28 -- Arab Legion and Israeli commanders fed armor and artillery into the mounting battle for Latrun tonight after hungry, outnumbered Israeli fighters in Jerusalem's Old City surrendered to King Abdullah's siege forces.

Veterans who become landlords are not exempt from the requirement of showing "compelling necessity" to obtain a certificate of eviction from the Temporary City Housing Authority, Supreme Court Justice Michael F. Walsh ruled yesterday in Brooklyn.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 28 -- Beatrice Pearson, New York stage actress who was brought to Hollywood last year by David O. Selznick but who has not yet appeared in a film, will make her screen debut as John Garfield's leading lady in "Tucker's People," it was announced today by Roberts Productions, the company which is making the picture at the Enterprise studio.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- The National Safety Council reported today that 8,700 persons had been killed in traffic accidents in the first four months of this year, a decrease of 7 per cent from the death toll in the same period last year.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The War Assets Administration declined today all bids received in connection with the disposal of the Government-owned blast furnace and by-products coke oven plant known as "the Republic Steel Facility at Cleveland."
LONDON, May 28 -- News of South Africa's rejection of former Prime Minister Smuts was received by Britons today with shock and dismay.

Two hundred ninety-five cadets of the graduating class of the United States Military Academy at West Point completed a twenty-four hour inspection and training tour of the Army's Port of Embarkation last night.

MILWAUKEE, May 28 -- The Northern Baptist Convention voted today to start, in conjunction with other religious bodies, an "immediate" World Peace Movement designed to "save the world from destruction."

We believe that Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate have done the sensible thing in voting to proceed at once with demolition of the remains of the old Aquarium structure in Battery Park. Tunnel construction plans could no longer be delayed. The Legislature had failed to grant the city permission to cede the site to the Federal Government for preservation as a national monument.

Today is the thirty-fourth day of the Greater New York Fund's eleventh annual campaign in behalf of 423 local hospitals, health and welfare agencies. In 1736 -- 212 years ago -- Patrick Henry, patriot, statesman, orator, was born.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 27 (Delayed) -- A spokesman for the State of Israel charged today that the Egyptian Government had intercepted four foreign ships at Suez Canel ports in the past week and confiscated all cargo consigned to Palestine. None of the material seized by Egypt was of military value, he said.

Glen Hughes, director of the School of Drama of the University of Washington and author of "Spring Fever," is working on a one-volume history of the American theatre. Starting with the first American theatrical activity, in 1700, the book will deal with plays, productions, writers and actors in all periods, including the recent developments in motion pictures, radio and television.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Dr. John Steelman, Assistant to President Truman, conferred today with representatives of Federal agencies and veterans' organizations on means for controlling the quality of housing financed with government-insured mortgages.

The Bendix Aviation Corporation reported yesterday, for the six months ended with March, a consolidated net income of $4,181,946 after all charges, including $2,769,916 provision for Federal income taxes.
LONDON, May 28 -- The British Medical Association Representative Body voted today to advise the medical profession to join the Labor Government's National Health Service.

An exhibition of recently acquired historical mementoes opened yesterday at the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West. In variety and rarity it is considered one of the most important of such displays the society has held.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, has written to Senator Wallace White Jr., of Maine, chairman of the Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, urging that legislation to assist the nation's merchant marine be adopted at this session of Congress, it was learned tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (U.P.) -- The American Federation of Labor said today that union members were voting fifteen to one against the Taft-Hartley Law.

One of the largest American refrigerator producers next Tuesday will begin a concerted drive to substantially increase exports to the sixteen countries covered by the European Recovery Plan, its export manager disclosed yesterday. Working with distributors in the sixteen countries, the company will attempt to persuade each government to grant more licenses and issue larger dollar allocations for imports of both home and commercial refrigeration units -- for adequate preservation of increased food supplies.

Denouncing the suggestion in some quarters that manufacturers are cutting shoe production to maintain shoe prices as "utterly absurd," W.W. Stephenson, executive vice president of the National Shoe Manufacturers Association, yesterday hit out at what he termed "irresponsible criticism of the pricing and production policies of the industry."

Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., which is in financial distress, yesterday paid a debenture obligation of $1,100,000 but its board of directors failed to name a new president at a meeting in Kansas City, Mo.

MANCHESTER, England, May 28 (Reuters) -- For the first time in this tour the Australian cricket tourists failed to win a match. Their game with Lancashire at Old Trafford, Manchester, ended in a draw today.

DETROIT, May 28 -- The seventeen-day strike against the Chrysler Corporation by the United Automobile Workers, CIO, was ended tonight when the company granted a flat wage increase of 13 cents an hour. This is 2 cents an hour more than was obtained by the 225,000 General Motors workers represented by the UAW under a cost-of-living formula.

DETROIT, May 28 -- The seventeen-day strike against the Chrysler Corporation by the United Automobile Workers, CIO, was ended tonight when the company granted a flat wage increase of 13 cents an hour. This is 2 cents an hour more than was obtained by the 225,000 General Motors workers represented by the UAW under a cost-of-living formula.

Bankers, faced with a slowdown in the rate of growth of their institutions, "are embarking on a program of harassing savings associations" by an attempt to belittle the value of the insurance of accounts provided by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, it was charged this week by George L. Bliss, president of the Century Savings and Loan Association.
PEIPING, May 28 -- A spokesman for Gen. Fu Tso-yi's headquarters here today spiked fears of an imminent Communist attack on Peiping.
BERLIN, May 28 -- Soviet military authorities consider all of Berlin part of the Soviet zone, Maj. Gen. Alexander G. Kotikov, Russian representative on the Allied Kommandatura, made clear today.
