District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday the arrest of two Milwaukee men on an indictment alleging they had misappropriated $30,000, down payment on an order for $70,000 worth of sleeping bags that were supposed to have been shipped to Algiers.

Retail sales here this week made a sizeable increase over the corresponding week last year, which contained the Memorial Day holiday. The department store gain was estimated as about 25 per cent. Several days of unseasonable weather kept the gain from being larger, it was estimated. Sales last week were up 9 per cent.

VIENNA, May 28 -- Today's meeting of the Allied Council for Austria was again largely a record of disagreement between the Soviet Union and the Western powers, but it was an agreeable form of disagreement, in keeping with the improved personal relations since the recent Soviet campaign of harassment in Vienna has ceased.

A strike of 300 bakery drivers against the Associated Bakers, a group of six concerns supplying bread and rolls to most New York restaurants, which had been scheduled for Tuesday, was postponed yesterday for forty-eight hours.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Nearly 50 per cent of the ships in the Great Lakes ore-carrying fleet are more than forty years old and should be replaced, Chairman Alvin F. Weichel, Republican, Ohio, of the House Merchant Marine Committee said today.

A board composed of the three State Racing Commissioners and two stewards of The Jockey Club yesterday heard charges that a prospective witness against Daniel Lamont of Altoona, Pa., had been "terrorized."

ARMONK, N.Y., May 28 -- With $60,000 saved for a new town hall under the pay-as-you-go plan, North Castle opened tonight construction bids from twenty-four builders and found a low estimate of $59,711 from Monda Munoz, Inc., of White Plains.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- New and improved devices of general and specialized interest in the developing fields of radio and in the services of communication and transportation, were predominant on this week's list of 384 inventions cited for patent awards by the United States Patent Office.

FORT WORTH, Tex., May 28 (AP) -- Clayton Heafner's putter didn't come close to cooling off today and the Charlotte, N.C., pro laid down a two-under-par 68 to increase his lead to three strokes at the midway point in the $15,000 Colonial National invitation golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- Secretary J.A. Krug charged today that the House broke its own rules, violated the Constitution invaded the rights of the Executive Branch, and undermined the reclamation program when it tacked a "rider" on the Interior Department's appropriation.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 28 -- Norman B. Boyle of Westminster was elected president of the Maryland Bankers Association today at the closing session of its fifty-second annual convention. He succeeds T. Howard Duckett of Hyattsville.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 28 -- Extension of the Reciprocal Trades Agreements Act for three years "in substantially its original form" was asked today by the Business and Professional Women's Clubs of New York State.

Fog continued to hamper shipping and air transport activities in the port and city for the second day yesterday and Weather Bureau officials said no relief from the blanketing haze could be expected before late tonight or tomorrow.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., May 28 -- Voters of this state will go to the polls tomorrow in a Democratic primary contest for state-wide offices, with the principal interest focused on the race for United States Senator and Governor.

Negotiations of an "exploratory" nature were resumed yesterday between the General Electric Company and the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers Union, CIO, shortly after a spokesman for the company denied that a wage offer had been made to the union.

The summer vacation season started yesterday with a rush -- a rush of travelers that jammed the railroad and bus terminals, took up every seat on planes and filled the highways with moto rists. The peak of the Memorial Day week-end travel was reached late in the afternoon and early evening and is expected to taper off somewhat today.

Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, who died on July 10, 1947, left an estate of $77,912, it was learned yesterday when his widow, Mrs. Bessie Hillman, petitioned Surrogate William T. Collins to exempt the estate from tax.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 28 -- Trade union officials remained silent today but official military government sources said they were certain the Ruhr steel workers would carry out the threat of a strike June 1 and 2 despite the military government appeal yesterday.
No longer the soft touch of yesteryear, the Phillies handed the Giants a 6-3 setback before 30,875 fans at the Polo Grounds last night.
PITTSBURGH, May 28 (AP) -- The league-leading Cardinals and the Pirates tied 1-1 tonight in a game halted by rain at the end of the sixth inning.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., May 28 -- Following are extracts from the text of a speech made before the Security Council today by Dr. Charles Malik, representative of Lebanon:
PORTLAND, Ore., May 28 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall warned the nation tonight against falling into a Russian trap baited with "cynical" peace propaganda.

Joseph Untermeyer, 19-year-old adopted son of the poet, Louis Untermeyer, of 600 West End Avenue, and Isaiah Warshaw, 30, a watchmaker, of 15 Mill Street, Brooklyn, were freed yesterday by Magistrate Frederick L. Strong in youth part of Felony Court of a charge of illegally possessing firearms and ammunition.

While pickets paraded with placards denouncing cash subsidies for housing as socialistic and communistic, ground was broken yesterday morning for a $15,000,000 veterans' housing development at Broadway and Fiftieth Street, Woodside, Queens.

ANTON Chekov, among many other things, has always been a writer's writer. The magic of his haunting artistry, its simplicity, its strength, and, above all, its delicate matching of style and subject-matter, has long fascinated the great novelists of England, France and Germany and has spurred a horde of hacks all over the world to ludicrous imitation.

HARRISON, N.Y., May 29 -- Things weren't tough enough among the breed improvers, so they stumbled into a new wrinkle -- portable mutuel machines. Legalized wagering was in effect today at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club, site of the renewed Adjacent Hunts, last presented a decade ago.
The national committee of the Communist party of the United States of America took credit yesterday for starting the third party led by Henry A. Wallace.

Following is an excerpt from the. voluminous diary written in the third person by the talented Italian director during the filming of "Paisan." The picture now is in the third month of its run at the World Theatre.

WHEN Prince Andrei Lobanov-Rostovsky, the descendant of an aristocratic family which had been prominent in Russia's diplomatic service, left his homeland early in 1920, after the collapse of Denikin's front he felt that:

The long tug-of-war between management and labor over wages came nearer a real settlement last week. Inauguration of a "parity wage formula" by the General Motors Corporation with the automobile and electrical workers' union was received favorably in financial quarters, which foresee industrial peace for two years.

The nation today will observe Memorial Day -- a day of remembrance for the veterans who fought to preserve the liberties of this land. President Harry S. Truman has issued a proclamation calling upon American citizens everywhere to make the day one to unite in prayer for permanent peace.

Closer coordination within the cooperative movement and a more intensive program of educating the public to its advantages are its primary needs, Alvin G. Shaffer, new general manager of Eastern Cooperatives, Inc., told the annual meeting of the organization yesterday.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 29 -- Following is the test of the amended British resolution on Palestine as adopted tonight by the United Nations Security Council:

NEW DELHI, India, May 15 -- The third American diplomatic mission to the isolated Himalayan Kingdom of Nepal, home of the famous fighting Gurkhas of the British and Indian Armies, has returned to New Delhi with the news that Nepal, like many larger nations, is preoccupied with a shortage of United States dollars.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 29 -- In a bitterly contested game in which the lead changed hands eight times and the winning goal was scored in the last seventeen seconds of play, Navy closed out a mediocre lacrosse season in spectacular fashion, defeating Army, 10 to 9, in the twenty-first meeting of the traditional series today.

THE Manhattan Camera Club took permanent possession of the New York City Interclub Trophy offered by the Miniature Camera Club at the Fourth Annual New York Invitational Competition, having won the award three times in succession.

TO own some kind of pet is one of a child's first rights, and no one knows it better than the children. All sorts of solemn arguments are advanced to explain why children need pets -- such as the sympathy acquired, the responsibility assumed -- all of them beside the point.

WARSAW, May 29 -- The Polish Government in a long communique today retorting to the State Department's announcement of the United States withdrawal from the Polish-American Mixed Nationality Commission, asserted it must maintain the sole right to interpret Polish legislation on the question of Polish citizenship.

In the course of the Remsen Memorial Lecture which he delivered last Friday before the Maryland Section of the American Chemical Society, Dr. Elmer V. McCollum of Johns Hopkins threw cold water on the compulsory bread-enrichment program adopted by many states. Bread enrichment is not worth what it costs, he thinks.

JUST sixteen years ago this week in this Review: Charles Morgan's "The Fountain" was hailed in a front-page review as "a novel of great distinction * * * exceptional as fiction is tending today; not for the mass of the reading public; at least, not for those readers who demand action and pure entertainment."

I read "Topics of the Times" in your issue of May 25, and I regret to say I smiled. There are things at which one should not smile, but you know how it is; and the piece was well written. I cut it out and showed it to others, and to my surprise they smiled the sneering smile and added a few gibes of their own.

CAMBERLEY, England, May 29 (AP) -- Field Marshall Montgomery said representatives from cities heavily bombed in World War II would be called together next year to help military experts chart a program for use if Britain underwent a "surprise attack."

PARIS, May 29 -- Persons acquainted with the views of the highest ranking officers of the French armed services said today that these officers felt they had been badly let down by the United States in the matter of aid on armaments.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 29 (AP) -- Members of the Knights of Columbus were urged tonight by Bishop Kearney of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rochester to combat forces seeking to undermine Christian civilization.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The General Motors wage settlement this week has more meaningful angles than General Motors has cars.

CENTRAL PARK is more than merely the outdoor "studio" for snapshots of relatives and friends that it seems to have become over the years. New York's "big front yard" offers possibilities for really fine pictures, but it probably yields fewer good ones than any other part of town.

After another exchange yesterday with John F. O'Connell, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, County Judge Samuel Leibowitz of Brooklyn said he hoped to bring all law enforcement agencies in on the problem of juveniles who obtain liquor from sources licensed by the SLA.

Approximately sixty privately operated, profit-making New York City schools will be affected by new Veterans Administration regulations, which have revised contract requirements to provide a firmer control over tuition rates charged by many private schools for training veterans under the GI Bill of Rights.

THIS afternoon and this evening the repertory company at the City Center will be giving the final performances of O'Neill's "S.S. Glencairn" series. For the most part these four one-act plays are admirably acted under Jose Ferrer's direction, and at the City Center they are offered at half the prices prevailing on Broadway.

MOST people, remembering the fairy tales and legends on which they were reared, are amazed to learn how comparatively recent in the history of literature is the story designed especially for children and how very recent is the one written purely to give pleasure.

WASHINGTON -- American tourists who regard their automobiles as indispensable adjuncts to their way of life at home and abroad were cheered by a recent development in international travel that offers them the prospect of taking their cars abroad at a minimum of expense and red tape.

PERHAPS the most serious problem faced by airline operators is that of sharply rising production costs and the resultant high prices, for new planes needed to keep airline service at peak operating conditions. The cost of the development of new types of airplanes has become quite literally prohibitive.

GRAND CANYON, Ariz. -- While many Western resorts claim high altitude as their distinction, Phantom Ranch considers itself unique for quite the opposite reason. It is situated approximately one mile below the rim of the Grand Canyon on Bright Angel Creek, a half mile above its junction with the Colorado River.

THIS well designed and strongly illustrated book about Norway, written for 12-to 15-year-olds, will appeal to all readers. Mrs. Thorne-Thomsen knows her country well, its history, geography and its customs. "In Norway" is filled with story and legend, and describes the sea and its men, the great fisheries, the farmers and woodsmen, the family life, the holidays of the country, the story of its truly democratic government.

THE series of six symphonies composed by Ralph Vaughan Williams over a period of forty years, forms an impressive record of the composer's growth as an artist, as well as affording evidence of the fundamental unity of his musical personality under its various manifestations.

IN both Great Britain and the United States the Russian question is the dominant consideration in framing foreign policy. Both nations emphatically reject the Communist solution for world problems, but at this point there are important differences in the atmosphere surrounding the discussion.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 -- Because another of octogenarian Cornelius McGillicuddy's venerable pitchers stopped the Yankees dead in their tracks at Shibe Park today, the astounding Mackmen tonight were five games out in front of Bucky Harris' champions, still going strong in their headlong dash as American League leaders.

BEFORE the late war American bridge periodicals occasionally received articles from a Hungarian named Robert Darvas (pronounced Darwash). His articles had two characteristics: they arranged English words in pure Hungarian idiom, and they described the most striking bridge hands anyone had ever seen.

WHAT happened socially and politically in Russia during the half century between Czar Nicholas II and the siege of Moscow in World War II? Mrs. Fischer, Russian wife of American foreign correspondent Louis Fischer, deals with this vast and complicated period in a first novel as ambitious as it is earnest.

The General Motors Corporation is the biggest company in America's biggest industry. GM assets total $2.5 billion. It has 375,000 employes in 100 plants in fifty-two cities in fifteen States and twenty-six plants abroad. It produces about 2,250,000 cars and trucks a year -- two of every five made in America.

On the eve of his sixtieth birthday, James A. Farley expressed confidence last night that the United States would meet the present crisis in world affairs successfully and bring lasting peace and security to all peoples.

Renewed and more open discussion in Japan of the possibility that Emperor Hirohito may abdicate within a few months marks at least a measurable approach to the idea of democracy. Formerly such talk in the press would have called for prompt and drastic thought control.
Today, May 30, is the thirty-fifth day of the Greater New York Fund's eleventh annual campaign in behalf of 423 local hospitals, health and welfare agencies.

JERUSALEM, May 29 (AP) - The surrender of the Jewish quarter in the Old City of Jerusalem was the hardest blow, morally and psychologically that the Jews have suf fered during the past six months. But militarily it was a relief from a heavy and vain burden.

BERLIN, May 29 -- As the outlines of a Western German state begin to emerge from the London conference, Soviet propagandists in Germany are adding new vigor and intensity to their propaganda drive based on the theme of "German unity."

THE steady gravitation of private collections toward public institutions continues. Two such collections are in the spotlight this week by reason of exhibition one in New York, the other in Boston. The Boston Museum has placed on view for the summer part of the collection of European and American paintings and Japanese prints bequeathed by the late John T. Spaulding.

The first successful production of a virus in the absence of the host cells (bacteria) has been reported by Dr. A.P. Krueger, chairman of the department of bacteriology at the University of California and scientific director of the Office of Naval Research project on airborne infections.

Despite the withdrawal of representatives of Israel from any part in the presentation of a special citation to the new Jewish state by The Churchman, independent Protestant Episcopal publication, the magazine announced yesterday that Dr. Israel Goldstein, prominent American Zionist, would accept the award and "convey The Churchman citation to the State of Israel."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 29 -- Dick Shellenbach, son of the former major league pitcher, shackled Harvard's baseball team today as Holy Cross scored a 3-1 victory.

The brisk pace that New York's auction galleries have maintained all season has slackened, and comparatively few sales are listed for the week. The Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, in a three-day sale from Wednesday through Friday will offer English and French furniture, Oriental rugs, paintings and other art objects.

The surprised dismay of the English people at the defeat of Premier Smuts in South Africa may perhaps remind them what they themselves did to Winston Churchill after the war. The election result may well cause misgivings. It weakens the links which bind the Commonwealth, for the consistent trend of the victors has been isolationist and anti-British.

WE of Lemonade Opera are proud that we are the first company in the United States to do one of the latest of Prokofieff's work "The Duenna." In doing this opera we are not only presenting a novelty but we are introducing a work of sterling worth, and at the same time, a popular, sparkling comic opera.

WHEN Bosley Crowther writes a review of a motion picture, and criticizes it as he did "The Iron Curtain," on May 13, his judgment may falter and his opinion may be wrong, but one will hardly allege that he is outside his sphere as a critic.

NOW that the theatre is foundering in a business slump that recalls the lean days before the war, why don't some of its wise heads start doing something about the problem? The theatre, of course, has priced itself up out of the reach of its greatest audience, and the obvious solution is to slash prices to a point where they come within reach.

PICTURE a stubborn idea in the mind of a stubborn man (who is also a "confessed optimist") and you begin to understand how a drive which was called impossible a year ago has now swept the world to become a reality.

PEOPLE, including some film critics, have been begging for a long, long time that our movies endeavor more often to break away from conventional plots, to try for new forms of expression with which to stimulate the senses and jolt the mind.

MONDAY is known to be a quiet evening in the restaurants. night clubs and theatres of New York. But on one recent Monday this month there was unaccustomed industry in the broad kitchen of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, and if not outright excitement, then a certain taut feeling among the dozen or so tall-hatted chefs who work there.

PARIS, May 29 -- Information from responsible diplomatic quarters has now been received that the Soviet Union is secretly applying stiff pressure on Rumania to induce that Danubian country to join the Soviet Union.

Each month in St. Louis, far away from the lights, crowds and glamour of the typical Broadway motion picture premiere, a number of motion picture "first nights" are held. The films are not the newest Hollywood releases; the theatre is in the living room or bedroom of a private home, and the audience frequently consists of only one person.

NO business is more of a mystery in the public mind than the book publishing business, and that is a pity, because of its immense social importance. The truth of this is so obvious that there is no need to enumerate the reasons.

CHARLES is a young and friendly black bear who lives with his mother and father and his Uncle Horace in a roomy cave in eastern Canada. His mother, Ursula, and his father, Sad William, are engaged in the business of making and selling Black's Salve, a kind of ointment made principally of elbow grease.

To encourage stockholder participation in its annual meetings, the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) some years ago inaugurated a practice that has proved most successful. On Tuesday, company officials expect a record attendance of more than 1,300 stockholders at the annual meeting in Flemington, N.J.

As soon as the weather permits New York City takes on a cosmopolitan air. Restaurateurs set their tables out on the sidewalks. In the daytime they open striped parasols, at night they light softly shaded lamps. In the reflection of pink and golden night lights, women flash bare white throats above the cut-out necklines of net, crepe, taffeta or pique.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, May 29 -- What Arab statesmanship had not achieved in thirty years since the Turkish Empire broke up has been done by the United Nations' partition vote. A common bond of hostility to the State of Israel has drawn all of the Arab states together in one cause.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 29 -- President Truman spent a busy morning here photographing the Navy-Cornell crew races with the movie camera presented to him by the White House Photographers Association. In the afternoon, he tossed a couple of balls to start the Army-Navy baseball game.

Ten courses on radio broadcasting, ranging from time sales to production and direction, will comprise the sixth annual Radio Institute presented jointly by the National Broadcasting Company and the University of California Extension School from June 21 to July 30.
MELBOURNE, Australia, May 29 -- A referendum today throughout the six states of Australia resulted in the defeat of the Labor Government's proposals for federal control of rents and prices.

Safety is hard to advertise. Most people think they have it, like common sense. Many hazards become contemptible because they are as familiar as the loose wire in the kitchen. Others are harder for the amateur to spot. Who sees the build-up of static electricity in the dress you clean with gasoline? Even the shock of a big hotel fire wears off and false security exerts its age-old drug.

BERLIN, May 29 -- Expecting a changed attitude on the part of the British-French Military Governments, Soviet newspapers again attacked the American Military Government tonight for its stand against the Russians on the question of military traffic in and out of this city.

CINCINNATI, May 29 -- Dr. Nelson Glueck, president of the Hebrew Union College, conferred honorary degrees upon five men and ordained twelve others as reform rabbis at the seminary's seventy-third ordination exercises today.

IT took a girl, Martha Greenhouse, and a professional group of young actors to achieve for "We, the People," a long-sought-after appearance of Fred Allen. Mr. Allen will be one of the guests this Tuesday at 9 P.M. on CBS, when the program makes its first broadcast as a simultaneous presentation on radio and television.

SEATTLE, May 29 (AP) -- The University of Washington crew nailed another rung in its climb toward Poughkeepsie and the Olympic Games today by crushing Wisconsin. The smooth-stroking varsity eight rowed the two miles in 10 minutes 17.2 seconds, the fastest time ever recorded on Lake Washington, to win by five-and-a-half lengths.

ALPINE, N.J., May 29 -- Two hundred and fifty New York City Boy Scouts helped to open the new Charles Hayden swimming pool at the 1,000-acre Alpine Scout camp at 3 o'clock today. Boys dived from both sides of the pool on a signal from J. Willard Hayden, trustee of the Charles Hayden Foundation, which contributed the pool and many of the buildings at the camp.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 29 (UP) -- Battle-hardened Arab regulars moved forward today to positions from which they might launch a three-pronged attack on Tel Aviv, capital of Israel and Palestine's largest Israeli city, sources in Trans-Jordan reported.

FOR six hundred years now, men have been singing about Robin Hood of Sherwood Forest without knowing for sure when he lived, if he lived, or who he was. Inconclusive attempts have been made to identify him with a minor royal functionary named Robert Hode, a rebel earl named Robert Fitz-Odo, a contemporary murderer named Robert Locksley.

Unless the supply of gas throughout the nation, and particularly along the Eastern seaboard, is increased soon, there will be a decided swing toward coal and oil for house heating. This was indicated by a survey made last week that showed a continuation of restrictions by gas utility companies on the installation of gas-heating equipment.

EXETER, N.H., May 29 -- Alumni Day ceremonies at Phillips Exeter Academy were marked today by an announcement that the school would receive more than $2,000,000 as residuary legatee under the will of Arthur W. Elting, an Albany physician.

BOSTON, May 29 -- Elwin Roe, called the Preacher, delivered one of his most convincing mound sermons tonight as he pitched the Dodgers to their second straight triumph over the Braves before 27,702 arclight fans and pushed Billy Southworth's crew into fifth place.

Retail activity last week was stimulated by shopping for the Memorial Day week-end, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Beachwear, sportswear and cotton dress departments were exceptionally busy.

MOVING day for house plants finds many window-sill tenants being neglected in favor of out-door gardening. Prompt attention, now or in early June to the chores contingent on their annual sojourn in the garden, will so rejuvenate them as to make you proud to have them indoors again next fall.

MOST gardens nowadays contain at least a few culinary and aromatic herbs. For decoration, scent and practical use in the kitchen, herbs are well worth while. Then, too, who can resist pinching off a nosegay on a stroll along the herb path? And that, of course, is only part of the fun of growing these delightful plants.

THE method Joe DiMaggio Co. uses to tell this story of inside baseball is the old one of giving the patient his medicine while he is laughing. This is no ordinary textbook on baseball; more textbooks would be read outside the classroom if they had as many laughs as this one.
PEIPING, May 29 (AP) -- Communist gains in Manchuria and central China were acknowledged today by pro-Government reports.

THE essential nobility of prostitutes being by now a fact pretty generally accepted by readers and writers of a certain kind of fiction, some parts of Elliott Arnold's "Everybody Slept Here" must be condemned by the conscientious reviewer as superfluous.

LEO DUROCHER, current manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers, who has returned to the wars again after an enforced year of quietude in baseball's Bastille, has come up with a book about his life with the beloved Bums, and at first glance he appears to tell all in typical no-holds-barred Durocher fashion.

William Stanley's International Bumble Bee, Van Wyck Loomis' Atlantic Hound, Robert McCullough's Herreshoff S boat Felicity and Patrick O'Gorman's Star Wahini were among the winners yesterday in the Y.R.A. championship regatta run by the Douglaston Yacht Squadron.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Senate Republican leaders moved today to put into full force a policy against the confirmation of Presidential appointees, with some exceptions, for the rest of this session.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 29 -- After five months Brazil has an inflation at the same level as at the beginning of the year. Prices are still at peak, while the consumer expects and hopes that the Government by taking control of surplus stocks of prime necessities may bring some price relief.

WHEN two years ago Ferris Greenslet wrote "The Lowells and Their Seven Worlds," he politely stated in a footnote that he was purposely slighting the story of the late Abbott Lawrence Lowell, former president of Harvard, because what he described as the "official" life of Lowell was in preparation by Lowell's friend and literary executor, Henry Aaron Yeomans.

PAUL SWAN'S weekly program in Studio 90, Carnegie Hall, will include the following numbers tonight: "Glimpse of the Chinese Theatre," "The Temptation," "On the Canvas of Space," "House That Jack Built," "Tight-Rope walker," "Spider Web," "Before the Great Silence," "The Four Elements," "Nostalgia Orientale."

There is a sweetness of May verging on June that no other time in the whole year can equal. And by sweetness is meant more than flower fragrance or honey taste; this is the greater sweetness of understanding and emotion, the glow of pleasure in being.

Generally favorable business conditions may continue through the balance of 1948, according to the composite opinion of purchasing agents who comprise the Business Survey Committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

It was one thing taking a season's-end cruise late last September as a sort of a farewell fling at 1947 and quite another experience to take the first 1948 cruise, say this week-end. The old courses, routes and places don't look quite the same.

JERUSALEM May 29 -- Arab Legion artillery was shelling the Jewish areas of New Jerusalem intermittently today and the crashing roar of projectiles was keeping people inside crowded air raid shelters for the second sabbath in succession.

AN announcement that the Philatelic Division of the Pan American Union at Washington will establish an Honorary Board of Inter-American Philatelic Advisers was made by Albert F. Kunze, the division's director, in a paper prepared for delivery last week at the twenty-fifth annual convention of the American Air Mail Society, held in Havana.

Communist strategists regard the Ministry of the Interior as the key Cabinet post in any government they hope to take over. The Interior Minister controls the police; he can make arrests, with or without warrants. The Interior Minister runs the elections. From the Communist viewpoint, the post is the stepping-stone to full power.

THE second district of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State will start the June procession of flower shows on Wednesday, June 2, when they hold their annual show at the Cathedral Chapter House, Garden City, L.I.
TOKYO, May 29 -- Pressure from business interests has finally convinced the opposition parties that a platform plank demanding reduced bureaucratic power would be politically popular.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 29 -- Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, addressing the United Nations Security Council today, suggested wryly that since the Protestants, Anglicans, Catholics, Jews and Moslems were doing nothing about preserving Jerusalem's holy places, perhaps it was up to the atheists of the world to save the city.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 29 -- Taking all three places in the broad jump, javelin and discus events for 27 points, Army's track and field team defeated Navy today by 77 points to 54. At the same time, Navy was administering the first shut-out defeat Army has suffered in the history of their baseball rivalry and winning by the largest margin registered by either team since 1920.

The article, "A Place to Go," by Anna M. Kross, was illustrated by pictures of children ranging in age from 7 to 11 years. The crux of the delinquency problem lies not in young children, but in the adolescents with time on their hands.

ATHENS, May 29 -- A Greek General Staff communique said a Regular Army unit operating northeast of Komotini in western Thrace and assisted by the Greek Air Force, attacked a rebel force. In the battle twenty-seven rebels were killed, ten captured and thirteen others surrendered.

"Oklahoma!" which was to Broadway musicals what the steam engine was to the industrial revolution, ended its New York run last night after having spent more than five years shattering theatrical fetishes and records.

CHICAGO, May 29 (AP) -- All grains turned downward today on the Board of Trade, unsettled by showers in the Wheat Belt and a substantial cut in July export allocations. The market opened lower and never was able to get to the previous close.

THE surprise settlement of the General Motors labor question put a rift last week in the united front which big industrialists had raised against a "third round" of wage increases. It looked as though it might be a rift in the direction of providing smoother sailing for business for another year or so.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 29 -- The last team home, Don Grant of Meadow Brook and Jimmy Burns of Rockaway Hunt, posted the low round of 62 in the Meadow Brook Club's spring invitation member guest best-ball golf tourney today.

FORT WORTH, Tex., May 29 -- Clayton Heafner clung to his lead in the Colonial national invitation golf tournament with a two-under par 68 today, but the sensation of the third round was Ben Hogan's mighty 65 that shot the little fellow within three strokes of the top.

Outside their formal sessions, in which the central theme was the industry's determination to resist Government controls, steel officials who convened here last week for the annual meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute expressed greatest concern over the more proximate twin problems of continuing increases in costs and worsening shortages of scrap metal.

TOKYO, May 29 -- Japanese opinion today was surprised but apparently generally approving of General MacArthur's refusal of the United States Senate's invitation to return and testify before the Appropriations Committee.

PRAGUE, May 29 -- Czechoslovakia's Action Committees, which spearheaded the coup of February, have played the central role in completing the job of formally taking over the republic for totalitarian communism. The single overwhelmingly Communist list of candidates for Parliamentary seats which is presented to voters in the election this week-end is the work of Action Committees.

LONDON, May 29 -- By a special deal with Rumania, the new Israel Government has assured itself of a continuing supply of all types of petroleum products, it was learned authoritatively today. Although the exact quantities covered by the contract and the prices were not revealed, it was said the supplies would be ample to meet all normal needs of the new state.

MADISON, Wis., May 29 (AP) -- America's top Olympic hopes in the shotput and discus bettered American records and Ohio State dethroned Illinois as team champion in the forty-eighth Big Nine outdoor track and field meet at Camp Randall Stadium today.

READERS who left a lamp in the window for Margery Sharp (when she disappeared into a respectable, serious novel called "Britannia Mews") will rejoice that she has returned to her lightsome ways, with one of her famous feather-pated females in tow.

SOON when the subway turnstile no longer plays the nickel serenade, that honored coin -- the common jitney -- will be hard put to qualify as a medium of exchange. The nickel, once a symbol of small equalitarian luxuries, is falling so low it is virtually a national insult to Thomas Jefferson.
MUNICH, Bavaria, May 29 -- Approximately 20 per cent of those elected in the small communities balloting in Bavaria April 25 were former Nazis, a United States Military Government check has shown.

LONDON, May 29 -- British diplomacy was striving mightily this week to prevent the British system of Middle East defenses, so laboriously contrived and so painfully defended during the past thirty years, from being shot to pieces overnight in Palestine.
TOKYO, May 28 -- Postwar Japan is developing her own rum row, on the style of America's Atlantic seaboard during the Nineteen Twenties.

WITH the decision last week of City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs not to press for legislation requiring the licensing of radio service men in New York, repair men renewed their efforts to clean their own house and regain and maintain public confidence.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 29 -- As Israeli forces intensified their attack on Arab-held Latrun, an Arab report today said, "The Latrun battle is going to decide the future of the Arabs in Jerusalem, Ramallah, Lydda and Ramleh." The Arabs said that 3,000 of their men were battling on that front, of which half were members of the Arab Legion.

Some members of the American armed forces in the Philippines appear to be Communists or Communist sympathizers and to be giving or selling munitions to the guerrilla forces there, Dr. Manuel V. Gallego, Secretary of Education in the Philippine Government, asserted yesterday.

JOGJAKARTA, Java, May 29 (AP) -- Mohammed Hatta, Vice President and Premier of the Indonesian Republic, planned a Cabinet shuffle today and indicated that the move might be because of dissension arising from Russian recognition of the Republic.

WARS focus our attention on-population, for deaths in wartime are unusually large in number and we are much concerned about our military manpower. Recent reports on population have puzzled us, however, because of their conflicting nature. Some of them seem to indicate reversals of trends.

CHICAGO, May 29 (AP) -- The Indians kept pace with the first-place Athletics in the American League pennant race today by scoring a second straight shut-out against the White Sox, 4 -- 0. Bob Lemon, pitching his seventh complete game, stopped Chicago with four singles to increase his runless string to twenty-three innings.
ADMIRAL FRANCO MAUGERI, chief of staff of the Italian Navy, begins his book with these sonorous sentences:

SANDWICH, England, May 29 -- Frank Stranahan, the millionaire's son from Toledo, Ohio, waded to the British amateur golf championship today with thirty-two holes of machine-like play on a day fit only for fish.

The New York offices of the General Motors Corporation and the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation made public yesterday the fact that for the first time a jet engine, the Allison 400-C4, has been certified by the Civil Aeronautics Administration for use in commercial transports.

ART rarely enters the courtroom, but when it does it sometimes helps to establish the rights of the artist and to clarify the uncertain line between his rights and those of the property owner. Since legal interpretation rests not only on the rules of law but also on the attitudes and mores of society, such decisions are a measure of the respect in which society holds its artists.

Buyers attending the first fall showings in the New York garment markets last week began placing of substantial orders even though price and delivery conditions were not entirely to their liking, according to a survey of the trade.

WITH admiral perspicacity Paul Rosenberg has added a new painter to his permanent gallery group -- Michel Patrix, a gifted young Frenchman still this side of 30. Patrix' first one-man exhibition, either here or abroad, makes an interesting and vivid supplement to the "post-Picasso" phase of abstract painting that has been taking more and more definite shape in recent years, with varying degrees of success, on both sides of the Atlantic.

AMERICAN vacationists going abroad this summer will be able to purchase foreign automobiles at list price, tax free, under a new cooperative plan inaugurated by dealers and manufacturers in the United States and Europe.

A month and a half of negotiations between steamship operators on all three 'coasts and six maritime unions -- five CIO affiliates and one independent -- have accomplished virtually nothing and the threat of a paralyzing strike in the marine industry when contracts expire June 15 remains.

Exploration by the United States and Brazilian governments of the possibility of extending guarantees to encourage American capital in joint Brazilian-American large-scale essential industrialization enterprises was urged in an interview last week by Arnold Tschudy, former director in Sao Paulo for the Office of Inter-American Affairs, and now serving as national councilor in the United States for the American Chamber of Commerce in that city.

WHEN Victor and Columbia tap a recording each month for issuance in non-breakable disks, they do so, it may be assumed, because they regard it as a choice item. The recordings do not always live up to this advance accolade, but the current exhibits from both companies are top-grade stuff from all points of view -- musical, interpretive and technical.

Fur trimmed and plain boxy coats and softly tailored silhouette suits are among the leading fall style trends, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

STANTON, Del., May 29 (AP) -- Itsabet, fast-stepping 3-year-old filly, carried the Brookfield Stable banner to victory today in the Wilmington Handicap, feature event of the opening program of Delaware Park's thirty-day meeting.

With the arrest of two men in connection with more than 100 burglaries in the Bedford section of Brooklyn, police announced yesterday that they had ended a one-year period of community jitters that had caused public appeals for protection to Mayor O'Dwyer and Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.

Your graphic and sympathetic treatment of the misery of the southern Italian peasant in your recent editorial deserves commendation. Land reform in southern Italy, as you correctly stress, should be pressed immediately, for political as well as for humanitarian reasons.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Washington shoved the Boston Red Sox deeper into seventh place here today by sweeping a doubleheader. The Senators rallied for three runs in the ninth inning to defeat Jack Kramer, 5 -- 4, then staggered to a 7-6 victory in the second game.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 29 -- The United Nations Security Council called tonight for a four-week cease-fire in Palestine. Giving the parties seventy-two hours in which to accept, the Council threatened to apply sanctions under Chapter VII of the Charter if the peace appeal were rejected by either party or subsequently violated.

MAKRONISOS, Greece, May 26 (Delayed) -- This Aegean island off the southeastern tip of Attica, about thirty miles from Athens, is where recruits for the Greek National Army have been sent for the past year whenever it was felt for one reason or another they were security risks.

Nothing could have incensed me more than Bernard Iddings Bell's article, "The School Can't Take the Place of the Home." * * * Most families nowadays are all; the child comes in contact with very few large groups until he goes to school

RE the anguished cry from George Bernard Shaw about his impending financial ruin [because of taxes on royalties from Maurice Evans' successful production of "Man and Superman"], I am constrained to comment that maybe he did not look too closely into the possible development of the fledgling chicken he helped to midwife so many decades ago, and which now has turned into a devouring eagle with an insatiable greed for play-wright's royalties.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., May 29 -- A pessimistic outlook in the cotton textile industry is unwarranted on the basis of current economic conditions, Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute, declared here today. Downward price revisions, he said, are merely an indication of the disappearance of sharp scarcities and resumption of competitive conditions in the trade.
IRIS at the present time have reached the peak of their bloom in and around New York City. They are the dominant flower in suburban gardens and several extensive displays are also open to the public.

General Smuts of South Africa, according to a news dispatch in THE NEW YORK TIMES on May 24, has proposed an "association" between the United States and the British Commonwealth of Nations. Amid the din and clatter of current debate about how to achieve world stability, we should earnestly consider the words of one of the wisest statesmen of our time.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., May 29 -- Guests of the New York City Police Athletic League, 2,700 boys and girls from Brooklyn and Staten Island, many of whom had never before been outside of the city's borders, frolicked this afternoon in Bear Mountain State Park.

"Satisfied, but not enthusiastic," is the way officials of the National Association of Women's and Children's Apparel Salesmen describe their reaction to the response by hotel operators to their recent "be kind to salesmen" campaign.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 29 -- A nine-run outburst in the fifth inning, which three Columbia hurlers were unable to halt, sparked Princeton to a 9-4 victory over the Lions on University Field today. The triumph was the Tigers' third in Eastern League competition and extended their winning streak to five games.

NOW that the revival of the Ferenc Molnar play, "The Play's the Thing" is in the hit class, the comedy will, in all likelihood, be transferred to the screen under the aegis of Jesse L. Lasky and Walter MacEwen at RKO, it was learned last week.

COPENHAGEN, May 29 -- Denmark will play the role of mediator between the divergent views of Sweden and Norway on the formation of a Scandinavian bloc when Premier Tage Erlanger of Sweden, Foreign Minister Halvard M. Lange of Norway and Danish Premier Hans Hedtoft meet at Copenhagen June 5.

Teaching is the occupation preferred for the first time in many years by Barnard College graduates, according to a report yesterday by Mrs. Frederick Burgess, acting director of the Barnard College Occupation Bureau. She attributes the choice to widespread publicity about teacher shortages and the increased wage scales and improved conditions offered by many communities.

The New York Stock Exchange is having a volume of trading that is well ahead of last year. During the first five months of this year, volume exceeded 136,160,000 shares, compared with 107,886,916 shares traded in the comparable period in 1947.

WHEN his carefully planned campaign fails to win him a coveted membership in the Cobra Club, Jimmie Reynolds, a newcomer with imagination, decides to have his own club, the most exclusive one in the world. Jimmie himself is the only member and serves as president, vice president, secretary and treasurer.

"FALL RIVER LEGEND" is Agnes de Mille's sixth ballet and is pretty certain to have a long and popular life in the Ballet Theatre repertoire. Apparently Miss de Mille likes to range widely in subject matter and milieu.

Two policemen were injured badly shortly before 10 o'clock last night when the radio car in which they were speeding through West Twenty-third Street to the scene of a sidewalk fist fight was in collision with a small privatily operated bus at the intersection of Seventh Avenue.

The General Motors two-year-wage contract will lower the cost of living and stabilize business conditions. This conclusion by expert economists and engineers is based on the fact that in Sweden similar contracts, tied to a cost of living index, have had the effect of creating an incentive for manufacturers to lower prices rather than to raise them.

PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S recent message to Congress asking statehood for Alaska is of interest to the travel public that is daily becoming better acquainted with the northern territory as the result of the opening of routes to vacation areas.

The promising outlook for a continuance of the current high rate of dividends, in contrast with the prevailing low rates for money, is creating greater interest in dividend-paying stocks as a means of increasing investment income.

GENEVA, May 29 -- Nearly fifty standards of practice designed to facilitate international air travel have been agreed upon at the twenty-nation meeting here sponsored by the United Nations International Civil Aviation Organization.
DELAWARE, Ohio, May 29 (AP) -- Harrison Dillard and Gunther Katzmar paced the Yellow Jackets of Baldwin-Wallace College to their fifth straight Ohio Conference track and field championship today.

HELSINKI, Finland, May 29 -- The Conservatives of little Finland, aided and abetted by the Liberals and Social Democrats, last week did something unprecedented for any state, big or small, in Moscow's orbit -- they voted the Communist Interior (Police) Minister, Yrjoe Leino, out of the office he had been holding.

Bankers, resentful of the prompt and public offensive of savings and loan associations leaders, reacting to banking's "discreet" efforts to curb the activities of "an objectionable element" in the industry, are considering all-out retaliation, it became known yesterday. The difficulties, long standing, reached a climax last week at the annual convention of the National Savings and Loan League in Atlantic City.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Howard University here today announced the acquisition of the Spingarn Collection of more than 5,000 items of Negro literature and related curios which resulted from thirty-five years of systematic accumulation by Arthur B. Spingarn, a New York lawyer.
The Police Department paid its annual tribute yesterday to its members who died in the line of duty or while serving in the armed forces.
Local school and community campaigns to combat juvenile delinquency, reduce truancy and improve neighborhood conditions are being intensified throughout the city.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 29 -- A new policy of "self-imposed" decentralization has been adopted by the United States and British Military Governments in dealing with the decartelization problem. Richardson Bronson, United States chairman of the newly established bipartite decartelization branch, said big industries would be asked to suggest their own formulas for dispersal.

BERLIN, May 28 (Delayed) -- Facing a strong Soviet propaganda barrage that would have observers believing that unity at all costs was the wish of the average German, officials of the United States Military Government made avaliable tonight the results of their own survey on this question.

ITALY-BOUND American tourists who may be wondering what kind of vacation they can expect there this summer may find considerable reassurance in this report of a six-month visit to northern Italy. My total expenses, including ship passage both ways, amounted to $1,000.

An exhibit marking the 600th anniversary of the University of Prague has been opened at the New York Public Library. The display traces the history of the institution -- one of the oldest in the world -- through books in various languages, through illustrations and photographs of eminent men connected with the university and through photos and drawings of architectural changes since 1348.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture has allotted 1,083,000 long tons of grain and grain products for export to shortage areas in July. This is equal to 40,708,000 bushels.

Though I am convinced of Trygve Lie's sincerity in writing "Trygve Lie Appraises the Future of the U.N.," I question the advisability of his hiding the tragic facts behind a curtain of ill-advised optimism.

The bell tolls the death of democracy in Czechoslovakia today as an expected 7,000,000 voters go to the polls to approve Communist Premier Gottwald's single list of candidates for Parliament. Having used the democratic processes of campaign argument and secret ballot to gain a majority in the national legislature two years ago, the Communists now abandon all pretense to such bourgeois practices and impose the familiar totalitarian dictum of a "yes" vote or else.

IF radio enjoys one measure of reasonable stability, it is probably in the musical programs produced by Frank Hummert. Through the years they have gained a distinction quite their own. It is almost impossible to tell one program from another and they all feature the same type of selection.

PRICE increases, car shortages, distribution of new models and lack of parking space will be among the vexing problems considered at the twenty-fifth annual convention of the New York State Automobile Dealers, which opens on Tuesday at the Hotel Commodore.

ATLANTA, May 29 -- Georgia political circles were stirred this week by the reunion of the Ellis Arnall and E.D. Rivers factions, prompting suggestions that a battle may be in the making to seat a rival delegation in the Democratic National Convention pledged to support renomination of President Truman.
PARIS, May 29 (AP) -- Machine-like Frank Parker of Los Angeles won the French international tennis championship late today, defeating Czechoslovakia's Jaroslav Drobny, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5, 5 -- 7, 8 -- 6.

FINISH is to furniture what a hat is to a lady's costume or a wallpaper to a room. It makes all the difference sometimes in whether a piece is formal or informal, conspicuous or retiring, stereotyped or distinctive.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 (AP) -- Yale's sweep oarsmen and singles sculler Jack Kelly Jr., of Philadelphia monopolized the spotlight today in the renewal of the American Henley regatta on the Schuylkill River.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 29 -- Buses of five coach lines serving 40,000 daily commuters between New York City and Rockland County, N.Y., and northern New Jersey will roll tomorrow morning for the first time in eight weeks following settlement of the strike here today.

TWO French symphony orchestras are now booked to come to this country next season, The Orchestre National de Paris, which has been in the picture for the last three months, has reservations to leave France on the Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam Oct. 6.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 -- A brief protest marked the opening session of the Polish-American Congress today when Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, former vice premier of Poland, rose to speak. A man in the audience of 3,500 delegates and guests walked to an open microphone on a table in front of the stage and said in Polish:

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 29 -- It was estimated today that about 1,000 Jews fell into the hands of the Arabs when the Old City capitulated after a five-month siege. There were approximately 1,500 inhabitants, excluding a defense force of about 300 members of the Haganah and of Irgun Zvai Leumi.

WICHITA, Kans., May 29 -- Kansas, the first state in the nation to introduce constitutional prohibition and the last to attempt real enforcement, is being troubled by strong whiffs of whisky. The dilemma promises to turn the November repeal referendum into a three-ring circus and already has prompted some interesting political gyrations.
DETROIT, May 29 (AP) -- Chicagoans won a lion's share of prizes as the eighty-day American Bowling Congress ended today.

Dr. E.W. Gudger of the American Museum of Natural History writes in the Salmon and Trout Magazine that the earliest account of fly-fishing is probably one given by Claudius Aelianus, who lived in the early part of the third century A.D. and who wrote a zoology (De Natura Animalium) in seventeen books.
PRAGUE, May 29 (UP) -- The Second International Congress of Composers and Music Critics adopted a "Communist Manifesto of Music" today.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- John L. Lewis' apparent zigzag policy on a new wage agreement in the bituminous coal industry has confused many operators and Government officials. On the one hand it is felt that he wants an agreement before June 30 when the present contract expires.

WEEK-END gardening is fun. It is only when the business gets out of hand that the "man with the hoe" begins to wonder why he didn't stick to golf and gin rummy. Easy does it, if he is going to enjoy his week-ends this summer.

SUMMIT, N.J., May 29 -- Lou Barbaro and Bobby Jacobson of the Hollywood Country Club, last year's runner-up team, advanced to the semi-finals of the State pro-amateur match play golf championship at the Canoe Brook Country Club today.

Current news films show Princess Elizabeth standing before a microphone in Paris and reading a speech in French. She is saying: "La France et la Grande-Bretagne doivent prendre la direction de ce mouvement."

NEW YORK's theatrical season of 1947-48, as reckoned traditionally by the span of Actors' Equity contracts, will end tomorrow and, like its predecessors, it becomes fair game for the statisticians. Here, then, is the annual departmental post-mortem in statistical form.

In anticipation of the third and final report luncheon of the Greater New York Fund drive on June 11 in the Roosevelt Hotel, more than 12,000 volunteers are intensifying their solicitation of business concerns and employe groups in behalf of 423 local hospitals, health and welfare agencies, it was announced yesterday.

Although there are still many salmon rivers where a day's fishing hovers around the $100 mark, salmon fishing is no longer restricted by the dollar sign, for thousands of anglers with limited means and an itching foot will soon be dropping flies on waters from the Narraguagus to the Humber.
CINCINNATI, May 29 (AP) -- Johnny Vander Meer and Ewell Blackwell teamed behind home runs by Danny Litwhiler and Virgil Stallcup today to pitch the Reds to a 4-3 victory over the Cubs.
PITTSBURGH, May 29 (AP) -- The Pirates scored their first 1948 triumph over the league-leading Cardinals, 7 -- 3, today -- thanks to sharp pitching by Rookie Bob Chesnes.

The Congressional Record (published by the Government Printing Office) prints every word spoken in Congress -- and a lot that are unspoken, but are written out ("Extension of Remarks") for the benefit of home constituents.

WHEN Congress decided five years ago to hold back Prof. Robert Morss Lovett's pay, it collided with a set of convictions and a man behind them. The pay issue was a small one, "a little patch of ground that hath in it no profit but the name," but the former Government Secretary of the Virgin Islands took his case to the Supreme Court, where he won it as Franklin Roosevelt said he should.

FROM the vantage point of a DP camp the battles in Palestine are seen in a strange, intense light. For here in Germany is the largest single concentration of potential citizens for the new Palestinian state. And this group includes potential fighters also, as was shown the other day when the first detachment of volunteers left their DP camp to join the Haganah.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 29 -- The Smith College School for Social Work, now entering its thirtieth year of recognized leadership, is preparing to launch a new program in the field of professional education for social case work.

More than $2,000,000,000 in new equipment installations will be required in long-term construction projects to set up plant facilities to process low-grade iron ores, iron and steel experts revealed here yesterday. The production of the first pig iron from Taconite in Minnesota last week brought consideration of these projects to the forefront of events in ferrous industries.

MILWAUKEE, May 29 -- The Northern Baptist Convention urged today that "every possible avenue" of diplomatic interchange between the Soviet Union and the United States be kept open and "used to the fullest extent."
Freakish fog that had hampered the port's shipping and air traffic more than two days lifted yesterday before noon, permitting normal activity.

THE modern tall bearded iris is as revolutionary as it is evolutionary. A call this season at the garden of an iris fancier who has a collection of the newest sorts will amaze the visitor. A great improvement is to be found not only in increased range and variety of color but in form, size and substance, and in wind and rain resistant qualities.

One of the New York Giants' most ardent supporters, Isaac (Ike) N. Falk, was held up early yesterday morning near his home at 1342 Franklin Avenue, the Bronx, after attending the night ball game between the Giants and Phillies at the Polo Grounds.

THE many who have long lamented that "The Road" was so enfeebled as to require very tender and specialized ministrations may find it both appropriate and reassuring that the leading custodians of its destiny on the West Coast now are two erstwhile social workers.
St. John's bolstered it second place position in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference yesterday by building up an early lead to defeat Fordham, 10 to 6, at Fordham Field.

DEVON, Pa., May 29 -- An entry of Richard K. Mellon virtually clinched the hunter conformation championship of the Devon Horse Show and Country Fair today, but Mr. Mellon's Rolling Rock Farm failed tonight to retire a coveted trophy on which its horses had won two legs.

SEATTLE, May 29 -- Action throughout the denomination to increase ministers' salaries to bring them into line with rising costs of living was demanded today by the 160th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

THIS May the National Music League looks back upon a successful and fruitful decade of service. It is the pioneer organization of its kind in America. Its purpose is aiding young artists, on the basis of their actual merits, and not by coddling or speculating in talent, to develop careers.

The rags-to-riches saga of Bob Giegengack's poor little boys from Yale had a deliriously happy ending for the charged-up New Haven contingent yesterday when the Elis crashed through to their first Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. outdoor track and field title since 1924.

Careless handling of livestock by farmers and shippers costs the American public millions of dollars each year for shoes and other leather goods, maintains Dr. Fred O'Flaherty, director of the Tanners' Council of the American Laboratory of the University of Cincinnati.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 29 -- American women should abandon the notion that they are "martyrs" suffering unjust discriminations, Dr. M. Eunice Hilton, dean of women at Syracuse University, declared here today.

The Arab League invasion of Palestine fifteen days ago -- an invasion aimed at the new Republic of Israel -- started political shock waves that grew in ever-widening circles. Last week, far away from the Middle East, the shocks were felt in world chancelleries and at the United Nations.

A Catholic priest assisted in the capture early yesterday morning of a man suspected of stealing religious articles from the church of the clergyman. He trailed the alleged thief three blocks to the elevated platform of the Parkchester station of the IRT subway line in the Bronx.

LONDON, May 29 -- Nine members of the staff of the Czechoslovak Embassy in London resigned today for "political reasons." Their action was in part a protest against the manner in which the general elections will be held in Czechoslovakia tomorrow.

BUENOS AIRES, May 29 -- Argentina, through Miguel Miranda, head of the National Economic Council, today insisted that the current dollar shortage was transient. He promised that business restrictions growing out of it would end when United States credits, which this nation confidently expects, start to arrive.

A two-day conference on cell division, sponsored by the New York Academy of Sciences, ended yesterday afternoon after sixteen reports had been presented. They detailed advances on many fronts toward an understanding of what happens when a living cell reproduces.

NANKING, May 29 -- Despite an original attempt to anticipate the effects of the inflation, China's actual Government expenditures already have surpassed the record budgetary mark of $96,000,000,000,000 (Chinese) for the first half of 1948.

PRAGUE, May 29 -- Czechoslovakia will go to the polls tomorrow to vote for a single list of overwhelmingly Communist candidates. Citizens will be under pressure to vote "yes" both from fear of the possible consequences of voting "no" and from the fact that there are no opposition candidates.
CHICAGO, May 29 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- One of the wonders of Washington that the tourists don't see (not closely, anyway) is the files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Size alone puts these files in the phenomenon class.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Following are verbatim extracts from the transcript of testimony given by William Z. Foster, chairman of the Communist party of the United States, at a Senate judiciary subcommittee hearing Friday on the Mundt - Nixon Communist - control bill:

ST. LOUIS, May 29 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns used three pitchers to scatter three hits for the Detroit Tigers and defeated the visiting team, 6 -- 1, today. The victory elevated the Brownies to fourth place in the American League race, just ahead of Detroit.

SCARCELY a garden exists that at one time or another does not present a bare spot entirely devoid of any bloom. Although this condition may be unavoidable, there are times when a little foresight might have filled this expected gap in the garden picture with color.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29 -- There's blood on the moon tonight over the speedway where the 500-mile automobile classic will take place on Monday. With the entry list filled, many of the thirty-three contestants are brooding upon an attempt to sabotage the car of Ted Horn, Paterson, N.J., others envision the moonlight glistening on the white headstone of Ralph Hepburn in faraway California.

A Park Avenue elevator operator attempted suicide last night in a taxicab by pouring gasoline over himself and setting fire to his clothing. Severely burned, he was taken to Beth David Hospital in a critical condition.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Henry A. Wallace asserted today that the Mundt-Nixon Communist control bill was an offensive act in "the cold war against Russia."

IN prisons and in concentration camps, among the perils, the monotony, the anxieties of warfare, and now among the ruins of historic cities, the best minds of Europe have been meditating with unexampled intensity. They have seen Western civilization brought low, not by barbarous aliens, but by pseudo-scientific notions exploiting the intellectual and moral backwardness of neglected, rootless masses.

From the engineering laboratories of the General Electric Company comes the first radical improvement in electric meters made in fifty years. What distinguishes the new electric meter is a rotor which, like Mahomet's coffin, floats in the air.

Flood waters spread an ever-widening path of destruction over the Pacific Northwest yesterday, according to The Associated Press. Gov. Mon C. Wallgren of Washington declared a state emergency and Gov. C.A. Robbins proclaimed an emergency in the ten northern counties of Idaho.

PERCE, Quebec -- One of the largest bird sanctuaries on the continent lies within easy reach of the tourist making a trip to the tip of the Gaspe Peninsula. Here, at Perce Rock, just off the little French-Canadian fishing village of Perce, and at Bonaventure Island, three miles out to sea from Perce, are the last large breeding places of a great variety of seabirds.

HAVE you ever tried to explain anything to your family? Priscilla Wilson, a young lady of 11, denied the regular Saturday matinee as a punishment for having eaten out of the dog's dish, makes an attempt:

LONDON, May 29 -- It has been a truism for decades that when world affairs come to any sort of crisis the United States and Great Britain naturally find themselves allied. They fought two world was together; they are both democracies in the Western sense with the same traditions, the same conceptions of law and justice, the same social system, the same language, the same ideals.

Declaring that Memorial Day should serve as a warning against future war, rabbis in sermons here yesterday said the Arab assault on the new State of Israel was a threat to world peace and to, the authority of the United Nations.

FOR a play that has been mostly on the shelves since it first was unveiled before a not too sympathetic Broadway in 1930, Edwin Justus Mayer's "Children of Darkness" is showing remarkable vitality these days.

MICKEY, the horse who insisted on joining the United States Cavalry and charged to fame during the Spanish-American War, didn't stop there. Here is another rousing chapter in his career, based on true incidents related by Captain Ansel O'Banion (who knew Mickey in the Philippines) to Carl Glick.

One hundred sixty-two persons were injured, none seriously, at the Belmont Park race track yesterday afternoon in a stampede of spectators that began, unaccountably, after a minor scuffle broke out under the grandstand.

ALBANY, May 29 -- Governor Dewey recommended today to Tighe E. Woods, Federal housing expediter, the appointment of sixty-seven additional members of advisory boards of the defense rental areas in the state.

THE great public debate about our defense requirements is again fixing attention upon air power. The seventy-group Air Force program and Secretary of Defense Forrestal's "balanced force" have been the foci of Congressional discussion. Is a powerful air force, equipped with the atom bomb, enough to insure victory in war, or should we also maintain powerful surface forces?

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., May 29 -- A new best-in-show dog appeared when Mrs. Sherman Reese Hoyt of Stamford, Conn., named as winner of the annual Rockland County Kennel Club exhibition the brindle Scottish terrier Champion Deep Haven Red Seal, owned by the Marlu Farm Kennels of West Long Branch, N.J., and handled by Johnny Murphy.

As an art student I found Eric Newton on "What Is Modern Art?" most satisfying. Too many people, through their ignorance of the graphic art elements, line, color, and texture, find modern art perplexing and thereby distasteful.

Good initial response was reported to showings here last week of fall lines of women's apparel, including coats, suits and dresses. Many buyers were here, with the number of store representatives expected to increase following the holiday tomorrow.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 29 -- Cornell's misplays gave Yale two runs in the first of the ninth today, and the Elis won, 4 -- 3, for their fifth Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League victory in seven starts.
JERUSALEM, May 29 (AP) -- There are 30,000 to 90,000 Jews in the modern sections of the city. They are cut off from the main sources of Israeli strength along the Palestine coast.

Bill Rigney, Sid Gordon and 41-year-old Thornton Lee of the Giants combined efforts to give Ben Chapman's presumptuous Phillies a neat 7-to-1 going over in the second game of the current series at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

OMAHA, May 29 -- Recent moves aimed at scattering defense installations and war industries through the Midwest have intensified speculation that strictly civilian industries will follow suit. The prevailing opinion appears to be that such a trend, already discernible, will continue.

Fourth and last to the eighth pole, Vulcan's Forge was an astounding first at the end of the one-mile Withers at Belmont Park yesterday -- and Coaltown saved second money by only a fraction of an inch.

Returns of capital may be taxed under the Federal personal income tax law on a purely arbitrary basis. For example, payments received periodically from an annuity are deemed to be taxable income to the extent of 3 per cent of the cost of the annuity.

THE second motion picture in Hollywood's current anti-Communist cycle to reach the cameras is Edward Small's FBI Meets Scotland Yard," a moderately budgeted melodrama which started last week with a minimum of fanfare.
SUNDAY mornings between 8:30 and 9 o'clock a novel quiz show on WNEW is asking and answering questions based on the Bible. The quizmaster is a pastor. And the prizes are Bibles.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Following is the text of a document submitted by the State Department to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee listing alleged violations by the Soviet Union of international agreements:

New York State has offered free paint to the first 200 communities to participate in the 1948 air-marking program. The goal of the program begun last year is 700 air-marked towns on main air routes, and it needs every push it can get. Only 100 communities have been marked.

JONES BEACH STATE PARK, L.I. -- With the start of the athletic and entertainment programs today this oceanfront park featuring three miles of sandy beach -- just thirty-three miles from midtown Manhattan -- will be in full operation.

First-class passengers on the United States liner America on her passage here last week were deprived for a brief period of the expert attention of the ship's tonsorial artist, Joseph Amer, when he missed the last gangway in Havre.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., May 29 -- Harold E. Stassen sought new delegate strength today in Missouri, which he regards as a key state with New Jersey in his contest with Gov. Thomas E. Dewey for the Republican presidential nomination.

This is the day to salute those who died in battle that we might live in peace. As this Memorial Day rolls around, it is harder than ever for those of us who have survived two wars to feel worthy of the high-hearted boys who marched away to a hundred battlefields and never came back.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 29 -- Official word came from Indonesia today that the United Nations' first attempt at ending a war had been successful.

BACK in 1935 Francis E. Townsend was the focus both of paeans of praise and salvos of condemnation. His followers hailed him as an economic messiah. His foes considered him a dangerous visionary, the "Pied Piper of the depression."

Prof. William J. Fry and his engineering colleagues at the University of Illinois have found that infra-red rays can be detected by their virtually instantaneous effect on a gas confined between two vibrating quartz crystals. Eventually it may be possible in the same way to detect very short radio waves, such as those used in radar.
LONDON, May 29 -- Instead of the usual annual army maneuvers next year, there will be an all-Britain civil defense exercise in which army and civilian experts will cooperate.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 29 -- Six records were erased yesterday at the eighth annual Schenectady interscholastic track and field games on Union College's Alexander Field. Two other marks were equaled as Metropolitan New York athletes annexed eleven titles outright and shared another on the sixteen-event program.

BERLIN, May 29 -- The split in this city's labor unions between the Communists and independents was completed today when the independents sent letters to the four Military Governments informing them that they had assumed the leadership of the Freie Deutsche Gewerkschafts Bund [Free German Trade Union].
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 29 -- They raised the broom in token of a Navy sweep today and the East was left without an unbeaten varsity eight as Cornell finally met its master on the Severn.

PRETORIA, South Africa, May 29 -- Dr. Daniel F. Malan, it is now certain, will accept the invitation to form a new South African Government. He is due in Pretoria on Monday to consult with Governor General Gideon Brand van Zyl, but the composition of his Cabinet may not be announced for several days.

WHEN one nation has been the aggressor in two major wars in twenty-five years, public opinion is liable to turn against that country and denounce all its members as barbarians whose innate bellicose passions cannot be eradicated.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- A roll of more than two score direct and corollary treaty violations by the Soviet Union, in the eyes of the State Department, was placed before Congress and the public today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 29 -- Citation took the top money in the $50,000 added Jersey Stakes at Garden State Park today, and did it so easily that he didn't appear to be in a race at all.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 30 -There was a blackout on Jerusalem and Latrun news tonight although actions in both places were continuing. Jerusalem is under complete siege, with its Israeli defenders holding off the Arab Legion and units of the Egyptian and Iraqi armies.

There has long been an urgent need for additional judges for the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, and particularly for filling the vacancy caused by the death in March of Judge John Bright. For this post President Truman has now nominated Samuel H. Kaufman.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 30 -- A visitor from Chattanooga, Lewis Oehmig, who won the Tennessee amateur golf title in 1938, and his partner, Ray Graham of Meadow Brook, gained the semi-final round of the Meadow Brook Club's invitation member-guest best-ball tourney today.

FORT WORTH, Tex., May 30 (AP) -- Clayton Heafner of Charlotte, N.C., laid down his fourth straight sub-par round today to win $3,000 first money in the $15,000 Colonial National invitation golf tournament and set a record for the 72-hole grind at 272.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The question whether the European Recovery Program will get an appropriation equal to the $5,300,000,000 authorized for its first year of operation will move nearer a final answer this week.

HOLLYWOOD, May 30 -- Albert Lewin, co-head of the Metro-Gold-wyn-Mayer editorial board with Lawrence Weingarten, has announced that he will exercise his contractual right to take a nine-month leave of absence to make a film independently this year.

A threatened strike of 20,000 workers against four major carpet and rug manufacturers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut was called off last night after the employers agreed to a "package" wage increase of 13 1/2 cents an hour.

First steps toward a complete cooperative housing service were taken yesterday at the annual meeting of Eastern Cooperatives, Inc. It represents 50,000 members of consumer cooperatives in eleven northeastern states.

The heavy demands of America's military machinery for lubricating oils will be slightly less of a problem early in 1949 when the Cit-Con Oil Corporation begins operation of the world's largest refinery plant for production of solvent refined lubricating oils.
NEW ORLEANS, May 30 (UP) -- New Orleans said good-by last night to a rambling streetcar named "Desire."

Babis Papadamis, Greek baritone, assisted by his compatriots, Leon Cotomatas, tenor, and Manolis Diamantis, bass, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. Each of the vocalists was heard in Italian operatics arias and Greek folk songs, on a program also containing two Greek lyrics arranged as trios.
