Speaking from radio station WCBS, Elmo Roper, public opinion analyst, said yesterday that if the election were to be held today, President Truman, as the Democratic candidate for his present post, would be defeated by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Harold E. Stassen, Governor Dewey or Gen. Douglas MacArthur by a margin of about 10 per cent.

CHICAGO, May 30 -- Students who will be graduated from Northwestern University's dental school June 16 demonstrated last week their use of a new technique in which they have been trained to operate while in a seated position.

Jewish patriots who fought with and aided Colonial troops in the American Revolution were honored yesterday at a Memorial Day ceremony in the Spanish-Portuguese Congregation Shearith Israel's New Bowery Cemetery, founded in 1682 on a site granted to the Jews in 1656.

ZURICH, Switzerland, May 30 -- Animated discussion has been provoked in Switzerland by the announcement in Washington last Tuesday that the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development had placed with the Bank for International Settlements in Basle an issue of 2 1/2 per cent Swiss franc bonds at par, maturing in 1953 and 1954, for an aggregate amount of 17,000,000 Swiss francs.
Today, May 31, is the thirtysixth day of the Greater New York Fund's eleventh annual campaign in behalf of 423 local hospitals, health and welfare agencies.

The beginning of June tomorrow will find the season still offering many shows. Annual exhibitions and other group shows bulk large among the week's attractions. Most of the galleries will be closed today.

Jack Benny is assigned the highest score by the latest report of C.E. Hooper, Inc., on evening radio programs. The report grades the remainder in the top ten in this classification as follows: Walter Winchell, "Radio Theatre," "My Friend Irma," "Fibber McGee and Molly," "Amos 'n' Andy," Edgar Bergen, Bob Hope, Fred Allen and "Truth or Consequences."
WASHINGTON, May 30 (UP) -About thirty film and stage writers will file an anti-trust suit Tuesday in an effort to compel motion-picture producers to lift their ban on alleged Communist scenarists.

At this critical juncture of international affairs, it is safe to say that there are a great many people in both Russia and the United States who would welcome an exchange of views between their two governments on outstanding points of friction. It is equally safe to say that there are a great many people on both sides who would regard the protestations of the other party with extreme suspicion.

The 116th Commencement season of New York University will open Wednesday with the first of a series of class day exercises for the 8,000 senior students who will receive their degrees June 9, it was announced yesterday. The exercises, which will be held throughout the university's thirteen colleges and divisions, will feature the presentation of awards to outstanding students, and farewell addresses by students and faculty members.

Lieut. Gen. George E. Stratemeyer, commanding general of the Air Defense Command, with headquarters at Mitchel Field, asserted yesterday that, until the United Nations could develop into an effective instrument to assure peace, the United States "must be prepared to protect this wonderful country of ours and our own interests.''

Mrs. Natalie Wales Paine, president of Common Cause, Inc., released yesterday a statement accusing Senator William Langer of North Dakota of attempting to defeat selective service legislation by confusing it with the civil rights issue.

A survey of leading museums and private collections has been started here to gather a comprehensive collection of ancient and modern musical instruments for exhibition at Grand Central Palace as part of the city's World's Fair of Music.
New York paid solemn tribute to the city's war dead yesterday in Memorial Day ceremonies and in prayers and sermons at the city's churches.

CAIRO, May 30 (AP) -- Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, secretary-general of the Arab League, said tonight that "the Zionists who started this war in Palestine must be left alone to take the punishment they deserve."

Man's destiny is determined ultimately not by changes in the map of the world but by what happens to the souls of men, the Rev. Dr. Percy L. Urban, dean of Berkeley Divinity School, New Haven, Conn., declared yesterday in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- This Government's second note to the little Arab state of Lebanon has repeated the first demands for the immediate release of forty-one Americans seized at Beirut, the State Department disclosed today.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., May 30 (AP) -- Joe Van Blerck Jr., Freeport, N.Y., drove his 225-cubic-inch hydroplane Aljo V to victory in the Ocean City Yacht Club's forty-three-mile Fite memorial marathon today.

CARLSTADT, N.J., May 30 -- Vic Scott, veteran professional from Forest Hills, L.I., dominated the seventeenth annual spring regatta of the New Jersey Outboard Association on the Hackensack River here this afternoon, capturing both heats of the Class B five-mile races, both in Class C and one of the tests in the featured Class F race for the Jules Sargavy Memorial Trophy.
LONG BEACH, Calif., May 30 -Five years ago Yoshiko Tanigawa was in the detention camp for Japanese-Americans at Tule Lake, Calif.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 30 -- John A. Edwards, 45 years old, a cook, of 1985 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, whose altercation with a woman and a man yesterday at Belmont Park race track led to a near-riot in which 162 persons were injured, was arraigned here today before Judge Noman F. Lent in First District Court.

WARSAW, May 30 -- The Soviet Government, in an effort to cover the Russian peoples' increased purchasing power as a result of the devaluation of the ruble, has ordered a considerable amount of consumer goods from Poland and Czechoslovakia, it was learned today.
BERLIN, May 30 -- The Communists now say that by Friday night 8,663,461 persons in the Soviet zone, 72.5 per cent of those entitled to vote, had signed the petition for German unity.

JERUSALEM, May 30 -- The Security Council's cease-fire order, authoritative Israeli quarters pointed out today, left unanswered the question of the Tel Aviv-Jerusalem road, which is vital to the Jews of Jerusalem. It is for this road that the biggest and bloodiest battle of the Palestine conflict is now being fought.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 (AP) -- Facts and figures on the thirty-second annual 500-mile auto race at Indianapolis Motor Speedway tomorrow:

AMSTERDAM, May 30 -- Considerable interest has been aroused here by a visit to Washington by Hendrik van Manschot, manager of the Javasche Bank, who is reported to be negotiating a dollar loan in behalf of the Dutch East Indies.

With Clint Hartung, in his initial start this season, going all the way and pitching a creditable 9-hitter, the Giants overwhelmed the Phillies, 10 -- 4, yesterday at the Polo Grounds. This triumph, coupled with the double setback of the Cardinals, moved Mel Ott's team to within a half length of the league-leaders.
Three new films are scheduled to arrive in first run theatres this week. The programs follow:

ST. LOUIS, May 30 (AP) -- Plans for a non-professional baseball world series to be held at either Havana, Cuba, or Caracas, Venezuela, in September, 1949, were approved today by Global Commissioner J.G. Taylor Spink.

Results of a survey on how newspapers handle radio program listings, now being conducted by the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association, will prompt many publishers to drop or limit free listings, a check of newspaper representatives disclosed last week.

Have not some of us become completely oblivious of the facts of life and world trade? Mr. Hull's program of so-called reciprocity has been repeatedly beclouded with high-sounding platitudes such as you have expressed.

ST. ANNE'S ON THE SEA, England, May 30 (UP) -- Nine American women stars, fresh from a resounding triumph in the Curtis Cup matches against England, were getting set today to tee off in the first round of the British women's amateur golf championships tomorrow.
LEXINGTON, Mo., May 30 (AP) -- Wally Bostwick, Modesto, Calif., downed two opponents today to reach the singles final in the National Junior College Tennis Tournament at Wentworth Military Academy.

BOSTON, May 30 -- Rained out of the finale of the three-game series here, the Dodgers left for home on the 2 o'clock train today. They play host to the second-place Giants in morning and afternoon games tomorrow. The contests start at 10:30 o'clock and 3 o'clock, respectively.
BERLIN, May 30 -- Negroes and Russians are taking the place of the Jews as "scapegoat" groups for the Germans, according to an American Military Government survey made available today.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- By land, sea and air thousands of aliens are trying to get into this country illegally. Some make it but most do not.

The Rev. Dr. Edward J. Jurji, Professor of Comparative Religions at Princeton Theological Seminary, decried yesterday the threat of force that Russia and the United States are urging upon the United Nations as a solution to the Palestine problem.

LONDON, Monday, May 31 -Viscountess Astor said today that she had found on her recent three-month visit to the United States that events in Palestine had created "anti-Semitic feeling throughout America" that was "so dangerous that many people are positively frightened of it."
WITH THE ARAB LEGION, in Central Palestine, May 30 -- Allied Arab forces appeared tonight to be grouping for the battle of Tel Aviv, the civil and military headquarters of the new State of Israel.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- At least one out of every four American families probably will overspend its income this year, according to analysts of the Federal Reserve Board.

Recommending strongly a broad anticartel policy by the United States, members of the Twentieth Century Fund's special committee on cartels and monopoly declared in a report made public over the week-end that support by the United States of the International Trade Organization is essential to such a policy.

Senator Robert A. Taft was the only contestant for the Republican nomination for President to make a definite gain in delegates elected last week, adding thirty of the thirty-three Texas delegates to his first-ballot support.

DETROIT, May 30 (AP) -- The United Auto Workers, CIO, announced today that its argeement with the Chrysler Corporation for a wage increase of 13 cents an hour was virtually assured of ratification by 75,000 workers. Enough Chrysler locals meeting today reported overwhelming approval of the settlement to insure its adoption, a union spokesman reported.

From the spacious days of Henry Irving and Ellen Terry, Dame May Whitty moved into the modern world and the new medium of the screen. Through that she was able to display for millions the full perfection of the older and richer art of the theater.

SEATTLE, May 30 -- A "different kind of Christianity" was demanded today to meet the needs in the "rubble and confusion" of the postwar world in the first sermon by the Rev. D. Jesse H. Baird of San Anselmo, Calif., as moderator of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Eniwetok and the breakdown of atomic energy control negotiations in the United Nations are likely to mean a bill to the American taxpayer of two and a half to three billion dollars for atomic energy development in the "next several" years.

Clifford Odets is coming back next week to the Broadway he deserted for Hollywood in 1942 after a playwriting career that blazed a bright path through the Thirties. This time, his back turned to the film industry, he plans to stay. With him will be a new play to be produced and directed by Harold Clurman, who staged virtually all his plays for the Group Theatre.
LONDON, May 30 -- In the last few days the stock market here have lost to some extent the firmness that they had consistently, displayed in recent weeks.

TROY, N.Y., May 30 -- "Fear could lead an open society like our own to destroy its most precious assets in a struggle with a closed society of Nazi or Soviet type," Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College declared in giving the principal address at the commencement of Russell Sage College today.

ALEXIS THOMPSON is a rather singular character. He is young, personable, handsome, intelligent and -- this doesn't hurt a bit, either -- a millionaire. Even the fact that he owns the Philadelphia Eagles pro football team hasn't aged him although it took him the longest while to get the once-bedraggled Eagles off the ground and fluttering their wings in approved style.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 30 (UP) -- Defense forces here were alerted and border precautions were redoubled today as result of a "war scare" yesterday that led to the arrest of 220 alleged Communists and the discovery of a large cache of submachine-guns.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 30 -- War-built Vanport City, five miles north of here, was submerged late this afternoon by flood waters of the Columbia River.
PHILADELPHIA, May 30 -- The Yankees found the answer to the Philadelphia story today, but they needed the aid of the elements in the solution.

CINCINNATI, May 30 (AP) -Cincinnati's Redlegs swept both ends of a double-header, defeating the Cubs, 6 -- 1 and 8 -- 3, today before a Memorial Sunday crowd of 19,378. Home runs by Grady Hatton and Howie Schultz provided first game scores, while ten hits off three hurlers gave the Reds their second game victory.

A drive to raise $185,000 for repairs to St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street, will be started this week, it was announced yesterday at the morning service.

PEIPING, May 30 -- North China university students today joined a movement already started by Shanghai students to oppose American policy in Japan. Some 2,000 students representing eleven North China colleges met this afternoon on the National Peiping University campus and heard messages drafted by their student leaders to Gen. Douglas MacArthur, Secretary Marshall and the American people.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 30 -- A "Freedom Garden" movement in the Elizabeth area, advocated by Fred D. Osman, Union County agricultural agent, has made little headway, Thomas E. Collins, city engineer who directed the wartime Victory Garden program here, admitted today.

Despite the absence of Soviet influences at the inter-American conference at Bogota, the United States and Latin America failed in the fight for democracy, Dr. Samuel Guy Inman asserted yesterday. He was guest preacher at the Park Avenue Christian Church of the Disciples of Christ, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 30 -- The Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, and Robert Moses, New York Park Commissioner and chairman of the Long Island State Park Commission, received the first honorary degrees to be granted by Hofstra College here, at its thirteenth annual commencement exercises this afternoon.
LONDON, May 30 (AP) -- Thousands of Europeans gathered on a Memorial Day of alternating sunshine and rain today to honor United States war dead at dozens of cemeteries.

LONGMEADOW, Mass., May 30 (AP) -- Gen. Omar Bradley warned today against the United States ever "stooping to expedients" to avoid the difficult decisions that come with world leadership or the heavy burdens that come with defense.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., May 30 (AP) -- Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas said today that Americans must dispel post-war fears by bold, vigorous action to make democracy work.
PHILADELPHIA, May 30 -- The huge demand for rooms during the national Republican convention has sent prices skyrocketing to fantastic levels.

PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., May 30 -- Nearly 300 students became the first graduates of the first "GI university" in the country this afternoon when appropriate ceremonies were held on the campus of Champlain College, one of the three institutions of the Associated Colleges of Upper New York.

PRAGUE, Monday, May 31 -- Czechs and Slovaks to an overwhelming extent chose to vote publicly yesterday in the presence of Government election committees rather than in voting booths and gave the Government its expected immense majority for the single Communist-dominated National Front list of deputies for the new Parliament.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 30 (AP) -- Deaths were reported tonight in the flood at Vanport City as disaster workers combed the houses.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- President Truman, after placing a Memorial Day wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier today, declared that the United States must have the ability to enforce the world peace for which it has always stood.

MILWAUKEE, May 30 -- The Church must either "evangelize" the world's leading scientists and political leaders or face the threat of destruction through the misuse of atomic power, the Rev. Dr. Samuel Macaulay Lindsay of Brookline, Mass., said here today.

The mechanism of the crosstown swing bridge over the Harlem River, known as the University Heights Bridge, connecting Manhattan and the Bronx, got out of order yesterday morning for fifty minutes, causing a holiday traffic snarl, particularly on the Manhattan side.
CHARD, England, May 30 -- Cut deep in the sunny hills of Somerset this little town is stirring with a new prosperity based on high farm prices, full employment and the rising hum of industry.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 -Lieut. Gov. Arthur W. Coolidge of Massachusetts declared today at the Polish-American Congress here that the Communist-controlled Government of Poland "has embarked on a new campaign to poison the minds of children."

With the holiday traffic casualty toll still unreckoned it is not too late to make another plea for caution during the time remaining before the use of motor cars returns to non-holiday normal. That earnest effort can bring a reward in lives saved is proved by the fact, that in spite of the traffic toll that cost 32,000 deaths last year, there is ground for encouragement when one takes the long-range view.

This year marks the hundredth anniversary of the birth of Robert W. de Forest, civil servant, patron of art and pioneer in social service. Because he distinguished himself in all these fields and contributed so notably to the social welfare and cultural life of this city he was often referred to as "New York's first citizen."

PARIS, May 30 -- Many observers here say that fear that Western German recovery might put France in a secondary position industrially is the basic reason for French reluctance to approve the rapid organization of a Western German state and the restoration of large seals production in the Ruhr.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 30 -- Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, paid a surprise visit here today to Alfred M. Landon. The Republican's Presidential nominee in 1936 forecast an early deadlock at Philadelphia, and "battle royal" over the GOP Presidential selection this year.

For several hours yesterday the Simpson Street Precinct in the Bronx took on the unscheduled appearance of a children's nursery, for in this period one lost boy and five abandoned children turned up at the police station.

PITTSBURGH, May 30 -- A few months ago steel companies were getting to a point where carryovers -- material promised for one month but carried over to the next -- were becoming smaller if not disappearing. In recent weeks, however, because of the coal strike some plants found that carryovers were on the upgrade.

The "new democracy" was well exemplified in the choiceless election held in Czechoslovakia yesterday. Of other countries in which the Soviet form of voting has been imposed, it is frequently said that they never had much democracy, anyway. The "reactionary governments" of the past are mentioned to imply that the citizens are hardly worse off under the rigid one-party rule of today.

Chocolate and vanilla are a standard combination when a contrast in taste is desired. In cake and cookies the two flavors go well together for another reason, too -- the colors, dark and light, may be molded into a variety of interesting patterns.

Underground streams of water flow deep in the earth between layers of rock. Veins come to the surface high on hillsides and springs of cold water start the long journey to the sea. The birthing of mighty rivers is a humble affair, but as little streams join to form small brooks and brooks come together to form creeks, which in turn are the lifeblood of rivers, the cycle is fulfilled.

The Marine Inventory Association, a group of steamship inventory men, was formed last week at a meeting held Thursday at the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street, it was announced yesterday by Harry C. Bloom, manager of the inventory department of the Alcoa Steamship Company and chairman of the board of the newly formed association.

LONDON, May 30 -- The Raw Cotton Commission announced today that beginning tomorrow its issue prices for Egyptian Zagora cotton would be reduced by 9 pence (about 15 cents) a pound to 25.9 pence. Prices for Egyptian Ashmouni cotton will be reduced 5 pence a pound to 34.75 pence.

PARIS, May 30 (UP) -- Mrs. Patricia Canning Todd, who caused an international sports storm three days ago when she withdrew from the women's singles, had a hand in winning two doubles titles today on the final day of the French international tennis championships.

ROME, May 30 -- Pope Pius XII today urged the Hungarian people to continue opposing the anticlerical campaign unleashed by their Communist Government as part of a policy designed to bring about the country's Bolshevization.

A police drive on the illegal sale and discharge of fireworks, said to be particularly widespread in the Bronx, was reported yesterday to have brought the first arrest of the season here on such a charge.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., May 30 -Mrs. Lancaster Andrew's hound Ch. Aristo von Marienlust was named best in show today at the sixth annual dog show of the Mid-Hudson Kennel Club, held in Springbrook Park. Stanley J. Halle of New York City was the best in show judge.

PRETORIA, South Africa, May 30 -- Gen. Thomas Holcomb, retiring United States Minister and dean of the diplomatic corps here, left by air for New York this morning with Mrs. Holcomb. They intend to live on their farm in Maryland.

MOSCOW, May 30 (UP) -- Two Armenian scientists, brothers, have received the award of a 200,000 ruble [$40,000] Stalin Prize for cosmic ray studies that led to their discovering a series of particles that clarify understanding of the structure of the atom.

SINGAPORE, May 30 -- Replyling to criticism of Malaya's special export duty on tin ore made in the United States Senate Armed Services Subcommittee last week, C.J. Pyke, economic adviser to the Malayan Federation, said today that the duty was no new invention directed at the Texas tin smelter. The duty, he pointed out, had been imposed forty years ago to protect the development of the Malayan smelters.

In an election which made a greater mockery of the democratic process than anything ever staged in Nazi Germany or Soviet Russia, the people of Czechoslovakia, once a model democracy, were constrained yesterday to record the same overwhelming majority for their new Communist masters that has become a familiar phenomenon in all states under a totalitarian regime, whether of the left or the right.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., May 30 -- Ten thousand persons attended this afternoon the twelfth annual memorial service at the National Cemetery in Pinelawn. The exercises were held in the rain at a rostrum in the northern section.

Certainly the city needs new school buildings -- not only in Morningside Heights on the Hudson, but in a number of other sections not so fortunately located. Your editorial welcome to Morningside Heights, Inc., and its work under the leadership of David Rockefeller will be seconded by all existing groups of citizens laboring for many years in behalf of public education.

In a manifesto released on May 25, the Railway Labor Executives Association, which purportedly speaks for "an overwhelming majority'' of the nation's rail workers, demanded that, as a matter of permanent policy, the Federal Government take over the ownership and operation of the country's railroads.
A 16-year-old youth with a juvenile delinquency record was charged yesterday with burglary and held in $10,000 bail in the Youth Term section of the Bronx Magistrates Court.

CHICAGO, May 30 -- Corn assumed leadership in the grain markets on the Board of Trade last week, rallying strongly after an early decline, while wheat and oats held within a range of around 3 cents for the week. Outside interest in the markets was comparatively light, with weather conditions and professional operations largely responsible for rapid price changes.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -- An outpouring of confidence and rivalry was displayed today by the thirty-three carefully groomed contestants who will ride tomorrow in the thirty-second annual 500-mile automobile classic at the speedway here.

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) -- The Indians, with twenty-one players appearing in the line-up, used a nine-run eighth inning to defeat the White Sox, 13 -- 8, in the second game of a double-header today. Chicago kayoed Bob Feller to win the opener, 4 -- 2, before 36,780 fans.

"The Power of the People" by J. Howard McGrath, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, will be brought out by Declan X. McMullen on June 30. It is a discussion of the background of politics, with emphasis on the Democratic party, from the time of Jefferson to the present.

MUNICH, Germany, May 30 -- Earliest returns in the municipal council elections in the larger communities of Bavaria today indicated that the Communist party had gained considerable strength, while the newly chartered Bavarian party had won much support in upper Bavaria at the expense of the Christian Social Union.

CHICAGO, May 30 -- President Truman repeated his advocacy of a national health program -- to reach all citizens in a greeting to the 1948 biennial nursing convention, which opens here tomorrow. More than 10,000 registered professional nurses are expected for the five-day meeting.

LONDON, May 30 -- The National Coal Board acknowledged today that it had unnecessarily ordered $8,000,000 worth of coal conveyor belting from the United States through a deliberately "generous" miscalculation.

DENVER, May 30 -- Dealing with what he called the effect of "international big business" on United States foreign policy, Henry A. Wallace assailed metal, oil and steel "trusts" and big airplane companies here tonight in an addreess before delegates to the Colorado third party convention.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -Washington swept a four-game series with Boston today as Early Wynn limited the Red Sox to five hits for an 8-1 victory. Ed Stewart and Gil Coan blasted home runs for the Senators, who dealt Denny Galehouse his third defeat without a triumph.

Ralph M. Heintz, vice president of Jack Heintz Precision Industries, Inc., Cleveland, has been relieved of his administrative duties to permit him to concentrate on research and development activities of the company.

The principles of Moral Re-Armament offer the best hope of combating Communist ideology and ameliorating the economic and political ills of the world. This was the composite view of delegates from ten European countries who arrived here yesterday on their way to a World Assembly marking the tenth anniversary of Moral Re-Armament that begins next week in California.

Capt. John Murphy, who first went to sea sixty years ago out of Dublin on the bark Belle Star, is scheduled to observe his seventy-fifth birthday somewhere along the east coast of Africa on June 27 aboard his latest command, the Earlham Victory.
College track talent in this Olympic year centers in the Middle West and Pacific Coast, but with strong support in the East, South and Southwest, The Associated Press states.

Under a new merchandising plan, one of the leading light machine tool manufacturers has increased the dealers' gross margin of profit on sales of his motorized machine tools by increasing the distributors' discount on electric motors from 15 per cent to 30 per cent, distributors revealed over the week-end.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 30 -- Harry Moore's Luders 16-footer Mist, Henry Malloy's 110 Corsair. Charles Tipke's Wee Scot Chase Me and Charles Portman's Dorinda IV and Niels Fossum's Terry in the two Lightning Divisions were the only winners today in A.Y.R.A. championship regatta conducted by in Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 30 -- The Indonesian Republic issued a statement here today charging the Netherlands Government with violating the Renville truce agreement by excluding Republican representatives from a Federal conference in Bandung, West Java.

JERUSALEM, May 30 -- Dr. Abraham Laufer of Hadassah, who was in charge of Jewish hospital facilities in the Old City for the last five weeks, told a press conference today that the medical situation had not been a factor in the decision to surrender.

The fleet and clever Liverpool Football Club of England scored its fifth triumph in this country by drubbing the American Soccer League All-Stars, 9 -- 2, at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.
MEXICO CITY, May 30 -- Plans for creating many new Mexican industries are being tied in with trade negotiations presently being conducted here by Mexican and United States Government officials.
A combination Columbia crew won the race for college varsity eights in the annual Memorial Day regatta of the New York Rowing Association on the Harlem yesterday.
PARIS, May 30 -- Memorial Day services were held today in eight World War II and five World War I military cemeteries in various parts of France.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- The first major shipments of industrial raw materials for European recovery were approved today as part of a $39,647,541 authorization for five countries.

"The stupidity of a large group of people here in the East, who are breaking their backs to keep God and His Christ out of American schools," was deplored by the Rev. Arthur J. McGratty in a sermon yesterday at a solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The six-story English basement dwelling on a lot 30 by 100.5 feet at 19 East Seventieth Street was sold by Mrs. Dave H. Morris to the Fejems Corporation, which insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

PEIPING, May 20 -- Chinese authorities here say that in the Nationalist area of northern Hopeh the situation, militarily and economically, is better now than it was a year ago. The area includes Peiping, Tientsin, Paoting, Chinwangtao and Shanhaikwan with connecting roads and railways and the surrounding hinterland.
HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., May 30 -Dr. Wilbour E. Saunders, headmaster of the Peddie School, presented honor awards to sixty-one students here today.

ATHENS, May 30 -- First Division headquarters at Lamia reported today that Army units had attacked rebels in the Mount Orthrys area of east central Greece and in a brief battle had killed eighteen and captured twenty-three.

ST. LOUIS, May 30 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser worked his way out of an eleventh-inning threat after Pat Mullin furnished a two-run lead with single in the top of the frame giving the Tigers a 6-to-4 victory over the Browns today. The triumph put Detroit back up in fourth place, dropping St. Louis back to fifth.

BATAVIA, Java, May 30 (Reuters) -- An Indonesian announcement that the Republic was recalling its Prague representative, Dr. Suripino, who recently was reported to have arranged an exchange of consuls between the Soviet Union and the Republic, is considered "absolutely unsatisfactory" by the Dutch.
There is more to the situation about newsprint for the European press, including British newspapers, than appears on the surface in the letter of Mr. Galantiere in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 24.

JERUSALEM, May 29 (Delayed) -- Old Mr. Katz was sitting in a barber shop reading the Palestine Post waiting to be shaved yesterday when an Arab artillery shell crashed through the window. The barber and the man in the chair were killed and Mr. Katz got a jagged piece of metal in his stomach.

Foreign freight forwarders in this area are considerably concerned over the recommendation be Maritime Commission trial examiners that the commission should seek legislative authority for their licensing, it was learned yesterday.

NANKING, May 30 -- The $125,000,000 "no strings" allotment in Washington's China aid program has been tentatively split up by the Chinese High Command into $87,500,000 for ground forces, $28,000,000 for the air force and $9,500,000 for the navy.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 30 -- Increasing doubts were expressed today in United Nations circles that the Arabs or Israel would accept the latest Security Council appeal for a four-week cessation of fighting. Most officials and delegates here, however, were hopefully keeping their fingers crossed.

The decision by the nation's distillers to begin a joint educational advertising program is the strongest break yet made in a longstanding policy of enduring "dry" attacks with cautious silence, industry spokesmen declared last week.
Columbia College will hold its annual class day exercises for 500 graduating seniors today at 10:30 A.M. in the Van Amringe Quadrangle.
VANCOUVER, B.C., May 30 (Canadian Press) -- Thousands toiled during the week-end to prevent further damage in the flood-devastated Fraser Valley.
LONDON, May 30 -- Dr. Israel Brodie, senior Jewish chaplain to the British armed forces, was unanimously elected Chief Rabbi of the British Empire today by delegates of Hebrew congregations.
Growing transatlantic air services accounted for a larger share of travel in 1947 than in any previous year, according to figures just issued on the twelve months steamship and air travel.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- A pipeline to carry natural gas in large quantities from the Gulf coast to the New York metropolitan area and other Middle Atlantic points had the approval today of the Federal Power Commission.
LONDON, May 30 (Reuters) -Track and field is easily the most popular choice of the seventeen sports open to the fifty-eight competing nations in the forthcoming Olympic Games here.

Six seminary students, including a 43-year-old New York emergency squad patrolman, were ordained as deacons yesterday afternoon in the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Evenue and Eighty-sixth Street, at ceremonies marking the close of the 149th annual New York Methodist Conference.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 -Bing Crosby, Joe E. Brown and a lot of other important names of the entertainment and sports world will put on a big golfing show here tomorrow because a smiling little fellow called Ben Coltrin passed away a few weeks ago.

The public is confronted with one more stark instance of the present financial plight of hospitals through the annual report of Roosevelt Hospital, a 411-bed institution at Fifty-ninth Street and Ninth Avenue. This institution, which in one way or another serves the theatre zone, some industrial territory and both luxury and tenement residential areas, had an operating deficit last year of $296,000.

When President Truman said that the death in 1943 of the four chaplains on the doomed ship Dorchester was "the greatest sermon ever preached" he doubtless was "thinking in human terms," the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said yesterday in his sermon in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, of which he is the pastor.

Henry A. Wallace, who has staked his political career as a candidate for the Presidency on championing the understanding of the Russians, is the latest victim of the official Soviet campaign to claim for Russia all scientific and technological discovery, it became known yesterday.

The ever-changing pageantry of the heavens will be represented in "Color in the Sky," the June show of the Hayden Planetarium, Eighty-first Street and Central Park West, beginning tomorrow, Gordon A. Atwater, chairman and curator, announced yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 30 (AP) -- Jersey City captured both ends of a double-header from Newark today, taking the opener, 6 -- 5, and the nightcap, which was called at the end of the fifth because of rain and darkness, by 6 -- 3.

The Mabel C. Evans estate of about three acres fronting on Woodmere Boulevard, Brower Point Beach and Barberry Lane, in Woodsburgh, L.I., has been purchased by an investing client of Eugene A. Hegy, broker in the all cash transaction.
PITTSBURGH, May 30 (AP) -- The Pirates whittled the Cardinal's National League lead to a half game today as they dumped the Redbirds in both ends of a double-header, 9 to 3 and 7 to 6.

RALEIGH, N.C., May 30 -- North Carolina Democrats yesterday nominated former Gov. J. Melville Broughton to fill the unexpired term of Senator J.W. Bailey, who died at the end of 1946, and to serve the six-year term beginning on Jan. 3, 1949.

TOKYO, May 30 -- Indications are piling up that the deconcentration of Japanese industry will be far less drastic than was at first planned. Already fifty of the original 325 companies designated for reorganization have been told that they will not need to make any changes.
OBAN, Scotland, May 30 P)-Unity Mitford died a lonely figure who spent most of her time walking the windswept moors with her spaniels.

LONDON, May 30 -- Issues of new securities calling for capital are showing signs of working up to the usual mid-summer climax. This year they promise to be heavier than at any time since the end of the last war. So far they have been a stimulating influence in the markets, but now they are beginning to have a reverse effect.

Cotton prices closed last week with only minor net changes. At the end of trading on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes from the previous week ranging from a decline of 27 to an advance of 14 points. Distant July delivery registered the only net gain.
WINNIPEG, May 31 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's total national income will probably reach a new high of more than $15,000,000,000 this year, Trade Minister C.D. Howe predicted here tonight.
Delegates representing 15,677 New York wholesale and warehouse workers voted unanimously yesterday to endorse the third party headed by Henry A. Wallace.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 31 -Horizon Pictures, the John Huston-Sam Spiegel company, has closed a deal for John Garfield to star with Jennifer Jones in "Rough Sketch," the firm's first production for Columbia release, which will start in August.
ATLANTA, May 31 (AP) -- The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States (South) today voted down a proposal to withdraw from the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

TORONTO, May 31 -Although the Canadian International Trade Fair only opened for business yesterday, thousands of orders running into an unofficial estimate of over a million dollars were placed the first day of business.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 31 -Six members of Garden City families received Gold Star lapel buttons at a Memorial Day ceremony here today. Lieut. Gen. George E. Stratemeyer, head of the Air Defense Command, made the presentations.
STANTON, Del., May 31 (AP) -- The racing silks of Bayard Sharp, a director of Delaware Park, were carried to an easy victory by Tide Rips in the featured Brandywine Handicap today.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Senator Taft, Ohio, came out today for a detailed Republican platform which would make the Democrats "get specific" in their Presidential campaign pledges.
The long Memorial Day week-end closed last night with the traditional homeward-bound rush.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Success of the United Nations will rest eventually on efforts to improve the quality of participation of the members," rather than on any amendment of the Charter, Warren R. Austin, chief of the United States delegation, said here today.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 31 (AP) -- Shannon II, a long-tailed campaigner from Australia, redeemed himself today with a sparkling victory in the $50,000 Argonaut Handicap at Hollywood Park before a record-breaking crowd of 71,789.

JERSEY CITY, May 31 (AP) -- Newark snapped Jersey City's fivegame winning streak today, taking the opening game of a doubleheader, 9 -- 2. The second game was called at the end of the sixth inning because of darkness with the score knotted at 2 -- 2.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics bounced out of the American League lead today and then quickly recaptured the top spot as Joe Coleman notched his sixth victory of the year, beating the Boston Red Sox, 2 -- 1, in the second game of a holiday twin bill.

CINCINNATI, May 31 (AP) -Nippy Jones' eighth-inning single spoiled Ken Raffensberger's try for a no-hitter today as the Cincinnati Reds took both ends of a double-header from the St. Louis Cardinals, 4 -- 3 and 7 -- 0, before a Memorial Day crowd of 24,009.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 31 -- While Israel fighter and bomber planes carried out a series of attacks at vital points from Ramleh to Tulkarm, land forces penetrated Arab Illies at Latrun today, burned a village and a police station and withdrew, leaving about 150 Arab dead.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 31 -- Floods which have left at least 60,000 persons homeless and caused an estimated $75,000,000 damage forced new evacuations in a score of Washington and Oregon cities tonight and hampered the search for possible dead in the ruins of Vanport.
Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, newly crowned British amateur golf champion, arrived by plane yesterday with the big trophy he won last week at Sandwich, England.

ALBANY, May 31 -- Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Commissioner of Health, announced today that preparations had been completed for the official transfer tomorrow of Broadacres Sanatorium, Utica, from Oneida County to the state. The transfer was requested formally by the County Board of Supervisors in January, 1947.
There was no catching Arnold Hanger's Harmonica in the sixty-second edition of the $50,000-added Suburban Handicap yesterday.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., May 31 -Charles Edison, former Governor of New Jersey and former Secretary of the Navy, urged today that the United States revitalize the principles of freedom, justice and tolerance on which the nation was founded. In a memorial address at the Chelbert-Battle Post of the American Legion of Sag Harbor, he called on the nation to "resell America to Americans and to the world."

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 31 (UP) -- Count Folke Bernadotte, Swedish Mediator for the United Nations, consulted with Premier David Ben-Gurion and Foreign Minister Moshe Shertok here shortly after his arrival from Haifa.

Paul Palmer, an editor of The Reader's Digest, has purchased the property of Alice E. Szekacs in Poundridge, N.Y. The main house, containing fourteen rooms and six baths, was built in 1810 and remodeled in 1947.

For twenty years the Little Red School House at 196 Bleecker Street and its younger affiliate, the Elisabeth Irwin High School at 40 Charlton Street, both in Greenwich Village, have been pace-setters in progressive education. The school became famous for adopting the new approach in education long before the idea was generally acceptable in the public schools.

Enlarged trade can do much to relieve the tension and contribute toward the peace to which all peoples aspire. The differences between Russia and the United States are fundamental and should not be glossed over. We can never tolerate police-state methods and ideals; nor will Russia, as now governed, permit democratic capitalism within her borders.

An intensive newspaper campaign for American Tobacco Company's Lucky Strike cigarettes is scheduled to break the week of June 7 and continue for twenty-four weeks thereafter. Magazines, newspaper Sunday supplements, car cards and spot radio announcements will also be used in addition to Your Hit Parade and Jack Benny radio programs.

Although more than half of Broadway's shows played holiday matinees yesterday, thereby spreading out somewhat the potential box-office returns, business proved generally excellent, according to a survey of the various theatres. The favorable reaction was attributed by many managers to the inclement weather, which kept people away from the ball parks and beaches, and to the large influx of out-of-town visitors.
LONDON, May 31 -- It might cost King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan something like 1,660,000 ($6,640,000) to continue his war in Palestine in defiance of Great Britain and the United Nations.

CHICAGO, May 31 -- Some kind of health insurance is inevitable, and unless voluntary prepaid health plans meet the demand within the next three years, large labor organizations will press for a program of compulsory Government health insurance.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 31 -- A more conciliatory mood has been noticed recently among Yugoslav officials dealing with Yugoslav-United States relations. Although no agreements of any importance have been reached to break the logjam of disagreements that has brought relations between the two countries to a dead point, there appears to be some improvement in personal contacts between Yugoslav and United States officials.

SUMMIT, N.J., May 31 -- Hal Sanderson and Dr. Stephen G. (Jerry) Lee of Canoe Brook won the New Jersey State pro-amateur match play golf championship for the second time today when they defeated Lou Barbaro and Bobby Jacobson of Hollywood, 5 and 4.

In the days of the Czar, Russians did their best to convince the West that they were not semi-Asiatic barbarians. They made the most of their academy of sciences, which is now an integral part of the Soviet Government and which rules every laboratory from Vladivostock to Odessa; they pointed to some of their distinguished physicists, chemists, and astronomers; they devised turbine locomotives and rocket ships before Germany, Great Britain and the United States.

LONDON, May 31 -- Orde Jonathan Ben-Zion Wingate, 4-year-old son of one of the Christian heroes of the Zionist movement, the late Maj. Gen. Orde C. Wingate, is to be reared in a Jewish collective settlement in Palestine, his mother was reported today to have told a meeting in Tel Aviv.

LONDON, May 31 -- The return of Hugh Dalton, former Chancellor of the Exchequer, to the British Cabinet as Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, after an eclipse of six months, was announced today. He succeeds Lord Pakenham, who in turn replaces Lord Nathan as Minister of Civil Aviation on the latter's resignation.
SEATTLE, May 31 -- Action restricting the functions of retired and resigned pastors was taken today by the 160th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, May 31 -- Arab League delegates assembled here today for consideration of the Security Council's call for a four-week truce, but owing to the non-arrival of the Egyptian delegate their meeting was postponed until tomorrow.

NOTTINGHAM, England, May 31 (Reuters) -- The Australian cricket team gained a first innings lead of 221 runs when they were dismissed for 400 in reply to Nottinghamshire's first innings total of 179 in their match today.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 31 (AP) -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. said today that "the founding fathers never intended that the Constitution should be a cloak" over Communists and others "who would overturn the Government of this nation."

The Elite Textile Printing Company has purchased the five-story factory building at 830 Monroe Street, Hoboken, N.J., from the Ninth Street Monroe Corporation and will use it for the printing of designs on silk and rayon ties. The C.B. Snyder Realty Company was the broker.

The turnover on the New York Stock Exchange in May was the heaviest in any month since September, 1946, and the most active for a corresponding month in fifteen years, or since 1933. Sales were above the million-share mark in every full day's session, with 3,836,500 shares traded on May 14, the largest total day's business since May 21, 1940.
JERUSALEM, May 31 -- Egyptian Army artillery based at Isdud bombarded today Israeli settlements at one end of Israel's coastal strip and the edge of the Negeb Desert.
Widespread adoption of guaranteed wage plans would help stabilize the demand for consumer goods but would not be sufficient in ittself to eliminate major fluctuations in the business cycle.

With the arrest of three 11-year-old boys on charges of juvenile delinquency, the police of the Far Rockaway station, Queens, announced yesterday that they had solved the mystery of a series of petty burglaries in stores, garages and other business establishments in the last three months.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 31 (AP) --A 5-year-old mare highly rated two years ago and a 2-year-old colt with prospects of a great future raced to easy triumphs today in the two feature races on Garden State Park's closing program.

Reports of children's difficulties are often made by schools, clinics, hospitals and other agencies long before the youngsters' court appearances as "delinquents," according to a report published today by the Child Study Association of America, 221 West Fifty-seventh Street.

BERLIN, May 31 -- A balance of power between Western and Eastern Europe cannot be struck without the participation of Western Germany as an economic and political unit, in the opinion of highly placed Military Government sources here.

A distinguished array of notables, headed by senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and James F. Byrnes, former Secretary of State, will receive honorary degrees from Columbia University at its 194th Commencement today.

PARIS, May 31 -- A demonstration of Rouxcolor, a remarkably realistic color method for motion pictures, was given here today by Armand Roux, who invented and developed the process in collaboration with his brother, Lucien.

The East Side Chamber of Commerce has extended its home library contest until June 30, it was announced yesterday. The contest, open to persons living in the area from Twenty-third Street to Dover Street, between Broadway and East River Drive, was scheduled to close yesterday.

JERUSALEM, May 31 -- In further moves to relieve pressure on the coastal strip and to ward off disaster, two columns of Israeli armored cars were advancing today on Jenin, in north central Palestine. One had come from Afule, in the Plain of Esdraelon, and the other from Megiddo, scene of Biblical Armageddon, near Mishmar Haemek, on the Haifa road.

LONDON, May 31-With the Johannesburg Stock Exchange closed for the Union holiday, gold shares in the London market were quieter today and fractionally lower where changed. South African industrials, however, were sold by British holders and prices dropped sharply.
RYE, N.Y., May 31 -- Only sixty-nine starting craft, little wind and constant murk marked the holiday regatta held today out on Long Island Sound, which was one of the championship series.
NANKING, May 31 -- Premier Wong Wen-hao succeeded today in forming a new Cabinet after a week of protracted negotiations.

More than fifty exporters representing the food, chemical and steel industries have formed a new trade association known as the Independent Merchant Exporters Association, it was announced over the holiday week-end. Formation of the group, it was said, is a result of a common feeling by members that their "very business existence is in jeopardy because of the present policies of the Office of International Trade."

The $8,000,000,000 American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which raised $1,100,000,000 last year for its expansion program, has some phases of operation which usually are lost in the maze of reports of activities.

DEVON, Pa., May 31 -- In a major upset Jervis Bay, entry of Vernon G. Cardy of Montreal, won the conformation hunter championship of the Devon Horse Show, defeating the Rolling Rock Farms' Ermine Coat which, until tonight, was thought to have the crown clinched.
Contrasting trends were shown in new financing in May. Public offerings of stocks increased sharply, while bond offerings declined to the smallest total in three months.

Flood waters raging across northwestern states have caused President Truman to proclaim wide sections of Oregon, Washington and Idaho a national disaster area. The full extent of the disaster still lies unrevealed under a sodden mass of wreckage in Vanport, Ore.

Thirty years ago yesterday 615 service men drifted in lifeboats and rafts in the Atlantic 500 miles west of Brest, France, after their troopship, the first to be hit by a torpedo, was sunk by a German submarine. Last night eighty members of the crew of the ship, the President Lincoln, held their annual commemoration reunion at the Astor Hotel.
Today, June 1, is the thirty-seventh day of the Greater New York Fund's eleventh annual campaign in behalf of 423 local hospitals, health and welfare agencies.

PARIS, May 31 -- The final meetings of committees of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation were in session all day and late tonight in preparation for a meeting of the executive committee to be held tomorrow or Wednesday.

Dwight P. Griswold chief of the American Mission for Aid to Greece, expressed optimism over the Greek military situation last night as he left to return to Athens. Mr. Griswold said he found the Greek problem to be well understood in the United States.

Maritime and navigation equipment originally costing about $300,000 and industrial equipment costing more than $1,000,000 feature the offerings by the War Assets Administration within the next two months, it was reported over the holiday week-end by John R. Campbell, New York regional director.

As the Security Council awaits the Arab and Israeli answers to its latest cease-fire order, due by seven o'clock tonight, the fighting in Palestine itself seems to be reaching a new crescendo. This development, and in particular the implications of the various troop dispositions, has cast fresh doubt on the ability of Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations mediator, to find a peaceful solution for what has thus far proved to be an insoluble problem.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Fighting in Palestine appeared today to be assuming the semblance of a "front" as an important week in the conflict opened.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 31 (AP) -- Six of the ten American starters gained the third round of the British women's amateur golf championship today in a bid to duplicate the triumph of American Frank Stranahan in the men's tournament last week at Sandwich.

This year may be the in a decade for jobs for university graduates, Robert F. Moore, director of placement at Columbia University, said yesterday. Jobs are not only plentiful in most fields but salaries offered to graduates are double those of ten years ago, he reported.

MUNICH, Germany, May 31 (AP) -- Communists and Right Wing parties cut sharply today into the strength of Western Germany's strongest political party, final returns from yesterday's municipal elections showed.

LONDON, May 31 -- The British paper mills are producing only about 27 per cent of their capacity because of the "Government's failure to supply the raw material," F.P. Bishop, general manager of the Newsprint Supply Company, said today.

PRAGUE, May 31 -- President Eduard Benes intends to resign his office probably within the next ten days or two weeks unless some vital development occurs to change his mind, it is once again reported, this time by an apparently thoroughly informed source.

Participation by the British Navy in the air show that will open the city's Golden Jubilee celebration at New York International Airport July 31 to Aug. 8 was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's committee.

About a week has passed since Kings County Judge Leibowitz and an official party made a tour of Brooklyn saloons and billiard parlors and found conditions which the judge considered "deplorable" but which some others in the party apparently didn't get very excited about.

NOT a day goes by in baseball when taunts, insults and other embroidered verbiage don't come flying out of opposite dugouts. The jockeys of the diamond never tire of riding their foes. Ever since the subject was first discussed in this space the correspondence has been rather heavy and a favorite target of the letter-writers would seem to be, for some unaccountable reason, Leo Ernest Durocher, an artist at tossing the verbal harpoon himself.

The Memorial Day doubleheader at the Stadium yesterday was a ground-gaining vehicle for the Yankees. While 62,626 fans cheered the individual exploits of Frank (Spec) Shea and Bobby Brown, the New Yorkers downed the Senators twice, 10 -- 0 and 5 -- 4, and shaved a full length from the leads of the Athletics and Indians.

Two armed men, who had hidden in the washroom until all customers had departed at 4 A.M. yesterday, held up a bar and grill at 1251 Avenue of the Americas and escaped with between $4,000 and $5,000 in cash and checks after binding the bartender and the manager, the police of the West Forty-seventh Street station reported.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 31 -- Israeli spokesmen indicated today that Israel would appeal to the United Nations not to impose a world-wide embargo of arms. The reply to the Council's four-week truce order is expected to arrive here tomorrow, before the 7 P.M. deadline.

ALBANY, May 31 -- Dr. Frederick MacCurdy, State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, announced today that extension of occupational therapy to all patients who can benefit by it in the twenty-six mental-hygiene hospitals and schools will be made possible through 209 new positions that will be available tomorrow.

Promoter Andy Niederreiter yesterday announced the supporting card to the middleweight championship bout between Rocky Graziano and challenger Tony Zale at the Ruppert Stadium, Newark, N.J., Wednesday night, June 9. Four six-rounders and two fours complete the program.

The Federal Government today formally will enter the contract dispute between Atlantic and Gulf steamship agents and operators and three maritime unions affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations, three meetings being scheduled with the principals.

WASHINGTON, May 3l -- Senator Taft may have put a quietus today on a movement within the Republican party to adopt at its national convention a short, easy-to-read statement of general principles as a pledged basis for all the acts and policies of its candidates if elected in November.

The peculiarities of New York speech, long a source of wonderment and even hilarity for the inhabitants of the hinterland, may become a thing of the past under a new program to be adopted by the Board of Education.

CLINTON, Tenn., May 31 (AP) -Circuit Judge Jesse L. Rogers ruled today that Nat Caldwell, reporter for The Nashville Tennessean, did not have to disclose sources of information contained in a news story.
PARIS, May 31 -- Premier Robert Schuman is expected to obtain a vote of confidence tomorrow, but the situation in his Cabinet remains disturbed.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 31 (AP) -- Arab armies poured men, guns and armor today into a forty-mile

Three leaders of an anti-Communist faction in the Bloomingdale department store union announced yesterday they had appealed to the international union to stay execution of a demand by the executive board of the Bloomingdale local that they be ousted from their store jobs, effective tomorrow.

The fraternal spirit of brothers in arms was bruised, if not shattered, yesterday afternoon at Memorial Day services in the Washington Heights section of the city. A color guard of ten British veterans of World War II walked out when one of the principal speakers attacked the Empire's record on the Palestine question.
Riter Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, have announced that Henry H. Williams, John A. Andresen, Henry G. Riter 4th, and John Y.G. Walker Jr. are registered representatives.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Senate hearings on the Mundt-Nixon Communist-control bill were indefinitely recessed late today amid angry cries from the bill's opponents that they would bring "thousands" to Washington to demonstrate against it.
Brooklyn, the Bronx, Queens, Newark and other communities in the metropolitan area paid their respects to the memory of the war dead yesterday at parades and patriotic services.

LONDON, May 31 -- A man with the equivalent of nearly half a billion dollars to spend gave a party tonight to announce that his firm was open for business. He is Lord Trefgarne, lawyer and Labor party politician, who is chairman of the Overseas Development Corporation, which has been authorized by the British Parliament to borrow up to 100,000,000 and invest it in projects to increase the productive capacity of the British colonial dependencies.

JERUSALEM, May 31 (AP) -- Officials of the Christian Union in Palestine made public today a manifesto saying that Israeli forces had used ten Christian religious and humanitarian institutions in Jerusalem as military bases.

The Giants and Dodgers went at it hip and thigh in an all-day tournament at Ebbets Field yesterday, but by the time the last survivor in a grand aggregate of 57,102 spectators had given way to sheer exhaustion, neither side was able to show an inch of gain on the other.

The European Recovery Plan will not impose an increased drain on the American economy in 1948, Harold Boeschenstein, president of Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation and former administrator of the wartime Controlled Materials Plan, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- President Truman today authorized use of war surplus property for relief and rehabilitation in the flood sections of the Northwest, declaring the territory a "disaster area."

LONDON, May 31 -- United States Ambassador Lewis W. Douglas laid a wreath on the tomb of the Unknown Warrior in Westminster Abbey after an American overseas Memorial Day service at St. Margaret's here today for men of United States forces buried in Britain.
CROTON, N.Y., May 31 -- Water cascaded over New York's Cornell Dam here today six inches above dam level, producing a scenic effect that attracted sightseers and photographers from many communities.
HAVANA, May 31 -- Armed forces were ordered into their quarters all over the island at midnight tonight for possible emergencies as Cuba prepared for tomorrow's general election.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 31 -Aided by excellent putting, Richard Remsen of Garden City Golf Club, erstwhile Long Island junior champion, and his partner, Thomas Le Boutillier of Meadow Brook, turned back Lewis Oehmig of Chattanooga and Ray Graham of the home club, 4 and 2, in the final of the Meadow Brook Club's member-guest best-ball tourney today.
Random notes.

If the 4,500 visitors who paid their respects yesterday to the Statue of Liberty return next Memorial Day they probably will find that many physical changes beautifying Bedloe's Island have taken place.
The happiest man at Belmont Park yesterday was Bernard M. Baruch. Here's the reason:

An altercation during an attempt by a husband to call on his estranged wife resulted last night in the death of Joseph Dunowicz, 49 years old, of 407 Georgia Avenue, Brooklyn, and in the suicide of his son-in-law, Charles Gordon, 35, of 66 Cannon Street, Manhattan, and the wounding of the wife, Mrs. Rose Gordon, 25.

CHICAGO, May 31 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs and the Pittsburgh Pirates split a double-header today, the Cubs edging the Bucs, 4 to 3, in the first game and the Pirates winning the second, 4 to 2, before 46,965 fans.

With pledges to keep the faith of their comrades in arms, the veterans of three wars marched in tribute to their dead yesterday. The processions commemorated the eightieth anniversary of Memorial Day, established by the Grand Army of the Republic.

DETROIT, May 31 (AP) -- Belting four pitchers for 15 hits, the Chicago White Sox came back to beat the Detroit Tigers, 9 to 3, before 55,875 fans in the second half of a double-header today after Detroit had won the opener, 5 to 4. Art Houtteman took his sixth straight defeat for the Tigers in the second game.

KATONAH, N.Y., May 31 -- A convocation of women from all the nations of the world, meeting for a month in some selected city of Western Europe, would be able to do much to end the menace of future wars, according to Maj. Gen. John F. O'Ryan, retired.

SALISBURY BEACH, Mass., May 31 (AP) -- After taking over the lead at the halfway mark, Tom Crane of Springfield, running his second marathon in nine days, defeated the experienced Johnny Kelly of Boston by 1 minute 17 seconds today in the 26-mile, 385-yard race from the Lawrence City Hall to this resort town.

LONDON, May 31 -- An agreement on Western Germany was at last reached today. The conference of representatives of the United States, Great Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg completed its discussions and will wind up tomorrow -- but there is a hitch.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 31 -- Overcast skies and occasional rain failed today to stop Memorial Day ceremonies in Westchester County.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 31 -- German bizonal authorities today won the first round of a significant "governmental" struggle as the Ruhr steel workers' two-day strike, scheduled to start tomorrow, was postponed.

OTTAWA, May 31 -- Strict neutrality is being observed by Canada in the Newfoundland plebiscite of June 3, and in view of this attitude there has developed some resentment against the manner in which certain United States Senators have wittingly or unwittingly been induced to exercise an oblique influence on the electors.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -Uncertainty developed today as to whether the European Recovery Plan and the national defense program may share in the voluntary allocation of steel under the Republican anti-inflation law.

"The Burnished Blade." a first novel by Lawrence Schoonover, has been scheduled for Sept. 28 publication by Macmillan. It is a story of the last days of feudalism in France and the barbarous Empire of Trebizond on the shores of the Black Sea.

For years there have been complaints concerning the misuse of automobile horns in New York City, and endless estimates of the decibel volume of this nuisance. A recent letter published on your editorial page resurrects the issue and offers a mild type of correction.

The Radio Writers Guild reports that it has broken off negotiations with a group of leading advertising agencies. Agency spokesmen, it was said, have continually refused "to recognize or enter into collective bargaining with the guild." Conversations began in January.

Because of increased costs of labor, food and materials, Lenox Hill Hospital operated last year at a net deficit of $93,669, a new peak, the seventy-eighth annual report showed yesterday. William H. Zinsser, hospital president, said the deficit was $53,685 above that in 1946 and indicated the "alarming conditions" that confronted the city's voluntary hospitals.

VANCOUVER, May 31 (Canadian Press) -- The flooded Fraser River left in its wake today more collapsed dikes, more homeless and new damage to farmlands. Losses in the Fraser Valley have been unofficially estimated at from $15,000,000 to $20,000,000.
SEOUL, Korea, May 31 -- The Korean National Assembly, elected on May 10 under the observation of the United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea, convened formally at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 31 -- A four-day fiesta in honor of Our Lady of Good Voyage, patroness of those who make their living by the sea, ended today with the annual blessing of the Portugese-American fishing fleet by the Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing, Archbishop of Boston.

GENEVA, May 31 -- The second session of the assembly of the International Civil Aviation Organization opening in Geneva tomorrow will review a year of solid achievement in international cooperation, Edward Warner, president of the group's council, said today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 31 -Carl P. Rollins, a leader among authorities on the graphic arts and book designing, will retire next month from his post as Printer to Yale University.
NORFOLK, Va., Tuesday, June 1 (UP) -- A Navy launch with a normal load of ninety men foundered in heavy seas last night as it approached the aircraft carrier Kearsarge in Hampton Roads.

BRUSSELS, May 31 (AP) -- Frank Parker of Los Angeles, winner of the French singles tennis title on Saturday, arrived early today and immediately defeated Andre Lacroix of Belgium in the first-round of the Belgian championship.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 31 -- The twentieth international congress of the P.E.N. opened here today under the patronage of King Frederik IX with 300 representatives from thirty countries.
TOKYO, Tuesday, June 1 -- The conclusion of a new currency agreement that is expected greatly to expand Japan's trade with the sterling area countries was announced today by Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

With less han three weeks remaining before the adjournment target date of June 19, a large amount of unfinished business still confronts Congress. Ten major appropriation bills are awaiting action. Among them is the measure which would redeem, with an actual cash appropriation, the promises implicit in Congressional approval of the Marshall Plan.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur could return to the United States without any "political implications" being attached to his actions "if he received a competent order" from Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall, Gen. Jonathan Wainwright, hero of Bataan and Corregidor, said today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31 -- The Polish-American Congress today urged Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, who is about to assume the presidency of Columbia University, to reject a Palish Government donation of $5,000 to the New York institution.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 31 -- The saving on materials handling offers industry the keyt to a reduction in its over-all production costs, industrial experts emphasized at a technical session of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, which opened its six-day semi-annual meeting here today.

A fog-shrouded harbor welcomed the Cunard White Star liner Britannic yesterday as the ship, refurbished during a year in a Liverpool yard, arrived here from the British Isles on her first commercial run since 1939.

MUKDEN, China, May 31 -- Although food is still the main concern of blockaded Mukden's civilian population, the last two weeks have brought a drop in grain prices and a rise in morale among officials here.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 31 -- A polo game for the benefit of the Disabled War Veterans of Nassau County and the Boy Scouts of America, Nassau chapter, will inaugurate the Long Island polo season on Sunday, when a match between the Meadowbrook team and the Westburys will be played on International Field at the Meadowbrook Club.
Accept my gratitude for your editorial of May 27, "The Arab Answer."

Emir Feisal al-Saud, Foreign Minister of Saudi Arabia and head of his country's delegation to the United Nations General Assembly, said last night that the Arabs "know that the hearts of the majority of the American people are for our cause" in the Holy Land war.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -The Munitions Board, chief planning agency in military procurement under the unified-service program, issued here today a booklet designed as a guide for use by every industrial plant in preparing for potential mobilization in event of another war.

Benjamin Wolfson has sold the two-story four-family building at 122 Bay Thirty-fourth Street, Brooklyn to Nathan Hershkowitz. Sam Abrams, Inc., broker in the transaction, arranged a purchase money loan of $10,000 with the Kings County Savings Bank.

WINNIPEG, May 31 (Canadian Press) -- Good buying by export interests in barley and a limited processor demand in both oats and barley marked the closing trade today on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange in the coarse grain futures market.

The City Stores Company, in its statement covering the three months ended with April, issued for release today, reports a consolidated net profit of $1,106,623 after taxes, minority interest and all charges.
CHARD, England, May 31 -- Tom Woolsey, solitary Communist in this typical farming town of western England, is waging a losing battle.

Totaling only $20,564,000, bonds called before maturity for payment in May dropped to the smallest figure for the month in fourteen years. The total compared with $28,044,000 in the preceding month and $143,934,000 for May, 1947.

NORWALK, Conn., May 31 -- Mustang, New York thirty-two foot auxiliary sloop owned by Roderick Stephens Jr., crossed the finish line first today in the Storm Trysail Club's third annual race for cruising yachts.

Allied Artists will make thirteen "high budget pictures" during the next twelve months, representing a total expenditure of approximately $13,000,000 or $3,000,000 more than originally planned, according to an announcement by Steve Broidy, president.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UP) -Republican National Chairman Carroll Reece said today that President Truman's forthcoming Western trip obviously was intended to "bolster the waning prospects of his party and of his own candidacy."

New York has fine restaurants, no doubt about that. But their strength does not lie in their strawberry shortcake. Perhaps under the influence of the man from France presiding in the kitchen, who knows all about Napoleons but very little about shortcake, their version of this greatest of American desserts consists largely of a slice of sponge cake bathed in crushed strawberries and dabbed up with stiffly whipped cream.

TORONTO, May 31 (Canadian Press) -Movements were mixed within a narrow range in quiet trading on the Toronto Stock Exchange today, probably due to the closing of the New York markets for the Memorial Day observance in the United States.

MANHASSET, L.I., May 31 -- Miss Joan Prytherch of Glen Head collected four blues in amassing 23 points with the 8-year-old gray mare Unearthly Hour to win the working hunter championship during the Oaks Hunt horse show on the Greentree estate today.

BERLIN, May 31 -- A continuing barrage in the Soviet-licensed press on the need for four-power agreement on currency reform was considered by Military Government officials today as an indication that Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, the Soviet Military Governor, might call a meeting of the Allied Control Council in July.

CLEVELAND, May 31 (AP) -- Cliff Fannin shut out the Cleveland Indians with four hits today as the St. Louis Browns won the nightcap of a double-header, 6 -- 0, after dropping the opener to the Tribesmen, 8 to 3, before 48,961 fans.
MONTREAL, May 31 (Canadian Press) -- Montreal's far-flung waterfront looked quiet today and proof of a shipping slump was given by an announcement that hundreds of longshoremen were without work.

Many buyers were in the wholesale apparel markets here last week and their response to fall ready-to-wear lines was good, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. A large number of retailers, it was reported, have changed their plans to delay their fall purchasing and have indicated they will be in the market within ten days.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 31 -- Egyptian Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha told newsmen tonight the Arab reply to the Security Council's four-week cease-fire proposal for Palestine would be "moderate, reasonable and acceptable." He did not say what the reply would be.
Dr. Solomon M. Schwarz, a specialist in Soviet economics, reported yesterday that individual real wages in Russia had declined about 50 per cent in the twenty years between 1928 and 1948.

A building loan of $241,000, insuer under Section 608 of the Federal Housing Administration, has been obtained by the Natland Realty Corporation from the National Bronx Bank of New York on the twenty-eight-family Linden Gardens apartment project now under construction at the southeast corner of Springfield Boulevard and 116th Avenue in St. Albans, Queens.

The time again has come to rip another leaf from the calendar, and upon this occasion it will be a pleasure. The days of May were black with misfortune locally, and the month of May was just as long as a month can be.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 31 -- Death took a holiday at the Speedway today while swarthy little Mauri Rose won the fastest 500-mile automobile classic in the history of the course. It was his third victory at this track, tying the record for triumphs.

BOSTON, May 31 (AP) -- Boston's Braves today snapped a four-game losing streak by whipping the Philadelphia Phillies, 10 -- 4, in the second game of a double-header. The Phils won the opener, 6 -- 3, ending a three-game losing streak of their own.
PITTSBURGH, June 1 (AP) -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced today a proposal for a "single uniform security package" for employes.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Advocates of the Presidential nomination of Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts are urging him to take the floor of the House of Representatives soon to make what they term "a dramatic speech" -- the purpose being to focus more favorable attention on his qualifications to lead the Republican party in the 1948 campaign.
Juvenile delinquency can be curbed, even in crowded, low-income areas, if the schools and the Police Department will work together, a Board of Education report declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Federal Works Administrator, was directed by President Truman today to mobilize all the Government's resources for relief of the flood-stricken communities of the Northwest.

The Russian Private School at 6 East Eighty-seventh Street, conducted since 1941 for the children of Soviet Union officials and employes in the New York area, will be closed when its term ends tomorrow and the children, from the age of 7 upward, will be returned to Russia, it became known yesterday in Municipal Court.

Prince Bertil of Sweden, 36-year-old son of Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf and third in line of succession to the Swedish throne, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon with a delegation of his countrymen to attend a centennial celebration to honor Swedish pioneers in the United States.

With respect to your leading editorial, "The Draft on Its Merits," which appeared in THE TIMES of May 28, I must disagree with your conclusion that "Selective Service and civil rights are largely separate problems."

"Reasonable" import controls are planned by the Philippines to ration the available dollar supply and may be put into effect by Oct. 1 or sooner, Louis G. Wagner of L. G. Wagner, Ltd., Manila, said yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 1 -- Israeli representatives charged today that Jerusalem reports of destruction by Israeli fighters of Christian religious centers were being put out by Arab sympathizers to "distort" the true situation in the Holy City.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 1 -- The United Nations Special Committee, which has been studying the question of creating an economic commission for the Middle East, decided today by a vote of 9 to 1 that the commission should be established to promote the economic development and raise the standard of living of the region.
