LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 1 -- Following is the text of the reply of the representative of the Provisional Government of Israel to a United Nations Security Council resolution proposing a four-week cease-fire in Palestine:
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Henry A. Wallace's backers took command today of a march on Washington against the Mundt-Nixon Communist control bill.
For 3 hours 20 minutes the Giants and Dodgers filled an open date in the schedule yesterday at Ebbets Field but still failed to reach a decision.

A banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., the First National Bank of Chicago and Lehman Brothers submitted the highest bid yesterday for issues of bonds of Seattle, Wash., totaling $7,500,000, maturing in two to twenty years.

The supply of natural gas in the Appalachian area will be increased 75,000,000 cubic feet a day to 508,000,000 cubic feet by the end of this year, according to the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation which operates the Big and Little Big Inch pipe lines.

STUTTGART, Germany, June 1 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay parted company with the Laenderrat [Council of States] here today on a note of the greatest optimism he has sounded since the capitulation. In his farewell address to the now outgrown organization, whose functions have been largely absorbed by the Bizonal Economic Council in Frankfort on the Main, he announced a virtual resumption of free trade with the other European states sharing in the Marshall Plan.
STANTON, Del., June 1 (AP) -- Darby Dan Farm's Darby D'Amour got up in the final stride today to beat Grandview Stable's favored Erigeron in the featured Elsmere Purse at Delaware Park.

PRETORIA, South Africa, June 1 -- Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, reacting to criticism within his following, came out from temporary retirement today to announce that he would continue to lead the minority United party and would be a candidate for Parliament in a constituency in Pretoria, whose incumbent will resign.

"There has never been a time when the need was greater for women with good training, high standards and the ability to work hard," Dean Millicent C. McIntosh told 300 Barnard College graduates at the annual class day exercises yesterday at 1 P.M. in the college gymnasium.

SCARSDALE N.Y., June 1 -- One amateur, 23-year-old Dick Mayer, holder of the New York State title, qualified with six professionals in the Metropolitan section's trials for the United States Open championship held at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club today.

The 194th Commencement exercises at Columbia University yesterday closed an academic year in which the university continued to reach out into new fields of service and yet maintained that steady concentration on essentials which, to the true educator, is the greatest source of satisfaction.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- The United States Supreme Court today refused to change its decision of May 3 in the Government's anti-trust suit against the Schine Chain Theatres, Inc. The Justice Department had asked a clarification of the decision which upheld, in part, the Government's contention that Schine has violated the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

Prediction of an excellent season in women's coat and suit departments was made yesterday by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers. Final capitulation in acceptance of the new look, it was pointed out in a bulletin to clients, has raised the potential number of purchasers for coats which will measure forty-eight to forty-nine inches in length.

Except for a new flurry of demand for the oils, the stock market held yesterday to a mixed pattern in slightly livelier trading due to activity in low-price issues. There were only a few price changes in excess of a point and, although the list leaned slightly to the lower side at the close, the combined averages managed to show an edge of 0.19 point as the result of strength in a few components.

WQXR will extend the end of its broadcasting day from 12:05 A.M. to 1 A.M., beginning Monday, June 14. The additional time will be filled by "Nightcap," a program of light, popular music which will not include jazz. News will not be broadcast at 1 A.M., the final report for the day continuing to be heard at midnight.

A step toward a program for importing German scrap metal for American steel mills and foundries was taken yesterday with organization of a metallurgical subcommittee of the Economic Commission for Europe.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null set aside yesterday a verdict returned last week by a jury after a six-day trial that awarded $100,000 to Juan Nieves, 36-year-old counterman, for the loss of his leg in a subway accident on Christmas Eve, 1946.

The money market was easier yesterday and Federal funds were quoted at one-half of 1 per cent. Federal Reserve member banks here, which held $80,000,000 in excess reserves on Wednesday, increased the amount to $200,000,000 on Thursday, largely through borrowings and sales of securities for Friday delivery.

LONDON, June 1 -- Great Britain's first internal airmail service started today on a 225-mile circular route in Norfolk. The service, operated at ordinary inland postage rates by the General Post Office with three Sikorsky S-51 helicopters, began with the delivery of 13,000 letters mailed in Peterborough late last night and up to 9 o'clock this morning.

The problem of fitting Germany into Europe becomes immediate with the conclusion of the six-power conference in London and the simultaneous meeting in Paris of the executive council of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation to formulate its report for the Harriman mission.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP) -- The Navy Department tonight released the names of twenty-eight persons "unaccounted for and *** believed missing" as a result of the swamping of a Liberty launch from the aircraft carrier Kearsarge in Hampton Roads, Norfolk, Va., last night.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 2.5 per cent in May, compared with the same month last year, according to a survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The lowest previous increase this year was 4.1 per cent in March.
Ceremonial solemnity, as prescribed by the etiquette of international diplomacy, marked the arrival a few days ago at Washington of Sir Oliver Franks, new British Ambassador to the United States.

BERLIN, June 1 -- The Soviet Military Administration has forced democratic parties into subservience in the Soviet zone of Germany so successfully during the occupation that it has created "apprehension that nothing short of force" can establish political democracy there, it was charged today in a British Military Government report.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 1 -- Hermann Reusch, German industrialist, was removed today from the Allied Steel Production Committee on demand of the German trade unions. The removal was announced by Dr. Erich Koehler, president of the Bizonal Economic Council, which originally had named him.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Special protection for the rights of war veterans during furloughs of Government workers was upheld by the Supreme Court in a unanimous ruling today.
New York City property owners will pay taxes in the coming fiscal year on assessed valuations aggregating $17,584,492,413 -- an increase of $646,026,960 over the current figure of $16,938,465,453.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 1 -- Twenty thousand persons were evacuated today from lowland towns and farms between Portland and the sea as National Guardsmen and civilian volunteers fought to maintain dikes against the flooded Columbia River.

Joining the Bonnard and photography shows at the Museum of Modern Art is a new exhibition, "Portraits in Prints," which opens to the general public today in the museum's Auditorium Gallery. This latest addition to the museum's repertoire of exhibitions represents twenty-eight artists from nine countries, both European and American, in portrait ventures in nearly all graphic media.

Yesterday milk went up 1 cent a quart bottle -- in cartons it is a little more -- to reach a city-wide average of 20 1/2 cents when purchased at a store. In June, 1941, six months before the war started, it cost 10 1/2 cents in New York. Last year at this time it was 16 cents.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 1 - Future earnings of the nation's electric utility industry must be made attractive enough to draw out from investors the vast amounts of new capital required to finance the industry's five-year $6,000,000,000 expansion program even if it means increased rates for consumers.

An "appalling increase in youthful delinquency" among young persons in the United States was attributed yesterday by Auxiliary Bishop Thomas J. McDonnell of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York to "lack of religion, lack of interest in the home and lack of freedom given by parents to their children to carry out ideals they have learned in school."

An appeal to municipalities, chambers of commerce and other business organizations to cooperate in securing more extensive highways and parking facilities was made yesterday by Charles A. Parsons president of the New York State Automobile Dealers, Inc., at the opening of the twenty-fifth anniversary meeting of that organization in the Commodore Hotel.

LONDON, June 1 -- A majority of the speakers in the House of Lords today again attacked the clause in the Criminal Justice Bill providing for abolition of the death penalty for a trial period of five years.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- Consumer credit rose to another record high during April with a gain of $219,000,000 that month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Freddie, a refugee German shepard dog, born in Shanghai after his mother had been aided in escaping the Nazi regime, was reunited yesterday with his owner, who is in New York on a visa.
LONDON, June 1 -- With pageantry dating from the days of the Norman conquest, Field Marshal Earl Wavell was installed today as the 146th Constable of the Tower of London.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 1 -- A military spokesman of the Israeli delegation today issued the following summary of the military situation:

The Weather Bureau confirmed yesterday with statistics the feeling held by many residents earlier about precipitation last month -- May was the second wettest one in the history of the agency. There were 8.82 inches of rain last month compared with 9.10 in May, 1908.

"Hazard," which arrives at the Paramount, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The romantic melodrama, produced by Paramount, starring Paulette Goddard and Macdonald Carey, was directed by George Marshall and produced by Mel Epstein from a screen play by Arthur Sheekman and Roy Chanslor and the novel by Mr. Chanslor. Fred Clark, Stanley Clements,Maxie Rosenbloom, James Millican and Frank Faylen are among the supporting players.
JERUSALEM, June 1 (AP) -- Firing in Jerusalem continued late today as the deadline of the latest United Nations cease-fire order neared.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 1 -- The Provisional Government of the State of Israel and the seven member nations of the Arab League announced this afternoon that that they had accepted a request by the United Nations Security Council for a four-week cease-fire order in Palestine.
Discovery of a half-brother who had been believed dead has complicated settlement of the estate of Ignace Jan Paderewski, Polish pianist and statesman, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Bids for a ten-year conditional lease of the Belasco Theatre in this city will be received by the Federal Government on July 1, Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Federal Works Administrator, announced today.

Accusing the Board of Education of being responsible for "the spiritual and intellectual breakdown in our public school system," Councilman Edward Rager, Manhattan Republican, called yesterday for an investigating commission to survey the city schools.
TEL AVIV, June 1 (AP) -- Israeli troops slashing behind an Egyptian coastal spearhead, have captured a town only three miles from the Egyptians' supply road, a communique announced today.

MILWAUKEE, June 1 -- Advances in science, engineering and industry are seen as a result of large computers now being built or in prospect with phenomenal new speeds in solving complex mathematical problems and with greatly expanded "memories," it was declared here today at the semi-annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.
ATHENS, June 1 -- The radio station of the Communist "First Provisional Democratic Government of Free Greece" has put out peace feelers.

SOME people don't like tropical West Africa, that strange land of wonderful old names, the grain coast, the gold coast, the ivory coast and the slave coast. They remember the heat and isolation, the fevers and running sores, and quote its former reputation as "the white man's graveyard." But Esther Warner is not one of them.

Old people in their seventies and eighties with young ideas in sculpture, painting and ceramics converged spryly on the American Museum of Natural History yesterday to be first to enter their exhibits in the Hobby Show for Older Persons opening next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Philadelphia Company, Pittsburgh, was ordered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to dispose of the gas and transportation properties in its $370,000,000 holding company system and then liquidate and dissolve.

Columbia University conferred honorary degrees on eight distinguished individuals and degrees in course on a record total of 7,995 academic candidates at its 194th commencement yesterday. The exercises were held in the traditional outdoor setting, in South Court on the Morningside Heights campus.

Events tonight: Prokofieff's "The Duenna," Lemonade Opera, Greenwich Mews Playhouse, 141 West Thirteenth Street, 8:30 o'clock; Rivka Mahat, soprano, Times Hall, 8:30; William Kothe, piano, Lexington Avenue Y.M. and Y.W.H.A., 8:40; Composers' Forum concert, Roesch Little Symphony, Clara Burling Roesch, conductor, Sophia Melvin, piano, Jeanne Mitchell, violin, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 1 (UP) -Israel's Air Force lashed out at the Arabs in widespread raids today.

BUENOS AIRES, June 1 (AP) -- Argentina's peso declined in value over the week-end, it was announced here today. From time to time dollars have been available on the so-called free market at prices ranging from 4.01 pesos to 4.02 pesos each.

Consolidated net profit of the Emerson Radio Phonograph Corporation and its subsidiaries for the twenty-six weeks ended on May 1 last, reached a new high record of $1,139,244, it was reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Mental hygiene offers the possibility of relieving the tensions and frustrations of a chaotic world, Dr. Louis A. Schwartz, chief of the division of neuropsychiatry, Woman's Hospital, Detroit, today told the National Organization for Public Health Nursing.

Declaring that the medical schools of the United States are facing a crisis because of "rapidly increasing expenses," Dr. Currier McEwen, dean of the New York University College of Medicine, called upon New York's business men to lend their "wholehearted support" to privately endowed institutions of medical education.

Homeless women and children in the Municipal Lodging House Annex at 8 East Third Street began packing their meager belongings yesterday in anticipation of the trek they will start on June 10 to other temporary quarters in the city's main shelter at 432 East Twenty-fifth Street.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange became somewhat irregular yesterday and closed 7 points lower to 18 points higher than Friday's final quotations.

Cable was money from home in the Duntreith Handicap, the Class C race that held the feature spot on the program at Belmont Park yesterday. The 5-year-old son of War Admiral scored handily in the mile-and-a-quarter event, beating Rocket Bomb, the runner-up, by three lengths.

In reply to the latest cease-fire order issued by the Security Council of the United Nations under threat of sanctions, both Israel and the Arab states have now submitted answers which hold out hope for a truce in Palestine. Both answers are accompanied by detailed explanations which the Security Council must now consider.

A new licensing pattern for the distribution of second-quarter Brazilian flour export allocations was announced yesterday by the Office of International Trade. The allocation is 1,280,000 bags, more than double the 1945 total and over twenty times pre-war shipments to Brazil.

Those puzzling Yankees continue to ride the roller coaster. After a chugging ascent to a three-game winning streak, they were sent hurtling down to defeat by the Senators last night. In the process, the world champions were made to look bad by Washington's Walter Masterson.

Tarleton Winchester, an American who has spent most of the last twenty-eight years in France and England as a shipping official, will sail on the America today to resume his work in the busiest post-war travel season. He is assistant European general manager for the United States Lines and is known to thousands of expatriates and more thousands of American travelers abroad.

BRUSSELS, June 1 (AP) -- Frank Parker of Los Angeles, winner of the French International tennis championship last week, moved into the third round of the Belgian International men's singles today when he beat Narendra Nath of India, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- The wheat market showed unexpected strength early in the session today on the Board of Trade, ignoring the good rains that were reported in Kansas and Nebraska last night, but the demand subsided quickly, with the weather news exerting more influence in the late trade, with hedging sales increasing.
LONDON, June 1 -- British officialdom's dogged hopes of obtaining a truce in Palestine were justified tonight by Arab and Israeli acceptances.

PARIS, June 1 -- Disturbed as relationships between the Great Powers have become over the tragic conflict in Palestine, the diplomacy of the three leading Allied capitals is quietly continuing to work for some basis of settlement.

Medals and certificates were awarded yesterday to twenty-four winners in the twenty-seventh annual national exhibition of advertising and editorial art at a luncheon given by the New York Art Directors Club in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Joint Committee on Labor-Management Relations voted today against recommending any changes in the Taft-Hartley Law this year. The decision was reported to be unanimous.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 1 -- President Eurico Gaspar Dutra, acting to meet the rising prices, sent to Congress today a three-point anti-inflation bill proposing: (1) A limitation on profits.

What had been planned as a delegation of 200 New Yorkers to testify in Washington against the Mundt-Nixon Communist-control bill mushroomed yesterday to more than 3,000 reservations for today's trip to protest the recessing of hearings by a Senate Judiciary subcommittee.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, June 1 -- Israeli airmen blasted Amman with high explosive and incendiary bombs today in the first attack on an Arab capital. Arab officials said six Arab civilians were killed in the surprise assault.

ST. ANNES-ON-THE-SEA, England, June 1 (AP) -- Miss Dorothy Kielty of Los Angeles sank a 90-foot chip shot from the five-inch rough on the edge of a trap today and advanced to the quarter-finals of the British women's amateur golf championship tournament.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- The Senate passed a bill today to give the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway Co. right-of-way to widen a tunnel leading to the St. George Ferry Terminal on Staten Island, New York.

TEL AVIV, June 1 -- With only a few hours to go before the cease-fire deadline in Palestine, Israeli forces were tonight mostly fighting outside the borders of the Jewish state as designed by the United Nations.
TOKYO, June 1 -- Another first in the history of Japan's democratization is scheduled to take place tomorrow when the Cabinet will appoint a business man as director of the Imperial household.

Establishment of a free employment bureau primarily to serve the 105,000 adolescent members of the Police Athletic League was recommended yesterday at a City Hall conference called by Mayor O'Dwyer on juvenile problems.
TOKYO, June 1 -- Leftists have taken control of Japan's largest labor organization, the Government Railway Workers Union. This is the first setback in the occupation's anti-Communist drive.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder told the Senate Appropriations Committee today that a moratorium on western European indebtedness to the United States would "impair the credit standing" of Marshall Plan countries and jeoparrize the loan program of the World Bank.

DARIEN, Conn., June 1 -- Fashion is worth the price, participants on THE NEW YORK TIMES radio forum generally agreed today. The forum, 132d in the series "What's On Your Mind?", was held here at the Holmes School under the auspices of the Darien Community Association and broadcast over WQXR.
PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (AP) -- Shortstop Eddie Joost committed his first error in forty-two games and the Athletics fell from the American League lead as they bowed to the Red Sox, 8 to 1, today.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A proposal for the creation of a Government foundation to conduct all international broadcasting and obviate dual responsibility between the State Department's "Voice of America" and the networks was advanced today by Charles R. Denny, a vice president of the National Broadcasting Company.

The New York State Police Conference, through its executive secretary, Peter Keresman, declared yesterday that each of the six policemen to whom Mayor O'Dwyer awarded posthumous Police Department Medals of Honor last week was killed by a "repeater" out on parole.

James E. Dooley, president of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations of the U.S., said yesterday his organization had accepted the resignation of Gulfstream Park at Hollywood, Fla., the Associated Press reported.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board today ordered a 2 per cent increase in reserve requirements of member banks in New York and Chicago, effective on June 11.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Extension of Federal old age and survivors insurance to an estimated 3,500,000 workers, but only at their employers' option for the most part, was approved today by the House Ways and Means Committee.

John L. Lewis filed a brief in the Federal District Court in Washington yesterday asking dismissal of the Government's request, now before the Court, for an order compelling him to recognize the Southern Coal Producers Association as bargaining agents. Today Judge T. Alan Goldsborough will listen to argument of both sides and is expected to render his decision.

Because Michael Kivatisky, 12 years old, considers New York the ideal summer resort, he rejected yesterday the Children's Aid Society's offer of a two-week free vacation at its Camp Bowdoin in New Hamburg, N.Y.

The nation's tee titans kept in the groove enough yesterday to qualify, but played second fiddle to a little-known Texas pro in sectional tests for the national open golf tournament, starting in Los Angeles June 10. The Associated Press reported.
LONDON, June 1 (UP) -- Following is the text of the rebel message, as reported by Tanjug, Yugoslav agency:

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Commodity Exchange Authority issued today a complaint against Ralph W. Moore, a trader in farm commodities here, on the ground that he issued a "memo to the press" last Oct. 1 for the purpose of causing an advance in the market price of lard for his own enrichment.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Senate Finance Committee, it was indicated today, will reject the House-approved provision for Congressional veto power over future reciprocal trade agreements. William L. Clayton, former Under-Secretary of State, said, however, that the House bill would still be unsatisfactory without this provision.
PHILADELPHIA, June 1 -- Former Gov. Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota declared tonight that the United States should send a major portion of its Navy to Palestine to carry out U.N. policy.

Representative Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts told 438 men and women in the graduating class of Pratt Institute yesterday that faith in their country, awareness of its destiny and personal sacrifice to protect it might help in averting war.
A two-year agreement was reached yesterday by eleven tanker companies with the National Maritime Union, CIO, which may prevent a crippling maritime strike when present contracts expire on June 15.

NOTTINGHAM, England, June 1 (Reuters) -- Nottinghamshire 299 for eight wickets, In their second innings today held the Australian cricketers to a draw and made the highest score against the Australians since the tour opened.

Major curriculum changes that will expand the number and content of "cultural" courses have been approved by the faculty of City College's School of Business and Civic Administration, 17 Lexington Avenue, and will be presented to the Board of Higher Education at its monthly meeting on June 21, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- Representative Walter G. Andrews, Republican, of New York, announced today he would not seek re-election.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- While efforts at the White House to break the deadlock in the pay dispute involving three railroad brotherhoods remained unavailing, sources in Congress said today that union and management leaders had agreed on a proposal to raise pension rates for retired rail workers by 20 per cent.

A new slim-looking vacuum cleaner designed to clean under low-slung furniture and to be stored in a small space will be at the Singer Sewing Center, 396 Fifth Avenue, Saturday. The new cleaner, to be in centers throughout the country by next week, also solves the problem of snarled cords, since it has a reel that winds and unwinds the cord to the required length.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 1 -- The ruling body of yachting in this country and Canada, the North American Yacht Racing Union, made fully detailed and sweeping plans to select a sailor today for the one-man representation of the United States in the Olympics in England this August.

The National Retail Dry Goods Association shortly will survey approximately 2,000 member stores with home furnishings operations to determine retailer recommendations for changes in market dates for all branches of the home furnishings industry, David H. Woog, home furnishings advisory committee manager disclosed yesterday.
PARIS, June 1 -- Premier Robert Schuman obtained today a heavy vote of confidence, but his Cabinet is so badly torn that its fate remains uncertain.

Members of the Bloomingdale department store unit of Local 3 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, voted overwhelmingly last night to uphold an order of their executive board expelling from the union and from their jobs three leaders of an anti-Communist faction.

By a 3-to-2 decision the Appellate Division in Brooklyn upheld yesterday the action of the Oyster Bay Zoning Board of Appeals in approving a variance of zoning to Long Island University of Brooklyn to extend its facilities on the estate of Mrs. Joseph E. Davies in Brookville.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Senate and House Republican leaders listed the stop-gap selective draft today for "must" passage before Congress adjourns.

GENEVA, June 1 -- Great Britain and Australia believe that the solution of the problems of international airline competition lies in international ownership of long-distance air transport, representatives of those two countries said today.

LONDON, June 1 -- British engineering experts have come to the conclusion that there is no practical way of controlling floods on the Thames and other such rivers in England, according to a publication of the Ministry of Agriculture issued today.

ROME -- June 1 -- Extensive land reforms that will permit the greatest possible number of farm laborers to become small landowners were promised by Premier Alcide de Gasperi this afternoon when he expounded his sixth Government's program to the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate.

Secrecy, fear and suspicion in top levels of the United States Government threaten to become an "epidemic," Marshall Field said last night at the commencement exercises of the New School for Social Research.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 1 -- Hunt Stromberg, indepedent producer, has concluded a package deal with Hal Wallis, also an independent, to borrow Lizabeth Scott, Don de Fore and Wendell Corey for the leading roles in "Too Late for Tears," which Stromberg will produce this summer for distribution by United Artists.

"Presidential Sweepstakes: The Story of Political Conventions and Campaigns," by the late Henry Luther Stoddard, will be published on June 14 by Putnam. Mr. Stoddard, who was born in the year Lincoln became President, represented The Philadelphia Press during Grant's last illness in New York and death at Mount McGregor and accompanied Jefferson Davis on his farewell tour of the South.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- John L. Lewis today cited the "history" of the "hostile, arbitrary, recalcitrant, negative and adamant attitude" of the Southern Coal Producers Association since 1941 in support of his refusal to bargain collectively with that association.

Rumors to the effect that heavy-weight champion Joe Louis was overweight and not in physical trim for the defense of his title against Jersey Joe Walcott on June 23 at Yankee Stadium were dispelled yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, June 1 -- An exceptionally small turnout of voters in party primaries today formally committed California's fifty-three votes to Gov. Earl Warren and fifty-four to President Truman on the first ballots at the Republican and Democratic National Conventions.

As children, clutched by their own mothers, watched from neighboring windows and fire-escapes, nearly 100 invited guests filled a garden in back of 304 East Thirty-third Street yesterday to witness the dedication of the new center of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service, which already has enabled 2,000 unwanted and orphaned infants to find parents.
Commission on Human Rights -- Adopted articles on arbitrary arrests, slavery, trials and personal liberties for inclusion in declaration on human rights.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 1 -- Matyas Rakosi, General Secretary of the Communist party in Hungary, announced in today's issue of the semi-monthly publication of the Communist Information Bureau that the time had come to recast and strip down the Communist parties of eastern Europe into smaller and more effective "striking'' forces.

INTERSECTIONAL play will be resumed on both baseball fronts today with the embattled teams squaring off in the same approximate pattern which was followed slightly more than a fortnight ago. The Western-teams of the American League will visit the Atlantic Seaboard and the Eastern teams of the senior circuit will head for the hinterlands.

The Screen Writers Guild and thirty individual writers charged in Federal Court yesterday that substantially all the motion picture producers in this country and their trade associations had combined and conspired to govern the political views and associations of persons engaged in the production of pictures.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 1 (AP) -- Baseball banned for life today a minor league club official and a pitcher-manager on charges of bribery, gambling and game-throwing.

Dean George B. Pegram of the graduate faculties of Columbia University was praised warmly yesterday for his long services to scholarship and to Columbia by three distinguished speakers at the annual commencement luncheon of the Columbia Alumni Federation in Faculty House, 400 West 117th Street.

Fears of metal scarcities as a result of the Government stockpiling programs have spurred a new scramble by America's leading industries for available ferrous and non-ferrous materials, according to participants in metal forums here yesterday.

The fourth-ranking member in the hierarchy of the Communist party in the United States, Jack Stachel, was arrested here yesterday on a Federal warrant for deportation proceedings. Held on Ellis Island five hours, Stachel, who steers party-line propaganda at all levels through the Department of Education, Agitation and Publications, was released late in the afternoon on $3,500 bond.

Feeling the effect of reduced volume in the last three months as a result of adverse weather and hard goods competition, children's wear buyers are making a cautious approach to the fall season, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- The Senate tonight defeated, 40 to 31, an effort to put the admission of displaced persons into the United States on a proportional basis.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The United States Air Force and the Navy formally merged their air transport services today in one of the largest operations yet undertaken to unify the military services. Henceforth the Military Air Transport Service will operate the dual organizations heretofore known as the Air Transport Command (Air Force) and the Naval Air Transport Service.

THE HAGUE, June 1 -- The First Chamber of the States General [Parliament] voted unanimously today in favor of a motion expressing satisfaction at the creation of the State of Israel. However, the Government announced that recognition must be withheld at present because of opposition in Dutch overseas territories.

Political leaders of the major and minor parties have begun to consider their nominations for local, state and Congressional posts, with both major parties yet to make final decisions as to what extent, if any, they will accept nominations proffered by either the Communist-dominated American Labor party, or the right-wing Liberal party.

CLEVELAND, June 1 -- Ninety-seven holders of common stock of the old Cliffs Corporation who did not approve the merger of their holding company with the Cleveland Cliffs Iron Company a year ago have received an offer to sell their 48,232 shares at $39 a share, less a commission of 37 cents a share.

BERLIN, June 1 -- The Soviet military administration is dismantling or plans to dismantle in the Russian zone of occupation nineteen industrial plants employing about 70,000 workers, it was learned today from a reliable British source.
The New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, world's largest and most modern commercial airfield, was opened on a limited basis at 8 A.M. yesterday for its first flight operations.

Charles W. Mackett has been appointed sales manager of the Hewitt rubber division of Hewitt-Robins, Inc., manufacturers of mechanical rubber goods. He formerly was assistant sales manager of the division.

LONDON, June 1 -- A new eight-page tabloid-size Government bulletin on industri production made its bow to workers and management today. The new publication, the product of the economic unit of the Central Office of Information, is known as the "Target."

TOKYO, June 1 -- The Japanese food situation is again growing somewhat serious despite Government promises that the ration may be increased soon and prospects of larger imports from the United States.

Guy W. Vaughan, president of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, announced yesterday that after taxes it had a consolidated net profit of $1,340,068 equal to 12 cents a common share, in the first three months of 1948. No comparison was available for the same period of last year, but the company had a net loss of $1,365,258 for 1947.

For the first time in forty-three years the people of South Korea yesterday could walk the streets of their cities and the lanes of their countryside with dignity. They still had no Constitution, they still had no Government, their land still was occupied by alien troops, but in their capital city of Seoul was meeting a National Assembly of their own choosing, which is to write a Constitution and form a Government.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- The Senate today passed a bill authorizing the discharge of "indiscreet or disloyal" government employes for national security reasons. The measure, approved by unanimous consent on a routine call of the Senate calendar, now goes to the House.
BROCKVILLE, Ont., June 1 (Canadian Press) -- Miss Barbara Ann Scott turned professional today.

Some new teams moved a step in the right direction in the Long Island challenge round matches of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub series at the Deepdale Country Club, Great Neck, yesterday.

Prosecution witnesses, including doctors and a dentist, testified yesterday that they gave bonuses ranging from $2,000 to $3,000 each to an alleged rent gouger for leases to professional apartments at Stuyvesant Town, East Side housing development operated by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
Issues of new public utility and railroad securities totaling more than $20,000,000 were awarded at competitive sales yesterday to underwriting managers as follows:

Considered an authority on Negro life as the result of the success of "Anna Lucasta," Harry Wagstaff Gribble has written and staged "Almost Faithful," which opens tonight under the auspices of the American Negro Theatre at its citadel, 15 West 126th Street.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., June 1 -- Earnings of the Standard Oil Company (N.J.) for the first half of 1948 will be approximately $210,000,000, or slightly more than $7.50 a capital share, the highest net income for any six months in the company's history, F.W. Abrams, chairman, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting here today.

In Installment 19 of his memoirs Winston Churchill asserts that the Baltic states had broken free from the Soviet Government in the civil war of 1918-20; that they had built up a type of society and government of which the main principle was hostility to communism and to Russia, and, last of all, that Latvia alone of all the Baltic states had associated itself with Hitlerite Germany.

JERUSALEM, June 1 -- A number of mortar shells fell in the Jewish areas of Jerusalem around midnight but no offensive action was undertaken by either side. The virtual blackout on military news continued here.

The first Distinguished Service Award of the American Cancer Committee to be bestowed by the Bronx Cancer Committee was presented last night to Jack D. Kelly, a member of the Adolph S. Ochs Post, American Legion, for his outstanding work in the Bronx committee's current campaign.
PARIS, June 1 -- The General Confederation of Labor (CGT), Communist-led and inspired issued orders to all its union locals today "to act" to gain an immediate 20 per cent increase in wages.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A last-minute spurt of testimony on a bill for a National Science Foundation got under way before the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee today.
HAVANA, June 1 -- President Ramon Grau San Martin tonight declared that Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras was the new President of the island in a broadcast to the public from the Presidential Palace.
CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- President Truman was asked today to expedite pending contracts for five passenger-cargo merchant vessels by John Green, president of the Industrial Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, CIO, and Mayor George Brunner of Camden, N.J.

Governor Dewey declared last night that acceptance by both sides of the United Nations appeal for a four-week Palestine truce was the "most heartening and hopeful news" to reach the world since hostilities started in the Holy Land.

Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company yesterday announced an increase of 5 per cent on its woven line of carpets, effective June 7. The company stated that the advance was made necessary by substantially higher raw materials and labor costs resulting from current negotiations for wage increases, which, when ratified, will be retroactive to June 1.

A two-year contract between Mailers Union No. 6 of the International Typographical Union, AFL, and thirteen major newspapers in this city went into effect yesterday, William Mapel, vice chairman of the Publishers Association of New York City, announced.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The State Department reminded the Soviet Government today that the United States still desired to revise the Italian peace treaty so as to restore Trieste to Italian sovereignty. A fourth note on the subject was handed to Alexander S. Panyushkin, the Soviet Ambassador, who is about to return to Moscow for a conference.

SEATTLE, June 1 -- Displaced persons from the American zones of Europe, if admitted to the United States under a bill pending in Congress, would be given every possible assistance by Presbyterians, the 160th General Assembly of the church declared today.

SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., June 1 -- By a new method of isotope separation known as "heat flush," the rare element helium 3 has been concentrated in the laboratory until it is 400,000 times more abundant than it actually is found, physicists meeting at the Ram's Head Inn here reported today.
I think an interesting postscript could be added to your editorial of May 5 entitled "Mr. Mayor, Any Smoke Plans?"

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 920, compared with 1,935 last week and 1,678 in the similar week of last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 313 arrivals yesterday against 868 last Tuesday.

Don G. Hays, formerly advertising director of The Wichita (Kansas) Eagle and The Indianapolis (Indiana) Star, has been named manager of the new chain store department within the retail division of the Bureau of Advertising, ANPA, it was announced yesterday.

The Harlem community prepared yesterday to pay tribute to Miss Anna E. Lawson, principal of the Julia Ward Howe Junior High School for Girls, at 212 West 120th Street, who completed twenty-five years of service in Harlem public schools.
LONDON, June 1 -- The Anglo-Iranian Oil Company's announcement of record profits of 18,564,857 in 1947, compared with 9,624,938 in 1946, caused great excitement in the stock market here today.

LONGMEADOW, Mass., June 1 (UP) -- A Longmeadow woman plunged a carving knife into the neck of her sleeping husband today in what was described as a possible "mercy killing." The pajama-clad body of Walton M. Blackford. 61 years old, a Springfield paper company executive, was found on a bed.

A resolution linking Economic Cooperation Administration purchases with the liquidation of indebtedness now owed by Latin-American countries to American exporters was adopted yesterday at the meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

WELLINGTON, N. Z., June 2 -- Walter Nash, Finance Minister, said in an interview today that reports that New Zealand might find it impracticable to live within her current overseas income and that her sterling balances would fall substantially during 1948 were true in substance.

LONDON, June 2 -- Britain will end the present year with the balance of trade still running against her unless a marked decline in prices of imports occurs, Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today. He added that if the costs of imports rose very rapidly while exports lagged, "

PALOMAR MOUNTAIN OBSERVATORY, Calif., June 2 -- The 200-inch telescope atop this granite mountain, 130 miles southeast of Pasadena, mightiest astronomical eye ever constructed by man for extending his power to explore the vastness of his cosmos, will be dedicated here tomorrow in the presence of about 1,000 distinguished scientists and leaders in other fields.

Governors Island dropped most of its military mien yesterday and turned the day over to a gala children's circus, put on by the reservation's Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts, Cub Scouts and Brownies to finance their activities for the coming year.

LONDON, June 2 -- The International Conference on the Safety of Life at Sea overrode today objections of the Soviet Union delegation to a preliminary draft convention. Delegates from thirty countries attending the conference, which has been in progress here for six weeks, accepted in substance the draft submitted by the General Provisions Committee at a plenary session.

Helen Hayes will terminate a prolonged absence from the air when she begins a show of her own, "Electric Theatre," on CBS, Sunday, Oct. 3, at 9 P. M. Original scripts, as well as adaptations of stage plays, are to be booked for the dramatic series, which will be produced by Joseph Stauffer and directed by Lester O'Keefe.

After studying pictures of the close finishes in the 100-yard dash and 120-yard high hurdles in last Saturday's Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships, Asa S. Bushnell yesterday announced revision of several minor placings in these events.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Note. The hand of politics now reaches into every act and policy of government. Its shadow if not its substance is felt in all three branches, not excluding the Judiciary. This complete intrusion of politics becomes established about this time every four years.
AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, June 2 (AP) -- King Abdullah beamed today and said the Arab League acceptance of the cease-fire in Palestine was the wisest decision in the League's history.

The Illinois Bell Telephone Company sold yesterday an issue of $60,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage 3 per cent bonds at an interest cost of 2.89 per cent to a banking syndicate of 101 participants headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. The winning bid was 102.2099 for a 3 per cent interest coupon. A syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co. bid 101.77999 for 3s.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 26*, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., June 2 -- Marymount College awarded degrees here today to ninety-two seniors at the college's twenty-fifth annual commencement exercises. Six hundred persons attended. Auxiliary Bishop Stephen J. Donahue of New York presided.

The John and Mary R. Markle Foundation appropriated $460,000 last year as gifts to medical colleges and universities for research, it was announced yesterday by John M. Russell, executive director, in the fund's annual report. These grants raised to $11,000,000 the total gifts made by the foundation in the twenty years since its founding.

Water polluted by the city's sewage has created a serious health hazard and has closed down "good bathing beaches," members of the Interstate Sanitation Commission found yesterday as they inspected the East River and the upper harbor.
TORONTO, June 2 (AP) -- Gigantic forest fires in northern Ontario roared across more than 125,000 acres today, destroying rich timber, killing wild life and endangering lumber camps.
TOKYO, June 2 -- Japan's top-heavy bureaucracy must be reduced in numbers and stripped of many of its powers, Premier Hitoshi Ashida declared in an exclusive interview today.

The names of eight boys and girls who will receive scholarships to Roman Catholic high schools as a result of competitive examinations held May 15 last were announced yesterday by officials of the Holy Name Society of the Police Department in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond, sponsor of the annual competition.

Fears that wartime expansion of production facilities would result in excess capacity in some lines and that surplus war plants and tools would be a drag on the market for capital goods have proved to be groundless, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York asserts in its Monthly Review published today.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., June 2 -Efficient production depends on "effective application of technology to all our industrial processes; cooperation of eployes; an uninterrupted flow of materials and parts, free of interference from industry-wide strikes or artificial restrictions on the use of materials and labor," Charles E. Wilson, president of General Motors Corporation, declared at a Chamber of Commerce luncheon here today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 2 (AP) --Midshipman E. Newbold Smith was honored today as the Naval Academy's foremost athlete as sixty-seven trophies, medals, cups, weapons and commendatory letters were presented to standout midshipmen at a brigade formation on Worden Field.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 2 -- The Massachusetts Institute of Technology said today it had "shed new light" on the mystery of cosmic rays.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A veteran labor leader, Daniel J. Tobin, taking for his theme, "Blunder of One Union Hurts All," has addressed a gentle admonition to some of his fellow-union chiefs for causing or threatening national paralysis strikes.

LOS ANGELES, June 2 -- Eight of California's fourteen Republican members of Congress gained a strong grip on re-election in November by capturing both Republican and Democratic nominations in yesterday's party primaries, nearly complete election returns indicated tonight.

JERUSALEM, June 1 (Delayed) -- Some 6,000 refugee Jewish women, children and aged from the exposed sections of Jewish Jerusalem, including 1,200 from the Old City, are making themselves at home in Katamon.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 2 (UP) -- Four hundred demonstrators from New Orleans, accusing Gov. Earl Long of attempting to put the South's largest city under "carpetbag rule," marched into the State Capitol today and dared Mr. Long to come out and meet them. He stayed in his office.

William W. Mathews sold to the Hampshire Development Company, Inc., the two-story dwelling and approximately four acres of vacant land on the north side of Arrandale Avenue, 225 feet east of Wood Road, Great Neck, L. I., for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $32,000.

Capitalizing on an eight-run third inning, Fordham snapped a five-game losing streak by conquering Manhattan, 14 -- 5, in a Metropolitan Conference battle at Fordham Field yesterday. The victory, the Rams' eighth in fourteen circuit starts, clinched fourth place for the Maroon.

Electric shock theraphy is "most helpful" in treatment of patients with involved mental reactions, Dr. James H. Wall declared yesterday in the annual report of the New York Hospital -- Westchester Division, formerly known as the Bloomingdale Asylum.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Fifty Washington correspondents unanimously forecast a Republican victory in November and by a wide margin predicted that Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan would be the next President.
Local food wholesalers have begun a concerted drive to get exemption from the city's general business tax, it became known yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 2 -Premier Riad es-Solh, returning today from the Arab conference in Amman, declared the Arab States would continue fighting in Palestine until the United Nations confirmed the cease-fire and gave assurance that the Jewish forces would observe it.

Miss Virginia C. Gildersleeve, dean emeritus of Barnard College, was guest of honor last night at a buffet supper in Barnard Hall given by the trustees of the college for reunion classes attending the annual alumnae day activities.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 2 -- The United Nations was urged by a group of information experts today to reduce closed-door sessions to a minimum.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 2 -RKO has named Fred Zinnemann, director of the recent European film, "The Search," to direct "Battleground," the studio's projected picture about the Battle of the Bulge, which Jesse Lasky and Walter McEwen will produce, starting in September.

Two boys, 8 and 12 years old, appeared at a livery stable at 175th Street and Park Avenue, the Bronx early yesterday morning and announced they wanted to hire a horse and wagon in which to run away. They offered to pay for it with a $25 war bond.

FOR the first time since his disputed victory over Jersey Joe Walcott, Joe Louis won a unanimous decision the other day. Alarmed by widespread rumors that the champion would be unable to boil off excess suet in time to meet the challenger at the Yankee Stadium on June 23, the Twentieth Century Sporting Club hastily arranged a safari to the Louis camp so that the boxing experts could see the Brown Bomber themselves.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Representative John E. Rankin, Democrat, of Mississippi, today demanded an "immediate investigation" of reports that certain newspaper, magazine and book publishers and motion picture producers would share a $15,000,000 subsidy under the European Recovery Program.

LONDON, June 2 -- The reassuring Middle East reports and gradual return of confidence regarding the political situation in South Africa provided a favorable background to the start of the new account in the stock market here today.

The executive committee of New York County Committee of the Liberal party has endorsed Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican, for re-election in the Twenty-first Congressional District, Murray Baron, county chairman, announced yesterday.

DETROIT, June 2 (AP) -- The Strategic Air Command's mightiest attacking force assembled since the war, about 350 planes in a single mass formation, struck at the Selfridge Field air base here today in a powerful mock bombing raid under simulated war conditions.

Exemption of positions in the state civil service from competition and the "political" appointment of a new president of the New York City Commission were criticized yesterday by the Civil Service Reform Association at its new headquarters at 120 East Twenty-ninth Street.
A recent editorial enumerates all the varieties of destruction of park property except the killing and injuring of squirrels and birds, on the ground and up in their nests.

This city's panorama of towering spires of steel and stone is viewed with constant awe and admiration by townspeople and visitors alike. But brushing aside for a moment the glamour of the skyscraper, and getting down to earth with facts and figures, New York's new tax assessment rolls emphasize anew that it takes a lot of money to erect and maintain these massive buildings.

LANDSBERG, Germany, June 2 (AP) -- Four German doctors and three SS (Elite Guard) officers were hanged today for having killed and maimed thousands of persons in medical experiments on Nazi concentration camp inmates.
BOSTON, June 2 (AP) -- A triple dead heat for show overshadowed the nine-length victory of the Circle K Farm's Misleader in the feature at Suffolk Downs before a crowd of 13,024 today.

Racketeering car dealers, irresponsible drivers and the proposed $5 and $10 auto use tax in New York were denounced yesterday at the annual meeting of the New York State Automobile Dealers at the Commodore Hotel.
HOUSTON, Tex., June 2 -- The Navy Department has approved sale of the Brown Ship Yard here to George and Herman Brown, who operated the yard during the war. The Houston Chronicle reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Thousands marched on Washington today in orderly demonstrations demanding defeat of the Mundt-Nixon Communist Control Bill and the enactment before Congress recesses of the so-called civil rights program.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 2 -- The Spanish Republican Government in Exile asked Secretary General Trygve Lie today to use the prestige of the United Nations to stop the execution of a Catalan political leader condemned to death by Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

Immediate doubling of America's aluminum capacity is not enough for what lies ahead of this country, George S. Brady, industrial consultant, told the closing session of the thirty-third annual convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

There is the danger in the present Congressional argument over the silly programs broadcast to South America by the National Broadcasting Company, under the aegis of "The Voice of America," that the whole State Department informational and cultural program, and especially radio, will suffer. This should not happen.
LONDON, June 2 -- The House of Lords rejected today by 181 votes to 28 the clause of the Government's Criminal Justice Bill providing abolition of capital punishment for a five-year trial period.
Mrs. Millard L. Robinson has purchased a cooperative apartment in 880 Fifth Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc. Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., are the agents.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 2 -- Currency reform for the three Western zones will be introduced in advance of the announcement that a Western German Government is to be formed, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Herbert Hoover said, in effect, today that the American standard of living was threatened by the high cost of government.

William Balderston, executive vice president of the Philco Corporation, was elected president to succeed John Ballantyne, who was named chairman of the board to replace Larry E. Gubb who declined re-election because of illness, it was announced following the organization meeting of the board held in Philadelphia yesterday.

Net income of the American Power and Light Company in 1947 amounted to $22,167,968, compared with $22,218,747 in 1946, according to the annual report issued yesterday. Operating revenues were improved at $157,913,188, as against $140,848,621 in the preceding year.
LONDON, June 2 -- The official announcement that an agreement had been reached by the six-power conference on Western Germany was issued here and in the other capitals concerned today.

Many and oft-repeated have been the Republican protests in Congress against giving large "discretionary" powers to the President. "Under the Constitution it is the business of Congress, and not of the Executive, to legislate." So has run the argument. And now?

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Borderminister Exploration Company, Ltd., of Ottawa, Canada, registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission 500,000 shares of $1 par-value common stock that is to be offered publicly at 40 cents a share, Canadian funds. Mark Daniels Co., Toronto, which holds an option on the stock at 30 cents a share, has been named as underwriter.
STANTON, Del., June 2 (AP) -- Cortright Wetherill's Raise You, a daughter of Case Ace and Lady Glory, won the $10,000 added five-furlong Polly Drummond Stakes at Delaware Park today.

PERHAPS the fact that the story of Robin Hood is one that we generally read first as children is a reason that it has been neglected by the modern writers of adult fiction. It is still one of the best-known stories in English, available in ballad, prose, technicolor and eomie-strip forms, but retaining always a good deal of the flavor of adolescent adventure that has come down with it from the late Middle Ages.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 2 -- The United Nations Security Council decided today that both the Provisional Government of Israel and the seven members of the Arab League had accepted unconditionally its resolution requesting a four-week cease-fire order in Palestine.

An Army private and his French fiancee were married yesterday afternoon after a New York benefactor, touched by their financial plight, posted bond for the girl's release from Ellis Island and provided the scene and equipment for the ceremony.

The United States liner America left here yesterday with 1,003 passengers, the largest number she has carried on an eastbound run this year. The ship sailed at 4:05 P. M. from Pier 61, North River, for Cobh, Southampton and Le Havre.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Unusual strength in July and September corn featured the grain trade today on the Board of Trade, and was a factor in lifting prices also for wheat and oats. The dry weather throughout the principal grain areas was a buying stimulant, but the July position in corn is apparently extremely tight, and this is the main bullish influence.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Bethlehem Steel Corporation submitted the apparent low bid of $23,116,000 each today for two 20,000-ton passenger-cargo vessels for American Export Lines, Inc., of New York. Three shipbuilding firms entered bids with the Maritime Commission.

Cuba has now laid down a four-year political pattern for itself in a Presidential election won by Dr. Carlos Prio Socarros, the Government candidate. This means that the middle-of-the-road, liberal policies of President Ramon Grau San Martin, who cannot succeed himself under the law, will be carried forward when Dr. Prio assumes office next October.

Today Newfoundland is holding a plebiscite, very different from the packed plebiscites of totalitarian Europe, to determine its national future. The questions at issue are whether the island shall march with the confederation of Canada, whether it will extend its economic bonds with the United States or whether it will retain its present commission form of government.

LONDON, June 2 -- A British Government spokesman revealed today before an aroused House of Lords that the Soviet Government had refused eighteen consecutive British requests to permit Russian-born wives of British subjects to leave Russia and join their husbands here.

The A. O. Smith Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries, manufacturer of metal products, had a net profit of $4,807,346 after taxes and all charges for the nine months ended on April 30, last, the company reported yesterday. The profit is equal to $4.81 a share and compares with $1,694,719 or $1.69 a share cleared in the similar period of the preceding fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -Robert E. Freer, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said today free competition is often "ruinous, harsh and brutal," but Government regulation of business would be worse.

SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., June 2 -- Scientific speculation by a group of leading theoretical physicists meeting at the Ram's Head Inn here centered today about the possibility that man may soon he able to remove heat until a substance is within one one-millionth of a degree of absolute zero -- the coldest temperature possible.

CINCINNATI, June 2 -- Husky Willard Marshall, and two long and lean fellows named Buddy Kerr and Larry Jansen pooled their natural resources today to start the Giants off on their second swing around the West with a 7-to-4 triumph over Johnny Neun's Reds.
Edgar Baker, general manager of Time-Life International, which publishes the international editions of Time and Life, said last night:
CORTLAND, N. Y., June 2 (AP) -- The Cortland Standard, this city's only daily newspaper, was published today despite a strike of L printers.

The Eastern College Athletic Conference has ruled college baseball players under its control may not play in the Vermont Northern League or similar resort circuits, under penalty of being declared ineligible for college competition.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- President Truman today asked Congress to appropriate $600,000 for disaster relief in the communities flooded by the Columbia in the Northwest.

Irving Brodsky, attorney, purchased from William Newman the vacant plot 270 by 200 feet on the west side of Central Avenue, south of Hartsdale Avenue, Hartsdale, Westchester County, through Sigmund I. Natanson, broker. He plans a super market and retail store center on the property, title to which was insured by the Lawyers Title Corporation.

BERLIN, June 2 -- A program of conciliation and appeasement for the Soviet zone has been announced by Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, commander of the Soviet Army in Germany and chief of the Soviet Military Administration.

In April, 1946, Mr. and Mrs. Girard Van Barkaloo Hale of Santa Barbara, Calif., heard of the devastation wrought by the Germans upon the little French village of Maille (Indre-et-Loire), near Tours, and decided to "adopt" it. Since then their generosity has gone a long way toward rehabilitating Maille and has started a wave of similar "adoptions" of European war-wrecked villages by other Americans.

A 41-year-old business man who enrolled at New York University in 1942 because he felt he "needed a diversion," will be graduated next Wednesday with the highest scholastic average in the history of the university's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance.

The News Syndicate Company, publisher of The Daily News, has acquired for all cash from J. Arthur Kennedy Son, Inc., the one and two-story buildings and vacant land at Ferris Street and Buttermilk Channel, Brooklyn. The property, which has a frontage of about 900 feet along the channel and bay, will be used by the purchaser as a paper warehouse.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (UP) -- Ralph W. Moore, a commodity trader here, today denied charges made by the Department of Agriculture that he issued to the press a false statement aimed at increasing lard prices.

NEW DELHI, India, June 2--With initial capital of $33,000,000, the India Government has established the rehabilitation Finance Administration to advance loans to industrialists and businessmen who were forced to abandon their enterprises in Pakistan during the disturbances following the inauguration of the two dominions.

The five-story building containing a restaurant and eight apartments and occupying a lot 18 by 100, feet at 52 East Fifty-second Street has been resold by David S. Meister, operator, to an investing client of Leo Eckman, attorney. The Cross Brown Company was the broker in the sale of the property, which is assessed for $66,000 and is between Madison and Park Avenues.

Mysterious goings-on in the subways have been warning us for some weeks that something like a revolution in the conditions of everyday life in New York is not far ahead. Strong, silent men have been seen about the stations -- like Times Square -- taking down the stout iron grills that fenced off the runways that got us to the BMT instead of to the IRT, for example.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP) -- The lowly White Sox kept the Athletics in second place in the American League race tonight as they pounded Bill Dietrich and Nelson Potter for 11 hits and a 7-3 victory. Cass Michaels of Chicago hit his second homer of the season in the sixth off Potter.
ST. ANNE'S-ON-SEA, England, June 2 (AP) -- Tiny Miss Louise Suggs of Atlanta, women's United States amateur golf champion, sloshed into the final of the women's British amateur championship today.

NEWARK, N. J., June 2 -- Middleweight champion Rocky Graziano and challenger Tony Zale were examined today by Dr. Max Stern of the New Jersey State Athletic Commission. The athletes, who will meet in a 15-round title contest at Ruppert Stadium next Wednesday night, were pronounced in excellent shape.

George de Cuevas, lessee of the International Theatre, Columbus Circle and Fifty-ninth Street, has turned over the house, without any strings attached, to the New York City Center of Music and Drama to cover "a preliminary trial period until January, 1949."

The serious young man walked vigorously to the podium, faced the symphony orchestra of eager teenagers and brought his poised right hand down, and with it there sounded the first notes of "Fantasy," the major composition performed yesterday at the annual "Concert of Original Compositions" of the High School of Music and Art.

Representatives of 125,000 unionized employes of the General Electric Company charged last night that GE's continued failure to follow the lead of other major companies in offering higher wages was "penalizing" its workers to the extent of "at least $1,000,000 every week."

The stock market remained yesterday at about its previous level, although continued demand for the oils inspired scattered bidding in other sections. Prices were irregularly higher at the close, when the steels and farm equipments came to the fore and permitted some gains in excess of a point although the combined average rose only 0.28.

The World's Committee of the Y. M. C. A. announced yesterday, through Dr. George Edmund Haynes, consultant for Africa, plans to develop for the African people "an indigenous leadership" to stave off social chaos in new industrial areas of the continent.
New York's record of accidental deaths in the last three years indicates that this city gradually is becoming a safer place in which to live, the Greater New York Safety Council reported yesterday.
Winners of this season's auditions of the Music Education League, entered as soloists in the various classes for piano, violin and voice, were announced yesterday. The list is as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Tentative orders have been issued to twenty-one Army, Navy and Air Force officers of high rank to go to Palestine as truce observers, it was learned today. All are colonels, lieutenant colonels, captains or commanders.
PARIS. June 2 -- After a day of parliamentary negotiations frought with the atmosphere of a crisis the Schuman Cabinet passed tonigth the first of a series of obstacles that had arisen in its path.

GENEVA, June 2 -- France and Italy have rejected the Polish coal allocated to them for the third quarter of 1948 by the coal allocations subcommittee of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Palestine truce and President Truman's "non-political" speaking tour of the country are scheduled to start at approximately the same time -- a coincidence that is worrying the State and Defense Departments.

PITTSBURGH, June 2 (AP) -- Johnny Sain allowed only three hits tonight, pitching the Braves to a 5-1 victory over the Pirates. A crowd of 25,710 saw Pittsburgh pull the first triple play of the National League season in the eighth inning.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 2 -- W. Newell Snow, Princeton University senior from New York, has been selected by the university faculty to deliver the Latin salutatory address at Princeton's 201st annual commencement exercises on June 15, it was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.
ROME, June 2 -- Pope Pius XII urged all Catholics today to press for needed social reforms "to provide the poorer classes with housing, bread and work."
Offerings of public utility and industrial stock valued at more than $16,000,000 will be placed on the market here today by underwriting syndicate managers as follows:

To nip a secession movement by anti-Communist elements in the United Office and Professional Workers, CIO, the national leaders of the union have suspended six locals of industrial insurance agents in Connecticut, Massachusetts and Missouri, it became known yesterday.

The election of Philip Lemler as vice president and general manager of Todd Shipyards Corporation operations in the San Francisco Bay area, effective July 1, was announced here yesterday by John D. Reilly, president of the company.

Tonight's events: Carnegie Pop concert, Viennese program, Mario Cortez, conductor, Elaine Malbin, soprano, Leslie Chabay, tenor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Donald Johnston, baritone, winner of the Concert Award of the American Theatre Wing's Professional Training Program, Times Hall, 8:30.

HAVANA, June 2 -- Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, former revolutionary leader and close friend of President Grau San Martin, was Cuba's undisputed President-elect today as official returns confirmed his victory in all six Provinces. The Vice President-elect is Dr. Guillermo Alonso Pujol.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A split within the Tariff Commission itself over whether a greater voice should be given the agency in the preparation of reciprocal trade agreements was brought out before the Senate Finance Committee today.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- The House of Delegates of the American Nurses' Association voted overwhelmingly today for one national nursing association in place of the six present organizations in the field, three of them professional and three of them numbering non-nurses in their memberships.
Shields Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, have announced the opening of an office in Houston, Text, with James R. Buck as resident manager and Robert R. Harmon as assistant.
ROME, June 2 (AP) -- Following is the English-language text of Pope Pius' address to a group of cardinal today:

ST. LOUIS, June 2 -- Through the happy combination of Young Gil Hodges' recent zest for driving in runs and California Joe Hatten's effective pitching, the Dodgers tonight beat the Cardinals for the first time in five attempts this year, 5 -- 3.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jun 2 -- The World Jewish Congress appealed today to the Commission on Human Rights to declare a fundamental right of persons to seek and receive asylum from persecution.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 2 -- Earl P. Shreve, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, speaking today before Dutch officials and business men and representatives of the United States State Department, said there must be no mistake as to the intention of the European Recovery Program.
Random notes.

NANKING, June 2 -- The Government acknowledged today that six of the thirteen Nationalist armies formed out of United States-trained and equipped divisions had been mauled by the Communists during the last two years of the civil war.
GLEN COVE, L. I., June 2 -- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association spring intersectional team matches for the Golf Illustrated Trophy were played over the Nassau Country Club course today.

Bawl Street Journal A preview of the 1948 Bond Club outing edition of the Bawl Street Journal was made available yesterday to the press, disclosing an eight-page satire in advertisements, cartoons and articles (unsigned) on Wall Street's ups and downs of recent memory.

" Dear Mike: We have read and reread the little story about you in the morning papers, which brings the astounding news that Michael Kivatisky, 12, one of nine children in a family which lives at 1376 First Avenue, has turned down the offer of a free two-week vacation at a camp in up-state New York.

The struggle of an Armenian shoemaker to obtain the release of three of his children from Catholic institutions in this city entered a new phase yesterday when a group of Protestant churchmen asked Raymond M. Hilliard, Welfare Commissioner, to intervene.

BOSTON, June 2 (UP) -- The American Federation of Labor had on file in Federal District Court today a suit against the Western Union Telegraph Company in an attempt to halt a mechanization program which the federation said nullified provisions of its contract and threatened the jobs of ready employes.

Three leaders of an anti-Communist faction in the Bloomingdale department store union, whose ouster from their store jobs had been demanded by the local union, won a stay of dismissal yesterday through the intervention of their parent union.

Interpreting the Arab and Israeli replies to its demand for a truce in Palestine as unconditional acceptances, the Security Council has now instructed Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations mediator, to set the day and hour when cease-fire orders are to be put into effect.

CHICAGO, June 2 (AP) -- Eddie Waitkus opened the twelfth inning with a single, raced to third on a combination passed ball and wild throw by Andy Seminick, then scored on Phil Cavarretta's single to lift the Cubs to a 2-1 victory over the Phillies today.

ALBANY, N. Y., June 2 -- Governor Dewey will fly to Boston Friday for a luncheon meeting with the Massachusetts delegation to the Republican National Convention, his executive assistant, James C. Hagerty, announced today. He will return to Albany the same night.

Two books have been chosen for August distribution by the Book-of-the-Month Club. They are "Road to Survival." by William Vogt, and "The Sky and the Forest," by C. S. Forester. Mr. Vogt's book, which will be published by William Sloane Associates on Aug. 5, is a discussion of man's food supply and the conservation of natural resources.

Libby, McNeil Libby are now starting a frozen food operation in the metropolitan area with twelve varieties of frozen fruits, vegetables and berries that is expected to carry them to second position in the local market "within the very near future," it was learned here yesterday from company officials and reliable trade sources.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong in the late trading yesterday and final prices were 9 to 25 points net higher, led by the strength in the July contract.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Rae Scarborough edged Bob Lemon in a pitching duel tonight, the Senators clustering their five hits into two innings to defeat the Indians, 2 -- 1, before a crowd of 20,405. Washington ended Lemon's string of 28 consecutive scoreless innings by pushing over a run in the fourth inning.

Production of crude oil in the United States increased last week 12,450 barrels to 5,451,650 barrels daily, marking a record high for the third successive week, according to the report of the American Petroleum Institute issued yesterday. Crude oil production for the week ended on May 31, 1947, was 5,024,350 barrels daily.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Management made a strong bid today for legislation to override the National Labor Relations Board's Inland Steel decision requiring employers to bargain with employes on pensions.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The House Judiciary Committee approved today a measure designed to waive judicial rulings blocking deportation proceedings against aliens accused of being Communists.

The Board of Transportation sold yesterday the last quantity of the 10,063,000 tokens purchased by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company in 1928 when that corporation began its ill-fated move for a higher subway fare.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 2 -After a day of confusion in the course of which Israel learned that its cease-fire order had been based upon a misapprehension of the Security Council's intentions, and after the deadline had been violated by the Arabs, new orders went out tonight to the Haganah and the fighting is again in full swing.
PARIS, June 2 -- Soviet diplomacy could not have selected a more apt moment to promote its "peace offensive" and its corollary effort to sow discord among the Western Allies.
Your lead editorial on May 26, entitled "Republican Folly," seems to me so misleading as to demand a brief protest.

The Omaha, Neb., Public Power District awarded yesterday $5,000,000 of electric revenue bonds due from 1950 to 1968 to a banking group headed by the First Boston Corporation at a net interest cost of 2.14658 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at quotations ranging from a price to yield 1 per cent to a dollar price of 100.

Lured by promises of immediate employment at substantial wages, hundreds of former service men and civilian students who put in long hours of study at privately operated drafting schools in the city have found their training virtually "worthless" and have been unable to qualify for jobs in architects' offices, it became known yesterday.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 2 -- Floodwaters of the Columbia River receded at an agonizingly slow rate today as companies of dike-workers continued their battle to maintain lower river leeves, and a relieved Portland concluded that its west side business district had been saved from inundation.

SALISBURY, Mo., June 2 (UP) -- President Harry S. Truman said that he "was not brought up to run from a fight," in a reply to a suggestion that he drop out of the Presidential race, it was revealed today. The suggestion was made by a Missouri dentist, Dr. H. H. Brummall of Salisbury, who engaged in an exchange of letters with Mr. Truman.
