BOSTON, June 2 (AP) -- Bob Dillinger's two - run single and a homer by Les Moss carried the Browns to a 3-1 victory as right-hander Fred Sanford kept seven Red Sox hits well scattered tonight before a crowd of 34,303 at Fenway Park.

Mrs. Howard S. Nilson of Sands Point led the field of thirty-eight players in the Women's Long Island Golf Association one-day tourney with a gross of 86 over the Oakland Golf Club course at Bayside, yesterday.

I was gratified to see from your distinguished correspondent in London, Herbert L. Matthews, that your contemporary The Times of London publicized my letter calling urgent attention to public feeling over here in regard to the British Government's policy on Palestine.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 2 (AP) -- An Amman dispatch said a column of several hundred Israeli fighters struck eighteen miles into Trans-Jordan before King Abdullah's legionnaires and Arab planes beat them back in a battle that lasted until noon today.

The maritime labor situation showed little change yesterday with meetings between Federal conciliators and two unions proving unproductive. The shipyards workers union, however, opened its negotiations with representatives of the Bethlehem Steel Company.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The Government today gave the European Recovery Program top priority on the purchase of United States war surpluses. Buying orders on behalf of the seventeen Marshall Plan countries will get the same priority on surplus goods as is granted Federal agencies, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, announced.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 2 -- The Yugoslav Government's Legal Gazette today threw some light on the sudden disappearance from the political scene of Sretan Zujovitch, former Minister of Finance, and lent weight to current reports that the Government and Communist party were being purged of unreliable elements and "deviationists."

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, and Andrew G. Clauson Jr., president of the Board of Education, demanded concrete evidence yesterday for a City Councilman's charges that "some schools are breeding nests for hoodlums and gangsters" and that some teachers were propagandizing un-American doctrines.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 2 -Sixty-four garden clubs on Long Island, which make up the Second District of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, staged their annual flower show at the Cathedral Chapter House here today.

Andrei A. Gromyko, Deputy Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union, canceled last night an address he was scheduled to deliver at the annual dinner of the American Russia Institute at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The theatrical season of 1948-49 gets off to an early start this evening with a double opening. At the St. James Theatre, where "Oklahoma!" held reign for so long, Lorraine Lester will unfold a musical play based on Washington Irving's "Legend of Sleepy Hollow."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 2 -- About to be graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he is majoring in chemistry and business, Ralph L. Evans of Bay Shore, L. I., representing the Eastern Massachusetts Yacht Racing Association, today earned a pre-graduation honor.

Within a short time two homes in Queens have been blown apart by gas explosions. Both were accompanied by the loss of human life. The first disaster was caused by the failure of the main shut-off valve. The second, by the failure of the people to find it.

Representatives of the long lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and 25,000 unionized long-distance telephone employes were reported near agreement last night at the end of a seven-hour negotiating session.

Henry H. Klein, former special counsel to the city on utilities, sought a temporary injunction in Supreme Court yesterday to prevent the city from increasing fares to 10 cents on subways and elevated lines on July 1. The order is returnable next Wednesday.

A one-year jail sentence and an $8,500 fine were imposed on a convicted rent gouger in Special Sessions yesterday as a "stern warning" to others seeking to profit on the housing shortage by extorting bonuses for granting living quarters.

EPSOM, England, June 2 (AP) -- A probable field of thirty-three was forecast for the 'English Derby at Epsom Downs on Saturday with the withdrawal today of Roaring Forties and Overhead. Both were outsiders in the betting. The mile and a half test on the famed uphill-downhill track will be worth $49,736 to the winner.

To Robert J. Kleberg's King Ranch went first money of $43,700 and permanent possession of the Coaching Club Cup when Scattered took command after ten of the eleven furlongs and moved out to victory in the $61,800 Coaching Club American Oaks, the East's richest race for 3-year-old fillies, at Belmont Park yesterday.
GENEVA, June 2 -- Max Hymans, secretary general of the French Ministry of Civil Aviation, was elected president of the Assembly of the United Nations International Civil Aviation Organization today.

A coalition movement in the Eighteeenth Congressional District to defeat Representative Vito Marcantonio gained impetus last night at a meeting sponsored by the Independent Citizens Committee for the Defeat of Marcantonio in the Mill Rock Post, Veterans of Foreign Wars, headquarters at 1749 First Avenue.

BERLIN, June 2 -- The first reaction of the German politicians to the uninformative communique issued at the close of the London conference on Western Germany is slightly bitter surprise that the Germans themselves cannot learn the substance of the agreed recommendations on their country's future until they have been discussed by the governments of six participating nations.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The House received a record peacetime armed services defense budget of $10,246,672,250 in cash and contract authorizations today. After less than two hours of debate it approved $6,559,939,000 for the Army and the Air Force by a vote of 348 to 2. Passage of the $3,686,733,250 Navy measure was scheduled for tomorrow.

Cardinal Hayes High School moved into the final round of the City C. H. S. A. A. baseball championship play-offs by vanquishing St. Ann's, the Manhattan titleholder, 3 -- 1, in an eight-inning contest yesterday at the Mount St. Michael field.
TRENTON, N. J., June 2 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll said today that he planned to recall the New Jersey Senate on June 28 to act on several of his appointments to key administration positions.
Joseph T. Sharkey, Vice-Chairman of the City Council, announced last night that he would offer a bill within two weeks to create a bureau that would enforce purification of New York's air.

The housing industry was both challenged and championed yesterday as local officials, architects and educators opened a three-day meeting intended to find the means for producing housing in the required large amounts and lowpriced ranges.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Senate, going into a night session because of the closeness of its adjournment date, gave its approval to the Displaced Persons Act of 1948. The vote was 63 to 13, reflecting regional rather than party divisions.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 2 -- Following is the text of a cablegram from the Egyptian Foreign Minister giving the reply of the Arab League to the cease-fire resolution adopted by the Security Council last Saturday:
MEXICO CITY, June 2 -- A mural painted by Diego Rivera in Mexico City's newly opened Hotel del Prado has become a center of religious controversy.

Herman Levine, Arthur Grayson and Annie Birnbach purchased from Margaret De Padlo eight one-story bungalows at 180-188A Beach Twenty-sixth Street, Edgemere, Queens, through Max Laufer, broker. Two purchase money mortgages in the sum of $20,000 were executed at the closing.

LONDON, June 2 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin voiced the hope today that no conditions set by the Jews or the Arabs would prevent the cease-fire from taking effect in Palestine or the discussions from proceeding on the settlement of the Palestine problem.

Complain to a baker that bread today is so puffy it has no taste or body, and he will reply that the public demands and likes it that way. In a recent survey by the Millers' National Federation, however, some facts and figures came to light that seem to prove that the baker may be wrong.

Hand-to-mouth buying policies in cotton textiles will backfire on many purchasers who are anticipating inventory accumulations at mill levels, W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The American Bosch Corporation, Springfield, Mass., at the direction of Attorney General Tom C. Clark, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 535,882 shares of $1 par value Class B common stock.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The wearing-in of Charles F. Brannan as Secretary of Agriculture today was made the occasion for a bipartisan demand for action now on the long-range farm program, not on the "must" list of Congressional leaders for action before recess.
LONDON, June 2 -- The Imperial Conference that has been proposed by Great Britain may have to take place without South Africa, it was learned today.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 2 -- Four planes piloted by women left the Westchester County Airport here this morning in a race to Miami, Fla., as part of the air show being conducted there by the Ninety-nines, an association of licensed women pilots.

" The Bride Goes Wild," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer comedy starring Van Johnson and June Allyson, will have its local premiere this morning at the Capitol. The child actor, Butch Jenkins. Hume Cronyn, Una Merkel, Arlene Dahl and Lloyd Corrigan are among the supporting players.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee discussed today Gen. Douglas MacArthur's wish to remain in Japan for the present and made no new move to recall him.

Opening of its fall and holiday men's wear line was announced yesterday by Textron, Inc., through Marshall Rawle, vice president in charge of marketing. Only two of the ten items included have reduced prices, the others remaining unchanged.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The United States Air Force has tentative plans for an academy to train its own regular officers, probably at Randolph Field, in Texas, where eventually the enrollment would approximate the size of the Army's cadet corps at West Point. Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Chief of Staff of the Air Force, making this announcement today, said the cost of the academy had been estimated "very roughly" at about $90,000,000.
Those twenty extra pounds that Vic Raschi packed on his 6-foot 2-inch frame over the winter inflated him into the most important personage on the Yankee pitching staff.
SEATTLE, June 2 -- The United States Government was urged today by the 160th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church to make new efforts to confer with Russian leaders on conflicting policies.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Despite "much uncertainty in the picture," an optimistic view of the outlook for the Pacific Northwest lumber industry was expressed here today by Paul C. Stevens, Western manager for the National American Wholesale Lumber Association, in a report today to the final session of the association's two-day annual meeting.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 2 -- Double taxation, high brackets and the capital gains tax are responsible for the current shortage of venture capital needed to finance industrial expansion in this country, the Edison Electric Institute was told today.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Despite "much uncertainty in the picture," an optimistic view of the outlook for the Pacific Northwest lumber industry was expressed here today by Paul C. Stevens, Western manager for the National American Wholesale Lumber Association, in a report today to the final session of the association's two-day annual meeting.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 2 -- Double taxation, high brackets and the capital gains tax are responsible for the current shortage of venture capital needed to finance industrial expansion in this country, the Edison Electric Institute was told today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Justice T. Alan Goldsborough attempted to act as peacemaker today in the dispute between the United Mine Workers and the Southern Coal Producers Association. At the close of today's hearing he invited Welly K. Hopkins, counsel for John L. Lewis and the miners' union, and John C. Gall, counsel for the Southern Association, to his chambers.

Donald Johnston, baritone and Army veteran, received a big sendoff in the form of a recital debut at Times Hall last night from the Professional Training Program of the American Theatre Wing. The event was his reward for winning the Wing's contest for singermembers of professional experience who had never appeared in recital.

Plans for the appointment of a sub-committee to organize a film section of Americans for Democratic Action were announced yesterday at a "freedom of the screen" luncheon given by the Arts Division of the ADA at the Lotos Club, 5 East Sixty-sixth Street.

Consumer interest in waterrepellent fabrics can best be served by simple codification of fair trade practice rules, it was asserted yesterday by Herman Goodman, chairman of the water-repellent fabric committee of the Textile Distributors Institute.

PITTSBURGH, June 3 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates, with a total of 10 hits, squeezed a 5-3 triumph out of the Boston Braves today, with Elmer Singleton making a nifty ninth-inning rescue of Pitcher Kirby Higbe.
BERLIN, June 3 -- The early proclamation of an "all-German" constitution by the Soviet-sponsored People's Congress in Berlin is expected by United States and British political officers here.

BERLIN, June 3 -- A few hours after he had finished discussing the possibility of extending to the Germans the rights of habeas corpus a United States Military Government official was arrested and detained by the Soviet Military Administration for unspecified charges, the United States Military Government disclosed today.

On paper and for the record, the Yankees lost to the Tigers, 6 - 2, when the Bengals scored four runs in the eleventh inning of their contest at the Stadium yesterday. However, every fan among the 15,571 who saw it will attest to the fact that the Yankees lost it in the ninth, when Gus Niarhos flubbed an attempted bunt on a squeeze play.
DES MOINES, June 3 -- Harold E. Stassen said today he had found no indication at this time of any blocs or combinations lining up for the Republican National Convention this month.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Republican and Democratic Congressional campaign strategists today marked about 100 House and nine Senate seats as the critical contests in the forthcoming battle for control of the next Congress.

Insurance companies in the future will offer property owners "package" policies that will cover all risks and casualties, it was forecast yesterday at the annual meeting of the Insurance Advertising Conference in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.6 per cent during the week ended May 29, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. At 164.4 per cent of the 1926 average, the bureau's comprehensive index was 0.7 per cent below the high point reached in mid-January and 1.7 per cent below the high point reached in May, 1920.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Gerard D. Reilly, former member of the National Labor Relations Board, told Congress today that major amendments to the Taft-Hartley Act now would be premature, but suggested legislation to correct three lines of decision on the Communist disclaimer section of the law.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 3 -Enterprise Productions has signed with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the domestic distribution of four Enterprise films, including the recently completed "Natural Impulse" (formerly "No Minor Vices"); the current "Tucker's People," the projected 'Wild Calendar" and one unspecified film, it was learned today from Metro.

Parents of small children are being smitten, just about now, with a malaise for which there is no sure cure, although the cause is well known. The sudden sinking sensation experienced by the mothers and fathers of youngsters from 6 to 16 years of age or thereabouts is due simply to the realization that the end of school is perilously near.

The DP relief bill just approved by the Senate is a sorry job. Throwing aside the high humanitarian principles of the original Stratton bill and all the powerful arguments advanced by military government, federal government, civic, labor and religious leaders in the past eighteen months, the Senate took one step to rectify the injustices of the Wiley-Revercomb bill by increasing the number of DP admissions to 200,000 for the next two years.

Joseph E. O'Grady, deputy director of the City Division of Labor Relations, announced last night that a settlement of a wage dispute between the Brooklyn Bridge Freezing and Cold Storage Company, 109 Cliff Street, and fourteen union operators of freezing equipment had been settled after an all-day session.

Open air commencement exercises will he held for the largest graduating class in the history of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, 3080 Broadway, at 4 P. M. Sunday in the quadrangle at the seminary. In case of inclement weather the exercises will be held indoors.

Special Sessions Justice Frederick L. Hackenburg declared yesterday in court that "outsiders" who took part in the strike against the New York Stock Exchange were there by orders "dictated by a foreign government, which under the guise of ideology tries to start trouble so that they can publish in Moscow, 'Riots in Wall Street.'"

A peace pact providing wage increases of $5 a week and other gains for 25,000 Manhattan building service workers gave assurance yesterday that there would be no interruption this year in elevator and janitorial service in 4,000 office, loft and apartment buildings.

Eight hundred and fifty Rotarians and members of their families arrived here yesterday on the Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam after attending the thirtyninth annual convention of Rotary International in Rio de Janeiro from May 16 to 20.

Jesse Flores of Stockton, Calif., and Johnny Williams of Montgomery, Ala., who fought a sizzling draw three weeks ago, will meet again tonight in the feature tenround contest at Madison Square Garden.

New York University scored its thirteenth victory in fourteen starts in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference yesterday as Tom Casey shut out St. John's with three hits while his mates were reaching Jerry Brown for eleven and a 3-to-0 verdict.

It was a wise move that the Olympic Rowing Committee made in switching the site of the final Olympic tryouts from Philadelphia's Schuylkill River to Princeton's Lake Carnegie for the ten-day aquatic show which begins on June 30. The Schuylkill had become not only inadequate but actually dangerous. Sandbars shifted overnight as the turbulent river constantly changed its course.

The effect of the United States Treasury's recent decision to hold the rate on its certificates at 1 1/8 per cent was "to treat the economy to a fresh dose of easy money," the National City Bank of New York asserts in its Monthly Letter, issued today.

LONDON, June 3 (UP) -- Oil experts said that the Palestine war was beginning to interfere seriously with oil production in the Middle East. These sources said that the southern branch of the Iraq Petroleum Company's pipeline from the Kirkuk fields to Haifa had ceased operation, and that production of the big Haifa refinery had been interrupted.

BOSTON, June 3 (AP) -- Jack Kramer won his third game of the season for the Red Sox today by pitching the Bostonians to a 3-2 triumph over his old mates, the St. Louis Browns. It was Kramer's first effort against St. Louis, for whom he had toiled eight years.

UPPER BROOKVILLE, L.I., June 3 -- A test pilot for the Grumman Aircraft Corporation and the wife of a gardener on the Vandeventer Crisp estate here were injured this morning when a Navy fighter plane made a forced landing on the estate and struck the gardener's cottage.

ABOARD PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S SPECIAL TRAIN, En route West, June 3 -- President Truman left Washington tonight on a transcontinental speaking tour which may decide his political fate. His train rolled out of Union Station in the capital at 11:05 P.M., Eastern daylight time.

WARSAW, June 3 -- The Government today began selling to its settlers in its new western territories half a million buildings acquired when the Soviet Union turned these former German lands over to Poland. These buildings are houses, handicraft workshops and small industrial establishments.

Boys High's consistent performers, providing a blazing finish to their 1947-48 season yesterday, romped off with the Greater New York interscholastic track and field championship at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island. Sponsored by the New York County Democratic Orgnization, the meet was part of the city's fiftieth jubilee program.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The House Appropriations Committee reduced by a third today a Congressional authorization of $15,000,000 to guarantee convertibility of foreign exchange paid for American newspapers, magazines, books and motion pictures circulating abroad under the European Recovery Program.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -President Truman today created a fact-finding board under the TaftHartley Act to investigate a dispute which threatens to tie up the nation's shipping June 15.
PRETORIA, South Africa, June 3 -- The new Nationalist Government of South Africa was announced tonight. The Cabinet list follows:

Deliberating less than a minute yesterday, three Special Sessions justices unanimously convicted Meyer Greenwald, an attorney formerly in charge of screening applicants for professional apartments in Stuyvesant Town, of rent gouging.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- A group of steel buyers testified today they paid more than $150,000 in premiums for steel since 1945 to the Wayne Sheet Steel Company, a Detroit warehousing company, or persons connected with it.

Although interest rates on small-home mortgages probably will go up, no substantial rise in construction costs is expected this year, according to speakers yesterday at the Institute of Housing and Planning Studies. The institute, under the sponsorship of the State Division of Housing, will end today a three-day conference in the Pennsylvania Hotel on means of increasing production and lowering the cost of housing.

CHICAGO, June 3 (AP) Leaders of the United Farm Equipment and Metal Workers Union, CIO, decided today to observe the nonCommunist provisions of the TaftHartley Act. Four executive board members quit rather than go along, the union said.
ST. PAUL, Minn., June 3 -Plans for settling displaced Europeans in Minnesota, the Dakotas, Wisconsin and Iowa were discussed I here today at a conference of the National Catholic Resettlement Council

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Strong efforts to pass at this session some version of the Mundt-Nixon Communist Control Bill were begun today by Senate Republicans after yesterday's mass demonstrations against the measure.

KENILWORTH, N.J., June 3 -Joe Birofka won the qualifying medal today in the eleventh annual public links championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association. He scored a three-over-par 75 on his home links, the Galloping Hill course of the Union County Park Commission, to lead his clubmate, Mike Kascin, by one stroke.

Toll gates on highways and bridges are like "millstones around the neck of New York," alowly strangling the free flow of traffic, arthur C. Butler, director, National Highway Users Conference, told the delegates yesterday at the closing session of the New York State Automobile Dealers at the Hotel Commodore.

Harnet Homes, Inc., purchased seventy-four lots in Rego Park, Queens, from Milton Barkin for improvement with one-family houses. The property occupies the two blocks on Dry Harbor Road between Eighty-fourth and Eighty-fifth Streets. Samuel L. Norman Associates were the brokers.

It will be just a year ago tomorrow since Secretary of State Marshall launched what President Truman has rightly characterized as '"the greatest venture in constructive statesmanship ever undertaken" -- the European Recovery Program. During that year the Program has been debated, weighed, balanced and perfected by seventeen national governments, by two international conferences, by several American research commissions, and by the American Congress, until it became a reality two months ago.

Roy A. Hunt, president of the Aluminum Company of America, yesterday called upon the nation's industries to "make every effort to assist in solving the tremendous shortage of facilities for generating the electric power so urgently needed by the nation's manufacturers and particularly by the electrochemical industries."
New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday it would receive bids next Friday on an issue of $6,000,000 temporary loan notes dated June 25 and due Dec. 27.

CINCINNATI, June 3 -- Ewell Blackwell, beanpole right-hander of the Reds, returned to a starting role tonight to demonstrate to an admiring crowd of 24,402 that he again was quite ready to take his place among baseball's top-ranking hurlers as Johnny Neun's Cincinnatians toppled the league-leading Giants, 6 to 4.

To meet the proposal of the Office of Industry Cooperation of the Department of Commerce for a voluntary War Production Board type of allocation program for industrial materials, officers of the Association of Steel Distributors yesterday authorized disclosure of complete details of their industrywide plan for an expanded allocations system.

This morning when the $1,500,1000 Schrafft's restaurant with a seating capacity of 1,260 opens its doors in the Esso Building in Rockefeller Center it will mark the fiftieth anniversary of the chain started by Frank G. Shattuck and now operated by his four sons and three grandsons.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Friday, June 4 -- A proposal to establish responsible self-government in Newfoundland led early today in returns from yesterday's referendum on this island's future.

A PRISON CAMP IN TRANS-JORDAN, June 3 (AP) -- The population of this desert camp was doubled today when 359 survivors of the Israeli settlement of Kfar Etzion were marched into the barbed-wire enclosure.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The National Theatre, the only legitimate establishment of its kind here, will be converted into a motion picture theatre in September, according to Marcus Heiman, president of the E Street Theatre Corporatiom

Prices of all tin content bronze ingot have been raised by commercial smelters from 1/4 to 2 cents, depending upon grade, and all white metals have also been raised to equalize sales prices because of the recent 9-cent increase in cost of tin content, nonferrous metals sources revealed here yesterday.

PARIS, June 3 -- Foreign Minister Bidault indicated before the National Assembly today that France considered the new state of Israel as having for the present no legal existence and almost no de facto existence.

The Carnegie Corporation has given Columbia University $150,000 to "begin work immediately on the development of an Institute of European Studies," Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of the university, announced yesterday. It is hoped that the new area institute can be opened in September 1949.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 3 -Rates of foreign exchange in several countries will have to be changed in the near future, but there is no reason why the International Monetary Fund should embark on a general adjustment of parities, either now or in the future, Camille Gutt, managing director of the fund, believes.

Gerard Swope, honorary president of the General Electric Company and a prominent figure in civic, social and industrial affairs during the last twenty-five years, announced yesterday that he had declined a high decoration of the British Government because of its "vacillating, reprehensible and nonconstructive attitude" toward the creation of a separate state in Palestine.

Dismissal of a City College instructor on charges of Communist activities and perjury was defended yesterday by Michael A. Castaldi, assistant New York City corporation counsel. Mr. Castaldi, who heads the education division of the city's Law Department, contended in a brief that circumstantial evidence sufficed to prove that the teacher's activities were "incompatible with good teaching service.

PELHAM, N.Y., June 3 -- The biggest turnout of the season teed up at the Pelham Country Club course today when seventy-eight members took part in the fourth one-day Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association tournament.

Harper will bring out Tuesday "Witnesses for Freedom: Negro Americans in Autobiography," by Rebecca Chalmers Barton, a study of the life stories of twenty-three Negro Americans. On June 23, the concern will bring out a condensed edition of the two-volume work, "An American Dilemma," by Gunnar Myrdal, under the title "The Negro in America."

Going back to Washington Irving, some people of taste and talent have made an unhackneyed musical play out of "Sleepy Hollow," which opened at the St. James last evening. Although Mr. and Mrs. Russell Maloney have not manufactured much of a musical comedy book, they have caught the quality of a legend, which is artless and joyous.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 3 -- A golf official and a seventeen year old junior accounted for the chief prize today in the Long Island Golf Association's one-day tourney over the North Hempstead Country Club course.
TEL AVIV, June 3 (UP) -- Thereh)0*0*0*iwas a general atmosphere of pessimism here over the truce prospects.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The House Appropriations Committee today pruned $1,745,000,000 from Administration estimates of Europe's minimum recovery needs through fiscal 1949 and went on to cut by more than 25 per cent the total foreign-aid program, including amounts already authorized by Congress.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Some political historians and observers are unable to see any future in the independent Democratic movement this year in the South. They give four reasons.

Savings deposits held by the 131 mutual savings banks in this state now total $9,959,002,091, representing an increase of $144,399,519 during the first quarter of 1948, it was reported recently by John Adikes, president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.

Fur retailers now in the market are tending to make commitments for deliveries to Sept. 1, when they will be in better position to judge consumer response for the latter part of the season, it was reported here yesterday. One fur merchandiser, stressing caution, recalled he gave buyers "the green light a year ago at this time," but now is advising operations on the "amber light" until September.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 3 -- The United Nations Security Council was taken aback today by the disclosure that Israel and the Palestinian Arabs still held opposite views on the way that the proposed cease-fire in Palestine would operate.

One thing New Yorkers haven't the temerity to boast about or even mention, contrary to their usual braggadocio, is the weather. Unquestionably, it's the world's worst, regardless of how the Federal Weather Bureau tries to assuage one with nice-looking statistics.

CHICAGO, June 3 (AP) -- Rookie Curt Simmons hurled the Phillies to a 4-to-3 victory over the Cubs today and his team-mate, Richie Ashburn, extended his batting streak to 20 games -- longest of the major-league season.

LOS ANGELES, June 3 -- The tenth anniversary of the moral rearmament movement, the international nonsectarian spiritual crusade led by Dr. Frank N. D. Buchman, was marked tonight by a large mass meeting in the Hollywood Bowl.

THE northernmost county east of Minnesota in the United States is Aroostook, Me., where the potatoes come from. Helen Hamlin, who was born and reared there and lives there now, thinks that Aroostook County is one of the finest pieces of real estate in this country. She has written a pleasant little book about it in "Pine, Potatoes and People:
PARIS, June 3 -- A swiftly gathering step-in in France around the foreign policy of Georges Bidault and the accords on Germany, signed in London today, is expected to reach its climax. Tuesday.

There is a great deal of unorganized, and hence largely ineffective, indignation against the smoke and soot nuisance in New York City. We are pleased to note that one of our most aggressive and influential civic agencies, the Citizens Union, has now decided to take the lead in seeing that something is done about air pollution.

Handwoven reproductions of historic and ancient Chinese patterned silks made by Japanese weavers under the auspices of the United States Government go on view today at the Metropolitan Museum. This series of damasks, brocades and twills is supplemented by original Chinese textiles from the museum and other collections.
Sixty-two-year-old Frank Kellman, whose lifelong effort to earn a living as pushcart peddler was ended last year when he lost his left leg in a bus accident, takes a philosophical view of life.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 3 -The Soviet Minister in Helsinki, Lieut. Gen. G. M. Savonenkov informed Premier Mauno Pekkala today that the Moscow Government had decided to cancel half the remaining reparations due from Finland to the Soviet Union.

A special citation honoring the new State of Israel for offering refuge to persecuted Jews of Europe and a home to displaced persons and for its stand for the dignity of man and equality of opportunity was presented last night by Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the New York area of the Methodist Church on behalf of the Churchman Associates.

Scientific investigation of food and container problems that would confront the nation in any future war is the purpose of a new national research organization headed by Dr. B. S. Clark, director of research for the American Can Company, it was announced yesterday.

Isadore Immerman has purchased the five-story apartment house at 1563 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, from Bessie F. Clarke for cash above a mortgage of $67,000. The building occupies an irregular plot about 81 by 152 feet. Solomon R. Seidman was attorney for the buyer and William Stock acted for the seller.

LONDON, June 3 -- The Labor Government's "purge" of Communists and Fascists in the civil service struck its first important victim today. E. J. Hicks, who until ten days ago was president of the Civil Service Clerical Association, was notified this morning by the Air Ministry, where he works as a higher clerical officer in the contracts department, that he had been placed on leave with pay.

PARIS, June 3 -- W. Averall Harriman, Ambassador at Large for the Economic Cooperation Administration, said today his first task would be to find how the United States could aid the Western European countries in reviving intraEuropean trade.

The president of the nation's biggest union has warned its 1,000,000 members that they will be jeopardizing the life of their union if they press too hard for higher wages in coming months, it was learned last night.

Senator Elbert D. Thomas, Democrat, of Utah, came out yesterday against the Mundt-Nixon AntiCommunist bill, declaring that while the odds were against its passing, "it would hurt everyone except those it is aimed at" if Congress made it into law.

The Old Look, in more ways than one, had a slight edge on the New Look yesterday at the fortyfifth annual Isaac and Regina Bierman garden party staged outdoors at the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews of New York, 121 West 105th Street.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-SEA, England, June 3 (AP) -- Little Miss Louise Suggs tramped eight miles through a tearing, soaking Irish Sea gale today to win the women's British golf championship cup. Providing a United States triumph for the second straight year in this tourney, the tense duel was climaxed on the doorstep of the clubhouse.

Senator Glen H. Taylor, candidate for Vice President on the third party ticket headed by Henry A. Wallace, will speak at six meetings in Queens, Brooklyn, Harlem and the Bronx on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, the National Wallace for President Committee announced yesterday.

Last year the President vetoed a National Science Foundation bill because it would have set up a Governmentsupported, autonomous research organization responsible to no one but itself. Heeding his objection, Senator Smith of New Jersey introduced in this Congress a new bill which, though not all that it should be, was approved by the Senate on May 5.

CLEVELAND, June 3 -- The Warner Swasey Company, machine tool builders, demonstrated its multiple gripper-shuttle loom today at a preview in which cloth was produced at more than two and one-half times the speed of conventional looms.

BELGRADE, June 3 -- The Yugoslav Government took steps today to increase the military potential of Yugoslavia with a new set of regulations ordering pre-military training for all boys and girls under military service age.

Arthur J. Weiland, executive vice president of Willys-Overland Motors, has been elected chairman of the board of directors of the Wilson Foundry and Machine Company, succeeding the late Hiram J. Leonard, it was annnounced yesterday.

VIENNA, June 3 -- A group of refugee East European politicians have proposed to their Western colleagues the formation of a volunteer "liberation army" of half a million Russian refugees to form part of a unified American-West European force, according to an Austrian editor who acted during the war as a German Army expert on Russia.

Governor Dewey ordered last night an immediate investigation by Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, into the expulsion of three anti-Communist leaders by the Bloomingdale department store union.

Formal opposition to the Eastern railroads' request for a 20 per cent increase in passenger fares was made before the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington yesterday by the National Association of Women's and Children's Apparel Salesmen, which has offices at 1776 Broadway.
Two liners scheduled to sail next !week for the troubled eastern Mediterranean have changed their itineraries, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Navy's projected 65,000-ton carrier, which has been receiving considerable attention in Congress and in the press, will carry more than a score of 100,000-pound fourengined planes, will have a designed speed of about thirty-three knots and will be the seventh ship in the United States Navy too wide to pass through the present 110-foot locks of the Panama Canal.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- h)0*0*0*iBuried gold, what the girls wear at Lake Placid and how to report lynchings to Russia -- all had a part today in the Congressional study of the "Voice of America.

Although everything is supposed to be hush hush, word has leaked out that Arthur Lesser, who brought Maurice Chevalier to this country, is preparing an ambitious revue entitled "Fifth Avenue," to go into rehearsal in mid-August for a Broadway unveiling in October.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 3 -- Australia agreed under United Nations auspices today to make a free gift to Poland of more than $800,000 worth of raw wool.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The phrase "client-attorney privilege" harassed the Securities and Exchange Commission again today when two Cleveland attorneys refused, for the second time, to answer certain questions of the agency with regard to its investigation of the recent $10,000,000 common stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.

The Joint Congressional Committeeh)0*0*0*ion Labor-Management Relations, which has been conducting hearings for the past week or more on proposed amendments to the Taft-Hartley Law, has voted not to recommend any changes at the present session. That means that in all probability it will not be reopened before 1949.

The Rev. Dr. Julius Mark, spiritual leader of the Vine Street Temple, Nashville, Tenn., was unanimously elected last night as senior rabbi of Congregation Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at Sixtyfifth Street. He succeeds Rabbi Emeritus Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson, who retired last Dec. 31.

0*0*0*iOWASHINGTON, June 3 -- Thirtyfour states have set up fire safety committees to work for fire-prevention in the year since the first national conference on this problem was held here in May of 1947, the White House reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Revival of the selective draft in peacetime went under Senate floor consideration today. Debate began seventyeight days after President Truman, in his March 17 message to Congress on foreign policy, had declared that voluntary enlistments had failed to bring the country's armed forces to safety strength and warned:
EPSOM, England, June 3 (AP) -The Aga Khan's 3-year-old Masaka outsped twenty-four other fillies today to win the mile-and-ahalf Oaks Stakes by six lengths from King George's Angelola.

Forty detectives started an intensive search yesterday for a "light-skinned Negro," about 16 or 17 years old, in connection with the fatal mugging of 50-year-old Mrs. Frieda Frank, a German refugee widow, who had been in this country six months.
A verbal bouquet to THE TIMES for its publication of the views expressed by my old friend Arnold Tschudy to the effect that United States investments be encouraged for our good neighbor Brazil.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 3 -- Broadening of the United Nations information program to offset the widespread feeling of skepticism concerning activities of the world peace organization was recommended here today at the final meeting of the advisory committee of information experts.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The House Committee on Appropriations today asked a moratorium on foreign debts owed to the United States as a way to reduce foreign aid expenditures.

Negotiations between the American Radio Association, CIO, and a committee representing eleven companies that control 300 tankers were ended yesterday with much the same agreement as that accepted on Tuesday by the negotiating committee of the National Maritime Union, CIO, it was learned last night.
The news for the most part is good for week-end marketers. In brief, the cheerful bulletins:

BUENOS AIRES, June 3 -- The eight-year dictatorship of Gen. Higinio Morinigo came to end in Paraguay today when, according to a broadcast by the official radio in Asuncion, the President yielded his office at the request "of the people and the armed forces."

Many buyers in all lines of the retail field today do not have the knowledge of textiles they need to do their jobs thoroughly and efficiently, J. D. Runkle, president of Crowley Milner, Detroit department store, told members and guests of the eighth annual graduating class of the Laboratory Institute of Merchandising yesterday at the Astor Hotel.

Henry Dreyer, one of the few 1936 Olympians who has legitimate hopes of making the grade again, will launch his campaign for this summer's trip to London in the New York Athletic Club games at Travers Island tomorrow. Still a formidable competitor at the age of 35, Dreyer will perform in the hammer throw.

WASHINGTON, June 3 - Department store sales in the week ended May 29 were 18 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This large increase represents in part the fact that this year stores were open for business six days, whereas during the corresponding week of last year most stores were closed on Memorial Day.

Fownes Brothers Co., Inc., will feature its new fall and winter gloves in the company's most extensive newspaper and magazine advertising campaign, it was announced yesterday. The schedule, begining in September and continuing through December, calls for full and half-page space in eight magazines, and newspaper insertions in New York, Chicago, San Francisco and Dallas.

Plans for modernizing a building that has been a landmark on the lower West Side for more than fifty years were disclosed yesterday with announcement of the sale of the old five-story Hotel Christopher at 386 West Street, southeast corner of Christopher Street.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -The Atomic Energy Commission firmly refused today to interfere in the labor dispute at Oak Ridge, Tenn., as uncertainty continued over whether there will be a strike next week when a Taft-Hartley law injunction expires.

ALBANY, June 3 -- The New York State Youth Commission announced today its approval of New York City's plans for extending summer recreation and educationh) 0*0*0*ifacilities to an estimated 41,000 city youngsters. Emmett R. Gauhn, chairman of the commission, notified Chairman Nathaniel Kaplan of the New York City Youth Board that the state would pay one-half the cost, about $147,500, of the $295,000 allocated by the Board of Estimate to this expanded summer program.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 3 -- A 26-year-old war widow, Mrs. Katherine Wainwright Austin of North Andover, Mass., was the color girl at the annual presentation of colors to the company with the best record in the Naval Academy Brigade of Midshipmen here today.
The Chase National Bank has been appointed registrar for the 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $50 par value, and common stock, $5 par value, of GambleSkogmo, Inc.

After a year's battle, the city's right to eject Aviation Distributors, Inc., from the city-owned tunnel at Forty-first Street and Park Avenue was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg.

The International Monetary Fund is planning to expand the distribution of its bulletin, International Financial Notes, based largely on items appearing in newspapers and periodicals. The publication, originally prepared for use by the fund's staff, will be sent hereafter without charge to members of the fund, for whom it is primarily intended.

For the first time since Hitler came into power in Germany in 1933, an organization has begun to function in that country to combat anti-Semitism and other forms of bigotry, Zachariah Shuster, European representative of the American Jewish Committee reported yesterday on his return from a fourteen-months trip to Europe.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee approved today a proposed declaration that would commit the United States to the principle of military aid to defensive alliances drawn up among the free countries of the world.
LAKE SUCCESS, June 3 (AP) -The United Nations said today that all employes more than 60 years of age, with some exceptions, would be dismissed.
BRUSSELS, June 3 (AP) -- Five American women qualified for the singles quarter-finals of the Belgian international tennis championships today and one was eliminated in the third round.

NEWARK, N.J., June 3 (AP) -Meadowbrook Bowl, scene of outdoor boxing shows for eleven seasons, is on the block, Willie Gilzenberg, vice president of the corporation that operates the bowl, said today. With Thomas J. (Babe) Culnan and William J. Patterson, president and secretary-treasurer, respectively, he said, the arena was for sale at $75,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 3 -- The electric utility industry was urged today to adopt an aggressive program of public information that would tell "what is wrong with Government adventures in collectivism" and put the light and power industry into the fight between private enterprise and socialism.

Network television on a coast-to-coast basis will not be in service until 1953, Sydney N. Strotz, administrative vice president in charge of television for the National Broadcasting Company, said yesterday.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 3 -Employes of Colt's Manufacturing Company will leave the United Electrical Workers Union July 6 and join the United Automobile Workers. The move was approved almost unanimously by 600 of the local's 1,125 members at a meeting here last night.

The stock market retreated yesterday in an orderly fashion with losses fairly widespread and, while a few of the key issues fell a point or more, the combined averages only slipped 0.40 point on the day. The rail equipments, which were among the recently neglected sections, came to life but failed to maintain early gains and the oils were set back by realizing.

The School of Retailing at New York University held its annual Class Day exercises for graduating seniors yesterday in the University's East Building. The ceremonies featured the presentation of prizes and awards to outstanding students.

JERUSALEM, June 3 -- Shooting in Jerusalem subsided to desultory sniping today as the city waited for the United NationS Security Council or Count Folke Bernadotte to set the time for the cease-fire. But Jewish Jerusalem had little confidence in the prospects of peace and continued to prepare for war.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 3 -- The Egyptian Navy bombarded a Palestine port as land fighting along the sandy southern approach to Tel Aviv reached new intensity tonight. Arab and Israeli forces claimed major victories on the same battlefield south of Tel Aviv.

James H. Durkin, president of the left wing United Office and Professional Workers Union, last night won the presidency of the Greater New York CIO Council by default when eight other nominees declined to run.

ALBANY, June 3 -- Emphasis on curative rather than mere custodial care and the effective use of new developments in psychiatry have marked the program in the state mental hospitals during the past year, Dr. Frederick MacCurdy, Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, reported today.
ST. LOUIS, June 3 -- Harry (The Cat) Brecheen regained his health tonight and so did the Cardinals.

LONDON, June 3 -- Arms deliveries to the Arab states were halted by the British Government today for the duration of the proposed cease-fire in Palestine. The Board of Trade issued an order revoking all licenses for the export of military supplies and equipment to Arab League states and Palestine.

Cooperation by management, labor and government in bringing about "the most productive results in business and industry." with "strict impartiality" by the government in cases of conflicts, was advocated yesterday as an important principle of American economy in a declaration adopted by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at the monthly meeting in its headquarters, 65 Liberty Street.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Senator Eugene D. Millikin, Republican, of Colorado, accused Secretary of State George C. Marshall today of treating Congress like an Army orderly.
City authorities are making an intensive study of various port development plans with the intention of selecting and implementing one of them in the near future, it was reported yesterday.

The third round of negotiations for a 1948 contract by the New York local of the International Typographical Union, AFL, with the publishers of thirteen major daily newspapers in this city got under way yesterday.

Misuse of relief funds is widespread, John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, informed Mayor O'Dwyer in an official report yesterday. As examples he cited the sending of money orders to friends and relatives outside the country and the taking of airplane trips to Puerto Rico by relief recipients.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Corn prices on the Board of Trade had a sharp recession today after moving up as much as 2 cents a bushel early. Profit-taking sales disclosed a slower demand in the late trade, while there was some selling on private forecasts of showers for Nebraska and western Iowa.

ROME, June 3 -- The Government won its first parliamentary victories today when the Chamber of Deputies in two separate votes defeated two Communist motions by considerably more than a 2-to1 majority. Both were proposed by Communist leader Palmiro Togliatti.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., June 3 -- Jared (Jerry) Aaronson, 8 years old, returned to his home here at 673 Locust Street today after flying from Texas, thoroughly convinced that his father, Dr. Wilbur R. Aaronson, a dentist, is unreasonably prejudiced against the Lone Star State.

Wall Street's telephones will get something of a breathing spell today as more than 500 of the top bond men of the investment houses turn their backs on the financial district for their annual day of field sports and carnival at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, Scarborough, N.Y.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 3 (AP) -- Columbia University's crews took two workouts on the Hudson today in preparation for the fortysixth Poughkeepsie Regatta June 22. They are the first to arrive for the event.

Detective John Aievoli, attached to the missing Persons Bureau of the Police Department, has received a six-month leave to work in the Asiatic area for identification of American war dead, it was announced yesterday by the office of Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.

It is easy to understand what impelled Jose Ferrer and his City Center acting company to offer Josef and Karel Capek's "The Insect Comedy" at the Fifty-fifth Street playhouse last night. Written in the wake of the first World War and done here in 1922 by William A. Brady as "The World We Live In," it continues to have a contemporary meaning that is a tribute to the playwrights.

BIGGS AIR FORCE BASE, El Paso, June 3 -- The "orphans" of the air force, the reserve, are getting here the first real training any of them have had since they left combat. Today the Ninety-first Reconnaissance Wing, forty-five officers and twelve enlisted men from northern New Jersey, got their first flights in the A-26 Douglas attack bombers of the Forty-seventh Bomb Group of the regulars.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) Secretary of Commerce Sawyer announced today the steel and iron industry has agreed to guarantee 110,000 to 128,000h)0*0*0*itons of pig iron monthly for cast iron products for homes.

LONDON, June 3 -- Most sections the stock markets here today were quiet. Apart from a further rise in British Government bonds, prices generally were lower. A small but steady stream of buying orders advanced gilt-edge issues as much as an eighth.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, June 3 (AP) -- The Congress of the elected House and the Government-appointed Upper House accepted General Morinigo's resignation and elected Dr. Frutos as Provisional President. He took the oath of office before a joint session, then went to the Presidential offices in Government Palace and began his work.
MOSCOW, June 3 (AP) -- The Soviet Union today handed out 121 Stalin Prizes totaling 8,400,000 rubles.
The season of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association will start today on the clay courts of the Jackson Heights Tennis Club in Queens.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Top leaders of the campaign to win the Republican Presidential nomination for Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York came to Washington today to predict his selection on an early ballot without a deadlock or recourse to a "smoke-filled room" conference.

TRENTON, N.J., June 3 -- The New Jersey Civil Service Commission today censured the Bayonne City Administration publicly for "unsatifactory and inadequate" methods in maintaining employe attendance and payroll records.
Mayor O'Dwyer issued a proclamation yesterday designating June 12 as "Municipal Mobilization Day" to mark the beginning of the city's observance of its Golden Anniversary as a fiveborough unit.

One of the key issues in the proposed constitution of the American Guild of Variety Artists, AFL, exercising jurisdiction over the night club and vaudeville field, was resolved yesterday as the union held its first national convention at the Park Central Hotel.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 3 -- The United Nations Kashmir Commission received the job today of looking into all the controversies that have kept India and Pakistan battling before the Security Council for six months.

Breaking a three-month silence on specific wage demands, the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, asked the General Electric Company yesterday for either of two types of pay rises for 125,000 employes.

The prospects for Catskill trout fishing are much better this weekend, and reports from the Beaverkill, Willowemoc, Esopus and Neversink on Thursday indicated that these streams were clear, at ideal height and with the water temperature hovering between 55 and 60 degrees.

The fourth annual meeting of the conference group on group work and recreation reached the general conclusion yesterday that social work, being a product of 'the community, must have' a more positive aim than the avoidance of neuroses, or adjustent' to 'the status quo.

PALOMAR MOUNTAIN OBSERVATORY, Calif., June 3 -- The 200-inch telescope, man's highest "Jacob's Ladder," reaching to stars and universes whose light started on its journey to earth a thousand million years ago, traveling all that time at a speed of 186,000 miles per second, was dedicated here today to the service of mankind amid forebodings for man's future through his misuse of knowledge.

Earning assets of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $111,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday. According to the data issued by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, all loans and investments of the banks stood at $18,940,000,000 on June 2.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Howard Myers, trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board, held today that seven locals of the International Typographical Union (AFL) had refused to bargain in good faith with commercial printers in six cities.

LOS ANGELES, June 3 -- Completion of the tally of Tuesday's state primary indicated tonight that Representative Helen Gahagan Douglas, Democrat, had virtually assured her re-election to Congress by winning both Democratic and Republican nominations, although she may be the center of a recount tussle.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- The house of delegates of the American Nurses' Association voted about three to one today to push the implementation of the organization's economic security program. The ANA, with two other nursing groups, is meeting here in the biennial nursing convention, which closes tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- During the week ended June 2, member bank reserve balances increased $193,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Consolidated retail sales of R. H. Macy Co. for the semi-annual period of twenty-six weeks ended on Jan. 31, last, rose 13 per cent to $172,407,000 from the $152,537,000 volume for the similar period of the previous fiscal year, according to the unaudited results released for publication today.

ST. JOHN'S, June 3 -- St. John's and the surrounding Avalon settlements polled heavily for responsible government today, with the vote for confederation less than 30 per cent and that for commission lagging far in the rear. However, votes coming in from outside districts indicated a strong leaning toward confederation and the initial lead for self-government was being sharply reduced.

Fleettown moved back into the steeplechase picture with emphasis at Belmont Park yesterday. Competing in the $10,000 added Corinthian Steeplechase Handicap, the Brookmeade Stable's 7-year-old son of Jamestown raced to a decisive triumph over seven others.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, June 3 (Reuters) -- Batting on a wicketh)0*0*0*idrying under sun and wind, the Australian cricketers were skittled out by Hampshire's spin-bowlers today for 117. Hampshire, which had scored 195 yesterday, became the first side to lead the Australians this tour.

In a Murray Hill investment deal reported yesterday the ten-story apartment house for twenty-seven families at 138-42 East Thirtysixth Street was sold by the Dorit Z. Cohn Associates to George Popkin. Assessed at $230,000, the property is 62.5 by 100 feet, near Lexington Avenue, and was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $182,000.
Four new trains will run between Jamaica, Queens, and Long Island City starting June 13, the Long Island Rail Road announced yesterday.

The Public Service Commission denied yesterday a petition of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad for authority to increase commutation fares on traffic in New York State by 25 per cent. The increases were proposed for sixty-trip monthly tickets and forty-six-trip monthly tickets for students.

An involved and somewhat profitless financial venture, in which three former minor officials of the General Electric Credit Corporation are accused of defrauding the concern of $180,000 in a period of eleven months, was described yesterday in General Sessions when the three were arraigned on charges of conspiracy and grand larceny.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The State Department received today from the Egyptian Government what was called "an unsatisfactory reply" to the United States protest against the blockade of Palestine.
LONDON, June 3 -- Some 300,000 Britons are waiting for the opportunity to emigrate to the Dominions, the House of Commons learned today.
The easier tone developed in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were 29 to 37 points net lower.

The election of Henry B. Fernald, tax expert and senior partner in Loomis, Suffern Fernald, to a four-year term as an alumni member of the New York University Council, was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of N. Y. U. Chancellor Chase made the announcement at the annual meeting of the Alumni Federation's board of directors, which was headed by Mr. Fernald thirteen years ago.

Andrew Cordier, executive assistant to Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, will participate tomorrow in a discussionh)0*0*0*iof "What has the United Nations Accomplished?" during the weekly Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Both the Veterans Administration and the State Department of Education defended themselves yesterday against charges by the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects that they had permitted "worthless" private schools of architectural drafting to operate as "diploma mills" for veterans.

Harmonious combinations of decorative fabrics to suggest fresh room schemes to homemakers were hung yesterday at the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles, 20 West Fiftyfifth Street, for the summer-long exhibit opening today.

The first of 6,400 American exchange students scheduled to go to Europe this Summer aboard four ships left here yesterday for Plymouth and Le Havre on the transport Marine Tiger. The ship sailed at 5:06 P.M. from Pier 61, North River.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 3 -- German anticipation of currency reform has paralyzed the economy of the bizonal area. Not only do ordinary consumers find it almost impossible to purchase the meager store items formerly available to them, but business men might just as well close their offices for all the business they do.

A White Plains landlord who allegedly had a fire escape ladder removed from her house and then obtained an eviction order against a tenant on the ground that the absence of the ladder violated the local building code was ordered yesterday by Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind to restore the ladder and desist from attempting to oust the tenant.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- By a voice vote the House approved and sent to the Senate today a $3,686,733,250 appropriations bill for the Department of the Navy, the Naval Service and the maintenance of the greatest navy in the world during the fiscal year starting July 1.

Against a background of colored slides of the paintings of James McNeil Whistler, the Guild of New York Dress Designers presented last night at the Sculpture Court of the Brooklyn Museum a showing of fall fashions inspired both by the colors and the silhouettes in this artist's work.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., June 3 (AP) -- Putting and approaching with near perfection, jaunty Jimmy Demaret scorched out a seven-underpar 65 to lead the way in today's first round of the Albuquerque open golf tournament.

ROME, June 4 -- The first general strike in Italy since the election on April 18 occurred in Bologna today. Although Bologna is a main Red stronghold, the strike was only partly successful. Most shops remained open, street-car service was interrupted only at noon and on all sides a marked tendency to disregard strike orders was noted.

One of the most popular shows in town for some weeks past has been the exhibition of pictures from the Berlin museums, put on at our own Metropolitan, as the catalogue carefully states, "in cooperation with the Department of the Army," which is the custodian of these temporarily "liberated" treasures.

A Lower East Side property that had been in the Astor family ownership for 132 years passed to new control yesterday when the five-story apartment house on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 10 Stanton Street was sold by the Estate of William Astor to the Ten Stanton Street Corporation, which insured title with the Home Title Guarantyh) 0*0*0*iCompany.

Manager Bucky Harris of the Yankees became the proud possessor of another starting pitcher last night. Thrown into the breach against the Tigers when an infected toe prevented Spec Shea from taking his regular turn, Frank Hiller limited Detroit to five hits and received credit for his first major league victory.
The International Harvester Company reported yesterday for the six months ended with last April a net income of $28,519,000 after all charges, including $12,522,000 provision for taxes.

An agreement reached yesterday between the American Telphone and Telegraph Company and the American Union of Telephone Workers. CIO, ended the long-standing threat of a nationwide strike of long-distance operators.

Coastal skeet shooters are now getting in some practice for the Great Eastern skeet championships, scheduled for June 18, 19 and 20 at Lordship, Conn. About fifteen events, plus a national telegraphic five-man team contest, will be shot during the three-day event, and more than 150 trophies will be awarded.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., June 4 -Newfoundlanders failed yesterday to register a majority opinion on their future Government and must hold a second referendum to decide between responsible self-government and confederation with Canada.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 4 -Senator Robert A. Taft made his first Southern campaign visit today and flatly asserted that if he wins the Republican Presidential nomination he is "very hopeful of carrying several Southern states under present conditions."

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 (AP) -Mike Guerra's double sent Ferris Fain across the plate with the winning counter in a three-run seventh-inning uprising as the Athletics gained a 4-3 victory over the White Sox tonight. Rookie Lou Brissie, third pitcher for Philadelphia, received credit for his fifth triumph.

The United Mine Workers of America announced yesterday that twelve more miners who were paralyzed from the waist down in coal mine accidents will get the cost of hospital treatment from the union's 1946 welfare and retirement fund.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -The National Association of Real Estate Boards and the Washington Real Estate Board were acquitted in Federal District Court today on a charge that they conspired to fix commissions.

PITTSBURGH, June 4 (AP) -The Boston Braves scored seven runs in the seventh inning to defeat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 10 -- 7, in a drawn-out contest tonight before a crowd of 37,355. Jim Russell's home run with two aboard was the big blow of the inning.
Twelve-year-old Elaine Monesmith, an expert marksman who handles a high-powered elephant rifle, is all excited about her coming safari to the Belgian Congo.
The letter from J. MacKaye questioning the proposal to admit 200,000 DP's to the United States spoke as if the proposal involved a change in immigration policy. Actually it does not.

The population of New York City was estimated to be 8,005,000 on Jan. 1, 1948, according to figures prepared by the Industrial and Economic Development Department of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc. This represents a gain of more than 1,000,000 in the last three years because the city's population actually decreased during the war years.

LONDON, June 4 -- The Soviet Union will receive a copy of the report of the recent six-power conference on Western Germany before it is issued publicly, a Foreign Office spokesman said today. This follows the practice employed after the first conference on Western Germany, which ended March 6.

PRAGUE, June 4 -- The Communist Minister of the Interior, Vaclav Nosek, disclosed today that former Minister of Justice Prokoph)0*0*0*iDrtina, one-time member of the London Government in Exile, would be tried on charges connected with the arrest of certain Communists in the Olomouc area before the February events that brought to power the present Communist eliminated regime.

JERUSALEM, June 4 -- Artillery shelling of the Jewish areas in Jerusalem was resumed this morning as twenty-five-pounder guns of the Trans-Jordan Arab Legion took up where they had left off on Wednesday afternoon.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 4 -- Catholic resettlement directors from sixteen dioceses in five north central states urged today immediate action by the House of Representatives on the admission of 200,000 persons to this country over a twoyear period.

Mary Cohen, in a purchase for investment, has acquired the sixstory seventy-three-family apartment house at 1254 Grant Avenue, the Bronx, from the F. W. Equities, Inc. The property, on a plot about 162 by 100 feet, is assessed at $255,000.

LONDON, June 4 -- A committee appointed by the Minister of Health recommended today that full time medical specialists employed in the universal state health service to be instituted next month should be paid from 1,500 to 5,000 a year in terms of the 1939 value of the money.

Although cotton textile prices continue to drift downward, the market can look for an upsurge in business in the third quarter of the year on the basis of consumer needs, it was predicted yesterday. Worth Street commission men pointed out that evidence of the demand is seen in consummation of gray goods sales in a declining market and the steady acceptance of goods purchased months ago.

WARSAW, June 4 -- Left-Wing Socialists from six countries will begin a two-day conference here tomorrow. The conference was originally conceived to establish contacts between various groups and perhaps organize into a body corresponding to the international Socialist committee meeting in Vienna this week-end.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -Cleveland poured five runs across the plate in the fifteenth inning to defeat Washington, 5 -- 0, and retain its American League lead tonight before a crowd of 29,555. The Indians scored their runs off relief pitchers Tom Ferrick and Dick Welteroth after Mickey Haefner had hurled twelve scoreless innings against Bob Feller, who was replaced by Bob Muncrief after eleven innings.

ALBANY, June 4 -- Gov. Dewey and legislative heads appointed todayh)0*0*0*i19 members to the temporary state commission established by the 1948 legislature to plan for the observance of the Swedish Pioneer Centennial the week of June 28. The centennial commorates the first Swedish immigration to the United States.

STANTON, Del., June 4 (AP) -Pentagon Stable's The Doge, one of the most unpredictable horses in training, had his running shoes on today and waltzed to an easy victory in the six-furlong Westover Purse, feature race of a program riddled by scratches because of the heavy Delaware Park track.
Fashions for teen-agers' summer play at the beach or farm will be presented this morning by Gimbels.

THE names of two World War II battles have been taken over into common speech to signify a certain kind of defeat: Dunkerque and Pearl Harbor. Both now indicate a distinct form of military disaster, along with the more venerable "Waterloo." Strangely enough, both Dunkerque and Pearl Harbor were defeats suffered by the victors. "Dunkirk,"* by A. D. Divine makes it seem less strange.
May I make a belated comment upon your report of May 29 on the pickets' parade at the housing site?
WEST POINT, N.Y., June 4 -June week festivities began today at the United States Military Academy for the 301 members of the class of 1948.

VIENNA, June 4 -- An international Socialist conference began today in Vienna the task of purging socialism of crypto-communism and of renewing socialism's allegiance to democracy. The Eastern European Socialist parties allied to or absorbed by communism have already been expelled, and today the Left-Wing Socialists in Italy, led by Pietro Nenni, were put on warning.

Ten blind girls gave a fashion show yesterday at the New York Institute for the Education of the Blind, 999 Pelham Parkway, the Bronx, featuring sport clothes, suits, coats and evening wear they had made in the institute's Home Economics Department.

A 5-year-old girl toured Brooklyn in a police radio car yesterday, looked in on a couple of accidents and picked up a great deal of ice cream and cake -- all because she had the good luck to get lost at one of Brooklyn's busiest intersections and not know where she lived.

An early flash, a blazing pace and a quick finish! That is the battle plan of Rocky Graziano, world middleweight champion, who is to defend his title for the first time Wednesday night in Ruppert Stadium,h) 0*0*0*iNewark, against the man from whom he won it last year, Tony Zale, the steel-muscled battler from Gary, Ind.

0*0*0*iOA rare archeological find, proving continuous human habitation in the Antelias Valley of Lebanon as far back as 75,000 B.C., was reported here yesterday by Father Joseph Murphy, a member of the Boston College-Fordham University Expedition.

CAT CAY, Bahamas, June 4 (AP) -- Julio Sanchez of Camaguey, Cuba, and Miaimi Beach, set an all-time record for the heaviest game fish to be caught in the Bahamas Islands when he boated a 749-pound bluefin tuna today.

LONDON, June 4 -- In Foreign Office circles today the belief seems to be growing that there is an underground international whispering campaign going on against Foreign Secretary Bevin. The Communist parties may or may not be involved but their publications are making the most of it.
Girls swept the field in the poster contest for young artist for which the Police Athletic League was sponsor in conjunction with the thirty-fourth annual outdoor art exhibit in Greenwich Village.

BRUSSELS, June 4 (AP) -- Frank Parker and Budge Patty, touring Los Angeles stars, swept into the singles semi-finals of the Belgian tennis tournament today and then teamed up to reach the semi-final round in doubles.

In answer to charges made in April by farmers and wholesale distributors that retail grocers were using mark-ups in excess of 100 per cent on vegetables andh)0*0*0*ifruits, the New York State Food Merchants Association has conducted a survey of merber stores.

Retail trade here this week declined slightly because of the holidayh)0*0*0*iwhich cut the number of business days to five, compared with six last year. Department store sales were estimated about 5 per cent under the corresponding week last year.

CALCUTTA, India, June 4 -- The allegation made two days ago by the West Bengal Home Minister, K. S. Roy, that the Communists were planning "an armed rising and violent seizure of power" has drawn criticism from such newspapers as have commented on the subject.

Four current exhibitions of paintings -- a one-man snow and three groups -- mark what is probably the last substantially active days of the art season. From here on in through the summer most galleries restrict their activity to the perennial summer group exhibitions or close altogether.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Adoption of resolutions and elections of officers marked today's final session of the biennial joint convention of the American Nurses Association, the National League for Nursing Education and the National Organization for Public Health Nursing.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 4 -- Secretary of the Navy John L. Sullivan issued a solemn warning today against any weakening of American armed forces if the United States was to full the desired role as guarantor of "peace through restrained strength."
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -May cash-ins of Series E Government savings bonds exceeded new purchases for the second consecutive month.

BERLIN, June 4 -- Despite optimism on the subject displayed by United States Military Government officials, German political sources in Berlin declare there is little enthusiasm on the part of the Social Democratic and Christian Democratic party leaders toward assuming responsibility in a Western German state.

The Welfare Department has been requested formally to transfer three children of Hamportzoon Choolokian from Catholic to Protestant institutions by a newly formed Committee for the Rights of the Choolokian family headed by the Right Rev. Tiran Nersoyan, Bishop of the Armenian Apostolic Orthodox Church.

The fact-finding board appointed by President Truman on Thursday to study the present maritime dispute will start formal hearings Monday morning in the Roosevelt Hotel, Harry Shulman, Yale Law School professor, who heads the board, announced last night. The board is scheduled to report back to the President by June 11.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Congress completed passage tonight of a bill to prevent the Administration from extending social security coverage to more than 500,000 salesmen and others who previously had been excluded as independent contractors.

The Communist campaign to wreck the Marshall Plan got a big boost from the United States Congress when the House of Representatives voted toh) 0*0*0*icut $553,000,000 from the first year's estimates for the foreign aid program and stretch the funds authorized from twelve months to cover fifteen.

Glassware retailers are limiting advance commitments to a maximum of ninety days instead of six months, department store buyers reported yesterday. They attributed the change in buying policy to greatly improved deliveries since Jan. 1 and in some cases to decline in unit and dollar volume compared with last year.

A syndicate of exiled Hungarian statesmen -- including the leaders of all the moderate political parties represented in the coalition that won a sweeping victory in the elections of November, 1945, only to be ousted by the Communist coup of May 1947 -- has taken over editorship of the Amerikai-Magyar Nepszava of New York, oldest and largest Hungarian-language daily in the country.
Any doubt of the superiority of Jesse Flores, Stockton, Calif., lightweight, over Johnny Williams, Montgomery, Ala., boxer, was dissipated last night in Madison Square Garden.

NANKING, June 4 -- Ambassador John Leighton Stuart said today that agitation here against Washington's Japan policy had produced "a growingly dangerous situation" that was "seriously damaging" Sino-American friendship.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Associate Justice T. Alan Goldsborough today directed John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers of America to bargain collectively with the Southern Coal Producers Association.

NUREMBERG, Germany, June 4 -- In a day-long session on the witness stand, Dr. Erich Kordt, formerlyh)0*0*0*ichief of the Ministries Bureau in the German Foreign Office, today characterized Baron Ernst von Weizsaecker, Adolf Hitler's Ambassador to the Vatican during the first two years of the war, as one of the most consistent opponents of the Nazis' program of aggressive war.
