DANBURY, Conn., June 4 -- A general strike of 2,500 union hatters that would deal a crippling blow to the principal industry of this city of 30,000 appeared imminent tonight with an announcement from local union officials that the workers had voted to walk off their jobs if the manufacturers persist in their refusal to grant pay increases.
CHICAGO, June 4 (AP) -- The Phillies unleashed a 13-hit bombardment for a total of 25 bases today to rout Johnny Schmitz and trounce the Cubs, 7 to 2.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 4 (UP) -- A Iraqi communique asserted tonight that 580 Israeli fighters were killed and 1,000 wounded today at Jenin, forty-five miles north of Jerusalem, on the central front, in the biggest battle of the Palestine war.

BUENOS AIRES, June 4 -- Miguel Miranda, head of the National Economic Mission, has told United States officials here that, as far as he is concerned, all Marshall Plan negotiations are as good as "finished," because Argentina is prepared to sell all her grain at the market price.

Frederick C. McLaughlin, educational director of the Public Education Association, made public yesterday a letter he had sent to the Rev. Arthur J. McGratty commenting on a Memorial Day sermon by Father McGratty at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

PRETORIA, South Africa, June 4 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Mafan's Cabinet, most of whose members are republicans, swore today to be "faithful and bear true allegiance to His Majesty, King George VI, his heirs and successors according to law."

LONDON, June 4 -- A Foreign Office spokesman denied today allegations made by David Ben-Gurion, Premier of Israel, that the British had connived in an Arab plan for the swift conquest of Palestine and the installation of King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan as ruler of the Holy Land.

BOSTON, June 4 -- Governor Dewey, in Boston to seek second or third ballot support from the Massachusetts delegation, said today he expects to lead the field on the first ballot at the Republican convention and that he expects to increase his lead until he is nominated for President.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Compulsory military training for 18year-old youths was eliminated from the stop-gap draft bill by the Senate today.

The fourth show of the Experimental Theatre's Invitational Series, sponsored by the American National Theatre and Academy, will be presented this evening ath) 0*0*0*ithe Lenox Hill Playhouse, 331 East Seventieth Street. Written by Barton Yarborough, it is called "These Tender Mercies" and concerns lynching and racial discrimination in a small Southern town of the early 1900's.
Under the provisions of the Charter, the chairmanship of the Security Council of the United Nations rotates to the delegate from each of the eleven nations, who serve for a term of one month.

Frisky, the wandering cat, is now a legend on Washington Heights. Known in the neighborhood as a quiet pet, she was foundh)0*0*0*iyesterday, hungry, her gray coat shabby, after two days of independence -- and imprisonment.

Samuel Greenberg has purchased the vacant plot at 45 Maple Street, Brooklyn, from Rita Woods in an all cash transaction negotiated by Tankoos, Smith Co. as brokers. The new owner plans the construction of two one-family dwellings on the land, which is 85 by 100 feet.
CINCINNATI, June 4 -- The Giants today won one of those games you accept with thanks and without trying to explain too deeply just how it was accomplished.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Registration statements covering 250,260 shares of common stock and $13,500,000 of sinking fund debentures were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three companies.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The House Rules Committee paved the way today for the chamber's consideration next week of the Fellows bill to admit into the United States 200,000 displaced persons over a two-year period.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The country's newspapers were accused by a labor leader today of pleading their own special interest in advocating unrestricted extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.

CRESTLINE, Ohio, June 4 -Right here in the heart of Republican Ohio, in the midst of an oldfashioned political rally, President Truman today contributed a figurative horse laugh to the debate on whether his speaking tour is political or nonpolitical.

BUENOS AIRES, June 4 -- Provisional President Juan Manuel Frutos of Paraguay swore in the new Cabinet in Asuncion today. It will serve until the President-elect, Finance Minister J. Natalicio Gonzalez takes office Aug. 15.

Elimination of "premium pay" to labor as well as to some elements of the construction industry was emphasized yesterday as a prime requisite for bringing down the cost of homes. Elimination of unproductive expenditures was ranked alongside increased standardization by building experts seeking cheaper housing methods at the closing sessions of the Institute of Housing and Planning Studies in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 4 -- Only the question of Jewish immigration into Palestine during the proposed four-week truce is obstructing agreement between the two parties on the date the cease-fire will become effective, Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator in the Holy Land, cabled the Security Council today.

Three members of the Police Department, two of them women, who devoted their evenings to the study of law for four years, will receive their Bachelor of Law degrees from Fordham University's Law School Wednesday night at commencement exercises.

The progress of the United Nations and its indispensability in preventing a crisis among the leading powers of the world was hailed yesterday by some of its officials, educators and civic leaders at a luncheon given in honor of Herschel V. Johnson, former United States Deputy Representative to the United Nations and now Ambassador-designate to Brazil.

BOSTON, June 4 (AP) -- Irving J. White's Count Lovely today gained a nose decision over C. S. Popovitz' Instanter with the 8-to-5 favorite, Harry Stutts' Busyridge, a length back before a crowd of 2,869 at Suffolk Downs.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, June 5 -- Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, United States commander in Korea, said today he had demanded of Guard Col. Gen. G. P. Korotkov, commander of the Soviet forces in North Korea that the Russians "make full and appropriate apologies" for the shooting across the border at the 38th parallel on May 26, in which an American civilian was wounded.

One of the basic "rights" granted to labor in the Wagner Act was that of bargaining through their own freely chosen representatives. When that law was superseded last year by the Taft-Hartley Act, provision was made to extend this same protection to management.
LONDON, June 4 -- Committee reports dealing with ship construction, radio equipment and safety of navigation won approval of the International Conference on Safety of Life at Sea here today.

PALOMAR OBSERVATORY, Calif., June 4 -- Man took his first blinking glances at the heavens last night through his 200-inch eye in the Hale telescope atop Palomar Mountain and was dazzled by a new radiance from the light of distant stars, four times brighter than any similar star-image he had ever seen before.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., June 4 (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret trimmed par three strokes for a 69 today to cling to a one-stroke lead half-way through the $10,000 Albuquerque Open golf tournament.

In a Greenwich Village deal two five-story apartment houses at 80-82 Charles Street were sold by the Erada Holding Company to theh)0*0*0*iAgke Realty Company, which obtained a mortgage loan of $35,000 from the Woodlawn Cemetery for ten years and 4 per cent and insured titles to the fee and mortgage with the Lawyers Title Corporation.

LONDON, June 4 -- The threat of a 25 per cent cut in aid from the European Recovery Program recommended by the Senate Appropriations Committee in Washington had a depressing effect on the stock markets here today. Industrial shares were the chief sufferers, and although there were no signs of heavy selling, prices gradually drifted throughout the list.

Residents of the Margaret Louisa, 14 East Sixteenth Street, oldest Y.W.C.A. residence in theh)0*0*0*icity, are baking a farewell cake for their final "at home" tomorrow, it was announced yesterday. The residence, familiarly called "the Maggy Lou" by several generations of women, will close its doors July 1 because of the high cost of complying with new fire regulations, and the property will be sold.

The Rev. Dr. Louis W. Pitt, rector of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, has been named Visiting Chaplain of Columbia University, Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of the university, announced yesterday. Dr. Pitt will serve from Sept. 1, 1948, to June 30, 1949.

The judicial calm and peaceful atmosphere that usually pervades Supreme Court changed quickly to one of tenseness yesterday whenh)0*0*0*iJustice Ferdinand Pecora's qualifications were questioned because of his "political views" in the suit brought by the Council on African Affairs to restrain Dr. Max Yergan from representing himself as the organization's executive secretary.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The House passed tonight a $5,980,710,228 omnibus foreign aid appropriation bill after Republican leaders turned back a coalition effort to restore $1,500,000,000 of the amount slashed by the Appropriations Committee from the European Recovery Program.

The cotton futures market onthe Hew .York Cotton Exchangeturned weak yesterday on weekend liquid/tion, continued favorable. weather and uncertaintiesregarding credit allocations toEurope by the Economic Cooperation Adrinistration.

Bidders backed away yesterday from the stock market and prices slid in one of the widest declines in a month. The retreat was a consequence of the spasmodic liquidation that has characterized recent sessions, and while the combined averages lost only 0.65 point on the day, much wider losses showed in some recently favored issues.

The Twentieth Century Fund has just released, under the title "Cartels Competition?" the second part of a study of foreign trade conducted over the last two years by a special research group. If the Government does not foster a policy of competition, the report concludes, the result is likely to be "economic concentration and private monopoly."
Following is the completed text of President Truman's address before the Swedish Pioneer Centennial Association in Chicago, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

The need of character training for children of grammar school age was stressed yesterday morning in an address by the Rev. Dr. Louis W. Pitt, rector of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, at the Grace Church School, 88 Fourth Avenue.

The Rev. Arthur R. McGratty, national director of the League of the Sacred Heart, ended last night at St. Patrick's Cathedral a novena consisting of devotions to the Sacred Heart of Jesus and in the interest of world peace. Noon as well as evening devotions were held for nine days, leading to the celebration yesterday of the Feast of the Sacred Heart.

With neithier defendant taking the stand to refute testimony of a score of witnesses that they had to pay them cash bonuses to acquire apartment leases, two moreh) 0*0*0*imen were speedily convicted in separate trials yesterday in Special Sessions of rent-gouging.

GENEVA, June 4 -- Britain's apparent determination to press for the deletion of the article in the international civil aviation convention that postpones the application of a standard of airworthiness for new types of planes had the international air assembly baffled today.

Louis J. Soudens, manager of Peeters-Van Roye, S.A., Belgian manufacturer of wool carpets and other textile products, yesterday recommended suspension by the United States of all duties on products imported from the sixteen European Recovery Program countries when such products represent no competitive threat to comparable items turned out byh)0*0*0*iAmerican manufacturers.

VIENNA, June 4 -- A squad of armed Russian soldiers burst into a police station in Vienna's inner city last night, knocked down an Austrian police guard, held up several British military policemen and took away two Russian secret service men and an American whom the British had just arrestted for having caused a disturbance.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended May 29, 1948, totaled 904,848 cars, the Association of Railroads announced today.

h)0*0*0*iSix years' testing in Swift Co.'s research laboratories has shown there is no justification for the prejudice that pork liver is strong in flavor. A recent report from the company says that this liver, if cooked properly, is just as pleasing to the palate as more expensive varieties of this rich-in-iron food.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 4 -- By a 9-to-3 vote, the United Nations Human Rights Commission rejected today a French move to make the fate of all stateless persons the direct concern of the international organization.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee rejected today the demands of opponents of Mundt-Nixon Communist-control bill for further public hearings.
EPSOM, England, June 4 (AP) -King George and as many of his subjects as can cram themselves into ancient Epsom Downs will watch the 169th English Derby tomorrow.

In a reply to statements by the State Department of Education and the Veterans Administration defending the courses of instruction offered in drafting schools here under the GI Bill of Rights, the committee on education of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects declared last night that revision and improvement in these courses were urgently needed.

Today's events: Robert Harter, baritone, at 5 and Cynthia Bernard, soprano, at 9 P.M., New York Foundling Hospital; Final Pop Concert, Irving Berlin Night, Jack Shaindlin, conductor; soloists: Irving Berlin, Vera Barton, Tony Craig, Jean Lawrence, Helen Steinbrecher and others, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Queens College Orchestral Society, Boris Schwatz, conductor, Sylvia Suzowsky, piano, Jamaica High School Auditorium, 8:30.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 4 -Harold E. Stassen and Gov. Earl Warren had lunch together and talked politics for three hours today but the two Presidential candidates agreed afterward that "no commitments were asked and no commitments were made."

The declaration prepared by the House Foreign Affairs Committee, proposing to put our Government on record as standing ready to aid militarily, as well as morally, any nation or any groups of nations that think and act as we do, and whose security is threatened, is an important development in the foreign policy of this country.

The state Liquor Authority advised Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in a letter yesterday that he had a "legal and moral obligation" to support his charges that Brooklyn tavern owners were violating the alcoholic beverage control laws.

Ted Atkinson rode his hundredth winner of the year at Belmont Park yesterday and marked up No. 101 and No. 102 later in the proceedings, but in the race that he wanted to win most he was carried under the wire last in a field of seven.

LONDON, June 4 -- London critics went into raptures today over "Caribbean Rhapsody," musical show presented at the Prince of Wales Theatre last night by Katherine Dunham, 38-year-old dancer from Chicago and her West Indian company.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Unions affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations raked the Taft-Hartley Law from stem to stern in an all-day hearing today before the Joint Committee on Labor-Management Relations.

Foreign pig iron is being offered here from Scandinavian, South American and Continental European sources at prices ranging from $80 to $105 a ton, N. E. Craig, an official of Hickman Williams Co., 70 Pine Street, revealed here yesterday.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will assume the presidency of Columbia University Monday morning with a complete absence of ceremony. Private handshakes and well wishes will be the only introduction to a full day of appointments and meetings with academic staff members.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 4 (U.P.) -- Count Bernadotte arrived here this morning from Haifa, Israel, and conferred for seventy-five minutes with Egyptian Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha. In Haifa he had conferred with Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Shertok for three hours last night.

The opening day of the tournament season of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association was marked by the defeat of the second-ranking player in the section yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club, Queens.

Advertising in the eight metropolitan daily newspapers totaled 13,412,375 lines during May, an increase of 8.05 per cent over theh)0*0*0*ilike period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Categories recording gains were: automotive, up 20.61 per cent; retail, 11 per cent, and classified, 8.93 per cent.

Walter Hendl, assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, will join the ranks of the radio quizmasters when he introduces a Sunday afternoon music quiz over WMCA on June 13 from 1:03 to 1:30 o'clock.

BOSTON, June 4 (AP) -- Boston's Red Sox today won their first double-header since last Labor Day as they whipped the ever trying St. Louis Browns, 10 -- 4 and 7 -- 2, before an appreciative Ladies Day crowd of 17,362, of whom 14,901 paid their way into Fenway Park.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 4 -- Although there was no elaboration of the reason that impelled the action, Edward J. Hummel, Ohio Secretary of State, ruled today that the group supporting Henryh) 0*0*0*iA. Wallace for president of the United States is not entitled to a place on the Ohio ballot.

Triumphing over 300,000 competitors in New York public and parochial schools, three girl students received top honors yesterday in the annual Americanism essay contest conducted by the State Chamber of Commerce in conjunction with the Board of Education and the Catholic School Boards.
LONDON, June 4 -- Buckingham Palace issued the following official announcement tonight:

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 4 -Mal Galletta, 1946 Long Island amateur champion, and Paul Engels of Hempstead won the medal in the eighth annual member-guest best-ball tourney of the Hempstead Golf Club today with a score of 68.

BALLSTON SPA., N.Y., June 4 -- A search for sunken treasure in the Hudson River near Bemis Heights and Fort Miller will be started this summer by Peter McLaren of Ballston Spa. He makes a hobby of locating sunken ships in waters in this area and retrieving from them coins and other valuables.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -President Truman today nominated Tracy S. Voorhees, New York attorney, as Assistant Secretary of the Army. Mr. Voorhees, 56, was an Army officer in the last World War and the Army's food administrator for occupied areas since 1947.

ALBANY, June 4 -- The Corn Exchange Bank and Trust Company, New York City, filed with the State Banking Department today an application for permission to open a branch at 6629-33 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn.

LONDON, June 4 -- Petroleum production in the Middle East might be nearly doubled within the next five years and the world-wide oil shortage considerably relieved except for the political and military disturbances that are now interfering with the expansion projects of British, American and allied companies.

The Maritime Commission announced yesterday that 500 young men had passed written examinations for matriculation at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L.I., in September, but that only 250 would receive appointments. The entering class is limited to that number.

No matter who makes the investigation of the Welfare Department, the findings are the same. This time it's the city's Commissioner of Investigation. Mr. Murtagh, at work on the Mayor's motion since last October, finds that some Welfare clients had not been visited for a whole year.

Thompson, president of theMortgage Bankers Association andpresident of the New Jersey RealtyCompany of iewark, N. J., toldmembers present at the first regular luncheon meeting of the organization yesterday in the HotelMartinique.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 4 (AP) -The mighty Columbia River was rising in new fury today.
Dr. Alfred C. Kinsey replied yesterday to critics, chiefly psychiatrists and sociologists, who have attacked his book, "Sexual Behavior in the Human Male."

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Liquidation of contracts by holders increased in the late trading in grains today on the Board of Trade and all cereals were weak at the close. Selling being accelerated by the prospects for a break in the dry spell which has been a big market influence for some time.

In a mood of bland irrelevance, Harry Wagstaff Gribble, the renowned March hare, has tossed a new light comedy, "Almost Faithful," on the patient stage of the American Negro Theatre in 126th Street. Although it opened formally on Wednesday, it was not certified as safe for critics untilh)0*0*0*ilast evening.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Devices of high potentiality both for the waging of war and employment in the ways of peace were among the 414 inventions patented this week by the United States Patent Office.

Bond houses will be occupied next week with a variety of competitive bidding transactions, especially in the field of municipal finance. An offering of railroad bonds -- $14,000,000 of twenty-year obligations of the Kansas City Southern Railway -- is among the corporate transactions coming up.h)

BERLIN, June 4 -- The Soviet campaign to win support of the workers of this city entered a new phase today when Maj. Gen. Alexander G. Kotikov, Soviet commandant, issued an order promisingh)0*0*0*iworkers in the Soviet sector wage increases ranging from 15 to 20 per cent, an additional 70,000 hot meals daily and better living conditions.

The northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street took on the character of a college campus by mid-morning yesterday as the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church became the scene for the forty-eighth commencement of Finch Junior College.

ST. LOUIS, June 4 -- Big Ralph Branca pitched the first shut-out of the season for a Brooklyn hurler and that's what he had to do to beat the Cardinals in tonight's game, a thriller down to the final out.

Three girls allegedly responsible for a holdup at knife-point were captured yesterday by a patrolman who climbed through the window of a BMT subway train about to pull out of the Whitehall Street station soon after 3 P.M.

Decisions made in Washington in the next two or three years may well transcend in importance decisions made by management at home, Fred Lazarus Jr., president of Federated Department Stores, Inc., and chairman of the board of Associated Merchandising Corporation, declared yesterday.

ATHENS, June 4 -- Premier Themistocles Sophoulis said today that Greece had "a real desire to live at peace with her neighbors"; but whether or not those Balkan neighbors could be regarded as seeking peace with Greece depended upon the way they dealt with the Greek Government's recent request for return of the Greek children taken across the border by the Communist-led rebels.

JERUSALEM, June 4 (AP) -- The Catholic priests of the Latin patriarchate in Jerusalem said today that a protest against the conduct of Israeli military operations in Jerusalem had been sent to the United Nations.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 4 -- The Government of Ceylon, which obtained Dominion status last February as a member of the British Commonwealth, applied today for membership in the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- It has been a long time since the Republican party has been so divided over any issue as it was today over the House Appropriations Committee's 24 per cent cut of the European Recovery Program funds which the House supported tonight.

William J. E. Wright, an Army transport captain who lost two ships by torpedoings during World War II, received a judgment of $125,000 against the Government in Federal Court yesterday for injuries he suffered when he was shot and permanently paralyzed by the first mate of a vessel on which he was a passenger in March, 1946.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 4 -Rex Harrison and Jeanne Crain were named today by 20th Century-Fox for the leading roles in "Accustomed as I Am," a screen comedy which John Mason Brown and Patricia Coleman are writing from Brown's recently published novel about a lecture tour.

All the top athletes of the metropolitan area and a few outstandingperformers from out of town willcompete in the 172d Spring games[of the New York Athletic Club atI Travers Island today. Fourteenl events are on the proram, withall running races except the 3,000meter steeplechase tr be conductedon a handicap basis.

BERLIN, June 4 --The Germans are now accepted by the British as "Christian and civilized people" and are to be treated accordingly, Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British Military Governor, announced today.

Samuel Reshevsky, United States chess champion, arrived yesterday aboard the Holland-America liner Veendam after a stay of three and a half months in Europe, during which period he competed with four others--three Russian representatives and one from The Netherlands -- in the long tournament for the world championship at The Hague and Moscow.

The executive committee of the Brightside Day Nursery at 89 Cannon Street held its final meeting there yesterday before the nursery, founded in 1894, closes on June 30. At the head of the table sat Mrs. S. R. Guggenheim, 80 years old, the only president the nursery has known in its fifty-four years.

h)0*0*0*iOA proposal by Westchester surface ways to increase bus fares by 3 cents a ride, from 5 to 8 cents, on three of its routes was suspended yesterday by the Public Service Commission, which has instituted a proceeding to determine whether the company is entitled to higher fares.

Efforts by Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, to investigate the expulsion of three anti-Communist leaders by the Bloomingdale department store union ran into a stone wall yesterday when the three refused to cooperate with the inquiry.

KENILWORTH, N.J., June 4 -Mike Elko, champion of the New Jersey Public Golf Organization, was eliminated in the second round of the Metropolitan Public Links championship over the Galloping Hill golf course today.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 4 -- The Minister-Presidents of the United States, British and French zones will meet tomorrow in Essen to discuss the economic problems of Western Germany. One of the principal topics will be the drop in Ruhr coal production.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., June 4 -- Ideal weather graced today the twenty-fourth field day of the Bond Club of New York, held here at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club which drew a record crowd of more than 500 investment bankers and brokers from New York and other financial centers of the country.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -The building boom continues. A Commerce Department report today noted that:

The Camp Fire Girls, Inc., raised its national membership by 46,000 girls in the last year, bringing its enrollment to 360,000, largest in the history of the organization, it was reported yesterday in the group's annual report for 1947.

Elliott Arnold will receive the Silver Medal of the Commonwealth Club of California on Tuesday for his book "Blood Brother," a novel about the Chiricahua Apaches. The presentation will be made by the club's president, Justice Homer R. Spence of California Supreme Court, at a dinner in San Francisco.

Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday that he would not tolerate in any city department or agency labor unions that go beyond their 'proper function" of promoting the welfare of their members to interfere in matters of city and departmental policy.

0*0*0*iOIndustrial construction costs are now fairly well stabilized at a level which is expected to continue for the next two years, Harry Matthews, president of the Brown Matthews Engineering Company, told the North Atlantic regional meeting of the Society of Industrial Realtors yesterday in the Biltmore Hotel.

TRENTON, N.J., June 4 -New Jersey educational authorities announced today that racial segregation, practiced in some school districts for many years, was being ended in twenty-two communities in time for the September opening of schools.

LONDON, June 4 -- Last of a phalanx of United States business men are leaving for home this week with order books virtually empty. The sales representatives came to Europe six weeks ago and in that time have canvassed practically every one of sixteen countries eligible for European Recovery Program funds.

A national survey is being made of steel requirements of America's major cities because municipal buyers fear that allocations and voluntary priorities used for national defense and Marshall Plan needs will pre-empt steel needed for municipal construction and maintenance projects.

Philip Randolph-Grant Reynolds civil disobedience campaign as a means of ending segregation of races in the the drafting and training of the armed forces.

Striking back sharply yesterday at a news magazine's description of New York as "a hell of a town," Park Commissioner Robert Moses said it was no such thing.

BALBOA HEIGHTS, Canal Zone -- Travelers to tropical America will find both air and sea transportation easier to obtain, at least until mid-October, than it was during the winter and spring. ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 7 -- In an ever-increasing stream, the vanguard of some 40,000 shriners poured into this resort today from all sections of North America for the seventy-fourth annual session of the imperial council, Ancient Arabic Order, Nobles of the Mystic Shrine.

PARIS, June 5 -- Next Tuesday the French Government will meet the grave problem of the accords on Germany after a week of serious dissension on internal matters. This dissension has severely shaken Premier Schuman's center combination known as the "Third Force."

PROVIDENCE -- Visitors to Rhode Island this summer will find several new attractions added to the sandy beach bathing, fresh and salt water boating and numerous forests, parks and parkways that make this little state a great big vacationland.

JERUSALEM, June 5 -- The bread ration for Jerusalem was cut today from 200 to 150 grams (about 5.25 ounces) a person.

MR. BRYANT'S maritime history of the United States gets the ambitious "Growth of America Series" off to a brisk start. As visualized by Editor Arthur B. Tourtellot, the series will eventually explore the whole material, social and cultural history of America.

BUENOS AIRES -- Midwinter is fastening its clutches on South America these days but there is still plenty of sunshine awaiting the traveler on this vast continent. The fact that Argentina and Chile can be frozen to the fur-coat stage while norteamericanos are sweltering through July and August emphasizes the intercontinental contrast.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- The recent merger of the Pocono Mountains Vacation Bureau and the resort members of the Pocono Mountains Chamber of Commerce is expected to give vacationists bound for this region's 400 resorts and 125 camps a new service which will enable them to make their holiday plans with greater ease.

MONTREAL -- This city and Quebec the two largest French-language cities outside France, expect a record number of visitors from south or the international border this summer. Resorts in the Laurentian lake and mountain areas north of Montreal advise early bookings.

TO most boys growing up in the 1920's, Babe Ruth was just about the biggest man in the world. Idolized by the youth of America, and by their fathers, too, the King of Swat was the most spectacular sports personality of his colorful era.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Vermonters throughout the state are preparing for one of their most important jobs of the year -- entertaining summer visitors. All is being put in readiness for the early June arrivals and for the nearly two million vacationists from outside Vermont who are expected to spend from two days to two months in the Green Mountain State this summer.

BOSTON, June 5 -- Held back until the quarter pole by confident Warren Mehrtens, the 3-year-old Better Self from Robert J. Kleberg's King Ranch splashed to a two-and-a-half-length victory over William G. Hehs' Salmagundi in the $50,000-added Yankee Handicap today before a drenched crowd of 23,000 at Suffolk Downs.

ROME, June 5 -- The Vatican Congregation of the Holy Office issued a "warning" today reminding all Catholics, whether members of clergy or laymen, that they were forbidden to participate in "mixed" congresses or meetings of Catholics and non-Catholics wherein matters of faith were discussed.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 5 (AP) -- The surging Columbia river rolled toward a new crest tonight with all dikes holding.

LIBERTY -- The vacationist who unloads his luggage at some Catskill Mountain resort this spring and summer is going to find virtually everything he wants in living accommodations, food, recreation and entertainment, according to the size of his budget.
CHICAGO, June 5 (AP) -- The United Packinghouse Workers, CIO, tonight ended its strike against Wilson Co. on the same terms as in a settlement made three weeks ago with the other three major packers.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 (AP) -- Cleveland's Indians untangled the snarl in the American League standings today by bombarding Joe Coleman and the Philadelphia Athletics for a 7-3 victory.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 -- For the first time in many months Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week registered a gain over the like 1947 period, totaling 149,433, as against 139,901 a year ago, an increase of 6.8 per cent. For 1948 to date Pennsylvania Railroad loadings totaled 2,717,354, to compare with 2,994,404 last year, a decrease of 9.3 per cent.

IN 1901, at the age of 7, William T. Tilden II, the son of a successful Philadelphia merchant in wool and hair, won the Junior Boys' Championship (age 15 and under) at the Onteora Tennis Club of Onteora, N.Y. As a glance at any of the various almanacs will show, he has come a long way since then, having won some seventy national titles, amateur and professional, the last one in 1945.

TOKYO, June 5 -- Sharp opposition is arising here to the Far Eastern Commission's proposals that Japan be required to replace cultural objects destroyed or lost in Allied countries as a result of her aggression. Gen. Douglas MacArthur, it is understood, has cabled a strongly worded protest against the "legalized looting of Japan's cultural resources."

VIENNA, June 5 -- A British communique today announced that the American snatched from the British military police Thursday night in Vienna's inner city by a squad of armed Russians had been released by the Russians through British intervention and handed over to United States military authorities.

BOSTON -- Off the coast of New England lies a vacation land which is fully "air conditioned" by the winds of the North Atlantic and affords a peace and quiet probably unequaled anywhere on the mainland. This vacation land consists of the more than 1,500 islands, big and small, that stand guard off the coast all the way from Block Island, off Rhode Island's Point Judith, to the very top of Maine.

English and American furniture for the country home and the informal city apartment also wrought iron furniture and sculpture for gardens will be auctioned at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday.

ESSEN, Germany, June 5 -- Rehabilitation of the Ruhr's coal and steel production has received highest priority in an effort to assure the projected Western German Government of a sound economy. In addition to a new concentration of threats and incentives upon German management and workers, the United States and British Military Governments are embarking on plans calling for increased outside aid.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The outstanding Republican figure on foreign policy, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, today assumed leadership of efforts in the Senate to restore House-imposed slashes in global aid activities, particularly the European Recovery Program.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A mere 1.14-point change in the consumers' price index will raise or lower the General Motors Corporation's payroll by more than $5,000,000 a year.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 5 -- Five Yale scientists will spend this summer in mountains two miles high, studying mysterious cosmic rays.

MR. SMITH, the United Press reporter who has been stationed in the White House press room since 1941, has used his spare time and his reportorial skill well in gathering together and putting into this book myriads of details and colorful anecdotes about the people around a President.

A PEONY and iris show will be held under the auspices of the Horticultural Society of New York, 598 Madison Avenue, on June 8 and 9. It will be open to the public from 2 to 10 P.M. on Tuesday and from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. on Wednesday.

THE name of Harold Laski, member of the executive committee of the British Labor party and Professor of Political Science at the University of London, on the title page will probably arouse a multitude of reactions in the American reading public, ranging from cold anger to indiscriminate admiration.

CONCORD, N.H. -- Fresh from the institute conducted for resort operators at the University of New Hampshire, mine host in this state is ready to welcome the summer visitor. His accommodations will be adequate, although vacationists are asked to make reservations early and so be sure of bed and board during the height of the season and over holiday week-ends.

OOTACAMUD, India, June 5 (AP) -- The United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East postponed today for the second time consideration of the application for associate membership for the Republic of Indonesia.

LONDON, June 5 -- British automobile manufacturers counted their invasion of the United States market a success today. They are now selling more cars in the United States than in any other non-empire country.

That is approximately 38 per cent of the budget for 1949 and 8 per cent of our estimated national income of 200 billion dollars.

CAIRO, June 5 (U.P.) -- A heavy Israeli assault on the Old City of Jerusalem was thrown back "with heavy losses" today by Arab legionnaires who later forced Israeli defenders on Mt. Scopus to surrender, the Legion reported today.

ATANTIC CITY -- The summer mood of merriment will be set for the New Jersey coast resorts from June 14 to 30 when Atlantic City stages its "Honeymoon in June" celebration for newly married couples. BUENOS AIRES, June 5 -- Miguel Miranda, head of the National Economic Council, confirmed today what he had told United States officials: that there was no need for special Marshall Plan missions to come here, because Argentina's price policy was fixed.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- After three weeks of fighting since the British vacated their mandate, Arab and Israeli forces still appear to be jockeying for position. Raids by land and air, desultory shelling and sporadic fighting extend from the Negeb area to Galilee, but neither side has won decisive victories and a full trial of strength has not occurred.

Talleyrand was amoral, unscrupulous, unchaste, a gambler, a grafter, a thief and a liar, a traitor to many causes.

VIENNA, June 5 -- The international Socialist conference meeting here today debated whether the Ruhr should be fully internationalized, or nationalized by the Germans and merely put under international supervision. It also continued its attempt to redefine democratic socialism but will not reach any conclusion until Monday.

The mail order and chain store companies made by far the best showing in retail trade last year, reporting a gain of 21.1 per cent in sales and an increase in profits of 6.7 per cent over 1946, according to a compilation of the annual reports of fifty-four retail companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz suggested yesterday that if the District Attorney of Brooklyn wanted the addresses of "Brooklyn dives" he consult the court records of criminal cases that occurred in Brooklyn taverns.

THE first tentative steps toward establishment of a motion picture industry in the State of Israel have resulted to date in production of a feature-length entertainment picture, "A Place Called Home," and completion of the first in a series of monthly news films generally titled "Israel Today."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 5 -- Babe Ruth, who didn't need a lot of book learning to grow great, stood on Yale Field this cloudy afternoon and presented a manuscript to the Yale University Library. It wasn't a case of the Bambino toting coals to Newcastle but a genuine contribution of a prime example of Americana, the story of Ruth's life.

PAINTERS, upholsterers, cabinet makers and carpet layers have been hard at work during the past twelve months rescuing from a state of dowdy disrepair hundreds of hotel rooms which have gone untouched for well over a decade.

HOBOKEN. N.J., June 5 -- Lasting industrial peace can be possible only when everyone realizes that the interests of owners, workers and consuming public are common interests, Dudley W. Figgis, president of the American Can Company, told the graduating class of Stevens Institute of Technology here today at the annual commencement exercises, in William Hall Walker Gymnasium.

ONCE we used to pack some peanut butter sandwiches into an old shoebox, tuck in an orange or two and call it a picnic. Since then, something has happened. A new school of outdoor dining has grown up, exemplified by the cowhide leather case that holds everything from a vacuum jug for martinis to stainless steel knives for a steak a la fresh air.

WASHINGTON -- The resorts that make up the Midsouth vacationland are already beginning to fill up, with indications in most areas that the 1948 season will equal that of last year. Reports on prices vary; some communities state that they will "try to keep them down"; others expect costs to be "slightly higher," and some claim a small reduction.

Rocky Graziano, world middleweight champion, makes the first defense of his title Wednesday night, against Tony Zale, Gary, Ind., veteran, from whom he won the crown last July in the steaming cauldron that was Chicago's Stadium. But, because he is under suspension in his native New York, the bout will be waged across the Hudson River.

THE Grand Ballet de Monte Carlo, George de Cuevas, director, opens an engagement of four weeks in Rio do Janeiro tomorrow. The company and all the scenery were scheduled to travel by air from Europe where they have just completed a month's engagement at the home theatre in Monaco and two weeks of touring in Belgium and Holland.

MISS KISSIN'S book is a sincere love-letter to this country -- that's about all. As a novel, it's a failure. Writing novels is still a crafty and sullen art, no matter how sincere you are. Miss Kissin isn't crafty enough to keep things going for very long.

After living for two days at the rate of $500 a day, a 24-year-old hospital orderly left the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday for the City Prison, charged with forgery, grand larceny and being a fugitive from the authorities of Salt Lake City, Utah.

Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the Zionist Organization of America, asserted last night that American Zionists "cannot and will not intervene in any form in the political life of Israel which is the exclusive prerogative of the citizens of the new republic, the Israelis."

LENOIR, N.C., June 5 -- Senator Robert A. Taft urged the South today to preserve its sectional tradition of "individual liberties free from outside interference" by forswearing allegiance to the New Deal and "its European theory of control by centralized government."

HYANNIS, Mass. -- Early June is one of the nicest times of year on Cape Cod. Most of the painting and shingling and repairing of the winter's damage has been done; the first of the summer guests are beginning to arrive; and for those Cape Codders who have finished preparing for the Cape's biggest business -- the summer folk from the cities -- there is a slight lull before the big rush starts.

WHAT are the distinctive features of Columbia University as the new president -- the thirteenth in a distinguished roster -- takes his seat, and in what directions is its growth tending? These are questions which arouse interest far beyond New York City or even the nation. In half a dozen years now Columbia will celebrate its two hundredth anniversary.

HENRY at the age of 6 was so well posted on the subject of gravity that he knew why some children fell on the playground slide. Henry was afraid to go down the slide, but he would stand by and explain, "Don't lean over so far. Your center of gravity is wrong."

ST. LOUIS, June 5 -- Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas, in a letter to a St. Louis editorial writer today, said activity toward his nomination for President on the Democratic ticket was against his "express desires and wishes."
LONDON, June 5 -- Another African peanut-growing project, vaster than the one in East Africa, is proposed in the report of the British West African Oil Seeds Mission.
The peonies are a little late this year. Too much cloud and rain, too little sun and warmth in May held them back. But now they come, in familiar generosity, half as big as cabbages.

Recent reports from Moscow musical circles have prompted me to give a little thought to the problem of contemporary art. After all the vague and evasive double talk I have read concerning the subject, I feel that my confused observations are quite as valid as any others that I have seen published.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 5 (AP) -- The Cyprus Government says that Zionist officials did not move to ship Jews from Cyprus to Palestine until after the United Nations had proposed an Arab-Jewish truce.
In his article on Bill Bojangles Robinson, Richard Strouse says that etymologists cannot disprove Robinson's contention that he invented "copacetic." Here's a true story that should help.

American business leaders were called on yesterday by Common Cause, Inc., a group announced as seeking to promote unity among the democratic peoples against Communist infiltration and aggression, to establish a huge development corporation that would employ anti-Communist displaced persons in profitable business ventures strategically located in the Near East and Africa.

GENEVA, June 5 -- Operations of the Economic Cooperation Administration are getting under way more slowly in Europe than in Washington. As of June 1, although the heads of three major missions to Britain. France and Italy had been appointed, none was established at his post.

NANKING, June 5 -- Foreign Minister Wang Shih-chien declared today that China and the United States still held divergent views on the disposal of war-supporting industries in Japan, but expressed the conviction that neither would "countenance Japanese rearmament."

The first rose of summer was blooming alone last week-end in the huge rose garden in the Botanical Garden up in the Bronx. Its "lovely companions" are blooming this week-end by the score and by the hundred.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Senate Finance Committee ended hearings today on extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, with a modified bill slated to go to the floor next week.
WEST POINT, N.Y., June 5 -- Playing an inspired brand of ball throughout, Army's revivified lacrosse team upset the highly favored Mount Washington club, 5 to 2, on the Plains today.

The three United States contestants in the 10,000-meter walking event at the Olympics will be determined today. Forty-two heel-and-toe racers from a wide span of the country will take the mark at 2 P. M. at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium in the combined final try-out and National A.A.U. championship.

ORNAMENTATION seems to have fallen out of favor lately -- partly, we suppose, because craftsmen are scarce and craft-work, in our modern world, is usually too expensive to use for extraneous embellishment. It is also because today's housekeepers resent the time it takes to care for intricate carving, delicate metal work, and similar adornment.

HENRY MILLER says that "a clown is a poet in action." The immortal bards might be pleased with the idea. Whether they would be equally pleased if anyone said that a poet is a clown in action is probably a very different kettle of fish.
BOSTON, June 5 (AP) -- Massachusetts' thirty-six delegate votes at the Democratic National Convention are going solid for President Truman.

WINCHESTER, Va. -- In a tour of Virginia's Shenandoah Valley totaling less than 400 miles, the sight-seeing motorist can cover most of its scenic and historic attractions. He can look out over the valley from the spectacular Skyline Drive and can descend beneath its floor into nine huge natural caverns.

ON June 18 the New York City Convention and Visitors Bureau will open its new headquarters at 500 Park Avenue, at Fifty-ninth Street. Here out-of-town visitors will be able to obtain information on every facet of city life and advice on how best to see everything.

New officers will be installed next Wednesday at the second anniversary dinner of TOPS, Inc. (Telephone Order of Personality and Smiles), a social club of chief telephone operators in charge of switchboards in newspapers, hotels and industrial plants.

ONE trouble with writing literary criticism in the guise of fiction is that the result challenges judgment according to its fictional qualities and merits, over and above the judgment invoked by its critical content. Miss Stern has set out to say her say about Robert Louis Stevenson by indirection in a fearfully ingenious full-length novel.

THIS summer more people are expected to travel than at any other time since the boom years of the late Twenties. Starved for the glamorous culture that can be achieved only through foreign adventure, Helen Hokinson's club women will again bustle about the Tate Gallery and peep down Paris' naughty, ominous alleys.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 5 -- Fighting from the north and east, Arab forces made a desperate attempt today to relieve an Egyptian column trapped in the Gaza coastal strip above Isdud.

WRITTEN by the late Felix Salten during his wartime sojourn in Switzerland, this rueful little case-history of a female feline's coming-of-age seems more notebook than integrated story -- a far cry, indeed, from the spell of "Bambi."

A TOUCH was put on the brake last week when the Federal Reserve Board ordered a 2 per cent increase in reserve requirements for member banks in the New York and Chicago districts, but business was not disturbed and keeps sailing on the even keel it has regained after its scare last February.

BUTTE, Mont. -- In every American there lurks something of Lewis and Clark. The motorist most displays his exploration qualities when, with road map spread out on his knee, he plots the course of his automobile through unknown and alluring territory.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A debate of surpassing bitterness and vehemence has engaged Washington this week over a measure that may or may not go to the Senate floor in the little time left for this session of Congress.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 5 -- Mrs. John H. Wells of Providence, R.I., civic leader and lecturer on international affairs, was elected first woman president of the Board of Trustees of Mount Holyoke College at the commencement meeting of the board this afternoon.

TRENTON, N.J. -- Late spring brought impatient vacationists to New Jersey's lake and mountain areas in such numbers as to be accepted as the harbinger of a prosperous and busy summer. Most visitors seemed content with the current rates, which run about the 1947 level of $35 to $45 a week.

THE family of this reviewer finally got around to seeing "Sitting Pretty" at its favorite show-shop last Saturday while Papa worked in the garden and generally communed with his soul. (Such tardiness is a family practice; we live well out in the suburbs and the kids usually go to the movies -- when they go -to a local third-run house).

PHILADELPHIA -- The thousands of June vacationists who are thinking of including in their holiday plans a visit to one of the greatest shows on earth -- the quadrennial feature of the American scene known as the Presidential nominating conventions -- are advised to gather round for a bit of advice and warning.

"THIS is the story of how some small boys in Bali decided among themselves to have a club and learn to play music, and how they became so clever that the Raja invited them to play at his palace when he married the beautiful princess."

DISTRIBUTION of awards for outstanding photographic achievement by camera club members during the 1947-1948 season will mark the annual dinner of the Metropolitan Camera Club Council June 17 at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 5 -- The Constitution Day festival of the Danish Social Democrat party brought together today Premier Hans Hedtoft of Denmark, Premier Tage Erlander of Sweden and Foreign Secretary Halvard Lange of Norway.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Washington scored its fifth straight victory of the season over the White Sox today, defeating the Chicagoans, 3 -- 2.

LAKE PLACID -- The distinctive appeal of Adirondack Park lies in its miles of woodlands, its mountains, lakes, brooks and streams and its atmosphere of wilderness peace. Preserved from undue exploitation, great parcels of land aggregating almost half of the park's area are owned by the state.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., June 5 -- After the break of a black-fingered squall over Long Island Sound this noon that scattered rain and dismal murk, sixty-two racing craft went out into sunshine for the championship regatta of the Sea Cliff Yacht Club.

TWO fairly representative shows of "primitive" art by a group of early Americans and a contemporary invite speculation on the enduring value of our multifarious forms of the "naive." Galerie St. Etienne is showing work by Hicks, Kane, Pickett and earlier anonymous figures.

THE manuscript of this book is said to have lain dormant and unpublished for almost a century, and unless it is a literary hoax, which all the evidence says it is not, it is a counterpart of Herman Melville's saga of the hazardous days of American whaling.

NEW DELHI, India, June 5 -- India's representative at the United Nations has been instructed to sign the Geneva agreement on reciprocal tariff concessions, the Government announced today. Some of the concessions thus granted to foreign products by India must be implemented by the Indian Parliament, which is to meet this summer.
Admiration and love impel the writer to add to the tribute paid the late Olga Samaroff by a group of her pupils in THE TIMES of May 23.
BRUSSELS, June 5 -- Miss Doris Hart, top-seeded woman player from Miami, Fla., was upset in the semi-finals of the Belgian international tennis tournament today, but two Californians, Frank Parker

The Red Bank Regatta "Rhubarb" was at last reconciled at a special Friday night meeting of the American Power Boat Association's National Council that ended early yesterday morning at Philadelphia. The 1948 edition of this popular race meet will be held Aug. 21-22, under a full and unconditional A.P.B.A. sanction and it was a case of all's well that ends well with this controversy that has rocked speedboating circles for many months.
IN the inlets, basins and marinas which dot the Atlantic seaboard from Basport, Me., to Key Largo, Fla., sails are being rigged and motors revved in anticipation of a lively boating season.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- The American Association of University Women announced today award of thirty-four fellowships to women to help them conduct advance research. The fellowships, most of them for $1,500, total $52,000.

MUSIC is not the only product of musical instruments. They are also a source of headaches. Musicians are constantly bedeviled by their breaking strings, faulty needs, sticky valves, balky keys, dampers and pedals.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 5 -- Faris el-Khouri of Syria, president of the Security Council, revealed today that he had instructed the United Nations Mediator in Palestine by cable that the Council's intention was that "no military advantage shall accrue to either side" during the proposed four-week truce.

Immobilization of $500,000,000 of banks' earning assets, resulting from the 2 per cent advance in reserve requirements ordered last week by the Federal Reserve Board will undoubtedly stiffen commercial lending rates, according to financial observers here.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- The outlook for revision of the seventy-eight-year-old Illinois Constitution, which in its present form handicaps the state in most of its functions, now appears brighter than at any time since the campaign to modernize the state's basic law began nearly sixty years ago.

To meet the increased interest in the Orient and the Soviet Union, the Far Eastern and Russian Language School of the University of California Extension will offer three full terms of study beginning this summer. The twelve-week summer session and the fall and spring semesters will be devoted to the program.

Declaring that the skillfulness of the Communists in underground warfare "can upset the balance of the world" Maj. Gen. William J. Donovan, wartime head of the Office of Strategic Services, warned yesterday against dependence upon the European Recovery Program alone as "an economic Maginot Line" for the solution of the problems provoked by the Soviet Union.

LONDON, June 5 -- A further drop in Britain's living standard and the spread of unemployment were seen as inevitable by Government officials here today if the House of Representatives vote cutting funds for aid to Europe won Senate endorsement.

AS an effort to delineate and explain Aroostook County, Maine's inland empire, "Pine, Potatoes and People" leaves several desires unfulfilled, but it is an enjoyable bit of Helen Hamlin's lively, folksy, conversational Maine commentary, and it merits companionship with many another book about the State of Maine.

THE Yazoo Delta down in Mississippi is one of the richest farming areas on earth, fitted to grow almost everything. Yet its natural wealth is handicapped by economic and social factors that are peculiar to the deep South. Moreover, its future is threatened by the technological changes taking place in agriculture.

ONE of the most fascinating gardening experiences I have had is observing Peruvian daffodil or ismene as it flowers. A miracle of rapid growth, in less than an hour it unfolds petal by petal from a closely fluted bud into a shimmering chalice of white.
THE farmers of New York State today will open their own network of frequency- modulation stations, a chain called Rural Radio Network.
CHICAGO, June 5 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows.

MUROC, Calif., June 5 -- One of the Air Force's big experimental jet-propelled "flying wing" bombers, known as the YB-49 and called the world's most powerful plane, crashed in the desert ten miles north of the Muroc air base during a test flight this morning. Its crew of five were killed.

The Polo Grounds, site of a host of diversified spectacles in its time, served as the theatre for another sports activity last night. Midget auto racing, reputed to be the fourth largest spectator -- and unquestionably the noisiest -- sport in the United States, moved into the ball park to the enthusiastic welcome of a surprising crowd of 22,418.

ATHENS, June 5 -- Army reports today from Epirus said that in the past forty-eight hours there has been a succession of sharp skirmishes with rebel units in the Soli district about thirty miles southwest of Yanina. The Army had lost thirteen dead and twelve wounded against eleven rebels killed and thirty-eight captured, the Army said.

AT 16 Abby Chapin is beginning to have growing pains. Daughter of a skilled craftsman in a New England factory town, she has never before been aware of any difference between herself and the mill manager's son whom she expects to marry.

Chiefs of the Economic Cooperation Administration missions to Great Britain and France sailed for Europe yesterday on the Holland-American liner Nieuw Amsterdam, which departed from Hoboken with 1,224 passengers, the largest number she ever carried on the eastbound crossing.
QUITO, Ecuador, June 5 (AP) -- A customs union of Colombia, Ecuador, Panama and Venezuela was approved last night by delegates of the four countries at an economic conference.
The text of President Truman's address at Omaha last night, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES, was as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Almost obscured from national attention by the sound and fury of the Presidential race is the equally important battle now being fought for the control of the next Congress, without whose sympathetic support our next Chief Executive cannot function efficiently or well.

BUENOS AIRES, June 5 -- The question whether a woman really minds having her age revealed enlivened a parliamentary debate here this week -- a debate in which Argentine deputies challenged one another on just how far gallantry should be permitted to enter public affairs.

HOW an "ordinary young man of peasant stock" came to betray the Soviet Union and bare the existence of a widespread conspiracy to obtain secret official information in Canada, the United States and the United Kingdom is the substance of the Gouzenko story.

The second quarterly installment of the 1948 Federal income tax is due Tuesday, June 15, and collectors of internal revenue have issued reminders to the public that declarations or revised declarations of estimated income tax for the current year must be filed on or before that date.

JUST twelve years ago this week in this Review: Thirty-three years' work was represented in "Stories of Three Decades," by Thomas Mann, and critic Louis Kronenberger found it "more than a sound tribute to one of the most distinguished of living writers." . . .

PUBLIC rose gardens are fascinating places to visit. In addition to extensive plantings -- which are both living catalogue and encyclopedia many of the gardens in the East have special programs during June.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- The tourist industry of Florida's west coast, long a convenient watering spot for vacationists from the hot interiors of Alabama and Georgia, is reaching farther north for summer visitors. The second greatest attraction, after the climate and ocean, now is the greatly reduced scale of rates.

COLONEL H.J. MATCHETT, Hollywood liaison officer for the Public Information Division of the Department of the Army, disclosed last week that his office is currently processing a dozen feature films with military backgrounds, a quantity which is almost up to wartime levels.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations reported today that its southern organizing campaign, which entered its third year this week, had added 800 local unions and more than 400,000 names to the rolls of CIO affiliates.

MIAMI -- Some 22,000 persons traveled into the new Everglades National Park during the past winter tourist season and most of them indicated that they would be back as the park is developed. Summer vacationists are showing as keen an interest in this new tropical wonderland.

AMERICAN readers can be grateful for this volume giving the most significant passages on Gandhi from the voluminous writings of Jawaharlal Nehru. The introduction is from Nehru's introduction to "Gandhiji: His Life and Work"; the body is taken from "Towards Freedom," "Glimpses of World History," and "The Discovery of India"; and the conclusion from Nehru's grief-wrought eulogy at Gandhi's death.
The Church Cup matches, which have not been held since the war, are included in the outdoor schedule announced yesterday by the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association.

DAVID BEN-GURION, Israel's first Prime Minister, decided about forty years ago that there was going to be a Jewish state in Palestine some time and that he was going to be one of its leaders. He has come to the realization of that dream, but it has meant forty years of toil, hardships, discouragement, imprisonment and even exile.

JUNE is the month when the majority of the country's summer hotels stage their official openings. From sandy beach to green mountain-top, from northern Maine to southern New Jersey, hotel orchestras will roll their drums and social directors snap their entertainers into line for what promises to be the gayest season since rationing went out.

Stranss: Suite from Der Rosenkavalier. Philadelphia Orchestra conducted by Eugene Ormandy. (Columbia, three twelve-inch disks). If you are fond of this opera of Richard Strauss, you may wish to have some of the orchestral passages, even if you have to take them without singers.

FOR THIS WEEK: Spray for aphids with a solution of nicotine sulfate and soap. If there are tiny green worms on the undersides of leaves, use arsenate of lead or rotenone. Rotenone is also effective against flea beetles, which have started to puncture leaves of tomatoes and beets . . . Rain has caused rank growth on perennials and weeds. Remove weeds by hand pulling or cultivating.

"Why They Join the Wallace Crusade," by Cabell Phillips, portrays Henry Wallace as a Messianic type. THE TIMES seems to forget that he was formerly Vice President and Secretary of Commerce, and that, while holding those offices, he commanded the admiration of many people.

Representatives of the four CIO-affiliated maritime unions meeting here in a unity conference last night expressed determination to continue the fight for current goals. The conference started Friday morning in the headquarters of the National Maritime Union, 346 West Seventeenth Street.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 5 (AP) -- Horse owners will have to accept a $17,500 cut in purses this summer at the Atlantic City race track.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 5 -- John Allen Murphy, a pioneer business and advertising writer and since 1940 a market research consultant of the G.M. Basford Company, 60 East Forty-second Street, New York, market research and public relations concern, died of a heart ailment in his home at 11 Walnut Avenue here last night at the age of 64.

OMAHA, June 5 -- Taunting the Republican leadership in Congress for inaction on farm legislation, President Truman offered tonight a four-plank farm program in which a permanent price support system and expanded soil conservation measures were the mainstays.

TWO new hybrid tea roses, named Forty-niner and Tallyho, have been designated as the All-America Rose Selections for 1949. This brings to twenty-five the number of varieties that have won this title in the nine years in which this method of testing new roses has existed.
Five leaders will receive honorary degrees this afternoon at the commencement of the Jewish Theological Seminary, 122d Street and Broadway. The exercises will be held in the seminary quadrangle.

IF YOU put a Lilliputian under a magnifying glass he would look like a giant. But he'd still be a Lilliputian. Well, there is a kind of writing that works like that. It's a way of looking at things close up, with a lot of detail to sharpen the eye.

THE legality of municipal and state film censor groups may be tested in a suit contemplated by the American Civil Liberties Union and/or the Motion Picture Association of America, it became known last week. Officials of both organizations have conferred and, although no decisions have been made, a spokesman for the MPAA divulged that "we are greatly interested."

AS the war in Europe approached its end there was a good deal of talk in the United States of a need for a cooling-off period between the close of hostilities and the beginning of peace negotiations. Then no one dreamed that three years after V-E Day we would still have made no real progress toward peace with Germany.

The decree restricting dollar transfers by Argentina will prove to be temporary, and it does not indicate any slackening of the internal financial progress and industrialization of the country, Ezra Teubal, Buenos Aires textile manufacturer and wool dealer, said in an interview here last week.

JACKSON, Miss., June 5 -- Mississippi's consistently inconsistent position on whisky is demonstrated in a state "black market" tax of 10 per cent on liquor sales made in violation of its prohibition statute. Existence of the unusual levy is an admission of inability to enforce the bone-dry law, largely because of sentiment in the "wet" areas of the state.

The New York Public Library's outstanding collection of material relating to baseball has been augmented by a recent gift from Daniel Hoffman. Among the books received is Ethan Allen's "Major League Baseball, Technique and Tactics."

I WONDER if Americans realize the importance of reducing trade barriers. Suppose, for example, that high tariffs or other major trade barriers existed between New York and New Jersey, or between California and Oregon. Suppose every time we crossed a state line we had to show a passport and stop to have our baggage examined by customs officers.
The request of the taxicab industry for a 30 per cent rise in fares has been referred by the Board of Estimate to William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation for study and report.

A few months ago, in one of the Veterans Administration domiciliary homes in the West, a 28-year-old World War II veteran was admitted because of diabetes. He had gone through the North African campaign and fighting in Europe without an injury, but was admitted to the VA hospital in mid-1946, when the disease was found in a pre-placement physical examination for a job as a crane operator.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- This year's crop of more than 200,000 college graduates and 1,000,000 high school graduates who strike out in search of jobs will find conditions generally favorable, Ewan Clague, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said today.

LONDON, June 5 -- Even among its supporters there are two views about Britain's Labor Government. The view which is held by what might be called the "moderates" is that the Government has moved too fast toward socialism in a time of economic distress.

MEXICO CITY -- Since tourism is Mexico's fourth largest source of income, dollar-spending visitors from the North will receive more than the usual attention this summer. Improvements are planned to attract Americans in the same large numbers as during the war.

Despite the opposition of the British Government, the partition of Palestine must stand and nothing must be permitted to weaken it, rabbis declared in sermons here yesterday. The Senate bill on displaced persons was held discriminatory against Jews.

The Joint Distribution Committee announced yesterday that for the first six months of this year it had allocated $36,389,700 for its relief, resettlement and reconstruction program. During June its appropriation will amount to $5,784,725.

VISITORS heading for the West this summer will have a long list of rodeos to choose from, for special emphasis is being placed upon this uniquely American event with the celebration of its sixtieth anniversary at the annual Frontier Day celebration at Prescott, Ariz., July 1-4.

SOME eight years back Jerome Moross and I began working on what became "Ballet Ballads." Our intention was to blend several elements of the American theatrical, dance and musical heritage into a pattern adapted to the contemporary stage.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 5 -- Some 2,000 Ute Indians, residing on or near tribal lands along the Utah-Colorado border, are hoping to acquire sudden wealth comparable to that of their Cherokee brethern in the State of Oklahoma.

PRAGUE, June 5 -- The Communist party, through its official bulletin boards for the information of the public, has warned residents of at least one Prague district that those who voted the whit "negative" ballots last Sunday might have exposed themselves to the vengeance of the party.

The indiscriminate use of "strong-arm" methods of psychotherapy such as electro-shock, injections of sodium amytol and lobotomy were attacked yesterday by Dr. Robert P. Knight, one of the nation's leading psychiatrists.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 5 (UP) -- The ancient town, of Yibna was the last Arab fortress between the Israeli capital and the Egyptian outposts two miles north of Isdud.

Some years ago it struck Henry Booth, president of Amalgamated Textiles, Ltd., an inventor of parts and a grandson of the Salvation Amy's founder, that in two thousand years there had been no fundamental change in tailoring. What with wages rising, it seemed to him about time to do away with fussy fitting.

IF it is not too late in the season, there is a piece of unfinished business concerning Tennessee Williams' "A Street-car Named Desire." In some comments that appeared in this place last December, I described it as a painful play written by a man with a "poetic awareness of people and life."

PARIS, June 5 -- The French Government today announced that it "recognized" the new Provisional government of Viet Nam as a member of the French Union and that an agreement to this effect had been signed at noon, Indo-China time, aboard a French cruiser in the Bay of Along, off Haiphong, between native leaders and the French High Commissioner, Robert Bollaert.

RESCRIPTS of the addresses made at the New England music critics' symposium held under the auspices of The Hartford Times at Hartford, May 18 and 19, a symposium in which the writer took part, have come to hand.

BRUNSWICK, Me., June 5--Bowdoin College conferred 158 bachelor degrees and six honorary degrees at its 143rd commencement today. Presentation of an honorary award to Maj. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor superintendent of the United States Military Academy, was deferred, his plane having been grounded by bad weather.

UNDOUBTEDLY the most gratifying news to arrive on Broadway in weeks came the other day from the direction of Studio, Inc., that acting school Elia Kazan, Cheryl Crawford and Robert Lewis founded early last season.

ALTHOUGH June is the ranking month for roses, the hybrid teas will also flower throughout the summer and put on another fine display in autumn. This is practically guaranteed by the right sort of care until late frost.

Unfavorable weather retarded expansion of the sale of seasonal merchandise here last week. Department store sales fell about 5 per cent under the like week of last year. In considerable part this was due to the fact that comparison was with six selling days in 1946 against five this year owing to the inclusion of the Memorial Day holiday.

Consolidated net income of $895,132,357 has been reported by 297 industrial manufacturers for the first quarter of 1948. This is an increase of 26 per cent over their returns of $709,651,780 for the first three months of last year, according to the present survey of official earnings statements.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 5 -- Although concerned about the "cold war," the 1,100 seniors who will receive their degrees from Harvard University next Thursday do not have to worry about jobs -- almost all of those who want to work can find employment immediately after graduation.
Government leaders were charged with fascism and American foreign policy as applied to Greece was castigated yesterday by a dozen speakers at the National Conference on American Policy in Greece.
NEW YORK CITY'S Golden Anniversary celebration this summer will provide three superlative shows of varied interest and genuine significance to visitors.
The three big dates on the political calendar for 1948 are:

In view of the many statements made about the Mundt-Nixon bill by those who have never actually read it, I thought you might like a letter from one who has studied it carefully because of a deep interest in civil liberties.

THERE probably is not a more tantalizing or elusive championship in the entire realm of sports than the National Open, the most cherished golf prize of them all. The form charts will hold up reasonably well in every branch of athletics you can name, even in something as completely unpredictable and illogical as hoss racing. But the divot-digging pastime is a horrible exception.

With most of the allocations of steel and iron for essential domestic programs, export and national defense requirements defined and found to be reasonable, the steel industry is now confident that it can fulfill these oblibations without the assistance of Government controls.

THIS book would not have pleased Thomas Jefferson, Alexander H. Stephens, or Jefferson Davis, for it really pictures the end of their conception of the United States as a loose federation of sovereign states and the rise, in its place, of a unified nation.

Navy and Air Corps contracts now in the formative stage, coupled with additional contract loads to be placed in metal-working plants here, after further national defense appropriations have been passed, will go far toward taking up all the slack in New York's metal-working industries.

Encouraged by the United States, British and French occupation authorities and "allowed to exist" by Soviet officials, the Waldorf schools in Germany are once again proving a leading force in European education. After being curtailed for more than a decade by the Nazis, the movement now has seventeen schools with more than 7,000 students in the four occupation zones, as well as twenty-two other schools in Europe and the United States.

THOUSAND ISLANDS -- The biggest business this summer in more than a decade is the optimistic prediction for the Thousand Islands area which extends for forty miles along the majestic St. Lawrence River from Cape Vincent, at the junction of Lake Ontario, to Alexandria Bay.
SHED a tear for the 1948 motorist. He has so many aids to "facilitate" his touring that if he's not careful, he'll never see the country at all.

DELAWARE, Ohio, June 5 (AP) -- In the greatest record-breaking spree the event has ever witnessed, Baldwin Wallace won the Ohio college track and field championship today for the fourth straight time, nosing out Miami's threatening Redskins, 62 1/5 to 58 3/10.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 5 (AP) -- New titlists were crowned today in the thirtieth annual New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association's outdoor track and field championships in Rutgers Stadium.

HOLLYWOOD. THERE has never been an equal to Bing Crosby in the history of show business. His recordings, including Hawaiian chants, barber-shop ballads, hymns, Irish lullabies and Western songs, are snapped up at the phenomenal rate of 10,000,000 copies a year.

EACH season has its particular pleasures, gastronomically speaking. Warm weather overloads the produce stands with berries and peaches, plums and watermelons and cantaloupes. It brings the venders to the sidewalks and parks, too, with their frozen beguilements for hot day.

MOBILE, Ala., June 5 -- When Alabama failed this week to elect its Governor as a delegate to the Democratic National Convention at Philadelphia, it did so for the first time in the state's history, it was believed. The defeated Governor is Big Jim Folsom who, in a runoff primary June 1, finished last in a field of seven.

THE uproar in Congress over NBC's rather startling broadcasts to Latin America once again has underscored the consequences of the widespread lack of understanding in this country of international short wave broadcasting.
