For at least a quarter of a century experimenters have reported that radioactivity stimulates the growth of both animal and plant tissue. Extensive research supported by the Atomic Energy Commission and carried on under the direction of Dr. William Bloom of the University of Chicago has so far failed to reveal any such effect on tissues of animals of various species.

AUBURN -- This is homecoming year among the Finger Lakes of western New York. From Canandaigua to Skaneateles, more than two dozen cities and villages are planning a series of special events to attract former residents, as well as newcomers, to this district.

SEOUL, Korea, June 5 -- The Korean National Assembly, which began work this week to set up a Korean national government under the auspices of the United Nations, is anticipating a favorable report on it from the United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea.
LOS ANGELES, June 5 -- California has just about written off hope of decisive action by the current Congress on its long feud with Arizona over division of Colorado River water.

IT was on the eve of the 16th of September, that day when all Mexico celebrates its freedom, that Alberto found a forlorn little puppy perched among Senor Poncho's bird cages. Would his father buy it? Would the puppy be sold first?

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The decisive Battle of Midway, in which the Japanese lost four airplane carriers, was cited today by the Navy -- on the eve of the sixth anniversary of the battle -- as vital proof of the value of carriers in both offensive and defensive war at sea.

THIS year for the first time you can spend a two-week vacation almost anywhere in the world by using the vast network of international airlines, reaching the farthest points in not much more than two days.
JERUSALEM, June 5 -- The Haganah today issued orders to military police in Israeli-occupied Arab sections in Jerusalem to shoot looters on sight.

DARIUS MILHAUD planned to wait until he was at least 50 before writing his first symphony; even Brahms did not move with more restraint. However, in the summer of 1939 the French composer, then nearing his forty-seventh birthday, agreed to do a symphony on commission of the Chicago Orchestra for its fiftieth anniversary season.

Timely hitting by Bobby Brown, Yogi Berra and Tommy Henrich and a highly satisfactory route-going mound performance by Charley (Red) Embree, served the Yankees well yesterday at the Stadium. With Embree twirling a seven-hitter, the Yankees routed the Browns, 7--1, between raindrops and before 9,160 fans.

After years of planning and arguing before Government agencies, a project for supplying New York and other cities of the East with natural gas by means of a $150,000,000 pipeline to stretch 1,840 miles from Texas and Louisiana across the continent to the Atlantic seaboard has at last been approved -- at least in principle -- by the Federal Power Commission.

A tentative agreement on a new wage and working agreement for employes of Todd Shipyards Corporation was reached yesterday after three weeks of negotiations, it was announced by Ed Duffy, president of Local 39, International Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America.

THESE four additions to the Broadway bookshelf include a dramatization of a great novel -- a first-rate war play that broke the jinx against that genre last October, with the crash of a block-buster -- another of Mr. Hammerstein's deceptively light-fingered libretti -- and a grievously mistaken "opera" by a successful short-story writer that never even reached the flinty Broadway boards.
This has been a slow season for the surfcaster, but this month will find thousands of these persistent optimists tramping the beaches and flailing the air with long rods from New Jersey to Maine.

PARIS, June 5 -- A threat of intervention by former President de Gaulle in France's foreign policy increased today the confusion of the Schuman Cabinet already split over several hot internal issues and engaged in a bitter conflict over France's stand on the German problem.

William L. Brann's Escadru, last in the Kentucky Derby in his last previous start a month ago, was an off-by-himself first in the ninth edition of the Peter Pan Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. He tood the lead approaching the eighth pole and moved away from the rest in a considerable hurry to win by four fat lengths in the role of 17-to-5 second choice.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Some 2,000 of the claimed 3 to 5 million followers of Dr. Francis E. Townsend have been in Washington this week for their eighth national convention.
Communities in New York State will promote international understanding on a personal level this summer by sending young citizens overseas as "community ambassadors."
FASTER time and new travel comfort between St. Louis and San Antonio became effective recently when the Missouri-Kansas-Texas and Frisco lines placed in service their stream-lined Texas Special.

THE time has come for the prospective summer vacationist to take steps. Now that Decoration Day has come and gone, the June-July-August vacation season is officially here, and the American who wants to travel in comfort should begin to make his plans.

Dr. Tom Spies, Professor of Nutrition and Metabolism in the Northwestern University Medical School, reports in the current issue of The Southern Medical Journal that vitamin B-12, recently isolated, seems to be an effective remedy in treating anemia.

ST. LOUIS, June 5 -- In a sweltering mid-August 99-degree temperature, the Cardinals suddenly caught fire today, overcame a four-run Brooklyn lead with a six-run outburst in the third inning, went on to beat the Dodgers, 9--6, and even the series at two games each.

PORTLAND, Me. -- Maine's resort industry is prepared to welcome a million summer visitors this season. These tourists will find that their dollar will buy approximately the same mount of food, accommodations and pleasure this year as in 1947.

WHEN four of the country's most famous players meet in a bridge game for a high stake (though it is not considered politic to mention such matters) they ought to produce at least one bridge hand worth reporting.

BOSTON, June 5 -- "Proper Bostonians" are determined to go to the United States Supreme Court, if necessary, to prevent construction of a privately owned garage beneath the "sacred sod" of Boston Common.

THE great American hegira of 1948 is under way and travel agencies, estimating their air and ship contingents for the long rush season, are confident that a new post-war record will be chronicled for 1948.

The semi-centennial of the discovery of radium will be observed by the American Radium Society at its thirtieth annual meeting June 20-22 in Chicago. American physicians who specialize in the treatment of cancer will have their first post-war opportunity to discuss progress with their fellows from foreign countries.
MUKDEN, Manchuria, June 5 -- Refugees arriving from Communist-held territory report that the Communists are hesitating to attack Mukden because of the tremendous losses that would be involved.
Column, a new national magazine, has produced its first issue, with the Westchester-Long Island community one of six key areas selected for the initial distribution.

PARIS -- This is the year of the American tourist in Europe. Lack of transport, shortage of hotel accommodations, and international jitters have served only to stimulate the greatest throng of tourists since 1938.

DEATH VALLEY, Calif. -- This 130-mile-long expanse of arid wasteland which was such a nightmare to the inexperienced and ill-equipped covered-wagon pioneers of a century ago now attracts around 160,000 tourists a year.

Financial markets continued last week to show an irregular trend for the third consecutive week, with selective issues moving higher as a result of special situations. The after-effect of the General Motors wage settlement was reflected in a stiffening attitude on the part of other employers of labor.

CINCINNATI, June 5 -- The Giants did some tall and fancy shooting for the fences at Crosley Field today. Two of their shots by Bill Rigney and Whitey Lockman cleared the barriers for homers. Two bounced off the walls for doubles.

CHICAGO, June 5 (AP) -- Although price changes in grains on the Board of Trade were not large today, the market showed an easier undertone. This was particularly true in wheat as the May contract got down around $2.28 a bushel at times.
After three weeks of war in Palestine, truce talks are under way.

THE author of the recently published novel "The Song of the Flea" (Doubleday) -- and, before that, "Faces in a Dusty Picture," "Night and the City," etc. -- is a strongly knit, trim Englishman with a D.H. Lawrence beard.

To help raise $3,000,000 for a Student War Memorial Building and other necessary extra-curricular facilities, City College will stage a "Jubilee Night" entertainment and spectacle on Thursday in Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- The State Department is getting ready to revise and tighten its whole system of farming out overseas programs to commercial networks. Officials said today that new "Voice of America" contracts with the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System would provide these things:

CHICAGO, June 5 (AP) -- A 23-day-old strike of 110 unionized CIO seamen, which tied up five tankers of the Standard Oil Company (Ind.) was settled today with a two-year agreement granting a 5 per cent wage increase.

CHAUTAUQUA -- This world-famous center of popular culture will celebrate its diamond jubilee this summer. Since 1874, when the Chautauqua Institution was founded as a nonprofit educational organization, it has sponsored summer courses of study in literature, music, religion, art and other fields, in addition to offering a variety of recreational activities.

The Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds asked Secretary of State George C. Marshall yesterday to urge Congress to appropriate $50,000,000 to enable the International Refugee Organization to speed up the program calling for the mass settlement of 100,000 displaced persons in the new State of Israel.

PRAGUE, June 5 -- Clement Gottwald's single electoral list and the semi, or in most cases wholly, public vote for an appointed parliament that would take office anyway aroused the "good soldier Schweik" condition in the Czechs. The town of Prague is full of stories about people who one way or another "fooled the Government."

All factors point to outstanding success for the fall season for dress lines, it was predicted last week. Orders already placed, according to some of the leading manufacturers of higher priced merchandise, exceed those of last year by a minimum of 10 per cent.

The new 1949 Ford will be unveiled next Thursday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at 11 A.M. in the Ford Motor Company's first post-war showing. This year's display of new models, Ford officials promise, will be the biggest and most spectacular company automobile show ever staged in this country.

THOUGH you may call it a romance, Maurice Walsh is actually singing a love song to the gracious homes of Ireland and the horse-breeding, whisky-drinking folk who dwell in them and manage to keep them intact by dint of perseverance, rugged labor and miracles.

A DWARF iris is defined by the American Iris Society as any kind less than sixteen inches tall. This blunt description, complains an ardent "dwarfite," was "obviously made by a devotee of tall bearded iris, with an utter lack of appreciation of the intrinsic values and possibilities of the other groups."

A sixteen-car Presidential special left Washington last Thursday night, carrying Mr. Truman, a few friends, an executive staff and a half a hundred correspondents. The President was off on a 10,000-mile, eighteen-day swing around the country. The trip was called a non-political inspection tour.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, June 5 -- American soldiers in relatively small numbers have been moving into Alaska for the past few weeks. Some of them are replacements for United States troops who have already served a hitch in the United States' northernmost outpost, but most of them represent additional strength.

LOUIS PASTEUR was the respectful, obedient, plodding son of a tanner. His boyhood gave little promise of a great scientific career. He made a miserable showing when he first took examinations to enter the Ecole Normale.

However depressing the international scene may appear to some this June Sunday of 1948, it requires no lengthy delving into the past to recall other Junes when matters were infinitely worse. We need not go back very far.

MADISON, Wis. -- Wisconsin's vacation season will be highlighted by the state's centennial celebration, which got off to a good start here on May 29, Statehood Day, and will reach its climax at the State Fair to be held near Milwaukee from Aug. 7 to 29.

IN his long pursuit for those elusive objectives he has labeled peace and security, man has found them often on board a ship, away from the ghastly reminders of land. This is especially likely to be true if the creature in him can adjust itself fairly quickly to the blessed routine of eating, sleeping and idling.

LONDON -- Compelled at last to accept the changed values of a world in which she earned more foreign currency last year from the tourist trade than from her cotton textile industry, once the country's biggest earner, Britain is for the first time this season extending privileges to foreign visitors denied to her own people.

IN a specially constructed studio in Billancourt, on the outskirts of Paris, Lou Bunin's "Alice au Pays des Merveilles," more familiarly known as "Alice in Wonderland," is nearing completion. The much-discussed color film project, which will combine puppet animation with live action sequences, has been in preparation since last June, although actual shooting didn't start until after the first of this year.

THE first of these two books seeks to explain how modern trade unions function and why they act the way they do. The second seeks to convince industry that productive efficiency can be doubled if the creative contributions of workers are tapped through Joint Production Committees composed equally of representatives of each plant's employes and management.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- A $33,638,370 authorization of new food and commodity shipments was announced today by the Economic Cooperation Administration. It thus maintained its steady flow of recovery goods to Europe despite a cut in foreign aid funds voted by the House.

A meeting to urge the State Legislature to enact a bill allowing teachers who are veterans of either World War to retire after twenty-five years' service was held yesterday at the office of the New York Teachers Guild, AFL, 2 East Twenty-third Street.

The 116th commencement season of New York University will open today at 4 P.M. with baccalaureate exercises in the chapel of the Gould Memorial Library on the University Heights campus, University Avenue and 181st Street.

BARDSTOWN, Ky. -- St. Joseph's Proto-Cathedral, with its collection of paintings, which includes works by Van Eyck, Rubens, Van Dyck and Murillo, is once more open to the public after major renovations. Off the regular tourist paths, the cathedral's remarkable collection of old masters is relatively unknown, although it has been here well over a century.

HARTFORD, Conn. -- Half a million visitors were entertained in the State of Connecticut last year and the coming summer season will be busy enough, tourist officials predict, to make the 1948 total as large, if not larger.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 5 (AP) -- Two swift Jamaica-born foot racers stole the show today with record performances in the annual Pacific Association Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships.

The first evidence that the labor shortage with which Soviet Ministries have been grappling is now over, not in the Russian economy, but in basic industries of it, came yesterday in information from Soviet sources that arrived here.

A 20-year-old youth jumped to his death last night from the roof of a building owned by a chiropractor after having refused to be treated there earlier in the day. Before he plunged he threatened his father with a 10-inch kitchen knife and smashed antiques and art objects belonging to the chiropractor that were valued by the police at $1,000.

TORONTO -- Ontario travel officials, scanning mounting numbers of advance inquiries for resort information, foresee new records for this summer. More American visitors than ever are expected in Ontario and record numbers of Canadians are planning to see more of Ontario than in former years, owing to the Canadian Government's monetary regulations.

FROM time to time in history, notably in Polynesia and Australia, it has been the fate of a primitive people to be brought suddenly and violently in contact with a materially more advanced civilization than their own and so to be forced to telescope the scientific progress of centuries into a few months or years.

ALBANY, June 5 -- After two years of survey and study, the State Joint Hospital Survey and Planning Commission recommended today a long-range coordinated hospital plan to cost about $750,000,000 and provide 54,000 additional hospital beds. Federal, state and local funds would be used and existing hospital facilities expanded.

HARRISBURG -- Western Pennsylvania resort areas have spent about $1,000,000 to provide new vacation features for this summer's visitors. A land of contrasts, the western section of the great Keystone State, accessible from the east by the famed Pennsylvania Turnpike and the modern Lincoln and William Penn Highways, is dotted with historic shrines, recreational areas and magnificent scenic sites.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col. -- Tourists planning a trip to the Rockies have a big chunk of the United States to move around in -- all along the Continental Divide for 1,110 miles from the top of Montana to the bottom of New Mexico.

THE New Dance Group "Festival Series" at the Mansfield was something of an ordeal. Not that its quality was low; quite to the contrary, it provided an embarrassment of riches. For six performances in five days, eight young choreographers in various combinations plied the spectators with works jammed with substance, brimming with design. overflowing with creative energy.

PARIS, June 5 -- On the anniversary of the speech by Secretary of State Marshall from which grew the European Recovery Program, western European nations finished today their report of estimates for imports, made possible through United States aid, for the third quarter of the year.

BOSTON -- Vacationists headed for Massachusetts in 1948 will find preparations long since made for the most attractive season since before the war. In addition to improvements to existing summer housing facilities throughout the Commonwealth, stockpiles of gasoline are reported ready for an 8 per cent increase in consumption, while railroads and airlines have added equipment to take care of transportation needs.
Thomas and Catherine Storie, who have walked 12,000 miles of city streets in the United States since they married twenty years ago, set out yesterday for walks in Utica and Albany on their vacations.
MIAMI, Fla. -- Florida's lower East Coast, long known as America's winter playground, expects this year to become a leading summer vacationland.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, called upon Governor Dewey yesterday, as titular head of the Republican party and candidate for its Presidential nomination, to repudiate the action of the Republican leadership of the House of Representatives Friday in slashing about $2,000,000,000 from the Truman Administration's foreign aid program.

It is only too evident that a truce in Palestine does not of itself solve the basic problem in the Near East. What it can do is for a period of weeks to stop the fighting, give a reprieve to those who would die in that fighting, and permit world public opinion, operating through the United Nations, to have its effect.

IN last Sunday's TIMES there was an admirable article by Olin Downes about the National Music League which "looks back upon a successful and fruitful decade of service." This phrase gives the impression that the National Music League is ten years old.

ROME, May 30 -- Russian propaganda movies have "laid an egg" in Italy. Shown widely before the elections, in the Communist workers' clubs found in every town, they are now a dead letter for the simple reason that they bored the Italian worker to death.
THE average angler is not an easy individual to please, but the prospects for both fresh and salt water fishing this season are sufficiently bright to banish the gloom of even the chronic pessimist.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., June 5 -- A third par-breaking card today kept Jimmy Demaret out front by a single stroke through three

YEARS ago there was a phrase in frequent use to designate the kind of reading supposedly fitting for the summer season. "Hammock fiction," I think it was, and it is now heard as rarely as hammocks are seen. Why the notion ever became prevalent that only the lightest of literary fluff was suitable for consumption during the summer time is one of the minor mysteries of life.
Two Bronx sisters were arrested early yesterday morning in their home and charged with planning an unsuccessful subway payroll hold-up Friday that resulted in the apprehension of three other girls.

Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., has completed its first fully coordinated executive training program which may be formally or informally applied to all its field operating branches throughout the world, G.A. Busch, assistant industrial relations manager, disclosed last week.

THIS country today leads the world in rose production and development of new varieties. Each season sees newcomers clamoring for admission to our gardens, bearing such unusual names and heralded with such fulsome description that we sometimes wonder whether we are considering a rose or a museum masterpiece.
MEXICO CITY, June 5 -- A large group of students effaced the words "God does not exist" from Diego Rivera's mural in the newly opened Hotel Prado last night.

Fall apparel orders increased substantially last week as buyers dropped their "wait and see" attitude toward fall purchasing, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

TAORMINA, Sicily -- In the heart of troubled Europe, this fabled resort town under Mount Etna is as serene as the sun on the Ionian Sea. Here life moves at the pace of the little donkeys who pull the gaily painted Sicilian carts.

CHICAGO -- Residents of Atlantic seaboard states are showing a steadily growing interest in the vacation possibilities of the Midwest, to their own delight as well as that of this region's resort operators.

UNION, N.J., June 5 -- C.F. Buckie of the home club teamed with J.A. Wiley Jr. of Forest Hill to set the pace with a 6 under par 65 in the annual member-guest invitation tournament of the Suburban Golf Club.

The Carnegie Hall Pop Concerts, founded and directed by Daniel Rybb and now managed by Ernest Anderson, ended their season last night before a full house. The final concert, devoted to the music of Irving Berlin, was conducted by Jack Shaindlin.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 5 -- Delegates to the annual sessions of the Newark Conference of the New York Area of the Methodist Church adopted this morning at the First Methodist Church here a resolution introduced by its public affairs committee opposing charity gambling. Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam presided.

STANTON, Del., June 5 (AP) -Crispin Oglebay's Noble Impulse found the winner's circle in a stakes event for the first time when the home-bred son of Bull Dog captured the eleventh running of the Christiana Stakes at Delaware Park today.

HAIL to the social director -- that ubiquitous follow who puts on the shows, arranges wiener roasts, dances with wallflowers, finds a cribbage partner for Aunt Mayme, and wages frantic war on a hundred other fronts against boredom among the clientele of summer hotels and camps.

MILAN, Italy, June 5 -- The fate of Eduard Benes, diminutive pre-war, wartime and post-war President of Czechoslovakia, is obviously sealed. Politically this week's rigged elections accomplished the end.

IF "The Shrouded Woman" were a few inches thicker, a fine film of tropic passion in Chile might be made of it. But Maria-Luisa Bombal is experimenting with style. Her characters, a multitude of women of seduction and men of violence, are defined only by a few vaporous words. Like an overstuffed sofa, her novel both implies and conceals a wealth of unsavory matter.

PITTSBURGH, June 5 (AP) -- Frankie Gustine's home run with Johnny Hopp on base in the last of the ninth gave the Pirates an 8-7 victory over the Braves today. Vernon Bickford, relief hurler, yielded the winning blow.

KENILWORTH, N.J., June 5 -- Joe Birofka of Galloping Hill, the medalist, reached the final of the Metropolitan Public Links championship over his home course today when he turned back George Baskiel of the Queens Golf Club, 1 up.

William Talbert of New York, fifth in the national ranking and Ladislav Hecht of Kew Gardens, Eastern clay court champion, will meet at 1:45 today in the final round of the invitation tournament of the Jackson Heights Tennis Club, Queens.

IT is a good thing at any time to pay attention to the past. A clarification of historical perspective is particularly helpful in an election year, but when that year comes during a period of world crisis, as the present one does, it becomes almost urgent to reconsider and re-evaluate one's national background in the light of immediate circumstances and their possible impact on the nation's future.
ON the outskirts of Caen, a Normandy city almost totally destroyed in the invasion, an old French woman swept a gnarled hand toward the acres of yawning space dotted with ruined buildings.

NEW DELHI, India, June 5 -- Prime Minister Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, in a letter to the president of the United Nations Security Council, stated today that the Indian Government would not assist in the implementation of the Council's resolution on the Kashmir dispute "until the objections raised by the Government of India have been satisfactorily met."

After twenty years of effort the two-hundred-inch reflecting telescope has been dedicated beneath the dome of Palomar Observatory in California. A new adventure into the unknown is about to begin -- new because with each improvement in telescopes it has been necessary to abandon old theories.

PEARL HARBOR, June 5 -- The island of Tinian in the Marshall Islands, wartime base for B-29 atomic bombing missions against Hiroshima and Nagasaki, has been selected by the Navy as the site of a proposed leper colony for Pacific Island natives, Admiral DeWitt C. Ramsey, commander-in-chief of the Pacific Fleet, announced here yesterday upon his return from West Coast First Task Fleet exercises.

LEWISBURG, Pa., June 5 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr., former Secretary of State, in an address read for him at the commencement exercises of Bucknell University today, called for recognition of the possibilities for exploitation of the natural resources of Liberia.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 5 (AP) -- A limit of 50 cents on the dollar on peacetime Federal income taxes was advocated by Harold E. Stassen today as part of the "dynamic capitalistic system" he favors.

FROM Tel Aviv comes word that the Israel definitive stamps described in this column last week were preceded by overprinted provisionals which were in postal use from May 10 until the State of Israel came into existence on May 15.

WE went up to the Metropolitan one day last week to take another look at the German pictures and had a heart-to-heart talk with Capt. Thomas Hughes, head of the museum's guards, a somewhat bald, medium-sized man with merry blue eyes.

MR. McILWAINE struck it rich for both his regionalistic thesis (that the way to understand America is region by region) and his story-telling ability when he dug into the past and present of Memphis, Tennessee.

The Women's Eastern Golf Association championship, open to women who are members of clubs belonging to the association, will get under way over the North Hills County Club Course, Douglaston, L.I., on Tuesday morning and continue until Thursday.

SEATTLE, Wash. -- The first public train tour of the region by a President of the United States in more than a decade will open this week the 1948 summer travel season in the Pacific Northwest. Not since the late Franklin D. Roosevelt dedicated Booneville Dam in 1937 has a President visited the broad Columbia River Valley.

BEAR MOUNTAIN -- A new lake and a virtually new Seven Lakes Drive -- its kinks and bends straightened out and a new surface laid from end to end -- await the summer visitors to Bear Mountain-Harriman State Parks.
It isn't often these days that hammer throwers capture the spotlight at a track and field meet but that's what happened yesterday at the annual spring games of the New York Athletic Club.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 5 (AP) -- Flying Rythm, an outsider, came from far behind on the outside and upset twelve rival 3-year-old fillies to win the $25,000-added Hollywood Oaks at Hollywood Park today.

LONDON, June 5 -- The South African election in which Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts and his Government were overthrown was a staggering blow to the British Commonwealth and Empire. To be sure, organizations, like men. can recover from hard blows, and it would be extremely short-sighted and pessimistic to start preparing an obituary.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Devastating floods in the Columbia River basin of the Pacific Northwest spurred Congressional action this week on flood control.

Dog show activity returns to the metropolitan area next week-end after being focused in the Boston vicinity this week-end. The opening skirmishes will take place in the sixteenth specialty of the Labrador Retriever Club at the Rockaway Hunting Club, Cedarhurst, L. I., on Friday.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 5 -- Two of Long Island's younger stars, George Stuhr Jr., Notre Dame captain-elect, and Charles Lane gained the semi-final round of the Hempstead Golf Club's member-guest best-ball tournament today when they defeated the Metropolitan junior champion, Billy Edwards, and his dad, Clarence Edwards, 1 up.
CHICAGO, June 5 (AP) -- The Phillies swept a double-header with the Cubs today, 4 to 2 and 6 to 5, to take the final four tilts of their five-game series.

DETROIT, June 5 (AP) -- Negotiators for the Briggs Manufacturing Company, automobile body producer, and the United Auto Workers, CIO, have agreed on a 13-cent hourly pay rise for 23,000 Briggs employes, a company spokesman said today.

THE erstwhile small trickle of audience participation shows and their accompanying "give-away" prizes has grown to flood proportions on the airwaves. The rush of sponsors to get on the bandwagon for the low production cost but high- Hooper-rating format, has pyramided the total of weekly prizes on network shows to a dollar value estimated by Variety, weekly entertainment trade paper, at about $84,000.

BERLIN, June 5 -- Germans participating in the organization of the Western German state envisaged by the London conference were directly threatened today as the Russian-inspired campaign against the Western Allies' program increased in volume and intensity.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Carroll Reece, chairman of the Republican National Committee, objected today to the payment, out of what he called "public funds," of the expenses for President Truman's Western trip. He said the President had already showed it was obviously "a pre-nomination campaign tour."

NEWARK, N.J., June 5 -- The Independent Progressive party, supporting Henry A. Wallace's Third party candidacy for President, was founded today at a convention in the Armory at which Senator Glen H. Taylor of Idaho Mr. Wallace's running mate, charged Republican and Democratic parties "with joining in a conspiracy to deprive American people of their civil rights in order to stop the forces for peace."

CAT CAY, Bahamas, June 5 (AP) -- George A. Lyon Jr., 29-year-old Detroit sportsman, held a slim lead today in the fifth annual Cat Cay international tuna tournament with six boated bluefins totaling 2,318 pounds.
CAIRO, June 5 (AP) -- There were conflicting accounts concerning the battle for Jenin, northern end of the Arab triangle menacing Tel Aviv and the Israeli coastal strip.

AMONG the visitors to Europe this summer will be thousands of veterans -- completely out of uniform -- disguised as students, business men and just plain trippers. Circumstance and desire finally have merged after three years, and now the goal of dreams and savings is in sight.

In contrast with dealings before the war, trading in "puts," "calls," "spreads" and "straddles" on securities is now being conducted more on a long-term rather than a short-term basis in the stock option market. Options running up to thirty days, which accounted for 70 to 99 per cent of the business prior to 1939, but which now average between 7 and 15 per cent, have been superseded by sixty-day, ninety-day and six-month contracts.

WHEN the Marlins decided to drive from New York City to San Francisco in their ancient automobile, they knew they were taking a risk. But Tressy, Pete and Mrs. Marlin felt sure that Mr. Marlin, an expert steam-shovel operator, could take them through safely.

A new page was inserted here last week in the hidebound rule book of financial advertising. Newspapers accepted an advertisement announcing a highly speculative offering of stock issued to finance production of a new small automobile on the condition that the advertisement make "full disclosure" of all the uncertainties and other questionable considerations surrounding the enterprise.

EDWARD JOHNSON, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, sailed for Europe last week-end on the Queen Elizabeth. He went quietly because the trip is a vacation, but it is not unlikely he will hear some singers on his travels.

MADRID, June 6 -- Spain's studied efforts to defeat in Latin America the United Nations resolutions of 1946 urging the recall of diplomatic mission chiefs from Madrid seems headed for success this year.

LONDON, June 6 (Reuters) -The trouble in Pocspetri arose, according to a Budapest radio account today, after the parish priest had threatened to excommunicate teachers voting for nationalization of the church schools.
MILWAUKEE, June 6 (AP) -- Rex Mays smashed into a brick wall today to avoid hitting Duke Dinsmore, tossed into his path in a 100-mile auto race. Mays was not injured.

Using the last-in-first-out (Lifo) method of inventory valuation for the first time since 1941, R. H. Macy Co. last week announced its 1947 earnings. The previous week Gimbel Brothers made public its earnings for 1947, also using the Lifo method for the first time since 1941.

If preliminary reports from the great grain-producing countries prove correct it may be feasible in the year ahead to end or substantially reduce bread rationing in Western Europe. Both official and private estimates agree that prospects of a grain surplus have not been so promising since 1939.

The voices of 500 choristers and of a congregation of 4,000, rising above the music of the great organ, soared through the reaches of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday afternoon in hymns of thanksgiving, as the city opened its golden anniversary celebration on a spiritual note.

The combined efforts of fifty-five member organizations representing more than 35,000 salesmen will be mustered in Washington this week in opposition to enactment of the "extended" Social Security bill (House Resolution 6777) which was approved last week by the House Ways and Means Committee, and to urge Presidential veto of the Gearhart bill (House Resolution 296) which was passed by Congress last Friday.

Our neighbor The Herald Tribune is now making its seventy-second annual appeal for the Fresh Air Fund, which sends needy children away from the hot sidewalks of New York for a vacation at camp or in pleasant towns at a distance. We take pleasure in inviting our readers' attention to this excellent cause, and their support of it.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 6 -Americans must not lose sight of their spiritual unity at a time "when we must meet an aggressive Soviet ideology on the one hand and face the possibility of a recrudescence of fascism on the other," Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, warned today.

A former city policeman was shot to death and a Department of Correction officer was wounded critically yesterday by a prisoner they were taking to the Gates Avenue station in Brooklyn for interfering in an arrest, the police reported.

TOKYO, June 6 -- The Japanese Government finally has moved to place a firmer financial foundation under the autonomous provincial governments established last year at the instigation of the occupation authorities as a step in the democratization of Japan.
CINCINNATI, June 6 -- Today's scheduled double header was converted into a single five-inning game by a cloudburst which inundated Crosley Field and made further play impossible.

SINGAPORE, June 6 (AP) -- Malcolm MacDonald, Britain's Commissioner for southeast Asia, said tonight that leaders of international communism had decided on a political offensive in Asia if they were checked in Europe.

Unbeaten since he lost to Washington on April 21 -- his first start -- Vic Raschi notched his seventh straight victory yesterday. The big righthander pitched his second successive shutout, a 3-hit, 3-0 triumph over the Browns, in the nightcap of a double-header before 56,101 fans at the Stadium.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, June 6 -- Post-war Germany's most powerful collective voice -- the Minister-Presidents of the three Western zones and representatives of the Berlin city administration, trade union leaders and the German coal administration -- concluded an extraordinary two-day conference here today with a demand for a return of the Ruhr mines to German hands.

The city was accused yesterday of wasting $3,515,000 to elevate a seven-block stretch of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive when "all that is needed to cope with the changing traffic pattern is to readjust a single signal light."

Rehabilitation of the Manila Electric Company, whose power-generating equipment was almost leveled by the Japanese, already has progressed to a point where, with fewer customers, kilowatt-hour consumption is showing an increase.

"There is a little Mussolini in us all," the Rev. John B. Sheerin of the Church of St. Paul the Apostle declared in his sermon yesterday at th Baccalaureate Mass that opened the 103d Fordham University Commencement week.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee is weighing the Mundt-Nixon bill with "a fair and open mind," Senator Alexander Wiley, committee chairman, declared today as he taxed American Communists with using "insolence * * * shady tricks * * * Hitlerian propagandistic devices * * * and wholesale name-calling" in opposing the legislation.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 6 -Plans for a week of alumni reunions and graduation activities that will culminate in Princeton University's 201st annual commencement exercises on June 15 were announced today by President Harold W. Dodds.

SUMMIT, N. J., June 6 -- Competition was keen today on the second and closing day of the Watchung Riding and Driving Club show on the grounds of the Union County Park concourse. The attendance was better than yesterday and it was announced that part of the proceeds would go to the Summit Home for Children.

PARIS, June 6 -- The fourth anniversary of the historic Allied landings on the Norman coast was celebrated here today in speeches by statesmen and diplomats, who expressed the hope that men would never again face the deadly task they faced that day.

PITTSBURGH, June 6 -- Despite the heavy demand for steel and the chance that the industry may face another stoppage of coal mining, talk in the trade last week centered around the controversy over the basing-point system of fixing prices for steel.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 6 -- While half the Egyptian force in Palestine is trying to fight its way out of a trap in the south, the Syrians applied pressure today in a pincer movement in the far north, striking from Syria and Lebanon.

KENILWORTH, N. J., June 6 -- Ray Sullivan of Hillside, N. J. won the Metropolitan Public Links championship today over the Galloping Hill links of the Union County Park Commission. Sullivan, a Galloping Hill regular, defeated his clubmate, Joe Birofka, 2 and 1, in the 36-hole final.
ST. LO, France, June 6 (UP) -This "Capital of Ruins" dedicated itself to the job of reconstruction today on the fourth anniversary of D-Day.

Worry, induced by self-centeredness, was described yesterday by the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street, as one of the "major scourges" of present-day civilization.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 6 -- Linda Darnell will play the title role in the screen version of Kenneth Roberts' 1947 novel, "Lydia Bailey," which will be filmed next winter, Twentieth Century-Fox has announced. The studio acquired film rights to the story, under a ten-year lease, for $215,000 before its publication, and subsequently put the property on the shelf because of the expected cost of filming.

BERLIN, June 6 -- The teaching of history will be resumed in this city's schools next fall as the result of a four-power agreement, John Thompson, chief of the education and cultural affairs branch in the United States sector of Berlin, disclosed today.

In the northland where roads and streams wind through the mountain valleys, where elms brood above meadow brooks and terraced pastures slant steeply above the mowings, one can lift his eyes to the mountain slopes above the pasture and see white lace on the heights.

ATHENS, June 6 -- The public prosecutor began today an interrogation of Constantine Hadjiargyris, Athens newspaper man and stepson of Premier Themistocles Sophoulis, in the case of the killing of George Polk, correspondent in Greece for the Columbia Broadcasting System.

LONDON, June 6 (UP) -- The Soviet Communist party newspaper Pravda charged today that the six-power conference had completed the splitting up of Germany, but declared the accord would never be recognized as lawful by either the Russians or Germans.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- To the State of Israel, to its officers and to its citizens were sent today "the heartfelt salutation of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, and its prayer that God may send it and them peace and tranquillity."

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., June 6 -- Tony and Cleo, the panhandling deer, celebrated their first birthday today and, since no one held a party for them, they took care of matters themselves by mooching from picnic tables.

Rabbi Bernard L. Levinthal, 82-year-old dean of the Orthodox rabbinate of Philadelphia, and his son, Rabbi Israel H. Levinthal, religious leader of the Brooklyn Jewish Center, received honorary doctorates yesterday at commencement exercises of the Jewish Institute of Religion, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street.

"The price is too high for the bankers to pay." "This is the end of an illusion." "The nations of Europe are learning that they cannot trust America." These are some of the headlines in the Communist press of Europe on the news of the cut in the appropriation for the European Recovery Program.

Economic Cooperation Administration developments last week influenced liquidation of cotton and brought about a softening of prices in the domestic market. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were off 10 to 52 points, the most pronounced recession in recent months.
HARRISBURG, Pa., June 6 (AP) -- A short circuit charged a public swimming pool with electricity today, killing one swimmer and injuring several others.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Senator Arthur Capper, Republican, of Kansas, who has served in the United States Senate since March 4, 1919, announced today that he would not be a candidate for re-election this fall.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Eighty prominent persons joined today in sending a telegram to Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr., requesting action on Federal aid to education.

THE most perplexing figure that the baseball season yet has produced is Richard Cummings Wakefield of the Detroit Tigers. When the big and good-natured Wakefield emerged from the Navy for post-war play, everyone was talking of him as a sure-shot challenger to Messrs. Ted Williams and Joe DiMaggio for the batting championship.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Starting tomorrow, Republican leaders will go to the whip for the driving finish they hope will bring Congress to adjournment June 19 -- two working weeks hence.

LONDON, June 6 -- Slowly but surely the stock markets here are running into less favorable weather. There is no sign of a bad break, and none is expected, but up and down the country investors are showing increasing reluctance to enter into new commitments.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6 (AP) -The front-running Cleveland Indians tagged the skidding Philadelphia Athletics with a pair of defeats today, 5 -- 3 and 11 -- 1, to open up a two-and-a-half game lead in the American League flag chase.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., June 6 (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret clipped five strokes off par for a 67 in the fourth round and a 72-hole score of 268 to win first money of $2,000 in the Albuquerque open golf tournament today.

During the months that I have been serving in Greece as director of the United States Information Service, I have had ample opportunity to observe at close range the work of the American voluntary agencies. Watching them at work I have often asked myself why they occupy such a unique place in the affection and confidence of the Greek people.

Marked strength in the Canadian free dollar which sold up to 93.82 cents, highest since March 25, 1947, was the one single incident of interest to emerge out of the trading in the foreign exchange market last week.

Shipping legislation vitally affecting the future of the merchant marine will go before Congress this week if shipping leaders and others interested in expanding the nation' maritime activity are successful in their efforts.

JERUSALEM, July 6 -- As artillery barrages against Jerusalem entered their fourth week today at least six civilians, including two women, were killed and a large but unspecified number, among them children, injured when mortar shells burst around the junction

American paper exporters are facing a steadily shrinking market and can hope for little direct or indirect benefits from the European Recovery Program, it was stated over the week-end by Harry Bengtsson, president of Benex Corporation, who heads the United States Paper Exporters Council, Inc.
Nine new films, including importations from England, France and Germany, comprise the list of arrivals due in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UP) -Attorney General Tom C. Clark said today that President Truman was within his legal rights when he seized the railroads last month to prevent a strike. He released the wording of a petition which he will file tomorrow with the Federal District Court asking it to overrule two rail Brotherhoods and a union which seek dismissal of the Federal Government's suit for an anti-strike injunction.

LONDON, June 6 -- The anniversary of D-Day was commemorated at Portsmouth today with the unveiling by Field Marshall Viscount Montgomery, chief of the British Imperial General Staff, of a memorial near the spot whence four years ago many Allied units had set out four years ago on the cross-channel endeavor. United States and French service men took part with British soldiers.

The two-day National Conference on American Policy in Greece at the Capitol Hotel closed last evening with the unanimous adoption of a series of resolutions and a program of action designed chiefly to effect abandonment by the United States of the Truman Doctrine.
CHICAGO, June 6 -- Americans of Swedish origin or descent were asked today by the primate of the state church of Sweden to honor the land of their ancestry by being great Americans.

ST. LOUIS, June 6 (AP) -- Red Schoendienst led the way with five doubles and a home run in the two games as the Cardinals swept a twin bill from the Phillies today, 11 -- 1 and 2 -- 0. The double victory put the Red Birds back on top of the National League as the Giants and the Pirates split their double-header.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 6 -- Capital decisions to effect the next stages in the socialization of Yugoslavia will be taken at the fifth congress of the Communist party of Yugoslavia that will open July 21 in Belgrade.

The 1948 measles epidemic, which has afflicted 24,319 children in New York this year and caused eighteen deaths, is running out, the Health Department reported yesterday. It added that the peak was passed a few weeks ago.

Governor Dewey, in a message to the Manhattan Region of the Zionist Organization of America, declared yesterday that the United States "must exercise its leadership in the United Nations to bring a just and lasting peace to Palestine and to assure the continuance of the free State of Israel."

The reporters who cover Police Headquarters demonstrated yesterday that one newspaper man is better than four "cops" -- when it comes to pitching a ball game at Schmidt's Farm, Scarsdale, any Sunday that falls on June 6 in a leap year.

TORONTO, June 6 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Seamen's Union claimed tonight that sixteen ships were either tied up or lost some crew members as a result of a strike the CSU called Saturday against four Great Lakes steamship companies.

Despite the curtailment of operating expenses since May 24, "Sally" was abruptly withdrawn from the Martin Beck after Saturday night's showing. Produced at an estimated cost of $150,000 by Hunt Stromberg Jr. and William Berney, the musical revival was performed thirty-six times, with a cast headed by Willie Howard, Bambi Linn and Jack Goode.

LONDON, June 6 -- During the past two weeks the Norwegian, Danish and Swedish Ambassadors in London have held informal conversations with officials of the British Foreign Office. No official version of these talks is available and unofficial accounts vary widely, but all versions agree on one point -- that the discussions concerned the military defense of the Scandinavian countries, which lie on the northern flank of the five-power Western Union.
If New Yorkers want to know where yesterday's pleasant balmy weather came from, it blew in from Nebraska. They will have to take the word of Ed Mullen, chief proclaimer for that Midwestern state.

The Weather Man handed a fine, sunny day to New York yesterday and the city's residents, grown weary of the recent spell of rain, fog and general gloom, journeyed by the thousands to parks, playgrounds and beaches.

Henry A. Wallace, in a radio address yesterday over WNBC, predicted victory for his new party in the November election, declaring that "our program is for peace, jobs and security; we will win because our program is concrete." He accused both major parties of preparing for war because they were "bankrupt" in a domestic program.
ABOARD PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S SPECIAL TRAIN ENROUTE WEST, June 6 -- President Truman promised to ride herd on Congress today when he received a pair of cowboy spurs in the heart of Republican Nebraska.

Already assured of the support of nearly a majority of the 1,234 votes to the Democratic National Convention, President Truman is virtually certain to get more than the 618 votes necessary to nominate him from among delegates to be elected this week, according to special dispatches to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Rains in the Northwest in the latter part of last week, together with the passage by the House of a foreign aid bill that made a substantial slash in the funds to be appropriated as compared to the amount that the Administration wanted, reversed the trend of prices in wheat and other grains.

At the annual concert of the Workmen's Circle Chorus last night in Town Hall, a program devoted to compositions by Lazar Weiner, its conductor, was presented in honor of his fiftieth birthday. Masha Benya, soprano; Nathaniel Sprinzena, tenor; Joseph Posner, baritone; Yehudi Wyner, pianist, and Koppel Lifshitz, narrator, were the assisting artists.

Grounds for civic pride, as well as a reasonable explanation for some of our pressing municipal problems, are provided by the estimate that New York City's population has now passed the 8,000,000 mark. The survey on which this estimate is founded was made by the Consolidated Edison Company, and it is granted that "any claim of complete accuracy would be presumptuous."

CHICAGO, June 6 (AP) -- Johnny Sain of the Braves pitched and batted his way to a 1-0 victory over the Cubs here today. The veteran right hander blanked the Cubs on four hits and topped it off by singling to score Jim Russell with the lone run of the game.
William Talbert added another trophy to his large collection of silverware yesterday when he won the invitation tournament of the Jackson Heights Tennis Club for the Gerald Lumsden Cup.

How New York and industrial designers find sources for their creations is pointed up in an exhibition opening today in the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. On display are the designers' end products, along with the material that inspired them, culled from the library's large collections.

An agreement by the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company to select dining car personnel without discriminating against Negroes will have "immediate beneficial effects" because the railroad is about to place in operation a number of additional grill cars, according to a joint statement issued yesterday by the New York State Commission Against Discrimination and the Massachusetts Fair Employment Practice Commission.

More than ever before there is a vital need for religion in formal education so that America's young men and women will be able to "test and sift" their "incentives land values," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, minister of Christ Church, Methodist, declared yesterday at New York University Baccalaureate services in the Gould Memorial Chapel, University Heights.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Two committees of the National Planning Association urged today a three-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, despite defects in past administration.

A survey of New York business concerns to prepare a comprehensive plan for staggering working hours to relieve rush hour congestion on the city subway lines will begin today, according to a joint announcement issued yesterday by the Board of Transportation, the city's Department of Commerce and the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 6 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, was authoritatively reported here tonight to have decided that men of military age might enter Israel during any truce period as long as they were kept immobilized.

Dr. William P. Jacobs, president of the American Cotton Manufacturers Association, appeared before the Senate Finance Committee on Thursday last week to give his views on the proposed renewal of the reciprocal trade agreements program, which expires by limitation next Saturday, June 12.
Ten thousand spectators watched the annual Corpus Christi procession and rally held under the auspices of the Bronx Nocturnal Adoration Society on the Fordham University campus yesterday afternoon.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 6 -- The growing solidarity among all free peoples was described as the greatest hope of avoiding another world war by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, to members of the graduating class of Notre Dame University's 103d commencement exercises here today.

At a crucial moment in history, when Western democracy is engaged in a supreme struggle for survival in the face of new totalitarian aggression from the East, a few antediluvian Republican leaders have undertaken to stampede the House of Representatives into slashing the funds for the European Recovery and other foreign aid programs on which the outcome of that struggle depends.

The General Motors two-year wage-rate agreement was properly called ingenious in your May 26 issue because, in tying wage-rate increases to a combination of consumer-price changes and secular advance, it recognizes relationships so sadly ignored or improperly considered in the major agreements growing out of similar difficulties during the past two years.

Roman Catholic clergy and laity honored yesterday Msgr. John J. E. O'Brien, for thirteen years pastor of St. Agnes Church, 149 East Forty-third Street, who is celebrating his golden jubilee in the priesthood. Auxiliary Bishop Thomas J. McDonnell presided at the church in a solemn pontifical mass at 11 A. M. The Rev. Joseph McSorley lauded Msgr. O'Brien in a sermon.

Two former Premiers of Lithuania, speaking at the annual conference of the Lithuanian-American Council of Societies of New York and New Jersey in the American Common, 40 East Fortieth Street, described yesterday afternoon the trials of that little Baltic state under Russian and German occupation.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 6 -- Presidential intervention in the maritime labor dispute -- which threatens to cause a nation-wide strike June 15 -- will begin with hearings here tomorrow.

"Teen Canteen," a television program designed for the age group covered in the title, will be introduced Tuesday, June 22, at 7:05 P.M., by WPIX, the station of The Daily News: The outlet is scheduled to open June 15 on channel 11.

Nearly 25,000 persons, members of the Holy Name Society and their amilies, marched into Ebbets Field yesterday afternoon to participate in the sixty-sixth annual religious and patriotic rally of the Brooklyn Diocesan Union of the society. There they heard the Very Rev. Harry C. Graham, national director of the society, call the rally a rededication of two fundamental principles: belief in the divinity of Christ and the tenets of democracy.
BALTIMORE, June 6 (AP) -- Jersey City made a sweep of the series by winning both ends of today's double-header from the Baltimore Orioles, 6 to 5 and 3 to 0.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, June 6 (AP) -- The Arab and Israeli agreement to accept a four-week truce in Palestine appeared to be cracking up tonight. A high Arab source placed the blame on two Israeli conditions -- immigration and the opening of the Jerusalem-Tel Aviv highway so that Jewish sections of Jerusalem can be supplied.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -Chicago's cellar-shackled White Sox dealt the Senators two defeats here today before a crowd of 15,772. The White Sox smashed out a 10-4 victory in the opener, then coasted to an 11-4 triumph in the second game.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Official copies of the London agreements on Western Germany will be released tomorrow morning in an atmosphere of concern here over reactions to the proposals from the Soviet Union and France.

Henry Laskau, representing New York's Maccabi A. C., took his second straight National A. A. U. 10,000-meter walk title yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium, thereby winning the right to represent the United States in the Olympics.
The Princeton (N.J.) Drama Festival opens its summer season this evening at the McCarter Theatre with Kay Francis starring in "The Last of Mrs. Cheyney," a revival of the Frederick Lonsdale play.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 6 -- By a margin of eleven seconds, Baruna, the big seagoing craft owned and handled by Henry C. Taylor, won the annual New York Yacht Club invitation cruise from here to Port Jefferson and return. This was the third victory for Baruna in the event, a prep for the New York-to-Bermuda race.

After an ownership of only a few days Loomes J. Grossman has resold the two-story taxpayer at the northwest corner of Eighty-ninth Avenue and 165th Street, in Jamaica, Queens, facing the new branch store of R.H. Macy Co.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 6 -- Outplaying their rivals throughout, Alan Corey's Meadow Brook riders halted Westbury, 8 to 4, in a National Polo League match on International Field of the Meadow Brook Club today.

Many businesses entered 1948 in a very strong position financially and have succeeded in maintaining that status, Roy A. Foulke, vice president of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday in an analysis of the financial structures of commercial and industrial businesses.
PAOTOW, China, June 4 (Delayed) -- A large-scale distribution of relief food over a vast area of Inner Mongolia will be started soon by agents of the United States China Relief Mission.
Dwellings and small apartment buildings formed the bulk of properties on the East Side reported passing to new ownerships over the week-end.

A sales improvement and training program started a year ago by the Milton Paper Company has produced indirect dollar benefits, it was announced over the week-end. While most major paper companies recently began sales training projects in anticipation of renewed competition, this is believed to be the first report on results of such programs.

Fall openings attracted a large number of buyers to wholesale apparel markets here last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Most buyers, the reports indicated, were satisfied with manufacturers' offerings of fall lines, but showed a tendency to "shop" thoroughly before placing commitments.

AMSTERDAM, June 6 -- Jonkheer Willem J. De Jonge, chairman of the Federation of Netherlands Indies Mountain Estate Enterprises of Amsterdam, has just returned from Washington where he attended meetings of a group studying the rubber industry.

Homemakers who have a penchant for art but a moderate budget may now own copies of fine pieces of sculpture to decorate a room corner or dramatize a book-case. Cast stone copies of the works of outstanding artists are being shown for the first time in New York at Lord Taylor's, where each is priced at $75.

Appointment of Laurence A. Thomas as manager of the Ohrbach store now under construction on Wilshire Boulevard in Los Angeles was announced over the week-end by Jerome K. Ohrbach, president of Ohrbach's, Inc.

As might be expected, a realistic approach to the city's traffic problem was made by Austin Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, at a recent meeting of the National Citizens Conference on Planning. He admitted the staggering magnitude in cost and construction necessary for essential municipal facilities.

PITTSBURGH, June 6 -- Ralph Kiner, a fellow who seems determined to travel in extremes, touched off his fourteenth homer of the year today, and with this one shot salvaged a number of things, including much of his reputation.

Defeating the Philadelphia Americans, champions of the American Soccer League by 5 -- 2 at Sterling Oval, the Bronx, the Brookhattans yesterday qualified for the Eastern final in the annual national challenge cup competition of the United States Soccer Football Association.

Introduction of new business machines has taught the Third Avenue Transit Company some disquieting things about some of its bus drivers. It also has brought a new impasse in relations between the company and the Transport Workers Union, CIO.

The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 326-28 West Eighty-sixth Street was sold by Wilgold, Inc., to the Anstan Realty Corporation for investment. Assessed at $300,000, the property contains 170 rooms, laid out in fifty apartments of three and four rooms each and was sold through Joseph H. Nassoit, Inc., broker.
The Standard Oil Company of California plans to build five large tankers at a total cost of $30,000,000, it was announced yesterday in San Francisco by T. S. Petersen, president of the company.

Too many churches today are "ecclesiastical zombies," so thoroughly dedicated to the past that their traditions, sacraments and ceremonials have become "shrouds of a corpse," the Rev. Karl M. Chworowsky, pastor of the Flatbush Unitarian Church, Beverly Road and East Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn, said yesterday in his sermon.

Thirteen Hunter College seniors majoring in speech have been gaining important clinical experience in the correction of speech disorders, as well as performing a valuable service to the community, Dr. Dorothy A. Doob, director of the speech clinic at the Long Island College Hospital and speech instructor at Hunter, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- A dry-weather scare in corn lifted prices of that grain sharply early last week on the Board of Trade, but a reaction set in on prospects for some relief, and most of the gains were wiped out. The crop has been planted in good season this year, and reports from almost all sections indicate an excellent stand.

PARIS, June 6 -- Indications from experts here negotiating in the organization for European Economic Cooperation to find means for a monetary accord on intra-European payments show that the problem probably will have to be tackled anew.

A form of "intellectual anemia" has infected modern society, and is affecting certain types of education and propaganda with the resultant production of "intellectual robots" instead of intellectual thinkers, the Rev. Edward Lodge Curran, president of the International Catholic Truth Society, asserted yesterday.

Pleasant warm weather desserts may be built around hard meringues, which suit the season for several reasons. For one thing, eggs -- the chief ingredient -- are most plentiful and at their lowest price now. Another favorable point is that meringue as a base for fruits, cream pie mixtures or ice cream is easier to make than a regular pastry shell.

While praising government agencies fighting juvenile delinquency, Justice John W. Hill, chief justice of Domestic Relations Court, conceded yesterday that such agencies might be inadequate to cope with the situation.

There will be no peace in the world so long as honor, truth and justice are being disregarded, Dr. Abraham N. Franzblau, dean of the Union School of Religious Education, said yesterday afternoon at the commencement exercises of the school at Congregation Emanu-el, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

BOSTON, June 6 (AP) -- Playing more like the experts forecast before the start of the season, the Red Sox today swept a double-header from the Tigers, 5 -- 4 and 12 -- 3, vaulting from seventh place to a triple tie for fourth in the American League.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $55,043,756,205. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
After a prolonged and crowded spring of gallery events, the active art season this week seems to have taken its decisive dip into the annual summer doldrums, with less than ten new events scheduled.

About $3,000,000 worth of war surplus goods, supplies, spare parts and plant equipment, offered in 377 lots representing more than 100 different lines of products, will be sold at a three-day public sale by the War Assets Administration in the Bronx beginning at 9:30 A. M. Wednesday, it was announced over the week-end.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 6 -- For the first time this year, the century mark was reached in a regatta out on Long Island Sound today. It was in the sixth of the championship series, that of the Huguenot Yacht Club.

The Air Force has been made the subject of three books that will be issued, by two concerns. Harold B. Hinton's history of United States air power, "Air Victory: The Men and the Machines," will be brought out by Harper on Wednesday. It will have a foreword by Lieut. Gen. Barton K. Yount, USA (retired).

MUNICH, Germany, June 6 (AP) -- A crowd of angry displaced persons from Poland and the Ukraine stoned and booed five Russian officers when they visited a displaced persons camp at Mittenwald today, a United States Army spokesman said.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 6 (AP) -A new crisis arose today along the lower Columbia River Valley as crest waters of a new flood battered levees already weakened in a week of high water.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The United Mine Workers disclosed today that all of the $4,564,449 left in the Miners' Health and Welfare Fund as of 1946 would be spent by the end of this month.

JERUSALEM, June 5 (Delayed) -- The war between the Israeli forces and Arabs was interrupted in Jerusalem for two hours from 3 to 5 o'clock this afternoon while the Jews passed through their lines into the Arab-held Old City at the New Gate forty-three women, ten old men, a stretcher case and a brown dog named Micky.

The United States Trade Mark Association's special committee on international conventions governing patents, trade marks and designs will intensify its study of proposed revisions of these agreements to be offered to the next Congress of the International Association for the Protection of Industrial Property, it was learned last week.

Trailing by a half point, Coach Howie Borck's well-balanced Cardinal Hayes troupe placed first and second in the last event of the program of the twenty-second annual outdoor track and field championships of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association

PARIS, June 6 -- As a curtain raiser to the attack on French foreign policy expected during the coming week from Charles de Gaulle, Gaston Palewski, one of his principal aides, today declared that the London accords on Germany were unacceptable.

A roaring five-alarm fire swept through the Stewart Lumber Company yard at Metropolitan and Woodward Avenues. Ridgewood, Queens, yesterday afternoon. The entire stock of lumber and nine buildings were destroyed, with a loss that may be as high as $500,000, according to Robert Link, secretary of the company.

Non-resident aid is the current answer to the problem of caring for the aged, Kingsley Kunhardt, president of the Peabody Home at 1000 Pelham Parkway, the Bronx, declared yesterday. He made this assertion at the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, 31 Nassau Street, of which he is vice-president and where the business office of the home is maintained.

NEWARK, N. J., June 6 (AP) -Dick Starr and Clarence Marshall hurled the Newark Bears to a double triumph over the Syracuse Chiefs, 3 -- 2 and 11 -- 0, today to protect their league lead while dropping the Chiefs into third place before 8,972 fans.

"Little Old New York" as it existed fifty years ago will come to life Saturday when 45,000 marchers join in a colorful moving pageant down Fifth Avenue to show the city's growth in the last half-century, it was announced yesterday.

There is a saying that old things are best. This peculiar paradox has been repeated so often it now seems to bear the stamp of popular truth. Possibly it is a product of the depravity of man, who is lazy and is a dreamer in a number of other ways besides this one.

LONDON, June 6 -- Was Lieut. Col. J. D. Tassoyev, Soviet Guards officer, abducted by British secret service agents from the home of an American official in Bremen or did he come to London voluntarily, as the British Foreign Office said on May 6?

For some reason, the Experimental Theatre chose to present "These Tender Mercies," by Barton Yarborough, for three performances over the week-end in its invitation series at the Lenox Hill Playhouse uptown. The reason grew increasingly obscure during last evening's showing.
In dispatches from London published in various New York papers on May 29, Latvian refugees were quoted as having said that Sweden would return all Baltic refugees to the Soviet Union.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 6 -- This resort gladly capitulated today as an army of fez-topped shriners 40,000 strong from all sections of the country moved its invasion into high gear.
BRUSSELS, June 6 (AP) -- Frank Parker and Mrs. Patricia Canning Todd swept singles honors for the United States today in the finals of the Belgian international tennis championships.

TOKYO, June 6 -- Gradually the occupation's trade officials are expanding Japan's commerce throughout the Orient, despite the handicap of dollar shortages. On March 31 the unsold and apparently unsalable stockpile of cotton goods reached a peak of 400,000,000 yards In cloth or its equivalents.

MEXICO CITY, June 5 (UP) -- A spokesman for Pemex, the Government controlled oil monopoly, indicated today that the company may give as much as 80 per cent of the oil produced to foreign concerns willing to invest capital in new exploitation on a share production basis.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 6 -- A birdie 3 at the home green by Bob Johnke decided the final of the Hempstead Golf Club's member-guest best-ball tournament today. The 15-foot putt holed by the club champion enabled him and his partner, Fred Head of Plandome,

ZURICH, June 6 -- Advertisements in Swiss newspapers inserted by persons careful to conceal their identities, offering to sell large amounts of Danish crowns against Swiss francs "at favorable terms," have aroused great uneasiness in banking circles in Copenhagen, and above all in the Danish National Bank, because it is feared that the illegal flight of capital is increasing.

BOSTON, June 6 (UP) -- The S.S. Nevada, a 6.900-ton Danish tanker, crushed her bow against an iceberg some thirty miles off Newfoundland today, but was in no immediate danger. Coast Guard headquarters here reported.

What makes a successful marriage? The theorists took the day off yesterday and those who had practical experience held the limelight as forty-two couples, all of whom have been married fifty years or more, were honored at the annual Golden Wedding Party sponsored by the Grand Street Boys Association.

BELGRADE, June 6 -- Information reaching Belgrade today disclosed that the Macedonian problem, which had agitated the Balkans for more than fifty years, has survived establishment of the present regimes in Yugoslavia and Bulgaria and continues as a source of disagreement between the two countries.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 6 -- Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, Primate of Hungary, told Catholics today that they should stop reading newspapers of the Government parties and stop listening to Hungarian broadcasts.
A city-wide inspection of medicine chests in homes was urged yesterday by Mrs. Marjorie B. May, home safety director of the Greater New York Safety Council.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 6 -- The new Patriarch of the Rumanian Orthodox Church, Justinian Marina, was installed this morning in the National Assembly building. The Orthodox Church has approximately 13,000,000 members in Rumania.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 6 -- Thirteen cadets of the graduating class at the United States Military Academy were honored for military and academic proficiency today in conjunction with the traditional June Week festivities. The awards are given annually by patriotic societies and prominent persons.

The American Tobacco Company, through its agency, Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., has signed a twenty-four-week contract with the American Newspaper Advertising Network, Inc., calling for continuous advertising of Lucky Strike cigarettes in nearly all of the network's fifty-four member papers, it was learned over the week-end.

The Music Education League presented yesterday afternoon at Town Hall the first of two concerts by winners of the year's auditions. The young artists played pianos in solo and ensemble, and one singer and one. violinist also were heard.

The American Tobacco Company, through its agency, Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., has signed a twenty-four-week contract with the American Newspaper Advertising Network, Inc., calling for continuous advertising of Lucky Strike cigarettes in nearly all of the network's fifty-four member papers, it was learned over the week-end.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board decided today that a national union cannot "front" for one of its local unions which has not signed non-Communist affidavits.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 7 -- Maxwell Anderson and Andrew Solt have been signed by Frank Ross to write the long-delayed screen version of Lloyd C. Douglas' novel, "The Robe," and a deal has been concluded for Victor Fleming to direct the picture starting about the first of the year, Ross disclosed today.

Ina Claire's next Broadway vehicle may well be "Jane," the S.N. Behrman dramatization of Somerset Maugham's short story of the same name, which the Theatre Guild plans to put on in the fall. At the moment, no contracts have been signed, but friends of the actress say that she is completely satisfied with the script sent to her recently by the Guild.

Today is the first day for the circulation of party designating petitions in the August primary for such offices as Assemblymen, State Senators, Representatives in Congress and lower judicial offices, including the Surrogate's Court.
Local industry has promised to spend $30,000,000 in the next four years for corrective measures to abate the smoke nuisance, Dr. Harry S. Mustard, Commissioner of Health, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Four decisions handed down by the United States Supreme Court today in divorce suits were expected to give further stimulus to the drive for uniform divorce laws.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 7 -- The Israeli Foreign Ministry answered tonight reports from Christian Arabs that Israeli forces had desecrated holy places in Palestine. It charged that Christian churches and religious foundations had been used as military headquarters, and pointed out that all twenty-seven synagogues in the Old City of Jerusalem had been destroyed.

More than the usual amount of paid advertising will be used in the coming Presidential campaign battle, according to advertising circles here yesterday. As an indication of what is ahead, it was noted that Republican factions alone spent over $100,000 for advertising in the Oregon primary.

PARIS, June 7 -- While Paris representatives of the New York law firm of Coudert Brothers categorically denied today that the firm had aided any of its French clients in concealment of several billion of francs in French assets abroad, the police here were reported ready to call in the Coudert's chief Paris representative, John B. Robinson, and question him.

Under the instructions now issued by the Argentine Government to banks in that country and to Argentine consuls in the United States, clarifying its May 14 instructions to banks in Argentina, there is no assurance as to when payment in dollars will be made on shipments, according to the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 7 -- Egypt has landed seaborne reinforcements in an attempt to break an armored spearhead out of encirclement by the Israeli Army at Isdud on Palestine's southern coastal plain, eyewitnesses said tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Contract parleys in the soft coal industry were on the verge of collapse today following a two-hour conference at which John L. Lewis made a demand on the operators "as a condition precedent to a new contract."
