LONDON, June 7 -- No one in London appeared to be surprised today that Dr. Edouard Benes, ill and politically impotent in his Communist-dominated country, finally had abdicated as President of Czechoslovakia. In the circumstances, his resignation was fully expected.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Following is the text of the communique released today of the six-power London conference on Western Germany:
Three London newspapers, The Times, The Daily Express and The Daily Telegraph, arrived in New York yesterday on the day of publication, inaugurating a service for their American readers.
The letter by Alvin Johnson in your edition of June 1 does not contribute to clear thinking about Palestine.

" THIS bankruptcy of the Security Council had been due to no Soviet veto. It had been due exclusively to the policies of selfish and short-sighted expediency pursued by Great Britain, and, still more, by the United States."

BOSTON, June 7 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, received an honorary degree of Doctor of Civil Laws today at the seventy-fifth annual commencement of Boston University. Eight other honorary degrees were bestowed by Dr. Daniel L. Marsh, president of the university.

Governor Dewey of New York and former Gov. Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota joined Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan yesterday in demanding that the cuts made by the House of Representatives in the European Recovery Plan appropriations be rescinded.

LONDON, June 7 -- Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, former Prime Minister of South Africa, answered today the question that everybody had been asking since his defeat by the Nationalists in the recent South African parliamentary elections.

A chain of sports fields owned and built by Americans for English youngsters, forced by lack of recreational facilities to risk their lives playing on busy streets and in the rubble of bombed sites, was proposed yesterday by Sir Noel Curtis-Bennett, founder of the National Playing Fields Association of Great Britain.

Just eleven days ago Eduard Benes celebrated, if that is the word to use, his sixty-fourth birthday. He had seen his country, freed from the domination of Austria, grow into an outpost of democracy, fall under the tyranny of the Nazis, then escape from that tyranny only to become a Communist serfdom.
The cotton futures market developed considerable irregularity yesterday and final prices on the New York Citton Exchange were 2 to 66 points net higher than Saturday's final levels.

The Queen of Bermuda, luxury liner on the New York to Bermuda run in pre-war years, is undergoing her reconversion at Newcastle-on-Tyne. It is expected that the work will be completed by November, in time to allow the vessel to enter her old run at the beginning of the winter travel season, the Furness, Withy Co., Ltd., operators of the vessel announced yesterday.

The essential issue of our time is how to reconcile individual freedom with economic security, Arthur J. Altmeyer, commissioner of the Social Security Administration in Washington, asserted yesterday.

THE glamour division in boxing is, naturally enough, the heavyweight class. But ranking right in back of it is the middleweight brigade which has far surpassed the normal quota of great champions. It's true that it has had a few duds but so have the heavyweights. Essentially, though, the 160-pounders have ranked high in skill, courage and ring appeal.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- United Airlines, Inc., Chicago, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 369,618 shares of $10 par value common stock and stated that if it needed additional funds another increase in passenger fares "might" be proposed.
Mayor O'Dwyer received yesterday a white shirt and a hat, both made in Nebraska, from members of the Junior Chamber of Commerce of that state when they visited City Hall.
OMAHA, Neb., June 7 -- The bolt of Nebraska's Democratic state chairman from President Truman was seen today as an indication of a strong feeling against Mr. Truman among mid-west party leaders.

LONDON, June 7 -- The international conference on safety of life at sea, meeting here under the chairmanship of Sir John Anderson approved today a new fifteen-article agreement to replace the International Convention of 1929.

Ruling that the Federal Government was not subject to the New York State Commercial Rent Laws, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals unanimously affirmed yesterday the Government's right to evict a lessee of its property in favor of a higher bidder.
Four pages of facts about the sheriffs' pageant to be presented Saturday as part of the parade opening the city's golden jubilee were made public yesterday by Sheriff John J. McCloskey.

A substantial increase in the number of exhibitors showing fabrics this year compared to 1947 was noted by an estimated 8,000 trade visitors who attended the second annual International Textile Industries Exposition which opened yesterday afternoon at Grand Central Palace.

MADRID, June 7 -- The Spanish Red Cross will be represented by three delegates at the international convention in Stockholm Aug. 20 despite protests of Russian satellite countries, national headquarters here announced today.
Your leading editorial of May 28 attacks Senator Langer for raising the issue of racial discrimination and segregation in connection with a proposed draft bill.

The Smoke Prevention Association of America, which has now reached the respectable age of 41 years, is holding its annual convention here this week. Started when official action was limited only to a few cities, and with a handful of smoke inspectors as charter members, it has grown in influence and membership through the years, and now draws delegations from coast to coast.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 7 -- With the United Nations Security Council still apparently unwilling to make a move toward settling the disputed interpretation of its latest request for a cease-fire in Palestine, the Soviet Union announced today that it wanted to join the United States, Belgium and France in sending military observers to the Holy Land to help carry out the Council resolution.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 7 -- There seemed little hope here tonight that Israel and the Arabs could get together on a truce. The main stumbling block is Irgun Zvai Leumi, a dissident group, which is defending Jerusalem along with units of the Haganah, Zionist Army.

The survey of Manhattan business concerns in connection with setting up a comprehensive plan to stagger working hours to relieve subway rush-hour congestion also will take in all departments in the city government, it was learned yesterday.

A sharp falling off in the number of leases including voluntary rent rises here, compared with last year, was reported yesterday by the local office of the Housing Expediter. Legal provision for such leases, embodying rent rises of 15 per cent or less, was authorized last July 1, and in the next two months 46,518 were filed.

Warning that stomach cancer often masquerades as stomach ulcer, Dr. Arthur W. Allen declared yesterday that the best chance for reducing the number of deaths from stomach cancer lay in prompt and complete surgical removal of gastric ulcers.

PITTSBURGH, June 7 -- Rallying heroically behind their faltering mound ace, Larry Jansen, the Giants tonight battered the Pirates into submission, 9 to 5, before a gathering of 23,243 that had confidently looked for something better from the Corsairs.

Textron Incorporated has purchased all the assets of Esmond Mills, Inc., in exchange for 139,508 shares of its $1.25 convertible preferred stock and the assumption by Textron of all Esmond liabilities, Royal Little, president of Textron, announced yesterday. The transfer was made subject to acceptance by Esmond stockholders of Textron's offer.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower became the thirteenth president of Columbia University yesterday. Except for brief early morning greetings and questions from photographers and reporters, there was no other outward sign on the Morningside Heights campus that the general had assumed office.

Voters and legislators who soon will be concerned about whether to support veterans' bonuses were warned by the Tax Foundation yesterday to "look beyond the emotional factors involved and give serious and studied consideration to immediate and future economic effects of such action." Bonus proposals face action at referendum or by the Legislatures in eight states, the foundation reported.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 7 -- Blending their efforts superbly, Dave Laux of the Sands Point Club and Pete Cassella from Island Hills out in Suffolk County turned in the winning card of 31, 33 -- 64 in the amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island Professional Golfers Association at the Cherry Valley Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- An Appeals Board on Export Controls directed by the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce will go into operation on June 15 to provide a "simple and efficient appeals procedure," it was announced today.

Store Sales Down 7% Here Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores decreased 9 per cent last week under the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The bottleneck in the state mental hygiene program is not lack of funds or overcrowding but a shortage of psychiatrists a social workers, Dr. Frederick MacCurdy, Commissioner of Mental Hygiene for New York State said yesterday.

BOSTON, June 7 -- Harry C. Browne, former actor and radio executive, was today elected president of the First Church of Christ, Scientist, famed Mother Church of Christian Science, at its annual meeting here.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 (AP) -- Pacific Coast shipowners estimated today they might be liable for as much as $20,000,000 in retroactive overtime pay, as result of the Supreme Court's decision. Large sums may have to be paid to workers "who never even dreamed they had it coming," they added.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., June 7 -- Warning that present laws made it impossible for unions to fight on any front without "getting our brains beat in," James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, called today for an immediate merger of all wings of the American labor movement.

In Sir John Orr's latest press conference at Geneva he calls attention again to the fact that world population is growing more rapidly than the world's food supply. As reported in THE TIMES of May 19, I gather that his immediate appeal is for action to relieve shortages in areas where food supply is too low for minimum nutritional needs.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Senate, in a sitting which continued into tonight, refused bluntly and decisively to tie the whole of President Truman's civil rights program to the stop-gap selective draft bill.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 -- Since future wars will be indefinitely more technological than those of the past, the nation's technologists and scientists must be organized now so they can be drawn into service instantly, Col. Charles S. Lawrence declared here today.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., June 7 -- The American pharmaceutical industry has a yearly stake of $400,000,000 in foreign drug markets, speakers declared at the American Drug Manufacturers Association's Annual meeting here today.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 7 (AP) -- The Shamrock Stable's Little Harp won the $5,000 inaugural purse today as Narrangansett Park began its 30-day summer meeting.

Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan defended yesterday the action of his office in constructing an elevated section of the East River Drive, between Eighteenth and Twenty-fifth Streets, declaring that it would eliminate traffic congestion not only locally but also along the entire waterfront.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 7 -- Mrs. E.T. Gerry of the Meadow Brook Club shot 50, 48 -- 98 to win medal honors with the low gross in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association qualifying round for the Class B match play championship at the North Shore Country Club today.

At the annual meeting of Federated Department Stores, Inc., held here yesterday, Fred Lazarus Jr., president, informed shareholders that sales in 1948 are expected to be moderately heavier than in 1947. "Our plans call for moderate dollar increases and we expect that unit volume gains will about equal the growth in sales," he said.

A 53-year-old real estate operator, accused of "promoting" ninety-seven persons into paying $35,000 for apartments in a twelve-story building that never went beyond the blueprint stage, yesterday was found guilty of extorting rental bonuses.
PRAGUE, June 7 -- President Eduard Benes resigned today without having signed the People's Democracy type of constitution that the Communist-dominated Government put through Parliament on May 9.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Supreme Court by a 5-to-3 decision affecting New York longshoremen held today that it was legal to pay them overtime on premium pay for working at inconvenient hours. The majority insisted that the pay formula did not mean payment of "overtime on overtime."

LONDON, June 7 -- The steadily mounting deficits and increasing pressure from within the nationalized airlines soon may force the British Government to abandon its "Fly British" policy, it was forecast here today by a reliable source.

Home and fashion accessories hand-made in Haiti have been imported for the Haitian Bazaar, a new store opening today at 133 West Third Street. The shop, to be open weekdays from noon to 8 P, M., is under the supervision of Winifred Mason, jewelry expert.

A statement by Frank J. Taylor, chairman of the committee for the companies and agents on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, that a maritime strike at this time would be "nothing short of a national disaster with world-wide repercussions," brought heated denial yesterday from Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, before a Presidential fact-finding board.
LOS ANGELES, June 7 (AP) -- Standard Oil Company of California's exclusive marketing contracts with some 7,000 independent service stations in the West were ruled illegal today.

Use of air transportation in the collection of cash items payable in a number of Federal Reserve bank and branch cities has cut a full day from the established collection time, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday in announcing a revision of its time schedules for these cities.
Random notes.

New York dress manufacturers produced a total of 81,870,000 dresses in 1947, a decrease of 12 per cent under the previous year, according to Julius Hochman, general manager, Joint Board of the Dress and Waistmakers' Union of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union (AFL).

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads told Congress today financial reserves of the railroads were not adequate for the capital improvement program necessary to keep the railways prepared for war.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (AP) -- Beau Jack, former Augusta, Ga., shoeshine boy who twice has been world's lightweight champion, gets a chance to reign for the third time July 12 in a fifteen-round title bout with Champion Ike Williams.

Coming from behind, Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School of Brooklyn captured the C.H.S.A.A. baseball championship of the city for the first time by defeating Cardinal Hayes Memorial of the Bronx at Ebbets Field yesterday, 6 -- 2.

" Potrait of Innocence" ("Nous les Gosses"), a French-made drama with Louise Carletti, Gilbert Gil, Jean-Pierre Geffroy, Pierre Larquey and Jean Buquet, will have its local premiere this morning a tthe Art Theatre, 36 East Eighth Street.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (UP) -- The United States said tonight that the Western powers had successfully met the challenge of "economic chaos, distress and despair" presented by Soviet policy on Germany.

Columbia University made another contribution to the 1948 edition of the New York Football Giants yesterday when it was announced by John Mara, the Giants' president, that Bruce Gehrke, the Lions' great wingman of last season, had affixed his signature to a contract.

GENEVA, June 7 -- Restrictions on the use of funds voted by the House of Representatives for the International Refugee Organization would, if maintained in the final appropriations act, deal a shattering blow to the refugee program, officials of the organization said here today.

JERUSALEM, June 7 -- Twenty-two of the twenty-seven synagogues in the Jewish Quarter of Jerusalem's Old City were destroyed before the community surrendered to Arab forces May 28, Isaac H. Herzog, chief rabbi of Palestine, said today. The five others probably were demolished after the Jews' departure, he added.

WARSAW, June 7 -- The arrest several weeks ago of a smooth-talking Polish confidence man who used the names of American Embassy officials, including that of Ambassador Stanton Griffis, to fleece Poles of about 100,000,000 zlotys ($250,000) was disclosed hero today.

Because baseball players belong in the city, according to Michael Kivatisky, the 12-year-old winner of the Children's Aid Society's annual award for sportsmanship, officially gave away yesterday the two-week camp vacation that came with his bronze medal.

After having attended New York University at intervals for sixteen years, John Lane of 1214 East Tenth Street, Brooklyn, will receive his degree tomorrow at the university's 116th commencement exercises. Fifty years old and a builder of two-family houses, he will get the degree of Bachelor of Science in Civil Engineering.
WASHINGTON. June 7 -- The use of sound trucks by political candidates and what the founding fathers might think of such devices were discussed today by the Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Ten West Point cadets leave New York by air Thursday for a month's tour of France.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts has been in public life for fifty years. On June 8. 1898, he was sworn in before President Paul Kruger as State Attorney of the South African Republic.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 7 -- Aubrey S. Eban, Israeli representative to the United Nations Security Council, today submitted the following letter to members of the Council:

The active interest of "every public-spirited citizen in this community must be brought to bear on the problem of New York City's displaced children," Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard declared yesterday. He made the assertion at a special meeting to discuss the lack of facilities for institutional and foster care called by the Citizens Committee on Children of New York City at the home of its president, Mrs. David M. Levy, 300 Park Avenue.

Books dealing with the writings of T.S. Eliot will be brought out by two concerns. Rinehart will issue on Thursday "T.S. Eliot: A Selected Critique," edited by Leonard Unger. The book will contain excerpts from thirty-one essays appraising Eliot's work.

Anyone who has visited East Hampton, which lies down toward the tip of Long Island, likes to remember its lovely village green, the Old Hook Mill at the north end of Main Street, the pretty little cottage John Howard Payne wrote about in "Home Sweet Home," and the white beach a five-minute drive from the center of town.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., June 7 (AP) -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall advised college students tonight to guard their emotions and try to get at the "true facts" before forming judgments on foreign affairs.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Carroll Reece, Republican National Chairman, designated Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts today to head the committee that will draft the party platform for the 1948 Presidential campaign.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Three successive Democratic efforts to extend the reciprocal trade program intact, with none of the restrictions voted by the House, were beaten down today by the Republicans, 7 to 6, in the Senate Finance Committee.

The doors opened yesterday at Madison Square Garden on the second annual Fashion Fair, an exposition of various branches of the women's apparel industry. This presentation will be held at the Garden through Sunday.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 7 (AP) -- The president of the American Bankers Association remarked here today that there was a shortage of people "with the disposition, the will and the capacity" to make the most of everyday opportunities.

Wallingford Riegger's Third Symphony has received the annual orchestral award of the Music Critics Circle of New York. Miles Kastendieck, president of the circle, announced yesterday. The piece was called "the symphonic work of most outstanding excellence composed by an American citizen and played for the first time in this city during the music season of 1947-48."

NANKING, June 7 -- Six Communist divisions have closed in on Changchun, former Japanese capital of "Manchukuo," and have begun shelling an emergency Government airstrip laid out on a broad boulevard inside the city, it was reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Obviously, if the Democratic platform declaration on "civil rights" does not specifically repudiate the President's legislative program, and yet avoids endorsement of the items in that program which have brought the threat of a walkout by several Southern delegations, these delegations may remain to the finish of the national convention.

PARIS, June 7 -- France soon may be able to begin an all-out effort to equip and modernize its industry and agriculture, Jean Monnet, author and director of the modernization plan bearing his name, said today in an optimistic report on the progress made in 1947.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 7 -- The Minister Presidents of the Western zones of Germany will accept a proffer to call a Constituent Assembly, but will strongly object to the Ruhr's internationalization when they meet with the military governors here next week.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- A bill authorizing the promotion of Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, wartime head of the atomic bomb project, to the permanent rank of major general was approved today by the House Armed Services Committee.

When Major General Bryant Moore took command of his 5,000 American "Blue Devils" in Trieste that unhappy city was regarded as one of the hottest trouble spots in Europe. The joint British and American force guarding the Free Territory totaled only 10,000 men.

LONDON, June 7 -- The United States, along with Great Britain and France, guarantees to keep military forces in Germany "until the peace of Europe is secured," it was revealed today, when the recommendations of the six-power conference on Western Germany were published as a second and final communique.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Restoration of all but a token cut in funds for the European Recovery Program gathered bipartisan support in the Senate today amid warnings of voter reaction against the Republican party if the $1,500,000,000 reduction ordered by the House was allowed to stand.

PEIPING, China, June 7 -- University students of Peiping have been aroused by United States Ambassador John Leighton Stuart's statement criticizing student demonstrations against American policy in Japan.

The party fishing boat Marlin II was towed yesterday to the Mill Basin Ship Repair Yard, Brooklyn, after being brought into Sheepshead Bay by a Coast Guard picket boat from the sea beyond Ambrose Lightship, where she had wallowed helplessly most of Sunday night with thirty persons aboard.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 7 -- A recent check of seven families composed of three members each indicated that 108,833 square inches of fabric, or the equivalent of a strip 250 feet long by three feet wide, have to be ironed every week.

LONDON, June 7 -- Shoppers were out early today throughout London's West End for the first post-war clearance sales, in which prices and the volumes of clothing coupons were halved. But queus grew only slowly; by 8 A. M. seven persons were waiting outside one of the major department stores.

Long Island University and its affiliated schools, the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy and the First Institute of Podiatry, held joint commencement exercises last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn. Degrees were conferred on 460 graduates.

A study by the Northern Trust Company of Chicago finds it "startling" that in all but five of the last fifteen years individual holdings of corporate and other non-government securities declined. Last year was the only one of the five when such investments absorbed more than $500,000,000 of new savings.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- Hedge pressure against liberal receipts of cash grain in the Southwest gave the wheat market on the Board of Trade a weak tone today, although there was fair support on small setbacks.

The report of the London conference on Germany, now published in full, marks another milestone in the evolution of Allied policy toward the principles of the Atlantic Charter, which are acquiring new validity as the only possible basis of a free world. In its essentials, especially in respect to German disarmament and safeguards against future German aggression, this report still keeps wholly within the Potsdam agreement.

A 13-year-old student at the Hebrew Institute of Borough Park, 5012 Thirteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, so much "enjoyed" the proceedings of a Police and Fire Department investigation into a series of fires at the school yesterday morning that he aroused the suspicions of departmental officials.

The American School of the Air will not be resumed in the fall by the Columbia Broadcasting System, Davidson Taylor, vice president in charge of public affairs for the network, announced yesterday. The program started eighteen years ago.

PRETORIA, South Africa, June 7 -- Indirect control of imports, affecting chiefly United States goods, is expected in the very near future here. Such an action would not imply an unfriendly intent on the part of the new Malan Government but the fact that South Africa's economic position is reaching a danger point.

Supreme Court Justice Edward R. Koch denied yesterday a motion for a temporary injunction brought by Dmitry Shostakovich, Aram Katchaturian, Serge Prokofieff and Nicolai Miaskovsky, Russian composers, to restrain Twentieth Century-Fox Film Company from using their names and music in connection with the film "The Iron Curtain."

CAIRO, Egypt, June 7 (U.P.) -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations mediator, presented a Palestine truce plan today to Israel and the Arab countries and demanded a "straightforward" yes or no answer within forty-eight hours.

TOKYO, June 7 -- The establishment of an exchange rate and the abolition of Japan's many different price ceilings would be delayed until well past the middle of 1950 under the Cabinet's long-range economic plan, just released.

LONDON, June 7 -- The banner of Margaret of Anjou, Queen of England in 1448, was hauled down today and replaced over Queens College, Cambridge, with the standard of Queen Elizabeth while she visited the university.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 7 (AP) -- Hot weather sent the snow-fed Columbia River surging toward a third flood crest today.

The United Parents Association will seek from the Board of Education a "bill of rights" for parents in respect to schools, David I. Ashe, an attorney, declared last night as he became president of the association. Mr. Ashe succeeded Mrs. Rose Shapiro, who ended a maximum term of four years.

PARIS, June 7 -- The resignation of President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia is interpreted outside the Communist section of France as a refusal to associate his name with the impending constitution. His decision will be applauded generally in tomorrow's press, which attaches small importance to ill health as the real motive.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 7 -- Lack of stability in leather-making raw material markets, which makes for uncertainty and confusion at the retail level, was deplored by George B. Hess, Baltimore shoe retailer and president of the National Shoe Retailers Association, speaking here today at the opening of the spring meeting of the Tanners Council of America.

Because of a lack of funds, the Board of Education has been forced to rescind pay rises it had approved for its staff of psychologists, it became known yesterday. Dr. Frank J. O'Brien, associate superintendent in charge of the board's Division of Child Welfare, termed the action "a serious blow" to the public school system's program for the prevention of juvenile delinquency.

ST. LOUIS, June 7 (AP) -- Two home runs by Dick Sisler provided Dutch Leonard of the Philadelphia Phillies with all the margin he needed to stifle the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, 5 to 1. Del Ennis also homered for the Phils and Start Musial's twelfth circuit clout deprived Leonard of a shut-out.

Arthur T. Vanderbilt, dean of the New York University School of Law, who will resign at the end of the current academic year to become the first Chief Justice of the newly created New Jersey Supreme Court, delivered a farewell address last night at the law school's Class Day exercises.

Despite Johnny Lindell's eighth homer of the year, Phil Rizzuto's second and nine other safeties, the Yankees finished second to the Browns, 5 -- 3, yesterday at the Stadium. There was nothing wrong with the Bombers' hitting against Rookie Ned Garver, but their spacing of these blows left something to be desired.
CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) -- Jim Russell had himself a field day at the plate today as the Braves beat the Cubs, 9 to 5. It was the Cubs' sixth straight loss.
CAIRO, June 7 (AP) -- An Arab league source said today that the Arab states were insisting, before agreeing to a truce in Palestine, on the following four major conditions:

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., June 7 (AP) -- A hopeful note of settling a month-long labor dispute in an atomic energy plant without a strike was sounded today as contract negotiations were renewed. The optimism was voiced by Thomas E. Lane, industrial relations director of Carbide and Carbon Chemicals Corporation, who said some progress had been made in new talks with officials of the AFL Atomic Trades and Labor Council.

NUREMBERG, Germany, June 7 -- Hypocrisy killed the League of Nations, Ernst yon Weizsaecker, German Ambassador to the Vatican during the war years, asserted this afternoon as he took the witness stand in his own defense at the trial here of former Wilhelmstrasse diplomats.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 7 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, British amateur champion, and a dozen other Americans will bid for the British open golf championship at Muirfield starting June 28.

VIENNA, June 7 -- The International Socialist Conference ended its labors today after declaring for socialization of the Ruhr, international control of all key factors of economic power in Europe and restoration of German political unity.
WEST POINT, N.Y., June 7 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, arrived at the United States Military Academy today and will address the 301 graduates at commencement exercises tomorrow morning.

An issue of $1,500,000 of bonds of Independent School District No. 1, Galena Park, Tex., will come up for sale on June 10. The bonds are dated July 1, 1948, and will come due on each July 15 from 1949 to 1982. They are callable on July 15, 1968.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 7 -- The new United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America began three weeks of sessions here with a meeting this afternoon in the Congress building. Foreign Minister German Vergara Donoso and other Chilean cabinet members and delegates from twenty-two countries including the United States, Britain, France and the Netherlands attended.

The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Mr. Millikin of Colorado, indicated yesterday that this group would probably vote approval of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements program largely as it stands. The principal departure from the President's recommendation would be a reduction in the period of renewal this time from three years to one.

The Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $46,289,211 after all charges, including $32,335,855 provision for taxes, for the nine months ended on April 30.

We welcome the prompt statements of Governor Dewey and Harold E. Stassen, urging that the cuts made in funds for the European Recovery Program by the House Republicans under the leadership of Chairman Taber be canceled and that the full amounts which Congress itself authorized only eight weeks ago be restored at once.

Demand that all meat exports to countries receiving aid under the European Recovery Program be stopped immediately was contained in a resolution passed unanimously yesterday by the New York State Association of Retail Meat Dealers at their annual convention in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court reversed yesterday a ruling of Max Meyer, arbitrator, in a labor dispute between the Western Union Telegraph Company and the American Communications Association, CIO, which directed the telegraph company to reinstate sixty-two of its employes suspended for their refusal to handle "hot" traffic.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its decision banning the cement industry's system of multiple basing point delivered prices.
DETROIT, Mich., June 7 -- After nearly reaching a settlement, the United Automobile Workers, CIO, broke off bargaining today with the Briggs Manufacturing Company, automotive parts supplier.

PARIS, June 7 -- The decision of the House of Representatives to reduce the allotments of United States aid has greatly hampered Foreign Minister Georges Bidault as he prepares to ask the French National Assembly to approve the London accords on Germany, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- With a characteristic split on economic and social philosophy, the Supreme Court of the United States rejected by a 5-4 decision today efforts of the Government to block the addition of another independent steel producer to the growing family of the United States Steel Corporation.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 7 (AP) -- Troops in the eastern prong of the Arab thrust into Palestine's "thumb" in the northeast are prodding the area between Lake Hule and the Sea of Galilee.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Ray Scarborough's four-hit pitching lifted Washington to a 7-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox and into undisputed possession of fourth place in the American League here tonight.
BERLIN, June 7 -- The first steps in the formation of a Western German state will be taken in Frankfort on the Main on June 15.
ATHENS, June 7 (AP) -- A palace announcement today said former King Michael of Rumania and Princess Anne of Bourbon-Parma would be married here Thursday.

A Congress which has been handling billions of dollars will face an important $4,000,000 issue during the next two weeks. This is the question of an initial appropriation to begin work on an $84,000,000 steam plant at New Johnsonville, Tenn., to supplement TVA's hydraulic output during low-water seasons.
CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) -- The "Fifty Outstanding Religious Books of the Year" were announced today by the Religious Books Round Table of the American Library Association.

The six-power plan for Western Germany, announced yesterday, probably will provide an index of Russian intentions in what Washington calls the "new phase" of United States-Russian relations now opening.

WHITE PLANTS, N.Y., June 7 -- Overcrowding at Tibbetts Brook Park in Yonkers, a 161-acre area of lakes, playgrounds, dining pavilions and a swimming pool operated by the Westchester County Park Commission, has become so acute that the police are unable to preserve order, Supervisor William I. Rodier of Yonkers told the County Board of Supervisors here today.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The West Virginia Water Service Company, Charleston, W. Va., submitted a registration statement for 8,000 shares of $5 preferred stock, no par value, that will be offered to the public at $100 a share. The company proposes to use the proceeds to retire $400,000 of loans held by the First National Bank of Boston and finance construction.

LONDON, June 7 -- Despite Senator Vandenberg's fight to stave off the proposed 25 per cent cut in the European aid program, the uncertainty of the situation led to further selling in the stock market here today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 7 -- Three hundred members of the Westchester County Republican Committee met today at the county center here and designated candidates to run in the August primary for nomination for eleven state and national legislative positions.

Hezekiah Cobb says that he is much interested in the idea advanced by the Director of the National Highway Users' Conference that the flow of traffic to New York City is being slowly strangled by a deadly encirclement of tollgates.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 -- President Truman's fact-finding board in the maritime dispute was described today as "a kangaroo court" as a two-man West Coast panel heard demands of unions on this coast.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- Herbert March of Chicago and Meyer Stern of New York, left-wing officials of the United Packinghouse Workers of America, CIO, have resigned, it was learned today. Mr. March is U.P.W.A. Chicago district director and also a member of the national committee of the Communist party.

Late buying in selected motor issues yesterday stemmed a decline in the stock market, although the force of the demand proved inadequate to change the course. Prices backed down on the lightest of pressure as business on the Stock Exchange contracted to 930,000 shares, the smallest volume in two months, compared with 1,100,000 shares on Friday.
POCATELLO, Idaho, June 7 -- President Truman asserted here today that there were interests, with allies in Congress, which were trying to restore the public utilities abuses of the Insull era.

Food prices will rise if the city adopts its proposal to raise the general business and financial tax by $30,000,000 this year, the City Council finance committee was told by spokesmen for the food industry at a City Hall hearing yesterday.

There was nothing in the way of stakes appeal on the racing card at Belmont Park yesterday, the nominal feature being the $4,000 Blandy purse. Nevertheless a crowd of 23,186 turned out for the day's activities, with price distribution in the competition being so generally satisfactory that, in the parlance of the paddock, "nobody got hurt."

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 7 -- Expressing the hope that Dr. Eduard Benes would be able to get out of Czechoslovakia now that he has resigned the Presidency, Dr. Jan Papanek, former Czech delegate to the United Nations, said today that Jan Masaryk was ready to leave the country the very day he was found dead.

LOS ANGELES, June 7 -- World developments, including a "real threat" of communism for the United States, call for the projection of Kiwanis International into the realm of public affairs, the organization's convention was told today.

The Park Association of New York City sent telegrams yesterday to Senator Styles Bridges, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, and Senators Robert F. Wagner and Irving M. Ives, both of New York, urging Senate approval of a $500,000 appropriation for improvements to the Statue of Liberty.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 7 -- The streets of this resort were crowded today by fez-wearing delegates to the seventy-fourth annual convention of the Ancient Arabic Order, Nobles of the Mystic Shrine.

Promising a major reorganization of the Welfare Department by July 1, Raymond M. Hilliard, Welfare Commissioner, said yesterday that nothing short of that step would meet the criticisms developed in three recent official investigations of welfare administration.

A champion of Zionism, a member of the International Court of Justice, a seamstress who became a concert soprano, a London fishmonger in a ten-gallon hat and actors, golfers and pugilists were among the 1,859 passengers who arrived here yesterday from abroad on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

HOVE, Sussex, June 7 (Reuters) -- On the eve of the first test cricket match between England and Australia, the tourists scored an easy victory over Sussex here today by an innings and 325 runs. Don Bradman, the Australian captain, scored his fourth century of the tour.

Rocky Graziano reached the end of his training grind yesterday for the defense of his world middle-weigh title tomorrow night in Ruppert Stadium, Newark, against Tony Zale, and the former champion was in a garrulous mood.

The National Piano Manufacturers Association will start a nine-month joint advertising and promotion campaign in September, it was announced yesterday by Robert A. Hill, president of the Aeolian American Corporation, at the association's fifty-first annual meeting in the New Yorker Hotel.

After disposing of the proposed civil rights amendments to the Selective Service Act that had appeared to be the principal barrier to passage, the Senate has moved purposefully to the forecast approval of a straightforward and workable plan for providing the manpower that is immediately needed to bring the military services to a state of defense readiness.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 8 (AP) -- Leading from start to finish, F.M. Poncelet's Charing Rock today won the feature at Narragansett Park by a length and a half over Marlet Stable's Mr. McGregor.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., June 8 -- Mrs. Ralph Neuberger of the home club turned in a 4-and-2 victory over Mrs. Karl Rosenberg of Inwood in a first-round match of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class B match play championship at the North Shore Country Club today.

According to those best qualified to judge -- the atomic scientists and other experts -- the hot war toward which the United States and Russia are now drifting is a war of absolute weapons capable of destroying so many of the vital parts of a nation that the power to recover is lost for generations or forever.
BERLIN, June 8 -- German reaction to the plans of the Western powers for establishment of a state in Western Germany and for control of the Ruhr is almost exclusively negative.

The Citizens Committee to Defeat Marcantonio approved last night eight persons acceptable as possible coalition candidates for Representative in the Eighteenth Congressional District, from which Representative Vito Marcantonio now is completing his fifth term.
NEW ORLEANS, June 8 -- Argentina and Uruguay will funnel their vast wool production through the Foreign Trade Zone here, according to plans announced today by Argentine Senator Diego Luis Molinari.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- Wheat futures were firmer at the start of business today on the Board of Trade, but reacted moderately. The market, however, held in a narrow price range. There was some local selling, and moderate hedge sales came from the Southwest, but heavy purchases by the Commodity Credit Corporation for the Saturday-Monday period modified bearish sentiment.

The port of Haifa has been restored to the itinerary of the government-owned, emergency class passenger vessel Marine Carp, which is scheduled to leave here on Friday, Maritime Commission spokesmen announced yesterday. They said the action was taken on a State Department order that reversed the department's previous "recommendation" that Haifa be dropped as a port of call.
The first load of steel and steel scrap from Japan has been offered to American industrialists by the Japanese Board of Trade, it was disclosed here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- What a member of Congress says in a Capitol cloakroom conversation is immune to lawsuit, Judge T. Alan Goldsborough ruled yesterday in Federal District Court.

The New York University College of Medicine held yesterday "last day" exercises at the Carnegie Lecture Hall, 338 East Twenty-sixth Street, for the 132 men and women who will receive medical degrees today at Ohio Field on University Heights.

LOS ANGELES, June 8 -- The golfing greats of the nation are entering the final preliminaries today prior to the start of the forty-eighth United States Open championship on Thursday at the Riviera Country Club, the longest course on which this test has ever been held.
LONDON, June 8 -- Both Jews and Arabs are recruiting soldiers for war in Palestine among Germany's displaced persons camps, The Jewish Chronicle, London weekly newspaper, reports.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The privately owned American merchant fleet in active service on June 1 comprised 1,117 vessels, or slightly more than the 1,092 operating on June 1, 1938, the National Federation of American Shipping reported here today.

COVENTRY, England, June 8 -- British automobile manufacturers are far from agreed about the wisdom of the Government's proposals that the industry should seek a permanent foothold in the United States volume market. This is apparent in any tour of this area, where most of Britain's automotive plants are situated.

Grover A. Whalen, chairman of Mayor O'Dwyer's golden anniversary committee, sent tickets yesterday for Saturday's "New York At Work" parade to Mrs. Bertha Wurster Couch, daughter of Brooklyn's last Mayor before the city consolidation, after being informed that she had not been invited to attend the opening of the anniversary period.

Speaking at three rallies last night in Brooklyn, Senator Glen H. Taylor, Vice Presidential running mate of Henry A. Wallace, chided President Truman for "issuing a propaganda barrage of messages and speeches at the last minute to cover up Democratic failure."

Today's events in Manhattan -- Mozart's "Don Giovanni," the Lemonade Opera, Greenwich Mews Playhouse, 141 West Thirteenth Street, 8:30 P.M.; Program of recorded music, New York Public Library, 12 noon; Dessoff Choir Summer Sing, Henry S. Drinker, conductor, 130 West Fifty-sixth Street, 8; Philippa Schuyler, piano, Townsend Harris Auditorium, City College, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Senate Republican leaders conceded today that only the faintest hope now remained of reaching their long-held objective of adjourning Congress on June 19.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- Washington mauled Bryan Stephens and Clem Dreisewerd for twelve hits, including a home run by Ed Stewart, to defeat the Browns, 6 -- 5, tonight. Milo Candini, second of the three Senators' pitchers, received credit for the victory, his first.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 8 -- Divertissements for children and adults, as well as sale of varied useful and decorative articles, have been planned for the Fair in behalf of all Long Island charities, to be held on the grounds of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Advent, Jericho Turnpike, throughout Friday afternoon.
PAOTOW, China, June 5 (Delayed) -- The flight of a Buriat Mongol tribe from communism, which began thirty years ago in Soviet Siberia, is being brought to an end on the grasslands west of Paotow.

VIENNA, June 8 -- The recent Russo-United States friction in Vienna, which reached a climax last week when a squad of armed Soviet soldiers kidnapped an American and a Russian from the British military police, was to have been the subject of a talk today between Col. Gen. Vladimir Kurasov, the Soviet commander, and Lieut. Gen. Geoffrey Keyes, commander of United States forces in Austria.
GENEVA, June 8 -- The discovery of what is believed to be one of the worst pellagra regions in the world is reported by nutrition experts recently returned from Rumania.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's rackets bureau scored yesterday in Special Sessions its most successful victory in the current drive on rent gougers when it won the conviction of two more persons and obtained guilty pleas from two others. One of the latter is a 43-year-old woman real estate broker who had been accused of extorting $19,350 in illegal fees.

ROME, June 8 -- A considerable number of displaced persons with previous experience in teaching expect to be resettled in the United States under a plan sponsored by the War Relief Services of the National Catholic Welfare Council of New York.
BUENOS AIRES, June 8 -- While Peron Government spokesmen insist that the planned economy in Argentina is here to stay two influential papers have dared to come out strongly against it.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The United States will trade with Russia and the Soviet satellite countries of eastern Europe on a "quid pro quo" basis for an indefinite period, Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer said here today. He emphasized, in a news conference, that this meant a relatively equal exchange of commodities, on a license basis for United States exports, in so far as these could be fitted into this country's international trade program.

A 21-year-old champion, Miss Patricia O'Sullivan of Orange, Conn., took a two-stroke lead as the first round of the women's Eastern 54-hole medal play championship got under way over the hilly North Hills Golf Club course at Douglaston, Queens, yesterday.

In the annual commencement exercises of Fordham College last night in the university gymnasium 192 graduates received their diplomas. The Most Rev. Thomas J. McDonnell, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, presided.

A window cleaner dangled unconscious at the end of one strap of his safety belt for nearly fifteen minutes yesterday morning after slipping from a ledge outside the bedroom of a fourth-floor apartment at 1030 Fifth Avenue.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 8 -- Plans to make the Benelux economic union of Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg fully effective in 1950, were adopted at a two-day meeting, which ended today, of Ministers and other high officials of the three countries.

London, June 8 -- The name of the doctor attending Princess Elizabeth, who is expecting a baby in October, was disclosed today. He is William Gilliatt, who practices in Mayfair's fashionable Brook Street and delivered the Duchess of Kent's three children.

ATHENS, June 8 -- The first answer to the Greek Government's request for the return of children abducted by the Greek rebels and distributed in Russian satellite countries was received at the Foreign Ministry tonight. It came from Hungary.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- An end to "hobby" lessons for veterans and a cut in funds for the Atomic Energy Commission were recommended today by the House Appropriations Committee.
In your editorial of May 31, "The Road to Despotism," you refer to the former easternmost province of Czechoslovakia as "Carpatho-Ukraine."

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 8 (AP) -- Yale University was named today to represent District 1 at the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Eastern baseball tournament at Winston-Salem, N.C., June 15 to 17.

Harold Riegelman, counsel for the Citizens Budget Committee, was elected chairman of the New York chapter of the American Jewish Committee last night at the chapter's annual meeting at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel.
After blocking an effort yesterday to revise a bill barring pinball machines in the city, the City Council cleared the way for final action on the measure at its meeting on Tuesday in City Hall.

CINCINNATI, June 8 -- The Dodgers today refrained from using that shuttle they had been riding between sixth and seventh places. By beating the Reds, 6 -- 5, they took a game and a half lead over Johnny Neun's seventh-placers.

Upsets were the order of the afternoon at Belmont Park yesterday, with the blows suffered by the favorite players in the crowd of 21,829 reaching the knockout stage in the $5,500 added Class C Hunters Island Handicap, in which the order of finish was the exact reverse of the order of favoritism.

BERLIN, June 8 -- To overcome the lack of long-term credit facilities for large-scale building projects, finance officials of the United States Military Government will ask the Bizonal Economic Administration to set up a reconstruction loan corporation, it was learned today.

PARIS, June 8 -- The situation in the French Cabinet became tense again today, when after having heard Foreign Minister Bidault it decided to submit the London accords on Germany to the National Assembly. The Ministers declined to say that the accords had been approved and there were indications that some Cabinet members wanted to append reservations.

No matter how hot the weather may be, the housewife has cooking to do. The temperature in the kitchen may seem very close to the 325 degrees F. to which the oven is turned, but dinner with at least one warm dish must be prepared.

When Field Marshal Earl Wavell was installed a few days ago as 146th Constable of the Tower of London, amid the splendid pageantry demanded by the tradition of centuries, Britons again bewildered those who think of them as colorless by suddenly revealing themselves once more as possessed of the secret of clothing their ceremonial doings in a colorfulness such as few nations can equal and fewer surpass.

ELLIS GIBBS ARNALL, the highly articulate former Governor of Georgia, is an unusual man. Enlightened, honest, courageous and able, he stands at one extreme of Georgia politics. The supporters of the Talmadge machine, of course, stand at the other. A politician with the politician's habit of indulging in glib generalizations and careless exaggerations, he never avoids unpleasant realities and controversial issues.
B.C. Ohlandt, formerly with Schenley Distillers Corporation, has joined National Distillers Products Corporation as sales manager of the monopoly state division.

The City Rent Commission granted to the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church yesterday certificates for the eviction of twenty-four families from the apartment building at 47 Claremont Avenue.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill requiring the retirement by July 1 of five-star Admirals Ernest J. King and Chester W. Nimitz.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Sir Oliver Franks, new British Ambassador, asked today for understanding of his country's approach to the Palestine problem.

Once more, for the thirty-first consecutive season, New Yorkers have an opportunity to hear some of the world's finest music played and sung by top-flight musicians at New York's Lewisohn Stadium. Here lovers of music may listen to great melodies in a setting of spaciousness, with a clear view of the night skies.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 8 -- Jacob A. Malik sat as the Soviet delegate to the Security Council for the first time today and kept a firm grip on his position as the United Nations' most silent diplomat.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday made an all-time record of 3,973 against 920 last week and 2,578 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,735 arrivals yesterday compared with 313 last Tuesday.
Twenty-four City College students were named yesterday to the school's chapter of Phi Beta Kappa after elections held at the Plaza Hotel. The new members are:

BERLIN, June 8 -- A German reporter who set out to sit up with a sick friend seven months ago has turned out to be a spy for the United States and Britain, according to the Soviet-licensed A.D.N. news agency. Tonight the agency circulated a long statement that it said was signed by Dieter Friede, a German journalist who disappeared on Nov. 2 of last year.
A neatly dressed matron from a small up-state village was arraigned in Felony Court here yesterday on charges of forgery and grand larceny.

A new high record of $309,213,000 in combined sales of the six department stores in the R. H. Macy Co., Inc., group was reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on May 1. Commenting on the quarterly statement, Jack I. Straus, president, stated that this represented the highest volume in the company's history and a rise of 9.7 per cent above the $281,859,000 reported a year before.
Graduation exercises of the eleventh and largest class of the Tobe-Coburn School for Fashion Careers were held yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

As president of Columbia University, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is deeply concerned with the need for increased adult education opportunities to help preserve our traditional freedoms, it was reported yesterday by Dr. Harry J. Carman, dean of Columbia College.

The action of the British House of Lords in voting away the right of its members to trial by a jury of peers of their own or higher rank will not shake the world. Nor will it, probably, either increase or decrease the tendency of British Lords to commit crimes. As a rule they do not steal, forge checks, break into other people's houses or commit murder.
LONDON, June 8 -- The Duke of Edinburgh was installed today as a citizen and fishmonger of the City of London.

The membership of American labor unions rose in 1947 to 14,280,000, Prof. Leo Wolman of Columbia University, who is carrying on research into wages and trades unionism for the National Bureau of Economic Research, said in a preliminary report released yesterday by the bureau.

LONDON, June 8 -- A Government-sponsored Working Party, after an investigation of all the major docks in Britain, recommended in its report issued today that consultative panels representing all port interests be established to advise on the allocation of labor during peak periods.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Southern Democrats, still up in arms at President Truman's demand for sweeping civil rights legislation, are preparing to make inclusion of a states' rights plank in the party platform the first big test at the National Convention next month.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., June 8 -- Union workers at the atomic laboratory here voted unanimously tonight to hold themselves ready for a strike on twenty-four hours' notice. One of their leaders said, however, "Things are halfway favorable for a settlement."
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Midland Terminal Railway Company, which has been hauling gold ore out of the Colorado mountains for sixty-two years, asked permission today to go out of business.

Mrs. Bleriot H. Lamarre, who was private secretary to Bennett E. Meyers when he was a major general with the Army Air Forces, filed yesterday with the clerk of the United States District Court in Brooklyn a $250,000 defamation of character suit against the former officer.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 8 -- Richard Maibaum has taken over production of "A Mask for Lucretia" at Paramount, and Ray Milland and Paulette Goddard have been named for the leading roles in the film, which is scheduled for the cameras next month, the studio announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Senate overrode recommendations of its Armed Services Committee tonight and reduced the duration of the proposed selective draft from five years to two.

Station WOR has selected North Bergen, N.J., as the transmitter site for its television outlet, WOR-TV, which is expected to go on the air on Channel 9 in the fall, Theodore C. Streibert, president of the station, announced yesterday.

The six-Power agreement on Germany has been approved promptly by the American, British and French Governments, and will undoubtedly find equal approval by the three Benelux countries. But it still has to surmount two formidable hurdles -- namely, the final French and German attitudes toward it. On these attitudes will depend its success or failure.

GENEVA, June 8 -- The draft of a new international transport agreement giving commercial vehicles the same facilities for temporary crossings of international frontiers as those now accorded to tourist automobiles was released here today.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. declared last night that the third party movement, headed by Henry A. Wallace, is, whether Mr. Wallace realizes it or not, "an accomplice of the Soviet offensive against the United States and free institutions everywhere."

Three new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At Loew's Criterion, the attraction is "The Lady From Shanghai," a Columbia melodrama starring Orson Welles and Rita Hayworth. Welles wrote the screen play, directed and produced the offering from a novel by Sherwood King.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UP) -- Senator Kenneth S. Wherry, Republican, of Nebraska, told steel industry officials today they would be saddled with compulsory allocations if they fail to improve distribution of steel.

As the City Council received a majority-backed proposal for a new five-man salaried board to check pollution of the city's air, members of the Smoke Prevention Association of America heard that improved combustion methods could eliminate harbor smoke.

Federal authorities began yesterday a nation-wide search for a handsome Danish sailor who disappeared on his way from Nebraska to face charges here that he mulcted a 49-year-old spinster of $17,700 while posing as the heir to baronial estates in Denmark and promising to marry her.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- John L. Lewis and counsel for the United Mine Workers today filed an answer in the Federal District Court to Ezra Van Horn, Welfare Fund trustee who is seeking to prevent payment of pensions to coal miners from the $40,000,000 welfare fund for 1947.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. John Cowles of Minneapolis of the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Richardson, to John Marshall Bullitt, son of Mrs. Donald M. Payson of Portland, Me., and the late Keith L. Bullitt of Los Angeles.
Minor rule changes and the approval of nineteen new delegates, an unusually large number, occupied the delegates of the American Kennel Club at their meeting in the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

The signing of a two-year contract between Todd Shipyards Corporation and Locals 15 and 39 of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, was announced yesterday by John D. Reilly, president of the corporation. The present contract expires June 23.

PARIS, June 8 -- Forty-four Jews are reported to have been killed by Arabs in Algeria in the last two days. Thirty-nine were killed and twenty-five wounded in Djerada today, while five were killed and thirty wounded in Oudja yesterday.

In a pitching duel of southpaws, Larry Cotillo gained the victory over Ray Schulz as Brooklyn Tech won the Brooklyn P.S.A.L. baseball championship, beating Abraham Lincoln at Ebbets Field yesterday, 1-0. Cotillo gave five hits and Schulz four.

Fabric makers were accused last night of wanting to continue their profits of the past few years without consideration of the needs of retailers and consumers. Thomas F. O'Donnell, divisional merchandise manager of ready-to-wear for Cavendish Trading Corporation, made his charges at a meeting of the Ready-to-Wear Group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Republicans closed ranks in the Senate Finance Committee today and obtained approval of a one-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act with revisions opposed by the Administration but less drastic than those voted by the House.

Members of the largest graduating class in New York University's history will formally complete their academic careers today at 10:30 A.M., when the university will celebrate its ll6th commencement with exercises at Ohio Field on the University Heights campus.
Today, June 9, is the forty-fifth day of the Greater New York Fund's eleventh annual campaign in behalf of 423 local hospitals, health and welfare agencies.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 8 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator in Palestine, notified the Security Council today that he had fixed the time for the start of a truce and cease-fire in the Holy Land for Friday at 6 A.M. (Greenwich Mean Time, 2 A.M. New York Time).
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered nine New England brick manufacturers to end what the commission called a price-fixing combination.

Requests for a delay in enforcement of a recent ban by the Eastern College Athletic Conference on participation of college baseball players in the Vermont Northern League and other resort circuits were in the hands of the E.C.A.C. executive council yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

ROME, June 8 -- Blows were struck in the Italian Senate today for the first time in the 150 years of its history when Communist and anti-Communist Senators clashed on the floor of the House during the discussion of the fate suffered by Italian war prisoners in Russia.

Former President Herbert Hoover is "one of the most maligned statesmen in American history," but is "gradually winning back the favor of the people," Eugene Lyons, former leftist writer, declared here yesterday. He spoke at a press interview in the offices of Doubleday Co., 14 West Forty-ninth Street.
LITCHFIELD, Conn., June 8 (AP) -- The townspeople of Litchfield have voted to "adopt" Lichfield, England.
New issues of railroad and public utility securities totaling $27,460,000 were awarded at competitive sale yesterday to underwriting syndicate managers, as follows:

The Senate Finance Committee yesterday adopted the House tariff bill in modified form. The Senate version carries an amendment which throws out a House provision giving Congress veto power over tariff rates negotiated by the President. However, it contains, in lieu of this, a provision under which he would have to notify Congress within thirty days if he should approve tariffs going beyond "peril points" that may have been established by the Tariff Commission.
JERUSALEM, June 8 (AP) -- The heaviest guns of the Trans-Jordan Arab Legion placed under fire today a new lifeline road secretly built by the Haganah to help the 90,000 besieged Jews in Jerusalem.

Freedom of speech was written into the United States Constitution in technologically simple days. The wildest dreams of the Founding Fathers did not include sound trucks. Hence the Supreme Court has just found it necessary to decide whether limits can constitutionally be placed on the volume of sound a person exercising this right can produce, and in a case involving the city of Lockport, N.Y., by a by a 5-to-4 vote, that they cannot.
LONDON, June 8 -- About a hundred foreign Bishops of the Anglican Communion have already reached Britain for the greatest Lambeth Conference in history that is to open here July 4.

Silvio Burigo, Fordham third baseman, who was named to the Metropolitan Conference all-star team, was accorded another honor by his teammates yesterday as they selected him most valuable player on the Ram nine. He joins players on seven other squads so named who will be given a gold watch by the University athletic association.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 8 (AP) -- Gov. Robert D. Blue and Representative John W. Gwynne were defeated for Republican renomination in yesterday's state primary, returns showed today. Organized labor expressed "complete satisfaction," with the results.

ROME, June 8 -- Charges that the Italian clergy played upon the religious feeling of the masses to influence last April's national elections in favor of the pro-Catholic Christian Democratic party were made today by I'Unita, the Communist party newspaper.
PRAGUE, June 8 (AP) -- Jaroslav Drobny of Czechoslovakia defeated Frank Parker, American tennis star, in an exhibition match today, 6 -- 3, 5 -- 7, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3.

As an example of the well-known tendency of red tape to reproduce itself, spread and entangle everything within reach, the following case from England may be of interest to your readers, and encourage them to fight this pest wherever they encounter it.

Speaking yesterday at City Hall as honorary national chairman of the American Overseas Aid-United Nations Appeal for Children, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said the campaign sought to eradicate "hatred and bitterness" among the world's starving children.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee formally approved today its "one-package" bill to commit the United States to the principle of military aid to alliances formed among the world's free nations. The vote, it was announced, was unanimous.

The American Broadcasting Company has listed a gross time charge of $3,850 per hour for ten stations in issuing the industry's first television-network rate card, it was announced yesterday. Fees for studio rehearsals and provision of mobile units to advertisers for remote pick-ups are also covered.

MEXICO CITY, June 8 -- Much more attractive contracts than have been awarded previously by Mexico since expropriation of foreign oil interests ten years ago may result from intensive negotiations being conducted this week by several American groups with the Mexican Government for drilling new wells and exploitation of the country's vast reserves that remain untapped, it was made known today.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- American imports dropped from a record high of $666,200,000 in March to $527,200,000 in April, the lowest figure in five months, the Census Bureau reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Seven United States Navy and Marine officers left here today for Palestine, where they will be joined by seven Army and seven Air Force officers from the European theatre to serve as truce observers.

BUDAPEST, June 8 -- The battle between the Communist-dominated Hungarian Government and the Hungarian Catholic Church, led by Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, over the nationalization of education reached a decisive stage today.

The air-transport industry will observe with great interest the reception accorded the stock offering later this month by United Air Lines, one of the four major domestic carriers. United will offer 369,618 shares of its common stock to present shareholders on June 28 to raise funds for capital expenditures, debt retirement and other purposes.

LONDON, June 8 -- When negotiations begin in Washington this week on terms of the bilateral agreements between the United States and the countries participating in the European Recovery Program, it is understood that the sixteen countries unanimously will request modification of the draft agreements prepared by the Economic Cooperation Administration, which they consider too exacting and stringent.

PEARL HARBOR, June 8 -- The battleships New York and Nevada, veterans of the atomic bomb tests at Bikini, and now moored in Pearl Harbor, will be sunk in July about fifty miles off Oahu as a climax to the Navy's Eniwetok experiment, The Honolulu Advertiser will say tomorrow morning.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 8 -- The United States delegation issued an unprecedented appeal to Congress today to pass the $65,000,000 United Nations headquarters loan or face the danger of removal of the site to another country.

Gen. John M. Franklin, president of United States Lines, informed shareholders at the annual meeting held yesterday in Hoboken, N.J., that the company's present financial condition will permit it to maintain the $2.50 annual dividend rate on the common stock.
JERUSALEM, June 8 -- The Haganah, Zionist army, opened to inspection today its first prisoner-of-war camp in Palestine. The camp holds slightly more than 100 captives, about 15 to 60 years old.
In your issue of May 9, Section 4, there appears an editorial regarding postal workers' pay. On the last page of the same section you print an article by Joseph A. Loftus, "Uncle Sam is Raising Pay."

Cleveland sold yesterday $12,000,000 of water works revenue bonds due from 1953 to 1972 to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at an interest cost of 2.236 per cent. Other bids ranged in interest cost from 2.24 per cent to 2.33 per cent.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- The Savoy Oil Company, Inc., of Tulsa, Okla., registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed offering of 150,000 shares of common stock.

BUTTE, Mont., June 8 -- President Truman declared with great asperity tonight that Congress should stay on the job until it passed a farm bill, set up price controls and approved a low-cost housing measure. All pretense that this was a nonpolitical tour was dropped when the Chief Executive made a bitter attack on Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican contender for the Presidential nomination.

Peonies, for the first time in a decade, are the theme of a two-day flower show in New York. Sponsored by the Horticultural Society of New York on the fifteenth floor at 598 Madison Avenue, the exhibits were opened to the public yesterday afternoon, and also may be seen from 10 A.M. until 4 P.M. today.

BERLIN, June 8 -- The United States will ship in all the food necessary to keep the population of its sector in Berlin alive if the Russians should cut off rail transport of supplies into the city, Col. Frank Howley, United States representative on the Berlin Kommandatura, told a press conference for German newspaper men today.

DETROIT, June 8 -- Clarence Day's "Life With Mother," a sequel to "Life With Father," and by the same authors, Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse, had its premiere tonight before an enthusiastic full house at the Cass Theatre.
Cotton futures were rather dull on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Final prices were 7 to 11 points net lower than Monday's closing levels.

In the first such action ever taken by a division of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, a group of transportation inspectors employed by the Third Avenue Transit Corporation has voted to condemn The Daily Worker for "interference" in the union's internal affairs and for attacks on Mayor O'Dwyer and City Councilman Michael J. Quill, the union's international president.

Refrigerator dollar volume in the last two weeks has increased from 30 to 60 per cent in department stores and from 40 to 75 per cent in some home furnishings chains, buyers and merchandize manager reported yesterday. Most outlets expect to chalk up a minimum gain of 30 per cent for the first six months over the corresponding period last year.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (U.P.) -- When the Government was selling its surplus radio equipment after the war ended it was not reckoning on a pair of teen-aged customers with a penchant for practical jokes.

A plea for political judgments based not on "labels" but on what is "intrinsically just and honest and right" was made yesterday by Lester Lawrence D. Steefel of Minneapolis, a national co-chairman of the Women for Wallace movement.

Congressional efforts to curtail funds already earmarked for the European Recovery Program were condemned yesterday by the executive committee of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America.

BOSTON, June 8 (AP) -- The Indians tonight blanked the Red Sox, 2 -- 0, on Manager Lou Boudreau's disputed two-run homer into the right-field seats in the fourth inning. The vast majority of 33,032 paid fans and the Red Sox claimed the ball left the playing field on the grandstand side of the foul pole but Umpire Charlie Berry held fast to his decision that the blow was a home run.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- A bill raising railroad pensions 20 per cent and cutting railroad unemployment contributions passed the House today, 380 to 0. It now goes to the Senate.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 8 -- Karl Rex Hammers of Pittsburgh, Pa., retiring Imperial Potentate of the Ancient Arabic Order, Nobles of the Mystic Shrine of North America, urged today that all Americans be 'a'lert to the vicious propaganda against Americanism -- the envy of those whose efforts have not been blessed with success in government."

LONDON, June 8 -- News from Washington that Republican party leaders favored the restoration of the proposed cuts in the European Recovery Program cheered the stock market here today. Sentiment also was helped by Sir Stafford Cripps' hint that the tax on bonus issues may be repealed in the next budget.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8 -- Robert E. Dineen, Superintendent of Insurance of New York State, announced here today that a joint committee of insurance commissioners and the industry will undertake a broad investigation of the problem of evaluating the privately purchased portfolios of insurance companies.

As Congress acts to cut down ERP appropriations for Western Europe, the Soviet Government cuts down its reparation claims in Eastern Europe. First Finland was relieved of a portion of the debt that has kept the Finns toiling nearly half time for Russia during the past two years.

The finest flowering of toiles de Jouy, the decorative fabrics printed with monochromatic scenic designs and widely imitated today, is dramatized in an exhibition that opened last evening at the Cultural Division of the French Embassy, 934 Fifth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- An effort in the House Education and Labor Committee to get Federal aid to education to the floor failed today on a parliamentary point but revealed strength behind the measure.

BALTIMORE, June 8 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York was told tonight that he could count on at least ten, and possibly fourteen, of Maryland's sixteen delegate votes for the Republican nomination for President. There is an outside chance, it was said, that he might get all sixteen.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 8 -- While the economic development of Asia and the Far East is hindered by problems that range from food shortage to the political tension between the United States and the Soviet Union, the war has bound the countries of Asia more closely together economically, the United Nations Secretariat reported here today.

The stock market emerged yesterday from a three weeks' period of consolidation and came within striking distance of the year's previous high. A gradual rise developed into a full-fledged upturn in the final hour and, under the leadership of the heavy industrials, prices were enlarged 1 to 3 points.

Fearing a shortage, the city Board of Health decided yesterday in an unusual action to allow milk and cream produced outside the approved New York milkshed to be imported here for sale under certain restrictions.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 8 -- Proposed entry of the American Federation of Musicians into the record-manufacturing business to avoid the Taft-Hartley Law has been discarded, it was announced here today before the second session of the fifty-first annual convention.

The National Maritime Union will strike on Tuesday if no contract agreement has been reached by that time, Joseph Curran, president of the union, told President Truman's fact-finding board yesterday at a hearing in the Roosevelt Hotel.

Herbert McKenley, the streamlined runner from Jamaica who lowered his own world 440-yard record to 46 seconds flat last Saturday at Berkeley, Calif., arrived in New York by air yesterday to prepare for the Sydenham Hospital Benefit Meet at Randalls Island Stadium on Saturday.

NANKING, June 8 -- Roger D. Lapham, Economic Cooperation Administration director for China, arrived here today and had preliminary talks with officials amid uncertainty about the final shape of aid to China.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 8 -- Welcomed into the Army and Air Force by James Forrestal Secretary of Defense, as soldiers for peace, 301 cadets of the United States Military Academy received their diplomas here today at the annual commencement exercises.

Amid New York City's many problems the child who, through no fault of its own, has no home must surely have a primary claim on the sympathy of our people and upon community responsibility, official and unofficial. The size of this problem may be surprising, even shocking, to those who may have thought that, because millions of dollars are spent on child care every year, the need was being fully met.
