LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 8 -- Despite India's "emphatic protests," the United Nations Security Council decided today not to rewrite the resolution empowering the Kashmir Commission to look into all aspects of the India-Pakistan controversies.

The squabble over who dropped bottles in Tibbetts Brook Park began to boil yesterday and was on the way to rivaling the mystery of the overalls in Mrs. Murphy's chowder. No music to date, only words, some of them harsh.
BUFFALO, N.Y., June 8 (AP) -- J.E. Denmark, vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, Ga., said here today that the public had become more "trust conscious."
PRAGUE, June 8 -- Czechoslovakia's Communist Premier, Klement Gottwald, has signed the Constitution that Dr. Eduard Benes refused to approve before he resigned yesterday as President.

PITTSBURGH, June 8 (AP) -- Pitt, whose football path has been rocky since hoisting the amateur standard a decade ago, reached a crossroads today with the resignation of Athletic Director James (White) Hagan.

Lumber production for the first quarter of the current year totaled 8,221,000,000 board feet, a decrease of 0.3 per cent compared with a year ago, according to the quarterly report of the Lumber Survey Committee released yesterday to the Secretary of Commerce.

Non-tuition courses in teacher education on a graduate level will be made available in the city's four municipal colleges this fall to 900 state residents, Dr. Paul Klapper, temporary dean of teacher education, announced yesterday.
The General Electric Company, the nation's largest electrical manufacturer, offered an 8 per cent wage increase yesterday to the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO.

First disclosures of high temperature alloy casting methods, using the precision molding "lost wax" process restricted as a military secret during the war, were demonstrated yesterday at a press preview at the Bayonne Works of International Nickel Company.

It took the Yankees twelve innings and three hours and eleven minutes to subdue the last-place White Sox, 3 to 2, in a tense, overtime thriller witnessed by 36,888 spectators at the Stadium last night. The triumph moved the Bombers into a second-place tie with the Athletics, three-and-a-half games behind the Indians.

I should like to take issue with some of Vincente Villamin's comments appearing in his letter published recently. Regardless of any distortion that may have been introduced by THE TIMES news item on the projected nationalization of the Manila Electric Company and the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company, the Philippine Government will be taking the easiest but by no means best way out in the present situation.
JERUSALEM, June 8 -- Jerusalem was heavily shelled today for the twenty-fourth day, according to a Jewish Agency spokesman.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 8 -- The "extraordinary relationship" between national disposable income and the dollar value of shoes consumed provides a reasonably accurate scale of determining public expenditures for footwear, members of the Tanners' Council of America, Inc., were told here today at the second session of their spring meeting.
MANILA, June 8 -- The Philippine Government is under growing pressure from business and mining interests to set a definite policy on resuming trade with Japan.

Of all the Allied Nations in World War II, only the United States "really fought a global war," Bernard M. Baruch writes in today's issue of The Saturday Evening Post. He castigates "the mistaken illusion that the war has enriched America."

SYDNEY, Australia, June 8 -- A former United States soldier who stowed away on a ship bound for Australia was caught today in sight of his goal because a ship's officer had a startlingly accurate dream.

Broadway circles were startled yesterday at the unusual move of Anthony B. Farrell, 48-year-old backer of "Hold It!" to buy the Warner Theatre, a house seating 1,600 at 1655 Broadway, between Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets, at an estimated price of $2,000,000 to prove a pet theory that a more desirable location would attract larger audiences than at the smaller National, the show's present home on Forty-first Street.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Norman Armour is resigning as Assistant Secretary of State for Political Affairs because of personal reasons, it was learned today.

Studies for drastic public improvements in Tarrytown and North Tarrytown, twin communities on the Hudson, will be submitted next Monday night to the authorities and civic groups of both communities in the Civic Center Building in Patriots Park, Tarrytown, it was announced yesterday.
The Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, will preside at the 103d annual commencement of Fordham University on Edwards Parade on the campus at 5 P.M. today.
PARIS, June 8 -- The openings of Paris milliners were six weeks early this year.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 8 -- A few hours before the Israeli Government announced that it had received truce proposals from Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator, the building containing the offices of the United Nations here was struck by two aerial bombs.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser registered his fifth straight pitching victory and his sixth of the season tonight as the Tigers handed the Athletics their fourth successive setback. The score was 2 to 1.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 8 -- Turning in two fine sub-par rounds, the team of Herman Freydberg and Buck Luce of the home club won the Metropolitan Golf Association amateur-pro championship at the Metropolis Country Club course today.
Three men, active in Brooklyn Catholic circles, received honorary degrees of Doctor of Laws last night at the ninetieth annual commencement exercises of St. Francis College of Brooklyn.

NUREMBERG, Germany, June 8 -- Ernst Weizsaecker, former German Ambassador to the Vatican, ascribed to himself today indirect responsibility for the temporary international settlement reached in 1938 at Munich.

Mayor O'Dwyer and Raymond M. Hilliard, Welfare Commissioner, joined yesterday in denying published reports that a "purge" was contemplated in the Welfare Department under the guise of a major reorganization.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 8 -- Militant application of Christian ideals to personal, national and international life offers the best possibility of averting another war and assuring victory throughout the world for democracy based on the brotherhood of man, Francis B. Sayre, president of the United Nations Trusteeship Council, asserted here today.

Some form of military force must be made available to the United Nations if the world organization is to fulfill its purpose of maintaining peace, a majority of participants declared yesterday in the 133d forum in the series "What's on Your Mind?"

Understanding of the brotherhood of man, the underlying principle which guides the work of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, is not today a matter we may accept or reject but a necessity for peace in the world, Dr. Channing H. Tobias said yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 8 -- A Soviet proposal that governments subsidize a "democratic" press by supplying publishing facilities and newsprint to newspapers that would give the board masses of people an outlet for opinion was turned down today by the United Nations Commission on Human Rights.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., June 8 -- The mackerel, which were so plentiful during the past few weeks, have begun to thin out, but as there was a possibility of picking up a few early bluefish, we decided to spend a day offshore with Capt. Douglas MacIntosh on his cruiser Ideal.

The weather forecast is fair and warm and the prospect is for a rousing battle tonight in Ruppert Stadium, Newark, when Rocky Graziano, world middleweight champion, and Tony Zale, Gary (Ind.) veteran who formerly held the title, wage their third championship encounter.
CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) -- The Braves breezed to an 11 -- 1 victory over the Cubs today behind the four-hit pitching of Vernon Bickford, right-handed rookie from Milwaukee. The winners got 13 hits.

The Lemonade Opera opened its second week at the Greenwich Mews Playhouse last night with Mozart's "Don Giovanni," the chief success of its first summer. A different conductor and two new talented sopranos were the new features of the production.

Pilot Radio Corporation yesterday introduced the first portable television receiver at a press review in its factory showrooms in Long Island City. The set has a three-inch direct view cathode ray tube giving a picture one and three-quarter by two and three-quarter inches and will list for $99.50.

ST. LOUIS, June 8 (AP) -- Sharp relief hurling by Ted Wilks gave the Cardinals a 7-to-5 victory over the Phillies tonight after Harry (The Cat) Brecheen was taken out. Erv Dusak punched the wining runs across in the fifth inning with his single.

The 1949 Ford models, which have been the subject of much mystery, speculation and guessing during the last six months, will be revealed to the public at 11 A.M. tomorrow when the Ford Motor Company opens a $500,000 automobile show in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
S. Jules Lakin has bought from the Walt Whitman School the property at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street, with a frontage of seventy feet on the avenue.

Auxiliary Bishop Joseph P. Donahue of the class of '97 of Manhattan College presided yesterday afternoon at the ninety-seventh annual commencement on the campus. More than 400 degrees, the largest number in the history of the institution, were awarded.

THE Butcher Boys will be at it for the third time in Newark's Ruppert Stadium tonight when Rocky Graziano and Tony Zale engage in a face-scrambling contest for the middleweight championship of the world. In their first fight Graziano beat Zale into a bloody pulp and lost. In the second one Zale had Graziano looking as though he'd just been run through a meat-chopper.

Orders and attendance soared at the second day of the second International Textile Industries Exposition at the Grand Central Palace yesterday. Industry members from more than twelve foreign countries registered at exhibitors' booths and more than 500 attended the first of three textile symposiums being held concurrently on the theme of "Fabric Futures."

Recent action broadening acceptability of "convertible" sterling in payment for Japanese goods was confirmed yesterday by the SCAP (Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers) Foreign Trade New York Office. Payment in 100 per cent convertible sterling is now acceptable on shipments going to countries participating in the over-all sterling payments agreement concluded in Tokyo between British and SCAP authorities on May 31.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 8 -- Following is the text of a note sent yesterday by Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator in Palestine, to the Arab states and the Provisional Government of Israel and released today by the Secretary General:

Two new pictures will open in first-run theatres this morning. At the Victoria, the attraction is "Design for Death," a forty-five minute documentary feature released by RKO. The film, which is described as dealing with the "dominant war pattern of Japanese history, and which won an Academy Award, was compiled from some 8,000,000 feet of confiscated Japanese film.
Martin P. Collins, former curtain and drapery buyer for Bloomingdale's, has been appointed general sales manager for the Cortley Curtain Corporation.

The Senate Committee on Appropriations has an opportunity this week in considering the appropriation for the Institute of Inter-American Affairs to undo a House blunder that could seriously undermine our relations with Latin America. It should restore the money cut from the Institute's requests for the fiscal year 1949 and give it authorization to enter into contracts with Latin-American countries for the following year.

PARIS, June 9 -- The Foreign Affairs Committee of the French National Assembly voted today by a narrow margin for consideration of the London accords on Western Germany with reservations as to French security and in the application of the agreements.

JERUSALEM, June 9 -- The Jewish newspaper Hadshot Zohorain today estimated the number of abandoned Arab villages and Bedouin camps in Palestine at 220, in addition to those that had been evacuated, and predicted that the Arab flight would have lasting results.

Fordham University held its 103d anual commencement yesterday at 5 P. M. in the University Gymnasium. Five thousand persons were at the exercises, originally scheduled for outdors but transferred because of the weather. A total of 702 graduates received degrees from the Graduate School and the Schools of Education, Adult Education, Social Service, Law, Pharmacy and Business.

The Regional Plan Association and five other civic organizations joined yesterday in a telegram urging Mayor O'Dwyer to halt construction on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive elevated highway between Eighteenth and Twenty-fifth Streets along the East River pending further investigation of the merits of the project.

BUENOS AIRES, June 9 -- The two biggest present questions in Argentine economy from the standpoint of all foreign and many domestic interests go unanswered in the official reports for 1947 of the Ministry of Finance and of the Central Bank of Argentina, which have just been made public.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 9 -- Maritime unions threatening a strike in all domestic ports next week requested an audience with President Truman today to acquaint him with "the reasonable demands submitted by these unions to their employers which the employers have arbitrarily rejected."

Early potatoes -- 12,000,000 bushels more than we ordinarily consume -- are on their way to market now. Housewives are asked by the United States Department of Agriculture to see that none of the new crop goes to waste. Potatoes must be included in menus more often than usual -- not only in their most popular form, boiled in their jackets, but also in soups, salads and casseroles.

STANTON, Del., June 9 (AP) -- The tables were turned in the Montchanin Handicap, which featured today's Delaware Park program, when Cedar Farm's George Case easily beat H. Hessey Miller's Hearth Mouse.

A group calling itself the Resist Conscription Committee, with offices at 2929 Broadway, is circulating on a country-wide basis petitions committing signers to refuse to register under any conscription law and to counsel others to do likewise.

TOKYO, June 9 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman, spending the second day of his visit in Tokyo on a 40,000-mile tour of the Pacific and the Far East, was received for half an hour this morning by Emperor Hirohito at the Imperial Palace.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 9 -- A score or more of former United States captains and majors are known to be in active command positions in the Army of Israel.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Cyrus Eaton of Otis Co., Cleveland investment bankers, accused the Securities and Exchange Commission today of attempting to "smear" the Otis concern instead of really investigating the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation's stock dealings.

One hundred and fifty New Jersey farmers in a motorcade of fifty cars flying American and Israeli flags, traveled here yesterday to donate blood for Israel at the Red Mogen Dovid Blood Bank, 326 East Thirty-ninth Street.

Following a sharp rise in gross sales during the first quarter of 1948 to $41,392,383, or more than five times the $7,744,203 reported in the comparable period in 1947, the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday for the period a consolidated net income of $2,019,727.
BRIGHTON, England, June 9 (AP) -- Champion Jockey Gordon Richards cracked two ribs in a fall today while making a desperate bid to end a twenty-eight-race losing streak.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Custody and control of the atomic bomb may be transferred from the Atomic Energy Commission to the armed services if military recommendations to that end are approved by the President.

RICHMOND, Va., June 9 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey of New York and former Governor Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota, courted the votes of Virginia's twenty-one delegates to the Republican National Convention at separate sessions today.
Two German art curators, brought here recently by the Department of the Army, have determined to reduce the Berlin collection of paintings now being seen by Americans, it became known yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 9 -- The Western powers agreed today to bring the atomic control controversy to the floor of the United Nations Security Council and press for approval of the decision to suspend the two-year-old Atomic Energy Commission.
Random notes.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., June 9 -- An arrangement by which the more than a half million doctors of the world will get to know one another better was announced today at the convention here of the American Drug Manufacturers Association. It will operate through what will be termed the World Medical Association, a federation of the national medical associations of the world.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- When the Senate Appropriations Committee met in the Senate Office Building this morning, the partisan supporters of Senator Vandenberg were jubilant.

Proud of his newly developed sprint, Herbert McKenley plans to go all out in an attempt to break the world 400-meter record of 46 seconds flat at the Sydenham Hospital benefit track meet at Randalls Island on Saturday evening.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 9 -- An international patrol squadron of six ships from the United States, France and Belgium was requested today by Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations mediator for Palestine, to prevent the Arab countries or Israel from bringing in fighting men or arms during the four-week truce period.

A $1,000 fellowship for a graduate woman student in chemistry has been established at Columbia University by an anonymous woman who benefited from a scholarship in her student days at the university. The fellowship will be a memorial to Miss Olive M. Lammert, a friend of the donor and former Professor of Chemistry at Vassar College.

Continuing to play excellent golf, Miss Patricia O'Sullivan of Orange, Conn., added an even men's par of 72 to her first-round 76 for a total of 148 as the second round of the Women's Eastern Golf Association championship was completed at the North Hills Golf Club in Douglaston, Queens, yesterday.

Beaumont, Tex., Independent School District awarded yesterday an issue of $2,956,000 construction bonds due on each June 1, from 1949 to 1973 to a banking syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co., at an interest cost of 2,768 per cent. The bid was 100.04 for 4s and 2 3/4s.

The Committee for Democratic Rights announced last night that it would employ sound trucks in demonstrations this afternoon before the National Republican Club at 54 West Fortieth Street and the National Democratic Club at 233 Madison Avenue despite the refusal of the Police Department to grant a permit for the use of the amplifying equipment.

Herbert H. Lehman, speaking last night at a dinner marking the climax of the New Rochelle community's drive for $1,500,000 in the United Jewish Appeal, asserted that the "vicious and unprovoked attack made upon Israel by the seven Arab states threatens the peace of the world and the very foundations of the concept of international justice."

After nine months, a special investigation of alleged bribery by operators of automobile driving schools to obtain drivers' licenses for their customers will be ended by the State Motor Vehicle Bureau on June 30, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, June 9 -- Scores of Britons, some celeberated and others unmarked by fame, were included tonight in the latest Birthday Honors list -- the twenty-fourth list published in the reign of King George VI.
The letter of criticism published in THE TIMES of May 26 with reference to my letter of May 20 requires a rebuttal if only to get the record straight.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The text of Senator Vandenberg's prepared statement to the Senate Appropriations Committee urging restoration of the cuts made by the House in foreign aid funds follows:

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP) -- The Senate tonight passed and sent to the White House a compromise bill giving the Labor Department and Federal Security Agency $1,863,480,000 to carry on their work during fiscal 1949. The House acted earlier today.

Food wholesalers and retailers, taking no chances of "missing the boat" as they did earlier in the year because of delayed order placing on spinach and asparagus, are now ready to negotiate for new packs, it was learned here yesterday. Major negotiations last year began in July.

The peony show that closed yesterday afternoon at 598 Madison Avenue was the last flower show the Horticultural Society of New York will hold at that address. Dismantling the exhibits coupled with preparations for moving, made the society's headquarters a beehive of activity after 4 P. M.

Successful millinery promotion will depend on the cooperation of manufacturers in supplying proper sizes for women's hats and teen age hats for younger wearers, Sam Finkelstein, chairman of Millinery Promotions, declared yesterday.

Late next fall Raymond Massey, whose theatrical activities in past seasons have been restricted to the acting phase of show business, will qualify for membership in the League of New York Theatres, the producing organization. For, the actor made known yesterday, he plans to have on the Broadway stage the drama version of "Hanging Judge," a "murder-will-out" novel by Bruce Hamilton, recently published by Harper Bros.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Secretary of State Marshall announced today that the United States had accepted the recommendations of the London conference on Western Germany. These call for a Federal Government with a measure of home rule for Western Germany together with continued occupation by the Big Four and pledges to prevent Germany from rearming.

For several years now there has been constant, justified complaint over the Federal Government's failure to surround the Statue of Liberty with a setting appropriate to its claims on the sentiment of the American people. It is probably the most famous monument in the world.
Today, June 10, is the forty-sixth day of the Greater New York Fund's eleventh annual campaign in behalf of 423 local hospitals, health and welfare agencies.

Profits gained by the public through cooperation of education, labor and the garment industry were pointed out yesterday by Maximilian Moss, vice president of the Board of Education, at the Fashion Institute of Technology exhibit in the Fashion Fair.
ROME, June 9 -- At a general audience today, Pope Pius XII told 1,200 peasants that the Church advocated "just social reforms" designed to improve the condition of workers in all fields.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 9 -- The first of what is expected to be a long list of socially prominent persons testified in Supreme Court here today before Justice Francis G. Hooley in an action seeking to determine what appears to be a moot point: "When does a dog fancier's fancy end and his financial interest begin?"

The stock market raced through the previous highs of the year yesterday and went on to the best levels since September, 1946, before realizing checked the upturn. Gains of a point and more in some industrial issues were held, but others were whittled to major fractions.

LONDON, June 9 (AP) -- The captains of the United States and British Wightman Cup tennis teams named their duelists today, but the British couldn't find anyone in their line-up to give them hope of regaining the women's trophy for the first time since 1930.

BERLIN, June 9. -- Official recognition of an anti-Communist bloc as governing body of this city's Trade Union Federation of 700,000 workers was announced today by the United States Military Government.

The oldest tenant of Carnegie Hall, Dr. Walter O. Robinson, who has maintained a speech and voice studio there for fifty years, was honored yesterday by its president, Robert E. Simon Jr. As a testimonial to his half century tenancy, Dr. Robinson received recordings of some of the great actors and orators of our time.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Postoffice Department, under orders to pay the five major airlines about $20,000,000 this year for carrying mail, today challenged the basis on which the Civil Aeronautics Board fixed this sum. It asserted, in a brief filed with the CAB, that too great a share of the costs of airlines operation was charged to the mail and not enough to the other services performed by the lines.

Domestic crude oil production last week averaged 5,475,800 barrels daily, a new peak, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This was 24,150 barrels more than the daily average output of 5,451,650 in the previous week and it compares with 5,064,200 in the week ended on June 7, 1947.

THE admirable new American College Dictionary leads off in its lucid soliloquy on the definition of legends by saying that a legend is "a non-historical or unverifiable story handed down by tradition from earlier times and popularly accepted as historical."

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Sixteen anti-inflationary recommendations were made in a 110-page report issued today on the twenty-six-city investigation into high prices of consumer goods made by three touring Congressional committees in September and October 1947.

LOS ANGELES, June 9 -- On the eve of the first round of the forty-eighth United States Open championship, which will get under way tomorrow over the Riviera Country Club course, some 171 potential competitors ended their preparations both on and off the links.

LONDON, June 9 -- Britain's proposed experiment in abolishing the death penalty foundered definitely today on the rocks of an aroused public opinion. The Cabinet induced the Labor party majority in the House of Commons to agree to retention of hanging in exceptional cases.

How do you stand on the great American dessert? Do you take your strawberries neat, New Yorker or country style? Making shortcake "the right way" has as many versions as chowder, each supported by partisans of high passion and sincerity, but whose judgments on rival strawberry recipes hew strictly to personal culinary traditions.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Credit extended on retail buying is "adding to inflationary pressures on scarce items," Secretary of the Treasury Snyder told a news conference today. "Consumer credit is now at an all-time high," he said.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis E. Pacifico of Rugby Road, Brooklyn, are wondering where they fit -- if at all -- in the city's Golden Anniversary celebration. Twenty-five years ago next Wednesday they were married in the course of the city's Silver Jubilee pageant and rode up Fifth Avenue on a splendid float in the parade that symbolized New York's industrial progress in the twenty-five years since consolidation.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 -- James F. Byrnes, former Secretary of State, declared here today that this country must press forward its rearmament program, with our strength organized to keep the peace and not on the theory "we want to fight Soviet communism" or that war was inevitable.

The police and officials of the Children's Society were searching last night for the father of three small boys, who had waited for him all afternoon and most of last evening in an automobile parked in front of 123 West Eightieth Street.

A rising clamor outside suggested the dog had discovered something of interest, and investigation found a rabbit. It was a very small rabbit, not long in this world. It must have strayed from its nest and, finding retreat cut off, had sought to hide in a universal and normal fashion -- by simply closing its eyes.

The Public Service Commission resumed yesterday hearings on electric rates paid to the Consolidated Edison Company by the City of New York for seventeen housing developments and twenty-one public markets. Robert B. Grove, a vice president of the company, testified that since last June 30 it had accepted payments under protest and that the difference to date was about $150,000.

LONDON, June 9 -- The House of Lords defeated the Government this evening on the vital second reading of the Parliament Bill, thus precipitating the first great constitutional issue between the two houses of Parliament since 1914.
ABOARD PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S TRAIN, June 9 -- President Truman denounced the present Republican-dominated Congress today as the worst in the country's history.

In the first War Assets Administration open auction in the East, $5,500,000 worth of war surplus goods was put on the block yesterday at the Bronx depot of the WAA, Eastchester Avenue and Haswell Street. Representatives of four foreign governments were present.

A one-week truce was established yesterday in the dispute between the Third Avenue Transit Corporation and the Transport Workers Union, CIO, over seven-day operation of new business machines installed by the company to check on bus runs and fare collections.

PEIPING, June 9 -- A demonstration by 4,000 students here today against United States policy in Japan developed into a clash between the students and their own governing authorities. The students and the police came to blows early this afternoon when parading students tried to rush a police cordon.
Disagreement over the World Federation of Trade Unions emerged yesterday as a major obstacle to unity of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Careful supervision of equipment and constant education of locomotive engine crews are necessary to comply with smoke ordinances, railroad officials declared yesterday at the forty-first annual convention of the Smoke Prevention Association of America in the Commodore Hotel. They urged cooperation with industry in curtailing smoke in populated areas.

Electric utilities in some areas are discussing the possibility of promoting sales of air-conditioning units with gas as fuel, according to the American Gas Association. The AGA further revealed yesterday that some electric utilities have even expressed a disinterest in the fast-growing air-conditioning business.

Maintenance of a minimum armed force, research and development of new and improved supply items and preparation of an industrial mobilization plan to take full advantage of America's industrial potential are the three factors essential to national defense, Maj. Gen. W. H. Middleswart, deputy quartermaster general, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON June 9 (AP) -- Small business came in for consideration today in the foreign aid program and in getting contracts and orders from the armed services.

The long-hoped-for truce in Palestine, for which the United Nations has been working for more than two months, is now set to go into effect at 2 A. M. tomorrow. At that hour, which will be 10 A. M. Israeli time, the trumpets which have hitherto called to war are scheduled to sound the call to cease fire on all fronts in the Holy Land.

Textile manufacturers are not living up to their responsibility of supplying quality fabrics despite technical advances made, Ephraim Freedman, director of the bureau of standards, R. H. Macy Co., charged yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP) -- The "simplified" withholding tax form which millions of wage-earners have been using to file their Federal income tax returns will be abolished after this year. It is too confusing, according to the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended June 2:

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Any prospect of a bi-partisan approach to extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, a key instrument in this country's foreign policy, practically vanished today. Senate Democrats, taking a no-compromise stand, promised to hold out to the end for an unconditional extension of the law, which expires at midnight Saturday.

Some china and glassware retailers are preparing to shave profits substantially on regular lines after July 1 in an effort to keep inventories at a workable level, several store buyers reported yesterday. An executive of one large retail group said that reductions will run to as 20 per cent and pointed out that the move will be distinct from cut-price clearances of "odds and ends" usual in the slow summer selling season.

Two months ago both houses of Congress authorized the expenditure of 5.3 billion dollars on the European Recovery Program during the first twelve months of its operation. A few days ago the House of Representatives voted to appropriate one and a half billion dollars less than the authorization called for.

Woven woolen and worsted apparel fabric production in the first quarter of 1948 was 116,200,000 linear yards, 7 per cent less than the corresponding period last year, it was announced yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.
BERLIN, June 9 -- The Russians increased their pressure on the Western Allies in Berlin today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 9 -- Hedy Lamarr has been signed to play Delilah in Cecil B. de Mille's projected fall production of "Samson and Delilah," Paramount announced today. Jesse Lasky Jr. and Frederick Frank are writing the scenario from an initial treatment done by Harold Lamb of the material in Chapters 13 to 16 of the Book of Judges.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 9 -- A Soviet delegate criticized American housing shortages and medical costs here today, likening doctors' fees to "butcher-shop lists" and contending that the average citizen paid one-third of his earnings to the landlord.

Directors of the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation authorized yesterday a share-for-share distribution of common stock to holders of the outstanding 500,000 shares of common stock of $1 par value.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican Presidential aspirant, will reply to President Truman's repeated gibes at the Republican-controlled Eightieth Congress Friday night in a nation-wide radio broadcast.

TOKYO, June 9 -- The Japanese Government has now presented to the Diet a bill that would raise the salaries of Premier Hitoshi Ashida and his Ministers by 800 per cent. Since the Government, after a long debate, has decided to seek about a 25 per cent increase in the average pay of its employes, this action is drawing a certain amount of unfavorable comment from the Japanese press.
Appropriately enough, inasmuch as she is owned by Harry M. Warner, president of Warner Brothers Pictures, Honeymoon proved most photogenic at Belmont Park yesterday.

Imported upholstery and drapery fabrics in the sumptous pre-war mood were shown yesterday at the opening of a new decorators' showroom for Oken Fabrics at 677 Fifth Avenue. There were silk broches from Italy, hand-colored brocades and velvets, ramie friezes from Holland, and English chintzes, along with domestic textures and prints.

ST. LOUIS, June 9 (AP) -- After knocking out Howie Pullet in a six-run second inning the Braves went on to an 11-to-5 triumph over the Cardinals tonight. Warren Spahn kept the Redbirds under control except for the eighth inning, when they scored three runs, but his team-mates' fifteen hits had provided enough margin for the victory.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 9 -- Presentation of the Ford scholarship to Miss Katherine Hallgren of Taylor's Island, Dorchester County, Md., was a feature of the annual banquet tonight of the Woman's National Farm and Garden Association.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- In a blistering attack on the "meat axe techniques" by which the House cut more than $1,500,000,000 from European recovery funds, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, demanded today full restoration of the Congressional authorization in the name of American leadership for world peace.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The coal industry needs 757,000 tons of steel during the next year, the National Coal Advisory Council said today.

ESSEN, Germany, June 9 -- Despite a major political squabble with the Minister-Presidents of the Western German states, authorities of the Bizonal Economic Administration joined the states chiefs today in demanding the return of the Ruhr coal mines to German hands as a prerequisite for increased production.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP) -- The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee today approved, 9 to 4, a bill to reorganize the Federal Communications Commission and write into law many of its disputed policies.
GENEVA, June 9 -- The admission of Austria and Finland to the International Civil Aviation Organization was unanimously approved today by the air organization's assembly.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Eugene Meyer, chairman of the board of The Washington Post, today was appointed chairman of a finance committee of the Overseas Writers Committee, which is inquiring into the murder in Greece of George Polk, correspondent of the Columbia Broadcasting Company.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, June 9 -- In a determined bid to break the blockade of Jerusalem before the cease-fire automatically freezes the present military positions, Israeli forces hurled themselves all last night at strong Arab Legion positions blocking the highway around Bab el Wad.

The larger savings banks in Manhattan generally will maintain their dividend rates at the current annual level of 1 1/2 per cent, it was learned yesterday. Despite the recent action of the Empire City Savings Bank, which announced plans to advance its rate on some deposits to 2 per cent, effective July 1, no other savings banks may be expected to follow the move.
BUFFALO, N. Y., June 9 (AP) -- A group of bankers was told today that "the first step in the establishment of good public relations for a bank is the establishment of good employe relations."
Underwriting managers here will offer to investors today issues of new public utility bonds and railroad equipment trust certificates totaling $22,055,000, as follows:
PITTSBURGH, June 9 -- The Dodgers dropped their fifth decision today in six games with the Pirates this season. A ladies' day crowd of 11,790 saw the local team win by 6 to 4.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 9 -- Gallaway Calhoun of Tyler, Tex., was elected Imperial Potentate of the Ancient Arabic order, Nobles of the Mystic Shrine of North America, at its seventy-fourth Imperial Council session here today.

Members of the Sanitation Workers Union, CIO, voted unanimously last night to man a mass picket line outside City Hall beginning next Wednesday to win a "square deal" and better working conditions from Mayor O'Dwyer.
Cotton futures closed on the New York Cotton Exchange 1 point higher to 2 points lower yesterday after a session of only moderate price fluctuations.

Benny Goodman, the Andrews Sisters, the Ink Spots and Henry Morgan are among the 100 entertainers from stage, screen and radio who will appear tonight in City College's "Jubilee Night" revue at 9 P. M. in Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

NEW DELHI, India, June 9 -- The relations between the Dominion of India and the Princely State of Hyderabad reached a fresh crisis today when negotiations between the States Ministry and the Hyderabad delegation led by Premier Mir Laik Ali again foudered.

RICHMOND, Va., June 9 -- Oliver W. Hill, a 31-year-old attorney, was elected to Richmond's new City Council in yesterday's election, the first Negro to be elected to a Richmond office since Reconstructions days. Returns today showed that he gained the last of nine places and was 150 votes ahead of T. B. du Cuennois, area director for the CIO, who was on a slate of nine offered by the Richmond Citizens Association.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The House Republican leaders were cold today to the suggestions of their Senate counterparts that this session of Congress might be prolonged beyond next week.

The Dairymen's League criticized the Board of Health yesterday for opening the local market to Western milk and cream, and hinted that dairymen in the New York milkshed might ship their milk to other markets that offer higher prices.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Inevitable, but very unfortunate, is the prospect that Congress will be in session during the Presidential campaign of 1948, which will move rapidly toward its peak after the Republicans have written their platform and nominated their ticket.

The Maritime Commission's plans for the improvement of the nin C-4 type emergency class passenger vessels now being operated in transatlantic service moved closer to realization yesterday with the formal opening here of bids from ship repair yards.

Operations of Spencer Kellogg Sons, Inc., vegetable oil processors, during the thirty-six weeks ended on May 8, last, resulted in a net profit of $4,709,912 after taxes and all deductions, according to the report issued yesterday.

Robert L. Riggs heads the list of sixteen players seeded in the draw for the national professional tennis championship, which will start Saturday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills. The ceremony was held at the club yesterday, with P. Schuyler Van Bloem, chairman of the tournament committee, in charge, and the names were drawn from the Benrus Trophy, on which Riggs has won the first two legs.

To accommodate an expected registration increase of 25,600 boys and girls in the New York public elementary schools and kindergartens next fall, the Board of Education plans to open five new schools and six additions to existing schools in September, it was announced yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 9 (AP) -- Even as the mediator's success in negotiating a truce agreement was announced, widely scattered fighting continued.

Newspaper publishers were urged yesterday to resume, as soon as possible, one-year rate protection on all national advertising along with elimination of discriminatory treatment of advertisers on such protection.

Maurice P. Davidson, chairman of the New York War and Peace Memorial Committee, called on the public yesterday for additional suggestions regarding the exact form the proposed "living war memorial" in Manhattan should take.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 (AP) -- The Tigers came from behind twice tonight to defeat the Athleticse, 7 to 4. George Kell drove his first homer of the year with two on in the sixth for Detroit as Philadelphia suffered its fifth straight defeat.

Despite the light rain and overcast skies that threatened the outdoor exercises, more than 11,000 persons attended New York University's 116th commencement yesterday at which a record total of 7,773 seniors were graduated. The exercises were held on Ohio Field on the Bronx campus.

Thunder roared, lightning streaked the gloomy sky overhead, rain deluged Newark yesterday as Rocky Graziano, world middleweight champion from the East Side, and Tony Zale, Gary, (Ind.), veteran who formerly held the title, weighed in for their third title bout, originally scheduled for Ruppert Stadium last night.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Bituminous coal operators and the United Mine Workers of America settled down today to the beginning of collective bargaining for a new contract on the basis of a mutual exchange of contract proposals.

Coming to Ebbets Field last night with a succession of victories gained in New York, Baltimore, Philadelphia, Fall River, St. Louis and Montreal, the all-conquering team of the Liverpool Soccer Club of England made it eight straight by defeating an eleven drawn from the four Metropolitan members of the American Soccer League, 5 -- 2.

LONDON, June 9 -- London observers were struck tonight by the energy, skill and finesse with which Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator, arranged the cease-fire in Palestine, reconciling the almost irreconcilable views of Arab states and the Government of Israel.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., June 9 (AP) -- Company and union officials entered their third negotiations session of the day early tonight, an encouraging sign toward settlement of the labor dispute at Oak Ridge National Laboratory.

Supposedly in reply to statements made in the preceding day by Senator Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska that small businesses were not getting a proper share of the output of steel, the American Iron and Steel Institute issued statistics yesterday to show that small business enterprises last year received 13 per cent more steel than in the preceding year and 57 per cent more than was allotted to them in 1940.

PITTSBURGH, June 9 -- Another player shift hit the Dodgers today with third baseman Spider Jorgensen released to the St. Paul American Association club on a twenty-four-hour recall option and pitcher Clyde King sold to the Phillies for the $10,000 waiver price.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Clint Hartung, the Hondo hotshot some thought had been permanently cooled off as a pitcher, experienced a sudden rise in temperature today to give a notable lift to the Giants just when they needed it most.

LONDON, June 9 -- Further "bear" covering was responsible for a firm start to the new account in the stock market here today. But, when covering had been completed around midday, absence of any large-scale public buying led to sagging tendency from best levels.

Thanks to the stand taken by Senators Millikin and Vandenberg, the Senate committee's version of the bill to extend the Hull trade program is not as bad as the one railroaded through the House. Under both the House and Senate measures the Tariff Commission would be required, in advance of all trade agreement negotiations, to determine limits within which adjustments and other concessions could be made on specific items without serious injury to domestic producers.

Graduating exercises for classes from five colleges of arts and sciences of St. John's University, Brooklyn, were held yesterday afternoon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Lafayette Avenue and Ashland Place, Brooklyn. The Very Rev. John A. Flynn, president of the university, gave diplomas to 441 graduates.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, June 10 -- The Senate agreed early today after thirty-six and a half hours of floor debate on the stop-gap draft bill to vote at 3 o'clock this afternoon on all pending amendments and then make its final decision on the President's proposal of Feb. 2 to assure the country a military "security strength" through a revival of selective service in peacetime.

ROME, June 9 -- The worst fight in Italian parliamentary history occurred in the Chamber of Deputies today when the Christian Democrats and the extreme Left battled against each other on floor of the House. Stenographers' benches were uprooted by the contestants and used as weapons to such good effect that three Deputies had to be treated at first-aid stations.

More goods at lower prices, coupled with higher wages, can be obtained by increasing the productivity of labor in a national drive capture over 5 billion dollars more in national income, Charles Luckman, president of Lever Brothers Company, Boston, told more than 600 members of the American Management Association yesterday.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., June 9 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. told members of the American Federation of Musicians today at their fifty-first annual convention here that "we can beat communism only with an honest, sincere program to eliminate the injustices upon which communism thrives."
ATHENS, June 9 (AP) -- Former King Michael of Romania and Princess Anne of Bourbon-Parma will be married in Athens tomorrow before a small assortment of royalty, ex-royalty and Cabinet Ministers.

Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, forecast continued prosperity, a high employment rate and further increases in automotive prices yesterday as the Ford 1949 models, developed with emphasis on styling, comfort and economy, were presented here.

Independent furniture stores will raise prices if proposed cancellation of exception ratings on less-than-carload furniture freight shipments is carried out by Eastern territory railroads, Roscoe R. Rau, executive vice president, National Retail Furniture Association, warned yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, June 9 (AP) -- The United Steelworkers, CIO, moved today for a court test on the constitutionality of that part of the Taft-Hartley Act which calls for union officers to sign non-Communist affidavits.
Detailed instructions for a complete revamping of the city's Department of Welfare, as ordered by the State Board of Social Welfare, were made public yesterday.

Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg added yesterday to his stature as a man and a statesman in his testimony before the Senate Appropriations Committee. Partisanship would have demanded that a Republican in a Presidential year deal gently with an issue which might split his party.

A biography of the late Msgr. Edward J. Flanagan and the growth of Boys Town, Neb., as yet untitled, has been scheduled for publication early next year by Doubleday. It is being written by Fulton and Will Oursler, who spent several weeks at Boys Town, observing, searching the records and conferring with Father Flanagan. All preliminary work had been completed when Father Flanagan died in April.

LONDON, June 9 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin announced the British Government's acceptance of the London recommendations to the House of Commons today. At the same time he made a statement that paralleled the one made in Washington by Secretary of State Marshall.

PARIS, June 9 -- Dr. Chaim Weizmann, President of Israel, today blamed the Arabs for most of the destruction during the Palestine warfare and for which certain groups, especially in England, have been blaming the Jews.

Democracy can survive in the "age of science" if it works to unite all peoples of the world, Dr. Carter Davidson, president of Union College, declared last night at the ninety-third annual commencement of Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn.

A county fair atmosphere pervaded Education Hall in the American Museum of Natural History yesterday when the Welfare Council of New York opened its second annual Hobby Show for Older People. With 2,000 displays, 1,000 exhibitors, the show continuing through Sunday from 2:30 to 5 P. M. was proclaimed "twice as big and twice as good" as that of last year by 500 visitors who viewed the arts and crafts and chatted with the exhibitors.

A plaque in honor of John Harpendingh, a New York merchant in the late Sixteen Hundreds, was unveiled yesterday by the Maiden Lane Historical Society at 24 John Street, where a path once ran between Maiden Lane and John Street.

WASHINGTON. June 9 (AP) -- Early Wynn checked the Browns with four hits tonight to notch his sixth victory as Washington won its third straight 5 -- 2. Gil Coan, with a home run and triple, led the Senators' eight-hit attack on Cliff Fannin, Al Widmar and Frank Biscan.

A meek, slender ne'er-do-well, with a long previous record of bad conduct, calmly told the police yesterday that he had killed Mrs. Frieda Frank outside the door of her Washington Heights home a week ago. He said she was one of fifteen women he had robbed in the last two months.

A two-hour conference attended by represenatives of thirteen daily newspapers and their 2,500 unionized composing-room employes resulted yesterday in agreement on two-thirds of the clauses to be contained in a new contract between the New York local of the International Typographical Union, AFL, and the Publishers Association of New York City.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Marshall's announcement of the United States' acceptance of the London program for Western Germany.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 9 -- Faris el-Khouri, the Syrian representative on the United Nations Security Council, said tonight that the cease-fire in Palestine would last only four weeks unless the Council meanwhile agreed on "a different solution" that was not based on the General Assembly's partition resolution of last November.

PRAGUE, June 9 -- The central committee of the Czechoslovak Communist party disclosed today that it had decided that Premier Klement Gottwald would be the next President of Czechoslovakia to replace ex-President Eduard Benes.

EASTON, Pa., June 9 -- Lafayette defeated West Virginia, 8-0, and Navy nosed out Rutgers, 3-2, in eleven innings in today's double-header to decide the N. C. A. A. District 2 baseball champion before 2,000 spectators. Lafayette and Navy will meet in the final here tomorrow.

CINCINNATI, June 9 (AP) -- Curt Simmons, Philadelphia's 19-year-old portsider, scattered nine hits among the Reds for a 3-2 victory tonight before a crowd of 28,423. Dick Sisler's ninth homer, a three-run poke, was the Phillies' scoring effort.

JERUSALEM, June 9 -- In the first shift in the line on the Jerusalem front since the Israeli forces lost their quarter of the Old City eleven days ago the Haganah early this morning threw the Arab Legion back 200 yards along an 800-yard front in the Musrara quarter.

Eight national prize-winning outfits and thirty-six other coats, suits and dresses that received honorable mention in the National Sewing Contest sponsored by the National Needlecraft Bureau were shown yesterday at a cocktail party in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 9 -- The Provisional Government of Israel and the seven-member nations of the Arab League today accepted unconditionally a United Nations Security Council request for a cease-fire in Palestine. The cessation of hostilities is scheduled to take effect at 6 o'clock Friday morning, Greenwich Mean Time, which is 2 A. M. New York daylight time, and is to last four weeks.
Kenneth S. Pratt has been appointed account executive for the Dodge division of the Chrysler Corporation.

Jobu Yasumura, wartime internee at the Japanese relocation center at Tule Lake, Calif., and a member of the staff of the American Baptist Home Mission Society since 1944, was ordained to the Christian ministry yesterday in the chapel of Riverside Church.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Marshall's announcement of the United States' acceptance of the London program for Western Germany.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 9 -- Faris el-Khouri, the Syrian representative on the United Nations Security Council, said tonight that the cease-fire in Palestine would last only four weeks unless the Council meanwhile agreed on "a different solution" that was not based on the General Assembly's partition resolution of last November.

PRAGUE, June 9 -- The central committee of the Czechoslovak Communist party disclosed today that it had decided that Premier Klement Gottwald would be the next President of Czechoslovakia to replace ex-President Eduard Benes.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Justice T. Alan Goldsborough in United States District Court today continued his temporary ban against a strike by three railroad unions.

Yugoslav support of Italian trusteeship over most of Italy's former colonies is a surprising and significant move. The recommendation is made in a formal memorandum from the Belgrade Government to the deputies of the Foreign Ministers who have been sitting for many months in London without coming to a decision on a question the Italian treaty failed to settle.

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, issued a statement yesterday disassociating itself from the political program of Dr. Judah L. Magnes, chairman of the Hadassah Council in Palestine. Dr. Magnes registered on June 5 with the Department of Justice in Washington as an agent for the Ihud Association of Jerusalem, a group which according to the Department of Justice "favors the establishment of a bi-national Arab-Jewish state in Palestine."
PHILADELPHIA, June 10 (AP) -Seven runs on two hits in the fourth inning carried the Athletics to a 10-4 conquest of the Tigers today and enabled the Mackmen to break their five-game losing streak.

MANILA, June 10 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo expressed the opinion today that "the cold war has been lost by Russia and won by the United States." It was his belief, he said, that the Soviet Union had failed in its two major objectives, first, that of mentally disarming the Ameriean people, and second, the alienating of Western Europe from United States assistance.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 10 -"The Breakers," the Cornelius Vanderbilt estate on Ochre Point, Newport, once valued at $9,000,000, has been leased for one year to the Preservation Society of Newport County, it was announced here today.

A bizarre tale of how death granted an eight-months' reprieve to a 22-year-old man, who did not realize he carried a fragment of an ice pick in his heart, was unfolded yesterday as the victim's assailant was sentenced in General Sessions to a five to ten-year prison term.

LAUREL, Md., June 10 (AP) -The four rear cars of the Baltimore Ohio's Diplomat jumped the track as it was taking an easy main-line curve past Laurel Race Track today and a man was killed trying to jump clear. State police, hospital and railroad officials reported at least forty-six persons injured.

LONDON, June 10 -- Operations conducted successfully inside the human heart for the first time in British surgical history to relieve disease within the heart are described by Dr. R. C. Brock today in The British Medical Journal.

The first test of the city ordinance regulating the use of sound trucks after the decision of the United States Supreme Court that upheld their use as part of the "free speech" guarantee of the Constitution, was staged here yesterday by left-wing groups.
STANTON, Del., June 10 (AP) -William H. Veeneman's Irish Sun turned in the fastest five furlongs of the meeting -- 0:59 flat, to win the Marshallton Purse at Delaware Park today.

In spite of the political atmosphere in which all current legislation is being debate, it is imperative that other considerations be brought to bear on a proposed amendment to the Atomic Energy Act of 1946. The amendment will probably be brought to a vote the present Congressional session.

KINGS POINT, N.Y., June 10 -In colorful ceremonies here this afternoon, 231 young men representing forty-two states and the Territory of Hawaii were graduated from the United States Merchant Marine Academy after completing their studies for careers as merchant officers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 10 -- Andrei A. Gromyko today renewed the Soviet Union's fight to have the United Nations Security Council send Russian military observers to help carry out the ceasefire and truce in Palestine, which is scheduled to begin at 2 A.M. tomorrow, New York daylight time.

TRENTON, N.J. June 10 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court today ordered the United Piece Dye Works of Lodi, N.J., to give David Morris, a Wall Street stock broker, a list of its preferred stockholders so that he might submit to them a plan of recapitalization.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 5 were 821,213 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 83,635 cars, or 9.2 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 79,534, or 8.8 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week of last year, and 8,915 or 1.1 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week of two years ago.

Rain or shine, the "New York at Work" parade that will open the city's Golden Anniversary celebration will be held on schedule tomorrow afternoon. This was made certain by an order issued yesterday by the Grand Marshal, Mayor O'Dwyer, which read:

Commencement exercises were conducted yesterday afternoon for graduates of the School of Commerce and the College of Pharmacy, St. John's University, Brooklyn, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Lafayette Avenue and Ashland Place, Brooklyn.

Miss Ella Widener's 7-year-old jumper Adaptable, whose specialty is scoring upsets, won the thirtythird running of the Meadow Brook Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. It was his first success in eight tries since the Grand National of last October, and he and his stable-mate, Chance Bullet, were the outsiders in the betting.
The Pantepec Oil Company of Venezuela, C.A., reported yesterday for 1947 a record net income of $3,319,607, equal to $1.11 a share, compared with $2,253,856 or 75 cents a share earned in 1946.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- An experimental airplane operated by the Air Force "has flown much faster than the speed of sound many times" in recent months, Secretary W. Stuart Symington disclosed today. The plane, known as the Bell XS-1, was piloted by a wartime ace, Capt. Charles E. Yeager, at the Muroc Air Force base.

A new city ambulance service, based on St. Clare's Hospital, 415 West Fifty-first Street, and covering the congested area from Broadway to the Hudson River between Thirty-fourth and Fiftyfourth Streets, will be started after July 1, it was announced yesterday by Mother M. Alice, superintendent of the hospital, which is conducted by the Sisters of the Third Order Regular of St. Francis.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The House began today its urgent task of providing emergency legislation for meeting the critical problem of Europe's displaced persons and wartime refugees.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -The Senate approved today the promotion of thirty high-ranking Air Force officers. Among them were Maj. Gen. Leon W. Johnson, commander of the Fifteenth Air Force at Colorado Springs, Col., and Maj. Gen. Laurence S. Kuter, head of the new Military Air Transport Service.

The management of the Standard Oil Company (N.J.) will consider the declaration of another stock dividend at the dividend meeting to be held next fall, according to a letter sent yesterday to stockholders with dividends of $1 a share in cash and of five shares of capital stock for each 200 shares held.
NEWARK, N.J., June 10 -- Tony Zale, sturdy Gary, Ind., ring veteran, regained the world middleweight title tonight.

DETROIT, June 10 -- A "triple play" simulated assault upon Selfridge Field, described by ordinance experts as the most elaborate maneuver since the end of the war, was staged today to demonstrate to about 6,000 manufacturers the requirements of the armed forces.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 -The Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific Coast today filed charges of unfair labor practices against the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 -After nearly thirty years of planning San Francisco today opened a foreign trade zone, the country's third "free port."
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A sampling of what this country can expect in a state-by-state revelation of child health needs by the American Society of Pediatrics was issued today for North Carolina.

The proposed local law to expand the power of the License Department to pass upon the "character of exhibitions, performances and advertising" of legitimate theatres was reported out favorably yesterday by the City Council committee on general welfare.

Sixty paralyzed ex-service men wheeled themselves into the Grand Central area yesterday. They went to enlist public support for a Congressional bill that would help them to get out of the hospitals and into "prosthetic homes." In an hour they obtained 7,500 signatures to their petitions, after which the wheelchair cavalcade returned to 99 Park Avenue, headquarters of the Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At Loew's State, the attraction is "Summer Holiday," the musical adaptation of the Eugene O'Neill play, "Ah, Wilderness!". Mickey Rooney, Gloria De Haven and Walter Huston head the cast of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer production, which was filmed in Technicolor.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 -Representatives of two securities firms told a Securities and Exchange Commission board of inquiry here today that the First California Company, an investment banking concern of this city, confirmed to them 105,000 shares of the recent Kaiser-Frazer Corporation common stock issue, despite the fact that they had indicated an interest in only 31,200 shares.

D. Anthony DeMaio, controllerof the Green Point Savings Bankof Brooklyn has completed twentyfive years of service with thebank, it was ~announced yesterday.A gold watch was presented to himby the bank's staff.

CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -- The Chicago Tribune, replying to criticism of that paper by President Truman, said today that "thanks in no small measure to The Tribune, the people of this nation know Mr. Truman for the nincompoop he is."
May I correct an error in the account of the P.E.N. International Congress in Copenhagen as printed in THE TIMES of June 1?

One-man rule of business is no longer efficient, when compared to methods in organizations in which management controls have been designed properly to delegate authority to subordinates, Gen. Brehon Somervell, president, Koppers Company, Inc., declared yesterday.

JERUSALEM, June 9 (Delayed) -- The establishment of two International Red Cross delegations for Palestine was announced this evening by the chief delegate, Jacques de Reynier, to become effective immediately. They will be on the Arab and Jewish sides of the Palestine war.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 10 -- John J. Rorech and David Schwartz, builders, were acquitted of sixteen counts of larceny and fraud by a jury in County Court here today.

The city must decide "very soon" whether to spend enough money for the rapid construction of planned sewage disposal plants or prohibit bathing at all beaches within its limits, Health Commissioner Harry S. Mustard declared yesterday in a memorandum to Mayor O'Dwyer.
OLYMPIA, Wash., June 10 (AP) -A White House official announced today that President Truman would be unable to attend Secretary of Labor Schwellenbach's funeral in Seattle.

More than 70,000 visitors inspected the Ford Motor Company exhibition of 1949 models that started yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. Mayor O'Dwyer formally opened the $500,000 array of attractions.
Delegates representing 125,000 unionized workers in ninety-six General Electric plants deferred final action yesterday on the company's offer of an 8 per cent wage increase.

[~zw Yo~ Tn~s.E.4.STON, ~Ps., June 10~Boblard, of Bridgeport, Conm, pitcheda five-hit shut-out as Lafayette defeated Navy, ~ 0, today to winthe N. C. A. _a_. District IX playoffs. Lafayette now goes to theEastern finals next week, at Winston-Salem, N. C.

Textile buyers for retail stores can insure a successful fall season by exercising greater care in selection of fabrics for over-the-counter sale, it was pointed out yesterday by Theodore Felner, merchandise counselor of R. H. Macy Co. Fabric departments will get their fair share of the increase in consumer purchasing power, he said, by intelligent merchandising and cooperation of textile supply houses.

The United States Mediation and Conciliation Service asked three maritime unions and representatives of Atlantic and Coast ship operators yesterday to attend meetings here today in connection with disputes over contracts expiring next Tuesday.

Play-by-play descriptions of the National Professional Tennis Championships to take place at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, will be carried over WNYC, beginning Monday. With Kevin Kennedy describing the action, the broadcast schedule will be from 2:05 to 4 P.M. on the opening day, and from 2:05 to 5 P.M. on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday.

Fordham Preparatory School held its 103d annual commencement yesterday evening in the university gymnasium before about 2,500 persons. One hundred and seventy-one graduates received their diplomas and listened to addresses by John P. Delaney and Eugene T. D'Ablemont, salutatorian and valedictorian, respectively.
Spiritual as well as physical mobilization is necessary for the defense of democracy, former Governor Herbert H. Lehman declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -The Agriculture Department said today that it had bought about 700,000 bushels of surplus 1948 crop potatoes to support prices Most of them were produced in Alabama, California and North Carolina. Government buying in Virginia is expected to start later this month.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The strong probability arose today that Congress would adjourn after all on its long-scheduled date of June 19.

Ninety-six candidates received degrees last night at the commencement exercises of Brooklyn Law School, in Richardson Hall, 375 Pearl Street, Brooklyn. Justice Henry G. Wenzel Jr. of the Appellate Division, Supreme Court, delivered the address, and the degrees were conferred by Justice William B. Carswell, Appellate Division, dean of the school.

PRAGUE, June 10 -- The first meeting of the new Parliament today disclosed the distribution of seats made by the Central Action Committee for Czech Lands and the Central Action Committee for Slovakia in drawing up the single lisf of candidates for the vote on May 30.

Expressing an optimistic view for business of the National Department Stores Corporation in the remainder of the year, Harry H. Schwartz, president, informed shareholders at the annual meeting held here yesterday, that acquisition of new stores was under consideration.
GRINNELL, Iowa, June 10 -Nearly 300 persons from twentythree states assembled on the Grinnell College campus today to discuss how to prevent a third world war.

The importance of the election of a qualified and impartial Surrogate of New York County to succeed Surrogate James A. Delehanty was stressed yesterday in a statement by Harrison Tweed, former president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

A happy reunion took place yesterday at the Children's Center, 2 East 105th Street, between a harassed father and his three small sons who were taken there by the police on Wednesday night after they were found in an automobile parked in front of 123 West Eightieth Street.
CLEVELAND, June 10 (AP) -- The contested merger of the ClevelandCliffs Iron Company and the Cliffs Corporation was approved today by Common Pleas Judge Charles J. McNamee.

BERLIN, June 10 -- Charging Soviet authorities with "brutal disregard for personal rights" Col. Frank L. Howley, United States commander in Berlin, compared Russian conduct in the kidnapping of a German reporter, Dieter Friede, with the Soviet purge trials of the Nineteen Thirties and the German reign of terror under Adolf Hitler.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 10 -- Public, private and club bathing beaches in New Rochelle and vicinity, closed since June 1 by pollution of Long Island Sound, received authorization today from health officials to reopen on Saturday.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Secretary of Labor Lewis B. Schwellenbach died in Walter Reed Hospital at 4:40 A.M. today after several weeks of illness. His age was 53.
ALBANY, June 10 -- Members of the three legislative committees and commissions met in Albany today to organize and elect officers for the coming year.

Electric shock therapy in conjunction with psychotherapy given to 100 patients with various types of mental illnesses resulted in complete recovery in 92 per cent of manic depressive cases and improvement in 72 per cent of schizophrenic cases, Dr. Joseph S. A. Miller, medical director of Hillside Hospital, Bellerose, Queens, said yesterday in his annual report.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Republicans in control of Congress still bubbled with indignation today at President Truman's remark that this was "the worst Congress" in history. One of their number asserted that there would be "some Congress-tanned Missouri jackass hide on the Christmas market -come November."

The majority of house organs, internal and external, fail to accomplish their basic objectives, members of House Magazines Incorporated were told yesterday at their annual meeting in the Roosevelt Hotel. HMI is a professional association of business and industrial editors in the New York metropolitan area.

Your editorial of May 28, "For the Board of Education," is timely. It may be well for the Mayor and the citizens of New York to know that it will not be setting a precedent to appoint a Negro to the Board of Education.

DETROIT, June 10 -- In a surprise move, the Packard Motor Company announced tonight both wage and price increases. The wage boost, arranged with the United Automobile Workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and covering 10,000 workers, is for 13 cents on the average.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 10 -- Folowing are the texts of the replies from the egyptian Government on behalf of Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Lebanon and Syria, and truce proposals of the United Nations Mediator in Palestine (separate replies similar to the Egyptian were received by the Mediator from Yemen, Trans-Jordan and Iraq):

Six weeks after his arrest for gauging payments of $2,000 to $4,000 each from eleven war-veteran doctors seeking professional apartments in Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, Meyer Greenwald, former tenant selector, started yesterday to serve a City Prison term up to three years.

ROME, June 10 -- Palmiro Togliatti, Italian Communist leader, this afternoon accused the United States of having donated $4,000,000 to anti-Communist parties as one of several means used to defeat the extreme Left-Wing bloc at the Italian national elections last April.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 10 (AP) -- The final business meeting of the Grand Army of the Republic, Department of New York, was history tonight.

ALES, France, June 10 (AP) -Japan's silk production has increased steadily since the war, Kanae Hatano, Japanese Agricultural Minister and head of his country's delegation to the International Silk Conference, said here today, Mr, Hatano and eight Japanese industrialists were invited to the silk Conference by the French Government.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Federal insurance agaihst permanent and total disability under the Social Security system was recommended today by a Congressional advisory group.

Shipments of rayon yarn and staple in May totaled 93,600,000 pounds, compared with 90,800,000 in April and 78,100,000 in May 1947, the Textile Economics Bureau's publication, Rayon Organon, reported yesterday. This brought the total of domestic rayon deliveries for the first five months of 1948 to 447,600,000 pounds, an increase of 17 per cent over the same months last year.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 10 -Trygve Lie, Secretary-General of the United Nations, urged today the formation "very soon" of a small armed guard force to back up Security Council decisions until the major powers could settle their differences over a permanent world army.

Gov. Earl Warren of California said yesterday he understood that one-half of the 1,094 delegates to the Republican National Convention were unpledged to any candidate for the nomination for President and that any votes for him outside the fifty-three from his home state would come from them.

On May 24 THE NEW YORK TIMES published an A.P. dispatch on the meeting in Washington of the International Peasant Union. It said that the aim of the exiled peasant leaders is to "return democratic and republican governments to their homelands."

ATHENS, June 10 (AP) -- Former King Michael and Princess Anne, whose romance encountered religious differences, were married today in the ritual of the Greek Orthodox Church. The ceremony united the royal families of Rumania and Denmark.

LONDON, June 10 -- Apart from early buying of British Government bonds, in which the 3 per cent British Electricity stock reached parity for the first time since it was issued, quiet ruled in the stock market here today.

ALBANY, June 10 -- Federal approval of the new coordinated hospital plan for New York State is expected "within a week" and construction of much-needed facilities will start in the early fall, it was stated today by Dr. John J. Bourke, executive director of the State Joint Hospital Survey and Planning Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 1O -- Primary market prices declined an average of 0.1 per cent during the week ended June 5, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. This fractional drop, reflecting fluctuations of less than 1/2 of 1 per cent in any one of the major commodity groups, brought the bureau's comprehensive index to 164.2 per cent of the 1925 average.

LOS ANGELES, June 10 -- Cecil B. DeMille, motion picture producer, predicted today that "at least 5,000,000 decent, idealistic, good Americans will vote the way the Communist party wants them to vote for their new third party next November."

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Department store sales for the week ended June 5 were down 4 per cent from the corresponding period of a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, though the agency pointed out that in many regions observance of the Memorial Day holiday occurred during the first week in June whereas last year the holiday was observed in the previous week.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Representative Clarence J. Brown, manager of Senator Robert A. Taft's campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination, declared today that the Ohioan would lead the field on the first ballot at the national convention with 312 votes.

Carl Sandburg, poet, biographer, historian and balladeer, will enter the field of the novel with the publication of "Remembrance Rock" on Oct. 7 by Harcourt, Brace. It is a story about America, covering episodes from early seventeenth century England to VE-Day.

Svend O. Sandgren, 52-year-old public school custodian, whose bull terrier pack fatally bit an 11-yearold boy last July 1, was sentenced yesterday in Bronx County Court to one to two years in Sing Sing prison. He was convicted last week by a jury of manslaughter in the second degree.

Two defendants were convicted and two others acquitted in MidManhattan Court yesterday on disorderly conduct charges for which they were arrested on May 11 during a demonstration in front of the Roxy Theatre against the showing of a film, "The Iron Curtain."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 10 -- Two of the leading Communists of the bizonal area were ejected from a meeting of bizonal officials today after the latter had constituted themselves as the official committee of the area for the development of the European Recovery Program.

Dr. Harry S. Mustard, New York City Health Commissioner, was the chief speaker as ninety-two received their medical degrees last night at the ninetieth commencement of the Long Island College of Medicine held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

The night would be hot and close, for if it were not, it would not be a true graduation night. The high school auditorium is crowded, and the glowing pride of parents no doubt adds something to the heat.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 10 (AP) -Egyptian sources said tonight that 300 Israeli fighters had been killed by Egyptian troops at Nitsanim, on the coastal plain south of Tel Aviv. Ten others were taken prisoner. Nitsanim is between El Majdal and Isdud.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Restoration of confidence to risk capital, political and currency stabilization were listed at today's annual meeting of the Machinery and Allied Products Institute, as chief factors in making possible continued large exports of capital goods.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday that operations in the first four months of 1948 resulted in a deficit of $587,784, in contrast with a net income of $3,875,733 in the corresponding period of 1947, when telegraph traffic was heavy due to the telephone strike.
