Almost 300 cadets and officers of the New York State Maritime Academy at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, are scheduled to leave today on a three-month cruise aboard the training ship Empire State II. The vessel will leave the academy dock at the fort at 9 A.M.
PARIS, June 10 -- By a compromise over the religious education issue late today the Schuman Cabinet regrouped its forces for the debate tomorrow on the six-power London accords on Western Germany.
OOTACAMUND, India, June 10 -- The third session of the United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East, now hearing its conclusion here, has had two concrete results:

JERUSALEM, June 10 -- During a special "cease-fire" from 8 A. M. until 2 P. M., arranged by the International Red Cross, the Jews of Jerusalem today got a foretaste of the month-long cease-fire negotiated for the United Nations Security Council by Count Folke Bernadotte which is to begin at 10 A. M. tomorrow.

LONDON, June 10 -- The King's birthday ceremony of Trooping the Color was postponed today because of Britain's post-war shortage of textiles. The threat of rain that would have ruined irreplaceable full dress uniforms of the parading soldiers, led their officers to call off the display.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -The Treasury announced today a special fifteen-day waiver of the limit on purchases of Series F and G Government savings bonds.

EVER since Plato drew up in '~The Republic" his blueprint for an-ideal state, a despotic and frightfully regimented one in modern eyes, men have been imagining utopias where matters would be arranged somewhat better than they are in an imperfect world. Most of the long line of utopias were plans for the improvement of government, and so were primarily political.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -An appropriation bill carrying cash and contract authority for $125,000,000 to speed up the national hospital construction program has been sent to President Truman by Congress.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, filed a petition in the Federal District Court of Appeals here today challenging the constitutionality of the non-Communist affidavit requirement of the Taft-Hartley Law.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 10 (AP) -- The University of Pennsylvania crews joined the Columbia Lions on the Hudson River today in preparation for the annual Poughkeepsie regatta June 22.

Although she praised the city for compiling a large volume of statistics on the social problems of today, Miss Charlotte Carr, executive director of the Citizens Committee on Children, criticized yesterday the lack of information for small area and neighborhood study.
CAIRO, June 10 (UP) -- The Arabs announced tonight that they would cancel the Palestine truce if the Jews showed ill-will in carrying it out.

INWOOD, L.I., June 10 -- Clipping four strokes from par and helped by four handicap strokes, Mal Galletta and Gordon Stott of North Hills won the Long Island Golf Association's best-ball championship with 69 -- 4 -- 65 at the Inwood Country Club today.

LONDON, June 10 -- As a consequence of the House of Lords' vote in favor of retaining the death penalty for capital offenses in Britain, James Chuter Ede, Home Secretary, announced today that from now on "reprieves in each capital case would be decided on its own merits.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 -Mayor Bernard Samuel today told Walter S. Hallanan, chairman of the committee on arrangements for the Republican National Convention, that it would be impossible to accede to the Republicans' request for permission to use Independence Hall for meetings during the convention.

Boston, Mass., borrowed yesterday $5,000,000 on temporary loan notes dated June 15 and due Nov. 8 and sold to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at an interest rate of 1.07 per cent. The bankers paid a premium of $109. The notes were reoffered to investors at a price to yield 0.9 per cent.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 10 -- The Soviet Union complained to the United States today that the magazine Newsweek was guilty of spreading propaganda for a new world war.
DETROIT, June 10 -- Shortages of supplies caused major lay-offs in the automotive industry today.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -Prospects are that this year's wheat crop will be the second largest in history, totaling 1,192,425,000 bushels, the Department of Agriculture said today.

NEWARK, N.J., June 10 -John B. Keenan, Director of Public Safety, an active Democrat since 1905 and a delegate to the party's convention in Philadelphia, received a letter today from The Philadelphia Bulletin congratulating him on his "election as a delegate to the Republican Convention" and welcoming him to the City of Brotherly Love.

CAIRO, June 10 UP) -- The Lebanese Government authorized the seizure of all Israel-bound shipments touching Beirut. Israel, in accepting the truce, already had declared any Arab attempt to confiscate or hold up cargoes would be regarded as a "warlike act."
AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, June 10 (UP) -- With the four-week truce only a few hours away, this was the military picture in the Holy Land:

LONDON, June 10 -- Orders have been sent from Haganah headquarters in the State of Israel to all recruiting agents in Europe and North America asking them to halt the movement of recruits toward Palestine during the ceasefire that takes effect for four weeks from tomorrow.

The Association of Knitted Glove and Mitten Manufacturers will seek to extend the knitted glove season as part of its "Wools for Warmth" promotional campaign, it was announced yesterday at the fall preview, fashion show in the Pennsylvania Hotel.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -Financing of small business stock issues costs 15 to 20 per cent on amounts under $500,000, the House Small Business Committee was told today.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Grain futures had an irregular course today, evening-up operations for the June Government report influencing prices materially. In all pits the July delivery was the weakest, while there appeared to be some short covering in the deferred positions.

CLEVELAND, June 10 -- A new comprehensive code of medical ethics is being prepared for final approval next year, the Rev. Gerald Kelly of St. Mary's College, St. Mary's, Kan, told the closing session of the Catholic Hospital Association convention today.

In the currant effort to settle the annual dispute between employing shipping operators and the maritime unions, much more is at stake than the token elements of wages, hiring terms and working conditions. The presence in New York of Harry Bridges, leader of the West Coast longshoremen and long a proponent of the left-wing philosophy as applied to the merchant marine, eloquently reflects political overtones in the dispute.

Any hope that prices will be lower this week-end will be destroyed as soon as consumers set foot inside retail markets today. The news is just about as budget blasting as it could be, according to the City Department of Markets.

LONDON, June 10 ~UP~LadyAstor, an outspoken temperanceleader, auctioned three bottles ofgin in the House of Commons to'day for $60 each. Personally, shesaid, she wouldn't give "tuppence"for them; Lady Astor consentedto serve as auctioneer because theproceeds went toward a memoria~for an old colleague and pioneerwoman trade unionist, MargAret1~c~C~llar~ Lady ~.stor prefacedthe auction with a temperance lecture to the prospective bidders.

BOSTON, June 10 (AP) -- Breaking out with their highest scoring inning of the season -- eight runs at the expense of Bob Feller -- the Red Sox today socked the Indians, 15 -- 7, for their second decision of the year in eight meetings with Cleveland.

The stock market was lifted into new high ground yesterday when buying developed in the aircraft division. The announcement by the Air Force that it would purchase 2,201 new planes as the first step toward the seventy-group program touched off a broad demand for issues of the warplane manufacturers.

A bit of Cape Cod atmosphere came to New York yesterday when Filene's of Boston and the New Haven Railroad staged a fashion show on the balcony above the concourse of the Grand Central Terminal. There 'was a touch of realism about this affair~ for 1,000 square feet of sand brough.t from Cape Cod provided the beach on I which'models clad in fetching play and bathing togs disported themselves in a make-believe beach scene.

NUREMBERG, Germany, June 10 -- In a four-hour rebuttal strongly attacking defense arguments that I. G. Farben executives did not realize Adolf Hitler was rearming Germany for aggressive war, the prosecution said its last word today in the trial of those executives.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 10 -Premier David Ben-Gurion today issued a warning to anyone in the state or occupied areas who violated the truce.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 10 -- After more than three months of a diplomatic truce, the sharp quarreling between the Republic of Indonesia and the Netherlands began again today, as each side accused the other of trying to gain control of all the islands of the East Indies.
ROME, June 10 (AP) -- Vatican prelates said today that the wedding in Athens of Princess Anne and former King Michael was "no marriage" in the eyes of the Roman Catholic church.

LEXINGTON, N.C., June 10 -North Carolina supporters of Governor Dewey for the Republican Presidential nomination tonight predicted confidently that he would get the sixteen votes he had been promised before. They added that he would probably get two additional, for a total of eighteen, with the balance divided four for Senator Robert A. Taft and two for Harold Stassen.

BERLIN, June 10 -- The main Communist attack on the Western Allies' plans for Western Germany began today. The party published its "interpretation" of what the plans mean to Germans and started its final drive to win signatures for the "People's Congress" petition on German unity before the petitioning period ends Sunday.

Robert Gunderson, blind 29-yearold radio expert, attended a luncheon in his honor yesterday at the New York Institute for the Education of the Blind, 999 Pelham Parkway, the Bronx, where on June 25 he will complete thirteen years as a teacher of radio.

In what amounted to an open declaration of war on Congressional candidates backed by Henry Wallace's third party, Louis Hollander, state president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, announced last night that the regional CIO Political Action Committee would oppose the election of Lee Pressman, former general counsel of the CIO, as Representative from the Fourteenth District in Brooklyn.

Frank Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., will play the opening stadium match in the national professional championships starting tomorrow at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills. The schedule was announced yesterday by P. Schuyler Van Bloem, the chairman.

Newspapers are being aided toward their third consecutive recordbreaking year of advertising gains by management's growing recognition that "all business is local," Alfred B. Stanford, director of the Bureau of Advertising, ANPA, stated in the bureau's thirty-fifth annual report, released yesterday.

With the exception of one canvas, Honore Daumier's "Don Quixote and Sancho Panza," the collection of German paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art will be shown in its entirety at its next display in the Philadelphia museum of Art, it was announced last night.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 10 -- Dom Morano of Orchard Hills, tournament winner in 1935, captured the medal in the qualifying round for the New Jersey state amateur golf championship at the Upper Montclair Country Club today.

GENEVA, June 10 -- Europe's requirements for United States coal will be reduced by 15 per cent in the third quarter of 1948 if the pattern of coal exports and imports recommended by the Coal Committee of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe is followed.

LOS ANGELES, June 10 -- In a bid to retain the nation's top golf title, Lew Worsham, defending champion, met the best his challengers offered today in the opening round of the United States open and went into a tie for the lead with a 67 over the Riviera Country Club course.

The Senate has voted a workable Selective Service Act to provide the men needed to fill the ranks of our armed forces. It is now squarely up to the House, and to the Republican leadership there, to force out of the House Rules Committee the companion measure that has been gathering dust in the Committee's files for weeks.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 10 -- On the eve of the cease-fire in Palestine, both sides appeared to be striking out with mighty force, to improve their positions before the deadline of 10 o'clock [Israeli time] tomorrow morning.
ST. LOUIS, June 10 (AP) -- Cardinal pitching again failed miserably tonight and the onrushing Braves made it two in a row over St. Louis, 10 to 2.
SANTIAGO, Chile, June 10 -The United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America today for the first time heard from a European country -- France.

LONDON, June 10 (AP) -- Mrs. Kay Stammers Menzies, the first playing captain of a British Wightman Cup team in many years, will lead the home challenge on the United States monopoly of the tennis trophy tomorrow with little hope of victory.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 10 -- The Netherlands Government, it was learned today, will reject a Soviet protest against what was called a "warmongering" article in the Socialist newspaper Het Vrije Volk of Amsterdam. The Government's view is that the article was legitimate comment and did not infringe Dutch law.

The triangular plot containing twenty-four acres on Ravine Drive Sands Point Road and Old Sands Point Road near Manor Haven Port Washington, L. I., has been purchased by the Union Free School District No. 4 of the Town of North Hempstead as the site for a proposed new school.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Bituminous coal contract negotiations took a turn for the worse today, canceling the limited optimism arising from the first $100-amonth pension offer made by the mine operators yesterday.

SEATTLE, Wash., June 10 -President Truman offered today the vision of a great network of river control projects but declared its realization would demand "the toughest kind of fight" against private interests and their friends in Congress.

A new bonus plan for salesmen in the Grocery Products Division of Pillsbury Mills, Inc., said to be a "radical departure" from any incentive compensation plan previously used in the flour industries, will be adopted immediately, Richard C. Painter, seaboard regional sales manager, disclosed in an interview yesterday.

LONDON, June 10 -- A new convention containing regulations designed to minimize the hazards of sea transport was signed here tonight by twenty-seven nations at the final session of the International Conference on Safety of Life at Sea.

ROME, June 10 -- Although both nations implicitly admit the necessity for joint action in the Mediterranean basin and have so admitted since the North African invasion in 1942, Britain and the United States are now pursuing somewhat divergent policies at several points in this area.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 10 -- Reports from Washington that Congress might adjourn without passing the $65,000,000 loan for the United Nations headquarters put a damper tonight on hopes that excavation for the East River site in Manhattan could start soon.

Bidding was active and more than $213,000 was recovered by the War Assets Administration in the second day of its auction sale at the Bronx Warehouse, Eastchester Road and Haswell Street, officials revealed yesterday. Remaining for sale are goods valued at acquisition cost of more than $2,000,000, of a total of about $9,000,000 originally offered at this auction, they added.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -Relief Pitcher Frank Biscan walked a batter to force across the winning run with one out in the ninth inning tonight as Washington edged the Browns, 5 -- 4. The Senators swept the three-game series with St. Louis, which rallied for two runs to tie the score at 4 -- 4 in the ninth.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Air Force will place orders in the fiscal year starting July 1 for 2,201 new airplanes costing $1,345,165,000, Secretary W. Stuart Symington said today. This total is in addition to $653,635,000 already allocated by the Air Force for purchase of new airplanes for the Navy.

Miss Patricia O'Sullivan of Orange, Conn., became the new women's Eastern golf champion with rounds of 76, 72 and 81 for a three-day, 54-hole total of 229 in the tourney concluded yesterday over the North Hills links in Douglaston, Queens.

WARSAW, June 10 -- The Government has ordered the Polish Orthodox Church to regulate its autocephalous (self-governing) position immediately -- in other words, to make its peace with the Russian mother church and resubmit to the authority of the Patriarch Alexei of Moscow.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -An examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission recommended today that the railroads consolidate and simplify their varied freight-rate schedules for the movement of wool and mohair.
Mayor O'Dwyer and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower reviewed thousands of Brooklyn's school children in parades yesterday afternoon held under the flags of peace and goodwill.

To become the first man to fly an airplane faster than the speed of sound and live to tell about it, Capt. Charles E. Yeager, World War II fighter ace from Myra, W. Va., sent the stubby Bell XS-1 rocket plane hurtling through space about twenty-five times faster than the first flight of the Wright brothers and from 100 to 200 miles an hour faster than the speed of a pistol bullet.
Tom Clark, United States Attorney General, called last night for joint action by all nations to bring about a speedy and lasting peace between the Arabs and Jews in the Near East.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Democratic hopes for unconditional extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act received a blow today when no Senate Republican, at a party conference, raised his voice against the so-called Millikin-Vandenberg compromise.

Herman H. Pancake has been appointed manager of the American Car and Foundry Company's new Mine Car and Special Products Sales Division, following retirement of H. D. Distelhurst, manager of the Miscellaneous Sales Division, after forty-three years with ACF.

LONDON, June 10 -- The German mentality has altered very little since Adolf Hitler's downfall, the International Committee for the Study of European Questions reported today. This committee is composed of private citizens in Britain, France, Norway and Belgium.

Temporary closing of the edifice of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, East Sixteenth Street and Stuyvesant Square, may be necessary this summer unless sufficient funds and pledges toward a goal of $185,000 for repairs are in hand soon, it was said yesterday.
For the first time in medical history, a group of wheel-chair patients took a show they had produced -- as part of their rehabilitation training -- on the road yesterday.

It is deeply disturbing to note that the United States Senate has passed a so-called displaced persons bill which is both flagrantly discriminatory and administratively impracticable. The bill is ineffective to accomplish its avowed purpose and some of its provisions are downright un-American. Here are its major defects:
Following is the text of President Truman's address at Seattle yesterday as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
NOTTINGHAM, England, June 10 (Reuters) -- England scored 165 in its first innings as the opening test of the five-match cricket series with Australia began today. Australia tallied 17 without loss.

PARIS, June 10 -- Jean Monnet, author of France's plan for recovery, in an exclusive interview today said that his second report, just issued, was in essence a warning to the French nation that there was a limit both in time and amount as to what could be expected from United States aid.
A $300 donation may be received by the United Jewish Appeal as the result of an altercation between two rival furniture dealers in an auction room last Thursday.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Harold E. Stassen, Republican Presidential contender, demanded today full restoration of the legislative authorization for the European Recovery Program as "a question of the national honor of the United States." The former Minnesota Governor went before the Senate Appropriations Committee at his own request to appeal to its Republican majority "not to tarnish the national honor of our country at this late hour in the session."
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- During the week ended June 9 member bank reserve balance increased $60,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LONDON, June 10 -- The Bowater Paper Corporation has entered into a contract to make newsprint in Britain for a publisher in the United States, a spokesman for the corporation said today. He reported British Government approval for the transaction, which is expected to earn about $2,500,000 in dollar exchange.
Random notes.

More extensive research to evaluate the content of atmospheric dust was advocated yesterday by James H. Carter, Commissioner of Smoke Regulation in St. Louis, as a means of achieving smoke and dust abatement throughout the country.

Rain failed to dampen the ardor of the gardeners, amateur and professional, who attended the annual Rose Growers Day at the New York Botanical Garden yesterday. Buds had opened in spite of unfavorable weather, so that there was considerable bloom, and all features of the program were presented, although not in their scheduled order.
The general executive board of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, AFL, voted unanimously yesterday to authorize a loan of $1,000,000 from the union treasury to the new State of Israel.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Even if -- as seems likely -- the fight over the European Recovery Program appropriation is settled with a compromise, the general feeling here is that the much more basic problem of the authority and mental attitude of the House Appropriations Committee will remain, regardless of the outcome of the November elections.

KWEISUI, China, June 8 (Delayed) -- The hunger scourge that has sent armies marching for thousands of years in Inner Asia has become a potent factor in the Communist-Nationalist struggle for Inner Mongolia.

BERLIN, June 10 -- The split between the Eastern and Western zones of Germany was intensified tonight when the British Military Government announced it had stopped issuing permits for interzonal travel because of "inexplicable Soviet restrictions."

Largely influenced by financing of European Cooperation Administration shipments, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $12,000,000 last week.
PARIS, June 10 --- Britain day was the first of sixteen nations to ratify the Convention setting up the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

A pair of adventuresome backers and sponsors, Marjorie Ewing and her husband, Sherman, have something novel in store for Broadway. In association with Giovanni Cardelli of Chicago's Opera Theatre, the couple will escort "The Rape of Lucretia" to the local stage in November, it was confirmed yesterday by Mr. Ewing.

PITTSBURGH, June 10 -- Ernie Bonham, the big ex-Yankee righthander, hurled a brilliant twohitter for his first triumph of the campaign as the Pirates beat the Dodgers, 4 -- 1, tonight before a crowd of 30,344 thrilled Forbes Field fans.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 10 -Oscar Levant was signed today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for a leading role with Fred Astaire and Judy Garland in "The Barclays of Broadway," a backstage comedy which Betty Comden and Adolph Green have written.

The National Court of Honor of the Boy Scouts of America will award medals and certificates to eighteen Boy Scouts and two cub scouts who saved the lives of others, it was announced yesterday by Dr. George J. Fisher, National Scout Commissioner.

The Hull Reciprocal Trade program is scheduled to expire by limitation at midnight tomorrow. If there is to be no gap, Congress has only a matter of hours, therefore, to decide whether or not it means to continue this legislation unimpaired, or to carry out the intention implicit in the House bill to "amend it to death."

The attempt of isolationists in Congress to wreck the European Recovery Program by slashing the funds for it has led to a showdown within the Republican party which recalls a like struggle over the League of Nations following the First World War. Then, too, many Republican leaders expressed themselves in favor of international cooperation in principle, but permitted this principle to be defeated and buried in public apathy, with consequences which are now history.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 10 (AP) -The two top-ranking players in the Southern tennis tournament swept to their third triumphs today.

TOKYO, June 10 -- The Japanese Government plans to increase its issue of unsecured paper money by about one-third if its record budget for 1948 is approved by the Diet, Finance Minister Tokutaro Kitamura told Parliament's upper house today.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Facsimile broadcasting on a commercial basis by licensees of FM (frequency modulation) radio stations operating commercially was authorized by the Federal Communications Commission in an order issued today, effective July 15.

Bond men ascribed the shading of prices yesterday in the markets for Treasury and municipal bonds to the announcement from Washington that the limitations on subscriptions to Series F and Series G savings bonds by professional investing institutions are to be relaxed for a fortnight in July.
NEWARK, June 10 -- Rocky Graziano weighed 158 1/2 pounds and Tony Zale 158 3/4 for the scheduled fifteen-round title bout tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -Government officials determined to prevent an all-coast, CIO maritime strike next week found themselves entangled today in a strange dilemma.

Adjustment of textile prices in recent weeks to reasonable levels removes one of the principal obstacles for exporters seeking to stem the downward trend in fabric sales abroad, it was pointed out yesterday by N. S. W. Vanderhoef, retiring president of the Textile Export Association of the United States.

Reginald Pearman, whose primary goal in the Olympics is the 800-meter run, will make his bid in that event in the Sydenham Hospital benefit trace meet at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island tomorrow evening. His performance against a field that includes Herb Barren, Bob Rehberg, Joe Nowicki and Jerry Connolly is likely to play an important part in shaping his future plans.

It was a rather provocative letter, even though it meant considerable excavating to dig up the facts. I have never heard the claim of Princeton refuted," it said, "that Joseph M. (Mac) Mann, on May 29, 1875, pitched the first no-hit, no-run game against Yale." The letter was signed by Stanley S. Morris, a Princetonian, of course.

CAMBRIDGE, England, June 10 -- The West must call a halt to Communist fifth columns, Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, former Prime Minister of South Africa, said today on being made Chancellor of Cambridge University.

The American Federation of Awtswill make bids on all the .~17 paintings of the State 'Department'scontroversial collection of America~n art which is being sold undersealed bids as "surplus" propertyby the War Assets Administration,it was announced yesterday at ameeting sponsored by ArtistsEquity Association.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 10 -- The Rev. Janos Asztalos, Roman Catholic rector on trial here by court-martial for fomenting sedition and inciting to murder during last week's riot in the village of Pacspetri against the nationalization of Catholic schools, made a confession in court today of the kind that so frequently occurs in eastern European countries.

Chester Bowles, addressing a world government rally at Carnegie -Hall, proposed last night that this country begin discussions in the United Nations of the steps necessary to create within that-organization "the machinery of world law within five or ten years at most."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 10 -- German officials have asked the occupation authorities to delay calling a constituent assembly until a "reasonable period" after Sept. 1, the date discussed at the London conference.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday and final prices were 3 to 40 points net lower, led by the July contract.
CHICAGO, June 10 -- The Giants, with Big Jawn Mize snapping smartly out of his prolonged batting drought, did some effective ball swatting today.

NEWARK, N.J., June 10 -- Tony Zale, unmarked and certainly unharmed by Rocky Graziano, will defend the middleweight championship he regained tonight against any man selected by the promoters -- with one exception. There will be no more meetings with Graziano.

PRETORIA, South Africa, June 10 -- While Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts was academically discussin communism and fifth columns at Cambridge University today the new South African Cabinet was considering outlawing the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Senate passed the stop-gap selective draft bill today by a 78-to-10 vote. The measure calls for the induction, for two years of military service, of up to 250,000 men, 19 through 25 years of age, during the fiscal year starting July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- By the narrowest margin and a midday switch of a Republican vote, outnumbered Democrats of the House Banking and Currency Committee won approval today of the major features of the Administrationsponsored Taft-Ellender-Wagner Housing Bill.

The board of the New York State Banking Department has added to the legal list four securities of a par value totaling $40,335,000, Elliott V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday. The securities are:

As a reward for their courage and efficient rehabilitation, forty physically handicapped young men and women received prizes and certificates yesterday at annual graduation ceremonies of the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled. Twenty-third Street and First Avenue.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The Senate Rules Committee today approved the expenditure of $50,000 for an investigation into the extent and character of economic concentration in this country.

Trial of a suit to test the legality of Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander's drive against pinball machines got under way yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora. The courtroom was crowded with machines manufacturers contend are legal but which the authorities say have either parts of the free-play equipment or may be converted readily for such purposes.

In view of the Soviet record for cc operation on such matters as atomic weapons and armaments in genera Germany and Japan, Korea and China noninterference in the affairs of other countries, economic restoration, the defense of democracy and the insuring of civil rights in all countries.

The Columbia Broadcasting System will offer the world premiere of "The Creation," a composition for narrator and orchestra by the American composer, Dehman Engel, on Sunday, June 20, from 3 to 4:30 P.M. The CBS symphony will be conducted by the composer for the initial performance, and Michael Redgrave, British actor, will be heard as narrator.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- William R. McComb, Wage and Hour Administrator, advised employers today that the Supreme Court decision this week on overtime pay would require changes in some pay practices for week-end and holiday work.

LONDON, June 11 (AP) -- America's tennis girls took a 2-1 lead at the outset of the Wightman Cup matches at Wimbledon today, but a young scrapper named Mrs. Molly Blair brought great cheer to British hearts.
Net income of the First National Stores, Inc., for the fiscal year ended on March 27 last, amounted to $5,629,705, a preliminary report said yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 11 (AP) -- The final campfire of the Grand Army of the Republic in New York State faded into embers tonight. The 82-year-old Civil War organization passed into history as James A. Hard, 106-year-old state commander, wrote the last chapter.
A 7-year-old boy suffering from a rare heart ailment arrived here yesterday on the Robin Line freighter Joliet Victory after a 7,860-mile voyage from Lourenco Marques, Portuguese East Africa.

Three more persons accused as members of a fake automobile accident ring that had defrauded insurance companies of $200,000 in two years were arraigned yesterday before General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein. They entered pleas of not guilty to indictments charging them with first degree grand larceny, attempted first degree grand larceny, filing false insurance claims and conspiracy.

LOS ANGELES, June 11 -- One of golf's old records went into the discard today when Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., smashed the low total for the initial thirty-six holes of the United States open championship by playing the Riviera Country Club course in 69 strokes for the second consecutive time.

ALBANY, June 11 -- The Court of Appeals dismissed without opinion today an action attacking the constitutionality of allocating $128,000 from the State Emergency Housing Fund to Canisius College, a Catholic institution in Buffalo.

Long Island Railroad commuters, whose chilly feelings toward the line have not yet thawed out since the winter's heavy snows played general havoc, suffered one more blow last night. This time, the officials of the road, who only a short while ago had sent out a bevy of handpicked girls to assure everybody that things would be better, could do nothing but own up and say they were sorry.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Senate Republican leaders decided today to let the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act expire at mid-night tomorrow, as prospects of week-end absences prompted a change of plans which originally called for final Congressional action on an extension before the deadline.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 (AP) -- Charles H. Grakelow refused today to accept dismissal from his post of Director of Supplies and Purchases as a special meeting of the City Council was called for Tuesday to act on nomination of Howard D. Stern as his successor.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- A phonograph mechanism for installation in motor-driven vehicles geared to provide while in motion audible instruction or comment pertinent to the route, including objects of interest along the way or, in the case of aircraft, objectives and directives for the information and guidance of the pilot, was one of the 427 inventions on which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

What the mechanically trained members of a police emergency squad were unable to do later, two teen-age boys succeeded in doing in the Bronx last night -- start a Diesel-powered bulldozer rolling under power and in gear.

The Sidney E. Hutchinson Cup, symbolic of the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League championship, has been won by Dartmouth College with a slate of seven victories and one setback, according to the official announcement yesterday.

Parents' attitudes toward a boy going to camp and competent cabin leadership when he gets there are major factors making for successful camping experience, according to facts newly compiled for the National Council, Y.M.C.A.
JACKSON, Miss., June 11 (AP) -- States rights Democrats today made public a four-point program of action they plan to follow in the Democratic National Convention.

The market for new capital next week will be on the inactive side, compared with the business of the recent past. The most substantial offering is the Kansas City Power and Light Company's issue of $12,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds and 80,000 shares of $100 par value preferred stock, on which bidding will take place on Monday.

Mrs. Henry Ford Sr. was one of the estimated 55,000 visitors yesterday at the Ford Motor Company exhibition of 1949 cars at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. She watched the series of attractions and passing crowds with keen interest, then smiled as she told of the first automobile show in which her late husband, founder of the Ford company, took part.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today the reorganization plan of Commonwealth and Southern Corporation is "unfair" to preferred stockholders.

DUNKIRK, N.Y., June 11 -- An attempt to organize the "neighborly spirit" of America on a national scale got under way here today in this town which considers itself the birthplace of the spreading movement for adoption of devastated European towns.
One thousand questionnaires designed to inform the public on the danger of closing child care centers for children of working mothers here will be distributed in Times Square today.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- When the Senate passed the so-called Vandenberg resolution tonight, 64 to 4, it rejected two extremely stubborn and popular American illusions, that there is safety for America in rejecting any sort of entangling commitments to other nations, and that the "balance of power" is an evil and discredited doctrine, incompatible with collective security, the United Nations and peace.

With sunny but hazy skies and warm temperatures forecast for this afternoon, New Yorkers are expected to turn out en masse to watch the "New York at Work" parade as it swings down Fifth Avenue from Ninety-fifth to Fifty-fifth Streets.
BERLIN, June 11 -- British troops halted today a Russian railroad train bound to Paris from Moscow at the border of the British Zone, the Soviet-licensed news service ADN reported tonight.

Total expenditures for alcoholic beverages, including public revenues, amounted to $9.6 billion in 1947, the office of Business Economics, Department of Commerce, revealed here yesterday on the basis of its latest estimates. Commenting upon this release, Vice Admiral F.E.M. Whiting, president of Licensed Beverage Industries, Inc., an industrial trade association, pointed out that the Department of Commerce report included $2,061,000,000 in direct, Federal, state and local taxes.

The apartment house for ten families at 103 West 114th Street was sold by Berkin Estates, Inc., represented by Barry Katzman, attorneys, to the Consolidated Eurekas Corporation, which insured title with the City Title Insurance Company. David Edwards represented the buyer, who paid cash over a mortgage of $13,350.

PARIS, June 11 -- Foreign Minister Bidault asked an unenthusiastic Assembly today to approve the recommendations of the six-power London conference on Western Germany to rebuild Europe in cooperation with the United States and Britain.

PITTSBURGH, June 11 -- The Dodgers never do anything the easy way. They finally salvaged a game from the Pirates today but it took 'em thirteen innings and three hours and twenty-four minutes to do it.

Eventful, indeed, was last night at the Stadium, where the Yankees and indians, the umpires, the fans and the weather took part in a melodramatic production that, at best, could only be tied in Hollywood -- or Brooklyn.

Interest in municipal government and civic circles centered yesterday on how to obtain quickly the money to build sewage-disposal plants, which Health Commissioner Harry S. Mustard asserted on Thursday were necessary to make city bathing beaches safe.

Leon Henderson, national chairman of Americans for Democratic Action, predicted last night that "roaring reaction would ride the rails" if independent voters failed this November to rise in support of progressive nominees for Congress.
Monday will be Flay Day, commemorating the 171st anniversary of the adoption of the national flag by Congress. Ceremonies marking the anniversary will be held tomorrow and also on Monday.
Scoring 18 of a possible 22 points, the New York Women's team retained the Griscom Cup in intercity golf competition yesterday over the North Hills Country Club course at Douglaston, Queens.
The passports of ten prospective passengers for troubled Palestine were seized and permission to sail on the liner Marine Carp was refused them last night. All were citizens of the United States.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 11 -- Pleas of not guilty were entered today by Joseph Buckley, Hudson County Penitentiary warden, and seven other penitentiary employes who were indicted two weeks ago by a Hudson County grand jury.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- A resolution endorsing the third party candidacy of Henry A. Wallace marked the closing session today of the five-day biennial convention of the United Furniture Workers of America, CIO, which has 55,000 members throughout the country.

Three group shows opening in the galleries this week offer a variety of both experimental and conventional work. Two are summer shows that come as resumes of the season and may be seen at the Mortimer Levitt and Contemporary Art galleries, respectively, while a group of young printmakers will show abstractions at the Jacques Seligmann Gallery.
LOS ANGELES, June 11 (AP) -- California's leading sire, Alibhai, was sold today for $500,000 by Louis B. Mayer to a syndicate of Kentucky breeders headed by Leslie Combs 2d.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, June 11 -- Israeli forces broke the cease-fire when it was only seven hours old with heavy fire on Arab Legion posts around Lydda at 1 P.M., Greenwich time [9 A.M. in New York and 3 P.M. in Palestine], a Trans-Jordan official charged today.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 11 -- Ray Torgerson and John F. Murphy of the Oakland Golf Club were four strokes under course figures with 34, 34 -- 68 to lead the qualifiers in the Cherry Valley member-guest tournament today.

The Berlin masterpieces are being packed off to Philadelphia today after nearly a month's visit at the Metropolitan Museum. As the most important single collection of old masters ever shown in New York, these pictures, the cream of the ruined galleries in the devastated capital of the old Reich, attracted great popular interest, inspired not only by love of art but by the curiosity aroused by heirlooms and war trophies.

The confused maritime labor issue, which threatens to culminate in a strike next week, was further complicated yesterday when shipping operators of the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts filed charges of unfair labor practices with the National Labor Relations Board against two of the leading unions.

Flanked by a legal battery of five attorneys headed by Arthur Garfield Hays, veteran trial lawyer, Gus Fusaro, the $47-a-week elevator starter accused of losing $250,000 of his friends' money through faulty stock investments, went on trial yesterday in General Sessions.

ST. LOUIS, June 11 (AP) -- The rampant Boston Braves swept their three-game series with the St. Louis Cardinals by rallying in the late innings tonight to win, 7 to 3. They took over undisputed possession of first place in the National League.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 11 -- James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, read before the convention of his union here today a telegram sent by President Truman from the Presidential train at Olympia, Wash., in which Mr. Truman charged that Congress, by commission and omission, was imperiling the future of America.

Calumet Farm's Citation, the handicappers' best friend, goes after the big one today -- the eightieth edition of the mile-and-a-half Belmont Stakes, oldest and most important race of the triple-crown series for 3-year-old thoroughbreds.

As successor to the Alien Property Custodian, Attorney General Tom Clark filed suit in Federal court yesterday against the Columbia Broadcasting System, the Procter Gamble Company and the advertising firm of Pedlar Ryan, Inc., for alleged infringement of the Government's copyright interests in the French novel "Mayerling."

Leading cancer research authorities declared yesterday that a large number of cancer cases were curable but progress toward solving the over-all puzzle of cancer must await the solution of some of the basic mysteries of life and growth.
PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- Following is the text of the speech made today by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio before the Union League Club of this city:

NEWARK, N.J., June 11 -- Mrs. Suzanne Kremer, 23 years old, a photographer living at 200 East Fifty-sixth Street, New York, who was arrested here last night when she refused to remove her pet cocker spaniel from the coach of a St. Louis-bound Pennsylvania train, was released today on her own recognizance, to answer on June 23 a charge of creating a disturbance.

ATHENS, June 11 -- The Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced today that it had received from the Greek delegate to the United Nations a message saying that Bulgaria sought "the restoration of normal diplomatic relations between Bulgaria and Greece."
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The text of the statement by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, to the Senate Appropriations Committee today follows:

NUREMBERG, Germany, June 11 -- Dr. Walter Siemers, German defense counsel representing Dr. Georg von Schnitzler, leveled an informal indictment against the Allies' handling of property in Germany during the final court session, today in the trial of I.G. Farben executives.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 11 -- Consolidation of the Tarrytown, Dobbs Ferry and Ossining Hospitals into a general hospital to serve the fifteen-mile segment of the Hudson Valley embraced by the present institutions was recommended today in a survey financed by John D. Rockefeller 3d.

NEWARK, N.J., June 11 (AP) -- Vice Chancellor John O. Bigelow temporarily restrained the board of directors of the Cuba Company today from proceeding with two proposed plans for meeting payments of a $6,937,077 bond issue due Jan. 1, 1949.
NANKING, June 11 -- Premier Wong Wen-hao had a hostile reception today when he appeared before the Legislative Yuan to outline his new Cabinet's policy.

TOKYO, June 11 -- Scandal investigations are beginning to shake the Ashida Cabinet. Forty leftist members of the Socialist party met yesterday and adopted a resolution demanding the removal of Deputy Premier Suehiro Nishio, a Socialist.

EASTON, Pa., June 11 -- In the commencement address at Lafayette College today Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, issued a challenge to make democracy work in the United States if this country is to help make democracy work abroad.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 -- Interest in the recent $10,000,000 common-stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation waned drastically on the West Coast just before the stock was offered to the public on Feb. 4, securities dealers told a Securities and Exchange Commission board of inquiry here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 11 Two delegates to the Assembly of the International Civil Aviation Organization in Geneva have asked for a full study of "a fair and economic system" by which airlines and other users of airports and their facilities will pay shares in the costs of airfield services, according to a report received from ICAO at United Nations headquarters.

Col. David Marcus, former New York City Commissioner of Correction and holder of the Distinguished Service Cross for his part in the surrenders of Italy and Germany and of the Bronze Star Medal for gallantry in action, was killed while leading Haganah forces on the Jerusalem front a few hours before the Arab-Israeli cease-fire became effective, local representatives of the Provisional Government of Israel announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- John L. Lewis and Senator H. Styles Bridges, respective miner and neutral trustees of the 1947 Welfare and Retirement Fund of the United Mine Workers of America, voted today, over the vigorous opposition of Ezra Van Horn, operators' trustee, to have the fund which they administer assume the obligations incurred by the 1946 welfare fund.

Motorists halted, passersby stared and even the patrolman on the beat was startled yesterday while groups of grimly determined women with towels wrapped around their heads and white smocks over their dresses darted across Fifth Avenue at Fifty-seventh Street during the congested shopping hours.

The L. S. Building Corporation, represented by Ben Halpern, attorney, has purchased an L-shaped plot of vacant land in Long Island City, Queens, from the City of New York for cash above a mortgage of $35,050. The property is on the east side of Steinway Court, 105 feet south of Broadway, extending through to the south side of Broadway.

A progressive, voluntary dental health insurance plan under which children would be able to receive proper care of their teeth at a cost of one cent a week will be presented before the American Academy of Dental Medicine at its second annual meeting, to be held today and tomorrow in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

The celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the Greater City starts today with a parade down Fifth Avenue. Our thoughts, as residents of New York, tumble about in past, present and future on such an occasion. We are now a city of 8,000,000 population.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Prospects for House action on the stop-gap selective draft, following yesterday's Senate approval of a program by a vote of 78 to 10, improved today. Both Republican and Democratic leaders in the House said they had become convinced by canvasses that the Rules Committee would allow the chamber's draft measure to go to the floor for a voting decision.

Considerably brightened, the New York Public Library's painting by Michael Munkacsy, "Blind Milton Dictating 'Paradise Lost' to His Daughters," was rehung yesterday on the south landing of the Central Building's second floor after an absence of nearly six months.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., June 11 -- In avoiding payment of ten-cent tolls on the Hutchinson River Parkway here, motorists are following a serpentine route through the village street for one mile and creating a "dreadful" situation, residents told village and Westchester county officials today.

OUJDA, French Morocco, June 11 (AP) -- Mohamed Hajoui, Pacha of Oujda, was stabbed here today by a fanatic Moslem after the funerals of the Jewish victims of the June 7 riots. Five Jews were killed and thirty other persons were injured in the riots.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- President Truman's castigation of the present Republican Congress as "the worst Congress we have had since the first one met" was denounced today by Senator Robert A. Taft as "an attack on the principle of representative government itself."

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- People in the northeastern United States need not have become excited if the sun blacked out today. The Weather Bureau said there was a gigantic smoke "cloud" in the air, traveling south from a Canadian forest fire.

VIENNA, June 11 -- Col. Gen. Vladimir Kurasov charged at the Allied Council meeting today that I some Austrian newspapers had been carrying on propaganda likely to encourage war and that the United States and British occupation powers bore "all the guilt and responsibility" for this.

In a radical departure from its present policy of exclusive war-service activities, the American Theatre Wing has decided to permit civilians as well as former GI's to participate in its training program for professionals in the amusement industry, it was announced yesterday.

GENEVA, June 11 -- French and Australia delegations have submitted resolutions to the economic commission of the Assembly of the International Civil Aviation Organization, calling for stepped-up efforts to establish international ownership of international airlines.

HARRISON, N.Y., June 11 -- Ermine Coat, owned by the Rolling Rock Farms of Ligonier, Pa., started well in the conformation hunter competition of the Greenwich horse show at the Blind Brook polo grounds today.

The periodic collection of various particles from the air by means of glass jars or similar containers strategically placed in an industrial community was recommended yesterday as a basis for standardizing the measurement of air pollution.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 11 -- Despite complaints of isolated violations by both sides, the first day of the United Nations cease-fire and truce in Palestine proceeded substantially according to schedule. Representatives of Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator, held several telephone conversations with officials here, and these were devoted entirely to the details of the proposed control plan.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 11 -- Victor Mature was named today for leading roles in two pictures, "Samson and Delilah" at Paramount and "Interference" at RKO.

Faced with buying cooking utensils for her new kitchen, the June bride may turn to her mother for answers to such questions as, "What do I really need? Would a ten-inch frying pan be better than an eight-inch? How many cake pans do you use regularly?"

BOSTON, June 11 (AP) -- With Ted Williams driving in seven of their runs, the Boston Red Sex opened a four-game series with the lowly Chicago White Sox by scoring 12-4 victory tonight before 33,420 fans. Dom DiMaggio and Johnny Pesky each tallied four times during the one-sided affair, which was interrupted twenty minutes by a shower.

The application of milk producers in the New York milkshed for higher prices will be fought by the city at the public hearing to be held by the United States Department of Agriculture in the Commodore Hotel at 10 P.M. on Monday, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday.

Sales of leading mail-order and chain-store companies increased 9.1 per cent in May, compared with the corresponding month in 1947, according to compilations covering thirty-nine companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. An increase of 13.1 per cent was shown for the first five months of the year.
WASINGTON, June 11 -- The House approved today by 289 to 91 a bill enabling 202,000 displaced Europeans and wartime refugees to enter the United States in the next two years.
LONDON, June 11 (AP) -- Comebacks marked the competition in the European Zone Davis Cup tennis eliminations today as teams from half a dozen countries struggled to survive the quarter-finals.
HARTFORD, Conn., June 11 -- Senator Scott W. Lucas, Democrat, of Illinois, said tonight the House Appropriations Committee had "driven a dagger into the heart" of the European Recovery Program.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Corporate financing aggregating more than $130,000,000 passed through the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

CINCINNATI, June 11 (AP) -- Herman Wehmeier's five-hit pitching for his fifth victory without loss and a barrage of fifteen blows, led by Johnny Wyrostek with two homers, a double and a single, carried Cincinnati to a 12-1 victory over Philadelphia today.
The Forest Hills Stadium will open its gates today for the earliest inaugural since the big tennis plant began business in 1923.

LONDON, June 11 -- Fuel Minister Hugh Gaitskell's blunt warning that Britain's miners were in danger of missing their target of coal production this year and the threat of drastic cuts in electricity next winter unsettled the stock markets here today.

American schools and colleges are again offering an opportunity for students and teachers to go abroad. In turn, our educational institutions have invited scholars to come to our classrooms and campuses. The State Department and other responsible government agencies are encouraging this policy; they recognize that it can help spread democratic traditions and ideals.
AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, June 11 (AP) -- Trans-Jordan's Premier predicted today that the Arabs might refuse to sit at the same conference table with the Jews at peace talks on the Island of Rhodes.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The National Association of Stevedores today asked the Justice Department to seek a Supreme Court rehearing of the court's recent overtime pay decision.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Producers of castings for the residential housing program would be given benefits not provided for in Public Law 395, if pig iron is allocated for their special benefit, John M. Price, representing the Gray Iron Founders Society, Inc., Cleveland, told Department of Commerce officials here at an industry-wide meeting on allocations problems.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The situation at Trieste may be described as "tranquil" at the moment, in the view of Maj. Gen. Bryant E. Moore, commander of United States forces there since the war, who visited Washington today preparatory to assuming his new task as director of Public Information of the Army.
TORONTO, June 11 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian International Trade Fair will wind up tomorrow after two weeks in which some 25,000 buyers have looked at the goods of 1,400 exhibitors.

The four-story nineteen-family apartment house at 314-20 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, has been purchased for investment by A.L. Poses, president of the 86 Willow Street Corporation. The seller was Florence E. Harling, in whose family it has been since 1928, when it was acquired from Dennis Hurley, the original owner.
A 31-year-old veteran, father of two children, who has been living with relatives for the last two years, hit the jackpot yesterday.

Retail trade here this week made little change compared with the corresponding week last year, partly because of inclement weather compared with the warmest week of the year in 1947. Department store sales were estimated as "unchanged." Sales last week were down 9 per cent.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Striking newspaper printers cannot vote on a final complete contract proposal made to them by the Chicago Newspaper Publishers Association, because terms of the proposal do not conform with union law and bargaining policies, Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, of the American Federation of Labor, told the publishers today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 11 -- This city began operating a traveling library today for the free distribution of books, motion picture films and, in early autumn, phonograph records. It is designed especially as an aid to commuters.

Commissioner Hilliard's announced determination to make a major reorganization of the Welfare Department by July 1, the state's exacting time-table of reforms demanded as a result of its extended inquiry, and Mayor O'Dwyer's insistence that there be no trespass on the "rights" of civil service employes during this reorganization all depend, for their successful accomplishment, on a high quality of teamwork cooperation.

ALBANY, June 11 -- Clifford J. Fletcher, Motor Vehicle Commissioner, announced today that the state's investigation of driver training schools in New York City will be "continued and carried on to an effective conclusion" by the Special Investigations Bureau after July 1.

Most department stores will raise furniture prices if Eastern railroads carry out proposed cancellation of exception ratings on less-than-carload furniture shipments, several store spokesmen agreed yesterday. They did not agree, however, on how much of the added costs incurred by such cancellation will be passed on to the consumer.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe reserved decision yesterday on a petition by Local 65 of the Wholesale and Warehouse Workers Union, CIO, for a temporary restraining order barring the National Labor Relations Board from holding a collective-bargaining election among warehouse employes of the F.W. Woolworth Company.

The oil and aircraft shares again provided yesterday a fresh lift to the stock market, although all divisions failed to make appreciable progress. Gains in some of the favored issues on the Stock Exchange ranged beyond 2 points and the combined averages showed a rise of 0.29 point on the day, although the number of issues to decline exceeded that with advances at the close.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 11 -- There is a state of indecision here at the moment in the wake of charges of many Arab violations of this morning's cease-fire, although Israeli commanders are still holding to orders not to fire unless fired upon.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 11 -- More than 140 persons died today in Denmark's worst shipping disaster when the passenger ship Kjoebenhavn struck a mine and sank in ten minutes before dawn in the Kattegat off Jutland.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 11 -- German bizonal authorities received permission today to make use of the existing industrial cartels or create new ones in an effort to get the German economy back on its feet.
The amendment submitted in Argentina to eliminate mention of women's ages in voting is one of the few things currently done there that has my complete approval.

Nineteen certificates of merit were presented yesterday to persons participating in the Hobby Show for Older People sponsored by the Welfare Council of New York City at the American Museum of Natural History. Mrs. James Brunot, chairman of the exhibit, said that tomorrow, on the show's final day, additional awards would be given.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Negotiations were begun today by Willard L. Thorp, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, with the Ambassadors and Ministers of Marshall Plan countries on agreements for conducting European recovery operations.

Ten new subway cars to be used on the run between Main Street, Flushing, and Times Square, arrived in the city yesterday morning. They were shuttled from the Hoboken terminal of the Lackawanna Railroad onto a barge and brought up the East River to Long Island City.

THE entire instrument panel of the Army's first airplane was a thing of simple beauty. It consisted -- wholly -- of a piece of string less than a foot long. This fragment of blowing twine was fastened to a crossbar between the old kite's wooden landing skids. Once he was airborne, the pilot gave it his anxious or serene attention.

BUENOS AIRES, June 11 -- Trade negotiations between Argentina and Russia, which were left in a state of suspension with the departure of the Soviet Mission headed Constantin V. Shevelev, on March 7, 1947, have now definitely been resumed, it was learned at the Foreign Office today.

NOTTINGHAM, England, June 11 (Reuters) -- A fine 130 not out by Don Bradman enabled Australia to gain a first innings' lead of 128 runs with six wicket still to fall at the end of the second day's play in the test cricket match against England.
In answer to "The Label 'Modern'" in THE TIMES concerning the Institute of Contemporary Art's recent public statement:
PITTSBURGH, June 11 (AP) -- The scheduled strike of a group of maritime unions will receive the support of the CIO, Philip Murray announced.

STANTON, Del., June 11 (AP) -- Highfortidies of the Nydrie Stable raced to a half-length victory in the Oak Orchard Purse at Delaware Park today. Hazel B. MacCrowe's Dog O'Sullivan proved a big disappointment to the favorite players, running last in the five-horse field.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Senate proclaimed tonight by a vote of 64 to 4 a high and solemn policy committing the United States to the principle of military aid to defensive alliances formed among the world's free nations.

DETROIT, June 11 -- The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation came to terms today with the United Automobile Workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, on an amended contract providing a net increase of about 14.4 cents an hour for 10,000 hourly rated employes.

The highest total ever collected by the Greater New York Fund -- $5,011,462 -- was announced at the third and final report luncheon yesterday by Henry C. Alexander, vice president of J.P. Morgan Co., and campaign chairman for the Fund.
AMMAN, June 11 (UP) -- King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan said today that the Arabs would accept no peace that left an independent Jewish state in the Holy Land.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 11 -- The study of the normal person, who is not necessarily mentally healthy, was described today as a much neglected field by Dr. Frederick W. Dershimer, one of the few industrial psychiatrists in the country.

BERLIN, June 11 -- Incentive schemes will not lose their role in the German economy with the completion of currency reform Maj. Gen. George P. Hays, Deputy United States Military Governor, said today. There is a likielihood that the incentive schemes, designed to reward workers for increasing their output in essential industries, may be expanded even after currency reform.

LONDON, June 11 -- American movie interests charged today that American film earnings in Britain would be cut by half this year as the result of discrimination by the Government and the trade in the British market. The spirit of the film accord concluded last March, it was added, has been violated by a series of actions directed by the Government and the trade this week against American interests.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The two independent divisions of the National Labor Relations Board -- the five board members and the general counsel -- told Congress today they could not agree on how far they should go in putting local business under the Taft-Hartley Law.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- Plans for industrial mobilization of industry must be understood by business men if they are to be implemented successfully in time of war, Maj. Gen. William H. Middleswart, deputy Quartermaster General, declared here today.

" Razzia," said to be the first post-war German film produced by the Defa Studios in the Soviet section of Berlin, will have its local premiere today at the Stanley. The cast features Paul Bildt, Eli Burgmer and Walter Gross. The dialogue is German, but there are English titles.
UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 11 -- Chet Sanok of Englewood opened defense of his New Jersey State amateur championship today with two comparatively easy victories.

In a ceremony at Governors Island yesterday afternoon the Army honored two citizens of the Philippine Commonwealth for their services to Americans during the Japanese occupation there. They were the late Enrique Pirovano, former president of the Dela Roma Ship Lines, and Dr. Florentino B. Herrera Jr., personal physician to the late President of the Philippines, Manuel Roxas.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- A total of $5,242,000 for planning rivers and harbors and flood-control projects is provided under the civil functions appropriation bill as now drafted.

Many of the sixty-eight United States Bishops who will attend the Lambeth Conference in London, opening July 1 and continuing through Aug. 8, will provide a supply of food for themselves and for gifts to their hosts.

Herbert McKenley, Lloyd La Beach and Chuck Fonville, who have broken world records this spring, head an all-star cast of track and field athletes in the Sydenham Hospital benefit meet at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island this evening.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 11 -- Palestine's truce today brought to a sputtering stop two major battles and several other actions, but produced charges of violations from both sides in its first day.

The New York City Housing Authority sold yesterday $6,000,000 of series F temporary loan notes due Dec. 27 to Chase National Bank and associates at an interest rate of 1.14 per cent. The bankers bid a premium of $66.

In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, published June 5, Herbert Bayard Swope suggested to Faris el-Khouri, this month president of the Security Council, that he relinquish his right and duty to occupy the chair, lest his political belief prejudice the Zionist case.

BOSTON, June 11 -- Dr. Arthur H. Compton, chancellor of Washington University, St. Louis, today cited Congress' "recent faltering action" in financing European recovery as a reminder that "when immediate danger of war seems relaxed, we Americans take the easy course."

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 11 -- The Grand National Assembly today voted legislation nationalizing industries, ore mines, banks, insurance companies, transport and navigation enterprises. Prime Minister Petru Groza announced in the Assembly that the Cabinet Council, which had met at a special session in Parliament from 10:30 to 11 A.M., had approved the bill of nationalization presented by Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej, Deputy Premier and secretary general of the Worker party.
PORTLAND, Ore., June l1 (AP) -- Fresh disaster struck the flood-weary Pacific Northwest today.

John Scofield, 16-year-old Mayor of the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., received yesterday a youth award from Bob Feller, Cleveland Indians' pitcher, for "distinguished community service" at a luncheon for 125 boys from the village in the Belmont-Plaza Hotel.

Sterling Cutting Radio Sponsorship of two national radio shows will be ended this summer by Sterling Drug, Inc., and the savings allocated to additional newspaper and publications advertising, it was announced yesterday by James Hill Jr., company president.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 11 -- The cease-fire was observed religiously today on the Petah Tiqva front just east of here where the Arabs hold Jerusalem's water supply source at Ras el Ein. Two weeks ago Israeli forces held this strategic point but were driven out after a terrific battle by the Iraqis.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 11 -- For the first time since atomic talks began two years ago, the United States called on the United Nations Security Council today to give its approval to the outline of a powerful international control agency.

Distress conveyances of Manhattan real estate during May totaled thirty-three, the same as for April, with a substantial reduction in the dollar volume of liens thus satisfied, according to a survey of completed foreclosures and surrenders to mortgages in lieu of foreclosure reported by the Real Estate Board of New York.
After seventeen weeks of negotiation, the General Electric Company and the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, reached agreement yesterday on an 8 per cent general wage increase.
NUREMBERG, Germany, June 11 (AP) -- A United States war crimes court ruled today that an industrialist must have advance knowledge of invasion plans to be convicted of plotting aggressive war.
ABOARD PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S SPECIAL TRAIN, SOUTHBOUND IN OREGON, June 11 -- President Truman signed this afternoon a Congressional resolution authorizing $10,000,000 for disaster housing relief.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 (AP) -- A four-run seventh inning rally and tight relief pitching by Charlie Harris enabled the Athletics to beat the Browns, 6 to 5, tonight. Harris relieved Phil Marchildon in the third inning and pitched one-hit ball.

Governor Dewey returned to New York yesterday well pleased with the results of his campaign for delegate support in Maryland, Virginia and North Carolina for the Republican Presidential nomination. He will go to Hartford today in search of second-choice backing from Connecticut delegates who are scheduled to enter Senator Raymond J. Baldwin as a "favorite son" candidate, for the Presidential nomination.

The second volume in the Centenary Series in American Literature will be issued in September by Funk Wagnalls, under the title "One Hundred Years Ago: American Writing of 1848." The collection has been edited by James Playsted.

JERUSALEM, June 11 -- After six months and eleven days of Arab-Jewish conflict and twenty-eight days of warfare between the armies of Israel and five Arab states the fighting was interrupted and the siege of Jerusalem was provisionally lifted at 10 o'clock this morning by a cease-fire that is scheduled to last for the next twenty-eight days.

LONDON, June 11 -- At the end of an eighteen-hour continuous all-night sitting of the House of Commons, this morning a Foreign Office spokesman reiterated the British Government's refusal to recognize the State of Israel at the present time.
WASHINGTON, June 11 - Senate Appropriations committeemen planned today to restore all except a fraction of the $5,300,000,000 authorized for the European Recovery Program.

Lumber production for the week ended June 5 decreased 12.3 per cent from the previous week and 17.7 per cent below the same week a year ago. Shipments were down 21 per cent compared with a year ago and orders were down 7.8 per cent, according to reports received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

INDIANAPOLIS June 11 -- United States Senator William E. Jenner lost his fight for the Republican nomination for Governor tonight to Hobart Creighton of Warsaw, Speaker of the Indiana House of Representatives.
The cotton futures market turned easier yesterday and closed 2 to 17 points lower. Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange held within a rather moderate range.

One of the truly great inventions of the age is the movable typewriter stand. This is the stand which, coasting on wheels, may be shifted from place to place, and it obviously has a most important psychological effect. With a movable typewriter stand, there no longer is the sense of being chained to the desk, like Cousin Caliban to the rock.

First worries about cancellations of orders have arisen among steel vendors, partially as a result of reports of cutbacks in the requirements of capital equipment for the Marshall Plan, a group of machinery manufacturers revealed here yesterday following an informal meeting at the Commodore Hotel.
Random notes.
Random notes.
Albert Graham, operator, recently sold the property at 2226-34 Third Avenue, northwest corner of 121st Street, to Eliahou I. Khedouri for investment.

PRAGUE, June 11 -- A warning by Antonin Gregor, Communist Minister for Foreign Trade, to workers, appearing on the front page of Rude Pravo, Communist Central party organ, that the foreign trade situation was dangerous has met with somewhat skeptical response in business quarters and from foreign trade experts stationed here.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Prices of wheat held better than generally was expected today in view of the June Government estimates, issued yesterday, which were higher than looked for on both winter and spring crops. After a fractional dip early on the Board of Trade prices rallied, and for a time held around the previous closing level.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Pat Mullin's triple and Art Houtteman's single broke a 6-6 tie and presented the Detroit Tigers a 7-6 victory over Washington in a teninning game here tonight. Houtteman, Detroit's fifth pitcher, was credited with his first victory of the year after eight defeats.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- The Giants ran head-on into something today for which they seemed totally unprepared. It was a 30-year-old perennial rookie righthander who up to this moment had not done very much to bring any joy to the life of Jolly Cholly Grimm.

This may sound strange to you, but I have come to the conclusion that the forces of Abdullah, about whom Clifton Daniel Writes (in "Man With an Obsession"), will be no match for the Israeli forces because of the way Abdullah's men prepare their coffee.

INSPIRED guesswork, plus some rather uninspired sleuthing, enables Gervase Fen to solve a disappearance, a burglary and two murders in and in the vicinity of Castrevenford School, where he has been invited to make the principal address and to give out prizes on Speech Day.

Brooklyn College's unique "History of American Music" course, which has been offered successfully for several semesters, will be expanded into two sessions next September. The course traces the role of music in this nation's history from the chamber music of the early Colonial days to the topical songs of the twentieth century.

In a gallop, with his ears pricked and with apparently about as much expenditure of energy as in a midweek workout, Calumet Farm's magnificent Citation completed the business of winning American racing's triple crown in an astounding performance at Belmont Park yesterday.
HERE is the chronological order of the major steps in television programming of the past two decades:

IN the parlance of the turf, "Best Sports Stories 1948" has a lot of early foot. It comes out winging with a piece by Stanley Woodward which is acclaimed by the judges (Franklin P. Adams, Quentin Reynolds and John Chamberlain) as the best sports news story of the year.

A permanent microfilm record of Stars and Stripes, the United States armed forces newspaper, is now in the files of the New York Public Library. It is the most complete file in existence, containing every edition published anywhere.

With the so-called Tidelands bill, which would give the off-shore lands of California to that state, blocked in the Senate and unlikely of enactment at this session of Congress, the Navy Department is in a position to obtain a reserve estimated at two to three billion barrels of petroleum off the coast of California with the mere signing of an executive order.

A BUSY man and one who obviously relishes a mystery, Alfred Hitchcock paused here briefly last week in a shuttle between London and Hollywood to divulge that he had acquired a novel and that the affairs of Transatlantic Pictures -- the Alfred Hitchcock-Sidney Bernstein company -- were continuing apace.

Designed to safeguard the Social Security status of wholesale salesmen -- in the face of possible adverse effect of legislation already passed or pending in Congress -- an employment contract provision has been devised in the interest of its 4,500 members throughout the country by the National Association of Women's and Children's Apparel Salesmen, which has headquarters at 215 Bona Allen Building, Atlanta, Ga.

At speeds higher than that of sound (750 miles an hour at sea level) ordinary paint peels from jet planes, with the result that the air flow is disrupted. What paint will stick? Paint is essential because salt air and sea water corrode plane surfaces.

The number of out-of-town buyers in wholesale markets here last week showed no sign of falling off and most buyers continued to "shop" thoroughly before placing orders for fall merchandise, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

ATHENS, June 12 -- The Greek Government said today that it was studying the Bulgarian proposals submitted to Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, concerning the resumption of normal diplomatic relations with Greece.

LEADERS of the tourist and travel organizations of more than forty-five countries will meet in Oslo, Norway, tomorrow for the fourteenth general assembly of the International Union of Official Travel Organizations.

MR. MARION, an American Communist, is convinced that the United States "seeks literally global strategic hegemony," that it is demanding world rule in the name of world leadership, and that its policy is directed by bankers and generals.

A new electronic signal control developed by the Otis Elevator Company automatically stops an elevator at the floor where a passenger is waiting after a small disk in a wall fixture has been touched. The disk looks like a push button, but it has no moving parts.

Development of a new technique by left-wing department store unions to evade the non-Communist requirements of the Taft-Hartley law and still obtain recognition by management has become clear as the result of a dispute between Oppenheim Collins Co., and a union representing its 550 employes.

ARMONK, N. Y., June 12 -- Ch. Carillon Colin of Puttencove, black standard poodle restarting his ring career after almost four years, took his first best in show today in the sixteenth annual Greenwich Kennel Club event on Wind Mill Farm.

THE new art of frequency modulation radio has had a rapid growth since the war. In 1945 there were fifty-two stations on the air and some 495,000 receivers in use.
