Today -- less than three years later -- there are 517 commercial FM radio stations and twenty non-commercial, educational outlets making FM service available to an estimated audience of 60,000,000.

WHILE the great majority of FM stations which are operated by the networks and AM stations are giving only duplicate program service, there is a growing minority of independent FM stations not operating on the carbon-copy policy of programming.

SARANACLAKE, N. Y., June 12 (AP) -- Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson called upon Congress tonight to expand the nation's postal service which he said was "literally bursting at the seams" under a record volume of mail.

THE subtitle of this indignant book by the former Associated Press correspondent in Spain, Charles Foltz Jr., honestly tells the prospective reader what he must expect to find. "A report unmasking the rulers of modern Spain." If it were only this, one might ask, "Why bother?"

GENEVA, June 12 -- The United States Economic Cooperation Administration has begun a big drive to mobilize European surplus goods to reduce the demands on the United States under the European Recovery Program, it was learned today.

Chet Gibbons of Paterson, N. J., won the twenty-five-lap feature race on the midget auto racing program at the Polo Grounds last night. A crowd of 13,146 saw the Jersey driver make a front-running performance of it almost all the way to score by a margin of 15 yards over Tony Bonadies of the Bronx.

THIS brace of psycho-thrillers proves once again (though no proof is needed at this late date) that the lady novelist can be more deadly than the male when she carpenters a whodunit in reverse. Miss Walker brings off a yarn about a tough guy and his still tougher moll with no more feminine overtones than a Bogart sneer.

Five months have passed since the Russian broadcast of the Voice of America, State Department broadcasting unit, beamed to the Soviet Union a brief summary of a comparison of Soviet and American prices in terms of work, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Dec. 21.

THE simultaneous presentation of programs over radio and television is scheduled for increasingly wide adoption. Producers in the two industries, however, are still not of one mind on how successful such duplication will be.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- Immigration agents today questioned thirty-nine Mexicans including one woman, who were smuggled across the country in a five-day 1,500-mile trip from Texas in the false bottom of a rickety truck loaded with melons.

CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) -- Prices of corn tumbled almost 5 cents a bushel at times today on the Board of Trade as the grain trade received reports of widespread rains over eastern Nebraska, all of Iowa and northern Illinois. Oats also weakened. Wheat was marked down slightly.

WHEREAS to a kennel master the dog, droopy-eared as a spaniel and silken-haired as a poodle, might have been only a problem in genetics, to Connie and her father and mother he was a delightful combination; he was Spoodles.

BY this autumn, television set owners in the New York area will be able to select their entertainment from seven different video stations -- more stations than in any other city in the world. Before the year is up, if plans work out, three newcomers will have joined the four outlets which are at present in operation.

MANY men and women who were in the war remember it, not as an exalting crisis of action, but rather as a depressing waste of human energy spent largely in fatigue, waiting and boredom. The fortunate among these recall also, as counterpoint, the friendships and the animosities, the emotions of good-will or of ill-will which had an intensified validity because of the atmosphere in which they were conceived.

ALBANY, June 12 -- About 200 Albany residents were on hand today for ceremonies in welcome to the New York State Maritime Academy's training ship Empire State II, which will leave here Wednesday on a three-month cruise to Trinidad, Madeira, Italy, France, Gibraltar and Algiers.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 12 (AP) -- Villanova College's Browning Ross scored a stunning upset today over Olympic hopeful Gerry Karver and set a new meet record in the Middle Atlantic A. A. U. 1,500-meter event.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 12 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York sought second-choice support from Connecticut delegates to the Republican National Convention at a dinner conference here tonight. By instruction of the recent state convention their first choice is Senator Raymond E. Baldwin, a favorite son.

Selective purchasing of coats, suits and dresses in the New York garment market has made it necessary for many buyers to extend their visits, it was stated last week. Two more weeks of brisk buying activity is anticipated by manufacturers and resident offices before completion of the first phase of fall inventory selections.
The National Maritime Union, CIO, has formally ratified a two-year contract with eleven companies that are operating 300 tankers, it was announced yesterday.

A freshly painted reconverted tank landing ship awaited her first commercial cargo at Pier 36, East River, yesterday, a symbol of the enterprise of two young former Army officers who fought for and won a niche in the competitive shipbuilding and repair field.

About 50 per cent of all people lose teeth prematurely as a result of malocclusion -- failure of the teeth to meet or mesh properly in biting and chewing -- Dr. Sidney E. Riesner, orthodontist at the Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx, declared yesterday in an address at the scientific session of the American Academy of Dental Medicine annual meeting in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The House passed last Tuesday forty-three measures as fast as the clerk could read off the numbers and titles. This was the bi-weekly calling of the private calendar of bills which have no general public impact and which, when they complete the legislative process, become private laws.

IN a dozen American communities people are talking about the Montclair Audit. For this small New Jersey town has set an example for others in the touchy civil rights field. One section in Boston already is engaged in a similar audit, and cities west to Chicago, south to Richmond and north to Windsor, Ont., are talking it up.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- A local union of teamsters at Albany, N. Y., whose strike was stopped by a court injunction, was cleared today of charges of unfair labor practice by a trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board.

LONDON, June 12 (AP) -- England has qualified for a berth in the semi-final round of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis play, but the British opponent will not be known until Monday.

IT is good to have Preston Jennings' "A Book of Trout Flies" in print again, and generally available. This pioneering study of the more important Northeastern trout-stream insects and their artificial imitations, once a $20 limited edition and now reprinted from the identical plates, is still the broadest work on its subject.

WE are now a half generation away from the Hoover Administration. Millions of Americans at present approaching middle age were too young either to vote for or against Mr. Hoover. Other millions about to cast their first ballot next fall are not old enough to know what the pre-Franklin-Roosevelt world was like.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., June 12 -- To give college teachers a broader understanding of what's going on in the world, Sarah Lawrence College and New York University have begun here a unique workshop in contemporary culture. Nearly 150 teachers from all sections of the country, working toward master's and doctoral degrees, are participating in the program.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 12 (UP) -- A blistering 0:47.1-record-breaking quarter-mile by Frank Fox of the Seton Hall A. A. was the outstanding performance in the annual New Jersey A. A. U. track and field championships at Woodman Field today. The former mark was 0:48.2.

THIS book ends with a question and an answer. "What is crime? It appears that crime is a reaction to unendurable internal and external pressures suffered by the individual. When we know all the elements responsible for these tension states, we shall be able to cope with crime and delinquencies."

WASHINGTON. UNTIL recently, rising prices caused a mounting fear of inflation and a growing sentiment for an affirmative program to combat It. Many felt that an uncurbed boom might lead quickly to a substantial recession in employment and business activity.

DETROIT, June 12 -- The Briggs Manufacturing Company and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, reached an agreement today based on a 13-cent hourly rise, plus an additional 3 1/2 cents in lieu of the six paid holidays.

A TEMPORARY alliance has been formed by the four television networks headquartered in New York to cover the Republican and Democratic national conventions in Philadelphia when they meet on June 21 and July 12, respectively.
HARRISON, N. Y., June 12 -- Keen competition in jumper classes at the Greenwich horse show at the Blind Brook polo grounds marked the second section of the three-day event today.

ROSSINI'S "Il Turco in Italia," to be given in an English version as "The Turk in Italy," will be the opera this summer at the Berkshire Festival. It will be performed Aug. 9 and 11 for Friends of the Berkshire Music Center.

EVERY spring in west Texas young Sid Lovell watched great herds of longhorns being driven north through Buffalo Gap to market. His wish to go on this long trek to Kansas is suddenly realized, and he joins his uncle's outfit, which comprises two wagons, twelve cowboys and four thousand head of cattle.

CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) -- A report on the status of enforcement of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's "Sanity Code" will be made to the executive committee in a meeting in Minneapolis starting Wednesday in conjunction with the N.C.A.A. track and field championships.

THE results of two methods of teaching photography are demonstrated in an exhibition of students' work opening Tuesday at the Photo League, 23 East Tenth Street. The show is a joint project of the league's school, which encourages shooting first and learning the techniques afterward, and the California School of Fine Arts, whose photographic curriculum as set up by Ansel Adams stresses mastery of technique.

A far-reaching program for teaching English to non-English-speaking displaced Europeans in a matter of weeks, instead of years, has been developed at Harvard University. Using film strips and recordings, a woman lecturer at the Harvard Graduate School of Education has taught 200 former DP's, now at work in English coal mines, to speak English in less than two months.

TORONTO, June 12 (Canadian Press) -- The Mexican Light and Power Company, Ltd., in its report for 1947 announced yesterday a credit balance of $878,938, Canadian funds, which was $483,436 more than in the previous year. Net income from operations, after allowing $1,844,000 for depreciation, was $3,056,936, compared with $2,787,385 in 1946.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 12 -- Three United States transport planes have been sent to Palestine to help Count Folk Bernadotte's international staff of military observers supervise the four-week truce between the Arabs and Israel, State Department spokesmen reported today.
A veteran ocean commuter, Mrs. Mary Seymour, 83 years old, of 222 Avenue A, Bayonne, N. J., sailed last week on her eightieth crossing of the Atlantic.
MOSCOW, June 12 (AP) -- The Literary Gazette asserted today that United States Ambassador Walter B. Smith was a member of a military clique that has taken over the United States State Department.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 12 -- On the second day of the truce in Palestine there were still several hot spots along the front today and the United Nations Truce Commission was trying its best to cool them down. Otherwise the ceasefire appeared to be functioning as well as had been expected.

LONDON -- British television is awaiting its greatest opportunity: the Olympic Games beginning July 29.

PRAGUE, June 12 -- Czechoslovak libraries will be purged of "books devoid of literary worth" during the coming summer vacation. All private, cooperative or other libraries accessible to the public will be suppressed under a library law now in preparation.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, June 12 -- Further consideration of the undertaking by the Benelux nations, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, to expand their customs union into an effective economic union by the beginning of 1950 has brought conviction here that United States aid is essential for fulfillment of the plan.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- Windy City weather added to the many frustrations of Leo Durocher and his Dodgers today when rain washed out the game with the Cubs and reduced the series to a single contest tomorrow.

As has been pointed out several times recently in this column, among the principal causes of the recent increase in chronic disease rates have been the great advances made in child care and the control of acute, infectious disease. One week from tomorrow the Republican party gathers in Philadelphia to name candidates and write a platform for the Presidential election. Four weeks from tomorrow the Democratic party gathers in the same city for the same reason.

I let myself be jostled by the theatre crowds in the spring rain, I studied the reflected play of colored lights in Broadway's wet pavement, stopped to hear the city's voice -- subways, traffic, policemen's whistles, the far-off call of river craft -- but the answer was not in these.

Cyrus S. Eaton of Otis Co,, Cleveland investment bankers, has finally turned against the Government agency that once considered him the "fair-haired" boy. THE legend of Henry Ford as a demigod of capitalism is deeply embedded in the folklore of our times. To the cognoscenti of big business he was the messiah of the mechanized age. At the other pole, one reads in Lincoln Steffens' autobiography, "he was a prophet without words, a reformer without politics, a legislator, statesman -- a radical."
PRAGUE, June 12 -- Archbishop Josef Beran will receive Klement Gottwald in St. Vitus Cathedral at Prague Castle immediately after M. Gottwald's ceremonial election to the Presidency Monday.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, June 12 -- Trans-Jordanian leaders were preparing today to leave for Cairo for an Arab League meeting and for subsequent talks in Rhodes called by Count Bernadotte. Opinion here was doubtful about the Mediator's chances of success, but the Arabs appeared to be willing to see what could be done.

KODACOLOR print enlargements in three new sizes, 5x7, 8x10 and 11x14 inches, are announced by Kodak in a new service. Four special sizes, 4x7 to 8x8 inches, will also be available. Portions of Kodacolor negatives may be cropped to permit enlargements of selected areas up to five diameters.

MR. LEWIS has a very soothing theory -- not exactly original with him. A man may be wrong, grammatically speaking, but if enough men are wrong they may turn out to be right after all. BUENOS AIRES, June 12 -- On the eve of the departure for Argentina of former United States Assistant Secretary of the Navy H. Struve Hensel on an "exploratory Marshall Plan mission," President Miguel Miranda of the National Economic Council declared today that he and the United States were in "complete accord" on an interpretation of the "market price" at which Argentina will sell foodstuffs to the Economic Cooperation Administration.

Cynthia Bernard, soprano and former League winner, was guest artist and Kenneth Walton was official accompanist.

PAOTOW, China, June 10 (Delayed) -- The flow of new Chinese settlers from south of the Great Wall into Suiyuan, Sino-Mongolian Province, during the last year has increased friction between Chinese and Mongols in Nationalist areas of Inner Mongolia.

The Festival of Shabuoth, commemorating the giving of the Ten Commandments to Moses on Mount Sinai by God, was ushered in at sundown yesterday in temples and synagogues throughout the city. Reform Jews will end the observance at sundown tonight, and members of the Orthodox and Conservative faith will end theirs at sundown tomorrow.

CENTER ISLAND, L. I., June 12 -- Scheduled to start a best four-out-of-seven elimination series tomorrow for the right to represent Long Island in the forthcoming Olympic trials, Llanoria, owned by the Whiton-Loomis syndicate, and James Sheldon's Star Wagon were among the three international six-meter sloops out today as the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association held its weekly regatta.

BERLIN, June 12 -- The Germans will decide whether or not they can accept the recommendations of the London Conference, and the Western powers have no intention of imposing recommendations on the people of Western Germany, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, declared at a press conference today.

THE New York Yankees formally will take cognizance today of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the opening of the Yankee Stadium and the winning of their first world championship. The stars of the 1923 team will play a five-inning game against the stars of other seasons, and sentimental memories of yesteryear will flood back with nostalgic appeal.

Van Wagoner, United States Military Governor of Bavaria, greeted 3,000 German and foreign guests today at the opening of the second International Youth Congress here with the assurance that "although great bitterness and distrust lies behind many of you, because of the unhappy events of the past decade, I have great faith in the open-mindedness of youth."

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 -- The Committee of Arrangements for the Republican National Convention, of which Walter S. Hallanan is chairman, is seeking to expedite the convention procedure so that the balloting for the nomination for President may begin on Wednesday night, June 23, it was learned today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 (AP) -- The rebounding Philadelphia Athletics won their third straight game today, beating the St. Louis, Browns, 3 -- 2, and they did all their scoring on only four hits.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The House passed by a voice vote today a bill continuing for another two years a virtually unchanged Government program for guaranteeing farm prices at specified levels.

THE arrival of television is as unmistakable as it is sudden. A year ago the feat of sending pictures through the air was largely a matter of technical interest. Today television is accepted as a practical wonder.

Evidence is at hand from many points of the compass that 1948 probably will be speedboating's biggest year with the largest number of contestants. America's premiere event, for instance, the Gold Cup, which moves back to Detroit this summer following its Jamaica Bay experience last year, probably will have the largest number of competitors in history.

FAIRLAWN, N. J., June 12 (AP) -- A former Viennese Supreme Court justice now living in New York City willingly paid a $5 fine for speeding and $3 in court costs in police court here last night with the comment, "This is the finest country in the world in which to live."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 12 -- Moshe Piyade, veteran Communist planner and member of the Yugoslav Politbureau, declared today that the dictatorship of the proletariat and its structural mechanisms as outlined by Marshal Stalin had been greatly perfected in Yugoslavia and were superior to similar mechanisms developed in the other "People's Democracies" of eastern Europe.

I am astonished by what Drew Middleton says in "Do the Men in the Kremlin Want War?" I quote: "In Greece-- as in many other countries--the United States has been obliged to guarantee a government rotten with corruption and inefficiency and a people so sorely stricken they would welcome any change."

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 -- A new method for studying the flow of blood in the brain and a new device for measuring the heart's pumping action, both hailed as important medical discoveries, have been developed, respectively, at the University of Pennsylvania and at Temple University.

Many of us can still remember when the Grand Army of the Republic made a stalwart figure in parades. It is hard for us to realize that nearly as many years have now passed since Lincoln made his speech at Gettysburg as the fourscore and seven that had then elapsed since the Declaration of Independence.

CINCINNATI, June 12 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds defeated Boston in both ends of a twin bill today, 3 -- 2 and 11 -- 9, to knock the Braves out of the National League leadership. Hank Sauer got his seventeenth homer with the bases loaded in the nightcap.

AKRON, Ohio, June 12 -- A wage increase of 11 cents an hour for 23,000 employes of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company in eight plants today marked the first wage settlement in the Big Four rubber industry.

A strong revival of interest in the stock market last week sent prices to the highest levels since September, 1946. Ignoring the slow progress in settling the coal and railroad wage disputes and the slashing of funds for European recovery, financial markets broke out of the narrow trading range in which they had been moving for three weeks.

BOARDING by the Coast Guard for inspection is usually a cause of anxiety to the small boatman. The reason is, as samplings have indicated, that more than half of the 450,000 pleasure motor craft in this country do not meet minimum legal requirements for safety.
OMAHA, Neb., June 12 -- There were jewels valued at $70,000 in a well-patronized sales display at the Nebraska Stock Growers' Association convention here this week.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 12 -- David A. More, Under Secretary of Labor, today was elected Director General of the International Labor Organization.

With the gradual merchandising reversion from a sellers' to a buyers' market continually more evident, aggressive retailers are becoming more and more aware of consumer demands. Various methods are being used in department and specialty stores here to determine the buying appetite of the public.

The eleventh Spanish invitation tennis tournament, sanctioned by the United States Lawn Tennis Association, got under way yesterday at the Hispano Tennis Club courts in Whitestone, Queens, with twenty-one matches contested. Four players, three of them seeded, advanced to the third bracket, a round ahead of the field.

TELEVISION receivers for the home range in price from $150 to $4,000. They come in a variety of models and combinations -- from the straight table type, offering television only, to custom-built consoles containing video, standard radio, frequency modulation radio and a phonograph.
John Kramer returned yesterday to the Forest Hills Stadium where he won the National amateur tennis crown last September, to launch his first bid for the professional championship.

After three years of research Dr. Sidney Raffel of Stanford University's medical school announces that he has identified in the tubercle bacillus a chemical substance which is responsible for the cell destruction characteristic of tuberculosis, The substance is a wax-like combination of starches and fatty acids.

THE threat of a strike by the Screen Actors Guild on Aug. 1, which has been the subject of much speculation since the actors and the producers broke off negotiation of a new contract in April, was materially lessened last week when the Guild announced that bargaining sessions will be resumed at the suggestion of the producers.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- President Truman's remark that Premier Stalin of Russia was a prisoner of his own Politburo took diplomatic Washington -- inspired many of the President's own experts -- by complete surprise today.

NOTTINGHAM, England, June 12 (Reuters) -- At the close of play in the test cricket match today England had scored 121 for two wickets in its second innings after Australia had gained a first innings' lead of 344 on a total of 509.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 12 -- A special committee of Berlin city officials and representatives of the Bizonal Economic Administration fashioned plans here today for Western German aid to the former capital. The proposals will be presented by the leaders of the bizonal administration to the United States and British Military Governors Monday.
On a trip unique in the annals of her Order, a sister of the Visitation of Holy Mary is in New York to seek assistance for her monastery in the south of France.

BOSTON, June 12 (AP) -- With Pat Seerey and Luke Appling generating the offense, Righthander Al Gettel won his first start for the Chicago White Sox today by holding the Boston Red Sox to seven hits for a 5-3 triumph.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 12 (AP) -- Both sides charged continued violations of cease-fire orders today.

AS Ellis Arnall rode in a bus from the town in which he had been speaking, he heard two men in the seat in front of him talking about his lecture. One of them said: "He had a big crowd but I was a little disappointed in him. He's not a profound man, just straight-forward and sincere."

COOKING, even its devotees must admit, is not the pleasantest of the pursuits offered by a summer day. There are greater attractions in warm weather, among them swimming, gardening and just sitting in the sun.

IN the struggle for the freedom of India, the Nehru family has been prominent. The youngest member of that family, Krishna Nehru, who has already written of her prison experience in her autobiography, "With No Regrets," adds, as it were, a post script in a little book, "Shadows On The Wall," made up of a dozen sketches of various of her fellow-prisoners.

More than one million of Father Knickerbocker's sons and daughters joined yesterday in a rousing and colorful Fifth Avenue outpouring in honor of the old gentleman's fiftieth birthday. From strange lands and faraway places, the 75,000 marchers in the "New York at Work" parade epitomized the wide variety of racial strains that study, work and live in the metropolis.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The heavy, heady aroma of November victory in the June air appears to be carrying Republicans in control of Congress back to the voting habits of the party in that golden political era of Harding, Coolidge and Hoover.

WHO is going to make the jokes on television? Comedy has always been a problem in every medium of entertainment, but in television comedy will pose a problem greater than any other form of entertainment or amusement -- whether it be live or mechanical.

PLANTS are stationary subjects and are thus a prey to injury by grubs or fungi in the soil where they grow, or to infestation blown or brought in from the surrounding area. They need a sturdy constitution to withstand the attacks of rapacious insects, as well as various fungus and virus diseases.
LONDON, June 12 -- The London liberal weekly, The Economist, gives President Truman today a relatively high rating for his performance in office.

SMEARING things up with lipstick, ink, and catsup just to see what will happen seems to have become a favorite game with manufacturers of new materials to put on the wall. What does happen, in all cases where such antics are publicized, is that the messy stuff comes right off with one whisk of a damp cloth.

BERLIN, June 12 -- Railroad traffic into Berlin from the British zone was resumed this evening after a twenty-two-hour hold-up resulting from the Soviet Military Administration's insistence on the "proper labeling of freight cars."

HOLLYWOOD. NEWS reports from Paris about the highly favorable reception given by the French press to a new additive process of color photography developed by Lucien and Armand Roux, which depends on filtered light rather than pigmentation of film, have caused a serious stir in the studios here.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 12 -- Grave concern is felt in official quarters here at what is considered to be meddling by the United Nations Commission of Good Offices in Indonesian affairs beyond its jurisdiction. It is the opinion in highest Dutch circles that some members of the commission are now engaged in the composition of new "proposals" markedly favorable to the republic and correspondingly disadvantageous to the Netherlands.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 12 -- United Nations officials have been meeting in emergency sessions to draw up a new construction program for the East River world capital as a result of congressional delay in approving the $65,000,000 building loan, it was learned today.

Concern and alarm over secular threats to religious education in America have been registered with the Department of Christian Education of the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church, the Rev. Frank C. Leeming announced yesterday.
COMMERCIALS are already a part of the television picture, and even now they are presented in a wide variety of ways. The best ones aim at achieving the all-important element of surprise.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., June 12 -- State police placed a "concentrated guard" around the home of Leroy Hutson, Negro radio engineer, in near-by Wall Township today after a twelve-foot cross was burned in front of the place last night bringing a crowd of more than twenty-five armed Negroes from surrounding towns to his defense.

OF the many misconceptions about television that the industry has inherited from its early, pioneering days of programming and publicizing, one of the most fixed in the public mind is that regarding makeup.

STANTON, Del., June 12 (AP) -- Page Boots, no better than econd in four previous starts this year, showed a clean pair of heels to twelve other 3-yeaer-olds in the 11th running of the $25,000 added Kent Stakes at Delaware Park today.

A BOOK chock full of lively, interesting ways to entertain friends, "Party Fun" will be a valuable guide to teen-age girls. There are suggestions for decorations, ice-breakers, food, and prizes for forty-eight different kinds of parties; a section of recipes and one that describes games of all sorts -- mixers, paper-and-pencil games, and relays for rougher fun.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Appropriation of all except $245,000,000 of the $5,300,000,000 authorized for the first year's operation of the European Recovery Program was approved tonight by the Senate Appropriations Committee.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 12 -- The retailers responsibility to the community is to make sure that merchandise is made available at the lowest possible price, according to Jack I. Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., of New York City.
CHILDREN'S programs already hold a prominent spot on the schedules of television stations; the younger generation is accounted an enthusiastic element in the television audience.

LONDON, June 12 (UP) -- The Earl of Derby, one of Britain's wealthiest young noblemen and former escort of Princess Margaret Rose, will marry Lady Isabel Milles-Lade, court circles said today. The wedding date is not set.
NORRIS, Tenn., June 12 -- This world-famous experiment in community planning under Government supervision will go on the auction block Tuesday -- with a minimum price tag of $1,849,750.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Soft coal operators and the United Mine Workers talked seriously and amicably today about a 1948 agreement for the first time.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga. -- The Franklin D. Roosevelt Warm Springs Memorial Commission is pushing preparations to open the Little White House shrine to the public by July 15, in time for the peak of the summer touring season.

HIKING and climbing vacations combine adventure and fun with economy. Championship walking or climbing ability is not a prerequisite for the enjoyment of a holiday afoot. However, proper equipment, good feet and sound health to enjoy this outdoor life are necessities.

AS a novel "Mister Roberts" won a few million friends, and as one of the more highly regarded of this season's plays it has added a few million more. Now that the printed form of the drama has come out, there is no reason to suppose its progress will be other than in the same direction.

VICTOR has won the race to be first to the reviewers with a new recording of Brahms' Ein Deutsches Requiem. Columbia has a performance in the works and it should be along shortly. Until the arrival of the Columbia version, which was made in Vienna, comparisons naturally must wait.

PARIS, June 12 -- The National Assembly suspended its debate on the six-power recommendations on Germany today with the outcome of the discussion in doubt. Between now and Tuesday, when the Assembly will reconvene, Government quarters are expected to sound out the United States and British Governments on how far the French can go in the matter of reservations.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 12 (AP) -- Vigorous protest was raised today following an announcement by the new Nationalist Government it will free five men imprisoned for war-time activities.

TELEVISION to most people is a scientific marvel -- a new medium of communication which opens up vast possibilities for greater communication, for new and varied methods of instruction and information, for entertainment and for cultural expression.

IN New York City, oustling vortex of the nation's music industry, Louis N. Shoobe is unique as a man who has firm opinions about everything and everybody musical and is yet content to hold his peace. His policy of silence stems from a naturally retiring disposition plus the fact that his own place in the music business calls for a high order of tactfulness.

RADIO broadcasting, which is music, plays, comedy, news -- and much more besides -- is today less than thirty years old. The rough edges are not yet rubbed off the older arts; nor, for all their age, have all their frontiers been conquered.

The New York Athletic Club, with Don Every setting the pace, captured the National foil team championship yesterday on the strips of the Fencer's Club. For the Winged Foot it marked a successful defense of the title which it had gained last year.

A resident School for Speech Correction will be held July 5-Aug. 14 at Syracuse University to assist children between 7 and 16 years of age to overcome stuttering, stammering and other speech handicaps. First established on an experimental basis in 1946 and held annually since, the school utilizes psychological and mechanical therapeutic techniques, supervised play programs, individual instruction, self-teaching and special courses.

THE fourth annual series of free outdoor square dances is scheduled to get under way tomorrow evening under the auspices of the New York Department of Parks, through the courtesy of the Pepsi-Cola Company.

After spending three months in business and industry, 150 students registered under the work-study program at Walter Hervey Junior College, one of the Y. M. C. A. schools of New York, will return to their desks and textbooks tomorrow for more "formal education."
ALBANY, N. Y., June 12 -- Nearly two hundred puddle-jumping outboard runabouts, incredibly fast, arrived today at the Albany Y. C.

AS a young intellectual Margaret Naumburg attained early to an understanding of Freud. Unlike most of the members of her group she was not content to apply her knowledge socially to the job of disconcerting her friends, but set out to develop its implications for education.

A series of books called the "Teach Yourself History Library," which will include nearly two score small volumes, is being published in England and this country. It is edited by an Oxford teacher and historian, Mr. A. L. Rowse of All Souls College, and resembles other series of books being published just now in Socialist Britain, where self-improvement is a popular theme.
BERKELEY, Calif., June 12 -- President Truman vigorously disavowed this afternoon any idea that this country might gamble for peace in two-handed "deals," with Russia.

The slumping Yankees suffered the embarrassment of a double defeat at the hands of the Indians yesterday before 68,586 persons at the Stadium. With Joe Gordon, the former New Yorker, poling one homer in the curtain-raiser and two in the afterpiece, Cleveland made it look easy en route to 7-5 and 9-4 victories.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Women got a permanent place today in the Army, Navy and Marine Corps.

STANDARD plants" are flowers or shrubs which are grown with a single stem to a desired height and then allowed to form a head of many short branches. They resemble miniature, symmetrical trees but actually are perennials that will bloom continuously through the summer.

TELEVISION will promote the theatre; there is no good reason for suspicion or fear on either side. Our experience to date indicates that television and Broadway have a natural affinity; they have much to gain and little to lose by the closest possible cooperation with each other.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- A Presidential fact-finding board reported today that the dispute threatening to immobilize the American maritime industry on Tuesday arose basically from the Taft-Hartley Law's impact on established practices of hiring men through the union.

AS an actress in television, I think it is perhaps questionable whether the spontaneity of video makes up for the lack of a finished product such as one views in a film. Films have the inestimable advantage of shooting and re-shooting, should even a tiny scene prove unsatisfactory for any reason whatsoever.

GREENVILLE, S. C., June 12 -- In action unprecedented in this region the Greenville County Democratic Executive Committee decided today to open its rolls to Negroes and permit them to vote in the party primaries.

DUNKIRK, N. Y., June 12 -- Efforts to break down world provincialism through permanent affiliation between towns of different nations began to take shape here today. The few score cities and towns in this country which already "adopted" communities overseas would be expanded to "thousands," with a permanent cultural relationship rather than temporary relief as their goal.

BERLIN, June 12 -- In strikingly similar announcements the three Western powers occupying this city announced today the measures they would take to counter the Soviet campaign of wooing support from this city's populace.

LONDON, June 12 (UP) -- "We are not earning our own living or paying our way, nor do the Government hold out the prospect of our doing so in the immediate future," Mr. Churchill said today in his Albert Hall speech.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., June 12 -- Banking's responsibility in an inflated economy will be weighed here carefully during the next three days by bankers of New York State. Representing all sections, some 600 commercial bank executives, members of the New York State Bankers Association, are gathering today for their fifty-second annual convention.

THE bright light of publicity now favoring television in the major metropolitan areas of this country has cast a temporary shadow over amplitude modulation and frequency modulation broadcasting. We in Rochester, N. Y., are enthusiastic over the future of television, both as manufacturers of television receivers and as near future television broadcasters.

ALERT advertisers have recognized the tremendous selling power which television offers and are now taking advantage of an opportunity to test in practice the promises which television in the laboratory has held out.

Twenty-one-year-old Betty Jane Holder of New Orleans, a former student at the University of Alabama, will leave New York tomorrow by air to visit "her" little French village of Mouleydier (Dordogne), near Bergerac, destroyed by German troops a fortnight after D-Day.

LONDON (By Wireless). THE House action ten days ago in cutting funds for ERP so heavily as, in the words of Secretary Marshall, to "alter the recovery program from one of reconstruction to one of relief," strengthened Europe's belief that American foreign policy is mercurial and unpredictable.
With two troops from Harlem as guests, 3,000 Brooklyn Girl Scouts took over Coney Island's Steeplechase Park yesterday for their fifteenth annual outing.

The Third Annual Intercollegiate Institute on the United Nations will be held at Finch College, 61 East Seventy-seventh Street, for a week beginning next Sunday, the sponsoring group, the Collegiate Council for the United Nations, announced yesterday.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 12 -- The Democratic State Convention ended its two-day session here today by praising President Truman's Administration but refraining from pledging the state's delegation in Philadelphia to any Presidential or Vice Presidential candidate.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers climbed into i fourth place in the American l League race today by defeating{ Washington, 4-1.
Mentioned among the "Footnotes" in your May 16 Magazine is the fact that sealskins auctioned this spring in St. Louis brought an average price of $70.10.

Two years ago we heard much about the KR treatment for cancer, "K" standing for Nina Kluyeva and "R" for her husband. Prof. Gregory Roskin. Both are Russian investigators who have been experimenting with this anti-cancer serum. In a report published in Science Drs. Theodore S. Hauschka and Margaret Blair Goodwin of the Lankenau Hospital Institute for Cancer Research, Philadelphia, state that they have been unable to verify the claims made for KR.

THE spicy fragrance over and above all the other sweet scents in a June garden can usually be traced to a clump of pinks. Not all of them are as scented as the perennials that open early, but various kinds of dianthus flower from May to frost.

SALMON, Idaho -- Many places in the United Stales have been called "the last frontier." This is a common description for groves and forests a few miles from trolley cars and downtown pavement, or almost any place that is able to offer the visitor superlative scenery and no neon signs.

MEXICO CITY, June 12 -- While the Federal Department of Pensions, which benefits from the Government ownership of the new Hotel del Prado, studies how painter Diego Rivera can be compelled to remove the words "God does not exist" from his hotel mural, President Miguel Aleman's comment, published today, was that the whole controversy was "unimportant."

Icy wings are still an airplane hazard, says David North, aeronautical engineer of Tulsa, Okla. In a paper read before the recent meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers he presented data obtained during 50,000 flight miles over the United States, four flights to Europe and three to Alaska.

New York City produces more than 1 billion gallons of sewage every day. About 40 per cent is treated in the city's thirteen sewage treatment plants; the rest is dumped direct from the sewers into the water around New York. As a result, the city's rivers are polluted; swimming in them is prohibited.

Rebounding after the setback in April resulting from the walkout of the coal miners, steel production in May amounted to 7,564,626 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, an increase of 1,346,469 tons over the total for April and the highest total for May in peacetime years, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

THE California Gold Rush, whose centenary is now undergoing elaborate observance in these parts, connotes offhand chiefly gold, bearded miners, barroom brawls, jumping frogs and the other bits of Americana immortalized by Twain and Harte.

After more than nine days of stolen freedom, Linda Estbrook, 15-year-old blond girl who was sent to the State School for Girls at Hudson, N. Y., several months ago after a series of penthouse burglaries, here last February, was picked up last night by two radio car policemen at 103rd Street and Broadway.

Taking advantage of loose fielding, Tottenville High, Richmond champion, defeated Brooklyn Tech, Brooklyn titleholder, 6 -- 1, in the semi-final round of the city P. S. A. L. baseball play-offs at Gabe's Stadium, West Brighton, S. I., yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UP) -- The magazine Aviation Week said today that a Russian DFS 346 jet fighter, based on German designs, had flown faster than the speed of sound. The publication, which originally disclosed that the American XS-1 had exceeded sonic speed, quoted reports from Russia to London as the source of its information.

ONE of the incidental consequences of the present situation in Palestine is that a project for shooting exteriors there for a film, "Life of St. Paul," is likely to be postponed sine die. This story has been for twelve years the special fancy of Anthony Havelock-Allan, of Constellation Films, who ingenuously admits that he was drawn to the Bible subject because he believes "there is a tremendous amount of good sense in the Christian teaching."

UNLIKE the mentally defective, who have been the subject of much modern writing, the physically afflicted person has rarely been assigned a leading role in fiction: one thinks, offhand, only of the hero in "Of Human Bondage" or of the several protagonists in "The Magic Mountain."

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, charged tonight that Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, in his Philadelphia speech retorting to President Truman's strictures on Congress, had clearly revealed the issue between the parties to be whether or not to return to the nineteenth century.

THERE are two passages in today's Treasure Chest which reflect contradictory aspects of our attitude toward words. Ivor Brown's comments on the word "yonderly" are evidence of the pleasure we have in them and of the fine distinctions of which they are capable.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- The University of Illinois announced today that it would begin immediate construction on a $53,000 building to house the world's first 20,000,000-volt betatron to be used in the treatment and research of deep-seated human cancer.

The School of Education at New York University in Washington Square will open next month the host comprehensive summer school program in its history, including workshops and seminars in three states, Dean Ernest O. Melby announced yesterday.

AMERICAN automotive engineers are watching intently the experiments with gas turbine engines for automobiles now taking place in England. These power plants, accredited with utilizing anything from "kerosene to candle ends," generate about 160 horsepower.

WHAT is to be the future of radio? Will it continue as a popular medium for entertainment, education and news or give way to television? These questions compare with the old queries on airplanes versus railroads and ships.

MEMBERS of the House and Senate continue during this election year to introduce bills calling for new stamps, even though the facilities of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing are, on the basis of a recent White House statement, already overtaxed.

AS far back as twenty years ago, nurserymen and gardeners with questioning minds began to wonder why transplanting could not be done during the summer instead of just in the spring and fall. They began to experiment and their experiments turned out so well that it is now predicted that most horticulturists will practice "all-season planting" within a few years.

Herbert McKenley failed in his attempt to break the world record for 400 meters yesterday. But the tall, slender Jamaican re-emphasized his rating as Olympic favorite by running away from a distinguished field in the fastest time ever registered in these parts.

At 10 A. M. Palestine time last Friday morning an Israeli GI, carrying a walkie-talkie, paced a front-line trench near Ras el Ein on the Jerusalem road twenty miles from Tel Aviv. Into the mike he repeated the staccato phrase Hafakit esh (cease fire).

The proposal made at Harvard by Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, that a small international police force be authorized and recruited by the U. N., for quick assignment to trouble spots in the world to enforce U. N. decisions, may give fresh impetus to a project which has long been debated, inconclusively, in the Military Staff Committee of the Security Council.

LOS ANGELES, June 12 -- In one of the most colorful settings in which the forty-eight-year old United States open championship has ever been staged, Ben Hogan, 35-year-old Texas-born golf professional, today won the title with a record-breaking score for the seventy-two holes of 276.

HAVING been sold a bill of goods by Frederick O'Brien's many books on the South Seas, the Guilds ventured forth the long way to paradise, via Europe and Africa. And though they expected the smell of frangipani and the "life vapor of hinano" to greet them, all they got was the stink of commerce and drying copra.

THERE are indications that a Nazi-minded organization is operating in the Scottish Highlands, and Antony Carne, a former captain in British Military Intelligence, is persuaded to look into the matter. While thousands of New Yorkers took part yesterday afternoon in the mammoth parade down Fifth Avenue to mark the opening of the city's fiftieth anniversary celebration, a family in Manhattan was celebrating another fiftieth anniversary -- the golden wedding of their parents.

AFTER far too long an absence -- five years -- the Swallows, Amazons and Scarabs are assembled again, all eight of them, and, of course, Captain Flint. It is the day before a happy but almost too smooth a sailing trip around the Hebrides is scheduled to end that John, the Ship's Naturalist, makes a startling discovery.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Forty-four research fellowships in medicine, biology and the physical sciences have been awarded to applicants from twenty states, the Atomic Energy Commission announced today. The recipients, who will study in twenty-four institutions throughout the United States, were chosen by National Research Council Fellowship Boards set up to administer the AEC-financed program.
ABOARD PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S SPECIAL TRAIN IN CALIFORNIA, June 12 -- At the rear platform of the Truman Special an old, old brand of politics is being practiced -- the politics of a man who wants votes.

LONDON, June 12 -- Looked at from Europe, a charitable view of the House of Representatives slash in ERP appropriations was fast gaining ground as the week ended. Never in the memory of European man has there been such a resounding "mea culpa" from across the Atlantic.

SUSANNA GAGE, daughter of strolling English actors, arrived in New York in 1778 to join the cast of the John Street Players. Opportunities for an ambitious young actress were better in New York than in London -- as were the chances of forgetting a hopeless love affair with a young English nobleman.

Thirty-eight firemen will receive medals Wednesday from Mayor O'Dwyer at a noon-day ceremony at City Hall, it was announced yesterday. All but two of the awards are for acts of heroism in 1947 and include honors to five men who died in the line of duty.
A NEW code of standards for radio stations, promulgated by the National Association of Broadcasters, is scheduled to become effective on July 1.

TELEVISION, which is daily establishing new records in programming, has yet to reveal fully its great potentialities for the spectacular. Science, which has made it potentially the greatest entertainment and educational force the world has ever known, will continually add to the medium's capabilities.

On behalf of the Labor Government, Great Britain's Department of Scientific and Industrial Research has long been working on the question of just how a small house should be built and equipped. Though the results will be applicable only to a small section of the United States, the British method of approaching the housing problem ought to interest American contractors and architects.

PHILADELPHIA -- When Don McNeill and "The Breakfast Club," one of the most popular morning network radio programs, were recently televised simultaneously with their regular radio broadcast, it is probable that a great many housewives in the New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore and Washington areas left their breakfast dishes unwashed so that they could see as well as hear this telecast.

LONDON, June 12 (UP) -- The International Committee for the Study of European Questions expressed the belief tonight that Russia's army could sweep to the Atlantic and the Mediterranean "in a fairly short space of time."
LONDON, June 12 -- Winston Churchill denounced the Labor Government today for deriding the United States system of private enterprise while at the same time being dependent upon that system for aid.

BRAINERD, Minn., June 12 -- The right wing of the strife-torn Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor party this afternoon asserted complete control of the party's state convention on an early showdown and caused the left-wing pro-Wallace elements of the party to hold a second D-F-L convention in Minneapolis over the week-end.

FINDING the right place for the television set in the living room sometimes raises problems in furniture arrangement -- problems that a bit of planning will solve easily. In planning the spot for the set the main thing to keep in mind is that guests should be seated comfortably and within proper viewing distance.

Even weathermen subscribe to the old saying that weather tends to perpetuate itself. Looking back on May, and noting what has been happening in June, the tendency is obvious. It is also cloudy and wet. There hasn't been enough sunshine in June to give a gardener even the beginning of a sunburn, let alone a summer tan. Not in these parts, there hasn't.

ABOUT two-thirds of the way through the first act of "Inside U. S. A." up at the Century Theatre something happens. The humidity lifts, the atmosphere brightens, you are certain at last that this is not actually a revival of "The Passing Show of 1928," after all, and life begins to look up.

THE fascination of getting the news by television lies in the medium's ability to take its audience to the immediate scene of action. Each viewer becomes his own reporter. Accordingly, telecasters give top priority to events which they can bring to the air at exactly the same time as they occur.

Students at Barnard College majoring in American civilization will make an exhaustive study of New York City, its historical background, its people and its present organization. The project is designed to synthesize the broad studies of American history, literature, government, geography, philosophy and geology, and to interpret American life as it is today.

RETAIL prices of frequency modulation receivers range from $44.95 to $1,595. The least expensive set is a table model, while the most expensive incorporates automatic phonograph facilities in a highly styled console cabinet which qualifies it as an acceptable piece of furniture.

Deputy Inspector Thomas F. Walsh, attached to the Fourth Division, suffered a heart attack yesterday afternoon while on duty near the reviewing stand of the jubilee parade at Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, and died at 6:20 P. M. in Roosevelt Hospital.

Action by the House Foreign Affairs Committee in approving Chairman Eaton's United Nations omnibus bill greatly enhances the prospect that Congress will authorize at this session the proposed $65,000,000 American loan for erection of a permanent U. N. headquarters in New York City. Among its many features the bill provides for such an authorization. If this nation intends to keep its promises, this authorization for the loan should be voted now.

MR. SUMNER WELLES, former Under-Secretary of State, who has done much for his country and for the world, has scarcely done a greater service than in writing this book. In a little over a hundred pages he has put the question of Palestine clearly in focus as the immediate crisis on which the preservation of peace in our time depends.
Last week, three years and one month after the collapse of the Third Reich, there were, in effect, two Germanys -- plus the international enclave of Berlin. The two Germanys are:

THE primary goal of the television industry at this time is the completion of a network service, similar to the networks of radio. Television cannot come into its own -- certainly cannot acquire adequate commercial support -- until it reaches a nation-wide audience.

MAN dreams forever of the Almost Perfect State. It may be as cheerful as the one sketched in the salty writings of Don Marquis. It may be as ponderable as Sir Thomas More's Utopia and Samuel Butler's Ere-whon.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 12 -- Preliminary skirmishes in parts of California's Central Valley indicate that farmers of this state are facing a serious drive by labor unions to get the great army of field workers organized during the coming harvest season.

Permit me to communicate to Delbert Clark my appreciation of his article, "The Palestine Crisis Seen From a DP Camp." In the brief space of about four Magazine columns. Mr. Clark presented a complete picture of the physical and mental state of Jewish displaced persons in Germany three years after the war during which European Jewry was decimated by the Nazis and their accomplices.

THE saloon, even when it was at odds with Andrew Volstead, ever has been the favorite forum of the man with something on his mind. In it he could air his preferences, his prejudices and his heresies: fulminate against his employers, his relatives and the status quo, voice his grievances against mankind, calypso singers and parking regulations.

JERUSALEM, June 12 -- Responsibility for working out details of the cease-fire concerning Jerusalem was placed today in the hands of the Security Council's three-man truce commission by Count Bernadotte, United Nations mrdiator, during a flying visit to the Holy City.

EVER since Bronco Billy Anderson first flung a tentative leg over a saddle astride a sawbuck on a Fort Lee studio stage, thereby commencing the cycle of Western cowboy films, horses -- or reasonable facsimiles -- have been conspicuous on the American screen.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 12 -- Yale failed to get an extra-base blow against two Princeton hurlers on University Field today, but the Eli nine capitalized on singles and loose Tiger fielding to gain a 7-5 victory before a crowd of 10,000 Princeton alumni here for reunion.

FEW, if any, of her former friends and acquaintances are glad to see Lissa Stanton when she returns to Ridgeton after an absence of thirteen years. This is especially true of her divorced husband, Geoffrey Paine, and his sister Adelle, who fear that Lissa is up to no good.

WARSAW, June 12 -- The statement that the great majority of people in every Eastern European country is anti-Communist, with the possible exception of Russia, contains more truth than can be found in most generalities. Yet to the great bewilderment of casual visitors from the West it is a needle-in-the-haystack task to find an organized group that is doing something about it.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 12 -- A brilliant individual round of 67 by Ray Torgerson enabled him and his guest, John F. Murphy of the Oakland Club, winners of the medal with 68, to march through the first round of the Cherry Valley member-guest tournament with a 4 and 3 victory over George McCree and William Henderson, Meadow Brook, the defending champions.

Thursday will mark a double anniversary for the Rev. Norbert Georges, a Dominican. The day will be the silver jubilee of his ordination to the priesthood and the tenth anniversary of his appointment as director of the Blessed Martin Guild.

Although weather was unfavorable last week, retail activity continued good, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Beachwear, junior sportswear and summer accessory departments reported high sales.
WHAT is television going to mean to the acting profession? Will it result in more or less employment? These and many other questions are being asked by performers.

TOKYO, June 12 (UP) -- United States aircraft were on a practice bombing mission over the area in which eleven fishing boats were sunk and fourteen Koreans killed last Tuesday, and the planes may have been involved in the incident, the United States Far East Air Forces said today.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- President Truman vetoed today the Bulwinkle bill to exempt railroad rate agreements from the anti-trust laws if the Interstate Commerce Commission approved them as "in furtherance of the national transportation policy."

Appealing to Democrats to maintain the liberal tradition of the party, Mayor Robert Taylor of Salamanca, N. Y., told delegates to the eighth biennial State Convention of the Affiliaed Young Democrats, Inc., yesterday that "We have let the liberal element of our party walk right out from under our nose."

After months of preparation, a small segment of the huge bulk of loot found by the Allied armies in Germany and Austria, and brought here to be sold for the rehabilitation of victims of Nazi persecution, will be exhibited on Wednesday, prior to sale at auction.
UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 12 -- Chet Sanok of Englewood will defend his New Jersey State amateur golf championship at the Upper Montclair Country Club tomorrow against Joe McBride of Arcola.

With pomp, ceremony and elaborate pageantry involving many heroes of the past, the silver anniversary of the Yankee Stadium will be celebrated today in a prelude to the final game of the series between the Yankees and Indians.

On the eve of its fiftieth anniversary, the International Paper Company announced yesterday details of its three-year expansion and modernization program, revealing that $40,000,000 is being spent on the Southern kraft division, and $6,000,000 on six Northern mills.

LONDON, June 12 -- America's strongly balanced Wightman Cup tennis team swept the final four matches on today's program at Wimbledon to complete a 6-to-1 conquest of Great Britain's game but out-gunned lassies.

IN one of the six stories in this volume Peter Chambers, that hard-boiled shamus, drinks milk. Not much milk, you understand. Just a sip, and strictly in the line of duty, for that one taste of an unaccustomed beverage leads him indirectly to the solution of a murder case.

With the record speed of a one-day change-over to national defense production now assured by a new multiple plant industrial mobilization plan, the full industrial requirements of the Munitions Board recommendations have been met by the thirteen plants of Bowser, Inc., K. F. Damon, president of the Johnson Consumer Industries, Inc., subsidiary, told an interviewer here yesterday.

A bill to set up the second peacetime draft in American history got over the half-way hurdle last Thursday on its road through Congress. The Senate passed S. 2655 -- the Selective Service Act of 1948. The bill still faces formidable opposition in the House.

Col. David Marcus, United States hero in World War II who was killed Thursday on the Jerusalem front while fighting for Israel, will be buried in the post cemetery at West Point with military honors, it was disclosed yesterday. Colonel Marcus, whose death occurred a few hours before the Palestine truce went into effect, was graduated from the Military Academy in 1924.

JERUSALEM, June 13 -- The three-day-old Palestine cease-fire was put in danger of being upset today by Israeli action in bringing an unchecked food convoy of forty-six trucks to Jerusalem and by Syrian action throwing a violent air, artillery and infantry attack against the Jewish settlements of Kfar Szold, Ein Gev and other points in Galilee.

PRAGUE, June 13 -- The Communist party disclosed today that nationalization had progressed to the point where only 5 per cent of all Czechoslovak industry remained in private hands., This exceeded by about 3 per cent the expected results of the second wave of nationalizations that was ordered after the February coup.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 13 -- The report from Washington this week that two American finance experts were on their way to Paris to take immediate steps to check the continuous shrinkage of trade among Western European countries revived hope in Europe that the American Government at last had decided to implement its avowed aim to promote the exchange of commodities among ERP countries and would remove bureaucratic restrictions now preventing private initiative from accelerating recovery.
George C. Stewart has been appointed Eastern sales manager of Lockheed Aircraft Service, Inc.

CINCINNATI, June 13 (AP) -- Boston's Braves bounced back into a tie for the National League leadership today by sinking the Reds, 8 -- 7 and 10 -- 5, in a doubleheader before a crowd of 30,590. A ninth-inning rally won the first game for the Braves, and they shelled Ewell Blackwell from the mound to take the second game.

With plans projected for assembly on eight lines the M. W. Kellog Company will be producing textile looms at the rate of 15,000 annually by the end of 1948, according to H. R. Austin, president. The company has the space and facilities to manufacture up to 30,000 looms a year, he said, and if the demand warrants such expansion it can be accomplished in four months.

LONDON, June 13 -- Winston Churchill, leader of the Conservative party, who called yesterday for the return of his party to power in Britain, was labeled today by Herbert Morrison, No. 2 in the Laborite hierarchy, as "a leader who doesn't lead."

A Vatican "decree" prohibiting Roman Catholics from participating officially in the constituting assembly of the World Council of Churches, to be held in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, Aug. 22 to Sept. 5, was assailed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Samuel M. Shoemaker in his sermon at Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

Referring to the many races represented in the Hawaiian Islands, the Right Rev. Harry S. Kennedy, Bishop of Honolulu for the Protestant Episcopal Church, said yesterday that "we believe we can live together." The bishop delivered the sermon at the 11 A. M. service of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at Ninetieth Street.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Throughout the forepart of last week corn on the Chicago Board of Trade showed a strong tone, registering a sharp upturn, but the gains were wiped out by free selling yesterday as good rains covered a large portion of the Corn Belt.
PITTSBURGH, June 13 (AP) -- The Pirates split a double-header with the Phils today, taking the nightcap, 9 to 2, after dropping the loosely played opener, 8 to 7, before 30,385 fans.

Until the motor launch Noria reached a point 350 feet offshore from City Island, her twelve-mile journey yesterday morning from her dock at the Astoria Boat Basin, in the East River, to a secret fishing spot in Long Island Sound was uneventful and unproductive, too, for the seventeen amateur fishermen aboard.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Wheat prices declined late in the week, following the Government June crop report that estimated both winter and spring wheat at well above general expectations. In addition there was selling pressure, based on good rains in the spring wheat territory and late week declines in coarse grains.

Ever since "Sleepy Hollow" had its premiere at the St. James on June 3, the handwriting was on the wall. On Saturday night the musical, based on Washington Irving's famous legend, succumbed, from malnutrition at the box-office. Only a dozen performances marked the brief career of the show, which took Lorraine Lester nearly two years to bring to the stage at a cost of $230,000, a sum supplied by almost 100 backers.
Vice Chairman Joseph T. Sharkey of the City Council gave yesterday the details of a measure to prevent pollution of the air. The bill will be offered at tomorrow's Council meeting in City Hall.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The votes of the delegations from Congress on important roll-calls in Congress during the period June 5 to 11 are given in the appended tabulation:

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 13 -- A plea for the militant practice of democracy in this country was made here today by the Rev. Dr. Morris S. Lazaron, rabbi of the Baltimore Hebrew Congregation. Dr. Lazaron delivered the baccalaureate sermon at the University of Virginia on the eve of that institution's 126th commencement.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- The Rev. Peter Marshall, the Senate's chaplain, deplores President Truman's later-softened charge that the Eightieth Congress was the "worst in history," but he thinks the law-makers should have given it the silent treatment.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 13 -- Library service to labor groups should be broadened and intensified, the opening session of the sixty-seventh annual conference of the American Library Association was told today by speakers addressing a meeting of the joint committee on library service to labor groups in Municipal Auditorium.

PRAGUE, June 13 -- Universities in the United States will be permitted to receive as Czechoslovak exchange students only those considered politically reliable by the Communist Ministry of the Interior.
The National Legion of Decency has placed the French-made feature film, "Passionnelle," and the Swedish-made film drama, "Torment,'' in its "Class C or Condemned'' category, it was learned yesterday.
Seven new films, including importations from England, Austria, France, Germany and Ireland, will arrive in first run theatres this week. The programs follow:

PORTSMOUTH, N. H., June 13 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey of New York said tonight he believed his chances of winning the republican Presidential nomination next week in Philadelphia were "excellent." This is the strongest language he has yet used with respect to his prospects.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 13 -- In a secret meeting of the Majlis [Parliament] today, Abdul Hussein Hajir was elected Premier of Iran, succeeding Ibrahim Hakimi. Mr. Hakimi, who twice previously had been Premier, this time had held the office only since last Dec. 22.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, June 12 (Delayed) (AP) -- Joint headquarters of the Arab armies in Palestine released today their official frontline positions, which, headquarters said, would be effective during the cease-fire.

BURBANK, Calif., June I3 -- Fully equipped to carry ninety-two passengers with provisions for 7,300 cubic feet of cargo, the second of the United States Navy's giant Constitutions successfully completed its first test flight here this week-end.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., June 13 -- Threat of a work stoppage at the Oak Ridge National Atomic Laboratory was averted today by a settlement calling for an average hourly wage increase of 15 1/2 cents an hour.

Salle Santelli retained the National three weapon team championship yesterday afternoon on the strips of the Fencers' Club when it defeated the host club in the final match, 2 -- 0. It also marked Santelli's second team victory in three days, having garnered the national saber title on Friday.

VERY young children say what they think, express what they feel, but soon we teach them not to. With maturity come caution and restraint, tact and courtesy -- and no more freedom of speech. So human beings rarely have intimate knowledge of each other. The secret places of the heart remain secret, and novelists who wish to expose them frequently resort to the stream of consciousness technique, the recording of unspoken, trivial and undirected thoughts.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., June 13 -- Avoidance o- bank nationalization rests squarely on the banking community itself, New York State Bankers were warned today, in a statement issued in connection with the annual convention of the New York State Bankers Association, now in session here.

Abscesses that formerly necessitated extraction now can be eliminated and the teeth preserved for added years of useful service, Dr. E. Alan Lieban, former director of the department of pulp canal therapy of New York University, said yesterday in an address at the closing session of the two-day annual meeting of the American Academy of Dental Medicine in the Pennsylvania Hotel.
ST. LOUIS, June 13 -- The Giants wound up their second western trip of the year today pretty much the way they had started it. One stride forward and one back.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 13 -- Champion Mazelaine Gallantry, a boxer from Tamaqua, Pa., made another visit to the New York metropolitan area a winning one today when he got best in show at the sixteenth event of the Longshore Kennel Club.

PRETORIA, South Africa, June 13 -- Indians in South Africa celebrated today the second anniversary of their passive resistance against the Asiatic Land Tenure and Indian Representation Act, the so-called "ghetto law."

CHICAGO, July 13 -- Consumers of America's meat production are one segment of the country's population who "could do something" about lowering the cost of their steaks and pork chops, "but evidence is rather conclusive that they will not," Walter A. Netsch, vice president of Armour Co. in charge of livestock purchasing, said today.

As the Department of Justice prepared to seek injunctions today under the Taft-Hartley Act that would avert a nation-wide maritime strike tomorrow, Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, declared yesterday that his union did "not intend to defy the law."
GENEVA, June 13 -- The excessive prices of European products are hampering the efforts of the United States to divert the demand for reconstruction goods from the United States to European sources.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 -- Federal court action to ward off a threatened nation-wide maritime strike probably will be sought in San Francisco and other key shipping cities tomorrow, under Presidential order.

When Count Folke Bernadotte accepted the role of United Nations mediator in Palestine on May 21, he said he believed there was "only a 1 per cent chance" that his mission could succeed. That slim chance was worth taking, he added, because it offered the one hope of extinguishing a spark that might set the world on fire.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 13 -- Joe McBride of Arcola celebrated the birth of a son today by scoring a crushing 8-and-7 victory over the defending champion, Chet Sanok of Englewood, in the 38-hole final of the New Jersey State amateur golf championship.

BRAINERD, Minn., June 13 -- The "right wing" convention of the Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor party voted unanimously here today "sincere appreciation" of President Truman, but declined almost unanimously to instruct its Democratic national convention delegation for him.

Nine of the seventy-three graduate students, representing seventeen European nations, who are scheduled to participate in the forthcoming Massachusetts Institute of Technology Foreign Student Summer Project arrived here yesterday. Five were passengers on the French liner Wisconsin and four Danish students came on the Marine Jumper.

During the business cycle, inventory holdings lag behind production by about six to nine months, and some inventories may continue to rise months after production has begun to fall. This new insight into the role of inventories' effect upon business cycles has been afforded by a special investigation of inventory fluctuations, in a report issued by the National Bureau of Economic Research over the week-end.

LONDON, June 13 (UP) -- Leon Blum proposed in 1936, while he was Premier of the Popular Front Government in France, that France and Germany draw up a joint Spanish policy calling for Generalissimo Francisco Franco to rule Spain, radio Moscow said today.

Air France, the French national airline, broke away yesterday from four other foreign flag air carriers on the Atlantic to sign the first agreement with the Port of New York Authority for space and facilities at New York International Airport, Idlewild.

The Affiliated Young Democrats, Inc., of New York State advocated yesterday the nomination of President Truman to succeed himself. A resolution, adopted at the closing session of the eighth biennial convention at the Piccadilly Hotel, declared that Mr. Truman was the choice of Franklin D. Roosevelt and that he had "demonstrated peerless qualities of leadership, statesmanship and integrity, which have led our people to prosperity at home and peace abroad."
VIENNA, June 13 -- Since the breakdown of the Austrian treaty negotiations in London, relations between the People's party and the Socialists in Austria's coalition Government have deteriorated.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Uncertain when the Interstate Commerce Commission will act on their application for a fare increase, eastern railroads are accepting reservations for passenger space for use from June 28 but are not selling space in advance.

The Northwestern University Traffic Institute will open this morning at New York University a two-week course in "modern methods of accident and congestion control" for city, county and state police officers in the northeastern states.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 13 -- The medalists, R. M. Torgerson and John F. Murphy of Oakland, continued their winning ways in the quarter-final round of the Cherry Valley member-guest tournament today by defeating Dr. Millard D. Webb and Jack Lyons, Garden City Golf, 4 and 2.

A New Englander from Springfield, Mass., John R. Whitehouse led downstream a record fleet of 181 starters yesterday from Albany to win the sixteenth running of the 136-mile Hudson River outboard marathon.
Suffering presents a two-fold opportunity for the follower of Christ, the Rev. Michael J. Deacy of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral declared in a sermon at solemn mass yesterday.

CHICAGO. June 13 -- An uncertain future today faced the seven remaining top officials of Montgomery Ward Co., who have staged an abortive revolt against the management practices of Sewell L. Avery, the company's 75-year-old chairman and chief executive.

HANOVER, N. H., June 13 -- Congress was called on to adopt a number of measures as "a minima for democratic morale in America and moral power in the world," by Dr. Frank P. Graham, president of the University of North Carolina, here today.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., June 13 -- Armed with a shotgun, which his wife "also has been taught to use," and with state policemen keeping a watchful eye on the premises, Leroy Hutson, 29-year-old Negro radio engineer in front of whose home in nearby Wall Township a twelve-foot cross was burned Friday night, said today: "I'm going to remain here."

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- A 159-page report on Poland, charting policies that, it was said, could easily double food production there and greatly increase the well-being of the people, was issued today by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration, in an acceleration of foreign recovery activities, authorized today its greatest procurement so far, an additional $95,610,605 for commodities and foodstuffs for eleven countries of Europe and Asia.

Because babies know what is best for them, they can often teach parents more than parents should try to teach them, according to Dr. James L. Hynes Jr., Professor of Education at State Teachers Colleg New Paltz, N. Y.

Promoting objectives is the primary problem of associations, according to a survey released over the week-end by Timely Associates, Inc. The percentage that set this as their major concern was 49.7, the study showed. New membership drives and the problem of generating enthusiasm among members placed second and third on the "worry list."

Cadet-Midshipman William E. Llewelyn of South Portland, Me., has taken command of the regiment of cadet-midshipmen at the Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, N.
