Y., it was announced last week following the school's graduation exercises. Mr. Llewelyn succeeds Robert Hellweg of St. Louis, Mo., who has completed his studies there.
NEVERS, France, June 13 (AP) -- Thousands of de Gaullist followers, after having heard their leader speak today, demanded the resignation of the National Government representative here.

An official Visitor Information Center, staffed by personnel familiar with the "cultural, sport, historic, entertainment and sight-seeing possibilities" of the city, will be maintained at its 500 Park Avenue offices by the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, Inc., Bernard F. Gimbel, president of the bureau and of Gimbel Brothers, announced yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer will lay the cornerstone of the $871,000 Brownsville health center in Brooklyn at 2 P. M. tomorrow, it was announced yesterday at City Hall. The center, which will be located on Bristol Street between Dumont and Blake Avenues, will be the first of fifteen units to be added to the Health Department's chain of neighborhood health centers, substations and child health stations.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- The seventy-three Pennsylvania delegates to the Republican National Convention, who, if united, probably could determine the party's nominee for President, were reported today to be sharply divided.
The second quarterly installment of the 1948 Federal income tax is due before midnight tomorrow.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, will depart late today for Prince Edwards Island, Canada, en route to Europe to study religious conditions in France, Italy, Austria, Czechoslovakia and Hungary.

PITTSBURGH, June 13 -- There was no dearth of orders for steel last week. If anything, demand was heavier than ever. Most steel sales offices were amazed at the continued strength of over-all demand. It was said here that many products which it had been thought would be easier to obtain were tightening up.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- The civil rights conference of the National Negro Council declared today, in a resolution adopted at a meeting here, that the failure of the Republican-controlled Congress to pass civil rights legislation would be construed by America's 13,000,000 Negroes as their "cruelest disillusionment" since the reconstruction era.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- House and Senate leaders, hoping to adjourn the Eightieth Congress next Saturday night, faced the difficult task today of acting on four to a half dozen important and controversial measures in the next six days.

BERLIN, June 13 -- This morning Frau Schmidt trudged over to the Soviet sector from her home in Wilmersdorf and signed the People's Congress petition for German unity. She had intended to go to Wannsee for a picnic with some friends.

BABYLON, L. I., June 13 -- James Dowling, 19 years old, of 210 Lakeview Avenue East, Brightwaters, L. I., was killed this evening by a bullet from a 22-caliber rifle he was handling in the rear yard of a friend's home here.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 13 -- Nina, the 59-foot schooner of Commodore DeCourcey Fales of the New York Yacht Club, easily won the Glen Cove to Newport race by an eight-minute lead over Howard Fuller's sloop Gesture today in 24 hours and a half.

LONDON, June 13 (UP) -- The Soviet Union has started to divert the course of several northern Russian rivers so that they will flow south into the Caspian Sea and keep it from drying up, according to Czechoslovak press reports reaching London today.

Seldom does THE NEW YORK TIMES, with its tradition of complete, unbiased reporting, fail to grasp the significance of an important news development. In my opinion, it did so on June 4 in reporting the legislation introduced by the House Foreign Affairs Committee to strengthen the U. N. machinery, encourage United States participation in collective defense ar rangements and order consultations on Charter revision.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., June 13 -- America must never allow itself to be maneuvered by communism into being the defender of the status quo in our economic society, John Foster Dulles declared today at the graduating exercises of Union College, undergraduate school of Union University.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 13 -- In several European and Latin-American countries, women have won new and important political rights within the last year, Miss Dorothy Kenyon, United States representative to the United Nations' Commission on the Status of Women, reported here today.

A two-week institute on the problems of hospital administration will open at 9 A. M. today in the main auditorium of Columbia University's School of Public Health, 600 West 168th Street. One hundred hospital administrators re expected to attend the institute, which is sponsored by the American College of Hospital Administration.

Governor Dewey's nomination of two Republican party workers who are not members of any tenant organization for Federal appointment as tenant representatives on the New York City area rent advisory board was denounced yesterday by the Emergency Committee on Rent and Housing as being "in flippant disregard" of the Government's rent control regulations.

BOSTON, June 13 -- An agreement reached today by the Collier Owners Association and the National Maritime Union (CIO), ended the danger that the New England coal fleet of thirty-two vessels would be involved in the maritime strike scheduled for Tuesday on the Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf Coasts.

HACKENSACK, N. J., June 13 -- New York and New Jersey motorists, particularly the New York variety, were admonished today by Judge Carmine Savino Jr. of the Bergen County Traffic Court to mend their driving manners on week-ends or stay at home.

PRAGUE, June 13 -- Communism's triumph in Czechoslovakia will be complete tomorrow when Premier Klement Gottwald, chairman of the Communist party, who ran for the Presidency against the late Thomas G. Masaryk in 1934 when it was a mere gesture, will be unanimously acclaimed President by the single-list Parliament of 300 members.

The top command of the American Labor party is ready to begin on July 1 the circulation of a petition to place on the Nov. 2 ballot a proposal to amend the City Charter to re-establish the five-cent fare on all municipal transit lines on Jan. 1, 1949, and make any future change subject to a mandatory referendum.

Interest is being whipped up in the Soviet Union in the political situation in Iran, which is pictured by Communist writers as the scene of "frequent rebellions and the continual national-democratic struggle" of Kurds and Azerbaijani.

Fall buying in wholesale garment markets here last week was brisk and most markets reported substantial sales, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Buyers continued to shop the new lines thoroughly before placing orders with manufacturers.

BERLIN, June 13 -- The Presidium of the Communist-dominated People's Council of the German People's Congress announced today an eight-point program for Germany to replace the London decisions of the Western powers, which it assailed as far worse than the Treaty of Versailles.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $54,595,792,522. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 (AP) -- Carl Scheib pitched the Philadelphia Athletics to a 3-1 victory over St. Louis today, after the Browns had won the first game, 7 -- 5, with a six-run uprising in the eighth inning, against Lou Brissie and Nelson Potter.

June is the beginning of the season when fish are most plentiful. Right now the markets are offering many varieties -- cod, mackerel, porgies and shellfish in liberal quantities. The economical specimens are a worthwhile investment for frequent use.

With the "no wage increase" pattern broken in the automobile, electrical, rubber and other major industries, interest shifted yesterday to the possibility of an early reversal of the steel industry's decision to withhold any rise in wages this year.

Foote, Cone and Belding International Corporation has been formed by Foote, Cone Belding, New York advertising agency, to handle its overseas business, it was announced over the week-end. The new firm was described as an outgrowth of the international division of the parent company and is a wholly owned subsidiary with offices at the latter's headquarters, 247 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Tigers breezed to 9-3 and 9-2 victories over Washington today to sweep a four-game series with the Senators and tighten their grip on fourth place. Dizzy Trout pitched a 6-hitter in the opener to win his seventh game, while Virgil Trucks gained his fourth decision with a seven-hitter in the nightcap.

In direct reply to the phony "peace offensive" launched by Russia as part of its "cold war" against the democracies, President Truman has again reiterated the fundamentals of American foreign policy. In doing so he has also put his finger on the distortion of the international situation that is the false basis of the latest Soviet maneuver.

Women all over the world fear the possibility of war and are doing all they can to maintain peace and promote understanding among nations, Mrs. Ambrose N. Diehl, president of the National Council of Women of the United States, reported here yesterday on her return from a four-month global trip.
They rolled back the years yesterday at the Stadium and in the all-too-brief period of ninety minutes revived diamond glories of a quarter-century.

Events tonight: New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Fritz Reiner, conductor, and Erica Morini, violin, Lewisohn Stadium, 8:30 o'clock; Fred Tait-Douglas, program of Scotch songs, Times Hall, 8:30; Bellini's "Norma," presented by Opera Tonight, Kenneth Hieber, conductor, the Pythian, 135 West Seventieth Street, 8:40.

LONDON, June 13 -- A British War Office spokesman disclosed today that 24,000 German prisoners out of 400,000 once held in this country had received permission to settle in the United Kingdom as "resident aliens."

Czechoslovakia, on orders from the Kremlin, is about to undergo a purge of books that do not toe the party line. Communist librarians in Prague are already pawing through public and private bookshelves to eliminate all "unworthy" literature. The process will continue through the summer, and by fall it is expected that every library in the new Red state will be cleansed of its former taint.

The Board of Transportation appealed yesterday to business concerns in lower Manhattan to help relieve rush-hour congestion on the rapid transit lines by staggering the arrival and departure time of employes. The most effective method, the board declared, would be to spread arrivals and departures by fifteen-minute intervals between 7 and 10 A. M. and 4 and 7 P. M.
ROME, June 13 -- Mario Montagnana, brother-in-law of Palmiro Togliatti, Communist leader, lost his post as regional Communist secretary in Piedmont today.
LONDON, June 13 -- The distinctly gloomy sentiment in the stock markets here a week ago has given place recently to a less pessimistic outlook.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 -- L. Mario Giannini, president of the Bank of America, told a Securities and Exchange Commission board of inquiry late yesterday that he advised the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation against floating its recent $10,000,000 common stock issue.

In the May 31 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES an editorial predicts that the mock elections in Czechoslovakia are but a prelude to the final incorporation of that state into the U.S.S.R. That was the pattern in the Baltic states, and according to two previous reports from C. L. Sulzberger, the incorporation of the Danubian states is in preparation in Rumania.

MANHEIM, Pa., June 13 (AP) -- A single red rose, lifted from a priceless bit of colonial glassware, was handed to a woman today, and for the fifty-sixth time the annual "legal debt" of the Zion Evangelical Lutheran Church was discharged in full.

PARIS, June 13 -- The arrival of two European Recovery Program chiefs of missions and the landing of several hundred American tourists at Southampton, Le Havre and Rotterdam were delayed eight hours or more yesterday when the British did not provide a boat train on the day the Holland-American liner Nieuw Amsterdam reached Southampton. This obliged the ship to wait all Friday night off Southampton before unloading passengers.

AMSTERDAM, June 13 -- The decisions reached at last week's conference of ministers of Benelux (Belgium, The Netherlands, Luxembourg) at Chateau d'Ardennes are termed almost sensational in well informed economic and financial quarters here and in The Hague.

The United Parents Association has presented to the Board of Education the outline of a program of education for personal and family living for students in public high schools. A petition signed by twenty-five educators, jurists and social welfare leaders urging early introduction by the city of the program to teach young men and women how to get along with each other and with their parents also was announced yesterday by the organization.

The upholstery fabrics of F. Schumacher Co., 60 West Fortieth Street, serve in a new line of duty, as fabric for the second dress collection of Barbara Barondess MacLean, a California interior decorator.

The past winter was hard on children in many New York homes where over- crowded housing, extreme cold and the fuel shortage were added to other serious economic and health problems. The Community Service Society wants to send nearly 1,700 such boys and girls on a much-needed vacation this summer.

Olin Downes' recent tribute to Mrs. Claire Reis, retiring executive chairman of the board of directors of the League of Composers, was appropriate and highly merited. We are especially indebted to her for her invaluable book, "Composers in America," recently reedited and reissued, which is an essential reference work for any library and a monumental contribution to American music.
Cardinal Spellman arrived at La Guardia Airport from Los Angeles at 9:43 o'clock last night after a 39,000-mile air tour of the Far East.

ATHENS, Greece, June 13 (UP) -- William J. Donovan, wartime chief of the United States Office of Strategic Services, left by plane today for New York after a preliminary investigation into the death of George Polk, Middle Eastern correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Consolidated net sales of The May Department Stores Company and subsidiaries for the year ended on last Jan. 21 were $358,013,576, the largest in the company's history and $27,681,708 more than the sales in the year ended on Jan. 31, 1947, the highest volume on record.

PARIS, June 13 -- France's request to postpone the Western Allied commanders talks in Frankfort on the Main, Germany, over the new Germna state was made to allow the French Assembly to complete its debate on the six-power recommendations on Western Germany, officials explained today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Max Ball of the Department of the Interior said today that the nation's gasoline supply for this summer and fall "looks pretty good." He coupled this report, which is more optimistic than others have been, with the disclosure that he plans to resign as director of the department's oil and gas division, effective on Aug. 1.

The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, led the congregation of St. Michael's Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-ninth Street, in a service of tribute yesterday afternoon to the parish's retiring rector, the Rev. Thomas McCandless.

DETROIT, June 13 -- Tribute to the American descendants of Swedish pioneers was paid here today by Prince Bertil, grandson of King Gustav of Sweden, at a rally which was the highlight of this community's observance of the centennial of Swedish settlement in the Middle West.
Play will resume in the national professional tennis championship at Forest Hills today after the interruption of yesterday's rain.

Miss Minerva Bernardino, chairman of the Inter-American Commission of Women, was honored yesterday as the Woman of the Americas for improving the condition of women in her native Dominican Republic and elsewhere through the United Nations.

Grass-edged, crooked fingers reach into the water along the northern shoreline. In between the twisting spits are the inlets that stab deeply into the mainland. In sheltered coves at low tide men go out on the gently sloping mud banks to dig clams; the black, rich soil is a pattern of crisscrossed rivulets and gullies glistening in the sun.

A regular program service will be opened tomorrow night at 7:30 on Channel 11 by WPIX, the television station of The Daily News. A program more than four hours in length has been arranged for the outlet's debut.

GRENLOCH, N. J., June 13 (AP) -- Jersey Joe Walcott put the accent on left hooks today in a spirited four-round session before a crowd of more than 1,000. The workout, originally scheduled for six rounds of boxing, was interrupted by a heavy downpour and the heavyweight challenger finished up his lighter exercises indoors.

Continuing a campaign against losses in this port from waterfront thievery, the Security Bureau, Inc., has notified member companies that employes dismissed for "misconduct" face a seven-week delay in obtaining unemployment benefits.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 -- Evidently happy over the effect of his speaking tour across the top of the United States, President Truman decided today to talk his way back to Washington across the middle of the country.
GRINNELL, Iowa, June 13 -- The National Conference for the Prevention of World War III ended four days of deliberations today on a harmonious note.

ALBANY, June 13 -- The Public Service Commission ruled today that gas and electric companies which require their customers to pay for special services must show the rate for each item in schedules filed with the commission. The tariffs must be filed by Aug. 1.
Sermons commemorating the first day of Shabuoth, the traditional Feast of Weeks, were preached yesterday in synagogues throughout the city.

Harvard University Press has scheduled three more volumes in its American Foreign Policy Library for publication before the end of the year. Seymour Harris, Harvard economist, is the author of "The European Recovery Program," and the editor of "Foreign Economic Policy for the United States," which are planned for the fall.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 13 -- A liner carrying 420 persons to Israel anchored in Tel Aviv harbor tonight, confronting Count Folke Bernadotte with his first immigration problem under the Israeli-Arab truce.

NOSTALGIA dripped all over the Yankee Stadium yesterday in the wake of weeping skies as an amazing crowd of 49,641 turned out to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the opening of the House That Ruth Built and to welcome back the heroes of the 1923 team which brought the first world championship to the Bronx Bombers.

Governor Driscoll of New Jersey has indicated that his state may create a State Highway Authority to finance and operate toll roads. The proposed Authority would be an arm of the State Highway Department and would be authorized to issue bonds to finance toll road construction without invoking the credit of the state.

Completing its first century of service to the City of New York, the Community Service Society provided help last year to 30,000 families, including 72,000 individuals, according to its annual report, made public yesterday by Walter S. Gifford, chairman of its board of trustees, and Bayard F. Pope, president.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 13 -- The United States will be such a "shining leader for the individual freedoms and dignity and faith by which we live" that free men everywhere will join this nation in a combination that no other power on earth can challenge, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower told 1,200 graduates of Rutgers University today.

MIAMI, Fla., June 13 -- The second charge in the double-barrelled campaign against the Miami City Commission will be loosed Wednesday when the Junior Chamber of Commerce starts circulating recall petitions against the city's mayor and four commissioners.

The Rev. Arthur R. Kleps, pastor of the Immanuel Evangelical Lutheran Church, Eighty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue, announced at the end of the morning service yesterday that he had received a call from Trinity Lutheran Church in Utica, N. Y.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 13 -- A wet easterly with accompanying sea roll moderated so that seventy-eight craft went out today for the championship Long Island Sound Association regatta of the Orienta Yacht Club.
LUCERNE, Switzerland, June 13 (AP) -- The United States Army won the military grand prize at the International Horse Show here today.

A narrow trading range characterized cotton prices in the domestic market last week and, although selling was not particularly aggressive, depressive factors outweighed constructive influences. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were off 2 to 29 points from the previous week.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- The American Veterans Committee's planning committee, which represents twenty-one chapters and 120,000 members, closed a two-day meeting today after adopting a resolution banning political activity by the AVC.

In this year 1948, when the fiftieth anniversary of the creation of our five-borough metropolis is being celebrated with fitting ceremonial, thoughts turn naturally and often to Greater New York as it was in 1898, when the proud appellation "Greater" was first added to "New York."

With the retirement of Dr. Amos O. Squire as medical examiner of Westchester, a public servant of exceptional abilities has been lost to the county. His work continued for so many years that it was taken for granted by many persons; his retirement is revealing the difficulty of replacing him.

HOLLYWOOD, June 13 -- "Celebration," a forthcoming magazine story by Richard Mealand, has been purchased for the screen by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a possible farce-comedy vehicle for Van Johnson and June Allyson. The story deals with an artist, his ex-wife, his fiancee, and his 80-year-old aunt, and it is expected that William H. Wright will produce the film version.

A former manager of a Latvian shipping line arrived here yesterday from Europe and declared he would claim a one-third share of more than $1,000,000 belonging to the company and now held by the United States Alien Property Custodian.
A medical center to provide free treatment for strikers and their families will be opened tonight under the auspices of the Greater New York Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- In the first announcement of its medal awards for 1948, the Franklin Institute said today that Charles D. Young, former vice president and director of the Pennsylvania Railroad, would receive the Henderson Medal on Oct. 20 for his contributions to the scientific advancement of the steam locomotive.

WARSAW, June 13 (UP) -- Poland and Czechoslovakia will coordinate their foreign trade policies, divide some of their industrial production and avoid "unhealthy competition" in foreign markets, it was announced today.

LOS ANGELES, June 13 -- As far as Ben Hogan's immediate golfing plans are concerned, he will continue to concentrate on the "home" tournaments. No foreign events, especially the British open at Muirfield, Scotland, beginning June 28, have any particular attraction for him.

NANUET, N. Y., June 13 -- More than 8,000 persons from all parts of the metropolitan area took part here today in the Silver Jubilee Pilgrimage to St. Anthony's Shrine at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Anthony. The first pilgrimage was in 1923.

Beach resorts in the metropolitan area were flying financial distress signals yesterday and it generally was predicted that a few more rainy week-ends might leave concessionnaires with little more than crying towels.
Parental and municipal indifference were held primarily responsible yesterday for Harlem's most serious problem -- juvenile delinquency.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Alberto Tarchiani, Italian Ambassador, today reported that the Communist strength in his country was falling off steadily.

PARIS, June 13 -- Georges Bidault, to survive as France's Foreign Minister, must convince the National Assembly that he has really waged a protracted diplomatic battle to carry out the French program in relation to setting up an international administration of the Ruhr area.
Notable in art events of this week will be the Wildenstein Gallery's summer exhibition of French portraits of the nineteenth century. It will open on Wednesday.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 13 -- Fighting has ceased in upper Galilee, post-truce explosive point in Palestine, indicating that the cease-fire has finally become a reality.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 13 (AP) -- The Columbia River today pushed its third crest in the lower valley to above the flood level that smashed the city of Vanport two weeks ago. The river menace will remain for several weeks in the flood stricken valley.

As author of those Spanish programs which have irked Congress, I'd like to say a few words to your reacers. I proved, beyond doubt, that I obeyed orders and, consequently, the blame was placed on others. When I told the committee that I had been imprisoned by the tyrant Gomez, one of the Senators expressed amazement that a man with my background should have been entrusted with those broadcasts.

SEA ISLE CITY, N. J., June 13 -- Arrangements have been made by the city commissioners for a test demonstration of mosquito and fly control by spraying this resort from the air, Mayor William A. Haffert announced today.

HARRISON, N. Y., June 13 -- Dalchoolin, aged brown gelding owned by Gordon Wright of White Plains, N. Y., annexed the Greenwich horse show open jumper title at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club grounds today by taking three blues for a total of 26 points.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Sunshine followed yesterday's rain, but so did Johnny Schmitz, slim southpaw ace, with the result that the Cubs beat the Dodgers, 3-1, before a thrilled throng of 40,930 cash customers at Wrigley Field today.
DUNKIRK, N. Y., June 13 -- The United Neighbors, an organization that would develop a web of links among towns in different countries to promote international understanding, was projected here today.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 13 -- Democracy is capable of producing more material wealth with economic justice than dictatorship, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, told the 580 members of the university's largest graduating class in his baccalaureate address today in University Chapel.

TOKYO, June 13 -- The harassed Tokyo housewife today is pinning her hopes on the lowly Irish potato to rescue her soon from her latest post-war dietary dilemma. There is a big ration of sugar with nothing to sprinkle it on.

For a city of its size and wealth, New York has been singularly backward in disposing of its wastes. One Health Commissioner after another has called attention to the potential danger of bathing in waters that lap the shores of Coney Island, Staten Island, Rockaway and Orchard Beach, though bacterial counts are not yet prohibitively high.

HARRISON, N. Y., June 13 -- Dalchoolin, aged brown gelding owned by Gordon Wright of White Plains, N. Y., annexed the Greenwich horse show open jumper title at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club grounds today by taking three blues for a total of 26 points.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Sunshine followed yesterday's rain, but so did Johnny Schmitz, slim southpaw ace, with the result that the Cubs beat the Dodgers, 3-1, before a thrilled throng of 40,930 cash customers at Wrigley Field today.
DUNKIRK, N. Y., June 13 -- The United Neighbors, an organization that would develop a web of links among towns in different countries to promote international understanding, was projected here today.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 13 -- Democracy is capable of producing more material wealth with economic justice than dictatorship, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, told the 580 members of the university's largest graduating class in his baccalaureate address today in University Chapel.

TOKYO, June 13 -- The harassed Tokyo housewife today is pinning her hopes on the lowly Irish potato to rescue her soon from her latest post-war dietary dilemma. There is a big ration of sugar with nothing to sprinkle it on.

For a city of its size and wealth, New York has been singularly backward in disposing of its wastes. One Health Commissioner after another has called attention to the potential danger of bathing in waters that lap the shores of Coney Island, Staten Island, Rockaway and Orchard Beach, though bacterial counts are not yet prohibitively high.

NOTTINGHAM, June 14 (Reuters) -- A fighting innings of 154 not out by Denis Compton today helped England to save an innings defeat in the first of the season's cricket test matches against Australia. England carried her second innings total to 345 for six wickets and at the close of play led by one run.
Marvin S. Bandoli has been appointed vice president in charge of sales of the Tracy Manufacturing Company, kitchen sinks and cabinets, effective July 1.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 14 -- Dr. George H. Gallup, director of the American Institute of Public Opinion, declared today that academic degrees should not be awarded to graduates until twenty-five years after graduation.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The Senate tonight quickly passed a record $442,179,098 Interior Department appropriations bill. More than half of the funds are earmarked for Western reclamation projects.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., June 14 -- Three-year-old, blond, blue-eyed Marie Henrietta Bullis, who, unaccompanied, arrived by plane in New York Saturday from her native Scotland to join her parents here, received as big a welcome tonight as this village was able to express.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., June 14 -- Early withdrawal of "favorite son" candidates from the Republican Presidential race is probable, leaving the field to major contenders for the nomination, Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey indicated today.

ALBANY, N. Y., June 14 -- Borrowing for payment of the bonus to New York State's veterans of World War II will be $100,000,000 less than the $400,000,000 originally estimated, State Controller Frank C. Moore announced today.
Two spokesmen for the City's government registered vigorous opposition yesterday to a proposal by dairy groups that would result in higher milk prices here if it is adopted.

Dairy companies report that New York and Chicago lead the rest of the country in their use of sour cream. June being the month when all milk products are the most plentiful, it's an apt time for those who don't know the preparation to investigate it.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Corn and oats futures, while weak at the start on the Board of Trade today, met good commission house support and late short covering lifted prices sharply near the close. Buying was based on moderate country offerings and the tight cash trade conditions.

The warm weather slump in restaurant business, just starting to be felt, will result in the next two months in the closing of at least half of the service food establishments in this city for periods of one to eight weeks, a survey indicated yesterday.

NUREMBERG, Germany, June 14 -- Ernst von Weizsaecker, former German Ambassador to the Vatican, said today that at the Vatican late in 1944 he transmitted to Francis Cardinal Spellman, then an archbishop, a memorandum to President Roosevelt intended to hasten peace.

Rippey did exactly what they wanted him to do yesterday and he did it to perfection. Asked to carry the top weight of 135 pounds in the $15,000 added Roseben Handicap the 5-year-old son of Pompey found the burden no trouble at all as he strode to victory by a length over Mrs. John D. Hertz's Owners Choice in the six-furlong test on the Widener course, with Mose Rauzin's Buzfuz third.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Michigan Consolidated Gas Company of Detroit, a subsidiary of American Light and Traction Company asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to increase its unsecured debt by $7,500,000 up to December 31, 1951.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- President Truman has signed three appropriation bills on his Western trip, the White House announced today. They cover expenditures of $2,957,715,226 for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1949.

LONDON, June 14 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, seeded No. 2, routed Gwyn Ruckett of Wales, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, to win his first round match in the London lawn tennis championships. The meet is a preview of next week's Wimbledon tournament.

Before this week is over the Republican majority in the Senate will have to decide whether or not it means to stand by our full commitments under the European Recovery Program or whether it will make concessions in order to save face for the House Republicans who cut one and a half billion dollars out of the program.

Four hundred persons crowded yesterday into a court room in the Brooklyn Supreme Court to pay tribute to the memory of Col. David Marcus, former New York City Commissioner of Correction, who was killed while serving with the Haganah forces in Palestine.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., June 14 (AP) -- Bill Bevens made his first start since spring training today when he worked three innings for the New York Yankees against their Binghamton Eastern League farmhands.

An all-electronic elevator signal system, believed to be the first major application of electronics to elevator control, has been installed in the new Universal Pictures Building at 445 Park Avenue, the Otis Elevator Company announced yesterday.

Stockholders of United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc. received yesterday the regular common quarterly dividend of 25 cents and an extra dividend of 30 cents, making a total of $1.60, for the fiscal year ended on June 30. In addition, a stock dividend of 10 per cent will be distributed by the company on July 30, to holders of record of July 8.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 14 -- Richard T. West of Washington captain and quarterback of Princeton's '47 varsity football team a Phi Beta Kappa scholar in economics, received the Class of 1901 Medal today as the outstanding member of Princeton's graduating class at senior prize exercises in Alexander Hall.

Trained social workers are needed to aid rehabilitation of tuberculous patients, it was agreed yesterday at a preliminary conference sponsored by the National Tuberculosis Association at the Pennsylvania Hotel. The forty-fourth annual meeting will open there today.

LONDON, June 14 -- An assurance that Britain would not concede power to the United States to interfere with Britain's rate of monetary exchange was repeated in the House of Commons today when the bilateral agreement between the two countries on the European Recovery Program came under discussion.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The House Rules Committee voted by 6 to 4 today to let the whole House vote on the stop-gap draft bill.
Leaders of the world's major religions will meet tomorrow, Thursday and Friday in Town Hall to devise plans for the moral and spiritual support of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- In cutting the European Recovery Program by 24 per cent, the House Appropriations Committee gave ten reasons, which were not answered in the testimony of both Secretary of State Marshall and ECA Administrator Paul Hoffman.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 14 -- A growing censorship of books and other reading matter is endangering our intellectual freedom, speakers warned today at the sixty-seventh annual conference of the American Library Association here.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Two Republican members of the Rules Committee of the House -- Harness of Indiana and Rizley of Oklahoma -- shifted position today, at the belated urgency of party leaders, against granting the House a vote on the Selective Military Service bill.
Princeton's 150-pound Eastern champions and the Kent (Conn.) School varsity eight sailed for England yesterday where they will row against twenty-three English crews in the Royal Henry regatta.

The comprehensive measure for control of air pollution which Vice Chairman Joseph T. Sharkey will introduce in the City Council today proposes new machinery and law for a fresh attack on a problem of great importance to the city's welfare and the comfort of its people.

Coast-to-coast broadcasting was disrupted yesterday at 2:19 P. M. when two cables carrying the lines of the four major radio networks were accidentally severed by a private construction company building a dam near Chappell, Neb. Telephone and telegraph service l also was affected.

There has been no abrupt or unseasonal change in the nation's weather, though almost everyone seems to think there has been, the Weather Bureau said yesterday. Government records show it as rather a good year.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 -- The governing body of the International Labor Organization delayed again today action on acceptance of affiliation of the World Federation of Trade Unions on a "consultative relationship" basis.

CINCINNATI, June 14 -- The United States is undergoing economic pressures which "spell a real and present danger of inflation," Charles Sawyer of Cincinnati, United States Secretary of Commerce, told delegates to the forty-fourth annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America today in the Netherland Plaza Hotel.

The five Federal Area Rent Directors in charge of residential rents in the city and Long Island announced yesterday a decision that collection of security deposits by landlords cannot be generally authorized here, since the practice was not general before the war.

Mayor O'Dwyer began yesterday "a very sympathetic inquiry" into the problems of Puerto Rican residents of the city when he conferred at City Hall with Miss Pearl Zimmerman, director of field operations of the Welfare Department, and Miss Juana G. Santana, Welfare Department social investigator.

METUCHEN, N. J., June 14 -- Benson Ford, vice president of the Ford Motor Company and director of the Lincoln-Mercury division, declared today that elimination of labor-management discord was a basic requirement for industrial progress. "We intend to do our best to contribute to this industrial peace," he said.

The qualities that have made George Biggar of New Jersey an ideal employe and good neighbor won recognition for him this year from the National Father's Day Committee as America's top "worker father."

LONDON, June 14 -- Winston Churchill tersely denied today a statement made yesterday by Herbert Morrison, leader of the House of Commons, that the former Prime Minister was drawing his 2,000 [$8,000] annual salary as leader of the Opposition in the House while absent from his duties.

JERUSALEM, June 14 -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine, heeding an ultimatum by the United Nations Truce Commission, agreed tonight to the establishment of a convoy check post at Bab el Wad, critical point on the main highway from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 14 -- The World Federation of Trade Unions, which claims to represent 65,000,000 persons in affiliated national organizations, complained to the United Nations today that labor's rights were being violated in nine member countries and in Spain and Portugal.
PARIS, June 14 -- Debate on the six-power London recommendations for Germany will reopen tomorrow in the National Assembly, with the prospect of a small majority vote containing some reservations.

Prizes were awarded yesterday to classes from kindergarten, elementary and junior high schools in the Bronx, for their work in furthering a "Cleanliness for Health" program that grew out of the "garbage crisis following the great snow, the day after Christmas, 1947."

THE Cleveland Indians had just routed the Yankees for the third straight time when Joe Gordon, who never allows his affection for his old team to influence his business-like operations for his new one, excitedly exclaimed: "We're in!" Perhaps the Flash is a trifle optimistic. Certainly he's much too premature. But the fact still remains that the Tribe is gaining an increased amount of respect both from rival clubs and the experts.

Another no-hit, no-run game by Billy Loes -- his fourth against P.S.A.L. competition this season -- gave Bryant High a 4-0 victory over George Washington at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday, and sent the Queens champions into the final against Tottenville, Staten Island titleholders.

Although manufacturers generally are adhering to existing price schedules on corsets and brassieres for early fall delivery, they have taken a "realistic" course in catering to a definite buyers' market, it was learned yesterday following the opening of the official fall market week for the industry.

First concrete steps to develop international standardization of textiles and textile test methods have been taken by fifteen nations, Vice Admiral G.F. Hussey, secretary, American Standards Association, disclosed yesterday. In a press conference at 70 East Forty-fifth Street, he said that a special textile committee of these nations has approved two types of yarn twists as standards recommended by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO).
LONDON, June 14 -- The Times of London said today that Russia was softening her political tactics in Europe.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts announced yesterday that it would receive bids until June 24 for $22,500,000 of bonds to be sold in two lots. One lot will consist of $6,000,000 of serial bonds maturing from 1949 to 1952 and $7,800,000 of bonds maturing from 1949 to 1958.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- William T. Faricy, president of the American Association of Railroads, told a Congressional committee today that Robert R. Young. chairman of the board of directors of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad, had made statements having "absolutely no foundation in fact."

ONE of the most baffling, peculiar and eccentric books that ever combined scholarship with folly is "The Plantagenets,"* by John Harvey. Strange and wonderful to behold is Mr. Harvey's longing for the past. Miniver Cheevy, hero of Robinson's poem, "loved the days of old when swords were bright and steeds were prancing."

ST. LOUIS, June 14 -- On the basis of a normal vacancy rate of 10 per cent, office space in our principal cities is 8,000,000 to 10,000,000 square feet short of the present demand, members of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers were told today at the opening business sessions of their forty-first annual convention.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Rear Adm. Thorvald A. Solberg, 52, an expert on atomic energy, was nominated by President Truman today to be the Navy's new Chief of Research.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today two bills designed to aid and strengthen the American merchant marine.

John A. Cassidy, member of the international executive board of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, has resigned as Nebraska state chairman of the Wallace-for-President committee, it was announced last night by Michael J. Quill, president of the union.

Skeptical observers of crosstides at work in the present market for high-grade investments have predicted that it would only be a matter of time before underwriters, inspired again by bullish "flashes," would begin to overbid the market again. Such predictions were borne out yesterday by the bidding for Kansas City Power and Light Company's bonds and preferred stock.

Another new opera company founded by young singers eager to get a hearing opened its first season last night when it gave Bellini's "Norma" in an English version on the stage of the ballroom of The Pythian, fraternal building, at 135 West Seventieth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Constitutionality of the act providing for renegotiation of war-time contracts, by which the Federal Government was able to recover billions of dollars in excessive profits, was upheld today by the United States Supreme Court.

Breakfronts and bean pots, easy chairs and ashtrays, all made by students at the American School for Craftsmen in Alfred, N.Y., will go on display today at America House, 485 Madison Avenue. The items and numerous other handmade articles for the home comprise an exhibition called "Unit for Living."
PARIS, June 14 -- A controversy has started in the French press and official circles as to whether former Marshal Petain is suffering from heart trouble.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Senate approved late today, after Democratic efforts to put through the Administration's own version had only narrowly been beaten off, a Republican bill to extend the Reciprocal Trade Act for one year in altered form. The vote on final passage was 70 to 18.

Broadway will be receiving "The Leading Lady," the period play written by Ruth Gordon, which her husband, Garson Kanin, will direct and produce, during the week of Oct. 3, it became known yesterday. Before bringing it here, Mr. Kanin and his producing associates, Victor Samrock and William Fields, will test the attraction for three weeks in Chicago beginning Sept. 13.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 14 -- James A. Sullivan, Vice Mayor of Yonkers until his resignation last August, was sentenced here today by County Judge Elbert T. Gallagher to pay a $1,000 fine and to serve one year in the Westchester County Penitentiary at Eastview.

BERLIN, June 14 -- Industrial enterprises in this city are suffering from slow economic strangulation and many face the prospect of shutting down as a result of Soviet transportation restrictions, German city officials disclosed today.

Late profit-taking yesterday stopped a new forward thrust by the stock market. Prices pushed into new high ground for the year during the morning, with many gains of more than a point, but realizing during the final hour reduced most advances to fractions or produced slight losses so that the price index declined 0.47 point.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., June 14 -- Establishment of a money and credit commission to study monetary and banking legislation and to make suitable recommendations to Congress was advocated today by Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of directors of the Chase National Bank of the City of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a foreign aid program calling for expenditures of $6,125,700,000 in the 1949 fiscal year and restoring an estimated $1,175,000,000 of the excisions recently ordered by the House.

SHANGHAI, June 14 -- A proposed State Department draft for a Chinese-American aid agreement has been returned to Washington with the recommendation of United States officials here that "more teeth" be inserted to assure firm supervisory control over aid expenditures in China.

Fishing clubs in the Metropolitan area are invited to send a representative to the striped bass conference scheduled to be held Thursday evening at the Empire Hotel, Broadway and Sixty-third Street. This meeting is being conducted by the Conservation Club of the Tarrytowns, and its purpose is to coordinate the sports and conservation groups in an effort to obtain the passage of another bass bill at the next Legislature.
Ordinarily it is hardly becoming for a foreigner to intervene in domestic American political affairs. But when the cause of democracy is at stake, an expression of opinion may not be out of place.

Employes of Oppenheim Collins Co., which operates department stores at 33 West Thirty-fourth Street and at 485 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, voted 208 to 7 last night to continue Local 1250, United Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes, CIO, as their collective bargaining agent.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- Representative Clarence J. Brown of Ohio, campaign manager for Senator Robert A. Taft, and Herbert Brownell Jr. of New York, one of the three campaign managers for Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, arrived today to open headquarters for these two candidates for the Republican nomination for President.
LONDON, June 14 -- The Speaker of the House of Commons, Col. D. Clifton Brown, ruled today that members of the House might make opprobrious remarks about the Franco regime in Spain.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Reorganization of the United Nations to isolate Russia from the other nations and point to the Soviet Union "as the potential aggressor" was advocated today by Jan Ciechanowski, former Polish Ambassador to the United States.
The $205,977,831 budget for the Maritime Commission, voted last week by the House Appropriations Committee, has been received with mixed feelings by leaders in the shipping industry here.
DUESSELDORF, Germany, June 14 -- Hugo Stinnes, Ruhr coal and steel magnate, was acquitted here today by a special denazification committee representing political parties and trade unions.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Government intervention loomed in the coal contract dispute as bituminous coal operators and miners drifted further apart today.

Federal Judge Edward A. Conger was asked yesterday to decide whether a group of American Merchant Marine seamen was entitled to a salvage claim against a tanker and her cargo of high octane gasoline because they voluntarily reboarded the vessel and brought it to port after being ordered to abandon ship.
Following is the text of President Truman's address before the Greater Los Angeles Press Club yesterday as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- This country is now having a peculiar sort of boom, with post-war food expenditures $8,000,000,000 more than might have been expected and durable goods $3,000,000,000 lower, Milton Gilbert, chief of the national income division, office of business economics, Department of Commerce, today told the American Marketing Association.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Gulf, Mobile Ohio Railroad Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to issue $7,000,000 of collateral trust bonds, dated July 1, to mature in 1968. On the advice of financial authorities, the railroad said, it felt it could finance proposed purchases of equipment in this manner at a favorable cost.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 14 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator in Palestine, indicated today that he might ask some countries to let him station his representatives in their ports to help carry out the immigration provisions of the cease-fire and truce agreement between Israel and the Arabs.

A diminutive millinery salesman, who the prosecutor's office said possessed a glib, smooth-voiced manner that had cajoled eighteen persons out of $158,350 for nonexistent supplies of textiles and steel, was arraigned yesterday in General Sessions on a grand larceny indictment.

ATHENS, June 14 (AP) -- Front advices said today that eight Greek Spitfire planes made a bomb and rocket attack yesterday on the Grammos Mountain village of Lykorrakhi, thought to be a headquarters of the Communist guerrilla chieftain, Markos Vafiades.

Miss Cloe E. Doyle, saftey education teacher, has been appointed director of the school and college division of the Greater New York Safety Council, it was announced yesterday. Frank L. Jones, president of the council, said at its headquarters, 60 East Forty-second Street, that Miss Doyle would take her new post Aug. 15.

A brother and sister testified yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Gus Fusaro, 53-year-old elevator starter accused of gambling away in faulty financial investments $121,775 belonging to others, that they lost $33,600 on stock transactions he had handled.

TOKYO, June 14 -- The results of the first post-war sale to Japanese publishers of United States and British book copyrights were announced today by headquarters' economic and scientific section. As a result, the Japanese soon may be able to read the translations of English language books that they have been seeking since the war's end.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The House Civil Service Committee today tentatively approved pay rises of $360 a year for civil service workers and $450 a year for postal workers.

A masterful four-hit pitching job by Right-hander Tim Fiori enabled the Police Department nine to gain its first triumph in years over its traditional rival, the Fire Department, by a score of 6 -- 0 last night before a crowd of 15,000 at the Polo Grounds.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 14 -- David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, proposed that college graduates resolve to devote some part of their careers to public service in an address today before the largest graduating class in the University of Virginia's 126 sessions.

LOS ANGELES, June 14 -- President Truman declared today that price controls should be in effect "right now" and demanded eleventh-hour action by Congress on seven other major issues on which he said it had been derelict.

NEWARK, N.J., June 14 (AP) -- Bob Porterfield was knocked out of the box for the first time in eleven starts tonight and Buffalo went on to post an 11-2 triumph that dropped Newark into second place of the International League.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today by a vote of 10 to 3 a much-softened version of the anti-lynching bill which had been before it about three months.
BERLIN, June 14 -- The signatures of three-quarters of a million Berliners to Communist petitions for German unity are being employed as a new weapon to force the Western Allies out of Berlin.

LONDON, June 14 -- The method and scope of the Labor Government's plan for nationalizing the steel industry are raising differences in the Cabinet that the Ministers will discuss at a meeting Thursday.

The results to date of President Truman's trip through the West have left the rank and file of New York Democrats completely unimpressed with Mr. Truman's ability to record a good vote here in November, a survey showed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The Supreme Court knocked down today a lower court ruling that would have multiplied the value of many national service life insurance policies at a cost of billions of dollars to the Government.

In a bid for additional markets and dollar exchange, two of Great Britain's largest advertising agencies will open a joint branch office here on Sept. 1, it was announced yesterday. The new agency, sponsored by S.H. Benson, Ltd., and Mather Crowther, Ltd., both of London, will be known as Benson Mather.
PITTSBURGH, June 14 (AP) -- Connie Mack exploded one of his loudest verbal blasts in sixty-two years of baseball trials and tribulations today after cutting loose two veteran pitchers.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 14 (AP) Miss Grace Lenczyk, the Connecticut miss who many experts predict will succeed Babe Didrickson Zaharias as queen of women's golf, shot a record 72 today to win medalist honors in the fourth annual National women's collegiate golf tourney.

The carnival season now is on, and life once again is full. This is the time for the ferris wheel and the airplane ride, and the three shots for a dime at a pyramid of bottles. This is the time for the merry-go-round, with its clang of the waltzes of Old Vienna, and the day of the red candy apple.

LONDON, June 14 -- American film prospects in Britain suffered a blow when the Government today gave formal approval to a drastic increase in screen time to be devoted to British films in theatres in this country. Harold Wilson, President of the Board of Trade, promulgated the order raising the mandatory time for British feature films to be shown in home theatres to 45 per cent, compared to the less than 20 per cent previously.

Brooklyn's Dodgers, sixth in the National League, defeated Cleveland's Indians, first in the American League, in an exhibition contest at Ebbets Field last night. Rex Barney, with one of his rare route-going mound performances, downed the Indians, 6 -- 2, before 12,622 fans.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 14 (UP) -- Police reported today that 100 persons were arrested last night during a demonstration by thousands of Catholics, most of them defiant women, against nationalization of church schools.

An order withholding meeting facilities at the Manhattan Beach housing project to the Beachhead Chapter of the American Veterans Committee was upheld unanimously yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn without an opinion.

LONDON, June 14 -- Although the British medical profession has agreed reluctantly to participate in the Government's universal medical health service program, an eleventh-hour refusal from the dentists was in prospect today. The Health Service Act takes effect July 5.

LONDON, June 14 (UP) -- British bookmakers today reported a flood of money on Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, to duplicate Bobby Jones' 1930 unique double and add the British open golf title to the British amateur crown he captured at Sandwich last month.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 14 -- American and British Military Governors, in separate confidential talks with the Minister-Presidents of their respective zones, outlined today the Western Allies' program for the future government of Germany, as agreed upon in London.

LONDON, June 14 -- Having failed to get the agreement of Egypt, the British Government announced today that Sir Robert Howe, British Governor General of the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, would be free to proceed with a project to give the Sudanese a greater degree of self-government.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 -- Seven thousand warehouse workers, members of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, went on strike today in a wage dispute and interrupted operations of 200 employer firms on both sides of San Francisco Bay.

BOSTON, June 14 -- Dr. Abram L. Sachar, first president of Brandeis University, pledged tonight that the new Jewish-sponsored institution would follow "without qualification" those ideals of "academic integrity" and service espoused by the late Supreme Court justice for whom it was named.
SHANGHAI, June 14 (2P) -- Communists made daring raids today within a few miles of uneasy Shanghai and Nanking.
Restraining orders issued yesterday by Federal Courts apparently averted for at least ten days a nation-wide strike of maritime workers that threatened to begin after midnight tonight.

American passenger vessels; capable of accommodating one hundred or more persons, now total thirty-six ships with a passenger capacity of 11,127, compared with a pre-war fleet of ninety-eight vessels capable of accommodating 36,015 passengers, a survey made by the National Federation of American Shipping disclosed yesterday.

Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $42,832,013 in the nine months ended on April 30 and a net profit of $6,450,058 in the three months ended on the same date. In the nine months to April 30, 1947, net income was $37,777,181; for the three months the net was $9,217,551.

The Royal Dutch Company for the Working of Petroleum Wells in the Netherlands Indies, a holding company, reported yesterday for the year ended on Dec. 31 a profit of 66,992,288 florins after expenses, interest and taxes. This compared with 72,607,501 florins in 1946.

ALBANY, June 14 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey has accepted "with regret" notice of the prospective retirement of Milo R. Maltbie, 77 years old, as chairman of the Public Service Commission, the Governor's office announced today.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe denied yesterday a motion by the Wholesale and Warehouse Workers Union, Local 65, CIO, for an injunction barring the National Labor Relations Board from holding a collective bargaining election among warehouse employes of the F.W. Woolworth Company.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Eleven leaders of the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee today were denied a Supreme Court review of their conviction of contempt of Congress.
PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (AP) -- The Phillies and the Dodgers today put in a bid for the season's wackiest baseball deal -- with Pitcher Clyde King in the middle.

Urging that Government expenditures be postponed wherever possible so that the American way of life will not be taxed out of existence, Morris Sayre, president of the Corn Products Refining Company and of the National Association of Manufacturers, charged yesterday that the President's first budget proposal contained $3,400,000,000 of expenditures unnecessary at this time.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., June 14 -- Assembled as an operational unit for the first time, 250 Air Reserve officers and enlisted men of the First Air Force, functioning as the 319th Light Bombardment Group, started a two-week period of active training at Stewart Field here today.

The 137th birthday anniversary of Harriet Beecher Stowe, author of "Uncle Tom's Cabin," was marked yesterday at the Hall of Fame of New York University, the Bronx. Two hundred children and adults were present under the direction of Cleveland G. Allen, Harlem writer, who for twenty years has organized the tributes.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 14 -- All was quiet on the Palestine front today. There were no further reports from the north, indicating that peace reigned there. No incidents occurred on the new "Burma Road" to Jerusalem, where supplies are going through nightly.

Fabric designs intended for woven textiles, but so varied in scale and pattern that they resemble modern decorative prints, were announced yesterday as winners in the woven textile design contest sponsored by the Moss Rose Manufacturing Company of Philadelphia.

In a letter to THE TIMES of June 3, J. Clarkson Miller complains that "Once again the pacifists among us are chanting the old refrain, 'War never settled anything.'" I am not sure just what pacifists Mr. Miller refers to, but I suggest to him that the pacifists I know and that I myself do not hold that wars do not settle things.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 14 -- One of the most interesting political contests of national significance in the South this year is taking place in the First Congressional District of Tennessee, the home of Carroll B. Reece, chairman of the Republican National Committee.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- In an unusual proceeding the Supreme Court decided a case today in which not even a majority of the nine justices was agreed in its reasoning.
GENEVA, N.Y., June 14 -- Herbert H. Lehman, former Governor of New York, called on all Americans today for an uncompromising devotion to democracy to combat communism and fascism.
BASLE, Switzerland, June 14 -- A new stage in European recovery is both announced and defined by the annual report of the Bank for International Settlements released here today.
Hundreds of Long Island Rail Road commuters reached New York from six to sixteen minutes late yesterday morning on twenty-five trains.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The "middle income" of the 42,000,000 families in the United States was $2,920 last year, up $320 from 1946.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- President Truman vetoed today a Social Security bill which, he said, would deprive 750,000 legally deserving persons of old-age and unemployment-insurance benefits and Congress quickly overrode the veto.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- New York State may tax receipts from bus transportation on parts of a journey within the state, cannot levy on the revenue from portions of the trip outside the state, the Supreme Court ruled by 6 to 3 today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 14 -- Edward Small has scheduled "The Treasure of Monte Cristo," a story distantly derived from Alexander Dumas' "The Count of Monte Cristo," as his next production for United Artists. George Bruce is writing the scenario and Small is seeking Louis Hayward for the leading role.

The editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 9 on "Our Waiting City Children" very effectively presents one of the outstanding unsolved problems in child care in New York City. It speaks of the "no man's land between state and city, between voluntary agencies and government" in the care of children who cannot be cared for in their own homes and for whom, therefore, places in foster homes and institutions must be found.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were strong during most of yesterday's session and closed 4 to 30 points higher than on Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- Carroll Reece, Republican National Chairman, tonight charged that President Truman's "I like old Joe Stalin" remark was a cynical and obvious effort to woo thousands of Communist and "fellow traveler" votes from Henry Wallace back to the Democratic party.

LONDON, June 14 -- The statement by Thakin Nu, the Burmese Premier on his party's wish to follow the Russian ideology and abolish capitalism caused a decline in all Burma shares in the stock market here today.

Herb McKenley, who will represent Jamaica in the Olympic Games this year, has received permission to defend his national 400-meter crown in the A.A.U. title events at Milwaukee on July 2 and 3, according to an announcement yesterday by Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the amateur body.

Flag Day observances were held in various parts of the city yesterday, culminating in an afternoon ceremony in City Hall Plaza at which several hundred school children heard speeches marking the 171st anniversary of the adoption of the Flag of the United States by Congress.

An informative article by George A. Mooney in a recent issue of THE TIMES calls attention to the confusion in the public mind concerning the insurance of investments in federal savings and loan associations. May I point out that such confusion exists because the public is not aware of the difference between the status of a federal savings and loan association investor and the status of a bank depositor.

PRAGUE, June 14 -- Czechoslovakia's new Communist President Klement Gottwald, in what amounted to his inaugural address this evening, painted a black picture of the former Czechoslovak republic known here as the first or Masaryk republic, and emphasized that this was a different regime.
Degrees and certificates will be awarded tonight to 1,918 members of the largest graduating class in the history of Brooklyn College at the twenty-third annual commencement exercises.
WASHINGTON, June l4 -- Senator J. Howaard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, named a committee of seventeen today to do the preliminary drafting work of the party platform for the 1948 campaign.

The manuscript of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's memoirs, "Crusade in Europe," has been read by the judges of the Book-of-the-Month Club and the book is to be distributed to the clubs members, at the time of its publication, if the general decides to release it. Doubleday hopes to publish it at the end of November.

A plan to remove two blighted areas from the business section of Flushing, Queens, and to replace them with a 1,100-car parking lot and low-rent housing will be outlined Thursday to the Board of Estimate, it was announced yesterday.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 14 -- Buck Worsham and Sal Nardozzi of the home club played brilliant golf to win the Westchester County Golf Association's pro-amateur best-ball one-day tournament over the West course at Winged Foot today with a five-under-par 32, 35 -- 67.

The American Association for the United Nations is sponsoring a competition for a United Nations poster upon request of the Department of Public Information of the United Nations. There will be three prizes of $1,500, $1,000 and $500, respectively, and ten honorable mentions which will receive $100 each. All entries must be submitted by Sept. 1.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- The vanguard of Republican leaders today found their convention city, a citadel of Republicanism since long before the turn of the century, in the midst of a major City Hall scandal, centering around charges that millions of dollars have been lost through inefficiency, waste and downright thievery.

The stevedoring industry in the United States faces ruin unless Congress enacts legislation to overcome the "disastrous" effects of the recent United States Supreme Court decision upholding overtime on overtime, the National Association of Stevedores declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Two bills estimated to increase by $161,000,000 annually the benefit payments to disabled veterans and to widows and the dependents of deceased veterans were passed today by the House.

Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmitri Manuilsky, courteous and affable, but just as tight-lipped regarding questions on his country's policies as his fellow Soviet diplomats, arrived here yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth. He will be president of the United Nations Security Council.

NEW HAVEN, June 14 (AP) -- The Federal District Court here postponed today until June 28 the hearing on a petition by the New Haven Railroad for permission to sue the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for $803,944.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- The nation's music merchants today viewed the greatest display of television equipment to be exhibited at the annual trade shows sponsored by the National Association of Music Merchants, a spokesman for the industry said at the opening of the exhibition.

The thirty-first season of concerts at Lewisohn Stadium began last night in style. There was a substantial amount of fine music. There was a bit of speech-making by prominent citizens. And some of these citizens did a little -- a very little -- digging of Lewisohn Stadium earth by way of breaking ground for a new, permanent building which will have a modern sage and acoustical shell, dressing and rehearsal rooms and music library.

"Nais," a French importation starring Fernandel and Jacqueline Bouvier in the title role, which arrives at the Sutton Theatre, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Marcel Pagnol produced and directed the romantic drama from the Emile Zola book, "Nais Micoulin." Dialogue of the Siritzky International release is French and there are English titles.

LOS ANGELES, June 14 -- John E. Wheeler, a representative of Turner-Poindexter Co., securities dealers of this city, said today that the firm had ordered 500 shares of the recent $10,000,000 common stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation despite the fact that members of the firm thought it "might be a sour deal."

Twenty-nine-month-old Kenneth Liebman fell six floors yesterday, landed on a grass plot, then got up and ran away. He was caught by witnesses and held until an ambulance arrived. There apparently was nothing wrong with the infant.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 14 (AP) -- Irving Gusen's Andys Glory defeated Tralle McBride's War Raider by five lengths in the featured six-furlongs race today before 14,362 at Narragansett Park.

Kansas City Power and Light Company gold $20,000,000 of first mortgage bonds and preferred stock at competitive bidding yesterday to banking syndicates at an interest cost of about 2.80 per cent for thirty-year bonds, and at a dividend cost of about 4.01 per cent for the stock. The awards were as follows:

Group practice centered in hospitals offers the best of modern medicine to the American public, Dr. Dean A. Clark, medical director of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, told 100 hospital administrators at the opening of a two-week institute yesterday at Columbia University's School of Public Health, 600 West 168th Street.

Robert Riggs, the defending champion, and Donald Budge, the man he has beaten in the final the past two years, played their opening matches yesterday in the national professional tennis tournament at Forest Hills.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 -- Storekeepers must make their stores more efficient to reap the profits of recent years, E.C. Lipman, president of the Emporium, of this city, said today in a keynote address to the mid-year conference of the management and personnel groups of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

A hearing on charges that City Councilman Eugene P. Connolly and eight others violated the city's Administrative Code by using loudspeakers without permits and making loud and unnecessary noise was adjourned yesterday in the Summons Part of Lower Manhattan Magistrate's Court until June 28.

TOKYO, June 14 -- Possibly before the end of this week, and certainly before the end of this month, the Japanese Government will announce a new price stabilization. The official ceilings will be roughly double what they are now.

CARDIFF, Wales, June 14 -- At the coal face in one of the seams of Tydraw Colliery, at the northern end of Rhondda Valley, six or eight Welsh miners crouched around this correspondent to discuss their problems.
Blocks of industrial and public utility securities valued at $8,700,000 will be offered to investors today by underwriting managers here, as follows:

With triumphant pride, the New York Football Giants yesterday announced the addition to their roster of another of the great college players of 1947 -- Charlie Conerly. The All-America halfback from the University of Mississippi signed a five-year contract with the Polo Grounds eleven, terms of payment unspecified, but probably close to six figures.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously approved today the proposed $65,000,000 United States loan to the United Nations for its permanent headquarters in New York.
Dr. Israel Oscar Weissman, former assistant director of the Jewish Hospital in Brooklyn, was appointed yesterday as director of Sydenham Hospital, the interracially operated institution in Harlem.

Russell Denison Niles, a member of the faculty of the New York University School of Law for nineteen years, has been appointed dean of the school to succeed Arthur T. Vanderbilt, who is resigning to become chief justice of the newly organized New Jersey Supreme Court.
PRAGUE, July 15 -- Premier Antonin Zapotocky presented today to President Klement Gottwald the names of the new Czechoslovak Cabinet. No important changes from the Cabinet of M. Gottwald were made.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 15 -- Hopes went up in the United Nations today at the news that the Senate Foreign Relations Committee had approved the world capital loan, but no official comment will be issued until the bill clears its crucial test in the House.

Forty children from two settlement houses were the guests yesterday of the Craftsmen's Equity Fair, which is holding its second annual outdoor show at Eighth Street and the Avenue of the Americas. This was a special occasion for the youngsters as the fair grounds were opened solely for them.

LAKE SUCESS, N. Y., June 15 -- The United States delegation to the United Nations was urged today to demand immediate adoption by the Security Council of economic and other non-military sanctions to be applied if and when the four-week truce in Palestine is violated or ends.

ASCOT, England, June 15 -- American-owned, British-bred horse -- William Woodward's Black Tarquin -- won the last and richest race today on the first day of the four-day Royal Ascot race meeting hug and helped the British stand off a formidable French invasion.

Two officials of the School of Music of the Brooklyn Free Musical Society, 205 East Sixty-seventh Street, were charged yesterday in Mid-Manhattan Court with violation of the State Labor Law by failure to pay back salary to an instructor.

Through no fault of the general membership, the House is being forced today to complete work in a few hours on one of the most important bills on which it has had to act this session -- Selective Service. The bill was presented to the Rules Committee by the House Armed Services Committee on May 7.

Most jewelry manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers favor a combined annual trade show by the two retail jewelers' associations rather than two separate shows, according to Abbot A. Harman, president of the Harman Watch Company.

Portraits of Premier Stalin and Marshal Tito and the hammer and sickle insignia in various parts of the Yugoslav passenger-cargo liner Radnik so incensed longshoremen yesterday that they refused to load cargo aboard the vessel at her Forty-fourth Street pier in Brooklyn.

SALZBURG, Austria, June 15 -- A plan to form a Hungarian resistance organization in Paris that would constitute the nucleus of an emigre government and contain all shades of democratic opinion has been blocked by the French General Staff, it was stated here today in Hungarian refugee circles.

NEW DELHI, India, June 15 -- Preparations for receiving the United Nations Commission on Kashmir are going forward here in a mood of surly rebellion. The Indian press has begun to lay the ground work for the rejection of any recommendations that the commission may make unless they favor India.

ABOARD PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S SPECIAL TRAIN IN NEW MEXICO, June 15 -- Homeward bound, President Truman will ease his attacks on Congress and in general will let his back-platform appearances serve chiefly to afford an opportunity for the public to get acquainted with him, it was learned today.
DAYTON, Ohio, June 15 (AP) -- Seven workers tried to crash a picket line of 600 men at the Univis Lens Company today and touched off an hour of punching, kicking and shouting.

Two new films will open in firstrun theatres this morning. At the Paramount the attraction is "Dream Girl," Paramount's picturization of the Elmer Rice hit play starring Betty Hutton in the title role. Mitchell Leisen directed and P. J. Wolfson produced the romantic comedy-drama, in which Patric Knowles, Virginia Field, Walter Abel and Peggy Wood are among the featured players.
NOTTINGHAM, June 15 (Reuters) -- Australia defeated England by eight wickets today in the first cricket test match of the season with more than two hours and eight wickets to spare.

The representatives of more than fifty leading industrial research laboratories met last night with a group of distinguished scientists and educators to consider a program for bringing scientific investigation in industry and on the campus closer together.

Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind denied yesterday a petition by a Congress of Industrial Organizations union, whose officers have refused to filed the non-Communist affidavits required by the Taft-Hartley Act, for an order restraining the regional office of the national Labor Relations Board from holding a collective bargaining election sought by a complying union.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Air National Guard is envisaged, under present plans, as a major factor in the defense of the continental United States, officials of the National Guard Bureau said today. It was explained that two-thirds of the fighter airplanes allocated for this mission are already assigned to Air National Guard units.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Soviet Union has accepted the United States proposal of last month for a conference on July 30 of the Big Four and the Danubian countries to arrange for free navigation of the Danube.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 15 -- The United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America tonight completed a week of sessions devoted to expositions of the respective national economic conditions obtaining in Latin America. Twenty-four countries are represented here.
"Youth United for Better Citizens Day" was observed yesterday in Brooklyn with a parade, a baseball game and a dinner.
