RANGOON, Burma, June 15 -- A speech made on Sunday by Premier Thakin Nu has cleared up the impression created by the program that he recently announced for a United Left party that his Anti-Fascist People's Freedom League was veering sharply to the extreme left.

All were agreed that the spirit of Alfred E. Smith must have been stirred yesterday when the children of old Public School 1, near where the late Governor's boyhood home stood on the lower East Side, put on a pageant celebrating the school's and the city's Golden Jubilee.

A lease for space at New York International Airport at Idlewild with one of the leading independent operators of freight and charter planes and a purveyor of airline service, Willis Air Service, Inc., was announced by the Port of New York Authority yesterday. The company will take the south half of Hangar No. 1 at the field, Sailors Aircraft Service, Inc., having taken the rest of the space in an earlier lease.
Governor Dewey and Mayor O'Dwyer both stressed last night the opportunity for public service in the joint operation of a newspaper and a television station.

In his Los Angeles speech President Truman went farther than he had gone at any time previously in his advocacy of anti-inflation legislation. Up to this week he had merely asked that Congress give him certain emergency control powers, to be invoked at such time as conditions, in his opinion, warranted such action.

BUENOS AIRES, June 15 -- A staff photographer for the Hora, Communist daily, was arrested yesterday while trying to take pictures of a labor tie-up in the port zone, the paper said today. According to the Hora, the photographer was subjected to treatment that, the police said, was intended to give him pneumonia.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., June 15 -- The Democratic organization headed by former Mayor Frank Hague, which has been in control of this city for thirty-one years, today ousted former Hudson County Freeholder John V. Kenny from the Democratic leadership of the Second Ward.

In concentrating on the effort to obtain six-Power agreement on a new German occupation policy, the aspect of the problem that makes some change imperative has been almost lost sight of. This is the condition of Germany itself. It is worse than at any time since the surrender.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 15 -- James Nasser, independent producer, has acquired two screen stories, "Joe Macbeth," by Philip Yordan, and "Caesar the Great," by Roland Brown, for filming this year under his releasing agreement with United Artists, the Nasser Production Company disclosed today.
LONDON, June 15 (AP) -- Russia appeared certain today to stay away from the first post-war Olympics in London.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The House accepted Senate revisions today and sent to the White House a bill to renew the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act for one year.

NORRIS, Tenn., June 15 -- In nineteen minutes of spirited bidding this town's urban area, once known as the country's most audacious venture into government planning of community life, was sold at public auction today for $2,107,500.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A $3,686,733,250 fund to operate and expand "the world's most formidable navy" sailed through the Senate tonight in less than thirty minutes. Action was by voice vote after a brief explanation by Senator Leverett Saltonstall of Massachusetts, floor manager for the bill.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- It feels "pretty nice" to fly faster than the speed of sound, Capt. Charles E. Yeager said today. Captain Yeager is officially credited with being the first man to accomplish this feat in the experimental Ben XS-1 at Muroc Lake, Calif., last Oct. 14.

CARDIFF, Wales, June 15 -- The losses of Great Britain's coal mines for their first year under nationalization will total about 25,000,000 [$100,000,000], it was learned here today. The official figures for 1947 are scheduled to come out at the end of the month and will be accompanied by explanations to demonstrate that heavy losses were inevitable.
NANKING, June 15 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek is directing Government military operations on the critical Central China front, a reliable source said today.

Large families in particular find that today's high food prices make it difficult to balance the budget and still provide adequate meals. For these people the United States Department of Agriculture offers practical help in its new publication, "Food for Families With School Children."

New recapitalization plans for both the St. Lawrence Corporation, Ltd., and its subsidiary, the St. Lawrence Paper Mills Company, Ltd., Canadian concerns, were made known yesterday in letters to shareholders. The letters were accompanied by notices of special meetings of stockholders on July 7 and 8 to vote upon the proposals.

The tuberculosis death rate dropped to a new low throughout the nation during 1947, Dr. James E. Perkins said yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Tuberculosis Association at the Pennsylvania Hotel. Two thousand leading figures in the fight against the "white plague" are expected to attend a week-long program of administrative and scientific conferences during the meeting.
The plight of the world's children is not yet understood by the Senate.

Dr. P. H. Chang, Consul General of China, accepted yesterday morning at Town Hall in behalf of President and Mme. Chiang Kaishek of China a copy of a documentary motion picture, "My Name Is Han." The picture, second production of the Protestant Film Commission, had its first showings yesterday in 125 cities of the United States and Canada.

Motion picture production has entered a critical period marked by a severe contraction of profits, Barney Balaban, president of Paramount Pictures, Inc., declared yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 15 (AP) -- Washington's Huskies arrived at the scene of some of their greatest rowing triumphs today and Coach Al Ulbrickson said that the June 22 Poughkeepsie Regatta "looks like a real boat race."

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Acting on the request of Thomas B. Hart, regional director of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Federal Judge John P. Barnes issued late today an order calling on the Tucker Corporation to show cause by June 22 why it should not be required to respond to a subpoena deuces tecum issued by the SEC asking the production of company records and files.

LONDON, June 15 (AP) -- The United States tennis contingent dominated the seedings for next week's Wimbledon championships announced today, topping both the men's and women's lists and gaining five of the eight places in each of the singles divisions.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 15 -- Alarmed at the growth of censorship in this country, responsible leaders of the American Library Association called on librarians today to create a professional group to fight the banning of books by religious, patriotic or Government pressures.
STANTON, Del., June 15 (AP) -- Delaware Park's steeplechase season opened today with the Tom Roby Steeplechase Stakes being run for the second time.

LONDON, June 15 -- Fears in London that Burma, five months after obtaining independence from Britain, might be moving into the Soviet orbit spurred Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin into action today. He invited the Burmese Ambassador, Sir Maung Gyee, to the Foreign Office to discuss the sharp and unexpected turn toward the extreme left taken by Thakin Nu, Burmese Premier.

Formation of a new national committee on radio and television production, headed by Walter Craig, vice president of Benton Bowles, Inc., was announced yesterday by the American Association of Advertising Agencies. Set up under the 4-A reorganization plan, it replaces the committee on radio broadcasting.

The "Armed Services Revue" will be introduced on NBC Thursday, July 1, at 8 P. M., to carry the recruiting messages of the Army and the Air Force. Burgess Meredith will be the regular master of ceremonies of the series, the premiere of which is timed roughly to coincide with the sixth anniversary of Irving Berlin's Broadway musical, "This Is the Army."

BERLIN, June 15 -- The nineteen member nations of the Inter-allied Reparations Agency today called upon Switzerland to make available immediately 100,000,000 Swiss francs as part of Germany's reparations payment. In a unanimous resolution the agency also called upon Switzerland to complete with the least possible delay the liquidation of German property in Switzerland.

THE second novel with a utopian theme which has come my way in less than a week is "The Bowl of Night,"* by Edward Liston. The first was "Walden Two," by B. F. Skinner. Except for their underlying purpose of imagining better ways of arranging human affairs than those which have so far been tried the two books do not resemble each other.

There was a reasonably orderly ceremony before yesterday's game at Ebbets Field between the Dodgers and the Reds, in which the two teams marched to the flagpole and raised the Brooks' 1947 championship pennant.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Federal Trade Commission ordered the ending today of a price-fixing conspiracy in restraint of trade by the Master Engravers Guild and the Master Engravers Service Corporation, both of Paterson, N.J., with thirteen textile engraving companies.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- An album containing a pictorial record of last year's student exchange project was presented today to Secretary of State George C. Marshall by representatives of the Institute of International Education and the American Friends Service Committee on behalf of the thirty-five organizations which sponsored the program.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company awarded, yesterday, to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., on their bid of 99.5101 for 2 3/8 per cent obligations, subject to approval by the Interstate Commerce Commission, an issue of $3,500,000 of serial equipment trust certificates.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Two bills revising Government subsidies for constructing and operating the merchant marine which were passed by the House yesterday, will not be acted upon by the Senate Commerce Committee, Senator Wallace H. White Jr., of Maine, the chairman, said today.

Although occupation authorities have promised action toward solving the complex problems and obstacles blocking re-establishment of "free enterprise" trade with Japan, it will be many years before this potentially excellent market can fully be opened to American products, Walter B. Baruch, vice president of Schenley International Corporation, told the annual meeting of the Export Managers Club yesterday at the Pennsylvania Hotel.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The House Rules Committee approved today two bills to raise the pay of Federal workers and partly offset the higher Post Office payroll by an increase in postal rates.

The Firemen's Medal of Supreme Sacrifice, a posthumous award of the Uniformed Firemen's Association of Greater New York, will be awarded to the next of kin of seven firemen who lost their lives in the last year at the annual Fire Department ceremonies today in City Hall Plaza.
LONDON, June 15 (AP) -- The women's singles division of the London tennis championship at the Queens Club became virtually an all-American affair today.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 15 -- After nearly three years of contraction, the Federal Government is being forced to abap. don its policy of rapid relinquishment of wartime leases on privately owned space because of expanding actiw'ties under the European Recovery Program and defense preparation, the National Association of Building Owners and Managers learned today.

A renewal of caution and selectivity in buying has developed in New York industrial purchasing departments because of mixed price trends in materials used in manufacturing, a canvass of leading companies revealed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- There are certainly no prospects of a non-inflationary monetary or fiscal policy at least until after election, Charles O. Hardy, staff director of the Joint Committee on the Economic Report, today told the American Marketing Association.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 3,054, compared with 3,973 last week and 2,379 in the similar week of last year, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,520 arrivals yesterday, against 1,735 last Thursday.

LISBON, Portugal, June 15 (UP) -- Admiral Jose Mendes Cabecadas and eleven other Portuguese leaders were found guilty today of having plotted against the Government, but were let off with light sentences. Two defendants were acquitted.

TRENTON, N. J., June 15 -- The $149,750,450 legislative appropriations bill, providing operating funds for the New Jersey State administration, but minus some post-war projects, had approval today of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.

After three witnesses had recanted their testimony Surrogate William T. Collins denied probate yesterday to the will of Mathilde Molesberger, 83-year-old spinster, which bequeathed the bulk of her $230,000 estate to the late Fred Dresel, 53-year-old superintendent of the apartment house in which she lived at 131 East Ninety-third Street.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A railroad union president said today that President Truman was responsible for blocking a wage settlement of three unions with the railroads.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Pan-Atlantic Steamship Corporation and Seatrain Lines, Inc., today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to suspend Newtex Steamship Corporation tariffs providing pick-up and delivery truck service in connection with its Port Newark terminal.

Degrees were awarded last night to 306 graduates of Queens College at commencement exercises on the campus in Flushing, Queens. It was the largest graduating class in the eleven-year history of the institution and included eighty-six war veterans.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- William L. Clayton, former Under-Secretary of State and now special adviser to Secretary George C. Marshall, appealed today for United States ratification of the Havana trade charter to "lay a firm foundation for world peace and world prosperity."
LONDON, June 15 (Reuters) -- A 20,000,000 ($80,000,000) motion-picture merger affecting 564 theatres is planned by J. Arthur Rank, British film leader, it was learned today.

Long Beach, Calif., awarded $3,600,000 of waterworks bonds due from 1951 to 1968 to a group headed by the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association at an interest cost of 1.942 per cent. The bid was 100.08 for 1 3/4s and 2s.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Northern and Western bituminous coal operators recessed as "futile" today their contract negotiations with the United Mine Workers because "there has been no progress toward getting a discussion of a new agreement."

In an editorial appearing in your issue of June 9 entitled "Behind the Tariff Fight," reference is made to a bill, HR 6379, as follows: "This bill, which follows more or less closely the ideology of the protectionist American Tariff League, would convert the Tariff Commission into a 'Foreign Trade Authority' empowered to terminate all trade agreements at the earliest possible moment."

The Rev. Dr. Harold H. Kelley, director of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York for the last fourteen years, will retire on Aug. 31, the institute announced yesterday. Dr. Kelley, who is 65 years old, plans to return with his wife to California, his home state.

The cornerstone of the $871,000 Brownsville Health Center, Bristol Street and Dumont Avenue, Brooklyn, initiating the post-war building program of the Department of Health, was laid yesterday by Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett in ceremonies attended by 500 of the 300,000 persons the project will serve in the Brownsville area.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 15 -- After being criticized by William J. Gottlieb, president of the Automobile Club of New York, for his "biased and dyspeptic attitude" toward New York automobile drivers, Judge Carmine Sabino Jr. of the Bergen County Traffic Court conceded tonight that "New Jersey has some bad drivers too."

Accused of writing a five-year series of annoying letters to Joseph M. Schenck, motion-picture producer, a woman who described herself as Miss Henrietta Weiner, "21-plus years old," of 400 Fort Washington Avenue, was arrested yesterday at 72 Spring Street, where she is employed as a machine operator.
Support for dairy groups that are seeking higher milk prices came yesterday from the Milk Dealers Association of Metropolitan New York.
PRAGUE, June 15 (UP) -- Following is the roster of the new Czechoslovak Cabinet, as announced today:
MOSCOW, June 15 (UP) -- Mrs. John Brand, a Russian war bride, announced in a letter in Pravda today that she had left a life of "slavery" in Britain to return to the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A Congressional committee today accused the National Broadcasting Company and the State Department of being jointly responsible for the "unfortunate" and "misleading" broadcasts to foreign countries on the Government's "Voice of America" program.

BERLIN, June 15 -- The iron noose that the Russians are drawing around Berlin grew tighter today. Isolation of the Western Allies and their German supporters in the city drew nearer as the Soviet Military Administration:

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 15 -- The United States, British and French Military Governors conferred for four and one-half hours today in the American's office on the economic problems of Western Germany, especially currency reform.
Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, a director of the Play Schools Association, appealed yesterday for funds for its all-day summer play school program for children 5 to 13 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 -- With members of the Republican National Committee, other party officials and convention delegates arriving in increasingly larger numbers, supporters of Thomas E. Dewey for the Presidential nomination began today to put on the pressure for their candidate with some favorable results.

LONDON, June 15 -- Jean Chauvel of the French Foreign Office, who was in London today seeking clarification on certain points of the six-power recommendations on Western Germany that were raised during the debate in the French Assembly, flew back to Paris tonight to communicate with Foreign Minister Bidault before M. Bidault makes his final speech in the debate tomorrow.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 (AP) -- The proposed multi-million-dollar merger of three Western oil companies, subject of a long and bitter court battle, has been abandoned.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 -- A work simplification program was recommended to the nation's retail stores today as a means of increasing productivity to meet a 2 per cent rise in the cost of doing business during the last year.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 15 -- Henry F. Schricker, elected Governor of Indiana in 1940, was nominated by the Democratic State Convention today to run for Governor again. The Indiana Constitution of 1851 prevents a Governor from succeeding himself.

With the breakdown of industry-wide collective bargaining in the fur industry, the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc., announced yesterday that it would file a $5,000,000 suit against the Furriers Joint Council of the International Fur and Leather Workers Union.

SEOUL, Korea, June 15 -- Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, United States commander in Korea, today called upon the Soviet Union to resume electric service for South Korea. The occasion was the arrival of a new shipment of goods for payment for the service.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, general chairman of the President's Highway Safety Conference, reported today to a conference committee meeting that the national fatality rate had been reduced in the last two years from 12 to 7.7 for each 100,000,000 miles of vehicle travel.

A national survey to determine our capacities as a nation for making effective use of technically trained college graduates was urged last night by Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, State Education Commissioner.

A four-month workhouse term for rent gouging was imposed yesterday in Special Sessions on Jacob Schaffer, 45-year-old former tax consultant convicted of being a "roving agent" for a one-time Stuyvesant Town tenant selector who now is serving an indeterminate sentence in City Prison.

A total of 8,785 persons in 3,363 Queens families was aided last year by the Community Service Society through its family counseling and health programs, the society announced yesterday. The Queens office of the organization is at 37-34 Eighty-second Street, Jackson Heights.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (AP) -- A throw by Catcher Andy Seminick with second uncovered on an attempted double steal permitted Stan Musial to score from third in the eighth inning tonight to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 2-1 victory over the Phillies.

CARDIFF, Wales, June 15 -- The first ship bearing bodies of American soldiers who died during the last war and were buried in the British Isles will sail from here on Friday. Already the brown steel boxes containing the wooden coffins are being loaded aboard the American transport Lawrence Victory for the last journey home.

Negotiations yesterday afternoon between representatives of the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, resulted in no progress. The company reaffirmed its position that an increase in shipyard wages was "completely unwarranted at this time."
LONDON, June 15 -- End-of-account stagnation, coupled with foreign political uncertainties kept the majority of brokers idle today.

An unusual demonstration in management-labor relations occurred last night when the operators of the Monte Carlo, night club at Madison Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, closed the place after a walk out by 160 employes and then invite dthe workers to dine, drink and dance "on the house."

Prolonged legal action is expected to follow the Federal Court restraining orders issued Monday under the Taft-Hartley act that averted at least temporarily a threatened nation-wide maritime strike of 100,000 workers.

A clash of interest between the proponents of party politics, and "the idealist" or reform groups developed yesterday in the season's final forum in the series of 134 discussions of public questions conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES under the title, "What's on Your Mind ?"

In a partial reversal of its previous stand, Soviet Russia has now accepted, under certain conditions, the American proposal for a conference beginning July 30 to arrange for free navigation on the Danube, as provided in the peace treaties with Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania.

LOS ANGELES, June 15 -- Almost 10,000 shares of the recent $10,000,000 common-stock issue of the Kaiser-Fraser Corporation were sold by a West Coast securities firm before the automobile manufacturer's registration statement was cleared by the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was disclosed today.

The deadline for the second quarerly installment of the 1948 Federal income tax and for revision of estimated income for the year passed yesterday with normal staffs kept fairly busy at the offices of the Collectors of Internal Revenue. A substantial volume of mail also was received.

Desire for economic betterment brings the typical Puerto Rican migrant to New York rather than the quest for just a job or support from the city's relief program, according to a nine-month study of migration conducted by Columbia University's Bureau of Applied Social Research for the Puerto Rican Government.

CLEVELAND, June 15 (AP) -- The Red Sox shelled Bob Lemon from the mound with a three-run outburst in the seventh inning tonight and went on to a 7-3 victory over the league-leading Indians before 51,380 Municipal Stadium fans. Southpaw Rookie Mel Parnell was credited with the triumph.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., June 15 -- The seventeen-man Hastings Police Department, criticized for "laxity" and "culpable neglect of duty" by a Westchester County grand jury in April, began to function today under the command of Sgt. John F. Manopoli of the State Police.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A dissatisfied stockholder in the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad obtained today what appears to be the first hearing ever ordered by the Interstate Commerce Commission on a railroad's application for authority to issue equipment trust certificates.

The collapse of the soft coal negotiations laid a restraining hand on the stock market yesterday although the oil issues remained strong and active. Fractional advances in the steels and motors were replaced by losses of the same proportion as selling developed in the final hour.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 15 (AP) -- While their employer looked on, between thirty and forty of Vivien Kellems' workers bought money orders today to pay their income taxes, which she had refused to withhold.

More than 1,000 persons assembled at Town Hall last night for a concert which was the first public function of the Women's Division of the Jewish Labor Committee. The program featured eleven selections from a forthcoming collection, "Songs of the Ghettos and Camps."

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., June 15 -- Breaking 90 for the first time in her career, Mrs. Michael Chernow of Elmwood won low gross honors with a card of 44, 42 -- 86 in the first one-day Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class B tournament over Vernon Hills course today.

In a busy session yesterday the City Council passed a bill to outlaw pinball machines in the city, adopted increased financial and business taxes designed to raise $30,000,000 in additional city revenue; filed measures aimed at increasing the number of taxicabs and expressed its disapproval of a theatre censorship measure by laying it over without date.

BOSTON, June 15 (AP) -- Johnny Sain pitched the Braves into undisputed possession of the National League lead with a six-hit performance against the last-place Cubs for a 6-3 victory tonight before a crowd of 24,124. Only one Chicago tally against the right-handed ace was earned.

The theatre needs a play like "E=mc2" for what it has to say. Presented last evening by the Experimental Theatre for the first of three performances before invited audiences in Columbia University's Brander Matthews Theatre, this stage documentary poses the challenge of atomic energy to our survival.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Senate approved tonight an amendment to grant to the Tennessee Valley Authority $4,000,000 for the construction of a steam plant to aid in the generation of electric power by the Authority.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 15 -- A special report describing the existence of Europe's 900,000 refugees as sordid and calling upon the countries of the world to open wide their doors, instead of just talking about it, will be submitted soon to the United Nations by Secretary General Trygve Lie, it was learned today.

The Prudential Insurance Company of America reported yesterday that occupancy of the first unit of Dryden Gardens, its housing project in East Orange, 1. J., is expected on Aug. 1. Harry J.tevens, Inc., broker, of Newark, is the managing agent and is handling applications.

Except for scattered breaches, which remain a possibility in cases where seamen disregard their leadership, Federal Court restraints have now staved off a crippling maritime strike. The maritime workers are vociferously protesting the Government injunction, although it is fairly well known within the industry that some of the union leaders, while obliged to protest for their own political reasons, find it not entirely lacking in advantages.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., June 15 -- Joe Louis admitted in a mass interview with a group of boxing writers that he doesn't punch as fast as he used to, although he thinks he punches just as hard, and that in the eleven years since he lifted the world heavyweight title from James J. Braddock he has lost more than 20 per cent of the speed he once boasted.

The eight-story business build. ing at 5 Fifth Avenue, erected some years ago by Frank Brothers, has been sold by Thomas NI. I Amendola through the Charles F. Noyes Company. Pease Elliman, Ine., represented the buyer, who, it is understood, will occupy the property after extensive alterations have been completed.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 -- The distribution of food, drugs, liquor and hardware from 200 warehouses on both sides of San Francisco Bay was at a standstill today as 7,000 members of Local 6 of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union stayed off their jobs for the second successive day in a wage dispute.

Those who impatiently are awaiting the arrival of the big bluefin tuna might be able to rush the season a bit by trying their luck at Casco Bay, on the Maine coast, for several big ones have been sighted during the past week.

With an estimated attendance of 250,000 persons for six days, the Ford Motor Company's exhibition of 1949 cars ended at 10 o'clock last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Just before the doors closed, J. R. Davis, vice president and director of sales and advertising, said in a message from Detroit:

CAIRO, Egypt, June 15 (AP) -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator, said today United Nations truce observers were patroling the Palestine coast in planes supplied by the United States to check on the arrival of ships carrying immigrants and supplies.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, was among seventeen Americans and two Britons who were decorated today for their war services by Sir Oliver Franks, the British Ambassador.

Evidently Bolivia's need for new external credits is bringing to the fore the prior need for squaring up accounts with private creditors who have been holding bonds which have been in default since 1931. Announcement by a Bolivian Government official that an "agreement in principle" has been reached on resuming debt service on about $60,000,000 of outstanding dollar bonds brought yesterday a flurry of trading, with rising prices, to the four issues dealt in here.
"Operation Ragweed 1948," the third annual phase of the city's campaign to reduce hay fever here by eliminating ragweed, will be opened today.
CHICAGO, June 15 -- Buying of wheat against sales of corn in the way of backspreading gave the bread grain a strong tone today on the Board of Trade.

Both Houses of Congress have passed a bill which would establish a National Heart Institute to combat diseases of the heart and circulatory system through research, the training of physicians and other means. Even if the President signs a measure which harmonizes with his views on social security, we have no more than a declaration of good intentions in the absence of a specific appropriation.

DETROIT, June 15 (AP) -- The Tigers inaugurated their brand new $400,000 lighting system by beating the Athletes, 4 to 1, tonight in the first American League night game in Detroit. Hal Newhouser took the occasion to hurl his finest game of the season -- a two-hitter -- for his seventh consecutive pitching triumph.

The stereotype of "American" that can be expected in Europe, the factors that account for it and the influence of students, as people, in establishing good human relationships were stressed yesterday by Dr. Alice V. Keliher, Professor of Education, New York University.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 15 (AP) -- The fourth annual women's intercollegiate golf championship race was a wide-open affair today as Shirley Spork of Michigan State Normal, 1947 victor, was eliminated in a first-round upset.

Rainwear manufacturers are confident that fall business will equal or exceed that of last year, according to the heads of the National Rainwear Manufacturers Association and the New York Raincoat Manufacturers Association.

THE HAGUE, June 15 -- Holland's festival of music, feature of Wilhelmina's golden jubilee celebration, opened tonight in The Stadsschouwburg, Amsterdam, with a performance of Debussy's "Pelleas and Melisande." Programs of orchestral music, opera and ballet will be given daily for the next month in the capital or at Scheveningen, a seaside resort near The Hague.

One hundred and eighty thousand city employes will be pressed into service to make New York's golden jubilee a financial success, it became known last night. They will be called upon to sell tickets for the exhibit at Grand Central Palace and the international air exposition to be held at Idlewild Airport.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 15 -- The scope and nature of the medical and food problems of Eastern Europe were brought into sharp focus last night by officials of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund as they completed an inspection tour in Yugoslavia.
The Investment Corporation of Philadelphia reported yesterday in its annual statement as of Dec. 31 last, a net loss of $268,272, of which $185,768 represented loss from transactions in securities.

ASCOT, England, June 15 -- Summer prints and flower- trimmed hats made today's Ascot race meeting one of the smartest and gayest in many years. In a medley of color, hardly rivalled by the jockeys racing colors, there was perhaps a preference for navy and white prints and for silver gray and champagne yellow ensembles.

If the plan now being discussed to set aside parts of some of New York's main thoroughfares for the exclusive use of pedestrians ever becomes a fact, this city will not be alone in having within its limits this restricted form of urban traffic.

Gordon Greenfield, secretary-treasurer of Oppenheim Collins Co., declared yesterday that Nicholas Carnes, president of Local 1250, United Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes, CIO, had given false figures at a union-sponsored election Monday night as to the number of employes on vacation.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The House grappled with the stop-gap draft problem today. By nightfall it appeared to be in a mood to approve decisively, as promptly as possible, the peacetime induction for two years of military service of perhaps 250,000 men 19 through 25 years of age.

Even at this early date, the problem of getting the right-sized house for such an important attraction as Moss Hart's latest play, "Light Up the Sky" (due here the week of Nov. 1), is of some concern to the sponsors, Joseph M. Hyman and Bernard Hart.

Kenneth Liebman, the twenty-nine-month-old youngster who on Monday fell six floors from his family's apartment at 1579 Metropolitan Avenue, the Bronx, was still a source of wonderment yesterday at Fordham Hospital.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- The Yankees went to great lengths tonight to blow the opening game of the second Western trip of the year to the tail-end White Sox. To be exact, they carried the struggle to eleven innings before going down, 9 to 8, with Yogi Berra, earlier the hero in an uphill battle, the hapless goat in defeat.

JERUSALEM, June 15 -- In an unprecedented meeting held under the auspices of the Truce Commission, Israeli and Arab commanders of Jerusalem shook hands today and checked maps of their forces' positions. Later they visited disputed points, involving houses claimed by both sides, in the Musrarah and Deir Abu Tor districts.

Fifty-one missionaries and deaconesses were commissioned last night for the Board of Missions and Church Extension of the Methodist Church at the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street. Bishop Walter W. Peele, of Richmond, Va., officiated.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 15 The use of radioactive phosphorus and a recently developed Geiger counter of a new type that can be inserted into the brain as a method of locating brain tumors was announced here today at the seventy-third annual meeting of the American Neurological Association.

TAMIMENT, Pa., June 15 -- The international executive board of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, decided today to give immediate consideration to an appeal by three leaders of an anti-Communist faction against their expulsion from the Bloomingdale Department Store Local in New York.

The young man who recently renounced his United States citizenship "to become a world citizen" and spoke of applying for membership in United World Federalists is quite misinformed about both the position of the organization and the nature of citizenship in a federated world.

Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman said yesterday that reconstruction aid aimed at economic independence was the "healthiest way" to rehabilitate Europe's 1,500,000 Jews, even if they resettled in Israel, the United States or elsewhere.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed somewhat irregular yesterday, 9 points lower to 31 points higher.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 15 -- Honorary degrees were conferred this morning on ten persons, including Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Katharine Cornell, actress, and Dr. Raymond B. Fosdick, at Princeton University's 201st commencement exercises.

In his fifth sale of a business property in the area, David S. !eister has conveyed the two,tory store and office building at 365-67 Bloomfield Avenue, corner of North Willow Street, in Montclair, N. J., to a group represented by Lewis Winetsky, attorney.

The shortage of steel for pipe in the gas utility industry today is the worst in the 100-year history of the industry, according to a report made by the American Gas Association yesterday following a survey.

Three mysterious Flying Fortresses, the B-17s of the European war, apparently converted to commercial use, were the subject of widespread search last night over the Eastern Atlantic and Western Mediterranean. The search, by Air Force planes from Santa Maria in the Azores and by naval planes from Tripoli, was touched off by a message from one of the planes intercepted early yesterday at the Coast Guard search and rescue headquarters in New York.
The first serious challenge to any of the headliners in the national professional tennis championship was offered yesterday in the Forest Hills Stadium.

In San Francisco, her native city, to which she was so fiercely loyal, Gertrude Atherton seemed indestructible. At 90 she had become a literary landmark, still pointing forward but dating back to the days of the pioneers. She had been a handsome woman, a California aristocrat, dominating any scene at which she was present.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, June 16 -- The Senate passed and sent to a conference with the House at 12:50 A.M. a foreign-aid program totaling $6,125,710,000, including $5,055,000,000 for Europe's recovery needs to April 3, 1949.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 15 -- Tex Moore of Lawrenceville led at the halfway mark of the thirty-second annual Eastern Interscholastic Golf Association championship tournament by carding 40,35 -- 75 for the par-71 Greenwich Country Club course today.
A bridegroom of two weeks made an unscheduled appearance in Felony Court yesterday to point out two suspects he said had stolen his car containing his clothes and his wife's trousseau.

MANHATTAN, Kan., June 15 -- Twelve guests from the East of Armour and Company of Chicago, beginning a two-week tour of Western livestock producing areas, arrived here this morning after being told by a packing industry expert that, contrary to most earlier predictions, meat supplies in the country's retail markets next month, and through September, will be about at the same level as in the year's second quarter.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Before opening his frontal assault on House Republicans for cutting the foreign recovery appropriations, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg told friends that in this act lay his final renunciation as a Republican Presidential possibility.

A group of former officers of the Empire Steel Corporation has formed the Penn-Ohio Steel Corporation to operate the Naval Industrial Reserve plant at Birdsboro, Pa., which has just been leased from the Government, it was announced here yesterday by principals in the new organization.

Barney Brainum, Inc., whole-sale jobber of metal, has purchased the one-story building at 19 to 23 Moore Street, Brooklyn, from the Columbia Woodworking Company. The building, on a plot 75 by 100 feet, contains 7,500 square feet of space.

Forty-year-old Fritz Ostermueller shut out the Giants with three measly singles last night in a Pittsburgh 2-0 triumph that dropped Mel Ott's club out of its first-place deadlock with the victorious Braves into a second-place tie with the Pirates.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 15 -- The United Nations Security Council today rejected a Soviet attempt to have Russian military observers sent to Palestine to help supervise compliance with the cease-fire agreement. In a final attempt to obtain the Council's agreement the Soviet representative, Andrei A. Gromyko, offered a pledge that only five Soviet officers would be sent.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., June 15 -- Bankers have a "moral duty" at this time to inform the public fully on the difference between banks of deposits and savings and loan associations, William A. Kielmann, retiring president of the New York State Bankers Association, declared here last night.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- President Truman sent a billion-dollar appropriation bill back to Congress today in a rare exercise of veto power.

Howard Hunt, author of a forthcoming novel, "Maelstrom," has gone to Paris to work in the Information Division of the office of Ambassador Averell W. Harriman. While there he hopes to continue work on another novel, which will be his fifth. "Maelstrom," a modern story set mostly in Mexico, will be published by Farrar, Straus on July 21.

DETROIT, June 15 -- Some 17,000 employes of the Hudson Motor Car Company received a wage increase of 13 cents an hour today under terms of a contract settlement reached by the company and the CIO United Automobile Workers Union.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The Taft-Ellender-Wagner housing bill appeared to be headed for the shelf tonight -- or possibly drastic revision.

CINCINNATI, June 15 -- The peace and freedom of the world may well depend upon the speed and skill with which Americans bestir themselves and surpass the Communists in the use of ideas in world politics, William Benton, head of the United States delegation to the United Nations Conference on Freedom of Information and the Press, told the convention of the Advertising Federation of America.
Negotiators representing thirteen New York daily newspapers and 2,500 composing room employes announced yesterday that their efforts to write a new contract had failed.

Champagne corks popped in the press box at Belmont Park yesterday. For a hurdle handicap, the New York Turf Writers Cup, was the main event of the first-day show of the United Hunts Racing Association, and the owner, trainer and rider of the winner, the 4-year-old colt Pebalong, were invited to lift glasses with the gentleman of the press after the numbers had been posted.

A large one-story Dodge-Chrysler automobile sales and service center is planned for Lynbrook, L. I., where the Harrontine Realty Corporation has purchased two parcels of land from Emil W. and Albert G. Beye. One plot, 200 by 323 feet by irregular, fronts on the south side of Sunrise Highway and extends through to the north side of Scranton Avenue.

Everyone needs a vacation, and I believe your readers will agree with me that blind people need it even more than the seeing. That is why the Lighthouse sponsors a vacation program for nearly 500 blind people of all ages, races or creeds.

PARIS, June 15 -- Sol Hurok, New York impresario, who has come here to draw up contracts for the appearance of the Paris State Opera Ballet in the United States and Canada next fall, announced today that he was "an ambassador extraordinary" and had "done more than any other man to kindle love for good music among Americans."

PARIS, June 15 -- While the French National Assembly kept on today with the debate on the six-power London recommendations for Western Germany, displaying a general reluctance to approve them, the French Foreign Office and majority leaders were endeavoring to get concessions from the other Western Allies that would help in obtaining a favorable Assembly vote.

Though the present divorce rate is still 200 per cent higher than at the time of World War I, the Family Service Association of America reported yesterday a decline in marital breakdowns in seventy-three of the eighty-nine cities surveyed last year.

PORTSMOUTH, N. H., June 15 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg's silence on his availability for the Republican Presidential nomination appeared today to be crippling efforts of his backers to win support among Republican Governors attending the fortieth annual Governors' Conference here.
SAARBRUECKEN, Germany, June 15 -- The moves to create three zones in western Germany are being watched with great interest and some apprehension in the tiny State of the Saar.

On June 3 you printed a letter from Sydney Moseley in which he stated that the present Palestine situation is leading to an acute deterioration in British-American relations and that Zionist activity in general, and Zionist advertisements in particular, are causing an anti-Semitism in Great Britain far greater than that which could have been hoped for by Joseph Goebbels.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Foreign countries, short on dollars and gold, reduced their purchases of United States goods and services by $400,000,000 during the first quarter of this year. United States imports from foreign countries were up $300,000,000 in comparison.

A Federal Expediting Court consisting of Circuit Court Judge Augustus N. Hand and District Court Judge Henry W. Goddard refused yesterday to issue a temporary injunction sought by the Department of Justice to bar a group of major motion picture companies from acquiring or selling any theatre interests pending a final judgment in a Government anti-trust suit against them.
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., June 15 (AP) -- Yale and Lafayette moved into favored positions tonight in the Eastern N.C.A.A. baseball tournament with victories over North Carolina and Illinois.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The National Labor Relations Board made clear today that its jurisdiction extended to building and construction cases, even though it had rarely exercised that jurisdiction.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Ezra Van Horn, operators' trustee of the United Mine Workers of America Welfare and Retirement Fund of 1947, filed suit today in the Federal District Court to restrain John L. Lewis and Senator H. Styles Bridges, respectively miners' and neutral trustees, from disbursing any money from the $40,000,000 fund.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Little prospect for relieving congestion on the Federal court calender in the Southern District of New York appeared likely today. Republican leadership seemingly had pigeonholed not only the nomination of Samuel H. Kaufman to a vacancy on the bench in the district, but also a bill by Senator Irving M. Ives to create an additional judgeship in the area. Politics bulked large in both actions.

MADRID, June 16 -- Re-establishment of noble titles made illegal by the Spanish republic in 1932 became effective today with publication of a decree issued by Generalissimo Franco based on the law enacted by the Cortes on May 4.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that the New York Stock Exchange and the United Financial Employes Union, AFL, had reached an agreement under which about 1,000 employes will receive weekly pay rises of $3, $4 and $5 a week, plus other benefits.

VIENNA, June 16 -- The Russian High Command in Austria today accused Dr. Alfred Migsch, Socialist Minister of Power, of "slandering the Soviet people." It added that it was considering the prevention of such occurrences in the future by ceasing to regard him "only as a member of the Austrian Government."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 16 -- King Gustaf V of Sweden was 90 years old today and half a million Swedes lining the route of his state drive through the main thoroughfares of the capital in an open carriage on this sunny afternoon cheered themselves hoarse.
SEOUL, Korea, June 16 -- The Soviet-controlled radio in North Korea reported today that the crews of two South Korea coast guard cutters had deserted with their vessels to North Korea.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 16 (AP) -- Harold Gray, 17 years old of Palo Alto, Calif., skippered St. George's School to the thirteenth Interscholastic yacht Racing Association championship today.

The right of agents of the Federal Housing Expediter to enter apartment houses to investigate complaints by tenants of violations of the Housing and Rents Laws was upheld yesterday in a unanimous decision of the Circuit Court of Appeals.

LONDON, June 16 (AP) -- Bob Falkenburg of Los Angeles, defending his London tennis championship at the Queens Club, scraped through into the quarter-finals today after dropping one set. Falkenburg eliminated K. Kukuljevic of India, 6 -- 3, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 3, in their men's singles match.

Crosley Motors, Inc., mass producer of lightweight cars, transacted sales of $17,203,857 in the nine months ended with last April, Powel Crosley Jr., president, reported to stockholders in the statement to be released today. The total exceeds by more than $5,000,000 the sales volume of $12,073,721 shown for the entire fiscal year ended on July 31, 1947.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 16 (AP) -- Miss Grace Lenczyk of Stetson University coasted through the second round today to remain the favorite in the women's collegiate golf championship. She defeated Miss Nancy Porter of the Women's College of the University of North Carolina, 6 and 5.

Large national defense contracts, for which letters of intent have been issued by Air Corps procurement officers were disclosed for the first time here yesterday by members of the Magnesium Association at the Pennsylvania Hotel, following a gathering of fifty executives.

The calendar tells us summer is near even if the weather does not. With the approach of the sultry season in mind, the delegate from this department asked Charles F. Rollet for some ideas on what to serve when it is too hot to eat.

MUNICH, Germany, June 16 -Sally Zeve, a Lithuanian displaced person who became managing partner in the Bavarian Trucking Company, was sentenced today to serve two years in Straubing Prison and was fined 40,000 Reichmarks upon conviction for having "fraudulently and wrongfully" disposed of ten trucks and two command cars that formerly were the property of the United States Army.

GENEVA, N. Y., June 16 -- A five-point program to bring about closer cooperation between county and town welfare officials and to clear up misunderstandings that have arisen since the passing of the Ostertag Law two years ago was announced today by Ralph King, president of the New York Public Welfare Association.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The House Rules Committee pigeonholed today a bill containing controversial public housing and slumclearance provisions of the Senateapproved Taft-Ellender-Wagner Long-Range Housing Bill.

Formation of a City Employes Organizing Committee to set up a new Congress of Industrial Organizations union of municipal workers in opposition to the United Public Workers, CIO, was announced yesterday at City Hall by Patrick J. Brady, former vice president of Local 111, UPW, with jurisdiction over custodial and maintenance employes.

The twelve-story and penthouse store and office building at 542-44 Fifth Avenue, southwest corner of Forty-fifth Street, was sold by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company and another, as trustees, to the Omnibus Realty Corporation, Elias A. Cohen, president, for investment in a deal reported yesterday by the Herbert Jacques Morris Corporation, the Charles F. Noyes Company and the Cruikshank Company, brokers.
I feel that I must draw your attention to one of the inaccuracies in M.S. Handler's story on Yugoslav-American relations in THE TIMES of June 1. Mr. Handler stated:

WESTBURY, L.I., June 16 -Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of the Piping Rock Club shot 37, 37 -74, one stroke over women's par for the course, to win the low gross prize in the one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the Meadow Brook Club today.

Worth Street dry-goods suppliers were heartened yesterday by reports that business has picked up for Southern dry-goods jobbers. News of increased activity, it was pointed out, might be the forerunner of large wholesale fall and winter purchases, long overdue.

There has been no more ironic reversal in the history of Czechoslovakia than the election of Klement Gottwald as President. Gottwald is a Communist and a faithful stooge of Moscow. The office he has taken over, relinquished by the disillusioned Dr. Benes, was once honored by Thomas Masaryk, father of the free republic and one of the great liberal statesmen of modern times.

GENEVA, June 16 -- A convention establishing new international law on the subject of property rights in aircraft that traverse national frontiers will be signed by as many as seven leading air powers here this week or next, Russell B. Adams, chief United States delegate to the Assembly of the International Civil Aviation Organization, predicted today.

PARIS, Thursday, June 17 -- The French National Assembly reluctantly voted by a majority of eight at 4:40 o'clock this morning that France would agree to participate in the application of London recommendations for western Germany. The count was 297 to 289.

Bernard Shaw, who objected to being called George Bernard Shaw, has turned huckster. Ireland was the theme that induced the irascible exile to take pencil in hand. The advertisement he has written -- for free -- will appear in July magazines in the United States.

While leaders in religion, diplomacy and public affairs undertook yesterday to support the United Nations as basic for peace and eventual world government, James P. Warburg, economist and author, declared that a separate peace with a new West German nation would in effect give all Germany to the Soviet Union.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 16 -Some 200,000 workers in the metal industries throughout Belgium went on strike this morning, tying up iron and steel factories, shipyards and construction works.

Arriving for a series of six matches in New York, Chicago, St. Louis, Toronto and Worcester, Masc a party of sixteen members of the Djurgarden Football Club of Stockholm, including fourteen players, landed early yesterday afternoon at La Guardia Field.
BATAVIA, Java, June 16 -- Negotiations between the Dutch and the Indonesian Republicans under the auspices of the United Nations Committee of Good Offices reached a complete deadlock today.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Just about the time Bucky Harris seemed ready to tear another handful of hair out of his head in a vain attempt to provoke a well-pitched game by a Yankee, Allie Reynolds moved on the scene today to prevent his skipper from balding himself completely.

PRAGUE, June 16 -- The Czechoslovak Government has taken over control of advertising in all periodicals published in this country, including the daily press. Ministry of Information regulations just issued set forth how advertisements shall be organized, thus determining who shall receive this income.

Stop Censorship, a theatrical group which is vigorously opposing censorship restrictions, issued a warning yesterday that "New Yorkers should not be lulled into a belief that all danger is past that the Cunningham Bill may become law."

TOKYO, June 16 -- Japan's Imperial Princes, blood relatives of Emperor Hirohito, are about to be ousted from sports organizations in which they hold official positions, by order of Premier Hitoshi Ashida's coalition Government.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 16 -- President Truman is returning to the capital with the conviction that he has decidedly improved the Democratic party's position through the West and with high hopes of election, it was learned today.

The Title Guarantee and Trust Company, 176 Broadway, and three of its officials were found guilty last night in General Sessions of conspiring to issue false information to other banking establishments concerning the financial stability of the convicted swindler, William B. Benjamin.
American leadership in the creation of a world government, through amendment of the Constitution and revision of the U.N. Charter, is cogently advocated by Dr. Henry A. Murray in THE TIMES of June 9.

The stock market lost more ground yesterday, although some recuperative power developed in the late trading. Demand was not sufficient, however, to overcome the early losses and, while fractional setbacks were general, a few recently favored issues lost a point and more and the combined averages dipped 0.49 point on the day.

Less than one-fourth of 1 per cent of total meat production of the United States will be exported during the next twelve months and none will go to Marshall Plan countries, Ralph S. Trigg, administrator of the Production and Marketing Administration and president of the Commodity Credit Corporation, told more than 500 members of the Grocery Manufacturers Representatives of New York yesterday at the Astor Hotel.

BERLIN, June 16 -- The Communist inspired People's Council for Germany, claiming it had been "legitimatized" by the results of the People's Congress petition for German unity, assumed today the aspect of a provisional government and presented three demands to the three Western powers. These were:

ALBANY, June 16 -- The Constitutionality of the New York State statute on released time for religious training was upheld today in a brief filed in the Supreme Court here in behalf of the Greater New York Coordinating Committee on Released Time of Jews, Protestants and Roman Catholics.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange again closed irregular 5 points lower to 10 points higher.

Many of the eighty-nine passengers scheduled to sail on the Yugoslav passenger-cargo ship Radnik carried their own luggage aboard the vessel yesterday as longshoremen refused for the second day to load cargo aboard the 6,566-ton ship at her Brooklyn pier.

"How to Predict Elections," by Louis H. Bean, will be published by Knopf on July 19. Mr. Bean, who has been associated with the Bureau of Agricultural Economists, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration and the Board of Economic Warfare, is now economic adviser to the Secretary of Agriculture.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, June l6 -- Fire today destroyed half of the $1,000,000 Heidelberg University building donated in 1929 by Americans through the efforts of former United States Ambassador to Germany Jacob Gould Schurman.

For the fifth successive week production of petroleum in the United States last week again established a new peak at an average of 5,479,600 barrels daily, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

After waiting all night in line before Our Lady Queen of Martyrs parochial school at Arden Street and Dongan Place, in the Inwood section, parents who were unable to register their children for the first grade made arrangements yesterday for a neighborhood meeting to discuss their problem.
Accommodations in midtown hotels at present are as hard to get as a new automobile and the room shortage will continue until July 1, the Hotel Association of New York reported yesterday.

BELGRADE Yugoslavia, June 16 -- More and more evidence is accumulating from official Communist sources to confirm the belief that fundamental organizational and tactical changes are occurring inside all the Communist parties in Europe.

The appointment of eight new members to the faculty of the Juilliard School of Music was announced yesterday by William Schuman, president. To share in the conducting of the school's two orchestras, three guest conductors have been invited for the first time, namely, Dean Dixon, Eleazar de Carvalho and Jean Paul Morel.

A vigorous plea for American aid in world-wide economic rehabilitation to safeguard weaker nations against a "vacuum of despair," provided the keynote for the thirteenth annual convention program of the National Federation of Sales Executives which opened its three-day session at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday with more than 1,200 delegates present.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The experience gained in flying the Bell XS-1 at speeds faster than that of sound will result in airplanes capable of much faster flight, it was predicted today by experts of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics.

The rebuilt passenger liner Nuevo Dominicano, the largest liner ever to fly the flag of the Dominican Republic, arrived in New York harbor yesterday to open passenger and cargo service to the Dominican ports of Ciudad Trujillo and Puerto Plata.

A final judgment dissolving the Mortgage Conference of New York and enjoining thirty-three banks, trust and insurance companies from restrictive practices in connection with real estate investment and management operations in this area was entered by consent of all concerned in Federal court yesterday.

There is no more desperate and basic need in this country than that for housing. This need has been estimated by backers of the Taft-Ellender-Wagner Housing Bill, which passed the Senate by voice vote on April 22, at 1,500,000 dwelling units a year for the next ten years.

"The Emperor Waltz," a Paramont comedy-romance with music, starring Bing Crosby and Joan Fontaine, which opens at the Radio City Music Hall, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Billy Wilder directed and Charles Brackett produced the Technicolor offering from their own story.

Jane Pickens will headline a program that will make its bow at 5:30 P.M. Sunday, July 4, over NBC. It will be primarily a musical offering, and the cast will include Jack Kilty, a vocal quartet and Norman Clothier and his orchestra.

General Electric Company yesterday increased list prices of a number of household appliances and two industrial equipment items from 5 to 12 percent. In announcing the increases during a press conference at company headquarters, 570 Lexington Avenue, Charles E. Wilson, president, emphasized that the advances were made on each product separately and added that the weighted average will not be up much more than 5 per cent.

Lack of human understanding rather than any defect in the charter of the United Nations is the cause of most of the difficulties among the members, according to Warren R. Austin, United States representative to the United Nations.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 16 (AP) -Two track and field stars will be missing from this year's National Collegiate Athletic Asssociation's event because their "years of eligibility" have run out, it became known today.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Trans World Airline today protested strongly against an application filed with the Civil Aeronautics Board by Pan American Airways to inaugurate domestic air services linking its ports of departure for international flights.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Senate brought along toward final passage tonight the first major bill in fourteen years to provide as Congressional policy a wide and substantial reduction in Government price guarantees to farmers.

The internal difficulties of Montgomery Ward Co., which have resulted in the resignations of top executives of the nation's second largest mail-order house, were widened yesterday when George Whitney, president, and H.P. Davison, vice president, of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., announced their resignations as directors.

Between $5,000,000 and $10,000,000 on deposit with the Treasurer of the City of New York is available for relief in the devastated countries of Europe, it was learned yesterday, when Philip Leonti of 291 Avenue X, Brooklyn, was notified that check for $2,000 was available for his mother, Mrs. Josephine Leonti, in Italy.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., June 16 -- Resolutions calling for revival of civilian defense organizations and a strengthening of the National Guard were approved unanimously at the closing business session of the fortieth annual conference of Governors.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 16 -President Truman asserted today that the foreign policy of this country should be kept out of the "political scramble of the Presidential election," but he promised no quarter on domestic issues.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- With the new Secretary of Agriculture, Charles F. Brannan, as witness, the House Select Committee to Investigate Commodity Transactions started today an inquiry into the inflationary potential of the Economic Cooperation Administration.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Wheat continued today the advance in prices that started yesterday on the Board of Trade and was strong throughout the session. A sharp falling off in cash wheat offerings in the Southwest, with a consequent limited amount of hedging and with early buying of July by cash interests, induced active buying.

The right of R.H. Macy Co. to pay a triple-time bonus to store employes who crossed picket lines to work during the drivers' strike in July, 1946, was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter.

Consumers will have the benefit of approved standards in rainwear in the next six months with the establishment of fair trade practices on labeling of water-resistant materials, it was pointed out last night by Simon Cohen, vice president of the National Rainwear Manufacturers Association.

LONDON, June 16 -- The favorable effect of the United States Senate's efforts toward restoration of the cuts made by the House of Representatives in the European Recovery Program on the stock markets here today was outweighed by the rapid spread of the dock strike here and as a result the market generally was dull and idle.

Future developments in the new science of antibiotic therapy may make it possible before long to combat, if not to eliminate all plant, animal and human disease, Dr. Selman A. Waksman told the National Tuberculosis Association meeting at the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday.

Mrs. Helene Dow of the host club successfully retained her women's national foils fencing championship last night at the Fencers Club. She turned back Miss Janice York of the Faulkner School of Fencing, Los Angeles, 4 and 2, in a fence-off after each had finished all even in the round-robin final at seven matches won and one lost.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Many oracles of the press, one group among whom has unanimously prophesied that Senator Vandenberg will be the Republican nominee for President, are now renegotiating their prediction. After the Senator deliberately dramatized his division over economic foreign policy with the House majority leaders, they began to say: "Well, it looks more like Dewey."

On Sunday, June 27, the bodies of 4,400 Americans who died in the last war are due to arrive at the New York Port of Embarkation in Brooklyn. They will be the first to arrive from cemeteries in the British Isles.

BERLIN, June 18 -- Despite the economic and political pressure they have exerted on the Western sectors of Berlin the Russians have gone out of their way recently to protest the absence of any political significance in these measures and to placate irate officials of the Western powers.

A banking syndicate headed by Glore, Forgan Co. and W.C. Langley Co. will offer to investors today an issue of 4 per cent $100 par value cumulative preferred stock of the Kansas City Power and Light Company at $101.25 a share, to yield about 3.95 per cent.

Between 13,500 and 14,000 long tons of fine tin will be produced in 1948 by Patino Mines and Enterprises Consolidated, Inc., Alexander B. Royce, counsel and vice president, who presided at the adjourned annual meeting, informed shareholders here yesterday.
One hundred and thirty members of the New York University faculty will be promoted to higher professorial rank, effective in September, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase announced yesterday.

Representatives of the Port of New York Authority and the New York City Housing Authority have begun a study of the need for large-scale, low-rental housing in the areas adjacent to the New York International Airport at Idlewild and to La Guardia Field, it was made known yesterday.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, June 16 -- The Netherlands Government condemned today the action of the United States and Australian members of the United Nations Committee of Good Offices for having on their own initiative submitted mediation proposals in Indonesia.

BOSTON, June 16 (AP) -- Home runs by Eddie Waitkus and Andy Pafko and some good relief pitching by Emil Kush today enabled the Cubs to defeat the Braves, 8 -- 5, the first decision for the Chicagoans over Boston in eight games this season.

ST. LOUIS, June 16 -- In their newest investment held of income realty, insurance companies already have acquired about $260,000,000 in properties in forty states, Glen McHugh of New York, vice president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, told the members of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers today.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., June 16 (AP) -- Yale took a commanding lead in the N.C.A.A. Eastern baseball tournament tonight by defeating Lafayette University, 11 to 2. Righthander Jim Duffus yielded only six hits as Yale hammered out fifteen hits.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 16 -- Norma Productions, the Burt Lancaster-Harold Hecht company, has acquired "The Eagle on the Cactus," a screen story about the Mexican revolution of 1915 by Gilbert Roland, former film star, and will produce it in Mexico in association with Ernest Pascal, Hecht announced today.

BOONTON, N.J., June 16 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of the home club took a one-stroke lead in the women's New Jersey State golf championship when she toured the rolling Knoll Golf Club course in 40, 40 -- 80 as the first round was completed today.

Jockey Pat Smithwick, 21-year-old six-footer from Baltimore, saved Adaptable's run for the late stages, and that plan of campaign paid off yesterday for the 3-to-1 second choice in the $15,000 added Temple Gwathmey Steeplechase on the second and final afternoon of the United Hunts Racing Association's meet at Belmont Park.

The House has an opportunity today to undo some of the harm it did yesterday to the cause of this country's security and its influence for world peace. If two of the amendments to the Selective Service bill which were adopted by considerable majorities in yesterday's session are not deleted, an indefensible gamble will have been taken with the manpower for our armed services.
The Gydnia America Line motorship Batory came into port yesterday two days late after having negotiated the last 1,200 miles of its crossing with one propeller.

DETROIT, June 18 (AP) -- Lefty Lou Brissie lost a tough one today as the Tigers ran their winning streak to six games, with a 2-to-1 victory over the Athletics in eleven innings. The 24-year-old Brissie had a one-hit 1-0 decision through eight innings but couldn't hold it.

The recent five-week shutdown of the bituminous coal mines marked the sixth time since April 1, 1943, that the national economy had been subjected to these paralyzing stoppages. Are we heading into a seventh?

The prophetic dreams a Colonial housewife might have had of hearth and home have been embodied in the local version of Mr. Blandings' Dream House that opens to the public this afternoon at Forty-eighth Street and Fifth Avenue.

Despite the chilly weather, 5,000 attended the New York Philharmonic-Symphony's third concert at the Lewisohn stadium last night. Fritz Reiner was again the conductor and Stell Andersen, pianist, was the soloist.

ROME, June 16 -- The Chamber of Deputies this evening voted its confidence in Premier Alcide de Gasperi's sixth government. The vote, 346 to 167, came at the end of a stormy five-hour sitting marked by left-wing heckling. It confirmed, that the extreme left had become almost isolated, since it had the support of only a few extreme rightist deputies.

CLERMONT-FERRAND, June 16 (AP) -- Associated Press photographer, Jean Jacques Levy, was set upon and beaten by state police when he approached the police barricade around the tire plant to take pictures. His camera was taken from him and destroyed.
RANGOON, Burma, June 16 -U Tin Tut, Burmese Foreign Minister, denied today that there had been a "reorientation of the Government's policy toward communism."
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Congress passed a bill over President Truman's veto today for the second time in three days, and the Senate overrode a third veto.

LONDON, June 16 (AP) -- Frank Parker, seeking his first Wimbledon title at the ripe tennis age of 32, will have to fight his way through the stronger half of the draw to reach the finals of the championships starting Monday.

The Board of Transportation started yesterday an educational drive to tell New Yorkers that new fares will be effective July 1 on subway, elevated, trolley car and bus lines operated by the city. Notices were posted in the various passenger carriers, and also will be placed on the billboards of the stations.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 16 -- The Arab countries have agreed in principle to making Jerusalem neutral ground, subject to unqualified agreement by the Jews.

Your recent editorial, "Why Not a Shorter Taxi?" advocating a three-passenger cab, might be revised as of July 1, when five adults will pay 50 cents for any subway ride. In many instances cab fares will be less than subway totals for groups of three, four and five people.
LONDON, Thursday, June 17 -- Great Britain's long battle in Palestine has been transferred to the editorial pages of the newspapers at home and is being fought this morning on an extended front.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 16 -Playing consistent golf, Tex Moore of Lawrenceville annexed medalist honors while leading his school to permanent possession of the team trophy in the thirty-six hole qualifying round of the thirty-second annual Eastern Interscholastic Golf Association tournament today at the Greenwich Country Club.

While an accused confidence man nervously wanted to enter a guilty plea to charges that he defrauded eighteen business men of $158,350 in a swindle scheme for scarce materials, General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein and an assistant district attorney engaged yesterday in a warm discussion on the latter's request for a severe sentence.
Whitehall Pharmacal Company, to Duane Jones Company, Inc., for advertising of Hill's Cold Tablets.

Reversing a policy of fourteen years, a majority of the seventeen justices in the Domestic Relations Court has decided to follow the tradition of colleagues in other city courts by donning judicial robes, it was learned yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, June 16 -- The American public, desiring full discussion on public issues and demanding the privilege of doing its own thinking, has shaped the American news viewpoint of unrestricted truth, Neil MacNeil, assistant night managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared here tonight.
The Veterans Administration appealed to local trade and professional groups yesterday to advise veterans on schools in their fields and to steer them away from training in overcrowded jobs.
The Russian "squeeze" on Berlin grew somewhat tighter yesterday, as the French political crisis -- in part a product of the six-power agreement for the consolidation of western Germany -- deepend.

The panic in Democratic ranks caused by the seeming weakness of the Truman Presidential candidacy spread yesterday to the Tammany Executive Committee, with the result that at least a dozen Tammany district leaders demanded that their local candidates get the right to run on both the Truman and Wallace tickets and try and salvage the election that way.

The United States has tried disarmament, appeasement, pacification and demobilization as preventives of war without success, but it has not tried a well-rounded program of national defense, Maj. Gen. Thomas B. Larkin, Quartermaster General of the Army, declared last night.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

The Mount Lebanon Baptist Church has purchased the church building at the southeast corner of Decatur Street and Lewis Avenue in Brooklyn from the Embury Methodist Church. Presently unoccupied, the building will be used by the purchaser after repairs and decorations have been completed.
PHILADELPHIA, June 16 (AP) -The Official program of the Republican National Convention, approved today by the Committee on Arrangements (all times are Eastern Daylight Time), follows:

There seems no end to the number of variations a simple chair or sofa can assume, to judge by the new collection presented yesterday at the Valley Upholstery Corporation, 428 West Fourteenth Street. Seven-foot sofas, sectional sofas, loveseats, armchairs, pull-up chairs and occasional tables, each with singular characteristics of design, are available immediately through decorators and will be found in the stores after July 1.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 16 -- A new type of brain surgery has been successful in relieving body pain of an intolerable and incurable nature, it was reported today to the seventy-third annual meeting of the American Neurological Association.
On June 3 you printed a letter by Polly Leeds, in which she stated that American Indians cannot vote and that they are not citizens, winding up with, "More shame to our democracy!"
Plans are now completed for the individual Maine Tuna Tournament, to be held this year at Boothbay Harbor on Aug. 11, 12, 13 and 14, with the Boothbay Region Tuna Club as host.
LONDON, June 16 -- The Ministry of Labor was striving desperately tonight to halt an outlaw strike of stevedores and longshoremen that threatened to paralyze the port of London.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 16 (AP) -- Two leading favorites in the Poughkeepsie Regatta June 2, Navy, the defending champion, and the University of California, arrived today to test their oars on the Hudson River before gunning for the rowing championship.

ONE of the great American folk-festival seasons is impending. Next week in Philadelphia the gaudy shenanigans leading to the selection of Presidential candidates gets under way. It is probably an appropriate time, therefore, to be reading a new book called "Presidential Sweepstakes,"* the pungent story of America's political conventions and campaigns, by Henry Luther Stoddard.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A Senate-House conference committee to work out an acceptable displaced-persons measure from widely differing bills from both chambers adjourned without a successful compromise this evening, and scheduled another meeting for tomorrow afternoon.
BERLIN, June 16 -- The Soviet Union snapped the last link in four-power government in Germany tonight when its representatives stalked out of a meeting of the Berlin Kommandatura.

In a match that will long be remembered by those fortunate to be present, Frank Kovacs came from two sets down to overcome the amazingly fine tennis of Francisco Segura yesterday in the national professional championship.

Negotiators representing 80,000 anthracite miners, members of John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers, and operators producing about 85 per cent of the nation's hard coal supply began discussions yesterday of a new contract.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The House refused today to accept the $6,125,710,000 foreign aid appropriation bill passed by the Senate and turned over to a conference committee the task of finding a middle ground acceptable to both chambers.
