PHILADELPHIA, June 16 -- The contest for the Republican Presidential nomination shapes up like a horse race at this stage of pre-convention week, with campaign managers of the various hopefuls cast in the role of jockeys who must make tough decisions as to the tactics most likely to insure victory.

SINGAPORE, June 16 (AP) -- Authorities ordered the immediate evacuation today of all European women and children from the Sungei Seiput district of the Malay Federation where Communists are charged with conducting a terror reign.

PARIS, June 16 -- A chain reaction of sympathetic strikes, involving an estimated 50,000 workers, spread after police early this morning had dislodged sitdown strikers in a tire and rubber factory in Clermont-Ferrand. One hundred and twenty were injured on both sides in the bloody fighting in the factory.

Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate, addressing a special plea to Congress on behalf of the City of New York, urged yesterday that prompt approval be given the $65,000,000 loan to construct the United Nations world capital along the East River.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended June 9:

For the third time in two seasons Big Ralph Branca knocked loudly on the door of the Hall of Fame when he held the Reds hitless for seven and two-thirds innings at Ebbets Field last night -but then the Dodgers had to break out of a tie to win, 4 -- 3, in the ninth inning.

CLEVELAND, June 16 (AP) -The Red Sox pounded Cleveland's Bob Feller to his fifth straight defeat today, 7 to 4, with a barrage of thirteen hits, including seventh-inning homers by Ted Williams and Bobby Doerr.
PEIPING, June 16 -- The Communist threat to the vital Tangshan coal mining center of northeast Hopeh has been repulsed, an announcement from Gen. Fu Tsoyi's headquarters here asserted this afternoon.

A self-confessed rent gouger, whose testimony helped convict two real estate brokers, was the only one of four defendants to escape a jail term yesterday in Special Sessions as the three others were sentenced to workhouse terms ranging from three months to a year.

Thousands of charwomen in Manhattan office and loft buildings will receive a wage increase of 10 cents an hour as the result of negotiations completed yesterday between their union and the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations, Inc.

EBBETS FIELD, where the Dodgers have been known to kick around a few balls themselves, will be the scene tomorrow night of an international soccer game between the Liverpool eleven of Britain and Djurgarden of Sweden. According to the historians, this will be the first fray on these shores between two top-flight foreign combinations and should furnish a brand of play considerably superior to that ever seen here before.
PHILADELPHIA, June 16 (AP) -Eighteen television stations will carry transmissions of the Republican National Convention to an estimated 10,000,000 persons.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 16 -- Andrei A. Gromyko bitterly accused the "ruling class" of the United States today of "rattling its atomic weapons" to step up war feeling in this country and put pressure on the Soviet Union.

The first Fire Department promotions to the rank of Deputy Chief since 1943 were made yesterday at City Hall at ceremonies in which Mayor O'Dwyer presented departmental medals to forty-seven firemen who distinguished themselves in 1947 by heroic deeds and meritorious conduct.

Eleven Army volunteers ended a five-week survival-ration test on Welfare Island yesterday without physical harm. Through their sacrifice -- some lost up to thirty-one pounds in weight -- the New York Medical College Research Unit decided on the best minimum ration for preserving body tissue under distress conditions.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 16 (UP) -- Parliament nationalized all of Hungary's church schools today over the bitter protests of the Catholic Church, which educates more than 50 per cent of the nation's children.

CHICAGO, June 16 (UP) -- Bernard Docusen, 21-year-old boxing star, and Ray (Sugar) Robinson, welterweight champion, completed training today for their fifteen-round title fight in Comiskey Park tomorrow night.

As was to be expected, the Russian Government has refused to accept the six-nation agreement regarding the creation of a federal regime for Germany, which kept the door open for Russian participation, and has let the world know that it so notified the Western Powers ten days ago.

COPAKE FALLS, N.Y. June 16 -- Following a motor trip through the hilly, heavily wooded and undeveloped region of primeval beauty where New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts meet, representatives of the Governors of the three states approved here today the area as a site for a tri-state park of thirty to forty thousand acres and the appointment of a joint committee to develop plans.

The merger of the Hebrew Union College in Cincinnati, the oldest rabbinical seminary in the country, with the Jewish Institute of Religion, founded in this city in 1922, was announced yesterday by officials of both institutions.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 -- A Washington dispatch in THE NEW YORK TIMES today concerning Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg had immediate but mixed reaction among the party leaders and delegates who have arrived here for next week's Republican National Convention.

The United Rank and File Educational Committee, which has been organized to combat Communist influence in trade unions, held its first public meeting last night at St. Nicholas Arena, Sixty-sixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 (AP) -- Slowdowns and work stoppages by some CIO West Coast maritime workers were predicted today despite union obedience to court orders forbidding the scheduled country-wide strike. Five unions have reset the strike hour for 10:30 A.M. June 24, when a ten-day Federal Court restraining order against it expires.

Dwight Deere Wiman announced yesterday the purchase of Marc Connelly's new comedy, "A Story for Strangers," for an early fall production. The transaction put to rest, once and for all, numerous past accounts of his imminent retirement from show business.

Edward Weinfeld, president of the National Public Housing Conference, charged Governor Dewey yesterday with responsibility for bottling up the Taft-EllenderWagner housing bill as a result of his "outrageous silence." Mr. Weinfeld was State Commissioner of Housing under Gov. Herbert H. Lehman.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -The New York stock brokerage concern of Edward R. Parker Company, Inc., was charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission today with practices that "would and did operate as a fraud and deceit" upon investors.

The danger and unfairness of requiring overworked building inspectors to assume responsibility for the safety of structures put up by unqualified "builders" was protested yesterday by speakers before the New York State Building Officials Conference in the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board today found the International Typographical Union, American Federation of Labor, and its Local 915 guilty of unfair labor practices in their dealings with The Nassau Review-Star, Rockville Centre, N.Y.

A tract of twenty-eight acres in Hewlett, L. I., has been sold by the Tesney Realty Corporation and the Deed Realty Corporation to Suntown Homes, Inc., of which E. Shulman is president, for improvement with about 140 one-family dwellings.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- In time of national emergency, women as well as men should be registered for industrial or military mobilization, as the need indicated, Col. Mary A. Hallaren, director of the Women's Army Corps, said today in reply to a question at a press conference.

LONDON, June 16 -- Russia was among the missing tonight when a record number of fifty-seven nations was listed by the British Olympic Organizing Committee as official entries in the Olympics. At the Berlin games in 1936, fifty-two nations accepted invitations and forty-eight participated.

A labor dispute resulted in the sudden closing yesterday of the Park Avenue Theatre, 487 Park Avenue, and the postponement until further notice of the local premiere of the British film, "The End of the River," starring Sabu.

A great many persons, including examples of the worthy and public spirited, contribute to a great aberration. In the interviews which celebrate their birthdays, and the memoires with which they sum up gracefully, they say they profit from reading in bed.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The National Labor Relations Board reported today that for the sixth consecutive month the number of cases received and elections conducted set new records.

WASHINGTON, June 16 --Violation of the Lobby Act was charged against four persons, including the Agricultural Commissioners of Texas and Georgia, and two farm organizations, in an indictment handed down by a Federal grand jury today.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The aviation industry will require from eighteen months to two years to reach the "mass-production" period of war planes ordered under the new defense schedule, according to a synopsis of industrial calculations made available here today.

Louis Aronson has purchased the three five-story apartment houses at 1203-09 Westchester Avenue and 1821 Longfellow Avenue, the Bronx, in a transaction negotiated by Herbert Charles Co. as brokers. The Westchester Avenue property was sold by the Lynn Realty Corporation and the Longfellow Avenue property by the Rod Rose Holding Corporation. Julius Perlbinder is president of both of the selling groups.

Mayor O'Dwyer renewed yesterday his assault upon the State Administration for its refusal to share directly with the cities of the state the $700,000,000 state surplus built up during war years of record state income.

New York has added another sprig to its sheaf of municipal leaderships by outdoing London in excessive use of motor horns, according to findings presented yesterday by Ernest H. Peabody, president of the League for Less Noise, 580 Fifth Avenue, and a member of the advisory committee of the National Noise Abatement Council.

Too many advertisements are "handsomely dressed smoothies, superficial and boastful," John Orr Young, pioneer advertising man, who is now a public relations counsel, declared last night at the "Democracy Awards" dinner held by the advertising chapter, American Veterans Committee, in the Plaza Hotel.
Richard H. Mansfield has resigned as a vice president of the Chase National Bank to become associated with John D. Rockefeller Jr., it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, June 16 -- The Cinematograph Exhibitors Association, representing independent concerns in Britain, protested today at its conference at Douglas, Isle of Man, against the increase in the quota of British motion pictures that must be shown here, beginning Oct. 1.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 16 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council defeated an attempt by the Soviet Union today to revive part of the partition plan for Palestine.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 16 -- Willie Turnesa of Knollwood, back in home territory a week, won the William Rice Hochster memorial tourney by one stroke at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club today by holing a birdie 3 at the last green for a thirty-six-hole total of 147.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander occupied the witness stand in Supreme Court all yesterday and defended his drive against pin ball gambling. He testified in an action brought by four manufacturers or distributors of the machines who are seeking to restrain him from carrying on the drive.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg refused today to give the word of availability that supporters are seeking to get an open boom under way for him for the Republican Presidential nomination.

The 680 pupils attending Public School 116, all of whom have perfect tooth records, were honored yesterday for their achievement by the Board of Education and the Community Service Society, which presented to each student a hardearned "varsity letter" -- T for teeth.

The board of directors of the Todd Shipyards Corporation yesterday elected John D. Reilly as president for the seventeenth consecutive year at a meeting in the corporation's offices at 1 Broadway. At a stockholders meeting earlier in the day Mr. Reilly and E.P. Enfer, the treasurer, were elected to four-year terms on the board of directors.

Tankers have started pumping into naval depots millions of gallons of fuel oil to repay the loans from Navy stocks which took the edge off distress last winter for East Coast families during the worst period of severe cold and oil shortage.

LONDON, June 16 -- The British Government will be sounded out on the absorption of Northern Ireland by the Government of Ireland [Eire] during talks scheduled here between top Irish and British officials, Prime Minister John Costello of Ireland said today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 16 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie said today that he was working on the specific details of his proposal for a small United Nations guard force, which would operate pending the establishment of a larger international force.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 16 -- Hopes of an eventual, though not an immediate, compromise settlement in Palestine were raised at United Nations headquarters by the report received today from Count Folke Bernadotte that the Arab League had named a liaison committee to go to Rhodes next week to take part in mediation efforts.

SAARBRUECKEN, Germany, June 16 -- Complicated reasons have been advanced for the nimble leap of the Saar district into the French field of influence since the liberation. The most plausible explanation seems to be that the people of the Saar chose the French economy in the reasonable conviction that Germany was finished and that France offered them more.

Two six-story buildings at 62-64 Worth Street and 31-33 Thomas Street, in the downtown textile district, were sold by Sophie G. Kernis, nominee of Charles F. Noyes, and Samuel Levy and associates to Greenwood Mills. Inc., now with offices in 35 Thomas Street.

His health steadily improving as he makes daily visits to the offices of the Twentieth Century S.C., Promoter Mike Jacobs yesterday gave quite definite indications of a favorable trend in the protracted convalescence period he has undergone.

LONDON, June 16 -- The British Government through its High Commissioner in Malaya is taking immediate and energetic steps to counteract a politically inspired wave of crime and violence now raging throughout the Peninsula, Arthur Creech Jones, Colonial Secretary, indicated today in the House of Commons.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The House Expenditures Committee demanded today that four former Capone gangsters, free on parole, be sent back to Federal prison. It made a point of identifying two lawyers who represented the men, as "personal" friends respectively of President Truman and Attorney General Tom Clark.

In your issue of June 9 there appears a letter from an employe of the Internal Revenue Bureau in which he makes a comparison of pending bills to increase the pay of postal employes as against other Federal employes.

Because "increased interest in instalment credit makes it necessary for bankers to have an intimate knowledge of this type of lending," the American Bankers Association has issued a bank-operating manual on the subject, according to an announcement by Lehman Plummer, chairman of the group's consumer credit committee.

Net sales of the Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries increased 9.9 per cent to $95,327,496 in the quarter ended on April 30 last, from $86,726,583 transacted in the corresponding three month of 1947, according to the report of operations issued yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, June 16 (AP) -- A four-hit eighth inning attack by the Browns, including doubles by Al Zarilla and Paul Lehner, gave them a 6-to-5 victory in a seesaw battle with the Senators tonight. Both clubs hit freely in the eighth and the Senators threatened in the top of the ninth but Al Widmar came in and set Washington down after two men reached base.

Forest Avenue, in the underprivileged Morrisania section of the Bronx, had it first outdoor art exhibit yesterday and the neighborhood turned out en masse to inspect -- and then to admire -- the paintings and sculpture turned out by its younger citizens.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 16 -- Warning against increased censorship by Government officials, Dr. Luther H. Evans, head of the Library of Congress, charged today that there was a growing tendency for "bureaucrats" in Washington to place information formerly available to all in the secret or restricted category.

First of many, many mistakes the Giants made yesterday was in not postponing their game with the Pirates. Intermittent sprinkling of rain during the morning and early afternoon would have provided justification for such a step.

Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, majority leader of the United States Senate and among the leading Republican Presidential possibilities, declared yesterday that America should spend less for foreign relief.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The House voted tentatively 156 to 88, this evening to reduce from two years to one year the period of service for men 19 through 25 years of age who would be inducted under the pending stop-gap selective draft bill.
JERUSALEM, June 16 -- Israeli and Arab military commanders in the city of Jerusalem late this afternoon signed maps delimiting areas under Israeli and Arab control.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Two Senate Committees investigating the "Voice of America," Government foreign information program, were in agreement tonight that the idea behind the broadcasting project was a sound one but that its administration required a serious overhauling.

TAMIMENT, Pa., Thursday, June 17 -- The international executive board of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, ordered early today that local unions involved in strike threats as a result of their failure to file non-Communist affidavits under the Taft-Hartley law be required to take a secret ballot among their members on whether to comply with the law.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The House mauled its stop-gap draft bill today into a condition in which, it was asserted in highly concerned defense circles, there remained in it "no draft at all." A final decision, by calling of the roll, was postponed until tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The President's hopeful joviality as he exchanges rear-platform banter with the crowds is not shared by many Democratic politicians. They are apprehensive, not only that his foreshadowed nomination for a full White House term will end in overwhelming defeat, but that it will break some of their strongest organizations in the big cities, and this result would hit the bosses much harder than the loss of the Presidency.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Senate passed late tonight, 79 to 3, a bill for a new long-term farm program sharply reducing the present price supports for basic agricultural commodities. The measure must now confront an unwelcoming prospect in the House, which already had abandoned all thought of new and fundamental farm legislation and had passed a simple extension of the present program.

ASCOT, England, June 17 (AP) -- Marcel Boussac's Arbar won the two-and-a-half-mile Ascot Gold Cup today. The 4-year-old French horse won for its owner the trophy valued at $500 and the major share of the $43,500 added purse.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Active buying of July wheat by a cash interest gave that delivery a strong upturn today on the Board of Trade, but the other months were in slower demand. Hedge selling increased moderately, but was still comparatively light, and was readily absorbed.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Prospects that the United States will have this year the second largest wheat crop in its history resulted today in allowing Latin America and the Philippines to buy all the flour that they want from this country.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 17 -- Three dozen sailing yachts between 35 and 72 feet length on deck are expected to start from here on Saturday in the race to Bermuda, a thrash of 635 miles out across the Gulf Stream. Most of them were here today undergoing inspection by the sailing committee of the Cruising Club, which will sponsor the contest.

LONDON, June 17 -- Winston Churchill called on Prime Minister Attlee tonight at 10 Downing Street and after ninety minutes of friendly conversation won from Mr. Attlee and Foreign Secretary Bevin a promise that they would consider the resolutions adopted at the recent United Europe conference at The Hague.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 -- With fifty-seven nations now in its fold the International Labor Organization opened its thirty-first conference here today and was hailed by President Truman as "an important bulwark of our machinery for international cooperation."

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., June 17 -- The educational value of a personal visit to a world heavyweight champion in training is beyond comprehension -- totally beyond comprehension. The assorted experts take a careful gander and usually bob up with conflicting opinions. Joe Louis looked good today for three rounds of sparring.
The Yugoslav liner Radnik, boycotted by anti-Communist longshoremen who have refused to load the ship at her Brooklyn pier, was taking on cargo yesterday with her own crew members doing the work.
Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday at City Hall that he had ordered an inquiry into "pricing practices" in the local milk industry.

Building codes, often blamed for retarding development and slowing production in the housing industry, were defended yesterday by Frank H. Alcott, representing the National Lumber Manufacturers Association, at the New York State Building Officials Conference in the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- A Senate-House conference committee agreed on an emergency displaced-person bill this evening, but only after a prolonged and bitter contest and harsh dissents from four members who refused to sign the agreement and two who did so "reluctantly."

The rails assumed the lead yesterday in the stock market and moved to within a few cents of the year's high, but the pivotal industrials were hampered by lack of interest and final prices proved mixed. Gains of a point and more were general among the carriers and some of the oils showed major increases, but the combined averages only had an edge of 0.01 point.

The Committee for Justice and Peace in the Holy Land yesterday urged American Zionists, both Christians and Jews, to "gravely consider the great growth of feeling in this country against the extreme Zionist pressure here." It warned against this pressure "with its insistence on separate Jewish nationalism, as causing danger of disruption of our national unity and encouraging anti-Semitism."

LONDON, June 17 -- The new quotas of British films that movie theatres here must show are neither fantastic nor unfair, as has been alleged in the United States, Harold Wilson, president of the Board of Trade, told the House of Commons tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Truman is expected to intervene in the coal-contract dispute within forty-eight hours, it was disclosed by informed sources today. The President will name a board of inquiry to investigate the dispute, paving the way to ask Attorney General Tom C. Clark to seek an eighty-day injunction under the Taft-Hartley Act.

PARIS, June 17 -- It was widely agreed in informed circles here that the National Assembly's qualified and reluctant approval of the London accord on Western Germany early today would change neither the French nor the Western Allies' policy in the near future.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 17 -- The United States industrial system will be seriously undermined if big business and small business are not permitted to function normally, Henry B. du Pont, vice president of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., said here tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 (AP) -- Stan Musials triple with the bases loaded and two out in the eighth inning gave the Cardinals a 4-1 triumph over the Phillies tonight. Musical also scored on Whitey Kurowski's single.

A four-year research program on the physical and chemical characteristics of wool will be undertaken jointly by the Textile Research Institute, the American Wool Council and the International Wool Secretariat, it was announced yesterday.

A merger of the Food Machinery Corporation and the Westvaco Chemical Corporation has been agreed upon by the managements of the companies, according to an announcement made yesterday by Paul L. Davies, president of Food Machinery, and by William B. Thom, president of Westvaco.

Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the Zionist Organization of America, in a press conference at the Brevoort Hotel, asserted yesterday that Great Britain "is definitely behind Count Bernadotte's spectacular attempt to organize a world-wide embargo on Jewish Immigration to Israel."
Thousands of New Yorkers thronged Times Square last night to witness the lighting up of their newest and gaudiest toy: the colossal commercial sign atop the Bond clothing store.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee today disposed of two delegate disputes, but postponed until tomorrow its decision on four others. To be decided are contests in Georgia, South Carolina, Mississippi and Alaska.

CLEVELAND, June 17 -- The Negro Newspaper Publishers Association declared at its annual meeting today that a crisis has been brought about in the Negro press by the rising costs of labor, newsprint and distribution. The association said that this condition has not been met adequately by new sources of advertising income or circulation revenue.

The State Department will be asked to make a "vigorous" protest to the British Government against the recently announced 45 per cent film quota and also to request negotiations to "reduce or eliminate" the new restrictions, it was announced yesterday by the Motion Picture Export Association, 546 Fifth Avenue.
WASHIGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Business stocks on hand failed to increase in April after gaining through the first three months of the year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

ABOARD PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S TRAIN AT INDIANAPOLIS, June 17 -- Attacking the "Republican leadership" directly, President Truman tonight accused it of resorting to parliamentary subterfuges to block the comprehensive housing program he had recommended on Feb. 23.
Random notes.

TAMIMENT, Pa., June 17 -- In one of the most blistering denunciations of intra-union procedue in labor history, an appeal committee set up by the international executive board of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, condemned today the expulsion of three leaders of an anti-Communist faction by the Bloomingdale Department store local in New York.

An interfaith rally for Israel arranged by the Marine Park Community Citizens Committee and said by that organization to have been the first of its kind in New York and possibly in the country was held last night in Public School 207 at Fillmore Avenue and Coleman Streets, Brooklyn.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There has been a lot of publicity recently regarding child care. I would like to give my idea of how the situation could be relieved.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- House and Senate conferees were deadlocked tonight in their effort to settle differences over the European Recovery Program and other items in the $6,125,710,000 foreign aid appropriation.

Tammany Hall nominated Assemblyman John P. Morrissey, leader of the Tenth Assembly District middle yesterday as its candidate for Representative in the Eighteenth District against the incumbent, Vito Marcantonio. It was the first time in recent years that Mr. Marcantonio, beneficiary many times of the Democratic endorsement, failed to receive the blessings of the Tammany leaders in the area involved.

Knockdown, in his second victory since he took the Santa Anita Derby in 1946, led for every foot of the mile-and-a-sixteenth Queens County Handicap as Aqueduct's twenty-seven-day race session opened yesterday. The longest homestretch in the land wasn't long enough for Stymie; he finished second at 17 to 20 after having been last in the field of six to the head of the 1,520-foot straightaway.

Mrs. George Polk of Fort Worth, Tex., mother of George Polk, Columbia Broadcasting System correspondent who was murdered in Salonika, Greece, in May, charged yesterday that the Greek authorities were seeking to make the case a personal affair.

JERUSALEM, June 17 -- Gershon Hirsch, a Jewish Agency spokesman, charged today that the Arab Legion was "stocking up men and materials in the Old City of Jerusalem'' while the Security Council's Truce Commission concerned itself "mainly with control of the Jews."

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 -- Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, and candidate for the Republican nomination for President, declared today that he would be third on the first ballot at the Republican National Convention and first on the last ballot.

Spectacular records in magnesium consumption for household products are being attained, T. W. Atkins, executive vice president of the Magnesium Association, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, revealed yesterday, following a report of production and distribution studies reviewed by its board of directors in a meeting in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Registering the largest weekly advance since Nov. 12, commercial, industrial, and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $69,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday.
The annual report of the Singer Manufacturing Company, manufacturer of sewing machines, disclosed yesterday a net profit of $13,707,536 after taxes and all charges for the year ended last Dec. 31.

GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., June 17 -- Forrest P. Gates of Gates Mills, Inc., leather glove company of Johnstown, N.Y., was nominated as president of the National Association of Leather Glove Manufacturers for 1948-49 at the meeting of the association's directors held this afternoon in the Johnstown Hotel.
JERUSALIM, June 17 -- The Arabs have agreed to the opening of a new lifeline to Jerusalem to substitute for the present by Agency "Burma Road," which is hardly beyond the mule pack stage.

A Government survey of the present status of steel allocations for exports will be completed by the end of the month, Morris Rosoff, general counsel of the National Association of Steel Exporters, Inc., and an industry committee of four exporters asserted following a conference with Secretary of Commerce Charles W. Sawyer at his offices in Washington yesterday.

Two new films will open in first-run theatres today. At the Ambassador, the arrival is "Lysistrata," an Austrian-made version of the classic Greek comedy, with Judith Holzmeister in the title role and Paul Kemp as her husband. The picture, reportedly the first made in the American zone of Vienna to be seen here, was directed by Alfred Stoger from an adaptation by Kaspar Loser.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 17 The United Nations Trusteeship Council set a major precedent today by rejecting for the first time the demand of a petitioner for an oral hearing.

BOONTON, N.J., June 17 -- Despite a 4-over-par 8 on the second hole, Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches added another 81 to her first-round 81 for 162 as the second round of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's medal play championship was concluded over The Knoll course today.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Dollar volume of consumer credit is likely to continue to increase this year, Thomas W. Rogers, executive vice president of the American Finance Conference, informed members of the National Association of Music Merchants meeting here in their annual convention.

Passenger railroad trackage regarded as unique in the United States -- that connecting Philadelphia, Baltimore and Washington -- will be a factor in appraising the going market price next week for the forthcoming issue of $17,570,000 of general mortgage long-term bonds of the railroad of the same name.

PARIS, June 17 -- While the strike-bound rubber factory in Clermont-Ferrand was relatively quiet today, it appeared clear that the Government had narrowly emerged from a foreign-policy crisis only to face a graver crisis over wages and prices.

The "Z" turn, the "butterfly" fold and the sprinkle-shake are not new dance steps but some of the scientific short cuts to ironing described in a new booklet just published by the Proctor Electric Company. Every motion necessary in the sprinkling, folding and ironing of articles found in the family washbasket is outlined in "Ironing Can Be Easy."

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Truman has signed the bill under which a national heart institute will be added to the group of research laboratories of the National Institute of Health, in Bethesda, Md. Other specialized research institutes in the great health center operated by the Public Health Service are the National Cancer Institute and the National Mental Health Institute.

LOS ANGELES, June 16 -- Classified advertising, "the peoples' own part of the paper," is an excellent public relations channel for the newspaper industry, the annual convention of the Association of Newspaper Classified Advertising Managers was told today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 17 -- Leatrice Joy, star of the silent screen, who retired from films in 1931, has been signed by Eagle- Lion to resume her career in "Red Stallion in the Rockies," with Arthur Fields (known on Broadway as Arthur Franz).

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The armed services have expressed appreciation to Portugal for "generous assistance and cooperation" through the extension for five years of transit facilities for United States military aircraft at Lagens airfield in the Azores, it was announced today.

American Airlines will save a minimum of $20,000 annually by adoption of suggestions for new plane mockup devices for pilot and mechanic training, Patricia von Schmidt, assistant to Helen Abbott, chief of the company suggestion systems department, disclosed yesterday.

The Cities Service Company and subsidiaries had a net income of $19,976,576, equal to $5.40 a share for each of the 3,702,000 common shares outstanding, for the first quarter of 1948, according to announcement yesterday that the report had been filed with the Guaranty Trust Company, trustee for debentures of the company, as required by the indenture.

Despite installation of about 4,600,000 kilowatts of new generating capacity this year -- a record which has not been approached since 1924 when the private utilities installed 3,800,000 kilowatts -- the national power supply situation will continue "tight but adequate,'' according to Charles E. Oakes, president of the Edison Electric Institute.

WSTBURY, L.I., June 17 -- Rudolph (Polly) Sipe suffered a broken right leg and possible internal injuries tonight during the fifth race, a one-mile pace, at Roosevelt Raceway. Driving Oxheart, owned by T.L. Gustin of Philadelphia, Sipe was in a collision with How John and Lady Gracious on the backstretch.

Led to believe that a three-run first inning was only the precursor of better things to come, the Dodgers allowed themselves to be hypnotized into defeat by the Reds in the closing game of their series at Ebbets Field yesterday.

Bronx authorities arrested a young man yesterday morning who is alleged to have defrauded twenty-five persons of at least $200,000 on the pretext that he could turn a 50 per cent profit in the gray market in steel for every $1 they invested.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The opening of the Stadium concerts on Monday, June 14, had much less of the extracurricular diversion of roaring motors and planes overhead. This was due to the cooperation of the Port of New York Authority, which operates La Guardia Airport; the Civil Aeronautics Administration, and the airlines.

While a Congressional Conference Committee met for a showdown on funds for the Foreign Aid Program, slashed by the House but largely restored by the Senate, Secretary of State Marshall presented before the House Foreign Affairs Committee a new summary of the world situation and thanked it for the fine job it has done in connection with that program. The thanks are well deserved.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 17 -- Describing library services in this country as "woefully inadequate," delegates attending the sixty-seventh annual American Library Association conference reported that 70,000,000 Americans either have no library facilities, or are but partially served.

Plans for promoting here a new color printing process developed by McCorquodale Co., Ltd., one of Great Britain's largest graphic arts concerns, were announced here yesterday by James C. Sanderson, a company director.

BOSTON, June 17 (AP) -- The Boston Braves once again took over the National League lead today, coming from behind twice to beat the cellar-shackled Chicago Cubs, 7 -- 6 and 8 -- 7, in a Bunker Hill holiday twin bill witnessed by 24, 714 fans.

Fifth Avenue's suburban corner at Forty-eighth Street, where country cottages are displayed for good causes, was the scene of a quaint ceremony yesterday as a new "dream house" was opened for the New York Heart Association drive for $250,000.

GENEVA, June 17 -- A curious parallelism between the monetary policy of the Soviet Union and the monetary experiences of Western European countries over the past thirty years has been brought to light by the Bank for International Settlements in its latest annual report.

I The Title Guarantee and Trust Company, 176 Broadway, which with three of its officials, was found guilty Wednesday of conspiring to issue false information other banking establishments, announced yesterday that it was covered by $250,000 worth of fraud insurance.

The S W Fine Foods, Inc., West Coast food packers and distributors, sold their recently completed branch warehouse at 370-380 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, to the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States for an indicated consideration of $875,000 and took back a long-term lease on the property.

ALBANY, June 17 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey returned to Albany today seemingly confident that his talks with other Republican state executives at the annual Conference of Governors had paved the way for his nomination for President on an early ballot.
Newark, N.J., announced yesterday that it will receive bids until June 29 on bond issues totaling $3,635,000. Dated July 15, 1948, the bonds will come due on each July 15, 1949 to 1968.
Edward R. Parker, New York securities broker and a civic leader in Metuchen, N.J., was permanently barred from the securities business in this state by the Supreme Court yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 17 -- Preston (Tex) Moore, medalist who paced Lawrenceville to the team championship in the Eastern Interscholastic Golf Association tournament at Greenwich Country Club during 36 holes of qualifying on Tuesday and Wednesday, moved into the quarter-finals as match play opened with completion of two rounds today.

OBERLIN, Ohio, June 17 -- Miss Helen Kenyon of New York was unanimously elected today to the Moderatorship of the General Council of the Congregational Christian Churches of the United States. The first woman to receive the denomination's highest honor, Miss Kenyon succeeded the Rev. Dr. Albert W. Palmer of California.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 17 -- Robinson Murray of Westchester Hills, Westchester Seniors' Golf Association champion, annexed low gross in the association's annual spring tournament at Hudson River with 40, 39 -- 79.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Democratic party is entering the Presidential campaign this year with about twice as much in the till as it had in 1944 and with party officials highly optimistic about fund-raising between now and election day.

PRAGUE, June 17 (UP) -- Premier Antonin Zapotooky said today that Czechoslovakia's entire industrial and agricultural system would be reconstructed "to eliminate every vestige of the capitalistic system."

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The House, completing a history-making clean sweep by Congress of three vetoes in four days, passed the Reed-Bulwinkle Bill over President Truman's objections today and then finished laying the groundwork for dealing the Chief Executive another defeat on the public housing issue.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 17-Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Pratt of Still Pond Farm gave a supper dance this evening to present to society Mrs. Pratt's daughter, Miss Ethel L. Manville. The party took place in an outdoor ballroom erected for the occasion with the dancing floor covered with a gay hued marquee studded with opalescent lights.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Every day I commute by car to the main office of the Tolstoy Foundation in New York City. The other day I had with me two displaced persons -- Russian intellectuals -- an old man of 71 years of age with his elderly wife. They came to this country six months ago. Their cousin, who gave them an affidavit of support, died after their arrival here.

The world Conference of Religion for Moral and Spiritual Support of the United Nations presented yesterday a gloomy picture of modern civilization as the 50-year-old product of an unsound materialistic philosophy. It prescribed as an antidote the renascence of religion, the family, home and school as the surest bases for human survival.

Visitors to the exhibit of the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, opening to the public today, will be surprised to find only two costumes on display, the main part of the showing consisting of seventeen magnificent portraits dating back some fifty years.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Senate approved a $6,915,676,052 spending program for the Army, Air Force and related defense agencies tonight.

A former tenant investigator for Stuyvesant Town who had reneged on promises to obtain apartments after persons gave him $1,350 was sentenced yesterday to six months in the workhouse. He had pleaded guilty June 8 in Special Sessions to a twelve-count information.

Fall women's ready-to-wear prices in the Montgomery Ward Co. catalog to be issued next month are listed at the same levels as those of last fall, high company officials disclosed here yesterday. In addition to maintaining price levels, it was stated, quality has been stepped up considerably in many lines.

William A. Brady, dean of theatrical producers and a rugged individualist, will observe his eighty-fifth birthday tomorrow. Nothing special will commemorate the event, he said. It will be just another day. In the past he used to be an avid reader of the Congressional Record.

BAY SHORE, L. I., June 17 -- A preview of the newest suburban unit of Hearn Department Stores, Inc., was held this afternoon with Leonard Ginsberg, president, and other officials welcoming city and local newspaper representatives who inspected the large one-floor structure here on Fourth Avenue, off Main Street.
Stockholders of the El Paso Natural Gas Company will be asked soon to approve sale of $56,000,000 of securities to finance an expansion program, it has been disclosed by Paul Kayser, president.

MOUNT CARMEL, Pa., June 17 -- A United Air Lines DC-6 passenger plane crashed and burned on a sparsely wooded hillside three miles northeast of here at 1:41 P.M. Eastern Daylight time today, killing all of its thirty-nine passengers and crew of four.

CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) -- The world welterweight championship bout between Ray (Sugar) Robinson, the titleholder, and challenger Bernard Docusen, set for tonight, has been postponed because of rain until Monday night, Promoter Irving Kovin announced.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y. June 17 -- The United States convinced the United Nations Security Council today not to try to pass judgment on responsibility for the latest breakdown in Dutch-republican political negotiations in Indonesia.

SEOUL. Korea, June 17 -- In response to demands by Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, United States commander in Korea, that the Soviet Union accept payments for electric power and restore current to south Korea, the Soviet north Korea commander, Guards Major Gen. S.P. Merkulov, charged in a letter that the American misrepresented the facts.

Approval by representatives of three Governors of a large new park area where New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts come together is a constructive step. In a region of mountain and plateau more than 30,000 acres would be set aside under a long-term joint project which would further both the conservation of natural resources and the recreational facilities of the three states.

BERLIN, June 17 -- Two new political parties, the Democratic Farmers party and the National Democratic party, have been licensed in the Soviet zone by the Soviet Military Administration, according to an announcement today by the Soviet news bureau.
CHICAGO, June 17 (UP) -- Bobby Locke registered nine one-putt greens to card a course-record 65 -- six under par -- for the first round lead in the $15,000 Chicago Victory golf championships today.
The Board of Standards and Appeals has approved a change in its regulations that will permit home owners here to install a second 275-gallon fuel oil tank in their homes, it was learned yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, June 17 -- Negotiations between India and Hyderabad, independent princely state, have broken down and India will strengthen her economic blockade of the principality, Prime Minister Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru indicated at a press conference tonight.

LONDON, June 17 (AP) -- Ranking tennis players seeded in the forthcoming Wimbledon tournament won their way today to all semifinal berths in the men's and women's singles of the London tennis championships at the Queen's Club.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 17 -- Although the Russians have described the projected Western German government as illegal, Communist parties in the Western zones will campaign for seats in the Constituent Assembly and for places in the subsequent parliament.

Untangling the "great American tax jungle" will be one of the foremost problems faced by the next Federal administration, Alger B. Chapman, president of the State Tax Commission, declared here yesterday.

LEESBURG, Va., June 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Whitney of Upperville, widely known horsewoman and the former wife of John Hay (Jock) Whitney, and Dr. E. Cooper Person Jr. of New York, obtained a marriage license at the office of the Loudoun County Clerk of Courts this afternoon.

Payments made in May by Latin-American concerns as a group against obligations connected with imports from the United States were slowest in a year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The latter's monthly study is based on the experience of the twelve New York City banks that make regular returns to it.

New York is "the greatest natural set in the world" and Holly,wood should take advantage of it, Edward C. Maguire, Commerce Commissioner, yesterday told members of the Associated Motion Picture Advertisers. Speaking at a luncheon at the Astor Hotel marking the iduction of AMPA officers for 1948-49, Mr. Maguire, who is Mayor O'Dwyer's motion-picture coordinator, said that the, city's codes governing filming in the streets were being rewritten to further expedite matters.

LOS ANGELES, June 17 -- The Association of Newspaper Classified Advertising Managers today formulated a plan for the creation of "coordinators" between it and the respective newspaper publishing associations in each of the forty-eight states and the Canadian provinces.
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., June 17 (AP) -- Yale University tonight became the Eastern N.C.A.A. baseball champion for the second straight year by defeating Lafayette, 4 to 3.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Edmond E. Lincoln's letter published June 3 seems to call for comment.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 17 -- The machinery for selecting the United States Olympic track and field squad will be set in motion tomorrow, when the twenty-seventh annual National Collegiate Athletic Association championships get under way in the University of Minnesota's vast Memorial Stadium.

OXFORD, Ohio, June 17 -- Latin textbooks and methods of teaching need "wholesale revision" for a realistic approach to the study of the subject, declared Dr. Norman J. Dewitt of Washington University, St. Louis, Mo., at the thirtieth anniversary meeting of the American Classical League today on the Miami University campus here.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 17 -- Fifty United Nations employes, including twenty-eight members of its uniformed guard force, will leave by air for Palestine Saturday to help supervise compliance with the four-week cease-fire and truce, it was announced today.
LONDON, June 17 -- The spread of the London dock strike, fears of wage troubles in the engineering industry and the general unsettled state of world politics depressed the stock market here today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: No one need search very far to discover what is wrong with the United Nations. Like the League at Geneva and all other attempts of men to play God, it is expedient in character. For example, it is reasonable and practical and starkly expedient for the U.N. to fire all of its employes who have reached 60.
Twenty-six thousand employes of the Consolidated Edison Company in New York and Westchester County have received an average wage increase of 11 cents an hour, it was announced last night.
GENEVA, June 17 -- The responsibility has been given to the United States for meeting about 18 per cent of the budget of the International Civil Aviation Organization.

LONDON, June 17 -- The first day's talks on a new trade treaty between Britain and Ireland were conducted "in a friendly spirit," a joint statement announced tonight. Negotiations will continue tomorrow when Ireland is to press her claims for higher prices and a wider market for her agricultural exports to Britain.

Maj. Gen. Francis B. Wilby, retired, former Commandant of the United States Military Academy, was elected last night as commander of New York Chapter, Military Order of the World Wars. The election at the New York Yacht Club followed a. dinner attended by 200 present and former officers of the Armed Forces.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The Senate Commerce Committee today agreed to make a last-minute attempt to push a ship subsidy bill through Congress before the scheduled adjournment Saturday.
GRENLOCH, N.J., June 17 -- It must be with style and speed that Jersey Joe Walcott hopes to lift the world heavyweight title from Joe Louis next Wednesday night at the Yankee Stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities asserted today that the real menace of communism lay in the fact that, for every member of the Communist party, "ten others are ready, willing and able" to do the party's work.

The ingenuity of a subway coin change clerk and the cooperation of 200 passengers beat transit emergency crews yesterday in effecting the quick rescue of a woman whose right leg was wedged between the IRT Lexington Avenue Eighty-sixth Street station platform and the first car of a southbound express train.

Of the total net profits of national banks in the continental United States during 1947, 60 per cent was plowed back into capital funds, according to the annual report of the National Bank Division of the American Bankers Association, issued recently.

The Board of Estimate, by authorizing the creation of two new executive posts in the Welfare Department, moved to cooperate with Raymond M. Hilliard, Welfare Commissioner, in his announced determination to reorganize the department to obtain more efficient administration of its relief and associated activities.

CLEVELAND, June 17 (AP) -- The resurgent Boston Red Sox handed the league-leading Cleveland Indians their fourth straight loss today, beating the faltering Tribe, 8 -- 6, for a sweep of the three-game series.

The Board of Estimate is scheduled to approve at a special meeting this afternoon a plan under which six private bus lines in Queens and the bus and street car lines of the Surface Transportation Corporation and the Third Avenue Transit Corporation in the Bronx will issue and honor transfers between their routes and city subway lines.

America's manufactured products are the best foreign ambassadors for this country, and the low-cost distribution systems developed here create world-wide advantages which are more powerful than any totalitarian propaganda.

GENEVA, N. Y., June 17 -- Robert T. Lansdale, State Commissioner of Welfare, today called for a comprehensive review of the programs of the public and private welfare agencies of the state to determine what share of community needs should be met by voluntary agencies and what share should be assumed by public agencies.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Friday, June 18 -- The Bizonal Economic Council went into a midnight session last night in an effort to pass legislation the leaders described as "urgent in connection with currency reform."

The Giants hit four homers, a triple, double, four singles and a new low yesterday at the Polo Grounds. For, despite round-trippers by Johnny Mize, Bill Rigney, Bobby Thomson and Willard Marshall, Mel Ott's men bowed, 9 -- 8, to the Pirates and suffered their fourth straight setback.
The sovereignty of John Kramer's tennis on turf, undisputed since his defeat by Jaroslav Drobny at Wimbledon in 1946, hung perilously in the balance yesterday at Forest Hills.
Cotton futures were moderately active yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and final prices were 6 to 18 points net higher.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 17 -- Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, secretary general of the Arab League, declared today that if the powers succeeded in imposing an independent Jewish state in the Middle East it would create chaos from which only the Russians could benefit.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 17 -- Reflecting the demand for more glass in homes and automobiles, flat glass production stands at an all-time high as mid-1948 approaches, John D. Biggers, president of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company, said today.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Admiral Raymond A. Spruance, who commanded naval forces in the battles of Midway and the Philippines and in the capture of the Gilberts, Marshalls, Saipan, Guam, Tinian, Iwo Jima and Okinawa, will retire at his own request July 1, the Navy said today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 17 -- The Commission on Human Rights prepared tonight to wind up its third session here, leaving unfinished the major part of its work but satisfied generally that it had made progress.

Friends and relatives waited in vain yesterday for the arrival at La Guardia Field of the four-engine United Air Lines plane with forty-three persons aboard that [had crashed into a high-tension power line and burned near Mount Carmel, Pa.

Only through patient and understanding negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union can we regain "the mutual confidence which has been lost in the three calamitous years since the Axis powers were defeated," Dr. Albert Einstein declared last night.

A suit to halt the demolition of the Aquarium in Battery Park, on the ground that it would be contrary to a section of the City Charter, was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by Alexander Hamilton of 1 Sutton Place South, an officer of the American Scenic and Historical Preservation Society.

BERLIN, June 17 (UP) -- The Russians suddenly announced today they believed it was possible for them to reach an agreement with the United States, France and Britain on a single currency reform program for all of Germany.
Harry L. Margules, treasurer of Saks Co. and controller of Saks-34th, has in addition been appointed store manager to succeed Howard E. Lovett, who has resigned.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The United States and Great Britain usually do not go to much trouble to protect themselves from the perils of majority rule, but they certainly are engaged in that process these days.

While there are funds and sites available for a low-rent city housing project near Idlewild Airport, such a project if built would not bet primarily for airport personnel. This was announced yesterday by Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority who with other city officials is studying the probable need and suitability of $16-a-room-a-monthl apartments in the airport area.
PHILADELPHIA, June 17 -- In a statement sent to all Congressmen, the American Friends Service Committee today expressed irrevocable opposition to conscription for military service.

The Eightieth Congress succeeded in writing a new record into legislative history when the House voted, 297 to 102, to override President Truman's veto of the Bulwinkle railroad rate bill, sustaining a similarly one-sided vote in the Senate, for this marked the third time within a week that Congress had defied the President on major legislative issues.
CLEVELAND, June 17 (AP) -- The Indians will "sink or swim with Feller," said Manager Lou Boudreau today.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- During the week ended June 16, member bank reserve balances increased $845,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

MOUNT CARMEL, Pa., June 17 -- Scattered bits of torn and twisted airplane wreckage, charred trees and underbrush and a wrecked transformer on a high tension electric power line bore eloquent testimony tonight to the swift tragedy that snuffed out the lives of thirty-nine passengers, including two children, and all four members of the crew of a United Air Lines transcontinental plane.

Capt. Granville Conway, president of the Cosmopolitan Shipping Company, and former War Shipping Administrator has received two decorations from foreign governments this week in recognition of his aid to allied shipping during the war.

Medical rehabilitation for the civilian disabled took another step forward yesterday when the Institute of Rehabilitation and Physical Medicine opened formally its new interim quarters at 325 East Thirty-eighth Street.

The House of Representatives went yesterday from bad to worse on the Selective Service bill. Having adopted on Wednesday a political formula for its implementation and a crippling amendment limiting the period of service to one year instead of two, it yesterday practically gutted the original bill.

BERLIN, June 17 -- The Soviet Military Administration banged down an "iron curtain" on a number of border crossing points between Bavaria in the United States zone and the Soviet zone today and issued a new set of rules restricting German travel into the Russian-controlled area.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended June 12, 1948, totaled 906,948 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 85,735 cars, or 10.4 per cent more than for the preceding week, 11,656 cars, or 1.3 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 39,030 cars, or 4.5 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

An all-Wagner program, which attracted an audience of 6,800 persons, was presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Fritz Reiner last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. Two Metropolitan artists, Rose Bampton, soprano, and Set Svanholm, tenor, were the soloists, both of them appearing at these concerts for the first time.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Six major tests of Congressional sentiment on foreign policy beginning with 1945 have found the Congress backing the Administration's position, Senator Millard Tydings, Democrat, of Maryland, said today in a Senate speech citing these votes.

In a move to develop a nationwide uniform method by which newspapers present data to advertisers and agencies, the Bureau of Advertising, ANPA, announced yesterday that it is sending every daily paper a "pilot model" for a standard market and media data form.

While the standards set by the thirty-two nation Safety at Sea Convention, held recently in London, do not achieve the strict regulations of the United States, they were described yesterday as a distinct step forward in the International field by members of the United States delegation who arrived on the United States liner America.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Led by advances of more than 1 per cent for foods and for chemicals and allied products, primary market prices rose an average of 0.4 per cent during the week ended June 12, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As an inveterate reader of your newspaper, who finds it almost indispensable, I am alarmed by your sympathetic comment on the public housing provision which the House of Representatives leadership would remove from the housing bill now pending. The humanitarian note in your editorial seems to identify you with the "do-gooders" whom the Martin-Halleck-Taber leadership execrates.

NANKING, June 17 -- Largely ignored since his election as Vice President of China seven weeks ago, Gen. Li Tsung-jen has found it difficult to win acceptance for the reforms he advocated during his campaign.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 17 (UP) -- David Ben-Gurion, Prime Minister of the provisional government, today informed Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations Palestine mediator, that Israel would accept no solution of the Palestine problem that did not call for a Jewish state and unrestricted immigration.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 17 -- Joseph E. Johnson, deputy United States representative in the United Nations Little Assembly, today urged that such an interim committee of the peace organization be continued for at least another year.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., June 17 -- When a horse skidded into the rail near the scene where another lost his life because of the water-logged track, the jockeys decided they had enough today and refused any more mounts.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 -- The Republican resolutions committee began hearings today on its platform of political promises for 1948. The session was marked by a skirmish involving representatives from the Deep South who want to soft-pedal civil rights and race relations to take votes from President Truman among rebellious Southern Democrats.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 -- Waterfront employers and the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, resumed negotiations today in a two-hour meeting with William P. Halloran, Federal conciliation commissioner, in an effort to avert a maritime strike postponed by a court restraining order.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Secretary of State Marshall was represented in Congress today as feeling that any retreat from the present firm policy of the United States would be a grave mistake that might even lead to war.
EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 17 -- F.R. Ryan of the home club shot 40, 37 -- 77 to capture the Long Island Golf Association senior championship for the third time at Wheatley Hills today.

The five two-story buildings at 8502-12 Twentieth Avenue, Brooklyn, containing five stores, twelve apartments and a public market, have been sold by Albert Levy to Harry Glenefsky and Solomon Getzel. The combined property, assessed at $97,000, occupies a plot 100 by 105 feet.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Weekly department store sales were up 1 per cent for the week ended June 12 compared to the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Percentage changes from like periods of a year ago are indicated in the following table:

PORT TALBOT, Wales, June 16 (Delayed) -- The biggest steel plant under construction in Europe is well advanced here in this gateway to the "black country" of South Wales. The Abbey Works of the Steel Company of Wales is typical of the great plans that Britons are making despite their economic crisis.

LONDON, June 17 -- Jean Paul Sartre's new play, "Crime Passionel," which opened last night at the Lyric Theatre in Hammersmith, western London suburb, had most of the London critics leaving the theatre in rather a bewildered state.

Five members of a farmers mission from New South Wales, Australia, completed yesterday a five-month survey of agriculture in the United States and Canada. They reported, as they left to return home by way of Great Britain, that they had learned a great deal about agricultural advances here that would be of benefit to fellowfarmers in Australia.

LONDON, June 17 (AP) -- Corn Trade News, commenting today on the "shelving of the world wheat agreement" reached earlier this year in Washington, said both Australia and Argentina will be happy to see it go.

The Board of Estimate unanimously adopted yesterday the proposed local law to banish pinball machines from the city, as enacted by the City Council on Tuesday by a vote of 12 to 10, with only Democratic votes in the affirmative.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark announced today the indictment of eight wallpaper manufacturers, a trade association and six individuals on charges of conspiring to fix prices in violation of the anti-trust laws.
BEDFORD, Ind., June 17 -- Seventeen nations received today "cornerstones of freedom, as a token of friendship and the desire of freedom-loving countries to maintain a democratic way of life.

Members of the visiting Swedish Djurgarden and English Liverpool Football Clubs were feted last night by the Sportsmanship Brotherhood at the Waldorf-Astoria preparatory to their meeting tonight at Ebbets Field in Brooklyn. This will mark the first clash in this country of two outstanding foreign soccer teams.
TRENTON, N.J., June 17 -- Interlocking directorates and investment by one insurance company in the stock of another now are permitted under new legislation in New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The "Voice of America" plans to report the Republican and Democratic national conventions to overseas listeners as probably the biggest news in the United States at the time.

Novel abstract sculpture in plastics by Leo Amino at the Clay Club is one of the highlights of the week in local art galleries. Other shows include a first New York one-man exhibition of paintings by the eighth selection, Kyle Morris, at the Pepsi-Cola Opportunity Gallery, and a retrospective group show by gallery members at the Bertha Schaefer Gallery.

Our scouts in the fruit and vegetable markets and at the Fishery Council are the only ones who have encouraging information this weekend. With warm weather approaching, supplies of these foods are increasing. As for meat, turkey, eggs and butter, not only are prices higher than they were last Friday, but predictions are that they'll continue in an upward direction.

"Great Scenes From Great Plays" is scheduled to have its first performance on Oct. 1 over the Mutual network, with Walter Hampden starring in "Cyrano de Bergerac." Mr. Hampden also will be the regular host on the series.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Push-button warfare has invaded the deep-sea fishing field.

WASHINGTON, June l7 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee tonight struck from a House bill a provision which would have forced the retirement from the Navy's active list at the end of this month of Fleet Admirals Ernest J. King and Chester W. Nimitz.

The purchase by an investor of the sixteen-story and penthouse apartment building for 126 families at 400 East Fifty-eighth Street, southeast corner of First Avenue, from the 400 East Fifty-eighth Street Corporation was announced yesterday.

LONDON, June 17 -- Prices of raw cotton to British mills have fluctuated more sharply under buying by the government than they did at any time in the ten years preceding war when the Liverpool raw cotton exchange was operating, Oliver Lyttelton, Conservative charged in the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark today announced a court order against the White Cap Company of Chicago ending alleged "restraints of trade" in the process of sealing glass food containers.

CLEVELAND, June 17 (AP) -- Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company granted an eleven-cent hourly wage increase to 28,000 employes today in the second agreement within a week between the United Rubber Workers, affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and member of the tire industry's "Big Four."

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 17 -- California's delegates to the Republican national convention headed for Philadelphia on a special train today with their champion, Gov. Earl Warren, asserting that the Presidential nomination was "wide open."

A major problem affecting New Yorkers and their children's welfare has just been placed on the desk of Secretary of Agriculture Brannan. He must decide in the next few days whether or not to raise the price of milk destined for this city, weighing testimony presented at a hearing by dairy farmers and by spokesmen interested in New York's children.

In what was described by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan as the first arrest of its kind in this state, an East Side neighborhood physician was arraigned yesterday in Special Sessions and charged with selling an illegitimate baby to a married couple for $1,700.

MUNICH, Germany, June 17 -- Fritz Kuhn was back in the toils today after his escape from the Dachau internment camp in February. He was recaptured yesterday after he had tried to obtain a permit to operate a chemist's laboratory.

Bendix Home Appliances, Inc., has assured its distributors that it will not raise prices of its home laundry equipment despite recent advances in labor and materials costs, Gerald O. Kaye, general sales manager, Bruno-New York, Inc., Bendix metropolitan area distributor, disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Tracy S. Voorhees took his oath of office as assistant Secretary of the Army today. The oath was administered by Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall.

Designs for street safety posters won awards for fifteen students yesterday at the Automobile Club of New York, 28 East Seventy-eighth Street. Checks totaling $350 were presented on behalf of the club by Dr. Frederic Ernst, associate superintendent of New York City schools.

Before the concert starting the thirty-first season of the Goldman Band tonight at 8:30 on the Mall in Central Park, the Park Association's Annual Award will be presented to Harry F. Guggenheim, president of the Guggenheim Memorial Foundation, for his outstanding contribution to the people of the city through the park and recreational system.

The nursery set can now have custom-designed rugs of its own, with the introduction yesterday of shaggy cotton rugs that boast large motifs especially suitable for children's rooms. The rugs, shown by the Edward Fields Company, Inc., 509 Madison Avenue, are the first patterned ones to be made of Boucleweave, a cotton carpeting of tightly twisted loops that up to now has been available only in solid colors.
DETROIT, June 17 (AP) -- Thanks to three runs that crossed the plate on errors, the Philadelphia Athletics snapped a six-game Detroit winning streak today by beating the Tigers, 5 to 2.

Directors of the C.B. Fleet Company, Inc., pharmaceutical manufacturer, have elected Charles G. Baber president. Mrs. Elizabeth M. Forsyth and Mrs. Carolyn F. Diggs were elected vice presidents. Harry D. Forsyth has been elevated to secretary-treasurer.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 17 -- The interim Government is about to nationalize electric light and power companies throughout Costa Rica. Negotiations to this end have reached an advanced stage, it was revealed today.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 18 -- Mel Patton, the chief hope of the United States for a flat-race victory in the Olympics, passed his first tests today with flying colors as the twenty-seventh National Collegiate Athletic Association track and field championships got under way in wretched weather at the University of Minnesota's Memorial Stadium.

JERUSALEM, June 18 -- Isaac Gruenbaum, Israeli Minister of Interior, writing in the Jerusalem newspaper Hayom today, proposed that Jewish Jerusalem should become part of the State of Israel in any future revision of the United Nations partition decision of Nov. 29.

LONDON, June 18 -- The feature of otherwise quiet stock markets here today was the strength of British Government bonds. For the first time since it was issued, the 3 per cent British Electricity stock changed hands at more than its par value and closed 1/16 point above parity.

BOONTON, N.J., June 18 -Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches won the Women's New Jersey Golf Association 54-hole medal play championship by the slim margin of one stroke as she added a third-round 80 to her two previous 81's for a total of 242 over The Knoll course today.

Due to strong Father's Day promotions, sales volume in retail trade here for the week is expected to be the heaviest of the spring season. They were expected to exceed the largst previous week -Easter week -- by 2 to 3 per cent in dollar volume, according to estimates made here yesterday.

Informal serving pieces especially planned to prevent chowders from cooling during supper and to make it possible to bring aspics to the able in perfect form are highlights of new dinnerware designed by Mary Wright. The specially shaped serving pieces are part of a complete group of modern semivitreous dinnerware to be introduced Monday at Altman's.

On New York's East Side, in Thirtyeighth Street, is a five-story brick building owned by the Milbank Memorial Fund, which has housed in the past many notable experiments and demonstrations in public health and welfare. This week this building was rededicated to a new cause, when ceremonies were held marking the formal opening of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center's Institute of Rehabilitation and Physical Medicine.

A basic real estate tax rate of $2.89 on each $100 of assessed valuation for 1948-49, the same as for the current fiscal year, was assured yesterday. Controller Lazarus Joseph sent to the City Council a report in which he made a final estimate of $401,636,874 on the city's general fund revenue for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

PARIS, June 18 -- Communist and non-Communist unions in Clermont-Ferrand began today negotiations for ending the strikes there as the Government withdrew the national police, but many workers were expected to respond tomorrow to the Communist call for a one-hour sympathy strike throughout France as part of a campaign for a general wage increase.

ABERYSTWYTH, Wales, June 18 -- Welsh agriculture is meeting the Labor Government's high targets thus far and there is promise of a good harvest this year, and the same is true of the whole of Britain.

CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) -- Bobby Locke and his magic putter carved another six-under-par 65 over Midlothian's tricky greens today to give the South African star a recordbreaking 36-hole score of 130 halfway in the Chicago Victory open golf tournament.

LONDON, June 18 -- The Government is prepared to move troops into London's strike-bound docks to unload food cargoes if efforts to end the outlaw dockworkers' strike fail this week-end. Companies from Guards regiments would be sent to the docks.

Indiscriminate use of streptomycin, the most potent anti-tuberculosis drug known, can condition a patient so that he later succumbs to the disease when the same agent might have saved him, it was reported yesterday.

OBERLIN, Ohio, June 18 -- A new middle-of-the-road bloc of nations was advocated tonight by Dr. Liston Pope, Professor of Social Ethics at Yale Divinity School, as the "most Christian" approach to resolving the present SovietAmerican impasse.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The House unanimously passed today a bill to raise postal workers' pay $450 a year and offset part of the cost by increasing postal rates.

Sadie B.' Drucker, individuallyand as adm/nistratnx of the estateof Philip Drucker, sold the twostory four-family house at 1479East Second Street, Brooklyn, toRose Shumsky for cash above amortgage of $8,500. Harry A. Levine was the broker.

Mayor O'Dwyer sailed at 7:05 P.M. yesterday aboard the Agwidawn, a 6,125-ton freighter of the Agwi Line, for a vacation trip to Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic. He carried with him for shipboard study reports by his Executive Committee on Administration recommending extensive reorganizations in several city departments, including Health and Sanitation.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 5 to 10 points lower after a rather quiet trading session.

PARIS, June 18 -- France protested to the United States today against the introduction of clauses such as that demanding mostfavored-nation treatment for the United States occupation zones in Germany, Japan and Korea, in the bilateral treaty submitted here through the Economic Cooperation Administration.

The North River waterfront from Forty-eighth Street to Fiftyseventh Street was a snarl of private cars, taxicabs and trucks from 8:30 A. M. to 5 P. M., yesterday as two transatlantic liners sailed with capacity lists and a third docked in the nine-block area.

A non-advertiser for the past fifty years, the S. H. Kress Company, variety chain store, is setting a pattern for other chains with a test campaign in fourteen West Coast newspapers, it was announced yesterday. Techniques being used, according to the agency, the Blackstone Company, are being considered by other chains.

CLEVELAND, June 18 -- The Negro Publishers Association today asked for a larger share of advertising from big business. The aid from large advertisers was compared with the economic aid for small nations in discussions during the second day of the group's annual meeting here.
BERLIN, June 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of the official summary of Western Germany's currency reform program; announced today:

America must meet the challenge of industrializing the rest of the world by enlarging the principle of "partnership capitalism," aimed at preserving man's freedoms and dignity, Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, said last night.

Off to a 6-0 lead in the first inning -- it soared to 10 -- 0 in the fifth -- the Cardinals and Howie Pollet staggered to a 12-8 victory over the Giants yesterday at the Polo Grounds. Never in contention, the locals rallied for five runs in the ninth, but were embarrassed by their fifth straight setback.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- The International Harvester Company offered wage increases of 11 cents an hour today to unions representing its 61,000 production employes in twenty-one plants. It also announced that it would put into effect commensurate wage increases for 25,000 salaried employes, including office workers.

GENEVA, June 18 -- The possibility that Soviet crews may soon fly commercial planes into New York was foreseen today by an aviation expert who had recently spent many months studying developments of civil aviation in Eastern Europe.

Since the Office of Rent Control failed to use "appropriate language" to establish a minimum age for classifying a person as an "occupant" of rented housing, theh)0*0*0*iAppellate Term in Brooklyn found yesterday that a landlord could exact additional rent for a newborn child.

Rear Admiral Monroe Kelly, USN, commandant of the Third Naval District, received a gold star in lieu of a second Legion of Merit yesterday afternoon at a reception on the Astor Hotel roof. Admiral Thomas C. Kinkaid, commander of the Eastern Frontier, made the presentation.
