Sambee is its name; its admirers say it's "like drinking a fruit salad." H. Hicks Son, specialists in the ice cream soda, created it, then had to copyright the name, it proved so popular. Waistline whittlers in particular like it; it becomes lunch for them.

In a ruling that may have farreaching effects on the relations between international unions and their locals, Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora temporarily restrained yesterday the president of the International Association of Machinists from suspending the New York local's president.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A process for the automatic extraction of eggs from their shells, discharge of the latter and separation of the contents of each egg, with yolk intact, for inspection, testing and ultimate disposition, was one of 414 inventions patented this week by the United States Patent Office.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -The Department of Commerce estimated today the United States will provide $7,500,000,000 in aid to foreign nations during 1948.
Middlesex County, N. J., r.nnounced yesterday that it would receive bids July 11 on bond issues totaling $532,000. Dated July '5, 1948, the bonds will come due July 15 from 19,:9 to 1963.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 18 -Sunny skies and light breezes, overcast and showers. Such were some of the weather predictions for the start of the yacht race tomorrow for Bermuda.

Reflecting a larger sales volume, the consolidated net profit of J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., textile concern, increased to $15,122,314 for the six months ended on May 1 from $14,995,165 in the corresponding period ended on May 3, 1947, the report showed yesterday.

ATHENS, June 18 (AP) -- Greek Army forces pushed forward in Western Macedonia under an air and artillery umbrella today as the Army's biggest offensive against the guerrillas rumbled into action. Fighter planes, artillery and troops were active on a forty-mile front from the Albanian border, near Lake Presba, south to Geneva.
SINGAPORE, June 18 (AP) -- A state of emergency was declared throughout Malaya today in an effort to halt a wave of terrorism allegedly caused by Communists.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 18 -While retrieving a ball from the roof of a one-story warehouse at 194 Rose Avenue, Eugene Demarest, 14 years old, who lives across the street at 193 Rose Avenue, slipped this evening into the seven-inch space separating the warehouse from a garage.

New York has always put out the welcome mat to visitors. Now, after yesterday's opening of the new offices of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, at 500 Park Avenue, the city will be better equipped to implement its hospitality. Mayor O'Dwyer in the opening ceremonies extended an invitation to "the entire world" to visit this "warm-hearted, friendly city," see the wonders of the metropolis and "savor its rich, historical background."
ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- The Yankees, with their eyes focused on the league-leading Indians, tripped right over the Browns tonight to suffer a damaging setback.

WASHINGTON, June 18--President Truman in a message to the Congress today announced that he proposed to appoint a special commission to recommend a "code of conduct" to govern employment relations in the plants developing atomic energy.

Two teen-age boys were in hospitals suffering from bullet wounds, and two others were held in Brooklyn Adolescent Court in $20,000 bail on felonious assault charges as the aftermath of what police called a flare-up of juvenile gang warfare in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

Shock and grief stir the nation in a disaster such as that which wiped out, in the twinkling of an eye, forty-three lives in the crash of a giant DC-6 airliner near Mount Carmel, Pa. Every agency of the Government concerned with air safety, the airline itself and the manufacturer must be unsparing, of course, in their efforts to determine the factors which led to this disaster.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 18 -- Military-type summer uniforms were issued today to the fifty United Nations employes who had volunteered yesterday to serve under Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator in Palestine.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A new Presidential boom started today on the eve of the Republican National Convention, but for a Democrat, Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas, with its activity aimed at the Democratic convention, scheduled to convene slightly less than a month from now.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Negotiations between the Senate and House over the European Recovery Program split wide open tonight, raising the possibility that the issue may have to be fought out on the floor of the Republican convention at Philadelphia.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 18 (AP) -- A Roman Catholic Bishop, Msgr. Sandor Kovacs, issued a pastoral letter today to teachers of church schools telling them they might decide "according to their conscience" whether to continue teaching under nationalization.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- James J. Wadsworth has been chosen special assistant to Paul G. Hoffman, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration, it was announced today.

Mrs. Arthur Wassner, 57 years old, was killed yesterday when a 400-pound flagstone slab, part of the parlor floor, extension balcony of an abandoned house at 565 West 185th Street, collapsed. The woman toppled twelve feet to an areaway. Boys at play found her buried under the stone.

A 34-year-old municipal Civil Service employe who, in 1938, began studying for his Bachelor of Arts degree in City College's evening session was notified yesterday that he would be the only summa cum laude graduate of 3,098 students participating in the college's commencement exercises this Tuesday.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 18 (AP) -- A permanent organization of Alabama states' rights Democrats was set up here today.

Seventyone of the one hundred largest manufacturing corporations in the United States gave $16.1h)0*0*0*imillions to charitable and welfare organizations during 1947, according to a survey on corporate donations, last year, which has just been completed by the National Industrial Conference Board.
Carl J. Meyer, a two-asterik apprentice jockey, the asterisks indicating a five-pound weight allowance, rode his first New York race at Aqueduct yesterday. He'll never forget it.

The Public Service Commission ordered the Long Island Rail Road Company yesterday to undertake immediately a five-point program to prevent any future breakdown of service from snowfall such as occurred last Dec. 26 and 27. Theh)0*0*0*icommission's report declared that in handling the storm the railroad company "delayed too long in taking action to combat the snow and that it placed its full snow program into operation too late."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 18 (AP) -- Allen Stack of Yale, one of the nation's outstanding backstroke swimmers who yesterday had improved on standing records, did it again today when he bettered the national times in the 200-meter and 220-yard events in Yale's 55-yard practice pool.

The Transport Workers Union, CIO, renewed yesterday its appeal for adoption by the Board of Transportation of the Davis O'Dwyer Plan, extending recognition to labor organizations on the basis of their numerical strength.

Four youths were arraigned yesterday in several sections of Felony Court on charges of burglaryh)0*0*0*iand possession of burglars' tools after a month's work by a detective who had but one clue -a single fingerprint on a jimmy.
CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) -- New construction this year probably will total about $16,400,000,000, a 17 per cent gain over 1947, the Producers Council estimated today.

.h)0*0*0*iOPHILADELPHIA, June 18 -Governor Thomas E. Dewey of New York won the first test on the strength of the rival candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination today, when the National Committee by a vote of 48 to 44 decided to recommend the seating of the Dewey Georgia delegation with sixteen votes.

A few furniture factories are offering merchandise to retailers at 10 to 15 per cent discounts for the first time since the war, buyers reported yesterday. It was emphasized the practice is confined to a limited number of suites over-priced since January.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 18 (AP) -Count Folke Bernadotte arrived at his peace headquarters in Rhodes today to begin the attempt to set up a basis for a permanent Palestine settlement.

h)0*0*0*iOThe effects of the rainy season have of been many and varied. Transplanting flowers has been easy this spring, for example, for a flower needs only to be thrown to the ground and immediately it takes root and grows. For another, the Weather Bureau, which normally is just a placid servant of the people, now has acquired an identity of its own.

Sidney Schwartz, top-seeded, defeated fourth-ranked Phil Hanna, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 1, in the semi-final of the annual Spanish tennis tournament at the Hispano T. C. courts in Whitestone, Queens, yesterday. The University of Miami ace and former national indoor junior ruler will meet Charley Masterson, seeded No. 3, in the final today at 1 P.M.

VIENNA, June 18 -- The Austrian Government is understood to have protested today to Soviet occupation authorities against their threat to hold its Minister of Power Alfred Migsch to account for having criticized living conditions in the Soviet Union.

Stockholders of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., will meet in Kansas City, Mo., on Aug. 10 to approve an increase in the authorized common stock from 3,000,000 to 4,000,000 shares, it was disclosed yesterday by Warren Lee Pierson, chairman.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 18 (UP) -- Israel officially informed Counth)0*0*0*iBernadotte today that it was ready to send delegates to Rhodes next week.

Seeking to rally all religious forces to bolster the United Nations, the Conference of Religion for Moral and Spiritual Support of the world body voted yesterday to change the name of one of its principal sponsoring agencies, the World Alliance for International Friendship Through the Churches.

TRENTON, N. J., June 18 (AP) -Million-dollar tax assessments on floating equipment owned by theh) 0*0*0*iNew York Central Railroad Company and the Erie Railroad Company were upheld today by the State Supreme Court.

The Public Service Commission, in a unanimous decision handed down yesterday, approved a plan for consolidation of the Long Island Lighting Company with its subsidiaries, the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company and the Nassau Suffolk Lighting Company.
The name of the newspaper PM will be changed to the New York Star next Wednesday, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, June 18 -- Early introduction of legislation designed to open the courts to the poorest persons was forecast today by Sir Hartley Shawcross, Britain's Attorney General.

The Methodist Church Home for the Aged in the City of New York has sold two vacant business plots in the Bronx to Ossining Associates, Inc., for cash above a short-term mortgage of $33,750. One of the plots, 100 by 100 feet, is at the southeast corner of West 238th Street and Corlear Avenue.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 18--The failure of the House of Representatives to pass the Library Demonstration Bill and the Federal Aid to Education Bill was blamed today entirely on the adverse stand taken by Speaker Joseph Martin and Floor Leader Charles Halleck, both Republicans.

For their outstanding achievements in intercultural and interfaith activities in school and community during the academic term ending this month, six boys and four girls who are pupils in the city's public secondary schools received a $100 cash scholarship each yesterday from B'nai B'rith.

A one-time assistant to the local regional director of the Federal Housing Administration was sentenced yesterday in Special Sessions to serve four months in the workhouse on his conviction for exacting a $4,000 bonus from a dentist seeking a professional apartment in Stuyvesant Town.
SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 18 (AP) -- State Controller Frank C. Moore forecast tonight establishment of a "Department of Local Government" in New York state.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The House, in an action which promised to provide a major electionyear issue, passed today a modified housing bill and sent it to the Senate for a doubtful fate. The vote was 317 to 90.

More than 10,000 music lovers braved lowering skies to attend the first Goldman Band concert of its thirty-first season in Central Park last night. In addition to the music, conducted by Edwin Franko Goldman and his son, Richard Franko Goldman, the crowd was treated to a ceremony in honor of the concerts' annual sponsor, the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 -- Republican platform drafters headed tonight into controversies over civil rights, labor and housing planks and a potential row over a foreign affairs declaration which Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., of Massachusetts, predicted would be the "most international" in party history.
An article in THE TIMES of June 13 contained the following statement:

Mayor O'Dwyer received unexpected support yesterday in hish)0*0*0*ibattle with the state administration for greater revenue sources when the New York State Conference of Mayors and Other Municipal Officials endorsed his stand for an increase in the city's real estate tax limit.

BUENOS AIRES, June 18 -Argentina has been by-passed by the Economic Cooperation Administration of the United States in the estimates for the final two quarters of 1948, a United States authority said today. He is H. Struve Hensel, a consultant of the administration and former Under Secretary of the Navy, who arrived here a few days ago.

BOSTON, June 18 (AP) -- For the third time in as many games the Boston Braves came from behind to win, defeating the Cincinnati Reds, 5 -- 4, tonight, before 30,759 fans. The Tribe routed Ewell (The Whip) Blackwell from the pitching mound for the third time this season.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The present Congress is unsurpassed by any other in its devotion to "special interests" rather than the general welfare, President Truman asserted today, shortly before his return to the capital.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18--Harold E. Stassen ended his pre-convention speech-making bid for the Republican Presidential nomination today with an attack upon "a Maginot-line type of reactionary thinking." He spoke to 1,500 members of the Union League Club, a Philadelphia citadel of rockbound Republicanism.
PHILADELPHIA, June 18 (AP) -- Elmer Riddle won his eighth game of the season against two defeats tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 2--0.

TAMIMENT, Pa., June 18 -- Reinstatement of three anti-Communists expelled from the Bloomingdale Department Store local in New York was ordered here tonight by the international executive board of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO.

Norman Lewis, former intercollegiate champion from New York University, beat Jose de Capriles, his Salle Santelli team-mate, 3 -- 1, in a fence-off to win the National electric epee championship last night at the Hotel Roosevelt. The event was the concluding one of the week-long national tournament.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Arthur G. Syran has been named Director of Transportation for the Economic Cooperation Administration, it was announced today.

BERLIN, June 18 -- New restrictions on all types of traffic into the Soviet zone were put into effect by the Soviet Military Administration late tonight in answer to currency reform in the Western zones.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday at a special meeting at City Hall agreements between the Board of Transportation and private operators of surface lines in the Bronx and Queens under which their passengers will be able to transfer to and from the city's rapid transit lines at a combined fare of 12 cents.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 18 -- The United Nations Committee of Good Offices in Indonesia asked the Netherlands today whether it was ready to continue the negotiations with the Republic of Indonesia, broken off Wednesday.

NANKING, June 18 -- Twenty thousand Communists under Gen. Chen Yi drove today to the gates of Kaifeng, the capital of Honan Province, in an offensive apparently designed to relieve pressure on Communist troops operating farther west above the Lung-Hai Railway.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The bituminous coal contract dispute went to the White House this afternoon. Cyrus F. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, found it impossible, at a stormy conference, to break the deadlock between the United Mine Workers of America and the nation's soft coal producers.

The Park Avenue Theatre, 487 Park Avenue, will reopen at noon today after having been closed since Wednesday as the result of a dispute between the management and Local 306 of the Moving Picture Machine Operators Union, International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, it was announced yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 18 -- A Tel Aviv convoy of essential supplies for the besieged population of Jerusalem arrived today after complete supervision at two United Nations check posts. The main road was used only in part because one section of it is still mined.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 18 -- The Government of the Belgian trust territory of Ruanda-Urundi is not based on the electoral system because the inhabitants do not understand the western concept of democracy, Maurice M. Simon, Governor of the territory, reported today to the United Nations Trusteeship Council.

MUNICH, Germany, June 18 -Black marketeers cashed in heavily today in advance of the currency reform in the Western zones. The illegal sale of cigarettes multiplied, with buyers paying 400 Reichsmarks a pack -- four times the normal price, or $40 at the Army rate of a 10-cent mark.

ALBANY, June 18 -- The State Board of Regents granted recognition today, for the first time, to Modern Hebrew as an approved state course of study in the high schools, with the appointment of a committee to assist the Education Department in the preparation of a syllabus on the subject.

The Yugoslav cargo-passenger ship Radnik, with the cargo that Brooklyn longshoremen had refused for three days to load safely in her holds as the result of the volunteer work of her crew, sailed from Forty-fourth Street Brooklyn at 7 A.M. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (UP) -The Senate today passed, but the House refused to accept, a compromise $5,855,308,851 Independent Offices Appropriations Bill carrying $521,851,000 for the Atomic Energy Commission.

Blind people need and love the sunshine as much as any of us -- more, in fact, because they never see it. The Lighthouse, whose beams have guided the blind of this city for so many years, hopes this year to send every one of the 500 sightless persons on its waiting list into the country for a breathing spell of fresh air and healthbuilding.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -President Truman today named a group of prominent Americans to represent this country in international organizations.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, tonight sharply criticized President Truman "for a self-serving political vacation at a moment when the whole Government should be on the job in Washington."
A non-English speaking witness testified yesterday, through an interpreter, at the trial of Gus Fusaro that, although he had lost $16,089, he still had faith in the 53-year-old elevator starter.

Deaf girls danced in perfect rhythm last night at the annual graduation exercises of the Lexington School for the Deaf in the Hunter College Playhouse, Sixtyeighth Street between Park and Lexington Avenue. Although unable to hear the music, the students kept time to it by feeling vibrations of the piano through the floor.

Back after six weeks spent inspecting new plays in London and Paris, Richard Myers, member of the theatrical partnership of Richard Aldrich and Myers, revealed yesterday that his firm will supplement its Broadway activities in the summer with a West End production. Next week, the team expects to close a deal with Peter Daubeney to join him in the presentation of a script called "Dear Life," by Charlotte Frances.

ALBANY, June 18 (AP) -- The Rev. John Wesley Lord of Westfield, N.J., and the Rev. Lloyd C. Wicke of Pittsburgh were elected bishops of the Methodist Church today by the Northeastern Jurisdictional Conference.

Hardly had the Official Visitors Information Bureau at 500 Park Avenue, at Fifty-ninth Street, been formally opened to the tourist public yesterday when it had its first client. He was Burgomaster Arnold J. D'Ailly of Amsterdam, Holland, who has been here as the guest of Mayor O'Dwyer.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Continuation of the present construction rate of 1,000,000 homes a year depends on the sales ability of the building industry and its success in eliminating from the market "thousands of undesirable houses," Edward R. Carr, past president of the National Association of Home Builders, said today.

MOUNT CARMEL, Pa., June 18 -- Preliminary investigation of the crash of a United Air Lines DC-6 yesterday afternoon in a colliery five miles northeast of here disclosed today that the huge aircraft tore into a steep, rocky hillside with all four engines running at high power.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 18 -- Following is the text of the draft International Declaration of Human Rights adopted today by the United Nations Human Rights Commission:

A taxicab driver was haled yesterday into Mid-Manhattan Court on a charge of petty larceny for allegedly short-changing a patrolman in civilian clothes, who had set a trap for the defendant by pretending to be intoxicated.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- After an extensive study of 800 victims of heart attack during the last two years, a committee of experts told members of the American Heart Association here today that the use of drugs to reduce the clotting time of the blood in connection with the usual treatment will "markedly lower" the death rate for coronary thrombosis when the heart muscles have been damaged.

In the first soccer game played in this country by two top foreign teams, the Liverpool squad of England defeated the Djurgarden eleven from Sweden, 3 -- 2, last night at Ebbets Field before a crowd of 18,400 paying customers.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 18 -- The three Western Allies announced today that a new form of German currency, to be called the Deutsche mark, would be issued Sunday to replace the Reichsmark, used since the inflation days of 1923 and now virtually worthless.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Robert N. Denham, general counsel for the National Labor Relations Board, announced today he had started an investigation of complaints that the International Typographical Union is violating a Federal court injunction that bars certain labor practices.
Two Army veterans were before the courts in the Bronx yesterday, on separate charges involving alleged swindles of $80,000 and $250,000.

ALBANY, June 18 -- Governor Dewey, in close touch by telephone today with his top aides at Philadelphia, will leave Albany by train tomorrow morning on the first leg of his trip to the national convention city. He plans to spend the night in New York and motor to Philadelphia Sunday morning.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., June 18 -- Approximately seventy-five representatives of musical organizations and music publishers registered here today for the three-day national convention of the American Symphony Orchestra League, which will start its business sessions tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Compromise legislation for admission of a limited number of displaced Europeans and political refugees was approved by the House today, but the measure was stalled in the Senate for the night while a filibuster against the draft held the floor.

Two new pictures, one from Hollywood and the other from London, will have local premieres today. "Lulu Belle," produced by Columbia and based on the Charles MacArthur-Edward Sheldon play of some years ago, will open at the Rivoli. Dorothy Lamour is starred ir. the romantic drama, which also features George Montgomery, Albert Dekker, Otto Kruger, Glenda Farrell and Greg NlcClure....

PITTSBURGH, June 18 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district continued downward last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. This is the third consecutive week in which a decrease has been reported.

Argument on the legality and merits of the restraining order barring a maritime strike on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, which was issued by Federal Judge John W. Clancy on Monday, was heard yesterday in the United States District Court here.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -The International Labor Conference completed organization of working committees today and heard David G. K. Owen, Assistant Secretary-General of the United Nations, assert that there was "no justification for pessimism or despair" over the U.N. since it was "a going concern."

THESE two new novels -- Ramon Sender's "The King and the Queen"* and Barnaby Conrad's "The Innocent Villa" -- have not much in common that you will particularly want to remember except that they are both about Spain. The parallels end there. Otherwise Mr. Conrad's story is as bright and superficial as a bullfight poster; Mr. Sender's as deeply concerned with the eternal verities of life and death as the bullfight itself.

WASHINGTON, Saturday, June 19 -- Senator Taylor paused early today in a filibuster against the draft bill as the scheduled adjournment of Congress tonight drew near. After some wrangling, Senator William Langer, Republican, of North Dakota, took his place.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill extending for two years the terms of present members of the Atomic Energy Commission. It is in conflict with the desires of President Truman.

The stock market lapsed yesterday into an indecisive stage accompanied by a contraction in business. The inability of the railway issues to further their previous strength caused some misgivings in trading circles, but the oils still continued to push forward although the advance failed to be as uniform as recently.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Wheat showed considerable strength early today on the Board of Trade but reacted sharply, profit-taking by longs being a factor. Hedge sales were not heavy, but while there was some absorption of the July by cash interests early, the demand from shorts appeared to have been pretty well satisfied, and the commission house buying was lighter than in recent sessions.

Anglican Bishops from all parts of the world and their wives will be received at Buckingham Palace on July 13 by King George VI andh)0*0*0*iQueen Elizabeth at the chief social feature of the Lambeth Conference that will open in London on July 1 and continue through Aug. 8.
PRAGUE, June 18 -- Minister of Information Vaclav Kopecky has suggested, in an address published here today, that the Soviet Union was preparing for some major diplomatic move.
BERLIN, June 18 - Although the currency reform plan of the Western Allies excluded Berlin, citizens here were greatly affected by its announcement today.

Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve, president of the Franco-American Audio-Visual Distribution Center, 934 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday the formation of an advisory council. The group will help the organization in promoting better Franco-American understanding through the distribution at cost of films and other material to national and international agencies and to cultural and educational groups.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 18 -"Calamity Jane," a screen story by Jerry Wald and Richard Macaulay which has been on and off the Warner Brothers production schedule since 1940, will be made next year as a Michael Curtiz production, the studio announced today.

Carl Glick, author of two books about his experiences with the Chinese in America, "Shake Hands with the Dragon" and "Three Times I Bow." is working on an autobiographical manuscript, entitled: "I'm a Busybody." It will deal with his experiences with all kinds of people as a magazine feature writer and little theatre organizer in the central and mountain states.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Eastern interests holding large blocks of stock in Montgomery Ward Co. will request a full explanation from Sewell L. Avery, chairman, and company directors of the events that occurred at the special board meeting on June 10, it was learned authoritatively today.

ALBANY, N. Y., June 18 (AP)-New York's death rate in April was 6 per cent below that of April, 1947, the State Health Department reported today. The decrease was attributed mainly to fewer deaths from heart disease and pneumonia.

As the Republicans gather in Philadelphia, it is interesting and cheering to recall that on June 17, exactly thirty-three years ago, in Independence Hall, the League to Enforce Peace was organized that had so much to do in radically changing their views on world affairs.
CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox defeated the Washington Senators, 5 to 2, tonight on only three hits, including Tony Lupien's second home run of the season, before 10,919 fans.

Jewish leaders here denounced yesterday the compromise displaced persons bill drawn up by a Senate-House conference committee Thursday night and approved yesterday by the House of Representatives. They called it discriminatory against Jews and Catholics and urged Congress to enact more equitable legislation.h) 0*0*0*iO

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 18 -In accordance with the repeatedly expressed wish of Earl Carroll, his theatre-restaurant here will continue to operate without interruption, despite Mr. Carroll's death yesterday in an airplane crash, Harry Long, his executive assistant, announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The enactment of draft legislation and a "satisfactory" European recovery appropriation were laid down tonight by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio as "must" accomplishment before the Eightieth Congress could adjourn.

A corporation controlled by Abraham Sonken, which owns 157 East 104th Street, has purchased two five-story tenements adjoining at 1651 Lexington Avenue and 155 East 104th Street from the Central Savings Bank in a deal negotiated by Hardy, Brauneis Naumann, Inc., brokers.

The screens of the Strand and the Gotham Theatres at Broadway and Forty-seventh Street were darkened at 2 P. M. yesterday when a utility worker's pneumatic drill touched underground wires and caused a short circuit. The drilling was to connect a water line into the building at 218 West Forty-seventh Street.

The eleven GIs from the Third Armored Division at Fort Knox, Ky., who lost up to thirty-one pounds each in a five-week survivalration test on Welfare Island, were regaining weight rapidly yesterday. Some will be released for a thirty-day furlough over the week-end.

An unexpected increase in the number of 16 and 17-year-old boys and girls leaving high school for work, as well as of children working part-time, has occurred in New York this spring, it was learned yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 18 -- The United Nations Commission on Human Rights adopted today its International Declaration of Human Rights setting up a "common standard of achievement for all peoples and all nations."

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- President Truman told Congress today in his third quarterly report on assistance to Greece and Turkey that "progress is being made in stabilizing the economy of Greece," but the situation in that country "remains critical."
Robert Riggs and Donald Budge, the defending champions, gained the final of the national professional doubles tournament yesterday in the Forest Hills Stadium of the West Side Tennis Club.

" Let's Dance America" is the title of the Columbia Broadcasting System's newest venture into summertime programming. Scheduled to begin on Saturday, July 3, in the 10 to 10:30 P.M. time segment, the series will be a weekly offering of the leading dance bands in the country in fifteen-minute samplings.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -When the Air Force disclosed today that it had ordered the 36th wing of jet fighters to take up station in the United States zone of Germany, it was stated here that across the zonal border the Russians reportedly operate a constantly growing force of jet fighters and some jet-powered bombers.

PRAGUE, June 18 (UP) -- Five hundred newspaper workers defied the Communist regime in Czechoslovakia today and threatened to strike to protest the closing of Social Democratic publications. It was the first open defiance of the Government since the Communists took over in February.

Whether Congress will pass a Selective Service bill before scheduled adjournment tonight is still uncertain. If it is a question of accepting a gutted, delayed-action bill such as the House voted yesterday morning, 283 to 130, or not adjourning, then adjournment must not be taken.

ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- The good done by the National Catholic Layman's Retreat Conference will be "far greater than the two big political conferences," Auxiliary Bishop John P. Cody of St. Louis told the conference today at its opening session.

Whether Congress will pass a Selective Service bill before scheduled adjournment tonight is still uncertain. If it is a question of accepting a gutted, delayed-action bill such as the House voted yesterday morning, 283 to 130, or not adjourning, then adjournment must not be taken.

ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- The good done by the National Catholic Layman's Retreat Conference will be "far greater than the two big political conferences," Auxiliary Bishop John P. Cody of St. Louis told the conference today at its opening session.

Peruvian International Airways signed a lease yesterday afternoon with the Port of New York Authority for space at the New York International Airport at Idlewild, it was learned here. PIA, which operates between New York and Santiago, Chile, thus became the second airline to sign with the Port Authority for service out of the big field when it is opened July 1, following the lead of Air France.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -When the Air Force disclosed today that it had ordered the 36th wing of jet fighters to take up station in the United States zone of Germany, it was stated here that across the zonal border the Russians reportedly operate a constantly growing force of jet fighters and some jet-powered bombers.

All the Powers of the London conference have now confirmed the agreement to establish a new regime in Western Germany. The French, the last and most reluctant to sign, have also joined in a drastic trizonal currency reform, the first step toward integrating the German economy into the European Recovery Program.

CLERMONT-FERRAND, France, June 18 -- Mobile guards and security battalions began leaving this rubber-manufacturing city today, easing the labor tension. More than a dozen army trucks loaded with men left in the late afternoon. Other government forces were dismantling machine-gun positions and obviously preparing to move out.

Daily average lumber production for the week ended June 12 was 12.9 per cent above the preceding week but was 8 per cent below the like week last year, with shipments down 2.1 per cent and orders down 5.7 per cent, from last year, according to reports received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
ROME, June 18 -- A moderately optimistic picture of Italy's finances was painted by Minister of the Treasury Giuseppe Pella in the Chamber of Deputies today during a discussion of the budget.

CLAREMONT, Calif., June 1S-- The latest of a half-dozen plays to come in the last twenty-five years from the pen of lipton Sinclair had its worlu premiere here last night. Entitled "A Giant's Strength," the three-act, six-scene drama, produced by the Valley Community Theatre, amateur company here, is IV[r. Sinclair's answer, or corollary, to the amiable prophecy of doom sounded by Thornton Wilder in "The Skin of Our Teeth."

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente, a leading aspirant for the Tammany designation for the post of Surrogate, denied yesterday that he was a political associate of Frank Costello, ex-convict and recognized slot machine king.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 18 -- The Soviet Union and the Ukraine joined in a charge today that the United States was trying to weaken the United Nations in general and the Security Council in particular.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 18 -Preston (Tex) Moore of Lawrenceville, the medalist, will oppose the defending champion, Bill Ragland of Choate, for the thirty-second Eastern Interscholastic Golf Association championship over the Greenwich Country Club course in a 36-hole final tomorrow.

A sentence of three to six years in state prison was imposed yesterday by General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen on a confessed swindler. The court excoriated him as "the most despicable and conscienceless swindler of whom I have ever heard."

WARSAW, Poland, June 18 -The Polish Government published today the text of a long note protesting to the French Government against the decisions of the London conference on Germany and describing them as a danger to the security of both countries.
Directors of the Central Railroad of New Jersey have approved in principle an adjustment plan for the reorganization of the road under the Mahaffie Act, it was announced yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Saturday, June 19 (AP) -- Pitcher Bob Lemon walked Sam Chapman and Rudy York with the bases loaded in the seventh inning to give the Philadelphia Athletics a 5-to-4 triumph over the league-leading Cleveland Indians in a rain-delayed game that ended early this morning.

CAMDEN, N. J., June 18 (AP) -The general executive board of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, CIO, charged today the president of the union's local at Perth Amboy, N. J., with failure to sign a non-Communist affidavit.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Air Force announced today the forthcoming transfer of the 36th Fighter Wing, equipped with Lockheed F-80 Shooting Stars, from Albrook Field, Panama Canal Zone, to Germany. The move will be made about Aug. 15, and the F-80's will be the first United States jet-propelled service airplanes to be sent to Europe.h)0*0*0*iO

The approaching end of training for the boxers coupled with an increased show of money in support of the challenger yesterday produced a slight change in the betting odds for the heavyweight title struggle between Champion Joe Louis and Jersey Joe Walcott to be waged next Wednesday night in the Yankee Stadium.
The following books of a religious or inspirational nature have been published recently:

NEW DELHI, India, June 18 -The recent surge of Communist influence in Southeast Asia, dramatized this week by the pronouncement of Burmese Premier Thakin Nu and the wave of disorders in Malaya, is causing concern in India.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)-A resolution setting up a Congressional committee to investigate the Federal Communications Commission was approved by the House Rules Committee today.

Things are beginning to appear patterned for the Dodgers. Their recent script readings have them starting fast, permitting the opposition to pass them and losing what apparently should have been successes.

Directors of the Grand Union Company have proposed a 2 1/4for-1 split-up of stock and a change in the value of the stock from no par to $10 par value, Lansing P. Shield, president, announced yesterday. Shareholders of record of June 28 will vote at a special meeting on July 28 on the proposal.

Stocks on hand in New York City department stores on May 31, 1948, were 8 per cent higher than on the corresponding day last year, according to a report issued by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The total increase for all department stores in the Second Federal Reserve District was 10 per cent.
LONDON, June 18 (AP) -- Two "injured feet" took Gardnar Mulloy and John Bromwich out of the London lawn tennis singles championship and Bob Falkenburg and Eric Sturgess into the final round today.

Although working within fairly tight budgetary limits, buyers of corsets and brassieres placed a substantial volume of business during the fall market week ended yesterday, according to a survey among volume producers. National brand line manufacturers, it was learned, are prepared to increase their unit output this year and are looking for a total industry volume up to $400,000,000 at retail.

The one-story building containing 77,000 square feet at 52-15 Flushing Avenue, Maspeth, Queens, has been leased by the War Relief Service-National Catholic Welfare from Rickey, Browne Donald, Inc. The property is served by a railroad siding. Isaac Lubow and F. G. Pflomm were the brokers in the transaction.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 19 (AP) -- Arab and Israeli delegations are expected to reach Rhodes Monday to confer with Count Bernadotte.

Edmund Reiss, commenting on Barbara Ward's recent article, "Keystone to a Western Union Is Britain," suggests that Britain should give Gibraltar to Spain. Mr. Reiss should read his history. There he would learn that in return for Gibraltar, some 200 years ago, England gave Spain Florida.

PARIS, June 19 -- The French Government called special attention today to the Assembly reservations when it formally notified the United States and British Governments of French participation in the London recommendations on Western Germany.

Financial markets pursued an irregular course last week, in contrast with the strong tone of the previous period, but an undercurrent of firmness was apparent. The impasse between the coal-mine operators and the unions again held the center of interest, although several labor settlements in various lines created a more cheerful note.

THERE is a small group of Indians living on Martha's Vineyard who were originally the first American collaborators. Their lore provides the background for Sylvia Bates' book and one of their descendants is its heroine. More than one minority group figures in this story.

The Selective Service measure that the Conference Committee agreed on, and which was quickly accepted by the Senate -- and last night by the House -- when the senseless Taylor-Langer filibuster was broken, is not what the National Defense Department asked for, but it is a much better bill than it seemed possible would be gotten out of the Committee and through Congress.

CLERMONT-FERRAND, France, June 19 -- Strikes in the Bergougnen, Michelin and Dunlop rubber factories appear to have been settled, at least temporarily, during a series of secret negotiations between the management, labor and the Government.

BOSTON, June 19 (AP) -- Right hander Johnny Sain protected the Braves' half-game first-place lead by shutting out the Reds, 5 -- 0, with a six-hit performance tonight before 24,425. The Tribesmen gained all eight of their hits at the expense of Tom Hughes during the first five frames.

The youth hostel movement in Europe is to be revived from the United States by air. A C-54 planeload of young persons, 17 to 25 years old, each with a bicycle carrying complete clothing and equipment in saddle bags, and each ten accompanied by an older leader, is scheduled to take off at 11 o'clock this morning from Bradley Field, near Hartford, Conn., headed for Geneva, Switzerland.

STARTING with a discussion of good health in general, and winding up with some pithy comment on good eating habits, United States Government specialists have done another good turn for parents in compiling a folder, "Foods Your Children Need."
"MAN Eater of Kumaon" will be unveiled at the Winter Garden here about July 1, culminating more than two years of planning, and, finally, production, it was disclosed last week by Frank B. Rosenberg.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Following are the salient provisions of the stop-gap selective draft program which Congress approved and sent to the White House tonight:

THE weather has always been the gardener's best alibi for unsuccessful efforts, and this year he has more than usual justification for holding Mother Nature responsible. For abnormal manifestations of pests and blights are currently playing havoc with gardens along the eastern seaboard.

Thank you for the fine article in THE TIMES Magazine on Dr. Francis E. Townsend and the Townsend Plan. It came at a very opportune time, preceding our national convention, and the writer, Allan Taylor, has done an outstanding service.

THIS book might have been written primarily for Harry S. Truman. Had it come from the press three years ago, the President's advisers would certainly have placed it on his list of required reading. It should be carefully consulted (though there is little likelihood that it will be) by the delegates to the Republican and Democratic conventions as they prepare to nominate their respective candidates for the office of Vice President.

TIENTSIN, June 18 (Delayed) -- Twenty-two Catholic nuns -- six of them Americans -- arrived here from Hsienhsien in Communist central Hopeh last night. They said they had no trouble with the Communists and that the Communists did not want them to leave.
BOOTHBAY HARBOR,Me. June 19 (AP) -- The schooner Bowdoin, her decks drenched by rain. hoisted anchor today and headed for the Arctic %with Donald B. ATaeMJllan, the explorer, aboard.

THE New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, Inc., opened its Visitor Information Center, 500 Park Avenue, at Fifty-ninth Street, Friday with a large reception at which Mayor O'Dwyer and Bernard F. Gimbel, president of the bureau, spoke, and the city's police quartet sang.
WASHINGTON, Sunday, June 20 -- Attempts to obtain Congressional approval of a housing bill bogged down early today after a Senate battle of invective, and hope was virtually abandoned.

One of the greatest current behind-the-scenes battles is being fought for managerial control of the second largest mail-order house and retail merchandising concern in the country -- Montgomery Ward Co. The internal struggle has produced within two weeks a long list of casualties; among them, the president, three vice presidents and three directors, two of whom of the last are officers of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc.

IT'S no surprise that Christopher Morley's daughter, Blythe, should be able to turn out a creditably written first novel. The general theme and scene of her story are not unexpected, either. "The Intemperate Season" represents the teens, a period which Miss Morley hasn't left very far behind; families like her Flemings and summer homes like theirs, abound along that portion of the Eastern seaboard where she was brought up.

Maine's old-timers, who foretell the severity of a coming winter by the fur on their wild animals, or the advent of spring by the groundhog's antics on his special day, might well prognosticate from this year's vigor of my Herbert Hoover rose. For never in its six seasons of generally mediocre existence in my rose bed did it previously put forth a gorgeous display.

THE HERB SOCIETY OF AMERICA, with headquarters at the York Club, 4 East Sixty-second Street, will hold its annual meeting tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday. A trip to the Cloisters, Fort Tryon Park is scheduled for tomorrow at 1 P.M.

The Carnegie Corporation has granted Columbia University $150,000 for a five-year period to enable the university "to begin work immediately on the development of an Institute of European Studies." The institute is expected to be the nation's only graduate center equipped to offer an integrated and intensive program of Western European studies.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 19 -- The United Nations sent out its first international police force tonight -- forty-nine men bound for Palestine to protect the truce.

Quantities of valuable jewelry and silverware from vast stockpiles of Nazi loot that were recovered by the Allied Armies in Germany and Austria will be auctioned in six sessions beginning tomorrow at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.
CLEVELAND, June 19 -- Bob Feller says he'll stick strictly to pitching from now on.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., June 19 -- Gil Tompkins and Sandy MacLeod of the Garden City Golf Club led the way into the semi-final round of the Seawane Harbor Club's third annual senior member-guest tourney today.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., June 19 (Religious News Service) -- This city in northern New York on the St. Lawrence River will turn back the clock 200 years Saturday afternoon, Aug. 14, when Father Guy Dessaules, Sulpician priest of the Seminary of Philosophy, Montreal, and three companions arrive here at the junction of the St. Lawrence and Oswegatchie Rivers in two birch bark canoes.

FIVE stamps belatedly released by Panama are inscribed "Cincuentenario de la Fundacion del Cuerpo de Bomberos de Colon" (Fiftieth Anniversary of the Founding of the Fire Department of Colon) and the dates 1897 and 1947.

Favorable shopping weather in the week preceding Father's Day brought sales to the point where they exceeded those of the same calendar week last year by about 20 per cent, the second largest gain in the year. Fall buying continued in the wholesale garment markets, but at a slower pace than the three previous weeks. Increased activity was noted in primary textile markets.

IT says on the jacket of this book that Mr. Abbot (who, as every whodunit fancier knows, is Fulton Oursler under a trans parent Inverness) is the only detective story writer ever to be published in The Reader's Digest, a distinction not nearly so impressive as the fact that he should give away (for $2.50) so many plots.

I have just finished reading again Raymond B. Fosdick's article "Not Dollars Alone -- Faith Is Also Needed." * * * We cannot be told too often that the much-abused term "standard of living" is not exclusively identified with material comforts and luxuries, but, on the contrary, embraces within its meaning cultural and spiritual values as well.

The prompt and efficient action of an International Red Cross delegation in Palestine "surely saved thousands of lives" in the recent hostilities in the Holy Land, Dr. Paul Ruegger, president of the international body, asserted yesterday.

HERE is a warm, simple story, a first novel that is another of the "I Remember Mama" genre, to be sure, but one that can still hold its own by the comparison. Mama, in Astrid Valley's "Marching Bonnet," is a worker in the Salvation Army.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Senate passed and sent to the White House tonight a bill to extend for two years the present terms of Chairman David E. Lilienthal and the four other members of the Atomic Energy Commission.

The Dodgers are being abused by their relatives these days. The Cubs, once their most obliging "cousins," smacked the Brooks down yesterday for the fifth time in seven meetings and the second straight in the series at Ebbets Field which concludes today.

Drs. Jacob B. Fishman, Alfred E. Wilhelmi and Jane A. Russell, three Yale physiological chemists, announced last week that they had developed a new method of extracting more powerful growth hormone from animal pituitary glands by a simple process. In a rat this hormone stimulates growth to twice the normal size in a few months.

THIS year's Presidential nominating conventions of the Republican and Democratic parties, in Philadelphia, are scheduled to receive the most extensive radio and television coverage ever accorded a political gathering.
ELY, Minn. -- A paddle-and-portage trip into the vast lake and forest wilderness of Northern Minnesota and Canada is one of the greatest adventures still to be had in North America.

General Motors Research Laboratories have "blocked out the problem" of converting solar energy into fuel, Charles F. Kettering, vice-president and director of research, revealed last week in an interview at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WITH East Forty-second Street bathed in kleig lights for the occasion, television station WPIX made an impressive debut last Tuesday evening. Owned by The Daily News, the outlet lifted the curtain on a schedule of programs which promises to give local video a decided fillip. In fact, it just could be that the newspaper boys are going to give the radio folk a good race for their money.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 19 -- The Middle States tennis team captured the Church Cup for the first time since 1927 today, defeating the Eastern Association at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, 7 to 2.

IT'S a week now since that wonderful Yankee party, the jubilee celebration on Sunday and the get-together dinner the night before. Not only was it an unforgettable week-end but fragments of the conversations come bobbing back into mind as the present-day Yankees mingled with the Yankees of yesteryear, the moderns glorying in the traditions that had been started a quarter of a century before by their glamorous trail-blazers.
PORTLAND, Me., June 19 -- Voters of the State of Maine go to the polls on Monday to nominate candidates for about 250 national, state and county offices.

STAGING six flower shows a year is a somewhat phenomenal program for an average size garden club to pursue. Yet the Flushing Garden Club of New York does just that and, what is more, carries them off with a minimum of fuss and a maximum of aplomb.

Fifty prominent educators, many of whom are college presidents, have begun a movement to bring the Baltic University in Exile from Germany to North America. A sponsors' committee of educators and community leaders has been formed. It is headed by Dr. Christian Gauss, dean-emeritus of Princeton University, and the Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University.

BINGHAM CANYON, Utah -- The "mountain that has become a hole in the ground" is attracting carloads of awed visitors these days, with Eastern tourists and European mining experts alike flocking in a steady stream to view one of the world's most amazing earth-moving operations.

OTTAWA, June 19 -- Canada expects to have available for export to European Recovery Program countries during the next twelve months a wide variety of products valued at just over $1,600,000,000, C.D. Howe, Minister of Trade and Commerce, told the House of Commons this morning when he tabled an estimate of this export program.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 19 (AP) -- The State Association of Real Estate Boards declared today that "abuses" in public housing merited "disclosure by a Congressional subcommittee indicating that there was flagrant waste and fraud."

"I'd hate to have to pitch here all the time," said George (Red) Munger, gazing at the Polo Grounds yesterday before taking the mound for the Cardinals against the Giants. "A pop fly beats you," he explained.

LONDON -- With the return of all but one of its war-requisitioned houses, the acquisition of four or more additional properties, and a million and a quarter dollars allocated to repairs and modernization, Trust Houses, England's largest hotel chain, is prepared for a record flow of tourists this summer.

Yesterday's prolonged uncertainty as to whether the Eightieth Congress should adjourn, recess or keep on going until its work was completed could not change one essential fact. This Congress will not go out of existence until next January. Its books will not be closed until then.

Mrs. Frances Leon Swadesh, whose congratulatory telegram to Senator Glen Taylor of Idaho broke up Mr. Taylor's filibuster against Senate action on the draft, "unwittingly rendered her country a great service" in the opinion of her father, Maurice Leon, Wall Street lawyer.

VARINA HOWELL was 17 when she met Jefferson Davis and 19 when she married him. In limiting her novel to these two years of girlhood and courtship, Miss Seifert has naturally been able to do little more than hint at the qualities of the future first lady of the Confederacy, whom she places among "the great women of our national chronicle."

The platform commitees of both major party conventions in Philadelphia will be asked to renew -- with emphasis -- the pledges of their 1944 campaign platforms to extend Social Security coverage to a greater number of American citizens.
FROM a slow and minuscule start only a couple of years ago, the summer theatre in these parts is burgeoning this season into an institution with potential Broadway repercussions.

Even as private builders are approaching the saturation point in the housing market they can serve at current high prices, the city faces a continuing need of 45,000 new dwelling units annually until 1970, according to a report of the City Planning Commission, made public yesterday by Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman.

In the course of human events there are times when history turns back on itself and gives what may be called a repeat performance -- though, naturally, we do not always get a perfect copy of the original.

MISS COMPTON-BURNETT is immensely unfair to most other contemporary British novelists. Using the same traditional material that so many of them use (hearts of oak and heads to match) she turns out a notably superior work of art for export, Her apparently effortless skill shows them up.

VIENNA, June 19 -- Chief Inspector Anton Marek of the Austrian Ministry of the Interior, who disappeared Thursday night after having been summoned to the legal headquarters of the Soviet Army here, has been arrested "for espionage against Soviet occupation troops."

LONDON, June 19 (Reuters) -- A first major step to self-government in the Sudan -- l,000 square miles of North African territory with a population of some 7,000,000 -- was taken today by the publication of an ordinance creating an Executive Council and an elected Legislative Assembly.

Experiments with radio communication in mines -- between the surface and underground workings, and between widely separated points underground -- have been made by the Bureau of Mines in several coal and iron mines. The human voice was transmitted by short waves through ground strata alone and via trolley wires, pipes and other metallic installations.

RENE KUHN is once again pointing a finger at a domineering woman. In her first thrust, "34 Charlton," (a novel which won the Avery Hopwood award a few years ago), she was concerned with a benevolent matriarch who ruled a household of women until she was pulled up short by the questing dreams and expanding ambitions of her granddaughter.

AMONG the things every motorist should know about the complexities of life behind the wheel is that there are at least twenty-eight traffic-law infractions in this city for which there are fines ranging from $2 to $15.
PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- For the first time in twelve years domestic questions have supplanted foreign policies as the main issues in a Presidential campaign.

Taking cognizance of the fact that most retailers have effected a transition to short term buying on numerous soft goods items, primary sellers of cotton textiles predicted last week that the long overdue upswing in that business will soon begin.

The Private Clinton and the Private Fahy, new police launches named in honor of two patrolmen who lost their lives while serving with the armed forces in World War II, were launched and commissioned yesterday. The ceremonies took place at the Harbor Precinct repair shop, Randalls Island, in the presence of Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- A court decision of interest in publishing circles was handed down here last Friday, when the United States Circuit Court of Appeals upheld, with one exception, a Federal Trade Commission order to book paper manufacturers to stop alleged price-fixing.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 19 -- Don Harrison and George Stuhr Jr., Garden City Country Club, eliminated the medalists, R.M. Torgerson and John F. Murphy, Oakland, 1 up, to reach the final round of the Cherry Valley invitation member-guest golf tournament today.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., June 19 -- In perhaps the greatest workout he has had since he started boxing here last May 20, Joe Louis today demonstrated the style of battle with which he expects to stow Jersey Joe Walcott away when they clash Wednesday night for the world heavyweight title in the Yankee Stadium, New York.

PRAGUE, June 19 (AP) -- Father Joseph Plojhar, Minister of Health in the Communist-controlled Czech Government, was suspended from the priesthood today for his political activity. Father Plojhar also is a member of Parliament and Vice Mayor of Ceske Budojevice.

MR. CARNEGIE's latest blue-print for a social Garden of Eden is so choked with formula, exhortation and case history that no reader will go entirely unrewarded. And with the world spinning to a fare-thee-well, there's no hurt in hearing Mr. Carnegie say again that worry wastes energy, fritters away lives and leads to physical ills.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 19 -- Off in an overhead murk and a sea splash, but with a southwest breeze to fan them along, thirty-six sailing yachts put out into that old devil sea today in the race to Bermuda.

The statistics that Hanson Baldwin cited in his article "What Air Power Can -- and Cannot -- Do" in his attempt to depreciate how effectively the United States Strategic Air Forces reduced the Reich to military impotence were carefully hand-picked out of the wealth of statistics available.

Admiral Andrews led American naval forces to victory in the first !phase of the Battle of the Atlantic.[ As commander of the Eastern SeaI Frontier during the first two years of the second World War he headed the ships and planes which drove] the German sfibmarines from theI American coastal - shipping lanes.

TURNING aside from stories of Army life, Mrs. Lambert has concocted a cheerful and timely story of a family caught in the housing shortage. Newly arrived in Pennsylvania and desperate, the Draytons moved into their cousin's Bucks County barn.

I The most effective measure in the campaign against waterfront thievery has been the passage of the New Jersey "fingerprinting law" which will guarantee that henceforth 'only persons of good character may be employed as watchmen and guards on that state's piers, E. E. Conroy, executive vice president of the Security Bureau, Inc., declared yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- Caucuses foreshadowing discussion of a proposed new world convention, or treaty, guaranteeing freedom of association and the rights of workers and employers to organize were held here today by delegates to the International Labor Conference. Committee sessions dealing with the subject are to begin Monday.

RECOLLECTIONS of childhood and youth -- in the hands of skillful story-tellers -- make moving books. Think of "Dusty Answer," "The Death of the Heart," "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn." "Morning Song" is another sensitive variation on this familiar theme.
LONDON, June 19 (AP) -- An outbreak of foot trouble among the top players threatens to take some of the gloss off the Wimbledon tennis championships starting on Monday.

EASILY the most interesting production we have had this month is "The Gioconda Smile," Aldous Huxley's first play for many years. Mainly on the strength of its author's name it would have its claim to careful notice, but apart from that altogether it is a fascinating example, for anybody who cares for the craft of writing, of the difficulties which a novelist meets when he comes into the theatre.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 19 -- Dr. Stanton, 7-year-old son of Bonny Castle, opened his Eastern campaign before 21,467 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight in impressive fashion. The gelding went the mile in 2:04 in winning the Massachusetts, a $3,500 free-for-all pace.

Reflecting record earnings and a high demand for petroleum products, the oil shares, which have had their biggest spurt in more than twenty-five years, added millions of dollars more to their market values on the New York Stock Exchange last week.

SAN FRANCISCO and Puerto Rico are some four thousand miles apart, but both are to be thanked for a new species of decorating materials. San Francisco is a place where architects and decorators take eagerly to oriental themes in design -- among them the decorative use of matting, bamboo and similar fibrous substances.

Your admirable columnist Mrs. McCormick wrote recently as if Congressional interference with foreign policy were something unusual. Alas, some thirty-odd years ago my classmate Huntington Wilson, Assistant Secretary of State in Wilson's Administration, sadly told me that no sooner had the State Department determined on a consistent policy than Congress ditched it.

A comprehensive picture of the extent to which the United States is dependent upon the shipping industry for maintenance of commerce and national safety and defense is contained in affidavits by heads of Government agencies submitted to Federal courts last week.

THREE corpses in Chapter Two and more to follow. Are you interested? Then read the story of Peter Chambers, Viggy O'Shea and others who are concerned about the contents of a certain Gladstone bag. Peter Chambers is a private detective, and Viggy is his most profitable client.

THERE have been many attempts to explain the phenomenon known as Bing Crosby, including the one so obvious it has the ring of paradox -- that he may not be bad as an entertainer. Barry Ulanov, biographer of "The Incredible Crosby," finds the full true reason quite easy.

Francis M. Gray of Good Shepherd Roman Catholic Parochial School, Cooper and Isham Streets, received a silver loving cup yesterday afternoon at the residence of Cardinal Spellman, 452 Madison Avenue, as grand prize winner in the annual Cardinal Hayes Christian Doctrine contest.

A bid of $10,000 by the City Art Museum of St. Louis for John Marin's semi-abstract "Seascape" topped all others yesterday when sealed bids of 148 bidders for one or all of the paintings in the State Department's controversial collection of American art were opened at the War Assets Administration regional office at 40 Wall Street under the supervision of Col. John S. Cooke.

BASICALLY "Melissa" is the Wife in Name Only story. Out of a misguided idea that she will be helping her sister write poetry and her brother to get a college education, Melissa Upjohn sacrifices herself to a marriage with a rich publisher.

ORIGINALLY published in 1907 and long out of print, this tale combines make-believe and moral in the true Victorian manner. The peppery Princess Floria believed that if she lost her temper altogether she would be a much nicer person.

Convinced, under current conditions, of the need for constructive action in the field of monetary and banking legislation, bankers indicated last week that they are not yet certain that it can best be accomplished through establishment of "another governmental commission."
LONDON. "WHY do the British get all these deficits?" asked Mr. Taber of a newspaper correspondent. "They never used to."
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Mayors of Los Angeles, Gary, Ind.; Crestline, Ohio, and several other cities took issue with Senator Taft today for his reference to "whistle-stops."

CHICAGO, June 19 -- With the keynoter, Gov. Dwight H. Green, and perhaps the key voters, the Illinois delegation majority entrained for Philadelphia tonight. The first caucus of the delegation of fifty-six, third largest in the convention, will be held tomorrow.

Almost $1,000,000 in cash and pledges have been obtained to finance the industry-sponsored Thomas Alva Edison Foundation, 40 West Fortieth Street. This organization will make available to business executives throughout the world the inner genius of Edison's inventive methods.

AT the end of its first operational year, the new Department of Theatre Arts at the University of California at Los Angeles, headed by Kenneth MacGowan, former film producer, has established a workshop program of documentary film production in collaboration with other divisions of the university and will graduate its first class this month.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 19 -- The people of this city appeared to take the currency reform in the western zones with comparative calm today. Reports reaching here indicated that this was true of other cities in Western Germany. Everyone had expected it.

The murder of George Polk, Middle East correspondent of the Columbia Broadcasting System, last May was "a cold, deliberate political demonstration . . . planned to be spectacular . . . planned to intimidate," Edward R. Murrow said last night.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- President Truman today nominated a twelve-member Public Advisory Board to assist the Economic Cooperation Administrator, Paul G. Hoffman, in managing the European Recovery Program.

Retailers rushed to complete their fall apparel purchases last week in order to test consumer reaction to fall styles and prices, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Adherence to dollar volume budgets, the report continued, caused the buyers difficulty in completing assortments; however it was pointed out that the budgets have acted as a brake on out-of-line inventories.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York will arrive in Philadelphia tomorrow at noon with Mrs. Dewey, Herbert Brownell Jr., one of his preconvention campaign managers, told a press conference today. The Governor and Mrs. Dewey will drive from New York by car.

WITH Ted Shawn back at the helm after a year's absence, the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival will get its ten scheduled week-ends of public performances under way on July 9 in its charming little theatre near Lee, Mass. Each program, as far as possible, will contain examples of classic, modern and ethnologic dance. The calendar is as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- The number of women delegates and alternates who will attend this year's convention of the Republican party is smaller than the 1944 total, but the range of women's political activities has grown.
BERLIN, June 19 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from a proclamation to the German people made today by Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Soviet commander:

IN 1946 (the last year for complete statistics) 620,000 couples were divorced in the United States. Dr. Bergler shows how divorce directly affects more than 5,500,000 of us in a single year. He says the great rise in the divorce-rate over the past fifty years results from our becoming more tolerant of divorce socially.

Victory beckoned to one of the great ex-champions of tennis yesterday in the Forest Hills Stadium as 8,000 spectators roared their encouragement, but youth in the person of John Kramer finally stopped the mighty onslaught of Donald Budge.

MOLINE, Ill., June 19 -Locals of the United Farm Equipment Workers, CIO, representing 8,700 production workers at the Farma and East Moline plants of International Harvester Company, last night voted to accept the ll-cent an-hour wage increase offered t.o all of its employees by the com party. Accpetancc, according to union leaders is contingent oft minor changes in the contract.

BERLIN, June 19 -- Out of the alarms and excursions that have marked the political struggle for Germany in the past week, three main indications have emerged to show the direction. Soviet foreign policy will probably take in Germany during this critical summer.

PRAGUE, June 19 -The possibility of something like a revolt of a portion of the Sokol organization against carrying through the Sokol games under the auspices of the present Communist-dominated regime appeared this weekend.

BUENOS AIRES, June 19 -- Relations between the United States and Argentina may relapse seriously as a result of the dashing of Argentine hopes for an immediate influx of dollars for the purchase of foodstuffs for the European Relief Program.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The third-round wage movement has picked up speed. Major settlements are being reached almost daily. Not all have been achieved peacefully, but the amount of disruption has been far less than was threatened and small in comparison with the magnitude of the negotiations.

THIS small but significant booklet on the divisions within the Christian church has been prepared by a notable group of English scholars and writers. These include the poet. T.S. Eliot; the Bishop of Southhampton; the Chancellor of St. Paul's Cathedral; faculty members of Oxford and Cambridge: Dom Gregory Dix of Nashdom Abbey, and others.

MEXICO CITY, June 19 -- While negotiations continue between the Mexican Government and several United States oil companies as well as independent groups, Antonio J. Bermudez, director of Pemex, the national agency for supervision of oil production, outlined today general terms under which foreign capital may participate in the development of new oil fields.

The current slump in exports, particularly to the sixteen Marshall Plan countries, will be more than offset by a sharp upturn that should begin within the next few weeks, foreign trade observers declared last week.

Rabbi David H. Panitz, preaching at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, west of Broadway, warned yesterday that the cessation of fighting in Palestine "must not be used to force the scuttling of partition, nor must it be used to force the Jews to 'compromise' away what the United Nations has decided is their just claim."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 19 (AP) -- The United States senior golf team defeated Canada, 36 1/2 to 8 1/2, today for the Duke of Devonshire Cup. It was the nineteenth consecutive victory for the United States in the matches which began in 1918.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Russian Government informed the United States in a note received by the State Department today that it would be possible to hold the projected ten-nation conference on freedom of navigation for the Danube this summer in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, after all.

Are there more songbirds than usual this year, or have their songs seemed louder and more carefree when heard against the background of rain, mist and overcast skies? Ever on a murky day, they have made the world more cheerful; and when the sun has shone they have opened up with huge choruses that echoed to the hilltops.

THE top subject of discussion in the film industry last week was, of course, the new British quota which requires theatres to set aside 45 per cent of their playing time for native-made pictures. American interests regarded the action as fresh evidence of the Labor Government's hostility toward the Hollywood industry.

With a view to clarifying income tax and withholding regulations pertaining to compensation paid to United States citizens employed and residing abroad, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, pursuant to the Administrative Procedure Act, has published in tentative form certain proposed amendments to the regulations (Federal Register, issue of May 7, 1948).

In your issue of April 4 you published a map demonstrating the prospective flow of the Marshall Plan aid to the different countries. According to this map an amount of $800,000,000 from the European total of $5,310,000,000 was scheduled to go to Western Germany.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- The 18 election campaign has reached a critical phase without halting the trend toward American leadership in the world. The question how is whether the Republican Party, in a nominating convention that is likely to be decisive, will expose a Presidential candidate next week who will carry on that hand.

CLEVELAND, June 19 (AP) -- The league-leading Indians, who hadn't been getting much pitching lately, got plenty of it today when Bob Muncrief and Russ Christopher combined for a brilliant three-hit shut-out as Cleveland downed the Athletics, 4 to 0.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The State Department announced today the appointment of a twenty-one-member delegation to the first meeting of the World Health Assembly scheduled to meet at Geneva on June 24.

SINCE the Metropolitan Museum put on its "Taste of the Seventies" exhibition two years ago, supplemented by the Knoedler Galleries centennial retrospective, no local event has so sharply focused attention on the differences between modern and non-modern art as the current exhibition at the Metropolitan, "The Turn of the Century."
PHILADELPHIA, June 19 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates scored three times in the ninth inning on only one hit to defeat the Philadelphia Phillies, 7 to 6, today.

"A WIDER ARC," Melville Cane's winnowing of the verse he has written in the last twenty-five years, does reveal the "wider arc" of his unusual gift for the nuance. The arc spans the playful and the serious, and one is able to plot it.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 19 -- As the Columbia River slowly ebbs from the most damaging flood crest since this area was settled by white men, advocates of a regional authority have started pointing out that any plan to control the great waterway must be international to be at all effective.

The "sellers' market" is over, top sales managers in America's million dollar industries revealed during a canvass on the business outlook last week. For the remainder of 1948, even if the "buyers' market" has not returned to very industry, leading sales managers are operating on the basis that completely new streamlined methods of selling must be applied on a larger scale than prewar techniques envisaged.

PRAGUE, June 19 -- Czechoslovakia's office-chair and drawing-board communism has come to full power so painlessly, culminating in the installation of a new Communist President and Parliament, that the rest should be easy. Expected now are a gradual tightening of the reins and a sharpening of the tempo, as in the training of a trotting horse.

LONDON, June 19 -- If Europeans were allowed to participate in American politics, those in the West would probably cast an overwhelming vote for Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg or some equally ardent champion of American economic aid to Europe.

Summer arrives officially tomorrow -- 8:11 A.M. Eastern daylight saving time -- and the Weather Man had cheerful informan about it yesterday. His charts indicated that the first day of the new season would be fair and warmer -- at least by the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Truman gambled in a big way as he headed West a-politicking with the Republican Congress just entering its adjournment drive. But the gamble has seemingly paid dividends, both for the Democratic party and for the President himself.
IT doubtless is no news to you that your favorite movie star smokes Koffos or feeds her dog Tay-Stee-Hors. But you'd be surprised at all the complexities behind the endorsement business.

Hazel Scott, pianist, made her debut as soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony, conducted by Walter Hendl, at Lewisohn Stadium last night. The concert attracted nearly 14,000 listeners, the largest number since the season started Monday night.

NARBERTH, Pa., June 19 -- Ch Knightscroft Symphony, Irish setter owned by Miss Helen Naylor of Blue Bell, and handled as usual by Harold Correll, was named best in a field of 794 dogs at the annual Bryn Mawr Kennel Club show at the Narberth Community Playground today.

Another round in the rift between the left and right-wing factions of the Council on African Affairs ended yesterday with the arrest of Dr. Doxey Wilkerson, a council member and member of the national committee of the Communist party; Harold Cammer, attorney for the leftist group within the council, and Thomas Lloyd, who told the police he was a furrier.

Thomas J. Shaw and Bill Shea of the Sands Point Golf Club scored 32, 34 -- 66 to gain a deadlock with Max Habricht and Dr. A. Keck, unattached, 33, 33 -- 66 at the halfway point in the Pomonok Golf Club's member-guest tournament in Flushing yesterday.
