PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- Harold E. Stassen, obviously angered by reports that he and his supporters were discussing a "deal" for a Taft-Stassen ticket, told reporters today that he would have no part in deals, nor in the slanders that produced reports of deals.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- Representative Clarence J. Brown, campaign manager for Senator Robert A. Taft, conceded for the first time today that Governor Thomas E. Dewey may lead the field on the first ballot for the Republican Presidential nomination.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 19 -- Pell-Mel Patton of Southern California, a key figure in the United States Olympic picture because he is this country's best bet to win in a flat race at London, captured the spotlight today with a smashing, fast-time sprint double in the twenty-seventh annual National Collegiate Athletic Association track and field championships.

MOUNT CARMEL, Pa., June 19 -- Government aeronautic experts, baffled thus far on the causes of the crash near here on Thursday of a United Air Lines DC-6 in which all forty-three aboard were killed, started today as an aid to their inquiry to "reconstruct" the shattered airplane on flat ground.

CLEVELAND, June 19 -- With shipments running more than 4,000,000 gross tons ahead of last year's peacetime record, iron ore traffic on the Great Lakes this season may reach the target of 86,000,000 tons requested by consumers, according to maritime officials here.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- In a 4-to-1 decision the National Labor Relations Board today ruled that the Taft-Hartley Act required an employer to bargain with his employes on any group health and accident insurance program covering them.

WHEN pirates scuttled Captain Crathorne's ship, and set him and his crew adrift, his family back in Newport knew nothing of his whereabouts for many months, but they carried on with the courage characteristic of American colonists.

Geoffrey Gorer's "Political Behavior in the Human Fe male" brought a blush of shame to my face. I kept trying to refute his sweeping generalities, but while I could think of a few individual exceptions, I had the unpleasant conviction that what he was saying was "too true to be funny." * * *

JOE LOUIS sat on the rubbing table in his Madison Square Garden dressing room last December. A white towel was draped over his head and down the sides of his face, giving his always inscrutable features a more sphinx-like quality than usual. His left eye was closed to a narrow slit His lips were puffed.

THE newest of the "mystery worlds" to command man's attention is that of high speed. Why should it be mysterious? A man can run a hundred yards in ten seconds; some birds have been known to make sixty miles an hour; an airliner can cover the distance between New York and Chicago in four hours and less.
CHICAGO, June 19 -- This vigorous city is moving toward a position in the top rank of the nation's medical research centers.

An exhibition of oriental books, selected from the Public Library's collection of Eastern writings to show the diversity of form that books have taken in various civilizations, opens tomorrow in the library' Main entrance Hall.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 19 -- Leaders in government and education in the South are going ahead with plans to establish separate regional schools for Negroes in fields of higher education; and they expect to have them in operation this fall.

ONE second of action is slowed down to three minutes of projection on a movie screen in Henry M. Lester's high-speed film study of the wing beats of a fly, to be shown Wednesday by Cinema 16 Film Society.

THIS work is a public domain, not a private park. All may walk therein and see this country and themselves in variegated activities and active passions. Its imaginative acuity recreates a sense of reality and actuality. The author's note to the earlier book stated "that a man is himself a city"; Part One introduced "the elemental character of the place."

PRETTY much of opposite schools, Mr. Winston Churchill and Mr. Norman Mailer nevertheless have something in common Mr. Mailer's novel, "The Naked and the Dead," is already a runaway seller and Mr. Churchill's "The Gathering Storm" gives every indication that it will follow suit.

THE penthouse apartment in which the Parrotts are to live rent-free for a limited time is ideal except for the corpse in the woodpile. Gordon Parrott is a detective on the staff of the District Attorney; in ordinary circumstances, his wife takes an active part in all murder investigations conducted by her husband, but this time Liz is "that way," as our grandmothers used to put it.

FOR THIS WEEK: Watch for aphids and spray with nicotine sulfate. Reddish brown ones have even covered the buds of madonna lilies this year. . . . As soon as soil dries out and becomes thoroughly warm, replant vegetable seeds which have not sprouted. Some, such as beans, have rotted during the past month because of the rain. . . .
Congress approved last week in a flurry of last-minute legislation the largest peacetime military appropriation bills in the nation's history.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, June 20 (AP) -- Senate and House conferees failed once more early today to agree on new farm price support legislation. Senator George D. Aiken and Representative Clifford R. Hope said they saw no possible chance of agreement.

MONTREAL, June 19 -- Canada's expected post-war shipping boom has temporarily hit the skids because of a general drop in available cargoes and slumping freight rates to the Continent, shipping men said here today.

Piling up points in fifteen of the nineteen events on the program, the New York Athletic Club completely over-shadowed its metropolitan rivals yesterday at Red Hook Stadium to capture the team title in the junior A.A.U. track and field championships.

HERE is that rare thing, a biography not of an individual but of a work of art. In it the author traces the career of Handel's "Messiah" from its conception more than two hundred years ago down to the present, and shows the influence it has had not only upon musicians but upon poets and philosophers as well.
ALMOST a quarter of a century ago, Brig. Gen. William Mitchell (more familiarly known as Billy Mitchell) wrote that "air power may be defined as the ability to do something in the air."

Dr. John G. Woods, one of Australia's world-famed seven "flying doctors," is in the United States on his first trip after having served nine years without a vacation in the bush homestead territory. On his first trip outside Australia, he intends to observe the latest American medical advances in surgery, medicine and dentistry.

GENEVA, June 19 -- More than 100 delegates from twenty-two European countries and an equal number from outside Europe will be present at the World Jewish Congress meeting opening at Montreux, Switzerland, June 27. Dr. Stephen S. Wise will head the United States delegation.
The two regattas that usually mark the end of the college rowing season, the Poughkeepsie races on the Hudson and the Harvard-Yale meeting on the Thames at New London, will be held this week.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin, was named today chairman of a Senate foreign relations subcommittee which will seek answers to questions raised by opponents of the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway and power development.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- The lead of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey for the Republican nomination for President was threatened late this afternoon when Kim Sigler, Governor of Michigan, issued a statement that he was certain Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg was available for the Presidential nomination.

CECIL B. DeMILLE, who has been leaping along the empyrean summits of sacred and profane history for better than two decades, may lay claim to something of a title when he trains his camera on "Samson and Delilah" in September.

THERE is a sound body of opinion which rather tenaciously holds that the unquenchable "motion pi'tures" go too often to the well of the legitimate theatre for dramatic material and that so many visitations are bound to result in eventual cracks. Maybe.

If all the nations of the earth honestly practiced the philosophy embodied in the twenty-eight articles of the International Declaration of Human Rights, adopted 12 to 0 yesterday by a United Nations commission, this world would indeed become a Utopia. Unfortunately, it can now be no more than an ideal for future attainment because of profoundly conflicting conceptions of the relation of the individual to the state.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The House passed and sent to the White House tonight a compromise stop-gap bill for the induction for twenty-one months of military service of men through 25 years of age.

THE prolific Mr. Wodehouse began writing novels in 1902 or thereabouts, and his devotees by this time must be only three or four short of legion. He created, among other notable personalities, Threepwood, Jeeves and Psmith, and his talent for cozily descrying the chinks in the armor of the tea-and-crumpets set is very likely unequaled by any writer on either side of the Atlantic.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- The GOP elephant crept into this city for the 1948 convention today with catlike tread. The general atmosphere was strangely unconventional, and, at first, a little puzzling. It took a while to figure how and why it differed from previous conventions, but the truth came suddenly, and a little shrilly.

THE Kleeman Gallery has assembled a collection of European and American modern works which is as eloquent of the recent history of the modern movement as you could wish. The scope and catholic nature of the selection give the show something of museum quality.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- The foreign affairs subcommittee of the Republican Resolutions Committee has adopted the so-called Vandenberg foreign relations plank for the party platform. Chairman Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., of Massachusetts said the vote of the subcommittee was unanimous.

AMHERST, Mass., June 19 -- Amherst fell before the sensational one-hit pitching of Righthander George Ditmar today as Williams College defeated the Jeffs, 3 -- 1, for the Little Three title before an Alumni Day crowd of 2,000 fans.

TOKYO, June 19 -- The Russians have been taking reprisals against Japanese prisoners of war because of "false stories" about the Soviet Union told here by former captives, according to Japanese officials.

WRITING in Poetry Ireland, a new monthly published in Dublin and devoted to the work of contemporary Irish poets, L. A. G. Strong remarks on the extent to which the prose work of James Stephens has overshadowed his poetry.

OSLO -- A Belgian proposal to eliminate or reduce passport and visa formalities for international travel was strongly opposed at meetings here last week of the International Union of Official Tourist Organizations, and the International Conference of National Travel Organizations. While there seemed to

THE grapevine has produced the name of another new singer engaged for the Metropolitan Opera, Italo Tajo, young Italian bass-baritone, who has already won attention here with his record album of six Mozart arias and his appearance in the Italian movies "The Barber of Seville" and "L'Elisir d'Amore."

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Justice T. Alan Goldsborough said today that he would rule next Thursday morning on the Government request for a permanent court order to prevent three railroad unions from striking.

ONE closes Mr. Berryman's book of poems with the satisfaction taken from a craft skillfully and lovingly exercised, but somehow without the excitement that attends the transformation of a craft into a completely realized art.

HAVING successfully rollicked through Mexico, Mr. Dodge, erstwhile mystery-story writer turned professional traveler, moves southward in his most recent book to the banana republics. The ostensible purpose of his fifteen-month residence in Guatemala was to gather material for future murder mysteries.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, June 20 -- The $6,030,710,228 foreign aid appropriation measure was passed by Congress and sent to the White House early today with $5,055,000,000 for starting the European Recovery Program. It was left to President Truman to decide whether the money should be spent in twelve or fifteen months.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 19 -- One of the golfing trophies highly prized by junior stars, the Pressrey Cup, went to Bill Ragland of Choate today when the 17-year-old youngster from Chattanooga won the Eastern Interscholastic Association championship 36-hole final over the Greenwich Country Club course for the second year in a row.

HOLLYWOOD -- "Robin Hood," "Treasure Island" and the other great adventure stories among the classics make excellent radio fare for both kids and adults, says Ralph Rose, director-adapter of the new Sunday CBS series, "Tell It Again," which features these dramatizations. But there are pitfalls for the actors who appear in these swashbuckling classics, warns Rose.

"Errors" of Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels, the founders of Marxian socialism, are "refuted" and their omissions supplied from inspirations drawn from Lenin and Stalin in the new magazine of the Institute of Economics of the Academy of Science of the Soviet Union, Voprosy Ekonomiki (Problems of Economics).

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 (AP) -- George L. Sheldon and Nelson E. Taylor asked the Federal District Court today to direct the Republican national convention to seat them as delegates from Mississippi. In addition, the two seek $5,000 damages.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 19 -- Miss Phyllis Hill, stage actress, and Jose Ferrer, director, producer and actor, were married here this morning in the meeting room of the Town Hall by Judge Archibald H. Tunick of the Town Court.

CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -- Corn led an advance in grains on the Board of Trade today. At times the yellow grain was up more than 2 cents a bushel, the July contract showing the best gain. Some buying was traced to commercial interests, and there also was short covering in this delivery.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 19 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association today awarded its East-West championship basketball play-offs for next season to the University of Washington at Seattle.

ONE of the attractive respects of records is that they make -- or should make -- accessible the art of other lands so that it may be relished again and again at one's pleasure. Occasionally it is the music of other countries that draws attention; at other times it is the performers.
The United'States Conciliation Service. will call a meeting of' ship owners and leaders of three seamen's unions next week in an effort to settle a threatened nationwide maritime strike.

THIS is a very special book; special because it is a highly personal, and even charming, philosophic essay. Reading this little book is like being talked to by a modest, sincere man obviously appreciative of beautiful objects, wise notions and the finer things in life.

Although dollar-hungry Europe keeps clinging to overvalued currencies and state controls in an attempt to keep internal economies insulated from the consequences of the war, at least one market continues to chart faithfully the ups and downs of international credit as measured by the yardstick of supply and demand, freely and lawfully applied.

CLEVELAND, June 19 -- Steps taken today by the Negro Newspaper Publishers Association to improve the quality and scope of their papers included the transfer of the annual awards for journalistic excellence to the Nieman Foundation of Harvard University and an agreement to join Hampton Institute and Tuskegee Institute in the training of printing craftsmen.
CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) -- Pitcher Marino Pieretti and Outfielder Pat Seerey, two additions via recent trades, blended their efforts to aid the White Sox in a 9-5 victory over the Senators today.

WHAT gives Winston Churchill his unique position among the figures of his age, among the figures of any age, indeed, is the extraordinary role he plays as the maker and the recorder of history. He is at once the hero of the drama and the dramatist. This dual character is immortalized in this book, the magnificent beginning of the crowning work of his life.
STANTON, Del., June 19 (AP) -- Miss Grillo finally ran back to her fine 1947 record today as she soundly whipped six other fillies and mares in the $25,000 added New Castle Handicap at Delaware Park.

Rabbi William F, Rosenblum, president of the Synagogue Council of America, and Henry Epstein, chairman of the National Community Relations Advisory Council, in a joint statement yesterday declared that their organizations "consider the New York system of released time to be inconsistent with the American principle of separation of church and state, and believe that system to have been invalidated by the recent United States Supreme Court decision in the McCollum case."

DESPITE authorization by Congress for a seventy-group Air Force and appropriations for sixty-six groups, plane manufacturers and other critics of the program are describing the announced allocations of money as leading to logistical imbalance.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 19 -- Disturbed at growing signs of censorship, members of the American Library Association concluding their week-long sessions here called upon civic and professional groups to join in a campaign to safeguard intellectual freedom in this country.

MANILA, June 19 -- Government control of imports, which Filipinos feel are too largely in alien hands, has been urged on a special session of Congress by President Elpidio Quirino. He asks legislation designed to accomplish what forbidden tariff applications cannot do.

PEIPING, June 17 (Delayed) -- The academic year, just coming to a close in this main center of higher education in China, has seen a steady shift of university opinion in favor of the Communists. This is the estimate of Americans and Chinese connected with the leading universities here.

In an effort to find more game and fewer hunters, a record number of American sportsmen seem to be heading for Africa this summer, and as most of them are taking along modern small-caliber, high-velocity rifles, the results of some of these safaris are bound to be interesting, if not amusing.

One of John L. Lewis' most powerful weapons in disputes with the coal-mine owners is time. The United Mine Workers dig coal -- or don't dig it -- as he directs. When they don't dig it, coal-starved industry slows down. There is public pressure for a settlement -- and usually Mr. Lewis gets what he wants.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP) -- The House completed Congressional action today on a bill to allow eight four-star admirals and generals to hold their ranks until June 30, 1950.

WASHINGTON. THERE is a good deal of talk that the approaching Republican National Convention at Philadelphia may have to resort to the "smoke-filled room" to nominate a candidate for President in this year so critical in our history and that of the world.
The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's forty-fifth championship will get under way over the Nassau Country Club course tomorrow. Play will continue through Saturday.

HUMAN power over the physical energies of nature has immensely increased. In moral ideal, power of man over physical nature should be employed to reduce, to eliminate progressively, the power of man over man. By what means shall we prevent its use to effect new, more subtle, more powerful agencies of subjection of men to other men?

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- It will probably be news to V.M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, that he has been frequently mentioned in United States Navy dispatches as "Dunker." The designation had nothing to do with his gastronomic propensities, which are unknown to the Navy.

PRETORIA, Union of South Africa, June 19 -- Political circles here are inclined to believe that Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts very soon will cease to play a leading part in this country. They find confirmation for this view in cabled reports of the former Prime Minister's remarks as he left England this morning, "I must return to my tasks which go on endlessly and lead nowhere."

For the first time in years, the American railroads have obtained some favorable legislation from the Congress. In its desire to afford the railroads some relief in their present efforts to meet the pressing transportation needs of the country, Congress has enacted the controversial Reed-Bulwinkle Bill over the President's veto and has passed a measure adjusting taxes on railroads for unemployment insurance which at present means a saving to the carriers of about $100,000,000 annually.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- "There'll be no deadlock," said Senator Robert A. Taft several weeks ago; "it will be Tom [Thomas E. Dewey] or me."

UNTIL the invention of talking pictures Leila Dove was a star in the silent movies. Now she is broke and wants to go back to Hollywood to recover large sum of money which she hid away after winning it in a crap game.

AN attempt by the Town of Webb to wipe out the black flies in the Old Forge-Eagle Bay section of the Fulton Chain of Lakes in the Central Adirondacks, is being watched closely by resort operators throughout this country and Canada.

JERUSALEM, June 19 -- The Jewish population of Jerusalem looked forward today to the prospect of receiving 100 truckloads of fresh food each day when a Jewish Agency spokesman indicated that all obstacles to sending in such shipments had been removed.

Of the tens of thousands of compounds which have been developed for medical use some have arrested the growth of cancers for a time. Who knows but there may be chemical relatives that are even more effective? Some of these chemical relatives have been made for other uses than those of medicine; some are mere suggestions still to be converted into realities; all deserve the consideration of biochemists and cancer specialists.

MILITARY Governments in Germany, Austria, Japan and Korea have opened approximately sixty United States Information Centers to place before the native populations American books, magazines and newspapers, thereby broadening the outlook of these peoples so long denied free access to news of world affairs, particularly American.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Senate completed Congressional action today on a $407,836,974 appropriation to operate the Interior Department for the next year and sent it to the White House.

When Milo R. Maltbie retires from the chairmanship of the Public Service Commission and from the Commission itself, which he has informed Governor Dewey he intends to do soon, it will be with a recognized record of service to the public in that field begun more than forty years ago.

WASHINGTON. THE American people want their Government to work as smoothly as possible. They want both President and Congress to carry out their pledges, and they have had sufficient experience to know that when the Executive and Legislative branches disagree, or fail to work together, the cause of good government has generally suffered.

The crux of the East-West struggle for Germany is this: the defeated Reich has 65,000,000 people and the greatest industrial potential in Europe. The Western powers want to link their parts of Germany to Western Europe, using German resources to aid European recovery.

The manufacturers of factory-built houses are missing the boat. There is a market for low-cost houses and they are not filling it. Babson may be right that it is the coming new industry. Of course, building methods are archaic, if only from a technological standpoint.

Although the exact reason for it is not clear, the American pleasure boating world shows signs of being regatta-crazy for 1948. Speedboat events are sprouting where none have ever existed or have not been held in years. Traditional fixtures on the calendar are attracting new record-sized entry lists.

THERE are five Barkington children, ranging from a new baby to Roddy, age 11. Patsy, the only girl, is 7. This book tells of ten amusing, sometimes hectic, episodes in their lives when they go to live with Grandmother because she has been sick. How Grandmother survives is a wonder!

PARIS, June 19 -- Socialists of Europe, Africa and Asia today opened in the Paris suburb of Puteaux a three-day conference to inaugurate a movement for a Socialist federation of Europe as the forerunner to world federation.

NANKING, June 19 -- American diplomatic observers here are trying to find the cause of the decline in good will toward the United States among various Chinese groups, particularly intellectuals, just as the new large scale aid program is about to go into effect.

ANYBODY who was connected with the Air Forces in England during the past war, and possibly quite a few people who weren't connected with either the Air Forces or England or the past war, probably remembers the Gremlins.

GORKY in his reminiscences quoted some schoolmaster as having written to Chekhov: "To tell the truth, scoundrels too are unhappy -- the devil take them." On this apothegm Mr. Swinnerton has pounced for a title-page motto; and, being Mr. Swinnerton and incapable of showy mystifications, he has flouted custom by making his motto count for something more than a printer's ornament.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 19 -- Thirty-five Communists have been arrested following the surprise declaration last night suspending civil rights for thirty days.

ROSES are irresistible, both in the garden and in arrangements. In order to enjoy them for a longer period in arrangements, three points must be kept in mind: when to cut, how to cut and how to condition them.

Major New York department stores will stand together in opposing attempts by left wing unions of their employes to circumvent the Taft-Hartley law by substituting novel security clauses in their contracts, it was indicated yesterday.

A little over two years ago Jim Daugherty sat in the huge Army discharge center a Camp Pickett, Va., awaiting his final papers and pay. He had finished him physical examination, checked in his clothing and equipment, and heard a final lecture on veterans' rights.

CERTAIN aspects of a transaction in the letters of an obscure deceased author arouse the curiosity of Henry Gamadge, who has been asked to examine the letters with a view to estimating their value. When he arrives at the Bradlock home, where the examination was to take place, he learns that the correspondence has already been sold, apparently in a great hurry.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- A safe and simple new technique for studying normal and abnormal flow of blood through the human heart by following injections of radiosodium with a spsecially designed Geiger-Mueller counter was reported to the meeting of the American Heart Association here today.

BERLIN, June 19 -- The United States and British Military Governments countered the Soviet Military Administration's land blockade of Berlin with air power today as the Russians strove to complete the isolation of this city and bring the whole of the Soviet zone behind the "iron curtain."

ROME, June 19 -- The Foreign Ministry faced the possibility today that Parliament might be unable to ratify the Italo-United States bilateral agreement for the European Recovery Program before the deadline of midnight, July 3.

The decline in retail activity last week was mainly attributed to bad weather, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Men's furnishings, notions and misses' sportswear departments reported the highest sales.

Light weight and a game head-end run won the $28,400 Gazelle Stakes for Havahome Stable's Sweet Dream at Aqueduct yesterday. Under 111 pounds and in receipt of a concession of ten from King Ranch's Scattered, Sweet Dream held on through the final yards to finish about a head in front of the one hailed as leading lady among the 3-year-olds.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, June 20 -- The Eightieth Congress struggled into today in tension and great fatigue toward some form of adjournament while Philadelphia beckoned the Republicans almost irresistibly toward their national convention.

On Jan. 2, 1947, 524 men and 7 women convened at the Capitol in Washington. They constituted the Eightieth Congress since the legislative branch came into being in 1789. Of the original Eightieth Congressmen fourteen have since died, nine have resigned: nineteen of the vacancies have been filled by special elections and appointments.

THERE are going to be four plays on Broadway dealing with the theatre and its people when the new season gets going in the fall and even the departmental trend-spotter last week was willing to make way for the operative-in-charge-of-coincidences.
ATHENS, June 19 (AP) -- Greek troops who advanced under a smoke screen today won Orlai Heights southwest of Nestorion, in the Grammos region of Western Macedonia, from stubborn guerrillas.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Truman named today a Board of Inquiry under the Taft-Hartley Act to report by next Wednesday on the coal-contract dispute.
GENEVA, June 19 -- Eleven nations signed a new multilateral convention here today on the recognition of property rights in aircraft.

TWENTY thousand eager and politically, voracious Republicans, intoxicated with a probably nonfatal dose of overconfidence, will swarm into Philadelphia this week for a victory jamboree unlike anything they have had for twenty years.

Charles Masterson of Hicksville, L.I., a school teacher at Poly Prep in Brooklyn, turned in one of the finest performances of his tennis career in routing top-seeded Sidney Schwartz, former National Junior champion from Brooklyn, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3, in the final of the Spanish invitation tennis tournament at the Hispano T.C. courts in Whitestone, Queens, yesterday.

The Third Inter-American Cardiological Congress met in Chicago last week. Some 500 physicians attended. Most of these were experts in heart diseases, and they came not only from Latin America but from all over the world.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- The delegates from nine states with 363 votes, virtually one-third of the 1,094 in the Republican National Convention which will convene here on Monday will determine the party nominee for President.

THE signs in the store windows all said "Welcome Hollywood." But the stores were closed, the sidewalks were literally pulled in and the natives were sporting more beards than you could find at Central Casting when a Warner Brothers location company of seventy-one people debarked from a nine-car special train here three weeks ago to begin shooting "Fighter Squadron," a Technicolor story of the United States Air Force in World War II.

NEW DELHI, India, June 19 -- Chakravarthi Rajagopalachari, 69-year-old Indian elder statesman, will take the oath of office as the first Indian Governor General on Monday morning. The ceremony will take place two hours after the present Governor General, Earl Mountbatten, leaves by special plane for London.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Senate passed by a feeble voice vote today a bill admitting up to 205,000 homeless Europeans and political refugees to the United States in the next two years, and giving hope of permanent residence to as many as 15,000 alien displaced persons already here on temporary visas.

OBERLIN, Ohio, June 19 -- The General Council of the Congregational Christian Churches, after nearly three hours of good-humored debate, decided today to postpone further discussion of its proposed merger with the Evangelical and Reformed Church until Monday morning.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- To the vacationist with a boat, Lake Champlain can be either a delightful thoroughfare leading from New York via the Hudson River to the St. Lawrence River and Canada, or a 100-mile calm lake for lazy holiday cruising.
PARIS, June 19 -- Many workers throughout France responded today to a Communist appeal for a one-hour general strike.

ATHENS, June 19 -- The Greek National Army, considerably strengthened by American supplies and ammunition, is now engaged in a major offensive designed to crush the Communist-led rebellion of the Markos guerrillas.

IF a continuous supply of beans is to be picked from bush varieties, more than one sowing must be made. The bush kinds -- preferred by many people -- do not yield over a long period, as the pole varieties do. Successive plantings will assure a crop throughout the summer.
CHICAGO, June 19 -- Bobby Locke shot his third straight sub-par round at Midlothian today, banging a 36, 34 -- 70 for a 54-hole

What peculiar reasoning is that of Eric Newton in his article "What Is Modern Art?" Having declared that "art is a record of human experience," he proceeds to decry the presentation of visual experience in the graphic arts!
Before Mr. Reiss accuses Great Britain of "staying" in the "Jersey Islands" and Malta, he should look to his history and geography.

LONDON, June 19 -- Hector McNeil, Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, proclaimed tonight Britain's adherence to the Charter of the United Nations as the basis of her foreign policy, despite the fall from the hopes of three years ago.

BEFORE the week is out the next President may be chosen at Philadelphia, according to the way many persons are thinking. Since most important business men are supposed to be of Republican persuasion, this result would not fail to be reassuring. In fact, some of the confidence now expressed in the business outlook might be traced to this source.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 19 -- Mrs. Helen Lewis, wife of a Chicago construction engineer, was found beaten to death at 11 A.M. today on the edge of the rain-soaked baseball field of Trevor Park. Less than five hours later the police arrested an electrician's helper and charged him with slaying the 37-year-old woman.

MOST people have a definite aversion to bugs. They say that all bugs should stay deep underground from June 1 to May 31, but Richmond Kelsey found a good-natured little bug on a small island in the Pacific who was too busy with his own problem to bother anyone.

THE "New York at Work" Golden Jubilee anniversary parade proved again that the people who watch parades frequently offer more interesting picture possibilities than the parade itself. Much of the latter is routine, little different from other parades and with hardly a shot to tempt the amateur's camera.

AN American entertained a Dane in a Copenhagen restaurant not long ago. Struggling with the menu, he suggested dish after dish, but the guest always answered, "No thank you; I'll just have bread and butter."

SINCE 1800 Washington has had its National Theatre. Within a few weeks the present National, on a site which has been a theatre since 1835, will be closing its doors to the stage, not by neglect of the public, but at the insistence of the American theatrical profession.

BERLIN, June 19 -- The City Assembly, in special session tonight, spurned Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky's proposal that it be included in a Soviet zone currency reform plan. It urged Berliners not to become "confused by unilateral declarations."

In the article, "30,000 Americans Can Be Wrong," Richard L. Neuberger remarks: "Not many people tell a candidate he is going to lose. And when he has lost he finds himself a lonely man. Many salty tears have been shed on election nights."

"STOP THE MUSIC," the ABC network's giveaway show, which in a matter of weeks has won national attention with its fabulous prizes, follows an elaborate procedure in choosing the names of persons who shall receive a lucky telephone call sfrom the studio. Every precaution is taken to be sure that there is no hitch in the program's presentation at 8 o'clock Sundays.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- It would be utterly misleading to assert, two days in advance of the first session of the Republican National Convention, that there is a mad scramble on for the Vice Presidential nomination. There is no question, however, that quite a few politically distinguished and ambitious gentlemen have the job in mind, some as a promotion and some as a compromise.

Ninety-two years ago this week in Philadelphia the Republican party -- organized two years before at Jackson, Mich. -- nominated its first Presidential candidate. He was John Charles Fremont of California. Five months later he was roundly beaten by James Buchanan of Pennsylvania, Democrat.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- Sweeping investigations of alleged graft in the administration of this city's municipal Government are sharing the local spotlight with the preparations for preliminaries of the Republican National Convention.

BAYSHORE, L.I., June 19 -- Dave Seaman and Jimmy Smith, Hempstead, winners of the medal honors on Friday, led the way through the first two rounds of the South Bay Golf Club's member-guest tournament today with two clean-cut victories.

WHILE the soil in my garden is as dry as the sands of the Sahara, some years ago I helped a friend start a garden on ground which had so many underground springs it was almost a swamp. Today the garden still thrives, proving that the home owner with moist land on his property can exploit successfully the unusual opportunities it affords.

The Music Lovers League, which gives annual awards to musicians, last night made its presentation to music critics. Noel Straus of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and Louis Biancolli of The World-Telegram, were chosen as the New York critics who have "consistently offered the most constructive and helpful criticism" during the 1947-48 season.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- Sweeping investigations of alleged thievery and graft in the Philadelphia government are sharing the local spotlight with the doings of the 1948 Republican National Convention.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 19 -- A gray day of light, fluky airs brought 125 starters, short courses and first places to Donald Millar's international Brendy, Rodney and Charles Ollinger's Herreshoff S. boat Sugar Cane, Ronald and Trygve Meyer's Atlantic Virginia and Donald Scholle's 110 Ten to One among others this afternoon.

DARIEN, Conn., June 19 -- Faugh-a-Ballagh, aged chestnut gelding from Mrs. Audrey Kennedy's Brookline, Mass., Seven Stars Stable and Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Hale's Greenwich, Conn., chestnut gelding Glen Erin excelled in the opening program of the two-day Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show today.

THIS is the month of graduations, in music schools and conservatories, as well as universities and other institutions of early achievement. It is a time of ceremonies, which precede by a few weeks or months the practical aftermath.

THE invariable difficulty a writer faces in attempting to portray (whether in semi-fiction or biography) the life and the character of a man like Arthur Rimbaud is that such people are neither understandable nor explicable -- except in their own terms.

WRITING in high good humor and yet with a deeply sensitive touch, Frances Warfield tells the story of a young girl who drew a rigid line around her life until she freed herself by acknowledging a weakness she never had been able to conceal.

CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) -- Gov. Earl Warren of California, Republican Presidential hopeful, predicted a deadlock today among the major candidates for the nomination and indicated a view that prospects would thereby be improved.

CONSIDERING the circumstances of its composition, Henry Luther Stoddard's "Presidential Sweepstakes" is a remarkable document. Mr. Stoddard began his apprenticeship as a political reporter as long ago as 1885 with an assignment to cover General Grant's death watch.

ST. LOUIS, June 19 -- Shaking off the lethargy that has enveloped them since they left New York, the Yankees, performing in the presence of Babe Ruth, 10,120 admiring youngsters and 5,271 paying clients, finally got around today to demonstrating their superiority over the Browns.

PARIS, June 19 -- The labor disorders that broke out this week in Clermont-Ferrand, and the sympathy strikes and wage demands that followed, abruptly turned the attention of France from the outside German problem to a gathering storm within.

THIS past spring has been particularly trying or peonies. For while the peony is a basically hardy plant, the flower buds of many varieties are susceptible to cold. Consequently, blasted and blackened buds, with malformed and poor flowers, are more prevalent this season than ever.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 20 -- With Reichsmarks invalid in Western Germany as of midnight tonight, this country's first currency reform since the wild inflationary days of 1923 was instituted this morning.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 20 -Charles P. Taft of Cincinnati today described as discouraging and i threatening the fanaticism, irre-i sponsibility and non-compromisei attitude of America's pressure groups. Dr. Taft brother of Senator Taft and president of the Fed-i eral Council of Churches of Christ, I , addressed the graduating class of Trini/y College.

Home furnishings installment stores now need dollar capital equal to between 60 and 75 per cent of their annual volume, Manfred I. Behrens Jr., vice president and general manager of Ludwig Baumann, declared in an interview last week.

City College has reversed itself on a decision made six years ago that resulted in the leveling of charges of anti-Semitism against Prof. William E. Knickerbocker, chairman of the Department of Romance Languages.

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- Sid Hudson, knocked out in his last nine starts, pitched the Senators to a 4-1 victory over the White Sox before 22,729 fans today after Chicago won the opener, 8 -- 5, as Luke Appling set a new American League record with ten assists at third base.

LONDON, June 20 -- The resistance of the stock markets here to adverse circumstances which a week ago gave promise of strengthening has weakened again and the general atmosphere is one of mild gloominess. The picture is relieved only by the comparative strength of gilt-edge securities, which, in fact, derive their support from the dubious outlook to which other securities, particularly industrials, are succumbing.
ORANGE, N.J., June 20 (AP) -Don McNeill of New York, National champion in 1940, swept into the quarter-final round of the New Jersey State men's tennis championships today by scoring three victories.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 20 -- Home economists from all sections of the country arrived here this week-end for the opening tomorrow of a four-day conference of the American Home Economics Association. Three thousand are expected to attend the thirty-ninth annual meeting at the Municipal Auditorium.

A spot bid sale of surplus goods beginning June 28 at the Bronx Customer Service Center, Eastchester Road, will include offerings of valves, fittings, jacks, pressure gauges, nuts, bolts, shackles hand tools, welding electrodes, pneumatic drills, Diesel engine parts, copper and brass tubing, marine hardware and wrenches, it was announced over the week-end by John R. Campbell, New York regional director of the War Assets Administration.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 20 (UP) -- Wisconsin, last of the eleven crews to arrive on the scene, occupied the Hudson alone today for a final stiff workout before Tuesday's Poughkeepsie regatta. For the most part, the other eights took it easy and even mixed a little pleasure with business as they wound up training for the three-mile classic.

BOSTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Boston Braves strengthened their grip on first place in the National League's race today by defeating the Cincinnati Reds, 5 -- 4 and 4 -- 1, their fifth and sixth victories in succession, before a crowd of 32,812.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 20 (AP) -Twenty persons were killed and forty-one wounded today by two heavy explosions in the Jewish quarter of Cairo's bazaar district. The blasts were believed to have been accidental detonations of fireworks explosives.

Salvation Army Captains Olive McKeown and Luella B. Larder, known to many as the "Angels of the Bowery," announced yesterday that they had discovered a new antagonist in their bailiwick -- the small translucent screen of the television set.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 20 -- The International Hope, owned by Bill John; the Herreshoff S boat Auley, belonging to W.S. Chesley Jr.; Howard Seymour's Atlantic Mutiny, and Arthur Deacon's Star Armade were among the winners this tantalizing day in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's regatta.

BERLIN, June 20 (Reuters) -- Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, the Soviet Military Governor, branding the introduction of currency reform in Western Germany as "illegal,'' said tonight it forced him Lo take "urgent steps" to "protect the interests of the German people."

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- Philadelphia isn't "abroad." As the Republican delegates gather from every state in the Union the scene is unmistakably American. It is impossible to imagine anywhere else the political folkways which reach their climax in the party conventions.
R.H. Whidden, formerly assistant sales manager of W.A. Sheaffer Pen Company, Fort Madison, Iowa, has been appointed general sales manager to succeed the late Rex M. Cohn.

ATHENS, June 20 -- Today's General Staff communique said that army units thrusting from the Nestorian sector southwest of Kastoria toward the Grammos mountain mass had taken their objectives after disposing of a rebel counter-attack supported by artillery.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 20 -- Aerial bombardment of San Jose and other cities was planned for dawn of June 28, declared President Jose Figueres of the Junta Government last night. In a broadcast he said he suspensed civil guarantees suddenly at Friday midnight because of a counter-revolutionary plot that Dr. Rafael Calderon Guardia y Munoz had been hatching in exile in Managua with the aid of Communist leaders still in this country.

PEARL RIVER, N.Y., June 20 -- People who used to wonder whether grandpa slept with his beard over the quilt or under it can now devote their spare time to deciding if an ordinary honey bee can get away with its stinger after jabbing it into a person. A start was made here on this subject today by the Bee Keepers Association.

A visit to housewares stores here is apt to result in one or more spur-of-the moment prchases, even if one intended simply to look around. Counters are well stocked with pots and pans and other equipment that has been hard or impossible to finch.

Your dispatch from Eugene, Ore., quotes President Truman as saying that he likes "old Joe" -- Stalin; that he is a decent fellow but a prisoner of the Politburo; that he would keep his agreements were it not for the bad fellows in the Politburo.
SALT LAKE CITY, June 20 -- The men who design the new skyscrapers, homes and factories of America have decided to try to meet the challenge of the atomic bomb in the construction field.
Nothing the Dodgers did on the field in Brooklyn yesterday became them so much as their leaving it.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, surveyed the work of the Republicans in Congress today and found none of it good.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- Michigan's delegation of forty-one to the Republican national convention set up the machinery in caucus tonight to boom Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, a native son, for the Presidential nomination.
The Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, used its regular morning worship service yesterday as a ceremony of recognition for Fathers' Day and "the responsibilities of parenthood."

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., June 20 -- "I'm on top of the hill and now I coast," Joe Louis said today before entering the ring before an overflow crowd of about 5,000 in his next-to-last public workout for the fifteen-round battle with Joe Walcott in Yankee Stadium Wednesday night.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 20 -Otis Co., as "stockholders and underwriters" of the two issues of Kaiser-Fraser stock demanded today that Henry J. Kaiser and Edgar Kaiser return to the shareholders of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation vital aluminum producing "assets and income worth millions of dollars."

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Hedge pressure in wheat diminished sharply as prices neared the expected loan level in the week, growers in the Southwest showing little inclination to sell at the lower levels. This served to reverse the price trend and wheat registered a big rally from early week low spots, although showing a considerable reaction from the extreme tops at the end of the week.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- About $1,000,000 of Federal money was granted today to eighty-six institutions for cancer studies.

The consolidated net income of the Electric Power Light Corporation and its subsidiaries reached a new high of $21,471,677 last year, compared with $16,881,635 in 1946, Edgar H. Dixon, president, reported in the annual statement issued yesterday for release today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 19 (Delayed) (UP) -- Foreign Minister Moshe Shertok declared today that Israel, fighting alone, had won all phases of the Palestine war and had smashed the myth of invincible Arab armies.
PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- The wives of the two major contenders for the Republican Presidential nomination held press conferences today and answered similar questions in a vastly different manner.

"DURING dinner the war went on." Only a master of the art of language would drop as simple, succinct and dry an understatement as this into a narrative distinguished for the most part by its matchless grandeur of expression. But that is the way Winston Churchill writes, with artful simplicity to counter his majestic rhythms, with humble and generous emotion, as well as with lordly satire and noble dignity.

SYOSSET, L.I., June 20 -- Frank Cook's aged bay mare Bay Girl, with Mrs. James W. Maloney riding, won the jumper championship with ten points during the Syosset Post, Veterans of Foreign Wars, horse show on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin H. Herzog today.

It may be, said Father William, that observing what goes on in your part of the world in Alice's Looking Glass -- and continually standing on my head as I do it -- has given me a distorted picture of the American scene during these past few months.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- There follows a record of the principal measures which were passed or rejected by the Eightieth Congress:

Now that the long battle for a real test of airships by this country has been successfully concluded in both Houses of Congress, all that remains is the Presidential signature for a new development in lighter-than-air. An intermediate type of transocean carrier costing from $10,000,000 to $20,000,000 is contemplated.

"Radio Theatre" occupies first place in the latest report on the comparative popularity of evening radio programs by C.E. Hooper, Inc. Listed in order as completing the top ten shows in this category are: Walter Winchell, "Fibber McGee and Molly," Bob Hope, "My Friend Irma," Jack Benny, "Arthur Godfrey's Talent Scouts," "Take It or Leave It," Red Skelton and "Mr. District Attorney."

A protective military alliance of the Scandinavian countries is in process of negotiation, Lithgow Osborne, president of the American-Scandinavian Foundation and wartime United States Ambassador to Norway, said yesterday on his return from a two-month tour of Norway, Sweden, Denmark and Iceland.
The Firemen's Fund Insurance Company announced yesterday that directors have authorized an increase in the number of shares to 1,000,000.
GRENLOCH, N.J., June 20 (AP) -- Jersey Joe Walcott today finished up his hard training for Wednesday night's fight by boxing five rounds in which the emphasis was all on speed.
Five new pictures are scheduled to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

An anomaly of twenty-five years ended at 12:01 A.M. today when the Police Department dropped its Telegraph Bureau and gave the agency a title befitting in modern scope. Hereafter the unit is to be known as the Communications Division.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 20 -- The chances for a settlement between the State of Israel and King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan "have lessened since his British-armed and officered Legion has attacked and shelled the civilian Jewish community in Jerusalem," Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the Zionist Organization of America, asserted here tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 20 -Patsy D'Agostino of New York, president of the National Association of Retail Grocers, said today that the association must continue to fight for equality of opportunity in order to maintain not only the health of individual small business but to guarantee the future of free enterprise.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- Pennsylvania's potentially powerful delegation avoided an open split tonight by reaffirming endorsement of the "favorite-son" candidacy of Senator Edward Martin, but one of the delegates announced that a commitment to Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg prevented him from making it unanimous.

Sales of phonograph records have fallen off during the last couple of years, and the recording industry is anxious to get things back into the groove. This was evidenced over the week-end with the introduction by Columbia of its newly developed long-playing records, and announcement by two manufacturers of players to accommodate the new records.

Openings this week in local art galleries include an exhibition of portraits of six centuries at the Lllienfeld Gallery, and work by twenty-one artists of pre-Hitler Germany at the Tribune Subway Gallery. The Lilienfeld show, covering a gamut from medieval masters to Derain, will open on Wednesday.

It was just about this time of the year, or June 15, 1215, to be exact, that John, King of England, was compelled to affix his royal seal to the Magna Charta, when the barons met the King on the quiet green meadow on the banks of the Thames, at a spot which still bears the name of Runnymede.

LOS ANGELES, June 20 -- General Omar N. Bradley, Chief of Staff of the Army, today hailed the passage of the draft act as gaining "for all peoples an eleventh hour chance to erase tension through understanding, to seek agreement through conference and to provide for the peace of the world through honest cooperation."

PARIS, June 20 -- Speaking in Verdun today at a ceremony on the anniversary of the battle there in World War I, Charles de Gaulle again attacked the French Government for having accepted the six-power London recommendations for Western Germany, which were provisionally approved by the National Assembly by a majority of eight Thursday.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -The Federal Government's petition for an eighty-day injunction against a threatened maritime strike will be heard here by Federal Judge George B. Harris tomorrow morning.

An estimated 30,000 people crowded onto the campus of Fordham University yesterday afternoon to witness the sixteenth annual Feis, sponsored by the United Irish Counties Association of New York. The Feis is a traditional athletic and cultural festival, modeled after the most important of the ancient assemblies in Ireland, the Feis of Tara.

PARIS, June 20 -- Veiling, the mystery and charm that it lends to women, was the leitmotif of the Bal de la Voilette last night, a brilliant event of the Paris season inaugurating the Maison de la Pensee Francaise, the new cultural center for artists, writers and the intelligentsia.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- Supporters of Harold E. Stassen for the Republican Presidential nomination were teaming up today with backers of Robert A. Taft and also some "dark-horse" candidates in an attempt to get the convention's Committee on Credentials to unseat the delegation from Georgia that the National Committee voted last week to admit.

Four thousand persons turned out yesterday to watch the second annual intradepartmental track and field games of the Police Sports Association of New York City held at the Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island. Three hundred police athletes who had survived eliminations in various precinct, division and borough commands qualified for the meet.
NANKING, June 20 (AP) -- The Communists' capture of Kaifeng, capital of Honan Province, was acknowledged today by pro-Government sources.

ST. LOUIS, June 20 -- Joe DiMaggio exploded three home runs today and while one may have been more or less ornamental, there was no questioning the importance the other two played in the day's events.
Throughout the country yesterday fathers broke out the flashiest ties seen since Christmas, tested gleaming lighters and transferred money to new billfolds in the annual observance of Father's Day.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Business has clearly taken a bigger and better turn after brief hesitation in early 1948, the Department of Commerce reported today.

LONDON, June 20 -- Commenting on so-called strings reported to be attached to the draft of bilateral agreements which are being negotiated with the United States to govern Marshall aid, The Economist, an influential weekly newspaper here, says that it looks as if caps had been thrown into the air too soon about materialization of this plan.

The shadowed wood road circles the lower end of the sugar grove, twists through birches, beeches and poplars on the boulder-strewn sidehill and doubles back around the shoulder to the spreading evergreen swamp beyond. Half a century ago a farmer and his sons lumbered the spruces, hemlocks and firs.

Total value of national advertising carried in daily newspapers this year should "at last break through the $400,000,000 mark," Alfred B. Stanford, director of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, predicted in an interview last week.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 20 -- Within the next twelve months, it is estimated here, Turkey will have 12,000 officers and 90,000 men trained in the latest American methods of warfare under the program of the Turkish-United States Army Group.

Just when everyone was about to give up on the Giants yesterday their wrecking crew salvaged the second game of a double-header with the Cardinals at the Polo Grounds. Having dropped the opener, 7 -- 2, the New Yorkers were trailing the Redbirds by two runs in the eighth inning of the after-piece when they came through with an awe-inspiring, record-tying display of power that turned apparent defeat into a conclusive 6-4 victory.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 20 -- Coaches, officials and athletes decamped today with the conviction that the collegians will need strong support on the Olympic track and field squad if the United States is to enjoy a sweeping success at London this summer.
AMSTERDAM, June 20 -- At the Benelux economic congress held here last week, the following resolutions were adopted:

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Statistical proof that cancer can be cured when the correct treatment is started early, and some new methods of using radium to halt the spread of malignant growth were presented as the American Radium Society began its annual meeting here today.

With both United Air Lines and American Airlines saying that they were experiencing one of their biggest, week-ends in traffic, and with other scheduled air lines reporting gains, only the non-scheduled freight carriers remained a dark spot in the air transport picture, a survey here showed yesterday.

The sixteenth anniversary of the death of Col. Francis P. Duffy -Father Duffy of the "Old Sixty-ninth" -- was marked yesterday afternoon by former members of the chaplain's regiment at his grave in St. Raymond's Cemetery in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Congress ended its Eightieth session just after dawn today, and most Republicans, some without benefit of sleep, departed a few hours later for their party's convention in Philadelphia.

The 1948 Commodity Year Book, just published by the Commodity Research Bureau, Inc., New York City, contains a study covering the previous twelve Presidential election years of this century. The study shows that both commodity and security prices generally have advanced in those years.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio arrived today in this already teeming convention city with word for his supporters that he felt he had a "very good prospect" of winning the Republican Presidential nomination.
Hundreds of persons thronged the block on Mulberry Street, between Canal and Hester Streets, yesterday for a fiesta to raise funds for the American Overseas Aid-United Nations Appeal for Children.

Three insurance companies have entered into an agreement to purchase $30,000,000 of Port of New York Authority Air Terminal bonds, Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the authority, announced last night. The bonds, due in 1978, with a 3 per cent coupon, will be sold at 99, reflecting an interest cost to the authority over the term of the bonds of 3.033 per cent.

Most buyers completed their purchases in wholesale apparel markets here last week and then prepared to concentrate on buying fall accessories and main floor merchandise, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- The Illinois delegation elected Gov. Dwight H. Green chairman tonight at a caucus in the Benjamin Franklin Hotel. The caucus also adopted a resolution directing the delegates to vote for Governor Green on the first ballot and authorizing him to call another caucus later.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 20 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, United States delegate, today hailed the new United Nations Declaration on Human Rights as a "document of very great intrinsic worth." In a statement reviewing the three weeks' work of the Commission on Human Rights of which she is chairman, Mrs. Roosevelt said the declaration embodied a "good deal of good, sound American tradition and law."

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., June 20 -- Maine expects to double production in its million-dollar lobster business this year. The annual "rearing" season is under way at the Department of Sea and Shore Fisheries' station at Juniper Neck. Modernization of facilities has revolutionized the method of producing "fourth stage" young lobsters.

The New York Hotel Trades Council and the Hotel Association of New York City announced jointly yesterday that the property of the Y.W.C.A. at Fiftieth Street and Tenth Avenue had been bought for a new health center.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 20 (AP) -- Paul Bienz and his school, Tulane, were the chief beneficiaries of a ruling today by National Collegiate Athletic Association officials.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 20 -- Only Willie Turnesa, former United States and British amateur champion and his team-mate, Dick Mayer, New York State titleholder, prevented the professional team of golfers from whitewashing the amateurs in the foursome matches today that concluded two days of exhibitions staged for the benefit of the Westchester Cerebral Palsy Association Clinic at Bedford Village.

ROME, June 20--The interest of political and diplomatic circles here is concentrated on the journey of two Communist leaders, Palmiro Togliatti and Pietro Secchia, to countries behind the Iron Curtain.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., June 20 -- Thank-you notes and tokens of gratitude are coming here by the scores from children in Europe and Asia who benefited from the labors of the pupils of the Short Hills and Glenwood Schools in collecting a variety of useful articles -- including cash -- for the aid of youngsters in impoverished areas overseas.

PHILADELPIA, June 20 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California denied to himself today a candidate's right to predict his own victory. Although an avowed aspirant for the Republican Presidential nomination, he limited his predictions to the following:

THE TIMES published May 26 an Associated Press dispatch from Detroit giving details of the wage settlement arrived at between the United Automobile Workers and General Motors. It is implied in several paragraphs of the story that the General Motors plan is unique in that it makes wage adjustments after Sept. 1 dependent upon the rise and fall of the consumer price index issued by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Senator Robert A. Taft and Governor Dewey, Presidential aspirants, in messages to the Mizrachi Organization of America, predicted yesterday the existence of a free and independent state of Israel in Palestine. The group opened its three-day annual convention with an afternoon session in the Pennsylvania Hotel and a dinner in the Astor Hotel.

The current upholstery and drapery fabric supply situation is following essentially the pattern of last year with the probability that the delay in filling orders will be longer than in the third and fourth quarters of 1947, according to an industry survey released over the week-end by the Upholstery and Drapery Fabric Manufacturers Association.

JERSEY CITY, June 20 (AP) -Jersey City and Rochester divided a double-header here today, the Little Giants coming back to annex the nightcap, 7 -- 4, after the Red Wings had taken the opener, 7 -- 4, before a crowd of 5,170.

As a result of the recent Federal Trade Commission ban on advertising use of the word "free" where there is an obligation to purchase, it was noted last week that a method of by-passing this restriction has developed. The specific instance is that in which a soap-flake manufacturer is including a "free" dish towel inside the package.
Monarch of the world of amateur tennis in 1947, John A. Kramer of Los Angeles extended his domination over the professional realm yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congrees during the period June 12 to 18, are given in the appended tabulation:

The ancient festival of Bikkurim, the offering of the first fruits of the year, was re-enacted yesterday morning on Central Park Mall by 2,000 children from Hebrew schools and youth groups in the New York area. The pageant was staged before 12,000 spectators by the Jewish National Fund of America in collaboration with the Jewish Education Committee of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Stringent proposals for exchange controls by the sixteen nations in the European Recovery Program to safeguard operation of the plan have been modified by the United States in view of objections by the United Kingdom and other governments.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., June 20 -Pat Mucci of Preakness Hills, and Hugo Earth Jr., won the thirteenth annual John F. Roche Memorial four-ball golf tournament at the Maplewood Country Club today with a 36-hole gross score of 139.

Mrs. Doris Levy, 40 years old, of 707 Kings Seventh-Walk, Brooklyn, will be writing the last chapter of an old story told in reverse when she receives her diploma tomorrow night from City College at commencement exercises in Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

LANGHORNE, Pa., June 20 (AP) -- Walt Brown, Massapequa, L.I., won the 100-mile AAA-sanctioned national championship auto race today at the Langhorne Speedway in 1 hour 6 minutes 55.66 seconds. He finished seven laps ahead of Mack Hellings, Burbank, Calif.

Special Sessions Justice Maurice Simmons, president of the United War Veterans, Inc., said yesterday the organization had not approved the candidacy of any individual for the Democratic nomination for Surrogate of New York County. He said he issued his statement because of published reports that a committee of war veterans had called upon Tammany leader Frank J. Sampson to urge the candidacy of Joseph A. Cox for the Surrogate nomination.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 20--As a result of new discoveries in photosynthesis, the process of food production by plants upon which all life on earth depends, man is now on the eve of one of the greatest achievements in his history--the creation of food in amounts sufficient to provide an adequate diet for the world's entire population.

OBERLIN, Ohio, June 20 -- A bipartisan proposal designed to assure the merger of the Congregational Christian Churches and the Evangelical and Reformed denomination, while avoiding a resubmission of the plan of union to the entire Congregational constituency, will be presented to the biennial meeting of the Congregational Christian General Council tomorrow, it was learned tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 20 -- Patricia Neal, whom Warner Brothers imported from Broadway last year, has been named by the studio to play the feminine lead, with Gary Cooper, in the screen version of Ayn Rand's novel, "The Fountainhead."
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, June 20 (AP) -- Authorities on both sides of the line separating Western Germany from the Soviet zone enforced stringent controls against currency smuggling today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 20 -- Teen-age canteens in Westchester County, created as wartime expedients to keep children entertained while parents were in defense activities, are taking a second breath and settling down as established neighborhood organizations, a survey by the Westchester Youth Club Council indicated today.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 20 -- One thousand friends and trade union colleagues of Sidney Hillman, former president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, CIO, took part today in a pilgrimage to his grave in Mount Hope Cemetery here.

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- In one of golf's greatest one-man shows, methodical Bobby Locke hammered a final round 66 today for a 72-hole total of 266 -- 18 under Midlothian's par and a winning margin of 16 strokes over Ellsworth Vines in the $15,000 Chicago Victory open tournament.

DETROIT, June 20 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox peeled off 12 hits to crack Hal Newhouser's seven-game winning streak and run their own string to five straight today by whipping the Detroit Tigers, 8 to 3. Dominic DiMaggio and Vern Stephens homered for the Sox as Mel Parnell hurled a four-hitter to take the victory.

The trend toward increased local taxes must be halted to prevent business from leaving the city, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York has advised Mayor O'Dwyer in a letter made public yesterday. The association predicted that failure to arrest the trend would result also in reduced employment and decline of property values.

A child's frequent accidents may be one sign that parents are bearing down too hard at home, and pediatricians should look into "overauthority" among causes of repeated injuries befalling their young patients. Dr. Ruth Morris Bakwin and Dr. Harry Bakwin, department of pediatrics, New York University's College of Medicine, came to this decision from a review of existing research on "Accident Proneness."

NEWARK, N.J., June. 20 -- Unvanquished since they opened at Randalls' Island a month ago. Liverpool's soccer players wound up their tour today with an 8 -- 0 victory over the New Jersey stars of the American Soccer League at the Newark City Stadium.

Once again a stage axiom is borne out, that good scripts never are allowed to languish. Getting the necessary backing for them is no trouble at all. The manner in which such properties are snapped up makes one think legerdemain is employed.

The consent of the Public Service Commission may be required before the Board of Transportation and the private operators of bus and street car lines in the Bronx and Queens can put into effect the agreements under which travelers in the two boroughs may use combinations of municipal and private transit facilities at a total fare of 12 cents.

METZ, France, June 20 -- For whatever it is now worth in today's warfare, France's Maginot Line remains almost intact, and certain French Army engineers believe that the United States would be wise to finance its reconditioning as a shield against possible Russian attack.
MONTREAL, June 20 (AP) -Montreal and Newark split a double-header here today, the Royals winning the opener 9 -- 5, but dropping the nightcap to the Bears, 3 -- 2.

AMSTERDAM, June 20 -- According to authoritative quarters here, Bolivia may propose at The Hague at a meeting of the working committee of the International Tin Study Group on next Tuesday reopening of the London Metal Market with a view to obtaining a freer price movement.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- Horn blast, hoarse and shrill outcry and general increasing din assailed William Penn's ears as he frowned down from the City Hall steeple today on a noisy sabbath. Pre-convention din picked up by the hour.

Asserting that rent increases had been imposed in the last thirty days on 5,000 families in this city on the basis of hardship pleas by landlords, Paul L. Ross, chairman of the New York Tenant Council on Rent and Housing, said yesterday that test cases would be brought in the Federal courts challenging the validity of the hardship regulation of the Office of Rent Control.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- A tentative draft of the Republican party's platform, covering eighty subjects in about 2,400 words, was whipped into shape today by a Drafting Sub-committee of the Resolutions Committee.

LONDON, June 20 -- The world's oil export center is likely to move from the Western Hemisphere to the iddle East, Sir William Fraser, Chairman of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, said in the company's annual statement to stockholder which was made public today.

PARIS, June 20--Before the first of July the French Parliament must act upon the international wheat accords signed last March in Washington between thirty-three importing countries and the three largest exporters, the United States, Canada and Australia.
CLEVELAND, June 20 (UP) -- Henry A. Wallace tonight called President Truman "a self-annointed angel" whose head is "too big for his halo."

The annual 36-hole member-guest tournament of the Pomonok Golf Club in Flushing ended in a three-way deadlock at 134 yesterday among Frank Niccolosi and Mal Galletta, North Hills, 67, 67; Jack Weir and Dr. O.V. Wibell, in Cherry Valley, 67, 67, and Frank Strafaci and Jerry Cauza, Crestmont, 68, 66.

Cotton prices last week held within a narrow trading range. At the close on Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were off 7 to up 70 points from the previous week. The only net recession was registered by the near-by July delivery.

PITTSBURGH, June 20 (AP) -- A new wage agreement was reached tonight between the United Electrical, Radio Machine Workers Union (CIO) and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. It provides an 8 per cent wage increase for 70,000 production and salaried employes.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 20 -President Charles Seymour of Yale University declared today that only by the right of question, of opinion and of criticism could the Communist threat be met in this country.

This is the second of two articles in appreciation of a man who, although little known to the public at large, possibly contributed more than any American of his time to raising the general level of economic literacy in this country. He was George E. Roberts, who died a fortnight ago at the age of ninety.

In view of the world conspiracy against freedom and progress, the piece of Paul P. Kennedy in THE TIMES of June 7 about the friendly moves of some of the other American republics toward Spain is worthy of fuller consideration.

Dr. Wincenty Natkanski, medical officer of the Gdynia America liner Batory, is a man sought out by events. He has just been notified that nearly thirty years ago he had a ruptured appendix and that by all medical standards he should be dead.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP) -Ralph Kiner bit his eighteenth and nineteenth home runs of the season today as the Pittsburgh Pirates won the nightcap, 7 -- 5, after the Philadelphia Phillies had taken the opener, 9 -- 0. The four-hit pitching of Dutch Leonard and the hitting of Eddie Miller, who drove in five runs, featured the first game.

Unthinkable as it may seem in a supposedly enlightened era of automobile driving and recreation-seeking, littering on the state parkways of Long Island has again become such an acute problem that the Long Island State Park Commission has issued a new warning to motorists.

WASHINGTON, June 20--Assistance to the United Nations through a loan from the United States for the construction of world headquarters in New York was abandoned today in the rush for Congressional adjournment.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Army probably will call 200,000 to 225,000 men during the first twelve months of the new draft program, a highly placed official said today.

STRATFORD, Conn., June 20 (AP) -- Russ Aitken, author and big-game hunter, today won the sixteenth annual Great Eastern individual skeet championship by defeating two other rivals in a thrilling shoot-off watched by more than 2,000 persons at the Lordship range here.

PITTSBURGH, June 20 -- Steel-makers last week saw no chance of a let-up in the heavy volume of steel demand. The ingot output rate last week, while remaining at 96.5 per cent of rated capacity, was believed to be below the actual volume of fresh business.

DARIEN, Conn., June 20 -Trader Bedford, owned by Arthur Nardin of New York City, won the $250 jumper stake today at the nineteenth annual Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show to collect a total of 24 points and garner the show championship with Pete Sheridan riding.

Real peace will not be found anywhere in the world until men learn Christ's ways of charity and cherish their neighbors' children as their own, Cardinal Spellman told 1,000 foster parents yesterday at a vesper service in their honor at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Double-features are the established policy of approximately one-fourth of the 18,351 motion-picture theatres throughout the country, it was revealed yesterday in a survey made by the research department of the Motion Picture Association of America.
CLEVELAND, June 20 (AP) -Cleveland's league-leading Indians swept a doubleheader from the Athletics today before an all-time major league record crowd of 82,781.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP) -Ralph Kiner bit his eighteenth and nineteenth home runs of the season today as the Pittsburgh Pirates won the nightcap, 7 -- 5, after the Philadelphia Phillies had taken the opener, 9 -- 0. The four-hit pitching of Dutch Leonard and the hitting of Eddie Miller, who drove in five runs, featured the first game.

Unthinkable as it may seem in a supposedly enlightened era of automobile driving and recreation-seeking, littering on the state parkways of Long Island has again become such an acute problem that the Long Island State Park Commission has issued a new warning to motorists.

Beach resorts in the metropolitan area welcomed their largest crowds of the year yesterday as warm, pleasant sunshine heralded the arrival of summer at 8:11 A.M., Daylight Saving Time, today. The temperature reached its maximum of 74 degrees at 4:50 P.M.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 20 -- Much of the "present discouragement" with the United Nations could be eliminated by the "intelligent and informed support" of individual citizens, Dr. William Agar, educational liaison chief of the United Nations Secretariat, said tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 20 -- The United Nations learned with dismay today that Congress did not approve the $65,000,000 world capital loan, but officials expressed the hope that the headquarters bill might be passed at a special session, called to act on the housing bill.

MOBILE Ala., June 20 -- Captain Norman G. Nicolson, president of the Waterman Steamship Corporation at Mobile, today confirmed the purchase of a floating drydock at Kearny, N.J., from the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.
BETTWS-Y-COED, Wales, June 20 -- Wales, like Scotland, is in a self-assertive mood these days and here in the north a visitor feels it most strongly.
