LONDON, June 20 (AP) -- Of all the world's amateur tennis players, only two appear capable of extending the American contingent in the Wimbledon championships which start tomorrow.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -- The World Federation of Trade Unions has won a consultative relationship with the International Labor Organization, but two rival federations are to come in on the same basis as the result of a compromise action taken by the ILO Governing Body after hours of debate.

The Republicans assemble at Philadelphia today with more prospects of success than they have had since 1928. On the basis of reliable predictions, as of this date, the odds are in favor of the election of a Republican President and Vice President and a Republican Congress.
BERLIN, June 20 -- The United States Army tonight stopped sending supplies into Berlin by rail for the American population. The action was taken rather than submit the trains to Soviet inspection.

NEW DELHI, India, June 30 (AP) -- About 100,000 persons thronged the municipal grounds tonight to bid farewell to Earl Mount batten, who gives up the Governor Generalship tomorrow to an Indian, Chakravarthi Rajagpalachari.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- On the eve of the Republican national convention, which will open tomorrow morning in the Municipal Auditorium, a "stop Dewey" movement started among the supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft and Harold E. Stassen, thus making it evident that they conceded that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey was in the lead for the nomination for President.
The Community Church held its last services at Town Hall yesterday. For fifteen years the hall's auditorium at 123 West Forty-third Street had been used as a place of worship.

An attempt to foretell the values that the spiritual man of the future will judge valid was made yesterday morning by the Rev. Homer Lewis Sheffer of Ridgewood, N.J., who delivered the sermon at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

Tens of thousands of New York veterans will have to stay "doubled up" in homes that are not their own, because of the failure of Congress to pass the Taft-Ellender-Wagner housing bill, Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UP) -- Chairman Wallace H. White Jr. of the Senate Commerce Committee today set up a subcommittee to investigate operations of the Federal Communications Commission while Congress is in recess.
PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- Following is the text of the speech by Carroll Reece, national chairman, formally opening the Republican National Convention:

Charles Yale Harrison, author of "Generals Die in Bed," will have a new novel published by Henry Holt in the fall under the title "Nobody's Fool." He is working on a new manuscript, a self-help book, which is scheduled for January publication.

OTTAWA, June 21 (Canadian Press) -- Pickets of the Canadian Seamen's Union moved from the lake and river docksides to Parliament Hill today and staged a three-hour demonstration for Government action against companies involved in the inland ship labor dispute.

SALEM, Mass., June 21 -- From the Navy's point of view one of the most important bills passed by the present Congress was the measure authorizing construction of a 65,000-ton prototype flush-deck carrier, Secretary of the Navy John L. Sullivan said tonight.

Superb musicianship was the outstanding feature of the Stadium Concert last night, when Isaac Stern, violinist, joined Fritz Reiner and the Philharmonic Symphony in an all-Brahms program. Approximately 9,000 listeners turned out for the program, which opened the series' second week.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Leading bituminous coal operators told President Truman's board of inquiry today that they saw no way of completing an agreement with the United Mine Workers before expiration of the current contract unless John L. Lewis removed his "road block."
CLEVELAND, June 21 -- Joe DiMaggio and the Yankees are still rolling through the West and tonight, to the great mental anguish of 49,837 onlookers, they rolled right over the league leading Indians.

Summer arrived officially at 8:11 A.M. yesterday after the wettest spring in Weather Bureau history. From March 20 to June 20 inclusive -- the period of "astronomical spring" -- a total of 16.83 inches of rain fell in this area, or 6.85 inches more than normal.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 21 -- The Greek Government has appealed to the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans to call for the return of Greek children, who, according to Greek officials, have been kidnapped to countries behind the Iron Curtain.
City College will confer academic degrees tonight on a record total of 3,098 graduates at its 102d Commencement exercises at Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.
ST. LOUIS, June 21 (AP) -- Three consecutive doubles after two were out in the ninth inning drove in four runs and enabled the St. Louis Browns to nose out the Philadelphia A's tonight, 9 to 8.

RHODES, Greece, June 21 -- Count Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator, hopes to have "suggestions" for a settlement of the Arab-Israeli warfare in Palestine ready to present in a few days, he said tonight. He will continue his peace efforts, he added, even if the four-week truce ends before any agreement is reached.
SHANGHAI, June 21 -- The Government Information Office at Nanking today confirmed the departure from the capital by air of President Chiang Kai-shek at noon.
CAIRO, June 21 (AP) -- The Arab League said today that new complaints of alleged Israeli violations of the Palestine cease-fire had been made to Count Bernadotte.

LONDON, June 21 -- Gains in exports and a reduction in imports last month brought Great Britain's adverse trade balance down to 41,000,000 (about $164,000,000), the smallest figure this year. The adverse balance in May was smaller than April by 17,400,000.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 21 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, announced today that the Israeli and Arab Governments had agreed to a No Man's Land in Jerusalem in which no civilian would be allowed to reside.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 -- Despite a budget reduced to $94,000,000 from a peak of $199,000,000 in 1945-46, the American Red Cross may be called upon to increase its services during the coming year because of selective service legislation and unforeseen developments, Basil O'Connor, the national president, said today.

VIENNA, June 21 -- The full Executive Committee of the People's party, the majority party in Austria, under the chairmanship of Chancellor Leopold Figl today voted to demand tomorrow a special session of Parliament to deal with what its resolution called the introduction of the rule of bare force in place of law by the Soviet occupation forces.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 21 -- Prof. Sidney Hook of New York University called today for a pooling of power by a union of democracies "to a point where an act of aggression by the Soviet regime would be suicidal."
So far as the principals are concerned, everything is set for the world heavyweight championship bout tomorrow night in the Yankee Stadium between Joe Louis and Jersey Joe Walcott.

The Port of New York Authority will lay the cornerstones of its new union motor truck terminals in Manhattan and Newark on Thursday. They have been under construction since early in 1947 and are expected to be ready late in 1949. Foundations have been completed and the lower structural steel is up.

A 17-year-old youth, accused of seven armed robberies, went on the witness stand yesterday in General Sessions to tell how his erstwhile buddy, Santo (Sal) Bretagna, took a .38-caliber pistol and avowed he was "going to kill somebody."
PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- Former Representative Clare Boothe Luce, of Connecticut, took the feminine spotlight on the first day of the 1948 Republican National Convention.

OBERLIN, Ohio, June 21 -- The proposed merger of the Congregational Christian Churches and the Evangelical and Reformed denomination today struck its second snag within a week when the biennial meeting of the general council of the former body voted, after considerable parliamentary wrangling, to defer further debate until tomorrow.

Certain savings and loan associations are now demanding that commercial banks repudiate recent criticisms of their activities made in the commercial banking field, it was learned yesterday. The demands are being served by individual associations upon the particular commercial banks which are the depositories of their cash and investments.

ROCK SPRINGS, Wyo., June 21 -- Discouraging word on the outlook for an increased supply of livestock and a decrease in retail prices for meat came today from Eugene G. Schulz, Commissioner of the Department of Markets, New York City, and from B. Frank Wells of Buffalo, president of the Retail Meat Dealers of Western New York.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 21 -- Yale University today awarded degrees to 945 members of the senior class in the college and School of Engineering.
PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- Following is the text of the keynote address by Gov. Dwight H. Green of Illinois at the Republican national convention:

Two officers of the LaSalle Yellowknife Gold Mines, Ltd., of Toronto entered pleas of innocent yesterday in the United States District Court in Brooklyn to an indictment charging them with disposing of $100,000 in unregistered securities in the United States in violation of the Securities Exchange Commission regulations.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 17 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 7 per cent.

A long-range program to supply the graphic art industry's manpower and technical training needs is showing gradual, but encouraging, results, it was reported yesterday at the opening session of the National Graphic Arts Education Association's twenty-third annual convention in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

The stock market yesterday encountered some stiff selling which produced the widest losses in more than a month. The pressure was heaviest in the final hour after a show of firmness in most sections and a good gain by the oil division.

The French liner De Grasse was delayed a half hour in sailing yesterday while a 68-year-old Frenchwoman, who had missed the last gangway, climbed nimbly from the deck of a tugboat into one of the liner's side ports.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 21 -- The power of education is our greatest weapon against the destructive use of the atomic bomb, Miss Ethel J. Alpenfels, anthropologist and associate professor of New York University's School of Education, declared here today.

The first wage discussion on the proposed basic agreement between Actors' Equity Association, which included Chorus Equity, and the League of New York Theatres, the managerial organization, consisting of producers, owners and operators of Broadway houses, was held yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor.

Expressing keen disappointment yesterday over the failure of Congress to vote $65,000,000 for the United Nations site in Manhattan before it adjourned last Sunday, city officials said that New York's supplementary contribution would be held up until the picture was clarified.

VIENNA, June 21 -- The Soviet member of a four-man international police patrol drew a gun on the driver of the patrol car, Sgt. Merrill Allen of Stonington, Me., at 3:45 A. M. today. He forced, with the aid of two other Russian soldiers, the three other members of the patrol and a prisoner into the Soviet Kommandatura.

Nearly a thousand persons who planned to greet passengers arriving on the Norwegian-America liner Stavangerfjord were kept waiting yesterday morning in South Street at Pier 8, East River, near Old Slip, by the steamship line, the Fire Department and the Department of Marine and Aviation.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 22 (AP) -- A United States spokesman today described as "absurd falsification" unofficial Chinese charges that America was building a war machine or an economic giant in Japan. The official denial is included in a firm note to the United States Consulate General in Shanghai from William Sebald, chief of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's diplomatic section and acting United States political adviser for Japan.

Henry C. Taylor's fast black-hulled yawl Baruna was in the lead yesterday afternoon in the yacht race from Newport to Bermuda, according to a radio dispatch received here. Following her in order were W.W. Anderson's yawl Escapade, De Coursey Fales' schooner Nina, the sloop Highland Light of the Naval Academy at Annapolis and John Timken's yawl Kitty Hawk, formerly the Wakiva.

George Holtzman, secretary of Supreme Automatic, Inc., a distributor of coin-operated amusement machines, was questioned yesterday on the evils of pinball machines, in the suit being heard by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, which seeks to prevent Police Commissioner Arthur Wallander from seizing pinball machines.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., June 21 -- The lack of interest on the part of the American people in the development of a program of family allowances was criticized tonight by Dr. George F. Davidson, Deputy Minister of Welfare of Canada.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 21 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council challenged the social and educational arrangements in the Belgian trust territory of Ruanda-Urundi today.

CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- Miss Margaret Gunther, pretty 25-year-old Tennessee State champion from Memphis, fired a 2-over-par 76 over tricky Skycrest Country Club today to win the medal in the qualifying round of the nineteenth women's western open golf tourney.
Net profit of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and its subsidiaries amounted to $21,860,652 in Canadian currency for the nine months ended on May 31, last, it was announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- Rolling organ thunder, sharp sounding brass and rich vocal music amplified to awesome degree, plus the cheers of some 15,000 elated adherents, filled the Municipal Convention Hall here at the first night session of the 1948 Republican Convention.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- The tentative text of the Republican platform for 1948, prepared by a drafting subcommittee and laid before the party's Resolutions Committee for Debate, Amendment and Final Approval, was as follows:

MANILA, June 21 -- President Elpidio Quirino today signed a proclamation granting absolute amnesty to the rebellious Hukbalahaps in the presence of their supreme commander, Luis Taruc, in Malacanan Palace. Thus he hopes to end a small civil war that has kept four Central Luzon provinces in an armed turmoil since their liberation from the Japanese.

Billy Graham, 142 3/4, East Side, beat Patsy Brandino, 142, Hamilton, Ontario, in the eight-round feature bout at Croke Park, the Bronx, before 4,700 last night. In the semi-final, a listed six-rounder, Jimmy Flood, 153 1/2, Yorkville, knocked out Jim Bearden, 150 3/4, Las Vegas, Nev., in 1:46 of the second.

LOS ANGELES, June 21 -- Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Chief of Staff of the Army, said today that the peacetime draft called for new viewpoints on the part of the service toward its personnel, notably in the direction of enlightened liberalism and democratic individualism.

LONDON, June 21 -- The House of Commons took steps tonight designed to block what Solicitor General Sir Frank Soskice called a "growing form of black-market dealings" by tourists bringing cars into Britain for resale.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., June 21 -- Elated with the "wonderful mess" they created on the Taconic State Parkway at the Underhill Road crossing here last evening by using local automobiles to snarl through traffic, residents said today they were looking forward to the Fourth of July week-end as a chance for another demonstration.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Application of recent developments in electronic and communications engineering to the advantage of medical science was vividly demonstrated here today as scientific exhibits in connection with the ninety-seventh annual meeting of the American Medical Association opened at Navy Pier.
PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- The mood of the delegates and alternates to the Republican National Convention and the spectators who filled the galleries was indicated clearly at tonight's session.

PASADENA, Calif., June 21 -- A unique photograph of cosmic ray phenomena taken high in the Swiss Alps, providing strong experimental evidence for the existence of a new elementary building block of the universe, with a mass midway between the electron and the proton, was exhibited here today at the symposium on cosmic rays.

Strong emphasis on machinery was the outstanding feature of the sixty-fifth annual convention of the National Confectioners Association and twenty-second Confectionery Industries Exposition, which opened yesterday at the Grand Central Palace.

Tammany Hall's ranks split wide open yesterday when Leader Frank J. Sampson announced that he would sponsor Vincent R. Impellitteri, president of the City Council, as the Democratic organization's choice for surrogate.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 21 -- Congressman Walter C. Ploeser, chairman of the House Small Business Committee, today urged the nation's small independent business to become an effective pressure group to combat not only business monopoly "but an even more deadly monopoly -- that of Government."

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today over ruled objections of a group of investors to payment of a $10,565, 227 claim of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company against its subsidiary, the New Orleans, Texas and Mexico Railway Company.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 21 -- Dr. Henry A. Cotton Jr., Deputy State Commissioner of Hospitals in New Jersey since 1946, died in Princeton Hospital last night at the age of 40. His death was ascribed to an inadvertent overdose of a sleeping powder, which he had taken Friday night as a chronic sufferer of insomnia.

PARIS, Tuesday, June 22 -- Several Ministers said early today at the end of a Cabinet meeting held to discuss the price of coal that the issue had been put up to the United States and that its response would determine whether the French Government must grant a subsidy to keep the price from rising.
RIDGEFIELD, Conn., June 21 -- Mrs. Gladys Martin of Danbury was solving a vexing transportation problem with real Yankee ingenuity today when an errant motor vehicle caused complications.

NEW DELHI, June 21 -- Chakravarthi Rajagopalachari took office as Governor General of India today at a swearing-in ceremony in the great gold and marble Durbar Hall of the Governor General's palace. Indian leaders and the New Delhi diplomatic corps were present in the large assembly.
Newport News, Va., announced yesterday that it would offer on July 12 an issue of $1,487,000 of public building bonds dated Aug. 1, 1948, and due on each Aug. 1 from 1949 to 1968.

NEWARK, N.J., June 21 -- Born in Mississippi, Mr. Russell joined a wagon train westward bound when he was 18 and lived in North Texas and southern Indian Territory. He returned two years later to Mississippi to attend school and went to the University at Oxford.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan arrived at the Republican convention tonight and counseled the party not to "falter in leadership for peace." He said in a statement that his attitude toward the nomination was unchanged. At the request of those here who are organizing a floor campaign for him, however, he offered comment which his supporters viewed as having special significance.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 -- Lloyd C. Fleming, Pacific Coast director of the Maritime Commission, testified in Federal Court today that a maritime strike would be a blow to the country's safety.

An 89-year-old precedent of the Dalzell Towing Company, Inc., was broken yesterday when stockholders, for the first time, elected seven outside business men to the board of directors of the family-controlled and operated concern.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 21 -- How widely one man may influence his time is illustrated by the exhibition of writings by former students of John M. Berdan which opened over the week-end at the Yale University Library.

Few of the keynote speeches which custom requires shall be delivered at national conventions of major political parties in the United States will ever find their way into collections of the world's great oratory. The keynoters are under difficulties. They have to sound off before the platform has been completed.

John Donald Walker, 47-year-old race-track tout and ex-convict who allegedly married three women in the last three years and fleeced them of $94,000 by representing himself as a wealthy business man and horse owner, was indicted yesterday on two counts of violating the National Stolen Property Act.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today agreed that a special master should be appointed to take evidence on conflicting claims by California and the Justice Department to sections of oil-rich coastal lands.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- A labor-and-social-welfare plank drafted by a resolutions subcommittee would pledge the Republican party to changes in the Taft-Hartley Law as experience indicated and to the establishment of a Department of Labor extension service for research and education in industrial relations.

Ralph Branca, who hasn't lost in a month -- the same cannot be said for the Dodgers -- scored his sixth straight victory and eighth of the campaign last night under the lights at Ebbets Field. The Pirates, last team to down the young right-hander, were his victims this time, 5-2, as the Brooklyn losing streak ended after four straight.

OTTAWA, June 21 (Canadian Press) -- The Government has decided to withdraw the special 25 per cent excise tax imposed on a broad list of goods last November and now is seeking to determine when this decision should be put into effect, The Canadian Press learned authoritatively today.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- United States and Western European Union officials are now working out final details of plans for military talks between the American Government and the European organization.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 21 -- On the eve of battle, Washington and California from the West and Navy's defending champions and Cornell of the East rank as the big four in tomorrow's Poughkeepsie regatta. The only other varsity eight considered to have any prospect of winning the three-mile pull on the Hudson is Princeton.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 21 -- Yugoslav Government spokesmen and the press have begun a frank discussion of the deteriorating food conditions in this country despite expectations of excellent harvests. The difficulties appear to resolve themselves into the serious failures of the centralized distributing system, inefficiencies and a lack of initiaitive on the part of he inexperienced new bureaucracy.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 21 -- Tom Brown, United States finalist in last year's Wimbledon tennis championship and seeded No. 4 in this year's tournament, had to fight through five hard sets today to beat his British opponent, 38-year-old Don Butler, and get through the first round of the men's singles.

BERLIN, Tuesday, June 22 -- Russian stubbornness over four-power currency reform for Germany eased late yesterday and it was learned early today that Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, the Soviet occupation chief, was willing to have currency reform in Berlin discussed by the Allied control authority on the level of financial advisers.

Joseph Tumielewicz, 52 years old, of 250 Berry Street, Brooklyn, died in Bellevue Hospital at 6:30 last night, less than two hours after he drank from a water cooler believed to have been contaminated by cyanide, Bellevue authorities reported.
Six cartons filled with union dues check-off cards signed by municipal transit employes were deposited with the Board of Transportation yesterday by the Transport Workers Union, CIO.

While combining marriage and a career is a problem women must decide individually, several husbands took time off yesterday from their own jobs to list the advantages of having working wives. They spoke at the opening of Mademoiselle magazine's second annual Jobs and Futures Conference in the Commodore Hotel.
PHILADELPHIA, Tuesday, June 22 -- The Republican Resolutions Committee adopted early today a proposed platform for 1948.

Issues of public utility bonds amounting to $43,000,000 were awarded at competitive sale yesterday to banking syndicates by the Southern Natural Gas Company and the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company. Reoffering of the bonds to investors will take place later in the week.

A price reduction averaging about 10 per cent has been made in alkyd resins, a synthetic organic product, and unprecedentedly "firm prices" at this reduced level have been guaranteed for the remainder of the year, setting a new formula for price policies in that branch of the chemical industry.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Congressional cut in European Recovery Funds will probably not be felt on the aid programs until the next quarter, which begins July 1, officials of the Economic Cooperation Administration suggested today.

Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, chairman of the American section of the Jewish Agency Executive, predicted last night that Great Britain would attempt "to force a cantonization scheme in Palestine, or, if that is not possible, to force the State of Israel to surrender the Negev and perhaps other sections of Israel."

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- The twenty-fourth Republican National Convention opened today with the delegates convinced that now the party was in successful pursuit of the Presidency of the United States.

Having thus far failed to find the ideal candidate, the mugwumps have decided to take a breather. But while they may find it necessary to sit out this election entirely, they will not be idle. Other individuals, cities, towns and states are using 1948 as a jubilee or celebration year, and so the mugwumps will, themselves, pay honor to one who well merits it.

Four veterans will get paintings from the State Department's controversial collection of American art, offered as surplus property by the War Assets Administration, if its Washington office upholds tomorrow the recommendations made yesterday at the regional office, 40 Wall Street.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- The Connecticut delegation decided this afternoon at a ninety-minute closed caucus to cast its block of nineteen votes, as originally planned for United States Senator Raymond E. Baldwin, a "favorite son," until released by him.

Morris Margolin has purchased the one-story taxpayer building containing five stores at the northwest corner of Farmer and Luzerne Avenues in Hollis, Queens, from the Hillburn Holding Corporation. The property occupies a plot 102 by 130 feet. Zager, Fields, Zimmerman, Skodnick Segall were attorneys for the buyer, who insured title with the Home Title Guaranty Company.
The three top-ranking players captured opening-round matches in the annual New York State women's tennis championship at the Bayside Tennis and Racquets Club yesterday.

Commenting yesterday on the city's plans to arrange a transfer system with private bus and trolley lines, Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, said no such arrangement could be effective until it had been filed with his agency.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., June 21 -- Belated statistics reveal that New Zealand had a record trading year in 1947, in which the United States figured as the Dominion's second-best customer. Exports totaled 129,400,000 ($414,000,000) and imports 128,700,000 ($411,840,000).

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- The twenty-fourth national convention of the Republican party got under way twenty-seven minutes late today, but, once started, zipped through the morning session in just an hour and thirty-six minutes.

Ill at his home with a heart condition and other complications, Paul Dullzell has resigned as international head of the Associated Actors and Artistes of America (Four A's), the parent A.F. of L. body maintaining jurisdiction over all the entertainment unions, and also from his duties as executive secretary-treasurer of Actors Equity Association, it became known yesterday.

Russeks Fifth Avenue gave a demonstration of fashion translations yesterday in a summer presentation on the St. Regis roof. It was a graphic illustration to the audience of how the store interprets an original French model for its clientele.

It is impossible to evaluate in conventional terms the magnanimity of the gift to the Alderman Library of the University of Virginia of the late United States Senator Carter Glass official and personal papers. Through the generosity of the late Senator's family, historians and students soon will be able to delve into a rich treasury of 300,000 items of memorabilia covering six decades of the distinguished Virginia stateman's public life.
SINGAPORE, June 21 (AP) -- Police tonight questioned more than 600 persons rounded up a few hours earlier in a series of anti-Communist raids throughout Malaya.

RYE, N.Y., June 21 -- A funeral service for Basil Harris of Rye, chairman of the board of directors of the United States Lines, was held here today in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection on the Boston Post Road. Attending were 1,500 persons including many church and business leaders.

The fifty-seventh local summer furniture market which opened yesterday in the New York Furniture Exchange, 206 Lexington Avenue, was marked by new products in virtually every category, many indirect price reductions and little buying by retailers.
The fact that he had to change a wooden left leg proved the undoing yesterday of James Beard, 23 years old, of 50 Morningside Avenue, after he had evaded the law for two hours.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday, closing 3 to 25 points net higher on the day, with distant months relatively stronger than nears.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Grain markets developed an easy undertone on the Board of Trade today as the result of highly beneficial rains in parts of the main corn, oats and spring wheat areas, which more than offset unwanted heavy rains in the Southwest, where harvesting of winter wheat is under way.

The Draft Act adopted by Congress on Saturday has proved a bonanza to National Guard recruiting officers and to a lesser degree has stimulated enlistments in the Army and the Navy. Under the act, men who are members of the National Guard at the date of enactment are exempt from service. Consequently hundreds of young men here were seeking yesterday to join the Guard before President Truman signed the bill.
Babe was a lonely seeing-eye dog last night.

Aurel Alth, acting consul general of Hungary in this city, resigned yesterday in protest against Communist domination of his country and because of recent "attempts to influence even the consular duties through political considerations."

In underwriting circles, it was admitted yesterday that the pricing of the new issue of 200,000 shares of Consumers Power Company preferred stock up for sale today is one of the most perplexing problems bidders have faced in weeks.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- National Guard headquarters said today that it was receiving reports from all over the country showing a rush of draft-age men to enlist.

First orders and sentiment among buyers at the annual trade showing of the National Association of Display Industries, being held this week in the New Yorker Hotel, indicated yesterday that most stores are planning to start fall and Christmas promotions about two weeks earlier than last year.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided today, 5 to 4, that the Memphis Natural Gas Company must pay Mississippi's franchise tax on corporations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 21 -- Joseph Cotten has been borrowed by Transatlantic Pictures, the Alfred Hitchcock-Sidney Bernstein producing company, from David O. Selznick to play Ingrid Bergman's husband in "Under Capricorn," the Selznick company announced today.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., June 21 -- Jerry Besio of Green Valley and his amateur partner, Charles Wood of Tamarac, scored a best ball 32, 33 -- 65, to win the Metropolitan P.G.A. one-day tournament at Vernon Hills this afternoon. Second pro-amateur team was that of Tony Longo, Inwood, and William Berenson, Fairview, with 34, 32 -- 66.

J. J. Slater, shoe retailers, have leased the premises at 533, 535 and 537 Madison Avenue for a period of twenty-one years, it was announced yesterday by Larry Horan, president. The property includes that occupied by the Monte Carlo Restaurant which closed last week following a strike of service personnel.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 21 -- Further moves were made today in an attempt to strengthen western Germany's economy in preparation for establishment of a government.

The most creditable feature of the "compromise" farm measure enacted in the dying moments of Congress is that it was passed on the understanding that its long-term provisions would be subject to further study and probable modification before Jan. 1, 1950, when they are scheduled to take effect.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 21 -- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship got under way today with a small field of fifty-nine competitors. The low entry was due to a new ruling that permitted only those with handicaps or 16 or under to play.

WARSAW, June 21 -- The same scurryings of European Communist leaders that preceded the first meeting of the Cominform (Communist Information Bureau) have been reported here over the weekend and it is believed that the second meeting of the top ranking party men is now in progress.

Under a London date line on June 10, your issue of the following day carried a news story captioned "Hitlerite Leaning Noted in Germany." That conclusion was reached by an international committee engaged in a study of European conditions; a study that summed up the findings in a single sentence that tells us "The German mentality has altered very little since Adolf Hitler's downfall."

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Indiana Gas Water Company, Inc., Indianapolis, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 60,000 shares of additional common stock, $10 par value, that are to be offered first the company's stockholders at the rate of one new share for $12.50 for each ten shares held.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 21 -- Arab countries in the United Nations will probably try to shift the permanent world capital from New York to Geneva as an aftermath of Congressional failure to approve the $65,000,000 construction loan, it was indicated here today.

After almost five years of service under the British flag the Liberty ship Adolph S. Ochs, named for the late publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES and The Chattanooga Times, has been returned to the Maritime Commission, it became known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board says 1948 business profits are "likely to be larger" than in 1947.

Failure of accounting methods to evaluate changes in purchasing power of the dollar has contributed to the presentation of an inaccurate picture of corporate earnings and economic worth, it was pointed out yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Association of Cost Accountants.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- The latest rumor in this city of sisterly gossip is that Harold Stassen and Senator Robert A. Taft, with the blessing and conniving of Col. Robert McCormick of The Chicago Tribune, have been playing footsy under the green baize table.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 21 -- The Summer Workshops opened up the center of creative arts at Adelphi College here today.

Failure of the Eightieth Congress to approve either the $65,000,000 loan for a permanent United Nations headquarters in this city or the Taft-Ellender-Wagner Housing bill is regrettable and disheartening. Both measures were high in the public interest and urgently needed.

Though native lettuce probably will be plentiful all summer, it's the early specimens coming to market now that rank highest for quality. This year the crops have been set back somewhat by rain and cold weather, for though lettuce thrives on cool nights, it requires warm, sunny days.

Grey Flight had just enough left in the last sixteenth to slip home the winner in the Flying Heels Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Leading at one stage of the six-furlong test by as much as five lengths, the Wheatley Stable's filly managed to score by a nose over the Greentree Stable's Blue Border in a tense finish that had a crowd of 21,754 roaring.

SHANGHAI, June 21 (Reuters) -- Opposition to the Sino-American agreement granting the right to United States vessels carrying aid to China to enter Chinese inland waters -- closed to foreign shipping since the end of the war -- was expressed here today by Chinese shipping circles.

CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- Joe Gordon, second baseman with the Cleveland Indians, showed signs of repeating the triumph he scored over Bobby Doerr, Boston Red Sox, a year ago for a starting berth in the fifteenth annual all-star game at St. Louis, July 13.

LONG weeks of punishing workouts and Spartan training have left the athletes in the proverbial pink of condition. The reference, however, is not to Messrs. Joe Louis and Jersey Joe Walcott even though it could be applied to them as well. It's to the oarsmen who win row at Poughkeepsie today in the worst-timed regatta the Hudson ever has produced.

After being in this country for one year, and having read your paper thoroughly throughout that time, I would like to express my appreciation for the wise and very courteous way in which you present the news. It is indeed a great relief to be able to turn to a paper which, although slightly biased, nevertheless spurns the lower forms of press sales campaigns, to which others have unfortunately succumbed.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- President Truman began to cope today with about 263 bills left to him by Congress. All of them must be acted on within ten days after reaching the White House.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The new British quota, said to operate against American films, was protested to the State Department today by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Export Association. He said the new restrictions would hold British exhibitors to reserve 45 per cent of their screen time for showing British films.

After nineteen years in its own swank clubhouse at 221 East Seventy-first Street, the Junior League of the City of New York has temporarily moved its offices -- which filled two floors of their former headquarters -- into two cubbyholes and a large cleaning closet in the Manhattan Storage and Warehouse Co. building at Third Avenue and Eightieth Street.
We are on the brink of a momentous election. We have no weapons of defense against a wrong decision except to pray hard and think straight.

A general wage increase of 11 cents an hour was offered yesterday to representatives of 12,000 unionized employes in five plants of the Bendix Aviation Corporation. The offer was made to the United Automobile Workers, CIO, in negotiations at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- Supporters of Thomas E. Dewey won today in a significant test of strength over a combination of Taft and Stassen forces when the Committee on Credentials voted, 26 to 24, to seat the sixteen-member pro-Dewey Georgia delegation.

BOSTON, June 21 (AP) - Lefthander Al Brazle was "right" tonight as he pitched the third-place St. Louis Cardinals to a 1-0 decision over the National League's leading Braves before 30,398 fans. Brazle, who had been defeated earlier in the season by the Tribe, had his sidearm sinker working so well that he, himself, threw out six Boston batters.

ATHENS, June 21 -- Striking directly against a major rebel stronghold in the Grammos Mountain region from the south, the Greek Army's Ninth Division pushed forward from Konitsa northeast along the Albanian border today.

KENVIL, N.J., June 21 -- Three men were killed and two others injured early this afternoon when three explosions in quick succession demolished as many buildings in the plant of the Hercules Powder Company here. Reverberations from the blasts were felt as far away as Manhattan, to the east, and Easton, Pa., to the west.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (AP) -- A member of The Chicago Tribune staff here said that when Mr. McCormick used "stooge" in his statement he referred to James H. Lee, Detroit's assistant corporation counsel. The other man Mr. McCormack referred to is Murray D. Van Wagoner, former Democratic Governor of Michigan, now civilian governor of Bavaria, Germany, The Tribune staff member added.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 21 -- The 150-year-old building known as the Octagon in the official heart of the nation's capital will be restored by the American Institute of Architects as a national historic shrine.

The growing movement toward holding grocery inventories to a minimum as protection against price breaks as summer and fall packing operations progress was seen by food advertising observers yesterday as likely to produce special "flash" ad drives aimed at unloading affected products.
Random notes:

Add to the ever-growing list of fall contenders for Broadway honors, "My Aunt, The Doctor," an Italian folk comedy by Armand Aulicino. It is to be done by Hugh Rennie, Anita Grannis and William Whiting, a new producing combine, which acquired the script from the Writers Literary Agency.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Supreme Court, winding up its term, dismissed today the indictment of the Congress of Industrial Organizations for spending money for political purposes, but side-stepped a decision on the constitutionality of the Taft-Hartley Law section under which the prosecution was started.
CHICAGO, June 21 -- Pay demands covering virtually every one of the 1,350,000 organized railroad employes are pending against the country's carriers, a survey disclosed today.

Right-wing representation in the Greater New York Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations was further reduced yesterday with an announcement that locals of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, with a combined membership of 40,000, had left or were in process of leaving the council.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- Robert G. Kelly, chairman of the West Virginia State Aeronautics Commission, today told the Civic Aeronautics Board he is much opposed to discontinuance of airmail pick-up service by All-American Aviation, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- A campaign strategy meeting of about fifteen influential Democrats with President Truman was reported today by Charles G. Ross, White House Secretary. The session was held yesterday at the Executive Mansion.
PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (AP) -- Hank Sauer's twentieth home run of the season provided the Cincinnati Reds with the winning margin tonight as they defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 4 -- 3.
PEIPING, June 21 -- The movement among university students and teachers here to refuse United States relief or even to purchase American-rationed flour is increasing.

The return bout betwen Joe Louis and Jersey Joe Walcott tomorrow night at Yankee Stadium will be televised over an NBC network covering seven cities, it was announced yesterday. Scenes of the fight will be carried in New York, Boston, Schenectady, Philadelphia, Washington, Baltimore and Richmond.

ROME, June 21 (UP) -- A secret consistory of the Roman Catholic Church today approved two canonizations for the 1950 Holy Year celebrations in a meeting in the presence of Pope Pius XII. Fourteen Cardinals met with the Pope for this year's most important church event in the scarlet-tapestried hall of the Consistory.

Dean Cetrulo, national saber champion, will represent this country in two events, the foil and saber, at the Olympic Games in London this summer, the United States Olympic Fencing Committee announced at a meeting in the office of Dernell Every, 122 East Forty-second Street, last night.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Danubian conference will meet in Belgrade on July 30 as originally scheduled, the State Department announced today, bringing to light a comedy of errors.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- President Truman was urged today by Representative Sol Bloom of New York to call a special session of Congress to permit action on a $65,000,000 loan to the United Nations for the construction of permanent headquarters in New York.

The city's inquiry into the milk companies' pricing practices, which starts today, will be pressed because the high price of milk is "such an acute problem," John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, said yesterday.

DETROIT, June 21 -- The Ford Motor Company offered today to settle its wage differences with the United Automobile Workers, CIO, by granting increases of 14 cents an hour to all workers making $1.50 or more an hour and 11 cents to those making less than $1.50.
LONDON, June 21 -- Britain's Deputy Prime Minister gave a demonstration of this country's kind of democracy tonight in the small gas-lighted auditorium of a London public school building.
PORTLAND, Me., June 21 -- Representative Margaret C. Smith forged steadily ahead of three male opponents for a Republican nomination to the United States Senate tonight.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 21 -- The first test of supremacy between the Government of Israel and its dissidents came today when Irgun Zvai Leumi, terrorist organization, attempted to land a shipload of arms on Palestinian shores, Israel now.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 21 -- The wallpaper industry's decision to continue a two-year line for 1949-50 is in the best interest of the consumer, dealer, wholesaler and manufacturer, Howard T. Hovde of Philadelphia, executive director of the National Wallpaper Wholesalers' Association, declared today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 21 -- Tom Gannon's home-run blast to deep center in the ninth inning, with John Caulfield on first base, provided Harvard with a 2-0 victory over Yale before a colorful commencement crowd of 8,000 today.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- After eight months of work, the Supreme Court drove through to its summer recess today.

"Give My Regards to Broadway," a romantic drama produced by Twentieth Century-Fox and featuring Dan Dailey, will have its local premiere tonight at the Roxy Theatre. The offering, filmed in Technicolor, includes Nancy Guild, Charles Winninger, Charlie Ruggles, Barbara Lawrence and Fay Bainter among its supporting players.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 21 (AP) -- The Medal for Merit was presented today to Dr. Irving Langmuir, associate director of the General Electric Company's research laboratory, and Dr. Brian O'Brien of the University of Rochester.

The initial auction sale of jewelry confiscated by the Nazis had its first session yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, and exceeded the highest expectations of appraisers.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey's convention headquarters were cheered tonight by what his supporters regard as two developments very favorable to his chances of winning the Republican Presidential nomination.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on the validity of a Trenton (N.J.) ordinance that bans the use of sound trucks.

With peace negotiations stalled in both Europe and the Far East, the Western Powers have now proceeded with the political and economic reorganization of the larger half of Germany under their control in an effort to make it self-supporting and a partner in European recovery.

TIENTSIN, China, June 21 -- Importers here are anxiously watching the United States Government's policy toward China regarding Economic Cooperation Administration purchases. They hope that established importing firms here will be allowed to bid on purchases of rehabilitation machinery, fertilizers, grains, etc., to be shipped under the ECA program from America.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- The candidate for President has not yet clearly appeared among the Republicans gathered here. But the candidate for kingmaker made himself plainly visible today when Col. Robert R. McCormick, editor of The Chicago Tribune, announced that he is in favor of nominating Senator Robert A. Taft and Harold E. Stassen as the party's national ticket.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 21 (AP) -- Vertigo II, lost in the bulky field in the early stages of the race, came out of the pack in the stretch to capture the Salvator Mile, opening feature of the Monmouth Park meeting today.

BERLIN, June 21 -- High officials of the United States Military Government are aiming at March 1, 1949, as the target date for the final establishment of a government in the proposed Western German state, it was learned from a reliable source today.

LONDON, June 21 -- Large quantities of foodstuffs, raw materials and productive machinery financed through the European Recovery Program lie untouched in ships holds here because of the unofficial strike of London dock workers.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- The weird union of the bargain counter and the national convention bore strange fruit in Governor Dewey's headquarters in the Bellevue Stratford here today. It must have had major seismic disturbances in the graves of Boies Penrose, Mark Hanna and Matt Quay, of the "chawterbacker" and ripe-oath-generation of Republican leaders.

Mrs. Virginia, Edmands Pennoyer, widow of Albert Adams Pennoyer of Berkeley, Calif., died yesterday at her home in Litchfield, Conn., at the age of 89. She was a daughter of Henry Dlay Geddes, and a granddaughter of Sheldon Ingalls Kellogg of Cincinnati.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- Americans increased their cash assets by $6,800,000,000 last year -- but one of every four families overspent its income then, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LONDON, June 21 -- The spread of the London dock strike outweighed the news of the final approval in the United States of the European Recovery Program and as a result, dullness was general in the stock market here today.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Earl G. Ward, vice president, controller and a director of Montgomery Ward Co., today resigned all his offices with the company. The resignation of Charles M. Odorizzi, vice president in charge of mail order operations, is expected to follow.

An underwriting syndicate of 121 banking houses headed by Alexander Brown Sons, Kidder, Peabody Co., Harriman, Ripley Co., Inc., and Lehman Brothers placed on the market yesterday an issue of $40,000,000 of thirty-year revenue bonds to finance construction of the Delaware Memorial Bridge.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, June 22 (UP) -- Tanned after a four-day sea voyage, Mayor William O'Dwyer of New York arrived today to a miniature New York welcome.

TORONTO, June 22 (Canadian Press) -- A special general meeting of shareholders of the Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd., today approved unanimously a by-law clarifying the directors' powers to borrow money. Henry Borden, K. C., president, said that while documents may be approved at the home office here, the signing may take place also in Brazil or London.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today an allocation of flour to the Provisional Government of Israel. The allocation amounts to 2,400 long tons, wheat equivalent. This roughly would be 40,000 100-pound bags of flour.

LAKE GEORGE, N. Y., June 22 -- Welfare Commissioner Raymond Hilliard of New York City today called on public welfare officials to stop using the "time-worn" excuses of inadequate staff and lack of money to cover up their shortcomings and instead to work to prevent people from becoming dependents.

Only favorable action on the $65,000,000 construction loan for the United Nations' capital on the East River at a special session of Congress this summer will keep the entire matter of financing and of use of the site from coming before the General Assembly at its Paris session in September, Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, declared yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 22 -- An industry-wide wallpaper promotion to cost between $250,000, and $500,000 in 1949 was outlined today by Julian Brightman of Julian Brightman Company, Cambridge, Mass., advertising counselor, before the semi-annual convention of the National Wallpaper Wholesalers Association at the Traymore Hotel.

Isidore Ginsberg, portly Queens attorney who was called the "most vicious of gray marketeers" last January at a Congressional inquiry into the scarcity and high cost of building materials, was convicted of grand larceny yesterday in Queens County Court.

PARIS, June 22 -- The United States Embassy here handed the French Government today a new and somewhat milder draft for an agreement covering conditions to be attached to United States financial assistance under the Foreign Aid Act.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The draft bill is not yet at the White House. It has been sent to the Republican National Convention in Philadelphia for Congressional leadership signatures.

Fat, bone and gristle may be thrown away by the butcher or the housewife. But such discards count as much in the final price of meat as the delicious edible portion. Because a cut usually is weighed before trimming and the cost figured, what you pay for and what you eat may be quite different. Hard on the budget?

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP) -- Representative Katharine St. George, of the Twenty-ninth New York District said tonight the voters would turn next fall to a Republican President to lead the nation "back to the heights of liberty and peace."

NEW DELHI, India, June 22 -- One of the nine persons accused in the case of the assassination of Mohandas K. Gandhi, Digambar Badge, has been "pardoned," Judge Atma Charan announced when the formal trial opened today. It is understood that Badge, a long-haired and bearded Hindu ascetic, who is described as a manufacturer of daggers and other small weapons in Poona, will turn state's evidence.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 22 -- Self-service packaged meats at lower prices will soon be delivered to market for resale in much the same manner that bread is today, the National Association of Retail Grocers was told today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- The Republican party, which confidently expects that its nominee will win the Presidency, assured the world today that it would continue to support the United Nations and the European Recovery Program, but might not be so liberal with American dollars or tariff cuts.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will have five new men next season and every member of the orchestra will receive an increase in salary, it was announced yesterday at the conclusion of negotiations between the orchestra and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians.
PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- Following is the text of the proposed Republican party platform for 1948 as announced today by the National Convention's Resolutions Committee:

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Federal District Judge William Campbell today ordered attorneys for the Tucker Corporation to file by June 30 an answer to the request of the Securities and Exchange Commission to inspect the automobile manufacturer's books.

PARIS, June 22 -- In the debate today on the proposed reorganization of the French aviation motor industry, the National Assembly heard numerous criticisms of the whole system of nationalized industry.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- An anti-draft picket entered the White House as a tourist and chained himself to an iron railing today in an effort to influence President Truman to veto the service measure. He was James Douglas Peck, 33 years old, of 112 East 119th Street, New York City.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society outbid four investment banking syndicates yesterday for $17,570,000 of long-term bonds of the Philadelphia, Baltimore Washington Railroad, an underlying carrier of the Pennsylvania System.
CHICAGO, June 22 -- Grain markets showed a strong undertone on the Board of Trade today and finished about at the top, with corn in the lead despite favorable weather conditions for the new crop.

New York is lagging behind other Eastern States in returning oil borrowed from the Navy during last winter's fuel oil shortage, according to a compilation yesterday by the Navy's bureau of supplies and accounts. A Navy spokesman said, however, that the department anticipated that all such loans would be repaid by June 30 -- the agreed deadline for return -- or that cargoes would be on their way from oil companies to Navy storage.

The State of California sold yesterday $10,000,000 of veterans' welfare bonds due Feb. 1, 1950 to 1968, to a banking syndicate headed by the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association and the Bankers Trust Company on a bid of 107.72 for 2 1/2s.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- An appeal to the women of America to elect a Republican President to end the "spending spree" of the national Government for the past sixteen years was made today by Mrs. Frances P. Bolton, Representative from Ohio, at the day session of the Republican National Convention in the Municipal Auditorium.

Pistol Pete Reiser, whose personal pains and miseries recently have been matched by those of the Dodgers, will be back with the team next Sunday and ready to play in the finale of the three-game series with the Cardinals.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -- Formation of a new corporation, The Spreckels Companies, and its acquisition of sugar properties estimated to be worth some $10,000,000, were announced today. The properties were taken over from the J. D. and A. B. Spreckels Company.

Thank you for calling attention of the people to the reprehensible conduct of certain members of Congress in regard to the housing problem in your excellent editorial of June 17. May I respectfully add several thoughts to it.

BERLIN, Wednesday, June 23 -- Berlin moved a step closer to chaos early today when Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, chief of the Soviet Military Administration, decreed currency reform in the Soviet zone of occupation and in all four sectors of Berlin.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- Pyaru, sad-eyed mahout for Eva, the baby elephant used as the Taft group's mascot, sat at the curb under a shed in the cobbled courtyard at the University of Pennsylvania's School of Veterinary Medicine today, dreaming of Pakistan where he and Eva were born.

If the amnesty that has been granted the Hukbalahaps in Central Luzon really brings peace to the rice bowl of the Philippines, President Quirino will have made a success of his Administration as successor to the late Manuel Roxas. The continued fighting since the war in Luzon's best agricultural provinces has been the blackest spot in the Philippines picture.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- In an interview broadcast by television and radio, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York told 800 reporters and news commentators this evening that he had made no deals or bargains of any kind to win support for the Republican nomination for President.

QUONSET POINT, R. I., June 23 -- A radio-controlled Navy fighter plane broke away from its mother plane and started on a pilotless flight toward Cape Cod this morning, but it plunged into the ocean a few miles south of Wood's Hole without, at any time, having been over an inhabited area.

The plight of a 19-year-old girl who was sentenced in Federal Court yesterday to eight months in prison for passing worthless checks was attributed by her mother to her resentment at her father's leaving the family. The mother said the girl was "a very good girl and very bright" but that she was "trying to make up because of her father's leaving.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- A final effort by Taft forces to cut into the early balloting strength of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey was stopped in its tracks today after Senator Edward Martin of Pennsylvania threw his support to the nomination of the New Yorker.

DETROIT, June 22 -- The highlight of the convention of Teachers of Deaf Children which opened here today, will be an exhibit tomorrow afternoon of group-hearing equipment tied in with television. At the Public School For the Deaf will be the first public showing of the new development, designed primarily for the use of children in school instruction.

GENEVA, June 22 -- Two specialized agencies of the United Nations gave strong indications today that they would reject attempts by the United States Congress to predetermine their policies or to place conditions on United States contributions to their budgets.
The left-wing Greater New York Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations suffered two major setbacks yesterday.
Ten scientists who headed government research projects during World War II received yesterday the Medal for Merit, highest civilian award. The ceremony took place on Governors Island.

DETROIT, June 22 (AP) -- Earl Wooten's first major league home run gave the Senators a 5-4 triumph over the Tigers tonight before 34,447 fans. Art Houtteman suffered his ninth defeat of the season when Washington chased him with four runs in the seventh inning.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- In the first ruling of its kind, the National Labor Relations Board today ordered Howard Rome either to return his toy factory to Akron, Ohio, or to hire twenty-eight Akron employes at Kenton, Ohio.

PORTLAND, Me., June 22 -- In a sweep of the state that surprised even her most ardent supporters, Representative Margaret Chase Smith rolled up 63,941 votes in yesterday's Republican Senatorial primary election, to gain a two-to-one margin over Gov. Horace Hildreth, who polled 31,228.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Labor-Management Relations Act of 1947, better known as the Taft-Hartley law, will celebrate its first birthday tomorrow.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 3,077 against 3,054 last week and 1,957 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,574 arrivals yesterday compared with 1,520 last Tuesday.

LONDON, June 22 -- The long-standing differences between Ireland and Britain over the prices paid for Irish meat and other agricultural products in the British market were wiped out tonight in a trade agreement initialed by statesmen of both nations.

Arnold J. d'Ailly, Burgomaster of Amsterdam, the Netherlands, presented yesterday long-stemmed clay pipes to members of the city government and the Golden Anniversary celebration committee in appreciation of hospitality on his visit here.

Manufacturers' break-even points, pushed upward by the inflationary spiral, spell danger in the event of production declines, speakers at the annual meeting of the National Association of Cost Accounts, warned yesterday. Manufacturers and distributors of capital and consumer goods, it was pointed out at the technical sessions in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, must find means of increasing efficiency for insuring their survival in times of stress.
CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- The Red Sox overcame a 6-2 deficit to gain their sixth straight victory before 27,838 persons tonight by clubbing the White Sox, 11 -- 6.

The establishment of the State of Israel does not permit, or necessitate, the liquidation of the World Zionist Organization and its instrumentalities such as the Jewish National Fund, Magistrate Morris Rothenberg, president of the fund, asserted yesterday.

After denial of a defense motion to dismiss an indictment for grand larceny and bucket shop operations, Gus Fusaro, 53-year-old elevator starter accused of swindling thirteen persons out of $118,000 in stock transactions, declared yesterday in the Court of General Sessions that he "never made a nickel" on the financial deals.
Henry A. Wallace, New party candidate for President, told 600 New York business men yesterday that big business and the two major political parties were undermining the country's future.
PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- Harold E. Stassen, who served on Navy flagships in the Pacific, showed every intention today of going down fighting in this Republican convention, if go down he must.

The skies were blue and the sun shone yesterday for the 566 aged residents of the Home and Hospital of the Daughters of Jacob. Although rain fell outside their windows at Findlay Avenue and 167th Street in the Bronx, they saw only an azure ceiling, beige walls and bright-hued furniture as they entered their new recreation room for the first time.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 22 -- Home economists henceforth must work on international as well as local, state and national levels, Miss Edna P. Amidon of the United States Office of Education, today told the American Economics Association convention.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- After a day and night of convention focus upon the picking of the Republican nominee for President, speculation on choice of the man for second place on the ticket broke into the open tonight. The cause was the development within the Pennsylvania delegation which appeared to make the hold firm for Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York on at least two-thirds of that state's 73 convention votes.

PASADENA, Calif., June 22 -- Discovery in the sun of a mechanism for accelerating atomic particles to enormous energies, providing the first definite clue to one of the great mysteries of the universe -- the origin of the cosmic radiations that bombard the earth from all directions day and night -- was reported here today at the cosmic ray symposium at the California Institute of Technology.

Issues of new public utility bonds totaling $43,000,000 and a new issue of $10,000,000 of convertible preferred stock of the Beneficial Industrial Loan Corporation will be offered to investors here today by underwriting managers, as follows:
Fifty borough officials, engineers and reporters went down into Queens' new $10,000,000 storm sewer yesterday for an inspection trip and reported that all was well underground.

ATHENS, June 22 -- The Greek Army was reported to be making appreciable gains in its pincers on the rebels along the Albanian frontier today. It gave details of its successes during the last twenty-four hours.
PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- The chief point of feminine interest at the Republican National Convention today was 700 miles away in Skowhegan, Me., the home of Representative Margaret Chase Smith.

Speaking for the candy industry as a whole, Ted Stempfel, chairman of the Sugar Committee of the National Confectionery Association, demanded yesterday that the Secretary of Agriculture assure the industry of (1) a stable and adequate supply of sugar, and (2) a price level that takes into consideration special needs of the industry and the consumer.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 22 -- The honor of being first across the finish line in the Newport-Bermuda ocean race tonight seemed to lie among Henry C. Taylor's yawl Baruna, fifty miles west of Bermuda; J. B. Ford Jr.'s yawl Royono, sixty miles northwest, and W. W. Anderson's yawl Escapade, ten miles astern of Royono.

VIENNA, June 22 -- The Austrian Cabinet decided today to take to the Allied Council next Friday the case of the Soviet seizure of Anton Marek, high police official in the Austrian Ministry of the Interior.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Whether atomic energy is used or misused in the future, it is apparent that nuclear physics will become increasingly important in the practice of the general physician, it was emphasized here today during a scientific assembly for doctors attending the annual meeting of the American Medical Association.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 22 -- Labeling of every garbage can with a skull and crossbones "to arouse the nation against one of the most potentially dangerous public enemies," and action to solve "the national problem" of dirty beer glasses were urged today at the first National Sanitation Clinic.
LONDON, June 22 -- The ranks of the striking waterfront workers were split today, arousing hopes of an early end to the dispute that has kept the port of London strikebound for more than a week.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 22 (AP) -- The Big Nine swept to twelve firsts and a tie for another to wallop the Pecific Coast Conference, 92 1/4 to 39 3/4, for its third straight dual track meet title in the eight-year series tonight.

The City Council accepted yesterday a report by its special committee on discrimination against students in secondary schools and colleges. The report recommended that Prof. William E. Knickerbocker, chairman of the City College Department of Romance Languages, be relieved of his position because of "reprehensible and unworthy conduct."

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP) -- New Jersey held fast tonight for Governor Alfred E. Driscoll as a favorite son candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination in the face of a break for Mr. Dewey in Pennsylvania's big 73-vote delegation.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Air Force announced today a simplification of the air defense organization on July 1 by which the forces will be reduced from six to four, each with a specific defense mission.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 22 (AP) -- The board of directors has approved a plan for the simplification of the corporate structure of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and for its eventual dissolution as a holding company, Earle J. Machold, president of the corporation, announced today.

Already friends and acquaintances are beginning to disappear, to pop up again in two weeks or so, their faces shining and lobster red, burned to a crisp or as sallow as ever, depending upon the nature of their epidermis and, to a great extent, upon the weather they have encountered during their absence.

THE NEW YORK TIMES for Thursday, June 17, carried a story under the headline "3 Faiths File Brief for Release Time." According to the story, the brief was filed in behalf of the Greater New York Coordinating Committee on Released Time of Jews, Protestants and Roman Catholics in opposition to a pending legal action to outlaw release public school time for religious instruction in New York.

LONDON, June 22 -- Worried representatives of British industrial and commercial interests in Malaya were assured by Colonial Secretary Arthur Creech Jones in a conference today that the British Government was determined to "eradicate the root causes" of political terrorism now threatening British lives and property in Malaya.

"Suspense" will be restored on CBS July 8, taking over the half-hour now held by the Dick Haymes Show, which bows out of the Thursday night spot at 9 o'clock after its broadcast July 1. Auto-Lite will switch its sponsorship from the retiring program to the new series.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 22 -- Freda Kirchwey, president of the Nation Associates, today accused Loy Henderson, head of the Near Eastern division of the State Department, of "anti-Jewish prejudices" and charged that the State Department "is now engaged in a new effort to whittle down the area of the Jewish state and would not hesitate to reduce that state to the size of Vatican City."

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -- Because this country's military men abroad "reflect the personality and attitudes of the Whole American people," Eugene O. Fosdick, national director of the Military Welfare Service of the American Red Cross, pleaded today that the nation display no lack of interest in the welfare of its men.
LONDON, June 22 -- Improvement in the May export trade figures, coupled with prospects of the ending of the London dock strike served to brighten the stock market here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 22 -- With one veto, the Soviet Union today blocked Security Council approval of the two-year-old atomic control plan and prevented suspension of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission.

In the light of what has just happened in Congress, and of the hard fight that took place there among Republicans themselves over the question of redeeming the American promises made under the Marshall Plan, the boldest and most challenging statement made in the original version of the Philadelphia platform as it came from the hands of its drafters was this sentence:
The curtain is scheduled to go down tonight in the Yankee Stadium on one of the brightest chapters in boxing's heavyweight championship history.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- John L. Lewis won an overwhelming and all-embracing victory in the United States District Court today when Justice T. Alan Goldsborough approved payment of $100-a-month pensions to members of the United Mine Workers of America at the age of 62 and after twenty years of service in the bituminous coal industry.
Your readers are so accustomed to factual accuracy on your editorial page that it is surprising to discover even a slight error.

All those who approve of the progressive idea in elementary and secondary school education will welcome the opportunity that has just been presented to participate in the $100,000 project for renovating and modernizing the buildings of the Little Red School House, at 196 Bleecker Street, and its affiliate, the Elisabeth Irwin High School, at 40 Charton Street, both in Greenwich Village.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- No statement issued in this country since the Marshall Plan became American policy will be read with such anxiety in Europe as the foreign policy planks of the Republican platform.

KANSAS CITY, June 22 -- Walter F. White, executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, chided Henry A. Wallace and his supporters today for starting a third party. Addressing the annual meeting of the association, Mr. White said that the Wallace movement would lead to the return of "a more conservative" Congress than the one just ended.

ALBANY, June 22 (AP) -- A 7 per cent "across-the-board" increase in intrastate trucking rates was approved today by the Public Service Commission. The decision may help avert a threatened strike by 20,000 up-state American Federation of Labor teamsters.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Cautious optimism over the possibility of healing the split in the Democratic party over civil rights was expressed by Representative John E. Rankin, Democrat, of Mississippi, today after a conference with President Truman.

With four members in opposition, the City Council voted yesterday to continue this year's basic tax rate of $2.89 on each $100 of assessed valuation through next year and adopted borough rates for 1948-49 slightly below the current ones.

Governor Dewey's chances for the Republican Presidential nomination "look very good," because of the tendency of political convention delegates to get on the band wagon once that wagon starts moving, in the opinion of former Postmaster General James A. Farley.

ST. LOUIS, June 22 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics exploded for a four-hit, four-run eighth inning against two St. Louis pitchers to break a tie and defeat the Browns, 7 to 6, tonight. Carl Scheib, Mackmen hurler, was pounded for four hits and three tallies in the last of the ninth. The box score.:

HOUSTON, Tex., June 22 -- Although oil men in this section generally have expressed disfavor on entering into contracts on development of Mexican oil properties, Eugene Holman, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, said here today that his company was interested.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- William L. Tobin, a Post Office analyst, said today that ending of the airmail pick-up system of All-American Aviation, Inc., would mean decreased service for some affected communities.

In receiving the Art and Industry Award for 1948 at the Fashion Institute of Technology commencement exercises last night, Grover Whalen hailed the apparel industry, with its $2,000,000,000 yearly volume of business, as New York's "number one industry" and New York as the "fashion capital of the world."

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A registration statement covering a proposed offering at competitive bidding of $11,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, series B, due 1978, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the New England Power Company, Boston.
Cotton futures were moderately active yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, and final prices were 15 to 22 points net higher.
LONDON, June 22 -- After a sharp and often critical debate today, the Amalgamated Engineering Union annual conference at Brighton supported Foreign Minister Bevin's foreign policy by a 3-to-2 vote.

ATHENS, Wednesday, June 23 (AP) -- Press dispatches from the Second Army Corps at Koziani said today that Greek Army units moving from Konitsa had been attacked from Albania with heavy artillery and mortars.

MONTREAL, June 22 (AP) -- A. B. (Happy) Chandler, Commissioner of Baseball, was among the 15,941 that saw Montreal and Newark split a double header tonight. The Royals took the abbreviated opener, 8 -- 3, and the Bears the nightcap, 2 -- 1.
This story starts from scratch. And, according to the mosquito control division of the Health Department, everyone in New York will be doing a lot of scratching next month.

An atmosphere of satisfaction yesterday pervaded the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, where, for the second successive day, jewelry being auctioned for the benefit of victims of Nazi action brought prices high above the most optimistic calculations.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP) -- Forces of Senator Robert A. Taft and Thomas E. Dewey began a drive tonight to wean away some of the seven Colorado votes in the Republican convention which went to Harold E. Stassen at a delegation caucus.
PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- The official program for the two sessions of the Republican National convention here tomorrow follow -- time is daylight saving:

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The National Guard, indirect beneficiary of the new United States draft program, is expected to be full up with volunteers by the end of this month and then to cease recruiting for a year. Authorities studying preliminary reports from several states on the first full day of volunteering after Congress passed the Selective Service Bill, made the estimate today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 22 -- The Israeli Army and Irgun Zvai Leumi, a Zionist dissident band, waged a violent battle today when Irgun attempted to land a cargo of arms and ammunition within a few hundred yards of the headquarters of United Nations truce officials.

The Senate of the Eighty-first Congress that convenes next January is going to have a "New Look." Margaret Chase Smith will be there. We are sure we are not being premature in conceding the election of Maine's Republican candidate in November. Winning elections is an old Smith custom.
Random notes.

DETROIT, June 22 (AP) -- The United Auto Workers, CIO, turned thumbs down today on a Ford Motor Company offer of an 11-to-14-cent-an-hour wage increase. It promised a counter-proposal later this week. Up to now it has demanded 30 cents an hour.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Two Congress of Industrial Organizations unions, the United Automobile Workers and the United Farm Equipment and Metal Workers, which represent 60,000 of 86,000 employes of International Harvester Company, have rejected the company's wage increase offer of 11 cents an hour.

LONDON, June 22 -- A more than sixfold increase in the output of the Iraq Petroleum Company was forecast today by the disclosure that the company had decided to construct a pipeline from Kirkuk to the eastern Mediterranean seaboard with an initial annual capacity of more than 14,000,000 tons of crude oil.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- President Truman announced this evening an agreement for the exchange of diplomatic missions with the new state of Israel.
A burst of strength in the rails yesterday, which carried them to the mid-May high for the year, bolstered a wavering stock market.

THOMAS CARLYLE was not a boxing expert. Neither was the Louis he addressed so dolefully the Joe Louis who will defend his world heavyweight crown in the Yankee Stadium tonight. But the similarity is a striking one. The Dark Destroyer had no stroke in him the first time he fought Jersey Joe Walcott. Will he have regained his missing punch for the return engagement?
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Lands would be added to complete the Saratoga National Historical Park in New York State under terms of a bill signed today by the President.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP) -- Danny Litwhiler's tenth-inning homer with Hank Sauer on base gave the Cincinnati Reds a 6-4 victory over the Phillies tonight. Sauer also hit a homer, his twenty-first of the season.

CLEVELAND, June 22 -- Joe DiMaggio's mighty bat was still booming base hits today. But the Yankees this time couldn't keep pace with the big fellow who, after warming up on two singles, exploded a tremendous homer for his sixteenth circuit wallop of the campaign and fifth in three days.

The new priorities and allocations authority, created by the Ploeser amendment to the peace-time draft bill, makes Secretary of Defense James Forrestal responsible for determining what prices for industrail materials are "reasonable," when military orders are involved, industrial purchasing executives revealed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Graduates of the National War College were warned by Secretary of Defense James Forrestal today that the United States could spend itself into defeat as surely as it could be defeated in a shooting war.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 22 -- Although preparations are being made for the amalgamation of the French zone with the already combined United States and British zones, all rail shipments of coal from the Ruhr to the French zone were cut off today by the United States and British Military Governments.

The new Government of Israel has been confronted with the first open challenge to its authority within its own domain as a result of the attempt of dissident groups to smuggle arms and men into Palestine in violation of the United Nations truce. This challenge has led to open battles on the beaches of Tel Aviv between the regular Israeli army and the Irgun Zvai Leumi, in which lives have been lost on both sides.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 22 -- Negotiations between the Netherlands Government and the Indonesian Republic will be resumed tomorrow, the Security Council of the United Nations was informed by cable today.
